column1: Morgan Street St. Louis Dark Lager
column5: Sampled at the St. Louis Heritage Festival. Of the three Dark Lagers I jotted notes for, this got the Gold. Filtered amber hue. Soapy white head. Touch smokey and grassy nose. Mild bready nose. Moderate and easy. Caramel bready with a touch of dried fruit. Slightly more complex than the previous two.

column1: Morgan Street St. Louis Dark Lager
column5: (tap at the brewfest) Medium brown. Mild malt aroma. Caramel malt flavor, but a bit of mustiness in the finish. Not one of the better efforts at the brewfest.

Sampled at St. Louis Microfest. Well, this sucked. From the previous reviews it didnâ€™t look like it was much better fresh at the brewfest last month. Poured amber with a dense beige head. The aroma had roasted malt and its fair share of diacetyl. Think body with semi-soft carbonation. The taste is the same as the aroma. Best they just dump the rest and forget they ever made it.

Tasted at St. Louis BrewFest, May 12, 2007. I did not enjoy any of the St. Louis Lagers at this brewfest, and this one was no different. Un-interesting aroma, appearance, and flavor makes this lager below average.
(tap at the brewfest) Medium brown. Mild malt aroma. Caramel malt flavor, but also a musty flavor. Not the best example of the festival beer there.
I had this at Global Brew. Pours copper with a white head. Taste caramel, lightly sweet. I thought this was good. I would drink this again. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
smooth and malty, a nice carmel flavor. pleasing reddish brown color. yum...........
Thought this one was solid. nice copper color, some woody notes. well balanced and easy to drink.

Growler from SkyinBrian. Pour is very much like a Vienna, ambery copper. Nose is some toffeeish character with a bit of tinnyness. Taste is pretty clean and balanced, quite drinkable and filling Nice.
Tap at the brewpub. The body was dark amber to copper. The head was off white. The aroma was pancakes with some dusty toffee. The taste was sweet apple core with some wood and iced tea. Pretty good.

Tasted 5/22/08. Draft from the brewpub. Filtered with an amber hue. Medium layer of off-white head. Caramel and a touch smokey. Honey and anise. Medium bodied with a floral roasty flavor. Touch peppery with a nice bitterness. Slight vanilla note. Caramel and mild malts. Good effervescence. Touch cola. Mild spice. Smooth. Mildly sticky. Solid lager!

On tap at the Heritage Brewers Festival. The best of all the fest special brews. Each brewer was supposed to make a dark lager just for the fest. Rich creamy dark malt sweetness without too much hops or the burnt malt flavor one frrequently gets when approaching this style. Smooth, clean and even perhaps a little too thin, but delicious none-the-less.

On tap at the brewpub. Poured dark gold with an off-white head. The aroma was mainly toasted malt ~ faint aroma. The body was on the lighter side with a TON of carbonation. The taste started with toasted malt that was quite grainy and finished spicy and sour. An okay beer.
(tap at the St. Louis Brewest) Medium brown. Mild malt aroma. Caramel malt flavor. This was my favorite of the examples at the brewfest.

On tap at Seattle Rock Bottom. Didnâ€™t get any details...figured itâ€™d be in here. Hazy amber with off white head. A little citrus hops in the taste. Too damn cold....A little rye and grain comes through once it warms. Mild and drinkable, but not worth trying.

Draught at Brouwerâ€™s CafÃ©: Fiery golden, moderate off-white head, lively carbonation, spotty lacing. &nbsp Bright bready nose, a little cereal. &nbsp Big meaty malt start, slight alcohol, cereal like on the finish. &nbsp Does come across as a Strong Golden, but in traditional American style it is bready without much aromatics. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Sticky sweet finish, especially as it warms. &nbsp Tiz okay, a little heavy at times. &nbsp Lives up to its name!

(Old rating discovered in a dusty pile of forgotten notes.) Pours clear gold with a white ring of foam. Light body and carbonation. Candy apple and band aid aroma. Soft mouthfeel, dry and slightly sour finish.

On tap at the brewpub, sweetness and alcohol are the dominant flavors. Not too thick, some caramel malts and slight citrus flavors also appear. What you would expect a Belgian to taste like. Pretty good.

6/30/07 On draught at the Seattle International Beerfest with BrewDad. Aroma is sweet malt forward with some non-objectionable plasticy and peppery esters. Appearance is light gold with a good maintained head. Flavor is sweet malt forward with some fruit, caramel and bubblegum. Delicious. Mouthfeel is light bodied. Overall, easy drinking, sweet, complex and very well made.

[Taster â€“ Seattle International Beerfest] Deep amber color with a thin head. Liked the Belgian aroma and the crisp use of herbs used in this beer. Has a deep malt flavor mixed with strong Belgian yeast. This was a good drinking beer.

Draft at the Seattle International Beerfest. Pours creamy-looking burnt orange/amber with very thin tan head. Surprisingly light nose: floral, cinnamon, honey, maybe some slight lemongrass. Medium body and light carb. All the sugar and spice notes from the nose return for the mid-palate. Light floral hop finish with slight sugary cling.

on tap. Nice head when poured, and maintained very light lacing. Bright yellow in appearance. Not as fruity as most Belgian goldens Iâ€™ve had. Finished dry and refreshing. Definitely too easy to drink given itâ€™s alcohol percentage! Iâ€™m fairly new to the Belgian Strong ale community, but I really liked this one.
On tap at Brouwerâ€™s Belgian Fest. Weird beer. Very effervescent, but in a light, almost cereal-grain sort of way. Not real good. Not exactly sure what to call this thing.
On tap at Brewpub. Clear w/ small head. Aroma of belgian yeast. Sweet malt with belgian yeast taste. Light alcohol kick. Very sweet. Not bad, but not great.
# 348; 7/2016. OstÅ™e bylinnÄ› chmelenÃ½ nÄ›meckÃ½ pilsener, v dochuti dosti obilnÃ½.
Clear yellow colour, white foam. Bit bready, light hoppy, some grassy bitterness. Good Pils.

"Fuchsberger Pils", Flasche von Cash, Schwandorf. - Goldgelb, klar. - In der Nase leicht stumpfes helles Malz und schÃ¶n herbe Zitronenschale. - Antrunk leicht sÃ¼ÃŸlich hellmalzig und schÃ¶n hopfenherb mit prominenter Zitronenschale und Gras. Deutliche aber angenehme RestsÃ¼ÃŸe. Milder rezent, eher vollmundig. SchÃ¶n grasiger hopfenherber, trockener Abgang. Lang anhaltender Nachtrunk mit mit zart schwefeligen AnklÃ¤ngen. - SchÃ¶n saftiges sÃ¼ddeutsches Pilsener, nicht allzu komplex aber knackig gehopft und sÃ¼ffig. Lecker!
Sampled at the brewpub. OK off white head. Clear yellow color. Small nobel hop aroma. Big hop taste and bitterness. No sweetness and low malt taste.
Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass zippy, nice head. Starts mild, malty, modest dry, fine sweetish notes. A bit grasy. Well balanced finish. Not bad.
Ins Glas ergieÃŸt sich ein klares goldgelbes Bier mit schÃ¶ner Schaumkrone. Geruch hopfig, getreidig, grasig. Geschmack hopfig, grasig, lang anhaltende Bitterkeit.
Clear golden yellow. Sweet creamy barley malt and moderate bitter green hops flavor.
Yellow body, white head. Toasty malt, bit cardboard, green hops, earthy notes. Grainy.
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is dry, malt, fruit, grain, grass. Flavour is dry, malt, hop, fruit, citrus. Ordinary beer.

bottled, as pilsener premium in a small bottle; thanks to mowbeer for bringing this to sloppy joe night. anyways, quite pale with a slight but lasting white head; aroma of lime peel; quite grassy with some honey rye flavours; got more and more enjoyable on the way down the glass. clean and high quality
Cask Conditioned, at the Market Porter, London. Dark brown body with a crimson, ruby hue. Ruby port flavour with a coffee finsh. A very nice drop. Classy brewery this one.

Cask Conditioned, at the Market Porter, London Deep amber coloured body with full beige head. Juicy full malt flavour with plenty of strength. Enough calories in this baby to feed you for a week. A diabetics nightmare but nice.

Bottle. Black with a small head. Pleasant malty aroma. Nice liquorice and slightly chocolate flavour with a medium body. Certainly different. Not sure if this is a retired beer as I bought it in March 2017, and at the time of this review( April 2017 ) the breweryâ€™s internet site is still live. Worth searching out.
Tried at JDW, The Royal Hop Pole, Tewkesbury. Deep almost black colour, thick white head, than had gone by the time I sat down. Roasted malt aroma, slight bitter taste, a touch rough.
Cask at Bell, Bath. Pours black with beige head. Coffee aroma. Roasted flavor with some fruit. Some bitterness as well.

Cask conditioned at The Royal Union, Cheltenham. Dark chestnut with off white head. This was a rich malty beer, lots of berry fruitiness, blackberry, raspberry perhaps with a roasted nutty edge. Very pleasant.

Cask@Seven Stars, Bristol. Quite much black colour, small brown head. Aroma is mild roast, some liquorice, ripe fruits as well as some mild salty notes. Flavour is fruity, wooden, floral, liquorice and some mild roasted notes.

Cask (gravity) @ The 17th Reading Beer and Cider Festival 2011, Reading, Berkshire England. Clear dark black brown colour with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, strong coffee, light toffee. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, brown sugar sweet, dark dark roasted, cold coffee, ash. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20110429]

Cask at The Village Inn, Nailsworth, Glos, 29.05.11 Pours nigh on black with a beige head atop. Nutty and roasty with a gentle warmth throughout, hops show but never dominate or get in the way, Really nice stout that I thoroughly enjoyed. A7 A4 T7 P4 Ov13 3.5
[Gravity cask at Chippenham Beer Festival] Deep brown-black, loose beige head. Rich coffee aroma. Taste is smoke and roasty malt. Rather thin by end. OK.

Cask Real Ale at Urhos. Pale slightly beige head with small bubbles.Dark black colour. Slightly sour taste.No sweetness. Malty taste. At the end hoppy bitterness. Not very deep taste. Nice colour. Quite dry.

Cask@St. Urhoâ€™s Pub Dark brown color, good creamy beige head. Aroma is coffeeish with tobacco ash, tiny hints of balsamico. Medium-bodied. Soft, milky palate. Flavor is milky, chocolaty, a bit woody. Lingering roastyness and ashy notes in the aftertaste.

10/7/2019. Cask at the 30th Ealing Beer Festival. Pours clear golden with a bubbly white head. Aroma of citrus, hops, grass, light vanilla and hint of spice. Moderate sweetness and medium bitterness. Light body, watery texture, fine carbonation. Bitter finish.
Cask @ Ealing Festival. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are grass, straw, malt, hops and has a nice bitter finish.

Cask at the Hope Tap (JDW), Reading. Deep gold with a moderate white head and a middling fizz. Caramel, spice, floral notes, and a touch of dry leaf in the mildly bitter finish. A better than average gold.
500ml bottle from local farm shop. Pours slightly cloudy amber with smooth head. Aroma citrus heavy with some wood, slight chemical edge and oiliness.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: 05Jul2019 Creamy citrus fruits, lemon peel, lemon meringue, tangerine. Pale, clear gold, medium, creamy, white head. Light bitter. More creamy citrus fruits, orange, lemon, tangerine, light lemon peel, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Quite nice. Bottle from The Misty Bottle.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: A: Clear gold with a small white head. N: Some faint malts. T: Crisp and bitter P: Thin O: It is certainly a well-made beer, but it is questionable whether it is in fact an IPA.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: 500ml bottle from Dobbies. Pours a generally clear golden amber, white froth. Aroma of grapefruit, citrus, lemon. Taste continues with prominent malt, some bitter lemon, grapefruit, weak bodied with a dry bitter close.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: Bottles from Dobbies Garden Centre Morpeth and Rehills, Newcastle. Straw coloured with a large white head of foam. It has a tropical fruity flavour with malt, biscuit and pine and more tropical fruit on the smooth finish. Good.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: Pours a golden colour. Taste is quite floral with some lemon, slight hoppiness and a malty finish

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: Bottle. Clear golden color, thick, fine white head. Hint of citrus, buttery, maybe some diacetyl aroma. Dry taste, moderate bitterness for an IPA. Gentle malty aftertaste, finishes bitter with not so much hop aroma. Pleasant body, medium to low carbonation. Looks nice, feels good, doesn't taste as good and won't qualify in my eyes for an IPA.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: Bottle @home, [Rating Backlog]. Pours golden, white head. Nose is lemon, cooked apple, yeast, slight sour. Taste is toffee, oranges, apples and grass, slightly sour, odd and not in a good way.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: 500ml bottle received as a birthday gift. Pours clear and golden with a thick white head. Aroma gentle malt with a hint of citrus. Tastes slightly sweet before finishing on a bitter note,

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: 500ml bottle brought back by my father from a trip to the Hebrides. Poured into a UK pint sleeve at home on 23rd June 2016. Light amber body, clean and clear: the head a white blanket of smooth foam. Light malts rule the nose and flavour, but only just, citrusy and bittering hops are just below the surface and help to make this a pleasant and easy drinking IPA.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: Bottle@yesprs - Golden pour with white head. Fruity and light malty aroma and taste, some lemon notes and grassy hoppy action, low carbonation, watery, light finish.

This is a backlog rating from 2008 from a bottle, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are fruity, yeast, caramel, resin, chocolate, all over the place.

Bomber, from Ratman197's cellar. Pours an unclear, brown color, with a medium, bubbly, tan head. The aroma is brown sugar, pine, figs, orange peel, earth, and a touch of soy sauce. Sweet and malty, with a surprisingly pleasant, dank bitterness. Heavy body, with an aggressive, syrupy palate. Probably past it's prime age, at only 12 years young! Quite tasty.

From Aug 2007 Purchased at Wilbur's in FT Collins for US$5.99 Pours from 22oz bottle(bottled in 2007) a nearly pitch black with reddish hues and a large head of foam that lingers for a while shrinking to an almost solid layer by the end of the session and it has plenty of lacing. The smell has roasted malt, fruit, and a touch of alcohol in it. The taste is very fruity to start. Lots of dark fruit like fig and plum hit my palate first then I get some caramel and roasted malt. After a few more sips, the hop bitterness moves in and though it doesn't dominate, it has enough of a presence to make me ask...why? When I get a Belgian Style Ale or indeed, a Belgian Ale, I'm not looking for nor expecting a strong Hop presence unless, say, I get a bottle of De Ranke XXX, or one of similar ilk, which I do love. Anywho, I'm just saying... After emptying more of my glass, I'm starting to notice the abv a bit but it's not obtrusive. All in all, it's a pretty tasty brew; it's just not what I expected for an example of the style and because of that, I'm a bit disappointed. For a more representative example of the style, I'd need to go elswhere and that's the bottom line for me.

Bottle from my cellar. The pour is dark, almost opaque deep brown with garnet highlights. Medium sized tan head. The aroma has molasses and raisins and a touch of alcohol. The flavor is sweet, but not cloying and follows the aroma. The alcohol in the aroma is hidden in the flavor. This has held up well.

Bottle at Avery. Pours dark copper brown with a fizzy tan head. Tastes like dried dark fruits, booze, raisin, roasted malt, and toffee. Medium body and low/medium carbonation. Smells like dried dark fruits, boozy, raisin, and chocolate.

Bottle on 05/07/2011. Dark brown body with a large frothy tan head. Sweet caramel, molasses, fruit and floral hop aroma. Sweet roast, chocolate and molasses flavor with caramel, fruit and a floral hop background. Medium full body with moderate carbonation.
Bottle. Brownish ruby pour. Fuller bodied. Chocolate, raisins, dark fruits, molasses, malted milk balls. 6-7 years old and holding up. Pretty complex. Pretty intense, nice, boozy

Six years old, pours darker chestnut roasted brown with a creamy beige head. the aroma brings aged yeast and some dough notes. Flavor brings big strong malts with some alcohol notes as well m for a little bite on the tongue to end the flavor.

From 2010 notes. Pours deep reddish/brown with a light brown head that goes to a nice ring. Smell is rich cocoa, deep dark malt, orange. Taste is Cocoa, light citrus, ash, dark fruit. I get cherry on the aftertaste then finishing dry. Medium body, fairly active carbonation...pretty creamy.

Thanks to Ted from Avery for sharing at WhipIn. Aroma is dark fruit and cherries. Pours an opaque blackish brown with a none lasting off whitehead. The taste has a smooth sweet fruit quality. Raisins, cherries and dark fruit. Medium- full body with soft carbonation. Overall, this was a pleasure to drink. Would be a great after dinner sipper. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Slightly cloudy yellow gold on tap. Aroma is light bubble gum clove and citrus. Flavor is light to a fault as is the body. Not getting off flavors previously mentioned, though. That was the IPA :)

July 25th, 2014 - I sat down with a friend here at Santa Cruz Mountain’s Brewery to try a long line of tasters, starting with the lightest of the team, the Wilder Wheat. It’s very thick and soupy, and on the darker side, perfectly aligned in color with what I would expect from milled wheat. But the nose is absolutely redolent with buttery popcorn and pears. I know that’s a no-no, but I typically like that flavor. Even so, this is a lot of butter, and it just drowns out anything else I can smell. The flavor is also disappointing, starting with a promising tang, but the flavor and mouthfeel collapse shortly afterwards, leaving me with a winding, long and unpleasant aftertaste.
Tap. Ours cloudy yellow, small white head, good lacing. Aroma is wheat, lemon, bit of clove. Flavor same, medium sweet, stronger clove, no bitterness. Light body, not bad.
Hazy burnt yellow Minor banana but not much. Grassy and lemon aroma. Pretty yeasty. Creamed corn, weak and thin. Leaves a chalky resin

On tap @ Santa Cruz Mountain Brewing. Very pale straw with a light haze and white head. Nose is quite bland. Some bread, wheat, and a hint of spice. Light paper, some yeast, and citrus peel. Light sweetness to the flavor. Some bread, lemon, paper, and spice. A fair amount of yeast and hints of grass.
Tap. Hazed very pale piss color with white head. Tart citrus, bready aromas. light body, average carbonation. Sweet tart lemon wheat, herbal, bready flavors----decent.

A very interesting, different wheat. Pours a light yellow, grey color. Very strange for a beer. Smells of citrus and salt water. Taste is light, a little watery, drinkable, but boring. Had on tap at the brewery. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle: &nbsp Pale straw, very cloudy, moderate to large sudsy white head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Wheat malt nose, slight sourness. &nbsp Very minor earthen funk. &nbsp Spritzy pale wheat malt flavor, slight soil and lemongrass. &nbsp Better than I expected, but its rather fizzy versus wheaty/thick. &nbsp Finishes with a bit more of that organic profile that one would expect. &nbsp Still, remains better than I thought it was going to be. &nbsp Simply, a little fizzy, not really wheaty enough, but had some minor sweetness and lemongrass notes that helped it along.
Draft. Hazy yellow, slight head. American wheat taste and texture, not much going on.

Draft. An unclear light golden beer with no head. The aroma has notes of wheat and citrus. The flavor is sweet with notes of wheat and phenols, leading to a dry, wheaty, phenolic, and plastic finish. Off - something wrong in the brewing proces.

Now called Hogwash this is the latest offering from Feral and at 11.9% it is almost three standard drinks in one glass. Deep dense strawberry coloured body with an off pink head and rings of lacing. Not big on aroma. The wine that has been added to this brew helps thin out the full body somewhat making it fairly easy to drink, a little like a strong red cordial, just beware of the alcohol content.

Color marrón rojizo, cristalina. Dos dedos de espuma con buena retención. Aroma a malta tostada, notas herbales y de pan. Gusto a cereal, ligero pan integral y toffee, un punto amargor herbal. Cuerpo acuoso. Cervezs de carácter maltoso sin misterios.

On tap at The Beer Spa Restaurant & Bar, pours a deep dark mahogany with a small white head. Aroma brings out bready malt and a hint of caramel. Flavour is nice and malty, with bready malt, some caramel and dark red fruits. Not all that complex, but it’s nice and malty. Good stuff.

Bottle from Vinbudin, Hevragerdi. Appearance - deep amber to chestnut. Attractive off white lacing. Nose - malt loaf with suggestion of raisin too. Taste - more malt loaf, going into molasses. Palate - medium bodied, creamy in texture. Nice tapered finish. It has the weight in the mouth of at least a Dubbel. Overall - served quite cold so impressed with the strength of the malty notes coming through. Really enjoyable.
On tap at Saeta Svinid in Reykjavik. Brown with a thin, frothy head. Aroma is caramel, burnt toast, cigarette ash. Bittersweet. Finishes with burnt notes, light coffee. Good.
Some light coffee and nut. Dark mahogany pour with ok head. Tangy but crisp finish like dried cod jerky. Bottle from Vinbudin.
Pite w browarze. £agodnie karmelkowe, trochê zbyt s³odkie. Œrednie piwo zdecydowanie nie powala ale do spo¿ycia.
Red brown beer, small head. Aroma is malt, coffee, roasted. Taste is watery, light flavour of coffee, malt and roasted. Aroma is better than flavour.

On tap at Olstofa in Akureyri. Pours a muddy amber brown with lots of creamy, lacing, off white head. Nose has mild grist, some nuts, some brown sugar, some caramel. Flavor is sweet with toffee and caramel, some mild bread, yeast, a little date. Finishes sweet. Not a bad Tmavy.
Had this beer at the brewery in Mobile...notihing spectacular here but definitely a pleasant surprise. Would have again.

Draught. Pours hazy yellow with a spare frothy white head, completely diminishing, spare lacing. Aroma is light malt (hay, straw, meal), light hops (grass, citrus), light yeast (dough, soap) with notes of coriander. Light bodied, thin texture, lively carbonation and a chalky finish. Average duration, light sweetness and bitterness, moderate acidity; heavy soap flavor.

Very pale gold, nowhere murky, unless the bottle is shaken; gushing-exploding to a huge, very equal white head. Bit oily, with virtually no wheatbeer characteristics. No coriander, no orangepeel, even no wheat. Strange. Sweet, again no "wit" notes, exept the very perfumey character - but it is like a light top-fermenting barley brew, not a wheat. Medium bodied, quite slick, nearly viscous. Poor witbier, even without coriandersurplus. I’m sure it will be bettered for the next batch (first try).

Draft: Cloudy, dark brown with a beige head. Light coffee, chocolate aroma. Nice taste....coffee and chocolate malt, again.... A little bit of roast. Pretty decent....just seems a tad on the light and watery side.
On tap at the brewpub. Dark brown pour with a tan head, Dark roasted malt and mild chocolate in the aroma and taste. Nice down-the-middle porter.

Pour on tap at the brewery, dark brownish black pour with off white head, aroma brought notes of sweet caramel, roast, chocolate, hints of earthy notes into a bit of coffee. Taste is sweet, some cocoa powder, hints of coffee, slight coffee, roast, finishing sweet, dry.
Draft sampler pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Taste is malts and coffee.

4oz on tap at the brewpub. Clear dark brown color. Minimal ring of off-white head. Decent ridges of lace. Good chocolate aroma, some mild coffee, some caramel malt. Moderate sweet taste, light bitter. Medium body. Light slick. Lighter carbonation. Solid porter.

Draft to taster at Half Moon. Looks solid; a translucent cola with very thin off-white lacing. Smells solid too; dark malt and coffee. Tastes like it smells with average mouthfeel. A solid example of the style.
Draft. Chocolate malt aroma. Dark chestnut with minimal head. Sweet light chocolate malt and mildly bitter herbal flavor. Tasty.

On tap at the brewpub The bigger beers were more interesting despite there only being two on tap. A robust porter has plenty of flavor to keep you interested. At the same time it doesn’t abrade the palate and tire you after a pint. Aroma / Appearance - A fluid brownish base is black around the edges. An ebony head idly sits on top like cake icing. Coffee, licorice, and chocolate are a bittersweet foundation for a nose that also harbors black licorice. Flavor / Palate - Velvet creamy malts soothe the palate. Raspberry, vanilla, chocolate, and coffee stir the senses into action. A sweeping fruity taste carries into a pleasant finish. This is one of the best porters that I’ve tried in a while and totally unexpected after previous samples.

Tap at brewery. Coffee, smoky peat, chocolate, and prune aroma. Black brown with a small tan head, light lacing. Coffee, chocolate, and earthy smoky peat flavor with a light floral bitterness in the finish. Light to medium body. Nice.

slightly above Average porter. Aroma is chocolate and coffee. Appearance is black/brown, moderate carbonation. Taste is balanced between hops and chocolate malts. Taste is coffee/chocolate. Palate is moderate. Overall, great porter and would have again..

Draft @ brewery. Nutty,earthy chocolate malt flavor. Clear chestnut with a large tan head. Roasted nuts and chocolate malt flavor. Body on the light side of medium, flat carbonation. Very nice sessionable beer.

Out of the sampler at the brewpub. Deep reddish brown color with a thin off-white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Deep roasted grain nose. The flavor has a caramel sweetness with dark roasted grains. Nice long bitter finish. Very enjoyable for a style I usually don’t like.

Draft sample at brewpub. Poured a clear reddish brown color with a moderate fizzy white head that diminished slowly with good lacing. Medium caramel malty aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Another drinkable beer.

This draft brew from the brew pub poured a head of foamy finely sized tan colored bubbles that were long lasting and left behind a transparent uncarbonated red brown colored body. The mild aroma was brown malt. The semi-flat mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish. The thin flavor contained notes of brown malt. Not one that I would likely buy again.

Draft at the brewery and rated on 5/5/07. Tan small head that was mostly lasting, sparse amount of lacing, transparent, red hue, and no visible carbonation. Nose was slightly roasty, malty and a hint of caramel. Ditto for the flavor and lightly hoppy. Smooth mouthfeel and light boy. Lacks aroma, easy drinking, session brew and would probably drink this one again as it was one of the better brews available.

Out of the sampler at the brewpub. Pale yellow color with a thin white head. Light citrus nose. This is a crisp beer with some lemon and bready malts. Not much to it. Not bad for a brewpub’s lightest offering.

Draft sample at brewpub. Poured a clear pale color with a moderate fizzy white head that diminished slowly with good lacing. Medium hoppy aroma. Light to medium body. Light to medium sweet flavor with a light to medium sweet finish of short duration. Drinkable soft beer that met my expectations.

This draft brew from the brew pub poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a transparent softly carbonated straw yellow colored body and a poor lacing. The weak aroma was malty. The crisp mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of mild hops and mild astringency. Not one that I would likely buy again.

Draft at brewery and rated on 5/5/07. Small white head that was mostly lasting, fair amount of lacing, transparent, no visible carbonation, and a yellow hue. Nose was moderatley malty, crisp and refreshing. Ditto for the flavor. Fairly smooth mouthfeel. Light body. More aroma would have been a nice addition to the brew IMO.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours typical traditional wheat. Aroma is of raw grains. Flavor is sweet smooth with banana notes. Mouthfeel is creamy bordering on gritty. Typical small brewpub wheat ale/hefeweissen.
On tap at the brewpub. Yellow pour with a white head. Typical wheat beer earth skunk in the taste and aroma. Nice enough wheat, just not my favorite version of the style.

Pour on tap at the brewery, clear yellow pour with thin white head, aroma is dough, grass, some bits oh spice. Taste is a mix of grass, bread, some yeast, touch of crackery notes, finishing slightly sweet. Not really wheat style.
Draft sampler pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of grain, yeast and some citrus. Taste is malts and yeast.

4oz on tap at the brewpub. Hazy golden orange color. Thin ring of off-white head. Some loose dots and bits of lace. Bready wheat aroma. Mild butter. Moderate sweet taste, lightly grainy. Light bitter. Decent, interesting wheat ale. Kind of grainy and unrefined, though, and a little undercarbonated. But ok.

Draft to taster at Half Moon. Looks solid; a slightly hazy gold with thin white lacing. Smells of wheat and a hint of lemon. Tastes like it smells, but blander and without the lemon, with a touch of grain. Solid on the palate. An easy drinker, but unmemorable.

On tap at the brewpub A fairly run of the mill wheat ale is not bad but not great. Falling somewhere along the middle of the spectrum it is a drinkable session beer worth a four ounce sample at least. Aroma / Appearance - A semitransparent golden base is contrasted by a stark white head. Malt and wheat stir up a mixture of old lemons and fruit sorbet. Flavor / Palate - Lemon butter spread over toasted whole wheat slices is flavorful but simple. A light tang is present in the finish to add honey drizzled over a slice of lemon. It is not the most complex of beers. Despite having had worse I would probably skip it if I ever revisited Kokomo.
Hazy yellow with a soapy head. Scent is wheat, lemon. Taste is malty, creamy, lemon and wheat. Very mild.
Growler, Lemon, yeast and wheat malt aroma. Hazy pale yellow with nice head. Light lemon, yeast, and strong wheat/barley malt flavor. Nice body. Very good - really like the malt flavor.
Tap at brewery. Light creamy wheat aroma. Hazy yellow with a small white head, thick creamy lacing. Creamy wheat malt flavor. Medium creamy body. Very smooth.
On tap at the brewpub. Pours with a white head. Medium malt and mild caramel sweetness in the aroma and taste. Solid standard amber.

Pour on tap at the brewery, clear red pour with white head, aroma brought notes of caramel, nuts, some grass, slight nutty notes as well. Taste is earth, grass, caramel, nuts, some biscuit, hints of yeasty bread, some slight off flavor almost a trashy note.
Draft sampler pours amber with a off white head. Aroma of malts, grain and toffee. Taste is caramel and grain with a hint of spice.

4oz on tap at the brewpub. Clear reddish, slight orange color. Thin off-white head. Medium plus body. Lighter carbonation. Kind of slick. Some caramel malt, light bit of spicy hop. Some earthy hop. Moderate plus sweet taste. Alright kind of maltier sweetier strong ale. Not much to it.
Draft: Clear, red-brown with a small, off-white head. Toffee, grain aroma. Taste is sweet toffee.... A fairly solid amber......no flash, but decent.

Draft to taster at Half Moon. Looks solid; a transparent reddish copper with eggshell lacing. Smells malty with notes of caramel and a bit of grain. Tastes like it smells with an average mouthfeel. Not bad.
Draft. Toffee malt and fresh hay aroma. Amber with small head. Sweet toffee malt flavor. Light alcoholic finish. Not bad.

On tap at the brewpub At last I made my way through the seemingly endless flight of wheat beers and moved on to the rest. This is a solid amber ale that is more interesting than most of the other lighter taps. One or two of these over dinner would be a good start before ticking the heavier drafts. Aroma / Appearance - The caramel colored body is mostly opaque except for a few stray bands of light. Candy corn, caramel, and molasses are a fall festival in a sample sized glass. For a 6% ABV beer the malt feels heavy. Flavor / Palate - Creamy from the first sip the texture of the mouthfeel binds together the parts. Caramel, chocolate, and a dash of red licorice are a blend of Twix, Nutella, and Twizzlers in liquid form. The sweet malty finish brightens the palate. Overall this is well rounded and worth a tick.

Tap at brewery. Light caramel malt aroma... almost nothing. Coppery amber with a small off-white head, moderate lacing. Light toast, caramel, and light herbal bitter flavor. Medium body, soft carbonation.

Nothing too special and out of the ordinary here. Aroma is crystal and light chocolate. Appearance is red, light carbonation. Taste is mostly crystal grain, chocolate malt, light hops. A standard, average red alte. Easy drinker though...

Bottle, 7.3%. Sweet and surprisingly yeasty aroma. Has a little molassis. Almost clear dark brown colour. Very big, quite stable tan head. Good sweet flavour, creamy and a little spicy. The bitterness is not so high, but does well to balance the sweetness. Roasted caramel finish.

Bottle. Pours cloudy dark amber with airy, quickly vanishing light tan head. Clear aroma of malt and caramel. Roasty onset, giving way to malty and caramellish sweetness that lingers on. A touch of roasted beans in the finish. Nice.
bread, haevy malt, roasted, molassea, brown, clear, tan foam, heavy cloying sweetness, medium body, sticky, lively,

Bottle 500ml. @ home. Clear medium red brown color with a large to huge , frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, bread - danish ryebread, moderate caramel. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20091105]
Bottle. Clear ruby colour with yeast at bottom. Rich aroma and taste of malts, licorice, roasted malts and fruits. Sweetish finish.
Bottle. Brown color with fine head. Nice aroma and hoppy and sweet malty flavor.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste malt, licorice, hops and roast malt.

0.5 l bottle. Hazy mahagony color, very fizzy appearance. Bready and peppery aroma with dark rye bread and cocoa. Sweetish flavor with caramel, warming alcohol, rye bread, cocoa and nuts. Too sharp carbonation.

Bottled. An unclear orange-brown beer with a thick bubbly tan head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of caramel, dusty hops, and over ripe fruits. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel sauce as well as light notes of spices - especially cinnamon. But also with a light alcohol burn on the tongue and palate, though the body is thin.
Brown colour. Off-white head, medium lasting. Aroma is heavy, fatty, burnt caramel. Flavor is heavy sweet. Oily texture. Warmning alcohol.
On draft at TBBC, poured a copper color, aroma of caramel, light dark fruit, and some nuts. Flavor is caramel and nuts, not much bitterness to it, ok beer overall.
Draft at the source. Hazy amber, flat. Aroma of caramel. Taste is bitter caramel.
Passable for the style. Amber colour. American citrus hop flavour, some hop aromas. Sweet malt, too much malt for style. Very lacey. On tap at the brewpub.
Draft @ Brewpub: Caramel color, no head and liht lacing. Nose of pine and hop, light metallic malt and some molasses. Nice floral british hops but a thinner body than average. Works well together.

draft @ TBBC copper, light off-white head. Aroma, bitter dark fruits, fresh hops yeasty and caramel malts. Flavors, light palate, some roasted malts and a tad of sweetness. As it warms up, the beer’s ESB bitter aspects are more forward, adding to the mix grassy hops. Overall it’s decent ESB, wish the nose had some extra complexity.
Pours a deep copper in color. Had the cask conditioned version in August. Notes of sweet malts with a nice backbone of nuts. Finishes with a nice rounded bitterness.

Cask at the brewery. Pours a nice reddish copper with a thick off white head. Malty sweet nutty aroma. Smooth malty taste with hints of sweetness, nuts and toffee. Great style to put on cask, the slightly warmer temp of the beer let a lot of flavors pop out. Really tasty session beer.
Tap. Pours a clear copper with a small head. Coffee, sweet malts, and caramel notes. Some crisp hop bitterness. Ok

Cask at TBBC. Pours a translucent golden amber with an average creamy/lacing white head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, nuts, citrus...kind of light aroma. Flavor of the same...kind of grainy with a touch of sweetness and hops.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours clear deep gold with a copper core, off white head and decent lacing. The aroma is malty sweet and roasty but leaning toward the sweet side. Overall the nose is too meek. The taste is mild with some pale to highly roasted malts along with a stream of mild hops that border on tasting pine like. To go along with the pine-ish hop note is a spice hoppiness that tries to carry the flavor experience to the finish. Decent ESB
Aroma is floral hops and English malts. The flavor is fruit, malts, a clean bite in the middle and a lingering mildly hoppy finish.

I enjoyed this "IPA" slightly more than their Mojo Risin IPA. This seemed more like a hoppy Pale Ale versus IPA, but had a the floral notes in the aroma and taste like many IPAs. Advertised on the bottle as "English-style Ale", so I'm not sure exactly what it is. Maybe somthing similar to Lagunitas 2009 Correction Ale. Is it a Pale Ale or IPA....that is the question???? Still another solid brew from Boulder Beer. Nothing by them really blowing me away yet, but they are reasonably priced for the quality they deliver.

From Sep 2007 This pours from 22oz bottle(bottled July 1 as per small stamp near base of the bottle) a clear gold with a healthy head of foam that shrinks fairly quickly....some spotting in the middle and some lacing hugging the side of my glass. The smell has some hoppy and sweet notes along with some bread and some fruit. Nice nose. The taste on first sip and I get some good caramel malt and bread followed by some grain and a mild hop character. Tasty. After a few more sips, there's more hoppiness in the flavour but it's balanced nicely by the malt and it really works well for me. I don't have to have a hop bomb in every IPA that I drink!! ;^) The mouthfeel is medium, the carbo is medium, and it finishes slightly sweet. Good stuff and it's going to be no problem at all finishing the bomber. I recommend it!

Poured into an English pint glass, the appearance was a ruddy burnt orange to amber color with a finger’s worth of white foamy head that dissipated at a nice pace. Sly sticky lace. The aroma had some semi-sweet bready to biscuity malts with a mild soapiness. Grassy and earthy hop bitterness. The flavor stays true to the aroma, semi-sweet with a subtle bitterness. Mild flowing hops to malts aftertaste with the same sort of finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a good sessionable sort of feel. Carbonation felt fine. ABV felt appropriate. Overall, this was definitely an English pale ale throughout and I could see myself coming back to if I could get it again.

Draft Third of a Pint at GBBF 2010 (Day 3), Earl’s Court, London Aug 2010 - Golden in colour. Hoppy; resiny and floral hops; good hop bitterness. Malty; grainy malts, caramel. Fruity; grapefruit citrus. Good hop/malt/fruit balance. Easy drinking. (2010-08)
Has a good upfront malt hit, fades pretty quick into a sweetness that is a bit much for me. Creative brew and I may re-review when I am not blasted.

On tap, on nitro, poured a clear deep golden hue w/ creamy white lasting head. Mild malty aroma. Initial flavor is light sweet w/ a light to moderate bitter finish. Tastes are ugly fruit, bitter melon, and biscuits. Medium bodied and velvety mouthfeel. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft sample. The beer is a gold color with a white head. Malty dough, nuts, and herbs. Sweet and gets dry in the finish. Medium body and medium carbonation.
Draft - pours yellow white head - nose/taste of coffee, light citrus - medium body
On tap at Fat Heads Pittsburgh. Pours gold with medium frothy white head leaving sticky lacing. The aroma is earth and pine. Medium body, juicy hop, grapefruit, light bitterness, good.

column1: Liberty Myrtle Beach Lincoln Street Wheat
column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draught in Columbia. Pours a light gold, not really cloudy. The aroma is faint and corny with light citrus notes and papery, woody hops. This is a pretty light beer with minimal European hops and slight citrus flavor. It’s rather crisp, but after half a glass I feel a building, sugary finish.

column1: Liberty Myrtle Beach Lincoln Street Wheat
column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draft (Columbia). Orange, lemon and wheat malt aroma. Clear orange yellow color with small head and light effervescense. Dry lemon mustiness and wheat malt flavor - mouthfeel and flavor like a Saison. When I ordered this, I expected a filtered version of their unfiltered wheat beer but was pleasantly surprised - a very nice and unusual beer - a dry American wheat.

Bottle. Shared at my 10K rating celebration. Nose is treacle, caramel, vanilla. Dark brown with lace. Sweet treacle flavor, chocolate, caramel, fudge, grapes. A bit oxidized, very fruity. A bit past its prime but lovely.

column1: Hoppin' Frog Wild Frog Wheat Ale
column5: From a bomber purchased at the brewery. Pours a clear gold with an off white head. Aromas are herbal. Flavors are moderately sweet.
Shipped from Cincinnati Ohio, mahogany and collar centering with hands of maple followed by a roasted hazel nut body balance Cena clean multi finish. Tina likes ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A nice well-balanced brown ale. Sorry, I had to upload these old ratings. They were for me, not for uploading. And also I need 75 characters, hence this sentence. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
brown color; caramel malt aroma; caramel malty flavor with hazelnut notes; smooth and well-balanced; medium bodied
2/17/17. Thanks, Bobbie! Brown pour with a small khaki head. Mild nutty aroma, some caramel. Okay flavor, mild chocolate aspect, hint of nuttiness, grains, caramel. Not bad.
Standard fare brown. Good nutty flavor with some hazelnut sweetness taste. Tad thin. Ok
Malty and nutty and somewhat hoppier than I expected. It was very smooth and had a good weight and texture. This was a good beer for a nice early autumn day.
At Reds/Cubs game. Pours dark brown. Nutty Carmel aroma and flavor. Creamy thick ---Rated via Beer Buddy

Bottle. Pours ruby brown with a one-inch head. Aromas of caramel, brown sugar and dark fruit. Flavors are brown sugar, biscuit, and a hint of dark fruit. Dry, crackery finish. Mild hop presence. Clean mouthfeel. Not much of a malty backbone to this beer, it’s more dry and bready. Not terrible, but definitely not memorable.
Another pretty bland brown ale. Not really much else to say about it honestly. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This is an excellent American brown ale, slightly more hoppy than an English brown ale.

column1: E. J. Phair English Pale Ale
column5: At NorCal Brewers Guild Festival at Raley Field. Light pine aroma; Golden color with little head. Starts with balanced malt and pine hop. LIght bitter finish. It does suggest an English ale.
Draft. Lowww ABV. Aroma of cola. Flavors of cola, cocoa and licorice. Seems to beer a bit toward ESB territory. Finishes with chewiness. Really nice!

On tap @ Auburn Alehouse. Clear light brown in color with off-white foam. Lots of toffee and toasted grains to this. Nice caramel, some chocolate, and earthy hops. Plenty of nutty, toasty, caramel sweetness. Good toffee and hints of cocoa. Slight coffee bitterness. Pretty good brewpub brown ale.

"a thin bodied, slightly nutty brown ale. average hue for the style. ok, but not unique or special. i’d usually prefer a porter or stout to this style of brown. the watery body is what killed it for me. Better at times but inconsistent."

Draft at brewpub. Strong dark bread and crusty malt in the nose. Light brown, almost red in color. Medium sized off white head tight bubbles. Laces well. Moderate toast and roast in the flavor, but not sharp or overly drying. Slightly thin, but very good. Didn’t get much hops from the beer though.

On draft at Tap 25. It pours a dark amber/brown color with a tan head. The aroma is sharply roasted and toasty with hints of cocoa and coffee. The flavor is very toasted and dry with strong roasted bitterness. Good body. A great session brown ale.

A half finger of head on a brown/amber body. Good lacing. The aroma is nutty with toasted malt. Nice. The flavor is roasted malt with a moderate bitterness from the middle to end. It is smooth with moderate carbonation and medium body. A fairly standard brown ale with an interesting kick of bitterness in the taste.
Sampler at the brew house. Great aroma of toffee and caramel malt. Pours a clear mohagony with an off-white head. Medium mouthfeel of chewy chocolate malt and full biscuit. Finishes nicely bitter.

Growler from the brewery. Clear brown with an off white head. Aroma of biscuit dough, herbal hops and fruity esters. Flavor is rich biscuit malt with some light hop bitterness. Medium body with average carbonation. One of the better standard beers from Auburn in my opinion, just a solid English style brown.

On tap at the brewery. Medium brown color and very translucent. Aroma is pretty typical brown ale - some sweet malts and nuttiness. Flavor is a little more complex than the aroma lets on with some nice light roasted malt flavors as well as some coffee notes. Palate is extremely light. Overall a decent brown that would be infinitely better with a little more body - just too watery for my taste.
Soft nutty notes on the nose. A hint of roast and chocoalte. Brown/amber pour, soft head. Toasted nut flavor, hints of roast, light sweetness, chocolate. Earthy bitterness rounds out the finish.

Draft. Version I'm driving king is at 6.3% and 65 IBU. Clear lager yellow. Nice lace. Aroma is of citrus juice. Flavors are if freshly squeezed lemon and lime, and burst forward. Malts are water cracker, and wafer thin. Hint of cocoa too. Wow.

Sample at GABF 10/08/2016, thanks to my sis for assistance with note-taking. The beer is a clear dark golden color with a medium thick off-white head that diminishes steadily. Partial rings of lace. Citrus, hops and malt aroma. Medium body with flavors of piney hops, citrus and malt. The finish is moderately bitter with a citrusy hop aftertaste. Pretty good overall.

50cl bottle pours with a crystal clear pure gold body that supports a dirty white head of foam. The aroma offers up clementine, tangerines, some mango, a slice of pineapple and then a bit of spicy sort of earthy hops toward the end of the draw. The taste delivers a nice bite of citrus hop bitterness backed up by a modest degree of mango, tangerine and tangelo juiciness. To midway the citrus hop bitterness ramps up and is then joined by spicy onion dank hop bitterness and some earthy hops. This stays tropical and citrus from front to back with plenty of tasty hop bitterness rimmed thinly by juicier fruity hop notes. Pretty nice IPA.

Pint at Pi Bar, good aroma, sweet, citrus. Orange and grapefruit. Grassy. Clean orange gold color, good head, ok lace. Bittersweet flavor. Medium body , smooth creamy mouthfeel, bittersweet finish. It’s nice. Flavor best part.

Bomber from Hayduke that we had together via facebook chat. Clear honey gold with a big almost white head. A citrus aroma with pine (and I can never smell or taste pine!). Citrus beginning and that includes grapefruit. Cat pee. Cinnamon. Fairly big bitterness and it is making the top of my throat become numb. Some tropical fruit comes in mid glass. Simcoe is not a favored hop for me and this one definitely features it.

Shared with Strykzone on Facebook Chat. Poured a very clear gold with a big white head and moderate lacing . Nose is tropical fruit, citrus, pine, and peach. Medium plus body. Smooth in the mouth. Flavor is very rich with the fruit dominating, some grapefruit, pine, and some cinnamon spice. The finish is pine bitterness and the flavor hangs in there. Really nice beer, very drinkable.

On tap @ Auburn Alehouse. Clear golden pour with white foam. Really nice, juicy orange and grapefruit. Pine, hints of peach, and a slight tropical note. Flavor is a touch sweet and has a lot of orange and peach. Bitter pine, grass, and citrus pith on the finish. Pretty good IPA.
A very nice West Coast IPA with a huge - almost gratuitous - hoppy taste to it. Very piney and resiny, with just a hint of sweet caramel in the aftertaste. A good pick for any hops fanatics.
Golden Amber appearance with good size head. Nice spicy orange smell. Hoppy with light malt taste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a golden amber color with white head. Hop, floral, citrus, caramel, pine and malt aroma and flavors. Medium body and carbonation. Decent bitterness and hop and caramel finish.
Smells like a diacetyl laden gruitt beer. Cloying spices with very faint cheesy hop notes. Even worse on the palate.
Faded garnet color with an ivory head. Siide-by-side this beer looks identical to the amber. Caramel malt aroma with some hop notes. Very thin mouth feel. Dry with some bready notes.

At NorCal Brewers Guild Festival at Raley Field. LIght hop aroma, seemingly accompanied by citrus. Darkish brown amber color with a light beige lacing head. Medium mouthfeel. Malt strongly balanced with a fruit/grapefruit hop - it’s very different - unique even. The finish is mildly bitter.
I had this beer on tap at Third Street Aleworks. This light bodied golden pour had a slightly sweet taste. It would be a good thirst quencher.
Sample at brewpub. Light yellow with white head. Grain and corn, bit of cereal and bread. Mild sweetness with a nice carbonation, odd sweet/tang at the end though.
Draft. A light golden beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of straw as well as a light notes of citrus. The flavor is sweet with notes of matl and hay. The body is light.

Draft. "Yellow Card Kölschbier" was so renamed for World Cup fever. Gold with head that disappears entirely. Vomit and tarragon aroma. Flavor at least adds some malty goodness. This example is an unfortunate contrast with the same beer a week or two ago - it was so good, I got a growler! I miss that delicate, nobley beer. I was even thinking about ordering a keg, it was that good. Re-rate, 9-2-2010: A totally different beer! This one is clear pale amber with a scraggly white head. The nose is of dark berries, warm malts, and uncut awesomeness. Flavor is gentle, fruity, grainy, and reflects the berry notes from the nose. Finish is a tiny bit chalky but otherwise crisp and pleasant.
The one I tasted was called "Yellow Card Kolschbier" so this may not be exactly the same thing. Pours urine yellow with earthy, dank, musty flavor and straw. Some spice berry flavor.

Another blonde ale with a very thin white head. Aroma of grains and light hops. In mouth, another faint beer with light malts, epsom salts, german hops. Light bodied. On tap at brewpub, August 16 2009.

Sampled at the brewpub. Transparent pale gold with no head. Mild aroma, grass and a little candy. Flavor is fruity and grassy up front and then melds into a classic grass kolsch. Thin, watery finish. More flavor than a standard Kolsch.
On tap. Pours an almost clear yellow with a white head. Discreet malt aroma. Medium body, sweet clean malts and a dry, lightly hoppy finish. 110709

From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden yellow with a fully gone white head. Aroma is mild fruity and vague cornish malt. Light malty and crisp bitterness in the flavour. Ends medium dry and slight golden malty.

Date: July 08, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear yellow, wispy white head Aroma: light sweet malt aroma Overall: light sweet malt aroma, touch of corn, light floral hops Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 8/20 Rating: 2.2/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: *+/4

Tasted on tap at the 10th Annual Bistro IPA Festival. This IPA pours a light orange gold color. Medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is orange, citrusy and a touch floral. A medium bodied India Pale Ale. The malts are fruity and sweet, touch of orange. The hops are floral and grapefruity and floral. Nice balance. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

Draft at NorCal Brewers Guild Festival at Raley Field. Gold amber color with a hint of white head. Citrus hop aroma. Light citrus hop flavor. Medium mouthfeel. Light malt balanced the finish. It was really tasty.

column1: Watch City Pocket Full of Rye Hefeweizen
column5: Draught pint at the brewpub on 8/13/07 A an orange-copper-tinted hefe-weisse with the rye obviously adding the deeper color. Head immediately fizzles to a ring, clarity is medium-high, no lacing. Strong spiciness in the nose has a fresh floral hop scent as well that creates a very crisply aromatic one-two punch. Definite toasted notes give a bit of an earthy feel to it, while the wheat and rye round out the finish, dulling things somewhat but also deepening the complexity. Light brown sugar and honey sweetness, with a vanilla flare and a bit of caramel. Medium strength of aroma, flawless, no alcohol noted. Great balance of sweetness, with just enough honey, sweet nuttiness and caramel to give it ample body but yet retain its drinkability. Clove and spicy rye are light, but notable on the finish, while an interesting malt complexity is formed from the chewy wheat, crackery malt huskiness and softer vanilla-caramel sugars. Low carbonation, could probably stand to be a bit tighter, but it is draught, so that’s understandable. Light citrus hints dot the finish and the yeast has not pumped out an overwhelming amount of phenols.

column1: Watch City Pocket Full of Rye Hefeweizen
column5: Aroma is resplendent with rye spiciness. The flavor is a tiny bit flat by comparison. Kudos to the brewer for trying this, rather innovative, combo. It’s well accomplished.

column1: Watch City Pocket Full of Rye Hefeweizen
column5: ~8oz glass @ brewpub. Color is muted gold and clear. Aroma is strong on the estery/banana/bubblegum. Some breadiness as it warms up. Taste leans toward a more lemon-y hefe with a light grainy flavor (which I attribute to the rye). A bit watered down and a bit too light-lager like. A nice thirst quencher and returnable just for that. Leaves a corny/banana aftertaste. A great idea but maybe batch two will come out with a bit more substance.

Out of a barrel in a rain-lashed marquee, Whitefriars, Coventry. Orange amber with white suds. Gently citrussy hop crispness with lingeringly biscuity malt. Octo fountained most of it over the floor, but that was in no way intended as a reflection of the beer’s quality.

Cask conditioned at The Three Tuns, Alcester, Warks. Gold with white head. Smooth, balanced beer, golden biscuity malt with a light orangelike hoppiness. Maybe a little short on flavour but quite acceptable.
Cask-conditioned at the Old Spot, Dursley 27/5/2013. Golden with a slight white head. Sweetish, rich tea biscuit malts, a hint of apricot and leafy hops, before a decent, bitter finish. Good.

Cask at The Corinium Hotel, Cirencester, Glos, 28.05.11 Pours light amber with a slim white head. Soft in the mouth with a gentle hoppiness, some stale biscuit and a rustic quality,in fact its quite old fashioned in style and flavours with that distinctive Uley thumbprint all over it. A6 A4 T7 P3 Ov13 3.3

Cask conditioned at The Hollybush, Alcester, Warks. Gold to amber beer with white head. Nicely set up bitter, quite balanced and drinkable, smooth biscuity notes, slightly buttery with an underlying fresh hop. Not bad.

Cask @ Charlie’s Bar, Copenhagen. Pours a clear reddish/amber color with a small off-white head. Fruity malty aroma with some hints of caramel. Sweet malty fruity flavor with some hoppy hints. Sweetish malty finish with some fruity hints.
Cask Handpump at the London Hotel, Llandudno 07/05/2007 Malt aroma. Copper golden coloured fruity and a little sour. Some bitterness in a crisp full malt finish.

Cask at Charlie’s Bar, Copenhagen. A deep red beer with a thin off-white head. The aroma is sweet with quite a lot of diacethyl combined with light notes of berries. The flavor is swet with notes of berries - especially cowberries and raspberries combined with a diacethyl fruityness - especially with notes of peaches, but also with notes of toffee, and hops that kick in late with a light bitterness.
Cask Conditioned at Charlie’s Pub, Copenhagen Hazy amber color. Malty aroma and flavor, a bit fruity too. Good body; strong bitterness. Maybe there is a light infection present. Solid.
copper colour ... mellow fruit nose ... bland with little fruit and a dull hoppyness.
Cask conditioned @ Humble Plumb, Soton. Fruity sweet malts, hints of toastiness and a woody flavour. Ok but I didnt find this particularly drinkable.

Cask conditioned at The Hollybush, Alcester Warks. Red amber with white head. Dark and flavourful bitter, quite old fashioned these days but certainly easily drinkable. Deeper roasted crystal malts but also a sweeter light roasted note in there too. A fairly standard Marstons hop finish, didn’t get the Marstons ’snatch’ in this one. I liked it.

Very pale yellow coloured ale covered by a minimal white cover. Extremely light, vegetal, green tasting lager with tart bready notes that might come from wheat, but nevertheless don’t really fit there rest. Almost textureless, this could be water with a bit of bubbles. I was quite astonished to see this beer winning the KBV fest’s best summer beer contest.
Bottled (thanks faroeviking!). Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is quite salty, malty and hoppy. Flavour is quite much the same, with focus on the saltwateryness.
Bottled Pale golden color, small white head. Buttery, meallic, lightly diacetylic aroma. Light palate, metallic, lightly grassy flavor with some diacetyl. Poor showing from Föroya.
Ligth amber, light citric fruit nose, sweet fruit hop with a little bitterness in its finish.

Aroma has a touch of sulphury salts, spicey malts, grassy and floural hops. Taste is similar but without the sulphur, though still a bit chalky, peppery hops leave a dry mouth, very sessionable. This was cask #13 in my work.
Cask Conditioned, at the Market Porter, Borough, London Pale yellow coloured body, white lacy head. Strong bitter bite, with sulphurous middle, late bitter bite on the palate. Not a bad opening.
Bottle thanks to Grumbo: Poured a orange tinted brown with a tan ring. Aroma is strong malts. Taste is sugary malts, dries in the finish. Not bad!

Sample courtesy of Grumbo, cheers Graham! Coppery amber colour, tan foam head leaving lacing and aroma of malt, dried fruity, caramel. Taste is malty, tangy, dried fruit, caramel, burnt toffee, spicy, boozy, earthy, nutty. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry spicy boozy finish. OK

21/7/2019. Bottle from Ben's Off Licence, Tottenham. Pours dark amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of brazil nuts, roasted malt, light chocolate, toasted sugars and burnt toffee. Medium sweetness, light bitterness. Moderate body, slight slick and smooth texture, very soft carbonation. Above average African beer.

Magasin africain "boniface" Strasbourg. Ambrée sombre, forte mousse. Nez sur le caramel cuit et note acidulé. Gout malté, reglisse acidulée et alcool, corps un peu flotteux sans carbonation. Fin un peu caramel et toujours cette note acidulée.

Many thanks for this beer to tderoeck. Piwo ma malenka piane jak na coca-coli dosc gwaltownie nalewajac, spore pecherzyki powietrza, nie zostawia sladu na szkle. Aromatu brak, barwa czerwona. W smaku jak karmi albo Polo-Cocta zmieszana z cherry-coke. Slodkosc, karmel i kukulki. Nic specjalnego, bardzo lekkie, bardziej jak slodki gazowany napoj niz piwo. No ale za to nowy kraj jest. Jedyny plusik z tego wszystkiego
Kolor - ciemny br¹z, klarowny. Piana - drobna, œrednio wysoka, trwa³a. Zapach - brak. Smak - lekki karmel, leciutko podpalane, œrednia s³odycz, lekka goryczka. Poprawne.

One of the better tasting Congolese beers. Sweet, dark, heavy. Better if brewed in Kinshasa - the beers coming from the Mbandaka brewery in the north have a heavy chemical taste. Large beers (720 ml). Don’t drink 2 or you will regret it in the morning!

Clear dark red amber colour, white head. Mineral aroma, cheap perfume, malts, green banana. Malty flavour, light sweet, brown sugar. Sweet finish, banana, dark malts. (from 72cL bottle @ Procrastinated Spontan Gent Tasting 2014. Thanks for sharing, tderoeck!!)
Pours chesnut brown color with a small white head. Malty nose and flavor. A bit of bread and caramel.

Big bottle sample courtesy of Erzengel@kevnic2008’s Kurstadt tasting 12/07/2014. Piedboeuf butterscotch aromatics diluted into an actually quite drinkable Lion bar of a beer. No abv nor real hops apparent, yet mellifluous like caramelised banana syrup without the stickiness. - Who would have suspected that this gruesome ex-colonial would be enjoying a Congolese beer in post-ritzy Slavic Baden-Baden instead of colourful Matonge...

Cask conditioned - handpump - Alexandra Arms Rugby. A copper coloured beer with a big white creamy head. The aroma is spoiled a little by the tight sparkler but there is a little hop. The taste has some lemony citrus notes. It is a light beer but easy to drink and I guess the name is representative of its drinkability.

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: Poured a translucent dark brown nearly black with no head. Aromas of cocoa, carmel, light vanilla and a hint of fruittiness. Palate was light to medium bodied and crisp with a tart finish. Flavors of cocoa, carmel and light fruittiness with a crisp tart finish.

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: Oaked version from a secret stash. I only got a sip, and I regret that I can’t get more. Amazing with so much maltiness and so perfectly mellowed by the aging process and raisininess and chocolate explodatizing the palate. If you missed it, you may actually be better off than those of us who know what it’s like to have loved and lost. (through metabolization/urination)

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: Hands down the best imperial stout ive ever tasted! Up front the flavorwas full of dark chocalate and carmel giving way to warming roastiness ans a nice alcohal finish.Our waiter said there is a burbon barrel conditioned version in the works,

11th June 2019; Shrewsbury Beer Exchange meeting in Chez Sophie, cheers to me for finding this in London and sharing with four like minded friends! 650ml bottle, amber bodied, off-white head with lacing to follow. Malty and pretty sweet from start to finish, a bit one dimensional, but you'd never guess it was brewed in Africa.

Bottle @ monthly tasting, Chez Sophie, June 19, thanks Jeremy for bringing this back from the big city. Hazy brown appearance, frothy off-white head. Grainy nose. Taste is grainy dark malt, some distant chocolate grain. Surprising to see this style being brewed here, and it's not too shabby.
Bottle from african deli in Brussels. Dark color, off white head. Roasted,lager, not really interesting...
Bottle @ Saxo tasting. Clear brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and caramel. Flavor is quite sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. 040518
Bottle, 7%. Clear dark amber/brown with small tan head. Aroma is malt, caramel, toasted and bread. Flavour is malt, caramel, toasted, bread, sweet, dusty and a little bitter.
Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Light bitter flavor. Very week caramellic notes. Short light bitter finish. Oily palate.

Not much aroma but looks nice. The flavor has a bit of a bite and some nice caramel notes throughout. Some alcohol presents itself in the aftertaste, but this is a solid not more than one at a time beer.

Cask Conditioned, at the Market Porter, Borough, London Pale golden body, slightly hazed. Stodgy cardboard aroma, tank water bitterness, minerally, metallic. Appears not to of travelled well from Yorkshire. I would recommend another try if nearer to Yorkshire.

Cask at the Victoria Inn, Rugby, 24/07/13. Hazed golden amber with a decent sized off white cap. Good lacing ensues. Nose is lightly toasted malt, citrus, touch of hops, bitter orange. Taste comprises light hops, bitter orange, citrus fruits, light mineral notes. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry finish with a little bitterness. Drinkable GB affair.

Dark coppery colored with little white head. Buttery aroma with thin caramel, not too rich aroma. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor has also strong butter with also caramel and lemon, aftertaste lasts with some dryness.

Cask-conditioned at the Bag ONails, Bristol 18/9/08. Amber coloured with a slight, off-white head. Decent hoppy aroma, with some citrus and pine resin and a touch of sweetness. Flavour began with some sweet malts before orange and red fruit took over, culminating in a decent dry finish. Very drinkable.

Cask gravity @ Reading Beer Festival 2008. Clear medium yellow amber color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, dusty, light hoppy, citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium to light, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. (010508)

Beer Of The Evening (so far), and the most balanced of the Atomic beers I’ve tried. Fibrous, spiky, American-like hopping again (actually Styrian Goldings), but cushioned with biscuit. Earthily citrussy, but leaves you thirsting for another sip. Inviting marmalade aroma with a rub of hopleaf. Tasty.
Cask Handpump at the Victoria, Rugby 17/03/2007 Fruit and hop aromas. Golden coloured smooth on the palate and fruity with some dryness and bitterness in a wheaty malt finish.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Victoria Inn Rugby. A golden coloured beer with a decent white head. The aroma has great hops with mandarins and oranges. These are replicated in the taste. Lots of fruity body and lots of character. Good.
Tried at the Leicester Beer Festival 2019. Deep ruby to black colour with a tan head. Aroma has lots of chocolate and rich malt. Taste light sweet and slightly dry. Full body.

28/9/2018. Cask at the St Albans Beer & Cider Festival 2018. Pours deep chestnut brown with a small beige head. Aroma of milky chocolate, malt, fruit, light caramel and coffee with moderate roasting. Moderate sweetness, light bitterness. Light body, slight watery texture, soft carbonation. A very drinkable enjoyable mild.

Cask at GBBF 2015 - London. Pours clear brown with a foamy, tan head. The aroma holds ashy roast. Light sweet flavour, some cigarettes, dry cocoa, well roasted malts, earth. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Dry and ashy on the finish, more tobacco, burnt leaves. So so.

Gravity at The Derby Winter Beer Festival. A copper brown colour with a frothy off white head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, some nuts, slight coffee, a little burnt sugar and subtle dark fruits. Taste of chocolate, caramel, some nuts, slight coffee, a little dark fruits, a hint of vanilla and subtle cookie dough. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A soft, dryish, chocolate brownie kind of bitterness to the finish. I like this, sweet like most milds but chocolatey and nutty with a nice bitter finish. Good.

Handpull cask at the Coach & Horses, Wellingborough. Very dark brown, almost with purplish notes. Opaque. Cream-tan head leaves lots of lacing. Chocolate malt aroma with a slight medicinal note. Taste is sweet, smooth and malty. Ovaltine notes are slowly overcome by an insistent but polite hop bitterness. Bittersweet balance in the long finish, with blackberry, red grape and charcoal notes. Tasty mild.

Cask 1/3 pint, gravity dispense, at the 16th Twickenham Beer & Cider Festival, Dark ruby / cola black colour, small beige head. Moderate roasty aroma, notes of mild coffee and dark chocolate. Pleasant and lively mouthfeel. Roasty flavour, coffee and dark chocolate again. Roasty aftertaste, some hops.
Cask gravity at the 2016 Twickenham Beer Festival, very dark brown with a thin head, burnt cocoa nose, dry-sweet and roasty-burnt with cocoa and faint strawberry notes. Very nice.
Cask at Milton Keynes Beer Festival; opaque dark mahogany brown pour with a bubbly off white head, aroma has chocolate, taste has chocolate, slight bitterness, dark fruits, hint of coffee.

Backlog rating. Cask at GBBF 2015. It pours a dark amber color with a minimal beige head. Aroma is sweet malty with notes of biscuit, raisins, caramel, light cocoa and vanilla. Taste is also sweet biscuity with notes of cocoa, vanilla, biscuit. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Overall, tasty mild
Gravity cask at Nottingham festival day two with fonefan, Charlotte & chriso. Deep clear brown color. Very roasty coffee ground aroma. Taste has espresso, burnt brownies. Very nice.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draft at the Autumn Festival of Ales 2007. Black pour, dark tan cream head. Aroma is mild but there is roast and some chocolate. Flavor is also mild - chocolate, roast, and some sourness.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: (draft @ The Strathallan Hotel - Rochester, NY) Dark black pour with a creamy tan head. Aroma is rich and roasty with lots of chocolate, coffee, and some cream. Flavor is smooth and roasty with a slick chocolate flavor and a roasty and slightly burned finish. Very rich and flavorful.
On tap at Arrogant Sour Festival 2019. Hazy orange, white head. Malty, bit yeasty, tart, light sourness, medium carbonation. Medium bodied.
Perfectly tarty, beautifully smashable, unfortunately across the Bass Strait.
This is a very good sour ale, all them sour bitches that rated it poorly can eat a dick.
Super barnyard. Straw. Clean body. Citrus. Sour. This is a great summer palate beer cleanser.
Little salty, little sour - a very approachable sour. Rich amber colour, pleasant aroma and decent body with average carbonation.
Delicious. Tastes like happy mangos on a tropical island. Could easily settle into this for a holiday!
Delicious master piece of subtle cider-esque sour flavour with a sweet pale ale hearty scaffolding. No doubt a must have at anytime and any light.
My pallet is cleansed. I am refreshed like a young man looking to run free in the wild. Add me if you are cute @tylerthehouseket if your are cute xx
A little thin for my taste, and not much to counter the acid. Would be good to refresh the palate after a sweet beer though.
This beer is really great I’ve heard some folks hate it but haters gone hate Yano

Reviewed from notes. Bar pour yields a burnt orange/amber color with a slim cap of a level white head. Light lacing did show it’s face. The smell had a light toasted to burnt caramel note. Light orange fruit made a slight stimulant but in a slight off sort of way. The taste was semi-sweet but through a malty sort of weird conglomeration of burnt bitter hops scaling themselves into this weird flavoring. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a light sessionability about it. The carbonation was fine for the style and to me. Overall, for a maibock, I dunno man, honestly, I just didn’t really care for the smell and taste.

Aroma was barely detectable. Color is a burnt yellow close to an orange and clear. Very little head. Did not like the flavor. To me it was as if someone threw up candy and banana. Palate was like the after taste that banana leaves behind. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft. Pours a clear light copper with the slightest of white heads. Minimal lacing. Sweet, grainy aroma. Medium body with a bit of carbonation. Flavor is also sweet with notes of honey and a touch of caramel. Overall out of balance. Too sweet.

In the bottle at an SOB tasting thanks to Phil’s Dad. Pours a light amber with a white head. This is surprisingly good for a Capitol product. Not German in the grainy intensity, but a bit sweeter with a smooth palate. Easy to drink.
a rite of spring, don’t care for the new labelling, buts its the same great beer.

Dark Amber color with White Ring. Light Sweet Malted Aroma. Light to Medium Mouthfeel. Sweet Musty Malt, Bitter Twang...Burnt Caramel Flavors...with a Dry Burnt Caramel Finish. Something Seems Off With This Brew but At Least Has Some Promise to it.

Clear light copper color, white head, almost no head at all though. Very sweet straight malt and sugar nose, cheap grains and sugary maple syrup and apple smell. Taste is also sweet, more apple and honey flavor, more grains, I can sort of see some bock qualities but it really tastes no different than their altbier. Too sweet.
on tap at uno in madison. Nice white head,light amber body, caramel taste with a decent palate but the finish was unbalanced,some alcohol bitterness. I doubt if I will be having this one again.

(NY Ave) Crystal clear apple juice body topped by small white head. Aroma is moderately sweet, peach/apple, some grassy, alcohol. Taste is moderately sweet, bread, some caramel, lager yeast, alcohol, grassy. Medium body, some stickiness.

column4: Lion Breweries - NZ (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: (Bottle 33 cl) Pours a clear golden with a white head. Sweet raspberry aroma - this has the aroma of Red Bull! Medium body with extremely sweet fruit notes - raspberries. And again absolutely no bitterness. Obviously an attempt aimed at the RTD segment. 120208

column4: Lion Breweries - NZ (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Bottle 33c. Golden clear body with normal size head. Berries in the nose. Fizzy beer with lots berries in the flavour. Reminds me a lot of red bull. Beer? Hmmm

column4: Lion Breweries - NZ (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Tasted 23/11/2007. One of many jubilant beers after cycling ’round the lake. This one was the only "energy" beer - the rest were quite nicely restorative. Straw gold, no head, capsicum aroma reminds me of a chilli beer. Sweet, firmly carbonated, a touch of spice and shorter than the proverbial short straw. Cheapest looking bottle and label I’ve ever seen. This must have huge margins. As a beer it is ghastly, if it were a non-alcoholic carbonated beverage it would be ok. Like Bozo, I had a quiet laugh at the nutritional information on the label.

column4: Lion Breweries - NZ (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Bottle, a slight haze to the gold colour, no head. An aroma of ginger and ground spice. A sweet palate, like a red bull. Not beer as you know it. Oh dear.

column4: Lion Breweries - NZ (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Oh dear......berocca meets a weak lager shandy. Insipid...!!! Funnily enough, the first beer I’ve seen labelled with nutritional information...

column4: Lion Breweries - NZ (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Yeah, last one to endure!!! Piss yellow in colour with white head. MMM gurana and food acid330. Looks like beer but is sickly sweet syrip. When will this marketing event stop!!!

column1: Govnors Public House Absolute Rat Bastard
column2: Lake In The Hills, Illinois, United States
column5: On tap at the Govnors Brew Pub. Poured a dark and deep amberish almost brown color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of orange peels, roasty, and toasty. Tastes of citrus, floral hops, caramel, a little fruity, and biscuity.

column1: Govnors Public House Absolute Rat Bastard
column2: Lake In The Hills, Illinois, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. The body was brown with some orange and the edges. The aroma was fairly sweet with some pears and cinnamon. The taste was lightly bitter with some black tea. There was also a muted sweetness like plums. Decent.

column1: Govnors Public House Absolute Rat Bastard
column2: Lake In The Hills, Illinois, United States
column5: Pour is dark brownish amber with a thin tan head...smell is faintly sweet with caramel and hop that I can’t put my finger on...taste is lightly sweet at first with some bright caramel flavors...then a medium metallic type bitterness...

column1: Govnors Public House Absolute Rat Bastard
column2: Lake In The Hills, Illinois, United States
column5: GTMW 2007. Brewer’s description in the festival program reads "Hybrid brown ale". Poured a clear reddish-orange color. Trim, off-white head. Aroma was of toasted bread and grassy hops. Nutty with a bit of biscuity malt and citrusy hops. Clean finish. To be honest, this one probably didn’t really get a fair shake as far as it’s rating goes. It’s tough to stand out when preceded by the likes of Surly barrel aged darkness and Minneapolis Town Hall Czar Jack.

column1: Govnors Public House Absolute Rat Bastard
column2: Lake In The Hills, Illinois, United States
column5: This poured a deep mahogany body lightly highlighted in red and had a minimalist’s beige head. The aroma was rich and malty but held an odd sourness that when blended together reminded me of the candy corn that I ate as a kid but can no longer stomach. Exhaling through my nostrils as I drank, I found it somewhat tasty, some roasted malts, dark dried fruits, caramel, a hint of smoke. Not a bad drink if you can divorce the aroma from the experience. Govnor’s Public House, Lake In The Hills, IL

column1: Govnors Public House Absolute Rat Bastard
column2: Lake In The Hills, Illinois, United States
column5: When I called the brewer to determine this beer’s style, "Muffy" or "Cissy" (or someone) gave me the runaround of "Well... it’s a dark beer, a little bitter, but not TOO bitter..." When I stopped them and said, "No... I know it’s an ALE, but what TYPE of ale?", they paused and proceeded to start reading the commercial description above. I thanked them and am listing this as an "Old Ale"... as is the case with the other Govnor’s brews with "Absolute" in their name. If anyone cares to try to get a better answer, feel free. (And suggest better education for the brewpub staff while you’re at it.) Poured a dark, coppered-mahogany with very little head save for a few soapy bubbles of halo.
