Vinegared aroma dissipates to find an odd underbelly of prune pastry filling and tart cherries. Flavor finds dark fruits and biscuity malts with a light smokiness and a covering of vinegar before an earthen linger. A bit on the thin side with an oiliness to the palate. It reminded me alot of Taylor Brewing’s Dark Satin... a "Dunkel" with strong vinegar notes that took a while for me to warm up to. Growler-fill from Govnor’s Public House, Lake In The Hills, IL 60156
On draft at brewery during RBSG 2016. Pours near black with a tan head. Nose of roasted malts and coconuts. Media plus body. Flavor is chocolate and coconut with a bitter finish. Nice.
Draft - pours black tan head - nose/taste of coconut, milk chocolate and light vanilla - medium body
Draft at the source. Dark maroon color. Nice aroma of coconut on a roast background. Taste is sweet coconut and cocoa. Very tasty and easy to drink.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a very dark brown with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is strong cocoa and roast. Medium body, nice sweetness from coconut, chocolate, light roast finish, very good.
Sampled at the brewey. Coconut leads and works well. Earth and chocolate. Not much roast. Bread and raisins. Good and drinkable.
Didn't like this one as much as other coconut stouts. Maybe the coconut was just not pronounced enough for me and only had a vague milky taste and not in a good milk stout way.
Sampler at Giant Eagle in Pittsburgh, PA A bit on the weak side and could have been heavier bodied, a common problem with Church Brew Works.

On tap. Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of chocolate malt, lactose, roasted malt, sweet malt. Flavor of coconut initially followed by chocolate malt, lactose, light roast, and more toasted coconut. Palate is slightly thin but overall very tasty and plenty of coconut! 7/4/8/4/14 (3.7/5)

draft, poured a black color with a small tan head. The aroma was malty. The flavor was bitter, watery and thin feel with strong coconut that just overtook the flavor, with a hint of malty chocolate undertone. The finish was long, and dry with lingering coconut. Ok.

On tap at Benjamin’s. Light roasted malt with a bit of acrid smoke, lactose sweetness and a hint of coconut and chocolate. Dark black opaque with creamy light tan lacing head. Medium body with medium carbonation. Starts medium dry with roasted and lightly burnt malt. Coconut flavor with some coffee and chocolate, and a bit of carbonic acidity. Finish is sweet with coconut and vanilla and mild nutty bitterness. A little watery.
Bottle shared by Benzai... Yellow to golden colour, decent sized white head. Aroma and flavor are malts, some hops, quite yeasty. Average to decent body and carbonation.

Light golden color with a moderate sized white head. Pale malt and floral and wild flower blooms in the aroma. Hints of bananas and dry spice as well. Quite heavy in feel, with a tight zip to keep it from getting too cloying. Light sweetness with some tropical fruit and wild flower honey. Lightly citric and biting in the finish and linger. Actually drank the whole bottle, which is more than I can say about many of my last few. 1/11
Bottle from Cracked Kettle. Golden body with rocky head. Hoppy and buttery nose. Very easy to drink, with hoppy flavour. Prickly and piney in the finish. Quite enjoyable.

From old notes. Distinctive appearance of clear faded yellow but vibrant with some loose beading and a thick creamy head. Firm and robust with a degree of lean chewy but not at all citric (despite when the label says) but long and lingering. Restrained and persistent with just a trace of sweetness at the end to add to that hybrid style. Leaves layers of lacing rings as drunk. As shame this was discontinued. It got none of the respect it deserved.
Bright orange with a lasting white head. Grassy and flowery aroma with hop notes. Flavor is sweet malt with citric notes. Body is medium and body is thick. Low carbonation.

easily the weakest GD offering i’ve had to date. i was thinking/hoping for a titan type ipa with a belgian yeast strain, but it appears the hops are different (and lighter), the belgian yeast isn’t very assertive, and the belgian pilsner malt may be a slight miss. as a beer, it’s still above average, balanced, and refreshing, but given my expectations of GD (and my expectations of this cool style) this ones a miss. Won’t visit again unless i see it on tap, or go to CO."
bottle, remeber this on tap at Coles also. enjoyable Belian IPA, golden pour, medium bodied. fruity belgian yeast, citrusy hops, herbal/medicinal notes. goodbeer
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein leicht trübes goldenes Bier mit ordentlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, malzig süß, leicht würzig. Geschmack leicht hefig, fruchtig malzig, Gewürze, blumig.
A blend of my two favorite beers styles. The belgian yeast adds some nice spicyness and the hop profile is pretty intense.

My bottle has a bottled-on-date of December 2011. Soooooo, here we go. Medium golden body, average hits head. Cooked pineapple and noodles come to mind, a bit of sweet spice. Not undrinkable, but clearly past it’s prime.

Draught. Body is medium to dark yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (grain), with a strong note of DMS. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter, slightly unclean. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. I feel sorry for Marc that he has to brew crap like this for the company when he’s capable of so much more (like the Quad for one).

Draught at BJ’s Boulder. Beer is hazy, light caramel-colored with a tiny, white, frothy head that disappears quicky The aroma is malty with light notes of toasted grain, caramel; Yeasty with traces of basement and dough; Moderate note of corney DMS and a light note of fruity generic berry. The flavoris moderately sweet, lighty acidic with a long, lightly acidic, lightly bitter finish. The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is fizzy.

On tap @ BJ’s Westminster poured a cloudy amber with a minimal off white head. Aromas of bread, light carmwel and a hint of fruit. Palate was light bodied crisp and slightly dry. Flavors of bread, light carmel and just a faint hint of fruit with a crisp semi-swwet finish. Not a very good beer.

column1: Square One St. Louis Dark Lager
column5: Actually a Schwarzbier (printed on the menu): Aroma of sweet caramel, roasted chocolate and light apple. Appearance is reddish brown with tan head. Flavor matches the nose with some light hop character. Palate is lively. Quite good.

column1: Square One St. Louis Dark Lager
column5: On tap at Square One Brewpub. Amber with a thin white head. Aroma of caramel, sweet bready malt and light hops. Boyd is balanced but kind of ho-hum with mild toffee and bready malt, mild spice and a touch of hops that produce no real bitterness.

column1: Square One St. Louis Dark Lager
column5: On tap at the Heritage Brew Festival. Pours a pale amber with quite a bit of character. Every brewer at the fest produced a "dark lager", but this one may have been the best. Not dark really, it had an assertive maltly taste with a clean crisp bitterness from the hops. Very refreshing!

column1: Square One St. Louis Dark Lager
column5: Sampled at the brewpub. Filtered and amber hued. Webbed bone white head. Grainy with a touch of caramel in the mild aroma. Medium bodied and off-dry. Good bready malts. Medium effervescence. Nice caramel breadiness. Quaffable with good session qualities.

column1: Square One St. Louis Dark Lager
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours dark gold / copper with a light tan dense head. The aroma has the typical Square One nectar fruits and lightly toasted malt. Medium body with an abundance of tingly carbonation. The flavor starts with nectar fruits, peppery spice and clean toasted malt. The finish has more fruitiness then a lingering spice. An okay beer.
Draft at the source. Sampled during RBSG. From notes. Lemon citrus with ginger and loads of spice. Interesting brew, but not my thing.
Pale light yellow pour with white head and lace. Aroma is ginger and clove. The flavor mirrors aroma with a touch of floral hops. Meduim bodied and thin but solid and refreshing.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a hazy yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty ginger aroma. Fruity malty spicy yeasty citrus flavor. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty citrus finish.

Taster at the brewpub during RBSG. Hazy pale yellow color. Thin ring of white head.. Good zesty grassy nose. Nice lemon grass flavor. Light body. Smooth, crisp, lighter carbonation. Light dry finish. Good floral hop. Moderate bitter taste, light zest. Good tasty lemongrass blond ale! My style.
Draft at source. Pours cloudy yellow with white head. Nose/taste of light spice, lemon, light malt and light bodied.

Sampled from the tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy light blonde with a white head that dissipates quickly to the edges. Aroma has sweet grains, light spice and light fruits. Flavor is similar with sweet grains and spice supported by a hint of light fruit.

On draught at the brewery. Pours a hazy blonde color without much in the way of head at all. The aroma is gingery & sweaty... odd, but not wholly offensive. The flavor is really gingery & spicy. It’s not overly sweet but has a nice bitterness to it. Refreshing really.

On tap @ Square One. Hazed straw yellow pour with a white head. Nose of biscuit, honey, herbs, ginger, and lavendar. Slight citrus/lemon, some bread, and lots of cracker. Mild biscuit. Decent sweetness on the palate. Good biscuit, bread, and some hints of honey. Light lemon tartness, some lavendar, ginger, and a bit of an herbal thyme note.
Sampled along the RBSG 2014 bus tour. Slightly perfumy and almost ham like. Hazy, light yellow with a small head. Sweet with a grassy and lemon character to it. Enjoyable.

Draft on tap at the brewery (St. Louis, MO). RBSG 2014 Friday Bus Tour. Pours a well hazed straw hue, gentle yellow glow with loose bubbly head that dies down, laces minimally. Aromas are a bit sweet and fruity, apple and gentle pear ester. Touches of bread, straw, and crisp cereal elements. A bit yeasty as the Belgian element comes out. Initial is a bit sweet, touches of bubblegum, gentle fruit. Lighter body with some dryness, gentle yeastiness. A bit fruity, the gentle bready malt, dryness with some yeastiness. Spice, fruity. Pretty well put together. Nice.
Draught at Copenhagen Beerfestival 2007. Hazy golden colour with a nice white head. Aroma of hip. Also flavour of hip, light fizzy finish, someway special and refreshing, but i not into hip.
tap. murky as hell. light brown color. no head. strange mix of wheat and "hyben". strange novelty beer.
Draft. An unclear orange beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel and oranges. While the flavor is sweet and mostly spicy, and no wonder the body is thin.
Muddy yellow colour with a small white head. Malty, fruity aroma with citric and yeasty notes. Sweet fruity flavor with a light yeasty finish.

A delightful aroma of malt and hops are mixed with a touch of the strong alcohol. The beer is very fruity, slightly hopped and have a good warming taste of alcohol. By type barley wine makes itself not particularly noticed among the otherwise large selection available of similar types. It will certainly find its true nature after being stored for some years. I would certainly like to acquire me a couple of bottles for to long-term storage. The finish is hoppy, warming and prolonged.
Hazy orange with a small white head. Malty, caramel aroma. Malty and sweet flavour

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body: &nbsp Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 3 &nbsp &nbsp Golden(1)->Dark brown(5) : 3 &nbsp &nbsp Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 2 Head: &nbsp None(1)->Large(5) : 3 &nbsp White(1)->Tan(5) : 2 &nbsp Lasting: 2 &nbsp Lacing : 2 Aroma: Intensity : 2 &nbsp Yeast : 2 &nbsp Bread : XX &nbsp Tropical Fruits : XX &nbsp Soap : XX &nbsp Diacetyl : XX Sulfur : XX &nbsp Fusel : XX &nbsp Malt : 3 &nbsp Biscuity : 2 &nbsp Hay : XX &nbsp Toasty : 2 &nbsp Caramel : 3 &nbsp Fruity : 2 &nbsp Nutty : XX &nbsp Honey : XX &nbsp Maple : XX &nbsp Molasses : XX &nbsp Cereals : XX &nbsp Grainy : XX Hops : 2 &nbsp Noble(1)->American(5) : 1 &nbsp Leafy : XX &nbsp Spicy : XX &nbsp Floral : XX &nbsp Lemon/Lime : XX &nbsp Grapefruit : XX Orange : 3 &nbsp Herbal : XX &nbsp Grassy : 2 &nbsp Pine/Spruce/Resin : XX &nbsp Notes : &nbsp Peach/Apricot : XX &nbsp Earth : 3 &nbsp Mint : XX &nbsp Butterscotch : XX &nbsp Smoke : XX &nbsp Dates : XX &nbsp Bourbon : 2 &nbsp Bubblegum : XX Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Sourness : XX &nbsp Bitterness : 4 &nbsp Complex : XX &nbsp Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 2 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 2 &nbsp Clean : XX &nbsp Sharp : XX &nbsp Watery : XX &nbsp Oily : XX &nbsp Chalk : 4 &nbsp Astringent : 2 &nbsp Alcohol : 4 &nbsp Mineral : XX &nbsp Oxidation : XX &nbsp Metallic : XX Comments: Lean-bodied barleywine tasting rather corny and syrupy at the same time, obviously boosted with sugars and finishing quite chalky, rough.

Draft. A slightly hazy red-brown beer with a thin orange head. The aroma is sweet with notes of grapefruit and hops, as well as a light touch of caramel. The flavor is sweet mlaty with primary notes of caramel and grapefruit, while the alcohol is felt in the mouth.

Bottle from Furusato Nozei. This is the Yu-agari Bijin label. Cocoa powder nose, lightly roasty, slightly creamy. Shiny dark brown to black with a fine, frothy head. Dry, roasty flavor, dark chocolate and coffee, a bit of burnt wood. I agree this is probably an ale and not a lager, although could be a schwarzbier. Body is rather light, crisp. Finish is mostly roasty and dry. Not bad at all, though somewhat forgettable.

Pours brownish black with thin greyish head. Aromas are smoky and hard to smell because I have a cold. Very bubbly carbonation, mouthfeel of a somewhat flat soda. Flavors are very smoky, roasty again, but without any trace of bitterness that can sometimes accompany dominant smokiness in a beer. Decent, not too filling, goes down easy.

Dark red-brown color with small white head. Very nice citrus hop aroma, sweet malt. Flavor is very balanced with super sweet malt, bitter-pine, bubblegum, pineapple. Med-large, full body with a lot of creaminess. A pretty amazing IPA and a great beer from john cutler.

Chicago Trip. Monday 12:30. Spoke with the brewer. This is brewed with Apollo hops. Not sure if it was also with Centennial and Fuggles or if Apollo is descended from those two. On tap. Golden beer. Wet grain aroma. Light foam. Attractive flowery hop nose with citrus notes as well. Very malty beer. Big bodied. Holds up a lot of hops. I believe this should be listed as an IIPA.

On tap at Piece. This was a dark one.. and could have been a DIPA, but I couldn’t get info. Poured a surprisingly deep brown with a short cap of off-white head. Aroma was of sweet, toasted grapefruit with caramel and perhaps a hint of chocolate.. pine resin accents.. deep, dark, and seductive! The flavor was even more enjoyable with a dark, sweet base of grapefruit, pine resin, and caramel.. hefty doses of pineapple and pine resin bitterness surrounding.. nice use of darker malts in there.. long, bitter pineapple finish.. very tasty! Medium-bodied with the sweet, toasty core supporting the higher bitterness well. Great stuff!

Bottle from Furusato Nozei. Yu-agari Bijin label. Slightly strange nose, stinky durian / very ripe tropical fruit, bit of toffee, ripe stone fruit, metal. Golden orange with a low, lacy head. Sweet, creamy flavor, toffee, creamy, tropical and stone fruit. Very light bitterness, slightly peppery. Touch of diacetyl maybe. Not a lot going on. Nose is a bit out there. Not bad.

Hooray! A halfway decent tasting beer made in Japan! Pours a pale slightly green golden color with a nice natural looking head. Flavor is mainly hops, some nice American IPA style hop. Has a slightly oily taste to it, but nothing too bad. Something of an ok beer, hooray!

Coming in a 500ml brown bottle, bottlle-conditioned. BBE Aug. 2007, served cool in a straight imperial pint glass. Appearance: pouring a very static pint of murky, russet-brown tea, with no beer head what-so-ever and very little carbonation detectable. Aroma: aromas of flowers, sour pears, and a touch of ripe blue berries rest on top of a Mild-like brown-sugary and sweet tea-ish malty backbone. Quite simplistic, and a tad stale as well as damp overall... Flavour: pretty mixed in flavour, featuring light chocolates, licorice, ground herbs, balanced by (yeah...) a touch of berry-ish sourness and longan-fruit tea. A belated flow of mild hop bitterness and a little bitter nuttiness creep up in the end, while the overall dry-ish mouthfeel resembles a Dark Mild. Palate: the structure of this ale is messed up, while the texture remains watery, showing no signs of fizziness at all. I wonder if the bottle-conditioning process, or the bottling process, has gone wrong. Also there’s no telling whether Juniper berries are indeed used in the brew, as this beer’s fruitiness is also like that of some other not-so-fresh ordinary bitter... All in all, an interesting beer this is, but desparately in need of more freshness and body in order to be an enjoyable one...
Copenhagen beerfestival 2007. Elderflower and flowery aromatic hop aroma. Cloudy golden, low head. Flowery perfumed flavor. Light body, slightly fizzy. Fresh.
Hazy orange colour with small white head.Taste of herb and like a mild IPA but more flowery and sweet.Flavor of elderflowers a really nice brew.
Bottled, 2007. Golden with small head. Aroma of malt and flowers. Flavor of elderflower on a tone of caramel.
This was version 2, it had an aroma of elderflower, but not too much. The flavor has some elderflower too and it has a dry finish, which suits the beer well.

Bottle of 50 cl. Cloudy dark amber with a medium off white head. The aroma is moderately malty and heavy hoppy with citrus, pine and grass. The taste is sweet and hops filled with notes of grass ok caramel. Moderately bitter in taste and a somewhat greater bitterness in the end
Hazy amber ale. Creamy off white head. Hoppy aroma with citrus and pine. Grazzy bitter flavour with some underlying malty sweetness. and grapefruit. Good.

Bottle 50cl. Poors nice brown in the glass with rather big head. Quite a lot of hop and pinewood in the nose, but also some nice soft malty tones. It tastes really nice. Well balanced. Bitter finnish as expected from an IPA, but not too much hop. Nice beer

Dieses IPA steht unfreiwillig schon länger im Keller - ich habe es erst jetzt wiederentdeckt, das MHD liegt 8 Monate zurück. Kann ein IPA da noch hopfig sein? Kann es. Kurz malziger Antrunk, danach bleibt die Malznote kräftig, wirkt aber eher im Hintergrund. Der Hopfen ist süßlich und wirkt kontrastreich zum Malz im Vordergrund. Der Hopfen kann sich nicht mehr steigern, wird aber etwas grasig und zum Ende bitter. Durch die malzige Hintergrund Note wirkt das Ganze nicht mehr allzu frisch, dafür aber eher würzig. Im Abgang wird das Bier noch einmal hopfig und würzig. Angenehm! Test vom 24.9.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,10,11,12,12,11 - 10,85
Bottle. Pours hazy amber with a creamy off white head. The aroma is citric hops, pine and spruce. A bit harsh. The flavour is grassy bitter with notes of caramel, and grapefruit. Long citric finish.

column1: Baird Ganko Oyaji (Stubborn Old Man) Barley Wine
column5: Bottle, bb 2/23 - guess that means it's a 2018 bottle. 11% ABV. Amber with a fat coat of cream head.3+ Aroma of bread, very ripe grapes, old lemons, light spices. Not all that heavy for its strength. Low carbonation. Bittersweet with bread, spices and quite vibrant marmalade-like citrus. Slips down - a slow drinker rather than a sipper. Subtle notes under its directness.

column1: Baird Ganko Oyaji (Stubborn Old Man) Barley Wine
column5: On tap. Deep amber with quite big, frothy and very solid white head. Very nice lacing - second ever barley wine which looks so good. Light to medium dried fruits aromas with raisins flavors on a strong malty background. Medium to full body, pretty smooth mouthfeel. A bit tart start with even stronger tart / bitter aftertaste. Decent

column1: Baird Ganko Oyaji (Stubborn Old Man) Barley Wine
column5: 330ml Bottle. Pours a light brown with off white head. Sweet nose with hints of a hidden malt complexion. Full body with the strong caramel flavours and malt backbone.

column1: Baird Ganko Oyaji (Stubborn Old Man) Barley Wine
column5: 360ml bottle (2013 version @ 10%). Pours dark brown without head. Caramel, toffee, raisins, candied orange, ginger, pepper, cinnamon, vanilla. Very sweet, not much attempt at balance, but all the better for it.

column1: Baird Ganko Oyaji (Stubborn Old Man) Barley Wine
column5: February 22nd, 2017 - Ganko Oyaji is one of the burlier, if not the burliest, brews available at their Takadanobaba tasting room. With a deep dark color, it looks the part, and the smell is stuffed with dark fruits, brown sugar and a boozy finish. Both the 2016 and 2017 smelled largely the same, save that the 2016 version’s alcohol note is more pronounced and a little more raw. The same is true of the flavors, each featuring the depth of sweetness of apple sauce, some ripe esters (bananas right before it’s banana bread time) and some figs. But there’s plenty of body to go around, holding up the fermented tasting sugars. February 20th, 2015 - One of the best named beers in Japan, the Ganjo Oyaji Barley Wine is a burly boy, swirling in its tulip glass with a deep, redwood haze. The head is a stack of tan pearls, keeping pressure not he nose of this brew, which itself is dense with red grape juice and graham crackers, and edged with alcohol. The taste is also quite sweet, but more forward with marshmallow, and featuring a slight tang to liven up the sticky sweets. As the beer warms those marshmallows take on a darker, roasted marshmallow note, which fits nicely with the progression of the evening.

column1: Baird Ganko Oyaji (Stubborn Old Man) Barley Wine
column5: Draft. A hazy golden beer with a white head. The aroma has notes of fruit, caramel, malt, and alcohol. The flavor is sweet with notes of alcohol, malt, over ripe fruits, and caramel, leading to a dry finish.

column1: Baird Ganko Oyaji (Stubborn Old Man) Barley Wine
column5: CBC2015, Pours orange with a small head, aroma of apples, grain, flavor is sweet with caramel, apples, grain, medium bodied

column1: Baird Ganko Oyaji (Stubborn Old Man) Barley Wine
column5: On tap at CBC15. Pale amber with off white head. Aroma has dried fruit, raisins, grain, slight caramel and citrus. Taste is dark fruit, sweet caramel, citrus, toast with a sweetish caramel finish. Good!

column1: Baird Ganko Oyaji (Stubborn Old Man) Barley Wine
column5: Draught@CBC2015 (blue session). Amber colour, small slightly off-white head. ARoma is fruity, some nectary and mildly alcoholic notes to it. Flavour is sweet malts, fruits, mild nectar, raisins as well as a slight alcoholic kick to it.

column1: Baird Ganko Oyaji (Stubborn Old Man) Barley Wine
column5: Draft @ CBC 2015. Pours a clear orange color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma with weak hoppy hints. Sweetish malty spicy caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty spicy caramel finish.
(on tap) Vague flowerish nose, subtle, with elderflower as the strongest influence. Light and waterish finish.

(33cl bottle, 6.5% abv) Hazy, orange golden colour with a huge foamy white head. Dusty and yeasty, sweet malty aroma with notes of ripe lemon. Sourish and slightly bitter-tart flavour, medium bodied with a lively carbonation. Slightly wheaty and almost astringent citrus- and lemon-fruity, yeasty taste which covers everything else; dry and sourish tart finish. Probably beyond its prime time as the bb-date is not visible anymore (19.IV.09).
33cl, retired brew, last tasted one year ago, exclusive, from the brewery, easy to drink, not balanced, cloudy, rocky head, nice brew

As TBone says "I suppose that this the right one even it doesn’t mention "Cuvée Speciale": it is 6.5% and contains: "water, pilsmout, tarwemout, hop (challenger en ek goldings), korrelgist lesaffre T58"." Pours out beautifully with a humongous head, especially with the Alvinne glass. A thick golden color with some slightly visible carbonation. Aroma is as usual for Alvinne, yeast gone wild, this is in the form of milky-pineapple with an airy Belgian feel and sweet candy. Taste is nicely different with the pilsner malt coming through and the esters are died down just a tad. Sweet finish but the strong carbonation chases away any negativity from that. My only complaint is that house yeastiness is so prevalent in all there beers that it is becoming a bit boring. Also, since when is a mistake beer become a "Speciale" beer, its like trading cards.33cL bottle @ Bierbrasserie Cambrinus, BB 03/2009, in a large Alvinne tulip on 5/19/08.

Bottle, 33 cl. We ware the first who drinked this beer, at a taste-evening on febr. with Glenn & Davy from Alvinne. This is a special brew, by mistake. Aroma and taste is very hoppy with a good mix of sweet and bitterness. A very good aftertaste. But ill prefere the Alvinne Blond

Bottled, alc. 6.5% I suppose that this the right one even it doesn’t mention "Cuvée Speciale": it is 6.5% and contains: "water, pilsmout, tarwemout, hop (challenger en ek goldings), korrelgist lesaffre T58". Hazy orange color, small white had. Perfumic hoppy aroma with hints of, leather an fruits. Medium-bodied. Dry, but fruity, some sourness, slightly cardboardish malty. Bitter, soapy aftertaste with touch of lemon.
Bottled. Hazy yellow colour, mediumsized white head . Aroma is sweetish sour/bitter and quite acidic. Flavour is quite much the same. Some slight fruityness also shows in it.
From bottle at 12de Vilvordia BierProefFestival. Hazy golden with a huge, rocky Duvel-like foam. Fruity hop aroma. sweet maltiness, matched by fruity hop bitterness. Nice.

A very special brew. A beer made by mistake. An error of the hop adding made it a mixture of Alvinne Blond and an Alvinne Extra. A very hoppy smell and a nice mix of sweet and bitterness. A very good aftertaste. We hope that they will repeat it because it is a very nice beer

29/VII/15 - 33cl bottle from De Bierloods / Zytholoog (Adegem) @ holidays - BB: IX/2010 (2015-1014) Clear pale blond beer, irregular fizzy white head, little stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: bit sourish, fruity, funky touch, little dirty. MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: bit sourish, fruity, lemony, some orange peel. Aftertaste: sourish, fruity, some tannins, orange peel, bit sugary.

bottle, white/very soft yellow coloured with very small (almost no head) fastly fading away. Smell .. some strawberry. Taste: very watery, difficult to find some tastes within. Very boring beer without any power. Not good at all!
Botella. Cloudy dark yellow. Yeasty sweet fruitish bit oxidated aroma. Ok mouthfeel. Flavour is sweet and yeasty with fruit, light spice. Taste like it’s has passed it’s best time to drink date.
shard by faroeviking. cloudy to muddy brown, smooth small white head. caramelly, malty, slightly spicy aroma. flavor is fruity, yeasty, spicy.

head: white , thin , creamy , bubbly colour: white/very light blond, hazy smell: wheats, yeast, citric, chalky, alcohol, something special like herbs or spices... taste: smoked , citric, vinegar , hops, yeast, somewhat dry , and a taste of wett popcorn ... in the end a somwhat skunky grassy taste ...
Bottle 0,33ltr: Hazy amber coloured ale with an lemony taste due the cranberries.

(bottle, 33cl) Hazy, yellow to light-golden colour with a firm but short foamy white head. Slightly yeasty, sour fruity aroma with notes of citrus, red berries and a touch of wheat. Moderately sour flavour with just a whiff of malty sweetness, light to medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Slim malty, wheaty base with an acidic fruit-accented taste of mainly citrus, sour berries; dry and slim acidic fruity and slightly tart finish. 30.III.10

Bottle 33cl. Light light unclear light to medium yellow orange color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, white head. Aroma is citrus berry acidic, craneberry acidic. Flavor is moderate sweet and acidic with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20090403]
A nice beer brewed for the open days last year. You find orange flowers and kardemon in the smell. The beer is rather sweet but with good after taste

Pours a cloudy golden orange from the bottle with bubbly off-white head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of floral and grassy notes with a hint of musty earth and Belgian esters. Taste follows, a hint of malt to back it up. Nothing very special, but cool concept.
Tap @ Biercap Barcelona. Hazy golden body with a medium white head. Green leaves, herbal, green tea. Hmm.
At Home hazy golden blonde colored body with a white head and with a spicy herby hops aroma a spicy herby hops yeast sweet taste with a bitter finish
Nevelig, viesgeel bier met kleine schuimkraag. Bloemen, rietsuiker, mouten, brood. Zoet, licht bitter. Volle body. Middelmatig.

Originally intented as X-mas ale Yellow, luxurious thick head over dark red-brown beer. Little sourish nose, cream-coffee, sweet and a lot of alcohol plus lots of fusels. Sweet-bitterish taste, fairly burned, burnt malts. Alcohol remaining hidden under all the roast. Ending slightly on lactic acid. Retronasal soft cheese/blue cheese. Sharp burning MF. Fusels coming out again, alcoholwarming. I "fear" a little infection, but it comes out actually very inviting. I like this beer!

Bottle, 33 cl. There is no label for this beer. (people on Waregemse Bierhappening love it) Now i’ll taste again @ home. Dark brown almost black color, with creamy head. Aroma: caramel malt, yeast. Medium body. Taste: sweet, malts, bitterness.

Sold as Paasstout in Waregem. It was meant to be the Potteloerke but by mistake they added the wrong mout on it. The result is a very fine stout. This beer is only availlable in a very small quantity. Taste this sweet and bitter beer

Tasted this years ago, can’t even remember when, but during cleaning up, I stumbled on old notes hastily scribbled on beer mats and pieces of paper and this was among them. Amber coloured beer with off-white, moussy head, caramelly flavour with some dried fruits and peaches, light leafy hop bitterness in the end. Okay but forgettable.

This this beer more times first with William @ vzw De oude Brouwerij of Zonegem. bought 24 bottles. (bottled in the old bottles from this brewery) One brew each year for Open monumentdag. Almost clear amber color, with a offwhite head. Aroma: sweet, fruits, malts. Medium body. Taste: sweet, full malts, fruits, caramel touch, soft bitterness. Good when its young.
Dark amber colour. Balanced between sweet and bitter. Fruity and malty, some notes of caramel.

A fruity and little spicy beer in an old kind of bottle. It is lmade for vzw De oude Brouwerij of Zonegem. You can reed it on the bottle. Still grafted on it. We are missing any label and the taste is sweet with some bitterness in the aftertaste. Really sa perfect balanced beer
Hand bottle drunk 5/26. Clear gold color with small head. Malty yeasty aroma. The taste was and malty with light sweetness. Nice refreshing bitter finish.

Hand bottled, thanks to my friend Dickinsonbeer. I typically shrug off lighter lagers like this and this one was resting in the back of the fridge, forgotten about. I cracked it tonight and i’m blown away by both its mouth feel and malt character. Extremely flavorful, fresh, succulent lightly toasty and bready malts. This is an eye opening beer and one heck of a lager. Thanks Paul.

on tap -pours a thin white head and yellow color. Aroma is mild grain, medium fruit. Taste is light/medium malt-some sweet, grain, balanced secondary spice floral hops. Some alcohol comes through, finishes fairly dry. OK carbonation.

Phenomenal Maibock. Pours a clear golden color (on the light side for the style) with nice lively carbonation and a foamy tight white head and awesome lace. Aroma is loaded with bready and slightly toasted malts, doughy, slightly nutty, and a fragrant herbal and spicy hop profile. Flavor is loaded with more lightly toasted malts, bready fresh pils malt, and noble spicy hops in the finish. Super smooth. Rivals Ramstein.

column1: Butte Creek Spring Run Organic Pale Ale
column5: Bottle: &nbsp Reddish caramel, very hazy, large fluffy off-white head, enjoyable lacing. &nbsp Malt oriented nose, very slight graininess. &nbsp Very little hop presense, if any. &nbsp Hmmm... on first sip I noticed that for an Organic its not as earthy/grainy as I have come to expect. &nbsp Its actually a bit malty, with a soft hop background. &nbsp This one is pretty easy to drink, and certainly a bit better than I expected. &nbsp Well rounded, feels fairly hefty for a Pale Ale. &nbsp Paler than most, er ligher perhaps, not as hop oriented, but I am a stickler about North West Pale Ales. &nbsp Its actually more appealing that its not all that grainy. &nbsp Decent little offering.

column1: Butte Creek Spring Run Organic Pale Ale
column5: Picked up at the new Hop City in Atlanta, Georgia. 22 oz. Nice caramel/orange in color. Thin head sitting on top. Little hazy, but still nice. Good looking beer. Slight hop aroma, but mianly biscuit and malts. Pungent aroma ,but not my favorite type of aroma. Very sweet beer at first, with a subtle hop aroma that develops into a decent bittering hop flavor. Leaves some decent lacing. The hops don’t play as big of a role as I would like them to. The caramel sweet malt flavor is what stands out the most. Not a huge Butte Creek fan.

column1: Butte Creek Spring Run Organic Pale Ale
column5: Pours nice copper color with a small off white head. Caramel and biscuit malts are quite prominent in the aroma with a nice balance from the piney hops. The flavor is similar, but the hops stand out nicely from the sweat and toasty malt background. Also picked this one up at Jungle Jim’s for $1.99, what a steal.

column1: Butte Creek Spring Run Organic Pale Ale
column5: 3/16/2009: Spring Run is an all-around good, solid pale ale. I like it. Its toffee maltiness is paired nicely with a honey sweetness. It is slightly dry and grainy in the middle. The front is balanced by a moderate level of pine and grassy bitterness. I could really just sit around and drink this well-bopped pale ale all day. I definitely need to go back and pick up a bunch more of this for the price (only $1.99+tax/bomber!). 1pt., 6fl. oz. bottle (5.7% alc. by vol) from Jungle Jim’s International Market in Fairfield, Ohio. Rating #14 for this beer.

column1: Butte Creek Spring Run Organic Pale Ale
column5: Bottle. Amber beer with an off-white head. Grapefruit and pine aroma. Grapefruit and pine flavor with light malt. Some bitterness. Medium bodied. Grapefruit and pine lingers with light caramel. Nice APA.

column1: Butte Creek Spring Run Organic Pale Ale
column5: 22oz bottle. Deep orange color, foamy off white colored head. Big aroma of citrus hops. Grapefruit, grass, and some bready malt all in the nose. Sharp hop bite. sweet caramel malt, very light toast. Lots of grapefruit. An all American Pale Ale hop. Pleasant spicy hop, finishes dry. Medium bodied. very nice hop character.

column1: Butte Creek Spring Run Organic Pale Ale
column5: Bottle from Bottle Barn Orange copper color with fine frothy beige head Lots of grapefruit aroma Flavor is mildly roasted caramel with relatively light grapefruit and pine Very smooth Finish is fairly decent bitter Very refreshing

column1: Butte Creek Spring Run Organic Pale Ale
column5: Bomber. Poured translucent brighter orange with a short cap of white head. The aroma picked up soft bready and caramel notes with vibrant citrusy and grassy accents.. smelled at the back like it may have a boozy bite. The flavor had an almost syrupy caramel base with moderate-to-high grapefruit and piney bitterness surrounding.. not bad, but nothing really popped. Medium-bodied with lower carbonation on the palate.. I didn’t much care for the long bitter finish that didn’t have any real flavor behind it.. aiight overall.

column1: Butte Creek Spring Run Organic Pale Ale
column5: pours a clear copper under a large foamy yellow head. fresh hoppy aroma, mostly floral, with some spicy malts. a bit of pepper. flavor is hoppy and moderately bitter. the malts are slightly restrained giving it a bit of a watery texture and mild soapy taste. but overall it’s pretty good.

column1: Butte Creek Spring Run Organic Pale Ale
column5: Dark copper color with a small beige head. Flavor and aroma of citrus and piney hops and caramel malts. Pretty good and drinkable.
Light gold with plenty of carbonation from bottle. Citrus, grassy and fruit notes in the aroma. Taste is smooth and easy drinking but not complex - like a beginner’s witbier.

Originally rated July 2007. This beer comes in a 12 pack, for one dollar more than their other swill lagers. It pours a cloudy golden-beige colour with a decent creamy-foam head that has pretty good retention, and very nice lacing. The nose is malty with some of that Belgian white yeast. Smooth watery mouthfeel, with very mild stickiness as it goes down. The taste is pretty light, with mostly malt and maybe wheat in the background. Some little citrus in the aftertaste. Above average for a PC brew, but too light tasting to be a good witbier. Good on the wallet though, and just right for the summer.

Poured cloudy straw coloured with a thin white head. Citrus aroma. A nice version of a belgian wheat beer considering they aren’t my favorite. Very drinkable, light citrus and malty flavour. Better than I expected.

On tap at in de Wildeman, Amsterdam. Pours a quite hazy brownish-red with islands of stark white, sticky foam floating and lasting. Aroma is predominantly caramel sweetness, but there also a very high ester profile in clove and banana notes, and a bit of that characteristic wheat funk/sourness. Taste is fairly complex, and quite fragrant at first sip. Great chewy malt presence: caramel, toffee sweetness upfront mingles with a fruity component reminiscent of dark berries and cherries as well. A slight sour note in the finish as well as a very faint alcohol presence. The aftertaste is striking and lasts considerably, a slight sour component sticking to the palate, and a bitter presence at the sides of the tongue. Despite high carbonation this retains a thick, complex mouthfeel. Quite nice, approaches Aventinus but doesn’t quite make it to those heights.

I had a glass at the same-named bar in the Times Square area of NYC. The draft was an opaque orange with a very full head of finely bubbled, light tan foam. It smelled slightly of peaches and coriander. The taste, grain, spice, toast, malt and a bit of yellow fruit. Not grabby but not bad either.

7/11/2011 2:45:11 PM clove, On tap at BXL Cafe East. Nice cuvee of amber complexion. Nose was fruity and spicy. Taste also caramel, toffee with some nice sweet fruit flavours. Enjoyable and Ommegang always very good.

Tap pour at bxl cafe. Mostly opaque amber-orange with solid white head in glass. Lacing all the way down. Orange zest, coriander and pizza dough on nose. Inviting. Taste is sweet fruits, some zip, coriander and a healthy amount of doughy yeast. Errs on the side of sweet, detracting slightly from an otherwise very well executed ale. True to description, highly sessionable. And at the gravity, a bit of a liability. Worth an order, or two.
Draft at BXL, amber orange pour.medium mouthfeel. Aromas and flavors of Fruity yeastiness, mild spice, coriander. Seems like its rare vos

Approximately 12 oz draft pour at BXL East in Midtown East Manhattan. The pour is a hazed copper golden, with a well formed 1 inch white head. Nice lace coats the glass. The aroma is straw, hay, clove and a light fruit yeast. The taste is the straw, hay, and a bit of fruity lemon lime. The beer is lightly sweet, then moves to yeast notes of the nose, though the clove is softer in the taste than the nose. Touch of banana as the beer warms. The palate is light bodied, thinner, almost approaches being watery. Soft carbonation, and a clean, thin finish. Easy drinking beer.

On tap at BXL East on many occasions. Pours lovely cloudy orange with a medium white fluffy head. Lovely aroma of citrus fruits with notes of spice. Orange/coriander flavors really come through in the aroma. Taste is well balanced with a nice amount of coriander, orange peel and yeast. Really enjoyable beer.

Tap at BXL, served in a saison dupont tumber, $6.Cool little joint at 1am I might add. Simple light amber pour with a small head. Yeast, spice, malt, grassy hops, more spices (not in a bad way, no soap), some dough.. Yep. This beer is pretty straight forward, but the spices aren’t overdone and I could have a couple more pints no problem. A clean, easy drinking beer that holds my attention. I couldn’t ask for much more.

On tap at bxl nyc, obvs. Have drank this beer deep into many evenings at my post-bway theater district hang. Rich, fruity, juicy aroma: wonderful, which unfortunately sets up an expectation that isn't exactly lived up to in the flavor. The nose is so interesting but the taste, especially in the finish, falls flat without enough bitterness. Makes it really drinkable as a session beer but not more. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had on tap at BXL cafe. Lovely orange hue capped by a soapy looking white head. Nose has light orange, coriander, and earthiness. Taste brings the addition of light biscuit. Bitterness is a bit cutting but enjoyable. Mouth is light bodied, does become dry. Yum. Rated via BeerBuddy

On tap at the BXL Cafe. Pours a cloudy orange with a thick white head. Aroma of sweet fruits, apple and pear, sweet malt. Flavor of light bready malt, sweet fruit, light spices. Pretty good saison and very drinkable. 7/4/8/4/14 (3.7/5)

Honey colored. Big, slightly off-white head. Corny, malt likka aroma. Tastes like malt likka too - sweetish, under-hopped, flaked corn profile. Medium to medium light body. Unpleasant syrupy finish. To be avoided. Indianapolis.

Flasche 0,5l: Heller Bernstein, Kupfer, kräftige Trübung, kräftiger stabiler feinporiger Schaum; frische Nase, kräftige fruchtige Süße, Bananen, kräftige Hefearomen, Malz, Malzzucker, Karamell, dezente Röstaromen, dezente trockene Säure; eher trockener Körper, unreife Bananen, Bananenschale, kräftige trockene Hefearomen, Malz, Getreide, etwas Karamell, sehr cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, leichte Röstaromen, dunkles Brot; angenehmer malzig-trockener Nachgang mit Hefearomen
50cl bottle. Pours hazy dark orange golden colour with a huge most good lasting off-white head. Aroma of citrus, caramel, wheat, clove. Taste of dark breadish malt, wheat, clove, caramel.

At Molina, near Eins+Alles. 0,5L from tap. Clouded amber/ochre with nice tiger orange gradient, with a clear white head. Sweet malts, banana, bananacandy, light caramel, green leaves. Medium sweet, light bitter. Over medium body, minerallike, fat, sugary, syruppy, and very smooth and soft carbonated. Caramel, leathery, bitter finish. Proper weizen!

Danke an pivnizub ! Endlich mal wieder ein Weizen, das nicht vor Früchten, insbesondere Banane, trieft. Eher im süffigen Bereich angesiedelt mit ein wenig an Gras, etwas Vanille und einem fein ausbalancierten, leicht ssuren Hintergrund. Nicht schlecht !

Bottle from Pivnizub - many thanks! The beer pours out in a hazy brown-amber colour with steady smooth head and medium to smooth body. Aroma of wheat and bread with some malty hints. Taste of wheat, bread, light yeast, hops, flowers and light malt. Refreshing and not as bad as expected.
It’s unclear golden with a huge, creamy and lasting head. The aroma has notes of yeast, fruit and wheat. The sweet flavor has notes of yeast, fruit/banana, wheat, and the finish is slightly spicy.
A rather light aroma has some mature banana and some hints of spices. Flavour has spices and sourish citron.
Bottle: Wheaty, light fruity aroma (citrus). Dark golden color. Flavor is fresh, sparkling and with notes of almonds and peaches. A bit boring.
Bottle. Amber clouds, lacing off-white foam. Dusty yeast and clove aroma. Spicy wheat, light orangepeel. Burpy mouthfeel, chewy enough though. Earthy retronasal.

(bottle) Cloudy, amber colour with a thick and slightly tanned foamy head. Slightly dusty and a a bit acidic fruity nose with a moderate wheat-character, a touch of cara-malt and notes of cloves and sulphur. Slightly sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a sharp carbonation. Slim wheaty base with chalky notes, citrus and traces of banana; quite dry and slim fruity and wheaty finish with a little fizz on the tongue. Mediocre Urweisse, not to be confused with a Dunkelweizen. 09.IV.10

Chestnut color with some hints of garnet when held to the light. Smallish dark cream head. Light fruit and lightly toasted malt aromas. Some hints of depth, but a fairly simple smell. Darker fruits, light spice and plenty of malt flavors make this known that there is a backbone to this one. Caramel, light cloves and fruits of bosc pears and figs couple with a mild spice to make this a worthy effort. Full and satisfying.

Cloudy off pink colored liquid with a off pink head. Yep!, it looks like a fruit beer. Malt-o-Meal aromas with a touch of acidic fruit. Light sweet malt flavors with the acidity from the strawberries to make this one quite quenching. Light fruit and mild wheat in the linger. I liked this one in a fruit beer way. Not too sweet and a nice blend of sweet/acid/tart.
Copper pour with creamy white head and lace. Light citrus with a malt kicker on aroma. Semi sweet malt with very light citrus bitter. Medium bodied and lightly carbonated.
3rd rating, tap at Nodding Head. Pours orange copper with a bright white ring. Nose is light and nice and pretty good. Taste is nice, with a good hoppiness.
On cask at the brewpub. Light body, a good hops aroma and a nice hop taste to it. In general, an easy drinking session beer.

Draft at the brewpub 5/13/07. Amber color with a thick white head. Crisp, fresh hop aroma. Flavor is primarily hops, with some malt in the background. Hops seem to start out slow then build towards the finish. A bit thinner bodied than other pale ales. Flavorful for its low ABV; excellent session beer.
Bottle@home; Appearance: golden with off-white head; Aroma: malt; taste: malt; Palate: refreshing, medium body, medium carbonation; Overall: ok.

Bottle @ weekly tasting shared by Dutchdrebus. Hazy yellow color, small white to off-white head. Weird aroma of alcohol, malts and plums, overripe fruits. Taste malts, again a hint of overripe fruits, alcohol, sweetish and again a bit weird. Does not taste like a tripel at all imo. And I don’t quite like it either.

Bottle @ home. Slightly hazy yellow colour with a small to medium sized white head. Smells glue, weird herbs, alcohol, sweet. Tastes malts, sweet, some herbs, slightly old, hint of cardboard, brie. Medium body, soft carbo.

zie dat de laatste rating van 4 jaar geleden is. schenkt wazig bleek geel/oranje. aroma van citrus en graan. eerste ervaringen zijn zachte en gladde smaken, dun/licht van textuur, alcohol komt ook door, iets pittigs van een pepertje (zeer licht), graan, lichte body, glad en zacht van textuur, lage co2,

Bottle 300ml. Clear medium yellow amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, moderate yeasty, spicy. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20100219]
Hazy orange with a tiny white short lasting head. Sweet fruity aroma with yeasty and malty notes. Flavour was sweet and mild hoppy with yeasty and fruity notes. Finished bitter and dry.

Bottled. An unclear dark golden beer with a thin off-white head. The aroma has notes of malt, straw, and peaches. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, straw, citrus, and yeast, leading to a dry and lightly tart finish.

Bottle, 9%. Faint hint of paint thinner in the aroma. Cloudy copper colour, small floating bits. Very small white head. The flavour is better than the aroma, nicely malty with a bit of caramelly malt notes. Medium bitterness. Good alcohol level.

Bottle 35 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours amber with tiny impurities and a small rough off-white head. Sweet caramel aroma. Solid body, a little low in carbonation, sweet apricot accents with a rather hoppy finish and quite some alcohol. 190210
Typical triple unripe bananasmell. Quite sweet with a nice alcohol aftertaste, but not much. If you like sweet triples have this one.

column1: Napf Schwarze Spinne (Beer of the Dark)
column5: Bottle at Monday Club Zurich. A sour stout and well done, very nice. Lighter nose than one might expect. Very nice!

column1: Napf Schwarze Spinne (Beer of the Dark)
column5: Courtesy of Philippe (Bov); the bottle is about one year old It pours a black color, with a generous creamy head. Mild aroma of roasted malts. The body is lean, there is a mild flavor of toasted malt, toasted nuts, with a very light sourness that adds some dynamicity; it never exceeds in a too ashy side. Correct bitterness. Balanced, enjoyable.

column1: Napf Schwarze Spinne (Beer of the Dark)
column5: blach as night but the head is dissapearing superspeedy smells of malt, caramel and hidden dried fruit and a artificial alcohol note tasts of malt, hidden dried fruits, caramel and artificial alcohol note aftertaste is some malt, rather sweetish and the alcohol is more artificially than warm even ahint of plastic 12 swiss francs for the bottle of 0.75 litres from the brew-restaurant stadthaus in huttwil- too expensive for a beer of this not so outstanding quality

column1: Napf Schwarze Spinne (Beer of the Dark)
column5: Dark red colored, little yellow head. Skunky aroma with some glue and mild licorice. Medium bodied. Flavor is better with roastiness and some coffee, caramel also with slightly drying aftertaste.

column1: Napf Schwarze Spinne (Beer of the Dark)
column5: Bottled (thanks Bov!). Dark brownish colour, small beige head. Aroma is sweet raisins, malts and some wood. Flavour is wooden, sour and slightly acidic fruity. Some slightly roasted notes are also to be found. Wouldn’t recognize this one as a schwarzbier...

column1: Napf Schwarze Spinne (Beer of the Dark)
column5: Bottled Nut brown color, small off-white head. Caramelly, lightly toasted aroma. Acidic, toasted malty, a bit caramelly-sticky mouthfeel. Grassy hops in the aftertaste.

column1: Napf Schwarze Spinne (Beer of the Dark)
column5: Bottled. Dark but brown, creamy head. Sweet and fruity, medium bodied, Very fruity with artificial cloying flavour of syrup, toffee and molasses as well as bread and saccharine. No bitterness. I suggest a name change to "Beer of the Drain".

column1: Napf Schwarze Spinne (Beer of the Dark)
column5: (Bottled, 0.75l) Very dark reddish brown with a small, fading head. Roasty, slightly alcoholic and licoricey aroma - not quite delicious, but interesting for sure. The flavor is more conventional, with roasty malt and slight smokiness. Medium-bodied, slicky palate with low carbonation. Strange for the style, but in its own way quite pleasant.

column1: Napf Schwarze Spinne (Beer of the Dark)
column5: bought at the Biertage 2007; labeled as top fermented Schwarzbier using mais - pours a very dark brown colour with a fast disappearing head; slightly toasted with notes of butter, caramel and diacetyl; sweet and medium-bodied at best; low carbonation; residual sweetness with a long caramelish finish - has about anything you can do wrong with a Schwarzbier

Sampled on draught at the John Baird in Muswell Hill. A dark chestnut brown colour with a gentle aroma of malt. The taste is very mild, with some notes of toast and nuts. Not much bitterness, but very easy to drink with a good flavour, albeit a little watery. A good example of a classic British style.

Gravity Cask Half Pint at Battersea Beer Festival, London in Feb 2010 - Dark Brown in colour. Malty; roast malts, chocolate. Fruity; raisins. Roast malty throughout. Bit bland. Easy drinking. (2010-02)

Cask@Pigs Ear Beer Fest 2011. Deep rubyish amber colour with a small off-white head. Aroma is wood, some caramel malts, mild toasted notes as well as some slight dark dry fruity/dark berryish notes. Flavour is rather similar in a nice balance.

On cask at The Bow Bar. Pours a dark copper - brown colour with a thin beige head. Aroma of caramel, coffee and chocolate. Similar flavours. A little thin with mild carbonation and some lingering chocolate. OK.

Cask at CPK. Pours clear brown with a creamy, white head. Woody malt nose, some nuts. Lightly sweet flavor, nutty, slightly toasty. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Very mild finish, faint toast and sugar, more nuttiness. OK.
Cask. An amber beer with a dense orangey head. The aroma has notes of matl and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel.

Cask (handpump) @ Rat & Ratchet (Ossett), 40 Chapel Hill, West Yorkshire, Huddersfield Road, HD1 3EB. Clear dark amber color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, nutty. Flavor is moderate sweet to light light heavy and moderate to heavy bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20100119]

Cask at the Battersea Beer Festival, 10th Feb 2010. Dark brown. Oily, meaty nose. Slightly creamy, somewhat fruity flavour. Definite milk chocolate notes. Ok weight. A bit slick and overall not a great mild.

Cask-conditioned at the Bag O’Nails, Bristol, 15/4/10. Dark brown with reddish undertones and a decent tan head. Aroma of berry fruit, dark chocolate and a touch of roasted malts. Easy drinking, with plenty more fruit and chocolate, doughy malts and a short, bitter finish. Good.
Cask. Clear dark amber with an off-white head. Lightly roasted malt in the nose. Thin and watery, a little hard roasted malt with a light malt biterness. 190110

On tap at Scion in Silver Spring, MD.  Clear, bright amber with a near-white head and very good lacing.  Aroma of barnyard yeast, light fruit (especially peach), lemony citrus and sweet grain.  Taste of sweet grain, orange, lemon, herbs, peach and yeast.   Medium body and medium/low carbonization.    A little sweet for a saison, but with enough sourness to compensate.  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very light lemon balm here that kind of makes my muscles feel tingly. Pours golden amber with OK head. Light sweet finish. Some heather. Tap at Scion Silver spring.

On tap at Max’s. Poured a golden amber color with a small off-white head. Aroma was some funky barnyard notes, herbal, and some floral notes. Flavor was some herbal, funky character. Sweetness. Some bubblegum character and some light rind notes, pepper.

Pint on tap at Alewife. Foggy orange-amber body sustains a quarter inch of beady foam on top. Nose is light funk, lemon and white grape must. Tastes of the same mix with a touch of herby resin. Light-medium body has high carbonation and a nice thirst-quenching balance.
Golden orange pour with aroma of fruit and spice. Flavor has pepper, spice, and citrus. Easy drinker.
Draft at the brewers art in Baltimore. Golden blonde color. Smells and tastes like a farmhouse ale with a light crisp taste. Very good ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft. Cloudy orange yellow, large bubble white head. Aroma of white pepper, mild barnyard. Taste is raw rye bread dough, straw, subtle pepper.

On tap at Brewer’s Art. Pours a hazed golden amber with a medium sized white head. Light musk, malt and a lemon, a touch herbal. Medium bodied, clear and smooth, musk, sweet flowers. Musk, toast, long and musky with a light tartness and touches of lemon.

Floral and sugary aroma with some helpful yeasties. Flavor fell a bit flat for me, though maybe it was because this was not the 1st brew of the night as it probably should have been. Palate is wonderfully refreshing, highly attenuated.
Aroma:very floral aroma,,light grapefruit hops..... Appearance:Light hazy-orange,light head... Flavor:Light citrus,grapefruit and floral hops...
pite jakiœ czas temu. uzupe³nienie profilu. Ocena przepisana z utpd. Mi³ego dnia.

column2: North Conway, New Hampshire, United States
column4: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
column5: 5th August 2008. On tap at GBBF. Bittersweet cloudy brown ale. Nothing remarkable.

column2: North Conway, New Hampshire, United States
column4: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
column5: Hazy brown with a small off-white head. Herbal almost incense like aroma. Dry and slightly roasted malty flavour with hops and spruce in the background.

column2: North Conway, New Hampshire, United States
column4: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
column5: Cask (gravity) @ Great British Beer Festival, GBBF 2008, Earls Court, London, England SW5. Clear medium brown amber color with a average, frothy, good lancing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, moderate hoppy, spuce. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. (060808)

column2: North Conway, New Hampshire, United States
column4: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
column5: GBBF, Trade Day, 2008 Gravity cask. Smells like church incense - frankincense. Spicy burp. Sweetish. Some crystal/amber malt. Pepper finish. Nice enough.

column2: North Conway, New Hampshire, United States
column4: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
column5: Cask, GBBF 08. Hazy brown with a small head. Aromas are dusty with pine. Some woody pine notes and hints of soy. Flavours are bitter green pine with some saltiness. Woody, bitter and smoky with sourness towards the finish. Reasonable.

column2: North Conway, New Hampshire, United States
column4: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
column5: A Mes rate: Gravicask at GBBF. Brown amber colour with a thin beige rim. Spruce, hops and yes, Mr. Silk is right, some frankincense. Plenty of ginger too. Wheaty malt finish. So so.

column2: North Conway, New Hampshire, United States
column4: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
column5: Cask, GBBF 08. Hazy brown, thin shortlived off white head, moderate condition. Gently woody aromas with hints of sweet malt and some herbal notes, dry bitter and earthy in the mouth with some suggestion of sap and a vaguely phenolic edge, lingering dry bitter herbal sappiness with a low residual sweetness.

column2: North Conway, New Hampshire, United States
column4: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
column5: Cask conditioned - gravity dospense - GBBF 2008. A slightly murky brown beer. The aroma is sour chocolate with acidity. The taste is more sourness with wood mixed in. By far the worst US beer I had at the fest.

column2: North Conway, New Hampshire, United States
column4: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
column5: Cask at GBBF 2008 ... light brown ... ligth hop ... woody light malts ... sweet hop little lime ..

column2: North Conway, New Hampshire, United States
column4: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
column5: Cask at GBBF 08. Cloudy amber with an interesting nose and flavour - juniper, incense, wood sap and varied spices that reminded me of my mum’s kitchen in my childhood. Average weight. An interesting beer.

Courtesy Degarth. Yellow/gold, lightly hazy. Apple pie, old wood, cinnamon, earth, small dose of honey, light colored fruits. Weird at first, but growing on me as it warms. Medium body, still. Very good, surprising.

The aroma is fantastic. It’s sweet like syrup with honey, fruit, and cinnamon. The appearance is golden and still. The flavor is where this one goes wrong. There is a sour taste that ruins the fruit and cinnamon elements. The sweetness from the aroma is hardly present, replaced by a more dry vinous character. The palate is thin. I am not really that impressed with this mead. It smells a lot better than it tastes. I think they used the wrong yeast and it might need more time to mature.

A true paradox in mead, the aroma is heavily, its got a sherry like aroma with some spice. taste however it is like a tart apple cider, that doesn’t work well. it like the mead makers used the wrong yeast when they could’ve made something really special, instead its sub par.

Fuck all ya’ll! Dave, John, Jason...I’m talking to you! Damn it I really liked this. Maybe I’m a mead moron, but I thought this tased really good. Granted it tasted a bit like cider, but I loved it. Anyway, the aroma is woody, vegetal and quite spicy with cinammon standing out. The body is golden, clear, still and headless just as every mead I have ever had looks. The flavor is simple....wood, apple, honey and cinammon. It does in fact taste like some liquid version of mom’s apple pie baked on a wooden pie tin. But I farking loved it. I thought the flavor was very good, if simple. I’d happily drink it again.

Mead courtesy of Degarth, thanks Joe. Pours clear yet tanted with Coors Light yellow-ish hue. Big aroma with odd yeast and alcohol notes that border on freezer burned rotting vegetation. The taste starts sweet then some of the interesting yeast notes and alcohol enter the picture. Taste is pretty nice. The finish creeps up with cinnamon apple pie. Very interesting.

Big thanks to Degarth for sharing this one. Pours a golden body with of course no head. Nose of spices, honey, wood, apples, cinammon, nutmeg. You would think that would be good, but for some reason it smells "off". On the tongue it tastes very cider like, with apples, honey, and the spices coming through. Tastes better than it smells. Very silky on the palate. A good amount of alcohol burn greets you in the finish, which is also slightly sweet and of medium length.

Light, very hazy golden body. In lieu of legs, a solid sheet of sticky honey teeters from the inside of the glass. An interesting conglomeration of bubbles gathers at the bottom of the glass. A slight apple-green tint encapsulates the golden remainder. Honey precedes heavy spices in the nose. Floral tones exude lavender and orange blossom water scents. Apples and doughy crust meld nicely with very moderately concealed alcohol. Perfumed as heavily as it is, musty notes seep through with focused intensity. Interesting, for sure. I wouldn’t delude someone’s explanation of this by calling it complex, but it’s got enough intricacies to be deemed worthy of sampling and sharing. Flavor is unorganized and really has lost much of its vibrancy. Spicing is muddled, cinnamon and orange pith noticeable first. Honey is dulled. Alcohol is far too noticeable for a sweetened mead. Finishes warm and dull, reasonably respectable length. Average at its very best.

on tap-pours a thick rich light brown head and deep red/mahogany color. Aroma is dark fruit-cherry, dark malt-molasses. Taste is dark fruit-cherry/raisin/plum/prune, vinuous, dark malt-molasses, some bitter/acidic, alcohol. Nicely done and potent, not quite my taste. After warming up, smoother, mellower, richer, nice. Occasional.
Brown. Sweet malty aroma that matches the taste. Good filing body. Creamy with nutty hints. Smooth and taste lingers well.

Found out about this by sheer accident when I wandered onto the web site to look up the King James. Maniac joined me for a pint. Straight up black in appearance with a nice tan head, quite attractive. Aroma was caramel with a faint hint of smoke. Flavor was more caramel, molasses, a touch more smoke, and the faintest tinge of black cherry. Surprisingly good, quite smooth bodied.
Dark black body with a medium creamy light brown head. Sweet caramel and molassas aroma. Rich chocolate, molassas and caramel flavor.

Barrel at GBBF 2007. A light yellow perry with no head. The aroma is slightly acidic with a slight pear note. The flavor is a mixture of sweet and acidic with medium strong notes of pear, leading to a dry finish.

Appearance Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 2 &nbsp Pale(1)->Dark(5) : 1 &nbsp Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 3 Aroma Intensity : 3 &nbsp Yeast : 3 &nbsp Bread : 2 &nbsp Hay: XX &nbsp Brett : XX &nbsp Floral: 2 &nbsp Wood: 2 &nbsp Leather: 1 &nbsp Barnyard : 2 &nbsp Medicine : XX &nbsp Phenols: XX &nbsp Cheese : XX &nbsp Vinous: 2 &nbsp Notes: Caramel : XX &nbsp Honey : XX &nbsp Applesauce: XX &nbsp Appleskin : XX Pear : 3 &nbsp Tropical FruitsXX &nbsp Flavor Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 4 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 2 Juicy: 3 &nbsp Sourness : 2 &nbsp Bitterness: XX &nbsp Farmy : XX &nbsp Complex: XX &nbsp Length : XX Palate Light(1)->Full(5) : 3 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 2 Chewy: XX &nbsp Sharp: XX &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringence : XX &nbsp Tea tannins : XX &nbsp Alcohol : X Comments: Rather sweet, but quickly drying out, tasty, pear juice oriented soft, if a bit alcoholic perry.
From plastic cask at Harbury beer Fest ’07. Greenish gold with no head. Good dry peary perry, some natural carbonation with a mouth drying tartness. A definite try again.

A Mes rate: Boxed baggage at Reading beer festival. Not too attractive looks wise but perry never is. Strange ginger and liquorice aroma. Nice & dry flavour. A little more interesting than first impressions would have you think. Definite whiskey character, finishes like an aged malt. Interesting but not amazing.
Draught @ Reading BF 2007. Good sharp finish with hints of tropical fruit. Tasty tartness but with a good level of sweetness to balance it out. Perhaps a slight hint of whisky.

Bag in a box at Reading BF 2007. This got a highly commended in the CAMRA cider and perry championships decided during the festival. Very very pale silver gold. It’s a decent soft perry. Some pear juice. Not very dry, but not sweet either.
Cloudy reddish pink with foamy pinkish white head Aroma is fruity (berries) and grainy Flava is sweet notes of raspberries Feels light silky with mild fizz Finishes sweet sticky
Bottle @ home, from a gift. Amber colour, white foam. Medium carbonation. Sweet and fruit with notes of stone fruit. Some caramel also. Light bitter finish. Ok beer.

Commissioned ale, tasted in the Kerkom version on 75 cl, since 2005. Coarse, light beige, stable foam, bronze colour, clear. Spicy character, cloves, pepper, some ginger, pear, dates, raisins, dried leaves, peanuts, iron, grass. Dried fruits in the mouth, nutty maltiness, some bitter chocolate, iron, dry, rather thin mouthfeel, medium long bitter finish.
Tasted in 2009 (backlog). Brown in color and cloudy with a small white head. Aroma is potatoes, raw malt and brown sugar. Taste is of grain malt and potatoes.

A clear amber colored beer, with a small beige head. The aroma of fruits, sweet, some caramel. The taste of sweet fruits, some berries and apple. In the back some bitter. The aftertaste of old flat fruits with boitter notes.
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. The look is clear, copper in color, and has a white head. The taste is tart, veggies, fruits, and alcohol. The taste is alcohol, fruits, and ok.

Bottle 75cl. @ The Danish Summer Gathering Tasting, TSODRBSG09. Clear medium amber color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy malty, caramel, fruiy, prune, wood , light roasted. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090822]
( 750ml bottle ) Pours a cloudy golden body with a medium white head. Aroma of raisins, caramel, and baked apple. Flavor of raisins, caramel malt, apple, coriander, and yeast.
bottle thanks to bu11zeye. poured amberish with a white head and lace. aroma was orange, citrus, and grains. flavor was grains, spice, and alcohol. light body.
bottle thanks to bu11zeye I believe. cloudy light brown with a cream head. fruity malts and yeast with light spices on the nose. decent on the palate with a big fruity flavor and a spicy finish.

Bottle from bu11zeye at the dallas tasting around thanksgving. I really didn’t know what to think of this brew. Pours orangey brown with a tan ring. Nose is sweet, weird. Taste is sweet, rich, and big.
2/4/2009 6:33:55 AM Golden body, slight head. Grassy and dull nose. Taste of fruits and sweet malt. Dry finish.

Kräuterartig hefig-süßer Antrunk mit eindeutigen Tendenzen in eine hellmalzig-würzige Richtung. Stark kräuterartig-gewürzig bleibend, es kommt im Mittelteil eine hopfige Note auf, welche aber gleich darauf von einem voluminösen Kräuteraroma verschlungen wird. Dieses, die Würzigkeit lenkende Aroma kommt etwas plötzlich vervor, man erwartet eher einen gleichbleibenden Aromenstrom. Zum Ende pendelt sichd as Ganze wieder ein, der Alkohol brennt etwas, das Bier ist süßlich und deutlich malzig neben der weiter vorhandenen Kräuternote. 7/11/12/12/10/12
Hazy orange with a bubbly, lasting white head. Aroma of citrus and spices including cinnamon. Dry and spicy flavour. Complex but very cloying spice.

Expired! Hazy orange coloured beer with small white head, and few carbonation. Also floks of yeast visible. Malty bit acloholic aroma. Full palate. Finish is alcoholic malty ending bitter and bit dry.

Light amber coloured beer with an average but diminishing white head. Rather yeasty aroma with a short herby and fruity touch. Full palate. Finish is bitter yeasty touched with a slight alcoholic vanilla hint. Overall a nice beer.
gold blond coloured sparkling body with lot of yeast particels and a white head a yeasty spicy fruity aroma a yeasty spicy fruity sweet taste with a nice alcholic sweet bitter finish

Brown yellow colored with murky appearance, vanishing yellow head. Lively carbonation. Lemony and caramelly aroma with nice touch of licorice, spiciness and some grainy note also present. Medium bodied. Flavor is also interesting with same licorice dominating, grains, lemon and some exotic fruits too, aftertaste turns to yeasty with some hops. Interesting brew.

A bottle, thanx to Jerre. A little hazy, yellow/golden colored beer, with a very thick white head. The aroma is malty sweet, fresh and fruity, with some spices. The taste is spicey, some coriander, with sweet malts and fruits like orange, mango and citrus. A little bitter. The aftertaste is mainly sweet.
33cl, exclusive brew Anno 2007, from Willems Grobbendonk, complex brew, balanced, cloudy, small head, good brew

(33cl bottle, as Hofgrobberke 2007, Lentebier, 8.0% abv) Cloudy, orange colour with yeast flakes swimming around and a short white layer. Sweet bready malty aroma with strong spicy notes of ginger and pepper. Moderately sweet flavour, medium bodied, slightly fizzy carbonation. Malt-accented base yeasty and light-fruity taste with spices getting stronger towards the sweet and bready, also pretty alcoholic finish with shades of herbal hops. Imo not particularly rounded and a bit too spicy (07.IV.09).
Bottle, amber with a yellowish bubby head. Aromatic fruity hop aroma. Very strong bitterness, dominating some sweet malt flavours with a touch of fruit hoppiness. Very drying the finish.
Nice smooth bourbon with s pleasant mix of malts and caramel. Taste follows with a smoothness of a beer that has been made time and time again. Absolutely solid

Tap at Hideout. Poured a black color with an average frothy brown head that lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy roasted malt, bourbon alcohol aroma. Moderate to heavy sweet roasted malt and bourbon flavor with a moderate to heavy sweet and small alcohol bite finish of moderate to long duration. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. This is a very good beer.

On tap at Hideout. Opaque dark brown body with reddish highlights at the edges, thin buff head. Bourbon dominates the aroma. Sharp bourbon body with alcohol, coffee, dark chocolate, and a bitter, lasting finish. Pillowy and soft, but thin. Lacks heft. Decent, but too sharp and bourbon-forward.

...on tap at the brewery...pours light black with medium ochre head..aroma of sweet malts, light bourbon, and a touch of coffee...an extremely soft and enveloping palate gives rise to an excellent bourbon aged beer...the bourbon present is not overwhelming and it complements the soft, sweet chocolate and coffee notes in this beer...marshmallow to follow with only hints at its high abv..nice

On tap at the Parkville Microbrew Festival. I thin this is one of those beers linked to a fundraiser. Testicular torsion syndrome, I believe (Go Team Venture). Pours black with an off-white head. Has an interestingly smokey roasted aroma. You could swear that there is salmon in there. A solid stout.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours very dark brown with a clinging tan head. The aroma has brown sugar, molasseses and roasted chocolate malt. Medium / full body that is slick and has lightly sharp carbonation. The taste has much of what was on the aroma along with some honey traits. The finish has lots of charred malt. There is also a bit of a hop kick at the end. As the beer warms a coffee presence becomes apparent. A respectable stout.

This beer was created by a patron of the Morgan Street Brewery who is a survivor of breast cancer. The beer tap handle was a pink ribbon. The beer is brewed with molasses, brown sugar and something called acai berries which is supposed to be high in anti-oxidants. The beer poured ultra-dark brown with a one-finger tall tan head that left good lacing. The aroma was heavy on molasses and brown sugar. The flavor was molasses, smoke and some fruit (I’ll go out on a limb and assume this was the acai). Damned watery mouthfeel that plagues every beer they produce was unfortunately hanging around for this one too.
16oz draft brewery-A dark amber with a huge off white head. Aroma and taste of vanilla and more vanilla. If you like vanilla which I do then you will enjoy this beer.

I suppose I could take the silly way out and enter this cask conditioned ale as a Cream Ale because it tastes like cream soda. That’s how so many "Cream Ales" got into our database, after all. But what this is is an Amber Ale heavily spiced with vanilla beans, hence its Spice/Herb/Vegetable listing. It pours a bright amber body with a bubbly ecru head. The aroma is vanilla over fruity malt with a light earthy bitterness. The flavor begins with sweet malts but is soon flooded over by vanilla. It finishes on that vanilla note with a mild herbal bitterness left on the tongue. Rock Bottom Warrenville, Warrenville, IL
16oz draft at brewery-A medium golden body with a huge white head and an aroma of grains. Taste of hay and grass. Not bad.

This lager pours a bright golden body with a heft, well sustained head that coated the glass with heavy lacing. It has a sweet grainy nose with a slight herbal hoppiness. Thin. It tastes of sweet grains and has a build-up of a floral and herbal bitterness. Crisp finish. Drinkable. Rock Bottom Warrenville, Warrenville, IL

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Cinquo de Mayo
column5: Draft at Rockfest. Pours a little dark for the style, deep brownish bronze with minimal white head. Nose is pils malt and toast, light hop notes as well. Pretty standard "beer" smell to it. On taste, toasty and a bit sweet, balanced by good hop bitterness. Reasonably clean and the toasty notes are nice. Tasty.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Cinquo de Mayo
column5: Taster glass, guest tap at Rock Bottom Yorktown. No foam in my glass, but it is just a 4 oz. pour. Still, this small sample shows a deeper brown color than for other Mexican Viennas I have met. Simple, light grainy beer smell. Taste is also kind of grainy, like a dark roast bock. I’m reminded, fairly or not, of Schell’s Bock. This roast barley taste can require some palate adjustment after I’ve enjoyed a big IPA. A bit estery, too, but that just adds to its charm.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Cinquo de Mayo
column5: 1 of 45 beers I tasetd at Rock Bottom Brewery’s Rockfest. Pours a reddish brown with a thin khaki head. Aroma is hoppy, bread, hay. Finishes easy with little bitterness

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Cinquo de Mayo
column5: On tap at Rock Bottom Orland Park. Pours ruby with a foamy tan head. Aroma is of malt, dark fruit, grain, faint hops, and caramel. Taste up front is slightly hoppy, but not enough hoppiness to really make an impact. The backbone consists of caramel malt with notes of dark fruit and grain. Had some strange ubderlying medicinal notes, which caught me by surprised and I disliked. Mouthfeel was very creamy and carbonated. A very drinkable beer, buct lacking in the hop flavor.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Cinquo de Mayo
column5: Served on tap at the brewpuib (Orland Park, IL). Pours a deep dark copper, clear, but pushing solid chestnut and dark deep reds, fairly big dull tan head that cakes and laces very well. Aromas are a bit muted, caramel and toffee malts push through, with a good biscuity sweetness, light nut, with underlying bitterness from some florals. A touch metallic. Initial is lighter, with decent caramel and breadiness, a light spice towards the backend, light bitterness to balance from florals. Cereal into the body. This is a-ok and sessionable at 4.5. Gets a little deeper partway in, more flavor, light toast, good all around for the style. Slight metallic in the finish, similar to their last seasonal. Cheers.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Cinquo de Mayo
column5: dark purplish brown, slight off-white head. nose is mostly air. musty, creamy flavor, but i can´t make anything specific out. medium bodied, dry finish. something was missing here, though i don´t quite know what.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Cinquo de Mayo
column5: on tap at RB OP. pours brown with off white head. nose of toffee, nuts, slightly roasty. flavors are a bit spicy, some dark fruit, caramel. not bad but watery.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Cinquo de Mayo
column5: Amber with a vermillion tint. An ecru head is short and unlasting. Grainy aroma with roasted nuts, faint, stale caramel and adjuncty touches of wet dog and street bum. Grainy flavor with a mild malted sweetnes and an earthen bitterness to finish. A little flat in the mouth, but a spritz of carbo adds a tingle to the finish. Alcohol creeps. Drinkable, but it could stand to be a little fuller-bodied. And sweeter. On draught (last May), at Rock Bottom, Orland Park, IL 60467

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Cinquo de Mayo
column5: On tap. Another one of RB’s crafted brews. Poured a nice sleek golden color with good head. Good retention as well, slightly carbonated, decent lacing. To me was a mix between a pilsener style and vienna style. Not your typical Marzen but slightly lighter with hints of sweet malts, caramel and a slight nuttiness. Was meduim bodied, thin, and well balanced for this style. Just a little too weak for me

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Cinquo de Mayo
column5: I saw the name and thought we had another Corona clone on our hands. But it’s actually a Vienna, somewhat thin, but not bad. It’s got a deep amber body with a healthy head that does some lasting lacing. The aroma is bready and sweet with caramel. Same with the flavor, although surprizingly a bit of alcohol comes through. Quaffable. Rock Bottom Orland Park, Orland Park, IL
