Well I hate to disagree... I loved this beer. I also had it at the aniversary party and I drank it until the last keg ran dry. I loved it so much I tracked the brewer down afer a few years and Im having him brew me a keg for my wedding. sorry to disagree and Ill post back with the follow-up keg.

Being a mead-maker and one very interested in different meads I was anxious to try this one. I had it the first week it was available, but it just wasn’t much. Very little flavor--but for what was present it was okay. Light honey, ...light oak. Nothing much else. Caramel? Yes. Cloudy (should bee less so) Smooth, creamy, murky dark rusty orange / red. Should have been better.

draft at founder’s anniversary party....appearance: mediuim brown with no existence of any head.....aroma: sweet honey and very sugary....taste: more of the same. sweet honey with more carbonation than i would expect, especially for the mead style. i concur with masonjer of this beer being very one-dimensional. given the choice, i would probably not order this again but nice to try anyway.

haven´t tried many braggots before, so I don´t have much to go from. Tried this at the brewery. Smelled sweet, tasted of honey, sugar, slightly floral. A bit one dimensional and overly sweet. Not bad though.

dark amber pour with no head..aroma of light honey, strawberry, and sugar...flavor of a tame mead (basic honey sugars)..a touch of berry fruit..the aftertaste of this beer is equal to the smell of a first aid kit

Draft at brewpub. Poured clear reddish copper color with minimal off-white fizzy head that mostly diminished with fair lacing. Heavy dark honey and spicy aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Heavy spicy sweet flavor with a rich sweet finish of moderate duration with a small alcohol burn as it warmed. Pleasing Devil Dancer and honey combo to give a barleywine flavor.

This is the first time I’ve tried a mead. It was dark orange in color. Very light aroma, some fruit and honey. The flavor was fairly sweet... the alcohol was definitely in the forefront. It was just OK... I probably wouldn’t order it again.

On tap at Founders. Their first stab at a braggot in a couple years, this version is significantly stronger than the previous version, pouring a murky orange-brown compared to the light yellow-orange creation of years past. Fruity aroma with honey and alcohol heat, a touch estery. Rather dry body, the honey sweet but subtle. Instead, dry, dusty notes and alcohol coax the palate. Drinkable but pricey and on the mediocre side.

In short: A tasty, crisp, super refreshing, fruity and floral blonde IPA. Nice! How: Tap at brewpub The look: Cloudy yellow blonde body topped by a small white head In long: The bright nose shows lemongrass, grapefruits and floral notes. Taste is crisp with a hay-like maltiness, a ton of fruity hops (grapefruits, mangos, oranges) as well as a strong countryside flowers sensation. Meidum-strong bitterness that is never aggressive. Good attenuation. Uber-refreshing. I really love those refreshing blonde IPAs. This is one pint I didn’t want to share. I hate it when a friend asks me to take a sip from my pint and I tell him to stick it up his ass and he’s all insulted even before I can tell him what “it” is.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours cloudy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is dry herbal, slight citrusy hoppy. Dry, bitter and light herbal hoppy flavoured. Bitter and slight citrusy. Bone dry finish. Slight spiced to herbal.

column1: John Harvards The Warriors Code ESB
column5: Cask. Aroma restrained, some lemon, spicy hops. Flavor semi-sweet, very lightly roasted, some honey, some hop spice. A touch on the watery side. Nice to get something local on cask, but didn’t really do it for me. Maybe I got the dregs?

column1: John Harvards The Warriors Code ESB
column5: On cask. Pours an orange/amber with a small head. Aroma of light fruits. Flavor of some general sweetness, orange, and honey. This beer is light, a little muddied, weak and blandish. Not really a fan.

column1: John Harvards The Warriors Code ESB
column5: On cask at John Harvards in Lake Grove. The beer is initially a very cloudy amber with a thin linen white head that quickly dissipated. After about five or six minutes, the beer settled and became mostly clear golden brown. Light, pleasant aroma of malt, caramel and brown sugar. The flavor is sweet up front with malt, caramel and brown sugar followed by some moderate hops bitterness. Lightly dry at the finish. Medium-full bodied with a creamy mouthfeel.

column1: John Harvards The Warriors Code ESB
column5: Tap at the Lake Grove location: Copper pour with a thin off white head, has some clarity. The aroma is malty, with caramel, raisiny notes and a light hop zest when it warms. Flavor is somewhat sweet, nice a nice malt character. Creamy body with a nice roasty and buttery aspect with nutty characteristics and a caramel note. Finish has a late balancing dry background. A solid, some what sweet/malty ESB.

column1: John Harvards The Warriors Code ESB
column5: Cask - cloudy amber with a frothy, creamy head - strongly malty aroma, with notes of caramel, oats, nuts, bread and cookie dough - oddly heavy and malty sweet for an ESB - caramel, brown sugar, bready/yeasty qualities - a slightly herbal, warrior hop tang on the back of the tongue - lingering breadiness - tastes a lot like a lighter version of their hoppopatamus, which really isn’t a bad thing at all.

Pale gold/straw color. Somewhat malty with a bit of a grains in flavor. However, I found the aroma to be a little off putting and chemical. The chemical aroma is out of place for Harvards, so I’m willing to overlook it to an extent.

Tap at JH. Aroma very lemony with a perfumy, floral quality there as well. Flavor again quite lemony, a sort of bittersweet lemon, at the same time lemon pastry and a lemon-grapefruit hybrid. Hops are at once on the gentle side, but also work nicely with that predominant lemon character. Tasty.

On tap at JH. Pours a clear deep yellow with a thick white head. Aroma of sweet fruits and floral hops. Flavor of some sweet fruits, stale wheat body, and a sweet finish. Spritzy and crisp. Pretty decent and certainly drinkable.

Tap at the brewpub. Pale golden coloured beer with a light haziness under a thin white head. Light herbal/floral hoppiness on the nose as well. Flavour is quite nice with a slightly sweet grainy maltiness followed by soft floral hops. Herbal finish with a light bitterness. Surprisingly good, really.

Looks like I had the new batch of this, tap @ the brewpub. Pint pour, clear yellow, macro-ish looking with not much head retention. The looks are the worst part of this beer. Aroma is a mix of so many different elements: starts with a hint of German herbal hops, which are the tip of a great cereal sweetness. Beneath that one picks up light citrus orange from American hops and light lagered fruitiness. Taste is similarly cereal/grainy sweet and faint fruity hops present. Seemed like a good maibock to me. Just a hint of bitterness to road it off. Very light and quaffable, but with the sweetness making you come back for more.

Tap at the Lake Grove location: Light yellow color with hardly any head. Subtle, restrained lemony hop aroma, somewhat crisp. Light bodied, with slightly creamy carbonation. Has a hint of tartness and a sour dough malt touch. Finish shows only a hint of saaz dryness. Light and simple; good for a session.

A decent attempt at a rather hard to produce style - cloudy straw color, with not much of a head, but rather sticky lace - grassy hop aroma, with hints of lemon and grainy malt - honey sweet flavor, with some light floral and fruity qualities - the saaz hop bite isn’t as prominent as I’d like; the sweetness keeps it from becoming very evident - a little overly sweet and not as clean as a good pils should be, but still fairly tasty.
On tap with Gary and Pam. Thin tan-murky orange/brown. A-pine, yeast, med malt. T-somewhat sweet orange/pine-yeast, med malt.
On tap at the brewpub. Comes a cloudy golden orange with a decent white head. Aroma of citrus and pine. Taste is grapefruit, tropical, and pine. Misses the mark.
Tap. Pours hazy orange with white head. Aroma is strong citrus. Lots of bitterness, dirty, grapefruit, kinda wheat-like. Really bad though...very odd.

A: Hazy Amber/Orangish Hue, Passes Minimal Light, Thick White Head, Great Lacing S: Grainy, Mildly Resin, T: Grainy, Resin, Mildly Bitter M: Great Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Semi Bitter Overall, a nicely mildly bitter IPA with a soft hop character...good but not great.
Poured hazy yellow with a little head. Nice citrus aromas, with grapefruit persisting thru the middle. Perfect bitterness for an IPA in my opinion. Light tang and bitter finish.

Served in a sampler glass at Wild Mtn. Pours a slightly cloudy copper with a small amount of white head that reduces to thin cap that lasts. Nice lacing. Fruity sweet up front, fading into a moderate hop bitterness that lingers. Moderate carbonation and slightly astringent finish. Could be hoppier, but overall a pretty good IPA. Definitely worth trying if you make it to Wild Mountain.

Tap at brewpub. Deep amber with orange highlights and a white head. Lots of citrus (grapefruit, orange) in the aroma, along with pine, floral and earthy notes. The taste was citrusy with a mild bitterness and some simple balancing malts. Medium bodied, moderately carbonated and slightly dry. Not bad.

Draft. Deep amber with orange highlights. Frothy white head, mostly diminishing. The aroma displays notes of toasted grain resin, pine and a bit of orange. The flavor is lightly to moderately bitter and lightly sweet. The finish is lightly sweet and moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture and lively carbonation. The way the malts are used in this IPA reminded me in some way of Alpha King which can be husky and chewy like this IPA. But Hop Diggity is not near as complex or as well balanced as Alpha King. The husky malts get muddled up with the earthy, green hops. Not very clean, but at least it is not overly thin.

Pours hazy orange with a decent off-white head. Citrus hops on the nose, flavor brings an astringence that I’m really not big on. Lots of hops &#40acerbic, citrus rind&#41, but a bit boozy, too. Not enough body to hold up that much alcohol.
On tap at the brewpub. Suprisingly nice. hoppy, rich and deserving of it’s decent score.
A decent pale ale. Fruity banana aroma with some hopps in there. A Belgium inspired IPA for sure. Slightly sweet fruity finish. Had at home

Served in a sampler glass at Wild Mountain. Pours amber with a half finger of off white head. Nice lacing. Flavor is hoppy, citrus up front and then hints of pale malt. Lively carbonation gives it a clean finish. Overall a solid pale ale.
On tap at the brewpub. A nice clean beer; medium body malt with a bit of caremel to it and a crisp hop bite with a semi-dry finish.

Draft. Deep amber, cloudy body. White, frothy head, mostly diminishing. Lots of resin and pine in the aroma. Notes of orange, toasted grain, bread crust. Hint of caramel. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. It finishes lightly sweet and moderately bitter. Medium to full body, watery texture and lively carbonation. Nicely balanced and refreshing. A bitterness approaching IPA. Very good and better made than Wild Mountain’s Hop Diggity.
Tap @ brewpub. Clear orange color, short head. Aroma of grapefruit, bit sweetish. Malty body, bitter, grapefruit, citrus. Decent pale ale.

Draft at the brewery. Unfiltered cloudy dark copper colored body with a white head and medium-to-thick lacing. Dry-hopping very evident, catty, resinous hops, actually resembles American ESB, musty pine and orange hops in the nose and tasted throughout as well. A malty nose of bread crust/toast stands up solidly on the palate, medium to full body, with some weird filmy carbonation issues noticed, but nothing too distracting or annoying. Fresh, delicious, well integrated toast/bran/bread crust with the mildly dry/catty orange flavored hops, with IPA/ESB-level bitterness. Quite good.

Draught at the brewery. FDGD 08. Beer is clear, medium oxidized amber. Head is small, frothy/creamy. Diminishes but mostly lasts. Clingy specks of lacing.The aroma is malty with a light note of toasted grain, Hoppy with a savory herbal trace, light-to-moderate dried apricot, resin/pine, grapefruit; Yeasty with a trace note of dough.The flavor is moderately sweet, moderately-to-heavily bitter, light-to-moderately acidic with a long, lightly-to-moderately bitter finish. Bitterness in aftertaste is blunt, perhaps metallic.The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is average.

Draught. Head is fully lasting. Body is hazy medium amber. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), moderately hoppy (grapefruit, resin), with a note of soap. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Not very adventurous, but not bad.

On tap @ Wild Mountain poured a clear amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of carmel, earthiness and light grapefruit. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, earthiness and light citrus with a smooth dry lingering moderatly bitter finish.
Nice carbonation and body/texture. Hops were bold, offering quite a bit of bitterness. Flowers, plants and grapefruit citrus. Subtle caramel in the malts. Notes of bread dough, too.

Aaliyah’s amber at brewpub. Deep brownish-reddish-amber with a creamy beige head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, roast and pine. The taste was dominated by chocolate and sweet malt, but had a nice, balancing hop profile and a very mild bitterness. Medium body. Interesting. I’ve never had anything like it.
Tap @ brewpub. Named as Aliyah’s amber ale. Hazy brown color, short head. Aroma of malt, some coffee, some mocha. Malty taste, licorice, licorice and again licorice.

Draft pint. Dark cola brown, looks like a brown ale, very dark overall with some dark red hues visible at the bottom of the glass. They went a little overboard with the chocolate malt in this batch, I was told... easily evident in the flavor, no surprise. Nose has some roast, some chocolate, some burnt crackers, but certainly has strong hop definition... cedar wood, pine, some green vegetal notes as well. Flavor is fresh and pungent, weird mixture of chocolate malt, a little roast, some pine-green hops, and some caramel malt. Strange beer.

Draught. Head is mostly lasting. Body is hazy medium amber. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (caramel, cookie, toasted grain), lightly to moderately hoppy (apricot), lightly yeasty (dough). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Decent example...on the sweet side and not all that exciting, but my pick of the three I tried.

On tap @ Wild Mountain poured a clear reddish amber with a lasting amber head. Aromas of carmel, earthiness, light pine and light citrus. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, earthiness and light fruittiness with a smooth dry lightly bitter finish.

Deep, dark amber hue. Rather lively carbonation. Very roast and toasty, with only a mildly sweet base to boot. Kind of chewy and dark natured. Had a curious, black ale or schwarzbier quality, with hints of tar, dark toast and anise. A little sticky at times. "Amber" is an ambiguous style, as many know, but this beer definitely leans toward the "brown ale" or "black ale" categories among the "amber ale" spectrum.

Draft. The menu listed this as seasonal, and it was available on May 15, so I assume it is a spring beer. There was a light raspberry aroma along with some other sweet malt. The flavor was pretty much the same; a medium flavored porter with notable raspberry tart flavors. I would have preferred slightly less raspberry and a fuller body.

Un-Muzzling Olde Muzzlehatch Ratings, #48. Draught pint at Acadia Café in Minneapolis, August 2008. Dark clear caramel with just a bit of lasting foamy head...woody, caramel-malty, lightly herbal-accented aroma, pleasant enough...alas the body is more than a bit sour and off, with detergent soapiness at first; warming up it gets a bit more palatable but it’s still a struggle to get through it...somewhat fizzy and light-bodied but not damagingly so; the flavor was enough damage I’m afraid.

Growler pour today at the brewery. Amber color pour, not much of an aroma that I could notice &#40good or bad&#41 and medium carbonation. Flavor was light malt, a little bitter and coppery on the finish. Not bad, but I wouldn’t go out of my way to pick this one up.

Draft at Stub & Herb’s. Pours a clear, dark amber body with thick white head. Light aroma of sweet caramel malts and biscuit with a hint of green hops. Flavor is mostly grain and malts with a green hop bite and finish. Smooth mouthfeel.

Date: 06/23/2007 Mode: Growler Source: Tasting, RBSG 2007 clear gold, wispy head, sweet caramel malt aroma with light floral hops, lots of earthy bitter hop flavor balanced by sweet caramel malt, long bitter finish a nice ESB Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

Pours a nice darkish amber hue with a nice head. Nice biscuity bready nose with hints of light chocolate and sweet malt, as well as a faint floral note. Nice even feel on the palate with a nice bitter bite for a 3.2 beer. Suprisingly good, and the best you’ll find at any ball game MLB or smaller in MN.
RBSG 2007: Growler: Copper in the thin pour, citrus on the nose. Taste like toast and malts with some grassiness, bitter finish. OK for me.
Clear copper amber bdy with a small whit ehead. Aroma of grain and caramel. Grainy malt flavor with light caramel in the background.
RBSG 2007: Growler: Poured a clear gold with an off white head. Aroma, bready with some sharp grainy notes. Flavor, pale malts, some herbal and grassy hops to it. Not bad.
Tap at the Flat Earth Open House. Dark copper color with no head. Slight orange aroma. Taste has some toasted malt. Bitter finish that borders on vegetal. Simple but good.
RBSG 07, from a growler. It was very nice of Flat Earth to donate this beer. Light biter malt and very light hops. Light, unoffensive bitter that has decent body but lacks flavor.
Sweet nose with hints of fruit, amber color, foamy head. Sweet soft malt base with a blend of grains. Great balance with a warm round texture. Excellent beer all around.

Draught half-pint at the brewpub, early May 2007. Pours a bright, almost clear brass with a small lasting head....lovely caramelized malts dominate the big nose, touches of vanilla, thyme and oregano show up....fairly dry in the body, surprisingly, with reasonable maltiness for the style, cookie-doughish texture towards the finish, grainy, no hoppiness noticeable....somewhat strong carbonation, medium to full mouthfeel. Fine, but nothing really exciting.

On tap. Sour tang of rye and raw grainy mash liquor. Mild sweetness and light funky spicy bitterness. Bit of lactic aroma, too. Hazy dark amber with lacing off-white head. Medium body with medium fizzy carbonation. Bit of a tang. Starts with honey and grainy sweetness, mild caramel/biscuit, then some rye or other raw grain. Quite a bit of carbonic gaseousness and sweet/sour tang toward the finish. Good little hint of funky sour mash before light fruity bitterness. Clean finish and after with a touch of sweetness.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Decent wit. Lightly cloudy some mild spice-coriander, yeast, lemon. Had it on tap in South Burlington

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: I suppose you should expect the unexpected with Magic Hat. Had it on tap and bottle and enjoyed both. I pleasant classic Wit.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Draft. Somewhat cloudy orange body, medium white head, typical witbier nose with banana, spice and citrus. Typical witbier flavors, nothing special.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: On tap @ Coles their latest Wonderbeer Series. Lightly cloudy some mild spice (Coriander, yeast, lemon). Decent wit

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Draught. Pours a cloudy yellow golden body with thin head. Aroma is faint - lemon, spices. Flavor is heavy perfume, light citrus, spices - corriander, yeast. The beer was not as balanced as I would have liked, at times it seemed to be all over the place. Not bad.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Tap at Ortino’s Northside. Pours a lightly hazy golden orange with a medium foamy lacing white head. They served this one with a lemon but I think I got rid of it quick enough so that it didn’t mess with the beer too much. Aroma of lemon, corriander, wheat and grassy. Flavor of lemon, corriander, some tart wheat, sweet maltiness, tingly carbonation and cereal grains.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Draught pint at Three Needs, mid-May 2007. Properly hazy-to-opaque light yellow-amber body with a surprisingly stable creamy white head in this standard pint glass....nice aroma, very cookiedough-yeasty, lemony with a fair amount of spices: coriander, a bit of ginger, and with some warmth, overripe banana and vanilla notes appear....full, well-balanced body, with a lovely pale malt presence throughout and moderate sweetness dissolving slowly into a citric/sourdough tartness at the finish...the carbonation level is just a touch too high for me, resulting in a slight thinness/soda quality right at the end, but otherwise this is very well-made, refreshing and pretty true to style. A really pleasant surprise from Magic Hat.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: On tap at Magic Hat. Nice citrusy aroma, little bit of yeasty funk. Cloudy pale golden beer with white foamy-creamy lacing head. Medium watery body with medium carbonation, goes down smooth. Quite a bit of yeasty farmhouse funkiness to it, somewhat dry with some peppercorn, maybe some coriander. Nice citrusy finish, smooth. Bit of wheat in the after. Decent little witbier.

Backlog. 33 cl bottle @ home, 2007 issue (also 6.5%), young. Pale blonde color, slightly hazy. Big head, but only a small layer remaining. Aroma’s: refreshing, fruit, a bit herbal/spicy, a bit caramel, with hints of coriander retronasal. Flavor is malty, fruity. Medium bodied. Firm bitter finish. Not as balanced as a real German Maibock, but a good interpretation.

Bottle. Slightly fruity aroma. Hazy golden colour. Very small white head. The flavour is nicely sweet and fruity, ending on a quite bitter note, slightly rough. High carbonation. Tastes like a pale ale to me, and a quite good one.

Bottle, In de Wildeman. Greyish blonde with chunks of yeast floating. Citrus sweets aroma. Flowery hoppy flavor with citrus. Sweetish and just a bit thin. Pear. Flowery hopbitter aftertaste with a hint of alcohol. A bit more body and this would be a very good beer.

(Bottle 33 cl) Courtesy of MiP. Slightly hazy golden with a handsome, dense, white head leaving some lacework. Fresh, citrusy nose. Medium body with lightly sweet malts and dry, floral and citrusy hop notes. Very soft mouthfeel and a dry, hoppy finish. Very decent. 230807
Aroma of caramel malts, some citrus and flowery hops. Hazy, orange-copper coloured with a lasting, whin head. Taste is floral hoppy, bit medicine in it, some citrus, yeast and caramel malt.

Cask at JDW by Baker St tube. Big fine white head atop a light copper ale. Nose has fresh bread dough, something faintly spicy (coriander?), hints of orange peel, body is full and malty with peachy notes, plus again that spicy note that lasts through to the finish, where some grassy hops also come through.

Cask - The Kings Head, Norwich. Served in a oversized pint glass allowing for a large, doming bubbly off-white head atop an brown/amber body. Mid fruit and caramel, some herby, yeasty notes on the aroma. Sweet and toasty malt flavours, some mroe fruit with a dry lightly hopped, mildly roasty bitterness in the finish. Soft mouthfeel, low carbonation and on the lighter side of medium in body.
Cask at EABF 10.Amber with no head,aroma of orange and lemon hops,taste of toffee and malt with some hop,dry finish.

Cask, gravity dispense at Woodford Beer Festival at The Duke, Woodford, Northants, 25-05-07. Pours standard brown colour, refreshing quite fruity with a dry finish, fine but no great shakes for my bones.
Cask conditioned @ Humble Plumb, Soton. A malty brown bitter with a little fruity caramel and mild hoppy presence in the finish. Fairly standard and quite uninteresting.
Dark brown with no head. Toasty, caramelly molasses nose is almost smokey. Sweet with brown sugar. Clean, soft and smooth. Very syrupy tasting, though, but in this case I don’t mind it.

Bottle. Opaque brown-black with tan head. Pronounced smokiness in the nose and also a touch of bourbon. Woodsy with some mineral flavors in the beginning. Molasses comes out in the end of the flavors and lingers nicely.

Poured dark brown-black color with mahoganey edges, nice tannish one full finger head, decent retention. The aroma was molasses, light coffee. The flavor was molasses, chocolate, some brown sugar with a touch of coffee in the finish. Pretty sticky stuff, more along the lines of a Baltic Porter in flavor than an Imperial Porter, but it was too sticky to be that. A nice find while leisurely passing through Sedona and the Grill, but I didn’t want more than one.
A danish, near black Dunkler Bock with light head. Aroma is coffee, prune, light liqourice., light yeast. Taste is bitter. Pearly. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very dark brown, offwhite froth. Light roasted aroma, fruity hops. Roasted, bitter flavour. Hoppy bitterness and light coffee notes. Caramely with light alc warmth. Has a little sourish note in the finish and does not seem entirely clean. Decent none the less.
Dark colour. Small head. Slightly malty taste, little bitterness. Medium carbonation. Boring stuff.
Golden yellow color with some nice lemon aromas. Herbal hop flavour with a bit more lemon, definitely the best Pilsner I’ve had in a long time
Bottle: Hazy gold with a small white head. Lemon, barley scent. Flavour is pretty solid pils malt, grain, lemon.. Slight pils/herb bittering. A nice, full-flavoured pilsner.
Bottle. Light metallic barley malt and herbal aroma. Golden yellow with large head. Sweet light lemon, barley malt, tin, and mildly bitter herbal hops flavor. Nice body.

Bottle to half-pint glass (thanks cards04). Looks good; a slightly hazy golden orange with white head. Smells solid; a nice balance of pilsner malt and hops. Tastes like it smells with a solid mouthfeel; not snappy though. A touch of biscuit as it opens up. Enjoyable.

On tap at Station Ho.st, pours black with a small tan head. Aroma brings out chalky notes, with dry cocoa powder and some roast. Flavour is much sweeter and more dynamic, with vanilla, toasted caramel and some roasted malt. A bit of cocoa in there. Nicely rounded and bold. Good stuff.

column1: Hopfenstark Baltic Porter de l'Ancrier (Vin Rouge)
column5: [Draught at Station Ho.st, Montreal. 2007 vintage] Pours deep black with a small frothy tan head. Some lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, dark fruit, light leafy hops, vinous notes and wood. Interesting flavour, it’s a bit sour, with dark malt, dark fruit, wood, red wine and chocolate. Medium bodied. Another fantastic rare treat!

column1: Hopfenstark Baltic Porter de l'Ancrier (Vin Rouge)
column5: on tap on the premises. funky the 13. unclear dark brown pour with thin yet creamy light beige head, some retention and lacing sticking. lactos and raspberries, some cherries, red grapes - vinous character for sure, astringent and peppery wood, coffee grinds, underlying chocolate - milky, bit of metal. moderate carbonation, light to medium body - oily, fruity, lightly tart and grassy-astringent finish. tasty sour. balanced.

column1: Hopfenstark Baltic Porter de l'Ancrier (Vin Rouge)
column5: Drank from a bottle (750 ml) from Éponge (Merci!) at Hopfenstark’s 4th anniversary on November 20, 2010. Very dark brown, medium head. Aroma of chocolate, with grapes and small tart fruit. Taste of malted chocolate, bitter fruit notes, a small dry bitterness. You would not think it is a Baltic Porter!

column1: Hopfenstark Baltic Porter de l'Ancrier (Vin Rouge)
column5: Pours a black color with ruby highlights and a thin light brown head. Pleasant aroma of chocolate, toasted bread and oak. Very good flavor of chocolate, oak, toasted brett and mild tartness, the aftertaste is bitter. The body is light to medium with a vinous texture and medium to lively carbonation. Another oak aging succes from Hopfenstark!

column1: Hopfenstark Baltic Porter de l'Ancrier (Vin Rouge)
column5: Bottle at BCTC 2009. POurs a nice deep dark black with a medium foamy beige head. Aroma is toast, nutty chocolate, larger than expected fruity esters, plum, raisin, slight burnt malts, oak, and light vanilla. Flavor is chocolate, fruits, burnt toast, light roast, nutty and earthy with a nice oaky finish that helps to dry it out a bit. Nice.

column1: Hopfenstark Baltic Porter de l'Ancrier (Vin Rouge)
column5: Bottle, one year oak-aged. Pours dark black, nice head retention, extensive lacing. Nose is nicely sour and funk. Taste is roasty and nicely sour. Some funk also. A bit acidic. Nice sour finish with some roasted malt. The sourness takes pretty much all the space here. A tiny bit buttery at the end. Very unusual and this may not be the result the brewer expected but it was quite nice.

column1: Hopfenstark Baltic Porter de l'Ancrier (Vin Rouge)
column5: 750 ml Bottle @ Host 3rd anniversary. At a first whiff from the glass I get some light fruit like peaches that quickly disappears and makes way for the traditional chocolate and spice aromas along with something quite winey, probably the oak barrel coming through. Taste if chocolate, roast coffee and some sour grapes, more of that oak aging. Something else.

column1: Hopfenstark Baltic Porter de l'Ancrier (Vin Rouge)
column5: Bottle. Mondiale 2009 - day 3. Brown-black murky pour, light brown frothy head. Fairly boozy sweet deep roast nutty malt with green fruit tartness, almost salty. The saltiness continues in the taste, oddly resiny, with green persimmon tartness balancing a chocolate sweet roastiness, plenty of alcohol, and some slightly vinous squeakiness - nice, though. Light-ish bodied, astringent and a little still - but slick and easy to drink ... that saltiness was very appealing.

column1: Hopfenstark Baltic Porter de l'Ancrier (Vin Rouge)
column5: Bottle at BCTC 2009: Murky brown pour with a light khaki head. Fruity aroma with some buttery oak and nutty crystal malt undertones. Slick light feel. Fruity with some buttery oak and cocoa- some tart green raisin notes leading to a toasted finish. Solid and interesting.

column1: Hopfenstark Baltic Porter de l'Ancrier (Vin Rouge)
column5: [2226-20090605] Sample. Sweet malt sour-infused aroma. Dark brown black body with a quick foamy light tan head. Sour seawater malt flavour is sweet throughout with a background of wood bandaid. Medium body is sour. Interesting and sweet, like the sour aspects. (0T @ Mondial 2009; Montreal, QC)

pretty fun stuff, but not for everybody...I live in Chester County Mushroom Country, Pennsylvania, and my wife and I agreed that this tastes and smells like the local mushroom farms. Kinda an earthy, funky, barnyard umami quality with a definitely fungal characteristic. predominant alcohol flavor as well. yellower than most sakes i’ve had. i like it, but i’m probably gonna be the odd one out. If you like exotic mushrooms, you’ll probably like this.

The aroma is not delicate. There is alcohol, rice, and grass. The appearance is clear yellow. The flavor is like the aroma. The palate is thin and oily. Overall it’s a pretty typical sake with a strong alcohol taste.
This is a full bodied sake with a deep rich oily finish. The alcohol hits you on the tongue at first sip and stays with you through out the end.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Czech Mate Pilsner
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Poured yellow with a small head. The aroma was just an awesome hoppiness and the flavor was nice and hoppy as well. The carbonation was excellent, and the beer was crisp and refreshing. I could drink this all day, an excellent version of a Bo Pils!

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Czech Mate Pilsner
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Nice lunchtime session beer with Saaz hops, medium bodied, light bitterness. Definitely fit the pilsner style profile I would think this is a good seller @ the brewpub.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Czech Mate Pilsner
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Pours with a TON of fluffy white head. Nice and clear body; yellow golden. Light grassy and mildly hoppy aroma. Mouthfeel is light and fizzy. A bit of bite to this one but not too much. A very good pilsener, I would drink again!

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Czech Mate Pilsner
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On tap at the KoP location. Poured a medium golden color with a smaller sized white head. Aromas of grassiness, lightly spicy, and light citrus. Tastes of the same; grass, some spiciness, and some citrus.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Czech Mate Pilsner
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draught at BrewPub: Aroma of hops, light citrus, and slight pine. Poured golden/yellow in color with a medium to large-sized, dense, white head, that lasted throughout. Clear. Sparkling. Very good lacing. Slightly sweet, slightly bitter flavor. Tastes of slight noble hops, corn, water, slight herbs, and a hint of lemon. Light to medium body. Dry, thin texture. Average carbonation. Corny, dry finish. Watery.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Czech Mate Pilsner
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Translucent gold body with a thin almost effervescent white head. Aroma was both citric and spicy, with some nice bready lager notes coming through. Flavor had a malty cereal base but was complemented well by the floral and spicy hop component, as well as a little more citrus than is common in most pilsners. Pretty good for pilsner.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Czech Mate Pilsner
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Clear golden yellow body and scattered white head. Citrus, floral and spice aromas with prominent lager yeast signatures. Quality continental pils malt depth with nice dryness and firm bitterness. This is a crisp and enjoyable pils with ample depth to make it interesting.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Czech Mate Pilsner
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On tap at KOP location. Pours a translucent golden with a smaller bubbly lightly lacing head. Aroma of floral and citrus notes along with cereal grains and some grassiness. Flavor of Cheerios, tropical fruits hops,, lingering grainy malts, lemon, grassy, hop bitterness, crisp but slightly thin.

Seattle Cask Festival Amber in color with a slight haze and light head. Nice easy drinking beer with a sweet lager like flavor. I get hints of caramel and some spices in the finish. This is a wonderful Keller.

Hazy amber color/ lasting beige head. Dusty pale malt, bready yeast, black pepper, dry spice aromas. Light to medium bodied. Mild caramel flavor with dusty pale malt, white bread yeast, dry spices. Tasty dry lager. draft@ Brouwers Cafe.

Tap at Brouwer’s. Pours orange gold with a foamy white head. Aroma is very floral/perfumey. Flavor is astringently fruity. Nicely bitter. Sort of a lingering oilness - definitely not diacetyl tho. This is a very nice medium light and quite flavorful ale.

Bottle: &nbsp Straw in color, slight hazy golden hue, large frothy white head, decent lacing. &nbsp Straw/Hay on the nose, otherwise slight cereal, a little barnish. &nbsp Sweet hay/grass on the tongue. &nbsp Seems a little spicy. &nbsp Some corn meal like aspects. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Has a bit of a peppery tinge on the finish. &nbsp A little heavier and spicier than expected. &nbsp Decent little beer otherwise.
(Draught) Pours a lightly hazy yellow body with a medium white head. Aroma of grass, florals, and sourdough bread. Flavor of grain, grass, and light florals.

Bomber thanks to Scrizzz to tick off the last style I have left! Poured into pint glass. Pours orangish light copper with a seafoamy white head that doesn’t last too long but leaves a bit of lace. Smells lightly spicy and yeasty. Tastes the same. Pretty light and spicy all around. Not bad, but not outstanding. Easy summer session beer. Would probably be quite good at converting macro drinkers.
Clean yellow, slight haze, tall strong bright white head. Slight sour nose, mostly floral. Dry and astringently bitter up front, floral hops come out more in the finish and leaves me pleasantly.
Biscuit malt character with thin fruit notes and a grassy, somewhat floral hop essence.
pours a clear pale straw yellow with a thin white head, and good lacing. smell is faint, slight corn, slight grain, and a touch of floral. taste is light, dry, grain, and a touch of citrus, ends dry.

22. Pours crystal clear burnished medium golden with a towering, sudsy platinum blonde head. Weird sour metallic nose, not very pleasant at all. Light watery body, fizzy carb, bit of hay and some herbal hop notes on the mid-palate. Not unpleasant, except for the nose, but ultra, ultra light. Light is fine, but leaving that aromatics problem exposed is telling.

Brewed again as part of their Legacy Series. Black with a tan head. Light roasted malts, a good chunk of hops that seem to exist mostly in the bitterness realm, earth, a bit of burnt malt, chocolate. Finish is long, dry and nicely bitter. Medium bodied. A real nice stout.

22 oz. bottle shared by shigadeyo. Pours dark brown with a medium beige head. The aroma has weak roasted malts and a strong hop presence. The flavor shows slightly more roast than in the nose, but is still very hoppy with a hint of dark fruits. Hoppy stouts are not my thing. Lighter side of medium bodied. Rating #25 for this beer.

Bottle shared by shigadeyo. Poured dark brown color with a large frothy brown head that was mostly lasted with heavy lacing. Moderate complex roasted malt and earthy hop aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture and flat carbonation. Medium roasted bittersweet flavor with a medium hoppy bitter finish of moderate duration. Drinkable, but out of balance.

7/30/2009: Silver City Sasquatch Stout... Aroma: Mineral-like, somewhat weak roasted malt/roasted barley. Appearance: Nearly black color with purple tint and opaque; beige head. Flavor: Weak cola-ish, minerally, watery roasted barley, char; dry chocolate/unsweetened cocoa finish. Palate: Medium-light body, lots of carbonation, not smooth. Overall: Not big or complex, moderately flavorful; reminds me of some of the BrewDog beers. 22 fl. oz. bottle (Alc. 6.8% by Vol) from via trade. Thanks! Rating #23 for this beer.
From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 13/10/2007 Hoppy aroma. Small tan head. Black strong in alcohol and fruity with some dryness in a crisp and bitter finish.

Thanks to Brandon for hooking me up with this bomber! Poured clear, deep brown with a medium cap of creamy, well-retained tan head. The aroma picked up an array of nicely-roasted black malts with dark chocolate, licorice, and black patent represented.. maybe a splash of earthy and herbal hoppage, but it was malty overall. The flavor lost a little specific character from the malts (mostly black patent with lesser coffee and dark chocolate), but the hops played a greater role (earth, pine, and citrus were well-blended in here).. finished with great balance between the roasty malts and hop bouquet. Medium-bodied and well-carbonated on the palate.. balance was great, and this was easy as could be to drink. I’d love to have a keg of this handy at the house.

Bottle. Pours nearly black with a tan head. Hop-and-blackberry drive the aroma along with some of the expected roasty tones; we see the same thing in the flavor only more so. Lots of blackberry and dark cherry, deep-roasted coffee, a decisive hop close with the Amarillo coming in even through the midrange to meld spicy citrus with the berries and keep both dancing lightly beneath the chocolate and coffee. Thisis a big high-octane stout, and it’s a very nice one in my book. Well worth a revisit.

Pours dark with light beige head. Roasted aroma immediately comes out as I pour. Flavor is roasted malts I wish I could taste the cents and the amarillo more. This is a few months old and the hops might’ve faded by now. Still a solid beer that deserves to be one of the better stouts out there.
From By The Bottle--Poured a deep dark brown-black body with a fluffy thick tan head. Nutty, creamy, chocolate and bitter hoppy nose. Roasty complex delicious finish. Awesome!

Poured a very dark brown color with a large brown head. Fairly hoppy full of piny hops and dry cocoa. The flavor was fairly hoppy as well but this time more citrusy and a big milk chcocolate base. Hops come back lightly at the finish followed by a moderate bitterness. Light-medium body and some warmth.

Dark, honey gold, filmy head, medium-heavy cloudiness. Sticky caramel aroma with light musk/smoke. Tangy, lightly sweet, very bitter. Medium body. Finishes out with an over-brewed bitterness. Not sure what the point in this really was, no real wheat appeal. Very light vanilla in the finish.

Tea colored, very thin head. Very light, sweet grainy aroma. Medium bitter, sweet toasted malt/grainy flavor. Saazy, or just Goldings - unlike any ESB I’ve had in terms of the hop profile. Comes across as an altbier. Light nutty finish. Drinkable but not anybody’s idea of ESB - UK or California. Some diacetyl. Light fruit. Indianapolis location.

column1: Rock Bottom Indianapolis Lil Mikeys Milk Stout
column5: Opaque, dark brown. Milk residue and coffee roast aroma. Very smooth roast flavor over charred nuts. Silky mouth, medium body. Not unique, but well done for a mass appeal stout.

Minneapolis. Sold only as "Saison," the waitress said it had no other name. Light spice and yeast in the aroma. Cloudy and unfiltered, yellow. Flavor is on the sweet side for the style, but it lacks any kind of farmhouse, sour, or intense yeast character.
Clear yella. Big estery aroma with light phenols - gum, tripel yeast, lightly salty, tangy. Good, nothing special.

column1: Rock Bottom Indianapolis Uncle Jons Dunkelweizen
column5: Cold, sour cream and sweet musty malt aroma. Murky, dark brown, very little head. Drier than it smells - deftly executed. Buffered, doesn’t go overly bitter. Herbal notes, brisk at times, little boozy edge to the finish. Slight less than medium body. Horehound herbal bitterness on the lips. Well done, especially for the style. Burnt sugar notes.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: From notes, tasted at Great American Beer Festival 2017. Will add more notes if I get to try this again. This was a miss here.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: Sampled at GABF 2017 in Denver, CO. Numerical rating only - did not take detailed notes.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden deep amber to brown with a small tan head. Aroma is caramelish and solid phenolic. Caramelish, phenolic, fruity and roasted malt. Bitter and dry phenolic finish, lasting malt and yeast impression.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft. Pours red/brown with a beige head. Lighy yeasty spicy aroma. the flavor has belgian yeasty notes and toasty and sweet malty notes. Dry finish. Nice.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: (Draught) Pours a reddish-brown body with a medium beige head. Aroma of raisins, molasses, prunes, chocolate, and toasted grain. Flavor of raisins, prunes, toasted malt, dates, caramel, some chocolate, and candi sugar with a dry finish.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours a bubbly off white head and dark copper color. Aroma is medium fruit, malty, yeasty, very light spices. Taste is medium fruit, malty, yeasty. Nice. Mild carbonation.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft at brewpub. Pours reddish amber with white head. Nose and taste of light bourbon, oak, vanilla and rye. Medium body.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours a foamy light tan head and copper/red color. Aroma is medium malt, secondary hops bitterness. Taste is sweet medium malt-caramel/scotch, smoky, secondary hops bitterness/floral/flat (English). OK carbonation.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours a white head and cloudy straw color. Aroma is banana, clove, wheat. Taste is balanced banana, clove, wheat. Smooth. OK effervescence.

50cl bottle. A clear chestnut brown beer with a mid-sized good lasting beige head. Aroma of mild caramelish malt, mild sweet malt. Taste of caramelish dark malt, hints of chocolate, nuts, mild bitterness, okay!
It’s dark brown with a creamy head. The aroma has notes of caramel, roasted malt, and a touch of straw. The flavor has a light sweetness and notes of caramel, roasted malt, light straw and fruit,

500 ml bottle. Thanks Timo A. Pours dark copper colour with a white firm head. Aroma of toasted malts, wet paper and some nuttiness. Flavour of toasted malts, slightly sour berries, wet paper, nuts and grassy hops. Light bodied, slick mouthfeel and a dry grassy finish with a papery malty finish. Their Max-Reger-Dunkel was much better.
bottle from the brewery. Clear brown colour, large off-white head. Malty with roasetd malts, caramel and chocolate. Shy hoppy finish. Well balanced Dunkel.
Red-brown color, thin, medium stable crown. Slightly acidic, somewhat lax. The departure of some malty. Average dark without a profile.

(bottle) Clear, dark brown colour with a fluffy off-white foamy head. Slightly dusty and sweet malty, slightly toasted aroma with a soft grainy touch and shades of herbal hops. Moderately bitter flavour with a light malty sweetness, light to medium bodied, medium, slightly crispy carbonation. Toast-malty taste with notes of caramel and a tinge of cacao; quite dry and bitter, moderately hoppy finish. A decent Dunkel (16.05.07).
Bottle - thanks pivnizub. Salty, light roasted and aromatic nose. Orange brown, huge golden lacing foam. Metalic roast base, light body,flat mouthfeel. Quick ashen aftertaste.

Bottle: Fluffy off-white head, deep amber coloured with reddish tints; delicate aroma of sweet and slightly toasted malt, a bit caramelly; moderate sweet-bitter flavour, light bodied; dryish bitter-sweet, a bit fruity finish. Not bad, a good, average Dunkel......
Tap @ Foodfestival ’14. Hazy amber pour with a generous pale head. Orange peel, spices, light yeast, some herbal notes and light syrupy sweetness.

Appearance: Hazy amber color with a white head that leaves an ok lacing. Aroma: Fruity, malty and some yeast. Palate: Medium + body. Slightly sweet and an ok bitterness. Average carbonation. Taste: Fruity, some spices, malty and yeast. Overall impression: I do not really know…god or bad…nah somewhere in the middle. I am not running for another bottle. Personal stats: Bottle Thomas brought with him home from Denmark

500 ml bottle at Montra Hotel Sabro Kro. Unpasteurised and unfiltered. ABV is 6.5%. Served a bit too warm. Deep golden to orange colour, slightly hazy. Moderate white head. Yeasty and malty aroma and flavour, notes of sugar, hints of ripe berries, spices and orange peel. A bit too yeasty to earn a higher rating.
Süßer milder Geruch. Helle durchsichtige Farbe. Der Antrunk ist mild und kohlensäurehaltig. Im Körper leichter Hopfen mit vollmundigen Arona, das lange Bestand hat.
Hazy golden with a decent white head. Grainy aroma. Taste is sweet grain with a very subtle bitterness. Very good.

31 Dec 2015, bottle. Yellow and faintly hazy. Nose is yeasty and faintly sweet. Med body and mildly fizzy. Mildly sweet, hints of light caramel, mildly bitter grassy and lemon hops. Actually very drinkable.

Bottle shared at Craft Beer Co, Clekenwell - London. Many thanks to Fergus for all this lager! Pours lightly hazy yellow-gold with a creamy, white head. The nose holds dry dough and light cereal. Light to medium sweet flavour, with nice bready pale malts, faint bitter hay, more cereal. Light bodied with average carbonation. Moderately dry on the finish, with crispy cereal and straw. Solid lager.

Bottle shared at Craft Beer Co. 10/09/2015. Picked up from Toon Outside Strassbourg. Yellow/ straw coloured pour with a lasting white frothy head. Aroma is grainy, semi sweet, slight eggy weg, grainy, slight staling. Flavour is composed of simple doughy, grainy, bready mlats with some spicy nobel hop, Palate is light and somewhat refreshing, dirty grains, airy carb. Dry fionish. Maybe a little age.

Bottle split at CBC Clerko thanks to Ferris, 10/09/15. Lightly hazed golden blonde with a decent off white covering. Nose is white pepper, earthy, light vegetal tones, straw cereal. Taste comprises caramel, light bread, pale malt, earthy, straw. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. So very so .. bland and found wanting.

10th September 2015 Craft Clerkenwell Bottle Share. Thanks to Fergus. Hazy yellowish gold beer, thin white head. Palate is light and semi dry, modest fine carbonation. Mild minerals. Thin malts. Semi sweet floralness. Super light nuts. Whisper of tangy citrus. Light crispy finish. Okay.

Bottle thanks to Fergus? It pours cloudy yellow-gold with a small white head. The nose is clean, soft, sweet, grainy, light paper and not much else. The taste is crisp, white bread, earth, straw, toasted grain, cracker, minerals and light grass with a dry peppery finish. Light-medium body and fine - moderate carbonation. Simple, but also pretty enjoyable.

Bottle share at CBC Clerkenwell at the guaranteed hangover tasting, thanks to Fergus. As ’Kuhler Krug Brauhausbier Helles Unfiltriert’. Hazy dark yellow, still, small foamy white head. Aroma is bready, crackers, malt syrup. Body is medium to light, soft carbonation, smooth. Taste is a bit farty (’how can something taste farty?’ you ask - it just does), bready, crackers, touch of egg with a soft bitterness. Pretty meh.
Couleur jaune, forte mousse blanche. Nez houblonné, céréales. Gout houblonné, céréales, notes maltées douces avec bonne amertume houblonnée en fin de bouche.
Can@Lars - Hazed golden pour with a white head. Fruity and malty, has some citrus fruity notes in play, sweet malty backing, medium body, hoppy bitter finish.
Sample from 33 cl can. Hazy golden colour with a thin white head. Fruity aroma with citrus, floral hoppy notes. Grainy notes. Taste is bitter. Medium bodied. Dry and bitter finish. Fair.
33 cl. can. A hazy golden coloured beer with a white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, hops, fruit, citrus, grapefruit, straw and with a bitter finish.
te ennek az aromája jobb mint az íze. elõbbi gyümölcsös frissességet ígér, utóbbi alkoholos világával parlagon hagy. felcsigáz és összetör. szégyellje magát.
Clear golden beer with a bubbly off white head. Aroma of malts and tangerine. Refreshing taste with flavours of citrus hops, malts, caramel and a lightly bitter finish.

33cl Can @ BrewDog Online Store, Fraseburgh, United Kingdom. Golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma is malt, straw, slightly hoppy and citrusy. Taste is malt, sweet, bitter, slightly hoppy, citrusy and herbal. Medium body, average carbonation.
Thanks craig. 2007. Still smoke but it has died away a little. Heavy roast. Lots of malt, thick palate. Low carbonation. Even with the age this is good.

Bottle thanks to cgarvie! Pours deep brown bordering on black, with no head. Aroma is chocolate, fudge, caramel and a hint of smoke. Taste is smoky, coal, ash, some red berry sweetness, some oak, a hint of vanilla. A bit of sherry oxidation is noticeable. Syrupy feel.

Bottle shared by b3shine. Pours a very dark brown color with a small disappearing beige head. The aroma is in your face smoked peat that has me thinking scotch not beer. There is also roasted malt present. The flavor is a complex mix of the smoked peat and wood from the barrel along with the roasted malt and dark chocolate from the stout. Mouthfeel is smooth as this was a bit undercarbonated. This one grew on me more as it warmed. I have not really been a fan of Scotch, but this was at least interesting and not as in your face as some of the other ones they have done.

330 ml bottle shared by b3shine - thanks again, Beau! BrewDog Paradox Islay Batch 006. Pours a deep, barely cloudy mahogany with no head, just a few bubbles around the edge. Huge Scotch barrel here, with smoke, peat, roasted malts, earth, tobacco, burnt sugar, and toast. Light-medium bodied, with low carbonation and a malty, peaty mouthfeel. Bottle was marked "Best by 31.12.08. It seemed way newer than 6-7 years old. Typo, maybe?

Bottle to snifter (shared with the group; thanks DuffMan). Looks solid; undercarbonated though. A translucent brownish cola with thin bubbly lacing. Smells of dark malt and oak with their signature leafiness. Tastes like it smells with some oxidation and a medium-bodied mouthfeel that’s thin for the style. Not bad, but underwhelming for a BA imperial stout.

330ml bottle, thanks to b3shine for sharing. Best before 31/12/08. Batch 06. Kind of clear dark brown color. Thin ring of off-white head, some bits of lace. Big, smokey savory character. Some caramel. Moderate - plus sweet taste, light to moderate bitter. Mild bit of warmth. Kind of a thin, watery feel. Very light carbonation. Kind of dry in the finish. Not bad, a lot better than expected (after trying the shitshow that was old islay barrel aged Brewdog DIPA -- whatever that was called).
Bottle at Craig’s Brewdog vintage tasting. Pours black, tcp, iodine, medicinal, peaty, smoky chocolate, a bit thin.

Bottle, bacth 001 Caol Illa 1996, 10%. Almost black with small beige head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, peat and whisky. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, peat, ash, medium sweet, whisky, hop, vinous and a little bitter.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Almost black with a light brown head. Aroma is dry, roasted malt and lots of peat. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish. 050714
Scotland: Smoky, peat infused, deep complex whiskey flavors. Islay whisky comes right through. Unique and wonderful beer.

Cask (gravity dispense) at Reading Beer Festival, May 2008. Orange gold. Bitter hoppy rather than aromatic. Lots of lemon in the flavour. I thought the balance was a bit off-kilter. As harrisoni said, a touch (too) astringent. Not one of Brewdog’s finest.

Cask gravity @ Reading Beer Festival 2008. Clear medium orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy hoppy, grape. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. (010508)
Cask gravity at Reading BF 08. Gold with thin white head. Does have some nice US hops. Bit of stewed fruit. Bit astringent, but drinkable and rather nice.
A Mes rate: Gravicask at Reading Beer Festival. Pale gold with a good white head. Decent hoops, lots of rubber and earth. Very soapy in the flavour. More rubber. Far from the best BrewDog.

Cask, Loughborough Fest 08. Bright gold with a small head. Aromas are grapefruit and very bitter green hops. Some lemon and apricot. Flavours are lemon and pine with associated bitterness. Woody and dry with a long aftertaste.
Cask, Covfest ’08. Gold and faintly misty. Distantly leafy snout. Assertive grapefruity hopping, Earl Grey with clinging dunked biscuit afters. Quite tasty, but one-dimensional.
Cask, gravity dispense, at 5th Globe Beer Festival, Dunstable, Bedfordshire. Hazy straw colour, white head. Hoppy aroma and sweet vinous taste. Bitter finish. Yep, trashy and enjoyable.
Cask@Loughborough Beer Festival 2008. Golden beer with a lightly dry aroma and a malty and dry flavour. Overall a nice very bitter and dry beer.

Cask @ The Market Porter, Borough. Pours a slightly hazy pale yellow color with a small white head. Hoppy malty citrus aroma. Sweet malty hoppy flavor with some hints of citrus. Dry hoppy finish with some bitter aftertaste.
Cask at Peterborough Beer Fest. Clear golden. Smokey lychee aroma. Sweet, fruity and solidly malty. Quite aggresively hoppy with salty punishingly bitter finish.

Tap at Grays. Deep opaque brown-black, thick respectable beige head. Viscous, a pretty decent beer, way better than most of Grays crap. Big rich bourbon caramel chocolate tones, but not much alcohol brutality, relatively mellow for the style. Still certainly full bodied with some rich bourbon chocolate sweetness. A nice balance, this is right on. A true accomplishment for Grays. Burnt caramel toffee notes. Mellow vanilla oak in the aroma. Nice, I can dig it.

On tap at the Old Fashioned. Black with ruby lowlights and a creamy tan head. Aroma of mild bourbon, dark malts, chocolate, vanilla and maple. Taste of chocolate, maple, dark roasted malts and light peat. The bourbon/oak did not really come into the flavors much and while it was okay, I was expecting a bit more.

On tap at the brewpub, pours black with a thick lasting tan head. Cappuchino aromas, very smooth with flavors of coffee, toffee, and caramel, with a bitter finish. Thus far my favorite offering at Gray’s.

This is cool, rating a beer for the first time here. The beer pours black with almost no head, white if there is one. The aroma had hints of coffee and caramel .... this is winter here, so my nose is not the best. Definite flavors of roasted malt, coffee, no hop flavors, a bit sweet. Medium body, moderately bitter from the roast/coffee, definite alcohol in the finish, I’d say this is a stronger version of their oatmeal stout - imperial oatmeal? Nice.

Served on draught at the Wisconsin Micro-brewers Beerfest in Chilton, Wisconsin. Pours a thick dark milk chocolate colored brew with a thick and creamy tan head that has some good retention and lacing. Aroma of roasted dark malts, a touch of bourbon whiskey, coffee and some dark pitted fruits. Taste is thick and creamy, full bodied with little carbonation and with flavors of toasted dark malt, some coffee and some soft chocolate and molasses flavors. Not much bourbon flavors in the taste of finish as detected in the aroma but a decent thick and creamy imperial stout that is worth trying again.

Dark brown with a thin lid of tan bubbles. Aromas of berries, roasted malt and coffee. Not overly complex but solid. Light toasted malt start that leads to roasted malt and lightly burnt coffee. No catching much bourbon in this. Perhaps they have toned it down since the earlier reviews. A solid imperial stout.

Dark, dark brown in color, but not black by any means...with an inch tall, light tan head. Aroma is soft, with notes of butter, bourbon and chocolate...not very many roasted malts. Flavor is very buttery, this is a smooth stout with more emphasis on the chocolate and sweetness than bitterness and coffee. The bourbon was very present, but not much oak. It was pretty good. Palate was medium-full with soft carbonation.

On tap @ Gray’s Tied House, 5/15/07. Got the last of the last--a pint of foam became four ounces of black beer--brown at the edges--and still managed a two finger tan head after 10 minutes of sitting. Aroma up front is fresh brown sugar (not that I’ve ever had it). vanilla, butter, strong alcohol, coffee and roasted malts. Flavor had strong alcohol up front with some whiskey--tongue numbingly so, unsweetened chocolate, some caramel and toffee. Too much whiskey, too much butter, too much alcohol. Almost flat with a thin body--though I can’t knock it because of the carbonation. I know this beer isn’t that crazy strong, but that alcohol kinda sucked. I guess I’m not a true dark beer lover.

24th June 2009 Cloudy dark chocolate coloured beer. Semi soft and semi dry palate. Rich sweet malt that has traces of ginger and sweet fruit. The alcohol is noticeable but not unpleasantly so, the aniseed provides counterbalance to the sweet malt. Warming afterglow. Tasty beer.

Bottle@Home.BBD is 081101, so a little old. Dark amber, thin short lasting white head. Armoa is caramel, some sweet fruit, plums. Taste caramel, toffee and abit of dark fruit. Medium body and soft carbonation. Overall nice, but abit to sweet
Copenhagen beerfestival 2007. Honeyish nose, ethylen. Murky brown. Slightly messy flavor: Oranges, diacetyl, ethanol, nuts. Lightbodied, mellow mouthfeel
Bottle at chris_o’s spot the amature tasting. Alround rating: Strong peppery alcohol, very sweet cloying, theres a relitivly nice flavour going on but its drinkability lets it down.
Bottle at Chris o’s…brown red,yeasty fruity ... sweet malty yeast cheewie little toffee

A Mes rate: Bottle at Chris O’s Pre GBBF Tasting Murky brown with a thin tan head. Lots of caramel and dark fruit with all the sweetness carried pretty well by some pleasant roast and bitterness. Thick and chewy and very enjoyable. Good stuff.

Bottled. Amber colour, mediumsized beige head. Aroma is raisins, caramel malts and some mild syrup, alcohol and wooden notes. too. Flavour is raisins, caramel, alcohol, sweet malts and some mild fruityness.
Bottle at Chris_o Pre GBBF Shindig 08. Decent syrupy malty aroma. It’s malty, a bit on the smooth side. It’s got some brown sugar.
Unclear brown with medium beige head. Sweet aroma with fruity, caramel and hoppy notes. Sweet flavor with caramel, roasted malt and hoppy notes leading it to a bitter end.

Deep dark amber colored with little light brown head. Raisinny and plummy aroma with mild alcohol, sweetness dominates with mild licorice and vinous tones. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is dominated by sweetness and licorice, raisins also present. Aftertaste is raisinny and vinous still, with mild alcohol. Sticky palate. Good BW with interesting sweetness and licorice.

This draft brew from the brew pub poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized light brown colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a semi-opaque no visible carbonation dark ruby red brown colored body. . The mouth feel was very tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of mild hops sweet and dark malt. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

On tap at Onion. Poured a clear, ruby-tinted dark brown with just a little beige head action. Sweet, darker chocolate notes steal the show in the aroma, and were quite enjoyable… some molasses and light herbal notes peek through at times. Flavor found sweet darker caramel and semi-sweet chocolate malts.. tasty.. back-end brings out some diacetyl notes and a mild chocolate bitterness.. drinkable, but much better on the front half. A little shy of medium body and sweet on the palate.. felt very nice until the tail-end.

Slightly yellow tinge in the tiny ceramic cup. Smell is a bit alcoholic, but more warming than solventy. There’s a delicate flavor with a bit of plum brandy, but it’s mostly washed down by the alcohol.
Clear pour. Subtle, dry aroma of rice and alcohol, mostly alcohol. A bit sweet with a minor kick at the end
Not really a sake fan. This is pretty sweet, vodka-like honeyness. Not better than a good beer, but nothing bad. Sake seems to lack depth.

From a760 ml bottle. The sake poured a pale yellow-golden color. The aroma was grass, rice, lemongrass and pronounced alcohol. Dryish with strong notes of rice, lemongrass and vodka. There was a faint undertone of vanilla that popped up for a minute and was then drowned in lemongrass and rice. Long tangy lemongrass finish. Fairly full bodied and oily texture. Ok.
My first sake, from a 720ml bottle. Rice aroma, clear, colorless pour, tastes of rice and alcohol. Fairly sweet, but good. (Not sure how to rate it; going middle-of-the-road for the time being.)

720 ml bottle. Pours clear and looks like water or vodka. Taste is of alcohol and is faintly of rice. A little sweet and the body is a little oiley. Good cold or warm. Reminds me of rubbing alcohol and vodka. Easy to drink and not half bad, but I was expecting a little more. Seems like a sake that could be used when doing shots.
A powerful sake with a heavy flavor of rice. The palate is semi thick with a long finish. mild wood and dry flavor make this a treat to drink.

Nothing about this Sake is subtle. The aroma has lots of rice, alcohol, grass, and wood. The appearance is virtually crystal clear. The flavor is like the aroma with a short burst followed by a dry, herbal finish. The palate is slightly oily. Overall it’s interesting but could be better.

On tap at Prairie Rock. Poured a clear reddish-amber with no head.. flat and translucent. Enjoyed the aroma of deeply-toasted, rum-laced caramel and dark fruits.. some alcohol apparent.. big & mean, but well-presented. The flavor found an odd blend of boozy caramel and plums upfront.. worked OK.. some unidentifiable bitterness and alcohol scald the back-end a bit.. ugly bitter, boozy finish. Warm on the palate with a smooth fore.. medium-heavy bodied.. gets ugly toward the finish.
Bottle. Reddish Amber in colour. Unfortunately the rhubarb obliterates the taste of the base beer. Very, very dry, rather bitter beer with a vanilla taste. Not for me. Truly a Strange Brew. (2008)

Feb 2008: This one of the ’Serious Country Ales’ themed beers from Greene King (owners of Ruddles name). I once had a Gurkin flavoured beer which had a green hue to it and actually tasted of girkins, it was horrible. I am reviewing this as I drink it and I don’t really want to taste nothing but rhubarb, so here goes. Clear 500ml bottle, no best before date visible on the bottle. Poured into my Bateman’s straight pint glass. Deep amber colour with a thin white head, looks OK but is no world beater in the appearance stakes. The aroma is more towards custurd than rhubarb, there is however some rhubarb crumble smells too. The taste is all rhubarb and sour rhubarb at that. The label doesn’t lie, apart from the bit about rhubarb having a sweetness. If it does have a sweetness i think they have boiled it out. No way of telling Bramling Cross Hops have been used unless you read the neck label. Different to anything I’ve ever had before and not all bad. I am not a huge rhubarb fan at the best of times but I’ve almost enjoyed this beer. Will I have another? Most likely not. I have had to start eating chesses to help me finish the bottle and hide the taste.

Bottle. No best before date but I’ve been putting this off for a while. Amber coloured. Disgustingly sweet aroma with obvious rhubarb but more like rhubarb and custard sweets. Tastes as it smells but actually even worse and without the nice sugaryness that actual rhubarb and custard sweets would have. Beyond awful.
8th January 2008 Amber gold beer. Crisp palate. Pronounced Rhubarb that leads to a bone dry hoppy and rhubarb finish that lingers and lingers. Unusual but the palate makes it hard work.

Light brown with a thin but lasting head, strong sweet fruity rhubarb aroma, flavour of rhubarb, vanilla and hops, dry and bitter, this is not a good idea for a beer, not nice at all. Nearly pored it down the drain and I could still taste this beer hours after drinking it.

Bottle @ Beer Exposed, September 2008. Pours clear, golden amber with a small, creamy, film head. Aroma is sweet, clear rhubarb character and caramel. High carbonation and a little thin. Flavour is weird, some rhubarb, a touch of tartness, caramel and doughy malts. Very weird, but actually drinkable.

Sweet actually smells of rhubarb, good enough to eat. No head amber with a hint of pink. Looks pretty flat. Mmmm tastes like rhubarb too but with malt mixed in. Has a bitter taste to it but then again it is rhubarb Considering it looks flat it is quite fizzy in the mouth. Enjoyed this beer would buy it again would be good to drink with custard mmmmmmmmm.

Bottle. At one time many years ago Ruddles was a highly respected name in the real ale world. At one point it seemed to be the only real ale stocked for miles. How times have changed! This was a truly awful novelty type drink not to be taken seriously. All i could taste was heaven forbid Rhubarb. As I love both beer and rhubarb it was a shock to taste both together. An experiment that hopefully will never be repeated again.

Bottle from Tesco. Truly awful. I should’ve read some of the reviews on here before wasting my money. Never, ever again. Nasty, musty odour, revolting chemical taste. Christ, this may well be the worst beer I’ve ever drunk. I poured it away after a couple of gulps. Possibly used in trench warfare during World War 1.
500ml Bottle - Amber in colkour. Vanilla and rhubabe in the aroma. Sweet rhubarb taste with some vanilla notes and light malt. Has the potential to be good but this is rather sickly.
Green yellow, creamy head. coardboardy malt, light saaz. Ok hop profile, maltiness lacking, doughy, not crisp. Flour aftertaste.
Aarhus, DK Bottled Malty body and a solid bitterness. Carbonation OK - a good frokost beer

Yellow colored with cloudy appearance. Medium sized yellow head. Strongly hopped and nice aroma with caramel and fruits, rather American aroma here with slight lemon and grass also. Medium bodied, soft palated. Flavor has even more sweet start with still dominating hops. Bubblegum and fine caramelly notes also here with soft palate. Aftertaste is still caramelly and hopped, I like this balance here. ESL, well, more like strong pilsner for me.

Bottle. Cell-phone rating. No detailed notes regarding appearance and aroma. Flavour is way more fresh and hoppy, than one would expect. Alcohol is well hidden and this is very fresh strong lager to quench your thirst with.

Bottle. Clear medium yellow orange color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, hay, fruity, moderate hoppy, grass, notes of peach. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texyure is oily, carbonation is soft. (100308)
Bottle, Average white head, mostly lasting. Yellow color. Light hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor.

Hazy golden with a nice head. The aroma has notes of fruit, citrus, grass and hops. The flavour has a nice bitterness, a light sourness, notes of fruit, grass, malt and the finish is rather dry with notes of grapefruit.

Bottle, bought @ Vinspecialisten, Kolding Storcenter. Pours a light hazy deep yellow with a great, medium, creamy off white head. Aroma is heavily hoppy, grass, pine and grapefruit. Quite full and rather creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is heavily hoppy with a crispyness and freshness from the Pilsner malts. Very nice.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body: &nbsp Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 2 &nbsp &nbsp Pale Yellow(1)->Dark brown(5) : 2 &nbsp &nbsp Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 3 Head: &nbsp None(1)->Large(5) : 3 &nbsp White(1)->Tan(5) : 1 &nbsp Lasting: 4 &nbsp Lacing : 4 Aroma: Intensity : 3 &nbsp Yeast : 2 &nbsp Bread : 2 &nbsp Apple : 1 &nbsp Tropical Fruits : XX &nbsp Soap : XX &nbsp DMS : XX &nbsp Diacetyl : XX Sulfur : XX &nbsp Malt : 4 &nbsp Biscuity : 3 &nbsp Hay : 3 &nbsp Toasty : 3 &nbsp Caramel : XX &nbsp Nuts : XX &nbsp Honey : XX &nbsp Cereals : 4 &nbsp Grainy : 3 Hops : 4 &nbsp Noble(1)->American(5) : 1 &nbsp Leafy : 4 &nbsp Spicy : XX &nbsp Floral : 3 &nbsp Lemon/Lime : 2 &nbsp Grapefruit : XX &nbsp Orange : XX &nbsp Herbal : XX &nbsp Grassy : 3 &nbsp Pine/Spruce/Resin : XX &nbsp Notes : &nbsp Peach/Apricot : XX &nbsp Earth : XX &nbsp Mint : XX &nbsp Butterscotch : XX &nbsp Smoke : XX Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Sourness : XX &nbsp Bitterness : 2 &nbsp Complex : 3 &nbsp Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 3 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 4 &nbsp Clean : 3 &nbsp Sharp : 4 &nbsp Watery : XX &nbsp Oily : XX &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringent : XX &nbsp Alcohol : 1 &nbsp Mineral : XX &nbsp Oxidation : XX &nbsp Metallic : XX Comments: Crisp yet thick, full-bodied example. It works tremendously in my opinion. Intense floral saaz in a firm, but permissive suit.
50 cl bottle. Cloudy golden color. Medium white head. Very floral/fruity, sour apple, hops and malt.
4/10 i mörkhet. Luktar syrligt, lite beskt. Fruktig och milt besk i smaken med en besk eftersmak.
Clear amber color with fine head. Aroma is lovely heavy hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and good hopy bitter.

Hazy amber with an off-white head. Aroma is malty, caramel and very hoppy - grapefruit and pine needles. Flavor is rather sweet and very bitter. Dry and very bitter finish with warming alcohol. Great beer for a hophead. 041107

Bottle at Springslickers fish fry. Pours hazy amber with a pale yellow head. Aroma of hops, lemon, and some Belgian funk. Homebrew like mouthfeel. Flavor of toffee and clove countered by some bitterness that is a cross between citrus rind and dried leafy herbs. Has some Triple characteristics as well. Finish is dry and grassy with notes of celery and hop resin, and some slight acidity as well.
Pours cloudy golden with a white head. Aroma is hoppy, flower, pine, grass and a hint of citrus. Flavour is like the aroma and also a light caramel sweetness.

This poured a murky orange color with a small head. The aroma was herbal with some oranges and spices as well. The flavor was not bitter as you would expect but contained some pine, oranges, spices, and an alcohol bite. The finish was rather sour. Overall a pretty good beer but different for a IIPA.

SpringsLicker’s Fish Fry. Sample from a bottle thanks to brentfeesh. Cloudy solid orange with a thin white head. Aroma is celery, spicy, some citrus. Taste is spicy hops, celery, citrus orange and lemon.
Orangish pour with creamy white head and lace. A cat piss/lite citrus aroma dominate. Brown sugar and light citrus flavor. Full bodied with nice carbonation.

Sampled at Springslicker’s Fish Fry ’09. Hazy orange pour with white head and suspended particulate. Mildewy, bready, lightly hopped. Sweet grapefruit flavor, with celery, and a light antiseptic finish. Kinda boring.

Bottle at the ’09 Fish Fry. Pours opaque gold with floaties and very small head. The aroma is tangerine, yeast, celery, and slight caramel. The flavor is sweet with some fruity hops, celery, and biscuit. A bit of twang marks the finish. Meh.

Clear red-tinted deep amber, one finger white head, rings of lace remain on the glass as I drink it. Nose is fairly pungent hoppiness, piney and floral – nice! Medium-bodied and moderately carbonated. Good piney hop flavor, enough maltiness to balance, nice bitter finish. Surprisingly good for this kind of a brewpub.

Edelflower fruity aroma, amber color clear with offtan head. Sweet and sligjt malty after aroma sweet and apricots in first flavors, bitterness hits back and strong. Very nice drinkable beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
50 cl bottle. Originally rated on 20100707. Pours copper color with a small head. Aroma of pine, caramel, hoppy fruits and grass. Flavor of hops, caramel, fruits, some resin and hay.
50 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 30.06.2010 Aroma has exotic fruits, some pine needles and toffee. Flavour is fruity and hoppy with some gooseberry bush and resin. A bit ashy and stale, but good anyway.

Bottled. Hazy goldeny amber colour with a small off-white head that leaves some lace. Aroma is caramel, some sweet and bready malts along with a nice floral and fruity tone to it. Flavour is fruity, floral, caramelly, mild bready as well as some crisp malty notes.
CBF;light soft fruit aroma,amber, hazy, off white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, nice soft light watery finish.
CBF 2012: Amber coloured and unclear. Has a white head, medium duration. Aroma is hoppy, faint caramel and..popcorn? Moderate sweet starting flavor, medium bitter finish. Watery, dry texture.

Bottle, bbd 12.02.12. ABV is 3,8. Very murky dark amber with a huge, but disintegrating off-white head. Aroma is malty and floral, some caramel, a touch of honey. Fllavor is sweet and nutty malty, some caramel, with a soft (decreasing, I guess - because of its age) bitterness. Citric note. Dry, dusty finish. Light body. Drinkable, slightly boring, guess its much better fresh.
Bottled. Fruity and malty nose. Pale brown head. Dark brownish reddish colour. Malty and fruity and hoppy taste. At the end slight hoppy bitterness. Unfiltered.
Bottle. Deep golden colour with an off-white head. Aroma is grapefruit, citrus, orange, buillon. Flavour is grapefruit, citrus, malt, orange. Medium body. Ordinary beer.
Bottle from K-Supermarket Kamppi. Originally rated on 11.7.2010. Quite well balanced pale ale with notes of fruits and hops.
jhhrfjkherkjhjkwef wekjflkjweklfjw lkjwlekjflkjweklfjlqkwjed lkjwkljdklqjwehhhhhhghhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh
(on tap) Super nose - tart, peaty and very well rounded, with a full barley taste. Good balance the sweet res-sugars and a dry, dry malt. Lasting head, long lasting in deed.
Black with a brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, with fruity notes. Taste is roasted malt, with some coffee and liquirish
Balck of color with a beige head. An aroma of coffee, liqurice, hops and blackbread. A flavor of smoke, liqurice, hops and coffee.

Draft. Pours a dark beer with a creamy and beige head. The aroma is fruity with roasted malts. Has notes of licorice and some sweetness. The flavor is coffee with licorice and sweetness. Nicely balanced. Nice stout, above average.

(Sampler at the brewpub) Penguin ESB is a deep shimmering amber ale with a thin, oily white head that leaves great lacing. Spicy hops dominate the nose. It has a very smooth medium bodyand the flavor is mellow, wooden and spicy. Excellent ESB!
Amber colour, white head. Aroma of caramel, vegetable. Malty flavour, vegetables. Finish caramel. (from draught @ GBBF ’14, London)
From my backlogg: Sample at Great British Beer Festival 2014. Clear golden beer with almost no head. Malty caramell citrus hay fruity aroma. Fruity honey caramell grassy hoppy flavour.

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 2014, Great British Beer Festival, London Olympia, Hammersmith Road, London, England W14 8UX. [ As Teme Valley TOther ]. Clear medium amber yellow color with a small to average, open and frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing to lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, pale nuts. Flavor is moderate sweet and light moderate bitter with a average duration, sweet malt, sweet nutty. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is flat to soft. [20140812]
