From cask. Pours clear and golden yellow. Toasted and breadish malty. Bitter, roasted and lingering dry breadish. Lasting toasted and breadish, slight herbal finish.
Cask @ GBBF 2014. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity weak hoppy aroma. Fruity malty weak citrus hoppy flavor. Has a fruity malty weak hoppy citrus finish.
Sample at Great British Beer Festival 2014. Clear golden beer, almost no head. Malty caramel aroma, hay, floral, citrus, grapes, some hay. Fruity honey flavor, caraml, floral, nectar, some grass.

Gravity at GBBF 2014. Poured a pale golden colour, with a thin white head. Aroma of straw, melon and honey. Bready malt flavours, with some tropical fruit; pretty light overall. Finish was chalk, grassy hop and hay.
Cask at GBBF Cloudy amber with a small beige head, no lacing. Aroma and flavors of caramel, fruity and bitters Drinkable, but not good
Sampled @ GBBF. Clear amber color, small off-white head. Smell and taste malts, slightly fruity, lightly bitter, a nt of caramel and slightly leaves. Average body and carbonation.
Apologies for the poor rating, which was due to a rugby discussion. Cask. Pale orange, still, small ring of white head. Aroma is lightly malty. Body is medium to smooth. Taste is mild and malty.
Golden with a small head.Slightly malty with a medium body. Nothing spectacular but still quite pleasant to drink. My first from this brewery for some time and quite pleasant.

12/2/2019. Bottle from Tuffins Supermarket, Craven Arms. Pours clear pale bright gold with a small off-white head. Aroma of hops, fruit, flowers, grass and caramel. Medium sweetness, moderate bitterness and body. Oily texture, soft carbonation. Sweet caramel finish. Pretty good.
Bottle from Tuffins, Craven Arms. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are fruits, malt, hops and has a sweet fruity hoppy finish.
Bottle from Tuffins, Craven Arms. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and bready. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 110219

Grain malts, light citrus fruits, floral hops. Slightly hazy gold, small, creamy, white head. Light bitter. More grain and cereal malts, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Alright, nice aroma.Cask at GBBF17, Kensington Olympia.

August 2017 - Cask handpull at GBBF 2017, Kensington Olympia. As 'Teme Valley Talbot'. Pale yellow, clear and still, foamy off-white head. Aroma is rice puffs, Honey Monster Sugar Puffs, honey. Body is light and smooth with soft carbonation. Taste has more rice puffs, honey, crackers, Honey Nut Loops and Sugar Puffs. Reminded me of my childhood. (5-4-6-4-13=3.2)

Cask at GBBF’17, day one, 08/08/17. Clear golden with a decent off white cap. Nose is light citric peel, pale malts, light sulphur whiff, grains. Taste comprises bread dough, lemon rind, pale malts, straw, grains. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, semi drying close. Whelming golde affair.

8th August 2017 GBBF Day 1. Cask. Almost clear gold beer, small bubbly pale cream colour head. Palate is light and fairly dry, modest carbonation. Grainy sweet malts. Dry floralness and insipid orange citrus. Tired tasting.
Cask at 2015 GBBF. Talbot Blond 4.4% brilliant clear blond with a bready aroma. Taste is bready and it has a mild crisp finish. A decently balanced blond. 3.5

Cask at GBBF 2015, day 5 - London. Pours totally clear gold with a frothy white head. The nose holds grainy pale bread, slight leaves. Light sweet flavor with more grainy pale bread, leaves, faint caramel, orange rind. Light bodied with fine carbonation; decent condition. Finishes with alright balance, more grainy pale malts, lightly toasted sugars, dirty hay. Tasty beer.

column1: Hair of the Dog Belgian Ale
column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: On tap at cheers to Belgian beers fest - cloudy tan, small foamy white head. Nose of oak, bourbon, and malt. Taste of sweet bourbon, barrel aged sweetness. Smooth finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Hair of the Dog Belgian Ale
column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Draught @ Brouwer’s Café: Deep burnt orange, moderate foamy off-white head, a few streams of carbonation, fairly nice lacing. &nbsp Campfire nose, loads of ash, rich biscuitiness as well. &nbsp Reminds me somewhat of the Adam, just not as complex with the malts. &nbsp Quite ashy on the tongue. &nbsp Somewhat of an odd concoction. &nbsp A little farmhouse like, some mustiness. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Finishes with a bit of smokiness, slightly biscuity. &nbsp Yeah, comes across as a lighter version of the Adam.

column1: Hair of the Dog Belgian Ale
column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: On tap at Brouwer’s Belgian Fest. Reddish brown with good head. Little bit of dark fruit sweetness, but not all that sweet for the style. Lots of spicy belgian yeast in the flavor.

column1: Hair of the Dog Belgian Ale
column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: A dark brown, strong Belgian ale. I called it an Abbey Dubbel, but I’m not sure about that distinction. Had on tap at the Brouwer’s Belgian Fest. Plenty of hops in this one, which makes it unusual. I really enjoyed it, but I think it will get better with time.
not the first (or second or third) style i’ll usually go for, but very well done for what it is. delicate aroma and hop/malt balance is acheived, and if anything, it’s a very nice session beer.

On tap @ Silver Peak poured a clear yellow with a small lasting white head. Aromas of straw, bread and a hint of citrus. Palate was light bodied crisp and dry. Flavors of straw and light bread with a smooth dry finish.
Nothing in the aroma. And not much going on in this beer either. A little hop flavor, it barely qualifies as a hot summer day brew.

Appearance is golden with white head. Aroma of sweet malt, grain, and some hops. Quite a nice flavor of various grains, citrus, light fruit, even a hint of cherry, finish with some hops. An enjoyable easy to drink beer.

column1: Town Hall Hillarys Step Strong Pale Ale
column5: Malts: all Golden Promise. Hops: 100% Summit dwarf. Named to honor a figure famous for mounting a daunting summit. Clear amber/bronze appearance, with a big, lasting creamy head. Lovely aromatics, big, fresh hops, citrus zest and spice...grassy and green. Wonderful. Taste: delcicious. Ample juicy malt, contained bitterness, mixed with fresh hop flavor, with fruity associations, then a bold, brash malty feel kicks in, riding with the higher alcohol. A meaty brew. Beefsteak and applesauce! Great drinking, too, despite the higher booze buzz. A beautiful blend of malt and hops, so smooth, so tasty. I’ll be helping kill these kegs at every opportunity.

column1: Town Hall Hillarys Step Strong Pale Ale
column5: I don’t get the American strong category, because it just isn’t that strong. But good anyway. Fairly well hopped nose with some citrus and pine. Flavor has a biscuit-bread quality from the malt and considerable hop bitterness. One of their better recent beers. Gold color, moderate head.

column1: Town Hall Hillarys Step Strong Pale Ale
column5: On cask at the Brewpub: ...and fabulous! Wow, nice gem look to a pale yellow gold. Smeared and glowing haze to its body. Creamy small top of smooth foam. Immense lacing or should I say straight up sheet of foam lays across the glass like a blanket of pillowy foam. Wow! Gorgeous! Aroma is of soft citrus and pine that carryies a well displayed sifting of orangey/pineapple juices mixed with tangerine soaked pine. Taste is quite nice, very firm and peppy with an overall smoothness that is killer. Tenderly soft in citrus juicyness that induces the ideas and tastes of the tropics. Pineapple, red oranges, tangerines, and some nice touches of skin dryness and pith. Earthy yet favors a subtle tone of sweetness over the top with its juicyness. Grassy touches the end with a nicely rounded bitterness thats easy to handle yet has a decent pep and zip to it to keep it interesting. Feel is super smooth and full on cask pulled delight. Oh so tender and smooth with an amazingly creamy feel with a small texture of buzzing hops and citrusy stuff that floats about. This stuff is gold to the throat. So smooth and tender and creamy its a breeze to drink. A damn fine drinker by TH. No surprise there. Good stuff!

column1: Town Hall Hillarys Step Strong Pale Ale
column5: Copper color with a thin head. Big aroma of oranges and hops. The taste falls into a sweet and sour malty soup. Very boozy for 7%.

column1: Town Hall Hillarys Step Strong Pale Ale
column5: Orange/Gold Color with White Skin. The Summit Hops Come Out Nicely in the Aroma. Piney and Floral..Medium Mouthfeel. Hop Harvest in the Mouth... Fairly Balanced. Hop Spikes Throughout. Dry Hopped Aftertaste. Aggressive Hop Ale.

column1: Town Hall Hillarys Step Strong Pale Ale
column5: Stron hop nose disrupted by the alcohol. Clear golden color. Faint white head. Harsh dry hop flavor with a lot of unbalanced alcohol.

column1: Town Hall Hillarys Step Strong Pale Ale
column5: Amber pour. Thin white head. Typical hoppy profile...mainly of the citrus variety. A dry grassy finish. This didn’t stand out but is solid nonetheless. Town Hall does a good job with their hoppy beers.

column1: Town Hall Hillarys Step Strong Pale Ale
column5: Didn’t take notes, but this was another nice solid beer from Town Hall. There was a flavor that became stronger as it warmed that I didn’t care for. Solid, just not my flavor.

column1: Town Hall Hillarys Step Strong Pale Ale
column5: Aroma is peaches, malt, and maybe a bit of marijuana? Slightly cloudy pale ale with small white head. Flavor is somewhat sweet up front, then bitter peaches, and quite bitter at the end. Lively carbonation throughout. Good beer.

column1: Town Hall Hillarys Step Strong Pale Ale
column5: Orange magma hued pour, completely clear. Light, crisp notes of citrus on the nose. Ginger bitten sesame seeds and honey wheat bread follow. Crushing bitterness. Firey licks of lavender perfumes. A mashed pulp of flower petals and sunflower seeds with an off-centered citrus hop punch. Not grapefruit, but unusually tangy like nectarine. Palate is slick and harsh, mellowing given some patience and adjustment. Mostly predictable, but not boring. Unique strokes against a proven and dependable canvas.

column1: Rock Bottom Chicago A Roll In The Hay
column5: Actually named A Roll In The Hay, this is a spiced up American wheat. It pours a very cloudy straw color with a substantial frothy head. The aroma is strong on the spices, especially ginger, but has a soft underlying wheat malt to it. The flavor is sweet and wheaty, the spices building beginning midway until it’s almost like talcum powder. Oddly refreshing. Rock Bottom Chicago, Chicago, IL

I would say this is more of a pilsner versus blonde ale. If expecting a blonde, then yes, I think it's a bit weak and thin. But, like I said...if this is classified as a pilsner, which I was actually expecting...it's quite decent. Bought it for the season as summer beer, and it serves the purpose. Grassy flavors with some bitter hop at the end. Appearance is a clear medium pale yellow. I wouldn't go out of my way or anything in the future, but can see me getting this again.
Pours a nice medium amber color. Aromas of sweet malts, and the faintest hint of hops. Flavors of caramel sweetness, a touch of fruit, and almost no hop. Nice dry finish.

Hazy golden coloured body with a rich, thick, three centimetre tall white head. Aroma of pale malt, grass, light hops and a touch of citrus. Light-bodied; Sharp metallic flavour up front with a grassy note, some subdued earthiness and a pale, yet distinct malt flavour. Aftertaste is a touch bland with a little grassiness and a light metallic note and a faint sweetness near the end. Overall, a light yet pungent grassy character with noticeable finish - not a bad beer for the style and showing much less bitterness than others in this style. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Whole Foods in Washington (Foggy Bottom, Eye Street NW), DC on 28-May-2015 for US$2,49 sampled at home in Washington on 12-November-2015.
Bottle. The deScription has a lot of flowery language for an IPA. Dark gold color with a large head. Citrus and spruce taste and aroma.
Thanks to iNBE. A little ale like and a little lager like. Both kind of sweet and hoppy. OK. Serving: Bottle

12 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Poured bright yellow, clear, white fizzy head and lots of lacing on the glass. Aroma of wheat, yeast and some hope; actually not bad. Taste is tart, hoppy, some grain but a bit too watery for my taste. Is not a bad beer by any means, but it’s certainly not a rockstar either.

Enjoy by 7/1/15 Slightly hazy gold color with a rocky white head. The aroma is big on spicy, citrusy, and floral Sterling hops. There is an underlying bready, crackery aroma of pils malt as well. Light malt body gets out of the way quick as a huge hop presence takes over. Finishes well on the bitter side, but clean and refreshing. Pretty good stuff.
Fairly straightforward pale malts - biscuity - with a dryish, almost continental hop character.
Semi-bitter grainy taste. Fruit in the aroma but mostly grain. Pretty light bodied and somewhat dry.

Bottle into a pilsner glass. Best by 05/24/2015 so over a week past freshness date and it was priced accordingly. A: Medium gold with a slight haze and an inch of head retaining nicely. Lots of carbonation and good lacing too. S: Light bread scent with a faint spicy hop note in the background. T: A bitter herbal taste up front fairly dominates anything coming in behind. Not altogether good. A bit of a round maltiness finally detected but too little too late. I guess the hop bombs were diffused with age. M: Medium body and slightly above average carbonation. Pretty average. O: This beer is past it’s freshness date which may explain it’s herbal/vegetal character. I’m sure it deserves another rating and maybe it will receive one but it will be a while before I purchase this again. Not very good.

column1: Big Bear Double IPA - Bourbon Barrel
column5: On draft at Big Bear. Showed up for some Sunday brunch and found this beauty on the draft line. Nice hoppy aroma mixed with a touch of woody bourbon. Mouth feel was a little watery but still a very solid showing here.

column1: Big Bear Double IPA - Bourbon Barrel
column5: On tap at the Jupiter beerfest. A big thanks to Tara the Tiger for hooking us up with the "private stash". Big oak, vanilla, and citrus flavors compliment this hoppy east coast DIPA. Florida ain’t San Diego, but this beer represents the state well......

column1: Big Bear Double IPA - Bourbon Barrel
column5: Draft… Lightly hazy orange ale with a small, creamy, off-white head. Good retention. Earthy, citrusy nose – pine, leather, grapefruit and only a rumor of oak. Maybe some Munich, caramel and/or crystal malts. Surprisingly, no bourbon. Full-bodied with a smooth, creamy mouthfeel and prickly carbonation. Bitter! Hearty malt backbone, but mainly just kick ass, earthy, grapefruit and pine hop bitterness. Lengthy, very bitter, almost-caustic finish. If I were a hophead, I would be ecstatic about this one, but I’m more of a bourbon barrel, imperial, big time malty, double IPA guy. This beer leaves me wanting more malt and a more refined flavor. I would have enjoyed this bourbon barrel aged beer a lot more if it had actually been aged in a bourbon barrel. The bitterness is way too intense and sharp for my palate. Also, maybe would be better on cask or nitro.

column1: Big Bear Double IPA - Bourbon Barrel
column5: Hazy amber. Big hoppy nose is very woody with papaya notes. Bitter, refreshing, herbal, woody, citrusy...fun stuff. Very complex yet seamlessly integrated. Outstanding.

column1: Big Bear Double IPA - Bourbon Barrel
column5: Cloudy amber dark orange rusty color. Smells like a pine forest with lots of evergreen, cedar, and a slight sweetness. Super quaffable, dangerous. Bursting with flavor, with an astringent tobacco finish and hints of smoke. Great hopping, excellent brew.

column1: Big Bear Double IPA - Bourbon Barrel
column5: tap at Jupiter brewfest. Great beer! orange color with a nice light head. Aroma has some great citrus hops with some woodsy notes. Flavor is a nice kick of hops with some woody malts. This beer is delicious. Matt really knows his beer!

column1: Big Bear Double IPA - Bourbon Barrel
column5: On tap at the JCBF, pours a orangish gold, cloudy. Big time nose of grape, citrus, and a bit of mollasses (from the barrel aging maybe?). Taste is amazing. Hugely hoppy and very bitter which is not my thing but tempered by an amazing smooth roundness to the malt, definitely some vanilla lingering in the finish along with the orange and grapefruit. Complex and brilliant, many felt this was the best in show, I’d be hard pressed to argue.

column1: Big Bear Double IPA - Bourbon Barrel
column5: on tap-pours a foamy/bubbly off white head and cloudy gold color. Aroma is citrus/pine hops bitter. Taste is grapefruit, citrus/pine hops bitter, good balance with medium malt-some sweet. Nice for 1 or 2. OK carbonation.

column1: Big Bear Double IPA - Bourbon Barrel
column5: On tap. A little below 9% ABV. Amber pour with a hoppy vanilla nose. Impressive double IPA. Good balance of hops and alcohol with an excellent smoothness delivered by the barrel aging. The floral, hoppy and vanilla components follow throughout the taste and leave a pleasant, slightly bitter finish. Great Florida brew.
Amber pour with a nice off-white head. Aroma of caramel, little bit of hops. Taste was good- caramel, soft carbonation, smooth. Left a great lacing on the glass.

Poured a reddish amber, then it falls apart. A big banana fruity estery nose, the banana esters completely overwhelm everything else. With the name, you would think that this is an amber with English hops, but the banana fruitiness dominates any other flavors, even the hops disappears under the bananas. This is the mystery of Rhodell’s, how can Mark produce such great DIPA’s, IPA’s, Imperial Stouts, Barley Wines, German style ales and lagers, but when it comes to Scottish Ales or Amber/Red ales, they all have this same. stupid, banana phenol, making them undrinkable. I don’t get it.

column1: John S. Rhodell Black Widow Imperial Stout
column5: This is a good RIS, not Dark Lord great, but still very good, one of the better brewpub RIS available in the Great Lakes/Midwest region. Aromas and taste of dark roast malts, coffee, cocoa and earthy grains, citric and bittering hops, just enough bitterness to counter the malts, the alcohol is in the background and provides a soft warmth in the palate, and a dryish roasted malty finish. This is a tasty and balanced RIS, Peoria is lucky to have the J. S. Rhodell brewpub, where the majority of the brews our of high quality.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body: &nbsp Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 2 &nbsp &nbsp Pale Yellow(1)->Copper(5) : 1 &nbsp &nbsp Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 1 Head: &nbsp None(1)->Large(5) : 1 &nbsp &nbsp Lasting: 1 &nbsp &nbsp Lacing : 1 Aroma: Intensity : 2 &nbsp Yeast : 2 &nbsp Bread : 2 &nbsp Apple : 3 &nbsp Tropical Fruits : XX &nbsp DMS : XX &nbsp Diacetyl : XX Sulphur : XX &nbsp Malt : 2 &nbsp Pilsner : 2 &nbsp Pale : XX &nbsp Vienna : XX &nbsp Biscuity : XX &nbsp Hay : XX &nbsp Toasty : XX &nbsp Caramel : XX &nbsp Honey : XX &nbsp Cereals : XX &nbsp Grainy : 2 Hops : 3 &nbsp Noble(1)->American(5) : 1 &nbsp Leafy : 2 &nbsp Floral : XX &nbsp Lemon/Lime : 3 &nbsp Herbal : XX &nbsp Grassy : XX &nbsp Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 2 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 2 &nbsp Sourness : 1 &nbsp Bitterness : 1 &nbsp Farmy : XX &nbsp Complex : XX &nbsp Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 1 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 2 &nbsp Clean : XX &nbsp Crisp : XX &nbsp Sharp : XX &nbsp Watery : 5 &nbsp Oily : XX &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringent : XX &nbsp Alcohol : XX &nbsp Mineral : XX &nbsp Oxidation : XX Comments: Sweet despite its general lightness and seemingly under-fermented, grainy, worty. Very watery.
Golden of color with a beige head. An aroma of vith notes of apples and hints of malt. A flavor with notes of malt, caramel and hints of apples.

Cask @ Charlie’s Bar, Copenhagen. Pours a clear golden color with a longlasting white head. Sweet malty fruity aroma with some hoppy hints. Sweet malty slightly hoppy flavor. Sweet malty finish with a fruity and slightly hoppy aftertaste.

Cask at Charlie’s Bar, Copenhagen. A hazy golden beer with a thin off-white head. The aroma is sweet fruity and malty, among the fruits citrus is the most dominant. The flavor is sweet with light notes of fruit - especially oranges, and a light flowery hoppy note, leading to a good bitter finish.
Cask conditioned at Charlies. Golden coloured. Rather hoppy aroma and flavour. Light and refreshing. A good Spring brew.

Cask @ The Wharf, Aalborg. Pours golden with a greyish/off-white head. Sweetis hand hoppy aroma, but weak. Kinda ‘off’. Flavour is very crispy hoppy with notes of hay. Slightly off smoked/burnt notes. Feels thin. 16-05-07.

From Sep 2007 This pours from 12oz bottle a clear amber with a very small head of foam that recedes rapidly. The smell is of sweet malt, some roastiness, and some hop. The taste has a good biscuit malt flavour up front with a more than ample hop bitterness that moves in about midway through. When I swish it in my mouth, I taste some earthy and roasted malt notes and overall, this is a pretty good tasting little beer and I find it's quite quaffable. The mouthfeel is medium light, the carbo is medium, and it finishes fairly dry. I'd buy this again, no problem.

12 ounce bottle into lager glass, best before 4/14/2016. Pours clear orange/light copper color with a 1 finger fairly dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty lacing clings on the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of cracker, toasted biscuit, light nuttiness, herbal, grass, light pepper, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Nice aromas with good balance and complexity of bready malt and earthy hop notes; with good strength. Taste of cracker, toasted biscuit, light nuttiness, herbal, grass, light pepper, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate herbal/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of cracker, toasted biscuit, light nuttiness, herbal, grass, light pepper, and yeast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Nice complexity, robustness, and balance of bready malt and earthy hop flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance, and zero astringent flavors after the finish. Pretty clean on lager flavors; slight yeasty notes are present. Moderate dryness from bitterness as well. Medium carbonation and light-medium body; with a very smooth, fairly crisp, creamy/grainy, and lightly sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 4.9%. Overall this is a nice Vienna lager. All around good complexity, robustness, and balance of bready malt and earthy hop flavors; very smooth and fairly crisp/clean to drink. A nicely enjoyable offering.
12 oz bottle. Poured a clear amber with a thin white head. Taste of caramel, slight roast and bready with a subtle hoppy bitter finish. Lively carbonation, medium body
Originally rated on 6/2/08. A mild offering from shiner. It isnt daring by any stretch but a well rounded, balanced beer. A little light on flavor, some malts, unoffensive, ok.
Shiners Bavarian style ale does not do it for me. Common taste for a common beer. You can do better than this one.
Amber pour with a sweet aroma. The flavor is also ver sweet with a wet finish. Some yeast, and light malts. Not too malty.

A nice amber lager from Shiner, pours an excellent clean amber color with lots of white lacing and foam, very classic look. Aroma is a subdued caramel maltiness, reminds me of a weaker version of a Brooklyn lager or original Shiner Bock. Taste likewise is a couple layers of caramel malt and grain notes, pleasant and not too sophisticated. Finishes clean, light-to-medium bodied. Decent flavor but a bit thin.
A throwback to my pre-ratebeer days. Can’t say I’ve been missing this one in the intervening years. Deep amber with lightly sweet and bitter notes.
Aroma is caramel malts and honey/butterscotch. The flavor is similar to the aroma, with a mild bitterness/slight tartness in the finish.

12 oz refridgerted pour into a Spiegelau IPA glass (for the hell of it). Aggressive pour produced a thin white half-finger head. Fades quickly. Clear as day, mild carbonation. Nose is sweet corn and a little malt. Body a thin, though not as thin as I expected. Crisp. Taste is alright. A little malt, a bit of bitterness, a little corny sweetness. Maybe some hay? Fine for this price point, but not something I’d pay for. Probably wouldn’t turn it down, I think.
Cask@The Criterion, Leicester. Pale beer with a light head. The aroma is lightly dry and the flavour is weakly dry. Overall an average beer.
Cask, The Criterion, Leicester. Golden with a small head. Aromas are spices and lemon with some sulphur. Dry and hoppy. Flavours are dry, hoppy and lightly bitter with citrus notes. Average.

On cask at Posterngate, York. My version had an ABV of 4.4%. Served golden and clear, with a good head and condition. A subtle citrus taste (?grapefruit) starts off, followed, by hints of herbs and spicy bitter finish. Easy drinking but plenty of flavour
Cask @ Barge & Barrel, Elland. Golden with a small smooth head. Has a very light and drinkable hoppy character that is slightly dry, but lacks flavour.
Cask at Lord Clifden; hazy golden amber pour with frothy off white head, mild hop aroma, taste has bready malts some hint of citrus bitter finish, adequate.

Cask conditioned at Far From the Madding Crowd, Oxford. Gold with white head. Crisp, dry hoppy beer, there is a citric, lemony flavour from the hops, palate filling and cleansing, long finish. A really pleasing beer and in great condition.
Cask stillage at Elland Brewery. Hoppy clean aroma and a clear golden appearance with a tight-foamed head. Medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lively with a long finish
Cask Stillage at the Elland Brewery, Elland 18/08/2007 Hoppy aroma. Golden coloured hoppy and slightly citrus with a crisp and bitter lasting finish.
cask at cloisters edinburgh... amber ..toffee hop nose ...slight sweet dryish hops ... with some creamy fruit ... grapefruit bitterness in linger..
Cask, The Black Horse, Walcote. Mellow orangey tang, pale pilsy grain and biscuit. Vanilla custard notes again. Nice, but lacking a bit of hop presence. Should have stayed on the Spotland.

Cask at GBBF 2007. A hazy dark golden beer with a cream colored head. The aroma is sweet malty and hoppy - the latter also giving it notes of grass. The flavor is sweet malty with primary notes of grass, leading to a dry bitter finish.
Golden with a small lasting head. Lemon and peach in the rather weak aroma. Semi sweet, fruity flavour with a nice clean hop finish.

Cask, The Criterion, Leicester. Amber gold with an off-white head. Aromas are Autumn fruit with sweet malts. Fairly bitter with some tea. Flavours are sweet, indistinct malts with too much sugar. A bit of the kit homebrew about it. "Flabby".

Cask, The Criterion, Leicester. Amber brown with a small head. Aromas are malty with Autumn fruit. Kentish hops with spices. Flavours are sweet toffee malts. Very hoppy and dry, yet viscous on the palate. Spicy, bitter hops to finish. Good.

Cask, The Criterion, Leicester. Golden with a small head. Aromas are fresh and hoppy with soft citrus. Quite floral. Crisp. Flavours are light sweet malts with spicy hops and floral notes. Some citrus. Crisp and refreshing with a bitter finish.
Weak appearance and character, although this malty effort does have a hint of aftertaste.
Cask Handpump at the Waterhouse JDW, Manchester 27/03/2011 Hoppy aroma. Clear golden coloured floral and hoppy with a fruity pineapple flavour. A hint of bitterness in a dry malt finish.

30th March 2011 JDW Fest. Clear gold beer, residual white head. Light palate, very moderate carbonation. Slightly dry. A little pale malt. Reasonable hops, trace of citrus with an ok bitter kick. Fairly well balanced. Finishes dry. Alright.
Cask, handpump at Far From The Madding Crowd, Oxford, with Baz 30.04.11 Pours gold with a white head. Nicely hoppy, solid but sweet malty base, some bitterness remains, its fine. A6 A4 T7 P4 Ov13 3.4
Cask, The Francis Newton, Sheffield, UK. Pale gold colour. Malt ginger aroma, sweet with a spicy bite. More sweetness battles with the hops. Syrupy at the end.
Cask-conditioned at the Jolly Sailor (JDW), Hanham, S Gloucestershire 5/04/2011. Golden in colour with a slight white head. Sweetish caramel with a touch of citrus and hint of sulphur. Ok.

Cask at the Gig House (JDW), Wokingham. Hazy amber with a loose white head; fruity aroma; fruity taste - but also chalky and with a hint of iodine; then a woody bitterness to finish. Not sure about this one.
From cask at Willow Walk. Pours cloudy orange with a small, creamy and white head. Aroma is slight toasted malty, breadish and dry herbal hoppy. Bitter, malty and slight herbal hoppy finish.
Cask at JDW Montagu Pyke. Pours a clear gold, with a small off white head. Slightly floral, honey, sweet caramel, toffee and citrus.

Cask Conditioned handpump Eastgate Northampton. A golden beer with a tight white head and lacing. Smells of glass nothing else. Sweet and sickly with wet wheaty cereal. Malts are bad and hops non existant. Poor.

Bottle. Looks like orange squash with a scummy head. Aromas are soft buttery malts with some lemon and spices. Quite lager-like. Flavours are biscuit malts and mellow lemon. Quite sweet. Some creamy and vanilla notes, too. Gentle lager-like hopping. A good Leek bottled beer!

750ml bottle, branded as Staffordshire and at 4%. Pours dark gold with a large, frothy head. Aroma is honey and lemon washing up liquid. Taste has straw to start, bitter straw and honey finish and a honey aftertaste.

Bottle. Yellow with a big head that soon dissipated. Unusual and very pleasant smoked citrus taste. Spoilt by the stack of sediment floating around. Realise that this is part of a BCA but why so much? it would probably put some people off what is an unusual and pleasant beer.

Bottle at home ... very fizzy foamed outof bottle ... nice Golden yellow (little sediment due to foam so will discount) ... lemon hop little spice ... sweetness light floral hops with little dry bitterness in linger.

Bottle. Golden with a large foam head. Aromas are biscuit malts with some sweet honey and floral notes. Some spices, especially coriander. Lager style hops. Flavours are soft biscuit malts with some citrus. Hints of honey sweetness. Nice spices and a good level of hopping. Dry on the finish. Has a nice foaming palate.

Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. As it’s the same ABV, I suspect this is the beer I drank under the title ’Shardlow Spring Equinox’, the attribution to ’Diddy’ clearly having being dropped for this year’s vernal reincarnation. Amber with a small white head. Buttery malt aroma with an interesting hint of cheap tomato ketchup. Sweet malty taste with an attractive leafy edge and some bitterness.

Cask, The Highcross, Leicester. Hazy gold with a dense off-white head. Aromas are caramel malts with soft lemon. Creamy and spicy with gentle hops. Flavours are smooth and creamy with hints of vanilla. Floral with some spices and citrus notes. OK.

***review from June 2008*** Poured out an awesome very burnt orange brew with red hues, crystal clear, usual small white cap but this time it was very creamy and gave out entire glass lacing the whole way through. Perfection in a glass. The aroma was concentrated raspberry syrup that is not overwhelmingly sweet. Almost like a raspberry sorbet. Boring and lacks vision big time. Obvious raspberry taste that seems fake and is probably just syrup. Decent biscuit malts in the middle.... a so-so beer at best.... just got my plate of "mall quality" over greasy fries... fuckers. Smooth and very tangy, good sour middle even if just for a second. Finishes empty.

Draft 6 oz at the brewpub; Almost pink, watery looking and still. No real discernable aroma and the berry flavor is restrained too. Very, very light. Made for non beer drinkers I think. Well made, I supposed, but I don’t think I’d seek this out again. (#2889, 5/15/2007)

Bottle, 22 oz from Jasper Brewing Company. Bottle brought home to Denmark from Jasper, Alberta, Canada. Pours a clear golden with a white dense head. Hoppy aroma in the nose. Strong taste, floral, a little caramel and lots of fruity hops. Medium carbonation. A very nice beer, taste almost like a double IPA.

Sampled at the Brew[ub in Jasper, Alberta. In my tasting glass a translucent amber with a white head. Nice lacing. Nose of light fruit and citrus. Light to medium body. Flavor is caramel malts with the same light fruit and citrus as the aroma. Finishes with a light bitterness. In spite of the relatively high ABV seems more like a session beer or the brewer s were skimping on the nops.

Jasper 22/7 2018. 50 cl on tap on Jasper Brewing’s Brewpub. While waiting for Via Rail (again). Pours hazy amber with medium-sized white head. Settles as thin layer of foam covering the surface of the beer. Crawling up the side of the glass. Substantial lacing. Aroma is fruity but subdued due to the cold serving temperature. Light sweet exotic fruit. Medium strong sour bitter notes of citrus. Medium carbonation. Thin, watery, lively texture. Flavor has fairly strong sweetness followed by medium bitterness. Aftertaste is bitter and lingers shortly. Overall a slightly thin and watery IPA. Get most things right but could use a little intensity.
I tasted this beer when I was traveling Jasper national park. Not a bad beer but also good beer.

[9289-20170620] Tap. Mild aroma, not much there. Clear, golden orange body with a medium-lasting foamy white head and some lacing. Bitter grainy leaf hops flavour is quite muted overall. Medium body is a little bitter. Average, but easy to drink. (5/3/6/3/13) 3.0 (@ Jasper brewpub, Jasper, AB)

2017-06-20. Dark orange amber body modest beige head. Aroma of caramel malt, light fruit. 6+ Flavour is fairly mild, lightly fruity, mild bitterness. Not unpleasant but a touch muddled throughout. Smooth average bodied palate, soft carbonation. Just okay. 6-7/3/6-7/3/14 On tap at Jasper Brewing, Jasper.
On holiday in Canada at the brewpub taster golden blond colored body with a white head and with a citrus hop aroma a sweet citrus hops slightly bitter taste with a bitter finish

Rating #1731 - 2015.06.05 - Sample @yegbeerfest. Golden amber pour with a creamy white head that bubbles away quickly. Hops, hops, hops, very fragrant with mild citrus (grapefruit, lemon) in the aroma. Mouthfeel is creamy, medium carbonation, and bitter hops on the finish - but not overpowering, very balanced with a light fruity sweetness. Delicious.
This is the best beer I had of theirs at their brewery. The hopiness isn't astringent and is average in strength. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, brought back from the brewery by Parksy and shared with the brewery crew. Medium orange, off white head. Grassy grapefruit, moderately sweet Crystal malt profile, moderate bitterness. Not bad.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body: &nbsp Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 2 &nbsp &nbsp Light Brown(1)->Pitch Black(5) : 2 &nbsp &nbsp Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 2 Head: &nbsp None(1)->Large(5) : 3 &nbsp Off-White(1)->Dark Brown(5) : 2 &nbsp Lasting: 3 &nbsp Lacing : 3 &nbsp Nitro : XX Aroma: Intensity : 2 &nbsp Yeast : 3 &nbsp Bread : 2 &nbsp Apple : XX &nbsp Tropical Fruits : XX &nbsp Ink : XX &nbsp Tar : XX &nbsp Olives : XX &nbsp DMS : XX Malt : 3 &nbsp Biscuity : XX &nbsp Burnt Toast : XX &nbsp Caramel : 3 &nbsp Nuts : 2 &nbsp Pumpernickel : XX &nbsp Cereals : 3 &nbsp Coffee : 2 &nbsp Dark Chocolate : XX &nbsp Vanilla : XX &nbsp Grapes : 2 &nbsp Blackberries : XX &nbsp Cherries : XX Hops : 2 &nbsp Noble(1)->American(5) : 1 &nbsp Leafy : XX &nbsp Floral : XX &nbsp Lemon/Lime : XX &nbsp Grapefruit : XX Orange : XX &nbsp Herbal : XX &nbsp Pine/Spruce/Resin : XX Notes : &nbsp Earth : 2 &nbsp Wood : XX &nbsp Mint : XX &nbsp Smoke : XX &nbsp Soy : XX &nbsp Bourbon : XX &nbsp Anise : XX Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 4 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 4 &nbsp Sourness : XX &nbsp Lactic : XX &nbsp Bitterness : XX &nbsp Complex : XX &nbsp Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 2 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 2 &nbsp Clean : XX &nbsp Sharp : XX &nbsp Watery : XX &nbsp Oily : XX &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringent : 1 &nbsp Alcohol : 2 &nbsp Mineral : XX &nbsp Oxidation : XX &nbsp Metallic : XX Comments: Very watery example with sweet+poor fruitiness and mostly grainy, unfocused and rather stale flavours neglecting completely hoppiness.
Reddish, brown colour with a beige head. Roasted malty aroma with a caramel and fruity sweet note and hints of some bitterness. Roasted, coffee bitter flavor with a light fruity note.
tap. it has a dark brown color with a small head. it is roasty in aroma as well as taste. bit sweet.
Draft. A deep red beer with a thin brown head. The aroma is sweet malty with primary notes of caramel, and so is the flavor, leading to a slightly bitter finish.
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Sweet wheat aroma with notes of banana. Light sweet flavour with some fruity notes and light banana.
Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, wheaty, fruity and light yeasty. Flavor is medium sweet. Sweet finish. Watery. 150707
Bottle. Orange7golden with small white head. Flavour is malt, wheat, sweet, and citrus.
17-JUL-2009. Bottle @Aarhus Radison. This is not a wheat beer! Not cloudy, but orangy. No yeasty notes. Ale-like, soft, light, uninteresting.
Clear golden with tiny white head. Sweet fruity aroma with yeasty notes. Sweet perfurmed flavour with yeasty and wheaty notes.

Bottle 66cl. at home.
Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, wheat, toffee, paper. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [230908]
Golden colour and clear. Has a white head. Aroma is faint malty, fruit, straw, grain. Flavor is lightly sweet. Sparkling.
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are wheat malt, yeast and notes of flowers.

Bottle. For a wheat beer the head is relativly small white and fluffy. Clear yellow body. Weak aroma of goodness knows what. Fruit? well I could not smell any. Flavor just as weak as the aroma, strangely enough it has a bit of bitterness. High carbonation, short aftertaste. I do not understand the purpose of this. Earlier Rating: 8/21/2006 Total Score: 2.9 Bottle. White creamy and lasting head. Hazy yellow body. Heavy lemon aroma. Acid lemon/orange flavor with just a bit of coriander without the expected sweetness.
Bottle. Small white diminishing head with good lacing and a clear yellow/orange body. Thin watery body. Disappointing and more like a pilsener than a wheat ale.

column1: John S. Rhodell Imperial Black Widow Hop Head Stout
column5: (draught at the brewpub) Dark black, very little head. Not a lot of aroma. Flavors of roast malt mixed with hops. Interesting blend.

column1: John S. Rhodell Imperial Black Widow Hop Head Stout
column5: Remind me of the Hoppin’ Frog’s Bodacious Black & Tan I had at the recent Peoria International Beer Festival. Poured a blackish brown with an off-white head. Aromas of citrus and roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Good moderate carbonation and a crisp, dryish, creamy smooth medium bodied mouthfeel. A pretty smooth blend of two styles, just enough sour citric bitterness to balance with the sweet roasted malts, an easy sipper, very tasty.

column1: John S. Rhodell Hop Head Heaven IPA
column5: From the tap, served at cellar temperature in a pint glass. Poured a slightly hazy reddish orange copper with a foamy, bubbly off-white that settled into a thin sudsy lacing, small amount of sticking. Tiny bubbles flow from the bottom to top for whole duration. A hop head’s aroma, pine resins, sweetly floral, citric zest and rind, with just a smack of graininess at the edges. Good active carbonation and crisp, dry, hop slick, velvety smooth medium-light bodied mouthfeel, pretty close to perfect for an IPA. If you like hops, then this is close to heaven, piney, oily, citric zesty with a pronounced rind bitterness, a lingering bitterness with a soft, mild numbing of the tongue, a light lemon flavor emerges towards the end, the malts have a sugary graininess that helps sweeten and add to the hop taste, the alcohol is barely noticeable, provides a low temperature warmth in palate that also helps enhance the hops, and a crisp, dry, hop and rind, grainy finish. Another great IPA from Mark at Rhodell, I can’t wait to try the single hop Summit IPA that is coming soon.
The Most has got a lighz golden colour with a thin to medium body. Aroma of unripe apples and trees. Taste of unripe apples, Barrel, trees. Harsh finish.
Muffig apfeliger Beginn, leichte Säure. Reife Äpfel, leider in viel zu geringem Umfang. Süffig, etwas langweilig. 7/7/8/7/10/7
Many thanks to Erzengel for sharing! Klare goldene Farbe. Der Geruch ist mild süß fruchtig, dezent reife Äpfel. Der Geschmack ist trocken fruchtig, geringe Süße, reife Äpfel, dezent säuerlich.

1l-bottle Bottle from Rewe in Sinsheim. Sourish-fresh and extreme dry. The apples and pears are there, but very dry and sourish. Easy to drink with not too much depth in the aftertaste. Crisp and clear.

Bottled. A light yellow cider with no head. The aroma is sweet apply with a slight acidic note. The flavor has a weird apple note combined with some acidic notes, leading to a dry acidic finish. The mouthfeel is thin and very sparkling due to a high level of carbonation.

Appearance Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 2 &nbsp Pale(1)->Dark(5) : 2 &nbsp Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 2 Aroma Intensity : 1 &nbsp Yeast : 3 &nbsp Bread : 2 &nbsp Hay: XX &nbsp Brett : XX &nbsp Floral: XX &nbsp Wood: XX &nbsp Leather: XX &nbsp Barnyard : XX &nbsp Medicine : 2 &nbsp Phenols: XX &nbsp Cheese : XX &nbsp Vinous: 3 &nbsp Notes: Caramel : XX &nbsp Honey : XX &nbsp Applesauce: XX &nbsp Appleskin : XX Pear : XX &nbsp Tropical FruitsXX &nbsp Flavor Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 2 Juicy: 3 &nbsp Sourness : 3 &nbsp Bitterness: XX &nbsp Farmy : XX &nbsp Complex: 2 &nbsp Length : 2 Palate Light(1)->Full(5) : 1 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 3 Chewy: XX &nbsp Sharp: XX &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringence : 2 &nbsp Tea tannins : XX &nbsp Alcohol : XX Comments: Tart and juicy cider with sulphur dioxide to stop refermenting. Vinous, but almost no yeast character. Refreshing, but very very simple.

(Bottle 100 cl) Courtesy of Hildigöltur. Pours a pale golden with a tiny, white head. Lightly tart apple aroma. Medium body with tart apple notes and a very high and bubbly carbonation. Finishes dry. 100507
Bottle. (THX to Hildigöltur) yellow colour with no head. Aroma is green apple, yeast. Flavour is yeast, green apples, citrus. Could be more mouth feeling.

Bottle. 100cl. (thx to Hildigöltur) A rather boring cider I think. It pours clear, pale yellow, without any head. Green apples and a little yeasty note in both aroma and flavor. Medium body and a little bit of fizzyness. Apples and yeast-notes in the finish as well. There’s some astringency in it, but it is a rather boring, but refreshing cider. (070510)
Bottle from Santa Isabel. Amber dark and clear with brief yellowish head. Caramel petrol notes in aroma. Mod carb. Some decent Maillardy caramel but also a little metallic. Ok

Draught @ New Holland. Pours a clear very dark copper color with a medium sized beige head. The aroma is sweet caramel and toffee with a decent helping of fruits and bread. The flavor was sweet caramel with a bit of roasted malt, fruity, light citrus, and a hint of toasted bread. I thought it was a little thin for the style. Solid effort.
On tap at New Holland. dark red/brown in color. Smells very heavy of sugar and caramel. Same for the taste but wasnt to heavy in taste , it was a little thin for me. Could have been better.

Draft sample at brewpub. Poured clear dark brown color with an moderate fizzy off-white head that was mostly lasting with fair lacing. Good sweet toasted nutty malty aroma. Medium body with sticky texture. Heavy roasted sweet flavor with a spicy bittersweet finish of average duration. Enjoyable brew.

On tap at the brewery. Deep garnet red-brown body, thick cream head. Aroma of berries, burnt caramels, and toast. Very sweet flavor profile with abundant berries, fruitskin, and residual sugars, backed by heavy toast and leafy hops. Medium-bodied. Lingering bitter fruitskin and toast finish. The body was almost marshmallowy, soft and sweet, but firmly carbonated.

Anniversary Trip 2007 5/19/2007: New Holland Uncle Heavy Scotch Ale is dark amber/brown in color and transparent. The aroma is chocolate, some char, roasted malt, nutty(?), and has some coffee undertones. Deep caramal and some chocolate comprise most of the flavor. There are also hints of bourbon and slightly charred oak. This beer is slightly dry, but mellow and smooth overall. I enjoyed their Scotch Ale quite a bit and it is probably one of my favorite New Holland beers... Draught sample at New Holland Brewing Company’s restaurant and pub in downtown New Holland, Michigan.

scotch ale on tap at the brewery...first i would like to note that they should be bottling this beer and the czarist over some of their weaker offerings (ex: blue goat dopplebock)...dark brown body with a slight reddish hue...medium-sized beige head..aroma of caramel and chocolate notes, small hints of honey and a touch of piney hops..flavor of milk chocolate malts with a earthy, grassy backbone..coating, pleasant palate...very nice overall, but could be amped up just a bit

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge A Spoonful Weighs a Ton
column5: A reddish copper ale with a thin moka head. A pleasant intense mix of treacle, licorice, and floral hops, citrusy notes. In mouth, a let down from the aroma, rather light and watery malt, with light British floral hops, a bit of lichee and tropical fruits. On tap at brewpub, July 1 2010.

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge A Spoonful Weighs a Ton
column5: Cask half pint at NERAX on 5/5/07 Great condition, bright and all with a plum-mahogany color and an off-white head that shows strong retention and moderate lacing. Lightly fruity nose is otherwise full of graham crackers and a bit of toffee. No hop apparency, maybe just the barest bit of leafiness. Some vanilla and sweet pale malts find their way in and greatly soften the harder toffee and cracker-like notes, resulting in an aromatic and balanced nose. A truly splendid mouthfeel does wonders for this very low gravity beer making it seem neither watery nor thin. Vanilla and honey are joined by a gentle chocolate graham cracker flavor as well as light bread and nuttiness on the finish. Very engaging, tight carbonation with moderate esters and no hop notes. Absolutely flawless and truly remarkable that an American brewer produced this. Draught pint at the brewpub on 5/19/07 The forced carbonation on draught really illustrates why these beers are so great on cask. The looser carbonation left it watery and made the body seem much, much lighter. The tight carbonation in the draught sample concentrates the maltiness and creaminess. Still a good beer and flawless, but just not meant to be served on draught.

The Bock is back at Rohrbach’s. I’m pretty sure this is a different recipe than it was before, but the name is the same. Rohrbach Bock is a crystal clear deep red beer with a thin off-white film that leaves nice lacing on the glass. The aroma has notes of chocolate, bread and roast. It smells grassy, with a a slight, soft sweetness. It is medium, maybe medium-full bodied, chewy, smooth and syrupy. The finish is sticky. It tastes slightly sweet, chocolatey and lightly fruity. The bitterness is light and grassy and the finish is tart. This is an ideal bock!

Acouple days ago I stopped in after helping my brother Ed trim all his bushes and plant roses. I wanted the Pale Ale, but they were out. I didn’t beleive it. I’m glad they still had the bock there. It was more premium($3.75 a glass) then their other permium beer. It was as JB said: Dark reddish brown with a thick creamy looking head. Very malty aroma along with some toffee. Rich creamy palate with a burnt feel to it. A bit of nuttiness adds to the body. I enjoyed it too.

Very attractive looking and a nice aroma made this one a bock I was looking forward to having the 1st sip of! Dark reddish brown with a thick creamy looking head. Very malty aroma along with some toffee. Rich creamy palate with a burnt feel to it. A bit of nuttiness adds to the body. Decent.
Growler fill at Chili Ave location - Copper color, no head, no nose at all. First taste is sour cherries then some nutmeg and cloves. I’d get it again, but not worth seeking out.

Thanks for adding the beer JB, I’ve been waiting for that. I found the sourness of the yeast to be too offensive for my liking. One of the few times I would have hoped for more hops. I like all other Rohrbach beers much more.

An unfiltered ale, with a nice copper color and good head. Minimal aroma except for a bit of a sourness I associated with the yeast not filtered off. The palate was fruity and sour, with minimal hops. This was interesting, reminded me a bit of a Wit.

This is what I expected when I first tried a Brown Ale- I was a little turned off by the low ABV but this brewers special turned out to be a nice friday afternoon summer treat. Somewhat thin but very malty at the same time- rich caramel flavor with strong hints root and maybe some sweet berries. Very nice.

Name: bock Date: 08/07/2008 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear gold, wispy white head, streaks of lace, Aroma: light sweet caramel malt aroma, Body: slick body, Flavor: sweet malt flavor, another dyactyl bomb, light balancing earthyness, light bitter finish, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 4/10; Overall: 8/20 Rating: 2.2/5.0 Drinkability: 5/10 Score: *+/4
Draft at Tied House under the name My Bock. Lightly hazed amber color with a modest off-white head. Moderate caramel and mild husk aromas. Similar flavors with a mild floral hops mix.

On tap @ Gray’s Tied House, 5/15/07. Clear rubyish brown with a 1/2 finger beige head that fades to a thick film. Served too cold in a frosted mug. Aroma of chocolate malts and light toffee, and a little bit of roast--seems dry. Flavor of light baker’s cocoa, toffee, a little bittersweet molasses, toasted grain, light earth--quite malty (go figure). Light to medium body with moderate carbonation. Decent.
Keg at the Arch and Abbey. Pours clear golden with a thin white head. Aromas of jammy raspberry. Taste is very sweet. No sign of wheat character.
Well balanced cask wheat beer. Strong raspberry taste and smell. Not bad...
Pint on tap at the old market hall, jdw. Thin creamy white head. Very hazy golden blond pour. Strong raspberry aftertaste. Not well balanced.. still an interesting beer.
Pours clear bright orange with a small frothy off-white head. Aroma is malty with some berry-like fruitiness. Taste is fruity sweetness with some bitter finish.

Cask. Aroma of soured fruit. Pours amber gold on the orange band. Has a spotted thin white head with little lacing. I assumed a wheat beer would be light and refreshing on a sultry day. But a pale would have been the better choice. Tastes of biscuits soaked in lychee juice and not in a good way. I can’t say the raspberries came through for me but that is not a disappointment but the rest is.

Cask handpump at The Joseph Else, Nottingham, Saturday 9th April 2016 with dad. Pours warm gold with a short lasting white to off white head. Raspberry notes on the nose, in the mouth this has a sweet fruity tang, I guess that the raspberries are just about discernible, it is absolutely fine however not a beer I would seek out again. We left both this and the Kelham Island Ace of Spades, though this was a little better. . A6 A4 T5 P3 Ov11 2.9

Draught (Sir Henry Royce, Peterborough) Soft grainy aroma, light wheatiness, some red berries, but more redcurrant than raspberry. Juicy, but sharp palate. Fruity, apple, some sourness. A bit messy and harsh. Cider-like tinges. Nope.

Cask at The Roebuck, Leek (Titanic) A hazy deep golden colour with a pink tint and a foamy off white head. Aroma of raspberry, a little apple, wheat, subtle acidic yogurt and some straw. Taste of raspberry, wheat, subtle barnyard funk, slight yogurt and maybe peach in there. Medium bodied and an oily texture. A sweet, slightly sour, raspberry wheat finish. Tastes exactly like it says on the pumpclip. Slightly acidic and sour but the sweetness balanced it out. Not a fan though.

Aroma: some malts, fruits, dark berries, hints of raspberries. Appearance: golden/orange, medium white head. Taste: moderate sweet, some bitters. Palate: light carbonation, bitters continue, medium long finish. Overall: OK fruity Wheat Beer - will probably never become my favourite beer style. Pint at the GBBF13, London.
Cask@city arms ruby tinged amber with tart raspberry aroma. Rich fruity body, gentle carbonation, medium mouth feel, quite acidic but quaffable.

Clear, medium brown. Pretty one-dimensional -- smells like baked ham, tastes like baked ham. Dry, underhopped, non-esteric, watery. Just brown smoky water. Couldn’t take a full pint of this. Rosemont, IL, by O’hare.

10% unmalted rye. Hazy amber. Big fruity, yoghurty aroma filled with tangerines. Quite a fresh, citrusy bitterness - orange, tangerine. The finish is dry. When it gets too warm it gets sort of tannic...maybe that’s the rye...I’m pretty bad at picking out rye. Not bad. Certainly the hoppiest beer they’ve brewed, to my recollection.

Tiny pour from a bottle at a tasting. Consumed on 9-23-17. Pours a hazy bronze with a small amount of beige head. Belgian, barfy, sweet smell. Excessively sweet taste. Frothy and light in the palate. Not good. 5.3.4.2.9=>2.3
[Growler] shared by Skyview. Aroma is vanilla, banana, and a touch of alcohol. Flavor is mostly clove, yeast, dry.
Courtesy of Skyview. Amber color with a thin head. Slight aroma of bananas. Sweet malt taste with cloves and a bit of coriander. A big improvement at Moosejaw.

On tap at the brewpub in Wisconsin Dells, pours a semi hazy golden amber brew with a fast dissolving off-white head. Good lacing though. Aroma of rich wheat, bananas, caramel, a touch of yeast with some grassy hops. Taste is more like a hefeweizen than a Belgian Strong Ale. Medium body with a good balance of yeast, wheat and slightly carbonated. Finish is smooth, creamy and a light banana aftertaste. One of the brewery’s best brews so far.
Thanks to Skyview for sharing again. It is medium bodied and golden colored. Sweet, with a bit of caramel. Some light fruit and malt. Light overall, and not particularly Belgian.
Thanks to skyview for sharing his growler! Banana wheat nose that reminds me more of a Hefeweizen than a belgian strong. Nice wheaty body with a little malty flavor and a slight wheat profile.

column1: Gwynt y Ddraig Two Trees Perry
column5: Cask at the Peterborough beer Festival 2019. A clear petrol yellow coloured pour with no head. Aroma is sweet suger plums, pear, light wood, white sugars. Flavour is composed of medium sweet, pear, white, peach, plum, white grapes. Drinks pretty good. Palate is medium still. Sugary.

column1: Gwynt y Ddraig Two Trees Perry
column5: Cask at Red Squirrel Amersham, 28/04/17. Pale golden with little in the way of a head. Nose is varnish, pear drop, Orchard wood, sweet notes. Taste comprises floral notes, pear drops, straw, apple pie, honey blossom. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, drying close. Ok.

column1: Alehouse It's Black Over Bill's Mother's
column5: Cask-conditioned at the Lower Red Lion, St Albans, 8/6/07. Near black with reddish tones and very little head. Aromas of dark fruits, chocolate and roasted notes. Flavours of black currants, coffee and more plain chocolate. An enjoyable mild.

column1: Alehouse It's Black Over Bill's Mother's
column5: Half pint gravity fed from the cask at the Ealing Beer Festival, poured a darkish brown with no head. A good flowery malt aroma. Was a bit watery with a plain malt taste. Wasn’t great (like "old socks" a companion told me).
On tap pours out hazy golden copper color topped with a white head. Nose is belg malts some spice and a little citrus. Taste is more of the nice sweet malts citrus floral and spice. Enjoyable

330ml bottle in Kyoto. Poured a slightly hazy golden colour with a bubbly round white head. The aroma is malt, big grainy, yeasty, citrus fruit. The flavour is moderate yeasty bitter, with a malt, yeasty, fruity citrus, hop bitter palate.

On tap at the brewery's Takadanobaba taproom. Clear amber body with a white head that had excellent retention. Moderately strong and rather exotic aroma with tropical fruit notes dominant. Flavor: It has both bready and fruity notes but the fruit notes are dominant. Moderately bitter. Moderately strong for style. Near medium body with medium-light carbonation.
Fresh, clean and middle weight. Lacks some obvious primary flavour but probably correct from the classic style. Pedestrian a little?
Keg, Harajuku. Hazy lemon and gold, thin head. Big grassy aroma with some juice. Description is bone dry and that's right. Bright, fresh, refreshing, herbal and dry. Really good.

Tap. Slightly hazy golden beer, small white head. Nose is spicy, some herbal tones, malt, and something I swear is taking a stab at tartness, but the stab is pretty weak. Flavor is citric, spicy, malt, herbs, green pepper. Hops and spicy notes in the finish. Saison-ish, not exactly a saison, but not completely off the mark. Fairly drinkable.

On tap at Pudel bar. Pours golden yellow colour with quite high white head. Slightly spicy, malty, slightly caramelly, grainy, even bit sour aroma. Grainy, bit malty, slightly caramelly, bit sour taste. Grassy, bitter finish. Grainy, very slightly sour aftertaste. Maltiness is dominating. Palate reiminds a lager. It is not a saison in a classical sense, but it is not bad as well.
Poured at Shelton Festival, hazy orange with medium white head. The aroma is strong yeast, earth, spices. Medium body, yeast, lemon zest, light dry finish, good.

Pours hazy yellow with very light white head. Aroma is bitter, hops, lime, floral, some birch, lemon peel, acid, wooden notes, herbs. Taste is floral, bitter, watery, some flour, yeast, citric acid, some lemon, grass, some birch and wooden notes. A bit watery but otherwise good beer!

33cl bottle from Rimi, Tallinn. Pours hazy deep golden to amber with a somewhat modest head. Fruity and fairly yeasty aroma with spicy notes, malt and hints of wheat and banana. Medium sweet with nice acidic notes and medium to low flavour intensity. Enjoyable.

column1: Baird Rustic Grace Daidai Dark Wheat Ale
column5: My Bottom Line: Caramel apples lightly roasting atop a well-positioned citrusy tartness end up balanced by the earthy hop finish. Yet another very drinkable and carefully crafted Baird fruit beer. Further Personal Perceptions: -A ring of foam circulates around the orangey copper. -The daidai’s citrusy discourse is an able companion the grain bill. -The body of this Baird fruit beer is just like most of the others: lean, lightly carbonated, and extremely drinkable. On tap at the brewery tap room.
Deep orange amber color. Very very mild toffeeish nose. Sweet, sweet toffee, almost Crunchie chocolate like, mouth. Mildly bitter at the back of the throat and in the finish.

Draft. A slightly hazy amber beer with a small off-white head. The aroma is sweet with flowery notes of hops as well as a touch of citrus. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel and flowery notes of hops, leading to a medium bitter finish. I was told, that this was merely a cask version of the IPA.
CBF07 sample from tap. No carbonation. Aroma is floral hoppy and sweet. Flavour is lovely sweet malty with a good flora and bitterhops making the finish.

Cloudy orange colour with a white head. Malty, light sweet aroma with notes of pine and fruit. Hoppy fruity flavor with some pine bittern notes and a vague malty sweetness. Light dry and bitter finish.
Draught. Cloudy golden coloured with an off white head. Fruity aroma of hops and pine needles. Sweet flavour of fruits, hops and pine needles.

(On tap) Slightly hazy, amber golden with an off-white head. Very weak citrus aroma. Medium body, a little flat. Sweetish caramel notes and some citrusy aroma hops in the finish - hops also leaving some bitterness. 130507
TAP: Pour is cloudy pale yellow. Aroma of grain, lemon, creamed corn, honey. Taste is similar but I was distracted by the mouthfeel. It was sudsy like soap.
A hazy dark yellow with fluffy head. Rye characters come out and you can taste a corny, nutty, earthy, light tasting beer. Hops leaves a citrusy zing.
It’s rare that I can’t swallow down a beer even when I don’t enjoy it. However, I had a free beer ticket I didn’t redeem after getting through my first cup.

On draught at the Titletown brewpub in Green Bay, WI. Pours a semi-clear golden pale colored brew with a decent white head that has some good retention and spotty lacing. Aroma of golden grain malt, citrus zest, a hint of honey and creamed corn. Taste is light to medium bodied, soft carbonation with flavors of golden grain malt, some citrus and Cascade hops, and a touch of honey. Finish is quite smooth, crisp, with a quick mild bitterness that disappears.
This beer poured a golden colour, with a noticeable grainy taste. It was very light, a touch of creamyness, with light roasted malts and subtle hops all the way through.

Somewhat difficult rating here as I enjoyed this after running 13.1 miles in the Green Bay Half Marathon. Beer was served nice and cold due to the outdoor temperature being about 40F. The body was very nice on this and had a nice, sweet malt flavor. Smooth beginning and ending to this beer.

On tap at Titletown. Clear yellowish color with light white head. Aroma is of light citrus and toasted hops. Taste is of sweet malt, light citrus notes, toasted grain and corn. Decently carbonated, this beer finishes quite smooth.

column1: Breckenridge 471 Small Batch Bourbon Barrel Aged IPA
column5: Boozy and big and mellow with caramel as an after thought and a little dark fruit almost like rubbing alcohol. Chestnut and approaching hop profile that does not get in. A plum pudding as another wafting thought before the abv takes over again. Some syrup. Interesting enough.

column1: Breckenridge 471 Small Batch Bourbon Barrel Aged IPA
column5: draft to 10oz glass. never thought the day would come to where the two mixed. lighter color pale mild clear brown I don’t know it was weird. the aroma was a definite bourbon, oak mix. the flavor you got hops underneath but it was mainly bourbon and oak and not much more. it was drinkable but just weird.

column1: Breckenridge 471 Small Batch Bourbon Barrel Aged IPA
column5: On tap at SLL. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head that falls to a ring quickly. Aroma of light bourbon, wood, and grapefruit. Flavor of bourbon, grapefruit juice, hops, and lots of alcohol on the finish. Thin body with light carbonation.

column1: Breckenridge 471 Small Batch Bourbon Barrel Aged IPA
column5: Bottle. Has a orangey copper color. Has a big bourbon taste with a hop after taste. The balance isn’t equal.

column1: Breckenridge 471 Small Batch Bourbon Barrel Aged IPA
column5: Draft at Bricks. Pours cloudy orange brown with off white head. Nose is some bourbon and pineapple. Taste is similar with some nice sweetness.

column1: Breckenridge 471 Small Batch Bourbon Barrel Aged IPA
column5: Bomber. Nice aroma of bourbon, oak and vanilla with slight pine resiny hops. Pours amber colored with a large, soapy white head with decent retention and some lacing. Starts with some caramel sweetness with some piney hop bitterness. Finishes dry with the bourbon, oak and vanilla pushing through the bitterness before it reasserts itself at the very end. Good, well balanced barrel aged IPA.

column1: Breckenridge 471 Small Batch Bourbon Barrel Aged IPA
column5: Poured from bottle, pours a dark amber orange with an off white head, Aroma is of more sweetness of caramel and malt with a good touch of whiskey and oak as well, flavor is of more whiskey and sweetness than anything, hops don’t really come through, honestly can’t even tell this is an IPA, meh.

column1: Breckenridge 471 Small Batch Bourbon Barrel Aged IPA
column5: Aroma is caramel, spices, light pine and a hint of bourbon. The flavor is grapefruit, malts, fruit and a long and warming alcohol/bourbon finish.

column1: Breckenridge 471 Small Batch Bourbon Barrel Aged IPA
column5: Bottle. It poured an amber color with an off-white head. The aroma was of bourbon, wood and some fruits. The taste was of bourbon, floral fruits, hops and some alcohol. Nice.

column1: Breckenridge 471 Small Batch Bourbon Barrel Aged IPA
column5: On tap at Lunar Brewing Co., and snifter served showing a clear, amber color, with a frothy, and quite persistent layer of soft white head foam, and wavy cling to the lacing. The nose was sweet & malty, with barrel induced notes of vanilla & coconut. The taste immediately expressed alcohol, not noticeably bourbon, some barrel/tannic astringency, citrusy bitterness, and a pleasant creaminess to the mouthfeel. Medium+ bodied, with soft carbonation, the finish was a bit sweeter than I would have liked, but otherwise, a decent, robust & warming brew.

Dark brown color with off white head. Fruity hops and sweet malt come together nicely in the nose with just a touch of coffee. Sweet malty start with toffee, cherries. Full bodied, but not so well balanced. Bitter dry finish with hints of toffee. This was the first beer made on the new brewing system. Although decent, I felt if it was made on the old system it would have been much better. Luckily since then the bigger system is making just as good stuff as the old system.
chiara buona schiuma buona persistenza lieve acidita limone poco corpo lieve sapido

Cask @ The 18th Reading Beer and Cider Festival 2012, Reading, Berkshire England. ABV: 5.0%. Hazy - murky medium orange colour with a large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, wheat, herbs, floral, ginger notes. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a long duration, herbal, floral, salty. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20120504]
The Gose tradition brought to Cologne! Flavor follows the style here: sweet and tarty, a little salty. Strong flavors of berries and herb make for an excellent savory beer.
(draught 0,3l @ Vánoèní pivní besídka Brno 2012) Champagne aroma. Cloudy orange color. Huge white head. Very sour. Light fizzy, light creamy texture.

Cask@Reading Beer Festival 2012. Hazy golden colour, small white head. Aroma is fruity, spicy and also has some slight herbal notes. Flavour is salty, sweet fruity along with sweet malts and some mild yeasty notes.

From the cask at Reading BF 2012. 5.0% on foreign bar. Cloudy pale gold lasting white head. Spicy herby aroma. Rosemary salty beer. Really interesting beer. Strange bizarre but quite drinkable. It is salty though.

From fresh growler - Hazy yellow body with a very small bubbled white head; Quite big nose, a little fat spicy flowery with a slight diesel oil touch; Soft carbonation in slightly thin very 1-dimensional, very lightly sour body; Medium long slightly sour a little salty body, lots of simple coriander seed aromas. Gose is really one of the beer styles I like the best, but this one is quite far behind the top contenders.

Milder Antrunk, etwas säuerlich, erfrischend. Würzig spritzig, hinten herum dabei aber würziger, angenehm. Hintern herum sogar etwas malzig, eher aber weitern leicht säuerlich. Angenehmes und sehr erfrischendes Bier.

16/12/2018. Draft at Flannery’s Irish Geo Pub, Santiago. Pours very dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, molasses and toffee. Moderate sweetness, medium bitterness. Medium to full body, sticky texture, soft carbonation. Easy drinking, pretty good.
Aroma of soft barley and little else. Has mellow foam head and a black body. Flavour is dark sugar and roasted barley without distinction. Okay on the mouth. It's very drinkable, if a little simple.
Cerveza Ale antigua. 8 grados de graduación alcohólica. Marrón oscura. Maltosa dulce y frutosa. Aromas a maltas tostadas, caramelo y a café. Buena!

Es una muy buena cerveza con toques a café, y algo de cacao. De aroma intenso y color negro azabache. Su graduación condice y armoniza bien con su sabor sin ser una cerveza completamente agresiva. Gran cerveza de Tübinger.

Opaque dark brown with some ruby hues. Medium sized creamy creme head. Aroma is dried fruits with some burnt sugar. Flavor is same dark candy sugar with some fruitcake and a slightly alcohol warmth at the end. Medium to light palate, a bit watery and non complex.

Cerveza de color marrón oscuro con una buena cabeza de color beige. Aroma a malta tostada, levadura, frutos rojos, cacao y café. Sabor fuerte a alcohol con notas de café y fuerte sabor a malta tostada con un amargor final. Excelente cerveza Chilena.

330 ml bottle. Coffe smell with a little bit of something like smell, I don’t know what it is. Fuzzy ugly with head with dark color, a little transparent. Acid taste, but not a very dark one, is quite soft, it’s like and amber beer. Boring afertaste. Ok, guys. May I be honest? I’m very offended by the strong bear on the packaging. It’s more like a Wiinie the Pooh having a picnic beer than a Terminator super strong me-lah-tiroh-a-toah- beer.

Bottle, 33cl. Opaque ruby/brown with a frothy brown head. Spicy herbal aroma with hints of berries, mud and dried fruits. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Smoked character with a strong rich malt flavor. Not overly sweet. Well balanced alcohol and bitter finish. Good beer.

Dark brown colour. The aroma mixes sour off notes (argh, not again) with caramel and light fudge. The taste has some soft dark sugars that show promise, but also a light milk chocolate character. I guess I would not bottle-condition this one, since that only causes it problems.
(330cc bottle) Pours a dark brown body with a tall beige head. Aroma of roasted grain, raisins, and mustiness. Flavor of raisins, plum, dates, caramel, light coffee, and roasted malt.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: 3.30.08 7.5% abv on this batch. Unfiltered, strong, typical Belgian Strong. Good example of the style. I second the need for glassware. Pints are no good for these brews

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft - Opaque dark gold, thick creamy white head. As it warmed, rich honeyed banana and fresh bread dough notes emerge. Had a nice underlying nose of grassy citrus and touches of pepper. Flavor was fruity and yeasty up front with balancing grassy, citric, and light peppery tones. Full bodied, medium carbonation, soft bittersweet finish. Too bad everything comes in a pint here. This one screamed for the proper glassware. Either way, well done in m y book...

Draught at the Brauerei. Pours clear amber with a medium, frothy off-white head, medium retention with light lacing. Aroma is cellar, musty melanoidin malt, bready and light earthy hops. Flavor is medium spicy and earthy hops and bitterness, cellar notes, biscuit and caramelized malt with a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

(draught) pours a slightly hazy golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of starchy pale malts, light strawberries, bubble gum and cherries, with a surprising hint of funky brett. flavour is caramel and pale malts, with a light hint of nettles and a dry starchy finish. medium to heavy-bodied with average carbonation.

(Tap) Es hat ein orange-goldene Farbe, ist leicht trüb mit einer fast weißen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist honigartig und mandarinig. Der Geschmack ist vollmundig und honigartig, Die Bittere ist stark, schlank und flacht dann schnell ab, bleibt aber lange und angenehm auf der Zunge zurück. Eine ganz leichte alkoholnote taucht nach vielen schücken auf.

On tap at brewpub in Konstanz. Deep, hazy copper color. Decent white head doesn’t last. Aroma of grains and oranges. Flavor is initially sweet--light malts, orange zest and some dessert spicing. Fades into a malty bitterness that carries you to the finish. Really outstanding, but I wonder if the recipe varies by year and brewpub franchise.
Short review from tap. Yellow golden beer. Grainy aroma. Leavy earthy taste. Okay
on tap chiara torbida schiuma media lieve nota matata un toccobfruttata amaro medio basso media secchezza
Drunk on draught at the brew house in Konstanz. Rather uninspiring light helles style beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Clear golden colorwith a white head. Grainy, straw, a bit herbal/floral hoppy aroma. Crisp, a little chewy, grainy pale malty.

Draught at the brew pub. Overall very unimpressive. However, aroma is light hops. Appearance is cloudy yelliw-ish with a light foam. Taste is so slightly bitter and sour. Very thin in the end. Not my favorite.

(hand-bottle) pours a hazy yellow colour with a frothy white head. aroma of grass, light rhubarb and mint, quite earthy, with a hint of pale malts. flavour is mostly the same, with light notes of pretzels, sweet spices and a minerally, estery finish. light to medium-bodied with average carbonation.

(Tap) Es hat eine getreidiggelbe Färbung, ist leicht trüb mit weißer Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist süß, fruchtig (vllt. gekochter Rhababer). Der Geschmack ist eher schlank, mittel-stark Bitter. Die Bittere ist breiter und hält länger an. Zusammengefasst; obere deutsche Mittelklasse.
On tap at Joh. Albrecht brewpub in Konstanz. Golden color with nice white head. Aroma, yeast, citrus. Taste, malt, hops, some spices, bittersweet finish. Drinkable beer.
draught at the brewpub. Dark golden colour, slightly hazy. Malty hoppy, slightly fruity. Not much more to say about it.

At the brewpub. Hazy golden with a bubbly white head. Very spicy aroma, feels very hoppy and green. Medium body, medium bitterness and a heavy carbonation. A touch of diacetyl in the flavour which also shows quite a lot of hops. soapy and almost cloying towards the finish. Pretty average.
oro quasi limpida buonaschiuma piuttosto persistente cereale discreta nota erbacea buon amaro

Draft sample at Brauhaus Joh. Albrecht, Düsseldorf, Germany. 10.06.2018. Pour it clear golden color with small white head. Aroma sweet nice yeasty note. Taste sweet yeasty, crispy, herbal bitterness, after taste really bitter. Nice refreshing. Good.

Sampled from tap at the brewpub. Clear, golden with a medium large, foamy, stable, white head. Sweetish, rather grassy, moderately floral and slightly fruity aroma of fresh grass, some grains and a touch of citrus. Slightly sweet, moderately bitter, rather grassy-spicy and slightly fruity taste of grains, fresh grass and some citrus, followed by a short, moderately bitter, rather grassy-spicy and quite dry finish. Thin body, smooth and slightly effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Nice!
Draught at the brewpub. Bready, herbal hops, light residual sweetness, strong grassy bitterness. High drinkability. Very tasty.
29-12-17 // draft at the brewpub in Düsseldorf. Slightly unfiltered yellowish. Solid foamy head. Grainy smoothness with a well balanced hop bitterness.
Draught at the brewpub. Clear golden colored with a medium sized white head. Malty aroma of hay and hops. Malty flavor of hay and hops. Hoppy finish.

On tap at the brewpub. Leicht trübes goldgelbes Bier mit einer ordentlichen weißen schaumkrone. Geruch leicht fruchtig hopfig, gering getreidig malzig. Geschmack angenehm hopfig bitter, leicht fruchtig, süffig.
Durchschnittshelles. Hellgelb mit dichter weißer Schaumkrone. Aromen von Cerialien und Malz. Geschmack eher getreidig, flach. Hatte mehr erwartet.

Draught at the brewpub Cloudy blond color with large frothy head. Pretty nice aroma of malt and noble hops, crispy cereals, light lemon. Too much carbonation; the mouthfeel is dry; quite good cereals, with strong bitterness and nice grassy presence; although there is too much yeast. Nice but rough.
On tap at the Pub. Smooth fresh fruity. The body is crisp, fresh with grainy hints. Smooth and round. Fruity bitterness in the end, round fruity tangy brew. Nice bitter and still smooth pils.

Draught. Medium high and quickly disappearing white creamy head. Hazy yellow green body. Weak fruity especially lemon aroma. Heavily carbonated lemon hops flavor with a some spicy notes. Short aftertaste.
On tap at the brewpub. A clear pale golden beer with a huge most good lasting white head. Aroma of spicy hops, pale malt. Taste of grassy bitter hops, hay, pale malt, mild bitterness.

Tap @ Joh. Albrecht, Soltau. Hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, grainy, light fruity and light hoppy - straw. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 080717

Sehr mineralisch, eigentlich nicht so meins. Hat eine angenehme Bitter-Note und einen weichen Abgang. Schmeckt ein wenig säuerlich, eigentlich angenehm. Im Glas leicht trüb. Lecker, aber das Kupfer ist besser. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Mild herber Antrunk, anfängliche Bitterkeit. Diese steigert sich zu einem knackigen Level, dahinter etwas grasig, rund. Getreidiger Ausklang, in der die Bitterkeit ebenfalls gefällt. 10/11/11/11//11

Draught @ Brauhaus Joh. Albrecht Soltau, Winsener Straße 34d, 29614 Soltau, Germany . Clear medium orange color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, hay, toasted, fruity, light moderate hoppy, flowers, citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20091107]

Draught at the brewpub. It is hazy, warm golden with a lasting, creamy, huge, white head. The aroma is very mild with notes of malt and flower. The flavour has a light sweetness and notes of malt, refreshing and dry citrus. It is smooth, mellow, but still very refreshing.
Draught at Joh. Albrecht Soltau. Golden coloured. Grassy aroma. Hoppy flavour with a dry and bitter finish. Fresh.

On tap into a sampler. Appearance is a hazy gold with a quickly dissipating white bead. Aroma is very yeasty. Taste is a bit spicy with notes of orange, clove, and coriander. Overall, a good attempt. Too bad there’s no real honey taste.

Draft @ Church Brew. Pours a murky, dulled golden-orange color; off-white head with good retention and fine-bubbled lacing. Sweet honey, juicy oranges, and slightly overripe fruits in the aroma; honeyed sweetness and coriander, mostly. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: Belgian sugar, chewy, viscous honey, and slightly rough spicing (coriander, white pepper); slightly abrasive on the edges, but decently drinkable and well-formed overall. Touch too sweet. Lengthy finish: touch of alcohol, honeyed sweetness, spicing, and Belgian sugar.
