Tap at Enibru. Aroma: Roasted grain, light nuttiness. Palate: Light-medium bodied, dry. Flavor: Very dry from the start, roasted nuttiness, light roasted coffee bean, perhaps some unsweetened caramel (?), lingering roasted grain finish. Comment: Uncompromisingly dry! This has character.
Tap at Ushi Tora. Light caramel maltiness. Little bit of hop bitterness. Quite light all round. Refreshing but maybe bit lacklustre.

Draught at Eni-bru. Bland pale-ale type beer, not much in terms of either malt or hops. I have no idea what is supposed to be Scottish about this. Very disappointing for a brewery that is usually pretty decent.
Light brown color. Earthy dark chocolate notes. Slightly sour mouth. A go nowhere chocolatey finish.

On tap: The aroma has lots of cranberry juice, cherry candy, and a hint of tootsie roll. It’s a dark hazy orangish-brown with a small beige head. The flavor has lots of cranberry with some hints of cherry syrup, There is a light herbal bitterness in the finish. Virtually no sourness. Different and interesting, but not very lambic-like.

This beer is based on a lambic with cranberry added. The aroma was too strong of cranberry. The flavor was also too much cranberry. A very sweet beer would be a good ladies beer. It was a good quality beer just not what you would expect a beer to taste like. Drinkable but would not order another.

Has a color coppery amber. A big head, which is kept enough time. The aroma is to sweet and something of fruits. The flavor is well malty, with something of excess of caramel. The hop is identified well. I would say that it is a balanced well beer. The body is average, good. The finish is with too much caramel (it is the serious mistake of the majority of the Chilean beers). Nevertheless, this beer on the average of the Chilean beers.
Hazy copper color, medium white head. Aroma is sweet of vanilla and banana. Flavor is sweet, with hints of honey and apple. Dry finish.

Appearance: coppery amber. Big head, beige, consistent and persistence. Aroma: Dominated by sweet malts and the hop. Fruity, with herbaceous and pine touches from of the hop. Candy, toasted cereal and reminiscences of pear. Flavor: sweet malted, candied, touches of the vanilla and honey. Fruity like the pear, quince and the skin orange. Liquory like whisky. Flavor begins sweet and finishes with medium and persistent bitterness. Presences of the hop that reminds herbs. Palate: Medium body, semi-oily texture. Medium carbonation. A nice surprise, it is much more than another handcrafted chilean beer. Very advisable.

WOW. Pours a total pitch, medium tan head. Aroma is milk chocolate, coffee, and a slight cherry note. Flavor is massively chocolate, sweet but not cloying, with an excellent hop balance that never makes itself known, but keeps those malts in line. very dark roasted coffee makes an appearance in the second half, next comes a lemony/grassy sensation, and a long bitter finish. This brewery definitely knows how to make a stout ("black sheep", as they call them).

Gravity cask at the Walsall Camra, beer festival 2015. Poured a clear dark brown with a bubbly off white head. The aroma is caramel malt. The flavour is moderate bitter with a light, slightly watery burnt malt, light hop bitter palate. Light bodied with soft carbonation.

First tasted this in Coanes, Johnstone in May 1994. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear mahogany in colour with a thin creamy white head. Slight note of weak coffee in the short aroma. Thin but creamy mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts deliver a rich digestive biscuit base laden with hedgerow fruit, bramble in particular. Dusty hop prickle gives a dry note to the short aftertaste. Finish is malty and moreish with maple syrup and dates. A lovely mild and well recommended.

I had a pint of this beer at the Sports man in Harborne yesterday. This beer has gone from strength to strength. The thick creamy head remained in the glass to the last drop. After i finished my pint, it felt like i had eaten a grapefruit.
16th November 2007 Warning! Early amateur rating! A fairly mild and somewhat watery IPA - a bit too Green King like.
Cask@Criterion, Leicester. Golden beer with a lightly hopped aroma and a standard bitter flavour. Overall an average watery and hopped beer.

Cask at Penderels Oak in London. Dark gold with awhite head, lots of floral hops on the nose, flavour is a good balance of sweet malt and bitter, with notes of peach, lemon and cornflakes, and a good bitter finish. A nice lighter-bodied best bitter.

Handpulled cask at JDW Hatch End, Harrow. Gold with a good thick white head in fine fresh condition. Unfortunately the flavour was a let down. This makes GK IPA seem flavoursome. One of the blandest bitters I’ve ever tried. An insult to the name of a brewer who’s beers I enjoyed back in the 80’s.

Cask at steam railway, Swindon. Golden bitter with thin head. Solvent nose. Predominant flavour of honey and biscuit. thin in the mouth. im not sure how fresh it was but the hops had all but disappeared.

Cask handpull at Penderal’s Oak, JDW, London. Gold with thin bubbly white head. It’s a golden bitter with decent citrus finish. Really quite drying on the finish, more than most bitters. Bit of yeast. Good lemony finish

Wetherspoon Festival, Nov 2007. JDW, Rochester. Not an exciting selection, but I love the idea of having 3 1/3 pints for the same price as a pint, and having the glasses marked with the special marker to show the number of the beer. This is a nice beer with Fuggles and Mount Hood hops. A soft session bitter, very drinkable. Juicy sweet, then a lovely dose of dusty hops in the finish. Chalky dry in the middle. Nice one.

Cask @ The Mansion, Gipsy Hill ,London. Nose of sulphur, citurs and metal. Pours a light amber colour beer. taste of citrus, grapefruit, some hops and malt. Quite pleasant if a little simple. Bitter and thin in the finish. Not bad.
Cobber of color with a white head. An aroma with bisquit, hops, flowers and grass notes. A flavor with corn, hops and citrus.
Bottle. Clear amber colour with small creamy off-white mostly lasting head. Malty aroma with notes of yeast. Taste is off again. 4 out of 5 beers was off.

Weich malziger Antrunk mit angenehmer aber leicht verwässerter Schokoladennote. Etwas fruchtig-kräuterartig im Mittelteil, das Mlz ist hier weiter das intensivste Aroma, leidet aber stärker als zuvor an der Wässrigkeit. Der Trend zur Wässrigkeit setzt sich auch im Abgang fort und bringt das Bier spürbar durcheinander, zum Ende wirkt es sehr schwach, da scheint die starke Röstigkeit fast schon unpassend. Ein noch unausgereiftes Bier. 7/9/6/7/7/6
Vom Fass (Abv.3,8%) im Mezzanine in Leuven/Belgien 2018-08 getrunken. Ein süffiges mildes Ale mit deutliche Citrus- und etwas Hopfenaroma. Unter dem Strich aber nichts besonderes.
Bottle. Clear, white foam. Medium carbonation. Sweet nose of lemonade, lemon juice. Strange bitter notes. Very sweet, not a beer but a lemonade.

25cl bottle Appearnce LIght diluted pale piss lfaint yellow ight with a small head, the lacing is still ok. Aroma: 7 up lemon and lime on top of malts Taste: Artifficial lime, wheat. Too sweet and articificial to be decent.t medium body,soft carbonation. Bad 7 Up is not beer.
small sample at our local bar some time ago, allready knew this should be very bad. very weird pale yellow colour, chemical lime, citrus, grains, artificial sweetness, lemonade, bad bad!!
250ml bottle. Hazy light brown color. Small size, white head, disappears. Wheaty poo, shit, sweet, sugar, lemonade in aroma. Sweet, lemon, vitamins, apple in taste. So sweet. Never again!

(Bottle, 0.25 l - BB 25/03/15, thanks Marduk, 20141227) The beer poured piss coloured and hazy. Its head was small and white. Aroma had lemon essence and yellow toilet paper. Palate was light bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were lemon essence, sweetness and very mild tartness. Aftertaste had lemon essence. A badly done wit wit bad flavour additives.

250ml bottle - thanks marduk! Fuck. Aroma is poo radler. Lemonadey, and actually pooey. Very pale. -1 for the very clear green glass bottle. Crappy lemonade taste. A bit dirty and yeasty. No idea if this is wheaty grains, barley grains, or dingleberries. Well in the horror zone. Yay - shitty beer from Marduk - muscling in on my territory - congrats on 2999!
Bottle @ ZZT X, small sample, thanks all for sharing! Hazy pale yellow color, short head. Aroma of ginger, lime. Sweet taste. Not that bad actually.
Bottle @ ZZTX. Aroma is artificial lemon, grains. Flavour is fake lemon, lemonade and wort. Yuck.

Bottle @ ZZT X, courtesey of kermis. Pours a clear golden beer with a small white head on top. Aroma of ginger and lemon. Flavor is disgustign with chemical fruity stuff going on and a light sour touch. Quite disgusting to be honest.

Aroma: Zoete fruitige neus (rijp fruit, compote), licht karamel, rustieke gistachtige noot. Uitzicht: Helder goudblond bier met mooi stevige witte schuimkraag. Smaak: Fruitig (rijp fruit, compote, abrikoos) met op het einde een licht grasachtige toets. Korte, zoete afdronk. Mondgevoel: Medium body, medium koolzuur.

Drinking one at the Gielen Eck in Luxembourg-Bonnevoie. Rather frothy head with lightly troubled golden appearance. Hoppy smell, sweet and bitter in the mouth with a flavour of stone fruits. Pity I‘m drinking it out of a bottle, I know it‘s definitely better from the vat.

330ml bottle, poured into Battin glass. A: Golden colour, slightly hazy, small head faded fast, left some lacing. S: Fruity phenols. T: Candy sugar, lingered on the palate. M: Medium to heavy body, fairly low carbonation. O: Slightly too sweet, sweetness drowned everything else out, decent but not spectacular.
Vodovy sladovy zbyteèný import co k tomu øíct... Chudák Dánsko které platí za tyto marketingové hovna ale dobøe jim tak.
500ml can (Superalko, Ikla). Pale yellow color. Medium size, white head, stays. Malty, caramel, some grains and paper in aroma and in taste. Happens.

column1: Lancaster Rare Rooster Summer Rye Ale
column5: Cloudy golden, almost orange pour. Quick white foam. Strong rye in the nose and complimentary bitter, piney hops. The malt provides some richness. Medium / light body with active fizz. Slightly sour hoppy finish.

column1: Lancaster Rare Rooster Summer Rye Ale
column5: Dry rye tang. Not all that spectacular. I would not try this one again. There are better rye beers out there.

column1: Lancaster Rare Rooster Summer Rye Ale
column5: Poured into a pint glass. Bought this for a buck at local place. Had this before, but this time is for reviewing. 3.0 A: Semi-hazy medium orange color. One finger of head that falls quickly and leaves not much lacing. I don’t remember it looking this pathetic. 3.5 S: Only a touch of rye. Doughy and buttery in a brewpubby sort of way, if that makes sense to anyone. 3.0 T: Not too big on the taste. Healthy bitter backbone. The same buttery flavor exists in the taste. Really not that great of a beer. No flavors that I want and plenty that I don’t. 3.0 M: Medium body. Undercarbonated. 2.5 D: Way too many problems. I don’t remember it being this bad. If I ever try it again, I’ll review it if it turns out any better. Serving type: bottle Reviewed on: 11-14-2009 22:48:18

column1: Lancaster Rare Rooster Summer Rye Ale
column5: Bottle to pilsner glass. You can smell the rye pretty easily. Has a different taste, but a nice finish. Spare head, colored white. Good lacing, cloudy body which is a dark y ellow / amber color. Lots of malt flavors like molasses and bread. Light hops, creamy texture, and soft carbonation. I personally wouldn’t look for more of this.

column1: Lancaster Rare Rooster Summer Rye Ale
column5: Pretty sure that Mt.McCloud provided this .. . Pours a golden yellow .. has a good foam presence .. . honey, rye bread, and light cereal notes .. . pretty light stuff, perfect for the end of a tasting .. . thanks for showin up dude...

column1: Lancaster Rare Rooster Summer Rye Ale
column5: Bottle. Is that a Blue Hen? Label certainly has enough blue and gold. Sweet spicy nose, a little rye, sure, but tons of spice I’d expect to find in a pumpkin beer (+vanilla). Amber pour still translucent, creamy and, yes, lacing beige head. Taste is much drier and bitterer than expected, a little harsh grain with some strange raspberry and blueberry notes. Touches of orange peel and pepper. Vial of liquid yeast in the finish along with some spruce. Medium-full carbonation ind a medium-full and slightly metallic body. Left sort of a dirty impression, but could be fine substitution for a summertime Wit.

column1: Lancaster Rare Rooster Summer Rye Ale
column5: Bottle. Cloudy orange copper with small head. Aroma is herbal with a ton of rye. Flavors of rye, caramel, coriander, and slight cheddar. Buttery mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Good stuff.

column1: Lancaster Rare Rooster Summer Rye Ale
column5: Bottle. Split with Tony. Pours a slightly hazy amber gold body. Aroma is sweet malt. Taste is flavorful sweet malt.

column1: Lancaster Rare Rooster Summer Rye Ale
column5: 12oz bottle thanks to my buddy ben4321. Orangish-amber color with a small, quickly dissipating off-white head. Aroma is rye bread, butter, and corn. Flavor is some rye, caramel malt, and grain, along with an overwhelming buttery diacetyl flavor that sort of kills it. Wouldn’t be too bad without that, not that it would really be that exciting either. Body is fairly watery and thin and it has a weird butteriness to the mouthfeel as well. Overall, not so good.

column1: Lancaster Rare Rooster Summer Rye Ale
column5: 12 oz bottle-amber color w/almost no head. Sour bread dough aroma. Flavors of sour/bad bread w/some rye, bad fruit... this just isn’t very good. Tasted like sour bread. I’ve had beer in bars which tasted like this...usually Yuengling in a crappy bar which doesn’t keep their tap lines clean, I always get the hell out of a place which serves beer like this, as I will in this case... this is drainpour!
Bottle. Reddish-pink, misty, pinkish foam. Aroma: sweet, elderberry and cherry, sweet candy. Taste: elderberry, cherries, lollipops and citric acid, very sweet.

Ruby red. Cloudy. Tall rocky pink head. Aroma of starchy cherries in a wheat base. Light body. Oily. Sweet fruity starchy taste. Spicy yeast behind it. Low bitterness. Not spectacular at all. But I love cheries. What can I do?
Bottle 33cl / Botella 33cl. @ Aeon Mall Nagoya Dome Mae, Nagoya, Japon. A: Hazy pink / Rosa turbio. T/S: Cherry, sweet, artificial / Cereza, dulce, artificial.

At Bruges Beer Fest. Pours clear red with an amber hue and a thin pink head. Fine aroma of cherry, strawberry, peach and blackcurrant. Tastes medium to heavy sweet. Light bitter and wheaty in the finish - not too dry, lingering red fruits. Light body, sticky texture, soft carbonation. Tasty Fruit Beer, I like it. (Edited 22/6/18)

Bottle. Cherries, candies, elderflower and marshmellows. Cherries dominate and the beer is excessively sweet, which resembles cough syrup. However, if not for the sweetness, it might have been genuinely tasty.

Bottle from Sugaya. Thick cherry nose. Hazy pink-tinged peach color, thin head, some lace. Cherryies, berries, sugar, with a gentle dry finish. Light body, tingly carbonation. Not so bad. Not very beer-like, but fairly tasty.

Sweet cherry beer (well, cherry, strawberry, plum and blackcurrant) based on Blanche de Namur. Aroma and taste of the basic beer, however, are completely overshadowed by a very sweet, artificial, sugary, cloying fruit candy taste not unlike grenadine or water ice, which leaves no room for anything else. Looks nice, with a bright and fierce cherry red under a lilac head, but I’ll never learn to appreciate these sickly sweet witbier-based design fruit beers.
Een lekker verfrissend fruitbiertje dat vooral lekker is tijdens warme zomerdagen.

Clear, golden colored, medium white head. Aroma is of some malt, bit grains, buttery. Medium sweet malt, light+ grains, buttery popcorn, light herbal bitterness, light bread in the finish. Medium to light bodied, soft carbonation, bit watery.
355ml bottle. Fresh grain aroma. Pours golden in colour with a small white head. Grainy malt flavour, not very strong. Thin body and a bit of a watery finish.
Some grain but this really doesn't come together well. Golden pour with ok head. Light tang on end. Tap at Deposito.

355ml brown bottle. Hazy gold with a thin white head. Nose - sweet, bready, grainy. Taste - grains, a bit toasty and some grassy notes. Drinks easy, not much else to write about. Could have been a pale lager or a kolsch.
Cerveza color dorado brillante muy traslúcida, de baja carbonatación y bajo lupulado. Muy fresca y con sabor y aroma moderado a cereales. Muy refrescante, pero sin mucha personalidad.

12 oz pour at Wings Army, Playa Del Carmen. A semi hazy pale yellow pour with a thin fizz head. Minerva has proven to be quite a nice collection of brews, I have learned on this trip. Straw, some corn on the aroma. Suspicious, but flavor seems to really save this. Good flavor. Refreshing. A touch of corn, but thin. Quite a carb bite here. Late cream corn reminder. A little better than what I would expect from a kolsch around here. Still, with this heat, very refreshing.
Muy fresca.... Es lo. Más característico de esta cerveza... Y muy fácil de beber.. Aunque poco sabor
Nothing to recommend of this beer. It poured a clear golden colour, with a face disappearing head and no lacing. The taste is citrus, wheat, and toffee. Doesn’t stand out.
Bottled. A crisp Kolsh! Less hop character than I was expecting. Malty and light. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Bright clear yellow, average white head. Light, corny cereal, mildly sweet with notes of paper and metal in the finish.
Taste: Malty with some German hops, caramel, clean finish. mellow fermented grain nose. Amber color hue, mostly clea, tall foamy head with nice lattice of lace.
Some rust and a decent malt complex. Pours reddish with foamy head. Goodneneough for style. On tap at Deposito in DF.
El Deposito, CDMX tap: pours deep amber with beige head. Aroma is caramel and roasty. Taste is lightly sweet. Lightly bitter.

Envase 355 servida en un Willi Becher. Color cobrizo con corona de espuma beige poco estable. Aroma dulce con notas a chicloso de caramelo, nuez y chocolate. Su sabor es inicialmente dulce a nueces caramelo y chocolate con un retrogusto ligeramente amargo y seco. Cuerpo ligero y de baja carbonatación. Una gran exponente del estilo Viena!

From tap at HOP The Beer Experience 2, Mexico D.F. Clear, deep amber to chestnut brown with a slightly off-white, stable head. The aroma is lightly malty - bread, toffee - along with a lightly fruity touch. Medium body with a light sweetness and a light bitterness. The flavor is lightly malty - caramel, dried fruits - lightly fruity along with some light, herbal hoppy notes and some cardboard. Finishes with a light herbal bitterness. Overall not entirely balanced and I didn´t like the combination of flavors. Aroma: 5 Appearance: 4 Taste: 6 Palate: 3 Overall: 9
355ml bottle purchased at City Market Interlomas, Mexico for $1.30 ($24.00pesos) Good.
Dark amber color, caramel flavour, a good beer, with good aroma............
Pours amber with a white head. It has light caramel aromas. The flavors has caramel, a bit of roast, a bit of herbal with moderate bitterness.

APARIENCIA: de color ámbar cobrizo con algunos destellos cafés a contraluz, se observa algo cristalina y una mediana actividad de carbonatación; corona de espuma color marfil, de burbujas compactas y algunas abiertas. AROMA: notas a caramelo quemado, grano tostado y nueces. SABOR: las notas a caramelo quemado predominan, además del grano tostado y algunas frutos secos como nueces; el retrogusto queda un amargor casi seco medio bajo, ligera permanencia de los sabores caramelo y tostado. SENSACIÓN: cuerpo ligero, mediana carbonatación. RESUMEN: Agradable cerveza con buena relación precio/calidad.

Muy suave al paladar para ser una cerveza ámbar. De muy buena textura, pero sobretodo su sabor, fresca y de maridaje variado. Para botanas y pastas (con pizza va muy bien) ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at El Deposito Roma, pours a pretty much opaque black with some sticky, lacing beige head. Nose is solid, malt, toast, some burnt caramel, bread, nutty. Flavor has more malt, some molasses now, bread, caramel, clear roasted almond. Finishes dry, a bit more than full bodied. Nicely made.
Taste; Smokey, bittersweet chocolate malt, rich, smooth finish. Same with the nose. dark brown hue, partly clear, tan foamy head, some lace. Medium body.

355ml bottle. Pours an unclear dark brown with amber edges and a small, creamy, short lived, tan head that leaves spotty lacing. Sweet aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, caramel and coffee. Sweet flavour of roasted malt, dark chocolate, licorice and bitter coffee in a dry, slightly sour finish. Medium body with an oily texture and soft carbonation. Simple, but this was actually good. Exceeded my expectations.
# 200; 1/2016. Výraznì kvasnicový, nakyslý helles s nepøíjemnou a zvláštní chutí konzervy sardinek (zkažená várka??).
The foam stability is good, the body light. The Aroma is malty, medium sweet. The taste is malty, sooft, no hops. Very light.

7/VII/18 - 50cl bottle @ JefVerstraete's place - BB: 7/XII/18 (2018-820) Thanks to JefVerstraete for sharing the bottle! Clear blond beer, big solid creamy irregular white head, pretty stable, adhesive, leaving a nice lacing in the glass. Aroma: metallic, some orange peel, malty, grains, bit of DMS. MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: malty, grains, sweet, cow fodder, pretty boring...
Bottle shared with tderoeck. Clear pale yellow colour, white foam. Bready, light notes of honey, bit cardboard. Boring beer.

Pours very clear, strawyellow, small white head; medium lacing. Smell is pale maltyness. Mild earthyness from the hops. Slight DMS. Taste is full, sharp, tad bitter at first. noticable DMS, than turns more malty, creamy, white breaddough. hint of metallic bitterness towards the end. Medium body and carbo.
Sampled at the brewpub. Fine white head. Clear yellow color. Small apple aroma. Hoppy taste and big bitterness for a Helles. No sweetness and small maltiness.

0,5 l Flasche. Aroma: malzig süß, erdig, leicht würzig. Erscheinung: Goldgelbes Bier, flacher, weißer, grobporiger Schaum, gute Gardine. Geschmack: malzig süß, minimal säuerlich, leicht bitter. Nachgeschmack: metallisch. Gesamt: trinkbar, mehr nicht.
sample, poured a golden colour with a white head. nose is grains, slight yeast notes, malts, citrus, light fruity, slight bitter aftertaste.
Hvala miru na ovom pivu...nismo uzalud najbolji prijatelji..još jedno njemaèko pivo od njega...pivo je pitko ..okus je zanimljiv..može drugo...
Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass zippy, small head. Starts mild, malty, modest dry. Light sourish hints, some lemon. Mild bitter background. Finish very mild, almost a bit washy. Okay.

Spent the weekend in the mountains with my sister and bother-in-law visiting from Halifax, and this is a must-do for luch. New summer seasonal on tap. Bright golden straw colour, clear, dense white head with generous lace down the entire glass. Light grassy/flowery aroma. Pale malt palate with a nice mild floral hop accent and a mild bitter finish. Not a classic rep of the style (lower-key than most), but really quite nice as a summer sessional. In my mind it comes across more like a bohemian pilsener than anything, I think.

Draft at the brewpub; very light amber and relatively still. Aroma is inviting, lightly malty with a tender hop topper. Flavors: flowery, perfumey, lightly carameled. Nice sessionable brew and a nice pint for my birthday. (#2898, 5/16/2007)
Bottle at Alex’s. Thanks. Pours a hazy yellow with a white head and lacings. Sweet and quite bitter. Aromas of cereals. Medium bodied. Soft carbonation. Long, very bitter finish.
ambrato schiuma media non molto persitente naso fruttato etilico leggero caramello lievito astringenza esteri buon corpo amaro discreto non armonica
Grande Barley wine con sensazioni olfattive di frutta secca e rossa , bocca complessa e dolce

From Jul 2007 Purchased as part of a mixed 6 Pack at Wilbur's in Ft Collins. It pours from 12oz bottle a clear light gold with not much foam to speak of and there's no lacing. The smell is as weak as the appearance. Nothing strikes my nose with any intensity. The taste...this is where it starts to shine a bit. I'm getting some good citrus. mainly lemon, hops up front and it has a good malt balance. The malt isn't sweet; it's more of an earthiness but it does well in balancing the hop presence. Mind you, this isn't a beer with the flavour of the ages but it's quite quaffable. The body is on the light side and it's lightly carbonated but it's a good one to turn to for a hot summer day. It's worthy of a try or 2.

Decent aroma, white head, virtually no lacing. Hazy body with fair carbonation. Slightly bitter flavor and similar finish. Not much happening here. Very disappointing, considering it’s from Bridgeport.

A decent EPA. The citrusness is a bit more than I would’ve wanted. Otherwise weak body, light golden orange appearance. Tried this in Taos NM riding in the back of a truck through the S. de Cristos. Could’ve influenced my appreciation of the beer...

355ml bottle sampled while on vacation in Oregon pours a golden orange color with a small white head that leaves very little lacing on the glass. Aroma is hay and some grassy hops. Taste is light malty sweet with some grassy and mild citrus hoppy bitterness. Light to medium body and light carbonation. Nothing memorable about this one, just an average pale ale.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a light clear pale gold with an average white head. Aroma of yeast, grain and some florals. Tastes is similar with some florals added. Nice light beer, not exceptional, but drinkable.

Pours hazy orange with a thin beige head that fades leaving something looking like a cropcircle. Aroma of grain, grass, very little citrus. Taste has orange, grain, grass. Medium thin body, pretty forgettable .

Lemon-hay to start. A brilliant straw, yellowish white head. Esters start followed by a clean grainy flavor. Clean and crisp. A good blone - lightly hopped with a creamy finish that is still refreshing.

12oz bottle. Hazy dulled orange color. Soapy, patchy, off-white head. Respectable orange-citrus hop aroma. Medium bodied and quite mild, this is a pretty nice session beer. Low carbonation. Maybe a hint of lemony wheat. A little too tame.

12 oz bottle that Mark brought for band practice - Smells like it’s name. A little hay aroma mixed with some barnyard. Yellow in color hinting toward orange. A bit sticky on the palate. Tastes better than the rest of the categories. Not a great beer, but drinkable.
Light body, lightly bitter flavor initially and finishing. Watery texture, flat carb, no head, medium yellow in color. I remember calling this one "imitation beer" upon tasting this.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Un-Muzzling Olde Muzzlehatch Ratings, #39. 473 ml can purchased somewhere in Ontario (July 2008), and consumed in a hotel room in Wisconsin or Minnesota, near Duluth (August 2009). Clear golden body with a frothy white head that sticks around for a bit...malty-sweet, just lightly grassy-hoppy aroma, fairly weak...pleasant, fairly full body, accent on the pale malts, and just a bit syrupy...not bitter, hoppy or dry enough in the end to save it, though it’s not horrible. I guess I’ll probably never get to try it again; doesn’t seem like it was a patch on their Premium Lager though, which I have had a few times and wouldn’t mind finding again.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Similar to the Lot 9 Pilsner. Very easy to drink with no aftertaste. Like every other Creemore product I have tried, this does not disappoint. MB

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: A decent, solid Pilsner from a home brewery. Taste is clean and bread-y and a bit bitter on the finish. Pretty refreshing overall and decent- not particularly hoppy. OK.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Like Hippy Hop -- the review below mine -- I’m always on the look out for a decent pilsner & am usually underwhelmed by what I find. This beer offers little hope on improving this sense of lost hope. Has that vitamin C absorbic acid flush that a good pils has but then it just falls flat. Meh.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Was pretty sure this wasn’t going to be the holy grail in my quest for a great pilsner, and it isn’t. Pour is dark gold with a small, quick-fading cap. Nose is virtually non-existent. Pale grain and....pale grain? Taste is clean, light cereal with a slightly bitter/spicy finish. Passable pils.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Pilsners have never excited me. Preferable to a Pale Lager but not by much. There just doesn’t seem to be a depth of flavour. some of the better ones from Europe or NA micros are okay, but really only okay. This is a clean yellowish gold, a frothing white head makes for a pretty appearance. The looks soon fade away and give rise to a mediocre beer that tastes and smells of fairly tame cereal graininess, corn and very mild spiciness. The texture seems a but "meh" as this just sort of vanishes down the throat without notice.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Can. Clear gold pour with a medium white head. Nothing too special but a decent cereal aroma and taste. Easy on any hops. Fairly light and refreshing if not overly flavorful.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: A decent Canadian take on a pilsner. Doesn't have nearly enough bitterness or crispness on the palate.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: 473 ml can from LCBO. Pours a blond colour with medium white head. Aroma is cereal, wheat. Clear and crisp. Pretty good pils.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Poured from can. Cereal and hay aroma. Clear and golden with white head. Very light bitter taste. Light body, thin texture, lively carbonation, with an abrupt finish. Pretty average overall.

Draft at Wrigleyville. Had this after freezing and leaving early from a late May Cubs-Sox game. Despite rating this a little lower than the La Deuxieme I had before it, I enjoyed this more. Easy drinking but with flavor. An excellent session ale at only 5.0%. Moderate hop profile invites you to keep them coming. Slightly hazy amber body. Excellent lace.

Odell Small Batch Festival. Copper, thin head, low carbonation. Candy aroma, floral, soft. Taste is lightly bitter with earthy, herbal hops. Traditional English malts. Fruitiness creeps into the finish. Lots of balance here, good session bitter. Very to-style.

Odell Small Batch Fest. Yellow, thin head, clear with lots of carbonation. Light sour aroma, lots of tangy and pungent hops. Smells IPA. Taste is certainly lager- bitter, minerals, german malts. Light sour finish. Palate pretty soft, but needs to have much less carbonation. Late fruitiness. Interesting.

Growler.. the more the merrier for this beer. Aroma is sweet. Every time I bring it to my nose I get a whiff of honey. Appearance is nothing out of the ordinary for an amber ale. Caramel color that is translucent. Taste is nice.. real nice! Of course this is coming from someone who likes a big hop profile, and this one’s got it. Medium to light body, goes down smooth with big hops following through at the end. This beer goes great with a nice, spicy burger (Burgatory, anyone?).
The most unique amber i have ever tasted... the dry hop technique has brought this beer on as one of Ray’s best. the hop flavor is tremendous.
Goldgelbes Bier mit ordentlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch getreidig, hopfig, grasig. Geschmack getreidig, grasig, leicht hopfig, Stroh.

0.5 l bottle at Timo A’s. Pale golden color. Delicate aroma of honeyish malt and restrained peppery hops. Taste of peppery hops and herbal bitterness with honeyish malt more on the background. Light to medium body. Fairly good pils.

50 cl bottle @ Timo A. Pours clear golden color with a small head. Hay and lemon on the nose, faint pale malts and some grassy hops. Hay on the flavor also, hops and mild malty notes. Crisp, good. 3414
Many thanks for this bottle to Beerhunter111. Golden colour. Nice, stable white head. The flavour is grainy with some flowery hop notes. Medium bitterness.

Bottle 500ml. @ home. Clear medium yellow color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, toasted, light moderate hoppy, grass. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20100723]

Bottle - thanks Pivnizub. Pale yelloq, thin frothy head. Grainy and herbal bitter nose. Light bready base with a convincing bitterhop counterpoint. Light and sparkly fresh on the palate. Bitterhop dry finish.
bottle, thanks to MoritzF and pivnizub. Clear and golden yellow, small head. Low carbonation. Full-bodied and malty, with hints of spicy hops.

(bottle, purchased at the brewery) Clear, golden colour with a medium-sized foamy white head. Aroma of citrousy hops with a moderately sweet, also fruity (pears), biscuit-like malt appearance. Sweet and slightly bitter flavour, light to medium bodied with a quite flat carbonation. Malt-accented, slightly strawy taste; sweet, slightly bitter finish with herbal hops that are not accented enough.

Bottle (purchased at the brewery): Golden coloured, smaller white head; intensive sweet-malty and bready nose with a big touch of herbal hops; moderate bitter-sweet flavour, light to medium-bodied with a solid malty base; distinctive sweet-malty/bready/buttery finish with a lingering bitter aftertaste. A well balanced, chewy brew........

50cl MHD01/2018, merci Pmob aus WF. - Has its moments and even some standput malt and hop character, only the mf like soggy porridge is so stale that it all falls apart. - Brackish amber-auburn. Not much of a nose apart from soaked Landbierkruste von vorgestern. - Starts soggy, then promising marzipan and nettle, even lemon, some pepper, then watery bread again soaked in aluminium rainwater. Schade.

Many thanks for this beer to kevnic2008. Przeterminowane piwo a takie pozytywne robi wrazenie ze hej. Po pierwsze wielka trwala spora czaoa piany. Biszkoptowo pigwowy aromat. W smaku mnostwo opiekanych tostow, nieco karmelu. Niewiele goryczki, no alez coz wymagac to kellerbier w koncu. Spora metnosc do tego.

Tap from a bar at Campo S. Margarita (€ 5). Accompanied by a superb pizza. Hazy amber colour with a big off-white head. Both retention and lacing ok. Nose - very mildly grainy. Malty taste, with a herbal bitter finish. Soft in the mouth, skinny thin carbonation. Very malty overall impression, but the finish did bring in some hops. Sub-par. The last 1/4 was horrific.

Wat wollen die uns eigentlich erzeahlen ? Ein klassisches Maerzen mit einer milden Sueffigkeit, etwas Malz und ein paar Rosinen im Hintergrund. Recht sueffig, milder Abgang, einfache Trinkbarkeit, aber sicher kein Klassiker.

Bottle from Erzengel - many thanks! The beer has got a deep amber-brown colour with a low head and medium body. Aroma of malt, bread and hops. Taste of mild hops, roasted barley, malt, bread, nuts and mild fruits. Smooth to drink, drinkable.

Leicht trübes orangegoldenes Bier mit ordentlicher beiger Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht röstmalzig, Karamell, getreidig, floral. Geschmack leicht nach Karamell und leicht röstmalzig, etwas wässrig werdend, leicht grasig.
Süßlich malziger Antrunk, mild herb, süffig. Dumpfer Mittelteil, etwas bitter. Unauffälliger Nachgeschmack, malzbetont. Trinkbar. 9/8/9/8/6/8

(bottle, a gift from the brewery exactly on the day of expiring date with the premise of drinking it with responsibility, otherwise to pour it away) Clear, golden colour with a foamy white medium-sized head. Moderately sweet, strawy malty aroma , slightly bready, slightly fruity with a spicy and shy hoppy touch. Sweet flavour, medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Robust malty and strawy taste with a noticeable herbal, spicy blend; malt-accented, initially sweet finish with a light hoppy blend and a moderately bitter aftertaste. Filled on the 16th of January, bb the 18th of May, it tastes still very fresh (19.05.07).

Bottle: Deep golden coloured, small, but firm white lacing head; delicate nose of sweet-malt with traces of toasted malt and herbal hops detectable; solid bitter-sweet flavour, light to medium-bodied; becomes drier towards the lingering bitter-hoppy finish. A well balanced and tasty Märzen.......

Muffiger Malzantrunk, wenig würzig. Das Bier wirkt alt, kaum karbonisiert, nicht überzeugend. Etwas Hefe, zum Ende auch eine leichte Schokoladennote. Potential ist vorhanden, mehr aber nicht. 12/10/9/7//9

Probably the best seasonal beer this local brewery has come up with. Brown/amber coloring. Nice taste of roasted grain, only slightly hoppy. Starts sweetish and leaves a soft sour mouthfeel afterwards. Very drinkable, does however only have moderate body. A bit less watery texture would have made this beer quite a blast. Nevertheless a fine Schwarzhafer from tap (only).

Draught @ Grafschafter Brauhaus, Nordhorn, Germany. Unclear light to medium amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, berry - fruity, strawberry stew. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and light bitter with a average to short duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. (210208)

Brewery tap. Brown color. Grainy aroma with orange. Grainy sweet flavor, sugary with orange and maple syrup. Milky. Just a bit thin. Pleasant beer, the slight sourness caused by the oats makes drinking this beer worthwile.
Bottle from Beerhunter111. Many thanks! Clear golden colour, white foam. Very grainy low alcohol beer. Light bitter, some malty sweetness. Not very bad for a non alcohol beer.

0.5 l bottle from local ’trinkgut’, best before November 2017. Clear, golden yellow with a medium large, frothy, slowly diminishing, white head. Sweetish, slightly grassy aroma of grains and some straw. Minimally sweetish, quite dry, moderately bitter and a bit watery taste of grains and some straw, followed by a short, moderately bitter, minimally grassy and very dry finish. Thin body, slightly effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Very neutral but drinkable.
500ml Flasche von McTapps. Goldgelbes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, getreidig, leicht süß. Geschmack malzig, leicht süß, leicht herb. Nicht schlecht für ein Alkoholfreies.
Pilsgelbe Farbe. Ein Duft von Hopfen und Gärungskohlensäure. Getreidig malzige Noten mit leicht hopfig herben Nachklang. Zwar vom ersten Schluck an als bleifrei zu erkennen, aber insgesamt ok.
Bottle shared with McTapps. Simple and surprisngly sweetish nonalc with maybe some aroma of sweets and liqorice. Strange one but drinkable.
Bottle shared with MichaelBruch. Deep golden colour with steady head. Sweet nose. Taste of sugared cereals, rice, malt and light hops. Very sweet, but drinkable. Nothing special.
Huge white head, sparkling clear golden colour. Sweet malt aroma. Fruity taste and pleasant palate. Very good non-alcoholic beer.
500 ml bottle. Pours clear golden with an enormous white head, very sparkly. Fruity aroma. Tastes fruity, but a bit flat. Mildly bitter fruity finish.
Sweet malty aroma with grainy and caramel notes. Grainy flavour with metal and cleaner hints.

Das Alkoholfreie schmeckt getreidig und im Abgang herb, im Grunde wie viele andere Alkoholfreie. Dabei wirkt es nicht so penetrant wie manch andere Alkoholfreie und kann locker mit so genannten "Premium" Biere mithalten. Süffig, trinkbar, könnte aromatischer sien, aber das könnte wohl jedes Alkoholfreie. Test vom 25.9.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,10,10,8,5,9 - 8,95

Im Geruch schon etwas abstoßend - eine Freundin bezeichnete es als "Mittelding zwischen Kuhsch*** und Erbrochenem"... Der Geschmack ist sehr scharf, mit Anklängen an Hühnerfrikassee, malzig-süßlich. Der Nachgeschmack ist sehr penetrant-scharf-süßlich. [In der Testrunde haben 4 von 5 Menschen ihr Glas weggeschüttet]. --> war nicht so ganz unser Geschmack… Test vom 24.1.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,1,7,3,12,2 - 4,25

Malzig-klebriger Antrunk, der den Alkoholgehalt nicht verbirgt, es noch nicht einmal versucht. Gleich darauf wird der Doppelbock aber sehr mild, neben der Würzigkeit ist das Bier doch tatsächlich wässrig. Unharmonisch geht es weiter, der Nachgeschmack, wo solche Biere meist noch einmal punkten können, ist tatsächlich etwas stärker, jedoch ist auch dieser wässrig, die Röstmalzigkeit lässt gar einen sauren Note noch Platz. Merkwürdiges, aber nicht gutes Bier. Test vom 30.8.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 7,5,6,4,9,5 - 5,40
bottle, thanks to the Ruhrgebiet! Clear dark brown colour, mid-sized head. Malty nose. Sticky sweetness and maltyess present. Hints of dried fruit, slightly sicy with some herbal accents. Quite nice.

(swing top bottle) Clear, dark amber colour with a small, slightly off-white head. Sweet, slightly roasted dark malt aroma with caramel (leaves the impresion of German malt bonbons) and a light spicy herbal hoppy touch in the background. Sweet and slightly bitter flavour, medium to full bodied with a well-carbonated and matured mouthfeel. Solid dark and slightly roasted malty base with caramel and hints of liquorice and herbal notes in the background; sweet-bitter, rounded toast-malty and elegantly hopped finish. The first brew from Altötting that convinces me.

Bottle. Clear medium to dark amber red color with a average, frothy / creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, sweet malt, light alcohol. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. (201207)

Bügelverschlußflasche: Amber coloured,clear, smaller off-white lacy head, sweet-caramelly to dark-malty nose with a tinge of spicy hops; solid bitter-sweet flavour, medium bodied; spicy hoppy-bitter finish underpinned by caramel and dark malt. Really a good Bock, the first brew from Hell, which is tasty...........

Swing top bottle. Dark brown color, no head. Malt, molasses and licorice in the aroma. malty sweet flavor, bready with roasted malt, apple syrup and licorice. Alcohol is fairly well hidden. The beer is not without complexity.

Bottle from Fleggaard, Süderlügum. Pours a deep orange amber with a small fizzy yellow head. Powerful bready aroma with rye, fruit and a little flowery hops. Flavour is sweet and bready with a distant metallic aftertaste. Finishes vinious and remotely bitter.
Bottle. Semi clear amber coloured with a medium sized head. Quite malty with notes af bread and grain.

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of fiulijn. Clear, dark orangey brown with an off-white head. Clean and very malty nose. Quite full-bodied with roasted malt and lightly burned caramel accents - very, very German. Almost no bitterness. 030707
Bottle, 50 cl, bought at Getränkeland, Binz. Overall pleasant, herbal accents quite prominent, medium carbonation and finish. Would have preferred a somewhat sweeter aroma.
Butelka 0,5 litra. Z³ota, klarowna barwa. Naprawdê spora bia³a piana. Lekko s³odowy aromat, z nut¹ kukurydzy. W smaku trochê jednak zbyt ma³o wyrazu. S³aba goryczka.

0,5 l bottle purchased somewhere in the Erzgebirge. Clear dark golden to copper in the glass, nearly two finger foamy pale beige head. Smells grassy grainy caramell with metallic parts. Taste has caramell, malt, fruity elements like apple. Low bitterness. Smooth and easy drinking stuff.
Piwo koloru herbaty, klarowne z solidn¹ bia³¹ pian¹. Wygl¹da jak dawny oktoberfest. Aromat i smak s³odowy, zbo¿owy, nuty karmelu oraz chmielu. Finisz lekko wytrawny. W sumie zaskoczenie na plus
Clear orange-golden, white head. Dark malt, caramel, coffee, resin, spruce, citrus. Medium bitterness, light to medium sweetness, medium sourness. Medium body, lively carbonation, sour finish.
Bottle @ Bockstival Afterparty with MrOrla. Pours Clear Golden with a creamy White head. White bread, Grass and grains. Dry and bitter finish. Very fine.

„Gessner Original Festbier", Bügelverschlußflasche (50 cl) von Getränke Hoffmann, Berlin. - Kupferrotgold, klar. - In der Nase breiteres Karamelmalz, eher derber Hopfen mit etwas Orangeat und ranziger Hopfenextrakt. - Antrunk karamelmalzig mit Anklängen an Seifenlauge. Wenig süß. Recht derbe malzige Bittere geht über in eigenartige leere, schwach orangenfruchtige Hopfenbittere. Vollmundig, leicht fuselig. Aromatisch leerer, dumpf bitterer Abgang, dem der billige Hopfenextrakt eine ranzige Note verleiht. - Grobschlächtig und leer, alles andere als festlich.

Dziwi¹ mnie niskie oceny tego piwa. Mój egzemplarz (warka do 2.11.16) jest smaczny i poprawny jak na swój styl. Aromat mocno s³odowy, lekko skontrowany zio³owym chmielem. W tle byæ mo¿e jakieœ niewielkie owoce czy nawet alkohol. Piwo bursztynowe, klarowne, o obfitej i d³ugo pozostaj¹cej pianie, osiadaj¹cej na szkle. Smak - czysty profil lagerowy, mocno s³odowy, z dobrze wyrównuj¹c¹ go goryczk¹, która jest mo¿e nawet ciut za du¿a i d³uga (ale tylko na ten styl). Piwo smaczne, g³adkie, z umiarkowanym wysyceniem - wizualnie wydawa³o siê, ¿e gazu mo¿e byæ za du¿o, ale w ustach nie przeszkadza.

Bottle. Clear gold-copper, low, quite nice but short-lasting head,some lacing.Aroma malty at first, a bit hoppy, later toasty, bready, nuts, quite pleasant.Taste smooth, full, sweetish but not annoyingly so, bready, a bit of metallic hops, typical for a lager. Carbonation medium, bitterness medium, fitting. Aftertaste malty, bready, a hint of nuts, slightly roasty, a little hoppy, grassy. Surprisingly nice Märzen, worth trying.
Aus der Flasche getrunken (Getränkehandel). Dunkelorange mit sehr stabilem Schaum im Glas. Verwässerte Malzigkeit im Antrunk.
theres the usual spiciness and yeast going on here (nothing offensive) but all in all it’s a pretty lightweight boring beer. definitely one of their weaker offerings."

(Old BA rate - tap) Poured with a thin pure white bubblier looking head. Coppery color, that it is a bit more like a Belgian pale ale, etc. Sweetish maltiness at first; unripe apple and grape aromas; fresh and a bit herbal. All things were a bit muted, though. Tart and just a bit sour; grape flavors; a bit yeasty; and pretty refreshing. Thinner MF, but still had a more substantial body. Snappy carbonation. Good drinkability for me, refreshing brew and there were enough interesting flavors to keep me interested.
Draft. Pours an orange body with a white head. Fruity esters peach, citrus, and some wheat notes. Apple and malt with a medium mouth feel and a light spiced finish. Nice session ale.

TAP: gold pour, no head. Coriander on the nose, same on taste, thin body. Tastes metallic. I’m hoping there was something wrong with this sample/pour, because this seemed like a pretty weak attempt at a dubbel.
Pours a clear lemon orange yellow. Aroma is creamy vanilla and grassy notes. Flavor is citrus hops. Body is light with fair carbonation.

On tap @ Victory. Clear amber brown with an off white head. Sweet yeasty aroma, very earthy and a candy sugar sweetness. Mostly sweet flavor with some hop bitterness and some sourness too. Medium body with mild carbonation and an extremely smooth well balanced finish.

[2375-20090801] Sample. Mild dog fur aroma and petrol and grains. Clear, golden orange body with a quick bubbly white head. More generic grainy malt in the flavour. Medium body. Doesn’t seem to be in wonderful shape. (BCTC @ Ommegang; Cooperstown, NY)

A decent offering from Victory. On tap at Coopers. Belgians are not my favorite but I like Victory so I really wanted to sample this one. Now that I did....I can forget about it just as quickly as I drank it.

2009-08-01. Dark orange amber body with a modest beige head. (3+) Aroma is surprisingly mild, touches of dry malt. (6+) Flavour is similar, pleasant dry malt, lightly alcoholic finish. Toasty malt touches. Modest malty base. Average plus palate. (3+) Enjoyably quaffable, but relatively mild and fails to wow in a crowd of much bolder beers. Still, I could seeing drinking a few of these in an evening quite happily. Seems like a cross between a dubbel and an abbey ale perhaps? On tap at BCTC 2009
Pouring at their booth at BCTC. Pours a clear light caramel color. Caramel and candy on the nose. Medium bodied and sweet, with a touch of grain before a light bitter finish.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Draught sample at the brewpub, July 26th. This was billed as just "Monk" on my visit, and I suppose it’s possible that it’s a different beer. But my guess is that it just varies a bit from batch to batch - and name to name - not enough to warrant a new listing. At any rate, what I had poured a moderate to dark gold, rather hazy/oily, with virtually no head...nose is fairly alcohol and sweet, a bit of that candy sugar perhaps, little of that yeasty Belgian character I’d expect...and the same is true in the body, which is very sweet, syrupy, and fairly harsh; boozy and cloying, with an off vegetal finish. Pretty terrible, but thankfully the worst sample we had.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On draft at the brewery it is a cloudy golden with an off white head. Light aroma is bubblegumthe taste is sweet and has hints of fruits Smooth finish

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On draft at the brewery. Pours a hazy gold with an off white head. Light bubblegum aroma. Flavors of sweet tropical fruits. Smooth finish.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On draught at the brewpub in downtown Mt. Horeb, Wisconsin. Pours a clear golden pale brew with a fast dissolving white head that nearly dissipates clean with no ring or lacing. Aroma of candi sugar, some apple, a hint of banana esters, and some wintergreen. Taste is full bodied, quite sweet with flavors of candi sugar, a hint of wintergreen, banana and some alcohol presence. Finish is still quite fruity sweet, syrupy with a lingering aftertaste of candi sugar, banana and yeast.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Hazed straw color with a small lid of white bubbles. Big estery aromas. Lots of over-ripe light fruit with hints apples and bananas. Some lightly earthy honey and malt also in the nose. Light fruit flavors as well. Some honey, pale malt, and floral flavors as well. Some decent flavors. A touch of alcohol. Thick, smooth feel, with just a little zip. While the aromas are a bit unbecoming, the flavors make up for it. Finish and lightly dry with a bit of floral flavors. A sipper for a cool day.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at the brewpub, pours cloudy, and smells like feet. Guess that’s not a stretch given the name. The taste is interesting, it’s sweet then quickly sour, fruity, candi sugared, it gets sweeter as it warms too. Talking to one of the brewers, he said it was just brewed, so it was a young beer, he said try it again in a week or two. I will the next time I’m in town. It’s ok.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at the Grumpy Troll brewpub. Cloudy yellow with a white dissipating head. Aroma of alcohol and fruit. Taste of fruit, malt and alcohol with a bubbly body that finishes a bit fruity.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Tap. Gold/orange in color with a medium head.yeasty aroma and a nice creamy palate.Tastes like a good weiss beer with a fruty finish I’m very happy that it tastes more like a weiss than anything Belgian. Also over 10% Alc but no alc flavor to take away from the rest of the beer! This is one great beer and me and my growler are within walking distance. Now if you’ll excuse me...

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Wow. What a different looking beer. It looks like a orange-banana juice and leaves a cloudy appearance on the glass. It looks very cloudy and banana yellow. Taste is banana, clove, pear. Quite tasty!

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at grumpy troll. Pours out a deep orangish yellow with little head. Some additional filtration would have helped. Aroma is actually quite good. Banana, clove, pear, and light cherry make an appearance.

Bottle from hbmason and jtwattsrugger...thanks Tim and John! - Pours hazy amber with a real thin white head. Light nuttiness, toasted malt, hay, honey, herbal hops. Just a hint of heat. Light toasty malt, pretty dry and clean. Herbal hop finish with a dry, bready light toasted finish. Crisp mouthfeel, though the carbonation is dialed up a bit much. Pretty enjoyable but not my favorite style.

Bottle shared by jcwattsrugger via maniac. Pour clear gold with a medium, fizzy white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma and flavor are heavy malt (biscuit, toast, caramel, cookie), floral hops, fruity esters, and buttered corn. Medium body, warmth, and carbonation with a sweet finish.
Bottle thanks to John. Pours honey amber. White head. Thin layer of retention. Nose of grain, honey and malt. Taste is lightly sweet honey, grain and malt. Light and smooth.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Really enjoyed this. It was malty, yet not sweet. Was surprised at the quality, given such a relatively small and remote spot. Only available at the micro-brewery/restaurant. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Clear dark amber with a big bubble head and lots of dots of lace. The odor is clearly smoked malt, but the smoke hardly shows in the taste - taste is pruney-sweet caramel malt that doesn’t change through the finish. Solid for the low alcohol, but I’d like it to have a little more going on,...almost session-like. Recommended.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Bottle: &nbsp Dirty caramel, moderate to thin off-white head, sparce lacing. &nbsp Musty nose, a little earthy, some wet cardboard and pilaf like elements. &nbsp Semi-sweet early malt start on the tongue. &nbsp Has an earthy aspect that is perhaps more akin to a basement. &nbsp Ceratinly malty, but not really peaty nor does it have charred wood/campfire. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate, although it does seem fairly sturdy. &nbsp Finishes with a bit more hop aspect. &nbsp Remains slightly earthy, musty, basement, with a semi-sweet malt background. &nbsp Tiz okay, but it is fairly simply. &nbsp Thanks Bob!

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at brewpub, pours a deep cloudy copper color with a thin white htead, aroma is of sweet malt with a hint of smoke, the flavor has great smoke notes that are not overwhelming and the malt balance is very nice, good beer.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: draft at the brepub. this pours hazy orangish copper sm off white head. nose has caramel and smoke. flavor smoky toffee nuts and cookies, light and easy drinking brew good.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Tap at the brewpub - Pours hazy amber with a frothy off-white head. Smells fruity, with lemon and honey on top of a sweet, malty base. It’s a bit too much, and comes off as a bit cloying. Taste is lots of bready malt with a bit of nuttiness. Finish is kind of flat and minerally, with a slight smokiness. Really carbonated and biting, which made it hard to pull flavors out initially. It warmed up a bit and the carbonation eased off and became a lot softer. Overall, however, this one was just flat and uninspired.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a cloudy amber color with thin white head that leaves chunks of lace here and there. Aroma is rich, sugary malt with a tiny touch of molasses. Flavor is malty, sugary, a touch of molasses, a little bit of dry grain following up, and very modest hop bitterness. I didn’t detect much of the smoke they talk about in the commercial description, which is unusual because smokey flavors usually hit me like a freight train. So I don’t consider it a loss that the smoke was basically absent. Palate is thick but a little flat. Nice, drinkable.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Unfiltered amber-brown color. Smooth malty aroma. Thick, sweet Bock-like flavor. A touch of smoke. Relatively clean for the style, not overly sweet or sticky. Excellent.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: This was my second selection and i thought it was great. Not as overwhelmingly smoky as some scotch ales i have tried but the flavor was definitely there. The apprerance was nice with a thick head and full mouth feel. A good example of the style, even more enjoyable that some because the brewer does not go overboard on the peat.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at the brewpub 7/31/09: Pours a transparent bright copper amber with a thin, wispy lacing white head. Aroma of sweet toasty caramel malt with some light piny hop character. Starts with good fullness and sweet caramely maltiness before a slightly drier bittersweet and crisp finish. An enjoyable Scotch ale, but could use a little more peaty character.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: 11/11/18. On tap at the brewery. Clear dark golden pour with a small white head that fades to a ring and laces okay. Corn chip aroma, touches of hay, pale malts, grass. Light flavor showing pale malts, corn chips, a hint of grass/lemon. Not bad.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Draft pours golden with a white head. Aroma of grains, grass and some caramel. Basically a lawnmower beer

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at the brewery, pours a clear gold with some soapy white head. Nose is yeasty, light bread, lemon. Flavor is approachable US lager, grist, yeast, biscuit, lemon. Dry finish.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Clear yellowish pour with white head. Typical lager. Budweiser like flavor not bad. Had this as part of a flight at Grumpy Troll in Mount Horeb, WI.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Tap at brewery. Pours clear straw color. Good lacing. Can't get much from the nose. Thin flavor and dry aftertaste. Ok.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Draft sampled at a tasting event. From notes. Light hops and loads of grain. Watery. Meh, nothing to seek out.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Has a really light grain wheat a scent, taste is similar as well, almost like a macro. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Clear straw, no head, thin streaks of lace. "The lager that forgot its taste." A true lite beer with a touch of bitter malt in the finish. I could detect no hops, but the flavor is so gentle, it’s hard to tell. Good for hot summer drinking (or maybe gulping!), but, otherwise, not enough to keep one’s interest.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Sampled from the tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear pale yellow with a white head that dissipates to the edges and barely laces. Aroma has notes of bread and grain with a bit of crisp lager yeast. Flavor starts with haysnd grain with crisp lager yeast and a bit of grassy hops in the finish.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Enjoyed on tap as part of a sampler at Grumpy Troll in Mt. Horeb, WI. Appearance very cloudy slightly dark gold with no head, like a juice. Aroma nothing really there. Taste goes down very crisp, light hay, bit of noticeable hops, really good for the style. Very good.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Un-Muzzling Olde Muzzlehatch Ratings, #88. Draught sample at the brewpub, mid-August 2008. Near-opaque blackness, big lasting tan head...nose of sweet, charred and roasted raisins, burnt malts, light red wine tannins...body is much less sweet, and a bit less interesting, mostly toasty and bitter malts, something reminiscent of cigarette ash...fairly light, strongly carbonated for style, but not thin; it works, overall.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Had this as part of a flight at Grumpy Troll in Mount Horeb, WI. Black and thick with brown bubbly head. Coffee and cocoa aroma. Coffee and malty creamy tastes. Delicious

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Bottle. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate aroma. Roasted malty chocolate flavor. Has a roasted malty bitter chocolate finish with hoppy hints.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Sample from 65 cl. bottle. Pitch black with a big, creamy tanned head. Roasted aroma with red berries, roasted malts, fruits, herbal hops. Taste is bitter. Medium body with a creamy texture. Finishes dry and roasted. Very enjoyable Stout.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Bottled. Dark brown coloured. Dense light brown head. Aroma. Sweetness, roast, chocolate. Flavour. Roast, sweetness, light herbs, chcolate. Medium bodied. Ends light roasted bitter.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Sample from Bottle - black pour with tan head. Roasted malty aroma and taste, some choc, coffee, caramel burnt sugar, roasted finish. Ok.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Bottle 65 cl. Pours an opaque black with a very lively and lacing beige head. Subtle, sweet vanillaish aroma. Medium body, very dry roast and a bitter - malt bitter finish. Appears bigger than it is. 081114

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Split a bomber with SHERM1016...Thanks! Pours black with muddy tan head....some minor lacing. Nose is chocolate and coffee....sweet initial taste are the same.....nicely smooth with large mouthfeel; sweet aftertaste....very tasty....

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: 22oz bottle, from the brewpub, spit with dwm1034. Pours a jet black color with a big tan head. Aroma is malty, chocolate, licorice, coffee. Medium on the palate with creamy carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, chocolate, coffee, a little smokey, licorice, with a bittersweet, chocolate finish.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Tap at brewery. Pours black with tan head. Tastes like roasted coffee with some dark chocolate.

column1: Grumpy Troll Spetsnaz Export Stout (Bourbon Barrel)
column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Un-Muzzling Olde Muzzlehatch Ratings, #89. Draught sample at the brewpub, mid-August 2008. Interesting that they had both this and the "regular", non-bourbonized version on tap at the same time. Anyway in this case the bourbon does no favors; the stable head on the regular Spetsnaz is replaced by a quick-dying one here, the body seeming just as inky and opaque but thinner...nose is all bourbon, perhaps some raisiny-grapy notes are in there but they’re pretty hard to find...body is also boozy and vinous, very sweet, though it does dry out and some toasty malts come in for a nice finish. Ehh, in the end it’s not bad but definitely simpler and less interesting than the "regular" version.

column1: Grumpy Troll Spetsnaz Export Stout (Bourbon Barrel)
column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Snifter at GT. Opaque brown-black body. Not much head, gone after a few minutes. Smooth and sweet, nice mixture between caramel, chocolate. Lightish on the booze. Smooth, middle of the road, but quite alright.

column1: Grumpy Troll Spetsnaz Export Stout (Bourbon Barrel)
column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at brewpub, pours black with a thin dark brown head, the aroma is roasty with some bourbon and chocolage, the flavor has a front end that is a ton of bourbon and not alot else, there is a little bit of chocolate in the finish, completely unbalanced for me with way too much bourbon and not enough chocolate and malt.

column1: Grumpy Troll Spetsnaz Export Stout (Bourbon Barrel)
column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Black pour with orange-tan head. Aroma of light bourbon, Sharp vanilla, and yellow cake batter. Flavor is an acidic roast with red wine-like flavors, wood tannin. Some light bourbon. Acidic finish.

column1: Grumpy Troll Spetsnaz Export Stout (Bourbon Barrel)
column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On draught at the Malt House: Pours a thick opaque black colour with a large creamy brown head. Aromas of oak, whiskey, and bbq smoke. Taste is rich with strong bourbon flavors and barbeque. Nutty, burnt toast and coffee grounds.

column1: Grumpy Troll Spetsnaz Export Stout (Bourbon Barrel)
column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Draft pour from the Brewpub. Pours black with a slight white head. Aroma of Chocolate and wisps of bourbon. Nice, smooth chocolate and bourbon flavor with some malt tones. A very good stout.

column1: Grumpy Troll Spetsnaz Export Stout (Bourbon Barrel)
column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Name: Bourbon Stout Date: 08/08/2008 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: black, wispy beige head, Aroma: sweet chocolate and vanilla aroma, touch of bourbon, light roasted blended with oak, Flavor: rich chocolate and bourbon flavor, nice vanilla sweetness, light oak, roasted come in from behind to add the balance, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.6/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ***/4

column1: Grumpy Troll Spetsnaz Export Stout (Bourbon Barrel)
column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On draught at the brewpub in downtown Mt Horeb, Wisconsin. Pours a semi-clear dark cola brown brew with virtually no head. Aroma of toasted dark malt and just a touch of bourbon and oak. Taste is medium bodied, no carbonation with flavors of toasted dark malt, vanilla, oak wood and some bourbon. Finish is slightly watery with a more distinct toasted dark malt and just barely any bourbon in the aftertaste. Not an in-yer-face bourbonized stout but just a dark beer with some light bourbon character.

column1: Grumpy Troll Spetsnaz Export Stout (Bourbon Barrel)
column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at the Grumpy Troll Brew Pub. Poured a dark black color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of roast, chocolate, wood, light bourbon, and light smoke. Tastes of wood, bourbon, vanilla, chocoalte, and roasty. Bourbon was not overpowering.

column1: Grumpy Troll Spetsnaz Export Stout (Bourbon Barrel)
column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Draft. Black with a full light brown head Aroma is a mix of malt, bourbon and wood. Full body. Has a malt start a strong bourbon middle and a wood finish.

Rich coffee aroma, dark chocolate, darkest brown, red at the edges. Good taste of roasted malt, fine coffee and dark chocolate. Medium bodied, well balanced, bitter and sour. Terrific! Keep up the fine work Perry!

Sample @ C’est, where it was called "Downtown" Mocha Brown. Kinda funky -- a distinct scent of bodily fluid. Slightly sweet and mild, with great lingering roasted coffee notes. Zero head, but apparently that wasn’t the brewer’s fault. Give it another shot, Perry!

Cask (gravity dispensed) at Volo, had a pint with blankboy after Jan’s. Deep dark brown, no head. Nice malty brown ale aroma with espresso hints. Taste features mild chocolate, mocha, coffee Deep tasty stuff, but the lack of carbonation hurt it - it was tough to slug through a pint, it could have used some life I think. But hey, Perry’s the man, serving us geeks with flavorful brews in a bland wasteland (but getting better in part thanks to him) - thanks Perry, this was flavorful and neat to try!

Cask at CW. Very dark brown body, no head, almost black. Aroma is quite roasty, light underlying mocha (7+). Flavour is coffee dominant, roasty, with lingering mocha in the finish and aftertaste. Smooth medium palate is lacking in carbonation, and would likely take it up a notch with appropriate carbonation. Very nice. Well done!

Cask (gravity dispensed) at Volo. Pours dark brown, almost black, with no head at all. Aroma of caramel malt, mild mocha and a hint of coffee. Slightly watery flavour of light coffee, caramel malt and faint hops. Average bodied. I think this beer would be better served on draught, it’s pretty lifeless this way, but as is it’s still a well made beer and pleasant enough.

Pint at Volo. Murky brown colour, upfront aroma of coffee and chocolate. Coffee flavour comes through from the first sip. Nice, lingering aftertaste like chocolate melting in your mouth. I just wish this had a bit more body to it.

Mocha brown colour, the aroma and the taste is one-dimensional coffee.A bit of mollassess and malt, but it could use lots more malt.and preferably other flavorings. Coffee taste is so-so, and I normally don’t drink cold coffee even it’s spiked. A little watery. Fresh cask at Volo Cafe.

Cask @ C’est What? Dark, woody brown with smallish ring on top.3- Smooth clean, well roasted beans . Good, clean fresh coffee aroma. Good, not as dry as top mocha goes but it’s up there. Neat brown malt base. For true coffee lovers this is excellent choice. Brown malts go well with rich coffee character that grows well o your palate. Chocolate, cocoa noted as well. Very good mocha beer that I would like to see as regular beer from this brewery

Cask. Very dark brown body with no head. Vanilla aroma including coffee beans and mocha. Silky medium-body with lots of bitter coffee, dark chocolate, and green hops. Chocolate and roast bitterness dominates throughout. Sampled at the C’est What Spring Festival Of Craft Brewers on May 25, 2007.

sample at C’est what. brown color, not much head kinda lacking but it is cask so that happenes some times. nose is definate coffee. kinda thin on the palate, but the taste is all coffee with a bit of choc, nice beer
On tap @ 10th Meibockfestival, last year. Hazy blond beer, white head. Aroma of flowers, malts and yeast. Flavour is sweet, slightly bitter and yeasty, some spice.

On tap at 10de Meibockfestival. Clear, deep amber with a nice, creamy offwhite head. Sweet and fruity aroma with hints of vegetables. Sweet and fruity flavours, spices and some bitterness. Nice, but not memorable. Too young?
On tap at Arendsnest. Orange colour. Quite eggy. Prickly mouthfeel. Quite good Blonde actually. Don’t know Prael all that well (yet). Will seek out more.

column1: Bristol Old No. 23 Port Barrel Aged Barley Wine
column5: Tried the 2016 and 2017 side by side, there were some noticeable differences but they were both delicious. They both poured the same, which was amber with a thin white head. Hey both smelled strong but smooth bourbon. The 2016 flavor was more grapes than bourbon the 2017 flavor was mainly bourbon. These were both very good beers

column1: Bristol Old No. 23 Port Barrel Aged Barley Wine
column5: On tap @ Falling Rock poured a clouidy milk chocolate brown with a small lasting creamy tan head. Aromas of port, oak, toffee, carmeldark fruit and a hint of oxidation. Palate was medium bodied smooth and warming. Flavors of port, oak, toffee, plums and a hint of spice with a smooth warming lingering bittersweet finish.

column1: Bristol Old No. 23 Port Barrel Aged Barley Wine
column5: Draught, Falling Rock. Head is mostly diminishing. Body is hazy dark amber. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted grain, cookie, caramel), lightly hoppy (apricot, resin), lightly yeasty (barnyard, horseblanket), with notes of plum, cherry, wood, dried mango, alcohol, hint of sherry. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic. I haven’t historically been a fan of the Old No. 23, so I didn’t have high hopes, but this was pretty darned good. Looks like it picked up some wild yeast in the barrel too...it’s light but adds an extra dimension. Guess it’s about time to re-rate the regular 23.

column1: Bristol Old No. 23 Port Barrel Aged Barley Wine
column5: 2004 vintage release, draught at Falling Rock. Pours clear mahagony with an average frothy, rocky light brown head, mostly lasting, good lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel), light hops (flowers, perfume), average yeast (dough) with heavy port notes, some prune and raisin as well. Full bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation and a bitter finish. Average duration, moderate sweetness, acidity and bitterness; the port is a nice addition to this already tasty Barleywine. Some oak and vanilla notes come through at the end.

column1: Bristol Old No. 23 Port Barrel Aged Barley Wine
column5: On tap at the Bristol Brewing Company in CO Springs, CO. Rich and creamy textured body with port taste dominating the sweet malt characteristics. Dark brown color.
Draft. Hazy copper with small beige head. Aroma of caramel and light floral hops. Medium body, moderate hop bitterness, and a light sweet finish.

GNBF. Poured clear, honeyed golden with a moderate off-white head. The aroma was sweet, with honey and toasted grainy malts leading.. fresh accents, but nothing exciting. The flavor was sweet again, with honey, caramel, and vanilla leading.. peppery alcohol and earthy bitterness around.. finished warm and malty, with a lot of residual sugars. Medium-bodied with just the right amount of carbonation.. warm and drinkable, but not great.
Copper in color with a sweet honey/candy aroma. Sweet in flavor as well. No real hint of alcohol.
Pours copper with a sweet caramel aroma. Slight honey flavor with a good hop presence. ABV is masked very well.
Growler courtesy of Skyview. Copper color with a medium head. Honey aroma and some Noble hop. Sweet honey taste with a medium hop bitterness. Tasty fine.

From Skyview’s growler. Caramel aroma. Sweet but a lot of bitter hops for the style, and interesting idea that has worked fairly well. The high abv is well hidden. One of South Shore’s better creations.
On tap at Wilmarths Deepwater Grille. Dark honey color with faint creamy head. Very sweet apple in the nose and body. Lots of sweet malt as well.

Third stop during May ’07 brewpub tour, brought us to the South Shore Brewery in Ashland, WI. Pours a semi-cloudy burnt coppery amber color brew with an average off-white head that dissolves very slowly to a fine film. Lacing is average. This maibock has aroma of sweet buttery toast, bananas, a touch of apriots, and sweet sugar. Taste is smooth, creamy, medium body and more sweetness on the tongue. Finish is sweet and no bitterness.

column1: Great Waters Holy Hand Grenade IPA
column5: On tap at the brewpub on 6/23/07: Pours a hazy copper orange with an airy, clingy-lacing light tan head. Aroma of fairly fresh, earthy piny English hops with a touch of floral citrus character and sweet caramel malt. Body starts fairly full and sweet with a nice earthy caramel sweetness and good floral lemony citrus hop balance before a crisp smooth bittersweet finish.

column1: Great Waters Holy Hand Grenade IPA
column5: Draft @ Brewpub: Copper color, light head and lacing. Nose of full on fresh woody, piney hops. The sweet pale malts underline it. Finishes balanced and creamy, fresh, yet musty. Good IPA. Woody!

column1: Great Waters Holy Hand Grenade IPA
column5: Date: 06/23/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy amber, fine beige head, drippy lace, sweet caramel malt aroma with earthy and floral hops, rich caramel malt flavor, good citrus character, lots of earthy hops keeps it dry, long bitter finish, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

column1: Great Waters Holy Hand Grenade IPA
column5: Cask pint at the brewpub, June 24 2007. Dark, dusky caramel-bronze in color with a small, lasting smooth head....fragrant floral hops dominate the aroma, light earthy musk, a bit of black pepper....caramel and baked fruits power the sweet, somewhat sugary/syrupy body, light earthy dry hops show up late to balance things out....bitterness increases a bit (and it is welcomed) as the glass warms in the sun....smooth, cream body, lovely low natural carbonation. Good job.

column1: Great Waters Holy Hand Grenade IPA
column5: Love the cask conditioned IPA. In my area, it is a hard find. Had one before a concert at Xcel Center. It was nice hop-balanced IPA that was held up with enough malt. Because of the time of year, the temperature (52°) of a cask-conditioned prevented me from having any more.

column1: Great Waters Holy Hand Grenade IPA
column5: Sample from cask at the brewpub. Pours clear orange to amber with an off-white head. Aroma is malty caramel beneath a little layer of aroma hops. Flavours starts out with a malty caramel dryness going into a floral hoppiness. Finish is a dry blend of malt and mild bitterness.

column1: Great Waters Holy Hand Grenade IPA
column5: (cask) Frothy beige head atop clear deep amber body. Aroma is medium sweet, caramel/toffee, some chocolate. Taste is medium sweet, floral/earthy, dusky, chocolate/caramel, some spice. Soft light-medium body, light resin. Very English-style IPA -- I’d never guess the IBUs given the hops used.

column1: Great Waters Holy Hand Grenade IPA
column5: On cask. Copper color with a thick head. Strong aroma of grains with a little piney hops. The taste is a good mix of sweet malt, bitterness and what I think is lemongrass. Something almost chocolaty, too. Interesting and tasty.

column1: Great Waters Holy Hand Grenade IPA
column5: One of their better beers. Amber color and a creamy head from the cask pull. Hops in the aroma. Bitter, herbal hop flavor. Dry finish. Good. Light malt.

column1: Great Waters Holy Hand Grenade IPA
column5: CASK: Dark Amber Color with Off White Head. Medium Mouthfeel, Nice and Creamy. Dark Grains Aroma. Dark and Dry Grain/Wheat Flavor...Sweet Malt Foundation. Vienna Malt, to be More Precise. Not Incredibly Hoppy Until It Warms Up a Bit. Some Dry Bread Notes as Well. Nice Vienna Ale.
Tap. Slightly hazy straw yellow. Bready, earthy, hoppy and zesty, and light dough in the aroma. Nicely hoppy, herbal, noble hops come through, biscuity malt. medium body with softer carbonation.

Sampled at the NoVa Summer Beer Fest in Leesburg, VA on 6/25/11. Pours a hazy straw yellow color with a medium creamy tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of bready malts and grassy hops. The taste is green apple, grassy hops and a bready malt finish. Medium bodied.

Sample @ Brewpub, Capitol Hill Pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, grain and floral hops. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.
