Hektische dicke Perlen, schönes Bernstein. In der Nase deutlicher Malz. Im Trunk leicht maischig, malzig, hintenweg süß. Gute Drinkability.
50cl bottle. Pours clear amber colour with a medium to small white head. Aroma of pale malt, toasted malt, grain. Taste is sweet malty, grainy, some metalic hops, bread.
Geruch getreidig, süß, helles Malz, Aprikose. Antrunk süß, helles Malz. Mitte fruchtig, brotig, Malz bis in den Abgang reichend; bittert unangehem nach. Nicht gut.
Bottle. Deep golden color. Malt, cookies in the aroma. Malty sweet cookie flavor with hints of caramel and soft grassy hops. Carbonation is soft.

0,5 l bottle. Dark golden in the glass, small foamy white head. Malt and apple with honey on the nose. Taste is more honey, malt, light alcoholic. Very low carbonated. Later increasing alcoholic sharpness and dull bitterness.

Many thanks to kappldav123 for this bottle! Intense malty beginning. Thick, viscous, malty. The typical Heller-Bock aroma is there, but a thick malty layer is lying heavy on top. Tastes more like a dunkler Bock in a blind taste. Not much bitterness, interesting sweetish-sticky malt, hints of dry grain, interesting.

Bottle by 12.10.12. Nice intensely grapey nose, some darker malt and caramel, too. Pours a clear, rich orange with a short white head. Some booze showing in the mouth,. faintly sweet with more white grape here, some honey and light berry, clashing darker caramel. Light-medium body, light bitterness, layers of malt.
Not a brilliant but not really bad either, would simply describe this as average in all it’s ways. a typical helles.
Poured a cloudy pale gold. Aroma of grass and malts. Taste is somewhat astringent with bitter finish. Crisp and clean.
Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass zippy, small head. Starts strong and spicy, a bit grasy. More and more malty-spicy. A bit unbalanced. Could be a bit stronger, but still okay.

0.5 l bottle as ’Rhöner Edel Export Spezial’ at 5.1% abv, best before March 2017, courtesy of Koelschtrinker, thanks Roman! Clear, golden yellow with a medium large, foamy, slowly diminishing, white head. Slightly sweetish, a bit grassy-spicy, a bit fruity aroma of straw, grains, honeyish malts and slight hints of citrus. Slightly sweetish, a bit grassy-spicy taste of straw, grains, some butter and hints of cardboard, followed by a short, moderately bitter, slightly grassy-spicy, quite metallic and stale finish. Medium body, smooth and slightly effervescent mouthfeel, average carbonation. Drinkable, but with some flaws, not enjoyable due to an unpleasantly stale and metallic finish.

Das Spezial Export wurde neuerdings zu Edel Export und hat laut Etikett 5,1%. Es kommt in einer 0,5l NRW Flasche und hat ein standardmäßiges Etikett. Im Glas ist das Bier goldfarben, wenig prickelnd und hat so gut wie keine Schaumkrone. Vom Geschmack bin ich hier hin- und hergerissen. Das Bier hat sehr gute Ansätze es ist würzig, süßlich malzig und doch recht süffig, wirkt aber an der ein oder anderen Stelle einfach blechern und abgestanden. Durchaus trinkbar, aber nichts besonderes.

Bottle 50cl given by Quack-Duck. A clear yellow beer with medium head. Nose is on barley sugar and wet paper. Aroma is low, barley sugar, wet paper, low body dusty hops, nutty, very boring and thin, poor caramel.
Geruch getreidig, etwas süßlich. Antrunk süßlich, Getreide, zieht bis zur Mitte. Im Schluß etwas Würze, kaum bitter. Na ja.
Klare goldene Farbe, mittelgroße weiße Schaumkrone. Der Geruch ist sehr malzig, leicht süß. Geschmack ist würzig malzig, leicht metallisch hopfig, naja!

#623 Hellgelbes Export mit Getreidenote im Aroma. Fester Antrunk, was vom recht hartem Brauwasser kommt. Für ein Export ists sehr malzbetont geraten; der Hopfen könnte prägnanter sein. Insgesamt ein mittelmäßiges Export. Test vom 2.1.2011, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 10,9,10,9,9,9 - 9,25
Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and light fruity. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish.
Bottle looks really good. Beer in the glass deep golden, nice head. Starts mild, modest soapy, sourish. Finish milder, less soapy. Should be more spicy.
courtesy of fiulijn - pale and clear golden beer with a poor white foam left; aroma of urine with hints of herbs and butter; medium-bodied, some tart herbal bitterness and a quite long herbal finish
Fader, wenig süßer Antrunk. Muffig, etwas blechern. Sehr wässrig, zum Ende minimal herb. Das erste Wort sagt es bereits: FAD! 8/5/5/4/8/4
The foam stability is good, body copper. The Aroma is malty, darkmalty. The taste is darkmalty, a tiny bit roasty and bitter. Very pleasant maltiness. Good.
Bottle. Pours amber copper with a White head. Toasted caramel, bread and grains. Medium bodied. Cool.

It’s dark golden with a huge, creamy head and the aroma has notes of roasted malt, caramel, hay and biscuit. The flavour has a moderate sweetness and notes of malt, caramel, biscuit and fruit. The finish is dry with hints of straw.
Coppery colored with little yellow head. Little yellow head. Toffee-chocolate dominates this aroma, some metallic note also here. Medium bodied. Flavor is also chocolaty with same lemony tone.
Bottled &#40Turrkila Beer Fest 2009&#41. Amber colour, small beige head. Aroma is fruits, caramel and some herbs. Flavour is caramel malts, some metallic and mild grassy notes.

Bottled &#40BB 12/2009&#41. Turkkila Beer Festival 2009 Amber color, small white head. Grassy hoppy, caramelly and toasted rye bread aroma. Grassy hoppy, a bit harsh, caramelly with toasted sugars. Quite typical South German dark beer.

Bottle: Literally copper coloured, clear, smaller, slowly diminishing off-white head; dark caramel and toasted malt in the nose with a spicy hoppy and a very faint metallic touch; moderate to light sweetish-bitter flavour with the faintest illusion of acidity, soft MF; short, toasted-malty and bitter finish, with some sourness shining through. Yawn.....

(bottle) Clear, chestnut-brown coloured with a slightly off-white foamy head of medium size. Light-sweet, toast-malty nose with cacao, toffee and a good dose of herbal hops. Mild bitter flavour with a moderate sweet edge, light to medium bodied, soft on carbon. Toast-malty taste with light notes of caramel and a herbal blend; moderately dry, bitter-sweet finish. A bit slim towards the finish but well-rounded and quite likeable. A good session Dunkel.
The foam stability is ok, body light. The Aroma is malty, barley. The taste is light, malty, a bit dry hay. Very light.

50 cl bottle. Rated on 18.11.2009 Bright colour, large but disappearing head.Aroma has rye bread and some vegetables. Flavour has rye bread and some grainy malt. Aftertaste is bitter in a harsh way. Drinkable.

Langweilig herber Antrunk, der schnell trocken wird. Die Getreidenoten im Mittelteil sind ebenfalls nur halbherzig, sie ebbt ab, die Herbe legt dagegen leicht zu.Dazu wird das Bier trockener, im Abgang ist immerhin eine leichte Würzigkeit vorhanden. Wie erwähnt, langweilig. 8/6/7/6/7/6

It’s warm golden with a creamy, white head and the aroma has notes of newly-harvested grain, malt, a touch of butterscotch and straw. The flavour has a light sweetness and notes of malt, bread, newly-harvested grain, a touch of butterscotch and straw. It’s a really nice helles.
Blond color; small head. Aroma of straws. Light malt flavor and straws, quite strong bitterness. Boring.

Bottle 500ml. [ As Findelberger Hell ]. Clear light to medium yellow color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, bread, toasted, oxidide malt. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20091130]

It’s unclear golden with a huge, creamy, white head and the aroma has notes of banana, yeast and wheat. The flavour is sweet with notes of clove/yeast, banana, a touch of citrus, light wheat and the finish is spicy.

Bottle 50cl. Unclear medium yellow color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, moderate yeasty, fruity, banana notes. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery to creamy, carbonation is soft. [20090913]

Bottle: Greenish-golden with a small, persistent layer, bubbles visible; artificial, sweet nose with traces of lemon, heavily diluted traces of beer in the background; delicate sweet-sour flavour; some grainy traces in the sweetish-lemony end. An interesting brew, ..., for lovers of artificial sweeteners.........

(bottle) Clear, yellow colour with a moderate foamy white head. Sweet citrus-fruity nose with a light malty, grainy background. Sweet flavour, citrousy taste with light bready malty notes; artificially sweet, slightly sticky finish.

The beer is now brewed at Brauhaus Giessen. Bottle looks very simple, but okay. Beer in the glass looks okay, small head. Starts dry-malty, metallically, unbalanced and more and more moldy with some sourish notes. Not very drinkable. Not my favourite.

Bottle: Golden coloured, average white head, visible carbonation; solid sweet-grainy nose; moderate sweet-bitter flavour, medium bodied; faint honeyish traces in the sweet-grainy finish. Unspectacular, but chewy brew.......

bottle, thanks to pivnizub. Golden yellow, large white head. Quite malty brew, not very full-bodied but still pleasant and ful of malty flavours. Slightly fruity, hoppy background. Quite well-balanced.

(bottle) Clear, golden colour with a foamy white medium head. Sweet, strawy malty aroma with honey a soft spicy herbal hoppy touch. Sweet flavour, medium to light bodied with a moderate carbonation. Malt-accented, minimal-grainy taste with a touch of cardboard; medium-sweet malty finish. Another profane one.
Bottle from Sagasser Getränkefachmarkt, Erfurt. Dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty and heavy caramel. Flavor is very sweet. Sweet finish. Watery. 130717
Light Amber color. Very strange light caramel nose with strange hop character. Super light body. Easy to drink but odd caramel character. Not my favorite.

Flasche (33 cl). - Tiefes Schwarzbraun mit Rotstich, kurzlebiger Schaum. - In der Nase schwach fruchtige Süße, Traubenzucker, Karamel. - Antrunk recht dünn und zuckrig süß mit schüchternen Röstnoten, Cola-Geschmack und einer schwachen Fruchtigkeit, die das Malzbier gerade noch erträglich macht. Nur schwach rezent. Im Abgang anhaltende Süße und ein ganz schwacher Anklang von milder Bittere; der auf dem Etikett versprochene „Doldenhopfen aus Spalt und der Hallertau“ kann hier nur in mikroskopischer Dosierung zum Einsatz gekommen sein. - Nicht direkt schlecht aber überhaupt nicht mein Bier.

0,33 l bottle with a nice label art work. Pours out nearly black, small tanned head in the glass. Sweet malt on the nose. Tastes the same. Malt and sugar sweetness. Okay for this kind of brew. Thanks to kappldav123.
0.33 l bottle from Eisenach... Dark color, short head... Sweet malt aroma of caramel, weak beer flavor... Sweet light beer, more like a malt beer for children... Sweet ending...
Bottle. Dark brown color. Caramel in the aroma. Malty sweet flavor. Apple syrup. Thin. The former DDR-version of a Dutch oud bruin. Drinkable when served cold.
Thank you to kappldav123. Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, toffee and roasted bread. Flavour follows the nose.
Bottle looks interesting. Beer in the glass deep black, small head. Starts very mild, soft-malty. Intense sweet notes. Finish well balanced, mild, almost a but washy. Okay.
It’s mahogany red with a creamy head and the aroma has notes of caramel, syrup, light straw and butter. The sweet flavor has notes of caramel, syrup and light straw.

Bottle 330ml. Clear medium to dark red brown color with a small average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting to diminishing, light beige head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy malty, dark carame, brown sugar. Flavor is heavy sweet and light bitter with a long to average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20100917]
Bottle from Sagasser Getränkefachmarkt, Erfurt. Hazy pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma is sweet, sugary and lemon. Flavor is medium sweet. Sweet finish. Watery. 130717
Zitroniger, eher dumpf trockener Antrunk. Erfrischend limonadig ohne jegliche Noten von Bier. Wässriger Nachhall. Trinkbar. 6/7/7/5/5/5

It’s a golden radler with a white head and the aroma has notes of malt and lemon-soda. The sweet flavour also has some citrus-sourness and notes of malt and lemon-soda, and the finish is dry. It’s not as sweet as many other radlers.

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium orange yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light malty, grain, hay, toasted, light lemon - old lemon. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration, brew mash. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20100918]

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours a clear golden with a small white head. Very little lemon aroma, some honey though. Thin body, very dry and again very little lemon. Ends dry and sulphurous with some metallic edges. 180910
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is pale yellow. Aroma and taste are malt and citrus.

(bottle) Clear, pale golden colour with a foamy white medium head. Sweet lemon aroma with a shy malty touch. Moderately sweet flavour with a light acidic touch. Citrus-fruity, chalky taste; sweet, slightly artificial finish. Forgettable.

Clear golden beer with a medium to big sized, medium to good lasting head. Aroma is grainy with pale malt, alcohol, fruits. Taste is grainy, light metallic, waterish, alcohol, light to medium sweet, with lasting sweetness in finish. Soft carbonation, medium body, oily texture. Good, but a bit boring.

Herber, recht würziger Getreideantrunk mit süßer Beinote, der die Herbe süffig erscheinen lässt. Das mild auftretende Malzaroma wirkt ebenfalls süßlich, der Hopfen wirkt mit feiner Note aber gegenteilig und balanciert das Bier aus. Nun setzt sich die bockige Süße etwas mehr durch, die sich gleichzeitig verstärkende Herbe kann aber eine zu deutliche Ausbreitung verhindern. Nettes, recht kerniges Bockbier. 10/11/12/12/10/11

Bottle 33cl. @ [ Thisted tasting ]. [ Trade by Koelschtrinker ]. Clear medium amber yellow color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, sugar notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration, and a alcohol burn in the finish. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20090316]

Thisted tasting. Courtesy of Fonefan. It is warm golden with small particles floating and a creamy head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, light fruit and a light sourness. The flavour has a light sweetness and notes of malt, caramel and the finish has some spicy alcohol and a little harsh citrus.
Bottle. Hazy golden colour with a little head. Aroma of maltness with hintsof caramel and hay. Malty sweet flavour with touch of hops.
Bottle. A yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is of malt, grass, hay and caramel, so is the taste, with some straw. Medium body with a sweet finish.
Bottle, 6.5%. Clear dark golden colour. Big, unstable head. Weak malty aroma. The flavour starts off quit clean, turning caramelly, malty, and then rough and peppery. A good, standard bock.
From 33 cL bottle. Pours clear golden yellow with a crispy white head. Malty and grassy aroma. Flavour is sweet malty with a slight sour note. Mild malty and vaguely bitter finish. Tasty.
Bottle. Clear golden coloured with a white head. Sweet fruity aroma of malts and grain. Sweet flavour of fruits, malts and hops. Hoppy finish.

(Bottle 33 cl) Courtesy of MoritzF. Clear, deep golden with a dense, white head leaving laces. Clean, malty nose. Medium body with sweet, pale malts. Dey and lightly bitter finish. Quite nice really. 290607

(screw cap bottle) Clear, red coloured hue with a mid-sized pink foamy head, slowly lacing. Heavily sweet and artificial fruity nose of berries, perhaps grenadine, that leaves no room for something else. Sweet flavour, syrupy fruity taste; very sweet and artificial finish with almost no beer character.
Süßlich malziger Antrunk mit leichter Herbe. Im Mittelteil steigt die Würzigkeit, vollmundiges helles Malz ohne die sonst oft störende Süße. Weicher, etwas brotiger Nachgeschmack. 11/10/11/12/7/11

Flasche aus dem Brauereiverkauf. - Helles Goldbraun, klar, kurzlebiger beigefarbener Schaum. - Geruch karamelmalzig, sehr süß, fuselig. - Antrunk dick karamelsüß mit Mais und einem Anflug von Toastbrot aber ohne bittere oder fruchtige Aromen, die ein Gegengewicht zu der klebrigen Malzsüße bieten könnten. Mild rezent, breit. Noch im Abgang vorwiegend malzsüß, mit Noten von Waldhonig. Klingt mit milder, wenig aromatischer Bittere aus. - Einfallsloser, malzsüß-klebriger Bock, kein Genuß.
Dunkelgoldenes Bier mit wenig Schaum. Geruch sehr malzig, süß, leicht alkoholisch. Geschmack sehr malzig, etwas fruchtig süß, grasig, leicht alkoholisch.
Many thanks for this bottle to Beerhunter111.A dark yellow beer. The aroma has notes of straw and malt. The flavor is bittersweet with notes of straw, malt, and alcohol

0.5 l bottle at Timo A’s! Copper color. Aromas of toasted bread, honey and toasted nuts. Taste of toasted bread and nuts with background herbal dryed fruit notes. Restrained alcohol warmth. Medium body. Good beer but hardly a bock.

50 cl bottle @ Timo A. Pours clear copper color with a small head. Malts and hay on the flavor, bread and some nuts also. Quite beady flavor too, malts, dry fruits and some wooden notes on the finish. Slick palate. A bit stuffy, otherwise decent. 4324

Bottled. A dark golden beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet malty combined with notes of fruit. The flavor is sweet malty with strong notes of hops and light notes of fruit. The alcohol warms the palate.
Bottle. A golden beer with a white head. The aroma is of corn and grass, the taste is of straw, corn and hay. Medium body with a dry finish.

Golden color. The aroma is quite ordinary, with the classic light cereals. The flavor is better, with a good balance of malt, sweetness and bitterness (actually higher than the average, in Germany); even if not much alcoholic, there is some quite alcohol warmth; good bitterness level, and the finish is quite long. Sweet Bock, good.

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of MoritzF. Clear, deep golden with a small, rough, white head. Sweetish malt aroma. Quite full in body with plenty of sweet malt and some biscuity accents. A touch of flowers before a rather hoppy finish. 171107

Flasche aus dem Brauereiverkauf. - Helles Goldbraun, klar, reichlich hellbeigefarbener Schaum. - In der Nase kräftiges Karamelmalz, Brotkruste und krautig-würziger Hopfen, leicht holzig-muffig; dazu eine etwas spritige Note, die an ein Bockbier erinnert. - Antrunk aromatisch karamelmalzig aber nicht zu süß. Würzig-pikante Aromen von Brotkruste, Toastbrot, gerösteten Nüssen und Bayrisch Blockmalz. Gut rezent, weiches Mundgefühl. Im Abgang kräftig hopfenwürzige, etwas holzige Herbe; recht trocken. Trockener, holzig bitterer Nachtrunk. - Recht eigenwilliges aber außerordentlich aromatisches Bier, nicht so glatt und harmlos-gefällig wie viele Dunkle. Der Hopfen agiert hier nicht nur im Hintergrund und zur Abrundung, sondern gestaltet den Charakter des Bieres unverkennbar mit. Wer sich an der leicht muffigen Geruchsnote nicht stört, kann hier ein wirklich interessantes Bier kennenlernen. Sehr empfehlenswert!
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein dunkel bernsteinfarbenes Bier mit ordentlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht röstmalzig, Karamell, leicht würzig. Geschmack würzig, Karamell, leicht röstmalzig.
0.5 l bottle, thanks Timo A! Copper color. Aromas of nuts and charred bread with hint of metal. Taste of toffee, nuts and charred bread crust. Medium body. Tastes a bit stale (BB two weeks ahead).
Many thanks for this bottle to Beerhunter111. Pours a amber color. Malty with shy hints of caramel, rustic, earthy hops.
Dark golden with a small white head. Aroma of bready malt, with a metallic touch. Sweet and malty flavour with hops and bitterness in the finish
Pours amber with a white head. Aroma is caramel and grassy hop. Flavour is caramel, grassy hop and fruity notes.

Very spritzy, like a Coca-Cola fountaining, but only small head, over deep-golden, visually very carbonated cider. Dry nose, some chalk, going over in dried apples & applerind aromas. Sweet, with of course apples, but also a pinch of ginger, lemonpeel and raw potato rind, finishing earthy. Quite empty palate, fizzy MF, too sweet to be refreshing. It’s obviously an "easy drinker". The Bio certificate is a plus, but it’s not really a good cider. Bit kiddies’ drink profile.

(33cl swing top bottle) Seems to be a new beer in their assortment: Clear, pale golden with a fluffy, quite persistent foamy white head. Sweet, slightly perfumed, cardboardy nose with a faint herbal hoppy touch. Sweet flavour, malty, slightly papery taste, light to medium bodied, soft on carbon. Light-sweet, faint bitter finish with papery malt. Bland.

Bügelverschlußflasche (33cl): Straw golden coloured, quickly diminishing white head; sweet-malty, a bit papery nose, underpinned by hayish hops; delicate, mainly bitter flavour, soft MF, light bodied; mild bitter-sweetish finish. Clean, unspectacular Pilsener...

Bottled @ UDRM. The aroma has malts mainly, caramel, toffee. Hazy, orange coloured beer with not much head. The taste is sweet, has a little sourness, caramel/toffee, raisins and some bread. Medium bodied.

Bottled @ Dutch "the Good, the Bad & the Ugly" tasting. Hazy light brown color, short head. Aroma of caramel, toffee. Sweet, bit dry, wheat, cookie, hint of alcohol. Hmm, bit unbalanced I think, but the aging gives some bite to it. And I like cookie now and then.
Unofficial Dutch RB Meeting. Brown colored brew. Very sweet aroma and flavor. Some sugar and spices. Dull.

75cl Bottle at The Good, The Bad & The Ugly tasting, from 2007. Hazy amber colour, white head. Aroma is very sweet, malty, overripe and dried fruits, bread, phenol. Flavour is sweet, bready, fruits, light plastic, bitter light alcoholic finish. Medium to fullbodied.

Old bottle @ meeting. Aroma is fowl yeast, mouldy bread and malt. Flavour is very sweet and definitely old, bready caramel with a touch of a sour infection like something. Yuck. If this is supposed to be good ageing then count me out.

Bottle at Unofficial Dutch RB Meeting. Quite old bottle, no date found but seems like 2007. Aroma is somewhat spicy, sugary and of aged beer. Flavor is sweet and aged. Not really my kind of brew but not bad.
Bottle Dark brown color. Malty, bready aroma with a hint of roast. Malty sweet, rather alcoholic flavor with caramel, roast and pear syrup. Roasted bittersweet aftertaste. Well balanced strong ale.
Dark brown colour with beige head.Aroma of caramel and raisins,strong alc and strong hoppy note as well.O.K beer.

PINT beer tasting session, Arendsnest, Amsterdam. Ruby coloured. Raisins and fruit in aroma, alcohol obviously present. Sweet flavour, some sourness, alcohol really kicks in. Not complex enough considered its gravity, but as jbrus mentioned, it might gain complexity upon aging.

Bottled. Aroma of raisin, strawberry jam and apple. Ruby color, off-white head, good lace. Sweet, bitter, wine-like, raisin, hints of cherry and licorice, malty, very alcoholic. Already nice but promisses to age well.

Bottle from the Beer Bar Jive, Kyoto. Poured a crystal clear golden colour with a lasting frothy white head. The aroma is malt, yeasty, floral perfume hop. The flavour is moderate bitter with a light, crisp, watery, mineral, floral hop bitter palate. Medium bodied with average carbonation.
Slightly hazy, has a bit dirty character. Not bad, a bit tart and light. Sweetish malt.

Part of the 580 yen tasting set. On tap at Kizakura Kappa Country. A slightly clearer pale straw gold than the Blue Nile a milder coriander nose as well with some earthiness. Great filmy long-lasting head with excellent Belgian lace. Smooth med-light body. Much more malt forward than the other beers with some fruitiness & spiciness. Probably the best balanced of the three Nile beers.

Draught at brewpub, Fushimi. Light gold, bubbly body. Very little aroma- some faint dusty hops and yeast. Light, fizzy mouthfeel. Fresh flavours of lemon, coriander. Not much happening here, but pleasant enough all the same.
Tap at the restaurant. Grainy and creamy. Quite crisp. Bit bland on the whole.

Bottle (rated in Apr 2008). Head is fully diminishing. Body is medium yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted bread/grain), lightly to moderately hoppy (flowers), trace yeast (dough), with a note of peach. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Pale yellow and thin head. Light smell of lemon. Taste: Butter with some wheat and coriander light sweetness and some fruity feel. Aftertaste is thin with some banana feel. A little thin and plane overall but drinkable without any negative things to say.

Aroma: At first whiff I immediately noted the aroma of sun-dried hay and the barnyard aroma characteristic of saisons. After spending a little more time with this brew, I also picked up the scent of lemon rind, resinous pine, and slight phenols. A few buttery notes snuck in as well. Appearance: This beer has an incredibly delicate and pale color and yet is topped with a persistent and foamy head. It almost has the appearance of a lager with the head of a hef. Lacing sticks to the glass here and there. Taste: Light buttery malts followed by faint earthy pine hops. A slight hef-funk finish rounds this beer out nicely. Mouthfeel: Slightly more carbonation than normal for a saison, but that’s not necessarily a disservice. It makes it seem more refreshing. Also, the taste really sticks with you. Overall: All around I think this is a pretty solid beer. It’s definitely very light for a saison and could use a little more yeasty funk to more appropriately represent the style, but on the other hand it’s a unique take on a saison that’s well done.
On draught at the brewpub. A thinnish, dryish, unspiced wheat beer the ingredients for which were researched by Egyptologists but sourced from Asahi, who oversee the place.
Bottle at K’s Hostel, Kyoto. Cloudy yellow - white head. Wheaty, coriander, spicy, fruity, light licorice yeasty, citric, light sweetness, orange, Plain.
Tap @ Tempe Nice gold color with no head or lacing. Very light almost unnoticible sweet aroma and flavor. Nothing great going on here Just a simple, light refreshing beer. not bad.

Tap @ Tempe location. Aroma was somwhat metalic with corn and bitter. Golden body with white head and some lacing. Flavor was intriging was sweet citrus lemon, spicey and a good dose of bitter bite. Leaves a somewhat metalic aftertaste on palate but a refreshing brew on a 100 degree day.

Pour is golden yellow with a sticky dense bright white head...smell is crisply grassy and sweet with a faint toasty grainy thing going on...taste is light and sweet up front with a grainy undertone....followed up by a light grassy bitterness...

On tap at RB – Yorktown. Poured clear bright golden with a short cap of white head. The aroma picked up dusty sweeter pale malt and bready notes with a touch of lemon and grass.. not very fragrant or interesting. The flavor was a little heavier with mostly pale malt at the core.. also a little honey paired with grass and wheaty bitterness on the edges.. dry finish with lemon, grass, and pale malty sweetness. Light-bodied with some odd sharpness and tartness on the palate.. dry and not very enjoyable finish. This wasn’t good.

Note to my friend Drnk_McDermott - Demand your rights as a beer geek and make them give you an unfrosted mug! That said, this is a light, sociable lager. It’s a bright yellow drink with a sustained fluffy head. The malts are sweet and bready and there’s a pleasant grassy bitterness that increases with consumption. Good warm weather brew. Rock Bottom Yorktown, Lombard, IL

Mug Club draft. This was a special edition beer to raise funds for a foundation honoring an area resident (see RB’s page for details). This is based, I thought, on the Line Drive Light, but I detect no adjuncts here. Just a very light lager malt, just a touch of chewiness, and a well supported background of bittering hops. Served in their frosted mug, though, but it’s a very decent lawnmower beer. Hey, Cornfield, I do ask for an unfrosted mug... when I remember to.

Draught pint at the brewpub, January 21 2007. Completely opaque black with no head whatsoever; well, it’s not on nitro anyway....fruity-chocolaty nose is interesting at first, with coconut seeming to form a principle component....later on caramel, weak coffee and some whisky-bourbon notes emerge.....on the tongue, similarly, a mishmash of flavors, not terribly well integrated, with a sweet/sour lactic quality growing in domination through the pint, burnt-chocolate/espresso notes overwhelming everything else at the finish, orangepeel hazily appearing and disappearing, and, unfortunately, the all-too-typical strong mineralic content of the water contributing to an overall grittiness in texture (as well as killing the head, I expect)....alcohol subtly apparent. Well, this one didn’t work though there’s some effort apparent.
Pours brown with an off white head. Aroma of sweet malt. Also has a Similar flavor.

Draught pint at the brewpub, January 21 2007. A small, diminishing off-white head tops the dark hazy brown body....reasonably fresh citric nose, orange and grapefruit burst forth with light caramelized malts in the background.....on the tongue it’s all acidic citrus, fresh and clean until the finish which is, like many Shed beers past and present, disfigured by the harsh mineralic qualities in the water though in this case the effect is muted somewhat....very light and effervescent body, strong prickly carbonation, quite bitter and dry at the finish but fruity acidity stays with you....pretty one-note but it’s a good one.
Dégustée le 2018-07-28. .
On tap at Flatbread. Opaque yellow orange with a thin white head. Earthy spicy with lots of clove and some light bready honey maltiness underneath. Decent but a little too much clove for my tastes.

Draught pint at the brewpub, February 2007. It pours a hazy, bright gold-yellow with a bit of lasting head (damn these pint glasses!)....orangepeel is the first whiff, then white pepper, coriander and very vague hints of ginger show up to color the expressive, lightly earthy and pungent nose....very, very dry on the tongue, highly carbonated, chalky-mineralic towards the finish, very light dried orange husk notes....with a few minutes’ warmth, enough sweetness arrives at the finish to mute the dry earthy attack and keep the hardness in check...very well done, very authentic dry saison, though there’s nothing really exciting about it.

Botella 33 cl en el Lúpulo Oviedo septiembre 2007. Fcpref 31..07..2008. (r22). Color amarillento ámbarino turbio con espuma blanca. Sabores frescos cereales y suaves cítricos. Cuerpo ligero fácil de beber. De lo más corriente. Sin mucho que decir.

courtesy of Antonio Rey - hazy dark blond beer with a moderate foam left; bready aroma with fair corny and citrusy notes; sweet and with a decent malt backbone; light citric sourness and some residual sweetness in the finish; aftertaste of oranges, spices, wheat and bread
Bona cervesa, equilibrada i gustosa. Buena cerveza, equilibrada y sabrosa.

Me encanta el color blanquecino de las blancas belgas. Esta no decepciona. La crema es consistente y blanca. Los aromas cítricos son correctos y las notas de fondo de cereales muy gustosas. Sabor suave pero persistente. Me encanta.

Botella de 330ml. Copa Cáliz Bruggs. Color amarillo limón y apariencia turbia. Espuma blanca, vivaz, que se disipa con rapidez. Aromas de levadura y especias con trazos de piel de naranja y cilantro redondeados por notas herbáceas. Entrada chispeante y leve sabor de malta. Cuerpo ligero y carbonatación alta.Textura densa y paladar especiado. El leve sabor tartárico del intermedio aporta una suave astringencia y permanece en el final agridulce. Retrogusto con herbal amargor. 330ml bottle. Bruggs Goblet glass. Lemon yellow color, foggy appearance. White froth, lively & quickly diminished head. Yeasty & spiced aromas, hints of orange zest & coriander rounded by herbal notes. Sparkling upfront & light malty flavor. Light body. High carbonation. Oily texture & spiced palate. Slight tartar flavor in the middle provides soft astringency & lingers into a sour/sweet finish. Herbal bitter aftertaste.
Hazy and pale golden colour with minimum and quickly diminishing white head. Aroma is citrus, cinnamon and yeast. Flavor is quite the same as aroma with some acid notes. The final is dry and bittery.
On bottle at El Estribo. Golden color, good foam. Fruity aromas , good intensity. Medium body & complexity . Well balanced & good carbonation. Enjoyable ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled@One Pint Pub, Helsinki (shared with Mankke & co). Hazy orangeish golden colour, small white head, that leaves some lace. Aroma is mild wheat, yeast, some slight bready malts, grains and mild herbal notes. Flavour is wheat, mild dishwater (without the perfumy notes), mild dry sour wooden notes as well as some slight yeast.

330ml bottle (One Pint Pub, Helsinki, Spanish Weeks 2011) 6 Stodgy grainy aroma, a bit bready, no sharpness or crispness. 3 Dull hazy toffee, not much head. 6- Again a bit stodgy, some dishwater, some sharpness, quite a blast of strange esters, some wheatiness. 3 Smooth palate, gentle carbonation. Finish continues the taste. 11+ Bizarre, more a wheat ale than a blanch certainly, and quite quirky and fun. Easy to drink. Stays drinkable even if pop out to drop your laptop in work, and get locked in Nokia Research Centre for an hour.

Cerveza de alta fermentación, Ale, estilo White beer, elaborada con maltas de cebada y trigo, trigo sin maltear y cilantro, y lúpulos Saaz. Cerveza turbia, color ambarino, seca, refrescante, cuerpo ligero con aromas y gustos cítricos y especiados.
Draft @ Brewpub: Yellow hazy, light head and lacing. Nose of belgian yeast and spicy herbs, moderate hops and malt. Thin flavor though, not much in the yeast areas in the tail. Meh.
(Draught) Pours a lightly cloudy golden body with a small white head. Aroma of coriander, orange peel, and soapiness. Flavor of grassy/floral hops, herbs, and spicy yeast with a dry finish.

Date: 06/23/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy yellow, fine white head, drippy lace, sweet estery aroma with light fruit and a nice spicy character, light sweet malt flavor, nice bitterness from start to finish, spicy character blends well with the bitterness, touch of fruityness keeps it balanced and complex Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **+/4

Draught glass at the brewpub, RBSG Minneapolis pub crawl, June 22 2007. Cloudy, bright gold-amber body with a small lasting white head, bit of lace....aroma of pears, lots of sweet and funky Belgian yeast, light earthy English hops; doesn’t meld perfectly but stays interesting....quite hoppy on the tongue, full-bodied, fairly juicy and fruity, lightly tart and a bit dry to finish.... to me it seemed more Belgian than English, but just barely so....a fascinating, reasonably successful experiment.

Pours hazy light orange to yellow with a white head. Fruity spicy aroma. Flavour is slight chemical and going into a mild bubblegum sensation. Mild bitter finish. Yeasty bubblegum flavoured beers I really don’t get, well brewed, but I just don’t like it.
RBSG 2007 Pub Crawl: Pours a clear gold in color with a white head. Aroma, bubble gum, yeast, and spice. Flavor, yeasty, lemon, spice, some cloyingness, and some pepper. Tasty beverage.
RBSG 2007 pub crawl. Nice thick head. Smelled spicey, tasted grassy with bananas. Smooth drink and finish.

RBSG 07weekendl. Pours a nice hazy golden with a fluffy lasting white head- and decent carbonation (when I came back the following day for the pub crawl , this beer seemed to have less carbonation). Aroma is spicy yet clean belgian ale yeast- tons of herbal an dgrassy hops- hoppy saison-like. Very hoppy flavor with some spicy phenols, grass, herbal and flowery with a nice tacky almost harsh bitterness which I loved. Smooth body and mouthfeel.

RBSG 2007 at Barley John’s. The beer is a hazy pale straw colored body with a creamy white head. The aroma is fruity yeasty Belgian ale mixed with an English hop. The flavor is fruity with light oranges and hay with Belgian yeasts. Drying palate with a nice bitterness and texture.
One of the better beers from BJ’s. It has a light Belgian yeast aroma that includes hops. Flavor is quite dry, lightly spiced. Cloudy yellow with a nice head. More of a saison than a Belgian ale.

(Sample at Uncle Billy’s on August 2, 2008) Damn, that’s dark for an IPA! Deep mahogany red. Can’t see anything through it but barely a faint glow and a glisten of light. A light head remaining after all this time. As much hop aroma as the pale ale. I sink my tongue in… a little thick, more alcohol. Warmer, yep, more alcohol. As I exhale I detect something… musky-bitter. Just barely failing (in my opinion) of acceptable amongst the IPA norm. But why is it so dark??? Seems more malty with maybe more caramel than most IPAs. That may have something to do with the color. When IPAs cross-breed with brown ales, what do you call it? Brown chicken brown cow!

On tap. Poured a hazy golden-amber color with a moderate off-white head that left some nice lacing. Nice leafy hop aroma with pine resin and light citrus. Flavor was moderately bitter with a nice piny, sticky hoppiness and moderate citrus (grapefruit, orange) finish with a lingering hop bitterness. Tasted really fresh, and went very well with the habanero wings and chili fries.
(Cask) Sweet grapefruit aroma. Dark yellow no head. Flavor: Sweet acidic fruit followed by a well balanced hop finish.
Draught (cask). Nose is light citrus hops. Cloudy orange with minimal white head. Very full-bodied, huge tropical fruit flavor. Highly drinkable.
Foam Rangers January meeting. Rich golden color with big hops on the nose. Flavor is full of hops with some nice malts. Tasty.

From sampler (almost got a pint)- solid golden color, non transparent. Heavy aroma of hops, very nice. Hits the mouth with hop overload (is it a double IPA?), medium body and malt, solid finish of hops/ acidic aftertaste. Not for the weak of heart, but very good!

Wonderful IPA. My facorite of the five beers that I tried, had to get a growler to bring more of this home. Very well hopped, perfect carbonation, complemented the food well too. I guess I’m a hop lover. Fair winds and following seas, Michael Jackson...

Great beer...good aroma and flavor from the hops...good level of bitterness. Nice malt to back it up. The cask version was absolutely delicious. Very smooth & the carbonation was perfect for a cask. Great job, Brian.

Amberish color, with a very hoppy smell and taste. A touch of sweetness, but I found this very similar to their pale ale, but a touch more bitter, perhaps. A nice strongly hopped IPA. I’d like to try this again now that I’m much fonder of IPAs than when I first rated this.

The only thing I can see going against the beers here so far are the silly names. At least this one was born with none. Deep amber or red color, nice full body and superb hopping. My crappy means of writing do few beers justice. Let Brian’s skills as an excellent bewer be known through his work and not my words. Yum.

column1: Uncle Billys Axe Handle Pale Ale
column5: Rated based on notes taken 13 July 2012 -- After drinking the Hop Zombie I really thought this was kind of a dud. Nothing really stood out at all to me.

column1: Uncle Billys Axe Handle Pale Ale
column5: Draught at the Uncle Billy's Brew & Que, Austin, TX. Cloudy golden colour with a small white head. Sweet and fruity hoppy aroma. The flavour is sweet fruity hops, mild bitterness and sweet malt. Maybe a bit too sweet to be really tasty. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Uncle Billys Axe Handle Pale Ale
column5: Draft... Hazy golden ale with a small, creamy, white head. Decent retention. The bouquet offers pale grains and those signature Simcoe, earthy, cat-pissy aromatics. Medium to full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and modest carbonation. Nice earthy hops dominate the flavor, but a firm malt backbone lends plenty of support. Finishes crisp with lingering bitterness.

column1: Uncle Billys Axe Handle Pale Ale
column5: Tried this on tap at the GABF in Denver, CO. Citrusy floral hoppy aroma. Citrus hoppy flavor with a bitter malty finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Uncle Billys Axe Handle Pale Ale
column5: Bottle: &nbsp Amber with golden tint, lots of sediment as the bottle winds down, large frothy white head, fairly nice lacing. &nbsp Very soft hop nose, a touch pithy. &nbsp Getting a little bit of that Cascade hop profile towards the back of this beer. &nbsp Decent maltiness, fairly clean. &nbsp Comes across as a softer Pale Ale. &nbps Not as hoppy as other PNW examples, but as is very enjoyable and solid. &nbsp Thanks for the bottle Bill!

column1: Uncle Billys Axe Handle Pale Ale
column5: Clear amber pour with a nice white head. Grapefruit and pine aroma. Taste has more prominent pine with grapefruit. Nice bitterness. Pretty good.

column1: Uncle Billys Axe Handle Pale Ale
column5: On tap at brewery- Pour is a clear golden, with thin white head..Nose is pineapple,fruits, floral, hops..Taste is citrus, hops, pineapple,spice, clove, pale..A super solid pale

column1: Uncle Billys Axe Handle Pale Ale
column5: Hazed almost orange with creamy white head and lace. Aroma of caramel malt and citrusy hops. Caramel malt, bread, and some resiny/citrus hop bitter. Light/medium bodied with good carbonation.

column1: Uncle Billys Axe Handle Pale Ale
column5: Half pint at the Lake Travis location. Had this immediately after having a bite of bbq with jabanero sauce so who knows? Clear and golden with a small off white head. Soft hops and heavier malts define this. Floral hops and citrus. Fruit comes out more as it warms (or as the sauce clears). This is dry and fairly bitter.

column1: Uncle Billys Axe Handle Pale Ale
column5: on tap-pours an off white head with trailing lace and gold color. Aroma is pine/lemon-citrus, light/medium malt. Taste is pine/lemon-citrus/pineapple, light/medium malt. Good carbonation, good drinking. Great session PA.

Draft... Clear golden ale with a small, fizzy, white head. The soft aroma is of pale malts and spicy, floral hops. Medium-bodied with a milky mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. The flavor is a refreshing, delicate blend of pale malt sweetness and spicy, floral hop bitterness. Short, crisp, lightly snappy finish. Nice for a blonde. It washed down my smoked chicken wings quite well.
Tap. Slightly hazy golden pour with a decent white head. Aroma is some bread with a hint of citrus. Taste is sweet malt and a little citrus.

On tap at the original Uncle Billy’s location. The beer pours a slightly hazy yellow color with a white head. The aroma is heavy on the grain and wheat, with not too much else going on. Fairly bland overall. The flavor is a little bit more exciting, but still pretty boring. I mainly get grain, as well as some grass. There is also a little bit of floral character, but it is subtle. Thin mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
on tap-pours an off white head and hazy yellow color. Aroma is perfumy, grain. Taste is perfumy/spice hops, sweet grain/light malt-honey. Good effervescence.
Tap at barton springs. Pale yellow with a white head, nose is sweet, grainy, and not much else. Thin palate, flavor is bland, easy to throw back.
On tap at Uncle Billy’s. Very light yellow with a small white head. Aroma is light and grainy. Taste is malts, grainy, a little bread, and some floral hops.
Very light color, white head, hardly anything in the nose. Not bad for a blonde.

On tap at brew pub. Pours a clear straw yellow with white fizzy head. Aroma is some what floral and earthy. Flavor has faint citrus notes with grass, light earthy hop flavor, little grain. Mouth feel is light body with high carbonation. Overall, easy drinking brew.
Watery yellow pour. Small bubbly white head. Lemon wheat, bitter grass. very foamy. Not great.

A sample served at the brew pub. Pours light and clear. Little hop aroma present, almost kolsch-like. Earthy tastes with subdued fruit. Light-bodied and gentle mouthfeel. Certainly drinkable, but not my favorite style.

Keg at the Brewpub in Beroun Day 4 of Fergus and Sarah’s Czech jaunt. 2/10/14. Clear mid amber / copper colourd pour with a lasting frothy cream head. Aroma is nutty toasted grains, jammy fruits and yeasty. Flavour is composed of sweet grains, toasty, nutty jammy fruits. Palate is fullish body, crisp and sweet. Very well balanced, hint of earthy. Tasty beer.
Bottled. A dark golden beer with a beige head. The aroma is acidic and sweet with notes of straw and malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and straw, as well as a touch of lemon.
bread, nuts, golden, hazy, white foam, medium bitterness, light sweetness, medium body, sticky, average yeast beer, PET 1,5l from Brewery
bottled, on the bus at rbesg08. it seemed like an off bottle, some caramel aroma, lightly grassy, somewhat musty and messy

[bottle] Aroma of honey and hops. Frothy top with big bubbles above cloudy gold-yellow. Quite bitter with fresh hops accents--otherwise boring. Light body that’s too low for style, medium carbonation, bitter finish.
Clear golden with medium white short lasting head. Sweet fruity aroma with floral and caramel notes. Sweet flavor with orange, yeast and caramel notes. Ends sweet.
Plastic bottle. Hazy yellow with a lasting white head. Aroma is grainy and bready malt. Dry malty flavour with a fruity note, decent hop flavour and bitter finish.

(6/26/08) Draught at the brewpub in Beroun. Hazy reddish-amber with a beige head. Aroma of malt, some toastiness and a bit of caramel. Sweetish malty flavor with some soft bitterness later. Medium-bodied. Nice.
Bottle on bus - RBESG. Cloudy yellow - white head. Peppery, straw, hay, spicy, honey, wierd, unclean, light infection, vegetables.
Bottle. Hazy and golden coloured. Nice and warm in the bus. Notes of grass, honey. spices, plastic and alcohol.
Brewery brewpub. Hazy orange golden color with thick white head. Aroma of mat, yeast, hops. Taste, solid malty base followed by nice hoppy bitterness.medium long hoppy birptter finish. Good.
Fles gedronken tijdens vakantie. Goudgeel helder bier, schuim blijft even staan. Weinig aroma, licht fruitig. De smaak is licht bitter. Smaak blijf even hangen. Matig pils
On tap @ the brewery. Tipikus nefiltrovany, könnyed testtel. Kicsit vizes. De sebaj.

On tap at Mad for Beer in Rome-Italy. Semi clear gold pour, tick white foamy head. Nose: rustic, pungent grass, grains. Mouth: Pils essence, clean feel of lemon grass and noble hops. Great Pils. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap @Mad for Beer (Rome). Pale golden appearance, a bit cloudy (unfiltered), decent white foam. Aroma is bread, cereals, dough rises, biscuits, little grass, so delicate! Flavour is little sweet with a decent bitter end, delicate, fresh and perfectly balanced. Low body, medium to low carbonation. So nice and tasty! I could drink it all night!

Draft. An unclear golden beer with a huge white head. The aroma is sweet wirth notes of malt, eggs, bread, and some hops. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of bread, eggs, and hops, as well as hints of straw and fruits, leading to a dry bitter finish.

From tap at Svejk, Frederiksberg, DK. Pours hazy orange with a slowly collapsing white head. Smooth yeasty and light toasted malty aroma. Mild sweetend malt flavour,light cornish and slight acidic initial flavoured. Subdued diacetyl accent, really minor - but there. Ends mild acidic and malty, light bittered.

Draught at the brewery tap. Cloudy, pale golden, quite stable small white head, distinctive yeasty, almost barnyardy nose with a hoppy background, light bitter/sweet flavour, light bodied as well, almost lingering hoppy and yeasty finish. Not really convincing........

Draught at Soldaten Svejk, Stockholm. (Served during a mini-festival for unpasteurized Czech beers.) Hazy golden, dense creamy head. Hay is dominant up front, some orange is present. Lies soft in the mouth with some malt sweetness, butter, salt and hay. Grassy hops dry it out and gives a balanced bitter finish.
on tap at the brewery, not available anywhere else. Huge head, hazy with yeast (unfiltered). Czech beer at its best. Fruity and yeasty with great hop flavours.
On Tap- Nose is fruits, banana, clove, bready, citrus, wheat, lemon..Taste is wheat, banana, clove, earthy,..Palate is light and refreshing
on tap-pours a white head and hazy yellow color. Aroma is banana/clove/pepper, light malt. Taste is banana/clove/pepper, light malt-slightly sweet. Thin finish.
On tap at brew pub. Cloudy yellow. Nose of a lighter German hefe...with some citrus in there as well. Flavor was pretty subdued, and very light bodied. Not for me.

(Sample at Uncle Billy’s on August 2, 2008) Served with an orange wedge… at first sight this looks like grapefruit/orange juice. Solid, cloudy. I notice that none of these samples seem to have much head. After a good amount of citrus goodness goes straight up my nose (there I go again), I feel the full aroma. Spoiled by the orange, I remove it. I still smell the rind on my fingers. Suddenly every encounter I’ve ever had with an orange flashes through my mind. Its aroma is citric, nothing more really. It’s flavor, though… you can actually taste some hay (unless that’s all psychological), with serious orange and lemon. Not sure why they would add an orange wedge to intensify this. I think I’d be drinking orange juice if I had left it in. I dig the palate, though. Thick, well-constructed. Lively, but not carbonated, tangy. Tastes natural, alcoholically, of course. Really not that bad.

On tap at the brewpub; nice cloudy yellow color with an average white head. Aroma was predominantly banana/bubblegum. Lacked much spicing or balance in the flavor. Found it a bit sweet; lacked great flavor for me, but it definitely was solid. The beer looked and smelled really good.
Pours a medium-dark golden/yellow/brown color with a medium white head. Aroma is of banana and yeast. Flavor is of banana and some spice. On tap.

Deep, cloudy yellow, candy sugar sweet aroma. Aroma is also very dirty, dirt earthen and beertank-like. Very cloudy, Small lacing. Fizzy mouth feel but not overly so. Just enough to be differently satisfying. Bold strong wheat flavor, accentuated by the fizz, but the taste is a little watery on the finish. Taste also has orange citrus flavor. The fizz lingers on the finish for a minute or more which is very satisfying.
Draught. Lemon and banana aromas with various yeast subtleties. Cloudy yellow with a good white head. Hardy and refreshing. Good balance of acidity and bitterness with some spice and ester presence.

An outstanding hefeweizen! Cloudy, ochre colored with a nice head & lacing. Nose is clightly citric, with some clove touches. Flavor has perfect tartness intermingling with cloves. Yeasts are not banana-like, but certainly play with your tongue. Awesome carbonation, with lots of fancy bubbling. Quality brew.

From sampler- came with lemon, bad bad bad, wanted it without to try first. Cloudy yellow in appearance. Aroma of wheat and fruit, nice. Hit the mouth a little watery, some fruit taste did stand out, but was gone long before it was swallowed.

This is one of Bateman’s ’Mystic Brews’, they are producing beers for various signs of the Zodiac during different times of the year. This beer was tasted at the bi-annual beer festival held at the brewery (May 2007). Hand pulled in the windmill, brewery bar. The pint sleeve glass had a dark amber beer with an off-white topped head, it looked good. The smell was most offputting, an almost fowl aroma of sulphur and farmyards almost made me take the beer back. Luckily the taste and mouthfeel made up for the aroma, a solid English bitter flavour, not a fantastic, must have another straight away sort of beer, but fine none-the-less.
Cask Handpump at the Plough, Houghton Green 30/05/2009 Some malt aroma. Amber coloured and a little fruity with a hint of dryness in a lasting malt finish.

Cask, Swan and Rushes, Leicester. Amber brown with a small head. Aromas are earthy berries with toffee. Flavours are toffee malts with tea and dry hops. Spices with citrus and traces of salt. Fruity and clean with pear. Very dry on the finish.

After Bateman’s Taurus, the first in their series of ’Mystic Brews’, I was looking forward to this month’s offering. Expectation was justified by this amber beer with a malty aroma and taste, balanced with pear fruit, a little smokiness and a crisp bitter finish. Beautifully served at the Wellington Arms, Bedford.
Dark cloudy amber, full-bodied with strong bourbon aroma. Creamy pa³ate with a taste that quickly explodes into a lingering bourbon finish.
got a six of the dubbel as a gift that rekindled my experience with the bourbon in 2008. i could’nt forget that celery salt flavor even after i got tanked. i think the combination hit it off for me.

On tap for Flying Fish Mad Monday. Pour is a deep blackish amber. Zero head and lacing. Aroma and taste is exploding with vintage oaky woods, butter, figs, raisins, burnt caramel, dark fruits and vanilla. Insanely smooth drinkability for an abbey dubbel. I like this better then prior 8 and Westmalle’s dubbel. Worthy of the silver it received at the 2008 GABF and hands down the best FF beer I have had. Amazing
Aroma of bourbon and caramel. Pours dark brown but not thick with no head. Tastes of bourbon, sour malt, and sugary. This was surprising and delicious!
I love this brew. Poured dark amber with a creamy tan head. Aroma of bourbon and plum. Mellow bourbon flavor with some fruit in the finish.
2008 GABF. Bourbon nose, cloudy golden medium body and mouthfeel. Caramel and vanilla in flavor. Medium finish. Quite tasty.
A great Belgian ale for those who can tell. The yeast is particularly strong and sweet.

On draft at Grey Lodge 7/08, served in a pint glass. Cloudy, dark amber with minimal head. Nice bourbon aroma. Was quite sweet at first, giving way to a lingering pleasant bourbon aftertaste. Overall, a very nice job.

On draft at the GL.  Pours a cloudy amber with a tiny light beige head.  Appears almost flatlike.  Aroma of light bourbon notes, caramel and sour vanilla oak.  Taste of light bourbon, vanilla oak and caramel.  Has a slightly sour finish.  Very nice done and not overdone with the bourbon.

Draft @ Grey Lodge. Pours a pulpy orange-brown color with golden edges; thin off-white head with patchy, fine-bubbled lacing. Solid amounts of slightly tart citrus, grapefruit, and sour-mash bourbon notes; pulpy fruits, citrusy bourbon, and a touch of toasty brown sugar. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: lots of lively, zesty citrus and grapefruit upfront, surrounding lightly chewy, toasty oak and bourbon; soft bourbon, light abbey dubbel presence underneath (brown sugar, breadiness), and just a really nice, zesty grapefruit and apple presence throughout; really enjoyable; not immensely heavy, just very nicely drinkable. Lengthy finish: breadiness, toasty malts, cereal, and a touch of soft brown sugar.

Bottle at home ...deep black v light thin head ... ... quite blackcurrant ...little balsamic vinegar which oddly isnt ruining this, though it does distract ... roast malts ... thinish mouth feel ... little copper.... bit midding
Bottled. Black as night with a short lived beige head. The aroma is fairly burnt malts. The taste is quite thin and watery amongst the burnt malts and sour coffee. A bit of a mish mash.
Bottle. Black beer with a light head. The aroma is lightly coffee, roasted and slightly smoked. The flavour is very grassy and watery coffee bitter. Overall a poorish beer.

Bottle 33cl. @ DHVL Gardenparty and Beerfestival 2009. Clear medium amber color with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, flowers, sweet honey notes, moderate yeasty, spicy, thyme. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090906]

33 cL bottle at DHVL Gardenparty and Beerfestival 2009. Pours clear and golden deep amber with a small white head. Aroma is dry and slight spiced. Vague malty and yeasty spiced flavorued. Nicely spiced and dry finish. Phenolic and dry finish.

Bottle, 33 cl. garden beerfestival 06.09.09 @ Heeren v Liedekercke. Hazy amber color, with off-white head. Aroma sweet, malts and spice. Medium body. Taste start sweet, full of malt, yeast touch, thyme, and little bitterness. . Dry end. Aftertaste bit spice &#40tyme&#41. Not bad.

Cask at the Nags Head, Covent Garden - as Nags Head,16/07/18. Clear golden copper with a decent off white head, good full glass lacing ensues. Nose is mellow fruit rinds, breads, straw, biscuit, light caramel. Taste comprises airy malts, toffee, toasted grains, light fruit cake, and little hedgerow. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, semi drying close. So so bitter ... a bit on the thin side.

Draught (Nag's Head, Bishop's Stortford) as "Nag's Head Ale" (6:4:5+:4:11=3.0-) Simple malty aroma, a dullish bitter. Dark orange. Full smooth palate. Boring twiggy bitter taste, a touch sulfurous and minerally.

Cask (Nags Head, Bishops Stortford) as "Nags Head Ale", 3.8%. Clear amber color. Grainy, dusty and dirty in aroma. Sourish, dirty, faint hops in taste. Feels dirty and not very well made. Average brew.

Pours a clear golden color with a light tan head. The smell is mineral, toasted malt, biscuit. The taste is mineral, toasted malt, ending dry and slightly bitter. The body is light+ with fine carbonation.
Draft at the Nag’s Head - Covent Garden. Hazy amber body with small creamy head. Rather pedestrian bitter, gentle malts in aroma and taste. Nothing too remarkable here. Drinkable, but forgettable.
Half pint @ Nag’s Head, London. Smooth, calm. Not that complex aroma as expected.

Pint draught (cask) as Nag’s Head bitter @ Nag’s Head, London. Clear amber or dark golden colour, nice head. Now, this is what a good bitter should taste - not just bitter hops and water but also malts and fruity flavours. This was the best bitter on my Christmas trip to London 2015.

Cask @ Nags Head McMullen, Covent Garden, London. Clear golden color, small creamy white to off-white head. Smell and taste malts, malt bitter, bitter and a weird kind of slightly vegetal hoppyness. Average body and carbonation. One of so so many, but it’s ok, drinkable.
Gold with average white head. Nose of malt and hints of hops. Very sweet up front, not as sweet as their honey, but plenty of honey sweetness. Nice carbination with a light hoppy and dry finish.

Draft at the brewery on 7/19/07. Clear gold under a medium white head. Grainy, peppery aroma with some light caramel. Medium body and light carbonation, with a pleasingly clean palate. Honey like sweetness offset by a softly citrus based bitterness, finishing clean adn dry.

On draught at the Big Sky brewery’s tap room in Missoula, Montana. Pours a clear golden amber brew with a fast dissolving white head. Aroma of light caramel malt, citrus and flowery hops with a touch of clover honey. Taste is llightly carbonated, light to medium bodied with a good balance of malt and citrus hop flavors. Finish is slightly metalic, dry and then soft with a sweet citrus aftertaste. It’s a little light in flavor but the finish is still a good pale ale.

Draft 8 oz glass at the brewery tap; golden amber and pretty active with an average thin head. Brisk aroma of honey and hops...smooth tangy malt brew with quite a fruity hop undertow. Good light ale with a bite. (#2924, 5/19/2007)

Bottle at home, 25/08/16. Clear golden orange with a well appointed off white head that retains well. Nose is earthy citric rinds, straw, orange peel, light bread dough, pale malts, faint spice. Taste comprises soft malts, straw, toasted grains, orange rind, bready. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, semi drying close with light bitterness. Ok golde.

Cask-conditioned, on gravity at the Nailsea and Backwell beer and cider festival, 16/7/2016. Deep gold in colour and with a slight, off-white, head. Citrus fruits, leafy hops, balancing biscuity malts and a dryish finish. A good beer.

Gravity at The Leek Hockey Club Beer Festival. A clear deep golden colour with a frothy white head. Aroma of lemon, some orange, a little peach and slight grassy, herbal hops. Taste of lemon, some orange, slight caramel and grassy, herbal hops. Light bodied and a slight oily texture. A sweetish, herbal bitterness in the finish. At times like a lemony cough sweet, but overall a decent blonde ale.

A pale golden yellow beer with a weak white head. A distinctly hoppy aroma, citrus fruits, lemon, orange and grapefruit! There is an underlying malt aroma too. The taste is dry, with plenty of hop flavours, a tiny hint of floral hop, then a burst of citrus fruit, again orange and lemon. These are present in a fairly long, dry finish. (Cask - 2007 Cambridge Beer Festival).

Draught sample at the brewpub, early March 2007. WHOA another IPA from Willimantic, who’d’a thunk it? Good thing these guys are so creative with their hops....pours totally opaque, unfiltered apricot-gold with just a bit of foam that lasts for a moment or two....the nose is gorgeously spicy-perfumy, with complex interactions of cardamom, lavender, cherry blossoms and pepper, really one of the most sublime aromas in a hoppy beer I’ve experienced....flavor is not quite as delightful but still top-notch, strongly hoppy-spicy-sharp throughout, lots of carroway/rye notes, light citrus (mostly grapefruit but a hint of lime as well), twiggy-barky towards the finish....moderate, very natural carbonation and quite full body. A delight, very easy to drink despite the complexity and sharpness.

column1: Rock Bottom Denver Black Bull Bock
column5: at greenwood village location. copper pour iwth nice clarity and frothy off white head. big sour malt, fruit, roasted nut aroma. smooth and medium body. roasted nuts/malts are solid. fresh hops, lemon, some dark fruit. nicely balanced and enjoyable.

Cask-conditioned at the Bon Accord, Glasgow 1/07/09. Golden in colour with a decent white head. Aroma of summer fruits with some grassy hops. Flavour of biscuit malts and and more fruit with a decent bitter finish. Good.

On top, halfway house Edinburgh ... Bright golden yellow ... lively fruit nose ... rich tea biscuits in the nose ...biscuity ... with bitter linger. After tom sugested i smells of rich tea biscuits thats all i could taste or smell. Thanks tom.

This sold out in my work so fast i didnt get the chance to taste it, so iu had to go to the bon accord to get it. Aroma is typical inveralmond house biscuity malt, peaches and lemon are here. Taste is a similar bag, but increadibly drinkable, balanced, really great ale.

Cask, Whey Pat Tavern Ale Festival, St Andrews. Note this is the "internal" version of the pale ale. Light amber, thin off-white head. Nose is slightly sherberty and bitter, not much to it. Mouth is better with bitterness, but some fruity goodness, reminded me of crab apples, hops and tannin. Palate ends very bitter, but quite smooth at the same time. One of those you don’t know you’re drinking so fast...
Very nice blonde ale. Super smooth from cask. A little citrus. A little malt.
Cask (4%), 1/3 pint by hand-pump at GRAF 2018, The Briggait, Glasgow on 21 Jun 2018: grassy lemon aroma, golden, thin white head, no lacing, lemon, biscuit flavour, creamy, balanced.

Cask at Den Engel, Leek. A clear straw colour with a medium white head. Aroma of lemon, slight apple, a little pale malt and subtle spicy hops. Taste of lemon, some apple, slight pale malts, a hint of liquorice and subtle spicy hops. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A short, dry, spicy hop bitterness in the finish. Soft citrus but weird spicy hop notes. Some apple but not offputting. Ok.
Cask @ The Salopian, Shrewsbury. Pours clearish gold, white head. Aroma is fruity, taste is jammy apricot and not what I’d consider typifies the Chinook hop, but it’s nice enough.
On Cask in Bell at Pensax. Really pale with grapefruit burst. Great session ale
Interesting golden ale tarte Apple maybe a hint of cinnamon hops come through at the end ok Retried at the navigation good beer citrus sessionable

On cask at Firefly, Worcester. Appearance - golden with a proportionate head. Nose - lemon and pale malt. Taste - more lemon barley water. Palate - light to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a long dry finish. Overall - a decent ale.

25th April 2015: gravity poured half-pint at a beer festival in the Duke of York, Lichfield. Another citrusy blonde, fed up with them. This was not as bad as some, but I would like brewers to move on now and leave this fad behind. Scored objectively.
Cask@The Victoria, Birmingham B1. Pale with a white head. Hoppy with citrus and floral notes. Pleasant, and easy drinking without being exceptional.
On cask at hopinn, Newcastle under Lyme. Light golden with a bright white head. Easy drinking pale, nothing particularly showstopping to make it stand out from 100s of other golden ales.
light, thin, lacks banana or any sweetness or characteristic spices. looks great, bigh white head and opaque orange, otherwise a complete failure, rare for fitgers.

Pours hazy yellow with nice fluffy white head, looked great in the glass. Aroma has notes of clove, banana, some bubblegum, sweet apricot and some pear. Taste is sweet but a bit lacking in intensity, has notes of bubblegum, banana in the forefront, slight clove in there, sweet and slightly dry finish. Refreshing.
Cloudy yellow pour with minimal head. Wheat dominates the nose. Wheat body with hint of banana.

On tap at the Fitgers Brewhouse in Duluth, MN, pours a very cloudy golden yellow brew with a fizzy white head. Fast dissolving to a fine lacing. Aroma of a typical hefeweizen of yeast and wheat with a touch of tropical fruit. Taste is medium body, carbonated, and a dry finish. Not much in hop bitterness but it has a dry aftertaste.

On tap at the brewpub. Clove and oyster platter aroma. Musky and mildly spiced. Sweet. Incredibly clouded deep gold, tinted in amber, with a perfectly white sharp head. Easily the most murky, clouded beer I’ve ever seen. Damn near milk. Flavor moves with a light gentle wheat oil grace, spritzy and full of banana peel and pulp. Gentle. A nip thin, but bringing stellar drinkability to the table. Finishes on a bite of almond skin, almost no hop presence. Clean, bright, and refreshingly. Quite enjoyable.

Tap at the Lake Grive location: Pours near black with a thin tan head. The aroma is decent, with a coffee-ish character. A bit thin bodied. The flavor has a roasty quality, however, there are some weird chemical-like flavors such as permanent marker. Some salty licorice notes, vinegar qualities with a somewhat vacant finish. Not a stand out Stout.
Cask conditioned @ Guide Dog, Soton. Brown. Oaky tobacco with toffee, dry toasty malts. Dry with dusty earthy hop finish. Quite pleasant but I dont think I’d want more than one.
Old Rating. Bottle. I didn’t realise that the brewery had closed since I sampled this beer. Pale brown bitter. A soft, malty, fruity bitter with a medium bitter finish.

Bottle conditioned, May 2008. No best before date. Amber colour. Dry and slightly bitter. Some hints of dry fruit. A rather dusty strong bitter that was perfectly respectable but didn’t deliver much punch for the style. Perhaps the ones imdownthepub and Fin had were from a better/fresher batch.

Bottle @ home. [ Courtesy chris_o ]. Clear medium amber color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, moderate yeasty, sour - acidic. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to light heavy bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium to light, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. (130508)

Bottle conditioned, 500ml, from Westholme Stores, Goring on Thames, Oxon. Ambrer with white head. Good, full bodied hoppy bitter with a deeper flavoured body than many. Some caramel and roasted barley notes, quite grainy with a slight touch of Burtonization, then the main show, the dry hops, big, fresh, bitter and dry giving a long refreshing finish. A well crafted bigger bitter.

BCA, picked up from Millets Farm near Abingdon, Oxon. Poured amber in colour with decent hoppy and malty aroma. Nice full flavoured bitter which is quite chewy with good fruitiness and malts prominent. Really enjoyed this beer from Butlers.

Bottle 500ml. @ home. [ As Genossenschaftsbrauerei Rötz Guttensteiner Halbe ]. Clear dark red brown colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, sweet malt, bread, caramel, dark malt, sugary malt, light brown sugar. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration, sweet malt, dark malt, sugary malt, fruit - berry notes. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20180122] 5-4-6-3-12
Bottle. Dark brown color. Malty caramelly aroma. Malty sweet, soft roasty caramelly flavor. medium to full bodied. Low on carbon. Quite pleasant. Thanks Beerhunter111!
50cl bottle. A clear dark brown beer with a small beige head. Aroma of mild roasted malt, caramel, hints of coffee. Taste of mild sweet caramelish dark malt, nuts, some chocolate, quite nice!
bottle, Danke pivnizub! Hazy brown colour, large off-white head. Caramel, roasted malt, ovomaltine, cocoa powder present. Meidum-bodied, smooth palate. A pleasure.

Bottle: Clear, ruby amber coloured, bigger loose - slowly collapsing - off-white head; light to moderate dryish roasty-caramelly nose; moderate sweet-bitter flavour, light bodied and soft; almost moderate sweetish-caramelly finish, accompanied by roasty and bitter flavours. Brave Dunkel......

(bottle) Hazy, dark brown colour with a thick and stable beige foamy head. Light-sweet, strong dark malty, roasty aroma with cacao/chocolate and a pleasant herbal hops presence. Mainly bitter, slightly sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a mild carbonation. Toast-malty, slightly roasted taste with chocolate and light notes of caramel; aromatic, dry, malt-accented finish with roasted barley, a herbal hoppy bite and a lasting aftertaste with chocolate. Well-crafted, moreish Dunkel. Normally I don´t go into details concerning bottle labels, but this one is really mentionable and old-fashioned (probably 1930ties design), showing the silhouette of a fierce looking robber-knight, Heinrich von Guttenstein, who gave the brew its name.

Bottled. An amber beer with a huge orange head. The aroma is sweet with notes of straw and metal. The flavor is sweet malty with metallic notes of alcohol, leading to a dry bitter finish. Quite simple.

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of MoritzF. Clear, amber golden with a creamy, off-white head. Sweetish aroma of roasted malt. Full body with a solid malt base, roasted malt accents and a little flowers with a dry finish without much bitterness. Neat alright. 201107

50 cL bottle. Pours slight hazy orange with a dense off-white head. Aroma is slight grainy and mild hoppy. Soft mix of mild caramel malt and bitterhops, almost mellow but at least smooth. End has a mild bitterness.
Bottled. Amber coloured. Prunes, caramel and roasted malts in the aroma and in the flavour. Sweet. Slightly dry finish.

Bottle: Light amber coloured, slightly lacing off-white head, solid malty and toasted-malty nose with some bitterness in the wings; moderate to solid sweet-bitter flavour, medium bodied; lingering bitter-sweet-toasted-malty finish. A quite malty and sweet, but all in all well balanced Bock........
Bottle at ronnies. Aroma is baked beans plus roasted malts, hints at chocolate malt. Taste is sweet pale malts, grassy hop, hints of baked beans and roasty. Not my scene.

Bottle, 6.3%. Slightly rough aroma, fruity from the hops. Clear dark copper colour. Stable light brown head. The flavour is quite malty and a little sweet. Well balanced by the alcohol with a tiny hint of plastic in the aftertaste. The plastic notes seem to give way for a nicer alcohol flavour as I have more.

(bottle, purchased at a drinks market somewhere in Meiningen) Clear, amber coloured with an initially fluffy, light tanned foam, quickly diminishing into a creamy layer. Sweet, slightly toasted malty nose, slightly nutty and minimal bready with a very faint hoppy note. Sweet flavour, medium body, crispy mouthfeel. Malt-accented, moderately toasted taste; sweet-bitter finish with moderate hops in the background and light notes of caramel in the aftertaste. Rather one-dimensional, also quite dark Maibock, not far away from the Winterbock by Meininger.

Brown pour with off white head and lace. Aroma of citrus hops and light chocolate. A flavor of fresh citrus hops, roasted malt and chocolate. Very smooth mouthfeel and good carbonation. Old notes from 07 darklord day.

Wax Color Code for Flossmoor Station Bottled IPA’s Black = X-IPA, Gold = Pretty Big IPA, Burgundy = Vishnu’s Vice IPA , Blue = Lady Columbia, Green = Ahtanumous, Silver = Hoppy Little "O", Red = The Curse, Dark Green = IPA for Change, Purple = Celebration IPA This bottled brew sealed with black wax from a bottle shop poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized off-white colored bubbles that were long lasting and left behind a very hazy strongly carbonated dark orange brown colored body and a fair lacing. The aroma was bready mild hop and dough. The mouth feel was strongly tingly at the start and mediumly tingly at the finish. The nice flavor contained notes of hops and caramel. Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.

Date: 04/28/2007 Mode: Growler Source: Brewpub black, wispy beige head, lots of speckled lace, sweet chocolate aroma with citrus hops, rich chocolate flavor, lots of citrus hops adds character but not well blended enough to balance, a really nice chocolate IPA, -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 04/29/2007 Mode: growler Source: tasting Score: 3.5 to 3.8 much better blended on the second night, the chocolate and citrus make for a great combination much like the roasted and citrus in the Black Sun, the sweetness from the XIPA also brings out more of the chocolate Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.8/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: ***/4

A blend of Pullman Brown and X IPA served from a growler given to kp by Matt on DL Day. Pours a clear dark brown body with a thin, off-white head. Although there are hops in the aroma, they aren’t what I expect from either an IPA or an IIPA. Not enough bitterness for it to be any form of IPA, but too far from a Brown Ale to go that direction. Chocolate IPA.

Draft at Flossmoor. Okay, so far this is a rate-able beer, so let’s pull out my memories of last month’s tasting: Pullman malts are very much there, in their molasses and leaf tobacco texture. Smell has the "X’s" hop nose. Totals up to a deep malt package with a counterpoint in heavy citrusy hops. Can go well for you if just try to get along.

This beer very much had the appearance of a brown ale but one whiff and you can tell it was mixed with an IPA. The very citrusy hop notes in the aroma make me very excited for actually sampling this brew. However, I felt the flavour was a let down. The first thing I thought was a chocolatey IPA. I really didn’t think the beers mixed well and probably would have prefered them by themselves. The brown ale undertones were good but the IPA thrown in gave it some strange characters and an odd balance which proved too hoppy and not well enough melded with the brown.

A blend of Pullman Brown and X IPA served from a growler given to kp by Matt around DL Day. Brown hued with a small frothy head and okay lacing. The aroma has a pronounced juicy fruit hop vapor along with with piney, clove, nutty, toffee and yeasty esters. WOW, that is hoppier than expected but still has great balance with a spicy finish layered over the base brown ale malts. There is some lingering acidity that added to the refreshment. The mouth feel is sharp and dry with a minor metallic note. I really dig it, what a strange brew but something he should really brew. We have hoppy Belgian Ales, why not hoppy Browns?

Can: Pours a golden pale color with light head, which goes down quick. A squalid nose with some light toast and a quickly disappointing hop and grassy chemical note. The flavor is sharp, not bitter or hoppy, just chemically and dry, lots of adjuncts and corn. Bah! Happoshu.

Another new macroswill from Sapporo. Clear, pale gold color with a white head, active carbonation (Gee surprise surprise) Scent of sour wet hay, taste, typical bland macro, light sweetness in the front, slight metallic tang in the middle, quick finish with a touch of dry grass and spice/cigar tobacco hop in the aftertaste. *Yawn* Why can’t they make beers with some flavor?

Bottle shared by RussianDragon. Turn back the clock. The beer is copper orange with a small off-white head. Light haze. Aromas include apples, brown sugar, yeast, oranges, butterscotch. Sweet and syrupy with prominent honey character. Thick on the palate with low carbonation. Alcohol presence is tamed by time but the beer is still a bit of a chore. Best shared many ways.

22 oz bottle. Pours a clear, still medium orange amber color with virtually no head. Aroma is mild yet medicinal with malt, caramel, toffee, booze and notes of dark fruit. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a long duration, fruity, caramel, alcohol, sweet candy, plum. Mouthfeel is thick and oily, carbonation is minimal. 6/10/14
Rated in 2010 (Backlog) - Orange gold with a small white head. Aroma is of grain, malt and caramel. Taste is of caramel, grain, maple, toffee, malt and honey.
Been a minute. Remember an Earthier malt bomb that was thick. Low carbonation. Sweet but dirty hoppy finish. Confused BW.

Obviously well aged bottle at this point - murky brown, thought not totally opaque pour with the thinnest of off-white heads that leaves a lasting ring at the edges of the glass. Aroma is malt, honey, brown sugar, hint of booze - somewhat faint...very sweet! Flavor is quite good - lots of honey, some sweet malt, lightly hopped, some booze at the end. Very little hint of the rye remaining, which is disappointing, but perusing some earlier reviews, I think this may have benefited nicely from the age. Palate is moderately thick, oily, light carbonation, slight burn on finish. Not a half bad beer...definitely better than the ratings had me expecting before open.
Aged 5+ years. I enjoyed this quite a bit, the beer was well integrated with a faint cherry sourness offsetting the thick, somewhat spicy brew. Nice warm finish.
Bottle. Golden in color, clear look, and has a light white head. The smell is sweet, yeast, rye, malts, cereal, and ok. The taste is sweet, a mingling of fruits, rye, and caramel.
