Bomber @ Kaj. Pours slightly cloudy darker amber with a small bubbly beige head. Aroma is fruity malty raisins a bit sourish toasted vinous. Flavor is vinous fruity malty grapes raisins slightly bitter very fresh. Finishes bitter malty fruity.

Bottle 12fl.oz. [ Trade by madmitch76 ]. [ Vintage 2007 ]. Clear medium orange amber colour with virtually none head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, oxidide, toffee, alcohol, plum notes. Flavour is moderate to light heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a long duration, fruity, caramel, alcohol, sweet candy, plum. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20121116]
2007 vintage enjoyed October 2, 2012. Carbonation kept over 5 years quite well and very smooth for a barleywine. Bit on the vinous side. Very nice beer which aged very well.
cask at cloister ... eep red brown ...thin tan head ... soft roast ... sweet fruits ... light sweet roast ... juicy roast ... light mellow roast ... nice

Cask (handpump) @ Gardeners Rest, 105 Neepsend Lane, Sheffield, South Yorkshire England S3 8AT. Clear medium to dark red brown color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, light coffee. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to light light heavy bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily and sticky, carbonation is flat to soft. [20100424]
Cask Handpump at the Gardener’s Rest, Sheffield 24/04/2010 Pale malt aroma. Dark coloured and a little rich on the palate with a dry and slightly bitter pale malt finish.
Cask at the University Arms, Sheffield. Pours a clear brown with a off-white head. Aroma is grainy. Flavors lean to chewy malts, chocolate, and grain. Need to re-rate.
Aroma was grainy with a bit of chocolate malt evedent. Taste was sillilar with a bit of bitterness that was unexpected.
A hooppy, grassy and hints of citrus nose. Taste was straight up durham yeast with loads of hops, really drinkable.
I don’t know much about craft beer, but I like this beer. It’s quite good.f

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Cambridge BF. A quite bright golden coloured beer. The aroma is hoppy with orange and lemon notes. The taste has hops also. Quite a light tasting beer, and suffering from being on the warm side, but decent enough.
Bottle. Brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is fruit, malt, hop, caramel. Flavour is fruit, malt, hop, caramel, bread, toffee, grain. Medium body. Ordinary beer. KRS 160814.

Bottle. Pours amber with an off-white head. Aroma of caramel, malt, some citrus, berries and fruitiness. Flavor is sweet and malty with some caramel, nuts,grains and chocolate. Medium body, average carbonation.

Bottle. It pours a finger-thick beige head over a brown body. The aroma has some bread crusts, but it’s rather weak. Toffee and dried fruits too. Toffee, chocolate, bread crusts and a hint of bitterness in the flavor. Some pine cone and grass. Medium body, quite dry, with a nice carbonation level. Lasting toffee and bread crust finish. Nothing impressive going on here, but it’s a decent ale for sure. 140816

Bottle 500ml @ Geokkjer Pours clear reddish brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, floral and hint of chocolate. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with a caramel and slightly chocolate finish. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.
# 381; 8/2016. Øízné, svìží pšenièné pivo s výraznì ovocnou chutí (pomeranèe, banány) a jemnou koøenitostí (høebíèek).
Bottle from bier-kaufen.de. Hazy yellow colour, creamy white foam. Nose of banana, yeast, light citrus. Taste is light sweet, some tart notes. Good hefeweizen.

Many thanks for this beer to kevnic2008. Piana wielka jak amerykanscy koszykarze z NBA, trwa³a niczym lod na Antarktydzie. Kolor jasny i lekko pomaranczowy, sporo osadu bylo, fajny drozdzowy posmak, skorka od chleba pszennego. Mimo drozdzowego harakteru pszeniczniak ten w moim odbiorze jest delikatny i przyjemny, dla wielu pijalny.
Sampled at the brewpub. Lasting fluffy white head. Light clowdy pale amber color. Balanced banana aroma. Big taste of bananas and low maltines. Dry finish.
Bottle. Blonde. Citrus in the aroma and flavor. Wheaty, slightly floral, refreshing.

Bottle 50cl. Clear medium golden, large frothy white head, half-way lasting, fair lacing; aroma is wheat, some banana, light citrus, yeasty; taste is medium sweet and light sour, average duration, wheat, bit banana, finish sweet with light sour touch; medium body, watery to oily texture, soft carbonation; ok Weisse.
Bottle looks simple but really good. Beer in the glass zippy, nice head. Starts mild, malty, more and more yeasty, not too dry. Mild sweetish notes. Well balanced finish, hints of banana. Nice.

bottle, shared with mowbeer. hazed light golden with a persistent head; light banana and vanilla in the aroma, somewhat subdued; hints of hay and vanilla, light bitterness; soft texture; drinkable enough
*Old rating. Best before 09.06.11. The beer is smooth and fresh. Yeasty-smooth, nice and round.

Pours hazy orange, with a big white head. Sweetish aroma with notes of wheat, burnt malts and some banana. Taste is malty and yeasty at first, but there are some banana, clove and herbal notes too. Taste is much better than aroma. Quite lively CO2. Tasty and refreshing. (0,5 l bottle, best before 17.07.2014)

Third, gravicask, shared with Finn at Twickenham Beer and Cider Festival. Almost naked surface, black in the glass, spotty lacing. Earthy malts on the nose. Moderate taste of earthy chocolate malts. Roasted, mid-sweet finish. Okay mild. (24.10.2019).

Bottle: sell-by 1.02.08, drunk two weeks past this. Pours near black with a healthy white head. Superb full mouth filling beer, fully malty texture, and the richness of a real secondary fermentation. A fair amount of yeast in bottom cm of bottle, rather than the inert window dressing of most Belgian equivalents. Flavour is full-on chocolatey pleasure, hints of earthy smokyness.I think this is a better beer than any Belgian dubbel, but it is at the same time not a Belgian dubbel style. This is an authentic version of something else. Porter? I’m of the opinion that the Belgian industry in general, especially ’Abbey’ beers is in a crisis of poor quality, and it is a shame to yoke this fine beer to that declining industry. OK, I except Graal Dubbel from this criticism, and I’m sure there are more. 3 Horne Dobbelaer from NL is great too. Damn! My thesis is being spoiled. Nice one though, Kilderkin.
A very good example of a Belgian style abbey ale. Rich, malty and slightly sweet. Nice.
Bottle at ronnies, bottle conditoned. Aroma is spicey, chocolate malt, sweetish, good yeasty character. Taste is similar, however noteably maltier, bready, biscuity and choc malt.
Black with no head. Aromas of tar and roasted hops with winter fruit, sugars and liquorice. In fact, very much like TCP! Quite watery, only slightly bitter. Rich and sweet.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Cambridge BF. Now here’s a thing. A British brewery trying Belgian styles and being pretty true to style too. Long live Kilderkin Brewery and let’s hope a new wave of British breweries might be spawned in their shadow. This is a black coloured beer with hints of a whitish head. The aroma is malty with chocolate and licquorice notes. Necessarily sweet. The taste is rich and has all the attributes of the aroma together with some yeasty notes. Very good and so refreshing for an English brewer.

From the barrel - Cambridge BF. A cloudy light orangey green coloured perry. The aroma is crisp and inviting with good pears. Pretty sweet on the nose. The taste is nice and fruity. Good sweetish pears. Very easy to drink, and nice tasty flavours.

From the barrel - Cambridge BF. A quite striking cloudy orange coloured cider. The aroma is dry and apples and some tannin. The taste is good apples with a hint of sweetness. A hint of cooking apples. Quite puckering. Another good product from Gwynt y Ddraig.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Bourbon Barrel)
column5: From Mar 2008 I got this in a trade with nutbrown. Thanks Alan! Batch 1: It pours a near pitch black with some reddish hues and a 2 finger head of billowy tannish foam. Nice lacing. Very good head retention. The smell has notes of bourbon and a strong sour nose that reminds me of a american wild ale. I also get a little vanilla. Not exactly what I was expecting, or was I? The taste has some bourbon, some vanilla, some good woodiness, a touch of chocolate, and strong sour notes. The sour, imo, is just a tad too strong here and does seem to dominate but it certainly is, for me, an easy drinking Porter. I can't say that I detect much of the smoke....some day, I would love to try the version that isn't barrel aged just to see how it compares. The mouthfeel is medium-light, the carbonation is fairly robust, and it finishes with a nice taste of that bourbon. Like I said before, it's easy drinking so I'd guess the abv would be in the ~6%abv range. All in all, I like this offering from Captain Lawrence, as I did the rum barrel aged version. Very interesting flavours and pretty darned palate pleasing.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Bourbon Barrel)
column5: Bottle shared with Anker. Nice pitch black body with a nice steady mocca colored head. The aroma is roasted with some deep ripe fruity and acidic notes mixed with oak and smoke. Quite sweet sourish and bitter roasted flavor. Smoked wood and light vanilla from the bourbon. Very nice.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Bourbon Barrel)
column5: Old noted from 2010 - batch 2. Appears a deep dark cola color with a tan head than goes to a ring with some lacing. The smell is sour, dark fruit and wood. The taste is grapes, sour tartness with dry wood in the middle ending with a dry finish. Very carbonated. Overall pretty impressive beer.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Bourbon Barrel)
column5: 750ml. Smoke tinged.oily, sour Porter, this is a great beer. Lots of depth. World Class beer all the way, this is just excellent. Vinous sour tones more than balance out the dark malt tones. I love the sour black ale style, and this one nails it. Awesome stuff.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Bourbon Barrel)
column5: [4715-20120818] Bottle. Roasty smoked dry wood sweet grainy malt aroma. Hazy, dark brown with a quick foamy tan head. Smoked sweet oak barrel roasted malt flavour. Full body. Wow, good. (8/3/8/4/15) 3.8 (@ Campground Brewdown 2012, Millmont, PA) Overheard: "You can taste dread."

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Bourbon Barrel)
column5: Bottle from Batch 1 courtesy of mcallister, thanks for the opportunity. Pours a solid dark brown/black color with a huge off white head that fills half the glass and takes forever to recede. The aroma holds some roast and chocolate with a solid hit of bourbon and oak and a curious fruity tartness. The flavor follows the aroma with the sour cherries and lemons taking over the lead role and just about obscuring the porter that was once in this bottle. Medium body with a ludicrous amount of carbonation and an tart ashy bubbly mouthfeel. This beer is a shell of its former self. Some wild yeast have gotten into the bottle and turned this beer, or maybe I just sat on the bottle for too many years.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Bourbon Barrel)
column5: Bottle Batches 01 & 02 courtesy of Max at Kramer’s Campground Brewdown 2012. Both pour a deep brownish body with light fizz. Aroma on Batch 01is musky, oaky, bourbon and chocolate, while Batch 02 has a much more pronounced sour acidity present. Mouthfeel is similar on both - medium to thin with notes of bourbon, oak, chocolate, and molasses. However, the flavor of Batch 02 is completely different - veering much more into a dark sour ale with notes of tart acidity, light oak, bourbon, wine barrel, chocolate and spice. Both very solid beers. Batch 01: 3.9, Batch 02: 4.1.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Bourbon Barrel)
column5: All four variants of Smoke From The Oak served side by side at my tasting on May 29, 2010. Thanks to Pete, Chris, and Brad for supplying the bottles. Review is from notes. This beer is a dark brown color. It has a decent sized head that fades quickly leaving very little lacing. Aromas are smoke, oak (go figure), and bourbon. The flavor is pretty nice. This was my second favorite of the four bottles. This particular variant was the most sour of the four bottles. There is some noticeable heat in the finish. Although, I would drink this again, I wasn’t especially impressed by any of the Smoke From The Oak lineup.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Bourbon Barrel)
column5: (Bottle) Pours black with brown edges. Small, light brown head. The aroma is sourish with buttery and woodsy bourbon. Light fruity and smoky undertones. Hints of dust and light horse blanket. The roast and the fruitiness play well together. The flavour is light sweet to dry, light bitter and medium sourish. Tones of vinegar, fruits, light roasted malt and citrus acid. Bit earthy and mouldy. The mouthfeel is tart with a light carbonation. Citric tart finish. Medium bodied.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Bourbon Barrel)
column5: It pours thick dark rum brown with a caramel head. The aroma has big sour notes with some chocolate bourbon as well. The flavor is super sour dominant, but good with not any wild phenyl notes but pure delicous sour.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Rum Barrel)
column5: Bottle At The Carnival Tasting Ulfborg Denmark 2015-02-28. Black beer with a beige head. Malty, rum. oak aroma with Cherry notes. Sweet licorice, fruity and Woody flavour. Love the smokey notes. Really a nice beer :-)

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Rum Barrel)
column5: Brown pour with a tan head. The aroma has a lot of smoke as well as some light rum notes. The flavor is full of smoke and ash, with quite a bit of chocolate. As the beer warms the sweet rum notes begin to show up. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Nice beer.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Rum Barrel)
column5: Bottle...Pour is dark black with a tan head...Nose is smoke, brownie, dry, spice, rum, sweetness...Taste is bacon, spice, smoke, sweet rum, dry, oak,

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Rum Barrel)
column5: Bottle shared by HoppasaurusRex, thanks for the opportunity Todd Opened over the sink and the bottle proceeded to pour itself. Dark brown/black color with a huge never ending tan head. Aromas of tart cherry with hints of chocolate and dark sugary rum notes. A hint of oxidation and a touch of earth. The flavor is tart with a lactic twang. Fleeting caramel and roasted notes with a bit of woody vanillin round out the flavor. Light body with a bubbly tart mouthfeel, and a moderate to high level of carbonation. Infected, but not horrible to drink.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Rum Barrel)
column5: Shared bottle procured from a friend. Pours hazy dark blackish with tan head. Nose is oaky rauchy rum, prune, brown sugar, dark fruit. Tastes oaky, with charred rauchy malt notes, rum, molasses, dark fruit, and a complex finish. This one is delicious.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Rum Barrel)
column5: Bottle. Thanks to foppa78 for sharing. Pours a deep brown with khaki head. Slight smoke, wood, malty, burnt oak aromas. Woody flavor, slight oak.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Rum Barrel)
column5: Bottle @ JetsonFest III in KC. Pours a black appearance with a thin brown head. Anise, moderately woody smoked, slightly tangy aroma. Fairly high carbonated, a bit red fruity, herbal/woody, spicy rum, light vanilla flavor with some tanginess on the finish. Carbonation is very high.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Rum Barrel)
column5: Pours thin but black with a thin head. On the nose there are notes of smoke some charcoal some sweetness and some chocolate and coffee. On the palate the sweetness is mostly cut by the smokiness. Yum! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Rum Barrel)
column5: Bottle from tap room. Pours black with an inch of khaki foam. Prominent rum notes on the nose and the tongue. Didn’t get much of the smoked porter action. Finish lingers a bit. Solid.

column1: Captain Lawrence Smoke from the Oak (Rum Barrel)
column5: Bottle - pours cola with quite a bit of white head. Aroma is big, dominated by the rum and smoke. Taste is sweet with the bite of the alcohol on the finish. Solid.

[Growler] shared by skyview. Pours a nice looking copper color with a small soapy head. Aroma is sweet malts, some citrus, and loads of honey. Flavor is very sweet, fairly rich, a little metallic, and some caramel.
From a growler. Amber color and a thick head. Dominant character of this beer is grain. Sweet caramel and some hops. Simple but solid. Medium palate.

Sampled on draught: Pours a semi hazey amber colour with a medium sized frothy white head. Aroma is toasty, brown sugar, and caramel. Taste is very creamy on the palate, well carbonated, with semi sweet flavors throughout each sip. caramel, over ripe apples, and cranberries.

Small pour (approximately 3 oz.), on tap at Gitchee Gumee Brewfest in Superior, WI on 4-5-08. This was the eighth of 12 beers that I rated (out of about 20 total beers that I tried). Called "Muskie Capital Honey Double Maibock" at the festival. This should be listed as a doppelbock instead of a heller bock. Pours a hazy to cloudy dark gold to light amber color. Short-lasting beige head. Sweet, classic heller bock smell; tart, honeyish, almost sour aroma. Sweet, honey taste. Alcohol noticeable in the flavor. Too sweet for my taste. Medium body. Smooth in the palate.

Somehow this brewery’s location in Hayward put the words of "touristy" and "novelty" in my mind rather than "brewing credentials" before I sampled this particular beer. I was brought in by the name...seemed more interesting than their other beers. And I found it a bit novel, but not especially commendable...sadly validating my pre-judged notions a bit. This beer is sweet and boozy, like many maibocks or doppelbocks that do not contain honey, and the perception that the inclusion of honey makes beer "smooth" was not particularly valid with this beer. If anything this beer was sweeter than other maibocks, and had a graham cracker character that I didn’t particularly care for. In addition, I was genuinely bothered by high levels of diacetyl I noticed once the beer warmed up in my hand a bit, which I thought inconsistent with the style and difficult to drink. A novel name, and a bit of a unique approach, but I can’t recommend the final outcome.
Watery, not much going on the nose of this hazy amber beer. Sweet malt flavor with sour apple taste common to all the beers here.

Fourth stop during May ’07 brewpub tour, brought us to the Muskie Capital Brewpub in Hayward, WI. Fresh at the brewpub on tap, pours a semi-cloudy burnt coppery amber color brew with an average off-white head that dissolves very slowly to a fine film. Aroma of sweet buttery toast, bananas, a touch of apple juice, and sweet sugar. Taste is smooth, creamy, medium body and more sweetness on the tongue. Finish is sweet and little bitterness. The brewmaster at Muskie Capital is the same brewmaster at South Shore in Ashland. The beers are almost identical in taste except the Hayward location version has a smoother, creamy finish.

Pours a cloudy light orange with a frothy white head that quickly dissipates. Sweet aroma of pils malt, yeast and dough. Flavor is initially somewhat dry and then the creamy sweetness comes through. Medium to full bodied, low carbonation. Very sweet finish.

Growler courtesy of Skyview. Gold color with no head. Aroma is barely detectable with only a bit of yeast showing up. Flavor is mostly wheat, but there is a too strong sour and tangy element that throws it off.
On tap at the brewpub. Brown orange color. Sweet malt nose with a less sweet malt body. Smooth finish, but with that same acidity/sourness as all the other beers here.
Another from Skyview, thanks Bob. This one isn’t so good. The aroma is ok with light fruit and yeast. Sweet flavor but something is off here, it doesn’t taste anything like a tripel should.

Fourth stop during May ’07 brewpub tour, On tap at the Hayward brewpub pours a semi-clear dark golden yellow brew with a thin white head that dissolves quickly to a fine film and nice lacing. Aroma of caramel, banana, medium roasted malt and a touch of yeast. Taste is very sweet, with character of caramel, burnt brown sugar, and hardly any hops. Finish is sweet, yeasty and no bitterness. Though it is the same recipe and brewmaster at the South Shore brewpub, the finish is a little smoother and an apple aftertaste.

Tap (Bergmann Kiosk, Dortmund) Lovely sweet bready grainy aroma. Redish, tight keggy head. Starchier taste. Some paperiness fron the hops. Pleasant palate, a little sweet, and crisp carbonation. Nice maltiness in the finish. Late finish quite bitter Shame about the paperness, but this goes down lovely.
*Old rating, best before 16.09.07. Malzig-muffiges Bier, feinherb, leicht malzig mit muffig herber Note.
Bottle trade with kevnic2008 cons 2014-08-14 Göteborg AR: wee roasted malt, melas AP: amber clear, frothy steady ofwhite head F: bready, wee caramel, cardboard box, melas bb 2014-07
Kupferrote Farbe, Geruch nach kräuterigem Hopfen, gemischt mit malziger Note. Bittere könnte mehr sein.
Bottle, amber brown color with creamy tan aroma, nutty caramel aroma, flavor is caramel, some grainy roast nuts

Bottle. Light amber, small to average and fully diminishing head. Moderate malty and sweetish aroma, some caramel and light bread, faint hoppyness. Medium, malty and sweetish flavor, some caramel and light bread, faint hoppyness. Finish is short to average, malty and lightly sweetish, some caramel and light roasted malt, light sharp metal with light hoppyness. Caramel sweetish helles - too sweet for me. Could use more hoppyness.

Ich weiß nicht. Ich hatte mich auf dieses Bier gefreut, aber ein Helles war es doch nicht. Zu viel Malz, zu dunkel, zu mufflig und am Ende ein leicht bitterer und zu trockener Abgang, Schade irgendwie.

Clear amber colour with low unsteady head and medium body. Nose of malt and barley. Taste of caramel, brown sugar, mild hops, light malt, light barley and cake. Easy to drink with some hints of nuts. Moderate carbonation. Light bitter finish but altogether quite quaffable.

#129 Kupferbraune Farbe mit feinstem, schneeweißem Schaum, toll. Im Aroma malzig-süß mit einer Hopfennote, die einem Irish Red ähnelt. Der Antrunk ist dann sehr mild-malzig geraten. Im Geschmack kommt dann wieder diese Irish Red Note. Der Abgang ist mir zu kurz geraten; da könnte ne Prise mehr an Aromahopfen nicht fehlen. Fazit: Durchaus leckeres Spezial, dass allerdings nicht an die Ausnahme-Qualität des DBB Export heran kommt. Glück Auf!

Milder Antrunk, holzig, die Malzigkeit wirkt etwas metallern. Weiter mild im Mittelteil, das Aroma ändert sich kaum noch. Die Holzigkeit wird stärker, das Malz etwas intensiver. Eher langweilig. Test vom 20.12.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 6,6,5,5,8,6 - 5,80
Bottle at the Funky 8, Brooklyn, NYC. Rich. Great chocolate cake character. Very well balanced. I enjoyed this one.

Location: 22 oz bottle from Buy Rite, 9/9/12, Not the best use of Rating #2400 Aroma: The nose is caramel/chocolate malts, nutty notes, and some earth Appearance: Pours a dark orange-amber-brown color with a beige head and minimal lace Flavor: The taste is mostly malts (caramel, chocolate, dark fruit), with minimal bitterness Palate: The body is medium, leaning light, a bit watery, with a short, imperfect duration Overall Impression: This one is OK, but it isn’t a favorite for me.
22nd November 2009 ChrisOs Kook Tasting. Hazy brown beer. Chocolate nose. Aged chocolate malt. No hops or anything else just light powdered chocolate.

Bomber pours deep rutty amber with minimal head. OK, let’s crack this Riddler. In the aroma I get big smashed cherries, brown sugar simmering plums and pomegranates as well as lesser amounts of earthiness and Christmas like spices. The taste is similar with bold cherry, plum and pomegranate fruitiness edged with a bit of roasted malts, earthiness and some yeasty spiciness. This is a bold fruity brew where yeasty spices and pomegranate tang attempt to balance the sweetness.

22oz bottle. Rating #64. Very murky and thick dark brown pour with a light tan head with decent lacing. Slightly sweet light fruit aroma, yeast and some caramel. More sweet fruitiness, slightly bitter with a little toasty aftertaste. (1711)

22 oz. bottle from Total Wine (Phoenix) - Pours a murky (muddy) light brown color with barley any head. No real lacing to speak of. Lightly carbonated. Aroma is esters, and toasted malt. Flavor is lightly sweetened toasted malt, esters, and light spice. Medium body. A decent beer.
Hazy reddish pour with a foamy head.. Aroma is sweet malt and brown sugar. Flavor was the same plus some dark fruit flavors, chocolate and some mild hop.
On tap; first rating in a while. Poured a auburn type with a brown head. Aroma of cola, fruit, and earth. Flavor was ok and a bit oxidized. Fruit and earth. Some yeast.
Pours dark amber with off-white head. Smells of bubblefum and dried fruit. Malty sweet. Medium body with thin texture. Malty smooth finish. Not bad, but a bit malty for my tastes.

Murky red brown pour, good sized frothy head. Aroma holds very nice nectar fruit presence that mixes with a bit of nuttiness, brown sugar, and cherry. Excellent fruit profile on the whole. Flavor holds lots of raisin, plum, fig, and a touch of alcohol bite on the tongue. Nothing special, but a tasty Belgian style brew from a local outfit.
A very dark brown/black color with a nice creamy head. Has a roasted caramel taste and aroma. Very great beer to top off the meal with.

Anniversary Trip 2007 5/20/2007: Ruppert’s Dark is very dark brown in color and has a creamy tan cown. The aroma is chocolate mocha with some citrusy hops. At first, the flavor is roasted barley with some coffee. Further in some hints of citrus hops can be found. With each passing drink is gets more and more citrusy and bittery like an IPA, but this would be more like a DARK IPA due to the malt and chocolate/roasty flavors. The finish has a roasty flavor as well and is slightly dry. The body is medium-full and this beer is smooth and has a little creaminess to the texture. Overall this beer is quite good. I really enjoyed it and found that the chocolate and roasted qualities really pair well with the citrusy hops and bitterness. This is a well-crafted brew and I actually liked it more than the Southern Tier Porter! 16 oz draught at Clementine’s (restaurant) in South Haven, Michigan. Note: After arriving home I called Southern Tier Brewing Company to inquire about this beer since it seemed similar to their Porter, but more citrusy. They confirmed that this is a different beer. It is brewed using a similar recipe as their Porter, but has 100 pounds less dark malt per batch...

column1: Kuhnhenn Double Rice India Pale Ale (DRIPA)
column5: 12oz can pours out golden topped with a white head. Nose is sweet caramel malts some pine citrus hops and a floral kick. Taste is more of the nice sweet caramel malts pine citrus bitterness and a pithy end.

column1: Kuhnhenn Double Rice India Pale Ale (DRIPA)
column5: fairly clear gold from the can with a light head, the rice lets the hops come through but as plenty of body, The abv is not un-noticed but adds to the overall great beer.

column1: Kuhnhenn Double Rice India Pale Ale (DRIPA)
column5: 12 oz can from Tavour. Hazy golden pour, fizzy head. Aroma is hoppy and lghtly fruity. Taste brings smooth malts with a huge hoppy bite. Light orange, minimally sweet. Bitterness stays on the palate. Sublime, smooth and strong.

column1: Kuhnhenn Double Rice India Pale Ale (DRIPA)
column5: 35.5cl can at home, bought at Slijterij Groningen, Vismarkt. Appearance: quite clear golden with sizable white head. Aroma: orange peel, citrus, hop resin, yeast, some rice. Taste: medium sweetness and high bitterness. Notes of hop resin, pine, orange peel, cooked rice, some lime. Palate: medium bodied, oily texture and lively carbonation. Dry bitter finish. Overall: a classical and bitter DIPA. Intense bitterness and not that much candied sugar/residual sugar in these. Not sure if the rice works for me.

column1: Kuhnhenn Double Rice India Pale Ale (DRIPA)
column5: Golden with medium white creamy head. Hoppy aroma. Medium strong bitterness mixed with sour an bit sweet grapefruit notes. Moderate maltiness comes later. Lasting bitter aftertaste.

column1: Kuhnhenn Double Rice India Pale Ale (DRIPA)
column5: Kind of what i expected. Clean unbalanced malt bill. Exposes warmth and boozyness but pleasant as a sipper. Crisp hop fprofile. CItrus and wood notes ride the alcholhol wave.

column1: Kuhnhenn Double Rice India Pale Ale (DRIPA)
column5: Pours slightly hazy yellow with nice head. Aroma: tangerine, honey melon, citrus, slightly mineral aroma. Taste: relatively dry, nice tangerine and citrus flavor, some pine in the palate. Overall crisp, dry and super drinkable, with alcohol very well hidden.

column1: Kuhnhenn Double Rice India Pale Ale (DRIPA)
column5: Can (12oz). Light golden and most clear with white head. Nice citrus aroma and taste, mostly lemon I think. Slight sweetness, but definitely finishes dry. Also a little pine bitterness in the end. Very nice. Will drink whenever I can get it.

column1: Kuhnhenn Double Rice India Pale Ale (DRIPA)
column5: 355ml can. Hazy, dark yellow-ish, golden colour with average to huge, thick, firm, frothy to creamy, moderately to mostly lasting, moderately lacing, white head. Fruity and citrusy, hoppy aroma, notes of peach, some kumquat, tangerine, spicy malty background. Taste is bitter, fruity and citrusy hoppy, spicy malty, notes of kumquat, some orange, tangerine; bitter and salty-spicy finish.

column1: Kuhnhenn Double Rice India Pale Ale (DRIPA)
column5: Can. Blonde. Citrus dominating the aroma. Citric, floral flavor. Hint of rye bread. Dry, not too hoppy, but solid.

Orange amber with a light fizzy head and no lace. Taste is traditional wit - caramel malt and citrus combined with summer spices, finishing with a light twist of bitter. Some nutmeg colored sediment comes with each bottle. Very drinkable.

#2 in a series of $1.00 Stegmaier 12 ounce botlte budget singles from The Party Source. Cloudy orange/yellow color with a good amount of sediment, small white head, moderate to strong sweet spicy aroma, small white head, somewhat thin body, sweet/tart/spicy/yeasty flavor--would be a nice hot weather brew. The best Stegmaier in this series.

Pours orange from bottle with a rapidly disappearing white head. has these estery notes on the nose which remind me a bit of a Hefe. Taste has some orange character. Fairly thin mouthfeel. Finish is a bit watery. I’ve had worse.
12 oz. bottle. Pours a cloudy golden brown with a thick white head. Light hazy straw colored pour, a little carbonation and a hint of orange peel and coriander. Rather pleasant.
12oz bottle from $10 variety pack. Hazy yellow color, bubbles on side of glass, sparse head. Sharper carbonation, slightly metallic aroma. Dry texture. R: "Dried apricot."

Good stuff. It’s aroma is a bit faint, with a bit orange peel maybe some spice. It’s appearance is lightly cloudy yellow. It’s also had a very heady fluff, which quickly dissipated. It’s flavor is very good, with a tart spice, some malts and fruit zest. It’s was very smooth. Overall a very nice brew. Thanks for picking it up JB.

From a variety 12 pack from State College - respectable enough version of a style that I wish would fade away sooner then later. Very cloudy and pale with some unknown bits floating around in it, but no points off for that, I thought it lent it character. Mild citrus nose + clove + funk, decent aromas wafting. Palate is a little bit sweet and a little bit sour. You know, I don’t have anything but good things to say about this one.
Bottle. Light hazy straw colored pour, a little carbonation and a little artificial orange aroma. Flavor is also oddly fake orange, some yeastiness and a finished unpleasantly bitter.

Pours a hazy bright orange with quickly dissapating bubbly white film. Aroma is typical white ale combo of doughiness, orange peel and coriander. Flavor a bit overcarbonated but surprisingly not overly watery. Good wheat dough base with good sweet orange sugared flavor and tad bit of spice. Overall, respectable enough.

Good stuff. It’s aroma is a bit faint, with a bit orange peel maybe some spice. It’s appearance is lightly cloudy yellow as expected. It’s also had a very heady fluff, which quickly dissipated. It’s flavor is very good, with a tart spice, strong malts and fruit zest. Overall a very nice brew.

This is a backlog rating from 2011 from a bottle picked upat Kuhnhenn, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are honey, floral, peaches, stonefruit, sweet but there is enough hoing on to not make it cloying, solid.

2006 bottle from the brewery, drunk 1/8/17. Appearance as pictured, clear, leaving plentiful sediment behind. Lovely, fiery, burnished copper. A mix of clean, lightly peppery honey, rich and sumptuous but accented with plentiful acidity to balance. Almost like tart peach or nectarine. Touch of raisin and vanilla creeping in from the age but otherwise no sign of the years. Little/no alcohol in the nose, which is very impressive. In the mouth it’s sticky, rich and full of sweet honey but almost perfectly balanced on the finish by the acidity that is lip-smacking and bright, leaving the stuff shockingly drinkable. Complex golden raisin, caramel, vanilla, grass, herbs and peach all provide an outstanding variation of flavor. Very clean, soft and with almost no sign of the alcohol. Awesome stuff.
Nip sized bottle. Poured golden color with no head. Fruity and honey sweetness. To me, more of a straight forward mead, but one that I liked none the less considering that.

Bottle at Clockwork’s 4K/5K/10K gathering. Pours a hazy yellow body with no head or lacing. Aroma is sweet fruit. Mouthfeel is medium to thick, rich with notes of flowers, honey, light booze and some peach cobbler.

Bottle, big thanks to James (Jredmond) for corking this one and bringing it down the the Ginger Man, 18/05/13. Lightly hazed pale golden with no head. Nose is sugars, piss, light apricot, booze. Taste comprises sugars, syrup, light floral sweetness,boozey fleshy fruit. Full bodied, slightly cloying, sweet.
Bottle. Pours clear gold with no head. Sweet honey, faint flowery notes, some hints of apple juice, and a medium sweet juicy honey finish. Not to sweet. Solid stuff.

The pour is pale yellow/milky white with alright lacing left on the glass. Aroma is fairly complex with notes of honey, peach, apples, and white wine. The flavor is more subtle at first with some slight fruitness/honey and transitions into a boozy overripe fruit finish. Medium bodied for a mead leaning more towards sweet than dry.

Bottle... This beer rocks!... Hazy straw-colored mead with sparce, but thick and beefy legs. The bouquet is a blend of wildflower honey, funky fallen apple and funky fallen peach accompanied by a mild note of ethanol. Full-bodied and sticky with the dawn of carbonation from over two years of warm storage - and the bottle wasn’t brand-spanking-new when I acquired it. The flavor presents wildflower honey and fuzzy fruits - pretty much as the commercial description reads. Sweet, warming finish with a nice hint of acidity. The 18% ABV is certainly well-disguised. This world class mead was provided by KickInChalice!

Bottle at the Colorado Mead Tasting ’12. Pour is golden orange with no head and great legs. Smell is floral, honeycomb, light apples, a touch of wood, vanilla, and fruit. Taste is white grapes, almonds, pear, wood, honey, and flowers with a dry lingering finish. Syrupy mouthfeel with no carbonation. Nice mead and not too sweet.

2012 Colorado Mead Tasting at Armin’s house. Thanks to Matt! Pours a light clear yellow appearance. Tangy, earthy/herbal, floral, apricot aroma. Not quite as sweet as the other Kuhnhenn meads. Somewhat dry finish with a moderate boozy burn. Peach, floral flavor. Kind of interesting.

This is a backlog rating from 2010 on draft at New Holland, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this cider are apples, sweet, light tart, pretty standard.

On tap at New Holland Brewpub. Slight ting of yellow to a rather clear and lifeless decapitated body. Aroma of apples, apple skins and cinnamon. Taste is tart with apples, cinnamon, spices, mild tannins and a dry finish. I preferred the raspberry cider to this one but obviously cant rate it.
Clear yellow body. Crisp and refreshing. Apple and nothing else. s A decent cider, but nothing that makes this noteworthy.

On tap at New Holland on our way to RBSG. Pours a clear watery yellow, still with no head. Vinous apples, sweet with a touch of vanilla. Medium bodied, crisp with a bit of alcohol peeking through. Warm apple flavors. Long crisp finish, vinous alcohol lingers.
Pours light. Aroma of apple, semi sweet. Sparkling clear. Very refreshing and a really good cider.

Draft sample at New Holland. Poured clear color with a small white head that diminished quickly with minimal lacing. Aroma of apple. Flavor of sweet apple with a light sweet finish of short duration. Light body with a thin texture. Refreshing drink.

Anniversary Trip 2007 5/19/2007: New Holland Michigan Apple Cider is super clear with almost not color at all. Very gently sparkling. Aroma is like apple wine. Some crisp apple and light white wine in the flavor. Light body. Draught sample at New Holland Brewing Company’s restaurant and pub in downtown New Holland, Michigan.
Pours a coppery amber. The malt is pretty big, lots of caramel, but not a lot of hops or character. Seems a bit one dimensional despite having plenty of flavor.

column4: Stonecutters Brewhouse (formerly Granite City Brew Pub)
column5: A hazy golden IPA with a thin white head. A pleasant floral hops aroma with light caramel notes, very typical. In mouth, a decent IPA with good balance of floral hops and malt. Medium bodied. Sampled at Vermont Brewfest July 19 2008.

column4: Stonecutters Brewhouse (formerly Granite City Brew Pub)
column5: Objectively speaking: A ridiculously off-target IPA. I like: Worst beer in a while. I dislike: While poured from the draught, this was full of yeast sediments. Problematic dry-hopping covers whatever flaws you can bet there are. Hugely yeasty in a dusty way, almost a pure dust flavour in fact. Empty maltiness provides no suppleness nor mouthfeel.

Tuesday, November 13, 2018. Bottle, 75cL. 4.5%. Purchase ("Cave de Beuvron", Beuvron-en-Auge (14), FR). Home. A sparkling bubbly clear cider; average white head ; no retention. Wood, apple, light flower. Light sweet, light to medium dry refreshing, bitter note. Medium body, light silky texture, good gaseous, sweet fruity rustic finish. Overall, enjoyable.

Bottle, bought at the ciderie. Aroma of fermenting apples. Sweet and sugary flavor, fernmenting apples. Not really a typical apple flavor, only in the aftertaste. Also a touch of horseblanket in the aftertaste. Very rural cider.

column1: Old Capitol Templeton Rye Pale Ale
column4: Old Capitol Brew Works and Public House
column5: Batch 1 at the brewpub. Hazy orange caramel with a 1/2 finger creamy light beige head, fades to a ring quickly. It did leave a couple strings of lace. Aroma of whiskey, vanilla, and oak up front. Kind of hard to pick up on much else. Flavor is of whiskey, vanilla with some spicy rye, caramel malts, very light buttery notes. Not too boozy, though it isn’t supposed to be over 6.2%, so no surprise there. The Templeton Rye finish is the best part of this beer. Creamy medium body with a slightly prickly carbonation. Pretty decent. 2nd Batch. So anyways, had a tulip from the second batch last night (12/11/07, and am doing this from memory. This batch had quite a bit of peach/apricot fruitiness and a lot of straight bitterness (5-6 out of 10) in the woody finish. If I can scrounge up my notes from the first batch, this review will make a little more sense. Templeton Rye is fairly fruity, and since I have a glass of it next to me, it is clear this is where the fruitiness came from. 2.6 isn’t my actual rating, just what I’m putting in until I find my scrap of paper.

column1: Old Capitol Templeton Rye Pale Ale
column4: Old Capitol Brew Works and Public House
column5: New batch on tap in a tulip in December 2007. Hazy dark amber body with an off white head. The aroma was definite Templeton Rye, and I could tell that when all I knew was that it was a barrel aged brew, not which barrels were used. There was a little bit of green apples and caramel. After it warmed the rye was more subtle with some bread crust. The taste was boozy grapefruit with up front rye. This was woody and dry. There were some definite hay notes in the finish. The barrel aging was a little much by the end. Pretty good for an Old Capitol brew.

column1: Old Capitol Templeton Rye Pale Ale
column4: Old Capitol Brew Works and Public House
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Served in an 8 oz tulip glass. Aged in barrels from a distillery in Templeton, Iowa. Poured a slightly hazy orange red color. Head was two fingers thick and off white with decent retention. A bit of lace was left on the glass at the end. Aroma was a mix of whiskey, citrusy hops, and husky grain. Dry on the tongue with a warming alcohol effect. I definitely tasted the whiskey along with some vanilla, subdued grapefruity hops, and husky grain. Plenty of alcohol. I was feeling it by the end of 8 oz.
330ml Flasche. Klar und schwarz. Minimale Schaumkrone. Malzig. Etwas Karamell und Röstaromen. Ordentlicher Körper. Gut trinkbar.
En este tipo de elaboración, la calidad es débil. Baja espuma. Curva de sabor plano. Sin que llame la atención. Cuenta con el amargor para disfrutar. Pero hay mejores.
330 bottle. Smell of coffe, butter. Dark color low head. Tastes boring. Hard to remember

Draught at Kross tap room. Dark brown color, white head. Bitter taste with roasted malts, coffee, a bit of smoke, chocolate and nuts. Bitter finish with roasted malts, chocolate, a bit of smoke, coffee and nuts. Very nice stout.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Mollys Titanic Brown Ale
column5: Mug club draft on tap at the brewpub (Lombard, IL). Pours a nice dark brown, reddish edges not really opaque but dark enough. A decent tannish head that laces ok, stays a thicker film. Aromas are a nice firm roasty cocoa base, brown malts throw earthy tobbacco, brown sugar, coffee grounds, a touch of sweetness and faint vanilla. Initial is firm, a lighter side of medium bodied with a good roasty base, coffee and roasted malts pair with sweeter brown malts, dark chocolate, brown sugar, good roast that sticks to the palate and provides a light floral bitterness on the backend. Still, roast is king with coffee, earthy tobbacco, and cocoa sticking. Nice, with just enough sweetness coming in. A drinker.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Mollys Titanic Brown Ale
column5: on tap at the brewpub. pours dark ruby brown with off white head. nose is very roasty and nutty. flavors are robust and roasty with chocolate and hazelnuts. flavors med body, big flavorful brown/porter that at times seems a tad astringent.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Mollys Titanic Brown Ale
column5: 4oz. sample. Dark brown pour with an off white head which reduced quickly to a thin ring, leaving some light lacing. Roasted malt, nuts, a touch of coffee, bakers chocolate, and toffee with a pleasant, bitter finish. All flavors were moderately potent in a nice balance. A good representative porter. Next time around, I was served in a club mug, and detected perfumy/floral notes in the aroma and a more pronounced brown sugar sweetness to the flavor.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Mollys Titanic Brown Ale
column5: Draught. Opaque with a thin off-white head, minimal spotty lacing. Aroma is dull dry nutty malts. Nice dry quaffable beer with some toffee sweet notes and a roast character with a strong dry finish of coffee. Rich and full in the mouth with a nice carbonation.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Mollys Titanic Brown Ale
column5: Pours dark brown with a frothy, minimal tan head. Very heavy carbonation. Aroma is of brown sugar, chocolate, and light roasted malt. The roasted malt was very subdued in the aroma. Taste is very nutty, with brown sugar, hops, roasted malt, and chocolate. More of a brown then a porter, but it was very drinkable and enjoyable.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Mollys Titanic Brown Ale
column5:
Dec. 2008 batch, 5.1% abv: Deep brown body with thin tan bubbles. Smell of mocha and freshly roasted malts. Taste falls right between porter and dry stout at first, with some coffee turning up in my throat. A bit of English hop, but also a perception of PNW pine. Could position between a session beer and a winter warmer.

First batch, June, 2007. 4.8% abv: Unfrosted Mug Club mug. at first it tends more toward brown than porter, but it’s much more complicated than that. Opaque, dark brown body under a thin head with slight lacing. Smell is light, but suggests hearty roast malts. First taste has chocolate roast malts, but not too much, as its balanced by what I think are English hops. Traces of coffee follow. Alcohol is light, but easily noticed. Earthy and nutty toward the middle, followed by almost stoutlike roasties. Very malty, but not overly sweet.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Mollys Titanic Brown Ale
column5: The name may be misleading, but brewmaster Tim Marshall tells me that this is a brown Porter. It pours a deep chestnut body with a bubbly, short lived off-white head. Good lacing, regardless. The aroma is light and chocolatey with a bit of toffee and some lightly roasted malts. It was perhaps a bit thin but still imparts a chocolate chip cookie flavor, completely with some chopped nuts. Pretty decent. Rock Bottom Yorktown, Lombard, IL

Reviewed from notes. Consumed last summer traveling through Wisconsin. The appearance has a clear yellow body, has a film of a white head, and carbonation is seen rising. The smell is basically corn/rice adjuncts, sweet malts. The taste is sweet all the way through, crisp dry finish. The palate is light, sessionable, and adequately carbonated for the style and for me. Overall, hey now, its a light lager and its not only made by a brewery, but a pizza place, so this is a pizza beer all the way through, Id probably have it again if I came through this area.
Probably their worst beer. No flavor. Similar to an old style. Pours a light yellow and is bitter ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the brewery, sampler flight. Hazy golden in color with no noticeable head. Surprisingly hoppy for a light, with a mild hop nose and some rice. Watery, no aftertaste. Not mush real taste at all, though.

On tap at the brewpub on 6/22/07: Pours a clear pale golden with a frothy well-lacing white head. Aroma of pale malt, noble hops and some graininess. Starts fairly sweet and grainy with some light earthy bitterness. Pretty true to style and therefore bland.

Date: 06/22/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub yellow with a slight haze, wispy white head, light sweet corn aroma, creamy body, lots of sweet corn flavor, light bitterness offers no balance, Aroma: 3/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 3/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 6/20 Rating: 1.8/5.0 Drinkability: 5/10 Score: */4

On tap at the brewpub in Wisconsin Dells, pours a light clear golden yellow brew with an average size white head that dissolves to a fair lacing. Aroma of sweet corn, flowery hops, some light citrus and a touch of hickory nuts. Taste is lightly carbonated, medium body, light, crisp and smooth finish. Taste is very good, kind of an in between between a kölsch and a pale lager.
Not impressed with this ipa. Has a wonderful look and smell to it, but the flavor is nothing spectacular. I would not recommend to anyone or get it again. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the brewpub in Wisconsin Dells, pours a clear copper color with a very slow dissolving off-white head with good retention and lacing. Aroma is sweet and malty with some hints of brown sugar For an IPA it is missing the hop character I am used to. Taste is light flavor, bitter on the tongue with a slight hint of hops near the end. Finish is smooth and creamy and missing the hop bite that most IPAs have. I am wondering if the Kilbourn Hop Ale and IPA were switched? For an amber ale this would be very good, but this IPA seems to be a little off.
Bottle. (Brief tasting notes and rating from old records) - BCA - Refreshing, crisp, tangy, bitter grapefruit citrus hoppy & malty ale. Bitter citrus-hoppy finish. (Backlog)

Brown 500ml bottle (bottle conditioned), best before 20th Nov 2008, drank July 2008. Very lively, only got half the bottle into my pint tumbler because of the head that appeared as I tried to pour. Pale amber/yellow with a white (large) head, clear and well carbonated, bubbles rising to replenish the head. Citrus aroma, mixed with hops and malts. It claims to have a continental style (whatever that means?) and it doesn’t taste like a normal English Bitter at all. The citrus flavours within the smell are very apparant in the taste, it is almost tangy, zesty even. It tasted a little green, as in not ready, but it only had 4 months life left and it had sat in my garage for over six months. The label also told me to serve it slightly chilled on a sunny day, so I did. A little watery for 4.8%, but not wishy-washy. The spritzy citrus flavours linger in the mouth for a while. Not really ’My Cup of Tea’, but an interesting brew none-the-less.
500ml Bottle at home 10/09/2007 Hoppy and floral aromas. Some carbonation. Clear golden coloured slightly pale and fruity with a crisp full malt finish.
Aroma of hops .Was yellow, cloudy and very lively. Tasted hoppy was very fizzy.
Bottle condition. Not great to be honest. Cloying and sickly. Shame as I was looking forward to it.
Bottle.Clear gold with a large head,aroma of peach and hops,taste is prickly with summer fruit,dry.

Bottled. A light gold coloured beer with a rocky lasting white head. Nice lemony and orangey hops on the aroma, together with a hint of soap. Some more hops in the taste, but more restrained. After pouring and checking the head, I feared for an infected BCA but it’s actually pretty pleasant.

Bottle conditioned, 500ml, from Tesco, Banbury. Gold to brown with short lasting Head. A little bit non descript. Dry and bitter wit a flowery aroma, some hop but needs to be searched out and a little malty fruitiness, but largely disappointing with a lack of freshness.

Bottle, 500ml. A pale golden colour with a huge frothy head. A floral hop and orange aroma. Taste is caramel, roasted malt, floral hops and really juicy citrus fruits. High carbonation. Very tasty, but rather too fizzy for my liking.

A Mes rate: Bottle from Tesco, obviously. Dark gold with a huge froth head that settled to nothing in seconds. Harsh soapy yeasty aroma with some rather unpleasant hops. Having to pluck up the courage to taste it. Actually not quite as bad as the nose. Tastes like a standard lager but with a harsh citric finish leaving some all too lengthy cardboard. Bit of a shocker all round. Actually no. The more I drink the worse it gets. Very very bad. Drain pour. Now let’s find something to cleanse my palate...

column2: Vinh Phu, Thuan An, Binh Duong Province, Vietnam
column5: This one’s on the lower end of wonderful world of Vietnamese lagers. Tastes like sour malt that goes flat in your mouth and sits badly in your stomach. Drank in a can in Saigon

column2: Vinh Phu, Thuan An, Binh Duong Province, Vietnam
column5: Slightly fluorescent gold, not much head. The aroma is appley and plasticy. Slightly sticky palate is mainly malt with light grains and acetaldehyde. Not particularly offensive but hardly inspiring.

column2: Vinh Phu, Thuan An, Binh Duong Province, Vietnam
column5: Can. Easier to find in Cambodia than Vietnam. Pours bright gold, has a white head. Aroma of Jolly Rancher apple candy and some green vegetables. Slightly sticky palate is not that bad. Tastes ok with a decent dry finish and seems to have some sweet malts and even some hops.

column2: Vinh Phu, Thuan An, Binh Duong Province, Vietnam
column5: Canned 12/2008. Pale yellow color, decent white head. Light ashy and fruity nose. Watery palate. Very papery and grainy flavor. Tastes very cheap.

column2: Vinh Phu, Thuan An, Binh Duong Province, Vietnam
column5: Can pours a pale yellow colour with a short lasting bubblish white head. Yeasty, moldy corn mash aroma. The flavour is yeasty and grainy with corn and hay. Very untasty finish.

column2: Vinh Phu, Thuan An, Binh Duong Province, Vietnam
column5: Can. A pale golden beer with a white head. The aroma is of corn and mold, the taste is thin, light sweet, of corn and fruity. Light body with a light sweet finish.

column2: Vinh Phu, Thuan An, Binh Duong Province, Vietnam
column5: Pale yellow with no head. Straw, hay and mold aroma. Sweet and bland thin flavour.

column2: Vinh Phu, Thuan An, Binh Duong Province, Vietnam
column5: Canmed. THX Theis. Pours a clear yellow with an average white head. Light sweetness. Some bitterness. Malty and slightly doughy. Medium carbonation. Chalky dry finish.

column2: Vinh Phu, Thuan An, Binh Duong Province, Vietnam
column5: Can. A light golden beer with a white head. The aroma is very weirdly grainy, metallic, and moldy, while the flavor is sweet with notes of straw and metal, leading to a dry bitter finish. Thanks Theis for hauling this home.

column2: Vinh Phu, Thuan An, Binh Duong Province, Vietnam
column5: Can (330 ml). Clear strawyellow - no head. Wierd sweet, honey, hibiscus flowery, straw, sugar, fruity. Strange.

Draft. A deep red beer with a light tan head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel as well as just a touch of butterscotch, leading to a dry bitter finish. The body is light.

Draught at the Twisted Hop, Christchurch. Pours cola brown with a frothy off white head. Aroma of toasted malt, fruit and nuts. The flavour is toasted malt, nuts, caramel and fruit. Medium bodied. Extremely smooth mouthfeel and low bitterness. A subtle beer with great flavour.

I love brown ales. I love that my local brews a brown ale and I love that it had returned after a year. The flavours were complex and nutty like a brown ale should be, and it is a credit to the man who brews it (although he is of only limited use to doing the cryptic crossword).
I was surprised by this, i was expecting a standard nutty brown ale but the lovely smokey flavour to it gives it a really different aspect, very enjoyable beer

On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear brown with a tanned head and nice lacings. Quite bitter with a hint if a sweet caramel backbone. Fruity hops aromas. Grapes. Medium to light bodied. Hint of liquirish. Very soft carbonation. Long dry finish.

Pint at the brewery. Beautiful malty dark brown colour. Rich full head. A fantastic balance of dark malts and subtle hops combines to deliver a well balanced smooth but complex enough drop. This is a great beer.

Tasted 25/05/2007. Flagon, from the brewery, served via my infamous Scotsman’s beer engine (i.e. a weedsprayer). Gorgeous combination of toasty and cocoa-like dark malts and fruity hops. Suave, svelte, sexy. Creamy mouthfeel and superbly fresh. I didn’t take any notes, and I drunk too much after this one to remember the finer points, but I can assure you it’s a cracker. Looking forward to my next trip to Christchurch already...

Well I have put off posting my rating on this for a bit because I wanted to wait for their All-American Cream Ale to come out for comparison. Draft last fall at Green Leafe Cafe. Poured a dark golden honey color with good white head. Aroma was grainy and slight caramel hints. Tasted about the same. Other people mentioned ’fruity’ but I didn’t pick up on that. Mouthfeel was somewhat thin with moderate carbonation.. Wasn’t crazy about it but the rest of my table liked it well enough because we ordered several pitchers of it.
From Skyview. An acidic aroma and acidic flavor. Prominent unprocessed grain flavor, barley, and some hops. Gold color, dry, and fairly simple. Light on the palate.
A growler ported in by Skyview. Dark brown color with a large head. Chalky and dry malt aroma. The malt taste manages to be both sweet and dry. A little molasses. Dry hop finish.

My parents were kind to pick up a growler of the American Ale straight from the brewpub in Williamsburg, VA. Pours a somewhat dark golden amber brew with a thin off-white head that quickly dissolves to a fine film and white ring. Aroma of multi-grain malt, a touch of citrus, some yeast and a touch of honey. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonation with flavors of light caramel malt and some flowery hop flavors. Finish is slightly watery, light malty with a light malt aftertaste. An average ale at best.

Draft at Greenleafe Tavern while on vacation. The pour was medium goldish, and I got aroma notes of mild hopcitrus, some pale malt, light fruit, honey, and ssome of that slight yeasty funk note that I seem to detect in most Williamsburg beers. Medium to light palate heft, with mild flavors of hopcitrus, light skinned fruit, and pale malt.

Draft at the Greene Leaf Cafe; Light amber and moderately carbonated. Sweet aroma kinda sneaks up on you and then there’s almost a vinegary touch. This drinks quite light, but it drinks so starchy it almost comes across like that vinegar I got in the aroma. Little odd, bitter finish, almost tart. I supposet this sounds bad, but actually the beer’s not bad ... it’s OK, but somewhat of a let down for WAW. (#2950, 5/24/2007)

Sampled at the Virginia Beer Fest. The keg was labeled Alewerks American Ale, but after speaking with maniac and his conversation with the brewers, for now we’ll leave it named Alewerks Ale. I’ll try and dig up as much info as I can for this. Came out golden bodied. Small white head. The nose seemed rather faint to me. Light grains, some faint caramel and light malt. Taste was on par with the aroma. Again nothing exciting but still well done. Light grains, some hops, softer malts and touches of fruit. Body is light-medium to medium. Soft carbonation. Ends with more grains, soft caramel and fruits and touches of maltiness. Average.

Virginia Beer Fest 2007. The head brewer told me that this is their American Ale. This is meant to be their general purpose beer. "Give me an Alewerks" and this is what they plan to give you. Clear golden amber body with a small white head. Somewhat grainy light caramel aroma. Grainy carmel and light fruit flavor. For a general purpose beer, this isn’t too bad.

Rating #2094- 2015.09.28 #CraftTakesSeattle Day 5, Beer 196 – Draught at Brewpub - Lunch before the plane ride home.Clear red-brown pour with an average creamy, tan head. Aroma is nutty (almond and cashew), and sweet roasted malts. Taste is light and sweet, with a clean mouthfeel that is quite refreshing, and a medium bitterness that dries out the finish a little too much.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear cola brown with a thin tan head. Soft nutty malt on the nose, a touch of roast. Medium bodied, toast and a bit of malt. Crisp malt into the finish. Not a ton going on here, easy but a touch dull.

Dark dark brown under a thin beige cap. Dark sweet nose with a weird accompanying green apple tone. The flavor is much the same with some dark biscuity bitter chocolate tones, something lightly sour with some light piney notes.
Draught. This is a pretty lack luster brew without much going for it. Give it a miss.

Draft @ Beveridge Place: Dark brown color with a light head. The nose is malty with caramel and light hops. The flavor is clean, balanced and chewy, light toast and biscuit with some creamy doughnut notes in the tail. Balanced hop flavor and finish. Not bad.
on tap at summit public, lightly sweet, slightly bitter with biscuity malts and a chewy palate.

Date: September 18, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub, Elliott Appearance: cloudy brown, wispy beige head, drippy lace Aroma: light chocolate aroma with a touch of caramel sweetness Body: thin body Flavor: sweet caramel and chocolate flavor, light earthy bitterness, toasted malt Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ** /4

On tap. Pours clear cola brown with a lacy off-white head. Sweet brown sugar aroma with maybe vanilla? Medium-light body, watery texture, light carbonation. Tons of brown sugar in the taste, along with some chocolate and molasses in the semi-crisp finish.

Dark brown with molasses/mahogany tinges and little head. Nutty, medium roast barley and hops in the nose. Ok malt and hop mix, PNW influenced. Well-balanced, with medium body. A pretty ho-hum brown ale.

Deep mahogany with a foamy head colored light tan. The nose comes out nicley with a touch of hazelnut and toasted malts. The flavor is also compirsed of a creamy, nuttiness. Reminds me of a thinner bodied Rogue Hazelnut Brown.

28 May 2018. At Café Cambrinus. Shared with Anke. Pours clear golden with a lasting, frothy, white head; lots of lacing. The aroma contains bready malt, grain, citrus, cookie, vanilla, honey, hot apple & pear, smoked bacon even. It tastes light to medium malty sweet, a bit bready & fruit, and light grainy bitter, yeast & citrus in theback. Dry, grainy finish, lingering bread & yeast. Light to medium body, slick texture, soft, almost flat, carbonation. I'd choose the brown version over this one, even though I'd recommend any other beer to tourists visiting the Cambrinus restaurant.
Van tap bij Cambrinus in Brugge. Typisch Belgisch gist, wat scherpig, ergens een zoetje. (6-2017).
On tap at Cafe Cambrinus Brugge. Clear gold colour lasting white head. A little soap and then decent tangerine fruit. Light bitterness. A little sweet. Lacked some carbonation. Soft blond. Ok.

The blonde house beer of Cambrinus in Brugues, also by Van Steenberge and also claimed to represent an original recipe so not an alias. Very thick, stable, off-white head, clear ’old gold’ colour, fizzy. Aroma of unmistakable DMS (cooked cauliflower), honey, caramel candy, powder sugar, dried mango, straw, coriander, apricot, dried banana. Sweet onset, banana and peach with a basic sourishness underneath, minerally carbo, smooth caramelly and somewhat honeyish malt sweetness, bit metallic, soft floral hoppiness in the end with some soapy coriander but more than anything, lingering malt sweetness. Boring and stereotypical, intended for the big masses like its brown counterpart, but more metallic.

Clear, golden colored, medium to small white head, not very lasting. Aroma is sweet brew sugary, orange, spicy, Belgian yeasty. Taste is medium+ sweet brewing sugar, bit bready, orange fruity, some yeast, more spicy, medium- bitterness, dryish finish. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, bit watery. (on tap, Cambrinus, Brugge)

Draught@Cambrinus, Bruges. Deep golden colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma is floral, fruity, some toffeeish and mild wooden notes. Flavour is rather similar. Balanced, but as such nothing special. Still a good stronger Session beer, which is easy to drink.

Draught @ Cambrinus, Bruges as "Cambrivinus Blond." Aroma is mild with grain and sweet apricot tones. Flavour has sweet apricot, fruit candy and mild alcohol notes. A tad too sweet. More rich than the bruin one.

Keg at Cambrinus in Brugges alongside the dark. Pours hazy Gold with a bright White head. yeasty tripel aroma. Banana and wheat. quite perfumed. Fairly hoppy, wheaty taste with a quite pleasant dryness. Decent but I preferred the dark.
Draft. Hazy golden yellow color, creamy yellow head. Aroma of peach and banana. Taste has spiced banana, citrus. OK.
Aroma of light malt, fruits, yeast, sugar, spices. Flavour is sweet with a light bitter finish. Some alcohol noticeable. Too sweet and cloying for me.
Cask gravity at the Ealing beer festival 2016, amber-brown with a thin ring, lightly malt syrupy nose, pleasantly malty bitter with a dry edge.
Cask. Clear and golden. Fruits and a hint of malt, citrus fruits/lemon in the taste, grassy hints.
Cask. Not bad. Not really golden as stated on the pump. Nice floral and malty flavour texture. Dusty yeast toffee. Easy bitter to drink.

Cask @ White Horse, Parson’s Green SW6. Pours a golden pale amber color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty weak hoppy aroma. Fruity malty weak hoppy apple flavor. Has a fruity malty weak hoppy finish.

Man of Kent, Rochester. I’ve been using the Man of Kent pub more and more over the past year or two, and have been pleased that beer quality has improved. Sadly, this beer wasn’t in good condition. The beer selection was much reduced, and the landlady was saying that during quiet periods they don’t put out many beers. Seems they have been noticing. Good. Then she got talking about the length of time a beer lasts. I only like to keep them on for four days, she says, but strong beers can go longer. I agree - a 9% beer can last way longer than four days, but a weak beer - like a 3.7% - wouldn’t do well after four days. O no! She firmly disagrees - our cellar is in perfect condition to keep beer. Oh, OK, says me - recalling the amount of warm beers I’ve had here, but being aware that you get barred from this place if you complain about the beer. I take the drinks back to our table, and - ah. the Guzzler is beyond its best. It’s warm, flabby, and heading toward sour. Note to self - only drink the strong beers in the Man of Kent.

Cask gravity at Crabble Corn Mill BF 2007. Rating 3300 so I suppose it is fitting that it is a Kentish beer. Gold colour with lasting off white head. Some lemony hop, bit of sweetish malt on aroma. Lemony/citrus easy drinking sessioin bitter. Dryness and citrus acids on finish pucker the cheeks. Very decent lemon/tangerine. Very refreshing, full fruit flavour.

Bottle: Many thanks to Joes for sharing this one: Vintage 2006: Very vast creamy light tan medium head on top of a deep deep dark brown to black colored beer with a light brown shine. The aroma is a nice mix of chocolate from the bottle and oatmeal, nuts, toffee, hints of roasted malts, hint of liquor/alcohol from the glass. The flavours of this beer are complex and not complex at the same time: chocolate, roast, hint of portish alcohol, light hint of coffee, oatmeal, bitter. Vinous and tasty! The aftertaste has notes of bitter, chocolate, roasted ingredients and herbs. Low carbo, soft mouthfeel, full body and a creamy light oily texture. Did this beer increase with all those years... Never had it before, so I don’t know, but after all these years it was still really good!

Fruchtiger Malzantrunk, sehr weich und flüssig. Angenehm aromatisch werdend, gut versteckt ist der Alkohol, der nur kurz herauslugt. Das Malz ist nicht übermäßig stark, eine dumpfe Hopfen-Getreidenote wirkt dagegen. Gutes, sehr harmonisches Bier. Vielen Dank an den Doppelbock für das Bier! 12/9/10/10/7/10
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, dried fruits, coffee. Flavour is roasted malt, alcohol, licorice, coffee, hop. Full bodied nice beer.

Bottle, from trade with jbrus. A clear, ruby-brown beer with a finger-thick beige head. Dried fruits, some roasted malts, a little licorice and alcohol, and some maltyness in the aroma. Maybe a bit weak, but very good. Sweet flavor with dried fruits, licorice, some roasted malts and coffee. The long-lasting finish is much the same. Some bitterness, but roasted bitterness, not much hoppy bitterness to brag about. Full-bodied and slightly warming. A lovely beer, warm and tasteful. (090501)

Bottled 0,75 ltr (BB 05/2009) Courtesy of bierkoning, thanks Edo! Dark brown, almost opaque color, steady creamy tan head, lots of lace. Strong licorice, roasted malty aroma. Full-bodied. Greasy coffee beans, dark chocolate, muscovado sugar. Aftertaste is short and it it is more sweet than roasted. De Molen is a quality brewery.

Bottled. Very dark brown colour with mediumsized brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, caramel some alchoholic sweetness as well as licorice. Flavour is very much roasted malts, sour coffee, some licorice. Aftertaste is smoked wood, licorice and some coffeeish notes. Very wellbalanced and nice. Some slight alcoholic sweetness as it warms up.

Bottle: Pours a dark brown to black with a medium light tan head. Aroma, roasted malts, coffee, and caramel. Flavor, coffee, caramel, roasted notes, some rich sweetness, some chocolate. Some fruits are evident, a gental bitterness on the finish, very nice beer.

Bottle, 8.6%. Fat vinous aroma, brown sugar. Almost black colour, small tight light brown head. The flavour is nicely roasted, vinous fruitiness, very flavourful. A little roasted bitterness, but by no means unpleasant. Creamy mouthfeel. Very nice.

Bottle. [thank you, Skortila!] Pours a very dark ruby-red. It is only possible to see the red when looking directly towards a lightsource. On top sits a healthy head that initially (on pouring) seemed fizzy, but is now a slowly degrading creamy mass with bigger bubbles nearer the liquid. Rich chocolate aroma, some vanilla, apples and roasted malts in there as well. Great mouthfeel, low carbonation. Flavour is sweet, lightly vinious, the chocolate again dominates. Amid this, there is slight hints of oak, vanilla, coffee. I would say that the initial flavours are just a touch too sweet. But the aftertaste is great, leaving a lasting impression of bitterness and roasted chocolate. For a very long time. The alcohol never burns either, it just warms gently. A good brew, but like the Borefts Stout, a bit on the sweet side.
Bottle:Dark brown in color with a full ight brown head.Rich, full flavor.Creamy,chocolate wheaty taste with a nice bitter aftertaste.Very well balanced beer.
PET bottle. Pale yellow colour. Fruity, appley aroma with honey pastilles and light butterscotch. Fruity, butterscotchy flavour and very light bodied. Weird beer.
(PET bottle, thanks larsniclas!) Shady pale yellow color, small white head. Acidic a bit fruity hoppy scent. Some smoke but mostly fruity taste, though very mild. Thin mouthfeel, low bitterness.

(Plastic bottle, thanks to larsniclas) Light fruity aroma with some flower water and some peas. A bit of hay and flour both in the aroma and in the flavour. Light fruit and light floral flavour with some hints of corn. Medium sweet. No bitterness. Tiny tart and a bit dry. Light body and mouthfeel.
Plastic bottle from Budapest Grand Market Hall.. Hazy golden with almost no head. Elderberries and bready maltiness in the aromna. Weird late bitterness witn spicy notes; pepper.
Thanks to larsniclas. Plastic bottle. Pale golden, small head. Malty aroma, bready notes and with some elder. Malty, cereal flavor, quite mild. Some spices in the finish.

Growler shared by psprings -- thanks, man! Pours garnet with no discernible head, really. Nice aroma of wood, dark cherries, and bitter apples. Odd flavor combination on the palate, possibly due to oxidation, but it works. Further apples, wood, and that rascally cherry sucrets taste that I typically associate with Arctic Devil.

Growler from Paul the dentist. Wicked find, Paul. This is definitely not a sour anymore. Nose is really mellow dark cherry, red apple skin, sweet malt, oxidation, and a mellow, unobtrusive wood character. Gave me chills because the combined effect reminded me of Valley Brew Dec 12 Cuvee Speciale, one of the finer beers ever brewed. Color was a deep amber-ruby. Flavor was much the same as the nose but less varied. Sweet. Dusty. Good.

Handbottle from a growler, courtesy of SoLan. Pours a dark garnet, with a trace of a head. Nose of caramel, spice, pepper, and a touch of acidity. Mildly tart and caramel, peppery spice in the finish. A little boozy with hints of barrel, round mouthfeel and slightly tannic with low carb.

Handbottle from rustychiles, thanks dude. Poured a muddled brown color with some pale ruby highlights and a 1/4 inch, bubbly off-white head that faded to a thin layer. Aroma of soft caramel, some light tart cherry, grape skin, a bit of funk, and some oak. Smooth, lightly sweet entry with a warm caramel character transitions into a smooth, moderately sweet vanilla oakiness that finishes lightly tart with some soft hints of fruit and a faint bourbon spiciness. Low, soft carbonation and moderate mouthfeel. Overall, I enjoyed this beer. While the flavors weren’t overly complex, they were very enjoyable. The base beer seems pretty solid.

Pros: Has some nice things going on. Part of me wants to like it because it is both sweet and strong. Cons: Thin mouth feel. Overbearing sweetness, making it out of balance. Really bland up front and towards the mid-palate. Flavors seem off. Just seems like a mistake.

Thanks to rustychiles for the share on this. Poured out of a growler into orval and bruery goblets. Next to no carbonation is present, but that is to be expected from a barrel-aged beer. Pours a very dark brown, much like many oud bruins. Aroma is of lots of dark candi sugars (figs, plums, dates, etc.), and some muted barrel and sour characters. First impression on taste is "wow." I know that’s not really saying much, but other words didn’t come to me at the time. This is a very complex beer. Lots of those dark fruits, lots of belgian yeast character, and on the tail end of the palate bourbon, oak, and lacto sourness. These final three elements really rounded out the beer. This does not taste like a 12.5%++ beer at all. It is hidden extremely well. Definitely not cloyingly sweet and extremely complex. The only major complaint I have is such low carbonation, but the quality of the beer still showed through.

I heard they tapped a 2005 Keg of this oak barrel aged beast at Papago and I’m pretty sure this is the same beer. If not I will make a new entry. Pours a nice hazy caramel color with a small off white head. Aroma is caramel, malts, sour mash, wood, spices, fruits and more. Flavor is fruits, significant sourness, whiskey, oak, caramel malts. Has a very nice sour barrely flavor going on and the age has done some nice things to this brew. 12.5% is hardly noticable or maybe I just don’t notice because this has such a nice flavor profile going on. Fantastic brew.
Fruity aroma, easy drinking for a stronger beer. Flavor is a nice sweet and sour mixture. Alcohol was noticable. Good stuff.

tap @ papago. bocky must be following me...? first time i’ve seen this so i had to try. smells of green apples, vanilla and whiskey. flavor reminded me of green apple pie with the cinnamon and vanilla. very rich warm mouthfeel. alcohol is definately present and the wood comes through nicely. great way to finish a meal...very strange 2005 version... they must have re-innoculated this? rich red apples, pie spice, fruit sourness, rotten grain, alcohol and yeast show in the aroma and flavor profile. sourness has appeared but this is nowhere near sour (it IS a quad after all). nonetheless, a tasty after dinner brew...

Tap @ Papago. Aroma had srong alcohol whisky along with some fruity sour aroma. Also some wood present. Dark body but brew pub is dimly lit average head. To me this was more in line with a whiskey old fashion sweet than a beer. And that is not all bad for me. Sweet fruity and sour flavors with an alcohol presence. Good sipping beer, easy on palate.

On tap: The aroma is a nice citrus cherry combination with some mild grapefruit hops. It’s a cloudy amber with a small off-white head that leaves behind nice lacing. The flavor starts with a quick citrus and cherry taste that quickly turns to a mild grapefruit hoppiness in the finish. The cherry really blends with with the sweet citrus flavors and grapefruit hoppiness.

From Jul 2007 Purchased from Poplar Wine & Spirits in Casper for US$10.50. Pours from 32oz waxed and sealed swing top bottle (bottled Apr 22 3007) a cloudy deep amber-brown with a smallish head of foam but it sticks around for the entire session and it has some lacing. The smell is big on the yeast! I'm also getting some sourness and some fruit but the yeast smell is strong and oh.... the sour notes are taking center stage now and I can't wait to take a sip. The taste is really fruity up front. There's a definite sour flavour that dominates the initial taste but that is offset by some good malty caramel sweetness and it has a lot of earthy tones in the background that become more noticeable as I take further sips. It's an unusual mixture of flavours but I find that it works for *my* taste buds and I find myself taking more and more sips. Pretty drinkable in my book. Further sips in and the sourness is still there but the malt presence balances out the brew nicely. I think Grand Teton has done a nice job within the style. I'm glad I bought 2 botttles for myself and 1 for a trade to another fan of the Grand Teton's Cellar Reserve series. This one is, imho, another well crafted brew. Thanks Grand Teton!

3 finger head that left very nice lacing atop a hazy amber brew. Aroma is funky sweet and sour.. reminds me of a sweeter smelling Orval.. spicy. Flavor begins with a spicy slightly sweet malty blast and trails into some nice bret mid palate and finish is fairly dry with a lingering bret and mild hop flavor. Green apples and a faint oakiness. Light/medium palate with only a touch of carbonation.
Had this on draft. Gentle acidity, complementing malt backbone. Great aroma. Not my favorite Oud Bruin, but not far from the top of the list!

Not an oud bruin. Smells very sweet -- malty, worty. Caramel, red apple, pear, bake bread. Got the malt side right; needs some acidity. Super-sugary flavor. Bread, caramel, toffee, apple cider, a bit of bretty funk. Zero Flanders acidity, and if this is actually 6 percent alcohol, I’ll eat my own shoes. Tastes more like a quad than anything, and not like a very good one.

My Bottom Line: Lactic connotations and vegetal undertones wade within this storyless Oud Bruin. Further Personal Perceptions: -A veil of foam covers the dull, misty pale red. -A touch of butyric acid (spoiled milk) is found in the nose. -Mouthfeel is a tad fluffy, which doesn’t work with the style (for me). -Acidity levels are low for the style. -After 4 different brews, this brewery just doesn’t do it for me. Bottle; 2013 vintage.

What a letdown this one. GT has always been solid, if not spectacular, and this, as a sour, is just crap. Smells and tastes of barn, yes...but in that dusty old smell. Very little tartness or sour (or really a whole lot of anything going on) in the aroma and flavor. Too gassy. More like a straight belgian, and a somewhat boring one at that. One timer for sure, not worth half what they charge. Stick to what you know guys, and sour ales ain’t it."
More like watered down barely wine. Too much of the malt interfere with flemish yeast character
