Aroma is fruity with apples, grapes and prune with a strong caramel sweetness under the fruity flavors. The beer has a rich caramel color and a modest tan head with some light cloudiness. Flavor is sweet with a strong raisin presence, light toasted malt which is well balanced with the sweetness. Body is modest with low carbonation. Overall a pretty good brew with a lot of sweetness present.

750 ml bottle- Pours an extremely hazy orange with minimal head that reduces to a collar. Aroma is extremely malty similar to a barleywine actually. The taste is similar, age has not been kind to this beer, malts similar to a barleywine. The vintage is 2013, PDT is 01/13, about 15 months, a true sour should stand up to much more than this ( possibly the retailer stored it improperly, huge windows shining sunlight right on the bottles?). From what I’ve read its the beer, WTF, extremely malty, not a sour at all!

1L swing top? bottle. Thanks to maniac! March 2014 DC Tasting. Poured a ruby clear color without a real head to speak of. Aroma was malty, sweet notes. Malt finish, some nutty notes. Age has oxidized this a bit (bottle was first opened in Sept), the sour/acid is missing, but was still enjoyable enough.

A beer special made for the pub Take one in Maastricht. Bottled on 4/16/2006 the only place where you can find it. A very nice combination of mouts. Although not strong still very nice taste. I like good bitter beers, but this beer the bitterness is not overwelming. A very nice brew

A very clean golden, creamy looking white head. Mediocre retention, not much for stickiness off the bat but it sticks on the glass as it goes Soft malts, fruity esters - apple and pear. A modest pepperiness. Sweet, fruity, clean. Incredibly easy to drink, a near perfect amount of carbonation. Smooth and quite a dry finish. Fairly simple and straight forward, but nicely done.
On tap at the brewpub. Apple juice-like color with a moderate head. Aroma of bananas and caramel. Taste is pineapple and banana. THin body.

On tap at the brewpub. Clear golden body with a small white head. Fruity caramel and floral hop aroma. Caramel fruit and molassas flavor. Medium full body with medum carbonation and a slightly syrupy finish.

On tap at the brewpub. According to the bartender, a batch of this is brewed every year, but the recipe changes. This one was 7.5% and 50 IBU. I don’t know whether the vintages vary enough to warrant different entries each year but, since the beer isn’t on RateBeer I can’t really judge. The "other site" has a version listed at 5.7%. It has a nice yeasty aroma, with lots of orange zest in the flavour. The mouthfeel is quite sweet and the bitterness (50 IBU seems quite pronounced for a Belgian style) doesn’t come through that strongly until the finish, but that is enough to prevent this brew seeming sticky sweet. Quite nice.

On tap (nitro) at the brewpub. An annual July release according to the bartender. No ABV given. Dark red colour with a smooth creamy head (not surprising, given to nitro dispense). However, the dispense does interfere somewhat with the aroma, which is a light, toasty malt. On the palate, the malt is deeper and darker,, with touches of cocoa powder chocolate. A very creditable, and credible, effort at a style that is not often seen in the US.

column1: Tyranena BGW Stickin It To The Man
column5: Bottle. Pours an amber body with a thin white head. Fresh hop tones with pine and grapefruit abundantly swirling from the glass. Lighter citrus, earth hop resins, and more pine with a light (thankfully) malt bill.

column1: Tyranena BGW Stickin It To The Man
column5: (12oz bottle) Pours a cloudy orange-brown body with a small off-white head. Aroma of toffee, citrus, caramel, maple, and some dried pine needles. Flavor of toffee, hops (grass, pine, earth), light cola, and caramel with a dry, bitter finish.

column1: Tyranena BGW Stickin It To The Man
column5: 12oz bottle. Pours a nice, hazy, sediment-filled garnet-orange with thin white head that leaves lots of lacing in its wake. Aroma is bitter hops, hops, and more hops, oh, and maybe a hint of citrus and malt. Flavor is, as one might expect, utterly dominated by sharp hop bitterness, but wit little in the way of pleasant citrus notes or balancing from the malt found in better versions of the style. Medium palate has a bitter follow-up just in case you didn’t get enough bitterness when you took the sip that you’re swallowing. Just one more example of the countless impetuous, in-your-face American IPAs done in a style I have never grown to appreciate and probably never will.

column1: Tyranena BGW Stickin It To The Man
column5: Sediment-heavy deep copper color under a short but creamy yellowhite head. Aroma is lemony, grassy, grapefruity and mildly floral. Flavor finds a pleasantly lopsided nod towards PNW hops with a dominance of grapefruit with dashes of pepper and pine. Rather full mouthfeel while the hops linger with a slow burn to the tongue and upper palate. This beer’s sharp, potent flavors make me think that the alcohol content is greater than it actually is. This is an IPA that really holds its own. ~~~~~~~~~~~~ No idea how long ago he gave it to me, but I got this from Cornfield.

column1: Tyranena BGW Stickin It To The Man
column5: Bottle. Deep golden colour with an off-white head. Aroma is hop, malt, grapefruit. Flavour is hop, malt, grapefruit. Full bodied beer, but could be more.

column1: Tyranena BGW Stickin It To The Man
column5: A- Pours a hazy orange hue with a big, fluffy, 2 finger off white head. S- Smells sweet, hints of piney hops. T- Taste is piney with a thick, bready middle full of light fruit and caramel notes leading into a big, bitter, back end. M- Medium bodied, decent carbonation. D- This is definitely an enjoyable brew. Doesn’t particularly stand out for me but I enjoyed it none the less.

column1: Tyranena BGW Stickin It To The Man
column5: 12oz bottle via trade with FlandersNed (thanks, steve!). pours a hazy, darker ruby/copper with a few floaties and a light, whispy, tan head. aroma is solid good with spicy, citrus hops, touches of earthy pine, and a hint of candied sugar. flavor is very solid, showcasing the spicy and herbal nature of the hops on a background of lemon and orange citrus with a substantial, sweet/fruity malt presence tempering the big hop bitterness. finish is a kick of citrus followed by mild floral hop bitterness. palate is smooth and drinkable with good carbonation. overall, a solid IPA.

column1: Tyranena BGW Stickin It To The Man
column5: Bottle. A more or less clear, golden beer with an off-white head. Piney and resiny nose on a malty background. The flavor has malts in the back, with pine cones and resin up front. Nice bitterness. Maybe a bit much bitterness actually, as it gets almost astringent. Full body. The bitterness lasts for a long time, with some malty sweetness to support the resiny finish. Just plain lovely, nothing extraordinary, and very easy drinkable. (090327)

column1: Tyranena BGW Stickin It To The Man
column5: I can’t thank naproxen enough for the opportunity to try this brew, which I thought I would never get to try. 12oz bottle poured into a tulip. Pours a hazy caramel brown that shows bright orange when held up to light. There is also a big tan head that sticks to glass handsomely on the way down. The aroma very balanced with lots of citrus hops still showing after all this time in addition to some candied fruit aromas. However, there is plenty of caramel malts in the nose as well. I really think the taste has suffered a little more than the nose with the age on this one. There are some floral pine hops up front before giving way to the caramel malts. There is a lingering dry bitterness in the finish. I think this would have been a seriously tasty beer when fresh. The mouthfeel is light to medium bodied and fairly slick though the carbonation has held up well. This is a good beer that has probably lost a little over time. I’m not sure about the ABV, but I doubt it’s quite up to DIPA level and maybe that contributes to the age deterioration.

column1: Tyranena BGW Stickin It To The Man
column5: Thanks kiefdog for the share. Pours a hazy brown with nose of caramel, grapefruit, malt, sugar, and noticeable pine. Flavor is lots of caramel, some sweet citrus, and lots of hop punch, finishing smoothly. Crisp, clean, and nice.
Cask (Peterborough BF 2007) Orange gold. Hoppy aroma, ginger hops and rich malty body.

Cask at Peterborough Beer Fest. Deep golden. Dusty nose. Medium sweet and dominated by chewy, caramelly malt. Notes of spun sugar and bread fills out. Solid body for it’s size, but really low bitterness.
Cask handpump at Cambridge BF ’07. Amber with a buttery malt aroma. Gentle, undemanding malt taste with a grainy background. A bit watery to be honest, and lacking bitterness.

Langweilig herber, dumpf hopfiger Antrunk. Wenig aromatisch auch im Mittelteil, spritzig, leider dumpf bleibend. Mild bitterer, etwas metallerner Abgang. 10/7/7/7//7 Earlier Rating: 6/5/2011 Total Score: 2.5 Sehr herber Geruch. Herber, fast bitter werdender Antrunk. Im Mittelteil ist die Herbe führen, wirkt zeitweise aber auch muffig. Etwas langweiliger Nachgeschmack, denn auch hier verändert sich recht wenig. Test vom 23.2.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 8,8,7,7,5,7 - 7,15

Schöne dunkelgoldene Farbe mit für ein Pils doch relativ süßlichem Geruch. Der Antrunk ist süffig-süßlich und schmeckt mehr nach Export als nach Pils. Im Hauptteil kommt eine etwas herbere Note durch, das Bier bleibt aber in der süßlichen Schiene. Auf der Zunge bleibt eine süßlich-würzige Note mit herbem Einschlag. --> Im Vergleich zum Thuringia Export nur ein bisschen Herber, sonst geschmacklich sehr ähnlich. Gut zu trinken, aber nicht sonderlich aromentief. Und für ein Pils definitiv zu würzig-süßlich! (Test vom 13.1.2009) --> 12,7,12,7,12,7 - 8,50
On tap in Potsdam. Loads of aromatic hoppiness, dry mouth feel. Light, yet very satisfying. Pale gold.
Bottled. A light golden beer with an off-white head. The aroma has notes of malt, bread, and straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, bread, and straw, leading to a bitter finish.
Draught, Berlin beer fest. Golden honey with a fluffy white head. Refreshing hops taste with a mild bitter aftertaste. low carbonation

It’s slightly hazy golden with a creamy, white head. The aroma has notes of malt, grain and flower. The flavour has a light sweetness and notes of malt, clover-flower, fruit and the finish is slightly dry. It’s soft and pleasant with a refreshing finish.

Bottle. Creamy barley malt and grass hops aroma. Golden yellow with minimal head. Tangy grass hops up front with a lighter barley malt flavor. Nice taste - hops more pronounced than is typical for the style.
Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of MiP. Clear yellow with a white head. Malty nose. Medium body with sweet malts and a little sulphur. Subdued bitterness. 040409

Bottle 50cl. Clear medium yellow color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20090404]
Bottle, 4.7%. Subtle aroma, hint of honey? Clear yellow colour. Small stable white head. The flavour is also subtle, but there is a hint of flowery aroma hops. Nevertheless, quite boring.
Box at Bardfest 2015. Hazy lemon colour with no head. Apple and vinegar on the nose. The taste is sweet apple. a little stewed flavour and a little tartness. Quite watery, but still a decent cider.

Box at the Winter Beer Festival in Derby. ABV was 6.5% though so not as strong as the website suggests. Light yellow slightly cloudy with no hear. Pleasant sour sweet apply nose. Lovely unusual flavours of gooseberry and particularly redcurrent on the finish. Really good.
On cask at The Devonshire Arms. Pours a slightly hazy, very light golden colour. Aroma of apples, yeast and alcohol. Similar flavours with an oily mouth-feel. Nicely dry and tart to finish.

From a plastic barrel @ GBBF 2011, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. ABV: 6.5%. Clear light yellow colour with virtually no head. Aroma is moderate to light light heavy apple, green apples, tart apples, apple peel, wood, barnyard. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average to long duration, dry, apples, barnyard - farmyard. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is flat. [20110805]
Cask@GBBF2011 (ABV 6.5 %). Golden colour, small head. Aroma is apples, biscuits, some bready and mild yeasty notes. Flavour is sweet apples, some slight dry wooden and earthy notes. Mouthdrying.

Cask, gravity at Cambridge BF ’07. Slightly hazy silver-gold. Ash and musty fruit aroma. Waves of summery sweetness and a delightfully sharp edge of sourness make this a rewarding, easy drinking real cider. No bitterness. Delicious.

column1: Crabby Larrys Dead Man Walkin' India Pale Ale
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Pours clear amber with a small white head. The aroma has light pine, light citrus, light floral notes. The taste has a nice bitterness, a bit of orange pith, light grapefruit.

column1: Crabby Larrys Dead Man Walkin' India Pale Ale
column5: Deep hazy golden orange pour foamy soapy off white head lots of sticky lacing ..... malty and citrusy hop aroma ..... taste of fresh citrusy bitter hops little floral and resinous hops ....dry bitter hop finish an enjoyable ipa not bad at all larry

column1: Crabby Larrys Dead Man Walkin' India Pale Ale
column5: Tap at Crabby Larrys. Pours a hazy deep amber with a normal off white head. Aroma of a nice citrusy and floral American hop nose with hints of caramel. Flavor of the same solid hoppy profile and a moderate does of caramel malt.

column1: Crabby Larrys Dead Man Walkin' India Pale Ale
column5: On tap at Brewpub. Pours a clear copper color with no head. Aroma of hops and caramel with a taste some caramel and citrus flavor. Lots of hop bitterness in the taste though. Good lacing. Overall, a good IPA.

column1: Crabby Larrys Dead Man Walkin' India Pale Ale
column5: on tap-pours an off white head and hazy gold color. Aroma is medium malt, secondary pine hops. Taste is sweet medium malt-caramel, secondary pine/citrus-pineapple hops.

column1: Crabby Larrys Dead Man Walkin' India Pale Ale
column5: Draft pours a murky amber with a thin white head. Has a nice aroma mixed malts with some good hoopy pines. Has a decent blend. Good flavors with a nice balance. Lightly hoppy and a solid finish. Good carbination and a good mouthfeel. This was by far my favorite at the resturant. I would order this one again.

column1: Crabby Larrys Dead Man Walkin' India Pale Ale
column5: Draught at BrewPub: Aroma of floral hops and caramel. Poured copper/amber in color with a small, dense, off-white head that lasted throughout. Very sparkling. Excellent lacing. Lightly sweet, lightly bitter flavor. Tastes of hops, malts, and flowers. Light body. Thin texture. Soft carbonation. Hoppy finish.

column1: Crabby Larrys Dead Man Walkin' India Pale Ale
column5: Pale amber in color with saopy head. Light malty aroma with minimal hops mixed in. The taste was the same with light herbal hop finish. Thinner bodied.

column1: Crabby Larrys Dead Man Walkin' India Pale Ale
column5: Draft at brewpub. Pours amber/orange in color with a beigh head. Aroma of citrus and some pine. Flavor is thin and dry with faint resin, grapefruit, pine and a touch of caramel

column1: Crabby Larrys Dead Man Walkin' India Pale Ale
column5: Amber color wiht a sweet aroma of Grapefruit&pine. Taste is a quality mix of citrus-pine hop. The beer menu says its all Amarillo. Decent enough.

Bottled at Katalin, Uppsala. Pale yellow, lightly hazy, firm creamy head. Spicy hops dominate the nose. Dry, crisp and herbal with fairly light body. Slim and drinkable, lightly grainy.Longer very bitter herbal finish.
Not surprised they retired this one. Tried for the first time back in 2008 and only now getting to the rating transfer. Weak and overly sweet. Chemical finish. Chocolate like a tootsie roll.

On tap at the 2007 Parkville Microbrew Festival. Pours a clear reddish brown color with a thin off-white head that has little staying power. Very mild roasted chocolate aroma that musters up little enthusiasm. A watery beer by body, but palatable. The chocolate is quite strong in the flavor and that gives it some respect from me. The finish seems much more of a bitter semi-sweet chocolate than a candy milk chocolate.

On tap at the Parkville Microbrew Festival. Pours black with a dark beige head. Has a strong vanilla aroma that seems real, but the odd chemical mid flavors betray this. It has a great chocolate finish that I like a lot.
The most ideal black beer among all black beers for my taste. Price is reasonable compared to its quality.

average frothy light brown head. fair lacing. mostly diminishing. flat thick brownish-black body. aroma: heavy malty, dark bread, dark chocolate, mild coffee. if and ff: moderate sweet light bitter; average duration. palate: medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, metallic finish. SABOR METÁLICO SURGE COMO DEFEITO, sabor café e chocolate, Leve amargor, média stouts importadas, acima da média comercial brasileira; 15 s

A botton fermentation macro stout with adjunts and stuff. It pours really black with big tan head (too dark, evidence of colourant). Weak medicinal aroma. Alcohol flavour, a little sweet (less sweeter than other Brazilian black beers), medicinal notes and a little bitterness. Palate is good, a little "sandy" (!?). It’s fairly good for a macro brewer that brews other really bad beers.

Bottle. Amazing beer that I find! Nice aroma, some chocolate and toasted malt, the flavor is wonderfull, caramel and bitterness at same time, nice beige head and mouthfeel is like chocolate tabacco bitter. Great beer! Cerveja escura tipo stout, aroma doce com notas de chocolate e malte torrado, sabor delicioso meio termo entre o doce e o amargo, fica um sabor de tabaco de chocolate amargo. Boa cerveja!

Aroma has some hop oil, ranging from nail polish remover-like scents to some floral aromas. A little boring and unusual in appearance, with a flat look, a little collar with a cloudy golden color. A very good malt undertone with biting hop qualities and some sharpness in flavor. Very nutty and somewhat velvety finish and a bit of the bitter.

This poured a hazy yellow color with a big fluffy white head. Aroma was sweet sdweet wheaty malts with hints of alcohol as well. Flavor was sweet with a flash of some hoppy bitterness and a long boozy aftertaste. This should not taste this strong at only 7.5

Draft @ Lost Coast. Pours a clear yellow color with a small white head. Has a malty grainy and slightly hoppy aroma. Sweetish malty grainy hoppy flavor. Has a sweetish grainy finish with a long bitter aftertaste.
very dissappointing. I was expexting this brew to pack a punch. No such luck. It was very bland and a little watery. Pass on this one.

At the brewpub, this was a cloudy orange, with small white pub head and light lacing. Nose of malts and citrus hops. Rich mouttfeel. Flavor is mostly citrus and pine hops, and the finish is nicely bitter. Hides the alcohol well. Easy drinking for such a high alcohol beer.

On tap at Capone’s. Pours a hazy golden orange with a medium creamy/bubbly white head that left some lacing. Aroma of sweet almost candy like maltiness, citrus, floral and lightly spicy hop notes and honey nut cheerios. Flavor of spicy, citrusy notes. Noble hops, lots of malty sweetness, but finishes dry. Hop bitterness is there, light alcohol and grainy notes. Iced tea flavor as it warmed up.

Pint - Eastside Club Tavern - Olympia, WA
Aroma – Nice decent hops and malt aroma.
Appearance – Golden in color, clear with a light head.
Flavor – A very nice pilsner flavor. Has a good balance of malts and hops. Strong alcohol flavor also.
Palate – Good Mouthfeel, Nice texture with a dry finish.
Overall – Good Pilsner flavor this was a good beer for the night.
Tasted @ the Loast Coast Brewery in Eureka. Pretty decent strong lager.
(Draught) Sampled at the Dog & Pony Alehouse in Renton, WA. Quick dissipated head atop a mildly carbonated, clear yellow body. Nose of iodine, vanilla. Flavour is strongly alcoholic. Average.

Draught @ Brouwer’s Café: Golden in color, slightly fiery, moderate frothy off-white head, fairly sticky lacing, strong carbonation.   Mealy nose, certainly malty, but also a fairly strong hop aspect.   Even a slight floral hint.   Seems decent enough.   Forwardly hoppy, a little bit of heat, decent malt background.   Not as flavorful as the nose suggested but still quite good.   Fairly clean.   This certainly feels like an Imperial Pilsner.   More hops than most.   Body and mouthfeel are full to moderate.   Warming finish.   I enjoyed this one even if it was a little abrasive.   Will probably mellow with time.

column1: Three Floyds Replicale/West Coast Red Ale
column5: a pretty straight forward American Amber with American hops. Not totally sure what the hops are, but they seem like Amarillo. Who knows. At any rate, quaffable and decent. Nice.

column1: Three Floyds Replicale/West Coast Red Ale
column5: On tap at FFF 9/22/07. Light red colored beer, decent looking head that quickly fades, moderate lacing. Slightly piney hop aroma, not as much maltiness as I like in a good west coast red. Flavor is fairly dry, not a whole lot of malt character at all, more piney hops, very one dimensional.

column1: Three Floyds Replicale/West Coast Red Ale
column5: On tap at 3F during RBSG Road Trip 2007. Clear copper with a nice tan head. Solid malty nose, strong citrus. Citrus flavors well balanced with the sweet malt flavors, very easy to drink.

column1: Three Floyds Replicale/West Coast Red Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Slightly hazy red body with a small creamy tan head. Sweet caramel and citrus hops aroma. Very sweet citrus hops flavor with some caramel and tea in the ending.

column1: Three Floyds Replicale/West Coast Red Ale
column5: draft at brewpub: Reddish amber. Aroma is PNW hops with some crystal goodness, typical malty sweetness you see in reds. Much bigger hop presence for a beer of this style, and much more enjoyable. Almost like the Alpha King of ambers, but not quite. Very enjoyable.

column1: Three Floyds Replicale/West Coast Red Ale
column5: On tap at Three Floyds, poured into an Imperial pint glass. This beer poured a deep reddish amber color with a small tan head that quickly faded away. Not much lace to speak of. The aroma consisted of citrus hops and some sweet maltiness. The flavor was very smooth, with a big citrusy/fruity taste with a nice roastiness, finishing off with a nice hit of bitter, spicy hops. The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with minimal carbonation. Very well done. I seemed to prefer this one over the Flossmoor version due to the bigger citrus presence.

column1: Three Floyds Replicale/West Coast Red Ale
column5: It seems that the suppliers thought that Munster is located in Illinois, and so the 3F folk got the goods to brew this year’s Illinois Craft Brewers Guild replicale. (I can’t wait to see what they do with Indiana’s replicale... and Michigan’s... and Ohio’s...) It pours a dark reddish brown with a thick beige head and does some intricate lacing. The aroma is hoppy, of course (this is Three Floyds), pine resin with a hit of grapefruits. The malts are toasty, sweet, and spicy. The flavor is pretty well balanced to begin with, but the bitterness from the hops - pine, grapefruit, earth - intesifies as you drink. It finishes on a warm, bitter note. Nice. Three Floyds Brewing Company and Brewpub, Munster, IN

column1: Three Floyds Replicale/West Coast Red Ale
column5: Draught. At the brewpub. Very interesting idea, and I was stoked to try this one, then the Flossmoor version a few hours later. Poured ruby-brown with an average rocky off-white head. Solid roast malt, rye and herbal/resin hop aroma. The taste had the same components, but the rye grain was almost carbonized, making the taste more bitter than the fairly balanced aroma, to the beer’s benefit - a nice light alcohol warmth joined the resin yielding a nice bitter roasty finish. The body seemed a bit flaccid, but it didn’t detract much from the solid carbonation and astringency - nice medium-long bitter linger on my tongue. Very, very good, maybe a tad thin - seemed almost cask-like, several pints would go down very easily and smoothly.

column1: Three Floyds Replicale/West Coast Red Ale
column5: Draft at Floyds. Mild hop nose right off the glass (suprised?). Deep red body that admits no highlight in the low light of the pub, except at the bottom. A thin scum of head. Very lightly carbonated, might even pass for a cask beer if I hadn’t been told that yes, it is pressurized. Slight warming alcohol is all that keeps it from being a great session beer. Hops finally take a stand at the end, playing footsie with every taste bud on the way down.

column1: Three Floyds Replicale/West Coast Red Ale
column5: This was a dark ruby beer with mild head ,malty but with a nice finish,very drinkable with a little FFF hop taste to it and malty.CHEERS to the guys for doing this one ,not bad at all. .
Tap at Midwest Brewfest. Pours a cloudy, thick yellow with an aroma of clove and banana. Flavor is watery clove. Average mouthfeel. Blah.

On tap at the Parkville Microbrew Festival. An outdstanding beer! Giant liquid Woody Allen banana flavor! Strong banana esters in the aroma. This big, big sweetness disappears rapidly leaving a quick clean finish. Very good beer.

On tap at the Parkville Microbrew Festival. Simply a horrible beer. Totally watery in that it lacks any malt body or sweetness. This insolent cur has the audacity to throw an unpleasant burnt flavor at you upon finish.

Smells like caramel candies and b.o. Pours dark brown with a bubbly head. Taste is mostly sweet caramel with a little bitterness. Drinkable, but I don’t really know how to classify it. Way too watery, could use a lot more substance- a lot more malt and alcohol.

Draught @ Na Louzi, Cesky Krumlov. Pours slightly hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of malt, white bread, grassy hops. Flavor is sweet, light bitter, malt, bready, hay, grass. Medium body, soft carbonation, light sweet finish. 220719
On tap at Na Louži. Pours mostly clear golden with thin white head. Aroma is malty and yeasty. Taste is sweet and somewhat bitter with malt, grassy hops and yeast.
Indoor. Na ezt nevezem én, ez az amiért az embernek érdemes. Tipikus cseh szuretlen, bármelyik cseh óba a szuretlen prototípus.
Tap, Cesky Krumlov, CZ, Malt,cereal,yeast,light fruity and grassy aroma, Bit hazy golden color, bigger lasting head, Sweeter taste, decent bitter ending, Medium body, Soft carbon, Pretty good.

(tap 0,5l @ Brewery) Aroma: Yeasts, malty. Appearance: Hazy, golden color. Medium, white head. Taste: Medium sweet, medium bitter, yeasts. Palate: Medium body. Fizzy. Light bitter finish. Overall: Nice yeasty lager.

Hazy orange colour, white head. Aroma of malts, yeast, fruity esters. Taste is light sweet, slightly bitter with a note of sourness. Well balanced. Light body, slick texture, soft to average carbonation.
On tap at Na Louzi, Cesky Krumlov. Pours golden color, white head. Aroma is malty, bit yeasty. Taste is medium bitter, lightly sweet, malty.

On tap at Pivovar Eggenberg, Cesky Krumlov. Close to clear deep golden with a white head. Moderate malty with slightly fruity and floral notes and hints of grass in the finish. Moderate sweet with balanced flavours and a rather mild bitterness. Tasty and very sessionable.
On tap. White head with trailing lace-slightly hazed gold. A-sweet grain. T-grain/ lt malt, 2nd earth/spice hops.
Draft. Pours hazed orange with a white head. Soft fruity sweetness, some yeasty minerally notes, very mild bitterness, light earthy notes, and a quick clean finish. Not bad.
on tap-pours a retaining thin off white head that laces and gold color. Aroma is faint citrus hops, medium malt. Taste is mild faint citrus/pine hops-some caramel. Mild carbonation.
This was far and away the best beer that I had here. A nice floral aroma, good cloudy color. Taste is hoppy but balanced, not just bitter. A nice crips bite rest on the tongue. Excellent stuff.

Enjoyed this one on draught at the brewpub in Tacoma, WA. Pours to a slightly hazy, deep golden to amber color, with a thick, creamy, white head, and a moderate carbonation. The nose on this beer is pungent and fragrant with big herbal/cirtus hop aromas that flood the nose. The palate is firm, with a good base of pale and biscuit malt, paired with a good herbal/citrus hop tang. This beer finishes with more good pale malt and tangy hop flavor up front, then ends with a bitter citrus/herbal hop bite that lingers. Excellent IPA that showcases Centennial hop aromas, flavors, and bitterness. Excellent aperitif beer, a great pint to match with foods on the brewpub’s menu, and a nice beer to sip and relax with at the bar.

Tap - Brewery A deep golden color with a thick hop aroma. This was the best beer I had this day here at the Engine house. Liked the malt characters and the hops where very good. For a PNW they could add a few more pounds of hops to go up in IBU’s. Not bad and I will order this again when I go back.

Draft. An unclear golden beer with a white head. The aroma has notes of malt and fresh hay. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, lemons, bread, and straw, as well as light notes of eggs, leading to a bitter finish. More flavor than in the filtered one.

Keg at the Aldersbacher bar in Prague. Pours hazy Gold with a thick white head. Aroma of freshly cut grass. There’s a good wack of malty caramel sweetness (particularly for a 10) and the hops are very pronounced and dry. Slighlty herbal. Lovely bitterness to finish. Drunk first thing after a long day at work. This hit the spot..

(draught) pours a hazy golden colour with a frothy white head. heavy aroma of sweet spices, most notably cinnamon, chewy pale malts and light floral hops, slightly musty. flavour is the same, very chewy and spicy, with some characteristic butter and a fresh minerally finish. slightly watery body with average carbonation.

From tap at Hospoda. Pours slight cloudy orange with a small, slight off-white head. Aroma is earthy and slight butterish. Crisp grassy, citrusy and zesty flavoured. Bitter, slight bubblegum and mild butterish flavoured. Crisp grassy and light malty. Bitter and grassy dry finish.

On tap at U Klokoènika. Slightly hazy golden with a lasting white head. Malty aroma with biscuit, some herbal hops and a hint of DMS vegetable. Sweet and malty flavour with toffee notes, herbal hops and a bitter finish.

Draught at U Klokoènika , Prague. Pours clear golden with a small white head and lacings. Hoppy nose and flavor. Some bready malts and grassy hops. Smooth and medium bodied. Dry end. Just as fine as the 12 unfiltered.

Draught at U Klokoènika in Prague. That brewery was my top surprise of a Czech tour, so it is no surprise that the yeast version of a contender as my trip favourite is killer. It is minimally hazy, bright and golden with a humongous 2-inches styrofoam top that lasts forever. Ridiculously easy 5. Somehow though, it is less delightfully straightforward as its filtered brother. Nonetheless, its freshness is to be lauded and its full-body is most impressive. Very fresh impression and convincing on the hop side with its leafy, herbal, spicy and... green side. A marvelous lager.
Draught. Mild fruity aroma. Clear dark golden colour. Big stable creamy off-white head. The flavour has a faint aroma hoppiness, slightly grassy. Medium bitterness, bites a bit in the finish.
Pale yellow colour, quite opaque, very bitter, full, refreshing, thin foam, making circles on glass. Draught at U Klokocnika, Prague 4 - Pankrac.

(Draught at U Klokoènika, Prague, 21 July 2008) Golden colour with frothy, white head. Clean, malty, grassy nose with slight notes of toffee. Clean, malty taste with toffee and a dry, grassy bitterness in the finish. Rather thin body. Clean and fresh, fairly nice.

column1: Kácov Hubertus 12° Svìtlý Ležák Prémium Nefiltrovaný
column5: # 1563. Very good unfiltered version of czech pilsner. Hazy, malty, yeasty, full bodied, crispy. 0,5 l, draught, pub, Toužim (CZ).

column1: Kácov Hubertus 12° Svìtlý Ležák Prémium Nefiltrovaný
column5: Aroma; floury malts, appleish fruit, leaves n cellar, bread notes. Look; off white huge head, silky near clear organic golden body. Taste; malts, hops, fermented notes, spiced apple, wooden caramel, syrup bread, honey note, butter - arch typical czech finish. Feel; good body, soft, modest co2. Overall really czech, super dvanactka. [pet b@BaseCamp Praha]

column1: Kácov Hubertus 12° Svìtlý Ležák Prémium Nefiltrovaný
column5: PET , Cesky Brod , CZ , Malt,bread,dough and grassy aroma , Hazy orange golden color with smaller head , Sweeter taste with nice bitter finish , Very soft carbon , Medium body , Pleasant beer.

column1: Kácov Hubertus 12° Svìtlý Ležák Prémium Nefiltrovaný
Kácov Hubertus 12° Svìtlý Ležák Prémium Nefiltrovaný
column5: Served in a Hubertus glass in Kutná Hora, CZ in 2011 (from notes) A - A hazy golden amber with a durable off-white head. Plenty of lacing. Aroma: yeasty with light malt and less hops. A sour note, presumably from the yeast. Taste: a bit sweet at first, but bitter hops kick in mid-taste and leave a long lasting finish. M - moderstely carbonated and crisp, with a medium body that is somewhat full for style. A bit less dry than a typical Czech pilsner. O - very good with no flaws to complain about, unless you find the sour note in the aroma objectionable, but not special either

column1: Kácov Hubertus 12° Svìtlý Ležák Prémium Nefiltrovaný
column5: Velice pøíjemná dvanáctka. Chu nièím nevyènívá, což ale neznamená, že by šlo o nìjaké europivo, jen je vše dobøe vyvážené.

column1: Kácov Hubertus 12° Svìtlý Ležák Prémium Nefiltrovaný
column5: 1 liter sealed plastic green bottle - kindly shared by JorisPPattyn. To set the record straight: I am not a pilsner drinker (because of the severe and profound dislike for all of those industrial corporates, yes, I am talking to you AB Inbev!)... But what the hell is this? One of the most raw and flavourful beers I have ever tasted (with regards to the ABV). Pours gold with a creaaaammy white head. Aroma of malt malt malt and some yeast.Medium body with nice bitterness level, not standing in the way of the flavours which is malt again with some flowerly notes.

column1: Kácov Hubertus 12° Svìtlý Ležák Prémium Nefiltrovaný
column5: Tap @ Pivovarsky Klub. Pours golden with a white head. Aroma of malt, grassy hops, light sourness. Flavor is malt, grass, soapy. Medium body, soft carbonation, bitter finish. Not very pleasant due to the offnote of soap. 040812

column1: Kácov Hubertus 12° Svìtlý Ležák Prémium Nefiltrovaný
column5: At a tasting , thx joris for bringing ! Served out of original sealed plastic bottle Head: Creamy, white Colour: gold Smell: creamy, sweet, malts, slight irony, hops Taste: flowery hops, soft , grassy, some malts, slight irony, bitter dry end , very balanced very nice ! Finally a good pilsner that i’ve tried !

column1: Kácov Hubertus 12° Svìtlý Ležák Prémium Nefiltrovaný
column5: On tap in restaurant Kreta in Kutna Hora. Aroma is weak malty with hint of nuts and hops. Taste is malty with nice hops aftertaste, overall a bit on the sweet side. Nice beer, certainly very drinkable.
Tried at the brewery in 2010. I appreciate the unique flavor but this beer tastes like the brewmaster used licorice as a sweetening agent. Points for inventiveness.

On tap at the brewpub. The brewmaster graciously gave us a sample of this BEFORE THE OFFICIAL OPENING TIME, thus likely violating all the rules of god and man. I’m so glad he lives on the edge because this is perhaps the best braggot I have ever tasted. Way better than my own homebrew braggot. I’m thinking that this is more on the mead end of the scale. I had always thought that braggot was 50-50 honey and malt, but this tastes like all honey with a slash of beer in it. So smooth. So heavenly.

On tap @ Dry Dock poured a clear brown with a small lasting off white head. Aromas of honey, carmel, toffee and light spice. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of honey, carmel, light toffeeand a hint of fruitiness with a crisp slightly dry fruity finish.

Beautiful floral and spicy hops greet the nose followed by toasty malts and a touch of butter. Clear golden body is topped by a dense, fine bubbled white head that lasts well and laces. Buttery character is far stronger in the flavour with toasty malts and moderate bitterness. Medium carbonation to the light body with a fairly slick and oily texture. Sampled on tap with Oakes and CapFlu at the brewpub in May 2007.

(Draught) Sampled at the brewpub. Pours a nicely carbonated deep amber body with a quick dissipating head. Nose of grassy hops and a mild canned corn. Flavour is slightly spiced, oily and has tones of diacetyl. Okay but average.

Golden colour. The head wasn’t terribly rich, though, especially for this style. Rich saaz nose with hints at big, bready malts. Moderately bitter flavour with a nice, slightly grassy saaz character. Apparently I missed the diacetyl, but I’ve got no problem with that. I ordered another and another and another.

damn man, this is my go to lately. i have had a few gallons to say the least, but i still don’t know what to say. when it is good, damn, it is good. i’ve had a couple of off pints that were weirdly grassy too. overall i love it. it pours a light tan and depending on who pours it i get no head, thin head or mammoth head. so don’t worry. aroma, well, american earthy scent, no weird banana or yeast, a touch of caramel and vinous hop with light grass. one of the better balanced brews i’ve had. granted there has been a couple off glasses, ut when it works, hold the phone mothefucker, i have siome drinking to do. caramel light buttered toffee flavor with a TOUCH OF GRASS, BUT A MUCH STRONGER BITTER BALANCE. THIS IS NOT ONE damn you caps locki. as i was saying, this is not one i really anaylize i just ordewr it drink it and smile. a nice slightly strong session beer. on a side note, i think these guys could do a good 3.4ish session, i hope thye try it at some point.

On tap @ Dry Dock poured a lightly hazy amber with a large lasting ivory head. Aromas of carmel, earthiness and some light fruity notes. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, light fruitiness and a light hint of earthiness with a smooth lightly sweet finish.
this is a distint rating taken during michigan winter beer festival, 2009...unfortunately, notes were not taken on most of these beers, but numbers are accurate.
Draft. Pours a ruby brune body with a thin white lacing. Big fruity flavor of raspberries, medicinal cherry and loads of alcohol, maybe vodka-esk. Light oak but just very strong.

MBG Winter Fest 2008, sample from oak barrel. Poured hazy reddish brown with an average fizzy off-white head that lasted with good lacing. Heavy raspberry, tart fruity and wood aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Medium sweet & sour fruity balanced flavor and a medium sweet woody finish of moderate duration. Good young that should be better with some age.

(Barrel) Pours a cloudy purplish-brown body with a small off-white head. Aroma of raspberries, overly ripen apples lying in an apple orchard, red grapes, light floral, and earthiness. Flavor of sweet, semi-tart raspberry, apple, grapes, and caramel with a dry oak finish. Excellent!

cask sample at MBGWF....poured a nice amber reddish burnt brown with a thin soapy off-white head....nose was really woody and vinous with a big raspberry component.... flavors of red fruit, wood, and earth.

Served out of a cask at the MBG winter fest. This one was a surprise so I was excited to try it. Nice woody raspberry on the nose. I think somebody described this before as actually eating the raspberrys vine and all. I thought the same thing. Nice lucsious raspberry with a strong wood character. Very nice overall.

2008 MBG Winter Fest, served from a oak cask: Brown with lots of ruby highlights, minimal head nor lace. The aroma is indeed raspberry along with clean oak, grassy, and just a beginning hint of Brettanomyces. The taste is acidic sourness and fruit with just a dash of pale and caramel malting. The finish is a touch woody and alcoholic. The mouth feel is sprite and a bit dry, warming. A good beer that should only get better once the funk takes hold.

Last drops from the barrel at Michigan Winter Beer Fest 2008. Sorry everyone. Glad i got a chance to have this. Nice raspberry and oak scent and flavor. I didn’t find as much alcohol in it as other people were saying. Hidden under all the fruit.

Sampled at the NOTB. The biggest surprise of the night for me. Was not expecting too much. Aroma was wood and rasberry. Solid blend. Flavor was about the same. One of the few beers that stood out for me and golubj.

First sample at NOTB EBF 08. Pours a murky violet tinted brownish gray with prety much no head and a very low carbonation (served from a barrel!). Aroma is intenste raspberry puree but earthy as well with some tartness- not as sweet and enticing as NG Rasp Tart though, and has a wierd phenolic alcohol burn in the end that was off-setting. Flavor is at first sweet rasp then gets a bit tart and finishes astringent with tannin, alcohol burn and paint thinner. Way too boozy and fusely for me- I almost couldnt drink it. I believe they said this was 12+% abv.

16 ounce draft at the Flying Dog Brewery in Frederick, Maryland. Sweet what to the nose. Dark yellow and cloudy with a thin white head. Taste the wheat and the sugars. Smooth and light. Little spice aftertaste. Wonderful beer. Cheers!

From Aug 2007 Purchased as part of a mixed 6Pack at Wilbur's in Ft Collins Pours from 12oz bottle starting off clear but then becomes very cloudy. It was like 2 seperate layers of beer until the clouds took over. ;^) It's got a very nice head of foam and lacing and colourwise, it's more of a pale straw gold. The smell is very fruity with a lot of lemon and lime permeating my nose buds. The taste has good lemon flavour with some spice and wheat and there's also some earthiness. It's pretty noticeable and good until just before the finish when it drops off some leaving it on the watery side. Still, this isn't a bad brew and it's a welcome drink for the hot summer day here in Casper.

Draft at Tilquin during 2019 Toer De Gueuze. Pours a hazy orange color without much head. Notes of oak, lemon, light sweet malt, and grain. Easy drinking at the lower percent but lacking complexity. This version was 3.6 percent, not sure if it would be a new entry?
Draft from Tilquin. Pale blond and hazy with thin soapy head. Aroma and flavour have a mild sharpness. Very light and wheaty. Very flavoursome.
Bright aroma with yeast, citrus. Yellow, slightly hazy without foam. The taste is slightly sour, a little malt and citrus. The body of the beer is light, the carbonation is light.

05.05.2019, (as Tilquin Meerts) @ Gueuzerie Tilquin during Toer de Geuze: Nice slightly bubbly-creamy mediumlasting head, slightly cloudy. Aroma is slightly dry sour-ish floral, sorrel, old lawn, minerals, hay, bark, old rotten leafs, berry skin, old rope, grass, hints of sulfur. Taste is slightly dry sour-ish grassy, sorrel, berry skin, hay, minerals, grass, old rope, weeds, fruit stones, unripe berries, oak. Medium bitterness, slightly dry and harsh sour-ish floral mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Fair enough, interesting.
On Tap @Gueuzerie Tilquin, Lembeek 04/05/19 Tomada como Tlquin Meerts Color amarillo anaranjado, aromas herbal, notas a cereal, sabor cereal, ligeramente acida, cuerpo ligero, floja.

Toer de Gueze 2017. Draught at Gueuzerie Tilquin. As "Tilquin Meerts". Slightly hazy with no head. The aroma has notes of fruit juice and peach. Flavor of peach and citrus juice, watery. Slightly dry, light-bodied.
On tap at Gueuzerie Tilquin during Toer de Gueze 2017, as Tilquin Meerts. Hazy yellow, no head. Wood, barnyard, citrus at the nose. Very light sourness, citric. Light-bodied, flat.
cask at tilquin during toer de gueuze Ever so lightly soured, quite thin in body with some residual sweetness. pale amber. little in the way of aroma. definitely interesting to try

On tap at the Tilquin English Beer Festival 2015. Fast klare goldene Farbe, sehr geringe weiße Schaumkrone. Der Geruch ist trocken fruchtig, sauer. Der Geschmack ist dezent säuerlich, trocken, pelzig, etwas Kraut.

On tap @ Tilquin English Beer Festival 2015. Pours a clear golden color with minimal head. The smell is funk, toasted malt. The taste is light funk, mild softness, some fruit, ending dry, crisp and slightly sour. Light in body very mild carbonation. Great for 3.6%

column1: La Rouget de Lisle Crin Blanc
column5: courtesy of Anna and Laurent - clear amber beer with no foam; subtle aroma of caramel and almond; medium-bodied, rounded and light oily; gentle bitterness, metallic notes; effervescent and a bit short caramelish, vegetable-like and flowery finish - not fully convincing

Not as bad as colt 45 or Big Bear, but close. This is the perfect example of how not to brew beer. Soapy, wheat and corn high lite the aroma. Piss yellow with a soapy white non existent head. Way too heavy of a corn taste also very soapy. Very bitter/sour. Strong corn aftertaste. Avoid.

column1: Mussel Inn Bitter Ass Extra Bitter Beer
column5: 1.3L plastic bottle from supermarket shared in our van. Bit hazy amber with off white head. Lots of butter, caramel, light fruity hops, sweet bready malts, toast, dried berries. Medium sweet and bitter. Just medium bodied. I’m not so susceptible to butter notes in beer, but here it’s very present. Otherwise OK.

column1: Mussel Inn Bitter Ass Extra Bitter Beer
column5: Pours an almost rosy copper colour with a white head subsiding gently. Aromas f amber malt, baking scones, grassines and perfume. It’s full and creamy, warm and alcoholic. Strong orange peel an amber malt flavours. Bitterness is fairly full on (around 35-40 IBU). Once you get over all the alcohol this creates thirst as good bitter should. Easily my favourite Mussel Inn beer.

column1: Mussel Inn Bitter Ass Extra Bitter Beer
column5: on tap at the inn. Dark copper colour. Nice hoppy aroma, think it may have been Fuggles. Light to medium body with a bitterish finish, but not nearly as bitter as the sign promised.

column1: Mussel Inn Bitter Ass Extra Bitter Beer
column5: Tasted Jan 07 @ Brewpub. Red amber colour, thin creamy head. Herb & floral nose. Tastes dark and rich - hard to describe. Big, full and well rounded. Another fantastic beer from what must be one of the best places in the world to drink.
Tasted 26/04 @ Ruby’s Bar. Wow, big thick rich malt dominant. A touch biting, perhaps served too cold but a good beer from such a great brewery in a very unique environment.

column1: Harrington's Classy Red Session Red IPA
column5: Standard longneck, bad label. Clear chestnut brown with a short, fluffy khaki head. Sweet, tannic aroma with faint notes of hard cinnamon/nutmeg/allspice type spices. I also pick up dry mustard, oddly. Lightly sweet, low bittering, a little spicy bitterness. Rudderless, but not bad. Low carbonation, watery mouthfeel. Ah well, off to watch rugby. Part of a mixpack from Pak N Save, Albany, Auckland.

column1: Harrington's Classy Red Session Red IPA
column5: 330ml bottle. Not much on the nose, some nice citrus and sweet malt on the palate, finishes off clean enough. Not memorable enough to buy again.

column1: Harrington's Classy Red Session Red IPA
column5: Delicious. Reminds me of a quality English Bitter . Nice malty flavour. Good to sup. Hoppy bitterness not overpowering. This beer is one of my favourites.

column1: Harrington's Classy Red Session Red IPA
column5: Cloudy amber red pour with high carbonation and thin head. Sour aroma, sour upfront palate with some roasted malt and short finish. Not classy, more mediocre.

column1: Harrington's Classy Red Session Red IPA
column5: 330ml bottle. Aroma is a little lacking, with a little watery caramel and a fairly bland bitterness. Flavour is much more interesting though. There’s plenty of caramel and pepper, some grapefruit bitterness and a nice clean grassy finish. A surprisingly nice beer in a style I’d usually not bother with.

column1: Harrington's Classy Red Session Red IPA
column5: 330ml red. Pours a deep red with off white head. Medium body with bold malt flavours, tied in with lingering bitter notes.

column1: Harrington's Classy Red Session Red IPA
column5: 500ml bottle BB 4/5/17 Ruby Red ?? Hmm, more like a light amberish brown. Malty, hoppy nose. Nice bitterness with a pleasant hoppy finish. Maybe a wee bit thin at the back. Nice enough but I’ve had better Red ales than this.

column1: Harrington's Classy Red Session Red IPA
column5: Hmm- says its american in style but to me it’s a very British tasting ale, with lots of holdings/fuggles, not too much new world "grapefruit hops".

column1: Harrington's Classy Red Session Red IPA
column5: Cloudy copper colour. Little head. Poured from bottle. Malt taste with a bitter finish. Smells like a fruity malt mixture

column1: Harrington's Classy Red Session Red IPA
column5: Alluring tropical aroma in an amber pour. This is an excellent middle of the road brew that shows how good a regular beer can be if the brewer actually cares.
Amber kleurig bier met een mooie volle schuimkraag, licht zoet en licht bitter met een bittere nasmaak. Medium body.
Soft and creamy on the palate which is not what I was expecting. Said "generous hops" however dominated by the malt.

330ml bottle Pours clear reddish brown with a good head. Feel: Medium body and nicely smooth, with crisp medium carbonation; dry finish. Aroma: caramel and medium roasted malts with a hint of fruit; simple but good.. Flavor: toffee + bready malts and a hint of hops. Slightly bitter but nicely balanced finish. O: easy drinking and recommended.
Clean bitterness, quite fizzy out of the bottle but made it very refreshing on a hot day, quite hoppy for the style but not over the top ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft at the source. Clear amber color, solid white head. Aroma of light caramel. Taste is sweet toasted caramel.
’twas okay, nice chocomalts are the main thing i get from this, and a bit of typical esb fruitiness up top. no all that complex and rather thin, but not a bad effort.
Had to drink from bottle so hard to judge appearance. . Medium carbonation and body. Caramel malts. Citrus. Medium bitterness.

Poured a translucent coppery brown colour with a one- to two-finger light tan head that retained well and laced well. Moderate carbonation. Aroma of malt but strongly of roasted grain. Taste of sweet malt and roasted grain followed by hops bitterness. Not a bitter beer as it is sweeter than it is bitter. Light to medium body. Short smooth, sweet and slightly bitter finish. Different to what a "bitter" beer ’should’ be - enjoyable.

Rather cautious, I was expecting this beer to gut me with bitterness, like a ferocious pig would to a horse. But this was not bad at all! Great appearance, pouring dark amber, with a generous head, although it disappears rather quickly. Malty nose and malty taste. No boar taint or bacon smokiness. The bitterness is there, but perhaps not enough to make it premium. Very pleasant though. More sweet than bitter. Nice call.

Bottle, 11C (bottle advises to serve at room temp _and_ at 4-6C), better as it warmed. Clear brown with an off white head. Aroma of chocolate, toffee and nuts. A little watery and rather overcarbonated for this sort of thing. Modest sweetness with some toffee, a little chocolate and nuts. Balancing grassy bitterness with some cocoa.

Bottle stated 4.1%ABV. Poured a hazy straw color with quickly diminishing white head and thin lacing. Aromas of banana and yeast. Taste is yeast and banana with a citrusy hop finish. Carbonation is adequate and a light body. A very nice wheat beer.

Clear deep yellow gold brew that produced almost zero head - the pour was a little careful, but there should have been alot more. Zero retention. Aroma is of cloves and dried banana chips and wheat. Taste is soft but appealing - one of the better Alley Kat brews that I have had in a long time. Nice banana taste that is mild but is held in check with the obvious presence of cloves. Wheaty too of course. Mouthfeel is smooth. Good carbonation. Near to medium bodied. Hard to describe the aftertaste as I just ran out of beer.

Crystal clear golden yellow body, big rocky cap produced during pour but vanished to nothing after about 10 seconds, very large bubbles are sticking to the walls and bottom of my glass this reminds of a glass of ginger ale. The smell has banana and tons of it, sweet smelling wheat malts and I guess overall it reminds me of banana cream pie, this stuff smells very simple and is very aromatic. Taste is very simple but appealing, wheaty, lots of banana and a touch of spice taste is very light crisp and clean leaving behind no after taste. This brew is very simple tasting and taste the way it should, it’s nothing great but for Alley Kat this is above average.

Bottled at Stockholm Beer Festival 2007. A slightly hazy golden beer with a thick yellowish head. The aroma is sweet with strong notes of citrus and banana, as well as light notes of wheat. The flavor is sweet malty and wheaty combined with notes of straw and light notes of citrus and banana.
0.34 l bottle. Golden color with vanishing head. Sweetish and refreshing aroma with banana, watermelon and wheat. Very bready flavor with some pepper, clove, coriander and hint of dryish sourness.
Sampled at SBWF, 2007. Pale golden. Small, white head. Light citrus and banana-notes. Pretty bland.
(Stockholm Beer Festival 2007) Bottle. Yellow, white head. Banana aroma, some wheat. Fruity and herbal flavor, quite boring.
Bottled. Golden colour, not much head. Aroma is wheat, some malts and candy. Flavour is wheat, caramel, fruits, some spicyness and sourish wood.
Bottled@SBWF 2007 Clear golden color, small white and creamy head. Bubblegum aroma. Bubblegum and banana in the flavor, a bit sourish notes. Decent Kristallweizen.

Bottled at Stockholm Beer Festival. Clear pale golden, firm head. Citric banana aroma. Sweet with rounded mouthfeel and medium body. Wheat malt mixed with butter and lemon. No bitterness. Quite refreshing.

Bottle 330ml Ibis Auckland hotel bar. Pours very dark brown with mahogany colour to the light, small white head that fades quickly. Fancy bottle like mini brandy type. Mild aroma, well carbonated and tastes clean, malty with little hops. Little of the promised chocolate coffee or toffee. By the end of the glass it seems like an inoffensive Porter but in no way memorable. Barely adequate or barely inadequate. There are definitely better NZ Porters out there.
500ml bottle from Liquorland Napier. Black color with slight head. Roasted malt aroma. Mild bitterness with roasted malt palate. OK porter.

Bottle. Clear, deep mahogany hue, finely bubbled light brown head. Aroma is brown bread and cocoa. The palate delivers the same in flavours, with predominant cola sweetness, and underlying dough and nut notes. Tannic peanut skin dryness in the finish. Thin mouthfeel. A bit odd for a porter, as it lacks both body and roast. I must comment on the bottle-- it is really quite striking in design, with a handsome etched glass emblem at the base of the neck. If only the quality of the beer held up to the quality of the packaging. Earlier Rating: 8/10/2009 Total Score: 2.8 Bottle. Looks great-- deep ruby red, thick brown head. Initially the aroma is very chocolatey, then after resting, some notes of breadcrusts and nuts. Mouthfeel is thin and fizzy. Flavours are chocolate and brown bread, hints of roast. Quite sweet, with low bitterness in the finish. Not terrible, just lacking body really.

330ml bottle pours almost black in color with a finger of tan head that leaves some spotted lacing on the glass. Aroma is light toasted grains with chocolate and herbal notes. Taste is a herbal hop bitterness with a caramel and chocolate malty sweetness. Light bodied with average carbonation. Overall, this brew is too light bodied and lacks the bold flavours associated with this style. Mediocre porter at best.

330ml green bottle bought at YATA in MOKO, Mong Kok. Clear blackish brown colour; Three-quarter finger head with beige foam which fades in 40 seconds; Very good sticky lacing with active slight carbonation; Fragrant and sweet aroma of dark malt, with fair roastyness, strong toffee, caramel, strong cream, coffee, light chocolate, sugar, faint dark fruits, yeast and faint grass; Close to light sweet taste of dark malt, with fair roastyness, caramel, light toffee, Cola, very light chocolate, Molasses notes, light bread, yeast, faint lemon, very light bitter hops and very light grass; Close to light body. Slick palate; Mouth Feel is fair dark maltyness in a light but slightly thick body. Roastyness is threadbare. Only some caramel to pop up the otherwise empty Cola taste. Very little chocolate and no coffee at all. Sweetness is minimal. Dry and bready with minimal lemon to end. Blah!... Hoppiness is faint grass in nose. Faint lemon and very light grass in taste; Bitterness is very low for an abrupt, almost non- astringent Cola-bready finish; Fairly dry after taste. Very easy and slightly bitter to mouth. Comments: For a 4% Porter, it has pretty promising aroma in strong toffee and coffee cream, but taste-wise, it’s a typical 4% - empty Cola with non-deScript low roastyness, almost devoid of any dark beer tastes. It’s not bad, it’s just feel like drinking a harmless exercise. Too lightweight for me!
BOTTLE. Poured a cola black with solid cream head.. Dark malts on the nose, some smoke? Assortment of dark, choc & coffee malts blended together with a good creamy finish.. Sourced Rosco

I bought this because of the cool bottle and the fact that, according to the sticker on the bottle, it won Gold in the 2014 brewers guild awards. How did this win anything?! Absolutely zero body and very little flavour. Ends on a weird sour note. Extremely disappointing.

On tap as the WHANGAMOMONA REPUBLIC DARK ALE at the Whangamomona Hotel. (Katie from the Hawkes Bay Independent Brewery tells me that Whangamomona Republic Dark Ale is the same beer as the Black Duck porter). I really liked this beer and am wondering now if beer always tastes much better when I’m on holiday! Rich ruby brown hue with small diminishing coffee crema head and delicate lacing. Delicious whisky peat toasted roasted malt, wood oil, liquorice,leather, coffee and especially chocolate aromas. Possibly some of those aromas may have been environmental rather than from the beer. Nicely balanced moderate bitterness and sweetness. Tingly carbonation, medium body, mildly oily texture, long dry finish.
Nice beer, not too strong in porter flavor. But tast is also a bit weak. Easy to drink, easy to enjoy
Nice roasty aroma. That’s where it stops really. Translucent brown body. Thin bodied, light roasted taste. Not a lot else going on. Heavily carbonated. Bland! Good as an introductory porter I suppose

On tap at the Porterhouse Brew Pub. Poured a deep brown color with an averaged sized tan head. Aromas of toffee, toasted nuts, light roast, and light brown sugar. Tastes of tofee, nutty, caramel, chocolate and lightly bready. Alcohol content well hidden.

On tap at the Porterhouse Brew Pub. Poured a medium and clear brown color with a smaller sized off white had. Aromas and tastes of caramel, toasted malts, chocolate (in the finishing tastes), and a littley nutty. Fizzy body. Alcohol content hidden.

Bottle at home. Pours brilliantly clear gold with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is sweet Pils malt, apple esters and light earthy hops. Flavor is apple esters, sweet Pils malt, light earthy hops and bitterness with a sweet finish. Light body and medium carbonation.

macro beer in a micro bottle. that said, this was actually the beer that was closest to what we expected from the style. slightly sweet, pretty clean, but still slightly "off" sourness to it...otherwise quite boring & flat."
Pour from bottle. Deep golden with white head. Malty pilsner, not so great. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle at Max’s tasting. Pours a clear gold with a thin white head. Cauliflower, grain, a bit vegetal. Medium-bodied, sweet, grainy. Rather empty.
Another gem generously shared by Puzzl. Wow, straight up Malta Goya with light earthy notes. Pretty bad, but not too bad.
Bottle at Max’s tasting. Pours clear gold with white head. Nose and taste of skunk, lucky charms, sweet corn, cereal grain and wort. Light bodied.
Bottle, I hate you Andy. Golden pour with white head. Light malt and cran with some off tones...
Bottle at max’s. Courtesy of Andy - huge thanks. Pours clear gold with light white lacing. Aroma is wet cereal and sweet grain. Mouthfeel is thin with bland malt and sugar.

A- filtered light gold with a quickly dissipating off white head. Virtually no lacing. S- fresh baked bread, yeast, overripe apples, squash, muddled citrus and a sweet malt. Some manufactured floral notes. M- smooth, light body with a slightly tacky, crisp and sweet palate. T- taste starts an odd bitter straw. The apple comes in next, with some lager funk and earthiness. Ending is malty and bready - very quick and efficient too.
12oz Bottle pours a pale golden color without much head. Not much flavor. Just doesn't taste good even when it's 120F.
At Mac’s Brewpub in Wellington, NZ, 05.27.10. Hazy orange gold, white head. Aroma is kiwi and citrus. Flavor is citrus hoppy with grass and malt. Thin body, but refreshing.

Draft. A dark golden beer with an off-white head. The aroma has strong notes of hop and grass as well as notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of grass and hops, leading to a dry and very bitter and hoppy finish.

Weirdly hop free nose given the alleged green hopping. Hints of caramel and a slight floral touch. Golden amber, like the 50/50 blend of Hoprocker and Sassy Red the bar poured me as a Brewjolais substitute when I arrived before the keg was on. Very malt driven, lots of crystal sweetness and a slightly chalky finish. No evidence of the hops other than a faint hint of lemon and remained thus even as it warmed. Nice enough beer but the 50/50 blend trumped this on balance.

Pleasant hoppy, floral aroma with a nice head and good bitter taste. A seasonal beer - unusual for Lion Nathan/Macs and an attempt to produce something made by a brewer instead of an accountant. Usually served too cold at Macs bars but gets better as it warms up and a nice session beer.

Pint at the brewery - day of release. Pours a radiant deep amber. Thin white head. Huge fresh hoppy aromas, bring the citrus and passionfruit home. Theres a bit of caramel malt underneath. Flavour has intense resiny hops, coating the mouth with a pleasant bitterness. The finish lasted about 10mins with the fresh brew. She became more subdued and balanced over time, still amazing. Cheers for this one Ally!

On tap at The Vic in Nelson. Hugely fragrant tropical fruit hop aroma. Luscious hop flavours dominate as well: passionfruit, tangerine, mango. Underlying malts are sweet and supportive. Finish is very bitter. In my mind this played as an American-style IPA but without the big ABV. Excellent.

2009, enjoyed thoroughly with Donfardz64 on the waterfront in Wellington. Dense white head with a lovely amber hue. Floral, fruity hops, complemented by a sweet malt. Damn attractive aroma, although not strong coming out of the tap. A nice bitterness in the flavour, balanced excellently by the malt. The hops manifest as grapes, pears and lime. Clean on the palate with plenty of hop flavour in the finish. Kind of like a sexed-up Hop-Rocker.
Bright orange in colour with firm white head. Citrus hoppy mouthfeel. Nice bitterness but was short. One of the better batchs.

Draught, pouring a sparkling clear golden amber with a white bubbly head. The aroma is very pleasing, juicy malts dominate with a strong fruity hop kick. A strong tropical fruit hop palate with plenty of bitterness and dryness. Reminiscent to me of the old Limburg Hopsmacker - very tasty. So much better than the rest of the Macs range it is difficult to believe it is from the same brewery.

I’ve tried this the last couple of years and thought it was very good. Never got around to rating it, as much as I enjoyed it. The 2008 vintage is excellent. I sip a glass of water and watch the world go by, as the two "pints" in front of me warm up and await the arrival of BozoNZ. Rich amber in the gloomy autumnal evening light, a little shy of brilliant, and topped off with a retreating off-white snow melt head. Sweet sticky malt greets the nose all the way from the table, with a rich and ripe fruity hop note comnig through as I lift the glass. Great malt/hop balance in the mouth. The hops are earthy, slightly sappy/piny and iron-like, with those classic kiwi tropical fruit notes coming through too. The malt is at the rich-end of being "typically Mac’s" - bready, with hints of vanilla. Taste bud stripping bitterness sneaks up on you and demands hot salty chips. We oblige and my palate is muted. For all of this it is a pretty clean beer, and superbly drinkable. Three pints and I’m on my bike. I’ll be back. Cheers Mac’s! I call her "Brewjolina", she should be a celebrity couple.

column1: Hams Brewhouse J. Allyns Robust Porter
column5: Sampled on draft at the brewpub. Pours a dark red tinted brown color with a medium head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma is roasted malts with some fruity notes. Taste is dark fairly bitter roasted malts, leather and coffee as well as an almost lactose like note. Very smooth and creamy. Medium bodied, Very good.

column1: Hams Brewhouse J. Allyns Robust Porter
column5: Courtesy of Quake1028. The aroma is mildly tart with muted roast malt notes, coffee and shoe leather. The body is a dark ruby-tinted brown color. Molasses, toasted grains, mild chcolate and coffee notes make up the flavor. Again it is a little tart and also tangy.

column1: Hams Brewhouse J. Allyns Robust Porter
column5: Thanks to matador for providing the growler. Black pour, no head, but the growler leaked a bit so I can cut it some slack. On the nose we have coffee, tart fruit, cocoa, molasses, tobacco and shoe leather. The taste features many of the same elements. Average mouthfeel, medium bodied. A very average porter.

column1: Hams Brewhouse J. Allyns Robust Porter
column5: Poured a dark brown from the tap. Had a frothy head , with no lacing. Had weak hints of roasted malts and barley. Had weak hints of hops, and spices. Very dissapointed. Nothing special here.

column1: Hams Brewhouse J. Allyns Robust Porter
column5: Draft at Greenville location. Opaque black with a small head. Aroma is a touch of smoke, earth, and metallic spicy hops. Palate is smooth, medium-bodied, a little watery and has a slight metallic twinge. Flavors of spicy chocolate, coffee, sweet smoke. Slightly better than average porter.

column1: Hams Brewhouse J. Allyns Robust Porter
column5: Growler from the brewery courtesy of frumptydumpty. Thanks Ryan. Pours a dark brown with a coca-cola like body. Nose is light chocolate, some coffee, and roasted malts. Flavor is similar to aroma, with a little tobbacco, and smoke in there too. Palate is a bit thin and lacking, but this also makes this an easy drinking porter for those just getting into the style. In any case, a noble attempt from an up and coming brewpub in eastern NC.

(Draught) Sampled at the brewpub on May 26, 2007. Pours a thin, white creamy head with a deep copper body. Nose of mild malts and a tad bready. The flavour is crisp, though I doubt the server’s claim that this is a weizen bock. Traditional bocks of this style are between 9-14 ABV and this one is only a 5.7 - in addition, the wheat flavour doesn’t make itself terrible apparent. Its on the lighter side but is a nicely balanced lager none the less. I would be able to drink this regularly.
On Tap at BJ’s Reno Location. Pours out a crisp light yellow topped with no head. Aroma of sweet pears and apples. Tast a little tart but very nice and pear like. Not bad.
Doesn’t smell like anything. Very pale. This tastes just like a pear, bartlett maybe. More than any other pear cider I’ve had, this taste like a pear, exactly. Just a bit sweet.
Pours with a yellowish, tinged clear hued sparkling body. Aroma is a bit artifical fruit. Taste is very sweet and cloying. Artifical tastes again. Too fizzy.
The aroma is sweet and has apples and pears. The flavor is very fruity and sweet but not cloying. The palate is thin. This is a very refreshing Perry.
75 cl bottle. Bottle conditioned. Flowery hops and a hint of licorice in the aroma. Hint of salt in the malty, flowery, hoppy flavor. Light bitter aftertaste with a hint of red berries. Likeable.
golden, hazy, white foam Aroma: sweet fruity, pears, Taste: medium sweet, light bitter, full body, yeasty, oily, pears, fruity, bitter sweet finish. interesting sweetesh beer

fruity malt and yast aroma, hazy golden with white creamy head. light sweet fruity taste, with a light bitter finish. full body, almost flat carbonation a bittersweat finish. very fresh, very drinkable, try this if you can!
On tap. Cloudy golden color with white head. Aroma - Malts, butter, bread. Taste - Dry, hops, grass.
Keg from brewery , South Bohemia , CZ , Malt,bread,grassy and buttery aroma , Hazy golden color with bigger lacing head , Sweeter taste with bitter finish , Full body , Soft carbon , Pretty good.
Barva: zlatá. Pìna hustá, držící. Vùnì: výrazná sladová. Chu: výrazná sladová chu, plné tìlo, hoøkost jen mírná, utopená. Hodnì sladké pivo s karamelovými tóny.

On tap at U Slovanské Lípy, Prague. Pours light cloudy golden with a big creamy white head. Aroma is malty, with light grassy hops. Taste is moderate sweet, thick malty, with a solid fresh grassy finish, not bad, but a tad on the sweet side.
Tap @ Pivovarsky Klub, Prague. Pours cloudy golden with a white head and lacings. Sweet malty. Grass, thick caramel, bread and lemony hops. A tad too sweet and feels stronger than 5%.
Tap @ Pivovarsky Klub, Prague. Pours golden with a white head. Aroma of malt, grassy hops, yeast. Taste is malt, grassy hops, yeast. Medium body, soft carbonation. 300711
@ Zly Casy - I have this down as a 10, which means that 5% is way too high. Light golden. Canned mushroom nose. Buttery, rancid and just generally not good. Funky butter. Brutal.
Draft @ Zly Casy. Warm gold with thick head. Earthy and mushroomy aroma, carrying through to the flavors, which have strong Shitake and Chinese mushroom qualities. But not as good.

Lasting tan head lingers over the not completely black robe. Quite straightforward nose of coffee grains, very burnt nose with ashes notes aplenty. Still, it keeps a fair dose of residual sugars, not quite caramelly, but a bit of a brown sugar touch to them. More roast steals the finale as little hops are felt at all and the grainy bitterness takes over. Gentle carbonation, light-medium bodied. An all-roast stout, perhaps not my style, but quality stuff.

(Draught at the brewpub) Coffee, roasted malty and licorice aroma. Black colour and brownish, thick, large, lasting head with good lacing. Coffee, roasted malty, sweet and licorice flavour. Softly carbonated and medium-bodied palate. 15/05/07

column2: San Martín de los Andes- Pcia. Neuquén, Argentina
column5: Appearance: dark coppery. High head, beige color, medium persistence and density. Aroma: Candy of the malts, liquory, red fruits, vanilla, toffee and good presence of hop. Flavor: Candy-toasted malts, Tones citric y of liquor. Good hoppyness. Sweet malted begin – nice finish with bitterness of hop. Good balance malts-hop and degree alcoholic. Palate: Medium body and creamy texture. Medium carbonation. Good Latin-American version of Scottish beer. Very advisable. (sorry for my english)
Crisp and easy drinking. Nice balance, and nice for what it is. Golden pour with decent head. Fairly dry, crisp end. Tap at brewery.
This is what my friends order if they don’t want anything terribly heavy or bold-flavored. That should tell you everything you need to know! Drinkable, not bitter, smooth, grainy.

Transfer from BA - Poured from growler into pint glass. Appearance - A pale straw color with a billowing white head that dissipated quickly. Smell - Not a whole lot of aroma, maybe a bit of malt and a little bit of caramel, but not much Taste - the taste matches the smell quite well. Not much about it. At the front a little bit of sweet caramel malt. Beyond that not a whole lot of detectable flavors present. Mouthfeel - For the lightness of the beer I felt it had a relatively nice body in terms of turbidity. The level of carbonation was just right. Overall - The beer could use a bit more robustness. Not the best of the brewpubs brews. It would however possibly be a good brew on a hot day after doing some good work outside. Its lightness would be fitting there.
well.. basically ... light grain .. dry medium dead grass .. . light mouthfeel .. nothing really to exciting, well- except of interesting waiter .. . . http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CljldVFRk6o
Draft at brewpub. Pours golden with a thin white head. Not much on the nose. Mouthfeel is thin and slightly creamy. Nice hint of malt on the tongue. Clean finisher. Solid for style.

Tap. Pours clear gold with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is corn, meal and cereal malt, spicy hops and a clean lager character. Flavor is malt forward with spicy hops and bitterness and a dry finish. Light body and warmth with medium carbonation.

Draft. Pours clear yellow with thin, fizzy white head; decent retention and lacing. Aroma is sweet malt and straw; not much there. Flavor is light sweet malt and not much else; typical light beer with a dry finish. Light body, medium carbonation, and low warmth.

On tap at Zeno’s Pub in State College, PA. Pours a crystal clear, yellow-gold colored body with a finger-width, fairly dense and frothy, white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is grainy and crisp with some lemon and a light grass. Some bready malts and a few florals. Flavor is similar. Lemony florals up front with some grainy malts and bread. A bit of a grassy hopping comes out at the end and helps this dry with a light bitterness. Medium length aftertaste following a light, smooth body and a crisp, moderate carbonation. Overall, a solid lager. Crisp and easy drinking with a solid lemon hopping, light bitterness, and light bready malt. Very easy drinking and enjoyable.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a clear golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty aroma with grainy hints. Sweetish malty crisp grainy flavor. Has a fruity malty finish with weak hints of hops.
On tap at brewpub. Clear gold with half inch white head. Aroma is BMC. Flavor is slightly better than BMC. Typical inoffensive pale lager.

tap at the brew pub. poured a hazy yellow with a white head. yeah, there is some orange in this thing. flavor was citrusy as the name implied with a mix of lemon and orange flavors. enjoyable flavor, but finished oddly, leaving a rough dry note.

Bottle (in Xi’an) Clear pale golden yellow with very short-lived head. Little aroma, somewhat malty. Medium body and carbonation. Slightly tangy foretaste with somewhat malty taste, but no bitterness. It’s acceptable, but not good.

628 ml. bottle. Pours golden with small white head. Smells of stale hops, a little flowery but also something synthetic to it. Flavor is ok. Soapy hops dominate, also some malt and rice flavors. Some bitterness. But also an underlying plastic taste. Pretty good for a chinese lager.
Golden. Aroma is cucumber melasses malt fresh hops slightly fruity or grassy. Taste is very sweet with not enough hoppy tartness. Still vrry smooth and drinkable. Nice.
Draught at 7 Stern brauerei. Small and very short white head. Sweet malty aroma and taste. Mild to medium bitterness and full body.
Tap at the source (6.3% abv). Pours golden. Aroma is sweet, malty, grainy. Flavor is sweet, malty, grainy, slight booze. Finish is sweet and grainy with light bitterness. Overall: ok.

Eingetrübte, orange gelbe Farbe mit ordentlicher, weißer Schaumkrone. Prägnanter, malziger, süßer Geruch. Malziger, süßlicher und brotiger Geschmack mit gut eingebundenem Alkohol, leichte Trockenheit im Abgang. Ok.

Draft at the brewpub. Pours hazy orange with a solid white head. Aroma is boozy sweet malt with a hint of orange. Taste is a sweet grain and malt hit, a lot of booze that fades a little leaving a sweet, dry finish. It’s ok.
On tap at brewery. Aroma isn’t cool at all and look is average. Taste is highly malty. I feel bread and yeast. Voltage is quite visible. An okay bock
Frisch vom Hahn im Biergarten der Brauerei. Goldig, leicht trübe im Glas. Malzig süßlich im Antrunk. Dann kommt leichte, nicht unangenehme Alkohollast im Nachgang.
Malty and slightly alcoholic aroma, golden color with a mild head. Again, malty taste, a bit sweet,

2016. May version tap. Orange color with medium white head. Sweet malty, fruity aroma, maybe some flowers. Taste, starts sweet, continues with orange, alcohol is noticeable especially in finish. Drinkable.

Draught at the brewpub. Dark golden, amber, moderate hazy body, with a big, creamy, lacing, white head. Quite light aroma of dried fruits, honey, citrus, some grass. Tastes of bread, citrus, dried fruits, honey, grass. Full, creamy mouthfeel, with an average carbonation. Finishes bitter-sweet, a bit zesty, fruity, bready, with some honey. OK. Not the best Bock from 7 Stern I’ve had. Nice fruit notes, but overall quite one-dimensional.

column2: San Martín de los Andes- Pcia. Neuquén, Argentina
column5: Bottle conditioned, black with a thin brown head. Toasted malt with caramal and coffee. Maybe a touch watery, but strong roasted malt flavours with coffee and bitter chocolate. Got much more bitter in the finish. A good porter.

column2: San Martín de los Andes- Pcia. Neuquén, Argentina
column5: Appearance: dark color with red tones. High head, dark beige color, medium consistence and persistence. Aroma: Toasted malts, roasted sugar, coffee, bitter chocolate and candy. Sweet with low presence of hop. Flavor: Highly toasted, touches of grain coffee and candy. Reminiscence of red wine. Sweet malted in the beginning and bitterness of toast in the finish. Low hoppyness. Palate: Medium body, silky texture. Low to medium carbonation. Advisable, but of the “Cervecería Sur Patagónica” my favorite beer is the “Roja”. (sorry for my english)
Soft roast and bread nose with good lacing. Mildly lactic and acidic body. Mild acidic finish with an overly roasted character.

Draught, Calistoga Inn. Head is mostly lasting. Body is dark brown to black. Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, chocolate syrup/milk). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Simple, uninteresting.

Draught at the brewery.
