Beer is opaque, dark brown with a small, frothy-creamy, light brown, diminishing-but-mostly lasting head.The aroma is malty with moderate notes of husky roasted grain, sourish chocolate syrup, coffee; Hoppy with a light note of resin/pine, trace of vegetal alfalfa; Yeasty with a light note of basement, trace of garden soil.The flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, trace bitter with a longish, trace acidic, moderately sweet finish.The body is medium-to-full, the texture is velvety and the carbonation is lively. Too sweet and syrupy.

Draught, Silverado. Head is mostly lasting. Body is lightly amber. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain, cookie, caramel), lightly hoppy (flowers, herbs), with a note of honey. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic. As with the stout, a fine creation. Delightful.

Draught at the brewery. Beer is hazy, medium caramel brown with a medium-sized, creamy, off-white, clingy, diminishing, but mostly lasting head.The aroma is malty with moderate-to-heavy notes of toasted grain, caramel, moderate note of butterscotch, light note of biscuit; Hoppy with a trace of herb; Yeasty with moderate notes of basement, dough; Light miscellaneous notes of alcohol, moderate tropical fruit.The flavor is moderate-to-heavily sweet, lightly acidic, trace bitter with a long, light-to-moderately sweet, lightly bitter, lightly acidic finish. Carmel-heavy retros.The body is medium-to-full, the texture is velvety and the carbonation is fizzy.Well done, nice.

Draught, Sebastopol. Body is dark brown to black. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (roasted grain, chocolate, husks), with a light note of lemon zest. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, soft carbonation. Strange sourish rendition.

Draught at the brewery. Beer is clear, very dark brown with a small, tan, frothy, mostly diminishing head. The aroma is malty with moderate notes of roasted grain, chocolate, coffee; Hoppy with a light herbal note; Yeasty with a trace of cobweb; Moderate note of cooking sherry, light note of brine. The flavor is light-to-moderately sweet, lightly bitter, lightly acidic with a long, trace bitter, lightly sweet, trace acidic finish. The body is medium, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

Tap at the brewpub. Deep hazy orange-gold beer. Creamy white head. Aroma is quite bready and malty. Very nice crackery maltiness. Quite clean with a bit of yeasty crackery maltiness. Lightly spicy hoppiness. Nice fresh bready crackery flavour. Great balance with a light peppery character on the back. Light herbal/leafy hoppiness with a peppery finish. They call this a dubbel, which it isn’t, but it’s a pretty solid altbier.

Tap at BF. Aroma of sweetish, orange fruits, toasted/baked malt. Flavor more of that malt with some leafy hops, particular at the finish. A bit sweet/cloying at times, but not in an overbearing way. Honestly had no idea what style it was as I drank it, but I guess I don’t feel so bad since others have said the same. All in all, not bad.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a hazy light brown with a small head. Aroma of sweet malt. Flavor is quite sweet with some fruity notes and candi sugar. Ok to drink but not very exciting. I was surprised to find out that this was an Abbey Dubbel because I didn’t detect any yeasty notes nor any other flavors you typically get in dubbels. An ok beer. 6/4/7/4/13 (3.4/5)

Tap at the Brewpub: Brown pour with an amber hue, and a thin off-white head. Looks pretty muddy, and I like it! Toasty aroma with some mild brown sugar qualities. It has that nice, dense, creamy body that Black Forest’s beers generally have. The flavor shows some dark malt sweetness, caramel-like, but doesn’t seem Belgian. I think it’s the yeast he used. Stuff seems more like a Scotch Ale. Has a mild roast and an earthy touch. The Belgian candi-sugar isn’t apparent at all, but overall it’s pretty tasty; however it didn’t have much Belgian character.

Describing it as ’all mixed together’ is really the best way to describe it. Rather a cloudy ruby headless pour. General flavor of some light cherry and amber flavors, with a hop finish that seemed strangely out of place. It isn’t bad, it just feels awkwardly put together. However, I must say that of the 5 things on tap at the brewpub that day, I would choose this one hands down again.

Draft @ Black Forest. Nice dance between malt and hops here with a nice cherry flavor mixed in with the sweet caramels. Poor head retention though and although the flavors were all mixed up, it all comes back together. Nice job Joe.

Tap at the brewpub - strange - it’s as if a doppelbock and a dubbel had a bastard child - the aroma is an interesting mix of sweet german malts and light belgian yeast and candi sugar notes - the flavor isn’t as sweet as the aroma suggests - some caramel and slight munich malt flavors, along with notes of cherries and a mild tartness on the back end - some raisin and brown sugar in the finish - fairly light and easy to drink, despite it’s strength - an interesting hybrid.

sampled at the brewpub, took a growler of this one. Deep reddish amber in color. Aroma is very malty, caramel, with fruit and sugar notes. Taste is again, pretty sweet (but not overly cloying) caramal, raisins, sugar, with not much hop presence in the finish.

Billed as a German/Belgian Dubbel hybrid. Tap @ brewpub, served in tall mug. Color is amber-brown, a clear beer but dark enough to make clarity medium, half the glass is filled with light translucence. Aroma is pretty strong, dark fruits, sugary maltiness, and sweet candied apples. Taste is very clean, very sweet german maltiness - sticky sweet brownie flavor. Finishes very clean with almost no bitterness at all. A light thirst quenching beer but sweet enough to keep one interested.

Growler shared at ’Biegaman’s Summer Gathering’ -- courtesy of Lexx, all the way from Chicago. Hoppy Kool-Aid aroma - nice. Sweet nutty taste - tastes liked kicked up beery iced-tea. Interesting hops and malt here, not your run of the mill stuff. Sugary. Very nice and quite drinkable. Huge thanks to Lexx for the opportunity to try this growler!

Sampler at Clybourn. Ruddy brown, semi-opaque pour with a slight glown when held to the light. Thin foam. Definite American slap of Amarillo and other Pacific hops. A nice US twist on a traditional English style, combined with well-tuned crystal malts. Dances on the tongue. GI makes some nice extreme beers, but the session styles at the brewpubs are equally worthy.

Draught. At the Clybourn brewpub. Poured hazy dark copper with an average on-tap off-white head. Pleasant if mild somewhat bitter aroma of fresh grassy hops and caramel light malt aroma, very mild alcohol. Very soft and easy-drinking taste, quite hoppy but not aggressively so, grassy to herbal hops spread liberally over a solid, sweet, malty body, the finish is balanced, definitely has a bit of booze to it, but not too sweet - reminded me a bit of an organic herbal iced tea at one point. Decent ESB body - pehaps a little thick, nice restrained astringency, very mild carbonation, quick flavour finish but it did leave a bit more alcohol on my palate than I’d expect from a classic ESB. Tasty, though - nicely hoppy without being overdone.

Chicago trip. Monday 14:17+. Muddy dark amber-orange/copper. No head. APA hop aroma. IPA taste with a strong malt body and finish. Sweet notes of alcohol. The alcohol dominates creating a dark IPA-malt liquor flavour.
Pours a deep dark iced-tea color. Quite sweet and heavier body. Not a huge fan, have had many better ESB’s from GI...

Growler shared at ’Biegaman’s Summer Gathering’ -- courtesy of Lexx, all the way from Chicago . Pours a cloudy orange-amber with a small diminishing off-white head. Very nice aroma of floral hops, caramel malt, citrus and other fruit. Flavour follows the aroma: floral hops backed by caramel malt along with some citrus and toffee and a pleasant bitter finish -- very refreshing and flavourful. Medium bodied. A somewhat unique take on the style, I really enjoyed it.

Cask gravity at the Berko beer fest. A clear chestnut brown coloured pour with a lasting grayish head. Aroma is rustic nutty, black liquorice, apple, treacle. Little sour milk. Flavour is composed of bitter black malts, liquorice roasted Nutts, burnt toast. Palate is tangy, semi sweet, moderate carbonation. Ok. Lingering roast.

Decent enough dark mild although perhaps not the most flavoursome on offer. Colour is heading towards porter with (at least where I drank it) a thick off-white head. Not a particularly strong finish but that’s only what is to be expected of a mild.

Cask at the Hampden Arms, Hampden, 17/04/16. Rich chestnut brown with a well appointed beige covering. Nose is burnt caramel, toasted brown bread, marshmallow, ight fruit esters. Taste comprises toffee, toasted marshmallow, caramelised brown sugar, light vanilla essence, hint of fruit loaf. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, semi drying close. Decent mild ... plenty of flavour on offer.

Cask at Reading Beer Festival 2012. Pours clear, pure gold with a foamy white head. Mostly dark berries in the nose. Light to medium sweet flavor with some dark toast, light chocolate, mellow leafy bitterness. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Light sweetness to finish with dark toast, mild berries, leaves. Basic stuff. Fairly bland (even for a mild) but not offensive.

Cask@Reading Beer Festival 2012. Slightly hazy ambery brown colour with a small off-white head. Aroma is zesty, nutty, mildly chocolaty with some slight toasted notes. Flavour is quite the same with the caramel and toasted notes being more evident.

Cask at Reading Beer Festival 2012. Pours a chestnut brown colour with a thin tan head. The aroma is all malt, the taste is full of roasted malt, with some chocolate and some nuttiness, with a dry finish.

Cask at the Lower Red Lion, St Albans on 13th May 2011. Copper with thin white head. Malty aroma; nutty liquid - hazelnut, slight smoke and fruity berries. Quite citric aftertaste. Slightly clingy, viscous mouthfeel.

Cask conditioned gravity dispense Northants Beer Festival 2011. A chestnut brown mild with white bubbles atop. Chocolate and nut in the aroma. Chocolate and fruit in the mouth. Good sweetness and a nice mild.

(Cask at White Horse, Parson’s Green, London, 22 May 2010) Reddish brown colour with frothy, off-white head. Malty, fruity nose with dark fruit, caramel and dusty hops. Malty, fruity taste with notes of caramel, dried fruit and some dusty hops in the finish. Light body, fairly sweet for a mild. Decent and drinkable.
cask at white horse ... parson green ... red brown ... thin tan head ... light sweet toffee hop ... juicy rich soft tofee and dark fruits ... little plum ... little yeast ...

7 3 7 3 13 Draft at Festivale der Bierkulturen, Cologne.fairly hazy golden orange with a white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, yeast, herbal notes. Flavour is above moderate sweet and moderate bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

"Helios Tripelbock", Flasche (33 cl) von Craftbeer-Dealer.com, dem Online-Shop von Schneider's Getränkemarkt. - Gelbbraun, gut trüb. - In der Nase prominent säuerlich-zitrusfruchtige Grapefruit, im Hintergrund schweres Karamelmalz. Die Säure ist so deutlich, daß ich anfangs eine Kontamination befürchtete, sehr zu Unrecht. - Antrunk breit hell- und leicht karamelmalzig mit wuchtiger Grapefruitbittere und unreifer Aprikose. Die massige Malzigkeit ist aufgelockert durch schwere obergärige Fruchtigkeit, was an einen Weizenbock erinnert (obwohl das Etikett nur Gerstenmalz aufführt). Ganz zarte modrig-holzige Noten. Wuchtige, aromatisch zitrusfruchtige Hopfenbittere. Mild rezent, ölig und alkoholisch schwer. Wuchtig zitrusbitterer Abgang. - Durch kernige Hopfung beeindruckendes, reiches aber etwas anstrengendes (da unrundes) Starkbier.

Heftiges Zeug. Wenn man schnell genug hinschnuppert, bevor einen die Lederhose über die Nase gezogen wird, kann man sich an einen wohligen Aprikosenmusduft erfreuen.Wild und very funky. Die neblig ockergelbe Brühe mit der üppigen Beschäumung ist optisch ein richtiger Hingucker. Perfekt. Der Trunk dann kräftig Gueuzeaffin. BOON BLACK LABEL läßt grüßen. Nur viel schartkantig und angriffslustiger. Azetonalarm und Citusinferno. Buttriger Sourtwister und Alkosweetspicefatman. Halleluja!!! BRAUSTELLE RULES!! AGAIN!!!! 0,33 Flasche direkt von der Stelle. Ca.3€.

0.33 l bottle from ’CraftBeer-Dealer.com’, best before February 2017. Slight gusher! Hazy, golden amber with a large, foamy, slowly diminishing, white head. Sourish-fruity, quite funky aroma of lemon, gooseberry, white grapes, sweat and urine. Sweetish-malty, a bit sourish, slightly funky and a bit fruity taste of caramel, honey, white grapes, gooseberry, lemon and some urine, followed by a rather long, medium grassy-bitter, moderately tart finish. Medium to full body, a bit astringent, slightly creamy and quite effervescent mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Quite tasty actually, expected the worst after the slight gusher and the sourish-funky aroma. Typical Braustelle stuff with an infection, but it’s not bad at all!
Dark blond with big, foaming head. Aroma has some wild, funky notes as does the flavour. Not sure if that’s intended. Later this really sweetens up with some apricot and orange.
330ml bottle. Hazy golden orange color with off white head. Malty, yeasty and light hoppy aroma, caramel, bready, fruity, spicy. Sweet and light acidic taste. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.
Orange color with little foam. Very thin smell. The taste is creamy, a little malty and yeasty and a boozy as well. Wheaty and dryish aftertaste.

Hazy deep golden color with big dense head. Yeasty, fruity, very fruity, like jam. Good hints at a fruit tartness as well. Taste is spicy, honey, bitter, instant foam in the mouth, super-smooth texture, but the taste is a bit weak compared to the aroma. Very alcoholic, like many Tripels. Interesting aroma though.

Honigsüßer Geruch, fruchtige Schwere in der Nase. Der Antrunk ist fruchtig-süßlich. Im Hauptteil wird das Bier erst leicht scharf, dann mild süßlich fruchtig. Die Hefe erzeugt eine cremige Milde, die dem Ganzen Weiche verleiht. Der Nachgeschmack bleibt lange uf der Zunge. Fruchtige Süße, schwere, gelbe Früchte, sehr mild für die 9,5%. Eine ganz leichte Herbe ist im Nachgeschmack wahrnehmbar. Toll! 13/12/12/12
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein rötlichbraunes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig, süß, fruchtig, Karamell. Geschmack röstmalzig, stark fruchtig süß, Karamell, schokoladig, leicht alkoholisch.

Awesome fruity yeast and pear aroma. Pours a light golden yellow, with an off-white head. Flavors are a total yeast showcase-- apple, pear and slight banana fruit flavors, with a subtle malt foundation. Grassy hop character. Alcohol is very well hidden under all this fruit and yeast character. Overall, an excellent belgian golden ale. Very flavorful.

on tap & then growler from 2 days ago-pours a disappearing off white head and hazy gold color. Aroma is musty, fruit, yeast. Taste is musty fruit, yeast, sweet malt, peppery/clove/spice. Occasional. Light side of medium body. OK effervescence.

Growler from the brewpub. Hazy orange in color with a medium sized off white head. Aroma: Alot of citrus and musty yeast hit my nose right away, with notes of spice in the background. Taste is very fruity alot of apple/pear, and mild notes of banana. Taste also has a moderate amount of musty yeast and light notes of spice, with some honey sugary sweetness across the palate. Finishes spicy and dry, with a light earthy hop bitterness. Very nice Belgian ale.
There is nothing innocent about this beer. Whoever brewed this one enjoys a hoppy taste. The smell and taste of hops prevail. A golden honey color with the perfect frothy head. Not bad.

Cold on tap at home: Pours a clear medium gold color with a big, persistent, foamy white head. Aroma is of funky yeast, light grains, grass and some barnyard. Taste is of sublime grassy hops, spice and light grains. Light to medium bodied and smooth; effervescent, with playful carbonation. Ending is malty with earth and grass notes. Moderately bitter aftertaste. Thanks, DirtyMike!!!
Frisch vom Hahn auf dem Schlossplatz in Köpenick getrunken. Dunkles Rotbraun mit heller Schaumkrone. Soll 8,5% haben. Das Malz dominiert über den Alkohol.

On tap at the Portland brewpub location on 5/27/07. I really was happy to see a new beer on tap, and i went back today to have another and they were out. Hopefully it’ll be back soon. This was a pretty good Pils. Nose wast musty malt, like a cellar. Poured a golden orange color with a thin white foam head. Flavors were sort of biscuity and caramelly with some notes of some lighter malts also. Pretty tasty new beer.

Clear. The aroma is very assertive - toasty, balsa wood, bamboo shoots...nice. Sweetish palate with a clean rice note. Soft body but fills the mouth. Hints at shiitake, enoki and bamboo shoots. Very drinkable.
Pale yellow with a fizzy white head. Faint malty aroma and taste with a hint of grain in the finish.

Draft sample from brewpub. Pours clear light amber with a small white head. The aroma was bready malts with a light fruitiness and not much else. The flavor was the same as the nose with a slightly dry and lightly bitter finish. This was pretty bland overall.

On Tap- The beer is a light golden color with a decent head that fades. The aroma is a light mixture that is lemony and herbal. The taste is slightly lemony and crisp. It has a light body with a dry finish and is very refreshing. The beer was much better than I expected. It goes down easy and is very satisfying. This looks like a good summer brew or anytime actually.
A blonde beer with a creamy white head. A biscuitty malt aroma. In mouth, a rather solventy taste, with grainy malt, a bit cloying and overbearing for the style. On tap at brewpub, August 2007.
This a very bad funky sour milk aroma. This aroma is a precursor to the beer. Sour milk and heavy, this is certainly not what was intended. Most likely guess is that this got contaminated somehow.
A nice simple floral aroma. This is really quite nice. A light hoppiness throughout, this is definitely one pale ale that could be a great session beer.

Very good pale ale here. Big fruity nose from what was obviously a very significant dose of hops. Some malts in there as well but hops are what this brew is all about. Slightly sweet flavor up front, but finishes with a dry and crisp bitterness. Outstanding.
Some light malt aroma, this is a pretty tasty beer. Light caramel notes and an easy beginning. Faint hops in the finish.
A nice malty dark aroma. Coffee. The flavor has a lot of cocoa and roastiness. An alright beer that tastes heavier than the alcohol allows.

Draft at the brewpub. Light amber color with a lightly lacing white head. Light caramel aroma with a little grassy hop. Medium body with mild carbonation. Flavor is caramel with a surprising dose of citrus/grass bitter. Ends lightly sweet with lingering bitter. [I used that word in my brewpub notes hours before I saw HighWine’s rating]. Quite nice.
Seasonal tap at the brewery. Straw color, thin white head. Faint nose witha touch of sour apple. Good balance of hops and malt. The bittering hops linger

10 ounce sample tasted at Rubcon’s Maibock Festival. Faint, grainy, metallic hopped aroma with some cardboardy aromas, too. Transparent golden body with a small foamy off-white head. Sprizy, rather carbonated start with some sweet malts present. Some honey-like flavors then follow. Finishes with a mild metallic hoppiness. Pretty drinkable stuff.
Pours golden with medium head. Aromas are mildly malty. Flavors are a bit sweet. It’s an average brew, nothing really stands out about it.
A nice rich aroma with a little hops. The flavor is much too thin and simple on this. Certainly didn’t pick up any oatmeal. Room for improvement.
Not that much of an aroma. The flavor definitely has some robust roasty characters. Not too sweet but fairly malty. Pretty decent.
From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 13/10/2007 Malt and hop aromas. Golden coloured and pale with a crisp and dry malt finish.
Nothing in the aroma. For a light lager beer, this was really quite pleasant. A good hop bite in the finish and clean and crisp throughout.
Smells of the lemon they put in it. This is bad (like most of this style), with or without the fruit. Just untasty and far too wheaty.
Smells like light honey. Really not so bad for a honey beer, since it only really comes out in the end. At little alcohol at the finish. Suprisingly their strongest brew.
A nice floral citrus aroma. A little bit light in color. A pleasant beginning segues into a bit of nutty characters at the end. Decent but not outstanding.
Nothing in the aroma except the lime they put in it. Mostly this doesn’t taste like anything, just yellow water. Only this and the wheat were truly undrinkable to me.

On tap at the Irvine location. Pours a semi-transparent, bronze-ish amber color with a healthy finger of fizzy white head. Fruity yeast aromatics that are a bit surprising, considering the style. Bosc pears and fuji apples back up a honey malt sweet backdrop. Light bodied, tingly carbonated mouthfeel. Lots of fruity sweetness, but I feel like the sweet attributes are coming from the yeast influence rather than the malt base. A bit more honey with some sweet apple juice concentrate. A little bit of crisp toasted french bread crusts make a grasp for some semblence of a bready malt backbone. Minimal hop bitterness, but a hint of herbal qualities linger in the final smack. I definitely don’t like the sweetness or fruity characters palate-wise, but the body is nice, light, and smooth, making this a refreshing sipper.

Very tasty porter. Roasty with a sweet malty undertone. A bit of coffee, but well balanced. Really good - I’m glad I picked up a couple to go. It is pretty complex, and you can savor it a bit. It cellars well too. RB says it is retired - I’m not sure about that. It shouldn’t be!

Velvety black with minimal head. Can smell the coffee right off the bat. Slick palate with solid but not overwhelming carbonation. Taste is rich roasty maltiness with a massive amount of coffee added. like biting into a mocha brownie. Worth the trip across the ferry.

On tap at the Irvine location. Slightly hazy, brassy gold colored pour with a thin layer of wispy off-white head. Dry, bitter malt backbone that has an almost rye-like, borderline husk tannin quality that is a bit astringent. Toasted baguette with a light caraway seed spice. A moderate herbal hop bitterness heightens the astringent sensation, but doesn’t contribute much besides adding bitter grassy qualities. Light to medium bodied, crisply carbonated mouthfeel. The carbonation is the perfect compliment for the flavor profile. I hate to use the word astringent to describe both the hop and malt characters, but it really fits best. The beer is enjoyable, but the puckering qualities seem to be developed from equal contributions by the malt and hop profiles. Spent grain husks and herbal grassy hops finish this one out quickly and cleanly, resulting in a simple and straightforward, yet easy drinking brew.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blonde des Bateliers
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Bit hazy golden with white head. Light yeasty, cloves, sweet bready malts, light herbs, more spicy yeast. Medium sweet and solid medium yeasty bitter. Medium bodied. Meh.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blonde des Bateliers
column5: Hazy yellow with average head. Malty, grainy, yeasty, floral, medium carbonation.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blonde des Bateliers
column5: #1495 Tap. Hazy yellow to golden body, high white head. Aroma of yeast, malts, vinous. Taste is lightly bitter, lightly sour, neutral. Fruity, vinous, malty, yeasty. Medium body and carbonation. OK.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blonde des Bateliers
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Cloudy, gold colored. AROMA- malty, yeasty, a bit fruity - vinous. FLAVOR- neutral to slightly sweet, slightly bitter, malty and vinous. Medium bodied. Tasty.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blonde des Bateliers
column5: Tap at the Au Brasseur .Nose is citrus, wheat. Palate is a nice mix of tart and citrus, some apricot. this is like a more fruity but less bitter ipa, but still as tart. I like it.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blonde des Bateliers
column5: Heller, wenig intensiver Antrunk mit milder Herbe. Minimal bitter, ansonsten im Mittelteil nur schwach aromatisch. Okay. 9/8/9/7//8

column1: Au Brasseur La Blonde des Bateliers
column5: Keg at Au Brasseur, Strasbourg, France. Gold with white head. This was a pretty thin beer with a boiled malt character, herby and light sweetness. CO2 wet cardboard. Not great.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blonde des Bateliers
column5: On tap the at the brewpub. 21/07/2015 two days after the Etape du Tour. Mostly clear bright yellow with a persistent white froth. Aroma is tangy grains, light apple, floral notes, light woody mould. Flavour is composed of light grains,woody, lemon zest, crisp pils grains. Lingering wood and zest. Palate is very refreshing light body, moderate carbonation, crisp dry finish.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blonde des Bateliers
column5: Bottled. Golden coloured. Unclear. Small denne off White head. Aroma. Yeast, fruits, sweetness. Flavour. Fruits, sweetness, some citrus. Thin bodied. Ends sweet and fruity

column1: Au Brasseur La Blonde des Bateliers
column5: 25cl on tap at the Au Brasseur. Lightly cloudy yellow beer with a small head. Aroma is light. Lightly malty and a very lightly floral. Soft carbonation and light and a bit creamy body. Taste is more bitter than sweet with some strange grassy notes. Overall, a drinkable starter but not to repeat.

Tap at the brewpub. Hazy light amber with almost white head. Spicy yeast, sweet caramel malts, light orange, dusty paper, bitter grassy notes, cloves, cardamom, flowery. Medium sweet, bit over medium bitter. Medium bodied. OK.
Hazy amber color with average head. Malty yeasty, bready, funky undertones, medium carbonation.

#1498 Tap at the brewpub. Hazy, light amber, high white head. Aroma of wood, wine, hops, bready tones. Taste is bitter, a bit sourish finish. Vinous, woody, bread, malts, yeast. Medium body and carbonation. Interesting alsasian variation of amber ale. Tasty.
Draught at the brewpub. Hazy, amber colored. AROMA- vinous, apricot, peach, wood. FLAVOR- neutral, pleasantly bitter, malty, fruity, tones of wood. Medium bodied. Good.
Wässriger, röstig bitterer Antrunk mit zunehmender Würzigkeit. Die vorhandene Muffigkeit bleibt hintergründig, zum Ende frischer und harmonischer. Zum Ende erheblich besser als zuvor. 10/7/8/9//8

Keg at Au Brasseur, Strasbourg, France. Hazy amber with white head. Sweet, thin and quite malty with a buttery note, some fruitiness perhaps otherwise fairly dull. Struggling a little with these Au Brasseur beers.

On tap the at the brewpub. 21/07/2015 two days after the Etape du Tour. Hazed golden / orange coloured pour with a lasting fine white head. Aroma is alcohol solvent and caramel apple. Flavour is composed of crisp semi sweet grains, light tangy apple, burnt toffee and honey. Palate is semi- sweet, little crisp, moderate carbonation. Flavour is better than the aroma.

Shared 33cl on tap at the Au Brasseur. Pours an almost clear amber colour with a off-white head. Aroma is malty, caramel, toasted, lightly yeast and with some leather notes. Soft carbonation and medium body. Taste is more sweet than bitter. Overall, probably the more tasteful and balanced of all the four we had (Blonde, Blanche, Amber and Brune), but a bit boring.

Draught @ Au Brasseur, 22, rue des Veaux, Strasbourg, France 67000. Clear medium amber orange colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, caramel, fruity, light yeasty, leather notes. Flavour is moderate sweet with a average duration, dry, caramel, notes. IMO. a bit borring. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20121003]

On tap at the brewpub. Dark golden/amber coloured, small white head, hint of malt in the nose. Sweet malty, light fruity and some hops with notes of metal. Single but pretty sharp hint of alcohol near the end.

column1: Au Brasseur La Brune du Quai
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Hazy dark brown with short lasting beige head. Roasted malts, dark chocolate, earthy funk, dead leaves, soft dried plums, mineral. Light sweet and medium bitter. Under medium bodied. This one has a light infection obviously, but it’s actually not too bad.

column1: Au Brasseur La Brune du Quai
column5: Hazy brown color with an average head. Malty, grainy, soy sauce, hints of liquorice, medium carbonation.

column1: Au Brasseur La Brune du Quai
column5: #1496 Tap. Deep red to copper body, high beige head. Aroma of plums, cherries, leaves of fruit trees, touch of coffee and bread. Taste is bitter, roasty, neutral, light sourness on the background. Red wine, grapes, plums, bread crusts, lightly coffee notes. Medium body and carbonation. Very good, interesting, perfectly balanced.

column1: Au Brasseur La Brune du Quai
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Cloudy, copper colored. AROMA- apple, plum, vinous. FLAVOR- slightly sweet, slightly sour, lightly bitter, vinous, red wine, bread crusts. Medium bodied. Very good.

column1: Au Brasseur La Brune du Quai
column5: Tap at the Au Brasseur in Straßburg .Nose is chocolate, toffee, toast. palate is a bit watery, toffee, bread, chocolate. The chocolate malt comes through nicely, but it is a bit lacking in the palate. Nothing special.

column1: Au Brasseur La Brune du Quai
column5: Dunkler, süßlich röstiger Beginn. Trockener und röstiger Mittelteil, schnell wässrig werdend. Nicht sonderlich spannend. 10/8/8/8//8

column1: Au Brasseur La Brune du Quai
column5: Keg at Au Brasseur, Strasbourg, France. Brown with no head. Thin and slightly fruity beer, some berries, some hints of fusty nuts. Boiled vegetables. Not for me.

column1: Au Brasseur La Brune du Quai
column5: On tap the at the brewpub. 21/07/2015 two days after the Etape du Tour. Mid amber / orange coloured pour with a fading greyish cream head. Aroma is terrible solvent apple, woody, mess. Nail polish remover. Flavour is composed of woody apple, burnt sugar, rusty penny, terrible Palate is thin and watery, semi sweet moderate carbonation. Pretty shitty.

column1: Au Brasseur La Brune du Quai
column5: Shared 33cl on tap at the Au Brasseur. Shows medium to dark brown colour with a fluffy off-white head. Aroma is roasted, malty, earthy and lightly yeast. Soft carbonation and medium body. Taste is more sweet than bitter, with the flavours dispersed into a long finish. Overall, a nice but not remarkable beer.

column1: Au Brasseur La Brune du Quai
column5: Draught @ Au Brasseur, 22, rue des Veaux, Strasbourg, France 67000. Clear medium to dark amber colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, stra, roasted, chestnut, light yeasty, earthy. Flavour is moderate sweet and light moderate bitter with a average to long duration, chestnut, earthy. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20121003]

column1: Au Brasseur La Blanche de l´Ill
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Hazy straw with big white head. Coriander, wheat, lots of dry grainy notes and dusty herbs, wheat flour, light lemon, cloves, almonds. Light sweet, under medium bitter and soft tart touch. Just medium bodied and slight dry feel. Pretty decent actually.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blanche de l´Ill
column5: Hazy yellow color with an average head. Malty, yeasty, herbal, spicy, dry, medium carbonation.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blanche de l´Ill
column5: Probably my favourite of the 4 beers this strasbourg place brews. Sweet and fruity but without the overkill of the clove aroma and taste you get so often in that style of beer.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blanche de l´Ill
column5: #1497 Tap. Really hazy, yellow body, small white head. Inviting aroma of yeast, white wine, coriander, spices, cumin, flowers, muscat, limes, lemongrass, malts. Taste is lightly sweet, bitter and a bit dry finish. White wine, white grapes, lemon, lemongrass, coriander, muscat. Medium body and carbonation. Great alsatian blanche beer, nice balanced and spiced. Enjoyable :)

column1: Au Brasseur La Blanche de l´Ill
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Hazy, straw colored. AROMA- fresh, limes, coriander, vinous. FLAVOR- neutral to slightly sweet, flavor the same as nose, hops. Medium bodied. Very good.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blanche de l´Ill
column5: Tap at the Au Brasseur in Straßburg. Pours dark yellow. Nose is hay, floral, citrus. Palate is tart, citrus hints of banana . Decent.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blanche de l´Ill
column5: Hell hefiger, mild süßer Antrunk. Leicht herb, weich, süffig. Zum Ende herber und insgesamt voller. Unauffällig aber nett. 10/9/10/11//10

column1: Au Brasseur La Blanche de l´Ill
column5: Keg at Au Brasseur, Strasbourg, France. Clouded Yellow with white head. Really quite a sweet beer, pear drops, floral but pretty thin. Little depth of flavours, skimpy. Not really for me.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blanche de l´Ill
column5: Bottle at Monday Club Zurich. A funky wit? Seems like something went wrong. Farmhouse and lactose, vinegar. Not wit-like at all, and not in a good way. Some sourness. Odd.

column1: Au Brasseur La Blanche de l´Ill
column5: On tap the at the brewpub. 21/07/2015 two days after the Etape du Tour. Clouded yellow straw coloured pour with a lasting white frothy head. Aroma is tangy doughy wheat grains, light orange, yogurt funk, some stale grains. Flavour is composed of wheaty, xesty lemon, peach, light grains, pithy yogurt. Palate is is little thin, chalky, highish carbonation, very dry in the finish. Not bad a little farmyard in the finish.
Transferring my data before I used to rate at Ratebeer. I’ll add a more detailed description when I drink it again.
Reddish colour, short fizzy head. Sweet fruity bit artificial aroma and flavour. Can’t find the beer.
Fruchtiger Antrunk und Nachgeschmack, nicht künstlich. Milde Limonade, die gücklicherweise nicht zu süß ist. Bier? Nö. Test vom 20.7.2007, Gebinde: PET Noten: 4,5,6,5,6,5 - 5,10

.25 cents at Lidl, walking from my house to get cheese, thought, what the hell for a .25 cent euro! It was hot here in the Saarland, so it went down easy, although abit artificial flavor, alcoholic fruit punch, yeah!!! Shoot me., it was ok.

Lidl@Düsseldorf; pet bottle - clear pinkish-red colour with no head retention, aroma of apple juice and strawberry marmelade; very sweet and light-bodied, sweetish and lemonade-like finish- even someone like me sometimes miss the Reinheitsgebot ...

Clear plastic bottle 50cl. Clear light to medium red color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is fruity sweet, passion fruit. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet with a average duration. Body is light, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20081122]

Plastic bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Clear pink with a dense, creamy pinkish head leaving some laces. Unpleasant and somewhat artificial fruit aroma. Light body, a little low in carbonation with berry-like accents. No bitterness. 221108
Clear orange with tiny off white head. Sweet fruity aroma with notes of abricot and passion fruits. Flavour likewise with a sweet peachy finish.
50 cL clear plastic bottle. Pours clear and golden pink with no head. Sweet berry fruity aroma. Sweet berry fruity towards raspberry and strawberry. Lingering sweet finish with a mild sugarish note.
The bottle looks terrible, the beer in the glass also. Chemical red. Tastes like GDR-limo - nasty.

Cloudy, little head, slight straw and citrus aroma. This wit has spice, bitter citrus fruit, and breadiness components. The Nit Wit was the first beer I had in this place, the first time stepping in, and well, it was quite tasty! Nice brew I’d have again. Brewer Greg Gerovac said this is his first Belgian-style at HB. It’s 4.5%.

column1: Huntington Beach Gearys Black Bear Oatmeal Stout
column5: Rich dark roasted malts, yet not too malty compared to oats; a tad heavy on the mouthfeel, long bitter finish. Decent stout.

Cask conditioned at the Alexandra Arms, Kettering, Northants, 25-05-07. Poured a light amber colour (not quite silver!) was very hazy. Some wheat very noticeable on the nose, taste was quite fruity and sweeter than expected. I really liked this beer but apart from the appearance and possibly the nose I’m not convinced that this had the rest of the attributes that I would imagine constituted a proper wheat beer

#641 Mittleres Bernstein, leicht trüb und sehr wenig Schaum. Ein erst säuerliches, dann ins malzige umschlagende Aroma. Im Antrunk für einen Bock sehr leicht geraten. Primär süßmalziger Geschmack, ja fast schon zu süß. Wird dann aber zunehmend würziger und ist im Abgang dann nachbitternd. Kann man trinken, aber zum großen Wurf mangelt es deutlich am nötigem Punch und der Komplexität, die ein guter Bock einfach haben sollte. Dieser ist mir neben der Schwäche auch vom Charakter her zu einfach gestrickt. Probierenswert jedoch allemal. Test vom 27.10.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,9,9,10,9,9 - 9,15
Bottle. Little hazy golden colour with a nice head. Little hoppy aroma. Flavour of bitterness and dryness, also with a malty notes. Medium body and little dull.
Bottle. A hazy yellow beer with a big white head. Light citric, malty, grassy aroma and taste. Medium body with a dry finish.
From 50 cL bottle. Hazy yellow with a white head. Mild grassy and citric aroma. Sweet to dry bitter flavoured. Dry malty finish with a good bitterness.
Bottled. Hazy golden, creamy head. Fruity, citric amd yeasty aroma. Sweet with medium-full body. Fruity and buttery but completely dominated by wild yeast flavours. Some piney notes. Low bitterness.
Bottle. Hazy yellow coloured with a white head. Fruity aroma of spices and herbs with notes of hops. Fruity flavour of spices, herbs and hops.

Bottle. Pours a pale, hazy yellow - much like a Belgian wit. A gigantic lacing creamy white head rises on top of the liquid. Sweet aroma, lots of malt with a citric bitter edge to it. Mild flavours as well with a hay-like edge before finishing on a strong hoppy note.

Bottled. A hazy light yellow beer with a lazing white head. The aroma is sweet citrusy combined with light notes of straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of straw, malt, and citrus, leading to a bitter finish with a strong note of straw. The body is thin.

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of joergen. Pours a cloudy, pale golden with tiny impurities and a creamy, white and lacing head. Lightly citrusy nose. Medium body with fruity accents and a dry, sharp bitterness. Very carbonated. Again a very unusual and atypical German beer. Is this really how it’s supposed to be?290607

Bottle. Huge frothy white head that lasted a very long time. Good display of lacework as well. Light cloudy orange color. Aroma of caramel, floral and citrus notes, clove, coriander and fruit. Medium bodied with an average carbonation and light dry texture. Balanced flavor between light-moderated sweet and bitter notes. Light bitter finish.

Sample from 50 cl. bottle. 2005 "vintage" - B.B. 2008. Muddy, dark amber with a thin, off-white head. Sweet aroma with caramel and roasted malts, faint smoke, coffee, light diacetyl/butter notes. Has not aged well: No fruitiness and the smoke has almost faded. Taste is sweet. Medium body, creamy texture. Short, sweet finish with light smoked notes. As other wheat beers, not meant for keeping.

Bottled. Very deep ambery brown colour, small beige head. Gets hazy brown with yeast in. Aroma is chocolate, nuttyness, and caramel. Flavour is chocolate, cookies, nuts and mild spices. Far from dunkelweizen, but still pleasant.

Bottled (BB 09/2010) Dark nutty brown color, small beige head. Chocolaty, yeasty aroma, also some vegetables. Some tobacco, cold coffee and vegetables in the flavor. Also light banana notes. Quite thin for being dunkelweizen. Odd too ...
Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma is roasted wheat, light hop (grass and pine). Flavour is light wheat, chocolate and coffee.
Brown with a tiny head. Aroma of caramel, milk chocolate and fruit. Sweet chocolate dominated flavour. Somewhat bland
Bottle at EsBF09. Mild yeasty and spicy aroma. No head. Mild roasted flavour, a bit of yeast. OK malty. Rough carbonation. Tastes like a standard German Dunkelweizen, but with a rougher carbonation.
On Tap @3 Fonteinen lambik-O-droom, Beersel. 16/11/2019 Color amarillo oscuro, sin espuma aromas funkys ligeros,, sabor acido, cuerpo ligero.
Hazy, orange colored, almost no white head. Tart fruit, lemony citric, moderate sourness, woody, earthy, dry finish, some grassy herbal notes. Medium- bodied, soft- carbonation, bit watery.
Poured from pitcher at lambik o droom. Pours a cloudy gold with small white head. The aroma is strong funk, earth, oak. Slick body, funky, earth, funky, light tartness, very good
Tap @ Lambik-o-droom. Hazy orange. Oak, citrus and sulphur in the aroma. Moderately sour flavor with oak, grapefruit and honey. Sulphur. Just a hint of rest sweetness.

A 200ml pour by hand pump from the cask into a 3 Fonteinen ballon glass. It was a lightly hazy golden colour with no head and no lacing. Aromas lightly sweet, fruity, almost stone fruit like. Tastes sour, light funk and light fruit flavours, lemon, apple. Light bodied with light carbonation. Overall, not what I expected but it’s one of the better Jonge Lambik’s that I’ve tried.
Served still from 3 Fonteinen Lambik-o-droom, Lot, Belgium. It pours unclear orange, with no head. Aroma is lemon, funky, grass, earth. Taste is light sour. Body is light, carbonation is low.

Poured right off the barrel (via serving jug), pours a hazed golden with a few bubbles resting on top. Musty aroma. Light lemon tartness, musty, quite fresh and refreshing. Notes: off the barrel at the facility, Sep ‘18
Served still at 3F. Bright hazy orange, thin white head. Oak, cheese rind, barnyard, apples. great!

Backlog. Cask at 3 Fonteinen Open Beer Days 2018. Amber color, white head. Sour taste with citrus, earthy notes, tart, acidic notes and grass. Sour finish with citrus, earthy notes, acidic notes, tart, wheat and grass. Refreshing stuff, quite raw.
Cask @ 3 Fonteinen Open Beer Days 2018. Smooth, slightly raw and earthy with some farmyard and earthiness.

Cask at GBBF '18, day 4, 10/08/18. Golden copper with a decent off white covering. Nose is twiggy, straw, light orange, biscuit. Taste comprises dusty fruits, caramel, hint of bread, grains, sweet malts. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, semi drying close. Pretty average fayre.

Cask at GBBF 2018. It poured clear brown with a small bubbly beige head. The aroma is sweet, oily, leather, cracker, rivita, wood and toasted nut. The taste is dry, bitter - sweet, oily, sugary, toffee, earthy, stewed tea, biscuit, grainy and fruit cake. Medium body and soft carbonation.. Quite sweet and oily. Very one dimensional. Pretty shit.

Cask conditioned at The Brewery Tap, Chester. Amber with white head. Quite a fruity, malty bitter, there is a tartish, raspberry note from somewhere but with a crisp biscuity malt it redeems itself. Reasonable in the close.

Clear copper, very little head. Light and fairly uninteresting malty aroma. Plenty of malt flavours, slightly woody and floral. Little in the way of hops which is a touch disappointing given the name, but decent enough.

Bottle light brown light tan head. Slightly fruity aroma. Medium mouth feel with decent malt flavors. Some hoppy flavors, some hop bitterness. If you classify this as a bitter it's very good. If you thought it was an IPA (based in name) you would be disappointed.

Bottle. Bottle conditioned chestnut brown beer. Smells fruity, malty. Thin mouthfeel, but tastes ok- almost spicy, mildly hoppy beer. I was expecting more powerful hop flavour from the name. Decent enough though. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cask. The High Cross (JDW), Leicester. White head, gold body. Hop, grass, fruity, spicy, dusty hops. Bitter. Dry finish.

Cask, Hinckley Fest 09. Amber brown with a small head. Aromas are fruity with weetabix. Earthy in its hops. Flavours are soft berries with sweet toffee. Quite yeasty with an earthy, dry, hoppy finish. OK.
Cask@Leicester Beer Festival, 2009. Golden brown beer with a plainly hopped aroma, and a lightly malty and roasted flavour. Overall a very average beer.
Keg at the brewery, 9/2/16. Clear amber, thin fizzy off-white head, decent retention. Aroma of toasted malt and caramel. The taste matches. Medium bodied.
Draft. Hazed muddled dark gold pour. This one is strong with herbal notes and a thick maltiness. Not the best.
On tap at the brewpub, pours a hazy dark amber with a light tan head. The smell is honey, grain. The taste is fruit, honey, nice hop counter with crisp dryness. Medium body with nice carbonation.

Snifter at SC. Unfiltered amber-brown. Thin, patchy off-white/beige head. Sort of an odd aroma, This is a unique twisted up beer. Sugary sweet malt tones, odd sour buttery tones, and a decent balancing bitterness. Solid alcohol richness. Clovy, spicey, sticky. Deep sweet malt tones, maybe a pinch underattenuated. Thick malt tones. Hardly World Class, but an interesting creation.

On tap at Silver Creek brewpub. Cloudy apricot with a thin off-white head. Aroma is pretty big with booze, fruit, tannins, and plenty of toffee and caramel. Taste is in line with aroma with plenty of malt and fruit and some moderate warming and a touch of brunt malt on the back end.

Great Taste 09. I’ve had a few imperial maibocks now but haven’t been impressed by many. The sweet malt took over in this one for me and the body wasn’t right. Not a bad brew, but I also don’t like the style.

Beer #25 at GTMW ’09. Just looks fine in the glass. Nice lager smell, just a little heavy. Another great imperial lager taste. Just a good imperial bock. And the more beers I sample here, the shorter my review notes get.

Sampled @ GTMW ’09 - Amber clear pour with a small white head. Smells of apple, but not much else -- a little sweet malt. Taste is lots of alcohol heat, more malt, and the same apple in the smell. The carbonation was jacked up to high, and there just wasn’t much here. Not a fan.

Orange-brown color profile. First thing that hits you is the strong peppery alcohol. Then comes caramel, malt, plums and toffee. It has been a while since I’ve had this one but from memory this beer was very enjoyable if you aren’t knocked out by initial alcohol. Very unique offering, to say the least.

Clear dark amber body with a tiny off-white head. The nose is sweet and vinous with herbs, plums and toffee. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter with golden raisins, herbs and slightly medicinal. Medium/full body is just slightly rough with moderate carbonation and a warm finish.

618ml bottle. Sampled in Xi’an. Exciting, a beer made from what I think is probably the most bitter food on earth. Pour golden with short white head. Aroma is ricey lager with slight flowery hop smell. Smells fresh. A little bit more bitter than the average chinese lager, which is really very tame. No sweetness. Extremely light and watery. Dry bitterness and rice in the aftertaste. Does not have as much of the bitter melon bitterness as I would like, but overall pretty well balanced.

Cask conditioned @ Waterloo Arms, Soton. Pale Colour. Light but pleasant lagery malts. Hops not especially flavoursome but have a nice level of bitterness with some growing earthy spice flavours. Not great but a drinkable pint with a good long finish.

column1: Top of the Hill Swim Test Saison
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: on tap-pours a Petri dish off white head that laces and yellow/gold color. Aroma is clove, spice-pepper, yeast, wheat-some sweet. Taste is clove, over-spiced, yeast, sweet light/medium malt, wheat. Sipping. OK effervescence.

column1: Top of the Hill Swim Test Saison
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Tap. The only beer on there tap list at the time taking advantage of NC popping-the-cap. Pours a slightly cloudy, washed out golden color. Smells of sweet oranges and lemons. The flavor adds more hoppiness to the fruit tastes than I was expecting and it’s a nice addition. I also tasted some bananas. This is a remarkably refreshing summer brew for an 8%er and will be the first beer I order whenever it’s on tap at Top of the Hill. Too bad they don’t bottle it yet cause I’d love to have a few of these on my porch back home.

column1: Top of the Hill Swim Test Saison
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery. Thanks for hookup Daniel--its nice having old elementary school chums working the bar. Pleasantly surprised to see a saison from the guys. Finally getting into the mix. Swim Test pours a hazy clear yellow with a small white head. Aroma is spicey and fruity with definite whiffs of yeast. Flavor is fruity and spicey with notes of orange peel and coriander. I had two imperial pints of this and I have to say I was impressed. These pints (coupled with the two ipa’s I had in additon to future liquor drinks) led to my demise later that evening and the following morning as I slept in and was late for work. At least I took some notes and actually remember enjoying these pints. I really hope "topo" will continue this trend with more adventurous offerings like this.
Cask at the Victoria Hotel, Beeston. Drinkable blonde ale with a citrus taste
Tried at the flying circus, Newark. Golden colour with a white head. Light malty and caramel aroma and taste. A touch of basement. Medium body.
Cask. Golden body with white foam top. Aroma hop fruits and pale malts. Taste medium bitter. Palate medium bodied oily texture and soft carbonation. Overall session worthy.
Cask conditioned at The Great Central Railway Beer Festival '17, Quorn, Leics. Gold with white head. There is a fruity, perfumed character to this, aromatic hopped note, light, It's fine.
On cask at Railway Inn, Mansfield. Pours golden amber with white head. Hoppy golden session, fragrant and chuggable.

Cask conditioned handpump Three Cocks Kettering 17/06/13. A yellow coloured beer with a whitish ring of head and lace. A nice citrussy beer. Lemon and lime notes. A good malt backbone gives a touch of sweetness but it works well. A nice beer to drink which is well constructed.

Cask (handpump) at the Victoria Hotel, Beeston on 14 July 2012. Bright gold. Thin white head. Excellent condition. Quite citric but very mellow - tending towards soft - on the palate. A slight gluey element in the aroma. Although it looked great, I’m not convinced this was in the best shape. Flagged for re-rate.

Cask, Leicester Fest ’08 (Thurs afternoon session). Pale, still and limp. Looks like a lager, but not helped by its conditioning. Watery tin mandarin notes, a crunch of apple boredom. Vague straw and biscuit. Almost Polish pils/pale lager. Zzz.

Cask at GBBF 2007. A light golden beer with a thick white head. The aroma is sweet with very citrusy hoppy notes. The flavor is sweet with a light malty back ground on which is citrusy hoppy notes, leading to a dry and slightly bitter finish. Nice.
Yellow with a lasting white head. Lemon and pine in the aroma. Dry and watery flavour.

I am assuming that this is the same vienna I had at the brewpub since this has been rated recently. At the brewpub it is called The Vienna Monologues...yup another clever name from those kooky guys over at the St. Matthews BBC. orange almost copper color with a small disappearing off white head. caramel hay aroma. bittersweet caramel grassy flavor. clean dry grassy bitter finish. light body. moderate carbonation. decent.

Draft at BBC St.Matthews. Pours clear amber with a fully receding off-white head. Aroma of light toasted malt, bready lager yeast, and a light note of floral hops. Taste is very clean and malty, and quite delicious. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with lively carbonation. I really enjoyed this brew, occasionally BBC brews up an excellent lager, and this is one of my new favorites.

Draft at St. Mattews brewpub. Poured clear brown color with a moderate frothy white head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Moderate sweet hoppy aroma. Medium body with a slick texture. Medium biitersweet flavor with a small bitter finish of moderate duration. Drinkable smooth brew.
Golden with a small white head. Citrus and pineapple in the hoppy aroma, with a hint of cabbage. Dry with some hoppy bitterness.

A Mes rate: Cask at Baker Street ’Sporks. Dark golden with a thin bubbly head. Straight down the line hoppy stuff with a strong citric note. Malt comes through more in the flavour with a very slight hint of spice. Bitter finish. Nothing special.
Draught (St. Urho’s , Helsinki) Sharply hoppy aroma. Slightly young mouthfeel, sacchariny bitter too. Mild lightly roasted grain body but dry resinous hopiness dominates. Long dry hoppy finish.

Cask, Rugby Fest 07. Clear golden/brown with a small head. Aromas are biscuit malts with citrus and some spices. Flavours are biscuit malts with lemon and gently hops. Some pepper and hints of woodiness. Prickly on the finish. Decent and hoppy.

Gravity, General Elliot BF, South Hinksey, Oxford. Nice pale gold, small but vicious layer of white clinging down the glass. Minty blackberry aroma, bright and fresh. just a little wholesome brown bread. A little butter, but nice. Gently hoppy in a flavor-forward way, not a bitter way. Berry esters, just a little toast in the finish. A bit more body than I think I prefer in such a light beer, but very nice overall. Lots of flavor, good summery beer.
330ml bottle at 4.1%. Pours clear gold with a medium-sized white head. Aroma is skunky, herbal, sweet malt. Taste is medium sweet, grassy hop, grain.

12 ounce bottle from John's Marketplace. My first Albania rating. Pours a clear golden hue with a large white head. A slightly odd apple and sweet malty nose. Toast, more glue like sweetness, grassy. Drinkable. Pretty clean.

33cl embossed green bottle. Pours gold and struggles to form a foamy/soapy white head. Aroma is skunky and sweet grain, hint of diacetyl and candy corn. Flavor is oxidized with nuttiness, caramel, light spice. Low carbonation. Not great, quite sweet and flat.
Pours golden with white head. Light adjunct like aroma. Light lager taste, very clean with a touch of lemon. Notes: on tap at Sarandë Beach, Albania Jul ‘19
#1466. Very poor beer. Pale gold color, terrible aroma (skunk), sourness and bad bitterness in taste. 0,3l bottle, Durres, Albania, market.
Obfita, szybko opadaj¹ca piana. Nie pachnie za bardzo niczym, trochê s³odów i to wszystko. W smaku ponownie delikatnie s³odowe, pozostawiaj¹ce w posmaku nieprzyjemn¹ wadê.
Poors light yellow, with no foam at all. Aroma and taste are quite bad, bit thin to drink. (Velp 201906)

Bottle at the hotel in Valbonë. Clear light golden, thin white foam. Light malty base, hint of adjuncty sweetness, and a slightly industrial attempt at pilsner-style hopping. Not the cleanest fermentation. Low to medium bitterness. All a bit thin really, probably my least favourite of the Albanian layers on this trip.
Aroma 3. Appearance 3. Taste 3. Palate 3. Overall 8. Malt and hops taste with a very slightly metalic aftertaste.

11.2 ounce bottle poured into a brandy snifter. The beer is a clear yellow with a lasting head of white foam. Aroma is grassy and earthy. The taste has an unmistakable caramel character. Sweet, herbal, caramely. Lighter body and medium carbonation.

Appears a hazy golden cloud with a small white cap that fades into a mild film. Steady streams of CO2 pump up to the top. Lots of sticky lace is left around the glass. Smell is of citrus, lemongrass, pumelo, and mild yeast. Flavors echo the aromas with a gentle tartness that grazes the tongue. Mouthfeel is mildly sweet and slightly tart up front.
On tap at the Wayne location. Poured a deeper amber color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas and tastes of wheat and honey comb. Had a light tart finish. Thinner body.
On tap at the Wayne location. Poured a medium and hazy golden color with a small sized white head. Typical aromas and tastes for a light beer - grainy with a light sweetness to it. Thin body

Canned. Surprisingly, "pils" here is not just a boring standard word but, rather a description of the style: dry, with harsh bitter notes, German pilsner. Unfortunately, the palate is just watery and empty.

500ml can of Stryke Pils - selected by Cellars International Ltd, for Nisa Today’s Holdings Ltd - according to "http://www.beercannews.com/COUNTRIES/United_Kingdom/UK_Can_News_01_2/body_uk_can_news_01_2.html" this seems to be the same beer as LCL Pils. Dark straw colour, white head disappears instantly; cardboard aroma; sickly sweet flavour; gassy; cloyingly sweet finish. Makes me wonder why I went to the trouble of identifying what it was.
Botella de. @Gustos, Guijuelo . 13/08/2019 Color amarillo claro corona de espuma blanca aromas metálicos, sabor cereal cuerpo ligero lager mala.

Bottle. Low but lasting white creamy head leaving nice lacings. Clear yellow body. Sweet mild barley malt aroma. Sweet mild and rather anonymous malty grassy flavor with little hops bitterness, low carbonation and a short aftertaste.
Bottle, 33cl. Pours clear, with none-to-little head. Very hoppy aroma, and similar on the palate. Overall a rather nondescript lager.

75cl bottle , Germany. Pours a clear gold with a lasting white foam. Palate is quite thin and watery. Nose is surprisingly allright. Fruit and hay. Malty and grainy flavor with a rusty metallic edge. Dry and citric.

33cl bottle. It poured a transparent yellow colour with a big white foamy head that settled down fast in the glass. The aroma smells of malts and hints of smoke. The flavour is really weak and thin and tastes of bread and water. It has a very short aftertaste.
Bottle 75 cl. Frothy white good mostly deminishing head. Yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Citrus notes. Light bitter flavor. Light bitter short finish. Watery palate. Not very good.

Bottled. An orange beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of caramel and hints of smoke. The flavor is sweet matly with light notes of caramel and smoke, leading to a bitter finish with light notes of hops. The body is thin.

Bottle 75cl. Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, fair lancing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, keller, toffee. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is medium to light, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. (300508)
Bottle. Colour pale yellow colour with large creamy white mostly lasting head. Malty aroma. Sweet flavor. Watery palate.
Light yellow and clear. Has a white head, mostly lasting. Light hoppy aroma, faint malty notes. Moderate sweet flavor. Sparkling.

12/10/2019. Bottle courtesy of Gabriel. Pours slightly hazy pale golden with a good size white head. Aroma of grain, sweet malt, straw, light veg, cereal and potato starch. Medium sweetness and light bitterness. Moderate body, slight watery texture, average carbonation. Quite dull.

Bottled, from Sagasser, Ilmenau. Lightly hazy pale golden, mid sized head. Fruity nose with a whiff of lemon. Mid sweet with light tartness and medium body. Rounded mouthfeel. Sourdough and grass. Low bitterness. Unclean.

Cask (handpump) at the Castle, Holborn. Golden / amber colour. I’m afraid I wasn’t getting enough variation in my diet in the course of this pub crawl. This was too similar to many of the other beers that had gone before and didn’t make much of an impression. Clean, with a touch of citrus and some biscuity malt but didn’t stand out from the crowd.

Cask (handpump) @ The Castle, 26 Furnival Street, Fleet Street, London, Greater London England EC4A 1JS. Clear medium yellow orange color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, moderate hoppy, citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet and shell bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090803]
Golden with a small white head. Aroma of fruit, including pears, and some biscuit. Dry, thin fruity flavour

Half pint, cask at The Castle, Holborn. Straw coloured body. Tiny, White layer. Sweet fruity aroma. Fine fruity summer taste of apricot and peaches, lightly spiced. Modest bitter finish. Medium to thin bodied. A bit unusual and quite likeable (London, 03.08.2009).

Cask@The Castle. Golden colour, not much head. Aroma is nectar, fruity and flowery hops along with some grapefruits and bready malts. Flavour is fruity, wooden, mildly yeasty as well as some grainy hops.
Cask@The Castle. Pale yellow color, vanishing white head. Lemony cat pee aroma. Lemon grass hoppy flavor. Some similarities to German supermarket lagers, wow. Lemony aftertaste.
Cask in the market porter. Aroma is grainy malts, grassy and yeasty. Taste is similar, the citrusy hops are coming through but its a bit boring.
Cask, The Criterion, Leicester. Golden with a white head. Aromas are grain with bitter grapefruit. Peppery with sulphur. Flavours are gritty grain with peppery, bitter hops. Dry on the finish.

Cask conditoned - handpump - George, Tiffield. A golden coloured beer with a white head and lacing. The aroma is grass and straw and some dirty dishwater. The taste is the same with added metal. Really disappointing, especially as I normally like Rugby beers.

Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Gold with a small white head. Aroma had a bit of citrus and perhaps a hint of honey. Plus a distinct whiff of gloss paint. Fairly predictable citrus taste and bitter finish. Fair enough.
500ml bottle from Elijah Allen & Son, Hawes. Pours golden with a medium white head. Aroma hops - citrus. Taste refreshing sharp bitterness, refreshing drink
Bottle conditioned. Pours a hazy orange colour with a fluffy white head, the aroma is hoppy with plenty of fruit, the taste is medium bitterness and with a dry bitter finish.
Gravity at the Guisborough Beer Festival. Golden with a frothy white head. Not much aroma. Pleasant citrus taste with a little grapefruit. Refreshing and easy drinking. Good.
Bottle from Drink? Hebden Bridge. Clear golden with a thin head. Fruit hopped with a dry fruitiness and texture that subdues the flavour. Has a strong tropical fruit aroma.

Cask at GBBF 2014 - London. Day 2. Pours clear yellow with a light, white cream head. Very crisp, with notes of brittle hay, dry biscuits, dry lemon. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Nicely balanced on the finish with some further dry pale malts. Quenching. Solid.
From cask. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is herbal, light citrusy hoppy. Bitter, citrusy and light grassy. Dry hoppy and slight fruity finish.
Cask @ GBBF 2014. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty citrus hoppy aroma. Fruity malty citrus hoppy bitter flavor. Has a fruity citrus hoppy bitter finish.
How: Cask. Where: GBBF 2014. Appearance: Golden colour with a small white head. Aroma: Subtle malt, grass, hops. Body: Medium body, low carbonation. Flavour: Malt, bitter.

Cask at GBBF ’14, day 2, 13/08/14. Clear golden with a moderate off white covering. Nose is earthy hops, candied orange peel, light pine, mango. Taste comprises earthy hops, straw, orange pith, lick of pine, light grapefruit. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. Solid GB action.

13th August 2014 GBBF Day 2. Cask. Almost clear pale gold beer. No head. Palate is light and semi dry. Not much carbonation. Floral light malts. Touch of citrus. Light dry finish. A passable if wimpy Golden.
Chicago Trip. Monday 12:30+. The other half of the Apollo/Bravo hop experiment. On tap. Cloudy yellow. Delicate enjoyable hops grow beautifully through the finish.

Anniversary Trip 2007 5/18/2007: Amber color with a large, dense, foamy white head and nice lacing. Mild level of visible carbonation. The aroma is sweet and earthy with some syrup and citrus present. At first the flavor is sweet light malts. Then it moves into a nice moderate bitterness through to the finish. This beer seems strong, but the there isn’t any alcohol in the flavor. Medium-light body. Smooth texture with a touch of creaminess to it. A well-crafted Maibock (which is quite a complement from me since I generally don’t care for too many Mai/Heller Bock beers!). Draught sample (6.5% ABV) at Saugatuck Brewing Company in Saugatuck, Michigan.
Very nice effort here...big caramel/toffee malt bill lends a creamy sweet texture. The citrus and pine hops, and a fair amount of them, add a nice bitter bite in the finish. Nice job.

Anniversary Trip 2007 5/18/2007: Hazy yellow witha a large, dense, creamy, long lasty, ivory-colored head. This beer is dry-hopped and ample fresh citrus and grapefruit hops are apparent in the aroma and flavor. There is just enough malt (toffeeish flavored) to hold this beer up and provide some balance. Above average level of bitterness. Dry finish with some grassy/vegetation like hops. A little thing on the palate, but not too bad. Average carbonation. Clean. Draught sample at Saugatuck Brewing Company in Saugatuck, Michigan.

Anniversary Trip 2007 5/18/2007: Cloudy yellowish-orange color. The small, foamy head is parchment in color and leaves interesting sculpture-like lacing. This beer is dry-hopped as evidenced by the fresh citrus and grassy hop aroma. Light toffee malt in the flavor along with lots of hops. There is a punch of hops and bitterness up front, but then it smooths out. There is lots of bitterness throughout and it also lingers, but it isn’t a raw, nasty, bitter bite. Medium body with a smooth and slick texture. This IPA packs in the bitterness! Draught sample at Saugatuck Brewing Company in Saugatuck, Michigan.

black, little tan bubbles rim side of glass for a head, lacy. mild nose of chocolate malt, trace of coffee. flavor starts with chocolate malt, then progresses toward bitter coffee. medium bodied, bitter finish. quite enjoyable. cheers.

Thanks to RAYBOY01 for bringing a growler of this to the mug club tapping at Flossmoor Station. This poured an opaque mahogany body, highlighted in ruby, with a substantal tan head. The aroma was chocolatey, complemented by roasted malt and dark caramel. The flavor well mirrored the nose, the roastiness becoming a bit more pronounced. It’s a tad thin for style, but otherwise a fine drink.

Growler shared at the Mug Club tapping by Rayboy. Gene, thanks a bunch! Pours a pitchblack opaque pour with with a ruby bottle, a small brown head that dies to a very small film, laces lightly. Aromas are chocolatey, cookies with a bit of coffee, a decent roasted malt blast, faint licorice, a touch of creamy sweetness. Initial is roasty, but not thick, chocolate and coffee, roasted malts with a decent sessionability thickness wise. I’m pretty surprisd to find this weighs in at 7.5. Flavors mesh well, good roast and sweetness balance. Nice.

Very dark brown pour with off-white head that lingers and laces. Nose is pretty strongly roasty with notes of chocolate and espresso. Flavors are sweet roasted barley malt, chocolate, hints of coffee, and nuts. Palate is just a tad thin-bodied, but there is a decent amount of creaminess as well. I really enjoyed this fine example of an underdone style.

Anniversary Trip 2007 5/18/2007: See-through mahogany color with a diminish tan head. Aroma has chocolate. The flavor is sweet and malty. At first there is a semi-sweet chocolate flavor that moves to a darker, morre bitter flavor due to the roasted malt mid-way through. This lends some chicory quality to the flavor as well. There is some of what I call the typical "Baltic Porter yeasty quality" lingering thoughout as well. Slightly dry finish. Medium body, smooth. There are lots of good flavors in this beer without being heavy. A very sessionable beer! My second favorite of the Saugatuck beers I tried on this trip (my favorite being the Bamberg Rauschbier).. Draught sample (7.5% ABV) at Saugatuck Brewing Company in Saugatuck, Michigan.

Sampler at the New Day Bar (Indianapolis, IN). First visit. Great visit! Pours a nearly clear, transparent hue. Like water, crystal clear, some brightness. Aromas are herbal and dry, earthy florals and pollen, a bit of clover, gentle clove like spice starts to grow and spread it’s wings. Initial is a medium body, gentle heat, kiss of white grapr, honey, clean fermentation makes this a bit hot without much supporting flavor. Some gentle warmth, earth, and clean sweetness. Bit of grape, grain. Some pollen, florals, and a bit of spiciness. Middle is gentle sweetness, bit of honey, white grape. Backend is crisp, a touch of sweetness, mellow heat picks up. Finish is dry, a bit of heat, faint honey and floral. A weird one. Certainly a bit dry, but perhaps a bit too fermented out. Interesting. Not my thing

Bottle to taster at New Day. Looks decent; still, transparent, and clear. It looks like water. Smells solid; dry white wine and honey. Tastes like it smells, but less robust, with a touch of clove. Average on the palate. Not my fave New Day mead.

Aroma of honey with floral hints; a touch of clove. Appearance is nearly white gold with no head or carbonation. Flavor is exceedingly dry up front with a more pronounced fruity/honey presence in the finish. Palate is light, oily and flat. Solid mead.
I was pleasantly surprised by this entry. The dry finish was great for this palate. A good showcase for the quality local ingredients used in this mead.
Much more straightforward flavor than the other meads. Obviously dryer than the others and much less bold. I’m not a big mead drinker so I have little to compare this to.

Batch 08-1 (67 cases made, and hand-numbered, apparently). Pale straw color. Doggedly dry with a hint of honey and about as much paper. Smooth and flattish, but clean and very like a white wine. There’s some flavor striation here that detracts from the overall harmony we’re always looking for, but on the whole, OK.

much drier, lighter, and drinkable than any mead I’ve had. notes of apple, honey, almost like a white wine. light floral, grassy note. very clean. nice stuff. really lets the honey shine through. simple, yet elegant.

This bottled mead from the meadery poured a head of large sized clear colored bubbles that were quickly diminishing and left behind a transparent light yellow colored body. The aroma was sweet dry and cardboard. The smooth dry mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start mediumly tingly at the harsh finish. The very mild sweet flavor was dry.

Batch #51 at New Day Meadery. Clear hue, sweet, spicy nose, honey, spicy, dry, clean flavor, tingly, dry mouthfeel and light-medium body. Just an okay Mead, nothing super special about it. Worthy of a try.

Anniversary Trip 2007 The tasting notes provided by the meadery provide a very accurate description of this mead: This traditional Dry Mead is light straw in color. It possesses a delicate spicy aroma, with a slight clove note. The flavor is light on the tongue, showing subtle honey character and red clover blossom, wrapped in a straw finish. Clean and dry; this is a true mead-lover’s mead. Residual Sugar: 0% | Alcohol Content: 12% | Style: Still. Vintage: 2005 | Batch number: 05-1 | Cases Made: 91 5/20/2007: New Day Dry Mead has the color and transparency of spring water! The aroma is like white wine with a delicate spiciness to it. Subtle honey note can be found in the flavor. Clean and dry (not bone-dry though) finish. Sampled at New Day Meadery in Elwood, Indiana.
Draft sampled at New Day. From notes. Floral and earthy honey sweetness. Not very dry at all, but still very good.
Draft pour at the source. Looks nearly like water. Smells earthy and musty. Tastes musty and funky. Drying finish.

Sampler at the New Day Bar (Indianapolis, IN). First visit. Great visit! Pours a near clear transparent hue, like water, faint touch of honey warmth at times. Just a faint golden flicker. Aromas are earthy, dry with florals, a bit of spice, herbal and clover feel. Some gentle spice mixes with a touch of honey, gentle earthy mineral feel. Initial is a bit more inviting than dry. Some mellow sweetnessn honey, and clover up front. Florals, touch of apple and mellow warmth comes into play. Middle is a touch spicy, dry. Some heat kicks into the backend, some alcohol related warmth. A more inviting front makes way to that telltale spicy, warm finish. More enjoyable than regular Dry by a good deal, but still not really my thing.
Bottle to taster at New Day. Looks solid; still, transparent, and clear. Smells of white wine and honey. Tastes like it smells with a semi-sweet backbone. A decent mead.
Definitely a sweeter version of their dry mead. The honey is accentuated in this mead with a nice, smooth, honey sweet finish.

Pours a very light yellow. Still. Nose is light honey aroma and not very prominent but pleasant. Also aroma of light wax, and very flowery like clover, and fruity candy. Also a little boozy in te nose. Taste, as mentioned is just slightly dry but leaves a little sweetness to keep it drinkable for me. Still seems pretty dry though. Smooth and almost full mouthfeel for a wine. Pretty good.
much sweeter than the dry mead. not as dry as the dry mead, but dry compared to other meads i’ve had. nice candy, honey. nice, but liked the dry mead from new day better.

Out of the bottle at the meadery. This was my favorite of the tour, and I bought some bottles to take home. Very pale yellow in color and still. Very floral honey forward nose. This semi-dry is much sweeter than the dry offerings from New Day and has a very nice floral and earthy honey flavor. The alcohol shows itself on the inhale. As shig said, this is much sweeter in the comparison, but this is a nice mead that should be tried.

Anniversary Trip 2007 The tasting notes provided by the meadery actually provide a very accurate description of this mead: A slightly sweeter version of our Dry Mead, our Semi-Dry Mead possesses the characteristic light straw color. The aroma is more pronounced, showing the sweet spice notes unique to East-central Indiana wildflower honey. The flavor is, too, slightly sweet with a pleasant honey flavor. The additional honey used in this variety provides a richer, fuller body and lingering sweetness that makes for a very enjoyable mead. Residual Sugar: 4% | Alcohol Content: 12% | Style: Still. Vintage: 2005 | Batch number: 05-2 | Cases Made: 82 5/20/2007: New Day Semi-Dry Mead looks clearer than water! Sweet honey and alcohol pop out of the aroma. The mead is much sweeter than all the other New Day meads. It’s only 4% residual sugar, but since their other meads are all quite dry, this one seems like sugar water or light corn syrup in comparison! There are lots of delicate honey flavors throughout and it is well-balanced overall. This mead has a soft and smooth feel and seems much more full in the mouth. A traditional, sweeter mead. Sampled at New Day Meadery in Elwood, Indiana.

column1: New Day Dry Red Raspberry Honey Wine
column5: Bottle: Pours clear, still, amber-red-orange.....no head. Raspberry, honey, alcohol aroma. Extremely dry...raspberry... So dry, it feels like it disappears on the tongue. Very nice.

column1: New Day Dry Red Raspberry Honey Wine
column5: Light, sweet, and refreshing. Raspberry in the aroma and throughout the flavor. Sweet and not overly tart.

column1: New Day Dry Red Raspberry Honey Wine
column5: Pours copper with a pinkish hue. Smells of honey, some boozy hints, tarte. Tastes of tarte raspberries, some lemony hints, dry honey undertones with a warming alcohol bite on the finish.

column1: New Day Dry Red Raspberry Honey Wine
column5: light, zinfandel , bright raspberry. fruity. very mellow, clean, drinkable. no harsh flavors. honey raspberry. dry, but not as dry as the dry mead or the peach mead. okay.

column1: New Day Dry Red Raspberry Honey Wine
column5: This bottled mead from themeadery poured a head of medium sized clear colored bubbles that were quickly diminishing and left behind a transparent uncarbonated rose hued body. The aroma was dry tart and raspberry. The smooth dry mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start mediumly tingly at the finish with a soft acidic aftertaste. The mild flavor contained notes of paper and mild sour tart raspberry. A decent one that I would consider having again.

column1: New Day Dry Red Raspberry Honey Wine
column5: Out of a bottle at the meadery. Pinkish blush color and still. The nose is an assertive raspberry that borders on cough syrup. A very crisp, dry mead with very fresh raspberry flavors and noticable alcohol. Nice and tart.

column1: New Day Dry Red Raspberry Honey Wine
column5: Rated at New Day Meadery. Orange hue; nose was roses, sweet, and fresh raspberries; flavor was fresh raspberries and fresh fruit; mouthfeel was fairly smooth and dry. This mead has a very pronounced aroma. I would definitely drink this again if given the opportunity. Worthy of a try!

column1: New Day Dry Red Raspberry Honey Wine
column5: Anniversary Trip 2007 The tasting notes provided by the meadery provide actually a very accurate description of this mead: This variety is our star: our Dry Red Raspberry Honey Wine is a vibrant ruby red, practically glowing in the glass. The aroma says “Hello, Raspberry!”. A subtle rose petal note plays off of the sparkling freshness of the fruit. You simply do not get any fresher than this without eating a handful of the berries themselves. The flavor is bright raspberry, well balanced, with just the right amount of tannin structure. The lasting fresh fruit finish leaves your palate crying for more! Residual Sugar: 0% | Alcohol Content: 12% | Style: Still. Vintage: 2006 | Batch number: 06-1 | Cases Made: 70 5/20/2007: New Day Dry Red Raspberry Honey Wine has a slightly lighter coral pink color than the New Day Dry Blueberry Honey Wine. The aroma is fresh, ripe raspberries with a hint of rose. The flavor is real raspberry that moves to a rose-flavored finish (like eating a rose!). There is some dry honey flavor present mid-way through the finish as well. Soft and mellow. Quite good! Sampled at New Day Meadery in Elwood, Indiana.

column1: New Day Dry Blueberry Honey Wine
column5: Sampler at the New Day Bar (Indianapolis, IN). First visit. Great visit! Pours a nice glowing pinkish orange hue, gentle haziness, glow overall is impressive. Aromas are decent blueberry, touches of citrusy orange and lemon, some gentle pomegranate, honey, and mellow earth. A bit of heather, florals, and honey. Initial is lighter end of the fold, some tart and tannic blueberry, a touch pulpy. Gentle honey, earth, florals. Some gentle pomegranate, citrus, some gentle fruit presence. Middle is a bit tart, tannic, lemon and some grapefruit. Tartness and dry bitter quality. Backend shows some residual sweetness, honey and blueberry, bit of floral. Finish is tart, lemony, and dry. A bit of florals, earth, decent dryness throughout. Interesting, enjoyable, flows well. I enjoyed this one.

column1: New Day Dry Blueberry Honey Wine
