column5: On tap at the meadery. Pours a clear ruby red. Aroma of sweet fruit, herbal leaves. Flavor of sweet blueberry. Dry. Lots of berries in the flavor. Ok, not terribly interesting though. 7/4/6/3/13 (3.3/5)

column1: New Day Dry Blueberry Honey Wine
column5: Bottle to taster at New Day. Looks good; a still, transparent orangish copper. Smells solid; cherry, blueberry, and honey with a bit of spice. Tastes like it smells, minus the spice. Good on the palate with a nice, dry finish. Enjoyable.

column1: New Day Dry Blueberry Honey Wine
column5: On tap at the source... Darker berry hued pour, minimal bubbles, slightly leggy... Aroma of softer blueberry and muddled honey, not clean... More of the same for flavor. Soft barely depictable honey with a moderate blueberry note. Pretty dry and not sweet as expected.

column1: New Day Dry Blueberry Honey Wine
column5: I really liked this wine, especially for the contrast against some of the other New Day offerings. Lots of blueberry and darker fruits. Sweet and bold.

column1: New Day Dry Blueberry Honey Wine
column5: Buzzed into this joint in Elwood for a tasting. Super dry crisp..like the dude that served it. Refined...yet pure country style. You can taste the Indiana in this bottle...its the well water...mineral rich with a light fruity cloud that rides you out with a grin that lets you experience the midwest from any part of the world.

column1: New Day Dry Blueberry Honey Wine
column5: sweet honey blueberries. a bit of cough syrup. nice and dry. floral. good, but liked the peach, plum, and dry mead better.

column1: New Day Dry Blueberry Honey Wine
column5: This bottled mead from the meadery poured a head of clear colored bubbles that left behind a transparent uncarbonated rose-brown colored body. The mouth feel was dry and soft. It has a nasal tingle and a soft start and a mildly vinous finish. The flavor semi-sweet softy harsh in the finish mildly acidic and dry.

column1: New Day Dry Blueberry Honey Wine
column5: glass from the bottle at O’Donnell’s in Ft Wayne - Pours surprisingly red and has a mild aroma with floral and honey notes along with the alcohol. The floral honey flavor is dry and the blueberries are very subtle. I wouldn’t have known it was blueberries in a blind tasting. Actually I was debating if I’d have even known that fruit was added. Odd. It’s still pretty good though.

column1: New Day Dry Blueberry Honey Wine
column5: Out of a bottle at the meadery. Attractive garnet red color and still. The alcohol dominated the nose in this one. Dry, fruity tartness that I wouldn’t have identified as blueberries without the name. Lots of floral honey notes and naticable alcohol.

column1: New Day Dry Peach Honey Wine
column5: I wanted to like this one more than I did, but the peach flavor--as expected--was muted and did not attribute much to the overall mead other than a vague tartness. This is not to say that this wasn’t a decent mead, but there are better entries at New Day.

column1: New Day Dry Peach Honey Wine
column5: Fresh and light aroma with lots of peaches. Sweet flavor with a honey body and peach tartness.

column1: New Day Dry Peach Honey Wine
column5: nice dry peach honey wine. nice tart peach and booze notes. some green apple. pretty good. quaffable. smooth. tart crisp. refreshing. would drink again.

column1: New Day Dry Peach Honey Wine
column5: bottle - Pours a clear straw color and has an aroma that puts me in mind of sweet peaches with some honey and alcohol as well. It tastes of honey with subdued peach flavors. Of course as the 0% residual sugars indicates, it’s a very dry honey wine and yet something about the taste that seemed a little sweet had me swearing there must be some sugar in it. It’s much like a very dry white wine, light and enjoyable, and doesn’t really have any false notes. The peaches come through more definitively than the blueberries do in their dry blueberry one. Nicely done.

column1: New Day Dry Peach Honey Wine
column5: This bottled mead from the meadery poured a head of large sized clear colored bubbles that were quickly diminishing and left behind a transparent very light yellow colored body. The aroma was sweet tart and honey. The dry mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start mediumly tingly at the harsh finish with sour tart notes. The soft flavor contained notes of semi-sweet dry peach.

column1: New Day Dry Peach Honey Wine
column5: Out of a bottle at a tasting at the meadery. Pale yellow color and still. Peach syrup nose. Long, dry peach flavor like peach cobbler and pits. Some sweet floral notes from the honey. Burns a little on the tongue.

column1: New Day Dry Peach Honey Wine
column5: Rated at New Day Meadery. Straw hue, nose was sweet, fresh peaches and tart and ditto for the flavor. Smooth, dry mouthfeel and light body. A very nice tasting Mead and one I would drink again. Nicely done and worthy of a try.

column1: New Day Dry Peach Honey Wine
column5: Anniversary Trip 2007 The tasting notes provided by the meadery actually provide a very accurate description of this mead: Combining tree-ripened, freshly picked Indiana peaches with our Indiana wildflower honey has resulted in a bright straw-yellow mead. The aroma is 100 percent fresh peach, with just a hint of wheat straw in the background. The flavor is subtle tart peach, bright and crisp. Allowing this Dry Peach Honey Wine to ferment to complete dryness allows the true characteristic of the fruit to come through in this delightful fruit and honey wine. Residual Sugar: 0% | Alcohol Content: 12% | Style: Still. Vintage: 2006 | Batch number: 06-3 | Cases Made: 83 5/20/2007: New Day Dry Peach Honey Wine is super clear with barely any shade of color. The aroma is fuzzy light peach with a hint of honey. Sublte tart peach can be found in the crisp flavor. Very dry on the palate. This mead reminds me of Sauvignon blanc wine. This one has the same alcohol content as the plain New Dry Dry Mead, but it tastes stronger. It also has a mouthfeel that seems more round... Sampled at New Day Meadery in Elwood, Indiana.

hand pull. poured a dark brown with a ring of off white bubbles. aroma a nutty sweetness, caramel, malt some medium fruits. flavor got a cola, nuts, caramel, a nice sweetness comes out at the finish. easy drinking beer

Handpull: The aroma has lots of carmael and vanilla with some light maple syrup. It’s dark brown with orange hilights and a small off-white head. The flavor has lots of vanilla with some caramel and mild fruitiness. The finish has sort of a watermelon flavor to it that lingers in the aftertaste.

Handpull. Dark brown body with small, off-white head. The aroma is moderately sweet, caramel and cashews. The flavor is light, cola, nuts and melon rind. Medium/light body is very soft with little carbonation.

Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury. Chestnut colour with white head. Cor, this ones a surprise, almost against calling it a bitter. Dark roasted malts, sweetish with chocolate malts, then a coffee note and then a zesty, american hop flavour zinging across the top. Very interesting and flavoursome, to me another C.V winner.

A dark orange brown coloured beer with a weak off-white head. A hoppy nose, fruity, but a bit sour, plus a hint of yeastiness. A dry zesty taste, hoppy, orange fruit flavour with a malty background flavour, that is taken over by a bready yeast flavour in the finish. (Cask - The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk).

Cask, Newark Fest 07. Toffee coloured with a small head. Aromsa are weetabix and toffee malts with chocolate and spices. Some Autumn fruit with herbal notes. Flavours are sweet malts with lots of toffee. Floral and herbal with dark chocolate bitterness on the finish.

Cask-conditioned at the Cornubia, Bristol 10/5/07. Dark ruby red colour with next to no head. Slight roasted notes in the aroma. Flavour was brambly with a touch of dark chocolate. Not much of a finish. An ok mild.

picked up a growler of this. pored a nice deep rich amber with a light tan head. aroma malts, honey, hops, bread. flavor the sweet malts, dry hops a little grassy. dry on the palate this was a way to easy beer to drink I finished the growler in no time.
Clear, amber body with small beige head. The aroma is biscuit, toasty and herbal. The flavor is biscuit, light butter and grassy. Medium/light body with soft carbonation, clean finish.

Draft Half Pint at Cask Pub & Kitchen, Pimlico, London in Mar 2011 - Dark Amber Brown in colour. Winter warmer in style. Malty; slightly roasty malts, caramel, hints of chocolate. Fruity; citrus orange and dark fruits. Hoppy; grassy hops. Sweetish malty fruity throughout. Very drinkable. (2011-03-07)
Bottle at home. Pours copper amber, nose is caramel, malty, the taste is similar.

From my backlog. Shared with andregoncalves. Coppery colour with a beige head with medium lasting. Aroa has notes of light caramel and red fruits with floral hops. Flavor is moderate bittery with earthy notes. Mild bittery final with short duration.
Bottle at animal, shared with teddybeer. Color is dark copper/red. Body is soft. Medium bitterness. Aroma is roasted, chocolate, coffee, malt, light fruit.
50cl bottle from ABCBeets. Thick white head. Clear golden pour. Lovely bitterness

500ml bottle. Clear, ruby red glowing, mahagony colour with huge, thick, creamy, fairly lasting, moderately lacing, beige head. Dry hoppy, fruity aroma, notes of red berries, lingonberry, cranberry. Taste is minimally sweet fruity, hints of red berries and their parings, bitter hoppy overtones, nuttily malt basis.

Dark murky reddish, tan head. Aroma is not there, perhaps some slight roast but that is it. Taste is fruity refreshing malty fullbodied goodness. Not about hops but about malt and body. Plenty of body for sure, and some similarity to an oirish stout.

500ml bottle. Amber Brown pour, fine frothy creme head. Dusty malt, toast, nuts in the aroma.Flavour is roasted, toasted malt, more nuts, blue cheese bitterness. Light enough body, soft carbonation. Touch of coffee and more nuttiness in the finish.Nice.

500 ml bottle. Pours a dark amber copper colour with a white thick head. Aroma of ripe banana, lingonberries and English toffee. Flavour of heavy biscuity malts, English toffee, sour lingonberries, grassy bitterness, some chocolate and some harsh herbal notes. Medium bodied, rough dry mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Finishes dry, bitter and harsh. Nice bitterness but has that certain off-flavour present.
The head is good, the body darkbrown. It smells darkmalty, CO2, a bit chocolate. The taste is darkmalty, chocolate, CO2, refreshing. Tasty and good. 11/11/11/11/11/11
Draught (Maypole, Camdbridge) Sweet caramelly aroma. Some vegetal hints. Nutty taste. Grainy too, some veg, and even beaniness. Perhaps fading a little, but wasn’t flat and dead in the mouth.

Cask gravity at the Watford Beer Festival 2014. Poured a clear amber, with a halo of rocky white head. Aroma of sweets, mouldy fruit and bread. Malty flavour, with some corn and caramel. Finish was toffee, toasted malt and wet grass.

Cask gravity at the Watford beer fest 2014. Orange light amber coloured pour with a lasting loose greyish head. Aroma is wet grass. Silage, stale grains and bit of spicy rye. Flavour follows, wet grass, and sweet nutty malt. Palate is watery, thin and sweet. Weird beer. Not a fan.
From the Bottle at Tom’s Ultimate Glasgow Tasting, Blackfriars 01/12/2007 Some fruit and malt aromas. Amber coloured fruity and a little rich on the palate. Crisp and slightly bitter finish.

Rich spiritous cask wood, cakey almond, sherry, toffee, mocca and single malt snout. On paper exactly the sort of malt-heavy richness that ordinarily turns me right off, in fact. But here it just works. Background chocolate and hopleaf interest to keep me guzzling. Alcohol right at the front, unfolding into choclolate creaminess, nuts, milky Rauch notes, berry fruit and currant. The usual applepeely BC tones. Chestnut and ivory with intricate lace. Slightly out of date bottle, and none the worse for it.

Bottle (in NZ), light brown colour which is a littly hazy (not surprising as gthe neck is caked with sediment) and no head. Coffee is the most dominant aroma, but there is a little chocolate in there too, a touch bready and some stewed fruit. A touch tart, though I will put this down to the travel. The palate is a touch thin, the hops come through a lot stronger than in the aroma, with a definite raisin flavour. Interestingly, the malt doesn’t really come through at all, though the finish is a little roasty. I’ve given this the benefit of the doubt on a few counts.

50cl. bottle: Pours a nice orangey chestnut with pretty creamy beige head. Coffee, toffee, and chocolate balanced nicely with hops, raisin, dark rum, and dried leaves. Smells a bit darker than it looks. On the tongue there is some nice toasted brown bread (think thick sliced heavy Irish brown bread) with a sprinkling of cocoa powder. Then hops come in to break up the toast a little. Some fruit follows. Possibly raisin and just a slight tough of something citrus. Roast comes back in and lasts through the finish with mild coffee. Also a touch of cookie dough adds some sweetness in the final seconds, but still ending dry. Quite nice
Bottle. Brown with a small head. Aromas are sweet weetabix malts with some smoky notes and peppery hops. Flavours are malty with sweet toffee. Rummy and rich with prickly hops. Dry on the finish.
Bottle. Golden and clear. Gentle bitterness with a hoppy furnish. Bottle conditioned in the correct manner.Very pleasant and easy to drink.

Pours a hazy dark brown/burgundy color with a big white head that leaves a small film. Aroma is deep, intense and malty. It shows notes of tobbacco, chocolate, truffles, watered down coffee, banana and bailey’s whiskey cream. Flavor is bittersweet with notes of chocolate, truffles, burnt caramenl, hazelnuts and mokka. Wow I liked it a lot.... This one doesn’t need complexity. Smooth silky texture, medium body. Carbonation is medium too. Finish is long, sweet and the aftertaste is chocolatey. A nice beer to sit and enjoy. Thanks to Gazza for this bottle Shared with Lilith and davidpl

Appearance: mid brown color. Medium head, beige and few dense. Aroma: toast grains, sweet chocolate, slight aromatic spicy like pepper, candy, fresh yeast ad fruity like plums and figs. Flavor: semi-toasted malts; tobaccos, sweet chocolate, mochas and light peppery touches. Fruity taste like figs, plums and dried-fruits. Medium hoppy final, dryness mainly from toasty. Toast and slight smoked aftertaste. Palate: medium body and silky texture. Low carbonated. Nice toasty and smoked. The tobacco taste is very pleasant. Thanks Gazza. Beer tasting with Panzerfaust and Lilith
Bottle at Toms Ultimate Glasgow Tasting: Poured amber with a tan head. Aroma is fruit with mild hops and malt. The taste is bitter metallic and hoppy with yeasty aftertaste.
Bottle at ultimate glasgow tasting. Aroma is roasted malts, grassy bitterness, lightly dusty yeast. Taste is similar too bitter for the yeast to work though.

[7300-20080108] Bottle. Smells like unpasteurized honey beeswax. Clear, light yellow body with a medium-lasting foamy white head. Black currant apple tea flavour is not very beer-like at all. Light body. Interesting once you get past the non-beer qualities, could make for an interesting honey beer. (6/3/5/3/11) 2.8 Overheard: "It’s like something crawled into a champagne bottle and died." (Lost rating #1035 from 2008; c/o DuctTape, w/ him, jerc, others)

bottle. Pale golden with one finger head. Sweet pickles and strawberry. I’ve been avoiding this one in the back of the fridge for a few weeks now. Not nearly as terrible as I was expecting. It almost works as a flavor combination. I’ve certainly had worse from Schmohz.
On tap at Quaker Steak. Color was cloudy straw, with pink tinge. Very bland taste. Medium body. Wouldn’t buy again.

Pour from a 12oz bottle, make your own 6 pack from Horrocks in GR. Cloudy weiss looking brew, dirty yellow with surprisingly dense white head. Aroma conjures pickle juice - a little acetic acid overtone, spice, dill, earth, dirty socks. Taste is like sweet zima malt beverage with a little sour and dirty socks and vitamin C in the finish, though the odor - er, aroma - adds to that. Watery mouth feel and palate. This brew should totally and completely suck by any objective measure, but who’s objective? It actually tastes really good.

MBGSF 2011. Poured light pinkish color and an average fizzy white head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Moderate tart fruit aroma. Light to medium body with with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium tingly berry flavor with a medium berry finish of moderate duration. Complex strange change of pace fruit beer.

You know, this beer keeps changing in complexity. The first few batches were outstanding, with a nice, strawberry aroma. Now, it seem to have too much zing and not as pleasant of a seasonal beer as it had been. No bad, though.

Bottle. A hazy yellow color body with a small fizzy white head , short lasting , lively carbonation. Aroma of light sweet berries with a bit of grass, maybe some dill weed . Flavor is slightly metallic with a bit of wheaty type tang ,strawberries and herbal hops ,pale malt . light body, thin feel, short fruity finish . Drinkable but a little off .

12 oz bottle from Party World on Alpine, Grand Rapids, MI. Cloudy, yellow with small white head. Aroma is gross, just gross with dry grain and a weird sour vegetale note, I can’t imagine that they really put pickles in it but it is slightly vinegary. Vinegar flavor up front with vegetale, grain and some sweeter fruit, like strawberry or other red tropical fruit. Light and watery body. This is bad in so many ways. Ugh... definite drain pour.

12oz Bottle. This smells royally fucked up. When I cracked the bottle, I wasn’t sure if someone had broken a jar of pickled beans on my floor or they were manufacturing styrofoam. Putting the nose dangerously close to the glass, I get a very pungent and acidic mix of pickled vegetables, tending towards Jalapeno, Watermelon, and popcorn. Weird. Pours a clearish hazy gold, with a thin white rim. I’m afraid to drink this. In the mouth, its even worse. Oh god. Did I just drink four day old stale pickled egg juice? Did someone put a cigarette out in this? Or did an old lady die? The description for this beer says, "No one seems to remember if the name, the logo or the recipe came first, but it was ridiculous." Try revolting. Who would make and bottle this? Sulphur, vinegar, and ash. Not beer, really. Oh my god. If there really are pickles in this beer, and I think there are, then, well...that’s just fucked up.

on tap at the brewery...cloudy yellowish body with medium white head..aroma of light sugar and strawberry..hints of wheat in the finish..the strawberry that was ever-present in the nose was more absent in the flavor, emphasizing just subtly its fruit....it tasted more like strawberry leaves than the fruit itself, but was very true to strawberry notes (all natural)..nice summer brew
Bottle. Color golden with medium white head. Aroma grass, grain, malt, some hop. Taste bread, grass, grain, butter.

A bright pale golden coloured beer with a frothy white. A light, fruity hop aroma, a touch floral. Dry mouthfeel. A dry hoppy taste, a touch metallic, zesty and slightly soapy fruit flavour. There is a gont of maltiness in the background. There finish is dry and zesty. Bottle from Globus, Plauen.

Bottle, danke David. Pale green-golden rocky white lacing head, fine carbonation. Fresh citric and grassy hop aroma. Medium light body, surprisingly chewy for the strength, sparkly dry mouthfeel. Good wallop of hops to keep it fresh and exiting. Really nice sessionable light Pils.

Bottle 50cl, from quack-Duck thanks. A clear yellow beer with medium head. Nose is well malty, aroma is low, watery, high carbonation, dusty hops presence, some barley sugar, very low body, near to low alcohol beers.

Frischer Antrunk, das Bier hat durchaus unangenehme Ansätze des Alkoholentzuges, da dieser aber nur teilweise erfolgte, bekommt das Bier nach kurzer unangenehmer Bitterkeit doch noch die Kurve und erhält die anfängliche Frische. Auch die deklarierte Spritzigkeit wird eingehalten. Es mangelt aber an Aromen, neben der Bitterkeit ist höchstens ein leichter Getreideton fassbar. Test vom 19.12.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,8,9,8,9,9 - 9,00
Bottled. A light golden beer with a thin off-white head. The aroma has notes of malt and straw. The flavor is sweet malty with main notes of straw.

Bottled@Björntasting. Pale yellowish golden colour, small white head. Aroma is eggy, vegetably, slightly sweet starchlike notes as well as mild bready malts. Flavour is much the same. Not very pleasant at all...
Bottled. Very pale yellow, small head. Dryish with light body. Lightly grainy with light grassy, spicy hops. Some late bitterness. Fresh and functional low gravity thirst quencher.
Bottle. Clear pale yellow colour with large creamy white mostly diminishing head. Medium malty aroma. Sweet flavor. Watery palate.
Bottle 50 cl. Clear yellow with a dense white head. Lightly malty nose. Light body, light malt accents and a discreet flowery whiff. Finishes dry. Refreshing. 220309

pathetic attempt at some sort of style that just didnt work out...what they tasted was a hoppy beer that happened to be brown...genious...i wont justify this by saying a thing about this beer other than there is no malt...

On tap at GRBC. Deep red body with non-existent head. Light, sweet toasty aroma with earthy hops, but served way too cold to develop properly. The body was bitter with a hollow, thin malt backbone that reminded me of sewage. Sometimes I just don’t understand what the point is...
this is actually worse that most macro beers...overly carbonated water with minimal food coloring..grassy, cereal-based beer that is just fucking disgusting...

On a night of exceptionally bad local craft beers, this one took first place. The appearance was worse than a Budweiser, with the clear straw body featuring messy soda-like fizz, akin to a Vernors Gingerale. To top that off, there was a strange jolly rancher-like artificial sweetener flavor that coated the sour, soapy, watered-down cereal notes. Unimaginably bad. Truly awful. Harrowing, as well.

Cask-conditioned at the Victoria, Clifton Lido, Bristol. Near black stout with a middling, off-white head. Aromas of liquorice and black coffee. Smooth to drink with toasted flavours prominent. Very enjoyable.

Bottle (bought at the brasserie): Clear golden, small creamy, slowly collapsing head, head, shy grainy-dusty nose nose with an also shy medical bitterness; very light bodied, moderate bitter-sweet flavour; traces of seet malt in the grainy-bitter finish. Not unpleasant, but a bit too "slim"......

(bottle, purchased at the brewery) Clear, golden colour with a medium-sized, not very persistent foamy white head. Sweet malty, grainy and slightly buttery nose with a light herbal hoppy touch and a tinge of citrus. Sweet-bitter flavour, light to medium bodied with a well-carbonated, crispy mouthfeel. Initially grainy, slightly fruity (citrus) taste with a touch of butter; medium-dry malt-accented finish with a present herbal hop-character staying in the background. Compared to the very bland and weak Zwickel, this one is much better and has some qualities of a (decent) Bohemian Pils.
Tried at the salutation inn, ham. Orange to Amber colour with a white head. Aroma malty light fruit and a touch of smoke. Taste medium bitter sweet. Light body.

Bottle. Despite being tagged as retired i bought a bottle in March 2017. Quite lively upon opening. Medium head with a bronze appearance. Bitter and quite well balanced. A good but not very exciting session bittter.

Cask at Sandford Park Ale House. Pours brilliantly clear pale amber with a medium, large bubbled off-white head, medium retention with light lacing. Aroma is biscuit malt, faint caramel and toast malt, light earthy and woody hops with apple and pear esters. Flavor is medium hops, moderate bitterness, light crisp malt and a dry finish. Light body and carbonation.

Cask conditioned gravity dispense Lamplighter Northampton 23/08/13. An orange gold coloured beer with a grey wisp of head. A fruity and grassy beer. A good body. Nicely balanced. Presentably drinkable.
Cask at Portculis Bristol. 8th May 2012. OK beer, lacked flavour, a bit dull and not something I would have again

Cask gravity @ The 3rd Stortford Beer Festival, Bishops Stortford CM23. Pours a pale amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty citrus hoppy aroma. Fruity malty citrus hoppy caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty hoppy citrus finish.

Cask at Stortford Beer Festival 2011. An amber beer with a bubbly yellowish head. The aroma has notes of fruit, malt, caramel, and hops. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of fruit on a malty background, leading to a dry and bitter finish. I find it a bit boring.

Cask (gravity) @ The 3rd Stortford Beer Festival, British Legion Club, 28 Windhill, Bishops Stortford , England CM23 2NG. Clear medium amber orange colour with a small to average, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, light to moderate hoppy, citrus, fruity, orange - citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, fruity, soapy, citrus. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110729]

Cask conditioned at The Tunnel Inn, Coates, Gloucs. Gold to amber with white head. Light slightly bittersweet summery beer, quite apricot fruity with a slight caramel background. Easy drinking for a sunny day in the pub garden.
Weak hay, citrus aroma. Pale golden colour with a thin lace. Light beer with a thin body. Weak finish.

Big thanks to ibrew2or3 for this one. Pours golden aroma is very floral with subtle notes ofnhoney coming through. The flavor is earthy and very floral. No honey sweetness here. Subtle oak and a mild tartness. A little thin and watery. May be a little past it’s prime.

Thanks for sharing, iowaherkeye. The body was medium bronze. A sweet aroma was floral with oak and honey. Plenty of booze were also apparent in the nose. The taste was nasty plastic with some wood. The honey is understated with some weird leather. This gets fairly boozy as it warms up. I wanted to like this one more, but this has some rough edges that hopefully will smooth out with age.

Thanks joeyiowacitysuckseye for breaking this out just for me being like "oh yeah that is something I’d like to see opened." Orange gold pour with no head/bubbles. Lots of honey and flower in the aroma. Flavor has honey, flowers, oak, grapes, and a bit of spice (pepper?). Finishes a bit thin. Not very sweet, or dry, or tart. Just middle of the road.

375mL bottle, 2004 from the brewery. Clear honey gold with some legs that did form after a few seconds. Plenty of honey, flower petals, juicy raisins, and white pepper. Flavor was kind of appley with some honey, pepper again, and a fair amount of alcohol in the bone dry finish. My label claims 8.0%, but that makes no sense at all--this is pretty boozy and a mead. Just a hint of tang present, and not terribly sweet, either. Dry finish. Full body. Pretty good mead.
2005. Not as good as the Orange Blossom, but good anyway. Honey and flower aroma that is more complex than the simple flavor, which is on the of a dry mead.

Purchased at the brewery. Pours still clear bold. It has a big big aroma of honey and the odd fusel mixed with mild earthiness. The taste starts thick and sweet as sweet honey attacks the senses. Then mild tropical fruitiness shows up as mild tannins arise and dry out the experience. It leaves a nice honey and faint fruitiness behind with a mild warming sensation.

OSLO and Guerde’s Memorial Weekend Tasting, 5/23/08. Courtesy of OSLO. Gold color. Aroma is a light mixture of clover and wildflower honey. Clover and maple syrup flavors. Light apple and a bit of grape, almost like Pinot Grigo.

Poured from a 375 ml bottle, vintage 2005. Slick clear honey. Powdery, sweet aroma of honey, shaved coconut, lavender, fresh green apples. Vibrant, with a degenerative rub of musty carpet and weird funk. Flavor is a hot, punchy perfume with golden raisins, pineapple, vanilla, and honey. Moments of chalky alcohol and phenolic heat lend some uncomfortable synthetic quality that manages persistence, obnoxiously. Steadfast. Medium body is warm and lightly acidic. Firm sweet finish. A smooth, complex example, but the complexity is a little disjointed and random, lacking the centering, well polished, satiating simplicity that it needs. Thanks Alister!

Sampled at Olso/Guerde’s Memorial Day tasting. A 2005 vintage and shared by Guerde. Pours a clear golden mead with no bubbles and a clean top. Aroma of honey, tart apples, some raisin and a touch of mango. Taste is a little high octane alcohol, tart apples, honey and a touch of floral character. Finish is slightly tart with a flowery aftertaste that slowly disappears.

2005 bottle courtesy Ibrew2or3. Pours a clear still golden. Aroma of alcohol, honey, and green apples. Taste is honey, green apples, golden raisins, and alcohol. Medium thin mouthfeel with smooth alcohol. Very good.

2004 bottle from the brewery, drunk 11/28/15. Clear, soft-apricot-lemon colored body has a fair amount of sediment on the bottom, but it is all left behind. As with many of my old bottles, I’m incredibly regretful of keeping them so long. Was just so irrationally obsessed with aging things but, while a mead can certainly handle some age, fruit can not and it’s utterly stupid to age this thing as long as I did. Thus, there is very little left of the fruit, at this point it’s just soft esters, with some apricot maybe being noticeable? Doubtful though and no way you’d pick it out blind. In its place, a very soft honey character, with light white bread and some peppery phenols. Minor oxidation, no flaws and no alcohol. Again in the flavor, the fruit has all but vanished. It does seem like you get some raspberry and apricot acidity, and maybe some dry, blueberry skin-like character, but again, I’m confident you wouldn’t pick up on this blind. Honey is lightly sweet, with a riesling/gruner character, light vanilla and very, very low carbonation. Still, as it warms and breathes (and sits out over night) it shows a perfectly capable mead whose only flaw is that it was aged 11 years. Very much keeping that in mind with my scoring.

375 ml bottle thanks at Clark VV. 2004 vintage. Clear gold color. Aroma is homey and rotten apricots, maybe a hint of a berry. Flavor has lost something over time. The Apple is here but faded, I don’t get Berry or other fruit. Just old honey, traces its of oxidation. Still somewhat drinkable.

Bottle shared by ClarkVV. Thanks, Clark! 2004 bottle! Pours light orange gold. Still. Aroma is honey, cardboard, earth. This is clearly past its prime, but still drinkable. Peach flavor is still there, honey, and cardboard oxidation.
Poured from bottle thanks ClarkVV 2004 vintage. Golden color with aroma of cinnamon and apples. Taste is faded apples and bitter honey. I am sure this was good years ago.

This is a 2004 vintage from Clark!!!! Thanks man for sharing. This is a golden color...obviously still. The smell is baked apples and cinnamon. This smells stupid good. I’d say the apricot dominates of the listed fruit. There’s a lot of basement mold taste to this, the apple is faded to a very bitter honey. I get a faint blueberry apricot and a little bit of banana. Unique, thin, low-sweetness. I like it.
Honey in color (of course). No head (obviously). Smells like strong sweet honey. Flavor is definitely some moldy honey and old fruit. For how old this is, that’s not surprising.

2004 Vintage

7/28/2007: Kuhnhenn Michigan Mixer Melomel is a still mead that is golden in color. It has nutty sunflower, light raspberry, and some floral blueberry notes in the aroma and flavor. The finish is slightly dry. This mead has a medium+ body and is delicate on the palate. The alcohol is extremely well hidden. Kuhnhenn makes great beer and excellent mead! I want more!

Sample from 375 mL bottle (11.5% ABV) shared at the "Columbus Tasting: Ate, now with gramatical errors" event. Thanks! Rating #6 for this mead...

Second mead I have tasted. Pours a clear light amber color with no head. The aroma is honey (again), floral, light alcohol, and fruity. The flavor is honey, some light spice, peaches, some apple and pear as well, and a touch of alcohol (not quite 11.5% though). A touch on the dry side. This is very easy to drink.

Shared but puddintane. Aroma was of a light fruitiness and sweetness with some floral notes. Flavor was really smooth and a lot light than most other meads ive had. Not alcohol really noticable at all in this one.

Bottle shared by Puddy at C-bus 8. Big thanks to Dave for this treat. Nice golden color with no head. The aroma was very floral with background of sweet honey and apples. Great balanced flavor of flowers, honey and light fruits--pears, apples and some subdued berry tastes. Easy to drink with only a hint of the alcohol. Damn good!

Dark copper color with a thick head of foam. Aroma is light but obvious ginger and a little bit of honey. The ginger comes screaming out in the flavor. Lemongrass is there, but very subdued. Moderately malty and somewhat sweet.
Pale brown color with thin, creamy white head. Fruity nose lost in the fine breeze outside, but the taste is a most excellent ginger and some other spices.

Very fruity aroma on this beer, surprisingly so. The flavour was very sweet, from the honey I guess. Pigfoot hit the ginger right on the ehad as well. This is something I would figure that my wife would like as it is very unobtrusive and tasty.

rass, and some spices. This one employs raspberry blossom honey, ginger, and lemon grass, American malts, American yeast....not sure about the hops. Clear, amber/dark orange color, huge billowing creamy head, intense carbonation in the glass... Ginger hits the nose, first, then the fruit...sweet honey underneath...not much from malt, little if any from hops. Pleasant on the tongue, if unobtrusive...sweetness, well balanced, is in charge...intriquing flavor, but simple interplay on the palate. Could use more something something... A unique combination of ingredients, an unusual and delightful flavor...but lacking in depth, texture, body...quite drinkable, though. A good experiment, sure to find it’s fans...just not sure if I’m one of them. If it had some hops, I’d like it better, I think...without them, this just lies on the tongue, doing nothing..

19th February 2012 On tap at the Rake. Hazy gold beer. Smells of bad eggs. Light palate with maybe some light hops - hard to tell under the bad eggs which pervade the taste as much as the smell. Grim!
cask at the stockbridge tap ... golden yellow ... creamy white head .. light toffee fruit nose ... light sweet lemon and peach hop ... light dry bitter... tasty enough
Cask Handpump at the Smithfield Hotel, Manchester 29/01/2010 Fruit and hop aromas. Clear golden coloured hoppy and fruity with a crisp and slightly dry floral malt finish.
Cask-conditioned at the Royal Oak, Bath 16/07/09. Deeop gold with a slight off-white head. Sweetish malts, some citrus hops and a decent bitter finish. Good.
Cask in the rake. Alround rating: Honey pale malts, perhaps a touch of wheat in the mouthfeel?, citrusy floral hop, touch of mandarin but it has a small dustyness. Drinkable stuff.
Handpump @ The Rake. Gold with a greenish tint and a white head. Pale malt and grassy hops in the nose. Taste has a crisp hop bite, citrus hints and a nice bitter linger. Not bad.

A Mes rate: cask cellar run at the Rake. Clean gold with a pretty impressive white head. Excellent creamy malt aroma topped off with a generous serving of grassy and aromatic hops. The flavour is similar but there is a unwanted meaty note that is really holding it back. Excellent dry grassy hop finish that has really good length. Other than the oily meaty note this is very good indeed. One of the best from Otley.

Cask (handpump) @ The Anchor Inn, Digbeth, Birmingham, England B5. [ As Otley O3 ]. Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy - creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, moderate to light heavy hoppy, grapefruit, lemon. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long to average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. Very nice ;o) (300708)

Cask conditioned at Brecon Beer Festival, Castle Hotel, Brecon, Powys. Pale gold with fullwhite head. It’s not often when going to a beer festival, that the best beer of the day is the last, not the first, so this was pretty dynamic to show above the previous beers. it was beautiful, hoppy throughout, dry,oily and bitter, as fresh as a daisy and, it has to be said, in absolute perfect nick. The finish is juicy and citric and had me quoting from Dylan Thomas, the Welsh poet (and boozer) who i was reading whilst in Wales. My tears are like the quiet drift; Of petals from some magic rose; And all my grief flows from the rift; Of unremembered skies and snows. I think, that if I touched the earth, It would crumble; It is so sad and beautiful, So tremulously like a dream.

Draught half-pint at NERAX on 5/5/07 A very warm-toned honey-orange/yellow body is bright, yielding a medium amount of white head that laces lightly and shows moderate retention. Citric hops in the nose are somewhat muted by a grainy, almost nutty malt character (could be some yeast in there too). Very papery and dry, seemingly a very high attenuation. Lemon and light tangerine break through, with moderate citric bitterness. Not flawed, just too much blandness/paperiness in the nose. Hops are strong up front, leading to very lightly sweet malts that recede quickly, allowing for a strong graininess on the end. What could be a crisp, husky, bite from the lager malts really just seems rather bland, grainy and too dry. Using those malts in beers with low carbonation is very difficult, because the carbonation adds back the body and balance that those malts need (one reason why they work so well in lagers). Schiehallion (cask lager) seems to have similar problems. Don’t need to cut it out entirely, but it needs a high proportion of pils malt or an English pale malt.

9th Aug 2018, on-tap 0.5 litre glass, at a random Schnell Imbiss in Quedlinburg sat in the afternoon sunshine. Golden pour, fast fading white topping. The nose had a malty front with a light floral note or two, taste also malty/grainy with a little grass/floral twist from the hops that also gave a balanced bitterness. OK for a cheap Pilsner.
An ok German pilsener. Yellow coloured and clear. Has a white head, medium duration. Malty aroma, notes of corn. Flavor starts sweet, moderate bitter finish.
Goldgelbes Bier mit ordentlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch hopfig, grasig, Citrus, blumig. Geschmack metallisch, grasig, hopfig.
Ordentliches Pilsner mit einer milden Bitterkeit und einer ebenso angenehmen Süffigkeit. Etwas an Malz mit ein bisschen Vanille und Butter. Ganz ok.

Pours out of the bottle in a clear light golden colour with low airy head and medium body. Aroma of mild hops and grass. Taste of mild hops, rye, grains, bread, grass and citrus. Easy to drink and refreshing. Not bad.
Goldiges Pils mit schöner Blume. Grasiges Hopfenaroma. Süßlich-malziger Antrunk der schnell vom herben Hopfennachgeschmack verdrängt wird. Das Premium aus gleichem Hause hat mehr Würze.
Draught at BBF12. No aroma. Clear shiny yellow colour. Small white head. Good malty flavour. Refreshing citric hop note. Good bitterness, very clean and not rough. Nicely biscuity roundoff.
Bottle. Blonde. Soft hat-like aroma. Hay-like hopbitter flavor, with a shy malt character. Almost medium bodied. Well hopped and well balanced pilsener.
Draught. Medium gold with a thin head. Flavour of malt and veg. Flavour is sweet malt with a lift butter base. Medium carbonation

So nun die "normale" Variante, kein Premium Zusatz zu erkennen. Dafür der Hinweis "Sie haben ein hervorragendes Pils ausgesucht!". Süßlicher Antrunk, herber Mittlteil mit leicht malzigem Ton, etwas getreidig. Im Nachgeschmack, wie auch schon im Mittelteil sehr hopfig, dazu leicht malzig und süß. Ist dem Premium Pils sehr ähnlich! Test vom 13.1.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,9,9,9,12,9 - 9,15

On tap at the brewery. Poured a Medium-light copper, fairly hazy with minimal head that dissipated fairly quickly. Aroma of lightly toasted bread and slight metallicness. Tastes like a light dunkelweizen. No strong bready flavors, nor strong typical wheat beer flavors. Fairly light bodied with a dry finish. Yeasty flavor dominates the finish, but not bready. This is an unoffensive dunkelweizen, however it does not display any outstanding qualities. The yeast is not as upfront as others nor does it take on any roasty or darker malt-type flavors. Poured quite a bit lighter than most and it was not only an indicator of overall flavor, but it was also a clue to the lack of complexity. Average at best unless it was an interpretation of the style...i.e. American style wheat beer.
Very similiar to the their Hefe, a little more of a roasted presence. Awfully thin with very little malt pressence. Not much bitterness to speak of and not much citrus sour either. Plain.

column1: Grand Teton Au Naturale (Organic Blonde Ale)
column5: From Feb 2007 Pours from 12oz sampler bottle(room Temp) a clear light gold with a small head of foam that reduces to a fine broken layer with some lacing. The smell is a delicate nose of hops with some malt sweetness barely noticeable. The taste is also delicate when it comes to the hops and malt. The malt doesn't impart any sweetness however and the hops are not bitter in the way I like the bitterness to taste. Strange tasting brew. I'd say the dominant flavour that hits my palate is grain...Thank goodness the finish is pretty clean. I'm always excited when I get to try a new offering from Grand Teton but...this one is just too ordinary and uninspiring. Maybe "Organic" Ale is not the way to go? Bottom line: I'm glad I got to try this one but I won't be buying any when it hits the retail market.

column1: Grand Teton Au Naturale (Organic Blonde Ale)
column5: 1/2" white head dies quickly leaving behind a little lacing atop a clear straw gold brew. Aroma is little more than husky pale malts... and quite a bit of yeasty fruitiness. Flavor mirrors the aroma but with bubbles. Pale malts and a sorta lingering pale malt finish. Little hop flavor or bitterness.

column1: Grand Teton Au Naturale (Organic Blonde Ale)
column5: "a light beer that distinguishes itself, just a little, from the pack. a delecate malty sweetness and hop aroma is there, as well as a slightly sweet, slightly citrus flavor. not bad, nothing special."

column1: Grand Teton Au Naturale (Organic Blonde Ale)
column5: Not a very good blonde. The expected citrus is there, but it is diluted by an unnecessary malty sweetness and a strange rotten vegetable taste. Appearance is nice and the smooth palate is suitable.

column1: Grand Teton Au Naturale (Organic Blonde Ale)
column5: bottled, pours cloudy gold with a minimal white head. aromas of grass and hay. on the tongue it is a bit tinny and metalic. slightly sweet and sour, finishes flat and unassuming. not one of GTBC better options.

column1: Grand Teton Au Naturale (Organic Blonde Ale)
column5: Cloudy orange-yellow, white head. Pleasant sweet malt aroma. Taste: Sweet bready, fruity, malty, toffee, sweet corn, cream corn and some grassy hops. A bit unbalanced. Ehh, this is ok, but wouldn’t buy again.

column1: Grand Teton Au Naturale (Organic Blonde Ale)
column5: Old bottle found while doing some cellar cleaning and rearranging. Pours a fairly clear golden orange with a sizable beiged white head. Old paper, degraded toast and a bit of sweetness. Definitely smells old. Strange coconut note as well. Sweet and dull, lots of age and old paper and malt flavors. Not good anymore. Odd bitterness and vegetal flavors creeping in. Dumped.

column1: Grand Teton Au Naturale (Organic Blonde Ale)
column5: Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty weak grainy aroma with some weak hoppy hints. Sweetish malty grainy caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy finish.

column1: Grand Teton Au Naturale (Organic Blonde Ale)
column5: Pours amber with a thin white head and some lacing. Notes of sweet dough and apples. Balanced taste, though a bit on the sweet side. Crisp and sessionable.

column1: Grand Teton Au Naturale (Organic Blonde Ale)
column5: Cloudy copper with a white head. Yeasty, grape like smell. Light bodied, smooth, malty, with a touch of bitterness to it. A decent session beer.

Aroma: Medium sweet, banana. Medium-light vanilla, banana peel. Appearance: Hazy, dark straw body. Large white head. Small bubbles. Good retention. Flavour: Medium clove, banana, vanilla. Low bitterness. Medium-light bready sweetness, banana peel. Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium carbonation, creamy, smooth. Slight bite, crispness. Overall: There is a crispness that is not to style, otherwise well balanced and quite pleasant. 500 ml can, roused, poured. 10A. Weissbier
Blik 50cl thuis. Vlak, weinig spannend. Beetje zoet, beetje tarwe, blijft een beetje. (3-2013).

Draft at St. Matthews brewpub. Poured clear golden color with medium white fizzy head that diminished slowly with fair lacing. Medium balanced aroma. Medium body with light carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable brew.

This one managed to gush all over Stew’s kitchen so we only ended up with about half a bottle. I wonder what you’d think if that happened after you shelled out $75 for a bottle... Anyway I thought this smelled really good. Just like the Framboise Froment with the intense jammy raspberry character and not much else. It seemed to carry the flavour of the seeds through too. The whole jammy, cooked element makes me think they’ve used extract (at least in part) but I could well be wrong. There’s not much else in the aroma, but the flavour has loads of meaty, salty, Vegemite/Marmite flavours which aren’t good at all. Stressed fermentation? Too long sitting on the yeast? I dunno, but it’s not good. Raspberry flavour is pushed into the background, but it remains nice. Malt character is all muddled and marred by the yeasty stuff. Damn. I was really excited to try this, but it was a bit of a letdown. I quite like the concept though, if they sort out the fermentation or whatever it is I think they’ll be on a winner.

Thin caramel head with a blood tinge. Darkish brown in colour with a cherry hue. Sweet nose, intense early, but settles quickly. Sweet fruits to taste with a weird hard, bitter edge. Can’t quite place my finger on it. Stinky fruit notes on the finish have some appeal. I hope this ain’t the $75 beer...oh dear!

Bottle 330ml (at the Redoak). Labelled as ‘Redoak Ice Breaker’. Served at cellar temperature. Pours a hazy dark brown. Head is small, lightly tanned quickly dissipates. Aroma is extremely rich and malty with notes of muscat soaked fruit cake, muscatels, caramelized dates, burnt toffee, chocolate and toasted raisin bread. Flavour is exceptionally smooth, with virtually no bitterness at all; toasted malts, burnt toffee, caramelized dates, sultana’s, muscat, rum and raisin chocolate and notes of earthy oak in the finish. Full bodied with very light carbonation, a slightly syrupy texture and a good length finish. Remarkably well balanced and smooth giving the ABV.

(bottle, many thanks to karin for this gem!) clear deep ruby colour with a creamy beige head. aroma of heavy bread dough and hazelnuts, with some big notes of marzipan, cherry syrup, milk chocolate, fudge, sugar icing and cornflakes. flavour is mostly brown sugar, fudge and yeast, not too sweet, with a hint of bubble gum, dried grapes and just a touch of alcohol in the light-bitter walnut finish. heavy-bodied with soft carbonation. impressive!

16-Feb-11 (250-ml sample bottle: Free bottle for stewarding the 2008 World Beer Cup in San Diego, CA) This eisbock is not nearly as sweet as other examples I’ve tried, and it shows greater complexity and balance. This is wonderfully malty, caramely and toasty, with a deliciously rich, melanoidin character, plus dark fruits such as figs and prunes, a modest vinous layer, toffee, molasses, and a terrific woodsy earthiness for superb contrast. An important key to this eisbock is that the sweetness is kept under control, and thus, the beer is very drinkable. The nose offers aromas of rich maltiness, decayed wood, earth, prunes, dried figs and apricots, toffee, and cocoa. It’s full bodied and rich on the palate, somewhat sticky, but also has a mild streak of earthy acidity in it, so the beer is never cloying. Carbonation is very light, so this is getting close to being still, but there is a mild layer of acidity running throughout, and this makes up for the low carbonation. The 14% alcohol is exceptionally well hidden; I can’t taste or smell the alcohol, nor is there any sensations in the mouth or throat related to higher alcohol levels. Ruddy brown in color and fairly hazy in appearance, the beer pours a thin sheet of tan-colored head that dissipates quickly to a thin ring. Overall, a very delicious and wonderfully crafted beer, one to savor for as long as your will power holds out. What a treat!

At the Café. Found these notes in a jacket, must’ve been from a few years back. Tawny body, white collar, visible legs. Vinous nose; sherry, muscat, brown sugar, mollasses, sultanas, caramel, oak, obvious alcohol. Incredibly rich body, almost fortified wine-like, low carbonation, syrup texture with slight gritty dryness. Amazingly rich body; sweet caramel, dark brown sugar, sherry and muscat overtones, oak and sultanas in the background, red-wine like nuances (dark berries) as it warms. Dry somewhat tannic finish with nice warming alcohol. Costs an arm and a leg, but a very tasty treat indeed. One of those styles that feels like you’re not drinking beer at all, this could be well on-par with Redoaks Reserve.

A heavily alcoholic eisbock without the frame to carry its 14% abv. To be fair, this was sampled in some spectacular company - I’m not just talking about Sully, Bridge, Linc, TimE and co - and probably suffered in comparison. It was succeeded by stunners like Millennium, Abyss and Hitachino Nest Espresso Stout - and there aren’t many beers that can live in that company. Redoak’s eisbock was a burnished teak colour, basically still, with the merest hint of a corona. Slick, oily body. Rich burnt sugars in the aroma, with strong woody notes and figs. Huge mouth-tingling surge of alcohol without enough malt/hops to balance it. Cherries, demorara sugar and raisins, but overwhelmed by rummy alcohol. I like "big" beers but this seemed crude and unbalanced compared to the Special Reserve or their strong porters. (Bottle courtesy of Linc at Sully’s Sydney RB Xmas 07 gathering. Thanks fellas.)

Bottle at the Redoak (250ml). I had high expectations for this one given the large alcohol content and I was not disappointed. Poured a deep muddy brown with virtually no head, it was very thick and looked more like motor oil coming out of the bottle rather than beer. Aroma was intense with the alcohol content present on the nose; caramelized dates and vanilla with a touch of port, sweet caramel, sticky toffee, some tart blackberries and a touch of sultanas and licorice. Flavor was fantastic and intensely complex; richly caramelized with sticky whisky notes, some prunes, vanilla, sweet toffee, burnt dates, moderate alcohol and a lightly warming finish. Full bodied with soft carbonation, a syrupy texture, sticky mouthfeel and a everlasting finish. For me this is the best brew I have had to date from the Redoak, I prefer it over the Old Baltic porter, but at $35 for 250ml’s I don’t think I will be having another any time soon.

I didn’t realize until I went on RB that this puppy measured in at 14%. I must say that it seemed much lighter. I found this Eisbock didn’t have the cloying sweetness that I find in others and still managed to have the depth of molassess, milk chocolate, caramel, brown sugar, cherries and oranges. It finishes warming with lingering brown sugar notes. Very nice.

In between the St Nick (too flat) and the Framboise Reserve (too fizzy) was this one which was just right! It shares that same dry biscuity malt flavour with the St Nick, whilst a salty palate and strong but clean alcohol give the impression of Scotch. The malt character especially is quite mellow, and definitely not fresh or vibrant. It’s not too sweet which is a major advantage when it comes to beers like this, but Eisbocks need LOTS of malt for mine, and this doesn’t deliver it. There’s really not enough going on in terms of flavour to justify the monstrous alcohol content. That said, it was a pretty enjoyable, if not memorable, experience. Good on em for doing Australia’s first (?) Eisbock.

Cola appearance with a very thin head. Massive, yeasty dirty nose, vegemite, complex...good. Alcohol laden palate with heat and licorice. Quite smooth and carries th 14% with incredible ease. Good fun.
nice reddish pink color some slight head had this one a while back so going on memory. flavor was sweet but not nast some real cherry but a little cough syrup flavor.. ok
Tap @ Brewpub. Smells like cherry Kool-aid, cloudy red/orange, zero head. Tastes like cherry Kool-aid, light bodied,not overly sour/sweet, or much of anything else. Poor.

[332-20070609] Tap @ Mill St. (Toronto, ON). Cherry fruit punch aroma. Very hazy, light red amber body with white bubbles instead of a head. Flavour is like a tangy fruit punch of cherry orange and hints of other citrus. Medium body is fairly smooth. Not very beer-like at all but nicely blended as it packs a sly alcohol punch.

Draught pint at the brewpub. Distinct reddish tinge to the colour and a fairly still body with very little head. The aroma and flavour are both sweet, but not cloying, with a good balance of slightly fruity malt and fresh cherry. Mellow hops in the finish - enough to be briefly noticeable, but not enough to seriously interfere with the primary malt and cherry characteristics. Enjoyable, if somewhat uneventful.

On tap at Brewpub, sold as Cherry Fruit Beer Appearance: colour of pomegranate juice, orange, copper-ruby overtones. Thick haze small bright ring on top. Aroma: plain sweet, fruity juice like. Light hints of black tea, hints of tobacco (cherry pits?) Medium bodied, sweet fruity character. Surprisingly juicy. Sticky, sweet cherry. Refreshing summer brew. A bit like fruit tea like. Cherry Fruit Beer suits this brew much more than Kriek listed previously.

Hazy, amber body with a light pink hue throughout the body. Small white head. Sweet candyish cherry aroma. Flavour is dominated by cherry, very sweet with light malt undertones. Slightly more full than average palate. Decent, mainstream fruit beer. Definitely not a Kriek.
Thick head. Brown beer. Not getting much scent. Good body. Dry delicate chocolate. Some fruit and then hops. very drinkable and smooth.

My Bottom Line: This complex Porter exhibits roastiness and molasses developing chocolatey and fruity side flavors. The balancing earthy hop finish lingers nicely, yet the overall effect is less than the sum of its parts. Further Personal Perceptions: -A creamy head decorates the darkest brown. -Vanilla adds more depth to the already layered maltiness. -The body is lean and active, yet I was expecting more from an anniversary selection. -The bottled version was a faithful rendition of the tapped. On tap at The Aldgate, and later from the bottle.

Molasses in color with a small tan head. Roasted malts, milk chocolate, vanilla fill out the aroma. Solid, but could be stronger. Very tasty. Milky chocolate, lightly roasted malts, vanilla, and bittersweet coffee. Finishes with some sweetness and bitter maltiness. Medium, properly carbonated body. A very enjoyable porter. Different and delicious.

Light brown color, thick ivory white head. Very sweet milk chocolate, lactose, vanilla, caccao nose. The theme continues in the mouth and almost is cloying, but just stops short. Lasting caccao, sweet vanilla finish. Very different, but very tasty. This was like no porter I have tried before.

It is the best non alcoholic beer I have ever drink. Very attractive design, good taste, hoppy flavour, nice color and stable foam. You can drink too much without worry about your fitness. It is low calorie less than 15kcal/100ml. Cheers!
Gravity Cask @ Waterloo Arms Beer Festival. Light colour. Mild hoppy aroma. Slightly stale malt. Fruity citric hops becoming more pronounced in the mouth and make up for the poor malt flavours.
On tap at BeerFes Osaka 2019. Dark fruit nose. Medium copper/orange color, thin off-white head. Mild fruity initial flavor, raisin, tree bark spice, touch of scratchy hops, thins out quickly.
Tap @ Kura Kura Ji-Beer House, Tokyo. Orange brown, reasonable head. Mild grain aroma. Orange biscuit malt flavour. Sharp with bitter citrus aftertaste. Decent but not outstanding pale ale.

Tap at Popeye. Golden amber colour, not much head. Aroma is lightly fruity, berries, solid sweet maltiness. Taste is grainy, some citrus hops, biscuity malt, quite fruity, quite dry. Solid if unexciting.

Draught at Popeye, Tokyo. Lightly hazy deep golden, small head. Aroma of tangerine and winegum. Fairly sweet with rounded mouthfeel. Light to medium bodied with caramelly malt and a bit of peach. Rather low bitterness.

Clear copper with a wimpy head. Light malts and then nothing in the aroma. Flavor is sadly the same as the aroma. Not bad, just boring as it gets. I actually forgot I drank this until I went through my notes- and I only had three pints that night.
On tap at Popeye. Light, very hoppy aroma. Light copper color. Very light malt flavor, hops predominate. Fragrant, fruity, bitter hops. Clean and crisp, but not enough malt for me. Great hops though.

My Bottom Line: This modest English Pale Ale’s orangey hoppiness spices up the lightly honeyed maltiness which is barely able to ride the soft prickling of carbonation. Further Personal Perceptions: -A ring of foam tops the clear pale orange-hued copper. -The orangey, leafy hoppiness dominates the flavor profile while being far from assertive. -The hermetic nose is thankfully not imitated by the talkative flavor profile. -Maltiness needs to be bulked up for balance to be achieved and pleasure to be increased. On tap at Popeye’s.

Apparently Preston is a brewpub in a mall in Tochigi prefecture Japan. Very small outfit with a funny name. The beer itself was a golden amber color and had a soft hoppy nose of apples and oranges. Soft hoppy body of orange and apples and just a touch of lime. Mildly bitter hoppy finish. Pleasent.
Small white head. Light brown body. Light tropical fruit hop taste with very mild mouthfeel. Apple notes. No real aftertaste. Simple. but nice. (0.25l on cask at Popeye.)
Very nice creamy light beer.as useally for british beer is not to strong. IPA have few other good beer to try

Draught pint at Fenway location on 5/5/07 Deep caramel-tinted brass with a full, off-white head that is quite dense and fairly creamy. Strong retention, with light lacing. Everyone often talks about how "dank" some IPAs and DIPAs smell and it’s true that hops are in the same family, but I’ve never really smelled too much a similarity...until this one. Don’t know what they used, but it was incredible! Not huge and in your face, nor even resinous and sticky. Just rather fuzzy and lightly dry, but with that distinct marajuana-like smell. Fruitiness comes on afterwards, with some light cherries and oranges and a smattering of tropical fruits. Huge burst of pine and citrus bitterness on the end is actually somewhat balanced by the strong maltiness. But it’s not hard/crystally maltiness, more of a soft, sweet, pale maltiness with some moderate caramel. No alcohol noted, no flaws, very high strength of aroma. Very bitter in the flavor, and quite dry, though there is a strong malt backbone. It really lets the hops go to work and an almost "fuzzy" feeling is left on the palate, I suppose it must be the hop resin. Leafy, slightly fruity and just full of wintergreen, pine and white grapefruit. Not a big IPA fan, but this one was quite good. Gravity could definitely be felt, though, and there was a fair bit of stickiness (residual sugar) on the finish, with some alcohol dryness (but no alcohol flavor). No flaws. Medium carbonation.

Draft sample. Poured clear golden to yellow color with an average creamy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate yeast, spice and sweet citrus aroma. Medium body with a light sticky texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet spice finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.
Sampled on our Great Lakes beer tour. Flavor is an orange, coriander and clove potpourri. Light aroma of oranges. Golden color, refreshing.
Clear pale pour thin white head and spotty lace. Spicy aroma. Similar flavor profile. Meh

Maybe this is another example where I love the style so much I’m rating it higher than most, but I thought this was a very good take on a Belgium wit and quite unique. Pours lightly hazy yellow with a small white head. The aroma has lots of sharp lemony citrus, bits of sweet orange, some some and a bit of chalk. Medium / thin crisp body with lots and lots of sharp carbonation that somehow works with the flavors. Starts with lots of lemony citrus, sharp wheat, some grapefruit and a little soapiness. This is extra tart for the style. The finish is clean, tart and short. Overall a very nice beer that I will get again if possible.
Thanks to BBB63 for this one. It pours a hazy straw yellow with a quiclydisappering head. It’s tangy sweet and thirst quenching

Bottle thanks to BBB63. Poured a clear bright golden with a quickly-receding cap of white head. Aroma was very heavy on the coriander with some nutmeg and orange peel behind.. very well-spiced.. odd vegetal sweetness emerges when you dig past the spicage. Flavor was very spicy, adding white pepper to the aforementioned spices.. sweet wheaty notes in the background. Not too good a balance between the sweet and spicy aspects and a bit watery on the palate.

Thanks BBB63. The beer pours to a thin mead-like plastic light-yellow/clear body with a thin white head. The aroma is butterscotch laden with some coriander too. The flavor is heavily spiced with coriander and sweet pale malts and light butterscotch. Average palate. The butterscotch distracts me significantly.

On tap at the brewpub. Pale yellow with some white head, but that damn thing way clear! There is an overwhelming perfume aroma. Pretty much the samething in the flavor. It tasted like flower pedals. A pretty heffty mouthfeel. Not all that good.

On tap at Mishawaka. Served in a pint glass. Pours a golden/orange with a minimal white head. Aromas of lemon, wheat and coriander. Flavor is light citrus with a good dose of coriander and spice. Mouthfeel is light and watery with weak carbonation. A light and refreshing summer brew.

Bottle and served in my Hoegaarden tumbler: Clean golden hue with a fizzy fading head and minimal spotted lace. The aroma has notes of cardamom, coriander, anise, orange zest, lime leaves, biscuity malt, American wheat and yeasts esters. The taste is moderately spiced with a nice amount of acidity and tart fruits. Just a hint of diacetyl but nothing to stand in the way. A wheat and pale malt driven base adds support to the spices. The mouth feel is refreshing enough for a summer brew and the acidic nature cleans the palate nicely, could be a touch more carbonated however. A very workman like beer, not quite session due to the ABV but enjoyable.

Draught pint at Fenway on 5/5/07 and again on 5/12/07 Glassy, light-peach colored ale is very soft on the eyes. White head is medium to small and recedes to cover readily. Moderate lacing left behind. Amazing...sake-like nose displays very similar qualities and is chalk full of esters. Peach, pear, golden apple and a very soft, leafy, but slightly juicy hoppiness sits on the back-end. Malts are quite attenuated and leave only a trace of honey and light whitebread. Almost smells like wildflowers on the end, it’s that soft. Rice adds a dry, almost papery-like quality. Medium to medium-high strengtht, no flaws. The only part I didnt like in the flavor was the dryness/paperiness that the rice produces. If this was just an all-malt beer, it might have been that much softer on the palate and given it a more supple malt feel. Mouthfeel aside, the flavors were terrific. Fruity and lightly spicy, the hops added pleasant bitterness and lots of green, leafy, almost lush, floral notes. Apples, peaches and pears build up, but the crisp rice and base malt finish helps cleanse the palate (so the rice may not be so bad afterall). No trace of alcohol or flaws. They have some really experimental things coming out of this brewery once every blue moon. This was a grand success in my book. Very drinkable and enjoyable.

This Belgian is real spiced up. Packs a punch that leaves that warm tingle in your stomach. Pours a nice bubbly golden tinge. Incredibly pleasing aroma for the first few tastes. Towards the bottom I became rather uninterested. Great to see such class produced in Salem, MA.

On draft at Fenway Park location. A clear light gold with puny head. Brewed in celebration of the Canal St. location’s sixth anniversary. Faintly sweet nose. Ripples of flavor include bubblegum, citrus, and melon. Flavor ends on a high note of hops and malt sweetness.

Sample at Beer Works Fenway: This beer pours a clear golden color with a thin ivory head that disappears quickly. S[ptty lacing. The aroma is floral hops and yeast, with touches of fruit. Light body with a floral character and mild hops and toasted malt flavor. Light yeast is present too. The finish is lightly yeasty with a slight peppery hops finish. Slightly above average overall.

Draught snifter at Fenway on 5/25/07 It seems like at least every other time I’m at BW, they’ve got a Belgian golden ale on tap and every time it’s a different name. I havent entered them all and I just fail to believe that they are changing the recipes that significantly each time. I see that this one is quite a bit higher in abv though, so why not... Fluffy white head is fairly persistent, but leaves only minor lacing. Mostly clear, deep gold body with moderate carbonation. About as standard and by-the-numbers BSGA as I can recall. Good enough interpretation of Duvel, but without the richness of malt, yeast intricacy and expressive carbonation of that one. It’s clean enough, but there’s a fair amount of acid on the finish, which also seems to have some problems with wateriness. Sweet, honey-like sugars build up with light toasted notes, resulting in a soft, somewhat malty mouthfeel (though the wateriness is evident). Light, grassy/flowery hops and just your basic yellow fruit esters with light phenolics. Alcohol well-contained.

(Canal Street) Crystal clear straw body with off-white head. Aroma is fairly mild, medium sweet, candi sugar, cardamom. Taste is moderately sweet, Belgian yeast, some cardamom, alcohol. Medium-full body, some stickiness.

Tap at the Canal Street location - served in a tulip glass, which is the first time I’ve seen a beer served here in other than a pint glass (and I’ve had the Herc and Double IPA) - perfectly clear golden pour, with minimal head - served way too cold - bright, floral, fruity aroma, with some candi sugar sweetness - very light and crisp - minimal sweetness, with no apparent alcohol - mild herbal and floral qualities, with some spice on the back of the tongue - finishes with light belgian yeast flavors - a bit thin, but refreshing for a strong ale.
Tap at brewpub. Dark cherry syrup, pepper and malt aroma. Dark amber with a small head. Tart cherry syrup and molasses malt flavor. A great unique beer combining dark lager and fruit flavors.

As Lach says, this doesn’t seem a million miles removed from the Framboise Froment and certainly not by enough to justify the difference in price. It’s a clean, decent sipper but there’s not enough complexity here to rank it any higher. Cloudy pink with an excitable head. Soft raspberry aroma - tart but restrained. Lean, champagne-like body. Fruit acids. Dry finish. (Bottle courtesy of Linc at Sully’s 2007 RB Xmas gathering. Thanks fellas.)

Clear, bright pink color. The nose to me back to picking freshing raspberries out of my grandparent’s garden and soaking them in water over the sink, this time though there was a touch of caramel in there. Superb. Light, acidic raspberry mouth that is very enjoyable. This is heading towards lambic territory, but then pulls back on sourness. Mouth feel is at times somewhat creamy. Chalky, raspberry finish. Very enjoyable.

The cork was in terrible shape. It was missing significant chunks and came apart on opening. Lovely looking beer though, vivid clear pink with a decent thin head. Loads of lovely fresh raspberry aroma with a significant seed character and a touch of volatile acid. Not much else is evident - it’s really hard to get a feel for the base beer at all. Very dry, with light raspberry flavour and subtle acid. Nice stuff - clean, light and dry, but there’s just not a great deal going on. And I’m still not convinced this is different to the Framboise Froment.

column1: Isle of Skye Lord of the Ales
column5: Cask at the Standing Order. Pours dark copper red, nose and taste are light citrus, sweet toffee.

column1: Isle of Skye Lord of the Ales
column5: Cask @ The Counting House JDW. Amber brown colour, good foamy head. Oaty malt aroma. Citrus toffee malt flavour. Bitter aftertaste. Big standard British bitter.

column1: Isle of Skye Lord of the Ales
column5: Cask by handpump at Cumberland Bar, Edinburgh (27 Mar 12) - clear deep golden ale, thin off-white head, barley / wheat malt aroma, caramel, good temperature, sharp taste, sour aftertaste

column1: Isle of Skye Lord of the Ales
column5: Cask at Prince of Wales, Aberdeen (great condition as usual). It pours dark amber, with a thin foamy white head. The nose is leather, fruit cake, raisin, plum, varnish and brandy. The taste is wood, raisin, plum, date, red grape, leather, smoke and wood polish, with a dry finish. It has a light to medium body and soft carbonation. Looking at the pervious reviews you would think this is terrible, but I thought it was really good. I even went back for another!

column1: Isle of Skye Lord of the Ales
column5: Copper colour. The aroma is fruity, but maybe with some sulphur as well. Thin and a bit sewagey. Really not on - something amiss here.

column1: Isle of Skye Lord of the Ales
column5: @ Blue Blazer. Dark coppery-red and clear. Aroma is tainted with non-acetone polish remover and glue. The yeasty flavors are quite annoying as well but not as offensive as the aromas. Sweet strawberry notes and sourdough. Not in its best form, I imagine.

column1: Isle of Skye Lord of the Ales
column5: Light amber in colour, citrus hop nose with a light fruity flavour with lots of hop bitterness.

column1: Isle of Skye Lord of the Ales
column5: VEyr good, but too bitte,r after a while, it is not at all refreshing. Good foam too.

column1: Isle of Skye Lord of the Ales
column5: Half pint pulled at the Halfway House in Ed\inburgh, a clear copper with a slightly tan head that laced a little down the glass. An interesting yeasty/malt aroma with a little spice. A tanginess in the background, but smooth overall, with a malt flavour with a little bit of orange coming through.
Cask Handpump at the Cask & Cutler, Sheffield 23/06/2007 Floral and hop aromas. Golden coloured and hoppy with a crisp and slightly bitter lasting malt finish.

Cask at the Hobgoblin, Reading, Berkshire. West Berkshire’s beer of the month for June.Golden colour with a trace of white head; grassy hop aroma; orange and caramel flavours; and a rounded bitter finish. Pleasant but not outstanding.

A: Amber Hue, Passes Most Light, Mild White Head Ring, Mild Lacing S: Caramel, Toffee, Malts T: Caramel, Sweet Malts M: Average Carbonation, Light to Medium Bodied, Mildly Sweet Overall, an average Maibock without any real memorable flavor.

Draught pint at Fenway on 5/5/07 Very light peach-golden beer with a slight rusty-orange tint. Large white head quickly recedes to cover, providing little lacing. Clear. Strong honey and munich-like malts combine to give a sweet-and-sour effect in the nose, with a bit of latent corn and very soft, grassy and earthy hops providing some much needed softness. Seemingly quite dry, without much lager yeast crispness, but the sourdough-like character persists on the finish. Medium strength of aroma, no real flaws, no alcohol. Sweet, somewhat simple, maltiness is full of honey dough and a bit of munich-like sourness. Lots of water in the beer (because it’s during the Red Sox’ season), diluting the flavor, but it’s still passable and clean, despite being neither hoppy, nor overly malty. Some bland, papery, almost tannic notes sit on the end and it never gains any real richness that you would expect from a bock. Somewhat of a washed out texture, with prickly, yet loose, carbonation. No alcohol noted.
Cask, Griffin, Carlisle. Fresh tasting, with a flowery, apple-like aroma. Pale gold appearance, clean, light taste.
Light amber coloured ale, almost no nose, wattery grassy flowery light citric hop.

Pours a darkish yellow/ light orange with a small white and bubbly head. Aroma is sweet and hoppy. Hops are there but there is a weird sweetness that is awful, it almost smells like sunscreen. Truly rough. Taste is pretty sweet upfront almost like alcoholic corn syrup. Very strange one indeed and will not be buying again.
Not that bad, but had better beers from kirin. Nothing special. Not much smell and not many taste

wow! it did not smell good--the nose is like bad rum and old shoes; egg flavor, thick and oily feel; unimpressive, soapy head; this needs a dish, and not strictly a beer drinker to consume it; not for me.
Can from MS. Color yellow, thin white head. Aroma sour, some cereals. Taste grassy, watery. Bad.
Clear golden with a tiny white head. Sweet malty aroma with hints of fruit. Sweet malty flavour with fruity and yeasty notes. Finished sweet.
50 cL can, courtesy of KimJohansen. Pours almost clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is dry malty and light hoppy. Mild spiced and carboardish with a light grassy note. Dry finish.
Canned. golden coloured. clear. Dense white head. Aroma of sweetness and fruits, light earth. Flavour of fruits and spice. Thin bodied. Dry fruity end.
Can. A golden beer with a lazing off-white head. The aroma has notes of malt, straw and a bit of hay. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, straw, leading to a dry finish.
Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of KimJohansen. Pours a cear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet malt and brewing cereal. Medium body, brewing cereal and a dry and hoppy finish. 080210

Smells like a very piss-poor lager in a can, which I say confidently after sampling way too many piss-poor lagers in a can: tinniness, some corn starch, watery stench like smelling grass that’s been freshly urinated upon. And I’ll assume it looks like a crappy lager as there’s no place to pour it on this chunnel train. Its saving grace is a very average taste with bready notes, some hops, and a slightly dry finish. But it doesn’t taste Belgian by any stretch. A poor showing all around. Avoid this "imported Belgian".

500ml can from a M&S store in Earls Court. Straw-yellow content with fragile lacework on the glass. A bit of cowshed to the nose. Sweet flavour of lime with papery notes. Fizzy carbonated. Very much in the direction of a soft drink (03.08.2009).
Sweet grainy aroma. Pale amber, Little head. Very weak malty and hoppy flavour. Watery. Finishes dry. Not to my taste.

Can, bought @ M&S, Edinburgh. Pours very pale golden with a small, frothy, white head. Aroma is super sweet, maize and brewing cereal. Medium carbonation, rather thin and watery. Very little flavour. Light grainy, sweet maize, some brewing cereal. Citric finish. Not good.
Golden hue. Vegetable aroma with notes of stale beer, banana and wet clothes. Vanilla flavour with notes of fruits and some sweetness. Decent bitterness.

Summer Edition. Golden with a nice head. The aroma is mild with a light sweetness and light notes of malt and caramel. The flavour has a light sweetness, notes of malt, caramel and no bitterness at all. It’s mild and easy to drink - and totally without any challenges.
Can. Pours a clear golden color with a white head. Sweetish malty grassy aroma. Sweet malty grainy flavor with some grassy hints. Sweetish malty finish.

Can. "Summer Edition". Clear golden with a very short lasting white head. No lacing. Bit sweet, yeasty, sour and metallic aroma. Thin, yeasty and sweetish sourish flavour with wet hay. Baaaad. Bit dry sour yeasty finish.
[b]Can[/b] Pale golden with a fluffy head. Sweet aroma. Thin and metallic flavour with notes of over cooked peas. Faint grassy flavour. Crap beer.
Can at home - shared with Mette & Jacob. Cear yellow - white head. Candlewax, white bread, thin & Boring. No BBQ, brown sugar or smoke !!!

Canned. Clear golden, rich head. Metallic nose. Sweet and unpleasantly fruity. Lightbodied with sticky,mellow mouthfeel. Boiled vegetables goes rampant in the flavour. Sugary finish with some old socks. Not really bland, more like revolting or disgusting.

Can: Clear golden pale colour, thin white head. Aroma of gras,vegetable,hay,citric,sweet maltyness,dry citric hopy nose. Flavor has a thin mouth feeling,sparkling,. Almost the same as the aroma profile. Thin body, short finish
Golden. A flowey hopy aroma and taste. Also some perfume. Not good.
Canned. Golden colour, not much head. Aroma is surprisingly not much anything at all. Flavour is hay, hops, malts and some slight earthy notes. Refreshing but not very exciting.
Can. A hazy golden beer with a white head. The aroma has notes of malt and straw as well as lighter notes of metal. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and metal. The body is light.

Can 50cl. Clear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, sugar. Flavor is light to moderate sweet with a average to short duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20090321]
Can 50 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Clear yellow with a dense white head leaving some lacework. Medium body with a good malt base with some sweetness and a fairly hoppy finish. 210309
Can, 5.3%. Citric aroma, a bit of sweet malt. Clear yellow colour. Small white head. The flavour is a little citric, other than that, not much to write about.

50 cL bottle. Pours almost clear and golden yellow with a thick and white head. Mild hoppy fruity to light grassy aroma. Light grassy and mild fruity hops flavoured with a mild malt base. Medium dry and slight grassy finish.

(Can) golden yellow colour with lasting, frothy, white head. Malty, grassy nose with notes of bread, hay, citrus, honey and fresh hops.
