Malty taste with bread, grass, citrus, orange peel and a decent grassy bitternes in a fairly short finish. Balanced sweetness, on the thin side. Quite decent but hardly exciting. In short: fresh and grassy standard lager.

Golden color with small head. Perfumed aroma with alcohol and tart fruitiness. Dry fruity and honeyish flavor with fruity-herbal bitterness. Somewhat soda like with low maltiness and coase bitterness.

500 ml can. Golden colour. Crystal clear. Tall white coarse head. Lovely floral hop aroma. Crisp malt aroma as well. Sparkling mouthfeel with crisp carbonation and lots of grainy malts. More floral hops flavourwise. Overall a nice quaffable rich pilsener. The somewhat above average alcohol content can be noticed as the beer is richer. Finishes with a dry and bitter taste.

Can. Big dense white head. Shiny golden color. Dry sourish malts, dusty and hayish hops in the aroma. Cardboard notes. Taste is much of the same; fairly dry, light sour and grainy with a quite unfresh bitterness. Medium body, soapy mouthfeel. Sourish-bitter ending. Hard to appreciate.
Can. Small head with short duration. Color is pale golden. Aroma and taste are malt and hops.
On tap at brewery a while back. Poured rusted gold with a stale budwies. nose. Watery and really funky, I’m not sure what style they were going for with this one? Save yourself a long trip...

Bottle from beeronthewall. Pour: Hazy dark straw, OW head. Nose: Mild hopcitrus, grainy pale malt Taste: Pale malt, mild hops, orangy citrus, a tad of funky yeasty flavor Overall: Not one I’d drink again.

pours a hazy orange gold with very small head. aroma of floral grain and a light citrus vinegar. medium body and light carbonation. tastes of malt, grass, a little floral hops, and vinegar. the beer has a light bitterness. would be ok but i think the beer got infected and under carbonated.

Slightly hazy orangish color with a small white head. Aroma is grain and caramel malt with a slightly butter effect. Its got the traditional Indian Wells flavor which can be only described as funky plus a nice crisp finish. A little sweetness as well. Light and pleasant. Like the other dude said, this is way better than the Mojave Silver.

12 ounce Bottle from the brewpub; Nose is grainywith maybe a slight caramel note; Medium dark gold color with a big off white head; tongue tingling caramel flavor with a bit of citrusy hop bitterness with lasts into the finish but with only minor bitterness. decent lagered beer with a nice appearance and decent flavor. Beats up on their Silver (light) beer I had right before this one.
yellow body with an average white head.typical lager aroma.flavor was of lemons,some sweet fruit,and water.
2/15 Tasting at RFD: An opaque yellow with strong wheat aromas. Smooth and rich with a slight lemony/hoppy flavor.
Always get mead when I can. This was more medicinal than good to drink. Was hoping the raspberry would sour this up but too sicky sweet - as is the pinky colour.

I couldn’t even finish this drink. There was something that just didn’t taste right about it. It was far too sweet for my liking and I had to choke down the gulps I managed. Sorry Alley Kat...you can’t win ’em all.
Pours a clear gold color. Average aroma of raspberries and honey. The flavor has raspberries and honey, but it feels more like a soda than a mead....

Really quite unpleasant overall I’m afraid to say. Pours a rather sickly orange-pink colour. Aroma of cough syrup and honey with a fair deal of alcohol (my bottle is 7.0% rather than 6.7%). The taste is just cloyingly sweet and the raspberry tastes very artificial. The mead taste is definitely there though, giving it a bit of interest, and it leaves a much better aftertaste than I’d expect. It’s trying at best to be a two trick pony - the honey and the raspberry - and it doesn’t really succeed at either.
Has some of that basic fermented honey that hints at being a real mead. Raspberry is just to artificial, and lacking in acidity to create a pleasurable beverage. Nice nose, that’s about it.

650ml brown bottle. Pours very light yellow, no head, faint haze. Aroma has some sweet honey, faint raspberry, white wine and tea. Sweet flavour, honey notes, but fairly bland. Finishes with some nice raspberry fruit flavour. Medium body, light carbonation.

Ugh. Gonna be a pour out for sure. Two very small sips in and I already don’t want any more. The colour is some unknown metallic gold /pink, crystal clear, no head, some carbonation. There is alot of raspberry and honey aroma - very sweet. The aroma is not that bad. Bleck! This is pretty awful. Maybe I am just not a fan of meads, or maybe this one sucks balls. Taste is terrible. It’s watered down pop. It’s got a nasty alcohol taste that is way to forward. It’s..the hell with it - I’m not drinking any more of this spew. Gasoline in my mouth? Mouthfeel is 100% unpleasant. Thin, watery and gasoline. The slight sweetness is overrun by nothingness. Over carbonated. Horrid. It’s like I’ve got a shot of Vodka in a pail full of melted ice. It’s possible that I consumed less than 75ml. Hello basement toilet - goodbye Alley Kat abomination. Did they even taste this BEFORE they bottled it? How could they say "hey, this is exactly what we were after"? One of the worst things I’ve ever drank. Alley Kat should be embarrased. Also, one of the cheapest labels ever made. A dead ringer to cheap home made wine labels.

"I’ve told my self every time I drink a mead I’ll never do it again and this is no different tasted like crap and was a complete waste money. Pale rose to an orangey pink in color absolutely no cap but tons of carbonation bubbling up, looks exactly like sparkling peach juice don’t look like beer or mead but I think this is what Alley Kat was going for so what ever. Aroma is very sweet tons of honey and noticeable raspberry and something that smells like feet, it is not completely offensive but it’s ungood. I can’t believe the 6% alcohol is very noticeable and what the hell is the malt they used for this baggot mead made from popcorn?!?!?! This taste like popcorn the aftertaste taste like popcorn, buttery popcorn combined with honey and raspberry HOW! WHY! Ok I just called the girl friend over to taste I did tell her what I thought this tasted like and right after the first sip she said popcorn so its not just me. I’m not to sure what Ally Kat was going for on this product but I think they wanted to make a brew that was sweet and light for girls to slam back but ended up with a huge batch of popcorn juice. This was a huge waste of money and time there is no good reason to drink this. I SHALL NEVER BUY MEAD AGAIN. Review done while watching Mythbusters.

Dark peach colour with a touch of light pink. Nose is raspberries, chai, roses, chardonnay, and light hops. Heavy caramel right away, with cream soda and chewing gum. Where are the raspberries? The sweetness mutes out the malt and hops, but there is a pleasent cream feel. More like a soda pop with a deceiving 7% ABV.

Cambridge Fest. A soft and drinkable best bitter of little character. Soft, flowery hops above an undistinguished and avaerage malt base. That all makes it sound worse than it actually is. The whole is more than the sum of its parts - and the finished result is as soft and delightful as a bland beer can be.

column2: Penn Yan, New York, United States
column5: Sampled at the meadery. Pours a very pale straw gold with no head. This is a still mead. A good bit drier and frankly less aromatic and less flavorful than their Contemporary Mead. This mead has the lowest percentage of residual sugar by far of all of their meads. I am very fond of this meadery, but I must confess that I was not at all impressed with this offering.

column2: Penn Yan, New York, United States
column5: Crisp clean and delightful. Lightly sweet but dry enough to enjoy it. A good mead but I like them a little sweeter.

column2: Penn Yan, New York, United States
column5: At the meadery. A slightly drier version of the Comtempory mead. Still fairly sweet and fruit but with a darker set of flavors

From the bottle @ Mondial de la Biere 2017, Montreal. Medium golden hue, still, with medium-high viscosity. Maple and vanilla sweetness intermingle with dense cooked apple flavour, lightly acidic finish. Tasty.

Sample from a bottle. Deep copper pour, clear. Aroma is really nice, candied apple, caramel, cinnamon apple, applesauce, light green apple. Taste is rich, decadent apple pie sweetness, lots of cinnamon and apple sauce. Palate is med-full bodied, quite boozy, you can certainly feel the added alcohol. Tasty stuff, not as refined as a great ice cider but certainly offers most of the same flavor profile.

2 oz sample from bottle (375 ml). Appearance: Clear copper with almost no alcohol legs despite the high abv. Aroma: The 16% abv is showing up as this is quite “hot”. There’s brown sugar, caramelized apples and notes of raisins. Taste: Heavily sweet. Boozy with brown sugar, caramelized apples, raisins, nutmeg and oak. Palate: Medium to full body. Not as thick as Ice Ciders. Warming, almost burning finish. Nutmeg aftertaste. Overall: Quite boozy. I don’t have a baseline for “Cidre de feu”, but if I compare this to Ice Ciders, this is far less complex and refined. Still an enjoyable beverage, but not one that I would seek again.

Bottle 375ml. Pours hazy amber with no head. Good legs. Aroma is of apples, lots of alcohol. Taste is of apples, tart, sugar, alcohol. Palate: Full bodied. No carbonation. Somewhat sticky. Burning alcohol. Overall: Quite nice, but very boozy.

Bittle sampled at Mondial 2015 in Montreal with Linh, Ken and Nica. Pours an amber body. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of apple cider, skins, earthy wood and alcohol. You really taste the heat in this one.

Pours a clear copper without any bubbles. Aroma of cooked apples, brown sugar and alcohol. Taste is sweet and almost cloying but also a little tart. Flavors of apple cider (duh) and not much else. Alcohol shows up a lot in the finish. Interesting but not the best in class.

pours cloudy and dirty amber, legs showing. brown sugar, caramelized apples, reds, unfiltered and unpasteurized apple juice, apple sauce, woodsy old rum, warming and tingling alcohol, spices - cinnamon feel, dried fruits, bit of earthiness. flat carbonation, medium body - syrupy, astringent, herbal finish and lightly tart finish. very good.

Had this on ST Patty’s Day. Poured a honey color with a small off white head. Aroma. sweet peaches covered with sugar some malt. flavor peaches and cream with hints of malt. nice and smooth mouth feel easy drinking

Toasted malts, filter coffee, chocolate. Clear, dark brown, small, creamy, beige head. Medium sweet. Sweet, toasted, dark malts continue, light charcoal, filter coffee, dry cacao, dark molasses, soft carbonation. Very nice Porter, quite sweet in aroma and palate. Keg at brewpub, Chicago.

A dark brown porter with a thick brown head. In aroma, a good chocolate with grassy hops, coffee and toffee. In mouth, a delicious sweet mocha chocolate with herbal hops, caramel notes, well balanced.

Tap @ Piece in Chicago with TheAlum. Pours a dark brown appearance with a brown head. A touch smoky, dark chocolate, vanilla, a touch fruity aroma. Light coconut, roasty, slightly smoky, dark chocolate flavor. Nice beer.

Poured a dark brown color with a medium sized light brown head. Aroma was some chocolate, with roasted malts, and dark fruits. Flavor was light roasted malts, chocolate, with some bitterness. Pretty enjoyable.

On tap: The aroma consists of dark chocolate, light smoke, and coffee. It’s a dark brown with a one finger tan head with good retention. The flavor starts with dark chocolate and butterscotch. The butterscotch lingers throughout. The finish has some fruitiness, a touch of smoke and roast. Medium bodied with mild carbonation and soft mouthfeel.

Sampled on tap at the brewpub (Chicago, IL). Pours a dark blackish hue, near opaque with some brownish glowing edges. A decent frothy tannish head dies to a ring and laces small, clinging as a film. Aromas are roasted malts, chocolate and touches of anise. Some more black licorice, coffee grounds, and touches of roast, toast, and toffee. Initial is fuller bodied, a full coffee and anise feel with roasted barley, toffee sweetness and caramel, touches of cocoa, both sweet and bitter, some molasses. Sweet and thicker, a heavy porter that brings a complex vibe, full bodied feel, and a lot of sweetness. The anise actually works well here, good roast and sweetness. A solid Porter, a bit bigger. Chocolate comes in much fuller as it warms, turning sweeter and roasty with just a light kiss of smokiness dancing in the finish and front of the palate at the end. Mmmmmm.

I had this on tap into a tasting glass at Piece. The beer is a very dark black, hardly any brown highlights. Light tan ok retention. The aroma is super sweet a hint of vanilla and chocolate with a big smokey finish. They say only light smoke but not the case at all. The taste is all about the smoke its everywhere and dominating and only shows anything else on the finish where you get a little sweetness. Light black licorice as well. This is ok, nothing special but if you want a little smoke while your out not a terrible choice. However, they have schlenkerla there so I’d go with that.

Deep brown almost black decent tan head. Aroma chocolate coffee vanilla licorice hints of smoke. Big malt body, smoke, roast coffee, touch of chocolate. Full body mild carb. Tasty brew good winter warmer cheers!

On tap at the brewpub. Poured black wit ha wooden brown head that lasted throughout the beer. Flavor was full of roasted malts with a bit of smoke and dark bread underlying. Flavor started with dark grains and a bit of sweet chocolate, but became much more roasty with even a bit of smoke growing into the finish.

Tap at Piece. Poured black with a deep amber edge and white head. Smell was a boozy roast with a hint of dark fruits... definitely got my mouth watering. Taste was roasty with a maple and dark fruit sweetness that blended well.
Golden color and clean. A bitter sweet malty taste and very foamy when you pour to the glass.

Many Thanks for this 330ml can to Manslow. Dzieki Marian. Piana srednia ale opada szybko niczym szczeka gdy posmakuje sie tego piwa. Jest tak nadmiernie kukurydziane ze esencja z gotowanej kukurydzy to pikus. Wodniste i niezbyt przyjemne piwo, ale sa dwa plusy tego piwa: Nowy kraj zaliczony. Country Tick: 136 and new Breweries.

"The beer is clear golden in colour with a massive foam top when poured into the glass. It taste malty and kind of cheap with a nice floral finish. The aftertaste is sweet and grainy. A very typical lager that probably taste a lot better when enjoyed in Papua New Guinea compared to chilly Norway." - beersoftheworldproject.wordpress.com Date: 25/01/2019 Bought at: Gateway Hotel in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea.

Kolor- z³oty, klarowny. Piana - drobna, œrednio wysoka, szybko pêkaj¹ca i znikaj¹ca. Zapach - nie wyczuwalny. Smak - lekki s³ód, lekki chmiel, lekka s³odycz i goryczka, odrobina kwasku. Tylko do gaszenia pragnienia.

330ml can into schooner glass. Thanks to Bitterlady. Aroma of sweet malt and cardboard. Pale amber beer, high carbonation. Fluffy white head which reduces to film. Light body, slight fizz on swallowing. Sweet finish with a small touch of tin. I thought this would taste like XXXX but it’s much flatter and sweeter. I bet you can drink this real quick in the heat of PNG.

Bottle 0.33l sample at Ratebeer Belgian Winter Gathering 2017 Antwerp, Belgium at Beerlovers Bar 25.02.2017. Thanks everybody for sharing great beers! Pour it golden color with small white head. Aroma thin almost nothing. Taste watery, easy drinakble, fizzy carbonation, some malty notes, light body, thin feel, astringent.
Hoppig en zoetig pilsener bier. Lekker van smaak maar mist enige diepgang. Goudgeel van kleur met een witte schuimlaag. -backlog de BierApp-
Pours a clear golden color with a small head. Nose is sweet and grainy, aroma is sweet.
Bottle from Kaufland, Bremen. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and moderate hoppy - straw. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 170317

Ein dünnes Fernsehbier mit prickeligem Geschmack und leicht bitter klebrigem aber erfrischendem Nachgeschmack. Nett im Sommer, hier passt der Begriff Hopfenkaltschale. Entspricht also der Herstellerbeschreibung...

As a fan of Werder Bremen, I do find the comments below rather offensive. But not as offensive as the pityful quality of this beer. What can a team do? If rugby fans drink Heineken at the RWC, Werder fans might as well put up with this.

Bottle design? Okay ... Pours out golden, mid carbonation, small white head. Malty and metallic on the nose. Taste is sweet malty at the start, followed by a thin hop herb. A beer without a bigger structure. Designed for the fans of the soccer team Werder Bremen, Germany. Should be okay for that kind of customers. (3. June 2012).
Bottle. Pale yellow colour, disappearing head. Aroma of grains. Taste is metallic, grains, light hops. Thin, not great.

0.33 l bottle at Bremerhaven... Clear golden-yellow color, average head... Some undefined hop aroma... Mild, for a Pilsener beer even a little bit watery taste... Short ending... Nothing special, but who cares, it is Werder Bremen...

Der erste Gedanke eines Ruhrgebietsjungen schreckt einen natürlich von der Optik ab, der Biertrinker aber ist natürlich angetan und fair. Fair muss man sagen, dass wir hier ein Pils haben, das süffige und süße Momente auf Lager hat, aber auch durchaus bitter enden kann. Kein großes Bier, aber ein solides ist es.

The bottle is quite stylish if you are interested in football, but the nose and the looks don’t promise that much. Light golden colour with unsteady and low head and medium to thin body. Nose of metall and bitter hops. Taste is also very thin and metallic with hints of bitter hops, light malt, unripe grains and grass. Very unpleasant to drink and way below average.

Pours a very cloudy hue that is orangey-brown with pinkish highlights. It has a thin white head that leaves lace on the glass. The aroma is big with bready malts and yeast and also has some spices and fruit (citrus, berries, bananas). The flavor has lots of sweet malt with some citrus and coriander flavors. There is also a hint of acidity and the finish is dry. The beer is fairly light in body and is very highly carbonated. Overall, a very pleasing saison.
Had at Elysian Fields; brewed at Tangletown. Very cloudy amber; looks like apple cider. Nice sweetness. Citrus aroma and taste. I enjoyed this.

Draft at Elysian Fields. Pours crystal clear medium amber with a slim rim of white. Big dust, vanilla, and pine nose. Best nose of the night so far. Fairly flat attack but otherwise nice-enough carb. Weird mix of caramel and citrus and vanilla on the mid-palate. Not so nice. Not really. Not much finish, either. Great name, middling beer.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Northampton BF. A test brew done at Hoggleys by the Phipps family who are in the throws of setting up their own brewery in Overthorpe Northants. A copper coloured beer with some berry fruits in the aroma, but unfortunately a hint of diacetyl also. The taste is nicely balanced, but fruitiness comes to the fore. A decent first effort.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Northampton BF. A dark brown coloured beer with a ruby hue and an off-white head. The aroma is very malty and fruity with a hint of coffee. The taste is more of the same and it is particularly fruity. Packed with flavour for such a low ABV.
Tried at the Deepings Beer Festival 2018. Dark almost black colour with a tan head. Aroma malty chocolate. Taste light sweet to slight bitter. Medium body.
Cask at tap house... Dark brown... Thin tan lacing... Soft sweet toffee fruit.. Light caramel toffee fruit.. Soft dusty toffee malts
Cask at West Kirby Tap. Creamy malty with light coffee. Medium sweet and a hint of roasty bitterness on the end.

Handpull cask at the Swan and Rushes, Leicester. Red-brown, translucent. Malt, oats and chocolate in the simple, honest aroma. Sweet/spicy taste, with a slightly sourish caramel biscuit finish. Weak palette. Pretty good but not a game-changer. But then again it was never meant to be.
Cask. Dark amber with a tiny off white head. Malty and fruity notes. Malt, fruit and roasted caramel. Medium to light body with a bitter sweet finish.

Cask at The Blisland Inn. Pours brown with a creamy light tan head. Aroma of dark malt and something roasty which only suggests coffee to me. That’s probably not it, but that’s how my brain interprets it. A bit light in body, and the flavor has that unusual "coffee". There’s dark malt, but the roasty flavor is distinctive.

Cask@the Spitting Feathers Brewery Tap. Clear dark brown looks with a thin tan head. Rather strange nose that somehow reminded me of pencil sharperner shavings. Lacking in body. Some roasted character in the flavour, but everything seemed just a bit wide of the mark here. Disappointing.
Cask Handpump at the Community Centre, Frodsham 12/05/2007 Slightly rich aroma. Mid brown coloured smooth and rich on the palate with some bitterness in a crisp burnt roast finish.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Northampton BF. A very dark brown coloured mild with a hint of purple. The aroma is dry and smoky, but there is a hint of fart. The taste is similar and there are hints of roastiness. A pretty average mild and not especially velvety. Score 2.8 Subsequent rating scored 3.5. Average becomes 3.1
Bottle. Dark with a full body.My bottle did say 3.8 but it tasted stronger than that. As you would expect from this brewery quirky but worth trying.

A Mes rate: 50cl bottle from Kris Wines. Aroma is ok I guess. Inoffensive but a bit too gentle. Malt and some chalky chocolate notes. Nice dark black / brown colour with a reasonable beige head. Chlorine and harsh watery stuff. Over carbed and lacking flavour. Not great.
It is Pit Prop but the label says 4.1%. Whatever, vinegary and average. Watery too. Bland. Not offensive, I just don’t like it.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Northampton BF. An almost black coloured mild. The aroma and taste unfortunately give the impression of lemon washing-up-liquid. I got hints of ginger also. Plenty of, presumably, unintentional and undesired citricity. Odd.

Draught at Norsminde Kro. Creamy white excellent mostly lastin g head. Yellow cloudy colour. Moderate hoppy and yeasty aroma. Light bitter flavor. Moderate bitter average finish. Only slightly rhubarbs notes. Oily palate.

Draft. An unclear golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet and very yeasty combined with notes of esters, wheat, and grain. The flavor is sweet and very yeasty combined with notes of fruit, rhubarb, esters, and wheat, as well as a slight acidity - is it from the rhubarbs? A more interesting, than good beer.

Draft. Cloudy golden colour. Very nice appearance and lasting head. But then.. I was expecting a wheat beer. I don´t know how to define this beer. I cant taste the rhubarb and there´s only hints of wheat. It´s an okay beer with a nice taste but its too much a undefined mix of aromas. The malty flawor being the red line thru the beer. Its a bit like an Hoegarten from last night. Fruity but boring and flat.

Draft - Hazy golden body, very creamy fine lasting white head; Very malty pilsner like nose with a very, very little rhubarb touch; Very boring bitter body, soft textured with not enough soft carbonation; Quite long very malty finish, no rhubarb what so ever, no wheat what so ever, but very malty. I dont know what the f... this is, but definitely not an American wheat spiced with rhubarb juice!
Cask. A hazy yellow beer with a thin lazing beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and butter. The flavor is sweet malty with light notes of butter, leading to a lightly bitter finish.

(Cask at The Rake, Southwark, London, 27 Nov 2010) Copper colour with foamy, off-white head. Malty, fruity nose with dried fruit, apricots and toast. Malty, fruity taste with notes of dried fruit, orange, apricots, marmalade, sweet toasty malt and a mild bitterness. More than medium body with rounded mouthfeel, fairly sweet. Quite nice.

Cask (gravity) @ NWAF 10, National Winter Ales Festival, The Venue, Sheridan Suite, Manchester, England. Clear medium yellow orange color with a small, fizzy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, moderate hoppy, citrus - orange - butter. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20100120]
Cask. Slightly hazy golden with a small white head. Sweetish malt and fruit in the nose. Quite full-bodied, almost flat with lots of sweet malt and fruit with a fairly discreet bitterness. 200110
Cask Stillage at NWAF The Venue, Miles Platting 20/01/2010 Hoppy aroma. Golden coloured strong in alcohol floral and hoppy with a crisp and dry bitter malt finish.

Cask conditioned at Brecon Beer Festival, Castle Hotel, Brecon, Powys. Clouded brown with no head. Seemed a bit green and unsettled to me, there was a powdery hoppy note, but the flavours were a little muddled. A big alchol kick on the finish. Disappointing really but nothing off in the flavour.

13-02-2019; bottle; at home (bought somewhere in Sweden). The looks of the beer are fine. It looks like a simple Pale Lager. The colour is golden yellow and the beer has a slight haziness. On top of the beer quite a lot of frothy white foam is formed. Foam retention is average. Not to special. The aroma of the beer is fine. The malts give some bready notes. It has a biscuit note too. The hops give some herbal aromas. There are also some rather earthy hops. Yeast gives a nutty touch and also a fruity hint. Not to intense or special; yet not bad. The taste of the beer is fine. Sweet malts, nice bitter hops and a slight fresh fruit note. Not to strong, but it is balanced. Not to special. The palate is fine. Light body, slightly thin texture and high carbonation. The finish is short. It has some of the bready malts and earthy hops. The end has some dry notes in it. All in all, drinkable beer, but not special. Good average.
Bottle. Pours a clear golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grainy aroma. Fruity malty grainy grassy flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy grassy finish.
bread, hay, cereal, floral, barnyard, basement aromas, golden, amber, clear, minimal head, white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, lively, bitter,

Cask conditioned at Brecon Beer Festival, Castle Hotel, Brecon, Powys. Amber with white head. Slight egginess on the nose which leads to a light malty bitter, restrained on hops in my opinion, despite the name. A little sulphery through to the finish, it was ok.

Lager with coarse and large foam. Good malty aroma with hints of citrus and a full taste of flower and a pleasant hoppy bitterness. Slightly spicy flavor in the final. This is a lovely, delicate hopped and refreshing lager.

Bottled (backlog). Hazy golden colour, small white head that vanishes quite quickly. Aroma is bready, fruity, mildly citrusy along with some grains. Flavour is grains, grass, herbs, bready malts and some sweetish notes as well.

15 cl. sample from 50 cl. bottle. Clear, golden-yellow colour with a frothy white head. Malty aroma with bread, grasses and light hops. Light bitter taste with some citrus notes. Light to medium body with an oily texture, lively carbonated. Moderate bitter finish with a good amount of bread notes. If you can manage the bread notes this an okay lager. However, there is a lot better choices out there..

Pours a clear and golden beer with a white head. The aroma is malt, notes of DMS, notes of sulphur and some hops. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is dry with sweetness and some bitterness. Overall this beer is below average.

Bottle 50cl from Henrik thanks, a cloudy golden beer with medium head and high carbonation. Nose is is grainy. Aroma is sweet, grainy, medium malty to low, fruit notes on orange, lemon touch, grassy hops at the finish. Body is a bit low expected something more malty/grainy for an unfiltered pils.
Pours golden with a white head. Aroma is crisp malt and grass. Flavour is crisp malt, grass and fruity notes.
Hazy golden with a lasting white head. Weak grainy aroma with a bit of grassy hops and a dusty note. Sweetish grainy flavour with grassy hops and a medium bitter finish
light malty,light hoppy,yellow,clear, minimal head, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, thin feel, flat,
From Fakta, Aarhus, DK. Bottled, 111109. Golden with white head. Aroma of malt with hay. Flavor is malt and some spice notes

Bottle @ Fakta. Pours hazy yellow with a small creamy white head and lacings. Grassy and straw flavor with a fine bitterness. Medium bodied. Crisp and dry. A bit of butter and buiscuit. Nevertheless quite Tasty.

Roughly frothy and very nice beer. More tones darker than expected for a vienna. Sweet malty aroma with hints of flowers. Deep caramel flavor and a full body that almost tangential more bock than vienna. Lovely beer that surprises me positively. Maybe a little too sweet overall, hop bitterness is in fact well hidden.

Bottled (backlog). Amber/pale copper colour with a small white head. Aroma is toffee, fruits, herbs and some slight wooden notes. Flavour is floral, grassy, some sweet bready and toffeeish malts along with mild herbal notes in the finish. Surprisingly good vienna.

15 cl. sample from 50 cl. bottle. Clear, copper colour with a small, fast fading white head. Light aroma with caramel and malts, a little bit fruitiness. Taste is light sweet. Medium body with a thinnish texture, soft carbonated. Short lived, sweet finish with a little bit bitterness. OK beer, but too anonymous.

Pours a clear and copper beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt with some DMS. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is dry with sweetness and some bitterness. Overall this beer is below average.
Bottle 50cl from Henrik thanks, an amber beer with medium head. Aroma is malty, toasted, fruit notes, light caramel, medium hopy.
Pours amber with a white head. Aroma is malt, light caramel and grass. Flavour follows the nose.
Amber with a lasting off-white head. Weak grainy aroma with a faint hint of grassy hops. Dry and thin malty flavour with a bit of caramel and a slightly hoppy finish
Old rating: Amber color with medium sized beige head. Fine smooth and balanced clasic with a good taste.

Draught @ Hansens Brewpub, Flensburg. Pours cloudy light brown with a small offwhite head. Aroma of malt, yeast, light caramel, sweet fruit, strawberry-/marmelade, some buttery notes. Flavor is rather weak, malt, caramel, light sweet, some light bitter fruity hops, little citrus. Thin to medium body, lively carbonation. 140515

Draught @ Flensburg Tall Ship Races 2015. Pours cloudy lightish copper brown with stable off-white head. Clear aroma of malt, with notes of yeast and caramel. Sweetish flavour of caramel malt, with estery and fruity notes, complemented by bitter, hoppy touches. Estery and malty aftertaste. Creamy mouthfeel despite the rather high carbonation. Okay.
From tap at the brewery. Only sold in a short time in the beginning of the summer, when thers regatta in the "förde".

To me it dosn’t seems like a brown ale, more like a mix between an ipa and some hefe. Amber and unclear, muddy, White head, fully lasting. Aroma is spicy, coriander, notes of citrus. Flavor has a heavy bitter finish. Dry texture.

Draught at the brewpub. Almost clear brown colour. Small creamy light brown head. Starts with a hoppy bite from semi-rough hops. Ends with a little sweetness from dark malts, but mostly bitter. Faint hint of aroma hops.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear, golden to copper body with a small off-white head. Malty and fruity nose with some caramel. Quite weak. Nice blend of caramel and fruityness in the flavor, some grains and a nice lasting bitterness. Medium body with decent carbonation. Not a very impressing beer, but sure drinkable. Works nicely as a summer beer too. (080517)

Draught at the brewpub. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Week light malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Moderate bitter average finsih. Oily palate. Actually a nice vienna.
Tap at brewpub. Pours hazy brown with a creamy white head. Aroma & taste is sweet of bread , caramel & malts. Medium bodied. Tasty & very drinkable!

From tap at the brewpub. Pours dark brown with a lacing white head. Aroma is malty with a mild spice note. Spiced and hoppy flavour with a solid bitterness into the finish. Mild sweet note with a light roasted caramel malt note as the main flavour impression. Solid bitterness with a light spice note in the far finish.

Tap @ Hansens. Pale hazy brown amber with a medium very creamy off white head. Sweet malty aroma with a mild caramel edge. Taste begins mild with caramel, then dry bitter and finishes spicy, with some pine and herbs. Quite bitter.
on tap at the brewpub. One of the best. A very colourful taste experience.

On tap at the brewpub. Hazy, orange presentation, with a minimal white head. In fact, more a layer of bubbles than a proper head. Quite weak nose, with a strange spicey note, some fruityness and grain-notes. Grainy, quite fruity flavor. There’s spices, but I would like more of them, especially flavorwise. Medium body. There’s a pleasant bitterness as well, especially in the flavor, but it seems the beers from Holmegaard are aiming a bit low for my likings. They are all certainly drinkable, but very far from exciting. (071006)

(On tap). Completely cloudy, orangey golden with a small, off-white head. Lightly sweetish, malty nose. Medium body, lightly sweet, caramellish malt and a very subdued bitterness. I cannot detect neither the cranberry nor the bog bilberries. Please tune up the spices. 071007

Cask (gravity) @ NWAF 2012, National Winter Ales Festival, The Venue, Sheridan Suite, Manchester, England. Clear medium amber color with a average, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, candy, sharp malt - candy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light moderate bitter with a long to average duration, sweet tobacco. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20120119]
Bottle from Björn, thanks. Almost no head. Clowdy golden color. Nice aroma with both hops and pale malt and just a tuch of caramell. Big hop taste with a fine malty body and firm bitterness.
Bottled. Hazy amber, small head. Fruity white pepper aroma. Medium bodied with well rounded mouthfeel. Fruity and buttery. Warming finish with low bitterness and some chalk.

Cask (handpump), as Heart of Wales Inn Stable, at the Darlington Spring Thing beer festival 2011. ABV was 6.8%, according to the festival programme. Cloudy orange colour, low head. Aroma of unfermented wort, fruity and grassy (or rather: hay-like) hops. Poor condition, the flavour seems "unfinished" and "raw". Some caramel, hops and fusel alcohols, quite dry. Not much to brag about.
Bottle. Slightly muddy appearance on opening which was a bit off putting. Pleasantly fruity with a medium body. Some bitterness and quite a powerful presence. Shame about the appearance.

Cask conditioned at Brecon Beer Festival, Castle Hotel, Brecon, Powys. Dark amber with no head. Dry, bitter beer but with a strong boiled vegetable note, maybe a bit cabbagy. Some sweetness through the finish, dark roasted malt. Its ok.
On tap at the Phantom Canyon Brewery. Brownish yellow color with almost no head. Faint orange citrus hop nose with a similarly hopped taste. A little malt balances the hops. Slightly bitter finish.

column1: Phantom Canyon Oak Aged Three-Nail Imperial IPA
column5: Found this one on tap in downtown Colorado Springs. Served in a brandy snifter style glass. Definite orangy aroma with citrus flavors. The hops level is certainly IPA range but the oak flavors make this one of the more unique IPA’s I had.

column1: Phantom Canyon Oak Aged Three-Nail Imperial IPA
column5: On tap at the Phantom Canyon Brewery. Slightly darker body than the regular 3-Nail. Smooth, richer orange hop nose with Vanilla and Oak intermingling with the hops in the body.
Light yellow body with minimal yead. Faint banana on the nose. Wheaty taste. On tap at Arctic Craft.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a small sized head of frothy medium sized white colored bubbles that were quickly diminishing and left behind a transparent softly carbonated body with junk floating in it . The weak aroma was malty and grassy. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish. The weird flavor contained notes of malt. There was something off in the flavor. A horrible one that I would rather not drink again. What’s with these beers from Florida we bought? So many bad ones came from there. My last set of ratings were the lowest I’ve seen in a long time.
12oz bottle from ABC in fort myers. copper pour. bubbly soda look - but almost no head. faint smells of medicine. tastes like flat caramel malts and skunkiness. astringent sweet finish. fairly awful.

Bottle.Small off-white head with decent retention, very little carbonation, transparent, no lacing, and a gold hue. The aroma reminds me of nothing but medicine and sulfur. The flavor was very astringent and bitter. Mouthfeel was fairly smooth and a medium bodied beer. Since I have nothing good to say about this "beer" other than don’t bother trying it.

...well, this beer tasted like the asshole of a red dragon, if such a thing existed. Horrible, overly syrupy with overpowering medicine flavors, like a cough syrup, or nyquil. I would bever drink this again, and you should never waste your money on it either, unless you are a dumbass, then do it.

Single 12 oz. bottle from Total Wine in Jacksonville. Bottled in China, imported by Cuidao USA out of Hollywood FL. I’m a bit wary because this beer is in the dreaded green bottle. Let’s see what’s up with this one...Pours a amber color with very little head. A bit of sediment is evident in the bottom of the bottle. Aroma is not existent. Taste is woeful. Caramel and skunk. I’m sure this beer, when fresh, is much better, but until they can figure out a way to bring a Chinese beer to America in something other than a barge ship, this is one to avoid at all costs. Yuck!

Bleh. Darkish copper, somewhat like tea. No head at all, along with virtually no effervescence. Sulfuric skunky aroma. A touch of strong caramel candy. Sulfur and bad toffee on a flat palate, with a unpleasant astringency and bitterness near the finish. Immediate drain pour!

I did my best job to find something, anything decent about this beer. i considered region and culture. this was horrible. the worst pale lager i have ever had. made me want to drink nat. light. since i couldnt even finsh it i will try and describe this disaister. smell is of herbs but not atractive ones such as fennel or coriander. more like medcine gone bad. taste is exactly the same, some kind of sweet medicine with NO CARBONATION. flat and replusive. light as water on the tongue and a terrible aftertaste. didnt bottle to remove it from the bottle other than pouring it down my sink. THANK GOD i bought only 1 bottle for a dollar. DON’T BOTHER TO TRY. EVER.

12 oz bottle. This bottle doesn’t mention the word “light”, but then I can’t read Chinese. It has “Xtreme Beer” on the label. So I don’t know where it belongs on RateBeer. RateBeer has become more jumbled and confusing, and with beer categories that often conflict with what the bottle label says. This one is definitely a pale lager just like its category states. Aroma of sweet pale malts Cheap and sweet tasting. Cloying. Typical cheap third world lager flavor reminiscent of watered down fortified red wine (Richard’s Wild Irish Rose?). This stuff probably sells for pennies a bottle in China, and is sold for quality import prices in the US. I can brew better than this even on a bad day. Barely drinkable and not even close to being worth the price paid (and that wasn’t much). Any cheap Ameican macro lager beats this. Boo..

Bottle... Lightly hazed, golden lager with a small, fizzy, white head. Medicinal aroma with undertones of brown sugar and toffee. The flavor is a blend of orange blossom and wildflower honey... sweet, sweet, sweet with a pinch of clove and just a touch more sweetness after the initial sweetness. Did I mention sweet? Just a few hops, please! Medium-bodied and moderately oily with lively carbonation. Sweet, mead-like finish... Luden’s honey flavored cough drops come to mind.

Cask conditioned at a Wetherspoons. Gold with white head. Served exceedingly cold and flat. Malty, thin bitter, a little underflavoured but that could be the temperature. Interesting that this Spoons had the barmaids wearing badges of their nationalities, not one was British.

I sampled this brew at the brewery in 2008. As it’s description says, this pale ale is light on hops which brings my rating of this beer lower than average. The flavor was not complex but it was smooth. Overall, this pale ale is average and I would probably not buy this beer again

12oz can(courtesy of RSRIZZO)-It pours a nice amber body with a small off white head and an aroma of malt and caramel. Taste of malt and burnt malt. No noticeable hosp characteristic. Not a very good APA but it fits an amber much better.

Can poured a clear brown with a disapating amber head. Aromas of carmel, cocoa, brown sugar and light spice. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, cocoa, ligfht fruittiness and a hint of spice with a smooth malty finish.

Winning floral and caramel malt aroma, appearance of dark apple cider. Subdued NW hop profile and more malt on the tongue. Light carbonation but good bite, enough for me anyway. Not really my favorite style, but a good balance here.

Had this beer at the All Colorado Beer Fest on 11/10/2007. Aroma is light with some roasted malt tones. Color is a light hazy brown with ok carbonation and a thin yet tight head. Taste is a wine like malt flavor on a thin body, this is backed by a mild hop flavor and fair bitterness. Its an ok beer.

Draught at All Colorado Beer Festival. Pours clear amber with a small, rocky, off-white head, diminishing with fair lacing. Aroma is average malt (bread, toasted grain, roasted grain), average hops (perfume, pine), light yeast (dough) with notes of apple. Medium bodied, oily texture, soft carbonation, and a bitter finish. Average duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and bitterness.
On tap at the Arctic Craft Brewery. Amber color with faint white head. Malty nose with a sweet malt body.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Northampton BF. A light golden coloured beer. The aroma is sweetish with a backdrop of citrus hoppy notes. The taste is quite sharp with grapefruit and lemon notes. A bit chewy but not bad.

column1: Arctic Craft Oak Aged Butterscotch Stout
column5: Growler RBSG 07. Black pour with no head. Aroma of light booze and buttery malt. Flavors of light roasted malt, vinous notes and some hot booze. Medium body with no carbonation, roasty/boozey with a vinous/dry finish.

column1: Arctic Craft Oak Aged Butterscotch Stout
column5: Growler at the RBSG grand tasting on 6/23/07: Pours an oily opaque with dark brown edges and a thin ring of light tan head. Aroma of earthy sweet lightly roasted and smoky malts with a hint of butterscotch. Body starts a little thinner with some mild lightly sweet and earthy caramel malt toward a lightly smoky bittersweet finish with a touch of butterscotch complexity. An interesting stout.

column1: Arctic Craft Oak Aged Butterscotch Stout
column5: RBSG 07 Minneapolis Grand Tasting: Murky dark brown, no head, light lacing. Nose of wood and barrel, light bourbon and soy sauce. The flavor is dry and woody, bourbon and light roast, some clean sweet chocolate. It’s ironic how so many beers to reek of diacetyl and this one actually advertises such and has none.

column1: Arctic Craft Oak Aged Butterscotch Stout
column5: Date: 06/23/2007 Mode: Growler Source: Tasting, RBSG 2007 opaque brown, wispy beige head, drops of lace, light sweet vanilla and chocolate aroma, dark chocolate flavor, lots of oakyness, hint of sweet vanilla, long bitter fnish from the oak Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: **/4

column1: Arctic Craft Oak Aged Butterscotch Stout
column5: RBSG 07. Growler. A very candy nose that has some abv with it (now I know why). A coal black pour with no head or lace. A deep hard coffee flavor and a diacetyl flavor that could be called butterscotch. A bit thin with no carbonation. I’m surprised that it was 15%.

column1: Arctic Craft Oak Aged Butterscotch Stout
column5: Growler... RBSG 07... Pitch black ale with no head. I’m able to pull no butterscotch out of the nose, but I’m getting loads of vanilla, sourmash and strong notes of chocolate. Woodsy, chocolaty flavor with a mild whisky burn. Full-bodied with an ultra-creamy mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Burnt, medium bitter finish with a touch of ethanol warmth. As I enter this rating, I see the ABV for this beer is around 15%. Wow, didn’t taste like it. Nice job, guys, however, where was all that butterscotch I was looking forward to?

column1: Arctic Craft Oak Aged Butterscotch Stout
column5: Sampled at the RBSG ’07 from growler, compliments of brewfiend. Pours a clear dark brown brew with no head except a thin bubble ring on the glass edge. Aroma of distinct butterscotch, caramel & toffee, with a touch of light creamed coffee. Taste is light to medium body, slick and smooth finish. Slight caramel aftertaste. The 15% alcohol seems to be high on the potent scale but it does has a slight alcohol warmth.

column1: Arctic Craft Oak Aged Butterscotch Stout
column5: (Growler) Pours a brown body with virtually no head. Aroma of butterscotch, nuts, and roastiness. Flavor of toffee, oak, and some chocolate. Flavors are too separated and do not blend that well. Abv well hidden.

column1: Arctic Craft Oak Aged Butterscotch Stout
column5: RBSG 2007 Grand Tasting - Dark brownish black, zero head. Nose was faint with alcohol, butterscotch, and coffee. Light flavor of butterscotch and coffee that ended with some soft bitter alcohol warmth. Light bodied and oily, soft carbonation, lightly bittersweet finish. My hope was high for this one, but expectations were not nearly met. They can’t all be gems...

column1: Arctic Craft Oak Aged Butterscotch Stout
column5: RBSG 2007 Grand Tasting Thanks Brewfiend for bringing this unique brew to the tasting. Sweet initial flavor. Undercarbonated, yet not terribly. Something just slightly off here. Didn’t taste like it was 15% ABV. Didn’t get any of the JD whiskey flavor either. Interesting attempt. Not my favorite.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Northampton BF. Another test brew for the upcoming Phipps Brewery done at Hoggleys. This one is more copper than gold despite the name. The aroma is pretty standard but again there are hints of diacetyl to spoil. The taste is pretty standard also. An acceptably balnced English bitter with decent hops and malt, but that diacetyl makes a small appearance again.
Rather pleasant slight honey / toffee hint but certainly not sweet - nor sharply bitter. Very quaffable and interesting enough for me to have a second dose!
Cask conditioned at Banbury Beer Fest ’14. Brown with white head. Sweet malted beer, some caramelisation, toffee notes, a little boiled character, some vegetable notes. Nothing outstanding.

Amber color with a small white head. The nose is lightly grassy with some strawberry and caramel malt. The taste is light floral hops, more caramel and orchard fruits. Fairly simple, clean flavors. Overall, OK. Nothing special. I don’t think this is a mild, mind.
Called a mild, but is a bitter to me. Dark gold with mid body. Fruity and sweet with light hoppy bitter.

Cask (gravity dispense) at Reading Beer Festival, 30 April 2009. Described n the festival programme as a "dark mild" but more of a copper colour really. Pleasant caramel aroma. Smooth and easy drinking. More caramel/toffee in the flavour than roast. A bit sweet. Fairly solid but didn’t really grab me. Not a patch on Beijing Black.
Cask (Southampton Beer Festival 2010) - Copper/red in colour. Malty and fruity aroma with dried fruit and caramel. Malty and fruity taste with dried fruit, caramel and hints of marzipan.

(Cask at Southampton Arms, Kentish Town, London, 20 May 2010) Nut brown colour with brief, beige head. Malty, slightly fruity nose with notes of dark fruit, slightly toasty malt and dusty hops. Malty, nutty taste with dark fruit, bready malt and dusty hops. Below medium body, balanced sweetness. Tasty and well balanced session ale.

Cask at the Southampton Arms on 18th May 2010. Brown with white head. Quite sweet with a fruity aroma and a touch of citrus hitting the roof of the mouth. Slightly watery texture and a sweet fruity aftertaste.
Cask gravity at Reading BF 09. Pretty chestnut colour. Caramel malty in mouth. Syrupy malt. Not wonderful

On gravity at the Reading Beer Festival, 01/05/09. Amber coloured with a slight, off-white head. Sweetish mild with some red fruit, a hint of lichen and not much else. came off worst amongst the milds sampled at the festival, and not a beer to be revisited.

Cask at the Cleveland Arms, London. Pours clear gold with a fine, white foam head. Ripe orange and citrus on the nose, with some melon, bubblegum and straw. Light to medium sweet flavor with ripe citrus, light pine, pale malts and light grass. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Mild sweet finish with more mellow pine, soft grass, orange, lemon and faint, toasty malts and leaves. Very solid overall.
On cask at king william iv, Nottingham . Pours pale yellow with white head. Floral but dry, a pilsner style to a real ale. Ok ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask (handpump) @ Market Porter, 9 Stoney Street, Southwark, London, Greater London England SE1 9AA. Clear medium yellow orange color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, light to moderate hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is flat. [20090731]
Golden with a small white head. Fruity pear and biscuit malt aroma with a hint of diacetyl. Boring caramel flavour with diacetyl

Half pint, cask in perfect condition, served at a fine drinking temperature and drunk upstairs at The Market Porter, London Bridge. Light sunset in body colour with a slight haze and a shinning surface. Floral aroma with discreet notes of hop resin. Has got a taste of earthy malts mixed with ripe dried fruits. Smooth bitter endnotes. Dry in the mouth. A quite decent start to a drinking week in London (01.08.2009).
Cask in the market porter. Alround rating: Pale malt that a bit biscuity, grassy floral hop, bit minerally, bit sulpgury. Drinkable. Alot of bits?

Cask@Market Porter. Pale yellowish golden colour, white head. Aroma is vanilla, fruits, wood as well as some earthy notes. Flavour is mildly sour wooden, some fruity and floral hops as well as mild vanillaish and herbal notes.

Cask conditioned at The Black Horse, Leominster, Hereford. Gold with white head. A beer that is slightly tart and acidic, maybe a little overkept. Some strawberry in the flavour, certainly fruity, but a little off putting.
Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Amber with a small white head. Fruity citric aroma. Pleasant grapefruit taste with a mid bitter finish. Very nice.
Cask at Charlie’s Bar, Copenhagen. An amber beer with a lazing beige. The aroma is fruity with a bit of caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes malt, caramel, and elderflowers.

From cask at Charlies. Pours cloudy orange with a small and slight tan head. Sweet fruity aroma, fresh citrusy hops. Flavour is bitter citric and fruity floral. Subdued malt base. Light bitter finish with a lasting fruity hops impression.

A Mes rate: gravicask at Battersea Beer Festival Golden brown with a thin white film top. Excellent bitter fruity hoppage, slight tobacco and a good earthy malt base. Maybe some slight germoline too. Really well balanced. Lovely and clean. Excellent bitter citrus finish with a lingering aftertaste. Nice and dry and effortlessly drinkable. Jolly good stuff.
Cask at the White Horse, 12th Nov 08. A great best bitter. Fresh, lively, very well balanced indeed. A delight to drink, it slips down so easy. Amber colouration, small foamy head.

Cask gravity @ Reading Beer Festival 2008. Light unclear medium amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, moderate to heavy hoppy, pine, grape, orange. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long to average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. (020508)
Cask gravityat Reading BF 08. Hazy copper colour with thin beige head. It’s a bitter, rather earthy. bit of sherbert hop, but otherwise fairly standard bitter.

Cask conditioned at The Ship Inn, Raglan, Gwent. Red brown with white head. Smooth and drinkable dry bitter, plenty of hop notes with a sharp note. Full roasted malt and a light fruitiness, perhaps the wheat. Liked it.

column1: RJ King Wingwalker Summer Honey Wheat
column5: hazy gold, no head, no lace. nose is mild sweet malt, perhaps some honey. flavor is mild sweet malt, perhaps some honey. medium bodied, dry finish. known world-wide as the beer that has the smell and taste of mild sweet malt, perhaps some honey. one dimensional. bottle courtesy of cornfield.

column1: RJ King Wingwalker Summer Honey Wheat
column5: Bought cheap at the local supermarket, which is not and will not be listed in Places! It pours a golden orange body with a short-lived white head. No lace. It has an unchecked sweet aroma, bready malt with old honey, including a bit of beeswax. The flavor, too, is bready and it has the stale sweetnes of honey. Glad it was cheap.

column1: RJ King Wingwalker Summer Honey Wheat
column5: pours a very cloudy orange with visible chunks of sediment. Very slight sweet smell to it. The taste is just... this beer has to be skunked, but given the other beers by this brewery, it could just be the normal taste. It’s like stale honey with some bitter hop aftertaste. Another sub-par beer from a sub-par brewery.

column1: RJ King Wingwalker Summer Honey Wheat
column5: Horrible beer with a thick milk like body. Cheap taste and reminds me more of food than beer. Skip this at all costs

column1: RJ King Wingwalker Summer Honey Wheat
column5: Found this one bottled at my local Osco liquor store in St. Charles, Illinois. Cloudy, dark orange pour with a thick white head. Timid nose, just a touch of malty sweetness and candy apple. Bready but watery, with a smooth, balanced finish. I see what they are doing, but I’m pretty indifferent about the results.

column1: RJ King Wingwalker Summer Honey Wheat
column5: Bottle - Thanks BuckDich. Pours a sunset golden with a small, short lived white head. Nose of citrus hops, wheat, and malt. Flavor is smooth with maltiness and a little citrus. Rather sweet. The "crisp finish" is fairly mute.

column1: RJ King Wingwalker Summer Honey Wheat
column5: Semi cloudy orange gold with minimal short lived head. Aroma is faint hence the lower rating. Mild grain with some honey sweetness and faint citrus. Mouth feel is watery but goes down quick and smooth. Just don’t let this get much warmer than fridge temps. Decent enough for what it is which is basically a Grocery Store lawn Mower beer. Better than BMC. Price about $6 a six. Have not seen it in 12’ers

column1: RJ King Wingwalker Summer Honey Wheat
column5: Thin, watery, sweet. I dont get how this is 3.3 avg? This is better than the light however.

column1: RJ King Wingwalker Summer Honey Wheat
column5: Unfiltered, dirty orange coloured beer, nice sized frothy white head. Aroma is rather weak,slightly cirtic ,but quite bready, not horrible. Some wheatiness in the flavour and a good semi-sweet honey tone, sweetness gives way at the end to a slight graininess. I actually liked the palate on this one, it felt full and smooth, and not to cloying. Actually not that bad of a summer beer, had far worse.

column1: RJ King Wingwalker Summer Honey Wheat
column5: Bottle: Meh, thin, light head and lacing. Very light smell, some stale starch. A bit of husk in the flavor, which is about all the flavor this one gives up. There’s a lot better summer beers for your money.
Cask at the Guildford arms... Amber.. Thin white lacing.. Soft sweet floral fruit nose.. Dry zezty fruits.. Light woody bitter.. Long bitter

Cask @ Bricklayer’s Arms, Putney SW15. Pours a slightly hazy pale amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty citrus hoppy aroma. Fruity malty citrus hoppy caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty citrus hoppy finish.
Cask at the Well and bucket. Shoreditch. Golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma is caramel and berry hop. . flavour follows with berry hedgerow hop and chalky water profile. Decent, but boring.

Cask, at the Sandy’s party, Charlton-on-Otmoor, Oxon 11-07-10 Pours reddy brown, eggy nose with some sweetness also. Taste is sweet malty but with steady bitterness, plenty of body, fruity with some hops showing late on. Nice. A6 A4 T7 P3 Ov13 3.3

Cask at the White Horse, 19th May 2010. Light amber with a line of white head. Thick-ish palate, lacks condition - it was hard going and it was probably the end of the barrel. Faint citrus aroma. Sharpish initial taste of clementines, then flat and lacking bite or any sort of dry finish. Will aim to re-rate when I can.
Cask conditioned at The crown, Pantygelli, Gwent. Amber with white head. Sweet hoppy bitter, delicious and full of flavour. Bright and refreshing, lovely.

My Bottom Line: A deft floral, soapy and orangey hop perfume offers plenty of flavors, leading to the pleasant herbal bitterness. As you have noticed, maltiness isn’t much of a player here, barely supporting this drinkable Bitter’s frugal hops. Further Personal Perceptions: -A veil of foam sits atop the hazy blond-amber. -The aroma and flavor profile are all in the same direction, which is disappointing (malt doesn’t contribute much). -This was served pretty cold, helping drinkability, but exposing the frail maltiness once it had warmed up. -Not much of a "Cuvée Spéciale" if you ask me, but I don’t think the brewer can do as he pleases at this brewpub. On tap at the brewpub.

column1: La Plaisir de Au Maître Brasseur (Brune Belge)
column5: 341ml bottle purchased at La Trappe a Fromage in Gatineau, Quebec. Deep clear mahogany in colour with a thin off-white head, light lacing. Aroma is quite malty, lots of caramel sweetness, brown sugar, dark fruits. Flavour is quite sweet with lots of sugar and caramel, some alcohol, a little watery as well, burnt cake. Thin alcoholic mouthfeel, medium/light body, moderate carbonation. Finishes long with alcohol and quite sweet still. Quite a bit of alcohol is noticeable and very sweet throughout. Unbalanced and thin. Opened in 2010.

column1: La Plaisir de Au Maître Brasseur (Brune Belge)
column5: Purchased a while back in Laval (I think) and cellared. Comes in a brown 750ml bottle with a plastic cork (like most cheap Champagne) and the metal-wire stopper. Pours a clean darker amber colour with an off-white foamy head, average retention and a little lacing. Aromas of apples (green and red) with some roasted malt and hints of licorice. Medium-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel. 8% ABV and no burn whatsoever. The taste is pretty mild too (a little too much). Still good, with some sweet malts, fruits, a touch of molasses and hints of hop in the finish. As I pour some more beer, the colour is becoming more copper and some haziness is showing from the stuff at the bottom of my bottle. I think this one is meant to be cellared a bit (as it might be unbalanced if drank too fresh).

column1: La Plaisir de Au Maître Brasseur (Brune Belge)
column5: Bottle. Pours a deep amber brown with a thin head light lacing. Aroma is raisin, brown sugar, toast, burnt notes, light orange zest, some chimay style yeast notes- fruity, light phenolic, spices, earth and cookie dough. Flavor is cobwebby, old crackery, dusty, fruity raisin esters, cookiedough, earth, must, light cinnamon hints? A bit stale and oxidized. I think this was drank in 2007.

column1: La Plaisir de Au Maître Brasseur (Brune Belge)
column5: Bottle - 341ml. Hazy brown body with low carbonation and a thin off-white foamy head. Its malty/hoppy aroma lacks strength. It carries some fruity hints. Hoppy taste with vineous/plummy notes. Ends with a decent bittersweet, warming finish. Drinkable.

column1: La Plaisir de Au Maître Brasseur (Brune Belge)
column5: Clear brown color with a medium tan head. Interesting aroma of fruits, brown sugar and malt. The flavor is sweet and fruity with a malt presence all along. The body is light with a creamy texture and soft carbonation.

Not too bad for style. Heavy on citrus aroma, with some apricot. Hint of florals. Pours amber with pretty good head and lacing. Light tangy finish. Some oak. Good balance and pretty drinkable. 2011 version at brewpub, called ’oakily dokily neighbor’.

Very clear, dark oak color. Filmy-beady head. Stewed fruit, lightly vinegraic malt aroma. Very sweet, syrupy tart. Light bittering. Mouthy with a fruity aftertaste. Well done, but not my style. Very fruity.

Sampled on tap at the brewery. The beer was a dark amber-brown color with a small to medium white head that had decent retention. The aroma was a mixture of wheat, yeast, and some lighter fruity and floral hop notes. It had an interesting flavor, which was mostly sweet, but also had a nice, sour counterpart. The body was full and somewhat wet, with some wheaty characteristics; medium carbonation and fizzyness.

Dark brown color, tan colored head. Nose of banana bread and some cloves, some grains, sweet and fruity as well with some maple and brown sugar qualities. Taste is very sweet, very thick and vinuous, undercarbonated, estery bananas and clove all over this one. A decent weizen bock, par for the course.

column4: Ellersick Brewing Co. Big E Ales
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Pours a crystal clear gold with definite presence of bubbles. Thin ring of white film atop. Grassy sweet hay-ish nose; these notes persist on the mid-palate. It’s a nice clean and mild, easy-drinking pale. Getting it fresh right down the street keeps the staleness away. Not gonna make me a pale lager fan right away, but this is decent stuff. Especially given the constraints of the style.

Hand-pulled cask @ The Church End Brewery taproom. Very subtle malt on the nose, thin in the mouth and on the finish, lacking any real bitterness or hop character. Some biscuit in the finish, but otherwise a bit of a dud.

Cask at the Crispin, Wokingham. A hazy amber pour with a tight cream head; aroma of sour cider apples; sour fruit taste with a soupy, grainy, body; and a tart finish. Poor, as this was getting towards the bottom of the barrel, but rapidly substituted by the publican, as he’s keen to ensure he serves good beer.
Cask @ Fox & Goose, Hebden Bridge. Clear gold with a creamy head. Has a dry pale ale fruitiness.

Cask at Anchor,Digbeth.Church End Festival,march 2013.Golden amber pour with smallish white head.Light malty nose and taste with some hints of fruit.Easy drinking session ale though a little too thin for my taste.
Cask in three judges. Aroma is very very sulphurus, bittering hop. Taste is dominated by sulphur and pale malts, but very bitter in the finish.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Malt Shovel Northampton. A golden beer with a whitish head and lacing. The aroma is subdued but pretty pleasant with hints of hop and fruity malts. The taste has some peachy notes. Some light flavours but all nicely balanced and making for what would be an easy beer to have a session on.
Cask@Melton Mowbray Beer Festival 2007. Dark golden beer with a fruity dry aroma and a toffee and lightly dry flavour. Overall an average beer.

Cask, Melton Fest 07. Golden with a small head. Aromas are hay and citrus with some spices. Some pear, too. Flavours are caramel and pear with tea. Mellow lemon with dry, bitter grapefruit on the finish.
Cask conditioned at The Dun Cow, Hornton, Oxon. Gold amber with white head. Light and easy boys bitter, decent bitterness, some sulpher, smooth and easy drinking.Sharpish finish.

Cask handpull at the altar. Golden amber with a creamy head of suds. Urinal nose with great big gust of sulphur. Mellow, orange-accented sessions with a caramel smoothness and a sprinkle of oats. Some softly raspberryish notes emerging as it warms. Even CE’s ’malt-driven’ bitters are tangily hopped. Quality, flavour-packed sessions.

Brown 500ml bottle, part of a mixed four pack given to me by a friend. Best before the end of June 2009, drank at the end of Nov 2008. Batch number 1009nnb. This is a bottle conditioned beer, so I poured it very slowly and carefully into a Imperial Pint sleeve glass. No sediment left the bottle. A very pale yellow almost golden body, loads of carbonisation rising up to the well formed white foaming head. We are talking straw blonde, almost lager like in appearance, but not as sparkling or bright. The aroma was of oatmeal biscuits and yeast with a hint of hops hidden away as the beer warmed in the glass. No storng over-riding flavours, oats, wheat, barley, white bread and some dry hoppy aftertaste is what I could find and I had to dig deep to find those. The carbonisation that showed its self during and after the pour wasn’t to be found in the actual drink, it wasn’t flat, but it wasn’t fizzy either, just about right. Sadly there was no real body, but it isn’t ’wishy-washy’. The sort of beer you’d blend with something stronger, and with more ’Umph’ if it was your own home-brew. Pleasant enough, but lacking in the body and flavour stakes for me. I do want the smaller guys to do well, but they have got to produce a product that ’knocks my socks off’ if they expect me and my mates (and the public in general) to pay the extra prices they need to survive, compared to the discounts the big boys can offer.

Bottled at Monk’s Café, Stockholm. Clear golden, small head. Floral minerally nose. Medium dry with clean, rounded mouthfeel. Citric and lemony, near no bitterness. An empty ale with no real sense of direction.
Bottle.Cloudy gold with a medium head,aroma of lemon and hop,taste is hoppy and sweet with yeast.
Bottle. Golden with a lively white head. Aromas are wheat and mellow lemon with yeast. Flavours are sweet mellow citrus with some yeast spritziness. Dry, hoppy and bitter on the finish. Decent.

A mid orange amber coloured beer with a weak white head. a strange fruit nose, some malt and a hint of hop, but a sweet strawberry jam aroma that is quite off-putting. The taste is bitter and malty, with hints of hop again, but then the jammy fruit element comes through that creates a cloying, bitter sweet finish. (Cask - The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk).
Nice in taste, and very interesting grasping sensation. I liked the head as well as the colour. Interesting features.
28th September 2007. Mid brown ale. Sweeter than normal IPA with tamarind! It’s subtle! A medium bitter finish.
Cask at GBBF 09 ... amber ... light sweet lemon peel hop nose ... light dry boring lemon.

Cask at GBBF 2009. Deep gold, slightly hazy, nose has loads of grapefruity hops and malt, palate is fruity and chewy with plenty of alcohol warmth and slight notes of melon and buttery chardonnay, then turning grapefruity and dry-bitter on the finish with a lingering citrus bitterness. An excellent interpretation of IPA.
Pale amber with a small white head. Fruity aroma with a little peach. Sweet with lots of hop flavour and bitterness.
Cask Handpump at the Harlequin, Sheffield 24/11/2007 Hoppy and slightly citrus aroma. Golden coloured and hoppy. Crisp and creamy on the palate. Some bitterness in a dry lasting finish.

Cask @ GBBF 2008. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty orange citrus aroma. Fruity malty hoppy orange flavor. Has a sweetish fruity and hoppy bitter finish with hints of orange in the aftertaste.

Cask conditioned at The Fat Cat, Norwich. Pale gold with white head. Fresh and hoppy beer, good dry body and quite light in character. Finishes dry, citric lemon and grapefruit. A very good beer and another example that you shouldn’t let a cask go to GBBF, where the quality is rubbish.

Cask @ Great British Beer Festival, GBBF 2008, Earls Court, London, England SW5. Clear medium orange golden color with virtually none head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel rubber, moderate hoppy citrus - lemon, orange. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. (060808)

(Cask at GBBF, London, 7 Aug 2008) Golden amber colour with frothy, white head. Fruity nose with orange, apricots and solid malt sweetness. Fruity taste with notes of orange, apricots, malt sweetness and earthy, citrussy hops in the finish. Nice hoppy beer with some alcohol bite.
Had this on our bike/brew tour, so this rating will be expanded on the next go-round.

Draught at the brewery. Fairly dark, basically black in the glass. Thin tan head. Ok nose of dark malts and citrusy hops. Fairly complex malt bill, but also pretty raw hoppy, with grapefruit hints. Good first attempt for them at this style. They should keep tweakng the recipe. Good beer overall.

Growler. Pours opaque with a foamy brown head, moderate retention. Aroma is cocoa, cream, faint caramel. Lots of bitterness and chocolate dominate the palate. Slight molasses. Finish has that nice blend of roasted malt and bitter hops. Just a touch sour. Medium bodied, texture is soft. Probably FCB’s best dark ale effort since Chocolate Stout, although the two beers are similar.

Pours dark brown with a tan head. The aging in Pinot Noir barrels immediately becomes apparent. An almost brett like aroma, grapes, and stone fruits spread on toast. Dark malts can be separated out in flavor to compliment the somewhat sour body. Finish is tart as well. Definitely different.

On tap at the Burien brewpub location. Pours out a Brown with red highs topped with a tan cream head. Aroma of Dark roast chocolate and light hops. Tast was of light dark chocolate and rich malts. There was a nice light bitterness on the end aswell.

Black with a tan, creamy head. Lots of roast and bitter coffee in the nose. Flavor is much the same following with a strong roast background and notes of coffee. There is some smoke wafting through the flavor as well. Yes, I just used wafting in a rating. Some mocha, and just a tiny bit of yeast there. Finishes fairly light bodied with a lot of flavors.
(Draught) Pours a dark brown body with a medium beige head. Aroma of vanilla, cocoa, roastiness, and herbs. Flavor of smoke, tobacco, light chocolate, and wood.

Draft at the Burien pub. Pours opaque black with a slim but clinging off-white head and lace. Roasty nose but not too much else happening there. Tingy soft tiny-bubble carb. Body’s medium full. Chocolate and roast on the mid-palate; fairly subdued finish.

Draft at brewpub. Dark amber with small head. Bit of belgian yeast in the aroma, but doesn’t follow through much in the taste. A bit of fusel alcohol in the taste with a bitter finish. Doesn’t work for me.
On tap at Brewpub Seattle. Pours out a amber topped with a little head. A little belgian but not what I was looking for.

Draft at the Burien pub. Medium clear amber with ruby gold highlights. Light white film and lace above the beer. Dusty, buttery, lemony nose. Tingly carb and mild body with orange pith, coriander, and peppery mil grain-husk-like hop in the finish.

column1: Elliott Bay West Seattle Pale Bock
column5: At West Seattle nothing special low bitterness tart sweet Ok beer drank today get

column1: Elliott Bay West Seattle Pale Bock
column5: Draft at the Burien pub. Crystal clear medium gold pour with a thin rim, no lace. Orange and bubblegum and wheat bread on the nose. Sharp carb, medium body, some butter and fruit on the mid-palate. No finish to speak of.

Clearish amber pour topped by an enormous off-white head. Malty, toasty soft honeyed nose bearing a certain graininess though bold enough. Sweet on the palate, uncomplicated honey-like and softly hoppy, floral and herbal brew. Unoriginal, but pleasantly drinkable and smooth-bodied.
Tap at Oudaen. Aroma of caramel malts, fruits and floral tones. Clear, amber coloured with a thin, off-white head. Taste is sweet, just a little sour with flowers and fruits in it. Caramel malty.

Tap @ Oudaen. Clear golden color, short head. Aroma of apple, some hop, pilsener malt, some alcohol, herbal and floral. Resembles a bit like a German Maibock with its apple cider taste, bit grainy, slight sour. I prefer an Ouwe Daen in the summer.
Tap at Oudaen,Utrecht: New seasonal beer for the summer, an so called summerbock. Amber looking brew thats is very sweet.
Decent ipa. Rated this beer using a different program and unfortunately I'm not able to transfer my comments here.

Draft at brewpub. Amber color with thin head. Good hop aroma and flavor mixed with flavorful malt. Had a glass of this with the chicken and sausage gumbo. Stood up well to the spicyness of the gumbo and tabasco. I like this beer a lot.

Draft at Lager’s in Metairie. Medium amber boy with little head. Even through all the smoke the aroma is crisp and hoppy with herbal, grassy notes. The flavor is hoppy but not overpowering; nice citrus and piney character. A light maltiness rounds out the flavor nicely. Finishes dry and sweet. This is a well-made IPA.

[i] [b] Bottle from Craig, cheers mate!, had this 01-02-08 [/i] [/b] Poured dark reddy brown very murky and a real erupter to the extent that I probably lost half of it over the work surface. Quite a fruity nose even a touch of sourness quite dry to taste bit sour again very fruity but this felt quite rough to me and afraid to say not my thing at all.

Bottle, thanks cgarvieuk! Lively carbonation, rocky head, cloudy red beer. Very rich beer, the label says this is ideal with roast beef, and you almost get a meaty feeling in the mouth. There are fruits and berries and loads of grain and malt, too. Sligtly oaky dry finish, a little sourness. They have managed to cram a lot of good stuff into this beer. I’d love to try it on cask!
Deep red brown, smokey malt nose, quite fizzy in mouth feel, lots of malt and rich fruit (blueberries?) very complex

(Draught) Pours a lasting thin, creamy head with an orange body. Nose of mild English malt. Very thin texture and palate. Minor tart bitterness through the end. Fairly average but nice bridging beer for the general population.
(Draught) Thin, dissipated creamy tan head with a deep orange body. Nose of mild roasted malts. Very potent flavours displayed - toasted malt and a great bitter hoppiness. Delicious stuff!

(Draught) Pours a thin, dissipated white head with a highly carbonated body. Tart nose. I thought I was detecting some berry nuts aromas but I had just come from The Berry Barn so I may have had some Saskatoon Berries on my hands. Very fresh and fulfilling for a hot day like today - but I’m not getting the wheat hint I’d expect from this style.

On tap at Craft Beer Market in Calgary, AB on 09/17/2011. Colour: Dark orange with red hue. Nose: Sweet raisin, sourdough bread, rich malt. Taste: Medium-light sweet, medium-light bitter, light sour. Soapy. Hops are stringent but do display some bitterness. Late wood blast. Average.

Pours a peachy colour, with unfiltered look, minimal head. Not a commonly made style this ide of the bond. Tangy bitterness, apricot and peach flavours. Decent flavour for a lower abv. Bramling Cross hops.Bottle at Zyn in Calgary under the previous name.

A pretty solid bitter style ale. The pour is amber bodied with a large foamy white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with a mild hoppy aroma. Fuggles and East Kent Golding hop nose. The taste is sweet and malty with a light hoppy finish. Overall, a sweet and very drinkable beer, just not memorable.

355ml brown bottle. Different label, just called "Bramling Cross" now. Pours an orange brown colour, slight haze. Small creamy white cap with some very creamy lacing. Nose has nutty malt up front, also a hint of toffee. Flavour is of nutty malt, caramel, slightly earthy. Nice hop fade, light leafy aftertaste. Light body, mild carboantion, gentle mouthfeel. Decent session beer.
Had some time ago, but remember it tasting off. Definitely not my favourite of Paddock Wood’s offerings. Would not get again.

***on tap at sugarbowl*** Pretty much the same but fresher. Worms. A not-quite clear light copper brew that poured out a thin cap with minimal carbonation. Aroma is on the mild side, but that is not to say that there is not an ample ammount to be found. Mainly malts (a touch caramelly) and some sweet orange-like citrusy hops - possible having a slight creamsicle smell. Taste is quite malty for a second then these tasty come in. They do not overpower, just blend it nicely. The hops are quite fruity and as the tasting moves along, are becoming more prominent. Light medium bodied. The hop hit is heavier than it should be but are quite tangy. Somewhat smooth feel. Finishes dry with a lingering hoppiness. Really drinkable. Another tasty concoction from Paddock.

Body looks hazy brown with a cooper tinge, cap was ok but quickly vanished only leaving a good sized skiff. Aroma has metallic hops that seem to turn into melon the longer you smell and lots of light creamy malt character seems to be a touch sweet but not over the top. Very bitter taste with a touch of crisp hops and tons upon tons of malt, and once again just like in the smell it has a bitter with slight melon finish. Clean taste with full bodied feel and a soft carbonation feel on the tung. Simple and tasty and easy to slam, highly enjoyable brew. Can the farmers in Saskatchewan even begin to appreciate this well crafted beer I mean it taste nothing like lucky lager.

Pours from a bottle with a deep amber color with a small, thin, white head and medium carbonation. Aroma is very light and made up of some light bread maltiness with a little stronger grassy hops aroma at the end. Flavor starts off with a light sweet bread flavor and ends with a grassy bitterness. Beer leaves a great lacing on the side of the glass and, as with all of Paddock Woods beer I have had, has a dead on mouth feel for the beer style. Another winner by this brewery.

Bottle courtesy of CBA: Poured an hazy amber color ale with a nice big foamy head with some good retention and some lacing. Aroma of biscuit malt with some dry hops. Taste was also dominated by some biscuit malt note with some nice English dry hops at the end. Body was above average with some nice carbonation. Very well done overall and something that I wouldn’t mind having as a regular session beer.

Bottle @ TimE’s House: Pours a hazy bronze brown color, a nice head and lacing. The nose is lightly vegetal, some light bright and woody hops along with a subtle malt essence.
