The flavor is piney with a decent yeast and malt body, thin disappointing finish. This beer seems adjustable to what you what, quaff it, chug it, but it’s certainly not one to be savored.

Bottle in Molenhof, Oostvleteren. Clear golden oily looking beer with a thin white foam head. Nose is sweet, perfumed, light candy, floral, light apple juice, hints of caramel, barley sugar, toasty barley grains. Taste is sweet, candy sugar, barley sugar, bitter dry—ish hop, floral perfumed sweetness, toasted barley grains. A shade on the sweet side for me but very decent. Finish is a lingering sweet toasted grains and candy, with a little prickly hop.

Clear dark brown pour with a thin ring of foam for a head. Smells like a bag of candy. Brown paper, molasses, some licorice, some vanilla and chocolate and maybe some mint too.. No hop aroma. The flavor is complex and sweet and pretty much follows the aroma. I don’t really pick up much character from the Bourbon, but perhaps it is subtle and is what is offering all of the complexities in the flavor. Caramel, dark dried fruits, molasses. Pretty tasty and I like that the Bourbon flavors are understated and balanced with the malts.
On cask at the brewery. It was nice to try this one. The American Ale really went well in the barrell. It was a nice change from stouts and sours in the barrells.

Served directly from oak barrel, this had a citrusy nose, and was a copper color with a small light tan head. The smoky bourbon barrel flavor was very pronounced and the mouthfeel was a tad sticky. Overall, it had a nice flavor (in a boilermaker sort of way), but I think this one is more of a winter brew. Next time, I hope they try aging their very drinkable Porter in this same fashion.

on cask at the brewery party 06.02.07 Lightly hazy amber in color with a small bubby head. Aroma: caramel, floral and citrus hops, notes of berries/dark fruit, wood and bourbon. Taste- pretty much the same as American ale with a good dose of bourbon and wood. Bourbon and oak is alittle too strong for this beer, as I expected it would be. Still, an interesting experiment.

Room temperature bottle at the hotel. Thanks Erzangel for the bottle! Dark brown. Aroma of malt drink, a bit of chocolate, some metal and nuts. Nutty, slightly bitter, slightly metallic and some English cake and prune. Light body, coke finish - a little burbt and some caramel - and soft fizz. Not too bad.
Malty-fresh. Hints of dryness, not too deep. Fresh, easy to drink with malty-sweetish hints. Not too intense in the aftertaste. Fresh.
Eigentlich recht vernüftig, wenn man den laffen Gehalt bedenkt. Angenehm im Malz, ein wenig Karamell im Hintergrund und trotz des dünnen Abschlusses durchaus vernünftig trinkbar.

Bottle from Erzengel - thank you, Gabriel. Vintage 2011. The beer has got a deep dark brown colour with an very low head and medium, flat body. Aroma of malt and bread. Taste of light malt, mild hops, bread, grains. Mild and malty finish. Easy drinkable and not a bad one.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein sehr dunkelbraunes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig, leicht hopfig, fruchtig. Geschmack röstmalzig, fruchtig, hopfig.

Thanks to Erzengel for that one. Bottle looks good. Beer in the glass very dark, almost black. Starts mild but not washy. Fine roasty-malty notes, modest dry background. Well balanced finish with some earthy hints. Nice!
Color is brown. Aroma and taste are rich roast malt, fruits, nuts and hops. Dry finish.
The head is medium, the body black. It smells a bit hoppy and chocolate. The taste is brownie, creamy, a bit chocolate, dry. Ok! 11/10/10/10/11/10
bottle from Erzengel. Clear brown colour, small off-white head. Very light-bodied, shy malt character, very slightly hoppy.

Thanks Gabriel for the bottle! Pours brown with reddish highlights with a tan head. Smells of rich malt, molasses - pretty simple. The taste follows the nose. Not a complex brew but interesting non the less. Nice carbonation, medium body.

L: -pours a clear ruby with a small to medium,quickly dissipating,foamy,beige head -low carbonation visible S: -nutty,syrupy,raisins,plums T: -Follows the nose + toffee,cloying F: -medium carbonation -medium to full body -alcohol noticable O: Nice Aromas, but too cloyingly sweet
Als „Maximilian sei stark“ in der 33er Möhre. In der Nase Malz, im Trunk ebenso, brotig, leicht schokoladig, herb, leicht bitter, joo, der passt. Erfreulich gut trinkbar.
Niente male, una doppelbock classica e ben fatta, color tonaca di frate con aroma maltato, al palato malto, caramello, puntina di liquirizia. Buon corpo.

Flascherl( als "Maximilian sei stark") Clear, deep ruby-amber coloured , medium-sized and lacy off-white head, moderate to solid sweet toasty-caramelly nose with loads of dried fruits underneath and the faintest hoppy traces; moderate to solid sweet flavour with a delicate bitterness, nearly full bodied; slightly lingering and slightly warming sweet fruity-toasty finish with a slight balancing bitterness in the aftertaste. Not bad. Typical bavarian Doppelbock...

330ml Bottle - Dark brown with red tinges. Rye bread, raisins and berries in the aroma. Fruity, malty and slightly musty taste with blackcurrant, juniper, rye bread, raisins and caramel. Rich and full-bodied yet easy to drink.

Flasche 0,33l (as "Maximilian sei stark"): Kastanienbraun, dunkles Mahagoni, glasklar, eher flüchtiger mittelporiger Schaum; würzige Nase, kräftige malzige Süße, kräftig Malzzucker, dunkles Karamell, dunkle/eingelegte Früchte, Backpflaumen, leichte Röstaromen; sehr würziger Körper, kräftige malzige Süße, Malzzucker, dunkles Karamell, Röstaromen, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, dunkle/getrocknete Früchte, leichte trockene Bitterkeit; angenehmer fruchtig-würziger Nachgang

(bottle, 33cl, as Maximilian sei stark) Clear, dark brown colour with a beige and firm medium-sized foamy head. Dark malty aroma with notes of bread crusts, caramel, molasses and subtle dried fruits. Moderately sweet flavour, full bodied with a smooth carbonation. Dark malt character, slightly molassy and starchy taste with caramel, sugar beet and bready notes; sweet and moderately molassy finish. Not the best one of its kin. 02.I.18

Tap at Capri. Dark brown color clear, tan head. Aroma ia thick grainy with lots is straw, hay, cereal. Taste sweetish yet balanced, creamy with much caramel, hints of licorice, dark roasted malts, black bread. Thick sticky texture, big body, quite dense. Heavy one, important ABV, fits in the style, which I'm not an huge fan of, ok though.

BOTTLE 33 CL as Hofbräuhaus Traunstein Maximilian sei stark. Clear chestnut brown, tan head. Rich, if a bit too direct, malty and brown sugar aroma. The taste is just as malty, but the grassy hop bitterness adds enough balance the needed complexity. Very good.
In Berlin unter dem Namen "Maximilian sei stark" vom Hahn getrunken. Farbe und Geschmack, wie erwartet. Ein Doppelbock mit Berechtigung, aber ohne Höhepunkte.
Sampled at the Manitou Wine Festival. Very sweet, with some good clover and wildflower notes. Light, creamy, crisp, and clean. This is a pretty solid, straightforward mead.

Pours pale yellow. Aromas of honey and musty grapes. Flavor is fairly sweet. Nice honey and hints of apple. Light cantelope and a bit of wax. Mild botanical notes. The sweetness builds. It’s fairly sweet with a nice medium feel. Not to bad though overall.

Bottled. Mead is clear, palest yellow without any head.Reminiscent of a dry Riesling. Light notes of mineral, traces of green apple peel and fusel alcohols.The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic with a long, moderately sweet finish.The body is medium/full, the texture is syrupy and the carbonation is still.

Bottle. No head (still). Body is light yellow. Aroma is notes of minerals and lime zest, hints of honey and fusel alcohol. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Medium body, syrupy texture, flat carbonation. A rather simple rendition, though not bad. Sweetness is rather cloying and tooth-aching, though you’d never guess it from the light, Riesling-like aroma.
Tasted at the fifth annual Colorado Wine Tasting Festival in Manitou Springs, CO. Light gold color with faint honey nose. Semi-sweet honey taste.

column1: Colorado Cellars Great Catherines Spiced Mead
column5: Sampled at the Manitou Wine Festival. The aroma is strong cinnamon and cloves. Very sweet, but mellowed by the heavy spicing. This is a great addition, and makes for a nice, Christmasy, variation.

column1: Colorado Cellars Great Catherines Spiced Mead
column5: Pours pale golden. Aromas is like sweet honey and pie spices. Flavor is nice. Wonderfully sweet with loads of cinnamon, allspice, and nutmeg. Hints of apple and mild grape skin. A bit of metallic like flavor in the finish. Very much like a pie spiced mead. I liked it.

column1: Colorado Cellars Great Catherines Spiced Mead
column5: Tasted at the fifth annual Colorado Wine Tasting Festival in Manitou Springs, CO. Supposedly there are 17 spices in this one and the nose is a bit more complex than the other spiced meads I tried today. Nutmeg and cinnamon dominate the nose and body. While there was honey in the nose and body, this mead tasted almost like apple pie.

column1: Colorado Cellars Great Catherines Spiced Mead
column5: No head (still). Body is clear light to medium yellow. Aroma is notes of nutmeg, clove, honey, alcohol. Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic. Medium to full body, syrupy texture, flat carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic. Fairly nice aroma, but very spice-heavy (would rather they complement than dominate). Tooth-achingly/undrinkably sweet, almost as much as many Polish meads. Alcohol seems pretty clean. Not bad at all, and I can see people who like heavily spiced dessert meads liking this quite a bit.
Die Hirse sorgt für ein unfassbar langweiliges Bier. Ein wenig strohig, ein wenig süß und eine dominante trockene und moderate Hopfenbitterkeit. Aber alles so fad, dass es keine. Spaß gemacht hat.
bottle bb 1/8/18 chiara torbida schiuma media non molto persistente nota citrica piuttosto cereali secca poco amara

330ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Pale yellow gold colour, white foam head leaving some lacing and malty, grassy aroma. Taste is grainy, gluey with a fruity apple-like note. Light bodied, soft carbonation, semi-dry finish. OK.

Light clear golden blond coloured beer with average carbonation and a small white head. Strange hoppy sweet grassy aroma. Medium light bitter sweet palate. Finish is very light bitter sweet with a short and light ending. Very medium lager this one.
gold blond coloured sparkling body with a white head a hoppy aroma a hoppy spicy wattery taste with a bitter finish
Clear blond coloured beer with small white head and medium carbonation. Hoppy aroma. Full palate. Finish is bit bitter and slightly sweet.

Bottled 0,66L. Yellow pale color limpid and decidedly lacking in fizz. Much brittle head. Decidedly lacking in particularitity aroma: much light and washed out. Decidedly watery and wretchedt aste. Indeed simple. Typical discount beer.
A 4.8% version on keg in Venice. Blond with a white head. No aroma. Typical bland lager taste. Hay with light metallic notes. High carbonation.
Pale golden color, small white head. Aroma malt, grass. Taste malt, grass, citrus.
S: corn, alcohol A: clear, pale white, minimal head T: sweet P: lively carb ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled 0,66L. Discount beer. Slightly fizzy and limpid yellow color. Light head of short resistance. Much modest aroma with notes of straw and dampen grains. Dry taste, watery, little balanced and with a decided bitter on the end.

I originally saw this for about $7.99, which was a little too high for me. Then saw it for about the same price as the regular smoked porter, just under $6, so figured I'd should try it now. Vanilla adds some sweetness to it, perhaps a tad too sweet. Takes away some of the smokiness. Might add some to the aroma though. Getting some toasted and roasted malt flavors as well. Still great beer and worth the try, just not sure this it needed the variations.
Tap @ SKAAL, Copenhagen. Hazy brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, light smoked and vanilla. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish. 030418
Draught at Skaal. Dark brown colored with a small beige head. Sweet and light roasted aroma of caramel and vanilla. Sweet and light roasted flavor of hops and vanilla. Hoppy finish.
Draft at Skaal. Dark brown with a tan head. Roasty chocolate, slight coffee, vanilla bean roasty bitterness.
A stunner. Smooth roasted aromas but with delicate balance. Malty and smooth with a slight coffee taste. An excellent local brew.

one of those porters that is like eating the rocks in between the traintracks. Enormously roasty. Very dark brown with red bits. yummy aroma of ash, marmalade, tar. very hoppy and dry in the mouth, with enormously long lasting bitter burnt toast and dark chocolate finish. there’s fat malt under it all to cushion the roast attack. quality beer. assertive, balanced, well put together. very impressive. (tap at debacle)

This was called "Hop Heads using Modus Operandus" when I tried it the Wig and Pen in the middle of May. An APA served through a randall and I was happy! Tasting notes stated that the hops used were Galaxy. Fresh hops both on the nose and in the taste with a decent backbone of malt. Only had one pint of this as there were other beers to try.

Draught at Wig & Pen, Canberra. This was served through the randall and as a result came out ridiculously fresh! Appeared dark golden with an off-white head that diminished. Notes and flavour of caramel, biscuit, grapefruit, passionfruit and pine. Oily mouthfeel with a smooth, bitter finish. Extremely drinkable!
All very interesting but foul tasting. Fish oil predominates with a rotten vegetable overtone. Will stick to the other Wig and Pen favourites.

Draught at the Wig & Pen. My first beer through a randall (topaz hops where used in this batch). Arrived copper with a creamy white head which was fully lasting. Aroma was packed to the brim with sappy pine cones and pine needles, with strong earthy and herbal notes, caramel malts, marmalade and some salt. Flavor was a strong oily hop bitterness with strong notes of fish oil, sappy resin with some toffee malts hiding beneath and a salty finish. Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation, oil/watery texture, dry/creamy mouthfeel and a great finish. Superbly different.

cool, my first ever beer through a randall. this was a darkish IPA - copper i’d call it - quite full bodied and crystal malty - but with the most ridiculously huge hop flavour. the malt and the hop acidity reminded me of a strong cup of assam tea. the hops in the randall were Victorian Super Pride which wouldnt be my first choice! however i enjoyed the bracing eucalyptus/menthol oiliness. not subtle in the slightest but full marks for overthetopness.

column2: Watkins Glen, New York, United States
column5: Long legged and thinned by age, this still melomel pours a murky red with caramel golden underlying hues. Quite unattractive. The aroma is ghastly. Medicinal cherry juice and tart honey don’t stand a chance at a peaceful marriage of flavor, a flavor that’s further inhibited by intrusive alcohol. The alcohol level found here errs on the low side for a typical cherry melomel, so this is especially concerning. The flavor brings grainy, sweet cherry skins and less than adequate honey into the fold. Sweetness is moderate, tartness is mild, though at an unacceptable level. Acidity is misleading; relevant and noticeable enough to bear mention, though it also doesn’t succeed in it’s intended purpose. Alcohol is drying and probably the only aspect of the palate that keeps this drinkable. The finish is medium-dry and cloying, never approaching the nuances and sensations of pleasure so often observed in better mead recipes. The mouthfeel is slick and spiky with grainy particulates. An awful mead.

column2: Watkins Glen, New York, United States
column5: The aroma is cherry cough syrup with gobs of honey propping it up. Copper/amber in color with no head. Very nice cherry kissed mead that is quite reserved in terms of alcohol. I don’t know much about meads, about what is ideal for them, but I do very much enjoy this.
Nearly the perfect beer. Great on Nitro +++ Sampled at the University of Oregon campus location.

Burnt malt and bourbon like aroma. Deep reddish brown opaque color with a creamy taupe head. Chocolate sweetness starts with traces of smoke and a quick bitterness finishes. Medium bodied but slick with lower carbonation. Good stout. Oatmeal not that noticeable but adds to mouthfeel.

On tap at the West Linn pub. Pours very dark brown with a smooth khaki head. Roasty chocolate with a very smooth body. On nitro, so everything was smoothed out giving an a milky character. Nice beer, a bit more roastiness then Terminator and more dark chocolate flavor staying in the finish.

Pint - The Olympic Club - Centralia, WA Aroma – Nice dark malt aroma with a light hops and oat aroma. Appearance – Dark black in color, thin head and clear. Flavor – Great flavor with a deep dark malt and has coffee and toffee flavors. Palate – Nice Mouthfeel, good Oaty texture with a dry finish. Overall – Huge dark flavor this was a very smooth taste. Loved this beer great brewed beer.
Tasted @ the McMenamins Kennedyschool in Portland. Black colored brew. Roasted, malty aroma. Creamy, sweet malty, light hoppy and some chocolate. Overall kinda nice.

Tap... Poured opaque black with a huge brown head. Roasted malt aroma. Smooth palate with flavors of sweet malt and mellow hops and other candy flavors. Sorta like Double Chocolate Stout but everything was suppressed and everything could have been exaggerated a little more.
A dark roasted aroma. Opaque black color. No noticeable head. Medium bodied; creamy; low carbonation. Clean, non-bitter finish. Decent. Tastes like the style should.
Vielen Dank an kevnic2008! Milchig trübe goldene Farbe, ordentliche weiße Schaumkrone. Geruch süß hefig, bananig, leicht malzig. Geschmack süß malzig, brotig, bananig, guter Durstlöscher!
Pours a clear golden color. The aroma has notes of yeast, wheat. Thin body. Watery.
It’s unclear golden with a creamy, white head. The aroma has notes of rancid butter and less rancid butter. The flavor is medium sweet and very, very buttery - it’s clearly off...

Rating is for the Reiser Light-Weizen. 2.9%. Soupy cloudy dark yellow. Thin head. Heavy banana and light clove aroma. Nice and zesty, refreshing on the tongue. Obviously no alcohol notes. Light banana flavour, with a bit of clove in the finish. Minimal aftertaste. A bit watery as you go through the bottle. A little pepperish but a decent pop for the road.

column2: Ostheim v. d. Rhön, Bavaria, Germany
column5: 50 cl bottle. Rated on 30.03.2010 Bright orange-yellow colour, thin small-bubbled head. Aroma has lots of bready malt and some glue. Flavour is stale and slightly acidic with cardboard, bitterness, bready malt and hints of vegetables. Drinkable.

column2: Ostheim v. d. Rhön, Bavaria, Germany
column5: It’s yellow-golden with a creamy, white head and the aroma has notes of newly-harvested grain, malt and flower. The flavour has a light sweetness and the same pleasant notes as the aroma. The finis is dry and refreshing with light notes of straw.

column2: Ostheim v. d. Rhön, Bavaria, Germany
column5: (bottle) Clear, golden colour with a medium-sized foamy white head. Medium-sweet grainy and slightly bready malt aroma with herbal and light spicy hops. Light-bitter flavour, soft grainy malty base, slightly bready and somewhat chalky with herbal notes from the beginning; light to medium bodied, quite smooth on carbon; dry, moderately bitter finish with balanced malty and herbal hoppy accents. Decent German Pilsener.

column2: Ostheim v. d. Rhön, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Bottle (500ml): Pale golden coloured, medium-sized white lacing head; distinctive sweet-malt and aromatic hops in the nose; moderate bitter-sweet flavour, light bodied, soft MF; lingering bitter-sweet, later bitter-aromatic finish. A clean, fine, well-crafted Pilsener

column1: Tama no Megumi (Ishikawa) Tama no Yorokobi Sake
column5: At the brewery. My second sake rating, so still don’t really know what I am doing. Aroma bit fruity, alcohol, pear, apple and pine. Taste nice and fruity, summer berries, bit of grape, pear again. Very smooth and pretty easy to drink. Touch of sweet creaminess there afterwards. Much nicer than their beers which were ok. This was very nice.
Cask conditioned @ Guide Dog, Soton. Golden Copper. Fruity hops. Sweetish malt and mild bitterness. Fairly standard pale hopback beer nothing exciting but reasonably pleasant.
Cask at Oliver Twist - Stockholm June ’07. Dominated by coffee big time. Brew with hints of roasted malts and chocolate. I wish I lived down the street from Oliver Twist - outstanding pub.

Cask, Oliver Twist Deepest brown, slight film leaving without lacing. Rather profound, strong complexified coffee that only develop its cherry, jammy complexity in mouth, though it feels a bit tart there and this removes from the coffee enjoyment. pear-like nuances. Of course all about the malts, faintest leafy hops. Tough graininess throughout. Smooth, rounded palate. Not a bad one.

Cask at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Pours out in a hazy dark brown colour, almost black topped with a creamy beige foam. Rich and harmounious aroma of black coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malts and flowery hops. Full, creamy and roasted flavour of black coffey, cocoa-power, nuts and dark chocolate. Full creamy body and finish of black coffee, nuts, ash and mild but lingering fruity aromatic hops

(Cask at Oliver Twist, Stockholm, 2 June 2007) Black colour with foamy beige head. Roasted nose with immense notes of black coffee and hints of chocolate. Roasted taste with a dominant coffee character, hints of chocolate, moccha and bitter coffee notes in the finish. A bit like drinking cold black, strong coffee. Not very modest, but very interesting (I agree with omhper, it was about time they brewed something adventurous again). Lovely coffee character.

Kaffekasken is a old Swedich way to drink coffey by adding a small amount of vodka to your coffey. This beer defenetly got the coofey aromas. As from what i could se at OT they have had some consults from a barista in making this beer. Me, not beeing a coffey drinker think that the aromas are to overvelming and the beer would be better if the aromas would be a little less.

Cask@Oliver Twist (thanks omhper!) Really dark brown colour with mediumsized creamy head. Aroma is a big coffeekick along with some roasted malts. Flavour is the same with some hops and sugar added. Also a lot of salted licorace. A real coffee bomb, and nice surprise to have something new from Nils Oscar!

Cask at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Dark cloudy brown, small creamy head. Pungent coffee aroma. Fairly sweet with coffee and crystalized sugar and vague notes of licorice luring underneath. Rounded uncomplicated malt structure. Salty finish. Finally something experimental from Nils Oscar again!

Bottle, Oliver twist fest Small 70L batch, 1g of coffee per liter on top of the chocolate. Rather generous light brown head covers the pretty black pour. Rather intense, dark chocolate nose bringing out a fair bit of acidity. Deep roastiness with a mild fruitiness emerging through, but not necessarily individual notes, just a rather general fruity feel, possibly even from the chocolate. medium bodied, fairly grainy bitterness. A good effort from Sigtuna, especially having brought the cocoa back themselves!

Bottled. Black opaque colour, with small beigeish head. Really dark chocolate in aroma along with some hints of coffee and vanilla. Also some bittering hops. Flavour is dry dark fruit along with chocolate and a lot of roasted notes.

Bottled at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Completely black,small head. Roasty licorice/chocolate aroma. Dry and crisp, intensely roasty. Fairly light bodied. Licorice mingles with chocolate in the finish. Lighter and more crisp than I’d guessed it to be.

Bottle: Golden, smaller but persistent foamy white layer, moderate sweet-malty nose with a fruity tinge and a touch of aromatic hops in the background; moderate bitter-sweet flavour, light malty base; slightly lingering bitter-pale-malty finish. Not bad, but not completely convincing........

Bottle. Golden, low carbonation, big creamy off-white head. Very faint hayish and metallic aroma. Lightbodied, a bit hay, just enough hops to balance and give a resiual dryness. Fairly light and watery.

(bottle) Clear, very pale golden, almost yellow coloured hue with a medium-sized blond foamy head. Slightly sweet, grainy and slightly perfumed and a bit green malt aroma with restrained herbal notes in the background. Medium-sweet flavour, medium to light bodied, moderately carbonated mouthfeel. Strong grainy, cereal character with faint notes of honey; moderately sweet, grainy finish with a cereal-like aftertaste. Not a particulary well-balanced, but acceptable grain-soup. Much better than the Zwickel version.

Bottle (purchased at the brewery): Golden coloured, hazy with clumps of yeast, rather small fluffy white head, that quickly collapses; moderate clovey and fruity nose (bananas, with lemons in the background), light to moderate sweet-tart flavour with a spoonful of bitterness, quite light bodied; light fruity finish with a light acidity and tartness in the very end. No reason to cry, but no reason to become a Weizen lover...

(bottle) Hazy, golden to light-orange colour with a fluffy, slightly yellow foamy head. Dusty, quite sharp and strong phenol-spicy nose, light sweet and acidic; noticeable wheat-character with citrus and a touch of banana-fruit in the background. Light sweet flavour, light to medium bodied, lively carbonated mouthfeel. Moderately wheaty and fruity but most of all phenolic taste; sweet and fruity, slightly acidic finish with a light-grainy aftertaste. Lacks balance.

(bottle) Clear, yellow colour with a medium-sized foamy white head. Sweet cirus-fruity and mineral-water like nose. Sweet flavour, citrusy taste with faint notes of grainy malt; artificially sweet and slightly tart finish.

Bottle (purchased at the brewery): Pale yellow, immedeately collapsing unknown head; mainly sweet-lemony, a bit tart and a bit grainy nose; mainly solid sweet flavour, only a bit of bitterness detectable, light bodied; traces of tartness in the sweetish finish. Not even refreshing.......

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: Bottled, 500ml from Vino in Stockbridge, Edinburgh. Gold with white head. Hazy yellow gold with white head. There is a bready, yeasty character to this from the start, some sweetness, lemon juice but a touch on the thin side. 500ml is a lot of this beer, it becomes somewhat flabby. It's okay overall.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: 500ml bottle from Scottish Real Ale Shop. Pours hazy pale gold, thin white head. Aromas of lemon, lager. Taste is very fruity too, mostly fresh lemon though. Light body, crisp finish. OK.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: Bottle at home a while ago from alesela golden blonde, dry, herbal, nondescript, medium bodied. Atrocious labels.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: Bottle, Christmas gift from Tom. Clear golden body with a thin white head. Lively carbonation. Light lacing. Aroma of lemon, grain and faint metal. Clean flavour of citrus, lemon and grass. Thin body with a watery texture. Nice fizz. A smooth, easy drinking Lager. Very nice.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: Bottle. This is a nice simple pale lager without much going for it but it ain’t bad either.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: 500ml bottle courtesy of JohnRMurdoch - clear straw, thin white head, aroma of corn and grain, hint of resin, lager malt, grassy, a bit bitter

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: Bottle from Hippo Beers. Golden amber colour, big head. Dry resin, corn grain aroma. Corn resin flavour, bitter aftertaste. Quite a big tasting lager.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: Bottle from a garden centre. Pours clear gold with a thick white head. Decent aroma decent flavour. A bit like a golden ale. Good though a slight herbiness on finish definitely drinkable. I thought ok.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: Pours golden with a nice prop head. Nose is metallic, spicy and herbaceous. Taste of more herbs, some pale male. Palate is well balanced - light to medium body n texture, clean finish. Overall, a well made pils.

column2: Isle of Colonsay, Argyll & Bute, Scotland
column5: 9th July 2011 Scopeys East Croydon tasting - Cheers Paul! Clear pale gold beer, tiny white head. Light semi dry palate. Dry lagerish malt, tiny bit of tangy hop. Dry finish. Drinkable - certainly had worse lagers.

Sampled on tap at DDC. The pour reveals a dark copper color with ruby highlights and a slightly cloudy, medium, offwhite head that leaves superb lacing on the glass. Very attractive aroma of hops, with caramel malt and candied fruits. Excellent flavor of hops, caramel malt and candied fruits, the alcohol is not detectable. The body is medium with a liquorous texture and gentle carbonation. Unlike a lot of barley wines, it’s not intense, but it’s not sybtle eather, it’s complex and an easy sipper, it’s dangerously easy to drink.

Tap at DDC. Clear redish-mahogany body topped by a beige ring of foam. Splendid barley wine that puts more emphasis on its complex fruity flavours rather than the thick caramelized malts. Dessert fruits flavours ranging from berries to kiwis(!) in a rich caramel and candy sweetness. Sweet creamy malted body with a cake/pancake taste and mouthfeel. Just the right amount of grassy hops to balance the whole thing and give the beer an overall herbal feeling. Excellent. Who could have thought I would find a top-class Barley Wine from New Brunswick in Montreal’s DDC? Certainly not my cousin Jeremy… he’s 3 years old.

On tap at DDC, June 2 2007. A clear reddish brown ale with a still appearance, a very thin light moka head. In aroma, a pleasant fruity sweet malt, like treacle candy, vinous notes and classy floral hops. In mouth, an honest and balanced caramel malt with good citrusy hops, resinous, and warming alcohol in finale....very nice.

My Bottom Line: A luxurious mouthfeel sets the stage for a complex baccate fruitiness to ride the seductive caramel maltiness of this most classy English-style Barley Wine. A resinous hop finish is perfectly positioned, and the following sip will be taken shortly after the lips and gums have been thoroughly licked clean. Further Personal Perceptions: -A sheet of foam laces atop the filtered blood red. -This vintage has been perfectly aged. -There is some alcohol warming, but in no way does it bother the experience; in fact, this warmth makes you want to slip deeper into your seat. -Earthiness tags along the resinous hop presence. -A grandiose beer from the Pump House; amazing work Daniel! 2005 vintage, on tap at Dieu du Ciel!, Montréal.
Cask conditioned at The Lamb & Flag, Oxford. Gold with white head. Malty beer with a distinct vanilla, buttery note, quite oily then a little bready. Somewhat disappointing.

2015 version at the Fox, Hanwell 13/5/2015. Deep, clear amber in colour, with a frothy, off-white, head. Flabby, sweet, malts, a touch of hedgerow fruit, culminating in a decent, bitter, finish. So so.

Cask at the Bull Inn, Stanford Dingley, Berkshire. A pale chestnut colour with a beige head; citrus and floral aroma; predominantly orange flavour; pepery and gently bitter finish. Worth the trip to deepest rural Berkshire to seek it out.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Northampton BF. A straw gold coloured beer with a whitish head. The aroma is lovely and hoppy with grapefruit notes and a hint of peppery spice. The taste is also wonderfully hoppy. More quenching grapefruit notes. Lovely bitterness. I am very impressed with Alehouse’s use of hops. Better than Oakham IMO.
Cask at GBBF 2010. A hazy amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has light notes of malt and lemons. The flavor is sweet matly with notes of citrus fruits, leading to a bitter finish.

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 2010, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Clear medium to dark amber color with a average, frothy to fizzy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted - caramel, moderate hoppy, medicine. Flavor is moderate sweet and heavy bitter with a average to long duration, metalic, medicine, sharp. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat, finish is light metalic. [20100805]
Cask Handpump at the GBBF, Earl’s Court 05/08/2010 Peppery aroma. Copper golden coloured fruity and bitter with a hint of dryness in a grainy malt finish.
Cask@GBBF2010. Amber colour, small white head. Aroma is peas, hops, grass and some earthy notes. Flavour is wooden, a bit nutty, caramel malty, a bit grassy as well as slightly sappy.
From cask. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is mild fruity and slight herbal. Acidic and dry hoppy. Bitter and dry. Slight acidic bitterness. Too sharp for my liking.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Northampton BF. A brown coloured beer with a beige coloured head. The aroma is a bit farty and dry. The taste is malty. There is some fruit but it’s ordianry and thin. Disappointing because the Light Ale was lovely.

Cask at GBBF 2007. An amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with primary notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of hops and caramel as well as lighter notes of citrus and bread. The body is thin.

Hazy copper coloured ale covered by a lasting off-white ring. Spicy toasted malts appear at first bready, but remind more of pancakes and with a strange algae-like herbal touch. Blueberry and strawberry toppings join in as well. Surprising flavours that you would not expect to be so good a match, but the balance is present and the assembling is efficient. One of my favourite from Wales, but quite watery.
Copper with a small white head. Malty aroma with a medicine off-note. Dry flavour with grassy hops and a hint of peat flavour.

Cask @ GBBF 2007, London. Hazy light to medium amber color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, medicine. Flavor is light to moderate sweet with a short duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat.

Cask@GBBF2007. Deep amber colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma is really much a wet cold cellar with mould and some balancing up caramel and fruity hops. Flavour is extremely wooden with some very earthy notes. Very refreshing and different.

Cask, GBBF 2007. Nose is charcoal and firework. Strong burnt charcoal, some hop. Appearance is dark chestnut, no head. Mouth is burnt and medical disinfectant, some sourness. Overwhelmingly burnt. What were they thinking?

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Northampton BF. A hazy murky brown color (not golden as the commercial description suggests). The aroma is malty but with hints of sulphur. The taste is malty and tastes a bit homebrew with some chemical qualities. Not very good.

column1: Eve's Roadkill For Eve Dry Cider
column5: From the barrel - Northampton BF. A hazy, light lime green coloured still cider. The aroma is sweet and fruity with lots of pulp but there does appear mto be more pear than apple notes. This is replicated in the taste. Not sure if it’s the dessert apples but it seems a bit of a hybrid to me. Hints of sourness. Very tasty but odd, but how welcome. A third cider producer in Northants.

Bottle. Nice "homebrew" feel to the packaging. Pours very pale yellow. Quite carbonated but that’s fine by me for this style. the nose is very limey and sweet. Intriguing hoppy mouthful. Peppery in some ways and kind of a blue cheese element. Not much else to note for me but I could have a few at a bbq definitley. It’s that kind of beer.

Bottle. Hazy light orange with no head. Aromas are caramel and wheat with soft spices and vanilla. Some sweet mellow lemon. Flavours are soft citrus and spices with vanilla and cream. Quite yeasty and spritzy. Dry on the finish.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Northampton BF. A pale blonde coloured beer. The aroma is citrus fruity but is a little tired. The taste is quite fruity and shap. Decent enough. Score 3.1 Subsequent rating scored 2.3. Average becomes 2.7

Gravicask (PBF2015, Tuesday) (6:4:6:4:13+=3.3+) Very pleasant quaffable dark beer. Plenty of bitter hops in the finish. More porter-like than properly stout. Still has plenty of roasted malt aromas and tastes, but it’s not got the depth of burntness that I expect from stouts.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Northampton BF. A black coloured stout with a tiny wisp of tan coloured head. The aroma is smoky with licquorice, roast and fruit notes. The taste is lovely with more fruit, smoke and light roast. A very tasty well brewed stout which really delivers.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Northampton BF. A hazy, copper coloured beer with a fruity aroma but with nasty notes of nail polish. The taste is like the aroma. A bit of a fizzy mess which tastes like it’s not brewed out. Very homebrew-like.
Cask (Peterborough BF 2007) Orange, no head. Starts with a smack of fruity hops, fills in with a great malty body, which gives it its finish.

Cask, Peterborough Fest 07. Amber gold with a small head. Aromas are weetabix malts with earthy notes. Hoppy and spicy. Flavours are malty with sweetened grapefruit. Some melon and kiwi. Has a great fruity bitter finish. Good stuff.

Pint pulled at the Horse & Groom in Caulcott (Oxfordshire), a clear deep amber colour wilth a light foamy white head. A warming malt aroma with a good hop tang. Very smooth in the mouth, slightly buttery with an easy malt flavour and a good bitter finish. Maieb - served in top condition this was as good as you suspected.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Northampton BF. A copper coloured beer with a loose white head. The aroma is sulphuric with rotten oranges. The taste, thankfully, is much better. Nice hops with plenty of rich citrus notes. Probably oranges. Wasn’t perfectly fresh which is a shame, as I reckon this beer has huge potential.

Cask conditioned at The Anchor, Digbeth, Birmingham. Copper colour with white head. A well balanced bitter, a fuller light malty, biscuity body with a sweetish fragrant hop. Long in flavour and palate, juicy and balanced. Lovely beer, much enjoyed.

Cask-conditioned at the Lower Red Lion, St Albans 7/7/07. Brown coloured with a moderate head. Had the hoppy aroma of most Ale House beers with a whiff of malt. Flavour was of grapefruit with a decent dry finish. Good, but this was nearing the end of the barrel and was a bit subdued.

Cask handpull at Lower Red Lion, St Albans. I fully endorse maeib’s rating This is amber with bubbly beige head. Good sharp pale grapefruit aroma. Rather amazing in the mouth. The hops on the finish are just stunning. OK so a better malt structure would be good, but this hoppy finish is almost startling.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Northampton BF. As I had thoroughly enjoyed the two Alehouse beers I had had previously at the fesival, I decided to sign off for this year with a third. This one didn’t disappoint. A mid brown coloured beer. The aroma is full of juicy hops. Orangey citrus aromas. The taste is also great hops. The malts are lovely too and really balanced the beer. Rock On Alehouse.

Rated:04.06.2007 Bottle brown,330 ml Very nice strong head, foamy, off-white, aroma is grassy, malt, taste is distinctive yeast, kind of smooth and not aggresive alcohol, kind of bit dry aftertaste, in closer investigation one could feel even some delicate notes of coffee or nuts and ends with white vine notes, very complex and interesting taste but not as much as it comes to aroma.

nice strong head, foamy, off-white, aroma is grassy, manure, old malt, taste is distinctive yeast, kind of smooth and not aggresive alcohol, kind of bit dry aftertaste, in closer investigation one could feel even some delicate notes of coffie or nuts and ends with white vine notes, very complex taste and very cheap beer, interesting, but you better not smell it

Draught at brewery. Pours black with a small, fizzy, light brown head, somewhat lasting with fair lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (molasses, chocolate, nutty), light hops (grass), average yeast (leather) with notes of tar and cola. Light bodied, oily texture, soft carbonation, and a bitter finish. Long duration, light sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.

On tap @ Palisade Brewery poured a translucent brownish black with a lasting amber head. Aromas of milk chocolate, coffee and vanilla. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of cocoa, light coffee and vanilla with a crisp slightly watery finish.

On tap @ Palisade Brewery poured a clear amber with a lasting ivory head. Aromas of citrus, carmel and a hint of earthiness. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of toasted malt, carmel and light citrus and earthiness with a smooth moderatly bitter finish.

column1: Kannah Creek Three Fjords Amber Lager
column5: tap at the brewpub - This beer has a very mild, slightly fruity aroma. The flavor has moderate hops bitterness and light fruit notes. It’s medium bodied with very low carbonation.

column1: Kannah Creek Three Fjords Amber Lager
column5: On tap @ Kannah Creek poured a clear amber with a small lasting ivory head. Aromas of citrus, carmel and a bit of fruitiness. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of bread, carmel and citrus with a crisp clean finish.

column1: Great Basin Paradise Valley Classic Pale Ale (CPA)
column5: on tap-pours a white head and gold color. Aroma is medium malt, earthy. Taste is medium malt-caramel, earthy hops.

column1: Great Basin Paradise Valley Classic Pale Ale (CPA)
column5: Clear gold with small white head. Aroma of sweet malt, citrus, and hops. Flavors are balanced hops and malt with some notes of bread and caramel. Decent, yet pretty standard pale ale.

column1: Great Basin Paradise Valley Classic Pale Ale (CPA)
column5: On tap @ Great Basin poured a clear golden amber with a minimal off white head. Aromas of biscuits, citrus and light carmel. Palate was light to medium bodied and crisp. Flavors of biscuits, light carmel and a hint of citrus with a crisp finish.

Bottle 33cl from 3 Brasseurs Strasbourg. A cloudy amber brown beer with good head, got some gushing. Nose is spicy with caramel and slightly sour background. Taste is quite sweet, tannic. Aroma is on caramel, toasted caramel, spice, light butterscotch, light lactic / sour notes that provides cherries notes. Finish is a bit vinous, good honey and caramel touch, pleasant and correct complexity;

Appearance: An amber-orange body with a thick, white head and a fair amount of carbonation. Smell: Some malt with a light sweetness. No maple syrup aroma. Taste: Slight roasted malt with a bitter finish, some caramel maybe but still no sign of the maple syrup. Mouthfeel: Better than the initial taste with a slight, shy sweetness. As it warms, the elusive maple comes out a little. A bit thin but i can taste the hops finish with it’s bitterness. Maple kind of an aftertaste only. There’s also a taste reminiscent of nuts.

Flip-top .75 litre bottle (most likely the French version): shared with my son on Christmas Day 2016. An off-white head sat on a reddy brown body that oozed maltiness from start to finish. More semi-sweet caramel and toffee notes than ’maple syrup’ in the nose and flavour for me. Quite liked it.

From a French bottle, light yeasty aroma, this is quite well balanced for a Belgian ale, I was worried the maple syrup would make it too sweet, but there is enough spice on the finish to make it quite drinkable .
Bottle from Les 3 Brasseurs Lille (FR). Amber with very rich beige head. Roasted carmel (not very intenese) taste with dry moderae bitterness, which stays in the aftertaste.

Surprisingly huge gusher. Surprising because this brewer’s beers are generally quite clean, even the bottle refermented ones. This is yeasty, peachy, Vienna malts, not bad but a straightforward blonde. Medium bitter (for the style) and simple malt base. Luckily not sugary and also quite a nice mouth feel. Not nice that I lost half the bottle though... (33cl bottle from the

Interesting dark orange pour with a hint of frothy head that dissipates. Sugary hop aroma. Oddly complex, as there’s certainly a general sugary (maple sugar!) malt backing, but also some definite hoppy and fruity notes that seem to interchange. An interesting taste, though it gets all mixed up in the finish, which makes drinking this a bit of a chore by the end of it. Certainly an interesting one!

Swing-top bottle - 750ml. Beautiful cloudy amber body with a huge off-white foamy head. Decent malty/hoppy aroma with maple hints. Alcohol is well hidden. Taste is well balanced but it lacks complexity. Carbonation is a bit agressive. Ends with a decent bittersweet finish. Drinkable.

Swing-top de 750ml. Liquide orangé foncée presque cuivré avec une mousse beige. Un nez simple sucré qui respire plus le houblon que le sirop d’érable. Une bouche fruitée, sucrée, dominée par la levure belge. Les saveurs d’érable sont introuvables.

Bottle (341 ml). Split 2-ways with Minderbinder. To be honest, we didn’t finished it. Appearance: Clear golden/orange with a small white head and some lacing. Aroma: Perfume, yeast/spices, alcohol notes (which is kind of weird for a 5 % abv beer) and light rotten fruits. Taste: Some spiciness, rotten fruits, perfumy notes an alcohol. Palate: Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Fruity finish. Overall: It’s pretty bad, but at least it can be drunk without the fear of passing away unlike La Place du Marché and Douce Caresse.

Bottle 341ml. Pours dark golden with low white head. Some lacing. Aroma is of fruits, sugar. Taste is of fruits, slight cardboard. Palate: Medium body. Medium carbonation. Overall: Not gross. Sweet. Not much to taste.
I come from France and I came here last summer and I loved this beer!!!

Summer 2012 Had this as part of a mixed 6-pack from a convenience store on St-Laurent. It poured a clear light amber with a malty caramel aroma but then with the first sip it completely fell apart. This sucked, the whole 6 pack was horrible, the color & look were fine for each style but they must have been infected or past their prime because every single beer tasted like bile. My brother finished them as no one else wanted to touch the stuff.

26/6/2018. Bottle at the Renaissance hotel, Las Vegas. Pours cloudy reddish brown with an average sized off-white/pink head. Aroma of raspberry, citrus, bittersweet fruits and light biscuit. Moderate sweetness, medium bitterness, light sours. Moderate body, slight watery texture, average carbonation.

Draft at Great Basin, Reno. Pours a reddish purple color with a fluff of white head. Lots of fresh and tart raspberries in the nose, the same in the taste. Really quite full of raspberries, sweet and tart. I suppose it is pretty one-dimensional, but it is well done and overall a tasty beer. Broke up the flight nicely.

Draft sample at the Reno airport from notes. Pours a slightly hazy reddish amber color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have a pale malt base with decent raspberry fruitiness, light fruit, watery, thin, average at best.
On tap at the brewery Pours clear red/golden with a small off-white head, light lacing. Aroma of sweet berries. Taste of berries and sweet Decent
Draft at the Reno source. Hazy reddish amber color. Aroma of raspberry. Taste has fresh berry and lemon. Easy drinking and not overly sweet.
On tap at Capitol Beer & Tap Room. Pours reddish brown With a great raspberry aroma and a nice pinkish head. There is a watery light malt flavor, but with some delicious raspberry.

as a foofoo beer, it’s actually done well, but this type of "beer" is just not to my liking. wine-coolerish in look and flavor...and aroma. nothing delicate about it. just sweet berry. works when it’s over 90 degrees, but even then..." 2/09 - compared to the yummy fruit lambics i’ve had lately, this just doesn’t match up. the chicks seem to like it, but my wife doesn’t."

Thanks Dara for the bottle. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a semi-dark red color with a one finger white foamy head that dissipated within about a minute. There wasn’t much lacing about this. The smell had a nice light raspberry interweaving itself in and out of some sweet malt. It seemed there were some light cherries and strawberries that were there as well. The taste was slightly sweet and added a decent tartness from the raspberries. On the palate, it sat about a light to medium on the body with a decent sessionability about it. The carbonation was there and decent for the style and for me. Slight tart raspberry aftertaste with a refreshing sort of crisp finish. Overall, good fruit beer, it seemed pretty authentic in the fruits that came out at least to me.

12 oz bottle a friend gave me for my birthday. Pours a dark red with a good white head that sticks around. Very spritzy. Got plenty of fruitiness going on. Very light-bodied, maybe a tad watery. Good raspberry presence. The ladies would love this.

Las Vegas, NV - Total Wine - Summerlin - 12 oz bottle. Pours a murky orangeish-purplish with an off-white bubbly head. Aroma has a hint of berries, some slight fruit muffin qualities. Flavor is pleasant with some nice fruity berry accents, a hint of yeast and just a touch of sour tart candy. Mouthfeel has a pleasant spritz to it. Not bad.
Bottle conditioned, a cloudy gold with a filmy beige head. A very yeasty and zesty citrus hop aroma. Effervescent and light, easy hopping with some fruity flavours. Quite a refreshing beer.

Appearance: very pale blond color, semi-transparent. Little head, of white color and few persistent. Aroma: fruitiness of green apples, peaches and pears: sourness of lemon and grapefruits. Herby and citric hoppy. Pale malty odor. Flavor: highly malty, yeasty and fruitiness. Apricots, banana and red apples. Light sourness of lemon. Reminiscences of honey and sugar. Some rancid problem. Low hoppy finish. Palate: light body, semi-oily texture. Very low carbonation. Refreshing beer; but neutral and without own character.

Bottle, in Valdivia’s city. Has a yellowish, very turbid color. The head is average, very rapid. The aroma is weak, malty and something of herbs, humid grass. In the palate it is soft enough, the masses appear and enough yeast (Too much). In the flavor there is no much, the malty is detected, but "sticky". Flour and cereals. Has a not good finish, with something of acidity. The body is light, with a just carbonation. It is not a good beer, is regular. It is better than the commercial beers of Chile, but has nothing special.

Bottled at Backstage, Patio Bellavista Pours a very hazy yellow color. Head is medium, white and fast diminishing. It leaves a small film. Aroma has grassy, herbal hops but it’s mainly malty and underdeveloped. It shows notes of cereal, grains, dough, white bread and a touch of apricots. Clearly the fermentation period was too short. Flavor is very malty, cereally, unrefined. I get notes of bread, dough, cereal, some soft oranges and not much more. Again, unripe. Just a step above the typical macro pale lager. Light to medium body and medium carbonation. Dull finish and aftertaste. The texture is juicy. A kinda’ refreshing beer but boring and amateur-ish.

Cask conditioned at Moreton in Marsh Beer Fest ’11. Amber with white head. Initially quite a tea like hop on a mid malt Rich Tea biscuit body. Then a little lemon note for some interest. Never really gets beyond this, although a dry finish. Ok.

Cask at Dean Swift. It pours golden yellow, with a decent bubbly white head. The nose is wood, toffee apple and white sugar. The taste is cardboard, wood, leather, astringency, lemon pith, brown bread and sweaty sock, with a long dry finish. Light to medium body and low carbonation. Not great.
Cask gravity at Rare Breeds BF 2007. Copper, thin bubbly off white. Biscuity citrus session bitter. Very quaffable, decent lemon/lime bite on finish. Slight mineral flavour.
Aroma malt, korn. Utseende klar lys gylden med hvitt skum. Smak malt, eple, korn, humle. Lett lager med lite fylde, lett fruktighet, kjedelig. Flaske smakt juli 2012, 33cl 4,7%

0,33l bottle. Clear very pale yellow colour with quickly disappearing white head. Aroma: Very light skunky, grainy something. Taste: Water....tastes like yellow water...okey, has a slightly sweet start and a very light bitter mouthfeel but don’t get me wrong, my imagination helps me out becouse it’s extremely watery. Very light body with medium carbonation. Short watery sour finish...Terrible beer...is it a beer?
330ml bottle. Clear pale golden color with white head. Light malty aroma. Sweet taste. Light thin body with soft carbonation.

Pours a clear yellow golden color, topped with a medium sized frothy head, white and no real retention. Very mild aroma, just some grainy notes and a bit skunky. Taste is sweet with some mild bitterness in the finish. Very light body, slightly watery. Not the best attempt, really.

column1: Omaha Jacks Rancho Mirage Brown Ale
column5: on tap-pours a disappearing off white head and red/copper color. Aroma is medium malt-caramel, nutty. Taste is medium malt-caramel, nutty, some hops bite, slight metallic (less than the red). OK/mild carbonation.

column1: Omaha Jacks Rancho Mirage Brown Ale
column5: This was served to me in the sampler instead of the porter. The aroma was sweet chocolate malt with a slight roastiness. The appearance was brown with a light red hue. Flavor was a mildly sweet malt flavor and that was about it. It was crisp, resfreshing, and light for the stlye. I guess there was a little roastiness here too. Not alot going on, but not bad I guess.
Draught. Rating #7. Hazy golden yellow color with a thick white head and decent lacing. Big apricot aroma and flavor followed by a light wheat finish. (2123)
Clear golden with a fizzy white head. Perfumey apricot aroma and taste with a watery palate and a finish that just falls flat.

Sample at brewery. Hazy orange-yellow color. Big aroma of apricot with a touch of wheat. Flavor is huge on the apricot sweetness. Medium-light body. A non-beer drinking companion really liked this one.
On tap a while back. Color was a cloudy gold. Aroma of apricot &#40alot of it&#41 and wheat. Flavor was much of the same; crisp and pretty nice for the style.

I have drank this numerous times and failed to rate. Orange and hazy. Apricot essence aroma on top of a big wheatiness. The flavor is big wheat and decent apricot. Their hefe is massively wheaty, I assume this is just that with apricot essence used during fermentation. Not bad.
on tap-pours an off white head that laces and dark gold/orange color. Aroma is apricot, wheat. Taste is apricot, wheat, some metallic.

Hazy Orange color while sitting at the brewery on our way to GABF. Lots of Apricot aromas. Even more on the flavor with a definte wheat flavor. Very very wheaty. I actually liked this and it’s not a style I usually go for.

It has a moderately creamy foam, and lots of great yeast residues floating around in the glass. It may deter some beer drinkers, but not me. I chew me like through the sediment if it is necessary for the overall impression. Wheat malts fresh aroma of freshly harvested grain is evident in the flavor and mixes lively with a little hard roasted malt. Slightly tangy berry fruits are to find only in taste but replaced over time by the hard roasted malt, newly harvested grains, dark caramel and banana and chocolate notes. It is very rich and tasteful.

Transfer from BA review on 5-29-12- Poured from bottle into pint glass Appearance – Pours a hazy brown color with a nice thick tan head. The head fades very slowly over time to give a small level of lacing. Smell – The aroma is heaviest of brown bread. These bready aromas are mixed with some dark fruit aromas of cherry and prune. Mingling with all these aromas is a very light alcohol aroma. Very nice blend overall. Taste – The flavors start out with a more malty and bready flavor. The flavors quickly change in nature, in which they sweeten at the expense of the malty due to flavors of sweeter fruit of cherry and prune entering the taste. These fruit tastes lose their sweetness however and begin lightly sour at the end the taste. As the fruit flavors begin to lightly sour, there is also the entrance of some spicy and yeasty flavors as well which when arriving with a lightly boozy flavor leave an intriguing warming taste on the tongue. Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is just above average with the carbonation level just below normal. Overall both suit the beer well with its sweeter then more sour flavors. Overall – A nice, slightly tart (but not too sour) weizenbock with a nice warming feel the is very pleasant to sit back and sip. I find this one a quite nice brew.

12oz bottle. Pours a clear light amber brown color with a thin creamy tan head. Aroma of toasted malt, banana, and clove. Tastes of banana sweetness, spiciness (pepper and clove), toasted malt, and yeast.

12 oz. bottle from Manchester Discount Beverage in Manchester, CT. Pours a cloudy rust color, not much lacing. Smell is spicy citrus, dark fruits. Definite plum and coriander, Belgian yeast. Taste is the best part, fruity, a bit roasty, sweet fruit and caramel, mild hop presence. Mouth feel is great, a bit viscous yet effervescent and alive. A great American version of this style. Definitely a smooth drinkability and plenty of kick to go with it. Advertised as a double dunkel but has single smoothness. This brewery, in general puts out really good stuff, will plan on reviewing more of their beers as soon as I can.

Heavy clove nose, with cocoa and soil underneath. Murky brown, wispy sediments, firm medium tan head. Creamy mouthfeel. Cocoa, clove, banana flavor. A tad boozy, but the brewer does label this as a double dunkelweizen. While it certainly isn’t quaffable, it’s hardly a chore. Pretty effin neat and a meal unto itself.

17th November 2011 Opaque cloudy red - brown beer. Tidy pale tan head. Palate is smooth with a trailing carbonated bite. Sweetish caramel malt, well balanced banana esters. Lactose and a little tangy fruits before the semi dry finish. Drinkable.

Bottle. Moderate toasted cereal for the malt, light to moderate cooked orange for the hops, moderate dough for the yeast, with hints of brown sugar and cream sherry. Head is tiny, off-white with no lacing and is fully diminishing. Color is murky, dark reddish brown. Flavor starts lightly to modeately sweet and acidic, then finishes lightl sweet and acidic. Palate is medium to full, creamy with a lively carbonation and a lightly astringent finish. Nice representation of a Dunkleweizen, sweet, full and rich.
12 oz bottle from Baruni’s in Baden, PA. Nearly perfect in every regard. Still wish my sister lived in Easton where I could get these good ales even fresher.
200711: Brown color with a fine beige foam. Fruity aroma. Sweet caramel flavor and notes from the wheat.

(35 cl bottle from Toft Vin) Pours cloudy brown with quickly dissipating head that leves lace. Aroma is malty with banana notes and a slightly acidic hint. Flavour follows the nose with some more pronounced acidity and a whiff of cardboard in addition to the caramel maltiness. Oily texture, soft carbonation, full body and a dry finish. Definitely not my kind of style.

Originally rated July 2007. Second brew tonight of the St-Urbain series. Pours a clean bronze colour with little to no carbonation. Off-white head that is foamy and does not stay as long as their blonde. A bit of lacing sticks to the glass. The aromas are pretty much the same as the blonde, and so is the mouthfeel. Again, that not-so-good metallic taste appears in the taste. The malt is different in this one, obviously, to make this a red lager. Meant to be dranked in the bottle though. I think I prefer the blonde.

Originally rated July 2007. This beer is getting bashed for trying to look like a microbrew, but being brewed by Labatt’s. Testing both of them tonight. The label does look nice though. Pours a golden colour with active carbonation. The head is pretty impressive for a macro lager. White, foamy and creamy, with lots of retention, leaving decent lacing all around. Smell of fresh malt at first pour, but then turns into some kind of adjunct aroma. Watery mouthfeel with a certain graininess to it. The taste is somewhat metallic at first, with a little malt and a smoke undertone in the finish. Kind of weird, but not really horrible. Swill material for sure.

A- dark brown with thick foamy light tan head that fades and leaves behind a good amount of lacing. S- very light smell of citrus and wheat. T- citrus upfront with hints of spices. Hints of dark fruit, nuts, clove, and apple too. Great yeast aftertaste. P- nice light smooth mouthfeel. Low carbonation and light body. O- This was definitely a treat and I would not hesitate to have it again. Light beer flavor in a dark beer. amazing. good for anytime of the year. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 06-21-2007 19:52:05
On tap at brewery: American style wheat beer which means that it has more malt profile than yeast, some nice caramel flavor along with wheat character, not real exciting however.
Draft pours a dark brown body with a tan head. Spicy nose, cinnamon and vanilla. Wheaty bubblegum. Thin malt body with some light etoh in the finish. Simple decent.

Tap at Spuyten. Pours a deep dark murky brown with a thin lasting off white head. aroma is phenolicy with some clove and light vanilla notes, with light caramel and a dry chocolate earthy character. Flavor is pretty good- lots of dark wheats, toasted malts, yeasty phenolics and some slight fruity ester tones. Mouthfeel and finish seemed pretty smooth but the carbonation was a bit dull for a weizen- seemed a bit lackluster overall. Ok though.
Poured dark brown with a light tan head. Aroma of malt and chocolate. Flavor of a typical dunkel, but very thin.

Draught: Lightly bitter aroma. Smells of banana, bubblegum, floral hops, and berries. Poured dark dark brown/black in color with a small, creamy, tan, head that diminished slowly. Odd flavor. Tasted of hops, bubblegum, light malts, and a little chocolate. Light to medium body. Thin, dry texture. Soft carbonation. Dry finish. Overall, does not smell or look anything like it tastes. Kinda the whole kitchen sink in one beer flavorwise. Boring. Not good, not bad.

On tap at Bocktown-This was a little too watery for me. Aroma was not very strong but could pick up some wheatiness to it. Pour was a dark black with a one finger off white head. That black color suprised me- I don’t think of dunkels being this dark. Taste was very different as well. Very complex- some roastiness and light fruit and a dry and sweet aftertaste. My only problem is the thin mouthfeel that almost feels watered down. Not bad but I would like to try a bottle if they bottle it.

Aren’t dunkleweizen such a cool style? This beer is dark brown and hazy and you can’t see thru it. Just like an unfiltered wheat but dark. No head to speak of. Can’t see thru this brew. Smell is wheatish, good wheat aromas. Cannot detect much spices. Oh, this stuff is good, right from the very first taste. No bitterness can be detected. Where is the alcohol? Better be careful with this, it is way too smooth. I must warn you, dunkelweizen is one of my favorite styles! There are also complexities of roasted-ness in there as well. Again, where is the bitterness? How lovely. Friendly and easy to get along with. Impy stout and IIPA lovers may not dig the splayed back attitude of this beer. Good, welcomed medium carbonation. Does seem just a little too laid back at times, but not in a negative way, you know, more acceptable! Beautiful finish, gentle and smooth. Would not hesitate to get more of this again. Dunkleweizen is great.
The Crown, Nuneaton. Straw-coloured and lacing like lager. Catfood dabs and apples on snout. Almond, vanilla, weak toast and grassiness. Wotsits. Not the best. Glad I had a half.
Cask Handpump at the Crescent, Salford 26/09/2002 Golden coloured and a little sweet on the palate with a grainy flavour. A hint of dryness in the finish.
Cask conditioned at The Royal Blenheim, Oxford. Amber with white head. Sweet, flowery hopped beer, turns dry on the close with a late malted flavour.

Bottle 50cl. Clear medium orange color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly - fully diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, gluten. Flavor is light to moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. (220808)
(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of fonefan. Slightly hazy pale golden with a small off-white head. Aroma of fresh apples. Light-bodied, again with notes of apple juice. Dry and fairly bitter finish. 220808

Third pint measured glass. Cask, hand-pulled at Bar UnusuALE, GBBF. Amber body with just one patch in the middle of the surface. Smell of mild citrus fruits. Some tropical fruits in flavour entwined with malts and followed by a dry bitter ending. Clean tasting, but rather watery texture (09.08.2008).

Bottled. A hazy light golden beer with a thin off-white head. The aroma is sweet malty with light notes of fruit and elderflowers. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of elderflowers as well as lighter notes of fruit, leading to a dry bitter finish. The body is thin. Thanks to fonefan and Brugmansia for sharing.

Bottle, thx to fonefan. It pours a hazy, yellowish golden body under a layer of white bubbles. It starts quite fruity on the aroma, but soon sourish, citric and slightly dusty scents escape the glass. There’s a little hoppy touch to it as well. Citrusy hops in the mouth, with some pale maltyness and a decent hoppy bitterness, but there’s also that sourish, citris flavor indication infection. Medium to thin body. The finish is malty and fruity with some bitterness. Well, it’s almost a decent beer, obviously going in the wrong direction. (080822)

50 cL bottle. Pours almost clear and golden yellow with a fully diminished white head. Mild spiced to tobacco like aroma. Flavour is dry and spiced hoppy with a classic tobacco note. Lingering bitter and spiced hops finish. Not my style of ale.

Cask at GBBF 08. Gold, thin white head. Empty pale malts, bit of hay, not hugely exciting, bit of rubber, bit of drying hop on finish. Decent condition, bit of peach fuzz, but overall not interesting.

Bavik's version of a low alcohol pale lager, at De Planck in Ghent. Medium thick, snow white, moussy, slowly opening head, cristal clear golden blonde robe with strings of vivid sparkling. Aroma of soggy chicken corn, cooked green beans, plastic, chalk, plaster, rubber, grass - every bit as unattractive as you'd expect from the style. Neutral onset, very sharply carbonated, numbing, accentuating a simple and thin grainy sourishness that becomes a tad sweeter and very cereally further on; chalk- and plaster-like flavours in the finish, wet paper with a slight grassy touch, as well as a lingering mineral effect from the strong carbonation. Dull, simple, thin, grainy and plastic-ish: even within its generally not very interesting style (politely put), this seems below average.

27/XII/15 - 25cl bottle @ Huyze Vacas (Waterland-Oudeman) - BB: n/a (2015-1814) Clear pale blond beer, creamy white head, pretty stable, adhesive, leaving a nice lacing in the glass. Aroma: very malty, grains, hay, rural touch, some cow fodder. MF: lively carbon, medium to light body. Taste: grains, cow fodder, hay, some citrus, very metallic. Aftertaste: soft bitterness, very metallic, grains, watery finish. Meh. Glad I didn’t walk all the way from Waregem train station to Gasolina in the pouring rain after Winterbieren Festival (Vichte) for this one, and I just stumbled upon it only a couple weeks later at Vacas’ place. ;)

Bottle @ gasolina Pours clear blonde good white head . Smell is sweet , grainy . Taste is bit bitter , underneath an intense sweetness from the malts . Slightly metallic , but not too much . Balanced , nice for a NA

Bottle. [thank you, Yespr] Pours pale golden with a small, fizzy, white head. Aroma is sweet, some medicine and artificial sweeteners. High carbonation, watery. Flavour is weak, sweet, some wet grains. Why?

Bottle 25 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours yellow with a slight haze with a white head. A little malt and sulphur in the nose. Thin body, vague malty notes, a little toffee and a rather metallic touch. Absolutely no bitterness. 020210
25 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is cornish and vague grassy. Cornish, flat malty and light grainy. Vague acid note, cornish and light grainy finish.

Bottle 25cl. @ home. Clear medium yellow color with a average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, vegetable, cardboard, corn. Flavor is light to moderate sweet with a average to short duration. Body is light, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20090314]
Bottle, 25 cl. Very watery-yellow color, with a medium snowwhite head. Aroma light malts, sweet. Thin body. Taste sweet but not too, malts and very low hop. Not soo bad, for a low alc. beer.
Drunk in a restaurant neer Vyghte. Although only 1 % alcohol,. Still very nice beer. Not to sweet but a good taste of hop.

on tap-pours an off white head with bubbles and hazy gold color. Aroma is lots of caramel, some sweet. Taste is caramel-medium malt, citrus lemon, some bitterness. Light side of medium body. Minimum/mild carbonation.

This was offered up yesterday by the waitress as a new brew at Caruso’s/Dahlonega Brewing. Poured on tap to a burntamber color with a thin off-white head that lingered well and left decent lacing. Aroma was pungent hops which was almost nauseating at first, but quickly turning more what I would expect from a bitter. Mouthfeel was slightly tingly and bitter, but not real pronounced. As for the flavor, nothing in particular stuck out, but it was reasonably enjoyable. I’m not sure of the ABV, but judging by the lack of it in either the aroma or taste, I’m guessing it to be in the 5.0-5.5% range. Finally, the finish was pleasant, but not bitter enough to earn the right to be called by that name. All and all, an enjoyable beer, just more along the lines of an English Pale Ale than a bitter.

Citrusy almost tart aroma... Golden in color... Flavor is caramel malts, slight bitterness... Palate is where it really is weak... Kind of leaves a cigar tobacco finish, slightly dirty bitter finish... Not the best, drinkable...
Orange pour with white head and lace. Light malt and light citrus hop aroma. Semi sweet malt with a decent citrus bitter. Medium bodied with good carbonation. nice balance.

On tap at the brewpub in Atlanta. Pours a clear, golden colored body with a thin, creamy, white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a good amount of lacing. Aroma has some distinct maltiness with a medium sweet caramel and light crystal. A lighter, soapy, earthy hop with some grapefruit. Similar flavor. A bit bready with a moderate caramel and crystal sweetness. A good amount of earthy hops grow into the finish where this dries with a medium-high, soapy bitterness. Lengthy aftertaste following a light to medium, somewhat thin feeling body with a light carbonation. Overall, a pretty bland IPA. It has a nice bitterness level, but its just not rubbing me the right way. Not bad, just unremarkable.

In short: A tasty, juicy and annoyingly astringent IPA. A bit off. How: Tap at brewpub The look: Clear dark golden body topped by an off-white ring of foam In long: Unfocussed hoppy nose that is at time fruity, leafy, piney and citric. Body has that typical run-of-the-mill brewpub feeling. Not watery or thin, just very juicy, like a breakfast juice with bubbles. Juicy fruity caramel with a basic carbonation. Hops bring a good fruity bitterness. Long finish. Given the family/touristy that Park Tavern is I expected a bland IPA but the beer is actually quite tasty. Most of it was ok except for a strange astringency. Very astringent in fact. And that bothered me a bit. Overall, just acceptable. I visited this Atlanta brewpub in late april 2010 when I had to spend a night in this city because my connection flight to Rome was grounded. I’m not 100% certain if my flight was grounded because of the Iceland volcanic ashes or because it had very strict parents.

Medium orange, clear. Nice aroma, citric and pine. Initial flavor had citric, pine, a touch of cat, pineapple. I would guess Simcoe, Amarillo, and Centennial floating around here. I could also be entirely wrong. Later, as it warmed, a very clear infection note arose. Apparently something sinister is lurking in the ale tanks. Too bad, this could have really been great.

Started going back to park tavern this month and have been pleasantly surprised to find the beer remarkably improved! This was a good solid IPA, the right amount of maltiness and strong on hops. Not overcarbonated so it slipped down the throat beautifully. This is what I expect but find it hard to get from a brewpub. Good job guys!
Strong, distinct malt backbone that sneaks the hops in the back door. Surprisingly strong, even for an IPA in terms of gravity.
Pre-carbonated version, after filtered. Like a good cask ale. Centennial, cascade and liberty hops according to Brian. A somewhat grapefruity.Grapefruit colour with soapy head. Drinkable.

Pours a deep orange with a sizable pure snow head that lingered a bit. Nose is quite similar to the pale ale, just more of it: citrus and bubblegum, very sweet. On the palate the citrus sweetness doesn’t really pan out, becomes quickly bitter with a strange menthol and celery hoppiness. Very thin on the palate. Not particularly impressed.

Name: IPA Date: 10/27/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear dark copper, fine beige head, lots of lace, Aroma: light sweet crystal malt aroma with light soapy hops, Flavor: rich crystal malt flavor, touch of caramel sweetness, lots of citrus hops, lasting bitter finish, touch of astrengency, -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name: IPA Date: 04/27/2008 Mode: draft Source: brewpub Score: 3.0 to 3.2 Aroma: sweet crystal malt aroma with lots of citrus hops, nice bready character, Flavor: sweet crystal and caramel malt flavor, breadyness sweetened by the dark caramel balances the citrus and floral hops, nice lasting bitterness, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

Draft sample at Keg Fest of Ale. Poured clear amber color with a minimal fizzy white head that mostly diminished with fair lacing. Moderate cream ale and floral aroma. Light to medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Light to medium sweet flavor with a light to medium sweet finish of short to moderate duration. My expectations where not met.
on tap at richos. Poured clear golden color with medium head and light laceing. Very light bitterness with hints of honey and rye. Slight licorish notes

On tap at Rich O’s Publick House during RBSG Road Trip 2007. Cloudy gold, no head. A very still beer. Rye is prominent in the nose and flavor. Lightly sour. Some almost wheatlike qualities, some banana. Rye and juniper are apparent in the flavor, and step on everything else. Not bad, but odd.

clear golden with a nice white head that disappears slowly. light floral honey aroma light pine and juniper with some wheaty notes. sweet honey light juniper and bitter caramel flavor. lingering honey juniper and hay finish. medium body. lively carbonation. interesting
growler from the brewery. Malty aroma, sweet with some spice. Very smooth, juniper berries, sweet malt, hints of spicy rye and hops, very floral. So smooth and refreshing, very good beer!

On tap at Rich O’s Publick House during RBSG Road Trip 2007. Clear light golden body with no head. Sweet fruit, almost banana aroma. Sweet juniper and rye flavor, somewhat light bodied with low carbonation.

Draught at the brewpub. Clean golden body with a short white head. Sweet malty nose is lightly fruity with a touch of vomit (would that be the hops or juniper?). Very ’European’ to me. Thin body, spicy and herby with this great planty sweetness coming in waves. Honey. Relaxing. A touch of malt oils up the body. Very interesting, liked this a lot!

Smells a lot like the raspberry, tastes like it too. Golden brown, no head off of the tap. Inital fruitiness, fades down in the middle, % and yeast at the end. Pretty under the radar. Good. Not spectacular or surprising.

A amberish orange pour with a thick finger of white head. Some good carbonation in the body. The aroma is grainy with some definate spiciness from the hops. The malts are grainy and bready in the middle with a slight german yeast presence. The finish is mildly hopped with some spice and light German taste. overall, a good beer, but not the best from Wild Rose

On tap at the brewer’s tap room. Orange. Light head. I’ll give the aroma the benefit of the doubt since they are brewing and the kitchen is also alive with many scents. Hop start surprises. Fairly grainy with a strong malty body. Sweet and with a touch of hops at the finish.

Draught at brewery. Nice sweet malt aroma, mild yeasty esters with rich ripe fruit and candi sugar. Very aromatic and true to style. Hazy amber brown with thin off-white head. Medium watery body, just short of being thick, with medium carbonation. Starts with malt and biscuit. Big sweet malty flavor, bit of candi sugar and caramel. Rich flavor of a traditional Belgian dubbel with a dry bitter finish. Very nicely done.
On tap at brewpub. Pours out a hazy brown topped with a white head. Nice and sweet along with a mouthfull of malt. Pretty nice
Tap at brewpub: Cloudy brown with a small ring head. Flavors of bananas and cloves are evident with a soapy aftertaste. It was actually better than my rating suggests.

Draft: Pours a murky brown amber with a thick off-white head. Nice lacing. Sweet and malty with a strong presence of dark fruits. The normal Belgian style spices, yeasty, and with citrus & banana accents.

Tap: Nearly the first pint from a fresh keg. Poured a muddy, super cloudy brownish orange color. Very light carbonation, no head or lacing. The nose is bright with sharp citrusy yeast and light hop, some fig and caramel malts are hiding underneath, but it’s still a bit brash and young. The flavor is fruity with a solid malty body and gobs of yeast esters all over the place. There’s all of your banana/clove stuff, the green apples, some spice. Oh, and some alcohol in the background. Potentially good, just a bit out of its element at the moment. I’ll have to retry this one.
