On Tap at the brewpub. Hazy orange amber with a modest sized but dense creamy light tan head. Lacing is coarse and spotty. Malty belgian yeasty sweet aroma. Damp potting soil and over ripe bananas. Flavor was at first classic sweet malty Belgian but quickly reveals an odd metallic chalky slant. woody and a bit of beauty bark. Full smooth palate and a fairly soft carbonation. Some of that banana and clove spice on the trailor but subdued and mild. Odd and somewhat forgettable.
(Draught) Sampler at the brewpub on June 4, 2010. Really cold glass and little aroma. Clear gold body with no carbonation. Slight bitterness. No yeastiness. Bland. 4/3/3/1/7

Central Eastern WA Road Trip – Twisp River Pub – Twisp, WA Aroma: Wheat malt with a hint of fruity banana/clove aromas. Appearance: Amber in color, Hazy with a thin head. Flavor: had a fruity flavor with the banana and clove. The malt was chewy and tasty. Palate: Dry Finish, with a Good Mouthfeel. Overall: Very nice Hefe.

Pacific Northwest Vacation 2007 8/20/2007: Methow Valley Hefeweizen smells and tastes kind of like cream of wheat with lemon citrus, some orange, and a touch of bitterness in the finish. It has a cloudy yellow color and a frothy white crown that leaves some residual lacing. The medium-bodied hefe is mellow and creamy on the palate. Quite tasty! Draught sample at the Twisp River Pub in Twisp, Washington. Rating #2 for this beer...
Cloudy yellow. Pretty tasty hef....lots of wheat and not so much citrus. Tasty.
Black w/ good head. Very mild and refreshing black ale...just enough roast to provide a little bitterness. Great session beer for a hot day. Nothing crazy, but right on for the style.

Cask at the Old Manor (JDW), Bracknell. Light chestnut in colour with a yellow green creamy head; attractive lemon and lime aromas; big citrus hop flavour, smooth and easy to drink; leaving an intense bitterness.

500ml bottle from Gloucester Services Farm Shop. Pours hazy orange with a promising wheat beer nose. Taste is uber-spicy and sweet, with an enthusiastic carbonation. Some dough and citrus. Pleasant German-style wheat beer.
Bottle from Gloucester services on the M5. Murky straw colour with a a big head that just disappeared. Aroma is a touch citrus the taste sharpe and slight citrus but a touch bland.

Bottle. Cloudy orange appearance and pored flat with vitually no head. Wheat dominates with some spices in the background. Reasonable but if it looked more attractive then it would have scored higher. I know that the appearance goes with the style but I still found it off putting.
On tap at Lamb & Flag in Oxford. Some typical wheat aromas on the nose, like foam banana. Similar taste. Strong carbonation. Tasty with allot of flavour.
Bottled 27/07/13. A hazy golden coloured beer with a white head a la hefe. Good authentic flavours here. Wheaty and slightly spicy. Same in the nose. A good length of flavour. Very competent.
Cask. Okay bright golden-yellow pour. Banana, clove, orange, citrus. Has all the right characteristics, but it’s undermined by a cloying sweetness that made this one a bit of a chore near the end.
Bottle. Pours a light gold colour with a thin white head, weak wheat aroma with some spice, the taste is bitter with plenty of spices with short bitter finish.

Good effervescences, aroma clove like phenolics of a wheat beer, appearance a little too light for a German style, taste as aroma lacking the banana notes I like in a weisse, which is funny as all other beers I have tried from this brewery have a banana note to them.

Keg at the Earl of Essex, London. Pours a lightly hazy yellow with a faint, white foam head. Doughy wheat nose with faint lemon tang. Light to medium sweet flavor with more doughy malts, some straw, mild wheat, faint white sugar. Light bodied with fine to average carbonation. Moderately sweet finish, still more dough, faint yeasty wheat, some cereal. Very basic, easy stuff. It does the trick on a warm afternoon when cycling around London.

500ml Bottle. Lively really didnt cover this one. It took 15 inutes to pour it into the glass. If I hadn’t been such a fan of Cotswold’s other beers I’d given up and gone and made a cup of tea. The bottle I got were all close to their expirey date and that may have explained their vitality but it was VARY VARY fizzy. Once things had settles down and some liquid had formed the wheat beer proves to be a very pale slightly cloudy yellow. The nose was summery with wheat, hops, yeast and a slight hint of citrus. These also came out in the taste with some sspices. I beautiful drink for the summer - IF you can get past the over lively start.

Bottle from Total Wine. Chilled; shaken. Milky white pour. Aromas of fruit and alcohol. Seems to be coconut and melon. Very smooth mouthfeel. There’s heat. It’s creamy. Very mild fruits and arguably floral esters. Suggests tropical fruit juices. Finish is smooth and warm. One of the more palatable sakes I’ve had. Perhaps this one is for beginners.

Served chilled. Extremely cloudy, milky white body with faint yellowish and cream colored hues. There is alot of unfiltered rice particulate, even for a Nigori. The sediment becomes very thick at the bottom of the glass if it sits for just a moment, and it is agitated with each sip. The aroma is typical sweet Nigori, with lemony, floral notes and a faint cream background. There is also quite a bit of alcohol present in the nose. The flavor follows suit exactly, though the creaminess seems more concentrated at the end of the glass where the sediment has gathered. Likewise, the mouthfeel goes from moderate to overly chunky and thick, which is not at all appealing. Overall, this is not a very well crafted rendition of the style.

The aroma is strong with alcohol, rice, paint, and coconut. The appearance is white and cloudy. The flavor is like the aroma with an alcohol burn. The palate is thin and not very oily. Overall a nice tasting sake that blows you away with alcohol.

pour a rich full flavor, the rice sediment is all of the place. taste seems sweet with tropical flavors. at the beginning with a high alcohol flavor. after the initial mellowness, the sake hits you hard the rest of the way.

The aroma is somewhere between sweet and dry with rice, alcohol, and sweet cream. The appearance is yellow-clear. the flavor is like the aroma with an emphasis on alcohol. The palate is thin and only slightly oily. Overall a decent sake but just a but too much alcohol for me.

This feels like a sake that would go well with desserts. the aroma has like a tapioca flavor, very mild but its present, taste is smooth yet not oily. even flavors and alcohol hides itself well. a winner

Not very Golden colored, only light yellow with fastly vanishing white head. Aroma is surprisingly clean with with crispy Saaz-hops and still convenient butter, also some lemon there. Medium bodied. Flavor is also good hopped with with again nice Slovakian butterness and Saaz-tones, aftertaste dries with lemon and mild cardboard. Crispy carbonation. Surprisingly clean and hopped, could be nominated for pilsner.

Pours a clear golden orange on tap with fluffy white head that dissipates to leave moderate lace. Aroma of light fruity hops and acetaldehyde, green apple galore. Taste is perfumey and grassy with fruity hop and light biscuit. A bit too much wrong with this.

Tap at Anthony’s in Lynnwood, WA. Pours translucent copper with an off-white head. Aroma is rather roasty malt, and citrus? Med body. Flavor is very roasty malt. Arguably citrus hop. Pretty malty, yet rather bitter.

Tapered Pils glass draft at Anthony’s in Spokane, Washington. The pour is clear orange golden with a one inch well formed off white head. The aroma is faint floral hops and muted cracker malt. The taste is the nose, clean enough, just very subdued malt and hop flavors. The palate is light to medium bodied, active carbonation and a dry floral finish. Decent.

Draft at Anthony’s at SEA. Pours a foggy copper color with a frothy white head. Not much on the aroma front. Slight hops. But outside of that, nothing. Strong, bitter taste. Maybe it’s bad hops? Dry finish but it does not really offer much else.

22oz at Sea-Tac Airport. Warm, hazed gold amber. Small foam. Toasty biscuit, a bit muddled but an alright malty pale ale balance. Drying bitter finish. Classic nw pale, quite tasty enough for an airport beer.

On tap. A quite clear one, golden-orange, and topped by an off-white head leaving lacings. Hop-driven aroma with pale malts in the back. Some caramel, borderline toffee, notes. Pine cones and citrus peel. The flavor is pretty much the same, with the added joy of bitterness. Some malty sweetness. Medium to full body, pleasant carbonation level. Bitter and fruity finish, peaches, pine cones and some grassy notes. Well, except that it’s a tad on the malty side, it’s a fine brew. 130702

Biscuit and toasted malts, floral mild hoppiness. Pours hazy amber, thin head, not lasting. Flavors of biscuity malt, toasted notes, a light sweetness and floral hops. Very mild hoppiness. Dry biscuity notes. Medium to medium high carbonation. Light body not hard to drink. Not interesting.
Draft at Hearthfire in Bellingham, WA. Moderate amber body, small head. Overall mild and subdued, but just enough hops to give it some flavor. Not bad, but forgettable.
On tap at Anthony’s SeaTac... golden amber in color with small head. Smell paint and floral. Touch of sweetness, taste was average. Wouldn’t order again unless in a pinch.

Tap at Anthony’s at Sea Tac. Copper/Amber pour, foamy off-white head that is lacing well. Not much nose but I can detect some faint floral hoppiness. Sweet and malty up front, followed by a well rounded blast of bitterness. The lingering flavor is a combination of sweetness on the tip of the tongue and sharp bitterness in the back of the mouth. Considering how strong the sweetness and bitterness are, this is surprisingly well balanced. Pale ale isn’t my most sought after style, but I can appreciate a good one and am pleased by the glass in front of me.
brown pour with lacy head. Oats come through on the nose and taste but overall pretty bland

Draft at the brewpub. Pours deep dark murky brown with a very thin moussy off-white head. Vacant nose. Soft carb. Light body. Very restrained flavors. No particular mid-palate or finish. This beer is off on a top-secret mission somewhere.
Uzupe³nienie ocen. Aromat wiœniowy i kwaœny. Smak wiœniowy, lekto, cytryna. Niezbyt z³o¿ony, ale nie jest Ÿle.

375ml bottle corked. Alez aromat wisni, malin i innych czerwonych owocow. Wyglad to ciemno bordowe, prawie buraczana barwa metna, zero piany. Spore starzenie w odpowiednich warunkach zrobilo swoje. Smak malo slodki bardzo wytrawne. czerwone grona, pozeczka czarna, agrest czerwony no i ta wisnia razem z pestka. Super owocowo wytrawnie i cierpko na zakonczenie.
red-wine like colour with practically no head; sour cherry aroma and taste, perfect lambic! Strongly recommended.

On tap at the brewery. It’s a flat, almost clear beer, deep ruby in color. The aroma has a lot of cherry, some citrus juice and a faint touch of almond, but I’d like it more pronounced. It’s quite dry and astringent on the palate, with flavors of lemon, cherries and some almond. Lasting finish. A quite nice one, although certainly in the commercial end of the spectrum. 110501
Bottle at the brewery at tour de Geueze. Red colour with no head. Aroma is sourness, cherry, malt, fruit. Flavour is sourness, cherry, malt, fruit. OK/Nice beer.

From bottle @ Brouwerij De Troch, Terant-Wambeek. No head, no carbonation. Shiny orangey red body. Smells like red fruit candy, with herbs and grass added. Acidic-sweet cherry taste. Quite artificial, with a note of cider apples. Light in body. Watered down, light acidic ending.

No head. Bright red body. Earthy cherry aroma. Dry-acidic waxy earthy taste with wooden tea notes. Fullish body. Mild mouthfeel with some acid bite. Dry waxy cherry aftertaste with floral notes. Didn’t like it much. (0.33l bottle shared by Ole_R.)
Bottle at the source, Tour de Geuze 2011. Cloudy purple color, small pink head that disappears quickly. Aroma of must and cherries. Taste is sour cherries from somebody’s attic. Not bad.
25 cl bottle. Murky Red/Brown body with very small off-white head. Flavour is sour and berries.

Bottle at Weekend of Spontaneous Fermentation Clear, ruby to brown/amber body. No head. Aroma of cherries, strawberry, wood, ... quite nice. Heavily sour, lightly sweet flavour. Interesting, but bit astringent mouthfeel. Quite nice, but not supercomplex. Balance is quite fine.

Draft sample a Keg Liqour Fest of Ale. Poured clear golden color with an average frothy white head that mostly diminished with fair lacing. Moderate green chili and hop aroma. Light to medium body with a soft carbonation. Medium hot chili flavor with a medium hot finish of long duration. Interesting heat added brew.

Draft and cask at the brewery in Bethesda. Tapped May 24, 2007. Cask was so much better, soft and fluffy yeast, fruity centennial and amarillo-like hop flavors, grassy and sweet. Some honey hop cone flavors, though I’m making this sounds like a hop bomb it’s not, it’s only midly hopped, mildly bitter, even light at times, so don’t get me wrong. There’s just not too much going on other than the hops, which are simply used and quite tasty. Finishes a bit wet and oily, but overall it’s not a bad IPA.

Draught @ E.J. Phair Brewing Co. and Alehouse, Concord, CA Pours cloudy golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, wheat, citrus and yeast. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter. Body is light, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

On tap at E.J Phair Concorde pub. A hazy orangey yellow beer with a small, white head. The aroma is weak, with pale malts, some tropical fruits and wheat hints. Fruity flavor with some malty sweetness. Sweet orange and some melon. Medium body, a tad flat. Short fruity finish. Overall, quite boring, but with refreshing qualities. 130807

On tap at pub. Pours cloudy yellow with a white head. Aroma of wheat, some fruitiness, some phenolic notes and some citrus. Flavor is sweet and fruity with some wheat, citrus and some phenolic notes. Medium body, average carbonation.

Draft. A hazy light yellow beer with a thin lazing white head. The aroma has notes of wheat combined with a lighter note of straw. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of lemon, medium notes of wheat, and light notes of plastic, leading to a dry wheaty finish. The body is light.

(tasted 3/14/08 going through some old ratings of EJ Phair since it looks like they are not brewing anymore.) The wheat was really pronounced. A strong metallic taste was the main flavor though. Rough to finish, this wasn’t good at all.
On tap. Hazy yellow with a small, off-white head. Lightly sweet, fruity nose. Medium body, lightly sweet fruit and some yeast. Dry, hoppy finish. 250709

Tap at the brewpub. Hazy straw color, thin white head. No nose to speak of. Taste isn’t pleasant at first but softens. Grassy/corriander flavors in the mouth. The aftertaste is better than the beer itself.

From tap at the taphouse in Concord. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is mild wheaty and light hops fruity. Crisp bitter flavoured, smooth wheat flavour, quite subdued though. Bitter and light citric finish.

Date: July 07, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy yellow, frothy white head Aroma: light wheat aroma, light floral hops Flavor: lots of wheat flavor, mild sweeteness and bitterness Overall: all about the wheat Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 7/20 Rating: 2.1/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *+/4

Daft. Golden beer with a white head. Light malt aroma with a bit of citrus and wheat. Citrus and malt flavor with a little wheat and more citrusy hops than you’d expect. Medium-light bodied. refreshing. Hops and malt linger with some wheat.

Tap @ Barley Johns. Pours a clear, dark golden appearance with a cream colored head and nice lacing. Strange fruity, caramel, lightly grainy aroma. Creamy, dull fruity (cherry?), earthy, herbal flavor. Really tasted off to me.

On tap at GTWM, pours a clear dark amber with a thin head, the aroma is of biscuits and some light malt, the flavor is pretty much one note with a lot of bread and some malt and slight caramel, really nothing over the top with this one.
On tap at GTMW - Pours hazy brown with a thin brown head. Nose is malty and bready, Taste is same, with not hopes and wave after wave of light bread malt. One-note, but tasty and easy-drinking.
On tap at BJ, this was a definitely favorite of mine, as going into it I didnt expect a hop bomb but instead a nice easy drinking well balanced clean beer which would be excellent if sold in bottles.
Tap at the brewpub. Slightly hazy deep copper pour with a sticky white head. Crackers, biscuit, dusty caramel malts - nice hop balance but more malt forward.

8/11/12. GTMW. Nice light amber pour with a solid khaki head. Aroma of bread, toast, and crackers with hints of rich, earthy hoppiness. Nice flavor with light caramel, bread, toast, and more of that rich hoppiness. Tasty.
Had this at the All Pints North festival in Duluth, MN. This had the usual caramel notes as well as a light caramel taste.

Pours a deep amber hue with meaium beige head. Aroma is toasty with notes of grain and caramel. Flavor is malt, grain, caramel, nuts, grass, and toast. Medium body with medium carbonation. A very enjoyable brew.

on tap at the brewery pours light amber with a thin off white head. Aroma is toasted malts, very bready. Flavor is fairly light nuts and toasted gain with a nice noble hop bite in the finish. Very clean and drinkable.

Tap at Barley Johns. Pour is amber orange with kahki off white head that is sticky. Aroma is citrus and malt with grass as well. Taste is smooth and subtle bitterness with a smooth malty bitter finish. Palate is thin to medium mouthfeel and finishes chaulky. Another solid drinker!
On tap at Iron Hill Newark, not getting much from the aromatics of wood, bourbon or vanilla, however the mere fact that this still served in a 22 oz mug is glorious!
GABF 2017. Black color with a heavy roast. Medium sweet, and there is light bourbon in the aroma and the flavor that accentuates but doesn't dominate the flavor and aroma.
From notes, tasted at Great American Beer Festival 2017. Will add more notes if I get to try this again. This was really good.
Sampled at GABF 2017 in Denver, CO. Numerical rating only - did not take detailed notes.

Pours almost pitch black with a half finger tan head with pretty good lacing. Aroma is of bourbon, roasted malts, bakers chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, dark fruits, licorice, and some very light booze. Taste is about the same as the aroma. Has a medium-full body with a creamy mouthfeel and a slightly bitter, medium-long finish. Overall, a pretty nice bourbon aged imperial stout that was a nice finish to a great lineup of wild and bourbon aged beer at the Maple Shade location.

On tap at Iron Hill. Pour is deep black with a tiny off-white head. Aroma is bourbon, cocoa, licorice, light coffee, and molasses. Flavor is sweet at first with notes of vanilla, chocolate, and oak, then switches to bourbon and peat on the finish. Very good.

Draft at Maple Shade BBB 2014. Pours out black with a small tan head. Aroma is of bourbon, roast, light coffee, chocolate, oak, vanilla, and some dried fruits. Taste is complex, with a nice smooth body, roasty malts, light coffee, bourbon, vanilla, dried alcohol soaked fruits, light chocolate, oak. Really nice beer.
Bottle at Paul’s tasting. Sweet bourbon and roasted malts, sweet dark chocolate, and lighter coffee. Super rich and delicious. Really damn good, and one of the highlights of the tasting for me.
750 bottle @Paul’s Blind Stout tasting-tan bubbles-black. A-bourbon/rye, licorice/anisr-sweet dk malt, peat/chickery. T-alcohol, bourbon/rye, licorice/anisr-sweet dk malt, peat/chickery bite.

Bottle at Paul’s "blind" tasting of massive quantities of imperial stout. Pours black. Nose and taste of roasted chocolate malt, milk chocolate, vanilla, oak and coffee roast. Medium body. Slight alcohol in finish.
Cask-conditioned at the Bag O’Nails, Bristol 5/6/07. Pale golden beer with a decent white head. Aroma of grassy hops followed by muted green fruit flavours and a decent finish. Not bad.

Cask-conditioned at the Bag O’Nails, Bristol 5/6/07. Amber coloured with a slight head. Slightly malty aroma. Flavour was harsh - predominantly of green wood with not much of a finish. I was pleased that I only ordered a half pint of this.
Clear copper. Earthy nose. Fresh light bitterness upfront. Brown sugar malt. Something possibly metallic In the finish, but still pretty enjoyable.

On tap at Sunshine Coast, pours a hazy copper with a small white head. Aroma brings out lots of diacetyl - nasty. Flavour is also a huge diacetyl bomb with not much else. Train wreck. Gotta fix this shit.

Medium sized head clear copper like pour aromas citrus caramel grain the flavours caramel herbal grassy strong medium bitter citrus good on the palate the finish good bitter goes down well lots of sweet malt okay stuff
From a bottle. Great example of style, minimal head, malty aroma with a mild finish. Good stuff.

Bottle from Archive Beer Bar (June 2014). Copper/brown, small tan head, toffee malt, earthy/herbal hops, low bitterness, brown sugar sweetness, light body, thin texture, soft carbonation, mild bitter finish. Just ok.
330ml bottle, poured a coppery brown colour. Nice bitterness with a slight touch of smoke. Very easy drinking. I thought it was a good beer. Also my local brewer so an extra point :)

Poured a dark copper colour with a thin light tan bubble head with poor lacing. Moderate carbonation. Aroma of slightly sourish malt. Taste of malt followed by slight hops then roasted grain. More roasted grain than I’d expect but it is not overly done - just the right amount. Virtually no bitterness which is strange for a "bitter" ale. Light to moderate body. Short soft smooth finish. An easy to drink beer in the English Real Ale style.
Pretty ordinary, though easy drinking. Was recommended this as a bitter beer, but it was very malty and caramely, with minimal hopping. Eh. Keep at it boys

330ml bottle. Very appealing to look at, copper in colour with a nicely rounded tan head and strong aroma of caramel and toffee. Robust body with a noce taste and well balanced bitterness level and good mouthfeel. Nice surprise from this relatively unknown brewery.

Draught at Platform Bar, Brisbane. Pours amber with medium white head. Light passionfruit and lychee on the nose. The flavour is biscuity malt, caramel, passionfruit and lychee. Good carbonation and moderate bitterness that shows through to the finish. It’s lacking the drinkablilty factor here.
On tap at Free State. Pours an amber color with white head. Malt, bread aromas. Mostly caramel malts in the flavor. Not bad, but not too interesting.
On tap at the brewery. Comes clear amber with a small white head. Aroma of malt, bread, and hops. Taste is caramel malt, bread, citrus, and pine. Nice!
Not a giant fan of this one. Aroma is buttery, with light hop notes. Light amber beer with thin white head.

Reviewed from notes. On tap in August 2009. Pours an amber-copper color with a white head that quickly falls, leaving just a bit of lacing. The nose has some floral, pine, and hebal hops with a bit of light caramel malt. Taste is slightly hoppy but pretty plain. Fairly good feel and all around pretty good drinkability. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 11-11-2010
Tap @ Free State. Deep amber color. Bready aroma. Flavor has a nice bread. Distant hop. Light and smooth. Lots of hops. Lingers on the palate. Nice citrus. Bold nutty cara malts.
Had on tap at the brewpub while visiting the university. I mainly remember it being a bit too dry.

2007 vintage, draft at the brewery. Toasty, fruity and lightly roasty aroma, hints of cherry and grape Kool-Aid(!) as well as suggestions of tea, spice and floral sweetness. Medium-dark copper color with a slight, white head. Flavor profile is malty, toasty and bitter, with biscuity, bready, very faintly sweet malts and prominent spicy hop character and bitterness. Slight citrus on the finish, also drying considerably by the end. Some lingering red apple skin and earthiness. Thin on the palate and gently prickly, body is medium. A bit challenging, I have to say. Apparently this is the batch that won a 2007 GABF Bronze.

Pint at the pub as they say. And guess what? Free state is good, nay great yet again. A nice light reddish colored beer under a simple head. The aroma was bready malts while the flavor had a slittly bitter finish. A great example of what an ESB should be like.

Pint at the brewpub with csbosox and holdenn. Pour was deep red with some fiery yellow and orange hues. Not served with head. Both the aroma and flavor are what I’d be looking for if I were sitting in a pub in the UK. really big biscuity and bready malt character with fairly restrained hops until you get the a strong bitter finish. Medium body with pretty average carbonation and a dry finish. Free State has really been on a roll for me lately.

Pint pour @ brewpub. A clear amber beer with a sticky head. Aroma is astringent, spiky, light but icky sweet malts. Taste is similar with light cherry as well. Eh. I had this again tonight, no astringency but just like a bland and blah ESB, there really isn’t another way to describe it.

It’s a smoky brew which tastes like it’s been done on the BBQ with your ribs or snags. Fans like me of Laphroaig will appreciate this intense flavour with mellow after-taste but will some will find it too strong. Leave your skirt at the door and give it a go. I love it.
Smokehouse, bushfire and bacon on the nose. Great smoky flavour, offset by caramel and toffee sweetness. Slightly bitter finish. Mild diacetyl off flavour. Good effort at a smoke beer.
This has been unretired. Same ABV. Nose is a little smoked salmon and caramel. In the mouth it’s quite light with a medium smokey finish. Decent but not a patch on the real thing.

I’m beging to enjoy smoked beers more and more .. I found this one to be quite delightful. Rich with strong smoke and caramel flavours backed up by a nice big body. Have tasted it twice now and enjoyed it very much on both occasions. Hopefully it will be available in bottles soon

On tap @ the Grand Central: I’d managed to sample this one while it was still in the fermenter on a tour of the brewery. A month or so on and this is a pretty dam tasty beer. Pours a deep, clear copper with a smallish head. Aroma - smokey ham with malt. Flavour is rich and smokey, slightly meaty with caramel malt notes. That probably doesn’t sound all that enticing but it is. Almost chewy mouthfeel with an faint honey like taste in the finish (with some alcohol evident). My pick of the range so far (still waiting for the Rye ESB). Hope fully this will be a regular.
Sensational flavor, light on the tummy. Midi, great for drinking during work.
Slightly musky aroma. Initial fizzy mouth feel moving to a flat watery light bitter taste. A reasonable mid strength beer with some flavour. Overall ok. Local brew.

On tap at Sunshine Coast, pours a clear blonde with a small white head. Aroma brings light toasted malt and a touch of hops. Flavour is along the same lines, with toasted malt, a little hops and some metallic astringency on the finish. Clean enough but weak.
From a bottle. Probably the best mid I’ve had, great flavour and decent body for the strength. Great job.
Bottle from Archive Beer Bar, Brisbane (June 2014). Pale gold/straw, frothy white head, bready/doughy, earthy/grassy hops, thin texture, light body, abrupt finish. Nothing special.

Pours a clear straw colour with thin white head. New world hops aroma bursts of pineapple, peach, passionfruit and grapes. Bread and graham cracker malt aroma in the background. Clean, medium body. Smooth, faint bitterness in the finish. Great beer to waste an afternoon with.

Poured a clear golden amber colour with a three-finger white foamy/sudsy head that took time to diminish. Poor lacing. Moderate to high carbonation. Aroma of earthy hops. Taste had virtually no bitterness but was musty/sour. Light to medium body.
ok beer. its major downfall which i guess is kinda big is that it lacks flavour! other than that though not too bad.

330ml bottle. Clear and sparkling with a honey gold colour and a loosley packed white head. Fruity aromas of peach and passionfruit with a hint of melon coming hrough. Medium body and light and dry in the mouth with some sweetness in the flavour.

Draught at Platform Bar, Brisbane. Pours orange with a small white head. Malt and citrus aroma with a hint of honey. Flavour is malt and citrus. A little thin by way of mouthfeel. OK carbonation and low bitterness. An improvement on the bottled version I had a while ago.

Traded bottle. Slightly hazy amber-gold colour with a thin white head and nice lacing. Aroma has some pineapple and bubble gum to it. Flavour is a little sweet but some spice in the finish. Not as light and refreshing as I was hoping.

From cletus via trade. The pour was a turbid brown and gold with a foamy white head that produced flecks of lacing. The aroma was malt, yeast and citrus. The flavor was very malty with plenty of yeast and citrus as well. Fuller mouthfeel than most wits. Had more personality than most beers of this style.

Bottle as a bonus from cletus. Pours an almost murky light brown color with a bit of a white head that fades off rather quickly. Citrus and lemon and mint on the nose. Medium bodied and a big minty/bubblegum flavor. Finishes with a slightly medicinal peppermint quality. Interesting take on a wheat beer.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of beerbill. Pours a very hazy peach color with a thin head. Not too impressive for a witbier. Weak aroma of banana, clove and grain. Taste is caramel, pineapple, wheat. Medium bodied. A little disappointing.

Poured a hazy whitish yellow color with a big white head. Aroma was very sweet almost gumball like. Flavor was very sweet, not many spices but extremely sweet and fruity,. reminded me of gumball head without the hops.

Appearance: Pours a clear, honey-hued body with a very sparse ring of white bubbles on top. Smell: Aroma of toasted spices, including clove and ginger with a backdrop of banana and lime fruitiness. Taste: Toasty, tangy wheat maltiness ushers in tastes of bananas, cloves, ginger and lime. Light, spicy bitterness. Remains toasty for the sweet finish. Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-low carbonation. A bit of a chewy, tongue-coating mouthfeel. Drinkability: I find the mouthfeel a bit heavy for me and find the lack of refreshing character to be a slight turn off.

Date: 10/11/2008 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting, Cellar Party Appearance: cloudy amber, wispy off white head, streaks of lace, Aroma: sweet fruity aroma with tangerine, light floral hops, Flavor: sweet malt flavor, lots of wheat character, citrus, earthy bitterness balanced with a fruity sweetness, lots of spicyness, long bitter finish, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

12oz bottle. 6.8%, 1.063OG, 9 IBUs. pours kinda dark for a Wit. Amber color. Very nice fruity, lime and corriander aroma. Very floral nose. Fruit flavored biscuit. Lots of bread along with a nice citrus tart flavor. Dry finish.

05-Aug-08 (12-oz bottle: Obtained 01-Aug-08 in trade with jjpm74, thanks John!) This may be the strangest wit I’ve come across. While the aromas of coriander and orange peel are apparent, what really jumps out is orange marmalade and coconut. Wow, the sweet coconut is almost overwhelming. But despite taking a sharp left turn from the style, the nose is exotic and interesting. A similar situation with the flavor. Lots of sugary-sweet coconut, grossly overripe bananas and sherry are partially offset by the mild bitterness and flavor of coriander and citrus peel. The problem with the heavy tropical character is that the beer is very weighty on the palate, nothing like what a real Belgian witbier should be. It’s heavy and cloying, lacking the refreshing character one expects from the style. It’s nearly 7% too, so that’s another clue. And the color is cloudy amber. Heading is small on the pour and fully dissipates, leaving no lace. An odd beer, it clearly isn’t meant to be a Hoegaarden clone. Forgetting the classic style though and treating it as its own entity, this beer still fails the drinkability test because of the syrupy, cloying body and the total lack of balance. Exotic and tropical, maybe the tropical fruit aromas and flavors are by design since this is series named after tropical storms. Too bad this hurricane came ashore.

Interesting nose on this one: one part damp coriander, one part potpourri, one part orange, and one part minty key lime pie. Flavor is centered more towards a typical witbier, with abundant coriander, a lot of orange and lemon peel, some wheat, and a strange bit of black pepper mixed in as well. Generally heavy on the yeast, normal for the style, and quite tasty but not really great.
Draft: Poured a hazy orange amber with a white head. Aroma is malty and yeasty. Taste was strong belgian yeast, fruits and sweet malts

Growler. Slightly hazy deep amber with a small head. Aroma of dried fruit, caramel, cloves and light musty basement. Flavor is lightly sweet caramel malt, zesty spice and some fruity yeast esters. Medium body with average carbonation. Pretty good beer, nice yeast and spice character.

19-Jan-08 (Draft: Connoisseur’s Session, 2008 Great Alaskan Beer and Barley Wine Festival in Anchorage, AK) Aromas of dark fruits, light roast and spicy yeast, but also something reminiscent of root beer. On the palate, core flavors of Belgian sugar and spicy, fruity yeast are joined by wheaty malts, brown sugar, dark molasses, dates and dark fruits, with a light hop character and soft bitterness. Medium-full bodied and medium in carbonation, but the spice helps keep the palate from weighing down. Opaque and dark brown in color, and initially capped by a small, tan head that settles to a wide ring.
Pours a deep hazy brown color with an off white head. Aroma is malty, lots of banana and cloves. Flavor is malty very clovey, with some banana and raisins.

Draft at the restaurant. Pours slightly hazy golden amber with a slim rim of white mousse and a little dab of lace up the side. Rich sweet floral and grass nose. Good medium body and carb on a nicely assertive attack. Rich hay and caramel mid-palate with a lightly lingering and completely refreshing grapefruit finish. They should call this Pentitentiary Pale (there’s a supermax in town) and market it. It could really appeal to the mainstream.

Draft at the restaurant. Crystal clear garnet amber pour under a clumpy thin white filmy mousse. Pretty vacant nose. Watery, light carb. Very subdued flavors on the mid-palate: a little bit of chewy malt sugar and kind of a sticky but neutral finish. Looks great but needs a nose and some flavor.
This is a pretty good brown ale. Nothing particularly stands out, but there's a nice malt backbone and mild hops. Just a very smooth drinking and enjoyable ale.

Draft at the restaurant. Pours deep dark murky brown with a slim rim of white. Thickish brown-sugary nose with a little bit of dust. Tingly and medium-bodied attack. Nicely sweetened mid-palate: molasses, with some of that brown sugar again and some caramel. Thin little tingly herbal hop finish. Pretty damn drinkable for a brown.
Old review from notes. Typically malty cobra beer with a sweet herby lemon grass taste. Finish to me was quite powdery. OK.
18th August 2007 Warning! Early amateur rating! There is a hint of aromatic herby lemon in this but only at the end. Otherwise it’s a bit too shandy like!

Bottle 250ml. Clear medium yellow orange color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, light to moderate hoppy, lemon - grass. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, artificial lemon sweet and bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100118]
Bottled. A light golden beer with a white head. The aroma is sweet with notes of malt and lemongrass. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and spices - light notes of cinnamon and lemongrass.
Pale yellow of color with a small white head. An aroma of lemon, boiled meat and sweets. A flavor of apples, sweets, lemons, orange and spice.

Bottled. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is lemon, malts and hops. Flavour is much the same. Actually you note more lagerish notes in this one than some of the other Cobra with bites. It’s still not that pleasant though...
Bottle 33cl. A bit pissy coloured, no head. Very sweet, a bit grassy. Shouldn’t have bothered making this

Clear golden colour. Medoum short lasting white creamish head. Sweet lemon grainy bit sourish synthetic aroma. Sweet lemon, bit malty lime flavour. Sweet lemonade finish. Sweet brew for totalmente nada.

(Bottle 25 cl) Clear pale golden with a small rough white head. Very subdued aroma - perhaps a hint of citrus. Medium body, sweetish and sugary with citrus accents. No bitternesss but has a vague acidity. 270408

Bottle. Thanks to Enjoyit. Pours a pale yellow with a small white head. Sweetish cereal aroma with notes of lemon grass and citrus. Not as powerful as the other Cobra Bite versions. Pretty bland, really. Flavour is sweet candy citrus. Cloying. Finish has some faint lingering biscuit notes. Soft palate. This is the Cobra Bite which mostly resembles actual beer, but that says more about the others than about this one. 03-07-08.

3 Judges. This could indeed be a one off brew are he made it from someone elses recipe. Appley, sweet, nutty, chestnuts, swetish fruits, floural and a fruity finish. Dont think it was in that good condition or that great a beer, neds more hops to balance.
Cask conditioned at The Wenlock Arms, Finsbury, London. Gold with white head. Decent crisp malty beer with a pleasant background hop not. Fruity, light and lasting. Not bad.
cask @ in the Ash village , north Kent. Golden and headless beer with a nice aromatic hoppy punch on the palate -

Cask conditioned at The Lord Rosebery, Scarborough. Served a little too warm. ABV is 3.7%. Golden colour, moderate creamy head. Moderate but nice hoppy aroma with some citrussy notes. Tolerably hoppy flavour, but not remarkable. Dry finish.
Botella. Amber like colour, medium white head. Toasted malt and caramel in the aroma. Flavour has a good toasty maltiness with caramel and some hops. Pleasant.

15th Aug 2016: shared 33cl bottle with my mate who’s wife brought this back from Japan after a cycling tour. Name gives away the colour, the head a beige affair. Caramel maltiness ruled both the aroma and taste, my sweet tooth liking it immediately: some hop action calmed the sweetness down nicely.

Bottle from Hasegawa. Caramel, bread and light pine on the nose. Average carbonation with a light body. Caramel and light brown sugar on the palate. Sweet with some light grassy bitterness on the finish. Pretty forgettable.
An amber beer with an off-white head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and spicy hops, leading to a bitter finish.

Hazy, brown colour and a thick tan head. Grassy aroma, some malts in the background. Bit of a dry taste, some yeast and a slight bitterness towards the end. Watery mouthfeel, not too heavy on the carbonation. It’s alright, overall. Not that impressive by any means but not too bad.
cloudy light brown, small smooth offwhite head. mild malty, slighly herbal. flavor is herbal, flowery, slightly sort of exotic fruity note.
Bottle@yesprs - Gusher! Gushes golden orange with biiiiig white head. Aroma and taste is sweet malty, caramel, some herbal hoppy notes, but artificial sour medicinal taste over riding this for me.
33 cl. bottle. Hazy golden colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, hops, fruit and brett.
33 cl bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small off white head. Aroma is roasted malty. Breadish. Toasted malty. Toasted malty and slight caramelish finish.
Bottle at Ungstrup. Clear orange colored with a medium sized off-white head. Fruity aroma of caramel and hops. Fruity flavor of caramel, hops and grass. Hoppy finish.

Bottle at Murphy’s Law. Clear golden with no head. Fresh pear juice, light funk, apple peel, light tart berries, earthy, CO2, dry bread, sweet gooseberries. Medium sweet and light tart. Under medium bodied.
lot pear, spice, cinnamon and oak. Semi dry. Excellent Balance. I loved it.

An unexpected gift from Rory in Antigua, thank you sir! Crystal clear bright golden color, fizzy. Aroma of dusty overripe pear flesh and skin. Taste is lightly tart pear, very fruity, dry finish. Very tasty.

Bottle, that is entirely different to the one in the pic on here. Asda. As Weston’s Slowly Aged Perry. Ticked off all the styles now, barring sake, prior to packing up on this now ropey website. Smells and tastes pretty much like any other Weston’s product. Sweet and fruity, with a hint of alcoholism, albeit reigned in compared to something like Vintage Cider. Drinks like pop and gets you fucked. Never been a real perry.
Aroma of fresh apples and berries. Light sour, medium bitter, medium sweet taste, with a bitter finish. Good, even if it smells more like a cider than like a perry.

Aus der Flasche im 2018-06 getrunken. Dieses Perry kommt zwischen Fruchtsäuere und -süße leicht säuerlich balanciert herüber. Daher ist es recht süffig. Die anfängliche Farmhausnote ist etwas gewöhnungsbedürftig. Somit bleibt ein feines und durstlöschendes Perry im Glas. Prost!

0.5l bottle: pours cristal clear wine-like golden with no head. Tannic~sorbitol~medium sweet pear character, tends toward young wine~slightly astringent dry finish. Medium bodied, lively carbonation, smooth texture.

2018.03.30 Bottle shared at home. Clear golden with short lived head. Sweet and dry pear peel, lots of orchard wood, touch of vanilla, raw almonds, parallel tastes to ginger, Crodino (Italian soft drink), moldy tree bark. Quite funky and dry. I love how this perry doesn’t taste like gummy bears, like some do. Moderate sweet and bitter, medium body and very soft carbonation. 7/3/7/3/16 / 2019.04.13 Bottle at Murphy’s. Clear amber no head. Sweet pear, pear peels, light sugary like stoved pears. Moderate sweet and bitter. Medium body and soft carbonation. 7/3/7/3/15
On bottle @Sherlock_Holmes. Pours clear yellow, with lively co2 The cider is dry, weak scent, not much taste of pear.

Cask at the Dove, Ipswich. Pours clear pale yellow gold with no head. Aroma of pear, caramel, apple and a hint of clove. Medium plus sweetness, light bitter and tartness. Moderate body, slight oily texture, flat carbonation.
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are malt, hops and caramel.
Bottle, 4.6%. Rough hop aroma. Orange/copper colour, looks a little hazy. Small white head. The flavour is rather rough. OK bitterness, but slightly harsh. Some metal. Not too pleasant.

Bottled. A golden amber beer with a medium beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel, malt, metal, and brewing cereal. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of caramel as well as medium notes of brewing cereal, and metal leading to a dry metallic finish.
Bottle. Clear amber colour wth a small white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, hops, fruit and caramel.

(bottle, courtesy of Papsoe) Almost clear, amber to copper colour with a non-persistent but lacy, slightly off-white foamy head. Sweet malty and nutty aroma with notes of toffee. Light sweet malty base with light notes of toffee and a subtle fruitiness; slim bodied; moderately dry, slightly papery malty finish. Drinkable, but nothing special.
Bottle.. Dark golden body with an small off white head. Aroma and taste of caramel and fruits. Weak and boring.

50 cL bottle. Pours clear amber/orange with a huge white head. Sweet malty, slight fruity aroma. Dry malty flavour, somewhat clean of grainy notes, and slight metallic bitter. Dry bitter and a slight herbal note in the finish. Decent.

Bottle. Golden to copper body, clear, with a beige head. Caramel, sweetness and butterscotch in the aroma. The flavor has butterscotch, toffee and a good dash of sweetness. Quite sticky, medium mouthfeel. Not too good, quite boring as well, and not a beer to be tasted again. (70705)
Bottle. Golden brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma is caramel, sweet, malt. Flavour is sweet, caramel, malt. boring beer.
500 ml bottle. Dark golden body with an off-white head. Harsh bitter aroma. Flavor is tame, thin, light malty and metallic. Really boring.

If you've got to drive, or you are on a session and need to drive the next day, then this is a pretty good tasting stout for the ABV. It's one of the few low ABV beers <3.5% that doesn't taste like it's low ABV, if someone was pouring this for me (blind) all night, I wouldn't think it's anything out of the ordinary.
Weich malziger, süßlich röstiger Beginn. Cremig, wässrig herb, sehr süffig, langer Nachhall. Gute Alternative zum normalen Guinness. 12/9/8/9//9
Keg pint at Beaumont House, Dublin. Black colour, the standard Guinness nitro head. Aroma and flavour nearly indiscernible from the regular Guinness. Much better than I feared.

Can at home. Pours almost black and has that nice foam even from can. Nose is chocolate malts, roast, light sweetness. Tastes dryish roast, chocolate, very malty, watery, bland. Velvety mouthfeel. Decent low abv beer anyway.

Can. Pours dark brown with a light red hue and a medium tan foam residing. Scent is medium notes of almond nuts. Taste is very light ale with pretty much no flavor and only minor bitterness with pretty much no value. Poor.

This weaker draught version looks and pours like regular strength Guinness only it?s thinner bodied and watery. It still has the characteristics but they?re all subdued. Flatter. Creamy nitro head. Aroma of burnt woods and roasted notes. Chestnut, wood and roasted malt on a thin watery body. Not good. If you can?t handle regular Guinness then I?m not sure what you?d get out of drinking this version. Who is the target consumer?

Milder, weaker more watery version of Guinness. It looks the same and the flavour is kept, although with a little less intensity. A good effort, but Guinness is not strong anyway so a mid-strength version is not the most desirable concept
Draught at the brewpub. Light flowerly, hoppy and a bit malty aroma. Golden color. Nice flowerly flavor, spicy, light sweet. Dry hoppy and light bitter finish.

Tap at Feral. Pours a deep copper/reddish with an off white head. Nose shows notes of banana, cloves, citrus and pine with a backing of zesty yeast. Toffee and belgium yeast dominate the taste. With hints of dried fruits - mainly apricot. Good beer
Feral Swan Valley Brewery ontap (1-July-2013) Light spiced fruit herbal aroma. Amber clear colour. Nutty light herbal fruit malt flavour. Light bitter herbal finish and melon aftertaste.
Squealer. Pours cloudy amber with a small off white head and a fruit yeast ester aroma. A light fruity clove flavour and also a sweet light malt note.

Tap at Feral. Pours a lovely cloudy amber with a small beige head. Leaves some nice lacing. Aroma shows notes of banana, cloves, pine and citrus with a slight backing of sour yeast. Rich toffee and citrus surround the mouth with typical belgian yeast. Notes of dried fruits - apricot pear come through as well. Fantastic beer

Fantastic candied banana nose. Really full on without being too much. In the mouth it loses it’s charm. A muddled medium bodied dubbel. A bit of candy sugar, caramel and not a lot of anything special.
Tap. Great beer. Nice mix of aromas, with roasted caramel, and bubblegum. Taste is sweet, with average duration. Palate is velvety, with a medium body. Dark yellow, with a frothy white head.

Alright, finer points aside this has already morphed from bluevegie’s rating. Is this the base for the long awaited Wine-beer. On draught at the brewhouse, the staff no help calling it a Belgian Tripel and also managing to serve us the most blonde ’Mild’ I have ever seen - it was their Pale ale!!! Anyways:- This produced an orange copper and bright in the pure sunlight. A creamy tan head bobbed atop and held, the body a tad gassy to look at for style?. Alcohol, higher alcohol fuelled caramel lathered soft mudcake nose - burnt underneath. Alcohol tickles like a strong liqueur port. Smoky, sweet burst onto the palate. Suggestively tannic, astringent burnt malt in back; deep, drawn, dark sugars upfront giving this no chance at harmony. Fizzy, served chilled?, but reasonably full as far as viscosity. Alcohol dries it right out in the swallow, and with the tannic malts doesn’t leave behind much in the way of desirables. A sharp, quite pronounced linger of smoke, dust and treacle develops on the palate and builds in the olfactories. I can’t lie, not the brewers best. But, I hope he still keeps pushing the barriers. (8.0%)

Sampled on tap at the Western Australian Beer Week Launch. While this was reasonable, it was clearely understtenuated and thus a little overtly sweet. Tastes like a belgian that need 6 moonhts in the bottle to ripen up. Hope they bottle it.

Muddy looking, orangey brown body with a short light tan head. Some caramel, burnt honey, and a perception of soft spices, pepper with a little medicinal note right on the finish, leaves a lining in your mouth and you don’t notice the alcohol even after the second one. Served a bit cold to be fully appreciated

Woody nose, dark brown. Dark toasted grain, tobacco and charcoal notes. Bitter burnt wood end with hops too. Intense flavor. Stands on its own--as a beer or a meal! Points for originality and for pushing the limit.

Draught pint at the brewpub, mid-May 2007. What is it with these dark IPAs? The next new thing in beer is making with the funny colors? Anyway, this poured totally black (duh), translucent with a smallish head and a bit of lacing....dry, herbal aroma, faint hoppiness, woody....body is very, very dry and harsh at first, the malts only show up when it’s warmed for 10 minutes or so, and a light fruity/citric sweetness enters the picture....remains dusty overall and somewhat hard to drink, but by the end of the pint I’m not unhappy about it.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Aroma is a bit hard to describe, maybe alcoholic, with a bit of plum. but the coloring is your typical dark brown with almost no lacing or head. There was none of the chocolate or espresso flavors I’ve come to expect from the style, and the mouthfeel was a bit watery, yet this was still a flavorful dark brew I’d try again.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Hand bottle for lou18. Small head, dark brown pour. Abit on the bitter side, burnt chocolate, smoke, finished abit bitter sweet. I enjoyed it, interesting flavor.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery. Dark brown, with small off white head. Nose was lots of peat, smoke, caramel. There is smoke in the taste, not as much as the nose. This was nice as is all Defiant brews.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: on tap at defiant. Brown, almost black in color with a small tan head. Aroma is smoke, chocolate, light vanilla, and that "defiant" character which I really can’t put a finger on. Taste is moderately smoky, some astringent black patent or light roast, with some chocolate, and light vanilla in the taste. Finishes astringent and lightly bitter.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Draft. Pours a copper toned body with a white head. Has a really odd spiced profile; tyme, wheat, fennel seed, flax seed, and some light herbal and grain warming. Soft light, the spices become a bit over done quickly, but a decent offering, i can see someone really liking this one.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Tap at The Long Room, NYC. Pours a dark, almost hazy yellow. Medium, fluffy white head. Aroma of sweet malts, corn, grass. Flavor is earthy, with strong grassy notes and a taste I would describe as raw pumpkin. Not the sweet kind found in pumpkin ales, mind you, but raw pumpkin. And it wasn’t necessesarily bad, either. Very crisp and clean.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Poured from growler filled at Defiant brewery. Aroma - smells just like the brewery - sweet bread and hop. Clear golden, thin white head. Malt is noticed at first, with the hops lingering in the aftertaste. Clean and crisp feel. An enjoyable pils, would be excellent if it had a little more more hop bite to it.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Tap at Barcade. Corny, cheesy, trashy, very unappealing aroma. Crisp, cheesy, basic "beer" flavor, like a bad corporate lager. A disappointment, and not at all a pilsener to me.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Tap at Barcade. The beer is very pale and straw-coloured. The nose is great. Really fresh and bright with a lot of bright fresh hoppiness. Quite zesty with a nice fresh floral character. Lots of bright lemony/citrusy character and a lot of soft spice. The malts are quite lean with a bready/crackery character. There is a lot of freshness and it is a really lovely pils.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Tap at Barcade: Hazy light golden with a white ring of head. Dry crackery pils aroma- dry and spicy with a light herbal saaz presence. Nice! Fluffy/spicy palate. Clean and very dry flavor with a crackery pils base. Has a nice minerally dryness. Lots of spicy noble hops (saaz/tetnang?) Nice!

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Growler filled at Shoreline Beverage and consumed later on the same day. Pours a clear gold with a moderate white head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left partial lace. Pleasant aroma that is a combination of yeast, grain and black pepper. The flavor is similar with yeast, grain and black pepper plus just a bit of cracker. Dries out just a bit towards the finish with mild-moderate bitterness. This is a nice, solid, pilsner.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Growler fill from Bierkraft - very hazy gold, with a thick, soapy film around the glass - somewhat lemony aroma, with slight herbal character, light wheat, bread - creamy on the palate - the flavor fails to make an impression at first, leaving nothing of much substance lingering after the first few sips - however, you start to realize that that is partly the point here - this is supposed to be a smooth, easy drinking beer - and as you get into it, you notice some bread yeast notes, dry, crackery, wheaty qualities, and crisp, dry, lightly peppery bitterness, especially on the back end - but none of these characteristics jump out at you - they never get in the way of the smooth, refreshing nature of the beer - quite a pleasure to drink, really - I’ve had my issues with Defiant, but I’m glad I tried this beer.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Tap at brewery. Cloudy body with small white head. Nose was yeasty. Light mouth feel here, refreshing brew.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: on tap at Defiant. Hazy golden in appearance. Aroma is pretty nice, wheaty, bready yeast, with some grain and pils malt. Taste is light bodied, with wheat, yeast, bready malts, with a moderately bitter finish. Found this to be an interesting beer.

Picked this up from Bayerisches Bierspezialitäten Pararadies Bienenfleiß, consumed at home Attenkirchen, Sunday 17th November 2019 whilst listening to Warmduscher - Tainted Lunch, cooking Goulash, Bread Dumplings, Potato Gratin and Brussels. Pours hazy puddle brown with an off white head. Toffeebanana combo', made me realise just how much I like this style of beer, nice little tang, soft mouthfeel, a little tiny retronasal thing going on. Lovely.

Dunkler Weizenbock mit 7,5 % Alkohol, 17,8 % Stammwürze (ein Doppelbock braucht eigentlich mind. 18 % Stammwürze - frag mich warum der Hersteller trotzdem die Bezeichnung Doppelbock wählt). Beeindruckende Optik. Absolut extreme Trübung, viel Hefe - sieht fast wie Milchkaffee aus. Der intensive Geruch erinnert an Likör (süß und alkoholig). Geschmack: sehr süß, ohne besonders malzig zu sein (erst hintenraus klingt das Malz nach). Hefig. Nicht sehr viel Frucht. Schön weich. Schwere, fast cremige Konsistenz - selten etwas ähnliches erlebt. Den hohen Alkoholgehalt schmeckt man. Stört aber nicht. Geschmacklich trifft es nicht zu 100 % meine Präferenzen, aber allein aufgrund der Optik und der Konsistenz einer meiner Top-5 Weizendoppelböcke (auch wenn dazu 0,2 % Stammwürze fehlen).

Haselnußbraun, sehr trüb mit stabiler beige Krone. Intensiver Geruch nach überreifen Bananen und süßem Malz. Auch der Alkoholgehalt ist im Geruch schon zu erahnen. Weicher Antrunk mit wohldosierter, feinperliger Kohlensäure, die ein cremiges Mundgefühl erzeugt. Viel Banane und eine sirupartige Süße, die in Verbindung mit dem deutlich spürbaren Alkohol kurz an Hustensaft erinnert. Voluminöser Körper ohne zu sättigend zu wirken. Von Süffigkeit zu reden wäre allerdings übertrieben. Langer würzig-süßer Abgang.
Hazy brownish. Aroma is pear banana slight phenolic cinnamon and muscat and alcohol. Taste is alcohol warmth sweet nut oil malt. Heavy oily but smooth. Not bad.

Flasche 0,5l: Dunkles Braun, sehr kräftige Trübung, kräftiger stabiler feinporiger Schaum; würzige Nase, malzige Süße, Karamell, Vanille, dunkle/eingelegte Früchte, Röstmalz, Malzzucker, dunkles Karamell, kräftige Hefearomen, dezente Hopfennoten, leicht alkoholisch; im Körper kräftige malzige Süße, dunkle Fruchtigkeit, getrocknete/eingelegte Früchte, Röstmalz, Malzzucker, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, kräftige Hefearomen, leicht alkoholisch; angenehmer fruchtig-würziger Nachgang
Melaza, mermelada, fruta confitada, fruta madura. Densa, melosa y de final seco.

L: -pours a cloudy chestnut brown with a small to medium,creamy,offwhite head -high carbonation visible S: Caramel,bready,clove,coriander,chocolate,banana,milky T: -chocolate,caramel,spicy,clove,bready,banana,brown sugar,syrup,raisins -low bitterniss for the style F: -medium carbonation -medium to full body -alcohol noticeable O: A tad too sweet, otherwise a great dark Weizenbock.
The beer does not look very inviting. Murky brown and no head but the taste compensates a lot. A nice Fruity weizenbock. Only drawback is that the beer is on the sweet side.

(Backlog from a forgotten MHD10/2013 cellar treasure). - Age & cellaring taken into account, this is still pretty much in tune with fresher ratings: intensely sweet boiled down Apfelmus/apple sauce and ripe banana compote with woody-musty notes of cinnamon stick and quark. Not much development 1/2 in to this 50cl bastard, getting sweeter upon each sip with hop balance probably faded by now. - I'll give it to these Weizenböcke that they seem to harbour a secret that seems to grow on you with age...
500ml bottle (5:4:6:3:12=3.0) Crazy sweet mashy aroma, some milkiness. Nice toffee taste. Lightish palate. Alcohol covered. Bitter hoppy finish.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Draft. Pours an amber body with an off white head. Light herbal hop tones, some earth and dry hop tones with some lavender notes and a floral earth y hemp y finish. A buttery mouth feel with hints of citrus, grass and wood. Nice.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: fruity with a German style hop profile that is demonstrative. nice moderate body and refreshing. no hint of alcohol it is aromatic.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: on cask @House of Brews NY-pours no head and cloudy amber/brown color. Aroma is sweet citrus hops (cascade?), secondary medium malt. Taste is sweet citrus hops (cascade?), secondary medium malt. Soft taste, slight herbal. Minimum carbonation.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: on tap at Defiant. Definitely my least favorite of the beers I tried while at the brewery. Hazy golden/light amber in appearance. Nose is floral, but also light notes of dish soap. Taste doesn’t get much better with that dish soap character making it’s appearance again. This is definitely not what Neil intended for this beer. maybe my palate was shot, who knows.

A Mes rate: Cask at London Drinker. Typical Dark Star. Awesome blend of Hop Head and something else. Creamy hop nose. Perfect golden colour. Creamy grassy hops in the mouth. Crisp clean Dark Star hoppy goodness. Excellent stuff.
Cask@London Drinker 07. Pretty nice. Typically hoppy Dark Star beer, full of fragrant hops. Grapefruity, floral, and with some nice bitterness in the finish. Very good.

[674-20070924] Cask @ Royal Oak (Bath, SM). Doughy yeast aroma also smells like horses and sweet apple. Clear, brown orange body with a small medium-lasting foamy white head. Very woody pine flavour (and horses). Light-medium body is watery. Unique blend, points for being interesting.

Gravity dispense at the Miners’ Arms Summer Beer Festival, St Werburgh’s Bristol 6/8/07. Copper coloured with a minimal head. Grassy hop and orange hop aroma. Flavour of citrus hops and some fruity malt, with a decent bitter finish. A very good session beer.
Cask Handpump at the New Oxford, Salford 04/05/2007 Hoppy aroma. Some carbonation. Clear golden coloured and hoppy with a little dryness and creaminess in a crisp and pale bitter finish.
Bottle. Black with a small head. Malty with chocolate and coffee standing out.Medium body and left lots of lacing. Very pleasant and lives up to the high standards this brewery sets.

Cask, Bree Louise, London. Swarthy dark brown looks. Notes of dark malts and coffee in the beak. Malty flavour with some roastiness and dark fruits. Lacking balance and on the thin side of the tracks. Didn’t really dig this one.

Bottle @ home. Deep reddish brown with a medium burnt orange head. Attractive. The nose is of chocolate covered nuts, roasted malt, notes of coffee and dry wood. Some hazelnut spread. The taste is coca cola, some chocolate and dried grass. Hints of oxidization. Some tobacco and mild tinny mineral. Mild berry. Medium body. Active, biting carbonation. Overall, the taste is a bit of a letdown after the inviting pour and aroma. Not bad, but this bottle’s probably seen better days.

bottle at Cropredy 2012 ... dark brown ... thick tan bubbly head ... soft sweet malty coffee nose ... sweet fruity plum toffee roast ... light bitter malts ... little bitter coffee ... nice but lacks a little body

28th May 2012 Craft. Clear dark red brown beer, small off white head. Smooth light palate, semi dry. Mild carbonation. Mild malts with a trace of dark toffee. Crisp mild dark fruits. Neutral finish. Fine but a little dull.
Cask at Euston Tap, London. A dark brown/amber coloured pour with a small beige head on top. Malty aroma. Tastes malty, caramel, dark fruit, some coffee detected. I couldn’t get on with this one.

Cask at CP&K. It pours deep ruby, with a decent beige head. The nose is smoke, bonfire, oak and earth. The taste is oak, wood, nut, earth, astringency, caramel, roasted malt and tangy dried fruit (raisin, cherry and plum), with a big dry finish. Medium body and soft carbonation. Ok.

Cask at The Craft Beer Co., London. Brown pour with a light head. Dark fruits and roasty malts in the aroma. Hints of cocoa. Light sweet flavor, nice roast, slightly dusty dark malts. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Dry roast finish, some burnt sugar, cocoa. Nice beer.

Cask conditioned gravity dispense Northants Beer Festival 2011. A near black coloured beer with a near beige head. Dry and malty in the nose. Chocolate, licorice and coffee in the mouth. Very dry. Bitter coffee. Very good.
Cask at Oxford BF ’08. Copper. Heavy, hairy malt aroma. Sweet malty taste, and definite fruitiness. Some bitterness: the overall effect quite rough, crude and tasty.
Nice blend of malt and hops. Cloudy amber colour with excellent head. Very fruity flavor with a slightly bitter finish. Light body with high carbonation.
Clear dark orange body with short head. Honey and crystal on the nose. Taste is a little bit cardboard and metallic, then some caramel notes.Ok.

When I popped the top on this baby, I thought someone had just pulled a pudding out of the oven. There’s a lot of honey and some toffee on the nose. The aroma’s a little overwhelming, but the taste is much fresher than expected, with a savoury, sour finish. If not for the aroma, you’d call it a summery drop. Pretty light and easy drinking.

Pours rich amber with a lasting head. Nose shows a lot of sweet malt, heaps of caramel, honey, golden syrup, toffee and butterscotch. Flavours are not as malty, but still show some caramel and toffee before a soft grainy character moves in. Some faint spicy hops are noticeable. Body feels a little watery.

A solid session ale if you can ignore the pretentious name and the usual marketing twaddle on the label. (THE "Original Pure Malt Ale"? Really?) Pours a hazy bronze with a nice pillowy head. Has the sort of doughy aroma you’d expect from a pure malt ale, especially the original one. Also some faint peachy notes and a less welcome metallic ring. Quite a full, creamy body for this style but it works for me, despite being more filling than refreshing. Fairly sweet in flavour, with minimal bitterness and a slightly sour, quenching finish. Toffeeish crystal malt notes in the mid-palate. (330ml bottle)

Bottle. Amber with a beige coat. Aroma of pears, butterscotch, earth and flowers. Sweetish and fairly plain caramel and biscuity malt with fruit and floral bitterness. A little too sweet and overcarbonated for mine, but a solid and likable drop.

Pours terribly. Rusty in colour, no head nor carbonation. Smells a smidge funky and crisp. The palate is where the fun is to be had. Crisp, zingy citrus and pear dances around the rich barley. Reasonable length. Not a bad drop.

330ml bottle. Murky brown copper colour with a flat beige head. Looks fairly solid in the glass and has a malty caramel aroma that is inviting. Flavour is very flat and a birtdisappointing given the strong full aroma.

Bottle 330ml. Well-balanced beer. Aroma is very malty, with a whisky touch, and also floral. Taste is sweet, with balancing bitterness, and average duration. Oily palate, with thin-to-medium body. Amber colour, with a frothy head that doesn’t last.
Small head carbonation medium dark gold beer aroma nutty malt caramel mildness flavour caramel nutty smooth taste rather simple type of ale bit tart or sour like at the finish borting ale

Draft at the Mill Creek brewpub. Pours opaque grainy ebony with thin moussy tan head and no lace. Very mild nose, light hints of brown sugar (which, it turns out, is actually in there). Not much else though. Rich full body and nice carb but very mild flavors and no finish. Still, it has a welcome beerishness.

Allein die Optik laesst einen schaudern. Die kuenstlichen Aromen ebenso. Und der Geschmack, der zwischen Limonade und Wuerstchenwasser liegt. Ernsthaft - wieso sollte man nicht ernst gemeinte Brauerezuegnisse ernsthaft bewerten ?

Pours out in a artifical orange colour with low head and thin body. Chemical aroma of oranges like you get in a orange lemonade. Pretty much the same taste with some hints of mild lager beer. Not nice to drink, too sweet.
Strong orange soda aroma with a hint of beer. Orange color with small head. Sweet orange soda flavor with a hint of beer.
Leichtes Orangenaroma, wässrig, etwas herber Nachgeschmack. Lasches Gesöff, das kein Mensch braucht. Test vom 20.7.2007, Gebinde: PET Noten: 5,4,5,5,4,5 - 4,80
Started drinking this one on a warm afternoon, started fine, but then the sweetness really comes out, it turns into a Orange crush like beverage, just abit too sweet, eh...
Lidl@Düsseldorf; pet bottle - clear and pale golden colour, poor head left; orange juice in the nose, very sweet with a fake acidity; lot of residual sugars in a fruity sweeties-like finish

Plastic bottle 50cl. Clear medium yellow orange color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate lemon - orange. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average to short duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20081122]

Plastic bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Clear golden with a white head. Distinct aroma of orange pop. Light-bodied, a little low in carbonation again with distinct notes of orange pop. Lightly sulphurous finish. 221108

50 cL clear plastic bottle. Pours clear and orange with a small fizzy white head. Orange fruity aroma. Sweet orange fruity with a distinct beer malty note. Somewhat artificial orange fruity. Sweet orange fruity into the far finish.

Tried in Berlin. Aroma was faint, smelling sweetly of oranges. Poured a clear orangish colour, no head. Palate is watery. Felt like drinking Fanta. Taste was flat. Mostly sweet, but a little bitter at times.
Cask at the Battersea Beer Festival, 10th Feb 2010. Amber with a bubbly head. Soft, quite woody nose but then a nutty, slightly sour flavour. Standard palate. Not my thing.
Cask, Leicester Fest 10. Golden with a small foam. Aromas are caramel and mellow lemon with butter and grain. Flavours are sweet grain and lemon with yeast. Fairly spritzy but a bit flat overall.
Draught at BBF 2010. Most gorgeous woody sweet nose. Light Amber brown colour. Quite sour start but quickly evens out. Very nutty and very drinkable.

1. Cask Handpump at the Black Horse, Darwen 24/08/2007 Thick white head. Golden coloured with an acidic taste. Slightly dry with a crisp and bitter finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Black Cock Inn, Broughton in Furness 13/06/2009 Some fruit aroma. White head. Golden coloured with a sour fruity flavour. Slightly acidic taste. A little dryness in a wheat and malt finish.
Cask at Abbotsford, Edinburgh. Bit rubbery/toasty with stemmy undertones. Low maltiness, low on hops.
On tap Edinburgh. A very boring bitter. Did not quench my thirst as suggested. aroma citrus, zesty peel, sweet honey pancakes, bread. Taste is similar but watery bitter. uninteresting.
This beer went on a roller coaster. Abbotsford - airflow. Hints of citrus, honey, roasted malt, biscuity, floural, orange peel bitter finish, lychee kickin it back later.
On Tap abbotsfor Edinburgh... golden orange .. cremola faom high citrus fruit nose ... Hight light very fruity hop .
Bowbar. Not a good ale. Honey, nuts, nut shells, a thin and water body, nothing in the finish at all.
On tap, bow bar edinburgh ... Bright golden orange ... Sweet clear honey ... little hop in nose ... Instant honey flavour ... quite fruity ... no real depth ... bit thin.

750 ml bottle from Jungle Jim's. Batch E!017. Old as hell. Geyser when opened, making a huge mess of my kitchen. Pours a cloudy chestnut brown amber with a large beige head that settles into a thick ring and thinner complete film. Notes of tart cherries, oak, vanilla, brown sugar, earth, dust, plums, oak, and booze. Medium-bodied, with high carbonation and a boozy, fruity, sweet, sour mouthfeel. A total mess. I know it's not fresh, but come on.

She started off with a bang, beer everywhere! Pours finally dark brown purple with a big frothy beigehead. Aroma is caramel sweetness and a light oak dryness. Taste is nice whiskey sweetness with some woody and floral notes.

Hazy deep plummy brown hue under a thin light tan head. Rich earthy boozy aroma with deep toasted barley tones and a little earthy depth. Smooth flavor that’s sweet and dark and toasty and slightly earthy flowing fruity plum and date flavors and a lingering boozy cocoa’d heat that’s earthy and toasty. Light ginger bready spice tones.

From Aug 2008 I got this bottle in a trade with nutbrown. Thanks Alan! It pours a murky dark brown with a tiny amount of foam...by the time I set the glass down, there was only a ring around the glass and a tiny bit of lacing. The smell has notes of fruit, chocolate, and oak. Very nice nose. The taste is well, very tasty. I'm getting some fruity tones with cherries being number 1, some good chocolate, vanilla, and a very nice rye *and* nice oaky/bourbon overtone that seem to blend very well with the other flavours. Nice! Nice medium mouthfeel here and the carbonation is lightly done. Also, the alcohol is very nicely hidden and doesn't hurt the drinkability much for me at all. The more I sip, the more I notice how complex this brew is...I guess that's because it's warming up since I opened it after I took it straight out of the fridge. ;^) Man, what a great sipping brew this is...and yet another very impressive offering from the gang at Ithaca. If this is available locally to you, *Please* don't let the price tag scare you away($16.95 for the 750ml)...imnsho, it is worth every penny and was a super inclusion in this trade. Thanks again muchly, Alan!!

Bottle with Pat and James in ’10. Pours a brown shade with a nice beige head. Smell and flavor are toffee, caramel malt, bicycle rust, and other metals. It went away but still noticed it. barrel notes in the aftertaste. Alright

Batch E!017 From notes. Tasted some time near the summer of 2012 from a capped 750mL bottle shared with the Nashville crew. Pours clear but very dark amber with a thick tan head that slowly recedes to thick lace. The nose is caramel and toffee with raisins, vanilla, and cinnamon oak. The flavor is a touch sweet with the vanilla, caramel, and raisin up front, moving to spicy rye and lightly bitter cinnamon. The body is full with very lively carbonation and a long caramel, toffee, and lightly bitter finish.

Bottle, batch E!017. Mahogany with beige head. Huge gusher which we eventually got under control. Nice semi-sweet maltiness, chewy, prune, raisin, rye, oak, quite dry and becomes more bitter on the finish, carbonation actually dies down and becomes quite nice with a moderate body. Balanced and enjoyable.

22 oz. bottle. Batch E 045. With ABV of 9 %. Purchased at One Stop Market. Dark brown/ Black color, thin fast vanishing head. Nose is large oak with hints of whiskey, light dark fruit. Flavor is mostly the same. Medium body with a soft carbonation. Starts with light rye with earthy malt and hints of tannins oak. Lightly vinous with red grapes. Is this infected? Lightly sour oak that lingers for awhile. I get mostly oak, dark fruit and red grape notes. Where is the whiskey? Because I only get oak. Not bad, still drinkable but not nearly what I had hoped for.

This beer poured a murky dark brown with a thin loose head of foam that fell before I even picked up the glass. Nose is lovely. Mellow and spicy rye. Deep but not too bold. A light airy wood and a modest sweet whiskey. Dry dark fruit like raisins, nuts and a touch of expansive malt sweetness like toffee and caramel. A fragrant bit of vanilla and I can’t wait to taste this. Taste is lovely. Spicy rye that has become modest with a bit of age and from the oak barrel. Deep and tall rye flavor that is not unbounded like most rye ales but rather proper and containing all it’s loveliness so that you can have it but so that it does not overrun the other flavors. A touch of smooth vanilla and airy wood. A surprise in some brilliant tart cherry. The cherry really enlivens the palate and lets you taste all the malt sweetness by contrast. The mouthfeel is surprisingly light with some tiny prickly bubbles in the finish. A small warming form the alcohol Smooth and very mellow. This one awesome beer.

A- As others have stated, this one is a gusher. I opened it in the sink and it quickly gushed out as i poured it into my glass. Very cloudy, murky brown color with a huge, tan head. S- Dark fruit, toffee, raisin and a lingering funky sweetness that worries me. T- Bold whiskey notes, dark fruit, raisin, brown sugar and a tart cherry finish. The cherry is very possibly an infection and it just throws the balance out of whack. Either my bottle wasn’t at the stage of the last two reviews or the infection hasnt nearly taken hold as much but it is still there, lingering. M- Thick with lots and lots of carbonation. D- This is not entirely undrinkable in it’s current state however it looks like sour cherry notes are pushing it there and it’s not nearly the beer it is supposed to be. I wasn’t able to finish my glass and drainpoured the rest of the bottle. Worth a shot I suppose.
Cask/gravity at Kingston BF, pale straw gold with a thin head and a light floral nose. Initially sweet, yet still grassy dry with a light crisp bitterness and more gentrl floral notes. Very nice.

Cask at the Equinox Beer Festival at the Rose & Crown, Sandhurst. Pale amber with a ring of white head; curious, slightly spicy aroma; and a sweet, pleasant, floral taste; then a dry finish with a definite touch of elderflower.

Cask at the Southampton Arms, London on 23rd July 2013. Amber with thin ring-and-film and almost no lacing. Floral hop and elderflower aromas. Fruity and floral in-mouth, with sweet elderflower, and lemon tang which extends into fruity finish. The eventual finish is somewhat grainy and bittersweet, and the mouthfeel is slightly zingy. Rated as a novelty beer.

Watercress Line Real Ale Train 1/6/13. Not entirely disagreeable amber coloured ale- an interesting almost indescribable flavour somewhere in the middle- a sort of very faintly smoky/meaty/umami sort of flavour. Maybe slightly sulphurous, but not in a bad way. Pleasant without being exceptional.
Cask @ Volunteer Arms, GBBF 2009. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty hoppy citrus aroma. Sweetish maltyhoppy bitter flavor. Has a fruity malty hoppy bitter finish.

Cask &#40Giddy Bridge JDW, Southampton&#41 - Gold/amber with a white head. Slightly hoppy aroma with hints of tea and malt. Hoppy and fruity taste with tea, grapefruit and some peppery malt notes. The finish is bitter and rather dry.
Cask at Volunteers Arms, GBBF 2007. A golden beer with a white head. The aroma is sweet with flowery and citrusy hoppy notes. The flavor is sweet with notes of citrus and malt. Refreshingly nice.
Yellow with a small white head. Sweet and friuty aroma, some mango. Sweet, fruity flavour and very quenching.

Cask at Merton Summer Beer Festival 06-07-07. Glorious golden colour with lovely bubbly white foam. Some sulphur on the aroma front, bitterness was quite pronounced and like Glen mentions it was actually quite dry. Tasty bitter, that maybe lacked a bit of maltiness to equal things out but I enjoyed the few small samples that I had over the weekend and another beer that had it’s own admirers.

Gravity, Far From The Madding Crowd. Pale gold, nice frothy white head. Ripe stalky garden aroma; compost, tomatoes, herbs. Interesting. A little weird. Malt aspect of this beer is very pleasant. Good white bread, slightly toasty. Hop character has some nice cinnamon and orange pith, but then notes of that same garden decay. A peculiar beer, and one that I initially found sort of unwelcoming. But it grew on me, and by the end I was kinda digging it. Plays by it’s own rules. Yeah, this is starting to sound pretty much like the plot of every underdog sport movie. (Previous rating: Gravity, Merton Beer Festival. Sticky open foam on a gold body. Berries, sulfur and peppermint aroma. Fresh, though partly fresh swamp. Light body, refreshing and delicate.
