Well-balanced bitterness. A good beer, though on a day with so many truly excellent beers, this one didn’t get it’s head out in front of the pack. 3.2 overall)
Cask conditioned at Merton beer Festival ’07. Gold, sl haze with white head. dry and unrelentingly bitter, heavyish body for a golden beer. Hard bitter finish, good without being great.

Gravity Cask @ Southampton Beer Festival ’07. Pale copper. Sukpurhy yeast. Mild leafy bitterness with hints of biscuity malts and bittersweet finish. Light body. Slightly rough finish with some more yeast. Some nice aspects but I wasnt quite sure about this one and I’m not entirely sure it was ready to be served. Potential to be better.
(cask - Coastguard, St. Margarets Bay) pale amber, mild hops aroma. Interesting hops/vegetable flavor.
Gravity Cask @ Southampton Beer Festival ’07. Paleish colour. Earthy fruits. Dusty with odd sweetness. Not particularly drinkable - an uninteresting pale bitter overlaid with odd funky flavours.
Pours an amber, somewhat malty, with a little bit of skunk. Bitter hop finish. Okay beer.

Reviewed from notes. Most of the time this was poured into a pint glass but twice it was poured into a stange. There wasn’t any difference between the two. The appearance had a gentle hazy golden color with a light transparency about it. There was a small white head that left some trickling lacing. The smell had some light sweet German malts along with a light underscore of lemon and a touch of sweet corn. The taste was mainly sweet through the previously mentioned flavors. On the palate, this one sat fairly light and had a good sessionability about it. The carbonation finishes somewhat harsh. Overall, I say it holds itself to being a good American styled kolsch worthy of having again but considering where I live and the distro I don’t mind sticking with Alaskan’s Summer Ale.

On tap at the Summer Shack, Alewife. Looks OK: pale gold with a thin broken head. Aromas of sour fruit, mild hops. Medium-high carbonation. Light body. Flavours of sour hops, grapefruit, bread crust. Not what I was expecting, but fresh and light. More like a lager than an koelsh.

Bottle. Slightly hazy golden beer wit a decent offwhite head. Malty bready aroma, dough notes, fruity, some citrus. bready dough flavor, caramel ,citrus, hay, some spicy notes. Malty dough finish with some fruits.

Smells of bready malt or biscuit or whatever that typical aroma is you get from a lot light colored german style beers. Appearance is light gold with a slightly cloudy body. Palate is a bit watered down. Taste is slightly fruity, slightly bitter. Overall, it lacks any strong flavor. This beer is not awesome....

On Tap Hamilton’s. Probably more of a Wheat Wine then a WeizenBock although just called a Wheat Beer at the brewery. Fusel alcohol was apparent giving it the ’hotness’. Rich body of malt and sweetness and a light banana. For a wheat wine and on draft it was tasty!

Damn. That’s some hot tasting beer right there. For what it was, it’s good, but could use a little mellowing out. Too much alcohol flavors. Usually that’s a winner for me, but this has trouble written all over it. True to the style though.

Pours with an orang-amber body topped by a thin head with a good amount of lacing considering the lack of head. It’s slightly sweet and malty with a touch of toffee, a hint of banana, and some other fruity esters. Full bodied and tingly from the carbonation.

Right down the middle for lagers. Plus, it’s organic so that makes everyone feels good. Extremely well balanced. The bubbles, nor malt nor hops overwhelm. The picture of the brewer on the bottle is a bit much, but I’d do the same thing. Cheers to River Cottage for offering a crisp, light, refreshing drink. Light the narrow botte head - slows down the drinking process.

Cask. An amber beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of hops and nettles. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel, hops lending it notes of flowers, as well as notes of nettles. The body is light.

Cask (Tasted in London) Clear amber colourwith a little head. Nice aroma of floral, hops and caramel. Nice flavour with notes of caramel, toffee, malt and some hops. Ends up little citrus.like and hints of peach and melon. Ends up with a very light body.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body:   Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 4     Pale Yellow(1)->Dark brown(5) : 2     Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 2 Head:   None(1)->Large(5) : 3   White(1)->Tan(5) : 2   Lasting: 3   Lacing : 3 Aroma: Intensity : 3   Yeast : 2   Bread : 3   Apple : XX   Tropical Fruits : XX   Soap : XX   DMS : XX   Diacetyl : XX Sulfur : XX   Malt : 2   Biscuity : XX   Hay : XX   Toasty : 2   Caramel : XX   Nuts : 2   Honey : XX   Cereals : 2   Grainy : XX Hops : 2   Noble(1)->American(5) : 1   Leafy : XX   Spicy : XX   Floral : 2   Lemon/Lime : XX   Grapefruit : XX   Orange : XX   Herbal : XX   Grassy : XX   Pine/Spruce/Resin : XX   Notes :   Peach/Apricot : XX   Earth : 2   Mint : XX   Butterscotch : XX   Smoke : XX Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3   Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 2   Sourness : XX   Bitterness : 1   Complex : XX   Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 2   Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 2   Clean : XX   Sharp : 3   Watery : 2   Oily : XX   Chalk : XX   Astringent : XX   Alcohol : XX   Mineral : 2   Oxidation : XX   Metallic : 2 Comments: Soft and fluffy, lacking direction and grip. Poor flavour profile.
Cask. Hazy amber with no head. Very low carbonated. Sweet aroma with quite a lot of toffee. Okay taste with caramel and a little sweetness. Very little bitterness.

Cask Conditioned @ Jolly Sailor Bursledon. Light haze with floaters sometimes indicative of a beer not quite ready by that wasnt the case here. Quite a bit of sweet toffeish malt with some background banana and a green herbaceous mouthfeel and flavour which could easily be from hops but I imagine is the contribution of the nettles. Very restrained bitterness in the finish but thankfully the malt does dry out slightly. Smooth and drinkable if tending towards bland and MOR.

column1: Pleasanton Main Street Train Wreck IPA
column5: Draft. Dark amber beer with a dark cream head. Grapefruit and light pine aroma. Big pine and earth flavor with grapefruit and light malt. Medium bodied. Nice bitterness. Big pine lingers with grapefruit and earth.

column1: Pleasanton Main Street Train Wreck IPA
column5: On tap at the brewery. This one of their best beers on tap. Aroma is of danky hops. I asked the bartender and she called the brewmaster to confirm what kind of hops it was made with. Summit, Columbus, and Magnum. Which confirmed my thoughts that there isn’t much citrus or fruit in the hops. More earthy tones. I also noticed it is unfiltered, and surprisingly cloudy. Thin white head left little lacing on the glass. Overall a very enjoyable IPA.

column1: Pleasanton Main Street Train Wreck IPA
column5: Poured into an English pint glass from a growler from the brewery. Color is a dark amber/light copper. Aroma is slightly sweet with resinous hop notes and a rich character in the background that resembles pipe tobacco. Flavor is slightly earthy with some woody notes towards the start, transitioning into resinous and spruce hop flavors towards the finish. Body is medium with an astringent and dry finish. Overall a decent IPA with a more mild and earthy flavor than many.

column1: Pleasanton Main Street Train Wreck IPA
column5: Sampled at the Bistro IPA fest. Strange name for a beer! It had an aroma of tropical fruit, caramel, and a hint of plastic. The flavor was tropical and citrus fruit with a hint of caramel. Not bad overall.

column1: Pleasanton Main Street Train Wreck IPA
column5: Tasted at the Bistro’s 13th Annual IPA Fest 8/7/2010. This IPA pours a medium orange gold color from the tap. Medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity and sweet, with a touch of citrus and floral hops. A medium bodied IPA. The malts are fruity and sweet. Hops are citrusy and floral. Medium bitter IPA. Nice balance. A touch of residual sweetness. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

column1: Pleasanton Main Street Train Wreck IPA
column5: On tap @ Main St. Pleasanton poured a cloudy copper with a large creamy lasting ivory head. Aromas of carmel, earthiness and light cirus and pine. Palate was light to medium bodied and slightly dry. Flavors of carmel, earthiness and light pine with a dry lingering bitter finish

From the tap this pours a deep brown highlighted in ruby and has a creamy beige head. The aroma is sweet and worty, and at first I thought this lager might rot my teeth. But the flavor includes a mild earthy bitterness and a touch of smoke that balance it out and make it a sessionable beer. Lafayette Brewing Company, Lafayette, IN
Tap. Aroma of decent, standard sweetish malt. Flavor of fairly weak, metallic malt. Average palate. Bland.

On tap. Pours a dark brown with a small white head. Aroma of flavor of sweet roasted malt, some roasted nuts, brown sugar. Smooth, creamy palate. Not very complex, but very good and drinkable. One of my favorite JH beers so far.

The description of this beer says it’s an "american version" of a brown ale - this makes sense, because it’s a much less malt-accented brown, with a much higher hop profile - she’s got a nice foamy head on her - aroma of brown sugar, strong roasted nut presence, and herbal hops - bready and nutty flavor, with a really nice, earthy hop kick to it - the hops wrap themselves nicely around a slight roasted malt character - a very tasty variation on the style.
The beer had almost no aroma. Dry, bitter and full of flavor is the best way to describe this beer. Was glad to try but it will be a while before trying it again.

Draft at Brewkettle. Beer is a clear golden color with slighlty mal/hops aroma. The flavor is of bitter hops but not as aggressive as I would expect from an IPA. There is a bit of malt flavor as well. The beer has a medium finish that is dry and bitter. Very pleasant!

The brewer said this was the kind of IPA that came together the night the before the beer was brewed. Not bad for the quick preparation. It’s really more of a Sierra Nevada type APA than an IPA, though. The pale malt is relatively dry, and the hops are just past balancing. The hops don’t come through a lot in the aroma, but more so in the flavor.

column2: West Des Moines, Iowa, United States
column5: For a good while now I’ve been the top rater for Rock Bottom Des Moines, it’s a weird quirk... but it’s always bugged me that when I bring up their page on Ratebeer, that I can see that there is not a check mark in the little box by the first listing. Thank you Rock Bottom Des Moines for amending this for me by brewing this again. Pours a hazy golden with a medium white head that leaves nice lacing on the glass. The aroma is floral and minerally, a tad spicy with a bright hoppy character. Not your typical wit aroma, but wonderful nonetheless. The flavor has plenty of orange rind in both the fruity and bitter sense. The beer has a touch of maltiness, not much in the way of spice besides the orangepeel. The beer is fairly dry and has some light mineral notes. Very nice beer.

column2: West Des Moines, Iowa, United States
column5: On tap a few weeks back. Color was dull gold. Aroma of citrus and wheat. Flavor was the same; alot of orange/spice. Pretty good stuff.

column2: West Des Moines, Iowa, United States
column5: (Savor, draft) Medium white head atop cloudy straw body. Aroma is medium sweet, lemon, some floral, light cardamom. Taste is medium sweet, lemon, some seltzer Light body, somewhat watery, no crispness.

column2: West Des Moines, Iowa, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Poured a cloudy yellow color. Head was thin, white, and left some decent lace behind. Aroma was fruit dominated, mostly orange and raspberry, accompanied by fresh malty cereal grain. Distinct citrus flavors of lime and orange with buttery, yeasty bread dough. Excellent wit.

column1: Rock Bottom Des Moines Black Belgian
column2: West Des Moines, Iowa, United States
column5: (Draught, labeled Belgique Noir) Pours a black body with a medium beige head. Aroma of anise, caramel, and toasted malt. Flavor of roasted/black malts, anise, caramel, and a touch of chocolate.

column1: Rock Bottom Des Moines Black Belgian
column2: West Des Moines, Iowa, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Opaque black in color. Head was thick and creamy with good retention and lacing. Distinct black licorice aroma. Slightly sweet on the tongue with subdued black licorice and roasty malt flavors. Full bodied with roasty bitterness lingering at the end.

This really didn’t look very good, flat milky sort of thick looking, actually almost white.... weird. Aroma is somewhat spicy with some lemon and chemicals, eh. Flavor was metallic with some orange and guess what, more weird chemical stuff. Palate was kind of thin. I feel like I’ve had a lot of odd experimental witbiers lately, but this one just didn’t work for me.
Mixed results on this one. Definitely not much of a Witbier, but not bad if you ignore that. More like a hefe. Aroma is good. Some dusty compost.

On tap at the brewpub. The body was cloudy dark orange gold with a thin white head. The aroma was fairly strong orange with some bread crust. The taste was orange peels with some floral notes. I had trouble detecting any spice at all in the taste or aroma. Bland, unless you want an orange tasting beer that isn’t that way due to hops.

Draft at the brewery. Cloudy hazed orange body with a small white head. Very juicy orange flavor with a chewy, thick wheat body. Some light spice/coriander up front, then some fresh apple and pear over the middle, leaving the mouth with a juicy, tangy, full citrus coating. A light acidity and bitterness in the finish rounds out a decent witbier. Things must have change since General Gao tried this one.

Draft at the brewpub. Golden light orange color. Only minimally hazy. I like my wits nice and cloudy. Low marks. Head was white and disappeared quickly. Citrusy aroma accompanied by a subtle cleaning solution smell, corinader, and pear. Sweet on the tongue. Tasted like weak fruit juice. Like a combination of guava and orange. There was also a light brown sugar note. Strange concoction not at all resembling a wit beer.
Bomber. Light haze on the golden body Light nose of yeast, hay and lemon. Flavor is the same with a bit of wheat. Light body is tingly and smooth.
Bottle. Hazy yellow with white head. Flavour is malt, wheat and light banana.

Bottle: &nbsp Pale straw, very dull, cloudy, and loaded with sediment. &nbsp Moderate to large white head, decent lacing, flat in carbonation. &nbsp Very dull wheaty aroma. &nbsp A little dank, wet sock perhaps. &nbsp Certainly wheaty on the tongue, but oddly enough for an American Wheat it doesn’t have that sulpher component, but it also doesn’t have any spices. &nbsp Straight up wheat malt, a little basement perhaps. &nbsp Not that filling, or should I say not heafty for a Wheat. &nbsp Seems dead on the tongue. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate otherwise. &nbsp Dry finish, slightly grainy. &nbsp Decent, but quite boring. &nbsp Lacks zest or umph. &nbsp About what I expected for an Organic Hefe.

Bottle sampled in Feb 2008: Pours a hazy yellow golden with a spotty white head. Aroma is slightly skunked and earthy with some clove, black pepper, and slightly estery yeastiness. Body starts lightly sweet and wheaty with a touch of lemon citrus and a drier, earthy bittersweet finish. Needs a little more body, sweetness and authentic yeast character.

hazy gold with a bit of sediment under a small fizzy white head. crisp aroma of wheat malt, honey, and corn flakes. clean flavors with a hint of sweet banana, honey, and dry toasted corn flakes. clean. refreshing and light. dry.
Bottle. Pale golden beer with a small whitish head. Clove and banana aroma. Wheat, clove, and light citrus flavor. Medium-light bodied. Wheat, spice, and light citrus lingers.

From bomber pours golden straw with faint yeasty aroma. The label says Hefeweizen, Bavarian and hazy, but it looks filtered with sparse, suspended yeasties. Body is more substantial than the pastuerized look would lead you to predict. Flavor only hints at style with some pilsner malt forward and with some clove phenols, but hardly any banana esthers to speak of.

btl by Springlicker. Straw hazed yellow pour with a bubbly white head and lace. Clove citrus and wheat on the nose. Papery, thick wheat, with a medium bitter. Watery with light carbonation. An unusual pre bitter taste but a nice bitter. Would be safe to say a beer that lacks character. Not bad but missing something

Pours the palest beer I’ve ever seen. I mean like clear. Some haze to it. One finger frothy white head. The nose is wheaty, spicy, some clove, no banana, some lemongrass, more citrus peel than I would expect. The flavor is very mild, some wheat, some banana, otherwise very mild. Not too impressive.

To me, a Hefe should be a medium yellow with a good bit of cloudiness. This was a thin yellow and very clear. It should also boast a tall, long lasting head and this one had a small head that disappeared almost immediately. Decaying citrus aroma that moves towards some clove. Dry finish to a thin, watery disappointing start. Very thin bodied for a Hefe.

column1: Marks & Spencer County Carlow Irish Stout
column5: 500ml bottle from M&S, Watford in 2017. Deep brown with a tan head. Aroma of roast malt, dried fruit and cake. Good body with roast malt and dates in flavour.

column1: Marks & Spencer County Carlow Irish Stout
column5: Dark brown to black colour with not lasting beige head. Aroma heavily roasted, alcohol, nuts, herbs. Taste dry, roasted, slightly watery at first getting heavier and bitter. Good

column1: Marks & Spencer County Carlow Irish Stout
column5: Bottle from Markschandschpenschers. Light chocolate aroma with a coffee streak. Dark and glossy. Foamy beige head is short-lived. Medium bitter with a creamy sweet undertow. Light-medium bodied. Slick. Fizzy carbonation. Long finish, dry. A tad astringent. It's fine but not particularly interesting.

column1: Marks & Spencer County Carlow Irish Stout
column5: Bottle from M&S, train station Cambridge. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, chocolate, lactose sugar and has a nice dry roasty finish.

column1: Marks & Spencer County Carlow Irish Stout
column5: Bottle from Marks & Spencer, Cambridge Railway Station. Clear bery dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, and chocolate. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 161018

column1: Marks & Spencer County Carlow Irish Stout
column5: Aroma of chocolate, coffee and hints of toast, nuts and vanilla. Black with a tan head. Medium sweet and medium bitter. Medium body with average carbonation. Dry and bitter finish. Overall a decent Dry Stout.

column1: Marks & Spencer County Carlow Irish Stout
column5: black. v thin bubbly head. roasty smell hint of english hop. roasty, toast, hint of chocolate in mouth. bit of dark fruit. dry and nice

column1: Marks & Spencer County Carlow Irish Stout
column5: 12Aug2018 Intense dark roasted malts, dark roast filter coffee, burnt toast, earthy, cacao. Hazy, very dark brown, medium, creamy, beige head. Light bitter. More dark roasted malts, cacao, dark roast, burnt coffee beans, toasted bread, soft carbonation, medium to full bodied. Decent, simple but nice. Bottle from M&S, Amersham.

column1: Marks & Spencer County Carlow Irish Stout
column5: Bottle as my B’day present from my friends :) Medium dark head, very dark brown colour. Aroma: coffee, dark chocolate. Lightly dry/sour, medium body, soft carbonation. Alright-ish.

column1: Marks & Spencer County Carlow Irish Stout
column5: 500 ml bottle bought at M&S in Langham Place, Mong Kok. Opaque blackish brown colour; Three finger head with crumpety beige foam which lasted for 3 minutes; Very good sticky lacing with near zero carbonation; Fragrant aroma of dark malt, with caramel, sticky toffee, strong chocolate, coffee, red fruits, floral, icing sugar, bread, light lemon and strawy grass; Close to light sweet taste of dark malt, with metallic, black coffee, tartness, light caramel, floral, very light molasses, herbs, biscuits, lemon, medium bitter hops and grass; Mid to light body. Slick palate; Mouth feel is very good dark maltyness in a slightly wheat-thinned but solid, chewy background. Mainly tartness with dark malt bitterness, plus quite notable black coffee with a touch of caramel. Flowery with low sweetness. Herbal with lemon to round. Effective!... Hoppiness is floral, light lemon and strawy grass in nose. Herbs, floral, lemon and grass in taste; Bitterness - malts and hops - is fairly strong for a lasting, mid to fair astringent bitter dark malty finish; Dry after taste. Coffee herbal and bitter to mouth. Comments: This one has good looks, decent toffee malty aroma, and a flat dark malt bitterness with a chewy feel. Only one small step away from being outstanding. Drinkable of course.

Tried at the Newark Beer Festival 2016. Pale yellow golden colour with a white head. Citrus aroma, not much is any ginger coming through. Taste might have warmth from the ginger, but it wasn’t that noticeable.

Cask@GBBF (thanks Mes!). Yellowish golden colour with a mediumsized white head. Aroma is fruity, floral and has some honey and mild bready notes as well. Flavour is spices, zest, caramel, herbs, grass and some toffee. Not overdoing the ginger.

A Mes rate. Cask at GBBF. I got chatting to a guy at the bar while he was ordering his third pint of this and upon hearing I had not tried it, he insisted on pouring some into my empty glass. I ended up with nigh on half a pint. Thankfully it was good. A pale petrol blonde colour with a thin off white head. Nice spritely hoppage all round on top of a faint but supportive biscuity malt base. Some spice and lemon in the finish. A little one dimensional but a very pleasant, highly quaffable drop.

Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury. Pale straw, greenish tinge with white head. Almost a cider in appearance, there is a citric nose to it, leading to a sharpish hoppy flavour with hints of lime. There is possibly ginger in the background. It is a light and refreshing pint, tangy, zesty and yes Rick it goes very well with Free Range pickled eggs.

Cask handpull, The Crown, Nuneaton- this version 3.9%. Pale chestnut with a faint mistiness at the edges, tight white collar. Orange jelly peppered with ground coriander seed aroma. Sourish redcurrant and peppery orange fruit, wheat-based biscuit, earth, dab of cinnamon, light Flemish splashes. Creamy afters with hints of milk chocolate and hazelnut. Decent, but like most of Cottage’s output I wouldn’t want another pint.
Cask handpull at Lower Red Lion, St Albans. Deep chestnut colour with lasting beige head. Bit of vinegar maybe. Dullish. Some dull malt, bit of plum fruit, some dryness on finish.

Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury. Brown amber with white head. Another fairly average beer from Cottage, they are definitely falling into the same trap as Archers. Perfumed, bitter, dry beer but fairly plain and basically dull. A touch of soapiness on the finish.
let bitter, har hvedens syrlighed, men ellers lidt tynd i det..............
Cask. Gold in colour. A clear wheat beer. Fruity; citrus-orangey, almost mild marmalade. Floral hops. Underlying wheaty malts; buttery. Mildly bitter citrus throughout. Drinkable. Not bad. (2008)

Tasted as O’Hanlon’s Double Champion Wheat Beer in order to show off its two medals, golden ale with wheat malt and creamy, dense, yellowish white head over a warm peach blonde colour, hazy with nice sparkling. Sweet and wheaty aroma with earthy, peppery hops, nutmeg, pumpkin, mango, cheese, pine resin, soap, chamomille. Fresh, vividly fruity onset with medium strong carbonation, dry background, bit grainy with sourish wheat malt, hoppy finish, resinous, spicy, honeyish and long. Very elegant, delicate and thirst-quenching ale, I enjoyed this a lot.

Bottle: (as Double Champion Wheat) Pours slightly hazy, dark gold with a tall, off-white head. Light pear, apple, wheat aroma. Taste is white fruit....pear, banana, apple.... Very light, fruity....a little bready. Very pleasant.

Pours a cloudy golden amber with a small white head. Aroma and taste of sweet banana mild fruity notes upfront mellows out to wheat, biscuit malt, yeast as it warms up with some moderate amount of mild peppery hops for balance. A light to medium body, with soft carbonation. The flavor became more prevalent as it warmed up. Overall not the best wheat ale but still goes down quite easy, a good brew.
On tap. Comes pale gold with a decent white head. Aroma of malt, grain, grass, and a bit of citrus. Taste is the same. Average.
Clear pale yellow color, fluffy white head. Aroma of white pepper and lemon. Taste has lemon and pepper. Easy drinking.

Draught at GABBF. Pours clear gold with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with good lacing. At is cereal and meal malt with faint earthy hops. Flavor is cereal and meal malt with faint earthy hops and bitterness and a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.

on tap @ Humpy’s / Anchorage Ak --- Hazy light golden amber color, white head cover, cobwebs of lace. Taste is brisk, somewhat bitter malt that moves with no change to a swallow full of carbonation and medium pine hops. An easy-going blonde on steroids that somehow works anyway.

Reviewed from notes. The appearance is a light golden yellow colored body with a one and a half finger white foamy head, with some clingy lacing. The smell is grassy, grainy and a little bit of sweet corn, just a little spicy. The taste has a light grassy/graininess, sweet aftertaste, sticky finish. The palate is light, sessionable, carbonation seems adequate for the style - nothing sharp, nothing watery and nothing spectacular. Overall, nothing spectacular, but nothing bad, would I have it again, perhaps depending what else was served, just another American Blonde Ale.
Bottle: Poured a golden with white whispery head. Sweet grains and light floral. Nice corn and grain with a wet finish.

Bottle. Pours to a golden body with a white head. Aroma is bready and has a light noble hop. The flavor is biscuits with some light noble hops. Very bready. There is a light metallicness. The palate, besides the metallicness is medium bodied and clean.

Thanks to Blake and Jenny for sharing! Poured lighter golden with a well-retained beige head. The aroma picked up toasted pale and bready malts with grass and light metallic accents. The flavor found pale malts at the core with a lot of metallic character and lightly-peppered grass around.. back to the metal on the finish. Tangy and metallic on the palate.. not a good feel or an enjoyable drink.

Bottle: &nbsp Dirty straw, fairly hazy, large frothy off-white head, nice lacing. &nbsp Pale bready aroma, even a faint bit of wheatiness. &nbsp I might think this was an American Wheat based on the look and aroma. &nbsp Wheaty and straw on the tongue, light sweetness, a touch dry. &nbsp Had it been clearer and without the wheaty aspect, I might think Golden Ale. &nbsp However, its not bright. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Finishes clean, with a soft wheat aspect. &nbsp Faint buttery straw/hay on the exit. &nbsp Yeah, seems more in line with an American Wheat than a Golden Ale. &nbsp Tiz alright.

650ml bomber pours a pale golden orange color with a 2 finger white head that settles down to leave some decent lacing on the glass. Aroma is mild but pleasant with some grains and citrus. Taste is a grainy malt sweetness with some light citrus hop bitterness and a dry finish. Light to medium body with good carbonation. A full flavored blonde ale that is recommended.

Orange amber color. Light tan head Nose is caramel, bread, pine and floral notes. Taste is pine up front. Pine and floral notes. Backed by big malt character. Very pine finish. Very much a PacNorwest style of IPA.
Bottle. Father brought back from trip to Alaska. Very smooth IPA - beautiful Carmel color - plenty hops. Very lovely beer

Tap. Pours Clear deep orange, small creamy off white head, good lacing. Aroma of malty bread, caramel, toasty, pine, floral. Flavor is light plus sweet, light bitter, Noble hops. Medium body. English style, but low bitterness.
Bottle poured Riverside in Fairbanks AK, copper with moderate ecru head. Nose light dank, apple, light earthy. Taste light bitter up front, caramel, earthy, and light grainy malt late.

Pours copper with an outstanding off white head (really one of the better heads I’ve seen in years). A moderately malty, moderately to lightly hop early American IPA. Notes: on tap at Pangea during our May ’17 Anchorage visit.
Bottle from La Bodega in Anchorage. Pours a dark copper color with a thin, off white head. Thick, hoppy aroma with a sweetness in the background. Good hop taste with a sweet malt finish. Decent IPA.
Draft at fest, medium amber, little head. Aroma is juicy citrus. Taste is orange, mango, grapefruit. Palate is light, carb moderate.
Tap at Sea Galley in Anchorage. Pours quite dark, almost brown, with a beige head. Aroma is malty. Med body. Flavor is more malt than hop. Quite unusual.

Bomber - it pours an iced tea color - a clear golden brown with a med off white head. The aroma is very bready - sweet, malty and notes of grain. English IPA style - malty, simple one dimensional hop and med body.
Bomber from a store in Skagway. Brassy orange pour with a small soapy head. English style malts, not really my deal.
Black with a tan head. Full bodied. Chocolate, light earth, vanilla, some molasses, and some background roasted malt. A fairly straightforward and tasty Porter.
On draft at the Wildflower Cafe in Talkeetna. Pours black with a tan head. Light toasted nose. Flavors of leather and coffee. Crisp roast finish. Pleasant
Bottle, nearly opaque beer, decent tan head fades, ok lace. Aroma is coffee, cocoa, faint metal, smoke. Taste is chocolate, coffee, cola. Palate a little light, carbonation a bit heavy.
Dark brown, thin head, almost smokiness in the dark malt character. Good body, slight sweetness in the balanced finish.

Reviewed from notes. Into a mug. The appearance has a black colored body with a slim half finger white foamy head, slight foamy lacing seems to speckle just a bit. The smell came across kinda smokey and a slight dark chocolate comes through in a weird sort of way, not exactly sure how to take this. The taste came through a sort of a smokey and sweet through the most part, slight smokey/meaty aftertaste, super dry finish. This one sits about a medium on the palate, though it gives off a somewhat sessionable quality to it. Carbonation is fairly subdued, but good for the style. Overall, this is not a normal porter I’m used to, a little bit smokier than I thought it would be but still a good one. Pretty sure I’d have this one again.

pours a dark brown with a red tint, above average carbonation, a small fizzy ten head that dissipates, and no lacing. smell is of cocoa, coffee, and a touch of vanilla. taste is fizzy, milk chocolate, coffee, and some malt. ends smooth. an easy drink.

650ml bomber pours almost black in color with a small light beige head that leaves a few spots of lace on the glass. Aroma is light roasted grains and chocolate with hints of dark fruits. Taste is a light roasty bitterness with some chocolate malty sweetness and fruit with a dry finish. A little thin in body for the style and softly carbonated. An easy drinking porter which would be a good entry beer for a beginner to step into this style.

Bottle: &nbsp Nearly black, thin foamy dark beige head, a few rings of lacing. &nbsp Soft buttery roasted malt nose, slight cocoa and even softer hops. &nbsp A touch tart on the tongue, pale roastiness, soft cocoa and chocolate. &nbsp Little to no hop presense found here. &nbsp Not a watery Porter, but very light. &nbsp Its smooth, but lacks any depth. &nbsp Very much middle of the road. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are average. &nbsp Clean finish, but its very lackluster. &nbsp Not a hoppy example, or big in the roasted malt department either. &nbsp Yeah... very drab and unexciting.

Nice little BA trade Bomber into a tulip Pours a dark, murky cola color and settles black. Nice, thick light brown head. Good body to the head. Falls off quickly though and leaves a layer of lacing on the sides of the glass. Nose is of slight smoke, or oak, chocolate, coffee, and roast. More roast in the taste with some coffee acidity and a bit of sourness. Slightly thin and watery but coffee and sourness hide it well. Dry, clean finish. More acid and sourness in the front and mid palate. Nothing exciting but it is a nice beer. Would gladly drink it again

Bottle, thanks SHIG! Pours black with a medium tan head. Aroma is roast, cocoa and light smoke. Flavor is light and semi-tart like a traditional porter. Big roast, cocoa nibs, tart cherry in the finish. Nice and highly drinkable.
Caramel and bread on the nose, negligible hops. Nice brown color. Deep caramel flavor, nice sweetness to it. Lacks a little depth but generally good flavor.

I poured this into a thistle. The appearance was a ruddy brown color with a one finger white foamy head that simmers down to a nice level coating over top of the body. There is some decent lacing clinging finely to the sides of the glass. The smell, holy caramel malty scotch, wow. This could be overbearing to some, but not too bad to me. Its just not that well balanced. The taste is super sweet through the caramel malts. There is a long caramel aftertaste leading into a dry caramel finish. On the palate, it sat about a light to medium on the body with a pretty good sessionable aspect to it. The carbonation is barely there - its almost too smooth and creamy to be true. Overall, not a bad Wee Heavy/Scotch ale, but its not exactly balanced as I didn’t get any peatiness in this one.
Ranks Mike, malty, fruity, toffee, caramel, slight nail polish, slight diacetyl, a bit metallic.
Dark amber in color, hazy with a thick head. Nice Malt flavor light hops. Nice spicy scotch ale. Easy drinking with a good finish.

Bottle:   Deep ruby hued amber, moderate frothy off-white head, spotty lacing.   Sweet and sweaty biscuity nose, some sugary fig/date like presense as well.   Strong sweet biscuity start, a touch caramel/toffee, with candied fig/dates.   No real peat, smoke, or campfire.   Very malty, sweet, and biscuity.   Needs more body and something to counteract the strong sweetness.   I will say if this is 8.5%, its well hidden.   Needs more traditional stuff, smoke, peat, charred wood, and campfire.   Can be difficult to finish a bomber by onces self.
22oz bottle shared by Mike Appearance: Clear copper with a small off-white head and some lacing Aroma and flavors of butter, caramel and toasted malts Tasted off
Bomber thanks to Mike. Pours a clear copper color with a small white head. A sweet caramel nose. A smooth easygoing flavor with caramel, light butter, light smoke. Decent.

Amber, clear, off white head. Aroma of sweet grainy malt, some caramel, a little buttery note. Flavor is crystal malt sweet with some grainy dryness in finish, and again a buttery note. A little on the light side for a wee heavy. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22. Pours a murky dark brown with a dense and creamy tan head that doesn’t stick around long enough. Big malty nose, showing caramel, biscuit, and shortbread cookies. Creamy medium body with soft carb. Malty mid palate, with caramel and cookies fully present. Long toasty caramel finish.
Bottle shared by shig, poured a dark cloudy orange, aromas of feint smoke, roasted malt, and caramel. Flavors are the same, solid beer that was very sessionable.

Grumbler purchase from the Breeze in, Juneau AK. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a soft hazy amber color with a decent transparency about it allowing some light carbonation to be seen rising. There was a one finger white foamy head that dissipated within about a minute. The lacing was somewhat sticky but ended up sliding just a bit. The smell had a sweet sticky citrus hoppiness and then a bitter sticky hoppiness. A light pale crisp maltiness came into play after a little bit of warming. The taste was bittersweet citrus hops and crisp caramel malts. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation was good for the style and for me as it was just enough harshness but managed to stay somewhat subdued. It’s crisp but settles slightly sticky over my tongue. Overall, good APA glad I was able to finally partake in an offering of Kassik’s that isn’t bottled.

Clear light amber color with a white head. Mild floral, piney hop aromas. Medium body. Good floral and pine hoppy flavors on a sweet pale malt base. Well balanced, full flavored Pale here. Draft@ Firetap

On tap @ The Peanut Farm. Clear yellow/gold with a small white head. Aroma is light on the hops for a Pale but they are there more piney with a bit of citrus, also a faint cereal aroma. Taste is sweet with a mild bitterness. Crisp and refreshing, light bodied with active carbonation. Good beer but more along the lines of a Golden/Blond, just not a lot of flavor or hop character but very drinkable.

22-Jan-08 (Draft: Kassik’s Kenai Brew Stop in Nikiski, AK) Sweet, honey-like malts and very light hop aromas lead into a pleasant, honey-sweet grainy malt flavor with lightly bitter hops for balance. Medium-bodied with a clean, pleasantly crisp mouthfeel. Pale golden color and slightly hazy in appearance. The whitish head pours to a quarter-inch, then settles to a wide ring. It may be an easy drinker, but it’s also pretty enjoyable.
Pours a hazy copper color with a white head. Aroma is malty with citrus hops. Flavor is malty with a nice bitter citrus finish.

this is good stout. when i first tryed it had a butter shots flavor to me. and i put one in fridge for 3 weeks and just drank it and the butterscotch flavor was not there anymore. i was going to hold on to it until i was reading that to age stouts u need 8 abv or above for better results. but if u like stouts and have a chance to try this one i would say give it a go. it has a medium mouth feel. taste is coffee with chocolate notes through out. some kind of fruit in it dates. or dark cherries. after 3 weeks the butterscotch flavor or toffee flavor leaves. has a light brown head. and leaves a nice lace behind on glass. and the alc is 7.2 abv.

09-Sep-11 (12-oz bottle, Part of the Brewer's Lunchbox Variety 12-Pack: Purchased 30-Jul-11 for $17.99 at BevMo in San Diego/Mira Mesa, CA) This pleasant-smelling IPA offers piney, grassy hops and sweet-smelling, caramely malts. The malt base is fairly grainy though, with the sweeter, caramely aspect not far behind. Hops are mostly piney, but not resiny, and the bitterness is medium. It's medium in weight and carbonation, and the finish is pleasantly dry and slightly dusty. Hazy, amber body is topped by half an inch of off-white head that settles to a patchy cap and wide ring with quite a lot of ringed and doily-like lacing up and down the glass. Overall, there isn't anything flashy here, but it's just a really nice, flavorful, and well-balanced IPA that goes down easy.

This is a good IPA, better than average I'd say. Is slightly lacking across the board compared to some top line IPAs, but besides that has good overall flavor and quality. Has the typical orange-gold to copper appearance, not the weak looking pale yellow IPA. Nice malty and hoppy taste....grapefruit and pine. Received as a gift, but this is something that I would buy if the price is right.
Fint IPA humlet, dog en anelse syrlig i eftersmagen. Det passer ikke helt slagsen

From Sep 2007 This pours from 12oz bottle a clear gold with lots of bubbles and a huge billowy head of foam with lots of lacing. The smell is hoppy with big grapefruit and floral notes The taste has loads of floral hops up front with a very good malty flavour lingering in the background. At times, the hops impart a really bitter flavour, at other times the malt somewhat balances out the hops..strange. Strange but very tasty. It finishes bitter, the mouthfeel is light and the carbo, well, it's less noticeable in the taste than I expected. Must be the Sam Adams glass working its magic on the initial pour. ;^) I'm close to finishing my glass and all the flavours seemed to have mellowed some but in a good way. Pretty drinkable and certainly a better IPA than some I've tried. Note to self: Get a Growler next time I'm in Ft Collins. The draft version is better on all counts.
Pours a clear golden yellow w/fizzy head. Aromas of fruity hops and citrus. Smooth hoppy taste with citrus and pine tail.
Aroma: floral, hay, Appearance: clear golden with a huge white head. UUUGE! Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, Palate: medium body, sticky, lively carbonation,, bitter finish Decent

This bottle was a good three or four months old when I drank it, but **** it was an unmitigated disaster. It had NO IPA characteristics - it was like a bad nut brown ale. Like somebody left a New Glarus Fat Squirrel in the sun and then spit some chew after drinking pink lemonade. Not a fan at all.
Pretty average for a competitive category. Aromas and Flavors are floral with a slight bitterness that lasts. Good balance with a medium weight but not very attractive. Too light.
Pours a hazed light brown orange.Yeast sediment. Aromas of overripe fruits, sweet caramel/ toffee, bready/ yeasty, some spices. Haven’t had this in a long time. Seems on the aged side. Decent OK IPA.
Medium amber in color with a whitish head that faded quickly. Floral hops, citrus zest, and a slight malt base. The finish is odd and ends hastily. Not bad, not a standout.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Sample off of Hopheads grolwer. Pours a hazy light amber/ coppery with a diminishing white head. Aroma is funky, and infected with something- either some brett or pedio- decent lactic character- some grape must, and a touch of acetobacter. While I kinda liked the funky infected arouma ( when cold it was nice, as it warmed it was kinda crappy), but the flavor was dull. Light cookie dough, herbal hops, light belgian yeast, dough, and an astringent finish.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: sampled on tap at the brewery and took out a growler. Hazy light orange in color. Aroma: Tart fruit- white grapes and notes of possible brett. Also some musty belgian yeast and light spice. Aroma is really nice. Taste I didn’t enjoy quite as much as the aroma. Taste has just about the same characteristics as the aroma- a moderate amount of white grape flavor, minus the tart and light funkyness. A little bit sugary , and becomes a bit muddled near the finish with a moderate hop bittering finish. Has some similarities to Captain Lawrence’s Cuvee De Castleton, but nowhere near as flavorful, tart and refined.

column1: Sprecher Czar Brew Bourbon Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: 12 ounce bottle from the brewery. Black, nearly no head. Aroma of whiskey, roast, oak. Taste is whiskey, oak, roast, chocolate, apple skins. Medium bodied, low booze.

column1: Sprecher Czar Brew Bourbon Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Sample All Pints North; pours black with a brown head; aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, molasses, and hints of dark fruits, vanilla, wood, and bourbon; taste is roasted malt, chocolate, dark fruits, molasses, and coffee with traces of wood and vanilla; dry, light bitter roasted malt finish

column1: Sprecher Czar Brew Bourbon Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Bomber, 2015 vintage? Rich bourbon aroma with notes of vanilla, roasted malt, dark chocolate, caramel and oak. Pours dark brown with a thin light brown head that has little retention and good lacing. Starts with rich roasted malt, dark chocolate and caramel flavors with a nice, full body and slick, viscous mouthfeel. Finishes very smooth with bourbon, vanilla and oak flavors and just a hint of booze and sweet dark fruit at the very end. Very nice BA Russian imperial.

column1: Sprecher Czar Brew Bourbon Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Black with a dark tan head. Shared a bottle. Deep coffee and chocolate note finishes well for being so heavy. Generally tasty.

column1: Sprecher Czar Brew Bourbon Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Inky black pour under a thin tan head. Lovely woody and dark malty nose with cocoa and whiskey and dark chocolate. Smooth but richly sweet and boozy flavor that’s roasty and full of dark chocolate, caramelly oak, whiskey/bourbon, light wood char, light vanilla and caramel, and a black malty linger. Delightful.

column1: Sprecher Czar Brew Bourbon Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: 22 ounce bottle into snifter, bottled on 11/15/2012. Pours pitch black color with a 1-2 finger dense dark tan head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty lacing clings around the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of big milk/dark chocolate, cocoa, caramel, vanilla, toffee, brown sugar, molasses, coconut, toasted oak, and bourbon; with lighter notes of leather, tobacco, raisin, plum, coffee, smoke, and roast/oak earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/roasted malt and bourbon barrel notes; with great strength. Taste of big milk/dark chocolate, cocoa, caramel, vanilla, toffee, brown sugar, molasses, coconut, toasted oak, and bourbon; with lighter notes of leather, tobacco, raisin, plum, coffee, smoke, and roast/oak earthiness. Light-moderate roasted bitterness and bourbon/oak spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of chocolate, cocoa, caramel, vanilla, toffee, brown sugar, molasses, coconut, toasted oak, bourbon, and roast/oak earthiness on the finish for a while. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roasted malt and bourbon barrel flavors; with a great roasted bitter/sweet balance, and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Slightly drying from bitter/spiciness as well. Light-medium carbonation and medium-full body; with a very smooth, creamy/silky, and lightly sticky/chalky mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent barrel aged Russian imperial stout! All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roasted malt and bourbon barrel flavors; very smooth and easy to drink for the big ABV. This aged extremely well. Tons of barrel presence with no booziness; and well rounded stout complexity in balance with the barrel notes. A very enjoyable offering.

column1: Sprecher Czar Brew Bourbon Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured thick and black with a small foamy brown head that left minimal lacing. The aroma was bitter with floral hops, roasty malts, wood, whiskey and cocoa. The flavor was bitter, roasty and woody with cola, cocoa, whiskey and an overwhelmingly boozy presence that was too sharp to really enjoy. Long finish. Moderately full bodied. Disappointing.

column1: Sprecher Czar Brew Bourbon Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle in a trade. Dat in my cellar about 18 months. Black in color, thin head. Aroma is moderate bourbon, vanilla, and coconut hints, mild roasted grain. Mild roasted malted grain backbone. Bourbon is has a light warming sensation after the swallow. Alcohol is hidden. Body fuller with a creamy/ lower carbonation. I am surprised at the lower ratings, must be batch (vintage) variations because what is in my glass is pretty nice.

column1: Sprecher Czar Brew Bourbon Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Bomber, from AFH. Looks really nice, dark, tan brown head, a slight reddish hue but looks like a classic Imperial Stout. The aroma though..next-level. Vanilla, Coconut, Bourbon and chocolate. There is a little bit of smokey year here. Mouthfeel is thin, carb is spot on but there’s just not a to of malt density here. the initial bit of smoke, wood and bourbon are on spot then it fades pretty fast. Actually, yeah the carb is pretty much on point, just it’s lacking the malt backbone it ends. The vanilla at the finish is a really nice touch.

column1: Sprecher Czar Brew Bourbon Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Nice deep rich black and coats the tongue, but isn’t thick. Heavy scent that lingers. A nice bourbon flavor but not bitter or harsh. The oak is even and lends to the idea of a stinky cheese pairing. Tap
Pale yellow colour. Small semi-stable white head. Sweet lemonade flavour, caramelly sweetness. Not much beer.
Bottle. Golden-yellow colour with a white head. Aroma is citrus, malt. Flavour is citrus, malt, lemon. Thin beer.

Bottle 500ml. Clear light to medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is light malty, toasted, moderate citrus, lemon. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and light light citrus acidic with a average to long duration, citrus. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110417]

Bottle 500ml @ fonefan Pours clear pale yellow with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, citrus and some mettalic notes. Taste is light to medium sweet. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

Bottle, courtesy of fonefan. A clear, yellowish golden beer with a small, white head. Mostly lemonade in the aroma, a little twist of pils in the back. Mostly lemon in the flavor too, finishing with a touch of metal. Slightly bitter too. Drinkable indeed, but I miss the flavor of beer in it. 110417
Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours a clear pale yellow with a small white head. Very sweet lemon aroma. Light body, very sweet and artificial lemon notes. Again a little minerally. 170411
Bottle @ Ulfborg Easter Weekend, 2011. 3rd session. Pours clear golden with a small off white head. Sweet lemonade and citrus. Artificial and sweet.
Bottle @ FOneFan. CLear pale yellow with small white head. Flavour is malt, dry, little sweet and lemon.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Medium head with medium duration. Color is pale yellow. Aroma and taste are lemon and malt. Refreshing.

It’s light-golden with a creamy, white head and the aroma has notes of malt, lemon-soda and butter. The flavour is sweet, very sweet actually even for a radler, and it has notes of malt, lemon-soda and a light sourness. It’s a little weird, even for a radler.

I wasn’t expecting much due to the fact that its a Utah beer. Still I was disappointed. copper pour with some lacing. weak dry hop aroma. slight bitterness. one dimensional. That one dimension is water. not good.

On tap @ SDBC - Pours a clear copper color with a small off white head. Nice lacing. Aroma is citrus, pine, and light esters. Flavor is citrus and floral hops with a light malt background. Medium body. A nice IPA. Probably the best beer of the evening.

This is some damn good stuff. Grapefruit and tropical punch aroma. Pours red/gold. Flavor is super citrus and pine. A little roasty caramel malt peaks through on the backend, but this one is a hop monster fo sho. Extremely resiny. Would like to have again, but this place is hella far away.

Draft at the SanDiego County Fair Craft Brewers Festival. Pours with an Orange-amber body topped by a meidum thick to thick head with a good amount of lacing. Slightly sweet and grapefruity with a nice maltiness, underlying pine notes, and fruity esters. Full bodied, smooth and warming.

Draft at brewery. Lots of green pine and floral aromas coming off this golden orange brew. Nice head too. Flavors were still very green and floral. Lots of Big C hops. Very good. Stood up quite nicely against the Alpine Pure Hoppiness that was also on tap.

column1: New Glarus Unplugged Bourbon Barrel Bock
column5: 15th January 2016 That’ll be me 20K then @ ChrisO’s. Bright clear amber beer, small pale tan head. Palate is light, semi dry and has decent fine carbonation. Dry but vibrant dried fruits. Spice and caramel. Good tangy bourbon on the back end. Light semi dry finish. Nicely fruity.

column1: New Glarus Unplugged Bourbon Barrel Bock
column5: Bottle shared at Kenny’s 20K, thanks to Essex Pappa, 15/01/16. Clear chestnut brown with a beige head. Nose is toffee, dates, spice, light metallic notes, plastic, booze. Taste comprises light bourbonics, sweet’’n’sour edge, toffee, fruit cake. Medium + body, fine carbonation, semi drying close with a touch of boost. Ok Dbock, barrel is fairly light, a touch harsh at times though.

column1: New Glarus Unplugged Bourbon Barrel Bock
column5: Bottle shared at Kenny’s 20k tasting - London. Cheers! Pours cloudy amber with a creamy head. The nose has light tangy fruits, toffee, butterscotch. Medium sweet flavour with moderate tartness, bread, some yeasty notes, bruised bananas, dough. Full bodied with fine to average carbonation. Sweet finish, with heavy bready sugars. Pretty OK.

column1: New Glarus Unplugged Bourbon Barrel Bock
column5: Bottle shared at the Kenny 20K mega monster tasting. 15/01/2016. Huge thanks to Kenny for this one. Clear reddy amber coloured pour with a loose white head. Aroma is Bourbon, oak, tart raspberry, woody apricot. Flavour is composed of brandy apple, woody Bourbon, , apricot, solvent, tangy, woody apple. Palate is semi sweet, moderate carbonation, little oily. I like it, maybe a little hot.

column1: New Glarus Unplugged Bourbon Barrel Bock
column5: Bottle share at Ken’s 20k tasting. Many thanks to Ken for bringing this whopper. Pours amber/brown with thin white head. Aroma of vanilla, fruits and a little booze. Tastes dark fruits, vanilla and a little leather armchair. Feels pleasant in the mouth. A good beer!

column1: New Glarus Unplugged Bourbon Barrel Bock
column5: Bottle share at Kenny’s , thanks to K-Man. As ’New Glarus Unplugged Bourbon Barrel Bock’, red foil. Dark red, hazy, small ring of tan head. Aroma is vanilla, raisin, booze, a little meaty - chicken almost. Body is medium, smooth, soft carbonation. Taste is tangy fruits, light washed out bourbon, raisin and vanilla. Decent BBA ale.

column1: New Glarus Unplugged Bourbon Barrel Bock
column5: 33cl bottle shared at Kenny’s 20K celebrations @Chriso’s, thanks to Kenny. Or pours a clean ruby color with minimal tan head. Aroma is sweet oxidised raisin and rum. Taste I also sweet and boozy with more raisins rum car board and light lemon. Light bodied with soft carboantion. Overall, quite tasty

column1: New Glarus Unplugged Bourbon Barrel Bock
column5: Bottle thanks to Ken at his 20K tasting. It pours clear deep amber with a tiny bubbly off-white head. The nose is sweet, toasted malt, vanilla, oily, fruit cake, brown bread, almond and Dundee cake. The taste is rich, oily, fruit cake, vanilla, toasted coconut, wood, varnish, leather, warming alcohol, quince jelly and tangy dark fruits with a slick finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Rich, mellow and rather quaffable. Works rather well.

column1: New Glarus Unplugged Bourbon Barrel Bock
column5: Bottle at Madmitch 20k tasting. Russet colour lasting white head. Bourbon on aroma. Very much bourbon. Sweet. Vanilla coconut. Sweet. OK if a little sweet. Good strawberry jam flavour.

column1: New Glarus Unplugged Bourbon Barrel Bock
column5: (backlog) Bottle at a tasting at maxxdaddy’s. Amber pour with tan head. Sherry, oxidation, light sweet tones, oak flavor. No real bourbon tones.

Poured into a pint glass, the appearance was a ruddy amber color with a sly transparency about it. Finger’s worth of white foamy head quickly dissipated. Left some stringy lace. The aroma had some nuts, toast, brown sugar and a touch of caramel malts. The flavor blended the prior noted aromas sweetly and then the toast and just a tad of roast. Semi-sweet malty aftertaste with a nutty finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Carbonation felt fine. ABV felt spot on. Overall, nice amber ale worthy of coming back to if I could get it again.
On tap. Pours a clear mahogany with moderate head, aromas of nuts, sweet toasted malts and brown sugar. Flavors are same tough stronger. Metallic nutty finish.

On tap at the Alibi Room, pours a hazy copper / orange with a small white head. Aroma of copper-like malt and metallic notes. Flavour of metallic notes and dry English bready malts. Very bland, but dry and would be very drinkable if not for the metallic notes. Too much metallic / coppery flavour.
Slightly cloudy orange amber colour with moderate biege head. Mild citric and malt nose. Dry bitter hop taste with lasting bitter hop finish.
1 litre swingtop bottle poured a copper color with a modest white head and some lacing. Aroma is caramel malts and some mild hops. Taste is grainy malt sweetness and some light hops.

It pours a hazy copper color with a soapy white head. It has a medium amount of carbonation The aroma is pretty boring little sweet notes but other than that not much. Even when it got warm. The flavor is nothing special. It has a huge malt base. It is not well balanced between the malt and hops. I am getting some carmel and a metallic taste. I think if I were to put a penny in my mouth it would taste just like this. It feels really thin at some points. It finishes with a dry and sweet and there is a little hops there. But it tends to linger around. Not a bad beer but nothing i would ever reach for again. These guys seem to do just ok stuff nothing that creates a wow experience

1L brown swingtop. Orange colour, small and creamy whitish head which fades to a ring. Caramel malt aroma. Flavour is nutty malt with a touch of chocolate and some caramel sweetness, faint fruitiness and light citrus/grassy hop presence. Aftertaste is nutty malts with some dryness. Medium body, mild carbonation. Drinkable, but not super interesting.
Not the best amber ale out there, but pretty solid. Nice barley malts, toffee, hops and mild yeast. A nice bitter hop finish. Pretty nice beer though.

Lot’s of caramel in the nose, with roasted malt and some fall grass. Colour is true to its name - copper. Flavour shows walnuts, tonnes of malt, dust and some roast near the end. Palate has a slight after film, but expertly carbonated. Finish is quite a nice light roast with the caramel making another appearence. Good stuff.

Huzzah for the one-litre swing top bottles favoured by Howe Sound (and by me as well)! Not much of a head with this one, what there was being a thin, ivory-coloured layer on top of a rather nice and clear amber/copper body. The aroma was quite malty, with some hop undertones; I found the flavour to be very much the same. Mouthfeel was smooth, and it finished sweet and malty.
4.0% amber colour with a good head, malty aroma and taste moderately goo bitter.

Can 440mcl. @ home. Clear medium amber orange color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, nutty, light hoppy, hay. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is medium to light, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20081206]

Can 440 ml. The beer is dark amber and the head is huge and creamy. The aroma has notes of fruit and caramel. The flavour has a light sweetness and a slightly citrussy dryness, notes of malt, caramel and fruit and it ends dry and citrussy. It’s uncomplicated and easy to drink, a nice session beer.

can from Tesco’s.No more than you expect from a cheap canned bitter.Full head upon pouring with a trace of maltiness.Orange clear appearance. Not the worst canned beer I have tried but as there in my experience is no such thing as a good canned bitter it will do
A lovely refreshing beer. love the barley taste to it pity tesco are stop selling it
440ml Can from Tesco. Reddish amber with a small white head; malt aroma; sweet caramel malt flavour with a fair amount of hops giving a dry finish. Not bad.
Can. Cherry caramel malt aroma. Reddish ambe color with small head. Toffee malt flavor with light hops finish. Decent canned bitter.
440ml can from Tesco. A fairly standard low quality canned lager. Light tasting - little character. No real off flavours, but tastes like the washings through from the making of a better beer.

Pours chestnut with decent off white head. Aroma malty and a little sweet, decent balance of sweet and more toasted malt flavours with a little hop kick on the swallow, if a little metallic. Mouthfeel a little thin and finish short but without unpleasant aftertastes. Decent canned bitter and went down well with a ham sandwich.

Thwaites revive the name of the historic Lancaster Brewery for this canned bitter. No doubt former patrons of Yates & Jackson are turning in their graves. As far as canned bitters go this isn’t too bad. Amber. Faint malty aroma. Pleasant malty sweetness to begin, followed by refreshing sourness and some bitterness. However it has many of the faults of canned beers, like a metallic taste, excessive carbonation, and a generally flaccid, watery feeling.

On tap at Hops & Pie. Clear reddish amber appearance with a beige head. Aroma of toasted malt, mild fruitiness and light caramel/toffee notes. Similar flavor, adding moderate sweetness and light bitterness. Light to medium body with a slight watery feel and a lingering malt finish. Not bad overall.

From Aug 2007 Purchased at Poplar Wine and Spirits in Casper for US$10.50 I was just about to enter this as a new beer but I see my good buddy jwc215 beat me to it. ;^) This one pours from waxed swing top 33.8oz bottle a hazy reddish gold with a thick head of foam with lots of sticky lacing. Very appealing appearance. The foam shrinks to a fine layer by the end of the session but it's *still* looking fine in my Sam Adams glass. The smell is of caramel malt but it's very delicate. The taste is semi sweet on my first sip and very earthy, almost tastes funky. As I take further sips, I'm getting some spice and a good hop bitterness, grass and a touch of lemon, that shows up near and through the finish. This is a tasty son of a gun! It has a medium mouthfeel and the carbo is lightly done. A very quaffable offering from Grand Teton...yet again. I'm really liking what this brewery in Victor Idaho is doing with their Cellar Reserve series. Bottom Line: If you see this one in your local store, give it a try. I recommend it!

On tap at the brewpub in Idaho. Clear deep amber body with a good white head. Aroma: sweet with a hint of caramel. Flavor: average strength for style. Hints of baked bread and toffee. Medium body and carbonation.
On draft at the brewery. Pours s clear gold with a white head. Flavors of white bread with some spec notes. Crisp clean finish.

2 finger head comes up like meringue... brew is crystal clear amber orange.. head sticks around forever.. so does the pretty lace.. Very rich malty aroma.. no hops to speak of.. waves of toasted malt.. not sweet.. not caramelly.. just thick toasted malt.. very nice. It strikes me as having a pretty dry finish.. with the assumed toasted malt essence .. no sweetness on the end. Medium/high malty sweetness out of the gate.. melts to toasty malts mid palate and a subtle earthy hop flavor is still stick around... very very clean from front to back.. Medium body and carbonation has a smooth velvety texture... deep malts but it’s never too sweet.. just very smooth and clean.

Hazy copper with a thin white foam cap. Biscuity nose with a little toasted English muffin and sweet honey coated cereal grains. The flavor is big and full with a lot of honey and toast and sweet cereal grains. Very smooth and sweet with a good honey PPP that’s very distinctive from other marzens. A wee bit grainy and biscuity but overall, this is basically a Honey Oktoberfest.

The color of this beer is a slightly hazy amber color with a medium white head. The aroma belnds yager yeast and lighter malts that are reminiscent of toast. The taste is slightly sour, a touch bitter, and a touch sweet, creating a very crisp flavor. The aftertaste is fairly abrupt, but the bite from the average carbonation does linger on the tongue. Also, the beer has a medium-light body and a slick texture.

Draught: med gold pour with thin head. Aroma is toasted marshmallow, caramel and light fruity hop. Flavour is toasted malt, light grainy bitterness, medium body. Pleasant enough. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at Wurst in Fargo. Pale yellow pour with a large head. Grains and malt, some toffee like sweetness. Kind of muted overall. Not great.
Pours a slightly hazy honey color. Aromas are very muted... Some grainy malt... That’s it. Nice malty flavors. average.

Tap at Back Road Fall Fest. Crazy green olive hops and musty funky yeasty aroma. Golden with a large off-white head. Musty basement, citrus, and spicy flavor with a light grassy bitter finish. Medium body.
A decent saison, interesting how they picked the ingredients and it makes it tasty and unique but not amazing.

tap at the brewery - The aroma is that nice yeasty, citrus accented, hoppy, spicy aroma that unmistakably a saison. It’s hazy dark yellow in color and has a lingering, dense head with lots of lacing. The taste is slightly sweet up front then goes to moderately strong hops bitterness, yeast, citrus, and the slightest touch of barnyard flavor. It finishes dry. Good brew.

12oz from BBB63, thank you Mike. Shared with my gf Cyn. Pours orange with a 2 finger tan head. Nose is sweet and spiced. Taste is spicy with touches of citrus and a bit of hoppy bitterness. The citrus bitter but also lemony. Can’t quite place the spices, but this is certainly a tasty saison.

Draft. Orange amber with good, creamy white head / Bread and citrus nose / Light body, overly tart and thin, with fair, bitter finish / Weak flavors of lemon, orange, and coriander / Lacks the finesse of similar tart saisons. Needs reworking.

Bottles courtesy of BBB. Dirty golden, huge off-white head, great lacing. Big floral and spice character up front. Either chamomile or paradise in the background, I swear, even though the description reads no. Flavor much the same, floral and fruit esters up front, dusty pils malt/spent grain through the middle, faint spice and skunk dry out the finish. Old euro hops is what I wrote in notes, but apparently it’s Mt. Hood. Could be a tad drier, but still very well done.

Growler shared by BBB63. Hazy orange-yellow pour with a white head. Aroma of light pale malt, barnyard elements, sea-salt and yeast. Flavors of spices, yeast, pale malt, light fruits and lemon zest. Medium body dry/creamy with a dry finish.

Growler sampled at the Pre-RBSG ’Tosa gathering on 6/21/07 courtesy of BBB63: Pours a hazy orange bronze with a wispy-lacing white head. Aroma of sweet, lightly toasted biscuity Belgian malt and some grassy hops. Body starts with a mild earthy bready sweetness and some toasty caramel balance toward a drier, more bitter finish. A nice saison.

Sample provided by the Big Bad Bear. Hazy, light amber/pale with a small white head. The nose is herbal and peppery with notes of pear and bread. The flavor is fairly dry, floral and hoppy with some pepper and doughy malts. Medium body is slightly rough with light carbonation. This is nicely done saison for an American brewer.

Bottle from my Santa in July, BBB63. Pours a clear orange with a slightly yellowish foamy head and nice lacings. Sweet with some dry-hops-like (think Orval) sourness. Yeasty with quite a bit of peppar. Long peppary finish. Tastes much like a tripel with pepper.
Black, tan head; rich, sweet dark malt &, molassas aroma and taste with subtle coffee, coconut, dark chocolate, carob. A bit cloying sweet in the finish but decent. Tried 4/29 at brewery.

column1: The Bag and Kettle Trout Brook Gold Light Ale
column4: The Bag and Kettle Brewing Company
column5: On draft as part of a sampler at Bag & Kettle at Sugarloaf. This was the least tasty of the bunch.

column1: The Bag and Kettle Trout Brook Gold Light Ale
column4: The Bag and Kettle Brewing Company
column5: (22 oz.bottle from 1828 Vintage House) Bland about sums it up...Pale yellow with off-white head. Aroma of light bread maltiness, gets a little dishrag-like as head recedes. Mouthfeel thin and slightly prickly/rough. Some light, broken rings of lacing. Flavor is minimal, faint corn/bread malt with even fainter hint of citrus tang. Not objectionable, just goes nowhere.

column1: The Bag and Kettle Trout Brook Gold Light Ale
column4: The Bag and Kettle Brewing Company
column5: 22oz bomber (contract brewed by Shipyard) from Ron’s in Farmington. Slightly hazy but fairly translucent yellow body with virtually no white head. Smell is not particularly strong, but malty sweetness dominates with a some floral hops to support. Tastes like biscuit malt with hints of floral hops and diacetyl. Thin watery mouthfeel. Pretty drinkable though. Nothing earth-shattering, but a fairly easy-drinking ale.
not very strong, kind of a dull flavor but sweet. its alright, not great but its ok.
On tap at brewery 4/29/07. A double IPA with white grapefruit rind hop aroma and flavor; some sweetness, honey, and an overall rich, full bodied, tasty brew. I’d order another!

column1: The Bag and Kettle Brown Bag Ale
column4: The Bag and Kettle Brewing Company
column5: On draft as part of a sampler at Bag & Kettle at Sugarloaf. This was one of the better ones though still not all that great.

column1: The Bag and Kettle Brown Bag Ale
column4: The Bag and Kettle Brewing Company
column5: Draught @ The Bag on Sugarloaf. It was nothing special pretty bland and boring.

column1: The Bag and Kettle Brown Bag Ale
column4: The Bag and Kettle Brewing Company
column5: 22oz bomber (brewed by Shipyard) from Ron’s in Farmington. Translucent reddish-brown body with a quarter inch of off-white head. Smells like caramel and chocolate malts. Caramel and chocolate malts dominate the flavor, with some supporting hop bitterness and a bit of astringency. On the lighter side of medium-bodied. Very drinkable for what it is. Not the best brown ale I’ve had, but a pretty decent one.
The head is ok, the body orange-brown and cloudy. The taste is malty, sweet, a bit yeasty. Less taste. Medium. 11/8/7/8/-/8

Darkish amber pour, opaque from the cloudiness. Adequate banana and clove nose, but tartish fruitiness, a bit like in the alt once again lays in the background. I can’t say it really disturbs in the nose, but in mouth, the thinned body obviously suffers from this phenomenon. I’m afraid they just are not at their best when playing with dark malts.

Second stop during the ABA Beer Tour ’07 in Belgrade, Montana. Sampled with kyzr at the brewpub. Pours a clear medium gold brew with a nice off-white head that slowly dissolves to a fine film. Aroma of toasted multi-grain cereal malt with a hint of flowery hops. Taste is medium bodied, lightly carbonated with a watery malt flavor. Finish is slightly bitter but the bitter aftertaste does not stay around very long.

Dark gold with off-white head. Very weak notes of malt on the nose. Flavor is lightly toasted malt that backs into a little bit of hoppiness. Body is medium, finish leaves an odd coating on the palate.

column1: Big Time Ave Rat Malt Liquor
column5: Smells and looks okay, which scores it higher than most malt liqours. First sip is extremely strong alcoholic and malt liqourish. It gets a bit better, but really isn’t nearly as great as it’s rated to me.

column1: Big Time Ave Rat Malt Liquor
column5: (Growler)Nice body with a corn finish in the flavor.Yellow in color with a white head.

column1: Big Time Ave Rat Malt Liquor
column5: A malt liquor! Maybe my first craft malt liquor. Pours a clear yellow with a small white head. The aroma is sweet hops, dirty malts. The flavor is a bit hot, aggressive, more hoppy than any other malt liquor ever. Not bad.

column1: Big Time Ave Rat Malt Liquor
column5: Sampler at the brewery. The best malt liquor I’ve ever had, fruitier and quite a bit hoppier than I expected, quite smooth, no sign of alcohol.

column1: Big Time Ave Rat Malt Liquor
column5: Sweet aroma with some grain, corn, and a touch fruity. I thought it was almost juicy. Golden pour with a decent lasting head. Sweet and grainy with hints of corn and a decent bitter finish. I love malt liquor so this one works for me.

column1: Big Time Ave Rat Malt Liquor
column5: Draught @ WABF 2008. Poursa clear golden color with a small white head. Sweet malty grainy aroma with some hints of corn. Sweet malty caramel and grainy flavor. Sweet warming caramel finish with some hints of corn.

column1: Big Time Ave Rat Malt Liquor
column5: Clear dark gold with a frothy white head. Big fruity, corn syrup berry aroma with ethyl alcohol. Nice smooth body. Good sweet pale malt lager flavors with a clean finish. Maybe they should bottle this, in 40 oz’ers and sell’m to the pan handlers on the ave........

column1: Big Time Ave Rat Malt Liquor
column5: On tap at WABL Fathers Day BrewFest 2008. Pours clear gold with a thin white head. Medium body & light carbonation. Sweet aroma and taste of biscuit and almonds, maybe a touch of plastic? Not an everyday drink, but ya gotta do at least one.

column1: Big Time Ave Rat Malt Liquor
column5: I had postponed tasting this one as I am not really interested in malt liquors at this point in my life and Big Time always has at least a few decent beers on tap. However, this was a surprising deviation for the style, and had I not known, I would never have pegged this as a malt liquor. It is blonde-bronze in appearance with a foamy-creamy head. Surprising burst of moderately appealing floral and perfumed notes in the aroma mingling with light graininess and alcohol. The flavor reinforces the perfumed-floweriness, with a strong hoppiness. This was akin to a highly hopped cream ale, as it has a smooth, creamy texture.

column1: Big Time Ave Rat Malt Liquor
column5: Sample at the pub. Yellow. Holds it head well. Grainy nose. Thick diesel and paint thinner. Almost drinkable.

Draught at Kennedy school. Tarru black with tan head. Lekker chocolate nose, with notes of hop. Creamy chocolate malt flavour, with notes of roast malt and sugar. Creamy finish, with just a note of dryness and bitterness to keep it from being cloying.

On tap at the Kennedy School location; nitrogenated. Deep murky black color with some softer charcoal shades and a tight layer of creamy tan head. Aroma is restrained, but has a soft milk chocolate nose with a hint of vanilla bean. Creamy chocolate mouse and caramel coffee mocha. Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel that’s the perfect weight and sweetness for the serving method. The flavors are really well put together on this one. Milk chocolate syrup and malt balls start out softly on the palate, matching the texture perfectly. The flavors transition seemlessly into a bit darker, more interesting ground of anise, brown sugar, and dark dry chocolate notes. Finishes dry with a pleasant smack of minty hops.

Nitro Tap at Rams Head Pub... Poured a deep black with a frothy brown head. Roasted malt aroma, mildly carbonated palate. Flavors of chocolate/mocha coffee, a touch of caramel or brown sugar. Finished silky smooth with a metallic aftertaste.

Had on nitro at the Queen Anne location in Seattle. Dark black w/ ultra creamy light brown head. Light aroma of roasted malt. Roasted malt in the flavor with coffee and chocolate. Pretty darn good. Light and sessionable, but still gives you plenty of taste.
On tap at the Federal Way location Clear light golden with a small white head, some lacing. Mild aroma of German malts. Taste is malty and caramel Ok
On tap at The Rock. Light pour with little to no head. Aroma is slim to none. Flavor is about the same. A little sweetness here and there. Watery mouthfeel.

Pint on tap at The Rock’s Edmonton location pours a pale straw color with a small white head that leaves very little lacing. Aroma is grassy and grainy with perhaps a hint of citrus. Taste is a grassy hop bitterness with a light malty grain sweetness. Not very inviting and not flavorful either.

January 29th, 2013 - I sort of knew walking into this line of samplers that I wasn’t going to like what was there. The pizza at this restaurant wasn’t good, so why should the brews? Still, I sighed and dove in, if not for the experience, than for those sweet, sweet beer review counts. The Rock’s Lite My Fire is light and pale, and almost invisible to the nose. The flavor is likewise bland, leaving a foamy palate to step in and define the drinking experience. There’s a little malt in there, but faint and, at this level of intensity, unpleasant.
Aroma is a sweet 2 row maltiness with only really the carbonation to add to it. Taste is fairly bland overall. Sweet grain body met with bland hopiness. Light gold body with a poorly retained head.
Pale piss color with white head. Light berry fruit, grainy pale malt aromas. Light bodied. Light berry fruit, grainy pale malt flavors--

Pour on tap at their location in Highlands Ranch, CO. Clear yellow with no head, aroma had some very slight grain and corn...that’s about it. Taste was fairly watery, some slight biscuit maybe with a hint of grass if you searched, but overall not much going on here.

Hazy blonde body, decent carbonation, pond scum head. Throughout the pint, not much aroma ever made it off the glass. However, the body was surprisingly respectable for a blonde ale. Light-bodied, but slightly sweet cereal graininess that is rather pleasant. A tad doughy. Not bad.

Draft at Lynnwood, WA location: Light appearance-wise, texture-wise and taste-wise, but that’s what they’re going for. Mouthfeel is slightly watery with a lively carbonation. Soda-like sweetness with hints of cereal. Mild bitterness and a slight tartness. For a light beer it’s not that bad. It’s drinkable but unexciting.

Draught@The Rock Wood Fired Pizza brewpub, Tacoma, WA Golden color, small white head. Light sweetish malty, brewing cereals aroma. Light-bodied. Light sweetish, brewing cereals flavor. A bit plasticky. Very weak palate. Light beer it is.

Cask Conditioned at The Upton Muggery, Upton upon Severn. Deep brown with beige head. Sweet malty beer, caramel and toffee, but again a boiled grainy flavour permeates the beer as if too much is being extracted from the wort. Acidic, grainy finish. Ushers used to be a fine beer, but no longer.
Künstlich süßer Antrunk nach Zitronenlimonade. Deutlich zu süß, zudem im Abgang erneut künstlich wirkend. 7/5/4/4/7/4
Pale gold with a thin head. Aromas are light lager grain with lemonade. Aromas are quite artificial. Flavours are dry grain with lemonade.
Pours a clear and very pale yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is malt and lemon. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness. Overall a beer below average.
Pours pale yellow with a large white head. Aroma is light malt and light soappy citrus. Flavour is soappy citrus, malt, cardboard and light DMS:
Bottle @ Bierzwerg.de. Pours clear pale yellow with a creamy white head. Nose is paper, grain and citrus. Paperish flavor. A bit of rubber. Thin and chemical.
Pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma of lemon soda, a hint of some herb, and a touch of DMS. Sweet and chemical flavour with a touch of lemon
It’s a light-golden radler with a white head, and both aroma and flavour is sweet with mild notes of malt and lemon-soda, that isn’t as dominating or cloying as in many radlers.
