Der Hauptteil wird noch etwas komplexer mit einer leichte, schon dem Whisky sehr nahekommenden Schärfe. Es schmeckt fast so, als hätte man Bier und Whisky gemischt. Dazu eine sehr ausgeprägte Holznote. Nur der Nachgeschmack ist von Seiten des Bieres etwas flach. Es macht den Eindruck, als ob das schöne Kaffee-Schokoladenaroma aprupt abfällt und eine komische Wässrigkeit hinterlässt, die zwar nur kurz anhält, aber irgendwie nicht zu dem schönen milden Holz-Vanille-Whiskyaroma passt, das sich auch im Nachgeschmack schön lange hält. Je länger man den Geschmack auf der Zunge hat, desto weicher wird er – wie bei einem guten Whisky. Auch taucht hier die schöne kaffe-schokoladigkeit des Stout wieder auf und fügt sich sehr toll mit der Whisky-Holznote zusammen. 14+11+13+13

Bottle at home in bonnie Scotland. It pours very dark brown with a small bubbly beige head. The nose is quite soft...roasted malt, sweet coffee, whisky, vanilla, caramel, chocolate, liquorice and a faint medicinal accent. The taste is also rather soft: caramel, chocolate, toast, roasted malt, whisky, wood, vanilla, earth, liquorice, coffee and some dark fruit with a warming bitter-sweet finish. Medium-full body, low carbonation and oily mouth-feel. Very nice indeed. I rather like how mellow and soft these older Paradox’s get with age. Very easy drinking.

In bottle at Craig’s. Pours a very dark brown colour with a lacy tan head. Aroma of whiskey, dark chocolate, espresso coffee, caramel and Ovaltine malt. Similar flavours with mild carbonation and an oily mouth-feel. Very nice.
Vanilla and gentle whisky nose. No carbonation, sweet chocolate, subtle whisky, warming.

Hope this is the right beer. Bartender said yes, this is the Belgian IPA they a serving, buts it’s very busy . . . Definitely has both characteristics of a Belgian, some barnyard flavor, a bit of citrus, a bit of spice, layered over with some good bitter grass that lingers well. Beautiful golden color.

On draught, hand drawn at the brewpub in Hayward, Wisconsin. Pours a clear golden amber brew with a heavy and creamy off-white head that has an excellent retention and thick lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, some citrus zest but could not pick up any orange or corlander scents. Taste is very smooth, creamy with hardly any carbonation. Flavors picked up are caramel malt and some citrus. Finish has a mild bitterness of most light IPA’s but then has a lingering and slightly sweet citrus aftertaste. The hand drawn draught version of this Wit/IPA is a nice touch.

I like witbier, and I like IPAs, so I figured I’d really like this fusion beer (two great tastes that taste great together, right?). And from that perspective, this beer is a bit disappointing...turns out flavors are not quite as additive as I would have hoped. Nonetheless, this beer is as advertised...I thought it to be a witbier with good amounts of clove/coriander spice and a touch of citrus-ness combined with a hearty helping of hops. While I would not categorize it as exceptional in either category, it was a very unique beer and I would still recommend it. The beer smelled exceptional; and the smell indicated that brewery had named the beer aptly, if not very creatively. Taste was a bit dissapointing in comparison...those same elements were present, but they did not meld together as well in my mouth as they did in my nostrils. You could definitely pickup on the wit spiciness and also detect a significant presence of slightly sweet hops, which contributed to the citrus notes in this beer, although not in a way usually assoicated with wits. Mouthfeel was nothing special (good or bad). While I wasn’t sure what to expect from this beer, or what to categorize it as, I did find it very unique. It wasn’t the best tasting beer I’ve ever had; I couldn’t help but think that maybe there was a reason brewers had not previously tried to fuse these two styles together, but nonetheless I thought the resulting product to be more or less what I expected and still commendable.

column4: Krebs Brewing Company / Pete's Place / Choc Beer
column5: bottle. pale golden with small head. not very funky for a saison, but otherwise solid. light bodied saison with a bit of a grassy, herbal twist.

column4: Krebs Brewing Company / Pete's Place / Choc Beer
column5: Good saison. Nice pour, clear, orange copper with medium white head. Aroma has some hop presence..grass, pine and citrus. Flavor has components of hops (same as aroma), but also of yeast and malt. Finish is clean and smooth.

column4: Krebs Brewing Company / Pete's Place / Choc Beer
column5: On tap. This beer was brewed by the guys at Pete’s and entered into the North American Beer Awards competition under the name "Summer Saison" but was changed to Lefty’s 363 in honor of the late, great Warren Spahn. Spahn holds the record for most wins by a left hander in MLB histroy at 363. Spahn owned a ranch just outside of Hartshorne, Oklahoma, a tiny hamlet that neighbors Krebs, the home of Petes Place. The beer itself poured a bit cloudy initially but settled into a nice clear gold and copper color that propped up an ample white head. Generous amounts of lacing. The aroma was of mild citrus and spice with definite bit of herbs/grassy quality underneath. The flavor was citrus and grass. Clean finish. Refreshing. Easy to drink.
Got this at Hal's Bottle Shop in Ross Twnshp--north of Pittsburgh. Really get the taste of maple syrup in this! A really good tasting brown ale! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The beer poured great with a dark reddish hue that passes some light through it, has an off white fomay head, and leaves some lacing on the glass. The smell is decent with a good blend of light caramal malt, toffee and maple sweetness. The beer tastes great as you the maltinepss up front, mild chocolate that gives away to the maple sweetness on the back end, not overpowering but enough to let you know that it is there. The mouthfeel is decent as the beer is well carbonated, medium bodied, and leaves you mildly dry with a sweet taste lingering. Overall, a good red maple ale that blendss together well without overpowering you.
Pours a dark copper color. Taste is overly sweet and has a mild nutty flavor. Don’t recommend unless you enjoy really sweet beer.
Sample at the brewpub. Hazy copper pour with a medium off-white head. Malty nose with caramel and hints of apricot. Sweet caramel flavor with a bit of roast in the finish.

Enjoyed via draft at the brewpub. Despite the advertisement of maple syrup being used in the brewing process, little was actually evident in the aroma or flavor of the finished beer; probably due to the fact that maple syrup is almost entirely fermentable. I was disappointed in most aspects of this beer. It was clean, but bland in scent and flavor. I realize that the brewpub is aiming for a wide variety of customers, but I don’t see that as a reason to dumb down styles to the point in which they have little to no flavor and complexity. Try the Paleo IPA instead.

Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured a dark copper color with a white head. The aroma was lightly fruity and nutty. The flavor was caramel, maple and light fruity hop with nutty malts underneath. The finish was medium length with notes fruit and caramel. Interesting.

This ale is not for the faint of heart. If you like sweetness, but not in beer, ah maybe try something else; otherwise you maybe in for a wonderful surprise. The ale has a nice taste however you may want to limit your intake to maybe one or two pints at the max because the sweetness of this ale is a little out of control. It is worth buying a pint of it for something different.

Draft. Body is brownish-amber wih an aroma that promises sweetness and a touch of hops. Flavor is another mater all together. The sweetness is WAY out of control and almost nauseating. Pretty awful stuff!

A very nice clear beer that has a color slightly darker than the ubiquitous pale yellow american lager. It is a little more brown. About the same color as a yuengling lager. Aroma is slightly hoppy. Flavor is an impact of hops and sweetness. The maple syrup is readily apparent as if it was added after the brew. However, this does not distract from the enjoyability of this brew. Only slight carbonation. The fizziness is medium low but appreciated and present. Finish is barely oppressive, some good personality. A little back of throat bitterness hangs but it is relatively mild.

Pink with rimming offwhite head; aroma is of prescription cough medicine; Flava is not like medicine, it is softly sweet notes of cherry then dry wheat and rounding out with notes of licorice; feels light but foamy fizz; finishes dry notes of wheat and semi tart

Poured on draft at the source. Pours a translucent amber color. White head. Aroma has some definitive cherry notes that give way to a bready nuance. Sweet and fruity cherries initially. Bready finish.

Fruit beers are generally hit or miss with me and I consider this a hit. The aroma is strongly cherries. The taste follows with all cherries, but isn’t overpowering. Overall the right balance of sweet cherries without losing sight of that fact it’s a beer.
Sample at the brewpub. Cloudy yellow pour with a thin white head. Creamy malt and cherry nose. Creamy malt flavor with lots of sweet cherries before a semi-dry finish.

On tap at North Country. Aroma of cherry Sucrets and pie filling, musky and sweet with some cherry bark. Medium amber haze with light white head. Medium-light body with medium carbonation. Starts mild with light acidity, some beany character, and sweet cherry pie filling. Mild finish, very light overall and finish. Refreshing summer quaff.

One of this brewpubs notorious fruit beers. They have some good ones. Has a pinkish champagne hue to this beer. Barely any head tho there is a froth on top. Sweet and sour cherries aroma. The taste is definately cherries, perhaps like cherry flavoring that needs a little sweetner. Is not syrupy sweet by no means and does not taste like a wine cooler, those are sweeter than this. Leaves an interesting lingering cherry taste on the palate. Really has more alky taste than the 4.4% listed here. Finish is quite interesting, at times it seems artificial and at other times it comes on like sour cherries freshly picked off a cherry tree. The cherry flavor seems a bit out of place but I thought this to be a good representation of a fruit beer when compared to others in this style.

On tap at the brewpub. Good banana clove aroma, sweet with light hops. Simple but very good nose. Clear dark amber with thin head. Medium body with light carbonation. Starts sweet with banana and clove, caramel malt, brown sugar. Smooth finish and after. Sweet and a bit of alcohol. Nice Dunkelweizen.

Boy, I love those wheat beer, aren’t they something else? This is a little higher on the alky percent scale when compared to many dunkel weizen. Probably should be a dunkler bock. Beatiful milky brown chocolate appearance that must be seen to appreciate! This beer has a head that just does no fade. After a while the froth just stands up on its own. Like a baloon that is slowly deflating. It just stands there like pants that need a good washing. Has a slight vinegary aroma that sticks out at ya. Also, it has hints of a strongish sweetsmelling ale. Wow, quite a wheat. Banana and spices abound in the flavors. Very, very nice and relatively complex. Lovely and friendly. Easy to like even with the uncovered hints of alky that are present. Finish does have some alky bitterness apparent on the back of the throat but is not oppressive or offensive. Just enough to let you know you drank a pretty strong brew. Just a little strong for my girlie taste buds.

On tap at North Country. NIce mild chocolate nose with sweet lactose and a hint of smoke. Nutty, coffee with molasses. Dark black opaque with thin lacing head. Medium creamy body with light carbonation. Starts moderately sweet with sweet malt chocolate and some nutty coffee. A little hop and nutty bitterness to it, too. Finish is semi-sweet with mild sugary tang. Smooth after with coffee and cream.

Tremendous pour, reminds me of used Harley shovelhead oil. Black and more black opaque. Chocolate mousse head that fades slowly. Good stoutish aroma attracts me to this brew. Makes my mouth water. Has a caution for lactose intolerant drinkers! Good example of a sweet milk stout. Not too bitter. Decent carbonation that is welcomed in this style. Lovely, friendly and easy. Finish is like any sweet stout, just a little of the back throat charcoaled bitterness but not so much that it becomes offensive. Youi know that satisfying taste of meat that was cooked just a little too long on the grill. Would like to sample this again. Just love those no oppressive sweet stouts. Fine examples of dark beer.

Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a black color with a medium sized creamy tan head that left great lacing. The aroma was dry, roasty, bitter and coffee. The flavor was roasty, bitter and dryish with vanilla, coffee and wood. Long finish. Medium body. Meh.

On tap at North Country. Roasted grain and light burnt nosee, a bit of molasses and chocolate. Dark ruby black clear with thin head. Medium body with medium carbonation. Starts moderately sweet with roasted and toasted malts. Chocolate and molasses. Quite a good bit of smoky acidic tang of black malt. Bitter hop and barley finish with lingering bitter after.
The description sounds great, but I found this slightly disappointing. It looks great and has hints of roasted chocolate with slight bitterness.

Black it is, like used shovelhead oil. Pour is black and opaque. Coal black. Looks attractive and has an annessette floral licorice aroma. I think I also detect some chocolate in there. Good schartzbier taste without much offensiveness. Not too bitter. Generally OK without being in your face. Fine example of a dark beer. Can’t taste much chocolate if any. This is an enjoyable brew, very good. Some back of throat bitterness builds on the throat towards the end of the session. This bitterness hangs around for a while after you are finished.

Had 13 beer flight on a beautiful custom wood flight. Beers overall were solid and the service was great. Nothing extraordinary overall with flight, but most palatable and easy to drink. A few unique beers with honey and lavender. Individual beers as follows: Worth your weight in gold: Lager taste, slight malty feel, plenty of flavor for a yellow clear beer. Nice lager. Slippery rock Dew: Thick in the mouth, honey flavor readily present, fresh and refreshing Station 33:Crisp, caramel malts, simple but enjoyable Mcleods Eva: Smooth, sweet at the end. Light and watery for a malty beer. Less overwhelming, good or bad, then many in the same style Squirel Nut Brown: Good rendition for the style Amber waves of grain: Can really taste the caramel malts. Drinkable. Simcoe Pale Ale: Smells like a christmas treee. Would be nice with a big dinner to cleanse the pallate between bites. Paleo IPA: average IPA Frias Porter: Good flavor bute falls a little short. Root beer flavor at the end Stonehouse stout: On nitro. Guiness feel in the mouth but a bit more boring. Fruit bowl: neat idea, apricot flavor this go around, great summer beer Lavender Abbey: Strong aroma and flavor. Lavender hits you in the face. Polarizing experience.
Draft at the brewpub. Pours a hazy amber with thin white head and soapy lace. Nose of peaches, apricots, grapefruit, light caramel. Medium body, great hoppy flavor.

This is first visit and I wanted to see how their APA stacked up. The amber color and smallish head was a good start. Some grapefruit and spruce but not the normal bitterness of simcoe hops. Some lemon notes were detected. The ale was smooth but thin without body. Smooth finish again with no bitterness.
On cask at north country. Pours a hazy dark amber color. Aroma of citrus hops. Taste is very hoppy for a pale ale which I like. This beer is much better on cask.

On tap at North Country. Super floral Simcoe aroma, sweet with apricot, pine resin and grapefruit. Sweet brown sugary malt. Dark amber clear with some haze, topped with a thin off-white lacing head. Medium body with medium-heavy carbonation. Starts with medium brown sugar sweetness and light grapefruit rind. Quickly descends into a full-fledged hop-heavy assault on the palate, going from fruity to floral to deep teeth-cleansing bitter. Finishes fairly smooth with light biscuit and big biter grassy hops. Nice pale ale.

Darker than your typical APA and a bit cloudy too. A bit piney or sprucy in the aroma. Has that bitter IPA flavor we are all familiar with, probably should be rated as an IPA. Hoppy taste that just will not quit. Good, grapefruit rind flavors. Bitter back of the throat taste that lasts and lasts and lasts. This brew is a little less acrid sharp than the Paleo IPA, but still has that IPA oppressiveness. IPA lovers, get a growler of this stuff to try.
keg at Black Door Helsinki 200608 Color:amber Taste:long lasting after bitterness. Nice one. Needs to re-rate later on
Draught@Kaunis Kampela, Helsinki. Amber color, nearly no head. Hoppy aroma. Bitter taste with a malty background and a long finish. A very quaffable bitter in the English style.
Not as good as Huvila´s original bitter. A good bitter, easy to drink but nothing special. A lack of personality is the only problem comparing to the other Huvila ales.

Draught@Bruxellensis. Felt very sweet to me, and very filtered down and dead (not sure about if its filtered/pasteurised). Sweet caramel and some touches of earthy hop charactyers, some orangey note and leafy hops. Tatsed a bit stale.

A Mes rate: Draught at Bruxellensis. Nice bight amber colour with a slight off white head. Decent spicy hop aroma that is very bitter and dry. Flavour very much along the same lines. Light fruity notes and some malt underneath giving it pretty good balance. Very delicate caramel lending it a bit of sweetness. Bitter finish. Thoroughly enjoyable and very English. Much better than thousands of others we have to choose from over here.

On tap @ Bruxellensis. Semi-hazy amber with off-white head. Faint caramel and biscuit-malt nose with some hops. Flavor is same, rolling into mild bitterness and a touch of dryness. More of a quaffer than the ESB, as you’d expect I reckon. Pretty nice quencher.

Draught Clear deep-copper-amber beer with small yellowish head. Sulphur, dried fruits on sulphur, ambrée malts, touch of hops. BItter of hops, sweet of dried fruit (apricot?), and a lot of suphur in the end again, meybe even some rubber. But very good balance. Well balanced, but the beer ends a bit thin. Nice drinking ale.

Draught @ Bruxellensis. Flowery hops and apricot in the aroma. Thin. Flowery, somnewhat earthy hops in the flavor. Loads of fruity esters, apricot especially. Long earthy hopbitter aftertaste. Well balanced beer.

Draught at Black Door, Helsinki Beautiful amber color, hazy; thin creamy head. The aroma is nice, but light. Good body strength, dry mouthfeel, strong caramel flavor, and a growing bitterness, very powerful at the end; in the final the malt and the hop mix very well together into a toffee impression. The final is extremely long. A perfectly brewed English styled Ale.

Draught. Amber colour with mediumsized creamy off-white head. Aroma is fruitish hoppy and slightly grassy. Flavour has a lot of fruit in it and is really smooth. Aftertaste gets is also nicely fruitish hoppy. quite dry.
Wakefield Beer Festival. Chestnut coloured with a head. Has a fine body for what is a session bitter.
On gravity at Swindon beer festival 27/10/2011. Amber with a slight off-white head. Light, cereal malts with a touch of hedgerow fruits and decent, bitter finish. Easy drinking.

Cask at the Carpenters Arms, London. Pours clear amber with a light, filmy head. Some pleasant hops greet the nose, along with bready malts. Lightly sweet with bread and butter maltiness, followed by some herbal and citrusy bitters. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Finish has some more bready malts and light hops. Average.

Cask. Ambery brown colour with small foamy white head. Aroma is is nectar, some herbs as well as quite fruity. Flavour is very much the same with a slight sweetish fruity and nectary finish. Quite basic.
Cask at the Broad Street Tavern, Wokingham. Reddish chestnut with a loose white head; sweet and malty to start, leading to a gently bitter finish. A very drinkable session bitter.

Cask at the Magpie & Crown, Brentford, 4th Jan 2010 with tashi. Classic bitter colour with a little bit of white head. Quite light palate. Strange flavour - there’s a bit of smoke, an odd "stone" mineral taste, nuttiness and a decent finish. Odd is probably the best way to describe it, but I like it.
500ml Bottle - As Anna-Festbier. Golden with a foamy head. Sultanas, lemon, grass and grain in the aroma. Grass, grain, citrus and some sweet bready notes in the taste.

3 August 2018. At Rixx, Bamberg. Cheers to Anke! As 'Lowenbräu Anna-Festbier'. Pours... into a mug; lasting, unstable, frothy, tan head; some lacing. Aroma of mouldy peach & orange, expired milk or yoghurt, sourdough & yeast, caramel, honey, herbs. It tastes light fruity sour, yoghurty & lactic, some sourdough, and light spicy bitter, a bit herbal; bready back. Dryish, tart, yeasty finish, bit grassy hoppy. Light to medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Weird aroma, but drinkable.
On keg at GBBF as Annafestbier, amber-brown with a big clingy fine head and a lightly malty and peppery-herbal nose. Toasty malt and light herbal bitterness,with an underlying sweetness.

"Buttenheimer Löwenbräu Anna-Festbier", Flasche (50 cl). - Dunkles Goldgelb, klar. - In der Nase schlankes (für ein Festbier), mild karamelliges Toastmalz und sehr milder aber eleganter kräuteriger Hopfen. - Antrunk satt toastig-karamelmalzig mit Brotkruste, zarter Honigsüße und nicht zu knapper aromatischer Hopfung mit Kräutern und bitterer Orangenschale. Milder rezent, vollmundig aber nicht dick. Im Abgang klassisch fränkische, aromatisch kräuterige Hopfenherbe, nicht aufdringlich aber angenehm präsent. - Elegantes, sehr gut gehopftes Märzen fränkischer Prägung mit wenig Alkohol aber viel Geschmack. Sehr gut!

Sweet grain, caramel malts, bread and molasses. Clear, pale gold, tiny, creamy, white head. Light sweet. More sweet grain malts, molasses, medium carbonation, medium bodied. Boring Maerzen. Keg at GBBF17, Kensington Olympia.

August 2017 - Keg at GBBF 2017, Kensington Olympia. As 'Löwenbräu Buttenheim Bartholomäus Festmärzen'. Golden orange, lightly sparkling, translucent with a small off-white head. Aroma is grainy, musty. Body is light and a little frothy with tingly to spritzy carbonation. Taste is grains, crackers, papery, a little spicy and dusty in the finish. Plain. (4-4-4-3-11=2.6)
Bottle at the brewpub. Clear orange -gold with a white head. Some minerals and some oxidation in the nose, sweet, raisins, oxidation in the mouth. Medium body, lobg and sweetish-raisins finish.
Keg at the Great British Beer Festival. Clear golden with a fine head. Typical noble hop aroma. Dry, clean bitterness with decent body. A decent Marzen (at the time I thought it was a helles!).
Keg at The Great British Beer Festival 2017, Kensington Olympia. Mid golden colour. Very pleasant.

Keg at GBBF. It pours clear yellow - gold with a decent white head. The aroma is soft, sweet, sponge cake, lemon drizzle, slight graininess, muffin and hay. The taste is crisp, dry, bitter, straw, grassy, grain, sponge cake, straw, some booty sting and damp leaves with a drying finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Interesting stuff.
on tap dorata schiuma media un po cartone nota erbaceo amaro medio vecchia?
Hyper ferreux avec une touche végétale sur une charpente molle et sans vie. Triste.
Bottle 0.5l at One Pint Pub, Helsinki. Originally rated 09092011. Colour is clear golden with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Grain and malts.

On bottle. Light, easy to drink and golden coloured. Medium low carbonation with a small no persistend head, it is very refreshing and pleasant to drink. Good when you are thirsty and you don’t need a complex beer.
500ml bottle. Aroma: cereal. Appearance: golden, clear, minimal head, sparkling. Taste: light sweetness. Palate: medium body, average carbonation, min bitter finish.

Bottled (thanks fonefan). Golden colour, small off-white head. Aroma is sweet malts, some mild bready notes as well as a mild earthyness. Flavour is sweet malts, some mild maizelike notes and also some earth and mild herbs. A strange burn on the tnogue as well.
Botted (BB 09/2010) Golden color, small white head. Grainy cardboardish aroma with herbal notes. Medium-bodied. Flavor is also papery, grainy with herbal touch. Typical Supermarket lager.
Pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma of grain and hay with a honey note. Sweet grainy flavour with a cardboard note. Hoppy finish

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium yellow color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, toasted, light to moderate hoppy, green grass. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100813]
Bottle @ Danish Summer Gathering, 2010. Pours clear yellow with a small creamy off white head. Grainy and grassy. Dry and bitter flavor. Medium bodied. Dry lasting end.
Sehr trübes goldgelbes Weizen mit geringem weißem Schaum. Geruch nach Nelken, würzig, hefig. Geschmack sehr hefig, leicht estrig fruchtig, würzig, wenig Nelke.

column1: Schloßbrauerei Fattigau Doppel Hopfen Premium Pils
column5: 0,5l Flasche. Tiefgelbes naturtrübes Pils mit schöner Schaumkrone. Außergewöhnlich malziger Geruch, im Geschmack gepaart mit Hopfen. Interessant!

column1: Schloßbrauerei Fattigau Doppel Hopfen Premium Pils
column5: Pour from a bottle at The Taste of DC event in Washington DC. Poured a clear golden color with a fluffy white head. Aroma was light herbal, grassy hop notes. Grain and bready. Light biscuit sweetness. Touch herbal and a little grassy hop notes. Crisp.

column1: Schloßbrauerei Fattigau Doppel Hopfen Premium Pils
column5: Bottle. Golden color. Floral hops and a hint of butter in the aroma. Malty floral buttery flavor. Diacetyl spoils the fun. Medium bodied.

column1: Schloßbrauerei Fattigau Doppel Hopfen Premium Pils
column5: Bottle thanks to the very generous Erlangernick. Prost. Clear pale gold lasting white head. Noble hoppy aroma. Oh yes, that’s a good German pils. Good German hop aroma, light in mouth, but then some lemon and lime and herb finish. Crisp and bitter. Lovely so refreshing. Went with my salmon en croute superbly.

column1: Schloßbrauerei Fattigau Doppel Hopfen Premium Pils
column5: Flasche (50 cl) im „Exklusiv-Karton“ von der Brauerei. - Goldgelb, blank; üblicher Schaum. - Geruch für ein Pilsener ungewöhnlich malzsüßlich-brotig, mit Stroh und stumpf hopfenwürzigem Hopfen. - Antrunk frisch hopfenwürzig, leicht krautig, feuchtes Laub, nur schwach zitronige Anklänge. Das mild süßliche helle Malz tritt zu deutlich hervor. Mild rezent, leicht mineralisch. Kräftig hopfenwürziger, nur mäßig bitterer Abgang; zu schwacher Nachtrunk. - Etwas einseitig gehopftes Pilsener, bei dem mir herb-fruchtige und harzige Hopfenaromen und überhaupt etwas „Pep“ fehlen. Von einem „Doppel Hopfen“ hatte ich mir mehr versprochen.

column1: Schloßbrauerei Fattigau Doppel Hopfen Premium Pils
column5: 0.5l Bottle. Golden color, white head. Moderate aroma of herbal/grassy hops, some grain and bread notes. Taste starts a bit too sweet, grain and malt notes dominate at first, then decent hoppy notes. Medium body, medium bitterness. Expected a bit more, still a solid brew.

column1: Schloßbrauerei Fattigau Doppel Hopfen Premium Pils
column5: Ins Glas ergießt sich ein klares goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hopfig, getreidig, grasig. Geschmack hopfig, grasig, lang anhaltende Bitterkeit.

column1: Schloßbrauerei Fattigau Doppel Hopfen Premium Pils
column5: aroma: grassy, hoppy, slightly butter/diacetyl, fresh, a bit sweet; colour is light golden, looks tasty, nice and for a pilsener very creamy foam on top of the beer; taste: slightly like metal, typical german hops, a bit grassy, very hoppy bitter but nevertheless quite refreshing. i like those southern pilsener due to their more hoppy character while the northern beers of this type don’t contain such a hop-aroma and are only bitter.

column1: Schloßbrauerei Fattigau Doppel Hopfen Premium Pils
column5: Plörrig hopfiger Antrunk mit geringer Fruchtigkeit. Mild herb, angenehme Süße. Diese stört aber nach einiger Zeit, laffer werdend, etwas brotig. 11/9/9/9/7/9

column1: Schloßbrauerei Fattigau Doppel Hopfen Premium Pils
column5: Bottle 0.33l from P&M Bonn. Pours clear golden with medium white head. Medium carbonation. Aroma is malt and grain with a rather unpleasant metal touch. Taste is malt with some sweetness, hops and a buttery hint. Good bitter aftertaste. Overall good drinkable but a bit bland.

500ml bottle. 25 days before its "best by". Pours a clear gold, quickly dissipating white foamy head. Aroma is grainy and lagery, a touch old, but not wholly oxidized. Flavor is grainy and sweet, properly oxidized, autolyzed yeast, sweetness actually helps. I would like to try it fresh.
Bottle at home. Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma of massive diacytel, light herbal, fruity, grains. Taste is maasive diacytel, grains, herbal. Wauw

500mL bottle from State Line, a dusty old number probably rescued from somewhere else, best before 26 09 17 but I'm going to give it a go ... for science. Nose citrus and sunny pale malt, very mild grain, hint of tightness, not staleness; expecting chalk. Pour clear, rich, fiery golden with a bubbly off-white head. Medium body medium-strong sweet, essentially no bitterness or tang. Strong malt character with a hint of grain and even a barest Hauch of spagh-funk from mildest noble hops. Everything feels settled, balanced, stable ... amazing how well this has held up, a clear three-for-three from this cache. Very drinkable, mature, classy, but with natural and rustic overtones, love it. [2019.07.01: 3.4]

Blind tasted with 4 other helles/dortmunder lagers. Lagers were: 1. Sly Fox Helles Golden Lager 2. Lakefront My Turn #023 Dylan 3. Benediktiner Original / Hell 4. Schloßbrauerei Fattigau Schloß-Export 5. Key Helles. Both raters rated the beers 21534. 600ml bottle. Nicely golden pour. Aroma is a bit old in the tooth, or oxidized. Falvor is autolyzed yeast, celery. Post tasting thoughts: This bottle was within its best by (7.17) but sometimes with German imports that is not a good timeframe. It also proclaims unpasteurized on the label which usually is a good thing but not here.
Dumpf hellmalziger Beginn. Mild würzig getreidig, zunehmende Süße. Zum Ende trocken, dumpf bleibend. Muss nicht sein. 7/6/6/7/8/6
Pour from a bottle at The Taste of DC event in Washington DC. Poured a clear golden yellow color with a small white head. Aroma was light sweet malts. Grassy notes. Crisp. Tasty.

Where and how: VB festival Aroma: mellow, straight lager with malty bottom that was accented by faint hops. At least it was clean. 6+ Appearance : Top: medium sized long lasting top, rocky white. Base: hazy pale gold Palate : slightly chewy texture, milder intensity. Taste: mostly bready malts with faint herbal hops on side.
A sweet fruity aroma, pours a hazy pale straw color. A sweet grain taste, light body and grain finish.
Poured from a bottle. Clear golden color, small white head. Mild bread aroma. Medium body with a mild bread flavor and a medium finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Hay and grass nose. Clear golden, thick head. Cane sugar, lightly sweet. Hay.
Clean malt profile and some light sugar sweetness. Pours hazy golden with good foamy head. Light sweet leave. Easy drinking and good balance for what it is. Bottle from Schneider’s.

Near black opaque body with a thin, beige, oily collar. Aromas of dark fruit, chocolate, roast, chocolate covered raisins. Medium too thick body, palate coating. Delicious flavor, bourbon character is present but not overbearing, blending in to the beer harmoniously. Outstanding.

500mL bottle from State Line, a dusty old number probably rescued from somewhere else, best before 26 09 17 but I'm going to give it a go ... for science. Still smells great, lemony, green noble hops with a little dusty, hint of graininess, very bright! Pour clear orange-golden with a bright white sudsy head. Crisp medium-full body, chalky coating of the palate along with light bubblegum and briefly intense estery fruitiness, supported by rock solid and juicy pale malt, touch of cereal grain, vanilla, very strong mineral character, some citric sunshine. Clean and thoroughly attenuated, spritzy and repeatable, if just a touch heavy by the end. Just gobsmacked at how well this has held up, don't be deterred if it's been stored properly! [2019.07.01: 3.8]

500ml bottle. BB 25.01.17. Pours a clear gold, white head. Aroma is buttery and czech pils-like. Fresh dough aroma, leafy herbs, smells pretty pleasant actually, not super oxidized. Flavor is fruity, lightly toasty bread, some bitter herbs, not bad at all.
Heller, süßlich herber Beginn. Wenig getreidig, sehr trocken werdend. Monoton, wenig grasig. 7/7/7/6/8/6
Light barley and some cereal. Pours golden with ok head and lacing. Light crisp finish. Not much here. Bottle.

Where and how: VB festival Aroma: clean but very mild nose, lacking Nobel hops. Appearance : Top: medium lighter top, rocky and white. Base: clear?, golden Palate : medium thinner body, frisky carbonation. Taste: faint hop feel, grassy with typical to this house worty character. other notes refreshing helles.
A sweet malt and bread aroma, pours a straw color without much head. Sweet grain taste with a light body and grainy finish.
Poured from a bottle. Light clear golden color, small white head. Mild wheat aroma. Light body with a light bread flavor and a mild finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Grainy nose. Hazy amber, medium head. Grain, hay, slightly beany. Medium body, soft carbonation.
Transparent golden body, effervescent, with an inch of white head. Aromas of grain, lager yeast, Germanic goodness. Lovely flavor. Clean and refreshing. Winning.
Nice Helles. Very light color, mild balanced aroma and a ver nice mild taste.

Bottled. Hazy pale golden, rich head. Aroma of ripe banana and boiled vegetables. Mid sweet with medium body clean, rounded mouthfeel. Ripe banana and bread, somewhat soaapy. Low bitterness. Not great.
Unclear yellow with a medium white head. Sweet yeasty aroma with banana notes. Flavour was sweet with yeasty, wheat and vague banana notes. Finished sweet.
Bottle 50 cl. Hazy and opaque yellow with an off-white head. Aroma of yeast and banana. Medium body with lightly sweet banana accents, citrus and yeast. Some phenols in the finish. 090209

caramel, bread, hay, cereal, chocolate, light sweetness, medium sweetness, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, medium bitterness, very bitter, light body, medium body, full body, thin feel, oily feel, creamy, sticky, fizzy, lively, average carbonation,
Zitrusfrüchte im Antrunk, sehr hefiger Körper mit feinen Bananennoten, im Abgang kommt eine leichte Säure hinzu. Das Bier wirkt sehr vollmundig.
Hazy orange/yellow colour with off-white head. The aroma has notes of banana, cloves and wheat.
*Old rating. Rated as "Blues Bier - The Blues Bar. Nice fruity-yeasty Weizen. Slightly sweetish, easy to drink, round.

0,5 l bottle BB 06. Jul 14 golden-orange color, cloudy and with a small white foam head. banana, clove, cereal, citrus, dough, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, slick feel, lively,
Trübes orangegelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, fruchtig. Geschmack hefig, fruchtig nach Banane, leicht würzig.
Just another German hefeweizen. I liked it, but it’s has nothing special compared to all the others.

Bottle. Golden, cloudy, average and mostly diminishing head. Moderate, malty – wheaty and sweetish aroma, some fruitiness with light banana and faint yeast. Body is medium, malty – wheaty and sweetish flavor, some fruitiness with light banana. Finish is average, malty – wheaty and lightly sweetish, light fruitiness and light banana. Not so sweet hefeweizen - nothing wrong/nothing special.
Hazy dark golden amber color with medium head. Aroma is yest, malt. Flavor is bitter, wheat.

500ml bottle. Hazy dark golden to amber colour with average, firm, frothy, white head. Yeasty aroma with a fruity apple touch, spicy background. Taste is minimally spicy with a decent fruity apple note. Good spicy, faint fruity note.

Draft back in June. Clear pour with a decent head. Not quite like the pilsener they had last year. Grassy aroma, with some nice maltiness. Decent hopiness in the flavor, grassy, and some malt. Decent.

Clear apple juice body atop an off-white head with nice lacing. Aroma is medium sweet, grassy/floral, some apricot. Taste is medium sweet, grassy, fruity (apricot/peach), quite hoppy. Medium-full body with some stickiness/syrup.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Summer Kölsch
column5: From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 13/10/2007 White head. Malt aroma. Clear golden coloured and hoppy with a crisp and slightly dry malt finish.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Summer Kölsch
column5: Mug club draft poured on tap at the brewpub (Orland Park, IL). Served as the Bottoms Up Kolsch though, same recipe though I hear. Pours a nice slightly hazy golden hue, decent whitish head that laces and stays small. Aromas are light, a bit grainy and a bit fruity, the beer doesn’t emanate a lot of aroma character. Initial is light bodied, highly summer sessionable with some fruity character, light graininess, honey sweetness is light, a touch cereal with a faint floral bitterness in the finish. A bit watery, but not a qualm, as it is quenching, a summer slammer for sure. Ok. 5, 3, 5, 2, 11: 2.6.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Summer Kölsch
column5: tap at rock bottom orland park..... pours transparent yellow with a thin film of white head.... aroma of grass and grains and very little of anything else.... grainy malts, somewhat sweet, with lively carbonation.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Summer Kölsch
column5: on tap at RB Orland Park, pours straw color, white head. sweet grainy aroma. sweet grainy, a touch of smoke, drinkable, but not a good kolsh.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Summer Kölsch
column5: enjoyed on-tap at rbop, under the moniker "bottom’s up kölsch". looks like whiskey, with little white bubbles floating on top. airy aroma. not much in the flavor department: some hint of fruity tartness. medium bodied with a hint of a bitter finish.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Summer Kölsch
column5: Had this one on draught at the brewpub in Orland Park as part of a sampler flight, billed as "Bottoms Up Kolsch." A tad sweet and very slightly citrusy, very timid.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Summer Kölsch
column5: This is the first Kölsch styled ale that I’ve had in a long time that wasn’t a honey bomb, the brewmaster apparently wanting to brew to style rather than pander to non-beer-geek brewpub patrons. It pours a bright yellow body with lively beading and a tall, frothy white head. The aroma is a smooth, somewhat grainy malt with grassy/floral hops. The grassy bitterness builds slightly in the flavor but retains a supportive role in balancing the light malty sweetness. Very smooth and refreshing with a softly bitter finish, this is a sessionable warm weather ale. Rock Bottom Orland Park, Orland Park, IL

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Oatmeal Stout
column5: Sampled on tap at the brewpub (Orland Park, IL). Pours a deep dark blackish brown pour, near opaque, with a small frothy light brown chocolate milk head. Dies to a film, laces small. Aromas are lighter, subtle cocoa and roast with sweet oatmeal, touches of coffee, light toffee, toast, and biscuits. Smooth and lighter. Initial is smooth, lighter end of medium bodied, cocoa up front, sweet oatmeal, some toffee, biscuits, touches of vanilla, creamy on the palate. Some light roast, toast, shortbread cookies. Backend preaches a touch of dry roast, coffee, and a light earthy ashy smoke. Pretty good sweet stout, some roast and earthy ash in the finish grabs me. The beer is lovely, lighter and creamy, with good roast, toast, sweet vanilla and oatmeal, with some cocoa. Pretty good flavor here. Aroma wasn’t great, looks ok, tastes very nice.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Oatmeal Stout
column5: dark brown, tiny tan bubbles, nice lacing. mild whiff of chocolate. roasted malt flvor, mild hints of coffee. light bodied, mildly bitter finish. a mild brew which is mildly disappointing.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Oatmeal Stout
column5: on tap at RB OP. pours black with creamy tan head. nose is dry powdery, bakers chocolate. flavor is really dry baker’s chocolate, lightly roasty, and coffee. very dry stout.

column1: Rock Bottom Orland Park Oatmeal Stout
column5: Brewmaster Iain Wilson nailed the style of slightly dry, nitro-pulled Stout that people in this area seem to like. It’s a tad too softly smooth and fluffy with somewhat muted aroma and flavors for my tates. It pours an intensely dark brown body with an ultra-creamy tan head that laces throughout the drink. The aroma contains lightly roasted malts and a bit of barley, strong cold coffee, and a touch of chocolate that isn’t present in the flavor. It finishes on a dry note. Not bad, but not my mug of beer. Rock Bottom Orland Park, Orland Park, IL

From Aug 2007 Purchased at Wilbur's Liquors in Ft Collins for US$5.99 It pours from 22oz bottle(bottled in May 2007) a clear light gold with a small head of foam that, after about the third sip, all but disappears from my glass but hey, there's some good lacing so it's a trade off. The smell is good. I'm getting some spice, banana, yeast and a touch of hop. The taste has some earthy malt followed by a good banana flavour and some yeastiness and there's a citric zinger about midway through. I started drinking this right out of the fridge so I'm waiting a bit to see what else comes out as it warms up.... Well, it's been a few minutes and I'm getting a touch of clove but nothing else has changed. At this point I'll add that it's quite the smooth drinker and I shouldn't have any problem finishing this bomber. I just finished pouring the rest of this Ale in my glass and there's no sign of any yeast sediment. I was kind of hoping for that. ;^) Overall, I think this is a pretty basic entry into the world of Belgian-Style Ales but I could not see myself not recommending it. It's flavourful and interesting enough to rule that possibility out. Give it a shot and see what you think of it.

On tap at Great Divide, pours a clear blonde with a small white head. Aroma brings out candied sugar, Belgian yeast and light fruity esters. Flavour is on the sweeter and estery side, with candied sugar, Belgian yeast, and estery notes. Not authentic, but it’s still pretty nice. Solid.
Pours a medium golden yellowish color. Aromas of fruit, yeast and some pepper. Flavors are sour, yeasty, and a touch of sweetness at the finish.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear orange gold with medium frothy white head that lasts. The aroma is yeast, spice, floral. Thin body,sweet honey malt, yeast, crisp finish, good.

11/24/2009 12:48:46 PM Bottle from Bierkoning. Nice golden body. Sweet, fruity and hoppy nose. Strong taste of honey. Some spicyness too. Taste of malts and toffee, with more honey in the end. Pretty good.

Bottle from Payless Liquor, where you definitely do not pay less for anything. Pours a golden body with almost no head. Nose of sour citrus, vanilla, and bread. Flavors include banana and cheese plus the others in the aroma. I may have to let this settle a bit because I’m getting an astringent alcohol bite all around the body. Light body and medium/full carbonation. As far as Belgians go, this is no where near the best I’ve tried, but it’s drinkable.

33 cl bottle @ Delirium Cafe, Brussels Aroma has apricot, moldy cellar tones and cardboard. Flavour has apricot, spicy tones, some moldy cellar and sweetish toffee. Quite well preserved, I like the spices here.

Perfectly clear dandelion yellow. No bubbles. Large bubbles of head explode and leave what looks like a foamy white mountain range. The head recedes to a layer of film that leaves slight lacing. The aroma has bright floral hops, slightly metallic, with hints of apples and pear. The flavor tarts sweet with notes of citrus and grass dominating. There’s also some spicy yeast in there, and a high hoppy bitterness throughout, but more so at the finish. Medium-light mouthfeel, pleasant carbonation level -- it’s not too intense, just lets you know it’s there. Enjoyable? Sure. Memorable? Not so much.
Here is an oddly named Belgian golden ale. Lightly lemony with a good amount of wheat malt/hefeweizen flavor. Pale pour with lacing, and a mild sour-sweet aroma. Another good GD release.

Bottle to shaker glass. Pours a quick white head, little lacing, a little retention on the sides. Aroma of wheat, yeast and anise. Taste is slightly sour, lightly bitter. Medium body, soft small bubble carbonation, slick mouth feel. Finishes dry with notes of wheat, yeast, sour apple and spice. It’s ok.
On tap at SDBC. Dark reddish brown with no head. Caramel malt aroma. Caramel and toffee taste with a roasty finish.
On tap @ SDBC - Pours a clear brown color with a small light tan head. Aroma is floral and light malt. Has a sweet malt flavor. Medium body. A decent beer.

Aroma is sweet and fruity. Hints of alcohol and mild chocolate. Some wierd weak plasticy aroma too. Flavor is more sweet fruitiness. Definite alcohol warmth and flavor. Kind of wine like. MIld hops peak through. Not for me.
Draft at the brewery. Dark brown with decent head. Lots of roasty toasty aromas. Hints of cherry in the flavor and the knows. Some alcohol, but not a lot. Very good.
On tap at SDBC. Clear light golden with creamy head. Orange and clove aroma. Tastes of orange, clove, corriander with a bready finish.
On tap @ SDBC - Pours a hazy straw color with a small white head. Light lacing. Has a light floral and wheat aroma. Flavor is light spice and esters. Light body. Not much here. Worth a try.

I got a very fruity nose on this beer. Kind of like fruit loops. Some perfumey aroma as well. Pours hazy yellow and white. Flavor has the same kind of fruit loops thing going on. Very interesting flavor. I kind of thought it was similar to Lennie’s Sunset Wheat. Light in body. Refreshing.
On draft at the brewery. Very nice spice filled aromas with hints of clove, pepper, and some sour notes too. Very drinkable and worth a try.
Draft at the brewery. Pale yellow but almost white. Very nice head. Very spicy on the aromas. Spice on the flavor too. Clove.... Some wheat twang and lemon zest on the finish. Very Refreshing.

Bottle. Both lightning beers to open the NFL seasonal foamed like crazy and didn’t dissipate. Dark Amber. This one had a nice deep malt aroma and flavor, but the hops were off. Slight unpleasantness and sharply bitter.

Amber with off white head - Good malt aroma with some caramel - Good malt body with some caramle flavours and there is olso some hops in the back - The malt and hop bitterness goes into the finish - This was nice

[ Keg ][ 4oz ][ Lightning ][ $1-2 ][ Plastic Cup ][ 7.19.14 ] >> Chill hazed amber pour, okay weak foam. Artificial cherry nose, soy, amber IPA like, sticky. Taste is tannic, harsh, dry, chemical. Harsh mouthfeel, all chemical.
Tap, amber pour, off white head, nose is caramel, taste is sweet, amber, cloves.

Draft at an overpriced SD Gaslamp district restaurant for a friend’s bachelor party. Pours a deep brown/red with no head. Assumed it was because of the craptastic pour. Aroma is sweet vanilla, mandarin, some oats. Taste is actually a really nicely balanced amber with some good hop bitterness, some rye notes and a nice bitter finish. Overall, this pairs very well for a big meat meal.

Bottle. Pours a hazy brown color with a moderate off-white head. Nose is very malty and seems like it has some hoppiness that has gone really bad. Taste is fizzy and malty with that spoiled hoppiness. Not very good.
Craft Brewers Conference 2012 Nice amber ale with a good malt and hops balance. Had a good solid finish.

Bottle. Rufous colored with a short ring of tan foam on the surface. Aroma is caramel, malt, soft grains, floral hops and mild citrus. Taste is big grains, caramel, light toffee, soft citrus, iced tea and floral hops. Body is soft overall but medium with a light, creamy carbonation. Ends with more citrus, grains, floral hops, tea notes and caramel.

Drinking this right now. For all the hop heads just grabbing IPA after IPA. This is a solid change up. Malty nose, bread. Beautiful color...amber with a light haze. Lightly carbonated and a strong hop finish on it. The bitterness is offset a bit by malts but man this is a really solid bitter offering.

Pours to a dark copper, with a very thin head (but amazingly more lacing that the appearance would portend). Like the commercial description says, this is drinkable and not overly charged. The beer has a nice malty aroma and flavor. It’s got a slight strong aftertaste that lingers, but is pleasant tasting.

On draught at Belmont Station. Poured a hazy straw yellow tone with a healthy white topping. Aromatic and flavorful. Fruity and sour notes that were subtle and complex. Oaky tannin notes made a cameo halfway through the tasting. Mild and true to style. The perfect warm-weather beer. Great great great!

Draught at Belmont Bier Cafe Puckerfest. A 2-year-old keg. This is the age at which Berliner Weisse is reputed to hit its stride, and my experience with Schultheiss at least backs that up. Cloudy, pale yellow. Very wheaty nose, slightly tart lime and wood accents. Moderate tartness on the palate and a clean light maltiness. Not a ton of nuance. On the whole this is a mild but authentic rendition...good to see it.
Tap at Bier Cafe: Murky gold, with a small white head. Sour astringent nose. Dry, sour somewhat lightly fruity profile.

Draft at Belmont Station: Pours a hazy yellow with a fluffy 1.5 finger white head. Sour lactic aroma and fresh wheat. Light on the palate, slightly creamy, slightly sweet with a really nice tart flavor. FInishes crisp. This beer goes down extremely easy and is quite refreshing. Cant imagine a better summer and/or session beer.

Pours cloudy stoplight yellow with a soft white head. Sour and mildly acidic aroma. Very light on the palate, but an excellent blend of sourness and yeast estery flavor. Refreshing and awesomely drinkable on a hot day. I was very impressed when I saw this on the menu, the local BJ’s brewery is tackling some hard to find styles and crafting some delicious beers.

Draught. Pours cloudy gold with a medium, creamy white head, medium retention with light lacing. Moderate rich sweet grainy malt, light earthy hops and hop bitterness, clean lager character, and a lightly sweet finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Des pointes d’abricots, des minéraux et du mais dans une sorte d’équilibre sucré et docile.

Draft at the brewery. Pours clear gold with a thin fizzy white head. Tastes like sweet corn, booze, musky hops, and dry toasted malt. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like sweet corn, booze, toasted malt, grassy.
On tap at the brewery. It poured a hazy, straw yellow color with a white head. The aroma was of grainy malts and earthy hops. The taste was grainy and malty with a dose of booze. Good stuff.
This is no impu pols, this is full blown malt likka. Pours dark gold. Wet grains, some hay, grass. Sweetness prevails.
Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a white head. Has a fruity malty grainy corny aroma. Sweetish malty grainy corny flavor with weak hoppy hints. Has a sweetish malty grainy finish.

Bottle from South bay Drugs. Created a fat development of foaming with a straw blonde golden color upon the eye. The nose was empty with only a small mention of hay and grass. The flavor was bitter and bold of grassy malt grains and Euro styled hops. Overall impression of this lager was that the taste resembled a marzen but that was just a hunch of mine.
This has a faint aroma. Interesting, beer is a bit sticky. Has quite a malt flavor at the beginning with a bit of hops at the end. Pretty good stuff.

If you like high-quality malt liquor, you’ll find the Ionizer ironically iconic--if a bit on the high side price-wise. Good, strong stuff with a nice balance. Since I live just a stumble, stagger and a slide from the brewery--I’m gonna’ go to the tasting room this Friday and get a growler of the stuff, take it home and drink it til’ I forget about the pain of life. Then I’m a-gonna quaff some more--just for the sake of art!
alex again... dark gold orange, no carbonation... the aroma is terrible, solvent... the taste is even worse, don’t bother with this

Draft at Oregon Brewers Festival, Portland, OR. White head that mostly lasted, spotty lacing, no visible carbonation, hazy, and a straw hue. Nose was malty, lightly hoppy, crisp, coriander, fruity, and a hint of spicyness. Ditto for the flavor. Smooth mouthfeel. Very, very quaffable, nicely done, quite tasty, and I definitely would partake in this brew again if it were to come my way. Absolutely worthy of a try!
A light colored Belgian strong ale. Slightly sour and crisp with bright spicy notes. Great complex finish with lots of fruitiness from malts and yeast. The hops give it a unique PNW feel, too.

This draft brew from the Oregon Brewers festival poured a head of foamy fine to medium sized white colored bubbles that were quickly diminishing and left behind a hazy and a fair lacing. The aroma was floral bready musty mild hop and fruity. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of malt hops fruity and floral. A decent one that I would consider buying again.
A very nice crisp belgian style golden. Coriander and a good hop balance allow this beer to be strong while being very refreshing. Like a saison with no wild funky yeast.
Deep golden with fine persistent white head, sweet and malt driven. Not much discernible hop character. Lots of caramel, cereal, softened grape nuts.
On tap at their Brew Pub. Putting my rating here - on the menu as ’Creek IPA’ @ 6.8%. Poured an amber color with a small sized off white head. Citrus with some sweetness in the tastes.
On tap at the brewpub Clear deep golden decent fresh Christ hop flavor and aroma Not very butter but well balanced and easy

Keg at the brewpub, 11/11/14. Lightly hazed golden amber with a decent beige covering. Nose is thin, light hops, caramel, orange, straw. Taste comprises muted grapefruit, mandarin, straw, vanilla, malty. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. Low quality IPA, perhaps they’ve changed brewer/recipe since the previous reviews of some 4 years ago don’t put it in this camp. Kind of formulaic mon and pop family diner brewpub affair and a poor one of these at that!

Draft @ the Brewpub. Pours a slightly hazy pale amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty hoppy citrus aroma. Fruity malty hoppy grapefruit flavor. Has a fruity hoppy bitter finish with hints of grapefruit in the aftertaste.

Sample at the brewpub. The beer pours a clear orange-gold color with a medium thin off-white head that recedes steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of hops and orange peel. Medium body with a moderately bitter hops flavor along with some malt and citrus notes. The finish is hoppy and lingers awhile. Above average overall.

Date: September 23, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: cloudy orange, creamy beige head, drippy lace Aroma: light sweet citrus aroma, touch of orange Flavor: sweet fruity flavor with abundant hops, lots of orange, balancing bitter orange rind character, plenty of balancing bitterness leads to a light bitter finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **+ /4

Taster – Max’s Fanno Creek Brew Pub – Tigard, OR Aroma: This had a good amount of hops added along with a nice malt backing. Appearance: Golden in color, clear with a thin head. Flavor: A very well balanced hops to malt. The roasty malt added to the hops which where very powerful. Palate: Dry finish, with a Good Mouthfeel. Overall: Nice IPA.

This pint was listed as an HPA on the menu. No IPA as such was listed. I had a number of tastings before picking this for a growler fill. I took it to a mini-reunion of some cousins from Switzerland. We killed the growler in about 30 minutes and it was a big hit. Nice dark amber with plenty of head and lacings. Nice floral hop aroma and flavors. Plenty of roasted malts to almost match the hop flavors. Nice beer!

On tap at the Fanno Creek brewery. A very vibrant smelling single hopped medium bodied India Pale. Employing yummy Centennial hops, this is an IPA for IPA drinkers. I was inspired to run to my car and grab my trusty growler so that I could bring more of this treat home for later. Great character, color and balance to this true to the style NW IPA.

Sample at the brewpub. Pours a murky copper-brown color with a medium thin beige head that recedes steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. Caramel and earthy malt in the nose. Medium body with flavors of peaty malt, caramel, dark fruit and a bit of hops. The finish is malty and has a caramel aftertaste. Decent overall.

Name: Scottish Date: September 23, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: opaque brown, fine beige head, streaks of lace Aroma: sweet malt aroma, light peat Flavor: sweet caramel malt flavor, touch of caramel sweetness, light smokey peat adds complexity, light earthyness for balance Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **+ /4

Thick rich malty sweet flavor that balanced out well with crisp spicy hops. I am not a big fan of Scotch ales, but this one was not too bad. Generously boozy, but not too overpowering. Good rainy day brew.

Rich and malty up front with a clean hop finish. I would like a touch more of hops for a bit more balance, the sweetness overwhelmed a bit. A solid beer that gives a nice departure from the IPAs and pales.

Bottle, so not appearance notes. Aroma is malty, sweet and full of caramel. Medium bodied. Taste is sweet with a hint of cocoa powder and lots of caramel. Lingering bitterness on the finish with hints of dark chocolate. Good, not great.
Had a couple of bottles at Jack’s Shack on the beach in Grand Turk. Caramel and malt aroma. Medium sweetness, very light bitterness. Light body, slight sticky texture. Pretty good.
12oz bottle pours a clear amber with some cloudy, white head. Nose has bread, yeast, grist, light caramel. Flavor has cream soda, bread, caramel. Slick finish.
Bottle at the Local DC Tasting. Clear golden brown with beige head. Aromas of malt and caramel. Same on the taste. Light body with a dry finish.
12oz bottle at the July DC tasting. Poured a light clear golden color with a small white head. Aroma was light, caramel malts. Sweet character. Herbal spice notes. Water.
At the rv ratebeer bottle share it is an effervescent golden color with a slight head. The aroma is malty and the taste is a bitter flavor with hints of pepper and some caramel.
Light rust and some malt. Ok and decent drinking. Amber pour with good head and lacing. Light tangy mash finish. Bottle.
Bottle courtesy of altonbrownd. Clear golden amber color, white head. Aroma of light caramel. Taste is lightly papery caramel. OK.
Country #116 - thanks to Bradley K! Dark amber body with medium head. Nose is malty, sweet. Taste is malt, caramel, brown sugar, spices. Smooth, creamy texture. Clean finish.
carried over from untapped to try and organize my beers in one spot for synchronicity.

Draft @ the Brewpub. Pours a hazy yellow color with a longlasting white head. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy citrus aroma. Fruity wheaty spicy citrus flavor. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy citrus finish.

Sample at the brewpub. This beer is a hazed yellow color with a thin white head that burns away quickly. Stringy lacing on the glass. The aroma is fruity and wheaty. Light and clean body with a citrus, wheat and spice flavor. The finish is mildly spiced with a yeast aftertaste. Average overall.

Date: September 23, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy yellow, fine white head, drippy lace Aroma: nice spicy aroma, light citrus, hint of sweetness Flavor: sweet malt flavor, nice touch of sweet orange, balancing spicyness Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: ** /4

Taster – Max’s Fanno Creek Brew Pub – Tigard, OR Aroma: Light Belgian aroma with a nice malt backing. Appearance: Light Golden in color, hazy with a thin head. Flavor: Malty flavor was big with a decent yeast backing. Palate: Dry finish, with a Good Mouthfeel. Overall: Nice Wit ale.
Has a good balance of the spices, hops, malts, and wheat that make this style. Nothing overdone. Had a pint on tap and it was a very tasty brew.
The perfect summer beer (well, that or Max’s pilsner). Crisp,straw colored, slightly bitter, and uber-quaffable. This is a lawnmower beer of the sitdown variety.

Lots of corriander and orange peel give this a very floral spicey aroma and flavor. It felt a bit under carbonated, so it wasn’t as crisp as I was hoping for. The flavors were great though, good balance and a lot of spice make for a great warm weather brew. Poured hazy gold with a thin white head.
Hazy straw colored liquid with fine persistent white head, low aroma volume, lightly creamy feel, a bit flat, biscuit, light toast. Easy drinking.
On tap at their Brew Pub. Poured a yellow to golden color with a small sized head. Yep ... a lighter golden ale ...
On tap at the brewpub clear deep golden light sweet malts with hints of honey. Sweet and mild.

Keg at the brewpub, 11/11/14. Clear golden with a moderate off white cap. Nose is light fruit, straw, malt, biscuit notes. Taste comprises caramel malt, grain, light citric fruit, straw. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. Dull.
On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear golden color with a medium white head. A light nose of banana and grain. The flavor is more grainy, easy, sweet esters, some perfume. Decent.

Draft @ the Brewpub. Pours a clear golden color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty grainy aroma. Fruity crisp malty flavor with some weak hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty crisp finish with some hoppy hints.

Sample at the brewpub. The beer is a mostly clear golden color with a thin white head that dissipates quickly. Spotty lacing on the glass. Mild grassy hops and malt in the nose. Light and clean body with sweet malt and hops flavors, as well as a touch of citrus. The finish is short and fruity. Barely average overall.

Date: September 23, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: cloudy gold, fine off white head, drippy lace Aroma: light malt aroma, light floral hops Flavor: sweet malt flavor, orage candy swetness, light balancing bitterness Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 8/20 Rating: 2.2/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: *+ /4

Taster – Max’s Fanno Creek Brew Pub – Tigard, OR Aroma: Nice light malt and hops aroma. Appearance: Golden in color, clear with a thin head. Flavor: Light malt and hops favor this was a great lawnmower beer. Palate: Dry finish, with a Good Mouthfeel. Overall: Nice light beer.

For those who prefer ales to lagers, here’s a sessionable summertime delight. Using crystal hops, this is a great way to welcome the warm season. Light in alcohol and body, but big in flavor and enjoyability.

I had a Pilsner on tap at Max’s Brewpub. I don’t think it was named Political Pilsner nor was that name on the beer menu. The Pilsner I had was much closer to an Amber in overall flavor but it was lighter in color. The abv was listed as 6.7% which was a surprise too. A tasty pint it was but a bit high on the alcohol for a session beer.

Crisp and dry pils, refreshing and clean. A bit too much body, but it’s not excessive on the palate, only feels a little heavy for a pils. It’s rare to find good lagers in town, this is one of the better ones.

I know it was the first batch of this stuff, so i’m sure it will improve over the next few batches. This stout felt like it lacked a bit of body and felt watery on the palate. Good roasted chocolate flavors with a touch of coffee in the finish. With a bit more body this will be excellent. Pours a deep black with a smooth tan head, this will be a staple of this place.

The smoke kept this beer going for its 1 year old life. While thin and slightly watery on the palate, the smoke gives this beer a lot of character. I generally enjoy smoke beers, so I was quite supprised to find this on tap. This new brew pub is making some very complex styles of beer in the Portland area. This beer might be a bit passed its prime, but still holds some good flavors.

The 1 year of age has really given this trippel a malty edge to it. Too malty for a tripel, and the carbonation was a bit low, so the esters from the yeast were more subtle, but still a very enjoyable beer.

I found the framboise had more depth to it, the Kriek tasted a bit thin and oxidized. Great dark cherry flavor none-the-less. Slighlty passed its prime it was affected by the wet-paper oxidized taste that overtook the oakiness and sourness a bit.

Aged in a barrel for 1 year, that is hard to find in the PNW. This turned out very well, like a good find out of a Belgian cafe. Tart and complex, with a medium sour finish to really get the mind going. Earthy and oak mix with a sweet raspberry flavor. Estery, dry, and sour in the finish.

Yah, not to often you find a 3 year old barleywine on tap, and when you do you expect to pay more then 3.50 or so for a glass. This beer was just incredible, big rich flavors that have gained a lot of character over the years. The 11% ABV doesn’t show at all in the flavor. Bready and a big melted caramel flavor up front, warming you up inside. Chocolate and notes of port in the finish. Here’s to hoping they have another keg to release next year for the 4 year old version.

A summertime brew from Water Street. Poured a hazey golden colour, little to no head and scattered lacing. Has a nice wheat flavor, not over doing it, but pleasent. a lemony zest aroma, also tastes of citrus fruit and honey.

Date: 06/21/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub, Milwaukee cloudy pale yellow, fine white head, light lemon aroma, lemon flavor, touch of sugary sweetness, light bitterness adds more complexity rather then balance Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10

Surprised to see only one rating for this beer. It is on tap at the brewery. This is a very nice summertime beer and could quench a thirst easily. It looked and smelled pretty much like a wheat beer. Honey and lemon flavors stood out. I do like a good wheat beer.

On tap at Water Street - Delafield. Poured a hazy, ugly yellow with no head sticking around. Sweet toasty banana and some darker sugars in the aroma.. not complex, but quite nice. The flavor was sweet again with banana and tangy lemon notes.. there were some residual, ugly floral notes at the finish.. some vegetal notes too. Tangy and sour notes accented the sweetness quite well.. lighter-bodied and slick on the palate.

On tap at the brewpub. Aroma is pleasingly nuanced and enjoyable with subtle fruits dashed with honey, whole grain cereal and plain fruits. A bit of sea salt plays in. Yet, still a little held back. Pours a pale amber, on the brass side of the color, with a rim of sparse white. Flavor begins in refreshing gentle tones of honey toasted oat, maple syrup and plum, backed by a chorus of alcoholic brightness and some nips of sugar. Round and enjoyable. Palate bulges with some hop matter and a crisp lemony sensation develops through the background. Heavily drinkable and a real stunner for the season right now.

On tap at the brewpub. Aroma tickles forth with a hexanous blast of tires and latex, confused with Indonesian raspberry candies. The traditional aromas get muddled with raspberry sauce and make a bit of a mess in the nose. Pours in murky pale orange, tinted rose and metallic in the corners. Head blushes. Flavor is a menagerie of banana, fruited chocolate, malt, candied raspberry gelato and some malt base. Acerbic and dry, seemingly well attenuated enough to stay away from stickiness. But it’s an awkward pairing, trying to blend Hefe phenols with the spritzy sourness of Framboise. Seeds and hop dust dry out the backend. Peculiar interaction of raspberries and wheat oil. I feel as if these brewers have some good ideas and try unique pairings, but don’t make the point of executing them well. Much like the Mogiana Malt, I think this could have been a winner, if they’d honed the Raspberry character and restrained some of the yeast products. Malt quality suffered. But, the spritzy bright lemon of the Hefe works. Really, as a fruit beer it’s above the majority of the field, for staying clean, unique, drinkable and not getting sickly sweet.

Bottle courtesy of Irishboy. Pours a cloudy, light golden color with a white head. Head lasts a long time. Has a medium mouthfeel. Smells like yeast and oranges. Has a slight tart taste to it with yeast, orange, and fresh flowers. Is highly carbonated. Overall not a bad brew.

12 oz bottle from Country Club Liquors; Nose is yeast, light spices and graininess; cloudy bright-pale yellow with a big yellow-tinged head; flavor of yeast, citrus, an unsual spiciness I cannot name or quite place, finish is a faint tart note. Quite enjoyable actually!

12oz bottle acquired in trade with odeed (thanks!). Poured a lighter and hazy yellow color with a huge sized white head. Aromas of cream corn (like I just opened a can of them), citrus, and spices. Tastes of citrus, spices, and light wheat. Body a little too lively for my tastes and on the thin side.

Slightly sour citrus aroma with cardamom and other spice? Hazy gold color with lots of bubbles and a persistent white head. Near medium body with creamy/fizzy carbonation. The flavor is citrus, pale malt and some spice. The finish turns a bit flat in comparison, but has some citrus and some bitter. It’s a pretty tasty wit.

Date: 12/04/2007 Mode: Bottle Source: Roadtrip hazy pale yellow, wispy white head, drops of lace, soapy malt aroma with spicy phenolics, sweet malt flavor turns lemony and tart, light spicyness, hint of citrus, Aroma: 2/10; Appearance: 4/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 4/10; Overall: 4/20 Rating: 1.2/5.0 Drinkability: 3/10 Score: -/4

Pours a murky light yellow with a small white head that quickly diminishes.. Man this is some bubbly stuff. Sediment floating around and settled to the bottom after a little bit. Smells yeasty with a little spice. Initially has a lot of lime in the flavor. after warming it has a nice amount of spice present. Not very sweet at all. Very lively carbonation. Has a sour finish that I liked but I don’t think it’s typical for this style. I haven’t had a lot of belgian whites but this is an enjoyable beer.
(Bottle) Pours a murky yellowish maize body with an average white head. Aroma of floral, dustiness, and lemon. Flavor of lemon juice, floral hops, nuts, and ground flaxseed. Quite sour for a wit.

Bottle. This one is very well made. The pour is turbid yellowy canary with 3-fingers of white head and clingy lacing. Smells of clovey spices, estery yeast, hopcitrus, and some perfumy floral wafts. The taste is clovey, citric, with solid malt, hops, honey, and perfumy florals in the finish. Very complex, smooth, crisp, and flavorful, this is a fabulous wit.
Pours golden with a medium head. Aroma is yeasty with apricots and spices. Flavors of some tangerine, vanilla, and spices. Body is light and refreshing. Finish is clean. Decent Wit.
Oatmeal stout. Pours black with a brown head. Big roasted/burnt malt aroma. Huge malty flavors with lots of coffee and chocolate. Body is very round, smooth, and creamy. Nice coffee finish.

10 ounce sample tasted at Rubicon’s maibock festival. Roasted, lightly smoky aroma with some mild buttery diacetyl aromas present. Mildly hazy amber body with a small off-yellowish head. Attractive with nice lacing, too. Small, sweet, buttery, diacetyl start. Becomes more grainy and roasted in the middle. Slightly burnt. Finishes with a bit of a nice, crisp hoppiness. Lightly floral mild bitterness. Sweet aftertaste with more of the diacetyl presence.

On tap at brewpub. Half pint. Light pine and spicy peppery hops present in the nose. Decent amount of modestly sweet malts present, too. Moderately hazy amber body with a small, fleeting off-white head. Peaty maltiness to start, becoming a little sweeter and toffee-like in the middle. Finishes with a nice spicy hop kick. A little cold and a bit too carbonated. Tasty, though. This would be killer on a hand pump.

On tap at 21st Amendment, June 2007. Deep mahogany with an off-white head. Rich caramel toffee in the nose with PacNW hop character. Rich, malty toffee flavor with loads of bittering, resinous, piney, grapefruity hops. Somewhat reminescent of Arrogant Bastard. A sliight tinge of roast in there too. Full and round body with fine-beaded carbonation. Nice beer.

lou is coming.. ugh..yes i am...its a little hoppy. its got... dark red to orange. tastes like hops little bit of hops.....YEA!!!...its tasty... its deep all jeans.. and i’m lookin at him. this brew’s allright.

color is a brownish amber and gets light toward the bottom. dude hooked me up with some nice head on this baby. Fat ass fool with a watermelon hat giving me some nice head. flavor... kind of a good flavor. has a little chocolate bite to it. apprearance is alright. has a nice smell to it. not bad.
Draft. Nice rich mahogony with a light tan head. Malty aroma with a bit of caramel and pine. malty, earthy flavor with light citrus. earthy malts linger. Medium body.

Had on tap at brew pub. I LOVE Reds and this one was right up my alley. This was my favorite beer of theirs. Very sweet malts up front, some pine and wood taste, and just a slight bitter finish. Very delightful indeed!

On tap @ 21st Amendment poured a clear dark reddish amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of pine, carmel and light citrus. Palate was medium bodied and crisp. Flavors of carmel, earthiness, pine and a hint of orange with a lingering bitter finish.
Tap. A reddish-brown color with a tan head. Nice hop profile. Slightly sweet malts and caramel with a crisp bitter finish. Medium bodied and smooth.
Nice malty bready backbone in this orange brew. I dug the aroma and flavor. Hoppy enough to notice, but doesn’t take away from the bready slightly spicy backbone."
Pours golden in color with a white head. Malt, caramel, floral, honey and hop aroma and flavors. Medium light body and average carbonation. Citrus and malt finish.
Draft at the den. Nose is toasty and bready with some fruitiness. Taste is sweet with a hint of pepper. Ok.
Good Maibock that i dare say is one of the better ones that i have had, but i havent had many. Sweet but not too much.

not a huge fan of bocks generally, and this one didn’t help out .. . pours a murky tan .. mild foam .. . very muddled and 80’s old lady sweater like .. . empty and off putting, very unlike bear republic quality .. . . ’you’re under arrest’ is a term i have heard way to much in my life. fuckin Cops reruns!
Clean hoppy lager aroma... if that’s a thing. Clear amber color in the glass. Nice citrus hops flavor with a hint of sweet toasty malt. Overall, very drinkable...
On tap at the Top in Gainesville. Malty, amber beer. It’s not great, but this is a style that rarely works--this is a solid version of the style with just a bit of hop bite in the finish.
Tap at stags head pours a golden copper. Nose of fruits hops. Tastes bready, of citrus, floral, grape skins, ginger, and syrup. Slight sticky finish kinda odd one

From tap at The Blind Tiger. Pours clear and golden brown to orange with a small off white head. Aroma is light estery to phenolic. Toasted malty, bitter, grassy and vague malty sweetness. Dry and bitter finish.

On draft at Mission Liquors. It pours a clear golden color with an off white head. The aroma is nice and malty sweet with some light fruit and grains. The mouthfeel is huge and a bit syrupy. Flavors of caramel malt and earthy hops. A bit too thick for me.

Draft. Light body, syrupy and thin, low bitterness. Massive dose diacetyl with some saccharine nutri-sweet and rice cake malt... seriously it’s like you stuck your nose inside a microwave popcorn bag. So basically that’s my rating, calling it a shit batch diacetyl bomb.
The head is ok, the body blond. It smells malty, sweet, mild. The taste is malty, sweet, less hoppy. Mild

500ml bottle. Extremely pale and light straw colour. Well carbonated and a massive white head forms that would do a hefeweizen proud. If only it looked as good as the girl in the pink hot pants on the label. Zesty and citrusy on the nose and on the palate. A little thin and sudsy, for some reason I expected more.

Good frothy head a pale gold pour aroma lemon grassy maltiness flavour bitter citric fruit taste sweet malt lot of carbon in the beer ripish fruit taste at the finish okay for a session a bit on the sour side.

(Bottle 50 cl) Clear, pale golden with a small, rough, off-white head. Aroma of hops and mash. Medium body with a fairly solid malt base - again with some mash, this doesn’t appear completely finished. Dry and hoppy finish. 010208
Tasted in New Zealand. Light in color and feeling. Clear body. Fair Head. Hoppy.

500 ml bottle - Pours a nice light clear golden with a good firm fluffy head. Aromas of a musty woolshed but in a nice kind of way - slightly grainy too. A touch watery to begin but certainly dries with a hint of pepperish notes towards the end. Cleansing.
50cl bottle. A clear pale golden beer with a white head. Aroma of mild floral malt, straw. Taste of straw, dry grainy malt, floral hops.
Ein eher unterdurchschnittliches Helles, fahler Geschmack. Ich hatte eine 0.5l Flasche gekauft.
Z notatek butelka 500ml pite na dzia³ce. Kolor jasnoz³oty, klarowne, piana znikoma aromat s³odowy, trochê dro¿d¿y w smaku lekko s³odkawe, troszkê zió³? Klasyczne, przeciêtne jasne dortmundzkie.
Frisch vom Hahn in Bodenmais getrunken. Sehr erfrischend nach der Arberwanderung. Leicht würzig, aber eher milder, weicher Geschmack.

A very tasty simple but potent Helle that tastes a bit like a Landbier, slightly almost wheaty (tastes like the smell of wheat) and hoppy. A bit of a surprise as the beer looks a bit common from the outside.

Farbe: helles Gelb, klar.Schaum: reichlich, dicht.Nase: bitter, säuerlich Geschmack: ebenso, wenig perlig, bitter und sauer, relat voller Körper für ein Helles. Sonst nicht viel: klar, schmeckt wie ein Bier nach Gerste und Hopfen aber nichts Bemerkenswertes. Nur minimaler bitterer Nachgeschmack. Gutes Helles zum Essen.
Tap @ Kuhalm Bodenmais. Grassy herbal aroma. Thinnish. Dry soft herbal hopbitter flavor with grassy notes. Soft malty, grassy notes in the finish. OK.
