(bottle, courtesy of Quack-Duck) Clear, deep golden colour with a short, but persistent foamy white head. Sweet, minimal toasty and buttery malt aroma, also quite bready with a tinge of herbal hops. Sweet flavour, minimal toasted cara-malty and bready taste, medium bodied, smooth on carbon; medium-dry, sweet-bitter, rounded malty and herbal hoppy finish. Pleasant Märzen with some qualities of a Bohemian 14°.

Bottle (under licence of Quack-Duck !): Deep golden coloured, small but stable white head; deep aromatic grainy-malty nose with a faint fruity and alcoholic touch, distinctive aromatic hops in the background; solid sweet, slightly bitter flavour, soft carbonation, light to medium bodied; sweet-malty finish with aromatic hops in the very end. A fine, very pleasant brew, like a good bohemian 14°..........
bottle, bought at the brewery. I can’t decide whether the colour is pale amber or deep golden yellow with a hint of copper. Malty nose. Malty and fruity flavours, slightly hoppy.
Pours clear straw gold with white head. Aroma is caramel, dms, light fruity, malty. Taste is light fruit, bread, malt. Slightly sweet finish. Very clean.
Nice crisp malt flavor, though the description of 'mild hops' is a bit overstated. Nice honey aroma. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a light straw from the tap, slight corn aroma, blurs the line between pale and Amber lager. Okay beer.
bomber, golden pour, thick head, lacing throughout drink. Light, clean crisp taste, excellent brew. At 4.2, easily could drink a 6 pack of this stuff.

Light floral breeze of an aroma. Hazy light yellow. Light citrus and very malty, I found it strangely had some smokey character to it. Nothing overt mind you. Light, flushed out body. Really a beach beer, which makes sense for the location.

22oz bottle in a shaker. Pours light golden with a white head. Aroma of pale and light toasted malts plus floral hops. Flavor a little light on everything. Average to light texture. A decent beer for the style, but not the best overall.

On tap at the brewpub. Clear bright golden color with a small white head and great lacing. Standard aroma, helles-like but with less honey to it, bready. The flavor is pleasant, with grain, pilsner malt, and bread.  Not big on the hops, but enjoyable. Very crisp and clean with a light and lively mouthfeel. Good for the style.

Pours a nice golden Cooper with thin white head, lots of lacing. aroma is soft and slightly floral, flavor is balanced with a soft malt profile, and pleasant slightly spicy hop kick on the back end. super easy drinker and a very nice take on this style

Bottle at home in Salisbury, shared with family. Pours pale yellow with a small, white head. Crispy crackers in the nose, some light lemon. Light sweet flavor, mild pale malts, white sugar, mild bread, faint citrus and straw bitterness. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Feels good. Lightly drying finish, some faint leafy bitterness, hay, straw. Pretty bland overall but not offensive.

Bottle. Pours a lightly hazed gold with a thin white head. Soft crisp grain, light hop presence, crackers and grain. Medium bodied, sweet and grainy, light touches of a very faint lemon citrus note. Crisp and clean, a touch sweet, and a little bit empty, but as it’s currently 95F inside, I’m quite happy with a bomber of this today.

Draught at brewpub. Pours clear tawny with an average frothy off-white head, excellent lacing, mostly lasting. Aroma is average malt (grain, meal), heavy hops (flowers, pine, spruce), average yeast (dough, sweat) with notes of apple and pear. Light bodied, slick texture, soft carbonation and a bitter finish. Long duration, light sweetness and acidity, heavy bitterness.
Heavily carbonated with creamy off white head. Faint bitterness in an otherwise sweet body. On tap at Phantom Canyon.

Brewer Greg Gerovac (formerly with Fordham and Sweetwater in the Wash. D.C. area) brewed this ESB for Huntington Beach’s anniversary - the party will be this October. It has Golena and First Gold hops and is about 37 IBUs. Minimal head from tap, copper color, rich, some hop bitterness, but not too big. Some mineral/metallic bitterness in the finish, but flavorful.

A very solid lager. Very clear gold pour with a nice white head. Aroma is light on the yeast and a nice malt character of toast and caramel comes through. Flavor is bitter but not much. Clean, crisp, refreshing brew.

This brew just won the Gold for Vienna Lager’s at the San Diego/Del Mar competition, beating out Sam Adams! Rich toffee/caramel aroma and flavor, some bitterness. Amber-copper color and miminal head. Rich, mineral notes.

Hazy, golden body with a small, white head. Rather faint aroma of pale malt, caramel, and hints of sweet fruits. Moderate flavour of caramel, pale malt, apple skin, a lager-like, crisp yeast profile, and traces of swimming pool chlorine. Moderate to light sweet taste with a light bitter finish. Dry mouthfeel, mid-bodied, moderate carbonation. Not too bad, but a bit strange. [50 cl bottle, enjoyed 5 months before BB date, from Dagli' Brugsen Blokhus, Jylland, Denmark]
Smager som deres IPA. Mild, svag, kedelig ale, som rummer en minimal smag af humle

How: Bottle. Where: Tasting at Björn, 2017-01-27. Appearance: Clear amber colour with a thick off-white head. Aroma: Mild malt, some caramel and citrus. Body: Medium body and carbonation. Flavour: Malt, caramel.
Bottled. Clear amber, small coarse head. Caramelly nose with some citrus, Mid sweet with medium body and clean mouthfeel. Caramelly with some butter and metal. Mid bitter finish.

column1: Barley's Meister Eckhart Spark Of The Divine
column5: Draft @ brew pub. Copper pour with a yellowed of white head. Aroma of toffee, booezy fruits, caramel malt and light hops. Flavors of bready caramel malt, brown sugar, toffee, earthy hops and booezy fruits. Thick body, quite coating on the tounge...sweet and boozey with a malty/sweet finish.

column1: Barley's Meister Eckhart Spark Of The Divine
column5: Rating for "Divine Barleywine"... migrated to this beer from "Barley’s Barley Wine" as suggested by Puddintane Honey thick with huge legs, deeply colored a rusty/bronze. Thick, rich & fruity aroma, lush with cherry, pear & cognac. Some citric hopping comes through as she warms. Thick-bodied with a mildly syrupy palate. Great balance here, not at all "hot" with rich malts tempered by a subtle bitterness, all the while with a soothing alcohol presence. On draught at Barleys’s Ale House #1, Columbus, Ohio 43215

column1: Barley's Meister Eckhart Spark Of The Divine
column5: Growler sampled at the Pre-RBSG ’Tosa gathering on 6/21/07 courtesy of nolankowal: Pours a transparent dark amber copper with a thin, wispy-lacing off-white head. Aroma of sweet caramel malt with a touch of fresh piny hops. Body starts with nice malty thickness and sweet caramel and light fruity esters balanced with a nice hoppy presence. A good barleywine.

column1: Barley's Meister Eckhart Spark Of The Divine
column5: Draft sample at Alehouse #1 on 8/8/07 under the name of Divine. Poured hazy brown color with an average fizzy off-white head that was mostly lasting with excellent lacing. Moderate tart fruit and alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a sticky texture. Heavy balanced flavor with a heavy bittersweet and small alcohol bite finish of long duration. My expectations where met with a standout beer.

column1: Barley's Meister Eckhart Spark Of The Divine
column5: Pours hazy brown with a tan head. The aroma has smoky rich malt, lots of caramel and toffee - very sweet. Medium / full body with soft carbonation. The flavor has rich caramel malt and lots of fruitiness. The finish adds some thick biscuit qualities to the malt. An okay barleywine.

column1: Barley's Meister Eckhart Spark Of The Divine
column5: Name: Meister Eckhart’s Spark of the Divine Barley Wine Date: 06/21/2007 Mode: Growler Source: Tasting, Pre-RBSG hazy dark amber, wispy off white head, huge rich dark caramel malt aroma with lots of earthy hops and some hot alcohol to add to the sweetness, sticky sweet body, rich dark caramel flavor, lots of sweetness, touch of earthy bitterness tries to add balance but instead adds complexity, -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name: Meister Eckhart’s Spark of the Divine Barley Wine Date: 07/22/2007 Mode: cask Source: brewpub downtown hazy dark amber, headless, almost produces legs on the glass, light sweet caramel aroma, creamy body, rich fruity flavor on dark caramel malt, sweetness is present but appears tempered in relation to the big fruity character, a touch of vanilla in the sweetness continues to grow, little to no aparent bitterness, only a hint of alcohol shows up in the very last sip of the second glass, more subdued and fruity than the draft growler, not sure which I prefer -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name: Meister Eckhart’s Spark of the Divine Barley Wine Date: 07/22/2007 Mode: draft Source: brewpub downtown muddy burnt orange, fine beige head, drops of lace, light sweet malt aroma with no alcohol, sticky sweet body is back, rich dark caramel malt flavor with a fruity sweetness, light bitterness, on second visit the draft version does have a bigger body and more assertive dark caramel flavor and bitterness than the cask, draft wins Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 9/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ***/4

column1: Barley's Meister Eckhart Spark Of The Divine
column5: Tap Ohio Brew Week. Pours hazy ruby-brown color with a thin tan colored head. Aroma is floral hops, thick caramel malts, brown sugar. Flavor is caramel malt, nice punch of floral hops, brown sugar, toffee, raisin. Palate is full bodied, mild carbonation, finishes sweet and sticky. One of the better brews from the event!

column1: Barley's Meister Eckhart Spark Of The Divine
column5: 7/20/2007: Barley’s Spark of the Divine Barleywine from Barley’s Ale House No. 1 has a slight chill haxe. It is darker amber in color with a foamy beige head. There are sweet, strong malts in the nose. The flavor is malty, and bit sweet, toasty, and strong. This beer has a medium body and is pretty smooth. It is a decent barleywine overall with a great name. Draught at the Oak Room during the Ohio Brew Week in Athens, Ohio. Rating #14 for this beer...

column1: Barley's Meister Eckhart Spark Of The Divine
column5: Tosa gathering, thanks nolankowal for sharing this growler: Hazy amber hue with a small fizzy head and some lace. The aroma has notes of fruity esters (pear, apple, fig), noble and grassy hops, floral aromatics and a touch buttery. The taste is acidic fruits, biscuity and nutty malts, with a light bitterness and a hint of pepper. The mouth feel is biting and warming, does smooth out in the end, a chalky aftertaste. Not too shabby but it would be better with some age to it.

column1: Barley's Meister Eckhart Spark Of The Divine
column5: Sampled at Brew Week in Athens. The aroma is sweet malt and ETOH. Copper and cloudy, with minimal head. Very full body and sweet though, not too heavy. The Alcohol is obvious and I’d peg the ABV as 10%. Finishes a bit long.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis St. Paul Pilsner
column5: Un-Muzzling Olde Muzzlehatch Ratings, #67. Draught sample at the brewpub, August 2008. Clear bright gold, a slight touch of lasting head, also a hint of lacing...grassy nose offers touches of lemon, some acerbic hoppy notes but rather weak ones...fairly sweet throughout, hops present all the time but muted, you have to search for them...mouthfeel rather soft for the style but not unpleasant. Pretty much the same quality as the Premium Lager which started off my tasting.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis St. Paul Pilsner
column5: Clear gold, moderately carbonated, slim white head. Mellow malty aroma with just a touch of hop presence. Smooth malt profile, nicely balanced with a slightly spicy, slightly flowery hop tang. Very smooth and easy to drink - a touch of smoke character (I don’t think smoked malt was used) in the aftertaste is intriguing.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis St. Paul Pilsner
column5: Draft @ Minneapolis Brewpub: Gold, light head and lacing. Nose of light chemically deet and crisp pilsner malts and noble hops. The flavor is thin, creamy but a bit lacking in hops. The finish is way too thin, just nothing there after the flavor fades.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis St. Paul Pilsner
column5: On tap (sampler) at the Minneapolis location, RBSG 2007 pre-tasting dinner. Clear light gold with a white head. Sweet, grainy nose, light malt. Cereal grain flavors, lightly perfumey and a touch of honey. OK.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis St. Paul Pilsner
column5: On tap (sampler) at the Minneapolis location, June 2007. Mid gold colour. Thin, but complete, white head. Not a lot of aroma - just a touch of grainy malt. Sweetish initial impact on the palate. There’s a modicum of hoppy bitterness in the flavour, combined with a little bready malt. Has rather more backbone than the North Star premium lager sampled just before but doesn’t make a huge impact. Quite pleasant and drinkable.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis St. Paul Pilsner
column5: Brewpub draft. Clear gold, small white head. Real grainy with some subtle, sweet perfume and some corn and a small hint of noble hops. Decent for a pils. Light body, balanced.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis St. Paul Pilsner
column5: Sampled at brewpub prior to RBSG’07. Pours a clear, pale golden brew with an average white head with nice lacing. Aroma of light citrus, breakfast cereal, and honey. Taste is lightly carbonated, medium bodied with some grassy hop bitterness. Finish is clean, sweet and crisp.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis St. Paul Pilsner
column5: On tap @ the brew pub: Pours a clear gold with a white head. Aroma, yeast, floral and grassy notes. Flavor, pale malts, some slight floral hop notes on the end. So so.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis St. Paul Pilsner
column5: Clear gold color with a thick head. Barely any aroma, but just a bit of grain. Massive raw grain taste and oddly sweet for a pils. Some floral hop on the finish that bitters it up just a bit.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis St. Paul Pilsner
column5: On tap at Rock Bottom Minneapolis before the RBSG 2007 Surly tour. Needs to be very cold. Thicker than most pilsners. Looks pretty, nice lacing, truely clear, clean finish.

column1: Storm Beer Black Moon Iron Stout
column5: Light chocolate aroma. Jet black colour with ok head. Sweet chocolate flavours with a slightly bitter finish. Medium to heavy body with ow carbonation.

column1: Storm Beer Black Moon Iron Stout
column5: This is my first beer from Indonesia, Bali. 330 ml bottle. Very dark in colour. Nice chocolate aroma. Flavour is mild, with hints of chocolate and coffee. A nice beer.

column1: Storm Beer Black Moon Iron Stout
column5: 330 ml bottle, as Storm Beer Iron Stout, in Bali. ABV is 5%. Black colour, moderate tan head. Moderate but nice roasty aroma, notes of coffee, hints of dark chocolate. Relatively light bodied. Medium dry flavour, distinct roasty notes of coffee, again with hints of dark chocolate. Fairly decent beer.

column1: Storm Beer Black Moon Iron Stout
column5: Nice and light mild stout. Light coffee, light milk chocolate, and a very tender semi-sweet bitter finish. Good stuff. Also the hardest of the Storm brews to find on Bali. Nice treat though when it’s an epic rain storm out!!!

column1: Storm Beer Black Moon Iron Stout
column5: I’m not a big Stout drinker but this Iron Stout WOWED my pallet. Really Beautiful drop!

column1: Storm Beer Black Moon Iron Stout
column5: The high level of carbonation made this beer almost tasteless. It could have been soda water for all I knew. However, after putting down the glass in disgust and leaving it to warm up and fizz down out came some real flavour of chocolate and coffee with only a mild after taste. Unsuited to chilling and over carbonated. Other than that, not too bad and would drink again.

column1: Storm Beer Black Moon Iron Stout
column5: Bottle in Bali. Pour is dark clear brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is light roasted malt, light brown sugar, and a light crisp hop character. Flavor is also light malty and light caramel with hints of crisp hoppiness in the finish. Very drinkable stout for the tropics with a nice malty character.

column1: Storm Beer Black Moon Iron Stout
column5: 33cl Bottle in Ubud, Bali, restaurant Nomad. Deep brown to black colour, light off white head. Aroma is sweet, liquorice, laurel, light roasted malts. Flavour is liquorice, laurel, light roasted malts, sweet and dry finish. Light to medium bodied, soft carbonation. Nice.

column1: Storm Beer Black Moon Iron Stout
column5: Thanks to TexasJeep for this beer. Black pour with small brown head. Nose of roasted malts with hops lingering in the backgroudn. Some roasted malts wtih lacto-sweetness as well. Not to bad of a flavor, and a bit of an ashy finish.

column1: Storm Beer Black Moon Iron Stout
column5: Fizzy light brown head over a black body. Sweet roasted malt, but hop presence as well. Taste reminded me of the Storm Golden Ale strangely enough. Early hop bite, but a late charcoal finish. Not that bad. Palate was quite thin and fizzy, further confusing me as to the brewers intent. A quirky brew that doesnt fit the style very well. No one is in Bali for a soothing quality beer, they need to keep it light for the bingers.

On tap at Far Bar. Pours a fairly clear browned amber with a medium sized tan head. Soft fruit and toast on the nose, a bit of cherry, wood, funk. Medium bodied, soft acidity, slow malt and a bit of cherry again. Long tartness, a nice amount of acidity, more cherry and wood. Dries out nicely with a bit of funk into the finish.

Draft. Bronze beer with a dark cream head. Tart and light sour aroma. Tart/sour flavor with light acetic notes and light cherry. Medium bodied. Tart/sourness lingers with light acetic notes and light cherries.
on tap-pours a white head and cloudy yellow color. Aroma is lemon zesty, musty. Taste is lemon zesty, musty, wheat. OK effervescence.

Hmmm a bock light...ok. Body is a transparent yellow/straw color and golds a wispy white head. Light malt aroma with a suggestion of fusel alcohol and hints of white fruit. Mostly watey and flavorless on the whole.
on tap-pours an light tan head and amber color. Aroma is sweet-honey, light malt/grain. Taste is light body, sweet-honey, light malt/grain, faint aromatic wood-hops.

A- Rich red/brown body with foamy off-white head. Leaves behind plenty of lacing in the glass. S- Deep malty smell with some hop background. T- Toasted malt and fruitiness come through first. The finish is a good hop-malt balance. Some hops and sweet malt linger. P- medium to high carbonation and somewhat thin body. O- This is a good scottish ale. Interesting and enjoyable. Easily sessionable. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 06-24-2007 16:35:42
I loved that this beer was brewed for the 2007 US open. Very good scottish ale

Sampled on draft at the Map Room at Regent Square this beer poured a chestnut color with a large dark tan head. The aroma was roasty, bitter and had faint elements of fruit, smoke, caramel and toffee. The finish was dry, smoky and roasty. Very complex yet something just did not work for me with this one. Interesting though.

Growler. Pours dark hazy caramel, off white head. Aroma is caramel, malt, grass, molasses. Flavor is caramel, vanilla, wheat, grass, slight molasses, and earthiness. Lighter in body than I would have preferred.

From growler. Nice bit of grainy maltiness to this one, with caramel and toasted malt. Mild neutral fruitiness and just a bit of tang. Mild neutral hoppiness and some apple skins. Cloudy medium brown with thin off-white lacing head. Medium bodied with medium carbonation, very easy drinking. Starts with nice bit of toasted malt, light caramel, and some apple essence. A little bit of chocolate and dry nuttiness and some dull acidity. Finish is smooth, with just a bit of fruity hops bitterness. Clean smooth after and makes for a very easy, enjoyable quaff. One of Scott’s milder beers in terms of hops. Very nice ale!

Growler from brewery. Hazy copper/amber body with small tan head. Aroma is quite mild... mostly earthy malt with a slight sweetness of dark fruits. Flavor has a nice toasty/earthy malt character and a little sweetness like the aroma. There is a small hop presence right as the beer slides down your throat, but it vanishes quickly under the dry toasted malt. Apparently this is my first Scottish ale rating, but from memory I would say this was better than other Scottish ales I’ve had (but not rated).

If this is a Scottish Ale, this is great, because I have not had an SA that has rated above a 2. Much more refined than the everyday scott. Do you know what a Mashie is? Well it tastes and smells like a little bit of mashie shaft has been ground up and used to spice this brew. Smells and tastes like a mashie, even feels the same way in my hand. This was on tap at the Bocktown, excellent beer tasting venue. The pour is a little perfumy aroma and just plain beer. Cloudy and dark but not black. Even cloudier and lighter than rootbeer. Looks more like a good duneklweizen. When I taste, I think ‘why are you trying to please such a small critical niche of tasters’. This has no attributes of impy stout, and neither does it have any characteristics of IPA? Tastes and feels like the dirt that has been thrown up in a fairway when using a mashie. Hey, how did this divot get into my mouth? Not sweet and not bitter. Could be a session brew if it is not hiding a high alky content. No alky hints prevalent. Interesting, woody but not burned or charred wood. Like fresh green hickory trees broken open from a lightning or wind storm . Mild, nice and friendly. Medium low carbonation. Must be tried to appreciate, my words lack description. Interesting and better than just OK, for a beer. Good for a variety. Finish is fun and happy. No bitter medicinal qualities. Another very distinct flavor from East End. IMHO the best and most behaved Scottish ale in it’s category so far.
@ the brewpub, San Marcos 18-2-22: En ganska rakt fram veteöl men som saknar fräschör
On tap at the brewpub. Hazy golden/orange with a small white head. Mild with some banana, light spices and some yeast.

On tap at San Marcos, pours a clear blonde with a small white head. Aroma brings out dry cereal notes and light clove. Flavour is sweet and estery, with lots of banana and sweet fruitiness. Not brewed to style and rather unpleasant. Not a fan.

Tap at the brewery. Pours cloudy yellow with a medium, creamy white head, long retention with good lacing. Aroma is banana, light bubble gum and cloves, and earthy wheat malt. Flavor is heavy banana, earthy wheat malt, cloves, bubble gum and a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.

OK, starting to run out of descriptors for all the classic german hefes we had on this trip. A shocking number, and they were all in the good-but-not-great range, which makes a detailed review even harder. This was in the lower-middle end of that range :)"
Draft at the brewpub. Light golden color. Not very wheaty. Decent look with a gold. Taste is smooth. Pretty bland ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the brewery in San Marcos, served in a tasting glass. Pours cloudy straw with a medium white head that fades to a thin cover and leaves a medium amount of fine lace. On the nose there are notes of coriander, banana, wheat and Belgian spice, along with mild malt. The flavour is medium sweet with banana and fruit, along with subtle Belgian spice. The finish is long and spicy with a distinct banana note. On the palate, it is medium in body with a creamy texture and soft carbonation. overall, this is a decent smooth hefeweizen with a nice banana note. Would make for a nice summer sipper. 2013-03-22

A slightly cloudy pour with a white head. Pretty decent banana aroma with a slight lemon tartness. Sweet bubblegum, moderate clove spiciness, and sweet bread/malt, and candied orange. Lots of banana flavor along with a nice sweet bready character. Lightly watery, some citrus zest, and a bit of bubblegum, clove, and a light tartness.
A hazy yellow, colored beer, with a thick white head. The aroma of fruits of bananas, with notes of bitter. The taste is fruity, banana, with wheat. the aftertaste is flat fruity, almost no bitter.

Pours cloudy, light yellow orange with a medium sized white head, specks of lace. Smells of bananas and yeast and a bit of cereal malt. Tastes about the same. Banana and yeast. Medium body, ok carbonation.

Tap at Garage 39's 4th Anniversary. I tried the Brewmaster healing time coffee Porter 5% A deep black with reddish highlights and a freaky beige head. The taste was big licorice, no coffee and almost infected like. Weird. This thing is ducked and tastes like a beer cocktail mixed with a low-rent boozy oaky tannic spirit. Fail, man for a 4th Anniversary Garage 39 busted out the boring from good breweries and lots of junk from budget breweries, biggest waste of a great space I've ever seen.
5.0% black with a quickly dissipating head, bitter fruit aroma, fizzy bitter tart taste with a coffee after-taste.

Botella. Clear dark brown colour, small beige like head, bubbly. Sweet aroma of dark malt and caramel with some coffee. Ok mouthfeel. Flavour is sweet with dark malt and caramel/toffee, bit nuts, some coffee. Rather thin and not a porter style brew, I would say.

A dark clear brown ale with a thcik big bubbled moka head. In aroma, a nice vanilla fudge aroma with sweet chocolate. In mouth, a nice maple and nuts taste, with caramel malt. Nice. Mondiale 2009, June 6 2009.

Bottle @ Mondial de la Biere 2009 Appearance: light brown , clean light amber light , good beige top. Neat handsome appearance. Nose: Off caramel aroma , hint of chocolate , milky finish. Slight roast. Flavor/Palate : Medium bodied with slightly muddy character. Light chocolate with charamel.
Aroma:strong toffe aroma,butter scotch... Appearance:Oily brown,good head.. Flavor:toffe-chocolate,the toffe flavor is very strong...
Bottle at Mondial 2009. Dark brown-red with a thin mocha head. Average retention. Aroma is wood, maple, sugar, alcohol, spices and caramel. Flavor is similar to the aroma. Thin body.

Bottle from the brewery. Lightish black color, dull-looking with a foamy head and lots of carbonation. Fruity, dark malt aroma, with coffee and funky yeast. Fruity flavor with cheap malt extract, funk-ass yeast, and a bit of coffee. Very bad. Less than 25% malt—what is the rest? Thin, sugary, ass. Bad all around.

Med brown color, dark fruit, molassess, dark chocolate and burnt sugar in nose. Not bad. Mouth is smooth, slightly sour, dark fruit and molassess. A bit too light, lingering molassess and soy flavors. Need a bit more umpphh to it, but still not bad.

12 oz bottle. Deep brown-red beer with a thin tan head. Aroma is sweet and nutty with a chewy molasses, toast and coffee character along with some overripe fruit. Earthy and slightly malty. Strangely thin bodied for something with so much residual sweetness. A bit of rum and plumminess. Thinnish and sweet. A very strange beast… just like the other beers from this brewery.

Bottle from Foodshow. A little old at this point I guess. Light honeydew melon and sweety fruit nose with some sugar and maybe sudachi? Body is very soda-like with a slight syrupiness. Cloying and sweet, but the fruit is there. Alcopop but like some of the johana’s not entirely awful. To be clear though, not a beer, fruit beer, but more of a soda fruit beer.

From tap at Beerfes Tokyo. Pours hazy pale, thin layer of foam. Aroma is somewhat fresh but not in the usual way. Green fruits, a berry with some resins. Tastes sweet. At first it’s just sweet, then hops disappear and what’s left is skunky sweetness. Some fruits add on later which makes it more tolerable. Well, quite exciting though, not really sure if I’d want to have it again.

On tap at the Kyoto Beer Fest 2014. Brewmaster was bafflingly popular at the event. A nice honey gold pour with a beige head that lingers and appetizing cabos fruit spritzy aroma. Medium bodied the taste is a bit cloying or medicinal fruitiness. Think some kind of citrusy sweet soda. Not really beer like & kind of cloying...
Honey aroma. Sweet yuzu-like juice flavor. More of a fruit panache than a usual beer, but works quite well, and puts emphasis on nice local products.

Bottle, AKA "The Brewmaster" (Hakata omiyage gift from Neko-chan). Sweet ’n’ sour fruit aroma, some chemical note or maybe mold. Stale fruity initial, peaches, BBQ sauce, hopping like envelope flap glue. Thin and rather unpleasant mouthfeel. Doesn’t seem completely attenuated, though I doubt it would be more than marginally better if it were. Really weird falvors for a golden/blond ale. Pretty bad. Who the f*#k is "K", anyway? And why does he let this guy brew?
Pours a cloudy golden. Aroma has yeasty florals, some citrus. Taste has a lot of citrus. Not my favorite beer, but love Fukuoka.
Bottle in Shinjuku, outside Shinjuku Park. Clear golden - white head. Sweetness. Wheaty. Light acid notes. Grassy. Light body. Herbeal notes. Ok hoppy notes.
5.0% gold colour wit ha nice head, sweet fruit and yeast aroma, bitter sweet Belgian blonde taste, best Japanese beer I have had to date.
Botella. Hazy deep golden colour. Nice hoppy and malty sweet aroma, Good mouthfeel. Pleasant bitter dry hoppy flavour with malt, mild sweetness. Dry bitter finish. Nice.

[2215-20090605] Sample. Mossy sweet maple floral toffee aroma has an odd floral note. Clear, medium orange body with a quick foamy white head. Maple floral malt flavour has an weird toffee note but is sweet throughout. Medium boozy body. Don’t care for the floral. (2T @ Mondial 2009; Montreal, QC)

A golden ale with a thin white head. A lightly lemony pale ale, with herbal hops, blandish. In mouth, a rather lemony pale ale with some interesting hops action. Strange and offputting. Mondiale 2009, June 5 2009.

Bottle @ Mondial de la Biere 2009 Appearance: finely hazed amber with white smallish top 3- Nose: citric , amber malts , sweet sided with good central hop profile. Refreshing clean aroma.7+ Flavor/Palate : medium full bodied. Amber malts . sweets neatly balanced with leafy-citric hops. Long-lasting finish. Pleasant brew.

2009-06-05. Dark yellow orange body with a small white head. Bizarre aroma, fresh honey according to MartinT but I would not of identified it as anything specific, touch of alcohol, florals come out as it warms. Flavour is also unusual, sweet fruity melange. (6+) Average to thin palate. Very interesting but a bit muddled overall, strange. Did not particularly care for it. Bottle labelled Brewmaster Blonde at Mondial 2009, Montreal
Bottle @ Mondial 2009. Aroma is orange, malt, plums, orange/amber, small custard head. Flavour is orange, malt and gummy bears. Light bodied, pleasantly sweet. Good.

column1: Sierra Nevada Celebration - Whiskey Barrel Aged
column5: Reviewed at the 2007 Strong Ale festival A- Clear light orange hue, thin white head is mostly dissipating, light lacing S- Wonderful bourbon and wood aromas dominate, tones of smokey malts, oak wood, cherries, vanilla, dark fruits T- Initial taste is vanilla and oak, a range of fruit tones appear midway, taste is somewhat diluted and a let-down given the amazing aromas M- Medium-bodied, watery texture, light carbonation D- Easy-to-drink ale, unfortunately the wood aromas over-ride the core malts and hops, taste doesn’t keep pace with the aroma

column1: Sierra Nevada Celebration - Whiskey Barrel Aged
column5: On tap at O’brien’s. Pours with an amber-brown body topped by a thin to medium thick head with little lacing. It’s slightly sweet with nice oaky, vanilla notes, a little malt and a nice hoppiness. A touch of frutiy alcohol esters show through. Full bodied, warming and smooth.

column1: Sierra Nevada Celebration - Whiskey Barrel Aged
column5: Tried a pint from tap at Obriens. From my notes and the current 4.26 rating from 5 people, I’m going to make it more difficult to be in the top 50/100. Looks like the keg was just tapped. Poured with a glass full of head. They kept pouring until the glass was full except for a 1 finger head. The head slowly settled to a 2mm thick creamy blanket. So far so good. The color is crystal clear amber, no cloudiness whatsoever. With a clean palate, I get a very mild aroma, some hops, some maltiness, kind of average beer smell. First taste has some maltiness that morphs into a background sourness, which reduces drinkability. A slight lingering hop bitterness at the back of my throat for a long finish. At the bottom of the glass, the aroma gets fresher, cleaner in a cucumber way. Certainly nothing special.

column1: Sierra Nevada Celebration - Whiskey Barrel Aged
column5: Draft at Stone Brewery. Aroma of borboun, some wood, and the citrus hops normal to sierra nevada. The flavor was good because the borboun was not overpowering; and the flavors mixed well together.

column1: Sierra Nevada Celebration - Whiskey Barrel Aged
column5: On tap at Stone. I really liked this, more than the original. Aroma was of borboun/whisky, vanilla, citrus and caramel. Flavor was much of the same; good blending and complexity. Didn’t find the whiskey overpowering at all.

column1: Sierra Nevada Celebration - Whiskey Barrel Aged
column5: On tap @ Stone - Pours a clear orangish-amber color with a small off white head. No lacing. Aroma is mostly oak/whiskey and light malt. Not the hops I was hoping for. Flavor agian, is mostly oak/whiskey, and very light hops and malt. Medium body. Palate is very whiskey like. Not sure what this beer needs. Time may round the edges, but the hops we enjoy in our annual Celebration is lost. I would have like to have tried this beer a couple months after it was brewed. A very interesting beer.

column1: Sierra Nevada Celebration - Whiskey Barrel Aged
column5: On tap. Pours copper colored with a white head. Hoppy aroma with citrus notes, vanilla and sweet bourbon. Maltier than I expected with an obvious hop character. Big vanilla and bourbon notes as well. Slightly sweet but bitter finish.

column1: Sierra Nevada Celebration - Whiskey Barrel Aged
column5: On tap at Stone. Clear orange brown with a creamy white head. Aroma of caramel, vanilla, apple, and whiskey. Thick creamy palate. A some what roasty taste of caramel and apple transitioning to a good pungent whiskey taste and finishing with a lingering oaky vanilla taste and a deep alcoholic warmth. This is an absolutely wonderful beer!

column4: La Voie Maltée - Microbrasserie du Saguenay
column5: On tap at the brewpub St-Do is the nickname for the street where the brewpub is, known for all the bars and a general party atmosphere, so why use this name for their all bio Beer is beyond me. Slightly opaque, almost greenish blonde with tiny bubbles rising from the bottom of the pint to the thin head on top. Green apple like a cider, quite fruity with a strange smell that I could only associate with Flinstones chewable vitamins. Hops come out a little harsh and throw the balance way off on this one, and it sticks to the aftertaste with a very vegetal flavor and it got pretty annoying. Body was way too light as well. Tasted like a botched batch of homebrew. I’ve tasted good bio Beers before, this one was just sub-par. I don’t think it’s the brewer who is to blame for this, it’s probably his supply of grain or hops that makes me want to say hurray for pesticides.

Bottle. Pours a very muddy deep yellow with a big bubbly white head that fizzes away. Aroma is extremely heavy - lots and lots of spices - coriander! I actually coughed when I first tried breathing in the aroma :o) Flavour is very medicinic and citric - this is infected! Pheuww...

Tap @ YNWA. Muddy dark yellow with no head. Very sweet fruity and sugary aroma with plenty of sweet orange peel. Medium mouthfeel - a touch oily. Flavour is immensly sweet with little notes of anything else - there is far too much sugar. Some caramel and oranges and lightly vinious.

2 draught pints at Harvard locale on 5/19/07 Some douchebag kept remarking to the bartender that this beer was phenolic. I then remarked that, "No, it wasn’t, are you sure you’re not just trying to sound cool?" to which he only remarked, "It’s phenolic." So I left it at that. I’ve had a lot of pilsners full of diacetyl, DMS and acetyldehyde, but I dont remember too many phenolic pilsners, and this one certainly wasnt. Let’s hear it for people trying to sound like they are superior in knowledge to everyone else at the bar.... Basic American pils. Golden-brass colored body has a small white head, with poor retention, light lacing. High clarity, quite fizzy. Somewhat underattenuated, and with lots of minerals and some acetyldehyde (but no phenols) in the nose, the malts seem rather sluggish and forceful, not having that light, crisp, dainty honey appeal of the better in the style. Hops are grassy, somewhat leafy and herbal as well, but are quite dry and not overly aromatic. Probably just a cream ale, there isnt much yeast crispness. Spicy herbal hop notes produce thyme, oregano and basil hints, with a bit of acidity. But not enough to cut through the sweet, sticky, vanilla and cookie-dough-like maltiness. Still, for the underattenuation, and some paperiness, it’s got a brisk enough carbonation (and not too much of it) to keep it drinkable. Not very complex, but passable. No alcohol noted.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Clear orange color. Massive lacing. Good bitter flavor with earthy finish. On tap at the Slyfox IPA Project event.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On tap at the Phoenixville location. Poured an amber color with an off white head. Aromas of floral hops with some pine. Tastes floral hops, pine, and had a light spiciness in the finish.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft at the Blind Tiger. Some floral and pine hops in the aroma. The flavor has some slightly earthy malt up front followed by a citrusy / piney hop bitterness. Tastes a little like a dry-hopped beer though with the hops being somewhat metallic, but it’s not too bad in that regard.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Date: 07/25/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub, Phoenixville clear gold, fine beige head, bits of lace, light floral hop aroma, sweet crystal malt flavor, light balancing hops, nice bitterness starts halfway through for a long earthy finish, this nice bitterness is the best thing going for this beer Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft. Darkish amber pour. Overhopped and not well balanced for my tastes. Mild hops - interesting but not very enjoyable to my taste.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Tap @ Sly Fox. The beer was clear orange with an off-white head. The aroma was hoppy some citrus notes but mainly floral. There was also toasted malt with a mild fruitiness. The flavor was dominated with floral hops. The bitterness was big full and kept growing through the very long dry finish.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On tap at Ginger Man. Very dark red pour. No head. Muddy hop aroma, kind of earthy, orange and mushroom. Caramel and bitter hop taste. Pumello and very dry citrus. An interesting hop, kind of a cross between British and American.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Tap at Ginger Man. Bright amber/orange colour with a thick fluffy tan head. Very fruity hop aroma with black currant, black berry and a soft woody resinousness. Jammy with light spiciness as well. Flavour is very hoppy with just enough malt sweetness to restrain it. Toasted grain and sweet caramel on the back set against strong resinous bitterness. Nice balance and another solid single hop brew. This hop is particularly nice.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Deep copper color, very intense aroma with notes of hops & pine, medium in body, very crisp, astringent flavors with lots of hops, very bitter & dry, notes of pine, bread & caramel, lightly toasted finish with a slight note of alcohol, very dry & bitter, an excellent IPA

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft @ Royersford & Growler from same. Amber color with a medium white head. Pleasant floral-earthen hop aroma with some caramel malts. Flavor has a nice earthy-hop taste mixed with some caramel malts, herbs, and just a bit of light fruit sweetness. Solid IPA with a tasty English hop varietal. Well done.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with medium creamy light brown mostly lasting head. Aroma is roasted malt with notes of licorice and coffee. Sweet flavor. Bitter finish.

Bottle. Creamy lightbrown good mostly lasting head. Very dark brown colour. Heavy malty and moderate hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Nice licorice notes. Long moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate. Nice.
Dark brown, almost brown. Clear. Beige head, mostly lastning. Roasted aroma, laqurice, coffee. Syrup texture. Soft carbonation.
Bottle. Black colour with a medium light brown head. Rich aroma and taste of roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Nice semi hoppy finish.
Dark reddish brow color with small head. Strong licorice aroma! Well balanced flavor. Slightly medic aftertaste, cough medicin?
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are rich licorice, milk chocolate, malt and coffee.
EBF 2008, Valby, DK. Bottled, 120908. Black with brown head. Aroma of coffee and roasts. Flavor is sweet with chocolate and malt.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is burned, roasted, sweet, chocolate, coffee. Flavour is sweet, burned, roasted, coffee, hop, chocolate, fruit. harmonic nice beer.

Bottle. It pours a black body with a nice tan head, looking just lovely in the glass. Sweetish, roasted, slightly strange aroma, but I can’t really pin what’s strange about it. Dusty and fruity as well. Sweet, burnt, tar-like flavor with chocolate, coffee, a good hoppiness and lots of sweetness. Full-bodied and a bit sticky in the mouth. Long, burnt finish with coffee. Lovely. (080509)

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a huge dark brown head. The aroma is sweet with strong notes of dark bitter chocolate, as well as lighter notes of roasted malt and citrusy hops. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of roasted malt and dark bitter chocolate, as well as some notes of straw and citrusy hops, leading to a very dry and roasted finish, where both the note of roasted malt and dark bitter chocolate lingers for a long while.
Bottle. Dark amber color with frothy white head. Aroma is hay, grass. Very dry. Medium bitterness.

25-MAR-2017, bottle @home, from Kvickly. Hazy dark orange with a lasting, creamy, off-white head. Huge hoppy aroma. Grape fruit, pine, butter, diacetyl? Yes, but hidden under the huge hops. Dank, very bitter, full. This is very good. Pitty with the diacetyl. Would have been great without it.

Reib’m Bier is a special brew which I acquired at the brewery in June 2007. Dark yellow colour, nearly amber, medium-sized head. Full-bodied malty and hoppy. The hops have a medicinal character, which brings interesting and rather unusual flavours into the beer.
cask at Pullman Helsinki 191208 amber white airy head. bit tangy first sip solid bitter easily drinkable too easy ?

Scrapping original rating - was off.
Cask (Pullman, Helsinki)
Pleasant light brown. Soft palate, some sacchariney dryness, but otherwise gentle but rich bitterness. Very tasty, if unexciting. Easy session. Some wet sheep later.
Cask 0.25L tasted at Kittys. Pale thin head. Slightly hazy golden copperish colour. Syrup and malt in the nose. Slightly lemony fruity taste. Slight sourness.

Cask@Kuikka Helsinki. Damn good surprise for a change. Reminds me of a good whisky, like lagavulin or laphroaig by being so smoky and tarry maybe even peat. medium bodied,but still a bit watery. very interesting and delicious.

Gravity, Far From The Madding Crowd summer ale festival. Copper, nicely contrasting white head. A little haze, in a beer that seems like it ought to be clear. Slightly sour bread aroma, a little doughy/yeast. Peppery dark bread flavor with a bit of rustic hop edge. Middle of the road.

Cask conditioned at The Twelve Bells, Cirencester, Glocs. Red amber with white head. Fully flavoured malty bitter, plenty of fruit and touches of spice, cranberry but still nicely dry and bitter on the finish. Very accomplished.
Cask-conditioned at the Bag O’Nails, Bristol 14/6/07. Dark amber coloured with slight, lacy head. Spicy aroma with some cinnamon. Flavour was fruity with a slightly sour finish. Drinkable.

Date: 05/17/2007 Mode: Firkin Source: Brewpub muddy burnt orange, frothy beige head, drops of lace, light caramel malt aroma with light floral hops, big creamy body, mild caramel malt flavor, lots of yeasty bready character, plenty of balancing hops to keep it honest without being hoppy, over time richer malt flavor develops and brings in more toasted bread crust, a hint of chocolate appears and disappears, some nice sweetness appears towards the bottom of the second pint -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 05/24/2007 Mode: cask coming off richer from the start this week, sweetness is still tempered a bit Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **/4

Appearance: Clear, ruby-red body with a thin, bubbly off-white head. Smell: Caramel malts and plenty of sweet, stove-top-cooked fruits with a reserved, though noticeable hint of citrus. Taste: Again, plenty of strong, juicy fruits flavors along with caramel malts and that ever-present citrus character which hightens on the mildy bitter finish. Mouthfeel: Medium-thin body. Mild carbonation. Drinkability: A pleasant, fresh-tasting amber ale that’s quite drinkable.

More of a copper in color than an amber. In the aroma, caramel malt comes through in spades along with a distinct citrus note in the aroma from the hops. Still more malt sweetness than hop bitterness in the flavor.

This was a good batch. Very fresh, of course, and really hit a good note with me. Beer had a small head, dark maple color, clear, very carbonated. Smelled of hops, burnt carmel, bread. Tasted strong of hops, almost a little too much for my tastes. Reminded me of a Sam Adams, only slightly stronger. The beer went nicely with the pizza and bread I had at the 5 Seasons! I recommend this one to anyone who likes Amber beers or brown ales.
Cask @ the 5SN. Ruby red amber color. Nice lacing. Aroma is of citrus hops. Rich caramel malts, followed by heavenly bitter hop finish. These pints went down just to easy!

column1: 5 Seasons North Black Hole American Stout
column5: Date: 06/14/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub black, wispy tan head, light roasted aroma, rich dry dark chocolate flavor, plenty of roasted malt giving of a nice coffee character, good bitterness in addition to the roasted leading to a long lasting bitter finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

column1: 5 Seasons North Black Hole American Stout
column5: Pretty much opaque. Rich roasty malts, brownies and coffee. This is near perfection. Rich, but not so much so that it’s not drinkable. Incredibly good stout.

column1: 5 Seasons North Black Hole American Stout
column5: On tap at the brewpub in Alpharetta. Dark black pour, fluffy mocha colored head. Whiffs of fresh earth and coffee in the aroma. Solid dry earthy, dark chocolate flavor. Just the right amount of chalkiness in the mouthfeel. Solid brewpub stout.

Draft at the Coronado Island location. Pours almost clear gold with a fizzy white head. Tastes like sweet wheat, some lime, faint sweet citrus hops, and some bready malt. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like sweet wheat, doughy malt, faint lime, and faint citrus hops.

Rating #1521 - 18.03.2015 - On tap at Coronado. Pours a golden yellow with a decent white bubbly head that fades quickly to a ring. Aroma is lime, wheat. Effervescent, medium-high carbonation with a fair bit of lime zest on the tongue Finish is quite crisp, and extremely refreshing. A slap in the face to the Inbev creature.
Restrained grassy aroma in a cloudy golden pour. Nice hints of citrus in the taste balanced by a crisp clean finish.

Draught at the Coronado. Hazy yellow colour with a tiny white head. Lime, lemongrass and tartness in the aroma. Nice. The flavour is lime zest, lime juice and some maltiness. Very limey. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
on tap at Coronado, so very much not retired. like a lite lager with a crapton of refreshing lime. I could go back to this on warm days fo sho.

Reviewed from notes. Pours a slightly-hazed yellow straw color with a white head that lasts for a bit before giving way and leaving behind a touch of lace. The nose is light with a bit of honey and grain plus a nice lime presence. Taste adds more lime and other flavors fade a bit. Feel is nice with the lime providing a nice character. A bit of spicing in there as well. Overall, a pretty good recipe. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 11-09-2010

Draft. A very light golden beer with a beutiful white head. The aroma has notes of malt and lime. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of lime combined with medium notes of malt, leading to a dry wheaty finish.
I wouldn’t really call this a fruit beer. Tap at Live Wire. Pours gold with a bright white head slight nose bit of lime bit of hops. sweet lime taste ok

On-tap at PP C’Bad. Pours clearish, green/yellow with a medium size white head and good lace. Smells light and grainy, plain. Tastes light and grainy and plain with just a faint hint of citrus and tonic water. Thin body, good carbonation. Tonic-esque.
On tap at the brewery. Hazy yellow pour. Citrus, wheat bread, lime juice, and a bit of fruit esters. simple beer, easy to drink.

First off, this is NOT a Marzen. Way too dark, and WAY to strong a roast character for the style. Strongly phenolic in aroma and flavor, which greatly overpowers any positive malt or hop character. Phenolic character most likely is from wild yeast infection, although in another beer the brewer claims it is from cloves. Why would anyone put cloves in a marzen? Pours clear, with a nice off-white head. I strongly doubt the claims of alcohol level. It is very likely 6-8 % at most.

On tap at Alt Platz. Murky brown with a brief white head. An excellent Märzen. Nose is woody caramel and smoky apple. Taste is caramel and nuts with a bit of butterscotch. Light sourness plays nicely off sweet notes. Medium body with just enough carb. Clean finish with light pith. Fresh and flavorful, top-notch.
Pours brown with a small head, aroma of grain, roasted, flavor of bread, roasted, grain, medium bodied
Tap @ Sour & Bitter #3. Clear amber body with a small white head. Malt, grain, wood, bread. Decent.

Draft at La Rovira, RBESG 2016. Clear brown with a small tan head. Aroma of malt, caramel, light overripe dark fruit and raisins. Flavour is moderate sweet and light moderate bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. [07-07-2016]

13.09.2016, tap @ UNA: Nice creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is slightly sour-ish roasted, weeds, minerals, dark malts, unripe banana, paper, bark, grass, sawdust, yeast. Taste is slightly sour-ish mineraly, weeds, sour grass, bloodlike minerals, bark, roasted grain, paper, yeast, almond essence, unripe banana. Medium, sour-ish mineraly mouthfeel. Next!
How : tap Appearance : almost clear light brown with a medium to small off-white head. Aroma : caramel, nuts, dark fruits and banana, Palate : light body, fizzy carbonation.

Draught @ [ Sour & Bitter #3 by Drikkeriet ], Atelier 1B - Gastronomisk Innovation, Frederiksborggade 1B, 4th, Copenhagen, Denmark 1360. [ As Pizza Port Badonk-A-Dunkel ]. Clear medium red amber color with a small to average, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, bread, dark malt, caramel, pale malt, wheat, moderate yeasty, vegetables. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration, wheat - yeast, dark malt, caramel, bread, yeast. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20160512]
On tap. Brown colour with beige head. Wheat, malt and roasted aroma. Sweet, wheat, malt, roasted and chocolate taste. Medium body.

Been to the San Clemente Pizza Port three times and never seen this: crazy to try it during the RBESG 2016 in Barcelona where it was on tap at La Rovira. Deep brown with a red hue, decent sized beige head. Semi-sweet malty molasses dominate the brew with both caramel and toffee aromas/flavours overpowering any hop content: there is however a slight bitterness in the finish.
Tap at La Rovira. Deep reddish brown with beige head. Caramel, toffee, dry cocoa, raisins, dry dead leaves. Light sweet and bitter. Under medium bodied. Not bad.
Draught at Himmeriget. Hazy dark brown to black with an off-white head. Aroma medium malty (caramel, roasted). Flavor medium sweet, light bitter. Light to medium body, soft carbonated.

Date: 05/24/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy yellow, dense white head, thick lace, light sweet malt aroma with light floral hops, medium body, sweet malt flavor, hint of corn from the 100% pilsner malt, light bitter finish, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 9/20 Rating: 2.8/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **/4

Light golden color. aroma of nuts and corn. flavors of malt and corn. very light and very refreshing. Reminds me of my favorite blond slut, Goes Down easy, finishes refreshing. Some of my favorite summers were spent with blonds. PROST!

On tap at the brewpub in Alpharetta. Light golden pour, soft white head, brief lacing. Not much of an aroma, perhaps some fresh lake water notes and a hint of grass. Flavor has some honey notes and some creaminess. Very crsip and clean - nice smooth mouthfeel. Good session starter.
Tap @ Stone Winter Storm ’08: Poured black with a brown head. Milk chocolate aroma. Mildly sweet. The flavor was semi-sweet and roasty. Some cocoa. Light to medium bodied. Smooth mouth feel.

On tap at Stone’s 2008 Winter Storm. Black. Big fluffy dark tan head. A bit of over roasted aroma, but still good. Leans dry. Small bubbles. Not my favorite style, because I like sweeter beers, but still good.
On tap at the bistro. Dark brown/black with a tan head. Mildly roasty flavor with some tingliness on the palate.

On tap at Stone. Dark brown with creamy tan head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Smooth creamy palate. Taste of semi-sweet chocolate, coffee, and a hint of vanilla. No after taste. The brewer only produced a small amount of this beer and estimated the ABV at 5.5 to 6% I hope Stone makes more of this damn good stout!

Bottle, thanks George999! Big biscuit malt aroma with notes of citrus hops and caramel malt. Pours clear golden colored with a thin off white head that has excellent retention and lacing. Starts with sweet biscuity malt as well as some caramel malt. Finishes dry, but smooth with light citrus and grassy hop bitterness. A little sweet for a pale, but a refreshing beer nonetheless.

Tap at Capital Brewing in Middleton, WI. Hazy blonde pour with decent head formation. Nose is mild orange citrus, celery. Flavor is very dense for style like a lot of Capital’s beers: thick and chewy, salty, big bready malt base, some celery flavors.
Very slight aroma of paper and a little hops. Flavor’s oxidized hops, fruit, soap, paper, not good. Don’t want to drink the rest of this.
Very average beer...mouth is all malt and biscuit...nose is kind of a yuck smell...not that great..
Draft at the source. Clear golden orange color. Aroma of orange peel. Taste is mixed citrus and butter.
Pours hazy amber with white head. Aroma is very malty, mostly caramel. Very nice caramel malt character. Little bit of citrus and pine from the hops. Nice well balanced refreshing pale ale.

Poured at home from 12oz can. Golden clear color, white head. Musty lager aroma. No hops or bitterness. Taste has a hint of honey and fruit. Overall a pretty pedestrian pale ale, but it is pretty easy drinking on the bright side.

"i agree with phishpond’s "weak on the hops" assertation. maybe i got an off batch, but this was one boring ass beer. my notes on this one say beer flavored water. not exactly what i look for in an apa."
Medium copper, translucent pour with a small head that leaves a bit of lace. Aroma is fairly mild with a bit of citrus and straw. Flavor follows suit. Medium body with slightly sticky mouthfeel.

Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a decent hazy orange looking color with a slight transparency about it that allowed a fair carbonation to be seen rising. There was less than a finger’s worth of head. The smell was based around some light sweet pine with just a tad of light sweet caramel malt. The taste was mainly sweet around the piney hops and sweet caramel malts. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. There’s nothing off and there’s nothing spectacular about it. Overall, an everyday APA worthy of having again and would probably be a pretty good pizza beer.

Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a hazy extremely pale yellow color with a large foamy white head that left decent lacing. The aroma was phenol, clove, yeast and a bit of bubblegum. The flavor was strong phenol with bubblegum, clove and yeast. Medium length finish. Medium body. Not good.
Draft. Medium white head with pale straw body. Aroma is medium sweet, banana, some lemon, light cotton candy. Taste is medium sweet, banana, light lemon. Light body.
Hazy yellow little lacy white head; aroma of bananna; Flava is light hints of bananna; feels watery; finishes dryish softly fruity

Tap. Pours hazy, pale yellow with thin, fizzy white head; decent retention and spare lacing. Aroma is banana, sweetbread, light yeast, cloves, floral hops, and light funk. Flavor is lightly sweet malts forward with good supporting light fruit esters and herbs with faint grassy hops; crisp, dry finish.

Tap. Pours lightly hazy pale yellow with a medium, fizzy white head, short retention with good lacing. Aroma is light banana esters with light citrus notes and spicy wheat. Flavor is malt forward with medium citrus notes and banana esters with a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.
Served with a lemon, with typical hefeweizen aroma, mouthfeel, and taste. Would be great during the hot summer months.
Pours pineapple with only slight cloudiness to it. Nice banana notes on the nose as well as the tongue. Clean finish. Solid but not spectacular example of style.

on draft at the brewery, pours hazy yellow with a tall white head. Aroma is rich wheat and banana. Flavor is a very full bodied wheat and toasted malt with lots of yeast banana and clove flavors lingering in the finish. A pleasant surprise.
Mostly translucent golden with a medium creamy white head. Aroma of banana, lemon and grains. Flavor of the same. Thin and sweet..

at brewpub for a beer dinner event. Poured hazy yellow in color with a thin white head. Aroma of wheat, and light lemon. Tastes of wheat, light fruity esters, slight notes of smoked malts &#40bizarre&#41, cloves.

Lots of boiled vegetable aroma up front. Once that dissipates, citrus, floral hops are notable along with a very sweet and somewhat musky honey-like malt character. Slightly hazy, deep copper body is topped by a large bubbled, cream coloured head that recedes quite rapidly to a partial cover with some lacing. Boiled vegetable flavour is strong with plenty of underlying malt sweetness and fairly assertive bitterness. Aftertaste is herbal and citrus hops. Medium light body is somewhat astringent and puckering. Strong carbonation is very pointy on the tongue and cheeks. Tulip glass. Cellar temperature. Bottle (Le Gobelet, Jan-08).

column1: Squatters Racer X Rye Golden Ale
column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Pours a a mellow orange amber color. Aromas of wheat, grapes, some spice. In the flavor there are hints of orange, grapes, with a slight hoppy bitter finish.

column1: Squatters Racer X Rye Golden Ale
column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Like everything else in the state of Utah.....it underwhelms you....actually, it cracks you up when you really think about it. You could lump all the Squatter’s brews in a bag--pull them out randomly--and still never guess the correct brew. Color is typical....amber....thin white head...crappy malt nose and taste....rye..what rye? Don’t waste your money on any brew in this state unless you can get some Uinta Anniversary barley wine......that’s it...period.

column1: Squatters Racer X Rye Golden Ale
column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: on tap-pours a white head and slightly hazy gold color. Aroma is mild ?. Taste is grain-some sweetness, nice effervescence on front of the tongue, light hops bite.

column1: Squatters Racer X Rye Golden Ale
column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Orange-amber colour with a white head. Aroma of cereally malt, a bit of spice. Not much in the way of hops. As the beer warms a bit of rye comes out in the malt. It’s barely perceptible and if I wasn’t looking for it, I’m not sure I’d notice it. Low bitterness and not a lot of hop flavour either. Meh.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Sampled at the Great American Beer Festival 2019 in Denver, Colorado. Light, clean, sweet, grainy.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at Red Rock. Good, light, flavorful and sweet. Very good and refreshing beer.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Aroma is light malt, soapy herbs. Straw colour with white head. Taste is light sweet and moderate bitter. Light+ body, water+ feel and soapy finish.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Sampled at GABF 2017 with Paul and Larry. Pours a golden yellow body with big white head. Mouthfeel is light bodied and crisp on the palate with notes of sweet pale malt, grains and spice.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: [ As Red Rock Organic Zwickel Bier ]. Clear light yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, grain, herbs. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a long duration, herbs, pale malt, grain, sweet malt. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20161230] 6-3-6-3-13

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Slightly hazy pale yellow with small white head. Aroma is malt, herbal, hop and grass. Flavour is malt, grass, herbal, spices, little perfume, hop, little sweet and a little bitter.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Frothy White fair mostly deminishing head. Grenish yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Light bitter flavor. Some soapy notes. Light bitter flavor. Short light bitter finish. Watery palate,

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Pours yellow with white head. Aroma of light malt, yeast, light grain, little sweet, herbs, hay-ish hops. Flavor is light sweet, light bitter, malt, yeast, hay, light citrus. Medium body, average to lively carbonation. 301216

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and herbal. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 301216

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are grass, straw, fruits, flowers, soap, malt and hops. Nice and bitter.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at the SLC BP. Foggy very light pale yellow with a fine dense white head sublet Belgian yeast notes light wheaty malt body.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Draft. Golden beer with a cream head. Lemon and wheat aroma. Lemon and wheat flavor with light spice. Medium bodied. Lemon and wheat linger with light spice.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: A little more flavor than the pils. Decent bready and bannana notes and a hazy off yellow color.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at Red Rock. Pours the typical hazed yellow with a nice white head. Aroma is lightly wheat, with coriander and slight orange. Flavor matches, more emphasis on the wheat than the spicing, slightly more coriander present than orange. Touch of a soapy mouthfeel - maybe some oats present? In any case, solid wit.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Wheat beer in smell and flavor, floral, citrus, nice body thanks to the unfiltered nature of the beer, light body and extrmely fresh this is my choice for hot summer days, ohhh and it is not as acid as many white beers.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Had this at the Downtown location. Received in a pint glass. 4.0 A: Well hazed bright yellow color. Came with a small head, but lots of lacing is left. 4.0 S: Big earthiness with a light herbal component. Good amount of corriander, neutral wheat, and a light pepperiness. Clean without off flavors. Quite solid. 3.5 T: Corriander, wheat, light pepper. Well brewed, but hard to distinguish from other solid wits. 3.5 M: Medium body. Well carbonated near the upper end of the style. Lightly bity. Otherwise, good here. 3.5 D: Good flavors and solid all around. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 06-21-2012 03:53:51

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at Red Rock downtown Appearance: Cloudy straw yellow with a medium sized white head and good lacing Aroma: Huge aroma of banana esters, yeast and coriander Taste: Banana, citrus and cloves Nice and refreshing, well made.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: GABF 2010, VG wit IMO. cloudy golden pour, balanced notes of citrus & coriander led spice. Nice mouthfeel & flavor. Nice beer

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Hazy pale yellow. Aroma of orange huice concentrate. Sweet and light bodied with clean, edgy mouthfeel. Some syrup and coriander. Low bitterness. Too sweet and edgy to be refreshing.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Taster Brewpub SLC 1/19/09-Pours a cloudy ahzy yellow with a small covering for a head. Aroma of coriander and citrus. Flavors of banana, coriander, and cloves. This was a pretty decent light bodied wit. Quite tasty.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Pours a murky golden orange color. Aromas of citrus hops, caramel malts. Flavor is bitter and hoppy with a touch of pepper/grapefruit with sweet malt.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: on tap-pours an off white head and slightly hazy yellow. Aroma is grain, light malt, secondary hops. Taste is grain/light malt, fruity, secondary hops-slight bitter. Light/medium body. OK carbonation.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Hazy copper coloured brew, thin white head. Aroma of pale malt and a touch of wheatiness as well. The flavour is pretty strange really with a bit of yeast and a spicy/juniper berry herbal quality over the pale malt. Light dustiness and a touch of graininess. Quite a strange brew, but the juniper/pine character really saves it. Low bitterness with a light sulphury character.

22oz bottle obtained aat the Brew Kettle. Amber-copper pour with a medium white ehad. Fairly clear for a wheat. Lightly sweet aroma in which the raspberries are noticable. Decent flavor. Lightly touched wheat and grain along with a hint of raspberry flavoring. Medium, somewhat wet mouthfeel. It’s drinkable, but nothing to get worked up about. Boring really.

Ehh. There’s absolutely nothing that stands out in this beer. A fruit beer should at least feature the fruit. If the fruit isn’t a featured aroma and flavor, then it should a subtle complement to the bolder malt, yeast, and hop flavors and aromas. This hazy red beer has enough raspberry to be noticed, but not enough to stand out. The wheat isn’t pronounced and there is no bitterness. There is a nice subtely vanilla creaminess almost from the interaction of malt, yeast, and fruit, but it’s not being featured either.

Cask at the Priory Arms, Stockwell, 5th June 2007. Clear amber, zero head. Really felt like just a normal bitter with cherry added - showed in the taste and the sweeter finish than expected. Interesting to try but no standout.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Newshouse - Nottingham. A slight hint of pink to this copper coloured beer which has a whitish head and lacing. The aroma has cherry essence. The taste has the same. Minimal hop flavours but actually intriguingly drinkable.

Pint pulled at The Bricklayers Arms in Putney (London), a slightly hazy amber colour with a filmy white head. A subtle but clean fresh cherry aroma with touches of chocolate (reminiscent of black forest gateau). The palate is a little sour, again with a subtle cherry flavour. Became more sour in the finish.

Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury. Pinkish amber with white head. Not too much sign of the double cherry, there is a strange floral character, with a basic hop flavour, but largely not much to write about. It’s ok

Cask-conditioned at the Hillgrove Porter Stores, Bristol. Pale yellow with a white head that left plenty of lacing. Light hoppy aroma followed by a slightly sweet malty flavour and a dry finish. A refreshing summer beer.

Cask, The Cherry Tree, Catthorpe. Pale misty gold with a white halo of suds. Fresh hop leafiness in the nose. Juicy malt, tangy hops, biscuity vanilla afters. Pleasantly uncomplicated after a long day on the sauce.
Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury. Pale amber with white head. Light bitter with a dry body, lightly hopped and crisp, lager type malt. Uninspiting

Flasche 0,33l: Kastanienbraun, dunkles Mahagoni, glasklar, stabiler mittelporiger beiger Schaum; in der Nase kräftige malzige Süße, dunkle/eingelegte Früchte, Malz, Malzzucker, dunkles Karamell, Trockenfrüchte, dezente Hopfenaromen, leichte Röstaromen, angenehme würzig-fruchtige Bitterkeit; frischer Körper, leichte malzige Süße, Malz, etwas Malzzucker, Getreide, Karamell, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, dezente Hopfennoten, angenehme Würze, mineralisch; angenehmer fruchtig-würziger Nachgang
330ml Flasche. Klar und dunkelbraun mit minimaler Schaumkrone. Sehr malzig mit feinen Röstaromen und Karamellnoten. Durchschnittlicher Körper.
Pours a dark copper color. Malty toasty bready caramely aroma with light fruits.
Dark small white head. Chcolate, roasted malt. Finish a bit watery A bit too sweet for my taste, least convincing of the 3 beers I had from this brewery.

08-Jan-10 (500-ml bottle: Purchased 30-Dec-09 for $2.79 at Holiday Wine Cellar in Escondido, CA) Aside from being slighlty lower in alcohol than the style calls for, this drinks very much like a doppelbock. Its sweet and very malty nose is loaded with chocolate, dark toast, and raisins. Deeply malty and very sweet on the palate, the beer offers a lot of chocolate, plus cocoa, prune, earth, brown sugar, dark toast, and lightly bitter roast. Full-bodied, almost syrupy on the palate, and fairly cloying after awhile. Carbonation is light-medium. Rich, medium-brown and ruddy tinted through the center with a golden edge and perfect clarity. The tan head pours rather small, barely peaking at a quarter-inch, before settling to a thin ring. Very yummy, but a bit too sweet, and it seems that this is a doppelbock with a lower attentuation level, hence the excessive sweetness and lower ABV.
Süßlicher, dunkel malziger Antrunk. Noten von Bitterschokolade, geringfügig bitter, rund. Würzig malziger Nachhall, weich. Gelungen. 9/9/10/10/10/10

330ml bottle (ALEhouse, Riga) Metallic caramel first, later husky grains, even later milky. Slightly watery body, caramel, tastes like it’s strong. Finish a bit papery. A little bit of wallpaper paste. Deep down I like the caramel, but it’s not a good bock.
330ml bottle. Clear copper color. No head. Caramel, sweet, minerals, candy in aroma. Caramel, malty, mild alcohol, fake hops, grainy notes in taste. Feels watery.

Pours dark, deep copper reddish, clear, beige medium, fast cap, no lasing. On nose toasted malt with deep touch of caramel sweetness. Taste - sweet with bitter notes of darker malt, a minimal sour @ the end. Lively carbanated, medium+ bodied, thick-slick texture, long toasted bitter finish. Aftertaste - floury bitter. Tasty malt oriented German dark brew, I still like those too.

Bottle share by Bob, pours a muddy brown/tea color with a very thin rim of head. Aroma of toffee, caramel, malt, and some dark fruit. Taste is some dark fruit and light caramel, finishes with some sweet malt and light bitter.
Gift from Simontomlinson. Clear copper appearance. Aroma is bitter, roasted, caramel and malt. Flavour is nutty, roasted, malt, hops and sweet.

Creamy off white head left a spotty cover on a translucent pale copper coloured still body. Fruity aroma with tea, pepper & spices. Medium bodied, soft the palate well carbonated back & cloying aft. Slightly hop forward tastes, fruity, tangy, berry, tea & herbal. Pleasant & easy drinking.

04Jul2019 Bitter grain malts, wet straw, grass, floral notes, light stone and citrus fruits. Clear gold, medium, creamy, white head. Light bitter. More bitter grain malts, wet straw, floral notes, citrus fruits, orange peel, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Boring. Bottle from Tesco Extra.
Clear golden color with off-white head. Aroma has caramel, hay and malt. Taste is malty sweet with long somewhat bitter aftertaste. Flavors of caramel, malt and hay.

Bottle in Fort William, Scotland. Golden pour with generous white head. Soft hoppy aroma, bit fruity. Taste moderate sweet, with a mild hopbitter aftertaste. Like most of British IPA's: this is hardly an IPA to me; too sweet, too little hops. Instead of using 7 malts, start using 7 hops :-) ...
The aroma is strong. Flowers, hops. Taste Malt with Peel and Flowers The finish is tart with bitterness.

(Cask by gravity at Bree Louise, Euston, London, 16 Apr 2009) Pale golden colour with brief, white head. Fruity, hoppy nose with grass, citrus peel and citrussy hops. Fruity, hoppy taste with notes of lemon, grass and generous doses of fresh hops. Light body, fairly dry. Fresh, hoppy and nice golden ale.
Cask @ 3 Judges. Dark yellow colour, small disappearing white head. Aroma of citric hops and sweet malts. Flavour has lemonade hops. Sweet finish.
Cask/pressure at Bow Bar, Edinburgh 13 Nov 08. Pale golden colored. A small white head. Aroma of citrus. Flavor is dry grapefruit. Dry bitter finish.
rbesg07, cask at the abbotsford, edinburgh. pale golden with a light white head, lemonade ice block aroma, slightly grassy with hints of apple peel and a good amount of bitterness

A half pint of this one on cask was served by air pressure dispense at The Bow Bar in Edinburgh where we had a good drinking session early on a Thursday afternoon. Shining golden body. Filmy bubbly head. Floral smell. Succulent fruits in flavour with a nice hop bitterness support. Dry palate. Well bodied for the low ABV strength [13.11.2008].

Cask at the New Barrack Tavern, Sheffield, South Yorks, 16-08-08 Almost straw coloured beer with white soft ice cream like head. Little bit thin on first taste, but there was a nice streaky bitterness that started to show and flex its muscles the further down this beer you got, some malts and fruit also, good beer, and a very nice pub with really friendly landlady and landlord.

Cask at Abbostford, Edinburgh. A golden beer with a slight haze under a thin lazing off-white head. The aroma is sweet with flowery hoppy notes. The flavor is sweet with light notes of malt and notes of flowery hops, elderberryflowers, and grass, leading to a dry and nicely bitter finish. The body is thin.

A cask ale for the hopheads this one. A flowery, peppery, spicy and very mineral golden ale. Clear and wearing a fair white head that slowly fades. Interesting palate has a rather crisp bite for a cask offering. Floral and efficient cutting bitter finish. Light limey and watermelon-like salted cracker notes. Good stuff.
Cask (Peterborough BF 2007) Sweet grapefruity citrus aroma. Well balanced taste - hoppy but not excessively so.
Cask in Glasgow. An outstanding bitter, just the beer if you really love hops. Flowery, dry, refreshing. Too extreme for some, I suppose.

column1: Titanic Brewing Stumbling Bee Honey Amber
column5: Almost no aroma. Brownish. The beer is better than the aroma. Flavor is sweet but at the right amount and the honey gives is a little bite that’s nice.

column1: Titanic Brewing Stumbling Bee Honey Amber
column5: chewy, sweet malty, the best beer I had at Titanic. Biggest body, yet very smooth. A lot Like Killinas but slightly thicker. A good beer to chug a few of.

column1: Titanic Brewing Stumbling Bee Honey Amber
column5: Pours clear amber with white head. Faint aroma of caramel, bread and hops. Similar flavors.Thin body with moderate carbonation. Average.

column1: Titanic Brewing Stumbling Bee Honey Amber
column5: Clear amber gold with thick, off-white head and some lacing. Mild, slightly bready aroma but not aromatic. Honey is not pronounced. Thin and quaffable. Very slight honey kiss at the back of the palate but thankfully not sweet. Lightly bready. Quite nice but thin.

column1: Titanic Brewing Stumbling Bee Honey Amber
column5: Light amber colour. Light aroma is vaguely malty. Cracker-y bland amber with light honey finish. Crisp, clean. Not too interesting but well-made.

column1: Titanic Brewing Stumbling Bee Honey Amber
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours clear copper with full thick off white head. The aroma is mild concealing hints of sweetness and malts. The taste is honey mixed with sweet malts that both grow in strength to the point of being moderately bold. Into the finish the malt roastiness becomes very nice adding welcomed interest.

column1: Titanic Brewing Stumbling Bee Honey Amber
column5: Tap. Nice looking hazy amber color with pillowed head. Not too much going on off the nose, light bready notes. Sweet honey is apparent. Smoothed almost syrupy body.

column1: Titanic Brewing Stumbling Bee Honey Amber
column5: on tap-pours a light tan head and gold color. Aroma is ??? Taste is honey, sweet medium/light malt. Mild carbonation.
Slušné pivko celkem, pøevažuje sladové tìlo a lehká chmelová hoøkost, lehce nasládlá chu,ovšem pìna po nalití rychle mizí. 58%
