Lane w knajpie w Brnie. Kolor ciemnoz³oty, spora piana, ale szybko opada. Przyjemny s³odowy aromat. Podobnie przyjemnie siê pije, dobry pilsner.

from bottle. A bit more alcohol than standard Czech beers, not that this is an endorsement. Frothy as poured into a glass but nothing to write home about. Fair solid representative of this type (14 degrees Balling) but nothing special. Drinkable, better than many average Czech beers but that´s about it. Not something I would go out of my way for.

From Damian Bottle Shop, Bratislava, 0,5l bottle, BBD: 08.02.16. Pours clear golden liquid, medium frothy white head, Aroma: sweet, malty, grainy, light tar, light caramel, Taste: light to medium sweet, medium bitter, light to medium sour, malty, grainy, herbal, harsh bitter, astringent, Palate: light to medium body, average carbonation, slick mouthfeel, medium long astringent finish, Overall: did not really enjoyed. grainy, astringent, bit sour.
F¾aša 500 ml z pivotéky v Nitre. Zlatožltá farba, jemná vysoká pena, aróma chme¾u a sladu. Nižšia rezkos, výrazne sladová chu s horkastým pozadím. V zložení cukor.

Bottle with 6.0 ABV. Golden colour, clear, rocky head that does not stay long, almost no lacing. Aroma is heavy malty - not very pleasant, a bit of herbal hops, a bit of alcohol. Light bitterness. Medium body, average carbonation. Boring.

Look; off white head and clear golden body. Aroma; good oily malts, fruity hops, flowers, meadow, dough, bread, buns. Taste; very juicy fruity malts blended with leafy hops, notes of yellow apples, butter on bread, buns, sweet-butterscotch. Soft carbonation and good body. Finishing in a fruity soft way, only faint notes that shows this is 1% stronger than usually. Good brew. Priceworthy, also after 2007-2009. [50cl brown bottle 5.8%abv BB08-06-2015. Won prices in 2007 2008 2009 label says. Pivarium . T@Ferie2015]

Vycap Richtar Jakub. Tmavsia zlata farba, biela husta pena. Vona sladova, jemne kvetinova a sladka. Chut sladka, sladova, stredne plne telo, slaba nasytenost. V pozadi chmelova dochut. Celkom vyvazene pivo.
Bottle from Cesky Brod , CZ , Clear golden color with smaller but lasting head , Malt,fruity,grassy and light alcohol aroma , Sweet taste with dry finish , Full body , Soft carbon , Pretty good.

Clear amber body with high creamy head. Aroma is light malty, clean. Taste has high malty sweetness with low earthy bitterness. Balanced to the sweet side with fruity notes. Body is full, medium carbonation.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draft - pours pale yellow with white head. Nose is floral. Flavor adds citrus. Light. Tasty for a style I tend to avoid.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: On tap. Golden/amber pour with a thin white top. Scent is grains and sweet fruit. Taste is weak sweet malts. Thin

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: Typical aroma and appearance for the style. The flavor was the odd thing. It had a start of a hefeweizen - the banana notes. That quickly fades and then a bit of malt finishes it. Just odd.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery. Very light sweet aroma with a bit of dactyl and mild hops. Medium dull amber clear with thin white head. Medium watery body with medium carbonation. Starts medium sweet with diacetyl, apples, and light sweet pale malt. Mild bitter finish, kind of dull with neutral fruity character. Meh.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: Pours a golden yellow color with a white head. Aroma is fruity, honey, and sugary. Flavor is fruity, grain, some honey, and a bitter astringent spicy finish.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: Rating 1051. Had on tap at the brewery in Hilton Head Island South Carolina. Hazy copper with a thin white rim of a head that was quickly discipating. Nose is sweet, grainey and thin. Taste is tangy, tart with some unripe lemon with a very present grain and earth feel to it. Pretty Good and very drinkable.
Cask Handpump at the Sun Inn, Macclesfield 08/05/2004 Golden amber coloured floral and fruity with a lasting hop finish.
Counting house, wetherspoons beer fest. Aroma is minimal but biscuit sweet honey and grassy hop. Taste is simialr with quite a bit of pale malts and grassy bittering hop.

Cask conditioned - handpump - JDW Northampton. A copper coloured beer with a whitish head and lace. The aroma is malty with hints of grass also. The taste is fialy nice and balanced with some good earthy grassy flavours.

Cask conditioned at The Drayton Beer Fest ’07. Clouded orange with no head. Green and opened too early and too warm, unfortunately a common theme at this festival. Some lasting bitterness with late hop note, thin malt.
Bottle. Backlog rating from bottle collection and historic scoring. Source not recorded. No tasting notes kept, just rating.

Cask Pint at Wibbas Down (JDW), Wimbledon, London in Feb 2010 - Orangey Amber in colour. Fruity; citrus-orange. Hoppy; slightly earthy hops. Malty; lightly toasty malts, some caramel, hint of chocolate. Quite tasty. Very drinkable. (2010-02)
Tried at the Three Horseshoes, Waddington. Ruby brown colour with a cream coloured head. Toffee and light coffee aroma. Fruity sweet taste.

Cask at the Alehouse, Reading. Reddish chestnut with a tight cream head; yeasty aroma with some fruit; soft and fruity in the mouth, with some malty carmael; and a very dry, yeasty and lightly bitter finish.

Cask at Baxter’s Court, JDW, London. Pours clear, dark gold with a foamy, white head. Toasty malt nose, some bread. Light sweet flavor with some leafy hops, toasty bread, light dirt, hints of dry toffee. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Light dry finish with more toasty bread, modest grain, dirt, moderate dry leafy bitterness. OK. Basic.

On tap @ the Haymarket. Pours a toffee brown with a nice creamy head. The nose is quite tight, giving off gentle toffee and resin notes. The taste is more of the same and the toffee for me is just missing that biscuity note. The palate is medium bodied and textured with a dry but not wholly refreshing finish. Overall, a good demonstration of the style (some sort of dry bitter) but it lacks generosity on the palate.
Cask by handpump at Drum & Monkey, Glasgow (1 Nov 12) - hazy amber brown, thin off-white head, malty aroma, caramel, nutty, herbal, bitter, malty aftertaste
In cask al Market Porter, Londra, una bitter un pochino scarica che risulta troppo piatta al palato

Cask hanpull at the old buttermarket Canterbury. Mid brown amber colour with thin lasting head from a sparkler. Its a ok bitter which is what I expect from this brewery. Touch of animal fat on the flavour. Aroma is not great with a touch of too much acidity and rest of flavour has a bit of that too. Touch of nuttiness . A bit too much like licking the i.side of a nut shell to me. Odd

Tasted this in The Esquire House, Glasgow in February 2010. Cask, handpump dispense. Crystal clear copper in colour with a thin white head. Slight hint of fresh green apple in the short aroma. Pale malts give a fiery maltloaf base with tart redcurrant fruit and toffee apple notes. Slight whiff of dusty hops gives a dry aftertaste in the balanced bitter sweet finish. An ok session bitter.
On tap at brewpub, a orange look to it with a a malty sweetness that is hard to descibe,not sure how strong but it was a different type of beer for me.CHEERS!

This is the first commercial brew of the new assistant brewer, and it’s not a bad effort. I was taken aback somewhat by the appearance, an orange bodied altbier. The head was okay and the lacing was constant. The aroma seem to be a bit too caramelly, but that faded in the flavor. It tasted of sweet malt with pepper and a floral/grassy bitterness that lasted into the finish. Not bad. Shoreline Brewery, Michigan City, IN

Draught sample at the brewpub, June 19 2007. Medium translucent amber, bit head, no lacing...lightly spicy aroma, noble hops present if muted, a touch of banana and clove? is this a hefeweizen or an altbier?.....dry, faintly fruity body, touch of caramel, light grassy hops, bit of mushy banana....light chalky finish. Hmmm, was this an example of different beer/same name? Except I had this just a couple of days (apparently) after the last reviewer. Heck I dunno, but it was so average I really don’t care either.

On tap at the brewery. Copper hue, but served with no head. Lots of hops here. Clean hop aromas, but not much malt character. Same with the flavor. Highly carbonated. They even admitted to me that it didn’t turn out the way they planned. Oh well. Give another go, and I’ll revisit this.
500ml bottle in 2012. Lightly hazy amber with a white head. Aroma of straw, grain and raisins. Malty flavour, with some fruity notes.
Pours golden with a substantial head. Hay on the nose and a fresh mouthfeel with a long, bitter finish.

500ml bottle. Poured a slightly hazy medium amber colour with a mostly lasting frothy white head. The aroma is grainy malt, gluey, cardboard, hay. The flavour is moderate bitter sweet, with a smooth, yeasty, light, malty, floral hop bitter palate. Medium to light bodied with soft carbonation.
Decent blonde ale, refreshing, summer golden ale, I would buy again as it's a decent ale
500ml bottle. Hate the branding! Sweet lemon aroma with biscuit malts. Same on the taste. Okay beer for refreshment, shit branding.
Just slightly darker than a lager, this one smells and tastes like a cheap, weak bitter. It might be a decent thirst-quencher in the summer, but I can envision no other use for it.

Botella de 500ml servida en pinta tulipán. Color dorada con una corona de espuma blanca ligera más o menos estable. Su aroma es fresco, cítrico y floral. Su sabor es suave y refrescante, predominantemente cítrico y a lespecies, con sutiles notas a granos ligeramente horneados. Su cuerpo es ligero con carbonatación media.
50cl bottle. Medium white head. Hazy golden pour. Slight bitterness. Easy drinking
Slight sour aftertaste. Refreshing with lemon citrus in mouth. Cleansing palate. Cheap from home bargains
Aroma mediocre. Buen color dorado, buena cabeza. Sabor muy maltoso, refrescante. Paladar corto. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask conditioned - handpump - Out Of The Vaults Leicester. A black coloured beer with a beige head and tan lacing. Looking lovely in the glass. The aroma is chocolatey with lightly roasted malts. The taste has chocoalte and a touch of fruity sweetness. Very nice.
Cask conditioned at Drayton Beer Fest ’07. Clouded gold with thin head. Poor thin beer, l;ager type malt with a tea like hop. Some bittersweetness on the finish.
Hazy orange beer with an off-white head. Yeast and light banana aroma. Banana and light citrus flavor with wheat and yeast
Bottle. Cloudy yellow, relatively low head. Somewhat phenolic and dusty aroma. Good bready base, clove, a bit fruit and perfume, almond finish. Relatively light body. Easy drinkable
bottle. Cloudy amber colour, medium-size head. Nothing special to notice, slightly dusty otherwise fruity and slightly yeasty.

(bottle, as Jubelweizen) Cloudy, light-orange colour with a medium-sized foamy white head. Light-sweet, even lighter acidic malty, slightly wheaty nose with banana and citrus, also some light clovy notes.Mild wheaty taste, slightly sweet and fruity (banana); medium-dry, slightly sweet finish with light spicy cloves. Mediocre, low-key Weizen.

Bottle: Hazy, quite firm, slowly collapsing white head; moderate nose: wheat, bananas and cloves with shy citrus fruit in the background; moderate sweetish, slightly sourish flavour, light- to medium-bodied, a bit fizzy; not too sweet wheaty-fruity finish with the faintest tartness in the aftertaste. A good, but not overwhelming Weizen..........

Hand-pulled pint in a Wetherspoon's pub on Mutley Plain, Plymouth; 2nd Nov 2019. Clear and clean golden body, white crown on top. Decent blend with a good malty base for the hops to play with. Pleasant easy drinking brew.

Cask at The Green Dragon, Leek (JDW) 4.5% ABV. A clear deep golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma of cereal malts, some orange, slight lemon, a hint of honey, a little fruit and subtle herbal hops. Taste of orange, slight lemon, some straw, a little fruit and subtle herbal hops. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A dryish, herbal hop bitterness in the finish. Lightly fruity, citrusy and herbal with sweet, honeyed malts. Standard but decent.

Station bar. Served again at warmed than room temp. This beer i have no doubt is good however the condition and way it was served made it near unfinishable. Sweet pale malts, hints of acidic ginger. Just far far too warm.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Criterion Leicester. A golden coloured beer with a white head and lacing. The aroma is quite wheaty and crunchy. The taste is the same. Not particularly hoppy but a nice toasty flavour.

Draught. Short, in fact very short head for a wheat beer. Hazy yellow body. More lemon than banana aroma. Heavily carbonated flavor of oranges and coriander. Short aftertaste. General impression: Is this a soda water?

Tap @ YNWA. A nice-looking pale yellow with a thin film head. Aroma is practically non-existent. Mouthfeel is equally watery. Flavour contains some lemons, a touch of maltiness and a little coriander. Very high carbonation. Dull, and unexiting.
33cl bottle from the brewery. A clear pale golden beer with white head. aroma of mild grainy malt, straw, moderate sweet malt. taste of straw, grainy malt, mild fruity malt, moderate bitterness.
Golden color, quite stable white head. Grassy-grainy nose, light bodied, light bitter flavour.

It’s golden, sliiightly hazy, and it has a white head. The aroma has notes of malt, brad and fruit! The flavor has a light sweetness and notes of bread, malt, fruit and a touch of dry straw in the finish - very well balanced!

Botle, thanks pivnizub. Fat fruity nose. Hazy golden, no head. Chewy, fat fruity malt body, a bit citrus, restrained hops. Sweet sugary aftertaste, slightly cloying. A good meal but not terribly exiting.

Bottle: Pale golden to golden, rather quickly diminishing white head; strawy, a bit cardboardy and worty nose; light to moderate sweetish-bitter flavour, a bit fizzy; sweetish-worty finish with some tired umbels in the aftertaste. Clean, but disappointing........

(33cl bottle) Clear, pale golden colour with a medium-sized foamy white head. Sweet and subtle fruity malty and strawy nose with shy herbal notes. Light-sweet flavour, strawy malty and slightly chalky taste with a faint fruity touch, light to medium bodied with a calm carbonation; moderately dry and slightly sweet finish with a very discreet herbal hoppy notes. Archetypical Helles (22.07.08).

Waldquel is a little brewery in a tiny village in the Bavarian Forest. Bottle, bought at the brewery. Lovely golden yellow colour, large head. Full-bodied with interesting malt and hop flavour: the hops remind me of medicinal herbs.

column2: West Palm Beach, Florida, United States
column5: on tap-pours a thin creamy white head that laces and hazy yellow color. Aroma is wheat/grapefruit, faint rock candy, banana. Taste is light grain, flat hops bite. Dry. Light body. Good effervescence. Occasional.

column2: Locations in Ogden and Layton, Utah, United States
column5: on tap-pours a disappearing off white head and slightly hazy gold color. Aroma is faint, sweet. Taste is sweet grain/medium malt, secondary hops-tangy. OK carbonation.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Erik the Red
column5: Imperial pint served draft at the brewpub. Pours a fairly transparent coppery red hue with small offwhite head. Aromas of caramel malt, some biscuity presence dominates with an inkling of hops. Taste is a lighter caramel, toffee, biscuity, toasty malt body but also light on the palate and sessionable. A bit of the bitterness on the backend is not a major player, but compliments well. A touch of lemon and spice. Delicate. A sessioner.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Erik the Red
column5: Cask at the pub. Pours a dark reddish amber with a bubbly soapy off-white head. Pine and grapefruity hop aroma. Flavor is dryly hoppy with little malt presence, fairly dry overall. Oily creamy cask feel with a mild lingering bitterness. Earlier Rating: 2/23/2008 Total Score: 3 Clear reddish brown thin foamy off white head. Slightly malty aroma taste is a bit sticky sweer malt, some roast a little nice lingeribg bitterness. Light body.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Erik the Red
column5: Cask at RBY. Pours a nice red/amber with a shaving foam offwhite head. Nose is mild, a touch of spice and lovely malts. Muted floral hops on the taste with a creamy, almost ESB quality to the structure. Finishes dry and keeps you wanting more. Pretty nice Amber.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Erik the Red
column5: Pours red with an off white head. Mild aroma, some caramel. I wasn’t expecting a crazy beer, but it was a well done amber. Good malt flavor with a little hop balance.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Erik the Red
column5: Sample at Yorktown RB bar. Poured a fairly clarified, light walnut color, with a bubbly, off white head, and light lacing. The aroma was toasty, with some caramel sweetness. The flavor added some medium, resiny bitterness to balance it off. Decent and drinkable.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Erik the Red
column5: On tap at Rock Bottom Yorktown. Rock Bottom Yorktown Erik the Red is a hazy, light mahogany red color with a small off-white head. The aroma is very faint and the flavor is full of bland malts and a bit of bitterness. This is very mediocre.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Erik the Red
column5: I was only expecting an ok beer, and thats pretty much what I got. Kind of bland but very drinkable, not even too great among ambers. Always better stuff available - I have to think this one is for the masses who go in looking for something like Sam Adams lager.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Erik the Red
column5: on tap at RB Yorktown, pours cloudy red-brown with white head. a spicy hop nose with toffee notes. flavor notes of toasted biscuit, caramel, spicy hops. tasty. I also sampled this on cask, even though it was served at room temp, i gave it the same score.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Erik the Red
column5: On tap at RB – Yorktown. Poured reddish-caramel with a short cap of looser beige head. The aroma picked up semi-sweet caramel and red wheat with nice floral and fruity hops as accent pieces.. simple and solid. This was quite tasty.. toasted, almost oaked caramel with light, complimentary pine bitterness at the edges.. warmth brought out an enjoyable medium-skinned fruity bouquet. Just shy of medium-bodied with nice balance on the palate.. a touch grainy.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Erik the Red
column5: Sampler from cask. Amber in color like a small kerosene lantern’s light. I first catch a bit of English ale and light fruit here. This pour is almost still, and very warming. Toffee malts, a nice fruity ale character. I’m going to imagine this is what a CAMRA-approved cask ale is like until such time as I can get to England.

Mug Club draft at RB. Inviting light brown color, a little like iced tea except for the thin, clingy white foam up top. Clean, malty beer smell with light hop notes. Taste is light, with toasty malts. Hops are close to a milder APA, but plenty of Noble-ity to go along with it. Unless I can have one head-to-head with an Anchor Steam, I’d say this is a fine version of the style.

This has a deep golden, nearly amber body with an off-white head that leaves a trail of lace behind it. It has an aroma of light caramel, a non-offensive touch of corn, and a light earthy, herbal hoppiness. Very lively in the mouth, a touch of grain is added to the flavor and the hops become more herb-like, almost like tea. The finish is crisp and well balanced. Tim brewed a good one for the warm days ahead. Rock Bottom Yorktown, Lombard, IL

NABA 08’: Pours a pale yellow color with white head. The nose is thin with a touch of hops and some toasty malt. The flavor is balanced, not too husky or brash, smooth clean toasty malt notes and a light noble hop note accenting the back. The finish is clean. Good but certainly not flavorful.
on tap-pours a white head and slightly hazy yellow color. Aroma is grain. Taste is grain-some sweetness, secondary light hops (halletaur?) nice light beer. OK carbonation.

Big fluffy and chunky white head that drops like I’ve never seen a head drop before. No lacing. Absolute minimum collar. Left behind a very pretty crystal clear straw colored brew. Nose is earthy hops and toasted bread. Sage and grassy herbs mixed with pale malts and Belgian candy sugar.. bubblegum and orange peel. Palate is tropical fruits and spicy hops.. American pale malts and Belgian esters are the finish. Medium/large body with a big bubble carbonation. Weird lingering estery flavors... quite a bit too sweet, but still pretty tasty... I can’t get past the finish.
"malty and sweet up front, hops in the throat after. not bad for their first bottled belgian. not my favorite style, but this is one of the better ones I’ve tried. not unfocused...just complex."
Aroma of clove, slight ginger and delicious funk. Pours ...golden with film. Taste is smooth and spicy with great cloves. Delicious and great.
22 oz. Bomber. Nice head and aroma. I had this on tap at the brewery when it came out. It was really good. I found a bomber of it and thought i would try it again. Very nice strong ale.

22oz bottle. Poured a medium and slightly hazy golden color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of some fruits, wet hay, and spices. Tastes of spices, fruity, and some lighter citrus. This one actually grew on me more and more as I drank it. Citrus (oranges) came out more too.

Bottle. Poured a slightly hazy light orange color. The white head reduced relatively quickly to a thin film. Fruity nose with apricot, vanilla, and subdued pineapple. There was also a whiff of hay. Medium bodied and sweet with moderate carbonation. The alcohol was noticeable. I tasted toasted coconut, apricot, and vanilla. A little odd, but not bad.
Tap @ Toronado (rating from 2007 notes). A golden color with a white head. A spiced, light fruit and sweet candy malt aroma. Peppery and crisp with a nice bite at the finish.

Deschutes Brewery--Anniversary Golden Ale--Bond Street Series--Belgian Stlyle--Nineteenth Year--2007 Release--22 oz. Bottle--8.70% ABV--60 IBU’s. 4.75 / 5.0. Golden Ale--Imperial. Thin lacy head. Clear bright gold color. Aromatic rich coriander hop spice front. Crisp dry sweet mild creamy mellow banana citrus wheat caramel subtle malt body. Delicious sweet Belgian spice HOPPY end. Sampled 6/18/2007

22 oz Bottle. Pours a deep golden with a white head. Leaves nice lacing. Aroma of sweetness, citrus, slight spice. Taste fruity, citrusy, alcohol is there, slightly off. Palate is crisp with an oily finish. Probably would have been better a year ago.

Deep gold with a white head that holds on. Perfume aroma. Very Belgian. This has a big thick mouth flavor in a belgian-looking beer. Closer to a hopped Tripel. Huge finishing sweetness. Lemons and oranges at finish. Outstanding. 2007 version, is just now coming into its prime. A must-age.
Cask @ Drink? Hebden Bridge. Clear golden with a creamy-smooth head. Crisp and hoppy, it's very nice in the palate.
Cask. Golden ale with a thin white head. Malty lemon nose. Taste is lemony sherbert. Straightforward zing taste. Punchy.
Cask at North Bar Leeds. hazy golden yellow color, white head. Aroma of lightly spiced hay. Taste is lightly dusty straw. OK.

Cask @ The Salopian Bar, Shrewsbury. Pours clear-ish amber, creamy head. Aroma is pale malts. Taste is grainy, pale malts, smooth pillowy mouthfeel. Not getting much in the way of citrus, but it’s decent enough.

On cask at Hop Inn, Newcastle Under Lyme - Hazy gold with slight head. Big fruity aroma, peachy then just a touch grainy, creamy on drinking. The hops show through, quite citrusy, sharp, the body remains a touch thin perhaps but still pretty drinkable.

On cask at Congress, Longton. Pours pale golden with white foam head. Maybe I’m a little bored of this type of ale at this time of year. Hoppy and light, refreshing but uninteresting. Abbeydale’s golden beers are usually better than this one.

Cask, handpump at The Hop Pole, Aylesbury, Bucks, 01.08.11 Pours pale gold with a slim white head. Nice citrus wafting up from this. There is a tangy citrus in the mouth, lemony, pithiness, good bitterness throughout, its a very good beer in very good nick. A7 A4 T7 P4 Ov14 3.7

&#40Cask at Dispensary, Liverpool, 20 July 2009&#41 Golden yellow colour with firm, white head. Fruity, hoppy nose with notes of garpefruit, lemon peel and freshly cut grass. Fruity, hoppy taste with fresh grass, lemon, grapefruit and a slightly soapy, citrussy finish. Light body, but with a good hop character. Tasty and refreshing.

Cask at The Waters Green Tavern, Macclesfield. Very pale yellow gold with thin white head. Very hoppy, little citrus and a dry bitter finish. My mate who loves a hoppy beer was raving about it, it was just quite tasty in my eyes.

1. Cask Stillage at Boundary, Audenshaw 18/06/2004 2. Cask Handpump at Bitter Suite, Preston 16/06/2007 Hoppy slightly citrus aroma. Clear golden coloured fruity and hoppy with some dryness and bitterness in a crisp finish.
Wow, this one! Another country with a lot of Inbev-crap, but what a crap! Thank you for reading.
Tap. Clear golden color. Small white head, stays. Almost no aroma. So watery and tasteless. Thank Satan its not offensive just watery.
Pours gold with a thick white head, quite carbonated with a hoppy taste and a relatively bitter finish.
Pale yellow, slightly golden lager with no head. Has a small aroma, not a lot of flavour but is crisp.

Keg at Dry Dock, Leeds. Pours a straw colour, decent pillowy head. Aroma is stagnant, skunky, very very faint hops. Taste is carbonated water with a small hop hint and a creaminess at the end. Watery body, finish is mercifully short. Taste isn’t offensive as such, but the aroma really is. This is truly terrible. I’d rather drink my own piss. Actually, I’d rather drink Chris de Burgh’s piss. Get me a doctor. UPDATE: Scratch that thing about the taste not being offensive. Drank a big gulp to get rid of it, horrible soapy aftertaste, made me almost nauseous. This is true crap.
Keg @ Charles XII, York. Pale gold. Thin white head. Fruit, corn, wheat, lager malt, hops. Fairly sweet for a lager. Crisp, refreshing, clean dry finish.

Keg Goose On Two Streets Northampton. A light golden beer with a whitish head and lacing. A cold, quick and dirty lager which has no finish and smells of ice. There’s not even a lagerish chemical kick to this. It actually tastes like water. Seriously. This is for people who don’t even like lager.
[Keg at Great Expectations, Reading] Pale gold, negligible white head, slight fizz. Thin, watery, sweet, some butter, very bland indeed.

Can. Clear yellow colour, medium short white bubbly head. Weak hay aroma. Thin mouthfeel. Quite mild flavour of something hay hoppish with a mild bitterness towards the finish. Quite thin but drinkable.
Can from Sainsbury’s. Poured a light gold colour with a thick white head. No aroma as such, the taste is very watery, nothing to report.
33cl, exclusive brewery, beer with anis, from WBF2007, not balanced, cloudy, nearly no head, nothing special
Bottle, 33 cl. (from KBW) A wrong combination. Golden color, no head. Aroma is anis an a bit hops. Even i not like anis. Medium body. Taste is not bad but there is always anis and a light bitterness.

Wow it says pils and it mentioned anis. My first impression of smell was Orange and later sure it was anis. Although i do not like anis. This beer has a very speial and complex tast. For a low alcohol beer this is fantastic. The taste of anis is there but still it is smooth
This is easily my favorite of the Bonaventure beers I had today. Plenty of hops in the first whiff and the first sip. A nice beer, doesn’t seem heavy. Should be a regular on tap.
had this at belmont and bonaventure. Quite enjoyed it both times. would have it agaiin
Clear amber color/ tan head. Nice hoppy pine, floral aromas. medium body. Mildly bitter pine hop flavors with roasted nuts, caramel sweetness.
On tap at the brewery. Pours with a hazy amber body and a ring. Aroma of hops. Mostly pine and a slight earthy note. Taste is hops, citrus, pine and caramel. Fizzy and dry mouthfeel.
On tap. Pours amber-orange. Fresh citrus hop aroma with a distinct leafy component. Falvor has lemonade, caramel malt sweetness, and herbal hops. Pretty solid, certainly not a shy beer.
On tap at Tustin Brewing’s 13th Aniversary party, dark gold pour is mildly flavored. This struck me more as a session ale

on draft at brewery, consumed on 11/12/07. Not as dark as their amber ale, this beer is a little on the orange/copper side. A resiny hop character greets the nose. Very well-balanced malt/hops flavor, neither overpowering nor overwhelmed. Slightly astringent aftertaste where hops linger on the palate. Not as hoppy as the name would leave you to believe, though hoppier than most red ales I have had.

Had this one a while back and forgot to rate it. I am pretty sure it is an American Strong Ale. It had a pretty strong citrus aroma. Poured a dark red. Flavor was pretty much grapefruit and pine with some mild toffee malt flavor. Resiny and thick. This one kind of reminded me of Arrogant Bastard in a smaller sense. This was a nice special beer, and I wanted to get a growler of it, but got the Strawberry Blonde because the old lady wanted a fruit beer.

column1: Bluegrass Bourbon Barrel Russian Imperial Porter
column5: Growler from Party Town from notes. Pours dark brown to black in color with a thin beige film. The aroma and flavor have chocolate, bourbon, dark fruits, vanilla, hints of wood, light roast, these barrel aged beers used to be so good from these guys.

column1: Bluegrass Bourbon Barrel Russian Imperial Porter
column5: Draft @ FoBAB 2009, Chicago, IL. Pours a dark brown black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and bourbon barrel aroma with hints of vanilla. Has a roasted malty chocolate flavor with weak hints of licorice and hints of bourbon and vanilla. Has a roasted malty chocolate and bourbon barrel vanilla finish.

column1: Bluegrass Bourbon Barrel Russian Imperial Porter
column5: Barrel aged aroma. Brown black color. Mellowed roastiness. Lightly sweet. Lots of hop bitterness. at toncatchers tasting.

column1: Bluegrass Bourbon Barrel Russian Imperial Porter
column5: Poured an opaque black color with a small, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malts, smoke, bakers chocolate, coffee, vanilla, and bourbon. Taste of roasted malts, dark chocolate, some smoke, vanilla, bourbon, and light alcohol in the finish.

column1: Bluegrass Bourbon Barrel Russian Imperial Porter
column5: Thanks to hopdog. Pours a deep black with some amber notes and a medium creamy tan head. Aroma of vanilla, chocolate, dark fruits, light bourbon, nuts, tobacco and caramel. Flavor of the same. Smooth and nicely balanced bourbon character.

column1: Bluegrass Bourbon Barrel Russian Imperial Porter
column5: Growler acquired in trade with alexsdad06 (thanks!). Poured a dark, dark brown (almost black color) with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of chocolate, roast, bourbon, stronger woodiness, and some vanilla. Tastes of the same stronger woodiness, bourbon, vanilla, some dark fruitiness, and roast. Dark fruits came out more as this warmed up. The bourbon was a little stronger in the tastes where the aromas had a stronger woodiness. Never would have guessed 11% - hidden with a nice and smooth/creamy body.

column1: Bluegrass Bourbon Barrel Russian Imperial Porter
column5: T3 tasting. Thought this was a stout until I saw the bottle. Dark brown leaning to black with red tints. Tan head to ring and oil slick. Chocolate, caramel, raisins and booze. Vanilla and creamy. Liked this one a lot.

column1: Bluegrass Bourbon Barrel Russian Imperial Porter
column5: Served from a bottle at toncatchers T3 tasting! Thanks to stefanje, lagunitasfan, weeheavysd, fordest, wetherel, alohac and of course toncatcher for suppling the house and grub. Decent BB IS. I thought it had just a little too much bourbon. Stinging burning down the throat. Still decent.

column1: Bluegrass Bourbon Barrel Russian Imperial Porter
column5: Growler courtesy of WeeHeavy at T3. A brown/black pour with a small tan head. The nose is strong with bourbon. The taste shows more bourbon and some sweet dark roasted malts. The finish is long and dry. The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. Overall: Now this is a bourbon barrel aged beer!

column1: Bluegrass Bourbon Barrel Russian Imperial Porter
column5: 2nd actual beer at the TTaT, ticker tasting at toncatcher’s. Growler from Alexsdad06 via trade. Damn this is good. Pours black with 1 finger tan head. Nose is sweet and malty and bourbony. Taste is sweet and malty rich bourbon quite good, and rich and very smooth.

column1: Cascade Lakes Bite of Bend Bitter
column5: Tap at Cascade Lakes Lodge pours out a amber topped with a off white head. I pick up a little wood and malt.

column1: Cascade Lakes Bite of Bend Bitter
column5: Tap @ Cascade Lakes Lodge: Copper color, nice head and lacing. Nose of husky 2-row, light hops and a bit of chalk. The flavor is unbalanced, dry and a bit malty, thin body, a messed up blonde or something.

column1: Cascade Lakes Bite of Bend Bitter
column5: On tap at the Lodge. Clear light amber with thin sandy head. Light m&lt aroma. Flavor was very bland and slightly woody. Barely maintaing its namesake. Not very bitter. Yawn.

Cold on tap: Pours a hazy copper color with a small ivory head. Aroma is of rich malts, fruit and grass. Taste is of rich malts, flowery hops and fruit with caramel notes. Light bodied and crisp with moderate carbonation. Ending is sweet, malty and fruity.
Bomber. Pours a clear yellow color with a medium white head. A fruity corn and lemon nose. The flavor is sweet corn, pils malt, a bit dirty. OK. A bit sweet and dirty.
Draft. Golden-straw beer with a cream head. Light malt and light spice aroma. Malt and grain flavor with light mineral and spice. Medium bodied. Grain and mineral lingers with spice.
Pours murky yellow with a thin off-white head and a nondescript aroma. There is a light fruity malt flavor with a slightly bitter dry finish.
An almost flourescent yellow with a hint of green to it. A slightly lemony tingle mixes with tinges of metallic grain. A little tart for me. Very husky from the grain and a tiny hint of DMS.

Bottle: &nbsp Pale straw, fairly translucent, moderate sudsy white head, spotty lacing, little to no carbonation. &nbsp Grassy nose, hay, straw, the usual suspects. &nbsp Malty on the tongue, grassy, good bout of sweetness. &nbsp A little dry on the backside, even perhaps a touch of astringency. &nbsp Lingering bright straw and grass. &nbsp Finishes fairly quickly, minor astringency after the finish. &nbsp Decent, not as crisp as others. &nbsp Decent body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Yeah, just needs to be maybe a little more sharp. &nbsp Otherwise, fairly decent.

22 oz bomber courtesy of bvc. Pour is slight chill haze yelloe, almost greenish tinge with a one inch pure white head. Tons of carbonation bubbles floating to the surface. Aroma is soft hay grassiness along with lemon citrus and mildly sweet floral. Fresh and clean, quite inviting. Taste is the nose, hay and grass, floral and lemon, and a really nice Saaz hop brightness. The after taste is crisp and clean. Palate is light bodied, unfiltered with a mineral element in the end. Really nice Pils, thanks for always having your eyes open for these sorts of beers Brandon.

22 oz bought from "Habits" in South Salem. Probably the brightest yellow beer i have seen..bright and crystal clear. Small white head. Pleasing doughy ,bready aromas with a tinge of lemon zest hop. Good Crisp sweet malt flvoured lager..with a hoppy buzz leaving bitterness at the end. Nice palate, crisp and refreshing. A nice lager..very good American lager..but not a pils by any means.

I like a crisp, clean and refreshing pilsner from time to time but it’s just not that exciting of a beer to me. So, as most of you already know, this is where the hedonistic scale doesn’t do justice. Rated to style I would have to increase everything but the palate score. Sweet grainy malt and noble hops in the nose. Light straw color with initial frothy white head that doesn’t persist and leaves slight lacing. Little carbonation visible. Substantial malt sweetness with a good hop presence that lends a long bitter finish. Medium to med. light body with medium carbonation and a smooth and creamy texture. Nice example of a Classic American Pilsner. Still, I think a nice IPA hop-bomb suits me just fine on a hot summer day.

Light yellow/medium straw, fluffy sticky white head. Dry fresh grassy aroma. Very clean, still dry and grassy in the sip, not much in the way of a hoppy finish, though it was a good clean and snappy contrast to the pale malt.
A decent dry aroma. The flavor on this is pretty dry and quite nice, but with just a hint of butter. Certainly what I wanted at the moment anyway.
On the X tap at Brewpub Pours out black topped with a tan head. Looks Great smells like mint. Ok we are doing ok. But then the tast WOW holy mint field. No thanks.

Tap @ Brewpub: Dark black, light tan head and nice lacing. Nose of mint and tobacco, almost like a menthol cigarette, nearly identical. The flavor is fresh and minty, but there’s nothing left of the porter. Finishes with mint, tail of mint, light roasty sweet residue for the mouthfeel. Wow, there’s a crap ton of mint in here. Bonus for the uniqueness, but I couldn’t finish a pint because it was making me noxious from all the mint.

On Tap at the BrewPub. Deep black with a full dense tan head. Aroma is moderately roasty and the mint is tjere as well. Flavor is big time mint. Took me a minute to pehg it...Spearmint. A bit much but interesting. A valiant effort.

On tap at Klub Malych pivovaru in Pilsen.Pours clear slightly hazy golden.Very malty and the hop character isn’t very fresh but a bit spicy and not so fruity as you would expect from a Czech Pilsner.Nothing special...

(bottle) Almost clear, pale golden colour with a mid-sized foamy white head. Slightly sweet and a bit papery malty nose with a medicinal and light flowery hoppy touch. Light-bitter flavour, slim bodied with a lively carbonation. Artificial malty taste with subtle fruity and light flowery notes; slim and slightly tart, shy but again medicinal hoppy finish. Not a great pleasure.

Bottle: Golden, smaller, quite stable head, malty and slightly medical hoppy nose with a touch of bandaid; moderate bitter-sweet flavour, light bodied, not watery, malty base detectable; medical traces or traces of bandaid in the bitter-sweet finish. A mild beer, drinkable, even though the "medical" taste doesn’t make it really attractive.....

I came across this beer by accident, when I got lost in Strakonice trying to find the famous bagpipe festival and asked for directions at a petrol station. Mestanska Desítka (10°) pours pale yellow with a large white head. Malty and fruity, slightly hoppy especially towards the finish. Perhaps a bit thin, but this is a very pleasant desítka.
Flasa. Zlata farba, slaba biela pena. Vona sladova, chlebova, zelezita. Chut sladova, chlebova, opat jemne zelezita dochut. Horkost skoro ziadna.
Prakticky tady pøidávám tento komentáø, jen aby tady nìco bylo, protože zpìtnì dopisuji 900 piv z mého seznamu a asi bych se musel u toho zbláznit.

Aroma; vgtbls, grass, pale malt products. Look; off white vanishing head, clear bright golden body. Taste; cardboard n vgtbls, and finishes cardboard'ish. Feel; thin body, fizzy. Overall; hmmm.... [bt.50cl abv0.5% xp30.11.17 Tasted@Thanxbeeringparty @PivotekaH7] 3221'4
Great beer. Pine apple and bitter. Draft at the bar. Easy drinking and smooth. Apricot and dry aftertaste ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

High, very bubbly and fast-reducing foam. Looking good, light-brown, etalon I would say. Aromas of clove, banana, bread. Taste of cereal, very soft, sweet-sour, with no bitterness, a bit watery.Light body, thin texture, and soft carbonation. In conclusion - drinkable, but a bit tasteless.

Hazy amber with large white head. Aroma is yeast, banana, soft and mild with a slight flowery fresh touch. Taste is soft yeasty sourness with some round fruity accents. Velvety on the tongue but also a bit watery. Well rounded, a bit watery as well. Drinkable! A good smooth and soft example of a Hefeweizen.

0,5 l bottle BB 18.01.15 Aroma: banana, dough, citrus, herbs, cereal / wheat. golden, cloudy, frothy & creamy white foam. medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, slick feel, soft carbonation,
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein trübes goldenes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, fruchtig, bananig. Geschmack hefig, bananig fruchtig, minimal würzig.
Pours golden straw, thin white head. Aroma is yeasty, spicy esters, clove. Taste is fruity, yeasty, light bitter finish, orange peel and banana.
500ml bottle from bierzwerg. Hazy yellow colour with big head. Aroma is yeasty. Flavour is yeast, wheat, quite nice.

Das ist ein Weizen gebraut für den Sommer. Mild, süffig, kaum sauer. Im Mittelteil angenehm hefig, zum Nachgeschmack hin etwas süßer. Könnt im allgemeinen noch etwas geschmacksintensiver sein, trotzdem rundum gelungen. Test vom 11.5.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,11,12,11,6,11 - 11,00

500 ml bottle picked up at Bier Hannes in Frankfurt and then dragged off to Kenya. Pours the normal hazy gold with a huge white head. Aroma is bananas, cloves, and sweet fruit. Taste is fruity bananas, hefe and some other flavors coming through. Palate is mellow and quite nice. A good solid German Hefe.

Interesting! Not traditional! Has a strange acrid funkiness upon full warming that I liked. Didn’t get cloying. As I stated, acrid, slightly sour/citric flavor component, more than standard. Definite lack of sweetness in this wheat beer. Bready, lip-smacking but not heavy-palated. Mostly diffuse grain and hay flavors. Pepper aroma, dusty. Clovey. No banana for me. I’d go back to this just for the shakeup. Great conditioning to the end.

The beer in the glass has a yellow-orange color, medium cloudy with a beautiful head. The beer smells yeasty, creamy, with a slight fruity note. It starts yeasty, creamy, very tasty. Moreover, joined by a clovy spicy note, overall the Weizen is very recent. The aftertaste is also good spicy, again with lots of clove flavors. The further course is extremely spicy and yeasty, creamy, but I miss something fruitiness.
Rating for the past. Pours a clear golden color, topped with a frothy white head. Malty aroma, a bit grainy. Sweet snd watery taste. Watered down standard lager. Good thing it’s out of production.
Lots of grass, corn and sweet cereal on the nose. Straw pale yellow with a white head of small bubbles. Taste is mostly corn and cereal. Some spice slightly on the back.
Notes from january 2010. Something like Pan lager but more watery. I don’t even understand why they make this. I see now that this beer is retired. Smart thing.
Pours pale golden with small white head. Aroma is slightly hoppy, bready and malty. Thin body. Watery malty flavor. Finish is weak.

50 cl can thanks to my uncle! Sampled on Nov 20, 2009 BB 09/04/10 Clear pale yellow color, rahter big fluffy white head. Nutty, malty, weak, acidic scent. Malty, dry, cream, grainy taste. Dry grainy bitterness. Medium mouthfeel.

really hard to find...i find few bottles in Plodine market in Vodice aldèí aroma ale i po chmelu, drží pìna, white foam, pale colour, pøíjmené hmelové aroma pøevalující se do chuti, light sweet, light finish, surprised, light good hop aroma and flavour
it is hard to find it ... i see this beer few times ... not very good beer ..

500ml botte - I didn’t drink all of it. Pours an airy, fast fading foam and a straw coloured body. Hard to find anything at all in this one - some grass to the nose and a flavour note of sweet vegetables. A light touch of fruity hops in a very short finish. Fizzy carbonation (Dubrovnik, 28.08.2008).
PAN Lager Light or something...The beer hasn’t got any off taste, but it has a thin body, minimal aroma, taste and texture. Will i buy it again? No, thanx!
Bottle. Pale lager, very Balkan style. Some hops, some malt, but there is also, unfortunately, some boiled carrot.

Looks like a mix of beer and lemonade.. I kind of dig the color. Smells super strong of wheat and moderately strong of citrus... the wheat is a bit overpowering. Pretty balanced taste of citrus, wheat, hops. Abrasive carbonation. It's a solid beer.
Taste includes a very hoppy after taste - not served with either an orange or lemon so not sure if that would have made it a bit more mellow ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft at Irish Pol. Hazy gold. Soft white foam. Juicy golden wheat beer with some sharp citrus hops. Apples. Tangerines. Scallions. Caramel cracker malts. Well balanced. Better than expected.

Tap. Pours hazy gold with a medium, fizzy white head, short retention sticking primarily to the edges with spotty lacing. Aroma is medium grainy malt with light hops and lemon notes. Flavor is lightly spicy wheat, faint hops, lemon notes, and a dry finish. Light body and warmth, medium carbonation.
Golden color white head aroma of sweet malts and wheat ... taste of wheat sweet malts.... a little citrusy and a light hop bite to it ... very drinkable and clean ..... 6% not detectable at all

Tap at McMenamins. Hazy straw pour. Mild wheaty apricot aroma, some citrus notes. Mouthfeel is thin. Flavor is light bodied, a bit sweet fruity, with a mild wheat sour finish. Not bad fir a summer beer.

Draft at Craft. Pours hazy deep gold toward copper with 1-finger off-white head. Further look showed the hazy may indeed have been chill haze. Nose is hopcitrus, white pepper, wheaty malt, apricotty fruit. Tastes hopcitric, with pale malt, fruit, spixy notes. Complex for this style, medium palate heft, and one fo the better wheat ales I have ever had. I almost growlered this one, but the Weed Shastafarian Porter won out.
Tap at Craft Ale House. Pours a hazy orange amber with little to no head. Aroma of sweet cereal malts, wheat and light citrus. Flavor of the same, sugary cheerios.

June 2007 - Thanks to eaglefan538 for sharing his growler. Pale gold color with decent head and lacing, pretty clear. Thin wheat base with a bit of citrus and a touch of grassy hop. A little thin, but a good hot summer day sipper
Thanks to eagle for this one. Poured a golden big head good lacing. Aroma was sweet, honey and yeast. Flavor was a little thin some honey grass hop not a bad one for the summer at all.

column1: Twin Lakes Caesar Rodney Golden Ale
column5: Draft at The Irish Pol. Cloudy orange gold pour with off-white foam. Medium caramel malts. Herbal tropical citrus hops. Grassy orange pineapple. Apricot nectar. Some dank. Bitter chlorophyll aftertaste.

column1: Twin Lakes Caesar Rodney Golden Ale
column5: Growler from the brewery. Light golden yellow color, good head. Light aroma of grass. Taste is a little grassy as well with a little bitterness to it. It leaves a funkey after taste that doesnt sit well. Not bad just not good. The overall texture of the beer is light. Kind of dissapointed since I like most of their beer. Maybe just a funky batch.

column1: Twin Lakes Caesar Rodney Golden Ale
column5: June 2007 - Thanks to eaglefan538 for sharing his Fathers Day growler. Gold color, good head and lacing. Grassiness dominates the aroma and flavor. Rich and full. Very good.

column1: Twin Lakes Caesar Rodney Golden Ale
column5: On tap at Jakes Seafood in Rehoboth DE. Pours a lightly hazy golden amber with a smaller bubbly white head. Aroma of mixed fruits, cereal grains and lemons. Flavor of lemon, bready grains, some grassiness and hope.

column1: Twin Lakes Caesar Rodney Golden Ale
column5: Another from eagle. Poured a golden color with good size head. Aroma was grassy which was not what i expected. Flavor had to much grass in it some wheat thin over all. Okay but nothing special.

column1: Twin Lakes Caesar Rodney Golden Ale
column5: Fresh growler from the brewery, Father’s Day special (early) from the wife. Poured a golden color with slight hints of orange, nice full head appearance. The aroma was herbal, slightly grassy, even somewhat corny. The flavor was herbacious, grass, more malt depth than the Spring Wheat, yet still on the light side. This was an average blonde ale, ok for the summer or joe beer drinker, but not enough character for my admiration.

column1: Goose Island Bourbon Barrel Aged Aviator Dopplebock
column5: On tap at the Clybourn location, Almost a dark tea color, super thin white head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla and dark fruit. Taste similar, lots of brbn/van, smooth

column1: Goose Island Bourbon Barrel Aged Aviator Dopplebock
column5: Sample at Goose Island Clybourn. Pours a clear red with a medium beige head. Malty nose with caramel, vanilla, oak and a bit of hop. Oaky vanilla flavor with lots of caramel and some bitter hops in the finish.

column1: Goose Island Bourbon Barrel Aged Aviator Dopplebock
column5: On tap at Goose Island Clybourn. Pours a clear crimson copper with a medium sized white head. Soft bourbon, vanilla, touch of isopropyl alcohol, malty and sweet. Medium bodied, big sweet malt, a touch of malty tartness. Big warm boozy finish with a bunch more toasty malt.

column1: Goose Island Bourbon Barrel Aged Aviator Dopplebock
column5: Hopefully this is the right beer. I was told this was there Dopplebock aged in 18yr Elysian Craig barrels. Ruby to brown pour w/ a small tan head and good lacing. Full well coated pal. Aroma is hard to distinguish very sweet aroma touch of light smokiness and definite plays from the barrel. Great flavor sweet dopple plus vanilla and light butter and bourbon. Smooth & amazingly balanced w/ a hint of alcohol in the finihs. An AMAZING dopple

column1: Goose Island Bourbon Barrel Aged Aviator Dopplebock
column5: On tap at GI Cly. Pours an amber brown with a thin white head. Red fruits malt toasted and sweet touch of alcohol. Cramy sweet and boozy flavors. Thin fruit and chocolate flavors with that alcohol in the finish. Decent but this beer was never meant to withstand a bourbon barrel.

column1: Goose Island Bourbon Barrel Aged Aviator Dopplebock
column5: Sampled after a tour at Clybourn. Fruity ester aroma and flavor up front and finishes slightly bitter... it was hard to judge b/c I had the Dublin Dry Stout right before it.

column1: Goose Island Bourbon Barrel Aged Aviator Dopplebock
column5: Lightly hazed mahogany color with a small small bubbled off-white head. Scents of bourbon, oak, light vanilla and medicinal undertones in the scents. Start is sweet with lots of malt goodness. Alcohol, bourbon and medicine break in and disrupt things a bit in the middle and into the finish. Fairly hot and a bit too much alcohol in the flavors distract.

column1: Goose Island Bourbon Barrel Aged Aviator Dopplebock
column5: on tap at GI Clybourn....dark cola brown pour with medium brown edges and a wispy off-white head....an abundance of bourbon and toffee in the nose. generally sweet druits and malts....for only aging in the barrel for 4 months, this one has a lot of BA flavors. significat bourbon almost suffocating the resemblence of the underlying base beer. semi-hot and boozy followthrough. caramel throughout and more dark fruits. i generally enjoyed this one.

column1: Goose Island Bourbon Barrel Aged Aviator Dopplebock
column5: Pour is lightly hazed ruby mahogany with a thin almost nonexistent head...smell has some wood to it and some vanilla but lots of alcohol...taste is sweet and caramelly for a second, then sitcky chewy vanilla bourbon sweet with a woody bitterness finishing it out...the wood really adds a character that doesn’t belong for this style...

column1: Goose Island Bourbon Barrel Aged Aviator Dopplebock
column5: pours very deep brown, no head. whiff od bourbon and some weird sweetness i couldn’t put my finger on. i got some bitterness and warmth from the bourbon, and that sweetness was there too. there was also something sour in the finish. i’m glad i tried this doppelbock, because i am not aq fan of the stle, but this was a bit better than i expected.

Draught. Small white and quickly disappearing head. Clear very dark brown body. Caramel aroma with a touch of hops. Nice bitterness with caramel and quite a good deal of carbonation. Short aftertaste. Would have expected it to be far more tasty.

Tap @ YNWA. Pours a redish brown with a small film head. Mild aroma with only a slight dose of hops. Taste has a lot of caramel and a little flowery hoppyness. It is not nearly dry enough to be an ESB, more likely a rather tame IPA. It is refreshing, but nothing exciting.

Bottle enjoyed at home Pale hazy, white head. Smells of malts, yeast esters and wood. Taste is light malted with good sweetness. Very summerish and refreshing. Some bitter finish and some tart fruits surprisingly arise after some sips

0.5L bottle bought @Vinmonopolet, Vika. A milk-shaded pale straw colored pour, topped by a tall snowy white head. Yeast and dough up front, then a vague scent of mellow yellow fuits and banana. Taste is undistinct and sappy. Soft bready pale malts, tin-canned fruit-juice fruitiness. Medium full, juicy texture. Bland, fruity and yeast-accented malt finish. Drinkable, but utterly boring and downplayed.

500ml bottle bought at Vinmonopolet Vika. Light yellow body with a slight haze. Lasting white head. Grass and wheat to the nose. The taste profile is a mix of lemon, wheat, and hay added by notes of light spices. Dry ending. Foamy in the mouth. Refreshing and ok (hotel room, Oslo 27.09.2011).

Small white head quickly shrinks with a hissing sound. Muddy yellow body. Mealy orangey wheaty aroma with herbal notes. Dry-sweet mealy herbal taste with wheaty orangey notes. Mid-bodied. Mild, soft mouthfeel. Dry oily papery orangey aftertaste with herbal mealy notes. Nice, quite decent, but a bit mealy and papery, and not as fresh as it could be. (0.5l bottle, wine monopoly Vika, Oslo.)
Fantastic beer in a fantastic environment! Must have beer in the brewpub true to Germany. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a hazy amber with a white head. Aromas of bubble gum yeast and wheat. Bready wheat flavor with bubble gum yeast. Very tasty; my descriptions don’t do it justice. Quite a lovely dunkelweizen here.

On draught at the brewpub. The beer is a clear dark amber color with a medium thin densely packed off-white head that burns away slowly. Thin rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramel and malt along with dark fruit. Medium body with a banana and dark fruit character and notes of roasted nuts and malt. The finish is fruity with a sweet caramel aftertaste. Decent overall.

7/07/2008: GLBC Lorelei is "a classic dark German wheat beer with roasty malt undertones." This description is right on the money! The aroma of this beer is like creamy wheat with a dry roastiness and hints of smoke. It’s appearance is cloudy, burnt gold. It has a thick, pillowy, ivory-colored head that creates fine, dense lacing effects. The beer tastes creamy with only some light floral hoppiness in the finish. It has a medium-full body, a soft palate, and is really creamy. It is good, but slightly disappointing overall. Draught sample (ABV 5.1%; IBU 20) at the Great Lakes Brewing Company Brewpub in Cleveland, Ohio. Rating #5 for this beer.

[382-20070630] Tap @ Great Lakes (Cleveland, OH). Light banana yeast aroma. Hazy, dark brown amber body with a medium-lasting white head. Flavour is like a sweet toffee banana split. Medium-full body. Nice, fairly toned down as it seems to be missing carbonation.

Draft at the brewpub. Headless hazy brown body. Muted yeasty aroma of dark malt. Similar flavour, light estery yeast notes, and toasty malt with light caramel notes. Average palate is under carbonated. Not unpleasant but a bit disappointing - I was hoping for a bigger Aventinus like flavour. I doubt that the name is a reference to the Gilmore Girls, but it brings up memories of the show nonetheless. How might the show have been different had Luke’s diner been serving up micro brew and pulled pork rather than coffee and donuts? Ok that was a stretch... but I got the reference in! :) 6/3/6+/3/13

This is the most unique offering from GL that I have tasted. The combination of wheat and dark beer worked magnificantly well. I would of just stuck with it if It wern’t for my desire to try the other offerings.

Pours a murky purple brown with small almond head. Aroma is banana and some caramel sweetness. Flavor is much the same banana and caramel, with a slight roasted malt and nutty finish. The banana stays around in the background the whole time with a slight smoky sweetness in the finish. Good beer I need to go back down and have a few more.
Bottle.Bronze with low carbonation. Thin and lacking in body. Some maltiness. Quite pleasant at first but soon fades into averageness.

[500ml bottle from deli in Ullswater] Pours dark brownish amber, highly carbonated from the bottle. Sweet, fruity aroma with a tinge of something quite bitter. On the palate, quite thin but a decent malty flavour with a touch of smoke. The decent malt backbone saves this, there’s a definite vegetal side to it. Decent but not amazing [15012011]

Bottled. Just enough smoke to qualify it as more than a smoky Bitter, and a Rauch. From the Warwickshire Alps. Creamy malt, hop bitterness and smoke in equal measure. Nibbles of earth, Twiglet and apple peel. Pours with a ruddy haze and a superbly creamy, rocky head of froth that clings to the side of the glass until it’s drained. Impressive.

Cask at JDW Standing Order, as ’The Standing Order red ale’. Pours deep amber with beige head. Nose is red fruits, toffee. Taste is quite rich, red fruits, burnt toffee, nuts, good maltiness. Decent, better than expected.
Cask. Just comments and numerals due to social interaction. Fruity malts, nutty, earth, caramel.

On cask at the Standing Order. Appearance - amber with a nice head. Nose - toffee and nuts. Taste - red fruit intermingled with toffee and nuts. Palate - close to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a long dry balanced finish. Overall - good stuff.
Cask at The Standing Order JDW. Pours clear copper, thin creamy head. Aromas of toffee, grassy hops, light fruit. Taste is red fruit and nuts. Light herbal note almost. Not bad.
Labelled as Great Glen, in ’spoons in Fort William, called The Great Glen....funnily enough! A pleasant malty/hoppy brew which I rather liked!
Cask at the White Lady. Pours reddish amber, lots of toffee and caramel, light fruit, dry.
Cask, Counting House, Glasgow. Orangey-brown, quite sweet like cookies, bit of toast. Fairly uneventful brown bitter.

Tasted this in the Salt Cot, Saltcoats (JDW) in July 2007. Badged as Salt Cot Red Ale. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear russet amber in colour with a thin creamy white head. Strong malty aroma with berry fruit much in evidence. Thin but creamy mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts gives a fiery digestive biscuit base with tart redcurrant fruit present. Good prickle of hop resins noted in the dry, earthy flavour to the bitter aftertaste. Finish is robust and malty with berry fruit and oak cask notes giving dry moreish flavours in the mouth. An excellent session ESB and very popular with the locals.

On cask as Crystal Palace Ale at The Crystal Palace in Glasgow. Pours a dark, red - orange colour with a thick, light tan head. Aroma isn’t great with caramel, barley, Weetabix and rolled oats. Similar flavours with hoppy pine and grassy notes, rolled oats and yeast. Alcohol is fairly present with mild carbonation and a little oily mouth-feel. Not for me.

Cask @ The Sir John Moore as Sir John Moore Red Ale & The Counting House as The Counting House Red Ale. Mild fruity aroma, amber brown colour. Flavour of mixed fruit, biscuit and caramel. Dry finish. Reasonable bitter.

column1: Seven Bridges Toasted Oat Pale Ale
column5: Draft at Seven Bridges brewpub. Poured hazy brown color with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate caramel malty and hoppy aroma. Medium body. Medium bittersweet grainy flavor with an average smooth bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Good change of standard styles brew.

column1: Seven Bridges Toasted Oat Pale Ale
column5: Pint on cask at the Seven Bridges Brewpub in Jacksonville FL. Had this about the end of April and forgot to rate it. Amber beer with a creamy white head. Aroma was lightly hoppy and pale malts. Flavor was malty and biscuity, with a good hop presence, but some odd flavors floating about. Not bad flavors, just unexpectedly different. Not enjoyable enough for me to go back for more, but certainly a decent enough drink. .. .. 07-15-2008 .. they brought it back as a seasonal, and I tried it again.. tasted sharp, green. Had a funky raw aroma. Not up to the usual standards for this brewpub. Maybe a few weeks of aging would settle it down, but this was hard to drink this year. Immediately switched to their regular IPA with better results.

column1: Seven Bridges Toasted Oat Pale Ale
column5: Has a carmelized grain/malt aroma with mild toastted abd dark fruit notes. Amber in color with a lasting, creamy white head. A little bit of diacetyl in the first sip followed by caramel, toasted malt some alcohol and some light biscuit notes. Very nice mouthfeel. Tastes a little shipyard/ringwood like, but that has never bothered me and doesn’t here.

column1: Rivertowne Buffalo Trace Bourbon Barrel Stout
column5: Date: 07/24/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub black, wispy tan head, light sweet roasted aroma with a hint of bourbon, great combination of sweet chocolate and bourbon balanced by the roasted Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **+/4

column1: Rivertowne Buffalo Trace Bourbon Barrel Stout
column5: Please, don’t mind my numbers on this one. I rate by how much I enjoy it and this was probably one of the most offensive beers I have tasted! This beer will match up with any impy stout in the top 25. I am serious, bitter complex concoction like you have ever tasted. I’m getting growlers of this and sending it to anybody who likes oak aged Yeti or Expedition. Sweetish candy aroma, big and black appearance, like 100,000 mile used engine oil. Head like chocolate mousse. Barely any carbonation and I swear I saw an oily coffee bean slick on top. This stuff coats your mouth like a good bourbon whiskey, WOW! Killer brew, way to much for my girlie taste buds but I saw this chick across from me say how good it tasted and purred right afterwards. I can’t stop puckering. If you like that big black stuff in the top 25, better seek this out, IMHO it is a killer. It’s a wonder that stuff like this is still classified as a beer.

column1: Rivertowne Buffalo Trace Bourbon Barrel Stout
column5: Barrel aging a beer is often a hit or miss thing with me. Generally speaking it tends to overpower the beer. This is not one of those types of beers. The barrel aging compliments and enhances with this beer. Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured a dark black color with a small brown head. The aroma was strong sweet bourbon, roasty malts and sweet chocolate. The flavor was rich sweet bourbon, sweet coffee and sweet chocolate syrup. The barrel took away all the bitterness of the regular imperial stout. When sampled side by side this made their regular imperial stout taste hoppy and harsh. The finish was sweet and silky smooth and hid the alcohol well in my opinion. Ambrosia.

column1: Rivertowne Buffalo Trace Bourbon Barrel Stout
column5: Draught sample from brewery. Dark black clear with no head. Thick oily body with smooth carbonation. Oak nose, with chocolate, coffee, vanilla, alcohol vapors and roasted dry bitterness. Starts with great oaken vanilla notes, plum and raisins. A bit of subdued smokiness, with coffee and a light fruity hoppiness. Smooth dry finish. This was done very nicely. Should get even better with aging and I hope I can try this one again. Smooth and rich with great balance.
moderate malt aromas. gold in color with light head. taste is lightly malty, very faint lemon note

On tap at Beerhead. Pours a fairly clear gold with a thin white head. Soft grain on the nose, crisp and with a touch of crackers. Medium bodied, sweetness, a bit of grain again. Soft and crisp. Light grain into the finish.
From tap. Pours hazy yellow, small white head. Aroma is mild estery, slight fruity. Mild sweet, light spiced to estery. Berry fruity. Mild citric note. Sweet and mild fruity finish.
Pours a cloudy pale yellow with a frothy white head. Aroma is light and yeasty. Taste is light and sweet with a Belgian yeast spiciness in the finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Sample at Rivertowne on 8/1/15. Clear gold pour with no head. Aroma of malt, not much else. Malty flavor with some crisp hop, but overall very bland.
Canned. Pale yellow white head. Aroma is light lemon and mild malt. Flavor is sort of Ricey pale lager flavor. Not excellent.
Pours a golden yellow color with a white creamy head. Aroma of lemon and grain with Citrusy flavor with lemon and hint of orange with some grain. Not bad for a summer beer.
A bubbly little beer. Flavorful with sharp malt and hop notes. Some fruit. Citrus or grapefruit. Decent stuff.
This poured a light golden color with a white head. Aroma was of pale malt and grassy Hood. Flavor similar, a little sweet and astringent too.
Pale yellow pour. Aroma of sweet malts and banana. Taste is sweet with a slight metallic tinge to it. not great b
Pours pineapple into glass with a thin white head. Nice banana and estery notes on the nose. The taste is balanced since it finishes clean without being overly dry. Best thing I’ve had here so far.

A- Translucent golden yellow body with thin white head. Head eventually subsides to thin white collar. No lacing is left behind in the glass. Haze is moderately thick and uniform. S- Sour citrus hits the nose first along with plenty of spices. A solid bready yeast is in the background along with hints of banana. T- Big sour citrus zest upfront with lots of spiciness and yeast to balance. Citrus fades for the finish where peppery spice and yeast really come out with hints of banana. Peppery spice and sweet bready spice linger. P- Low carbonation accentuates the smooth, yeasty mouthfeel of this one. O- Other than the appearance this is almost exactly how I like my hefes. This one has bold flavor but a very light and drinkable character too. This is a bit more sour than the typical hefe-but it makes it much more interesting. Something I hope is around when I visit again-because its delicious! Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 10-08-2007 00:39:06

Very cloudy hefe weizen like most unfiltered, and the aroma is a welcome hello to your nose.. Banana, clove, and a yeasty sweetness wins you over and then the taste you would expect from a hefe’. Very smooth, refreshing, and a beer that you can enjoy over and over on a warm summer day.

Pours a hazy light nectarine peach flesh color. A creamy white head that didn’t last very long. Nose of yeast, clove, and banana. Very spicy. A little bit of sour citrus flavor. A nice bitey yeasty flavor. Solid.
On tap at the Pour House. Hazy gold, white head. Aroma is malty, spicy, yeasty. Flavor is slight banana, oily wheat, corn. Lingering wheat.

Good, rather spicey hefe aroma. Cloudy light yellow beer appearnce, like a witbier. Bananas, oranges, and spices abound in the flavors. Not too overwhelming as with many spiced wheat beers. Has some good tingles. Pretty good taste and easy to enjoy. Friendly and happy. Has some characteristics of wine in the flavors. Just a tad of bitterness. Overall, not bad.

Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured a cloudy pale straw yellow color with a trace of a white head. The aroma was light wheat and banana. The flavor was a nice mix of clove, bubblegum and wheat. There was a banana undertone that lingered on the finish. A nice example of the style.

Draught sample at brewery. Light lemony clove aroma, wheaty, yeasty and a touch of banana. Cloudy pale butterscotch with light foamy lacing head. Medium-light watery body with medium carbonation. Good weizen profile with some acidity to it. Wheaty with mild clove and chalky bitter finish. A bit more lemony that many other German wheats so it takes on a bit of witbier quality. Lemon yeasty finish with light bitterness.

This poured a medium orange color with an off white head. Aroma was of gryassy hops, butter, caramel and yeast. Flavor was somewhat astringent and dirty, light earthy grassy hops and finised sweetness. meh.

This was tatsed on Mother’s Day while heading back to Virginia. The beer was clear straw color with smallish head that laced downthe glass. It had a smooth bitterness that was very subtle. OK but not great. They claim to keep Fuggle’s hops on a nitrogen blanket. Need to learn more about this. I like their mug program for regular customers.
Sweet coldwater and cat pee aroma. Cereal, pepper, slightly briny, medium bitter. Starchy mouthfeel. Back to the workshop.

Pours a clear fizzy apple cider color with a thick eggshell head. A nice sweet toffee nose. Flavor is kind of on the weak side. There is a lot of grainy flavors without much bitterness to balance it. The texture is kind of watery as well. Pretty average ESB.
On tap at the Pour House. Clear, bubbly pale orange, off white head. Aroma is malt and grass. Flavor is the same with toffee, and of course watery.

Date: 07/24/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear dark gold, creamy beige head, lots of lace, light hop aroma, creamy body, lots of good bitter flavor well blended with caramel malt, just enought sweetness to keep the balance, nice long bitter finish, this is what an ESB is supposed to be like Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.3/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **+/4

Draft sample at brewpub. Golden amber color. Slight floral nose. Nice milt malt flavor with a distinct fuggle hops finish. Big fan. Very, very drinkable. 4/13/08 Holy crap, this is on nitro now. Insane. So friggin tasty. Me likey

Ubiquitous pale yellow american lager color. Barely any aroma, just the typical hints of beerness. Earthly flavor that is very similar to the Babbling Brook. and the Ultra Light Tackle. Virtually flat even though I can see carbonation in the brew. Bitter as it’s namesake implies. Cannot hold a candle to Hobgoblin. More on the bitter side of ESB.

Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured a bright orange color with a large yellow-white head. The aroma was light sweet fruity hops. The flavor was tangy, fruity and bitter with a mild hop presence. There was a tangy finish.

Draught sample at brewery. Hazy medium amber with foamy white lacing head. Medium fruity hops in the nose, with light biscuity malt and raw grains. Medium watery body with smooth carbonation. Starts with nice grain maltiness. Biscuit and caramel. Mild bittering in finish with a nice smooth dryness. A really nice session beer. Sweetish with dry finish, full of flavor, but not overpowering in any dimension. I could drink this all day.

Draft sample at the brewery. Dark brown to black color. Roasted barly nose with hints of coffee. Tasted "roasty" with predominant coffe overtones. Crisp finish with alcohol warmth, but not overpowering. Behemoth of a beer. Pretty good. Actually, damn good.

Roasty dark aroma. Black like used motor oil. Taste is typical impy stout. Don’t be fooled by my numbers, I just don’t care for impy stouts. This stuff however will stand up to any impy stout in the top 25. Interesting rock like background flavors. Rivertowne makes the offensive brews that other brewpubs are afraid they feel they can’t sell. Excellent example of obtrusive impy stout.

Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured a dark black color with a small dark brown head. The aroma was sweet roasty chocolate. The flavor was sweet and robust with elements of coffee, chocolate syrup and floral hops. The finish was long with sweet chocolate notes. The alcohol showed a bit.

Draught sample at brewery. Dark brown-black body with thin light-tan lacing head. Medium-heavy chewy body with smooth carbonation. Great coffee-chocolate aroma with mild bitterness. Slight bit of cocoa and hazelnut. Bit of smoke. Starts with heavy chocolate-coffee malts, good roasted grain notes and a bit of vanilla and oak. Extremely flavorful and rich with just the right amount of bitter at the finish. Light alcohol and vinuous notes with just a bit of tang. Would be good to bottle and age a bit more.
Hazy copper orange color with a creamy off-white head. Aroma of pine, citrus, and caramel. Creamy body with citrus and caramel sweetness with some pine and hop bitterness. Decent.
can - very nice orange color. Decent hop aroma. Hop and malt flavor but something seems off - old can maybe?
The aroma is sweet and the appearance is hazy. The taste contradicts the aroma and is a bit sour. The palate is dry and not over hoppy. Overall, this is an okay IPA.

How is it, in an era where breweries are throwing C&D’s at each other all willie-nillie, that Rivertowne and Rivertown can coexist, seemingly peacefully? Or have they had their squabbles? I suppose I could google it to find out, but that’s too much effort. I’ll just choose to sit back and think everything is fine.

Pours a coppery orange with a medium head of white foam. Aroma is not very prominent. Some malts and light citrus with notes of caramel. Fairly refreshing with a malt backbone and a sharp bite at the finish. Feels like a red IPA. Pretty good. Not much pine or citrus flavors. Just a tad bitter aftertaste. Enjoyable.
can - purchased at random at Total WIne in FL. Not bad - but average for IPAs. Just didn’t do it for me

Classic IPA that lacks the citra hops and other piney or citrus hops I love. Well- crafted though. Great aroma with a standard-at-best palate. Needs fruit or complex palate to break from standard though. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz. can from Santa. Pours a clear dark golden/amber color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have a big malt character up front, caramel, light toast, with some orange and grapefruit citrus, some herbal tea, hops seem a bit faded, just ok.

Pours translucent orange-amber into the glass with a wispy head that leaves ring lacing. The nose is of caramel and oranges. Flavors are citrusy (bright), grassiness, caramel and a grassy, lightly peppering bitter finish. The mouthfeel is semi-active and the palate is semi-juicy. Goes down well with a medium body. What it lacks in complexity, it slightly redeems itself in drinkability, especially in the hot summer months.

Canned. No clear date. Pours honey golden, off-white head, pillowy. Aroma is malt forward, caramel notes, light orange, pineapple, lemon citrus notes, bready notes. Flavor is actually fairly hop forward, definite bite. Caramel malt, fairly bready middle of the mouth, slight hop finish. Ok.

Date: 07/24/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy amber, fine dirty white head, streaks of drippy lace, light biscuit malt aroma, well balanced flavor with plenty of bitterness on a dry malt base, bitterness lasts through a long finish, just to dry for me Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4
Draft at the brewpub. Light amber color. Malty, hoppy nose. A nice malt start wit ha crisp, prevelant hop finish. Mild to medium body. Pretty good.

Ignore my numbers, I don’t care for hopped up beers, if you like hops, you gotta try this. Some hints of floral hops in the aroma, just barely. Slightly darker than the typical pale yellow american lager. I think there is a little bit of haze in the appearance. Good medium hop bite, starts out wanting to be an IPA and almost gets there. Medium low carbonation. Overall, a good amber ale that borders on IPA with the hop characters. Finish is like many hopped beers, bitter and medium length lasting. Glad to have had the chance to taste this beer. IMHO Not quite as enjoyable as the less hopped Rock Bottom North Star Amber Ale.

Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured an orange-bronze color with a large yellow-white head. The aroma was a bit light but was sweet, fruity and malty. The flavor was fruity and nutty with a moderate hop presence. The finish was nutty and hoppy.

Draught sample at brewery. Hazy reddish amber with light foamy lacing head. Very nice opaque luminescent quality. BIt of biscuit and fruity hops in the nose. Mild hoppiness but clean. Medium watery body with medium carbonation. Starts rather dry with some nutty grainy bitterness. Neutral fruit and a bit of grassy hops. Nice hoppy finish with mild sweet malt notes. Light bitter after. Very enjoyable amber ale.

Pours kind of a muddy peach with a very thin head. Big raspberries on the nose. Nice raspberries on the nose without being too cloying. I think a little sourness on the finish would make this perfect.

Sample at the brewpub (as "Razzmatazz"). The beer pours a murky peach color with a thin and fizzy off-white head that evaporates quickly. Spotty lacing on the glass. Tart raspberry aroma with some malty notes. Light body with flavors of raspberries, wheat and malt. The finish is slightly sour with the raspberry taste lingering. Slightly above average overall.

&#40draft @ Rivertowne Pour House - Monroeville, PA&#41 Hazy amber color with a fizzy white head. Aroma is tart raspberries mixed with some wheat and grass. Flavor is bitter and tart raspberries and a lightly sour wheat note. Raspberry flavor lingers on the palate for a while. Decent.

Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured a bright red-orange with a small pinkish head. The aroma was sweet and tart berry. The flavor was sweet, tangy and tart berry with a light undertone of " real beer" that was not overwhelmed by the fruit. The raspberry was crisp and identifiable. I was rather impressed with this one.

Draught sample at brewery. Light fruity aroma with nice notes of raspberry and mild citrus. Light tartness and medium sweet. Bit of fruity hops. Cloudy pink body with little pink-tinted head. Looks like pink grapefruit juice. Medium watery body with medium-high carbonation, short of effervescent. Starts with nice hit of tart raspberry juice, though a bit sweet. Not cloying sweet like Lindemans, but not sour juicy like more typical framboise. Light acidity. Medium bitter finish with light berry notes in the after. Fairly clean overall. Nice quenching fruit beer.
On tap at the Pour House. Barely yellow with white head. Aroma is fruit, wheat, grass. Flavor is the same and very watery.

Date: 07/24/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy pale yellow, creamy off white head, a few drops of lace, light sweet fruity malt aroma, lots of fruity flavor, sweet with a light tart finish, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4
