2010-09-05, draught at the brewpub, 6-4-6-3-12=31 Dark chestnut clor, with red shades; generous creamy head. Nice aroma of caramel, maybe with some butter. Mild caramel flavor, with very light roasted malt; correct bitterness. Pleasant, but easy. 2007-06-13, draught at the brewpub, 6-4-6-3-14=33 Dark chestnut color. Soft aroma of dark caramel and some cereals. Good body structure, well balanced between some caramel and very light roasted malt; correct bitterness. Nothing is impressive here, but it’s soft and easy to drink, more than the average in the style.

Draught @ Schuhbeck’s Check Inn, Flugplatz Egelsbach/Außerhalb, Egelsbach, Hesse, Germany 63329. Murky medium to dark orange colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, wheat, oat, moderate yeasty, fruity, yeast. Flavour is moderate sweet and light light acidic with a average to long duration, fruity acidic, yeasty, wheat, oat, paper, earthy notes! Body is medium, texture is creamy, carbonation is soft. [20121001]
Tap. Strong wheat and banana aroma. Cloudy orange-amber color with moderate head. Sweet banana/orange and wheat malt flavor. Light bitter finish. Very nice.

Draught at the brewpub Cloudy copper color. Some aroma of malt, fresh, light banana and spices. Good body structure; some malt sweetness, some spicy and fruity taste; the final gets drier. Quite good, and balanced as all the beers here.

column4: Stonecutters Brewhouse (formerly Granite City Brew Pub)
column5: Objectively speaking: A problematic brown ale with no roastiness. I like: Terrible beer. I dislike: Murky reddish brown, depressingly headless. Rather lifeless yeasty palate. Highly watery body.

column4: Stonecutters Brewhouse (formerly Granite City Brew Pub)
column5: Draft at the Brew Pub - Poured a very cloudy brown in color (not red at all). Aroma was slightly malty with faint hops. Flavor was not particularly distinct... a little malt and hops. Not one of their better efforts...

column4: Stonecutters Brewhouse (formerly Granite City Brew Pub)
column5: Draft at the Brew Pub - Poured an almost clear dark brown amber in color with a very small tan head that faded. Little carbonation. Some chill haze to cloud it. Aroma was malty with a hint of nuttiness and mild hops. Flavor tracked the aroma pretty closely. Mildly bitter with a pleasant nutty/maltiness that carried through to the end. A bit watery. Mildly bitter on the finish. OK, but needs some work still. I’ll be back to try it again soon.

When somebody types a beer as a Smoke Chocolate Chipotle Porter, you know I have to give it a whirl. They pretty much nailed it as there’s a definite spicy kick to the start of the flavor that mellows out into a smoky malt and finishes with chocolate overtones. The overall flavors were kinda weak though leaving me unfulfilled and although I liked the idea, the flavors just didn’t mesh that well together.
Pours the color of cola with a thin beige head. Aroma of salty smoke and nice roast. Roasted malts and a nice medium smoke effect. A little thin and watery perhaps.
Brown-black with a ring of head. Hints of spice and licorice swirl around a black patent centric roast. Flavor quality diminished by strong burnt charcoal note and dank sock character.

On tap at brewpub. Black with thick creamy head. Lots of roasted malt in the aroma and taste. Nice bitterness. Thick. Well made and most enjoyable I’ve had from Stix. Also tried this porter at Washington Winter Fest ’07 with Chocolate and Chipotle in the mix. Very tasty.

Draft at the Diamond Knot brewhouse. Black. Thin but solid-looking grayish head with bountiful lace. Not much nose happening, pleasant or unpleasant. Great body, though; just starting to creep out of the medium range (but only just). Roasty and patenty, kinda acrid, even, right from the attack. Creamy and chocolately but definitely not to the detriment of the roastiness. Light cocoa finish. Nice enough.

Draft at Diamond Knot Brewery. Pours a dark brown with a tan head on top. Aroma is of roasted coffee, vanilla, and malts. Flavor is very watered down with vanilla, roasted malt, and coffee sneaking in. Lacking way to much on the palate as well.

Draft at Stix. Deep, rich brown. Thin, light tan head. Roasted coffee flavor. More soda-like carbonation than most porters gives this the feeling of a pale ale, but the flavor’s all porter. Toasted malts, clean finish. I don’t know why nobody else likes this one, but I sure did.

On Draught at Washington Brewers Festival. Aroma has some phenols and fruity malt forward. Dark brown, with a tan head, ok retention. Flavor is dried fruit forward, some roast bite, slightly metallic and sour. Body is medium/full, with very low carb texture. Was definitely put off by some strange sourness and bad roast feel.

Tap at fest : I probably wouldn’t have tried this, but at the Festival, they were the only place that had any kind of palate cleanser (pretzels). It was brown with a loose fast fading head. Light and thin, no noticeable roast, seemed like a bland brown ale

This is a very unusual interpretation of the style. On a blind tasting I would have pegged this as a sweet stout. It has a full, slightly syrupy body and seems way to roasty for a porter, but they list it as a porter, so what are ya gonna do. Lots of vanilla/nut/coffee in the middle leading to an espresso finish. As a porter it’s an OK stout.

Enjoyed at the Icefjord Bryghus in lovely Ilulissat, Greenland. Tastes like it has no hops. Utterly indistinguishable in taste or appearance from their Angelica Ale. The beer reminds me of Kelpie or Gromet. Not too good, but it was fun watching the icebergs. No aroma of fruit or flavor thereof. Not even tart.

Enjoyed at the Icefjord Bryghus in lovely Ilulissat, Greenland. Tastes like it has no hops. Angelica is a local herb. The beer reminds me of Kelpie or Gromet. Not too good, but it was fun watching the icebergs.
500ml bottle (thanks Viil). Straight from the bottle. Malty, sweet, fake hops in aroma/taste. Malts are nice. Drinkable brew.
Z³ote, przejrzyste z bia³¹ drogn¹ pian¹. Aromaty s³odowe, w tle nuty miodu i karmelu, w smaku dokladnie to samo. Ca³kiem dobre.
Celkom dobré pivo, avšak trošku ma sklamalo kvôli svojej chuti, pravý kelti by mali ma horkô jak sa u nás v oèovej vypráva :D každopádne dobré pivo, stojí za skúšku :D

W aromacie s³ód, miód i ubóstwo. W smaku to samo, ale ma taki czeski sznyt, jest wyczuwalny zio³owy chmiel w aromacie i smaku, nasycenie za wysokie, ale nalane na "7 razy" i jest dobrze. Ogolnie nic ciekawego, ale jak siê jest 5 km od Skalite to grzech nie skosztowaæ.
0.5 l bottle. Pours clear golden with medium head. A: light malty, hops, T: medium carbonated with medium body, bit malty, bitter with lingering bitter aftertaste
Orange color, middle foam size. Good beer, aroma and taste fit into the style.
pite jakiœ czas temu. uzupe³nienie profilu. Ocena przepisana z utpd. Mi³ego dnia.

Angeblich wurde Tschechien und die Slowakei unter anderem von den Kelten besiedelt. Diese errichteten in der Nähe des heutigen Bratislava eine Siedlung. Ob das wahr ist weiß ich nicht, aber dieses Bier ist ihnen gewidmet. Ich trank meine Dose dieses Biers als ich an der Grenze Vyšné Nemecké warten musste. Es ist ein einfaches Zehngrädiges, das anfangs einen komischen süßlichen Geschmack hat, aber je mehr man davon trinkt, umso bekömmlicher wird es. Bestimmt kein besonders weiter Wurf, aber doch gut trinkbar.
Bottle.Yellow with a small head,aroma of citrus fruit,taste is fruity and yeasty.
Bottle at Chris_o’s. A blonde, fruity beer with a good dose of hops. Good but nothing special.

Bottle. Golden with lively carbonation. Aromas are crisp hops and citrus with yeast and hints of sulphur. Flavours are mellow citrus with pineapple. Fairly sweet with spritzy yeast. Pretty refreshing.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body: &nbsp Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 3 &nbsp &nbsp Pale Yellow(1)->Dark brown(5) : 1 &nbsp &nbsp Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 2 Head: &nbsp None(1)->Large(5) : 4 &nbsp White(1)->Tan(5) : 2 &nbsp Lasting: 3 &nbsp Lacing : 2 Aroma: Intensity : 2 &nbsp Yeast : 3 &nbsp Bread : 2 &nbsp Apple : XX &nbsp Tropical Fruits : XX &nbsp Soap : XX &nbsp DMS : XX &nbsp Diacetyl : XX Sulfur : 4 &nbsp Malt : 2 &nbsp Biscuity : 1 &nbsp Hay : 2 &nbsp Toasty : XX &nbsp Caramel : XX &nbsp Nuts : XX &nbsp Honey : XX &nbsp Cereals : 2 &nbsp Grainy : 4 Hops : 1 &nbsp Noble(1)->American(5) : 1 &nbsp Leafy : 1 &nbsp Spicy : XX &nbsp Floral : XX &nbsp Lemon/Lime : 1 &nbsp Grapefruit : XX &nbsp Orange : XX &nbsp Herbal : XX &nbsp Grassy : XX &nbsp Pine/Spruce/Resin : XX &nbsp Notes : &nbsp Peach/Apricot : XX &nbsp Earth : XX &nbsp Mint : XX &nbsp Butterscotch : XX &nbsp Smoke : XX Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Sourness : XX &nbsp Bitterness : 2 &nbsp Complex : XX &nbsp Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 2 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 3 &nbsp Clean : XX &nbsp Sharp : XX &nbsp Watery : 1 &nbsp Oily : XX &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringent : XX &nbsp Alcohol : XX &nbsp Mineral : 1 &nbsp Oxidation : XX &nbsp Metallic : XX Comments: Higher alcohols and strong sulphur dominate from beginning to finish.

Bottle, at London Shindig, August 2007. Hazy straw colour. Slightly sharp, yeasty aroma. Light bitterness on the palate, with plenty of citrus. Sharp tangy mouthfeel, with a light body. Not bad. Might have suffered from being tasted directly after the Arcadia Cocoa Loco. Might try this one again if I get a chance.

Bottle @ Chris_o shindig 2007. Light unclear, light to medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, bread. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Bottled. Pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma of lemon and elderflower. FLavour is citrus-like sour, with some bitterness.
Bottled. Yellowish golden colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma is very skunky hops. Flavour is citrus, earth and some yeasty notes.
Bottled. A slightly hazy light yellow beer with a lazing white head. The aroma is sweet citrusy. The flavor is malty combined with notes of cardboard, leading to a dry bitter finish.
Bottle@chris_o. Citrus hops. Light hazy, pale yellow color, white head, good lace. Light malty, very floral, citrus. Full and dry. Nice, not complex but interesting.

500ml can pours a clear golden color with a 2 finger white head that settles quite quickly leaving very little lacing behind. Aroma is grassy with a hint of herbal and grainy notes. Taste is a light citrus and grassy hop bitterness with a mild caramel malty sweetness. Grainy mouth feel. Light bodied with decent carbonation. Overall, a typical brew for the style and nothing really stands out.
Pours a clear brown with light tab head and good lacing. Aroma is of syrupy malt. Taste is nicely balanced sweet and bready. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

[bottle] Kind of fruity hay aroma with some oxidized cardboard character. Light copper and clear under bubbly white that quickly drops to some patches and a ring. Cardboardy hay with only slight hops flavour. The only redeeming quality of this beer is that the bitterness is not overboard for the lack of malt and hops flavour. Light body, moderate carbonation, crisp and clean finish.

(bottle) Clear, pale golden colour with a foamy white medium head. Sweet grainy, slightly fruity aroma with a touch o cara-malt, honey and distinctive herbal hops. Light-sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Slightly grainy, cara-malty and subtle fruity taste; almost dry, sweet and slightly bitter, malt-accented finish with a light but balancing herbal hoppy touch. Good Export-Lager (15.03.08).

500 ml bottle: poured golden yellow with a small white head. Grains and fruit in the aroma. Light apple with a touch of wet cardboard. Flavor is fairly full with fruity notes of apple and a little grape. Mild graininess. Light bitter finish. Good beer. Full flavored.
Mediocre at best "premium lager". Some malt, rough alcohol flavors despite only being 5%. Not at all interesting.
Chocolate malty creamy and smooth well balanced some astringency but overall very enjoyable.

Draught at 1516 Brewing Co. Vienna. Notes from July 08. Pours brown with an off white head. Aroma of toasted malt and chocolate. Flavour is sweet malt and chocolate. Good mouthfeel with a bitter finish.
nice strong dark teddybear brown. nice blent of mat with roasted wheat to create enough sugars to giv ethe brew its strength. subtle and simple with just a touof hop and sparkel.
Pours a hazy amber brown color with an off white head. Aroma is honey, wheat, and some yeast. Flavor is honey, malt, wheat, and a light bitter finish.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body: &nbsp Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 4 &nbsp Light Brown(1)->Dark(5) : 4 &nbsp Ruby : XX &nbsp Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 3 Head: &nbsp None(1)->Large(5) : 5 &nbsp White(1)->Tan(5) : 2 &nbsp Lasting: 4 &nbsp Lacing : 5 Aroma: Intensity : 3 &nbsp Yeast : 2 &nbsp Bread : 1 &nbsp Apple : XX &nbsp Esters : XX &nbsp Banana : XX &nbsp Phenols : XX &nbsp Leather : 2 &nbsp Perfume : 2 &nbsp DMS : XX &nbsp Diacetyl : XX Malt : 4 &nbsp Biscuity : 3 &nbsp Toast : 4 &nbsp Caramel : 2 &nbsp Toffee : 2 &nbsp Maple : XX &nbsp Molasses : XX &nbsp Nuts : 2 &nbsp Candy : XX &nbsp Pumpernickel : XX &nbsp Cereals : 3 &nbsp Fruits : 4 &nbsp Chocolate : 2 &nbsp Coffee : XX &nbsp Vanilla : XX &nbsp Grapes : 2 &nbsp Blackberries : XX &nbsp Dates : XX &nbsp Cherries : XX &nbsp Plums : 3 &nbsp Figs : XX Hops : 2 &nbsp Noble(1)->American(5) : 1 &nbsp Leafy : XX &nbsp Floral : 2 &nbsp Orange : 2 &nbsp Herbal : XX &nbsp Spicy : XX &nbsp Pine/Spruce/Resin : XX Notes : &nbsp Earth : XX &nbsp Wood : XX &nbsp Cloves : XX &nbsp Smoke : XX &nbsp Pepper : XX &nbsp Ginger : XX &nbsp Peach/Pear/Apricot : 1 &nbsp Candi Sugar : XX &nbsp Anise : XX &nbsp Vinous : XX Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Sourness : XX &nbsp Bitterness : 1 &nbsp Complex : 4 &nbsp Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 3 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 3 &nbsp Clean : XX &nbsp Sharp : XX &nbsp Watery : XX &nbsp Oily : XX &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringent : XX &nbsp Alcohol : X &nbsp Mineral : XX &nbsp Oxidation : XX &nbsp Metallic : 1 Comments: The low scores are a total mystery to me. This was easily amongst my favourites of 100+ beers tried in Austria. From what I think I understood, they brewed it using no basic pale malt and went for only specialty ones, though obviously munich and Vienna would be a fair proportion of the grain bill. That explains the “pure” from the name. I found it malt profile to be fabulous, very complex, fruity lager with a profound, spot on toastiness and beautifully nuances all throughout. And for all its maltiness and shy hops, it never becomes to sweet. Subtlety as an art.

Dark coppery colored, medium sized yellow head. Yeasty-flowery, only mildly roasted aroma with hints of chocolate. Medium bodied. Flavor is richer with roastiness and obvious chocolate, aftertaste dries nicely with hops, also some chocolate stays there.

Draught@brewpub, Vienna Copper brown color, creamy brown head. Nose is mainly diacetylic. Less butterscotch in the flavor (still some). Medium-bodied. Malty. Caramelly malts, light toasted notes, toffee. Light hops in the aftertaste. Unfortunately not clean batch.

Draught at the pub: Caramel and toffee aroma. Brown, light orange color, creamy off-white head. Flavor is velvety, malty and roasty. Light sweet caramel and toffee notes. Toasty, sweet and roast bitter end. Fine, aromatic beer.

Beer No. 1 on my tour through Austria, Germany and Denmark. Draught at the brewpub. Yellow/golden coloured, medium sized white head, strong barnyard nose. Very lively carbonation. Sweetish malty, light hoppy and yeasty with touch of honey near the end. Pleasant and refreshing.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body: &nbsp Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 3 &nbsp &nbsp Pale Yellow(1)->Copper(5) : 2 &nbsp &nbsp Still(1)->Volcanic Sparkling(5) : 3 Head: &nbsp None(1)->Large(5) : 4 &nbsp &nbsp Lasting: 4 &nbsp &nbsp Lacing : 4 Aroma: Intensity : 3 &nbsp Yeast : 3 &nbsp Bread : 4 &nbsp Dough : XX &nbsp Esters : XX &nbsp Phenols : XX &nbsp Dusty : XX &nbsp Spicy : 1 &nbsp Apple : XX &nbsp Banana : XX &nbsp Tropical Fruits : XX &nbsp Brett : XX &nbsp Barnyard : XX &nbsp Leather : XX &nbsp Wood : XX &nbsp Vinous : XX &nbsp Cheese : XX &nbsp DMS : XX &nbsp Diacetyl : XX Sulfur : XX Malt : 3 &nbsp Pilsner : 3 &nbsp Pale : XX &nbsp Vienna : XX &nbsp Biscuity : 2 &nbsp Toasty : XX &nbsp Hay : XX &nbsp Caramel : XX &nbsp Honey : XX &nbsp Cereals : 3 &nbsp Grainy : 2 &nbsp Wheat : 1 Hops : 3 &nbsp Noble(1)->American(5) : 1 &nbsp Leafy : 1 &nbsp Perfume : XX &nbsp Orange : XX &nbsp Floral : 2 &nbsp Lemon/Lime : XX &nbsp Herbal : XX &nbsp Grassy : 3 &nbsp Piney : XX Notes : Pepper : XX &nbsp Cloves : XX &nbsp Coriander : XX &nbsp Ginger : XX &nbsp Orange : XX &nbsp Earth : XX &nbsp Vanilla : XX &nbsp Oxidation : XX &nbsp Bubblegum : XX Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Sourness : XX &nbsp Acetic : XX &nbsp Lactic : XX &nbsp Bitterness : 3 &nbsp Farmy : XX &nbsp Complex : 2 &nbsp Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 4 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 3 &nbsp Clean : 3 &nbsp Sharp : XX &nbsp Watery : XX &nbsp Oily : XX &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringent : XX &nbsp Alcohol : XX &nbsp Mineral : XX Comments: Fully cerealic, yeasty, grassy and tasty unfiltered lager with a complex bready foundation.
Dorada, aroma normal, hecha para ser consumida en grandes cantidades, de difícil acceso en Venezuela
Better than regular Regional, but mostly it’s just a thirst-quencher made to be consumed in enormous quantities.

Pale golden look with average white head. Light grassy aroma. Refreshing, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour. Short aftertaste. Average lager. This one is especially popular in night clubs and in baseball games of Caracas stadium. Fashion marketing, but with decent taste.

Can – 250 ml. - Has a golden and yellowish color. The aroma is good enough, hoppy. Has head small, very rapid, but with a decent cord. In the palate the herbs are well-known, ultimately it becomes rather tart, but it is surprisingly dry. Has an average, luminous and transparent body. I would say that it is a beer that leaves a pleasant viciousness. It is better than the regional normal beer.

Cask, Last Plantagenet, Leicester. Hazy gold with a dense head. Aromas are dry with bitter grapefruit. Peppery and hoppy with minimal malts. Flavours are dry bitter lemon with resinous hops. Herbal and floral on the finish with green hops.

Cask at the Babbington Arms (JDW), Derby. Pale gold with a creamy, off-white head; citrus aroma; smooth and creamy in the mouth, sweet to start, but developing a sharp grapefruit bitterness; giving a lengthy finish.

column1: Wyre Piddle Marcos King of the Watusi
column5: Clear light amber. Lacy, lasting white head. Little aroma manages to peak through the foam. Still, a pretty hoppy ale in mouth where a mineral and floral bitterness displays the bittering intentions. Pretty bland grainy malts fail to excite or provide more than minimal support. Average.

column1: Wyre Piddle Marcos King of the Watusi
column5: Cask at the Babbington Arms (JDW), Derby. Gold with a creamy off-white head; rather unpleasant vegetative aroma; and strange vegetable flavours, sour and fruity at the same time, with perhaps a hint of melon; a dry finish. Rather strange, and not very welcoming.
Cask at the Brunswick Arms, Derby. Reddish brown with a trace of white head; fresh aroma of wet grass; creamy body with some fruit; and a long, growing bitter finish. Excellent.

On tap at the brewery in boringville. Chalk board said "low" so this HAS to be a super old batch that should have been dumped. No way it deserves even the less than stellar reviews if everyone on here had this beer. Pours a hazy orange with no head served in a pint glass. Aroma is bread, slight paper to cardboard and some stale malt. Taste is bread, malt, diacetyl and no hop presence at all. I wouldn’t even guess this was an IPA but rather a golden amber or something. This was the last chance for anything at Steelhead. Done.

Clear orange pour with a white head. Butter, orange, and bready malts on the nose. Some cracker malts, light pine, and some grass. Flavor has a touch of citrus to it, but too much diacytel flavor. Some bread, a bit of cracker, and a mild pine bitterness. Light herbal and floral hop notes. Kind of acidic as it warms, too.

Tasted on 1/23/11 on draft at Steelhead Irvine. Pours cloudy golden with a thin white head that leaves a thin collar of lace. The nose is citrus and floral hops with a good amount of bread and hay malts. The flavor starts off with a hint of caramel, moving to the bread and hay, and then finishing with a good dose of the floral and lemon citrus hops. The body is medium and somewhat sticky with average carbonation and a long bitter hops finish.
Tap at the Irvine location. Rating #7. Hazy glowing orange with a nice lacing white head. Resiny and a bit piney. Fruity, tropical fruit as a matter of fact, light citrus and tasty. (1388)
Clear light amber color/ white head. Nice floral, pine sap, sweet pale malt aromas. Decent pale grainy malt, bitter floral hop flavors.
I had this on tap at Irvine &#40Go Anteaters!!!&#41. I thought it was a very approachable IPA: nice citrus hoppy nose and flavor with some good malt balance.

Tap @ the brewpub. Fairly hazy amber color with a persistent off-white head. Moderate grapefruit and citrus front to the aroma. Some sweaty and pine hops also show up. Mild grapefruit jucie flavor that covers up most of the malt. Dry mild-moderate long bitter finish. The body is light.

Date: 12/02/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy orange. creamy beige head, waves of drippy lace, sweet crystal malt aroma with fruity and citrus hops, citrus hop flavor supported by the sweet crystal malt, nice tangerine sweetness, just the right amount of bitterness for balance without taking too much from the hop flavor, lasting bitter finish, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

OC tour, tap at Irvine brewpub: Slightly hazy golden hue with frothy head and okay lace. The aroma has notes of piney citric hops, biscuit and cardboardy malt, allspice, and cobweb. The taste is moderate bitter over chalky pale malts, nutty and has a hint of citric twang. The mouth feel is dry and snappy. A drinkable IPA methinks.

Had this a while back and forgot to rate. This one was on tap at the Irvine, CA location. It had apparently just won an award at the GABF. It was an unfiltered looking IPA. Was a murky orange/brown color. Aroma was nice and hoppy. Lots of grapefruit and citrus. Flavor was much of the same. Nice hop bitterness. Mildly malty for balance purposes, but it was pretty much hop favored. It was my favorite of their brews at the Irvine location.

Bottled at Monk’s Café Wallingatan, Stockholm. Cloudy pale golden, rich very brief head. Chalky nose. Dry and yeasty, chalky and citric. Fruity with light body and soapy mouthfeel. Minerally chalky finish.

Bottled at Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm. Pours out in a cloudy pale yellow appearance with a small white foam. Minerals, dough, banana, yeast and alcohol in the aroma. Light-bodied with with notes of dough, apricts and banana. Short doughy and a bit yeasty finish. No bitterness.

Bottle, november 07. Turbid copper/ orange/ brown color with a medium bubbly head. Harsh phenollic/ chlorine flavor. Clearly infected. Sad, phenollic, skunky aroma. Medium to light palate, harsh, astringent, hard to go through. Shamefully infected amber ale.

Appearance: pale reddish color. Medium head, white and some dense. Aroma: citric and some chlorine’s smells. Very yeasty. Unpleasant. Flavor: pale malts in the start. Excessive yeasty, plastic’s touch and sourness from infection problems. Palate: light body and medium carbonation. Unpleasant and disappointment beer.
Bottle from Fukito, BsAs - Badly infected, undrinkable sadly... shame, as the labels were nice!
On tap at Ox, Portland, OR. Hazy copper, white head. Citrus, caramel, floral notes, resin. Okay.
Good enough if all other IPAs are sold out but not the hop monster I was hoping for. I admit I love extremely hoppy beers like Rogue 8 hop.

Bottle shared with Ladi at Bad flash on his historic last day at work. Picked up this and the IRA and had them side by side. both were disappointing honestly but I think the IRA was narrowly better. It’s a decent beer. Went down smooth but the hop levels were not fit for purpose. Picking up an IPA from Oregon, I mistakenly believed the hops would dominate.

Tap at Woodstock. A: Cloudy copper with a thin white head. N: Grapefruit, pine, earth, papaya, orange zest, and pineapple. T: Bitter and sweet, but mostly bitter. M: Medium resinous body, biting carbonation, no alcohol. O: Standard IPA, but one that’s a lot more refined than I remember.

West Coast IPA from a 50 cl bottle; at more than one and a half year of age, this is clearly too old for an American IPA, but anyway, I promise I won’t let this get in the way of my appreciation of this Oregon micro brewery, which is completely new to me. Thick and frothy, irregularly edged, egg-white head, thinning but remaining closed for a long time and leaving patches of thick ’membranous’ lacing around the edge, clearly hops-enhanced, crowning a ’sunset’ orange hued, deep and warm golden beer with tiny strings of fizz here and there, lightly hazy, turning equally cloudy and even more intensely ’sunset orange’ with sediment. Aroma is already faded due to age, but still breathes the remnants of powerful hops over a firm malty background, with impressions of moist white pepper, old pine branches, grapefruit peel, ginger powder, dried wormwood, tonic water, old bread crust and dito biscuit, dried out orange flesh, faint hints of parsley, gin, lemon zest, straw, cold fried chicken skin, cardboard, soap. Sweetish fruit in the onset, traces of apricot, apple and vague orange sweetness but everything rather subdued, with a sourish edge as well as the first signs of grapefruity hop bitterness; carbonation remains very soft, a bit too soft even for this style, to my taste at least, but tingles very subtly on the sides of the tongue. Smooth, lightly oily, very supple, soft mouthfeel. Soft cereally sweetish core with a clear toasted edge, gaining some strength in the finish just as the hops, that have been developing in bitterness right from the start, take over completely and ensure a long, spicy, leafy, ’bright green’ bitterness coating the back of the mouth, resinous and tonic water-like with retronasal hints of grapefruit peel and pine, while some juicy maltiness peeps through in the very end; alcohol remains practically hidden. The aroma is clearly suffering from age after 1.5 years on a shelf - unsurprisingly, of course - and showing the first signs of oxidation, apart from having largely lost the more delicate Cascade and Centennial features it must doubtlessly have when fresh; still, based on experience alone, I can feel that this must have been a solid IPA when young, with a firm toasted edge in its malt department to support a strong, rooty and spicy hop bitterness that lasts for a long time. It is that basic bitterness that has remained firmly in place so in the mouth, this beer still behaves more than decent for its style. Too bad for the faded and withering aroma, I’d love to taste this young and ’green’, but from a merely didactical point of view, it is also interesting to taste an IPA at this age if only to experience first hand what age does with it. As for style: this is about as West Coast as it gets even at this age.

Bottle 50cl. poured into a pint glass. Slightly unclear pale amber, tall creamy white head to off-white head, good retention and lacing; aroma pale malts, grain, lemon peel, pine, wet hay; taste medium sweet and bitter, malty, caramel, grainy, citrus; malty dry bitter finish, husky and chalky notes; medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation; solid IPA.
Decent IPA. Tasty enough. Some hops, not overwhelming though. Not bad, but could be better.

Bottle from PCC Fremont Seattle. Pours clear deep amber with off-white head. Nose is spicy pine resin with some caramel malt. Flavor is very big - a rush of very fresh tasting alpha acid-infused maltiness, just slightly sweet but also quite rich. Good backbone. Aftertaste is long-lingering hop resin fruity bitterness. Another spectacular IPA from my favor PNW Coast ale brewers. They deserve accolades for every single beer I’ve tried since moving to the PNW - Killer Green, The Vaporizer, etc.- each has its own character and each is a new, distinct and bold contribution to a world oversaturated with mediocre IPAs. I’ve stopped rating beers after ten years of seeking out the best and brightest- and I just have to return to rave about this brewery.

Bottle 500ml. [ As Double Mountain Hop Lava ]. Hazy - murky matt - golden medium orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, sweet malt, moderate to heavy hoppy, orange - citrus. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, caramel, sweet malt, hoppy, fruity. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20150928]
On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear orange gold with frothy white head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is earht and fruity malt. Medium mouth, grass, citrus, lingering bitterness, good.

Bottled alc. 5.0% Hazy amber color, steady small off-white head. Aroma is odd: peat, grass, metal. Active carbonation. Flavor is similar to nose: hard iron flavors, peat, woody hoppyness. Like all Argentinian micros: not really an American amber ale.
Bottled. Ambery golden, small head. Aroma is aloe vera, spices, tar, slight smoked wood, some mild notes of herbs as well. Flavour is rather similar with also some slight yeasty notes.

Bottled at Monk’s Café Wallingatan, Stockholm. Cloudy pale amber, minimal head. Chalky pear aroma. Sweet and fruity with light-medium body and clean mouthfeel. Dusty, eatrhy minerals over a crystallic clean body. Salty finish.

Bottled at Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm. Pours out in an opaque reddish brown colour with a low creamy white foam. Caramel, dough, yeast and glue in the aroma. Flat flavour without depth of earth and minerals with undertones of caramel. Low bitterness in the aftertaste with notes of acidic wild yeast and caramel. Felt slightly infected.
Bottle @ Cervelar: Great rubi red color, nice medium head, taste is a bit wierd, chemical and artificial. Not good, has this gone bad?

Bottle, november 07. Slightly hazy pale, yellow/ golden color with fizzy carbonatation and a medium, white head. Awfull, rancid, phenollic chlorine aroma. Infection is evident. Sweet flavor followed by rough phenollic/ chlorine notes. Badly infected. Medium to light palate, bland, rough, astringent and fizzy. Horrible.

Appearance: amber orange color, turbid. Great head, ivory color, dense and very persistent. Lively bubbles. Aroma: yeasty and toasty malty. Some of toffee and honey. Fruity reminiscences like peaches and pears. Low hoppy smells. Intensive mineralized and metallic touches. Flavor: too much yeasty, out style. However, existing toasty malty notes and other (underground) like toffee, candy and honey. Stone peach fruitiness. Bitter finish, for excessive yeasty. Palate: light to medium body. Too much carbonized. Bad beer, too much yeasty and excessive carbonated.
Bottle from Fukito, BsAs - Again, badly infected and the TCP completely overshadowed the other tastes, shame.
Bottle. Pours a hazy ark brown color with a small off-white head. Has a malty grainy earthy caramel aroma. Sweetish malty yeasty caramel flavor. Has a sweetish malty finish with inhts of caramel.

Bottled Murky brown color, steady beige head. Odd sticky herbal-grassy nose, not very beer-like. Crisp carbonation. Yeasty, herbal flavor, some alcoholic harshness. Glueish-harsh flavors in the aftertaste. Pler ...
Bottled. Amber colour, small beige head. Aroma is aloe vera, burnt and roasted rubber, some spices. Flavour is quite much the same with slightly peated malty notes. Not very pleasant.

Bottled at Monk’s Café Wallingatan, Stockholm. Dark cloudy brown. Minerally chestnuts and iro and peanut butter up front. Mid sweet with medium body. Fruity with chalk and syrup, rather mushy mouthfeel. Peculiar.

Bottled at Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm. Pours out in a dark cloudy brown colour with a low fluffy white foam. Roasty chocolate aroma with salty and tarry undertones. Medium.bodied with notes of tar, milky chocolate and fudge in the flavour with sourish undertones. Peppery and roasty finish with notes of milky chocolate. Decent stout.

Bottle, november 07. Sight gusher, opaque black color with a medium, bubbly beige head. Acrid, phenollic/ chlorine flavor badly infected. Light mouthfeel, fizzy and astringent. Nasty. Phenollic/ chlorine aroma with some coffee notes. Impresentable stout.
Bottle from Fukito, BsAs - Sadly another infected beer, a decent liquoricey, treacly flavour was spoilt by the phenols.

Appearance: dark brown color. Great head, beige color, consistent and persistent. Aroma: very yeasty with earthy and banana smells. Slight cacao and coffee smells. Ripe fruitiness slightly acid, similar to blackberries and plums. Citric hoppy. Flavors: excessive yeasty and sourness. Earthy notes, maybe from yeast. Fruitiness similar to blackberries and plums. Final with high roast malty, persistent similar to grain coffee. Liquory. Hoppy and dry-herby aftertaste. Palate: medium body and high carbonation. Mediocre, too much yeasty.

FYI I am rating this beer based on it’s style. This cream ale pours brilliantly clear and with a minimal amount of head that is pure white. Slight DMS in the aroma (which is accurate to style) and with a slight sweetness. It drinks clean and dry. There is a very subtle hint of noble American hops that gives off a slight amount of citrus, grass, and hay. Flavor is crisp and clean, low-carbonate water gives off the impression of a softer beer. A true American’s lawnmower beer! Cream ales are hard to find these days, especially fresh, and well-made versions. Wish the carbonation was increased a bit to enhance the impression of a spritzy, refreshing, summer guzzler.

Aroma is adjunct laden bready malt sweetness. Pours a hazy yellow gold with a nice head. Smooth flavors with a light ale sweetness, some corn and a crisp finish. Drinks well and is flavorful for what it is. I like cream ales and I enjoyed this one, my only complaint is that it might have been a little too adjuncty.
9/8/07 On draught at the brewery. Aroma and flavor are well blended between slight sourness, sweetness of malt and a very round hop character. Texture has a light creaminess and low bite of any kind.
Golden yellow colored pour with medium sized head. This had a malty aroma with some citrus. A slight hoppy sweet finish. Not bad at all.

Very light golden color. A good session beer at about 4%. Light and very drinkable on a hot day. A very ight citrus aroma with a very clean finish. Not enough hops for this hop head but could throw back a couple of these while washing the old truck!

2007 - Washington Brewers Festival – Kenmore WA A light golden yellow clear through the glass with a thin head. This beer was light and refreshing and had a great malt background. Loved the mild hops and the crisp finish was great. Had a slight fruity nose to the finish. Good beer.

Had this at Thompsons as Solar Wheat. I am guessing it is the same brew. Hazy dark golden with a lovelly bubbly eggshell white head. McMenamins always look good in the imperial pint glass. Aroma as usual is subdued bready malts a little hop but not unpleasing Taste i was expecting more whet and clove, but this is typical golden ale/American wheat crossover territory..sweet, caramel and a touch of hop..not horrific but very average. Actually not too thin on the palate ompred to many from this brewer.\ Overall a very average brew ..the only big PLUS being the green power aspect. So a tentative thumbs up(ish).

Draught @ WABF 2008. Pours a hazy golden color with small white head. Fruity malty aroma with some hints of ginger. Fruity malty slightly spicy ginger flavor. Sweetish fruity slightly spicy finish with some hints of hops in the aftertaste.
For a beer that is made entirely with solar power, its tasty. Nothing exciting, a simple golden ale, perhaps a bit more spicy.

Draught, Six ArmsLight golden-amber. Limey, orangey, peppery aroma. Massive ginger flavour. Maybe there’s some pepper or cardamom in there but this is really heavy on the ginger. Quick, refreshing finish.

2007 - Washington Brewers Festival – Kenmore WA A light golden yellow color with a light flavor. This was more of a golden ale than a fruit beer. The beer was light in flavors and malts with a light hops addition. A good lawnmower beer for the hot days.
bottled courtesy of Pat the accountant - dark golden color. Boozy Belgian aroma and flavor.

Bottle thanks to Evil Jason. Had this before but didn’t rate. Clear golden with a nice white head. Aroma is very herbal, thyme, ginger, cardamom, some citrus and Belgian yeast. Flavor is sweet and malty, honey, tangerine, lots of herbal notes. Medium-full bodied with average carbonation. Decent.

Pours hazy dark golden N: clay, ginger, lactic tartness. Odd T: taste works better than the nose at this point. Sweet sirupy and yeasty taste. In the aftertaste the ginger shows again and makes it weird again. Funny but odd..
Clear copper of color with a off white head. An aroma of spice, sweets, mead and orange. Oxidixed aroma. A flavor of spice, honey, mead, sweets and orange. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone

Sampled this one on draught at the brewpub in Mukilteo, WA. Pours to a beautiful, bright, golden color, with a tight, white head that fades, and a moderate carbonation. The nose on this beer is well balanced, with good, crisp, pale malt aroma, paired with fresh, grassy/herbal hop aromas. Palate is fairly clean with some good pale malt flavors, but becomes muddled, with some estery fruitness, that is a flaw in this style of beer. This beer finishes with more pale malt, and some estery fruit flavor up front, then ends with some grassy hop bitterenss to balance. Stylistically, this beer could have been cleaner, and the esters were clearly a flaw. Tasty enough brew, but no a great example of dortmunder.
Clear golden body. Thick, low head. Fresh malty aroma with light herbal hops. Er...fruity, off-flavour of too warm fermentation. This smelled so promising but really came unglued. Damn.
Dark cloudy golden with thin head. Wheat aroma with a bit of citrus and fruit. Light bodied. OK.

Draft. Cloudy dark orange color. Mild fruity nose with more roasted undertones than most hefe’s. The taste is almost as much pale ale as hefe with caramel flavors blending with citrus and hops. Interesting, but doesn’t leave a clean feeling in the mouth. Interesting, and a good effort, but not quite perfect.

9/26/07 On draught at Larry’s brewing supply, Kent, Wa. Aroma is caramel and fruity esters forward. Appearance is a hazy gold with a good off-white head. Flavor is very fruity banana with very light malt character. Mouthfeel is fairly watery with medium body and almost no carb bite. Overall, very easy drinking, but definitely needs more texture and bite.
Amber in color, loose beige head. Lightly spiced banana nose.More banana in the taste, but quite thin and undercarbonated.

Hazy dark amber colour. Somewhat loose head. The aroma is of banana, cinnamon and pale malt. As it warms it really picks up some Schneidery yeast notes. The body is thin and this does it great disservice on the palate as it comes across slightly toasty & fruity but gutless. Weissbier needs sugars. The finish is watery. Not sure how many of these I could sink.
Nice dark yellow color. Strong hop taste like a IPA should have. However it's smoother than most. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Taps clear topaz with a fair ivory head. Aroma yields fresh malt and a little resiny hops. Much bolder flavor presents piney hops, fresh malt, a hint of citrus. Texture offers fair body and fizz. Not the best IPA out there, but number it among those worthy of at least a snort.

Sampled at the brewpub on my honeymoon - It pours lightly hazy golden with a white head. It has a medium body with moderate carbonation. The taste has pale malt, floral notes and spicy hops. the finish has dried leaves and is fairly woody. Decent.
Sample at Ram in downtown Columbus on 1/26/18. Pours clear orange to amber with a thick white head. Nose of malt, dank hop and citrus. Malt and spicy rye flavor with an earthy hop finish.
Pours s clear yellow Amber. Good lacing. Taste has a strange note of fresh mint. Maybe celery.

Appearance: Medium amber. Slightly hazy. Finger of white foam. Nose: Light hop aroma. Grass, citrus and some floral. Lightly roasted malt. Taste: mildly bittersweet grass and citrus hops with lightly sweet caramel. Body: medium to lighter, nitro bubbles. Parting thoughts: I did have this on the nitro tap. The creamy texture was classic nitro. I feel like it might have detracted a bit from this more subtle ale.
Draft flight at Ram Columbus on June 22, 2017. Medium dark orange/amber hue, sweet somewhat medicinal aroma, somewhat soapy/malty taste with very little hop character. Pass!

Draft to taster at the Fishers brewpub. Looks decent; a transparent golden orange with white lacing. Smells and tastes of aged fruity and grassy hops with a mildly bittersweet backbone. A touch of spice on the tongue as well. Mouthfeel is medium-bodied. An inoffensive but underwhelming example of the style.
An okay pale ale. Tried this during HILT in Indianapolis in 2016. Mild and citrusy. Well balanced with caramel sweetness.

Draft at source. Aroma is very floral and fruity with light citrus hop notes. Not a bad aroma. Fairly hazy orange with minimal white head. Initially bitter followed by a supporting malt but not caramel sweet. Light bread. Hop flavor is very floral like the nose, roses. Decent enough beer but I don’t care for the hops.
Tap at the brewpub. Pours a nice amber hue. A good amount of malt, caramel, with a nice hop bitterness. Pretty nice.

Full-bodied, as the description claims. Pours cloudy amber with a hearty head. Heavy malt presence is very well balanced by plenty of hops. This is heavier and more flavorful than a typical pale ale. Pretty good.

Biscuit, grainy malt aromas with some pepperry, floral hops too. Pours amber with a decent thin head. Flavors of grainy buttery malt and peppery, aspiriny, and floral hops. Did not really do it for me.

Draft at Brouwer’s. Hazy dark coppery amber with a thin whitish head. Butter, caramel, and piney hops on the nose. Rich, creamy, buttery body. Active, lively carb. Caramel, butter, toast, butter, and piney hops on the mid-palate. Serious QA issues with this batch. Gonna hafta re-rate at some point.

Easy light bronze color with filmy head. Very mild hop aroma of perhaps Willamette or Mt. Hood. Not the firecracker of explosive hop flavors for which I had hoped. A mild, slightly light-bodied APA that is rather boring for the PNW.

Draught pint at Redbones on 11/15/07 Chill-hazed amber/peach-golden body is well carbonated and topped by a neatly retained white head that leaves moderate lacing. Hoppy nose, of course, with a full floral aroma and plentiful orange, lemon and grapefruit brace on the finish. Some traces of "hop tea" in the nose, but lightly sweet vanilla-honey malts help disperse those suggestions and provide a balance. Some fresh yeast adds a light papery blandness on the finish. Liberally hopped in the nose, but I think some deeper malt sweetness would allow the hop aromatics to unfold better. As is, there’s too much exposed bitterness that dominates. No flaws, alcohol. Flavor, then, is not surprisingly quite bitter. Not too much so, I guess (though more than I prefer), but the malt is more woody than it is sugary, which seems unfavorable here, as it allows a lot of tea-like bitterness and near astringency on the finish. Tons of grapefruit and lemon. As it warms, more honeyish and graham cracker-like maltiness emerges, allowing for more balance. Really clean, with perfect carbonation and an unfiltered, almost chewy texture. Good, if rather mundane.
On CASK at Big Time Brewery Seattle, For a Ohio State Football game. Pours out a hazy amber topped with a white head. Light floral and citrus hops. A pretty bitter end. Pretty tasty from CASK.

Tap at the Big Time. Cloudy orange-brown with a nice head. The first glass of this was awesome: nice nose, fruity, lots of citrus hop flavor without the aggressiveness of most IPAs, a splendid session-style beer. After a glass of Scarlet Fire to put it into context, the second glass was still pretty darn good, though weaker on the front and more metallic-bitter on the back than that classic IPA.
cask. dark amber, thin head. i can barely smell anything, is it just me? head gathers to dozens of dark white dots. soapy beginnings that persist into the piercing bitter finish.

Cloudy copper. Thin head. Deep, pithy, citrusy hops on the nose. The flavour is balanced by Big Time standards, with woody hops and caramel/toffee malts, plus grapefruit. Smooth. Fairly mellow finish, all told.

column1: Big Time The Big Dance - Oaked
column5: On tap at Big Time. Poured deep amber with a white head. Aroma was fruity, malty, and cherry. Highly sweet with no bitterness. Thin body with a sweet finish.

column1: Big Time The Big Dance - Oaked
column5: Hazy amber,lasting beige head.Molasses alcohol nose. Sweet brown sugar molasses profile,hint of vanilla, big hop finish, light alcohol heat.

column1: Big Time The Big Dance - Oaked
column5: Hazy dark amber...loose head. The aroma is an interesting mix of citrus, caramelly/toffeeish malts, wood and a big toasted oak note. Big woody, toasty character on the palate with ample hop bitterness and a light sweet splash of vanilla. Big body. Finishes slightly chewy/earthy and woody with again a little vanilla sweetness.
A light hop aroma with some malt. Flavor is a bit plain. Some hops but really pretty smooth. Almost a bit flat. The finish is just blah, leaves things to be desired.

Tap @ Parkway. Clear, light gold pour with a short white head leaving heavy lace. Toasty, medium-light body with a musty, bitter-umami hoppiness. Not a bad APA, but more like a golden to me. A solid standby from an up and coming brewery.

Clear golden pour with a loose, sudsy white head, falls to a frayed fringe about the edges. Smells a little floral, earthy, grassy. Oddly nutty, toasty malt flavor on a light body. Hop flavor is more earthy, grassy, herbal, slightly soapy, with a mildly resinous bitter finish. This is a pretty easy sipper, but a little off in flavor.

On tap @ Parkway Tavern. Hazy gold pour with a brief, short head which leaves a moderate coarse lace. Resinous hop nose transitions into a nutty, toasty medium body with a light-roasted malt sweetness. The hops return at the finish, adding a pleasant, citrus bitterness. Very sessionable summer ale.

draft at naked city during game two of the boston la alds. pours a slightly hazy light amber with a nice creamy light white head and plenty of sheets and strings of lace. mild grassy nose. by mild, i mean you need to dampen your nostrils to pick up the aroma. bur at least no flaws show. creamy medium body with little carb. grassy, mildly biscuity mid palate, with a rather toasty hop finish.

Gold colored brew with a thin head. Aroma was very similar to their IPA to me. A little sweeter and grainier with similar hop profiles. Flavors of pale malts/biscuits and cereal grains followed by a decent herbal/leafy hop finish. Seemed pretty darn thin to me.

On draught at Washington Brewers Festival. Aroma is sour malt forward with a light citrus tone. Appearance is cloudy with a chunky white head with low retention. Flavor is sweet malt forward, slightly sour with a low hop flavor and low bittering. Mouthfeel is light bodied with low texture and no warmth. Not typical for style, has a bit more round flavor than most.

Golden-amber colour. No head. Aroma of earthy, grassy hops and diacetyl. Flat body. Diacetyl-accented character, light hops. Ack. Thin body. This brewery apparently brews one keg at a time so this sort of thing could be an abberation of the most minor kind...

12 oz can. Can says it all “dark smooth ale”. It is smooth as heck. On the sweet side due to massive malting. Tiny tiny hop detection. Sips nearly like a Russian Imperial Stout, but ‘only’ 7.8 abv. In that realm, I guess it could be considered relatively ‘sessionable’.
16 oz tallboy poured at T Mobile Park. Drank out of can so unsure of pour. Smells like molasses and malt. Malty flavour. Good.
Though it is a touch to sweet for me, I still did enjoy this beer. Full and rich stout without getting extreme.
Gotta disagree with some reviewers, I think this is an ASA. Either way it’s very interesting.
A Milk Stout parading as an American Strong Ale. I would say it leans more towards the Stout side of the scale.
Wonderful sweet and smooth! This has to be one of the bestest beers i have had in a super long time! I personally can't get enough!

Pours a dark brown with a small off white head which is gone quickly.......aroma is caramel, nut, sweet toffee.....taste is nicely bittered caramel, nut, with a medium body, touch of booze near the end, slight earth, nut finish. Quite refreshing. Well done.

355ml can, Antenna America, Kannai. Pours dark brown with some light brown foam on the top, disappearing fairly quickly. Nose is nutty, some caramel and strong malty base there, lightly spicy. Bitter notes. Taste is caramelly as well, light toasted character with subdued malt sweetness in the background. Bittenress giving an extra edge. Light tartness there. Dry finish with some spices lingering together with bitterness on the tongue even after drink itself is long gone.
355ml can. thanks Devyn. Pours dark brown with a creamy off-white head. Aroma is pomegranate juice and raisin. Flavor is sweet and spiced, bit metallic. nothing special.
One of my favorite beers. A dark malty beer that is very smooth. Nice balanced taste w/ hints of chocolate and caramel. Enjoyed this as a draft at the Iron Duck Restaurant in Ellensburg. Nice place

Rating #2092- 2015.09.28 #CraftTakesSeattle Day 5, Beer 194 – Draught at Brewpub - Lunch before the plane ride home. This is a crisp, clear, grainy blonde beer with a dry, bland, macro feel. Grassy, mild vegetal. Bleh.
At EBB Lake City. Creamy golden yellow, sweet creamy aroma. Body is muddle and sweet. Alright, solid beer, but not my thing. Banana and grain.
On tap at West Seattle brewpub. Pours out a cloudy straw topped with a white head. Aroma of crisp malts. Tast more of the malt and some light bread.
Hazy amber colour. Earthy, mossy hop aroma. Sweetish character, just enough to counter a light grassy hoppiness. Good for what it is - a boring style.
Draught (6.5% ABV) at The Hereford Beer House, Hereford. Gold with no head. Drying apple skin notes with a tannic acid background, sharp bitterness. Reasonable cider.

A Mes rate. Cask at the Southampton Arms. Hazy orange brown colour. Decent fruit, some spice and a hint of cinnamon too. Not really dry enough for my liking thanks to a sugary hit in the finish. Decent stuff though.
Barrel @ Soton Beer Festival 07. Fruity with dryish finish and almost bitter nutty finish. Drinkable but not great.
Rating from 2005. Sehr schön süffiges Kristallweizen. Süßlich-mild, weich und sortentypisch. Allein im Nachgeschmack etwas herb für ein Kristallweizen, aber durchaus harmonierend. --> 11
The bottle looks good, the beer in the glass is very zippy, but not much foam. Tastes sourish and dry, the fruityness is missing. Finish too hard. Not a good kristallweizen!
Bottle, 5.3%. Weak aroma. Clear yellow colour, white head. Slight plastic flavour. Some wheat. A bit rough.
50 cL bottle. Pours clear and pale yellow with a dense white head. Light butterish aroma. Flavour is spiced and mild malty. Dry spiced and buttery finish.

Bottle (bought at the brewery): Pale golden, rapidly vanishing white foam; delicate grainy-wheaty and clovey nose with traces of nutmeg; rather sweet flavour; wheaty, slightly sourish and sweetish finish. No pleasure.......

(bottle) Clear, golden colour with a medium-sized foamy white head. Sweet wheaty and slightly bready nose with sourish notes of citrus. Sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a lively carbonation. Pretty undynamic wheat-malty, slightly fruity taste; quite bitter, slightly hoppy finish with spicy phenols. Not a bad example of the style.
Ich muss ich dem Doppelbock anschließen, ein wenig aromaschwach und wässrig, also eigentlich nicht wirklich gut... Test vom 22.1.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 14,8,11,7,11,7 - 8,65
The bottle looks good, the beer in the glass also. Starts like a good hefeweizen, fruity, yeasty, lilke banana. The finish is a bit weaker, bit still round and well balanced. Good beer!
Bottle, 5.0%. Weak banana aroma, hint of citrus. The flavour has a little banana and citrus and a bit more bitterness than most Hefeweizens.

50 cL bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a huge white and slowly collapsing white head. Medium dry wheaty and light estery/bubblegum aroma. Flavour is solid fruity from the esters and light wheaty to. Medium dry. Light yeasty touch into a dry estery finish.

Bottle (bought at the brewery): Hazy, deep golden, plenty of bubbles, slowly diminishing fluffy white head; moderate orangey-yeasty, a bit wheaty nose with a molecular hoppiness in the wings; solid sweet-bitter flavour, light to medium-bodied; wheaty-yeasty aromas in the sweet and a bit sourish finish. Very pleasant, very refreshing bottom fermented Wheat-beer..............

(bottle) A bottom-fermented beer, brewed with mostly wheat-malt sounds interesting and is pretty uncommon (not only) in Germany. Cloudy, orange colour with a big and dense foamy white head. Yeasty, moderately sweet, distinctive wheat-malty and grainy aroma with vanilla and light fruity notes of apricots and citrus. Medium-sweet flavour with a light touch of acidity, light bodied with a lively carbonation. Strong grainy, cereal-like taste with notes of vanilla and a very subtle fruitiness; medium-dry, wheaty and grainy finish with loads of vanilla and cereals in the aftertaste. Pleasant to drink and likeable brew.

“Michael Premium Pilsner“, vom Faß im Gasthof zum Deutschen Haus, Weißenstadt. - Goldgelb, blank, schöner sahniger Schaum. - Antrunk mild aber elegant kräuterig (Petersilie?) und mit milder Zitronenschale gehopft. Zartes helles Malz mit feiner Restsüße. Mild rezent, weich im Mund. Im Abgang leicht trockene, mild zitronenschalige Hopfenherbe mit Anklängen an Chinin oder Pampelmusenschale. - Mild aber fein gehopftes Pilsner mit individueller Hopfennote, ohne wuchtige Herbe aber rund und süffig. Sehr schön.
50cl bottle from the brewery shop. Pours clear golden colour with a mid-sized most good lasting white head. Aroma of grainy malt, bitter spicy hops. Taste of grains, bitter spicy hops, average Pils!
Many thanks for this beer to Beerhunter111. Pours a clear golden color with white foamy head. Aroma - Malts, bread, grass. Taste - Hops, herbs, malts.
Mild bitterer Beginn. Steigend herb, hell würzig. Trockener Mittelteil, bitter zum Ende mit angenehmem Hopfen. Typisches Pils. 8/8/9/9/7/8

Draft pour in Weissenstadt. Clear gold and effervescent with a lasting head. Little hop aroma, simple calcium carbonate mineral quality, light touch of baked crackers and bread from the malt. Rough carbonation, lightly sweet, lightly bitter, pasty in the mouth. No character whatsoever.

It’s golden with a creamy, white head and the aroma has initial strong notes of vegetables and cooked cabbage, but it get’s a little better and reveils malt and straw too. The flavor has a light sweetness and notes of malt, straw and caramel, and the flavour is slightly dry.

500ml bottle! The beer in glass is golden yellow with a slight reddish tinge. The head is very durable and fine. The smell is VERY sweet-hoppy. Starts with good aroma hops and moderately tart. The aftertaste is hoppy-bitter. Could be more recent, all in all. The further course is then clearly bitter.

Bottled. A golden beer with a white head. The aroma has notes of malt as well as lighter notes of caramel and straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and straw as well as lighter notes of eggs and butter, leading to a dry, bitter, and strawy finish.
The bottle looks good - but the name says nothing about the beer. The beer in the glass is okay, creamy head. Tastes spicy, only modest hoppy, malty and well balanced finish. Good beer!

Bottle 50cl.
Clear light to medium yellow color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, moderate buttery. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20081004]

500ml bottle! The beer in glass is orange-yellow and medium cloudy, which loses its head, unfortunately, very fast. The smell is yeasty clovy. Starts very yeasty, subtle clove flavor, while very spicy effect. Towards the middle part it gets a little fruity, tangy, what does the whole very good. The finish is then fermented fruity, sour becoming minimal.
Bottled. An unclear golden beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of malt as well as a touch of butter. The flavor is sweet malty with light notes of butter.

Bottle 50cl. Unclear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, hay, light to moderate yeasty, moderate toffee. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20090321]
Bottle 50 cl. Pours almost clear golden with an off-white head. Lightly sweet fruit aroma. Medium-bodied, banana and yeast. Lightly astringent finish. 210309
The bottle looks good, the beer in the glass also. Starts strong and yeasty, modest sourish, the finish is much too dry and floury. Not my favourite!
Bottle, 5.6%. Weak plastic aroma, not too bad. Hazy grey amber colour. Small white head. The flavour is a little old, yeasty and malty, but drinkable.

50 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Mild hoppy aroma with a light bitterness showing through. Vague butterish note in aroma and initial flavour. Light bitter and mild cornish finish.

500ml bottle (One Pint, Helsinki, German beer days 2007) Light orange, with a big fluffy white head. Pink perfumy aroma. Slightly watery in the mouth at first but on swallowing you realise it’s quite bitter. Not unpleasant, but missing something body-wise.

Bottle (purchased at the brewery): Slightly hazy, pale golden, small, but persistent white foam, a touch of vegetables in the wheaty, a bit phenolic nose; medium bodied, moderate sweet, slightly bitter flavour; sweetish-fruity (bananas), a bit tart and bitter finish. Neither pleasant nor disgusting.........

(bottle) Hazy, orange colour with a big foamy white head. Slightly yeasty and sweet malty aroma, moderately wheaty and fruity (citrus, banana) with light spicy phenols. Sweet, slightly acidic flavour, light to medium bodied with a lively carbonated mouthfeel. Slightly yeasty, slightly grainy taste with a moderate wheat-character, also citrus fruity; a bit slim and sour, wheaty and fruity finish. Average Hefeweizen.

Chadds Ford. Poured a medium amber color body with a small slippery off-white head. The aroma was a sweet resiny pine with someflral notes and a little sourdough. The flavors are mostly sticky grapefruit and resiny pine with a little citrus and some mild yeast. Good enough for me to take home a growler.

Draft at Chadds Ford. The pour was deep copper with off-white head. The aroma was hoppy, piney, tannic, with not a lot of malt. It looked very good and smelled pretty good, but the taste was rather weak in the malt department, giving a sort of hoppy iced tea flavor, but not sweet. This isn’t one I’d quaff again.

On tap: Nice banana aroma with light bubblegum and hints of citrus. Hazy golden-orange with a minimal white head. The flavor starts with a nice dose of banana and faint bubblegum. Light citrusy background. The finish has light lemon, pepper, and mild bitterness. Light bodied with soft carbonation.
On tap at D room. Cloudy golden in color with a nice white head. Malty grainy fruity aroma. Citrusy floral notes. Hoppy and malty flavor. Finish is bitter. Medium bodied. Drinkable.
On tap at Drafting Room. Hazy gold with a lasting head. flavor is cereal with some pineapple and a nice amount of bitterness hops in the finish. Boozy and somewhat tasty.

On tap at the D Room. Pours a hazy golden yellow with a medium creamy lacing white head. Aroma of light citrus, floral, cereal grains and pretzels. Lots of hop flavor and bitterness, some grapefruit, bready and piney. Being a lager there is not a whole lot of fruitiness so the hop flavor and bitterest is up front.

Tap. Yellow with nice white head. Aroma was pilsner like. Malty note throughout. The taste was pretty firm with some sweetness. citrus hop finish. Thicker. The sign stated that this was an imperial pilsner.....thats what it looked and tasted like, not a european strong ale.

As far as "regular ol-" lagers go, this is one of the best, a dark golden color with a modest white head, left a nice lacing around the glass, nose of wheat, slight citrus & bread, flavors of grapefruit, caramel & toast, full-bodied, got that "full" feeling after finishing a pint of this, a very well-done lager

Clear golden body with a clean foamy white head. Citrusy pineapple aroma with sourdough and hay notes. Doughy pale malt background in the flaovr, plus abundant fresh hops. Has a vague lemony-cat box quality. Lightly sweet with some notable tartness and developing bitterness. A big, hoppy pilsner. This is a little rough around the edges, but grew on me.

Poured a hazy dark golden color with a small, white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of bread, toffee malts, citrus, cereal, and floral hops. Taste was sweet up front, cereal grains, wood, bubblegum, light skunk, toffee malts, vanilla, citrus, and a moderate bitterness in the finish. Light alcohol as well in the finish.

Draft at DRE. Hazy medium golden pour with 1-finger whitish head. The aroma is very hoppy and citric, with a solid amount of floral spicy peppery hints. It smelled to me like a sort of hoppy saison at first, with a lot of peppery notes. The palate is medium, crisp, and complex, with flavors of pale malt, citric hops, and a lot of finishing black pepper and some floral notes, all while stylistically retaining the pilsner signature. I had a pint, then a growler, and I’ll be going back for another growler or two of this. And, indeed, the 7% alcohol is truly well hidden. This one is great.

On tap at TDR Springhouse. Happens to be my RB rating #3,200. Poured a meduim golden color with a smaller sized white head. Aromas and tastes of grass (not an overpowering grassiness), light spices, some citrus and somewhat of a honey sweetness. Didn’t realize the alcohol content was over 7%.
I thought this was really amazing. Nice pilsener style, sweet, almost a candycane sweet. Had a bit of spice, nice smooth body, very nice brew.
Fotoforititxyxotxit og lt leh or itighgbxlhcohcohdkhxmgxkhchclhhfjfykhfkhcjycjhxhckgxkhckhcjcmhv ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This pale ale is not bad, but it is not very interesting either. Malty flavour and little bitterness, weak hop aroma and taste. But it has improved, as the first time I tasted it it was all diacetyl. A little more bitterness would make it a lot better.
Hazy light brown liquid, small head. Sweet aroma of malt with hints of fruit and berries. Light body, average carbonation. Taste is sweet, a bit sour.

Draught, Capitol HillCloudy dark amber. Not much head. Fruity aroma (banana, with hints of smoke). Whoa - really pithy hop bitterness. Fluffy body (that’s good malts) but kind of fizzy (and bad carbo). Interesting - a way overhopped weizen - but the components aren’t working all that well together. The grapefruity bitterness is doing its own thing, the sweet banana weizen is doing its own thing, but they aren’t coming together and the beer suffers as a result.
Its a very nice pub to go with friends or with your girlfriend/boyfriend. Great pub!!!

Tasted this in the Three Judges, Glasgow in April 2006. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear pale straw in colour with a thin creamy white head. Strong lingering aroma of dusty hops in this. Thin resiny mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt base gives a slight digestive biscuit note with really tart grapefruit peel and lemon drop notes. Any sweetness is soon lost amid a big whack of drying hop resins sucking all the moisture out of your mouth like a wet vac. Finish is dry, astringent and very bitter with dry hop flowers evident. Not my favourite from the portfolio but if you like moisture sucking bitters then this is for you.
Cask@Criterion, Leicester. Golden beer with a dry and floral aroma. The flavour is bitter and quite dry. Overall a quite plain dry and bitter beer.
Cask at Paterborough beer fest. Alround rating: Grassy, hoppy, quite bitter, lemony citrus character. Exactly what im used to from durham, good stuff.

A Mes rate: gravicask at Peterborough Beer Festival. Bright yellow gold with a thin white rim and wery good condition. Pleasant straw and hay aroma with some good citric notes. Very grassy in the mouth with a lovely malt base. Excellent citric bitterness in the finish. Gloriously dry and pleasing mouthfeel. Being used to their high abv brews, this is something new to me; a sessionable and very drinkable beer from Durham. Lovely.

Cask, The Flowerpot, Derby. Amber gold with a small head. Aromas are Autumn fruit with bitter, earthy hops. Quite prickly. Flavours are dry bitter hops. Lightly fruity with lemon and bitter grapefruit on the finish. Easy drinking clean beer.
Cask@Flowerpot, Derby. Reddish brown beer with a lightly dry and malty aroma and a malty, dry and yeasty flavour. Overall an average beer.

Cask, The Flower Pot, Derby. Brown with red tints and a small head. Aromas are malty with chocolate. Flavours are malty and fruity with some berries and citrus. Some chocolate, too. Dry on the finish.
Cask@Babington Arms, Derby. Black beer with a light head. The aroma is lightly malty and sour and the flavour is lightly malty and dry. Overall an average beer.

Cask, The Babington Arms, Derby. Very dark brown with a beige foam. Aromas are chocolate with cream. Lactose with earthy malts. Flavours are creamy with light roast malts. Light chocolate malts with hints of berry. A decent mild.
Cask Handpump at the Bath Hotel, Sheffield 07/04/2007 Very fruity aroma. Golden coloured fruity and a little spicy. Some dryness in a crisp and smooth malt finish.
Cask@Babington Arms, Derby. Darkly golden beer with a light head. The aroma is malty and dry and the flavour is lightly dry and malty. Overall an average beer.

Cask, The Babington Arms, Derby. Hazy gold with a dense head. Aromas are carmel malts with hay, yeast and lemon. Some acidicy. Flavours are fruity with lemon, especially in marmalade form. Clean hops with spices. Fairly bitter. Apparently this is a light version of Tabatha the Knackered. I would class it as a blond ale.

Bon Accord, gareth forgot to ask for the sparkler off. Aroma is minimal due to sparkler, hints of grass and herble hop. Taste is slightly acidic, going onto citrus hints and pale malts, a bit of chalkness in the mouthfeel.
Cask-conditioned at the Bag O’Nails, Bristol. An indifferent golden ale with a slightly sweet aroma followed by some flavours of malt and a hint of hops in the finish. Bland.

Bomber, XX edition. Rich roasted malt aroma with notes of chocolate, coffee, bourbon, oak and vanilla. Pours deep brown with a thin mocha brown head that has little retention or lacing. Starts with rich roasted malt, chocolate and coffee flavors as well as having a rich, but medium body and slick, viscous mouthfeel. Finishes quite smooth with bourbon, oak and vanilla flavors joining the rich roasted malt. May have lost a step after 11 years (especially in the body) but still quite excellent.
Vintage bottle shared by alexsdad06 pour opaque black with thin tan head. Nose mineral chocolate, molasses, prune, bakers chocolate. Taste mineral chocolate, prune, light anise, mild mineral.

Bottle via an impromptu trade with the Mitch that is mad cheers Ken; was going to save this for a special occasion with the KFC drought of 2018 and the beast from the east have fucked up my plans so I’ve decided to drink it alone, firstly it’s a shame this review will disappear along with Ratebeer I’ve gained about 2 stone because of this site which I don’t mind about because I was destined to be obese, but JoeT when we spoke you said you didn’t want to commit website suicide but you’re on that path but seriously I don’t care as long as I get to 10k, ok back to the beer it pours opaque dark brown with a thin creamy tan head, aroma has big chocolate and rich malt, taste has sweet chocolate, light bourbon, vanilla hints, very sweet, got some coconut, I like this beer,

Bottle at home on our last night in this house in Seattle. This week I’ve gone through XXV, XXIV, XXIII, and finally we’re down to the last bottle. I don’t know anymore why I wanted to buy all of these in the first place, or why I would want to hold onto them for so long, but those questions are irrelevant now. Dark pour with creamy brown head that dissipates to a ring but never disappears. Smells old (faded hops), but once it’s in the mouth it comes to life. Lovely milk chocolate with a surprisingly pleasant coffee backing. Moderately sweet; its age doesn’t detract at all at this point, and I can honestly say this is my favorite of the bunch. The rest ... aging did them no favors. Maybe that’s true here, too, but unlike those I’m actually enjoying this one. I guess they just don’t make them like they used to.
XXI Pours Black with dirty foam colored medium head. Big nose of roasted coffee. Flavor has dark chocolate, espresso and hints of bourbon. Nice thick body that is made to sip. From Old Notes

[Backlog 2014] Bottle courtesy of Eric at his place for a tasting. Pours a deep blackish brown body with nice thick tan head. Nose is oak, soft vanilla notes, toast, cream and coffee roast. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with notes of toasted malt, oak, bourbon, coffee roast, caramel and very faint sharpie marker.

First of all this is the XX version. Secondly, this is one of the weirdest beers I’ve ever had. Appearance is a short-lived brown head, no lace, and opaque brown black color. Aroma at first is dark ripe fruits, cocoa, coffee, lumber, leather, but soon that goes waaay bad - to a dirty public toilet! And that aroma kind of comes and goes, but it’s nasty. And when I went to take my first sip, my god, that nasty aroma was going into my mouth!! That wasn’t easy. After a bit the flavor gives way to the initial aroma qualities, plus whiskey, vanilla and a bit of tang and bitter. Body is so so as carbonation is on the flat side. Luckily the nastiness don’t persist into the finish.

Poured from the bottle into a small tasting glass, the first of many beers brought from home and popped open at Dark Lord Day 2011. Espresso brown in color and mostly opaque, save some amber highlights. A frothy, sticky, one-finger head the color of cocoa powder remains in place for a long while. Hints of bourbon and vanilla in the nose, along with tangy dark chocolate and too-old coffee, which may be a result of the beer’s age (close to two years now). A bit of Sourdough tang pops up. Interesting amounts of piney hops remain. When cold, Black Butte tastes like a mouthful of bottlecaps — it’s heavily metallic. Warm is much, much better, exhibiting espresso mingled with sweet cocoa powder and more bitter dark chocolate, as well as a bit of Sourdough bread and some pine. Smooth blend. Extremely light carbonation is all that remains. Silky, creamy, slightly chalky medium body. Alcohol in the nose. Coffee-forward porters aren’t usually the most graceful cellar beers, but Black Butte XXI is still pretty awesome after all this time.
Bottle thanks to Rick, pours a very dark brown with small tan head. The aroma is strong roast, coffee, wood. Medium mouthfeel with strong roast, dark chocolate, wood, vanilla, held up very well.
Pitch black color, light brown head. Charcoal, marshmallows, dark chocolate, big coffee beans, vanilla, dark chocolate, marshmallows, big espresso mouth. WOW, the espresso beans REALLY jump out.

(Cask at Wenlock Arms, London, 9 Aug 2008) Golden colour with frothy, off-white head. Fruity nose with orange, hints of dusty hops and malt sweetness. Fruity taste with notes of citrus and biscuity malt. Short, citrussy finish. Decent, but rather boring.

Cask at the Back of Beyond (JDW), Reading. Straw colour with a white head; sweet vanilla aroma; creamy in the mouth with honey and a trace of citrus; a sweet and honeyed finish. Light and refreshing, but too sweet for me.

Cask-conditioned at the Bag O’Nails, Bristol 19/6/07. Pale gold with slight white head. This was a bit like the old BBC Seaside Specials of the 1970s: inoffensive, superficially attractive, unmemorable and creating little impact. This had little aroma or flavour worth mentioning, but was easy enough to drink once.

This must be a big seller so freshness could not be an issue. C hop aroma, small head and lace in the glass, OK so far. Grapefruit taste but dry, chemical taste, terrible something gone wrong in a chemical factory aftertaste.Incredibly dissapointing double.

16oz draft at the restaurant downstairs. The Amherst Brewing Company is the best place in Amherst for a burger and a beer. This beer stood out on the chalkboard. The "double" was underlined. The aroma was lemon, citrus, and boozy pine. The color was dark orange and brown with a small head. The flavors were pine trees, molasses, oranges, and alcohol. This was similar to the Great Divide Hercules that I had last weekend. This was by far the best ABC beer that I have had. The imperial stout was 2nd. The Puffer’s Smoked Porter is 3rd.
Draft Old Boise Brewfest: Poured a clear rich yellow with a large white head. Aroma is light of malts, taste added a little hops and breadiness. Nice.
On Tap at the Old Boise Brew Fest 07 pours out clear gold topped with a white head. a little malt going on but. It’s a Pils what could be going on not much.

On Tap at the Boise Ram. Crystal clearl bright yellow with a nice snowy white head. Very faint light malt aroma. Flavor is sweet very pale malts, honey and bready. Very clean quick palatte and refreshing. Very slight metallic after taste. Nice.

Bottle: Clear yellow, nice head and lacing. Nose of crisp hops and sweet light toasty malt. Clean and dry flavor, plenty of hop bitterness to balance the floral notes. Nice crisp finish. Excellent pilsner, fresh, easy drinking, yet balanced and quaffable.

column1: Metolius Dolly Varden India Pale Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: my dad-in-law got this one at a grocery outlet, so it may be just past it’s prime, but there’s no date. the hop aroma and flavor are there, but not very floral or aromatic, and it’s a bit malt/spice/fruit heavy for my taste. medium-well bodied, ornage with small white head. even compared to east coast ipa’s, the hops (simcoe?) are overpowered by the malt and probably a little old...not the brewer’s fault, but it’s all i got. not good enough to have again."

column1: Metolius Dolly Varden India Pale Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Taste good not a overwelming bitterness Great apperance and aroma overall good beer to drink.

column1: Metolius Dolly Varden India Pale Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Not a fan. Nutty and Carmel taste mild hops. Malty. Pours dark orange and head doesn't stick at all. Would not have this again ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Metolius Dolly Varden India Pale Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Maybe the worst IPA I have tried. Skunky and weak flavor; and not Hoppy. How could an IPA not be hoppy. I love IPAs, but shouldn’t have ventured too far from Dogfish Head or the other’s that I have been enjoying

column1: Metolius Dolly Varden India Pale Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Pours very light, with a thin head. Head dissipates after a couple minutes. The taste is a bit alcohol-like. Mouthfeel is a bit dry and light. Overall a decent beer for the price. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Metolius Dolly Varden India Pale Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 26 may 2012, bottle. Yellow, clear, occasional bubbles. Nose is cane sugar malt and slightly grassy malt. Med body and mildly fizzy. Mild grassy hops, some faint sugary malt malt. Faint grapefruit bitter finish. Meh. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Metolius Dolly Varden India Pale Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 12oz. bottle from Bert’s Better Beers. Good looking brew. Thick lacing in a somewhat transparent gold color. The nose is very lightly hopped. Mostly pale malts. Some easy malt and bread like qualities. Almost no hops in the finish. Feels very much like an APA rather than a true IPA. No way to tell the age, but I know Bert doesn’t sell old beer so…. This is a very low end IPA. Not bad, just nothing to get excited about.

column1: Metolius Dolly Varden India Pale Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle at home, out of my Maudite glass, thanks to Duffman for the trade! Pours clar golden bronze, with a 1-finger thick cream-coloured head, solid lacing. Nose is... offputting. Pencil shavings, vague citrus, hot metal, some grain/chaff notes here, also spent grains, almost tannic... lots of sawdust in the aroma too. Like sawdust and hot metal filings... Flavours of round clean grain, some vegetal hops, really not much going on. Almost disappointingly good after how genuinely wretched the nose was. Dreadful stuff. Avoid at all costs.

column1: Metolius Dolly Varden India Pale Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: bottle. sneaking f-ing pyramid brewery! always making up new breweries to try and sling their products. same average pyramid beer in a different labeled bottle. keep trying guys.........I do however appreciate the fish label.

column1: Metolius Dolly Varden India Pale Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: From a bottle. I think Duffman gave me this beer from a six pack. Didn’t care for it. Not bad, but by no means good... tons of better IPAs.
