(Bottle) Very bad beer. Amber colour, weak head that disappears quickly. Aroma is sweet, tea like... Tea with lemon. Taste is very watery. In absolute distance I can taste little bit of malt and slight bitterness. Finish is like mineral water. Almost no body with high carbonation. This beer is as if someone made this half beer and half water. Week, watery and almost no features.
Bottle. Pours a golden amber with a short-lived white head. Stale sweet grainy aroma. Watery graint palate, sweet but light, with a boxboard note in the finish. Don’t bother.
On tap at the brewery bar. Pours golden with a fluffy dissapearing head. Little malt aroma. Slightly bitter hop palate, good malty body, clean crisp finish. Some lingering malt and hop.
(On tap) Clear, deep golden with a creamy, white head. Lightly sweet caramel nose. Light in body, light notes of malt - everything about this beer seem light! Short and dry finish. 190208
Tasted 27/10/2007. 5oz sampler from the brewery bar. Amber, caramelly, watery, fizzy, alcohol, sans hops. We’ve all tasted this before, haven’t we?
330ml bottle. Little or no aroma. Moderate malty notes but no bitterness nor too sweet. Clean but uneventful.

Bottle from Queens Plaza Beer & Wine 220215. Thin looking and thn in the mouth. Looks like a weak glass of cold tea. No head, very little aroma and flavour. Not sure where the "classic" part of the name comes into it.

Bottle. Clear light amber, thin brief head. Weak aroma of caramel and apples. Thin palate with weak flavours of caramel and cider. Finish is dry with a boxboard staleness. On the poor side of average.
On tap at brewery bar. Pours pale golden. Small malt aromas, clean body, bitter, not much hop, a bit watery. Nutty malt lingers a bit. Quite simple.
(On tap) Clear, amber golden with a small, white head. Sweetish malt aroma. Light in body with light notes of malt and caramel. There’s also a light, underlying acidity. The finish is dry. 190208

Tasted 27/10/2006. 5oz taster from tap at the brewery bar. Brown, whispy off-white head, caramelly, slight ester. Cold, quite thin and with a sugary cidery bite. Nothing wrong with this, besides the philosophy behind it’s recipe.
330 ml bottle. Std NZ draught colour. Slight biscuity and a damp cotton aroma. Quite malt/mealy flavours but a thin finish. Decent alternative to other mainstream offerings.

This appears on the golden side of lager with minimal head from the pour into the glass. There runs an almost standard lager malt aroma with just a faint suggestion of noble hops, or I could be talking out my arse and it smells of non-noble varieties. To give it its due, it smells like a legion of standard lagers. Sadly in this age of celebrated differentiation, it isn’t enough. The flavour is a little plain with pale malt and a twinge of bitterness. Probably ideal as a quaffing beer on a warm day when critical analysis is the last thing on your mind.

Drank this last night whilst watching my mates play indoor football. Forced to sit out due to a fractured ankle i thought I might as well enjoy a beer whilst i watched. bargain price of $3.50 which almost exactly matched the change in my pocket, so I was pleased, but only momentarily. Had a sip and thought ’somethings amiss here’ . It claimed it was all malt but it was so thin and wrong tasting i doubted its veracity but looking closer saw the label indicated a small amount of wheat in the grist which might account for the thin-ness in the mouth. No hops to speak of and possibly the least appealing beer I’ve had in a while. At least the boys won at football though

On tap at Matson’s brewery bar. Pours golden with a thin head. Bit of malt and hop in the aroma but not very strong. Starts with bitter hops then a robust malthy body comes through which stays with you for a while. Quite a nice aftertaste which mkes you want another sip. Excellent social beer but nothing out of the ordinary.
(On tap) Clear golden with a small, white head. Vaguely perfumy aroma. Light-bodied with weak malty accents. The finish is dry and lightly bitter. 190208

Tasted 27/10/2006. 5oz taster from the brewery bar. Honey malt sweetness, carbonic dryness doesn’t quite cut through, and absolutely nothing to show in the hop department. Another well made beer with "Old school beer drinker" written all over it. Why, oh why? Good plant, obviously well used (given that the beers are prtty clean), but there’s nothing going for these beers in the recipe.

330ml bottle. Light straw golden, fair fluffy head. Faint citrus/lemon aroma. Brief but unremarkable, slight hints of dryness and flirts with wheat but nothing to test the tastebuds. Again, fairly mainstream.
Thin head, clear dark brown body. Light nutty aroma. Taste is grassy hops, light buttery malts. Slightly toasted. Finishes light sour, molasses. Hint of burn. Light texture, slightly oily.

Nose is leather, wet hay, vanilla, mild chocolate, coffee, and toffee notes. Quickly disappearing head, very dark brown. Wonderfully complex flavor features everything on the nose with the addition of vinous dark fruit notes. Wonderful mouth feel which is slightly hurt by alcohol. A very nice drinking experience. I actually prefer the regular Old Engine Oil, but this is definatly a little bit more complex beer due to the dark/dried fruits and leather/vanilla notes.

Pours near black, perhaps very very dark brown with brown head. Nose has a clean, marshmallowy roastiness at first. Start to notice some baking chocolate too after a few whiffs. On the palate is baker’s chocolate, spirity/alcohol, and a smooth chocolate finish. The chocolate comes across in a dry way - not very sweet. Finish is a little chalky and alcoholic.
Cask Handpump at the Roundhouse, Barrow Hill 19/05/2007 Small tan head. Black rich strong and fruity with a smooth and bitter burnt roast finish. ABV 9.0%

STBF07. Beautiful beer to look at. Aroma is sweet roasted barley, chocolate out its nut, hints of chocolate coated coffee beans. Has perhaps the best mouthfeel iv ever had in a beer. Taste is amazing chocolate chocolate chocolate. Win Win Win!
Edinburgh Beer festival 07 ... deep red black ... rich smokey deep malt ... sweet roast ... lots of coffee ... lots of chocolate ... smooth
Good.. But somehow generic. (This beer rating was imported from FB and unfortunately lacks any further comments.)
On tap at Tinkoff Brewpub, St Petersburg. A little thin but drinkable porter. Slightly sweet caramel and some roasted malt flavour. By no means a great beer but worth a try if you’re in the area.

Bottled, 6.0% / 14%. Neither a porter, nor a dunkel (as his less stronger predecessor). It is probably vienna, but with lack of normal hop bitterness. Dark amber with thin head. Taste is neutral and slightly grainy and alcoholic.
Bottle. Brown color, little head. Fruity aroma. Sweet malty, can feel alcohol too. Aftertaste isnt long.
0.5l bottle. brown with small beige head. Not a porter IMO. sweet and roasted.very light. yeast. not very special.

[i](Bottle bbe 07/2007)[/i] Dark brown, thin beige head. Nose is syrupy malts, some vanilla like wood and rye pudding. Flavor has roasted malts, quite sweet & syrupy. Some raisins and liquorice, not much hops. Medium bodied and a bit sticky palate. This one is more like a sweet dunkel.
Bottled Amberish brown with a very small head. Sweet toffee aroma with notes of tobacco and maybe some smoke. Dry flavour of dark, bitter chocolate. Somewhat harsh finish.
Bottled, thanks oh6gdx! Nut brown, minimal head. Light licorice aroma. Sweet and quite fruity. medium bodied with some light caramelly malt. No bitterness.
Pours dark like the night of Leningrad. Mild sweet malty taste. A bit sweet and sour breadish aroma. Too thin to be a decent porter.

(Bottle BB 10/10/07) Caramel, slightly roasted aroma with a hint of alcohol. Dark amber colour, clear and small, white head. Caramel and slightly roasted malty flavour. Lively carbonated and medium-bodied palate. 23/08/07
Had on tap at Fitgers, with raspberry syrup, cloudy grapefruit pour. Aroma of raspberry and a nice light funk. Taste is light raspberry and solid sour.
On tap at Winterfest 2013. Yellow pour with head. Wheat with a tart fruitiness, wish they would have had the syrup like Pour Decisions had with Acerbity at the event.
Tap at Winterfest 2013. Gold pour with a big white head. Wheat and mild fruit, slightly tart. Decent berliner weisse, but falls a little short of Acerbity in my opinion.
Thanks to Mike for this... Clear honey gold, nice bright white head... Nose is honey wheat with a bit of lemon and a bit of musk... The taste is mostly lemon with some brett, super easy to drink

Pours clear yellow from a growler, with nice white head. Aroma has notes of lemon, biscuit, touch of funk. Tastes starts slightly tart, goes into lemon and biscuit, and a slightly harsh bitter finish from the lively carbonation. Not a bad berliner, has all the right components, just needs to get more sour to really close it all.

Growler. Clear light yellow pour, plenty of effervesence and a bready lemon aroma. Flavor was watery thin, lemons and a little malt on the finish. Not quite what I was hoping for, but this would be great for a hot summer day (hope they consider changing the release date someday).

[Growler] Pours very hazy orange with a tiny white head. Aroma is certainly big on wheat, with pear and lemon also present. Taste is very nice, with the big wheat character balanced with green apple, peach skin, pear, and nice acidity. I don’t like high carbonation, but was this was a little flat even for me. Otherwise, medium mouthfeel, with a very long finish. Overall, a very nice beer that is dangerously drinkable, and only got better as I drank more of it.

Approx. 4oz pour out of a growler. Thank you so very much for saving a bit of this for me Will! Pours a hell of a lot darker than any Berliner Weiss I’ve ever encountered. Dark, thick, muddy brown with some orange highlights. Little appearance of carbonation. Funky and lightly tart yeast on the nose. Slightly malty. Definite hints of brown sugar. A bit of candy/toffee sweetness. Green apple and pear skin upon warming. Flavor is incredibly tart and acidic for a Berliner Weiss... awesome! Very tart on the sides and back of the tongue with a bruisingly acidic finish. Definitely full bodied for the style. The finish lasts forever... I wish this were on tap all the time, I’d drink the hell out of this! Thanks a ton Will!

(growler, thanks STLWill!) Pours hazy gold with a white head. This is far darker than most Berliner Weisses. Aroma is not really sour, but instead there are scents of grapes and some yeastiness, along with lightly toasted malt. The taste is definitely sour, and tastes just like a sweet-tart candy. The finish is just very dry and sour, and carries on well after drinking. This is really good, and it is significantly underrated.

Growler RBSG 07. Murky orange pour with a white head. Aroma of appl skin, light cherry, toasted malt, vinous and sour notes. Flavors of dry white wine, sour, and apple skin. Light body, sour throughout with a super dry finish. Nice way to start the evening.
(Growler) Pours a dark brown body with a small beige head. Aroma of tobacco, toasted bread, orange peel, and coriander. Flavor of herbs, toasted malt, caramel, and cocoa with a dry finish.

Growler... RBSG 07... Pours dark with a mid-sized, frothy, tan head. This wit’s aroma is of the usual suspects (bread dough, orange peel, coriander, banana), but with a nice dose of cocoa thrown into the mix. Spicy, caramel flavor with moderate sweetness, mild bitterness and lots of coriander and cocoa. Light bodied and pretty thin with medium carbonation. Crisp, spicy, chocolate finish. Strange brew!

Thanks to JK and Badgerben for bringing this growler south from Duluth to the Twin Cities. Sampled at the RBSG ’07 Grand Tasting room, pours an opaque dark brown brew with a thick tan head. Aroma of sweet caramel malt, cloves, and a touch of vegetable margarine. Taste of roasted wheat malt, yeast, coriander, and some bubblegum. Palate is light bodied, carbonated with a slight metalic feel. Finish is dry malty, with some spice aftertaste.

RBSG07. From growler. Pours black with a creamy head. Aroma is butterish, coriander and bubblegum yeast. Flavour is wheaty with notes of yeast. Malty finish. Solid but nothing really great. I had this at the end of the evening, so I guess even though the cap was on the growler it had oxidised a bit.
Dark black body with a tan head. Coriander spice with some other spices. Caramel and some other spices.
RBSG 2007, dark and tan: spicy nose with caramelly taste. Very syrupy finish.

(RBSG07, growler) Cola black body with beige head. Aroma is medium sweet, some sourness, wheat, light clove. Taste is medium sweet, wheat, light caramel, coriander. Watery light body. I assume this is a stab at a Tarwebier.

I will echo JK--at the brewpub they had this labeled a "white night". Very interesting beer. Dark black, clinging head. Interesting flavors, suggesting of curry (that coriander, perhaps). It works interesting things with food pairings. Worth a try. (on tap at brewpub)
RBSG 2007: Poured dark brown with a tan head. Aroma, cloves, some spice, sweet malts. Flavor, very spicy, caramel, some floral notes. Sweet and spicy on the finish.
Sampled at the RBSG 07 Grand Tasting. Black beer with balanced malt and hops. dry malt finish with a bit of spice. Better than I expected.

Bottle 49/424. Pours a hazy brine color with minimal tan head. Aroma is sweet fruity, citrusy, juicy, kind of a rotten fruit character. Flavor is fruit juice, apples, citrus, but no sourness whatsoever, enemy after drinking a bunch of impy stouts.
Pours a gross purple brown. Dirty fruit smell. Taste is bad fruit. Dog poop. Thanks drewface -- rated with beerbasher/winphone
bottleshare thanks to DexterCat. Nose is like applesauce and paper/cardboard. Bottle #49 of 424 shelfies. Taste is a malt and fruit bomb. Absolutely no sourness. Decent but not a sour.
Bottleshare thanks to Drewface. 49/424. Pours cloudy brown/amber. Aroma is weird, funky, almost like dirty underwear. Taste is malty, weird, sweet, and still like dirty draws. Not a fan.

Thanks Jason for sharing. Bottle 181. The beer pours to a deep mahogany with a thin white head. Aroma is light and grainy with rhubarb. Flavor is sweet and tangy and rhubarb. The palate is sweeter than I would have expected.

750mL bottle, #181/424. Poured very deep garnety-brown with a nice cap of toasted beige head. The aroma picked up sour cherries, Bretty funk, lactic notes, and oak over warmer fruity sugars.. this was very good. The flavor found sour cherries, oak, and a bit of Balsamic vinegar over pale and fruity malts.. sour, spicy, and a bit refreshing on the finish. Medium-bodied and engaging on the palate.. this was way better than expected.
bottle. p hazed amber wh head n funky soapy fl sharp vinager and sweet grain some tropical fruit, mushy and odd. 6/3/6/3/13

Bottle shared by Jeff at the RBSG (no shirts necessary) hotel tasting. Pours brown orange with a white thin head. Tart red fruit cherries in the aroma - mellow but decent. Tart cheesy earthy cherries oak funky flavors. Really interesting and a pretty solid beer. 8/3/8/3/15

Bottle shared by Jeff during the opening night of the RBSG, thanks for all the effort and the great beers you shared! Poured a cloudy amber brown with a yellowish brown head that was thick and lasted. Aroma was quite tart/sour with cherries mainly and there was a backing caramel and toffee note. Flavor was similar with a sour overtone, mainly cherries with caramel and toffee backing.

750 ml shared by northerbrews. Thanks! Amazing share! Pours a deep dark brownish red hue, dark and hazy, a nice frothy offwhite towards tan head laces well. Aromas are caramel and toffee, sour cherries, a decent nice sourness and touch of lactic acid. Initial is similar, light tartness. Decent sour, tasty with caramel and biscuits with with sour cherries. Lingering bread and biscuits. A lighter but decent sour. Not bad fairly sweet still even with time.. Kinda has that typical New Holland sour lightness and still fairly biscuity. Not bad, just not very sour
Black with a light tan head and some lacing, nose of dark roasted malts, bitter coffee flavor, nice smooth finish. Pretty good.

Date: 07/24/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub black, fine brown head, lots of patterened lace, faint dry roasted malt aroma, big thick body, rich dark chocolate and roasted malt aroma, just enough sweetness to balance the dark malts, nice long bitter finish, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.5/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **+/4

Of all the beers I’ve tasted at Red Star, this is definitely the most offensive. IMHO Red Star is usually known for their gentle and impressive lager variations. IF you like imp stout you otta get a growler of this stuff. I’m not an imp stout lover so ignore my numbers and just read the text if you are a liker of that style. Imperial stout aroma and appearance. Barely any head but lots of cool looking lacing. Very little if any carbonation greets the palate. Oppressive bitterness on the initial slug that is so common with many imp stouts. Bitter back of throat impression like somebody made me eat a piece of meat that was cooked way to long and charred on the grill. Oh yes, imp stout style to the max. Such a contrast to the rest of the beers I’ve had at Red Star! Overall, imp stouts are just a little too much for my girlie taste buds. Not quite as good as Old Heathen but I liked Old Heathen because it is a bit milder than most imp stouts.

Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured pitch black with a large dark brown head that lingered. The aroma was fairly strong roasty malts, coffee and floral hops. The flavor was dry, very roasty and had elements of bitter coffee, toffee and floral hops. There was a long bitter roasty finish. The beer had a fairly thick mouthfeel.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Bright amber color, with a small beige head, leaving laces, toasted malt, with a grainy note, with a hint of buttery caramel, with some toffee and nutty accents, subtle floral hop in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a crisp crunchy, grainy toasted malt character, with a leafy flowery hop note, a faint fruity accent of sultana, leading towards a grainy, malty, dry hop finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a hazy gold with thin white head. Somewhat flat for the style and slightly flavorless. Not enough belgian funk on the finish.

Pours copper with a thin white head. Smells of spice and dry hops with some sweet underlying malt. Tastes sweet with some underlying spiciness. Mouthfeel is a little on the thin side for the style. Overall, a decent attempt.
Wypite 09.2017 Zapach: Ciemne pieczywo, przypalona skórka od chleba, jasny s³ód. Smak: Lekka palonoœæ, karmel i lekka metalicznoœæ. Próba na ¿elazo nic nie wykazuje. Koncerniak zdatny do wypicia
01-09-18 // bottle at the Lowest Bar on Earth at the Dead Sea in Jerusalem. Tasted great after mudding in the dead sea :D a sweetish, slightly roasted malty beer.
on tap in Tel Aviv. Pours amber with white head. body is medium and smooth. Taste is of grain caramel malt and herbal hops. much better than I expected.

Bottle poured into a plastic cup. Clear amber with white head. The aroma has notes of grains, caramel and some lemon. Bitterish and sourish flavor with notes of grains, caramel and lemon. Light to medium-bodied.
Mediocre lager. Fairly standard but more on the malty side and a bit sweet. Better than most other choices in Israel though. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle with a different opening cap. It poured an amber color with an off-white head. The aroma was of herbs and grain. The taste was of grass, grain, herbs and some caramel. It had a light body and was sweet.

330ml bottle in Israel. Sweetish malty beginning. Fresh but smooth. Hints of alcoholic sweetness, but round. Refreshing with not much bitterness in the aftertaste, round and malty-sweetish nice. Easy to drink, nice malty sweetness, round and good!

Bottle, 330ml. Pours clear copper, with a medium-short light beige head. Aroma of sweet malt, fruity hops. Body is light, with medium strong carbonation. Slightly oily texture. Tastes slightly sweet with light hops bitterness. Flavors of malt, light caramel, hops, vegetal. Quite crisp and refreshing but ends slightly sticky, with notes of caramel and sweet malt. A very acceptable commercial beer.

Well it's an improvement on the "Green" pale lager, but still sub-par and overall unappetizing. This amber lager pours a dirty earthy bronze appearance, decent head and lacing. Aroma is nonexistent but clean. Taste is malty, caramel, some hop bitterness actually palatable, but something's off. The mouthfeel was alright, smooth and medium bodied. I would say it's Yuengling's awkward European half-brother, haha. In Israel, Goldstar definitely recommended over this.
On tap. Pours amber, clear, frothy head, some lacing. Aroma: caramel, metal, malt. Taste: caramel, malt, hint of hops, hint of buckwheat honey.

Pours a clear amber brown on tap with fluffy off-white head that leaves light lace. Aroma of sweet malt and a hint of crisp yeast. Taste follows, almost lager like. Really not that exciting, which is probably what most people want at a baseball game.
Tastes like it would be served at a ballpark. Got a pint in the ATL airport. Nice deep color. Very brown. Vaguely reminiscent of a brown ale actually. Not hoppy. Simple.
Not bad for AB. A good amber similar to Yuengling but a little sweeter. Perfect for some Georgia Bulldog ball cap tip-it-on-back-to-me-nah-nah-nah ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Before craft beer was available at Turner Field, Tomahawk was my jam. Virtually scentless. Pours a very pale brown. Honestly, this is just a sweet mess. More carbonation would probably help to mask how utterly average this beer tastes Draft - Turner Field - Atlanta, GA
On tap at the Braves bar at the ATL airport. Pours a brown amber color. Not much of a head. Aroma of alcohol and malts. Fizzy mouth feel.

On draught @ The Chop House. Poured an decent looking amber with just a small head. Aroma was of caramel malts and some bread. Flavors were a bit subdued but pleasant. A bit of sweetness from the caramel malts. Drank smooth, well carbonated. Given the bleak selection at Braves games this is the way to go.

When I heard this beer was from Anheuser-Busch I was skeptical. But since it’s only served at Turner Field in the Chop House I had to try it. I was pleasantly surprised. Came out of the tap a medium deep amber color with a slightly off white head. Roasted/earthen aroma with a hint of almond. Pretty decent mouth feel, being fresh helps a ton. Nice bitter taste with an after taste of slight honey. Overall I really enjoyed it for what it is and I will definitely have it again at the next game!!

On draught at Chophouse in plastic cup. Pours a deep copper with ample foamy crown that has very decent retention and leaves lots of fingery lacing on the plastic cup. Aroma is malty, with toffee and some some adjunct on the nose (either corn or rice), with only a slight hint of grassy hops, but a slight EtOH burn. Flavour is sweet malt, a bit of roasted character, close to toffee, and finishes cleanly with a semi-dry hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is creamy with moderate carbonation that is sufficient to bring out hop flavours in the mouth without overpowering the malt character of the beer. The only beer I can drink at Turner Field. Unfortunately I have only found two locations in the ballpark that sell this beer, one of them being the Chop House and the other one a stand on the lower level of the right field terrace. I’m sure they have this elsewhere, like the 755 Club but they should distribute it more throughout the stadium!!!

Sept. 19, 2008. Braves vs. Mets. Draft, $6.50 / pint. Pours copper color, creamy head. Aroma of malts. Initial flavors were of honeydew melon. Wow. Then it continued to taste like any old amber ale. Sweet malt character, woody hop finish. The best thing Turner Field has to offer. The beer was definitely better than the game. Braves lost 9-5.

Draft at the 755 club at Turner Field. I went out on a limb and tried the only thing on draft I had never heard of and was pleasantly surprised. Poured a deep orange/amber (hard to tell in the plastic pint glass they gave me) with a pillowy white head. Mostly sweet malt and corn in the nose but some caramel and slight notion of a hop showed up at some point. Body was mostly sweet malts throughout with an off-dry finish. Good carbonation, very drinkable, a no-brainer for Turner Field’s draft list. Surprised this is an AB product.

column1: Fog City Diners Fog City Ale
column5: I had this at the iconoclastic Fog City Diner in San Francisco with an unbelievably delicious cobb sandwhich. The waitress told me it was a Gordon Biersch brew made just for the restaurant-- can’t confirm this. Anyway, it came in a nice shaker glass, slightly orange golden, a little hazy with a thin white cap. Saazy hop aroma, woody and leafy. More like a Bohemian pilsener than anything, but actually really nice. The whole vibe of the afternoon was great, which of course plays into the rating.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Golden color with a modest off-white head. Very light aromas, with some honey, citrus, floral perfume, and light toasted bread. Pale malts and and clove honey in the flavors. Finish has a generic bitterness which dries things out and at the end it seems flavorless. Refreshing, but not fulfilling. 2/12

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: bottle from Crafted in Haymarket, VA Aroma: citrus, tropical fruit,cereal Appearance: clear amber with a white head Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, Palate: medium body, slick feel, average carbonation, long finish, Decent

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: [Dec 28 2015] On tap at Snowbird Ski Area. Nice golden body with slight head. Nose is malty, floral. Taste is sweet, hoppy, Nice bitter in the finish.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Wyld hey? Not nearly as wyld as that wily Teuton from foreign shores known as VAL FUCKING BLATZ! That man was truly & verily WYLD. Crazy WYLD. He was the Chuck Yeager of continental brewers in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. That MOFO was KRAZY WYLD. If he would have been on a plane that had snakes on it, those verminous little bastards would have jumped out on a suicide mission to avoid his righteous wrath.....errr...where was I going with this? Dunno. This beer is OK, just don’t expect it to be comparable in any way, shape or form to the original WYLD beverage of bacchanalian mayhem: BLATZ!

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: 12 oz can served in a lager glass. A: Large foamy white head over a pale, hazed, golden body. Plenty of sticky lacing get left on the glass. Fruity with a hint of toffee. Mild bitterness. Feel: Light but not watery body with medium carbonation.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: 8/X/15 - 12Fl. Oz. can @ home - BB: V/14/15 (2015-1455) Thanks to ElManana+1 for sharing the can! Clear blond beer, small creamy aery head, unstable, bit adhesive. Aroma: sweet, malty, honey. MF: soft carbon, medium to light body. Taste: rather sweet, some citrus, bit grassy, pretty bitter. Aftertaste: some citrus, honey, bit sweet, malty, caramel, nice bitterness. Pretty ok for a beer past date, kept it into account though when rating, so gave it a little more than it actually tasted.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: This was an okay American pale ale was a bit dry and bitter, but still drinkable.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Can at tderoeck's place. Malty, light hoppy, good pilsener/lager, but for an american pale ale, it falls too short.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Bottle 35,5cl / Botella 35,5cl. @ Maverik Adventure’s First Stop, Monticello, UT, USA A: Golden / Dorado. T/S: Malt, cereal, sweet / Malta, cereal, dulce.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Bottle from Harvest Market, Bedford NH. Aroma is citrusy hops, a little bit of sulfur, basement. Appearance is pale yellow with greenish tint. Cloudy with sediment and 2 finger width pillowy white head with nice sparkle, retention that was too long, and foamy lacing. Taste is citrusy with a bit of skunk but way overpowered by palate. Palate is light bodied with thin texture but all of that is obscured by way too much fizzy carbonation (like a cheap champagne). Finish is like you are drowning in foam but then is abruptly gone. Overall, this may not have been the fairest representation of this beer--it was a bit old. I’ll have to get another at some point and re-rate. This version had a lot of negatives.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body: &nbsp Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 4 &nbsp &nbsp Light Brown(1)->Pitch Black(5) : 4 &nbsp &nbsp Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 2 Head: &nbsp None(1)->Large(5) : 2 &nbsp Off-White(1)->Dark Brown(5) : 2 &nbsp Lasting: 2 &nbsp Lacing : 2 &nbsp Nitro : XX Aroma: Intensity : 3 &nbsp Yeast : 3 &nbsp Bread : 4 &nbsp Apple : XX &nbsp Tropical Fruits : 2 &nbsp Ink : XX &nbsp Tar : XX &nbsp Olives : XX &nbsp DMS : XX Malt : 3 &nbsp Biscuity : XX &nbsp Burnt Toast : 2 &nbsp Caramel : XX &nbsp Nuts : XX &nbsp Pumpernickel : XX &nbsp Cereals : XX &nbsp Coffee : 3 &nbsp Dark Chocolate : 2 &nbsp Vanilla : XX &nbsp Grapes : 1 &nbsp Blackberries : 1 &nbsp Cherries : XX Hops : 2 &nbsp Noble(1)->American(5) : 1 &nbsp Leafy : XX &nbsp Floral : 1 &nbsp Lemon/Lime : XX &nbsp Grapefruit : XX Orange : XX &nbsp Herbal : XX &nbsp Pine/Spruce/Resin : XX Notes : &nbsp Earth : 2 &nbsp Wood : XX &nbsp Mint : XX &nbsp Smoke : 2 &nbsp Soy : XX &nbsp Bourbon : XX &nbsp Anise : XX Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Sourness : 2 &nbsp Lactic : XX &nbsp Bitterness : 2 &nbsp Complex : XX &nbsp Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 4 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 2 &nbsp Clean : XX &nbsp Sharp : XX &nbsp Watery : XX &nbsp Oily : XX &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringent : XX &nbsp Alcohol : XX &nbsp Mineral : 4 &nbsp Oxidation : XX &nbsp Metallic : XX Comments: A certain fruitiness from the yeast keeps the interest level up for this rather chewy and thick stout with a pungent mineral character.

Bottle@Chris_o’s. Nice stout. Nice aromas of chocolate, caramel, and mocha. Palate is lightly sweet to start, but combatted nicely in the finish with a nice long roasty malt finish, which also shows notes of dark chocolate, and also rum n’ raisin. This was very nice.

Aug 2007 chris_o Shindig Smooth chocolate stout - soft and oh so dreamy delicious. Lingering bitterness. Enjoyable and full of character. It has the the clean, lifeless taste of a filtered beer - however, still awesome.

Lovely really rich, deep brown, almost black appearance. Lots of roasty malt, coffee and chocolate in the aroma. More of the same on the palate. Smooth, but firm, mouthfeel. Quite tarry, but not heavy. Beautifully balanced and possibly the best beer of the day, despite the very strong opposition. I’d love to try this one on cask. Shame it seems to be a one-off.

Bottled. Black with a light brown, medium sized head. Weak roast aroma with toffee and caramel and licorice. The roast flavour has notes of smoke and charcoal, and a long lasting burned aftertaste. Seemed a little thin for that rich flavour.

Bottle @ Chris_o shindig 2007. Dark brown color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, light brown head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, burnt, strong coffee, coal. Flavor is light to moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. (Coal / burnt bitter). Body is medium, texture is oily, syrupy, carbonation is soft to flat.

Bottled. Very dark brown colour, mediumsized brown head. Aroma is slightly roasted malts, burnt wet wood, some grass and a bit of caramel. Flavour is mainly wet and burnt wood, leather and some roasted malts.

Bottle at the Chris_o shindig. Deep black, nice rust colored head. Luscious caramel brown sweetness--deep and comforting in a way I associate with a good doppelbock. Flavor is an oceany iodine, soft sour chocolate, a bit of apple esters, nice chalky bitterness. A real stunner at less than 5%, and one of my most memorable beers of the tasting.

Bottle. Jet black beer with a tiny chocolate head. Roasted malt aroma. Fairly sweet to taste, some roasted malt, chocolate and coffee, a bit of smoke and a touch of pop corn. One of the best beers at the tasting.

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a thin brown head. The aroma is sweet malty with strong notes of chocolate and caramel, as well as light notes of coffee. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel and chocolate, like ice cream topping, combined with a light note of licorice. Nice, but the body is a bit thin.
brewed in vietnam for liquorland why cant it be made australia but taste is none existant cheap crap worst beer i have tryed never again i hope the beer gods dont hold it against me sorry
Faint aroma of grains? Taste is relatively sweet and corn-like with some mild hay. It is not the worst, but not good by any means.

In it’s catagory as a large commercial beer, this is my second prefered. Loverly colour but not pale or golden as many in here say. Very poor head retention. Perfect mouthfeel. Right amount of bitterness. very flat flavour but better than most of the others. It is not a home brew or a craft brew. Don’t expect it to be. It should be judged in it’s class and if done so, comes out pretty good. Nice experience and refreshing.
can from a liquorland in newcastle. dull pale golden, minimal head but plenty of fizz; industrial aroma, some light cordial fruitiness, tinny bitterness; barely drinkable

330ml can into schooner glass. NOT made by Boags, can says ’Made in Vietnam’ for Australian Beer Connoisseurs. Smells of sweet corn and bread. Amber beer with a few bubbles, derisory white head which becomes a film. Light body, quite sweet. Finish is mildly metallic with stale cardboard and distant sugar. I’ve had much worse.
From a bottle. Pours clear gold with a tinned fruit aroma, watery mouth feel and bland taste.
Bought a cartoon of cans because they were well priced. But this beer has absolutely no aroma & no taste wouldn’t buy it again.
Next to no nose. Nice straw colour with a cleanish finish with a little bight.

Bottle- Pours a clear golden color with a decent head that fades to bits of lacing. Fairly mild aroma of grain with a bit of malt sweetness and just a trace of citrus Taste of some malt sweetness and grain. Mild bitterness and a clean finish. Light body, fairly crisp, quite smooth and a bit refreshing. Decent lager that is non-offensive. Good session beer. Goes down easy on a hot day.
Bottle- I’m just updating my records. Great name, but a very boring beer, lacking in any flavours or aromas.

column1: Crow Peak Lazy Daze Summer Ale
column5: Sampled at the brewery’s taproom in Spearfish, South Dakota. Pours a semi-hazy golden blonde brew with an average white head that quickly dissolves to ring with good lacing. Aroma of some llight roasted multi-grain malt, some green vegetable and flowery/herbal hops. Taste is highly carbonated, light bodied, with flavors of light white bread dough, cloves, some earthy herbs and grassy hop bitterness. Finish is dry, light, crisp with a slight herbal spice aftertaste.

column1: Crow Peak Bear Butte Brown Ale
column5: Reviewed from notes. Thanks Scott. This was poured into a mug. The appearance was a brown color with a film of a little white head that fell off fairly quick. Light stringy lace. The aroma had some coffee, earthy hops, light roast and a little bit of dark chocolate at the very end. The flavor took all of the previously mentioned aromas and brought them together somewhat sweet to lead into the aftertaste and mildly into the finish. The feel was just a tad under medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Carbonation felt fine. ABV felt as projected. Overall, good brown ale worthy of coming back to.

column1: Crow Peak Bear Butte Brown Ale
column5: Can. No detailed notes on this one - had a couple of cans on a trip to South Dakota. Nice, nutty brown ale with maybe a little too much sweetness for my taste.

column1: Crow Peak Bear Butte Brown Ale
column5: Can. Brown color, medium tan head. Aroma of dark cocoa, subtle coffee grounds. Taste is mostly sweet milk chocolate. Not bad.

column1: Crow Peak Bear Butte Brown Ale
column5: Can. Pours brown with a small tan head. Aroma of caramel and nuts. Flavor of light caramel, nuts and had some subtle chocolate.

column1: Crow Peak Bear Butte Brown Ale
column5: (12oz can thanks to jjfoodie) clear brown, no head. Nose of fart, nutty with shells. Taste of nuts, honey, taste is the best part of it, medium roast, bit of coffee grounds. Thin body and roasty finish.

column1: Crow Peak Bear Butte Brown Ale
column5: On tap @ GABF. Brown pour with a tan head. Coffee, earthy hops, and roast on the nose. Some toffee, dark chocolate, and toasted malt. Slight nuttiness. Flavor is decently sweet and malty. Toast, toffee, and chocolate. Some earthy hop and coffee ground bitterness. Alright.

column1: Crow Peak Bear Butte Brown Ale
column5: poured from a growler, nice brown color with a minimal tan head. Tastes of rich roasted coffee, lightly sweet, dark sweet chocolate and finishes slightly bitter.

column1: Crow Peak Bear Butte Brown Ale
column5: Drinks Very Smooth, Looks great, The aroma is very Pleasing. Great finish...I will drink as many pints i can!!!

column1: Crow Peak Bear Butte Brown Ale
column5: Date: 06/23/2007 Mode: Growler Source: Tasting, RBSG 2007 clear brown, wispy beige head, light milk chocolate aroma, watery body, toasted and milk chocolate flavor, light bitterness, touch of sweetness brinks out the chocolate and gives it a milky character, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: **/4

column1: Crow Peak Bear Butte Brown Ale
column5: RBSG 2007 Grand Tasting. Clear brown with a small white head. Lightly nutty nose and flavor, some toasty caramel. OK.

For me to be able to drink a light beer and say, "WOW, this is one hell of a beer" is really something, i am more of a dark Beer Drinker, and usually HATE light beer but this beer is really something...it is smooth, tastes great, and looks spectacular! Thank you Jeff D. for making such a great beer!

Sampled at the brewery’s taproom in Spearfish, South Dakota. Pours a clear golden pale straw color brew with a thin white head that quickly dissolves to a fine film. Aroma of light roasted barley malt, some citrus zest and flowery hops. Taste is medium bodied, lightly carbonated with a fruity/citrus malt and flowery hop flavor. Finish is smooth, light and crisp with a slight fruity aftertaste that quickly disappears. Quite a decent refreshing light beer.
Dry porter, and heavy. Not so drinkable, non offensive. Can from the state. Like more mouthfeel.

Brown black colour, off-white head. Aroma of malts, caramel, cacao, chocolate, roasted malts. Sweet flavour, caramel, cacao. Finish caramel and roasted malts. (from 355mL can @ RBBSG'17, Evergem. Thanks for sharing, tderoeck!)

26/VIII/17 - 12Fl. Oz. can, shared @ RBBSG17 - BB: n/a (2017-1330) Thanks to Ryan for the trade! Clear red brown beer, small creamy beige head, little stable. Aroma: pretty roasted, caramel, sweet, bit sugary, chocolate, very nice scent! MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: pretty roasted start, chocolate, bit hoppy, little sourish. Aftertaste: little sour, fruity, malty, little sweet, soft roast, quite some chocolate.

12oz can. Opaque brown-black body. Definitely some underlying oddness, but the heavier specialty malts sort of cover it up...well not really. Has that warming acidic stomach acid disgusting tone which just kills it. Like an infected Baltic Porter. Pretty bad.

Intense dark chocolate, cacao, charcoal. Clear, very dark brown, tiny, creamy, beige head. Light sweet. More dark chocolate, cacao, dark roast coffee, dark malts, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Decent. Keg at GABF17, Denver.

Pours very dark brown with a garnet hue. Light, toasty dark malt in the aroma with a hint of something kinda lactic. Has a nice dark breadiness to the taste but is sweeter than most porters. Slight burnt character. Little to no hop bitterness or flavor. Semi-full, slick mouthfeel. Finishes fairly dry. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Roast and some chocolate. Comes off a little light like khakis though. Black pour with decent head and lacing. Some caramel in otherwise bitter finish. Can.
Sample from can at GNBF. Pour was dark brown, tan head. Aroma was chocolate, roasted malt. Taste was mild bitter, roast malt, light coffee.

Can/Fest. A- Smoky, roasty, cocoa. A- Brown color, dark liquid, tan head. T- Smoke, cocoa, roasty. P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, balanced finish. O- Not bad for a plain jane porter. Nice flavor profile and thankfully not thin and watery.

Thank you for sharing tderoeck! 355 ml. can sampled @ RBBSG17. Dark amber, little head. Nose is herbal leaves, bark, roasted, almost smoked. Far too herbal bitter, thin roasted, low burned malt, burned coffee. Weak.
Can. Deep Google with one finger head. Moderate malt body. Hops to match. Nothing particularly unique, but decent. First South Dakota beer. Woot.
Clear copper pour with a white head. The aroma has pine grassy hops. It has a medium body with lively carbonation. The taste is bitter with dry finish.
Very nice IPA. Aroma is quite hoppy and taste decent bitter. Nice lacing foam. Gift from Mark. (Velp 201809)
Golden pour, muddled nose of mostly malt. Taste follows with a bitter, clean finish. Very average.

Can 355ml, tasting: Aroma: resin oils, grassy greens with sweeter side, hint of lemongrass at end. Look: top – large top, long lasting. Base – fine haze on amber gold Palate: medium thinner bodied. , average softer carbonation, softer texture Taste: mix of resin and lemongrass with prominent candy like caramel side to it. Too sugary.

12 ounce can. Pours an amber color with a one inch white head that lasts. Taste is of malt, citrus, hops, pine and some resin. Similar aroma. Has a medium body with a sweet and dry finish. Overall, pretty good.

12oz can. Pretty shwaggy aroma. Shwaggy borderline off tones, brewhouse. Really weak brewing. Filtered, which might be the only thing that helps it. Antiquated caramel and toffee tones that pretty much no one wants in an IPA in 2017. More of a tan orange body than amber in my opinion. Drinkable, but on the edge. No real impressive hop tone, and an off aroma. Weak.
Can in WY. Pours light golden orange with small white head. Aromas of caramel malts, pine, and a little grapefruit. Flavors light hop bitterness, pine and grapefruit hop notes, and pale malts.

355ml can. At last, a SD tick, missed out on ND though. Pours a clear gold with a bright white head. Aroma is toffee and herbs, some citrus. Flavor is a bit melony, herbs, bready malt, not super bitter, searching for more bittenress.

20/VII/17 - 12Fl. Oz. can from a trade, shared @ home - BB: no date on the can (2017-1052) Thanks to Ryan for the trade! New State Tick! Clear orange beer, creamy irregular off-white head, little stable, adhesive, leaving some lacing in the glass. Aroma: pretty sweet, some honey, oxidised? Ripe tropical fruits, some citrus, something sweet, malty. MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: pretty sweet, honey, malty, grains, bitter, very harsh bitterness, some tropical fruits in the distance. Aftertaste: bitter, bit resinous, piny, citrus, grapefruit, passion fruit touch, very hoppy, dry finish. Is this too old or just not very good? (the other ratings suggest the latter)

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours a white head and cloudy reddish orange color. Aroma is fruity, rock candy, wheat, banana-yeast. Taste is fruity-pear/aple/raspberry, wheat, banana-yeast, faint hops. Comes across like a Belgian fruit cider, nice. Occasional. Good effervescence.

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Twisted Kilt
column5: Firkin @ DuClaw Real Ale Festival. Caramel color pour with no head and light carbonation. Oak, toffee, and some smoke in the aroma. Caramel flavor with a nice amount of smoke in there. Oak added a bit much to the Kilt.

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Twisted Kilt
column5: Bottle RBSG 07. Dirty brown pour with a light tan head. Aroma of rich caramel, light bourbon, and sweet malt. Flavors of bready caramel malt, light bourbon and a tinge of smoke. Medium body, malty and boozey with a boozey finish.

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Twisted Kilt
column5: RBSG 07 Minneapolis Grand Tasting: Brown/ebony, light head and lacing. Nose of dark plum and toast, crusty bread and fig. Nice malts, smooth and spicy with light alcohol. Good, nice finish. Excellent actually.

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Twisted Kilt
column5: Dark mahogany pour with a thin and fully diminishing beige head, oily with a cola appearance. The aroma contains toffee, bourbon, wet oak, burned caramel, vinous notes, stale cherries and mild peat and chocolate. The flavor is rapidly dispersed across the palate, toffee and chocolate nearly disintegrating upon impact. Sweetness is medium high, bitterness low, acidity low and astringency mild. Stale nuances surround what little evidence of good taste remains. The finish has mild vanilla introduced, caramel and toffee, mild peaty spice lingering. The mouthfeel is undercarbonated, thin and watery, tannic and boring, though nothing strikes the palate as offensive. Drab defined.

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Twisted Kilt
column5: Name: Twisted Kilt, BA Date: 06/23/2007 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting, RBSG 2007 dark brown, wispy beige head, oaky dark caramel aroma, lots of dark caramel flavor, lots of oak character does a good job balancing the caramel sweetness, nice vanilla blends well with the caramel Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.7/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ***/4

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Twisted Kilt
column5: Bottle… RBSG 07… Mostly clear, very dark ruby ale with a small, creamy, khaki head. Good retention. Earthy nose with notes of red wine and white oak. Lots of tanginess and sweetness on the palate as what was modest hopping to begin with must have been sucked up into the oak barrel. The oak provides vanilla in return. Medium-bodied and syrupy with soft carbonation. Woodsy, sweet finish. A huge disappointment from one of my favorite brewpubs, but they can’t all be “dead-on”, I guess.

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Twisted Kilt
column5: Supplied by scraff, sampled at the RBSG ’07 Grand Tasting room. Pours a clear dark brown brew with a thin off-white head that quickly dissolves to a fine film. Aroma is light with scents of sweet pitted fruit, toffee and a touch of vanilla. Taste is sweet, fruity, some light chocolate and smoked peat. Palate is medium bodied, lightly carbonated with a sllight smokey aftertaste Finish is smooth and dry peaty.

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Twisted Kilt
column5: (1L Bottle) Pours an amber-brown body with a small off-white head. Aroma of toffee, oak, vanilla, and fruitiness. Flavor of fruit, caramel, chocolate, and toasted malt.

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Twisted Kilt
column5: Dark brown with only a small head that didn’t stick. Vanilla and alcohol in the sweet nose. Chocolate sweetness in the flavour of this one as well as some alcohol presence and some wood.

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Twisted Kilt
column5: RBSG 2007 Grand Tasting - Ruby brown, thin tan creamy head. Nose was soft with notes of toffee, vanilla, oak, and hints of cherry. Flavor was a touch lighter with notes of wood, caramel, and tangy vanilla and cherry. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, dark fruity finish. In my opinion, the barrel seems to have taken away some of the complexity of the original version. Still nice, but not what I had hoped for...

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Had this at the Trolley Square location. Received in a perfect pint look-alike. 3.5 A: Clear dark yellow color. Came without a head. 3.0 S: Light graininess. Light sweet grassiness. Not bad, but needs more power. 2.5 T: Like the nose, but even more boring. Light graininess and light grassiness. 3.5 M: Lighter body. Good moderate carbonation. Clean and crisp. 3.0 D: Again, not much going on, but easy enough to drink. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 06-23-2012 03:58:50

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub Appearance: Clear golden with a medium sized white head and good lacing Aroma: Bready, citrus and yeast Taste: Wheat, biscuity and yeast Nice and smooth, easy drinking

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: on tap 7/22/10. dark yellow with a small white head. the aroma and flavor are fruity (?), earthy yeast, spicy hops and cereal. noble hops and straw are accentuated in the flavor. it is medium to full bodied but crisp, spicy and highly drinkable. it has more oomph than what i am accustomed to in the style. 6/3/6/4/13-

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Cleargolden, minimakl head. Grassy nose. Fairly light bodied, a bit clean and hard. Grassy and salty, pretty lifeless but also nicely refreshing.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Pours a golden yellow. Aromas of lemon, grains, celery. Flavor is crisp, dry, sweet malt, and a mild hop.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: NABA 08’: Pours a gold color with average head. The nose is lightly soapy with a touch of noble hops and light malt. Thin body and a watery mouthfeel. Light toasty biscuit in the tail and a balanced finished. No esters or anything. Eh.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear gold with a good size white fluffy head. The aroma is light malts and floral hops. The taste was well balanced between a sweet malt that was very mild and a nice semi-bitter hops. Very well made and quite tasty. As usual I enjoyed this Desert Edge beer. Keep em coming.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: @Mountain Beerfest-on tap-pours a white head that laces and yellow color. Aroma is grain-some sweetness with lime and grassy, secondary hops-perfumy. Taste is not up to aroma-grain-some sweetness with lime and grassy, secondary hops-perfumy/flatness. Mild carbonation.

on tap and bottled at U Medvídku in Prague. This was the first X-Beer produced by U Medvidku. Rather dark colour, oily consistence, malty and sweet nose, nearly no head. Rather sweet taste with hints of roasted malt, fruit (wild berries?) and only slightly hopped. Very long finish and aftertaste.
On tap in salzburg. Cloudy gold with small head. Herbal aroma. Crispy malts taste. Average for the style
14th December 2007 Draft in Salzburg, Austria. Unfiltered draft. Sharp and crisp. Bitter orange and grapefruit undertones. A decent beer!

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body: &nbsp Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 3 &nbsp &nbsp Pale Yellow(1)->Copper(5) : 1 &nbsp &nbsp Still(1)->Volcanic Sparkling(5) : 3 Head: &nbsp None(1)->Large(5) : 4 &nbsp &nbsp Lasting: 4 &nbsp &nbsp Lacing : 4 Aroma: Intensity : 3 &nbsp Yeast : 2 &nbsp Bread : 3 &nbsp Dough : XX &nbsp Esters : XX &nbsp Phenols : XX &nbsp Dusty : XX &nbsp Spicy : 5 &nbsp Apple : XX &nbsp Banana : 1 &nbsp Tropical Fruits : 1 &nbsp Brett : XX &nbsp Barnyard : XX &nbsp Leather : XX &nbsp Wood : XX &nbsp Vinous : XX &nbsp Cheese : XX &nbsp DMS : XX &nbsp Diacetyl : XX Sulfur : XX Malt : 3 &nbsp Pilsner : 4 &nbsp Pale : XX &nbsp Vienna : XX &nbsp Biscuity : XX &nbsp Toasty : 1 &nbsp Hay : 2 &nbsp Caramel : XX &nbsp Honey : XX &nbsp Cereals : XX &nbsp Grainy : 2 &nbsp Wheat : 2 Hops : 3 &nbsp Noble(1)->American(5) : 1 &nbsp Leafy : XX &nbsp Perfume : XX &nbsp Orange : XX &nbsp Floral : 2 &nbsp Lemon/Lime : XX &nbsp Herbal : 1 &nbsp Grassy : 3 &nbsp Piney : XX Notes : Pepper : XX &nbsp Cloves : XX &nbsp Coriander : XX &nbsp Ginger : XX &nbsp Orange : XX &nbsp Earth : XX &nbsp Vanilla : XX &nbsp Oxidation : XX &nbsp Bubblegum : XX Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 2 &nbsp Sourness : 1 &nbsp Acetic : XX &nbsp Lactic : XX &nbsp Bitterness : XX &nbsp Farmy : 1 &nbsp Complex : XX &nbsp Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 3 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 3 &nbsp Clean : 3 &nbsp Sharp : XX &nbsp Watery : XX &nbsp Oily : XX &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringent : XX &nbsp Alcohol : XX &nbsp Mineral : XX Comments: An excellent, fresh pint full of delicious pils malt, fresh yeast and delicate grassy hops. For a Brau Union beer, one can’t expect much better.

Appearance: Amber reddish. Medium head, beige color, slightly rocky, medium persistence. Aroma: Malty and candy. Fruity and sourness of green apples, quince and pear. Floral and herbal touches of hops. Very yeasty. Flavor: fruity and sourness similar to aroma from quince and green apples. Dryness and sweetness of pink grapefruit. Yeasty and candy start. Medium hop-dry in the finish, with persistence. A few herbal and metallic in the end. I remember some of the American bitter beers. Palate: Medium carbonation. Medium body with watery texture. Good dryness, advisable beer. (sorry for my english)

Getreidig-wässriger Antrunk mit zunehmender bitteren Trockenheit, zum Ende auch typische Aromen des Alkoholentzugs. An sich ist das Bier aber erfrischend, lange Zeit merkt man kaum, dass das Bier nur 2,8% besitzt. Störend ist nur in weiteren Teilen die Wässrigkeit, die das Bier zwar nicht schlecht, wohl aber langweilig wirken lässt. Als Sommererfrischung gut! 9/7/8/6/9/7

clear and deep golden-bronze colour, very little foam remaining; the aroma is a mix between plastic, straw and paperboard; moderate malt body and carbonation; slightly oily with a bitter and spicy aftertaste; the finish is short and quite watery with notes of carton and pepper

This is a low-alcohol beer with 2.8% ABV. Bottle, pale yellow, medium-sized head. Malty nose. Malty flavour, hints of honey, otherwise quite thin. Not watery, but not full-bodied either. Thirst-quencher for hot summer days.
Aroma is citrus and grassy hints of pine over a honey malt base, cascade maybe. Taste is a similkar beast hoppy in the way i like it.

courtesy of Philipp and Thomas - hazy blond beer with a little white foam left; aroma of cellar and dust, hints of almonds; moderate carbonation, medium-bodied, a hint of sourness, decently dry, short grainy and slightly citric finish - not terrible

This tiny brewery is situated in Ramsen, only about 100metres from the German border. ABV is between 4.8% and 5.2%. This beer is a pale lager, unfiltered with a beautiful head and a lovely hoppy nose. Hoppy flavours, slightly malty in the background. Nice flowery hops. Good palate, dry finish. I am looking forward to taste their Ale and Weizenbier.
A good beer. By itself the aftertaste is a little off. But after another beer it taste better.Not my favorite wheat beer but good.
Bottle - Soft candied banana. Clear gold with a small white head. Sweet candied banana, citrus peel bite and a decent finish.

A 12 fl oz bottle with no clear bottled on or best before date. Poured into a Riedel weizen glass. It was a hazy dark straw orange colour with a big three finger white head that had good retention but left only slight lacing. Aromas of nice wheat, banana, clove, banana bread and bubblegum. Tastes much like the aroma, there’s wheat, banana, clove and bubblegum with a hint of fuzzy peach and cinnamon. Medium to light bodied with moderate carbonation. Overall, maybe I had too high hopes to start with, but it wasn’t as good as I expected it to be. I much preferred Bubbler over Dancing Man Wheat, maybe it was the cinnamon spices at the end. Having said that, it’s not bad and still definitely drinkable.

12 oz. bottle. Pours an unclear, bright yellow color, with a medium, fizzy, white head. The aroma is straw, banana, orange juice, cloves, and lemon zest. Sweet and doughy, with a light, crisp, bitter finish. Light to medium body, with a chewy, creamy mouthfeel, and a lovely, sharp finish. This is simply fantastic.

12 oz bottle from the variety pack. Pours cloudy golden with a thick off-white head with great retention. Aroma is clove, bubblegum, banana, wheat, peppery. Taste is sweet and spicy with noticeable but not overwhelming alcohol. Flavors match the aroma. Just like a real German weizenbock. So good.
Has a real banana flavor to it. Just a really good solid beer all the way around

Light orange,fluffy head, hazy. Zesty bannna and clove aroma. Citrus and fruit , clove is bigger in taste, spice, zesty finish. 7.2%? thats bigger than the average hefeweizen. Soft, somewhat slick. Peppery citrus finish. Pretty good , Im not big on clove, this is more clove forward.
VERY tasty and smooth. nothing offensive here whatsoever. bit of clove and sweetness and extremely drinkable. new glarus has one heck of a reputation for being some of the smoothest beers around.

Bottle at Uber Tap Room with GLBTQ crew. Weird flute glass. Hazy yellow and golden with minimal head. Nose has traditional banana and cloves with a light funk. Taste is a pleasant banana with wheat undertones. Very much in the vein of other hefeweizens I’ve sampled. Easy to drink hiding the alcohol well. A good representation of the style. I would ask this to join me on the dance floor for an Eric Clapton track at least one more time.

From the tap at Tofflers Pub and Grill in New Glarus. Pours hazy golden colored with a huge fluffy white head. Aroma if sweet banana, apples, and cinnamon.. Flavor is malts, banana, pears and apples. Decent, but I just smell a little too much banana and cinnamon for my liking

Cask @ Kingston Arms, Cambridge. Pale yellow coloured. Quite clear. Fluffy off white head. Light flowers and sweetness in the aroma. Light spice. Flavour is flowery, spiced and sweet. Is medium bodied. Quite dry. Sweetish and bitter in the end.

Bottle from Macknade's Fine Foods, Faversham. Black with a middling beige head and a moderate fizz. Maybe a touch too fizzy for my liking. Coffee and a little chocolate up front, then tobacco and salt, followed by soy sauce & unami in a dry finish. An unusually savoury stout; I really rather enjoyed it.

Kij, Londyn. Podane na azocie, wiec piana zacna. W aromacie slabiutko. Czuæ kawe. W smaku kwaœna kawa, niewiele wiêcej. W sumie srednio o jednowymiarowo. Problemow brak, alewodotryskow tez. Cialo œrednie, nasycenie niskie. Alkohol niewyczuwalny.
Cask at the Kentish Belle, Bexleyheath. Black pour with a beige head. Nose of liquorice toffee,coffee, dark chocolate. Flavours of licorice toffee, chocolate, caramel, smoke. Good.

Bottle drunk in the Crab & Winkle in Whitstable while eating Whitstable oysters. You cant get much more terroir than that!! Lovely colour with a nice long lasting head. Plenty of toasted malts and dare a say a tang of the sea to the flavour? Great mouth feel and it perfectly complemented the local oysters that were eaten raw with a touch of vinegar. Bliss. I even got my 10 year old to try a bit of oyster; which she hated. Heathen.

Cask at PoW, Farnborough. Nil aroma. Dark. Thin beige head. Light bitter. Slight sourness. Coffee. Berries. Something odd and umami. Pretty light. Minimal carbonation. Astringent finish. Thought it was a pretty poor attempt. Bland as...
Another roasted stout. There’s a nice forward hop in there and nothing unpleasant about the roastiness. But that’s it really no head, not creamy. A bit uneventful.

Bottle. Black in colour. Malty; coffee, dark chocolate, roasty malts, caramel, hint of vanilla. Fruity; some fruit, raisins. Sweet roast malty throughout. Dry roasty finish. Relatively subtle. Very drinkable. (2010-01)

Tap at the Hotel Continental, Whitstable. Poured a clear dark brown with a broken tan head and a few bubbles. The aroma is roasty malt, sweet creamy caramel, chocolate. The flavour is moderate sweet with a crisp, watery, smoky, liqourice hop bitter palate. Medium bodied with average carbonation.

Draft while in London. Dark black with staying medium head. Aroma has hints of coffee beans, vanilla. Creamy texture. Medium bodied. Smooth. Slight chaulky. Pretty good. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From tap at hotel Continental, Pours dark brown liquid, small creamy tan head, Aroma: chocolate, espresso, roasty, floral, Taste: light to medium sweet, medium bitter, light sour, roasty, espresso, dark chocolate, light fruity, Palate: light to medium body, average carbonation, slick mouthfeel, long roasty carbonation. Overall: nice, quite drinkable, bit light bodied, enjoyed.
On tap. Dark golden pour with a thick white top. Floral scent. Sweet malt taste with biscuit notes.
Draft at brewpub. Very mild ale with sunny malts. Green flavors on mild sweet body. Ok, could session this, very drinkable

Draft sample at brewpub. Poured a clear amber color with an average frothy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Medium dough and floral hop aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium balanced bittersweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Smooth drinkable session brew.

Sampled on draught at the brewpub in downtown Billings, Montana. Pours a clear golden straw brew with a fast dissolving off-white head that diminishes to a fine film and white ring. Aroma of light bread dough with some flowery hops and a touch of citrus zest. Taste is light to medium bodied, some carbonation with a citrus and bready flavor. Finish is slightly sweet at first and then a dry bready aftertaste with some light bitterness. One of the more flavorable blond ales.

column1: Angry Hanks Anger Management Belgian Wheat
column5: From 16oz can to tumbler. Pour is a hazy yellow, thick fizzy white head. Nose is super faint, doughy, bready, slight orange. Taste is light bodied, sweet. Finishes pillowy and juicy on the mouth.

column1: Angry Hanks Anger Management Belgian Wheat
column5: This beer has a very good taste. It has just the right amount of bitterness.

column1: Angry Hanks Anger Management Belgian Wheat
column5: Almost perfectly clear light golden, definitely doesn’t look like a wheat or a witbier... sudsy white head... Nose is all about the spicing and orange peel.... Flavor is the same as the aroma with big citrus and stale coriander.. Wheat is there, but there is no characteristic yeasty tang... Expected light body... Pretty underwhelmed... Same American Ale yeast and just relying on additions to make it a "witbier"?

column1: Angry Hanks Anger Management Belgian Wheat
column5: On tap. Hazy golden pour with an off white top. Scent is mild yeast and fruit. Taste is wheat and citrus.

column1: Angry Hanks Anger Management Belgian Wheat
column5: Hazed light yellow. Very buttery, huge diactyl . Creamy wheat body with some tart matling. alright.

column1: Angry Hanks Anger Management Belgian Wheat
column5: Tap @ Texas Roadhouse Billings. Pours a clear(?) golden orange with a finger of sandy beige head. Nose is mild, lightly fruity, yeast, corriander, and cloves. Tastes mild with the heavier wheat presence, citrus comes next. The cloves and corriander are there, but are pretty subdued from the sweetness. The wheat and citrus make things pretty sweet and mellow.

column1: Angry Hanks Anger Management Belgian Wheat
column5: Sample at the 2nd annual Montana Brewers festival. Aroma of clove, banana. Color is hazed yellow. Tastes a bit nutty... with clove and banana again. Medium light body, high carbonation

column1: Angry Hanks Anger Management Belgian Wheat
column5: Draft sample at Ibrewpub. Poured clear pale color with an average fizzy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate yeasty, citrus and coriander aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium yeasty citrus sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.

column1: Angry Hanks Anger Management Belgian Wheat
column5: Thanks to Skyview. An interesting beer, that blends some character of a Belgian ale with a wit. No visible sediment. There is lots of spice, loads of citrus and and a considerable grains of paradise presence. Some bubblegum. Cloudy yellow. Much more malt sweetness than most of the style.

column1: Angry Hanks Anger Management Belgian Wheat
column5: Growler from Skyview, but of course. Hazy yellow color with a large head. Big coriander aroma. Lots of fruit and citrus. Absolute coriander bomb. Moderate wheat. A very good wheat beer, but for me personally, the overwhelming coriander kills it.

column1: Angry Hanks Head Trauma India Pale Ale
column5: Draft at the brewery. So I’m a brain tumor survivor, I got have the "head trauma." And it was a good choice. Golden pour. This has a "stiff" body -- the best word I could think of, meant as a compliment. Despite the lighter appearance, this delivers a fully loaded flavor profile with both a solid malt undertow and a delicious hoppy wavetop. (#6375, 10/11/2016)

column1: Angry Hanks Head Trauma India Pale Ale
column5: WHY NO TASTERS AT THIS PLACE?!?!? Pours clear orange with decent white head.. astringent oversparged malt with bitterhops and no real hop flavor or aroma... pretty bad and nobody should be forced to by a full pint of a bad beer... Offer tasters please.

column1: Angry Hanks Head Trauma India Pale Ale
column5: Drank with Ratman last August. Pours semi cloudy gold. Significant head and lace in a pint glass. Moderate carbonation and mouthfeel. Flavors of fruit rind, minerals, oak, bitter root. Overall bold and flavorful but minerally and funky bitter.

column1: Angry Hanks Head Trauma India Pale Ale
column5: On tap. Clear golden pour with a thin white head. Scent is citrus and pine. Taste is pine, citrus, biscuits and more citrus.

column1: Angry Hanks Head Trauma India Pale Ale
column5: Growler poured a clear tarnished gold with a small lingering ivory head. Aromas of biscuit, grapefruit zest, lemon zest and a hint of pine. Palate was medium bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of straw, lemon zest, grapefruit zest and light pine with a crisp dry bitter lingering citrus finish.

column1: Angry Hanks Head Trauma India Pale Ale
column5: Nice clear golden color with nice head. Fruity, citrusy aroma with much the same as far as taste. Lots of citrus. Crisp slightly dry mouthfeel. Good beer.

column1: Angry Hanks Head Trauma India Pale Ale
column5: draft. clear honey amber with a white head. nose is mostly clean - focused mango/orange/peach hops. medium to light body, fruity and sweet without being chewy or overly sugary. clean and snappy malt throughout with good dryness / bitterness balance in the finish.

column1: Angry Hanks Head Trauma India Pale Ale
column5: Draft sample at brewpub. Poured clear golden color with a large frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with excellent lacing. Moderate sour citrus hop and earthy malt aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. My expectations where met with a very good complex brew.

column1: Angry Hanks Head Trauma India Pale Ale
column5: Draft at the taphouse: Pours a clear copper color with a large, thick and creamy beige head. Lots of thick lacing. Aroma is heavy in citrus, florals, and light maltiness. Certainly hop oriented, full of citrus and light in the floral hops. A smooth caramel malt base. This is their signature brew and was certainly worth a few pints.

column1: Angry Hanks Head Trauma India Pale Ale
column5: Sampled on draught at the brewpub in downtown Billings, Montana. Pours a semi-hazy golden amber brew with a fast dissolving white head that leaves behind a white ring. Aroma of orange and citrus zest, light roasted caramel malt, with a touch of honey and orange taffy. Taste is lightly carbonated, medium bodied with a tangy orange/citrus flavor. Finish is slightly smooth, sweet with a lingering orange peel aftertaste that has a lingering mild bitterness.

column1: Angry Hanks Dog Slobber Brown Ale
column5: This is some damm fine beer. Its like a middle aged women who has been there and done it and knows she still has it going on.

column1: Angry Hanks Dog Slobber Brown Ale
column5: Pours clear chestnut brown.. thin off white head.. First beer that I’ve really liked from this place... Traditional nutty and dark dry toast, light grassy hoppiness.. Dry cocoa with warmth... body is still pretty watery.

column1: Angry Hanks Dog Slobber Brown Ale
column5: On tap. Clear brown pour with a light brown head. Scent is toast, caramel and brown sugar. Taste is toasted malts and chocolate.

column1: Angry Hanks Dog Slobber Brown Ale
column5: Best brown I’ve had- very nice malty aroma. Great slightly frothy brown pour with great rings. Carmel chocolate nutty taste just slightly tho. Not overdone - real good

column1: Angry Hanks Dog Slobber Brown Ale
column5: Draft sample at brewpub. Poured a clear brown color with an creamy light brown head that was mostly lasting and produced good lacing. Good toasted malt, caramel, coffee and dough aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Good toasted sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.

column1: Angry Hanks Dog Slobber Brown Ale
column5: Draft at taphouse: Pours a nice depth of brown with a thick and creamy tan head. Thick lacing. Nose is more malty, roasty, and nutty than previous ales sampled at Hank’s. Flavor is smooth and malty with very little floral hops. Light bits of chocolate and coffee balance out this nice little brown ale.

column1: Angry Hanks Dog Slobber Brown Ale
column5: Growler poured a clear dark brown with red highlights and a lasting creamy brown head. Aromas of cocoa, coffee, roasted nuts and a hint of tobacco. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of bakers cocoa, coffee and roasted nuts with a smooth dry lingering malty finish.

column1: Angry Hanks Dog Slobber Brown Ale
column5: Sampled on draught at the brewpub in downtown Billings, Montana. Pours a clear brown caramel brew with a thick off-white head that has good retention and lacing. Aroma of toasted multi-grain biscuits, roasted nuts with a touch of flowery hops. Taste is medium bodied, very light carbonation with a sweet malt and light dry bitterness. Finish is light, dry with a toasted biscuit and nutty aftertaste.

column1: Angry Hanks Dog Slobber Brown Ale
column5: On draught at the brewery taproom, pours a dense brown color with a thick tan head. Medium-bodied, with an even dry/sweet malty flavor. a clean, slightly dry finish with underlying hop bitterness. A full mouthfeel, a bit filling. Overall - OKAY.

column1: Angry Hanks Dirty Girl Dunkel Weizen
column5: On tap. Hazy brown pour with a tan head. Scent is caramel, wheat and toast. Toasted, malty taste with wheat and fruit notes.

column1: Angry Hanks Dirty Girl Dunkel Weizen
column5: Draft at brewpub. Poured a hazy brown color with an average light brown head that was mostly lasting and produced good lacing. Good toasted malt, caramel and dough aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Good toasted bittersweet flavor with an average sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.

column1: Angry Hanks Dirty Girl Dunkel Weizen
column5: Sampled on draught at the brewpub in downtown Billings, Montana. Pours a hazy caramel amber brew with a thin white head that has good retention. Aroma of dry multi-grain biscuits with caramel and honey. Taste is medium bodied, some light carbonation, with a good balance of sweet malt and flowery hop flavor. Finish is a quick light malty aftertaste with very little bitterness.

column1: Angry Hanks Dirty Girl Dunkel Weizen
column5: On draught at the brewery. Pours a hazy brown with a white head. Light-to-medium body with a nice dark malt flavor. Mellow wheaty flavor, well-carbonated but no esters and a very clean finish. Nice!

column1: Angry Hanks Street Fight Imperial Red Ale
column5: This is by far the best Red Ale that I have ever tried. It has the best taste and best appearance out of any other Red Ale.

column1: Angry Hanks Street Fight Imperial Red Ale
column5: Draft at the brewery taproom.. Pours lightly hazed amber red with nice white head... sweetish caramel malt and light dry toast, hops are bitter but add not enough flavor or aroma... And since when is 6.5% "imperial"? This place is sorta a joke IMO.

column1: Angry Hanks Street Fight Imperial Red Ale
column5: Served on tap in a pint glass Appearance – The beer is served deep amber color with a one finger head of fizzy white foam. The head fades rather rapidly, leaving just a trace of lace on the sides of the glass. Smell – The aroma of the beer is strongest of a citrus smell mixed with some fruitiness of apple and pear. Along with these flavors some lighter citrus of tangerine and a little bit of a grassy hop smell are there as well. Taste – Upfront the taste is strongest of a slightly citrus flavor with both a grapefruit hop as well as a tangerine sweetness. Along with these flavors comes some other fruit flavors of an apple and pear nature. These sweeter flavors lighten up a bit all while the grapefruit hop remains constant and is joined by other hop tastes of grass and a bit of pine at the finish taking the taste to its end. Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is on the average side in terms of thickness and creaminess with a carbonation level that was a tad lighter. For the flavors and styles it was rather appropriate and made for a rather easy drinker. Overall – A decent brew overall, but nothing out of this world. A nice one to a least give a try to if you get the chance.

column1: Angry Hanks Street Fight Imperial Red Ale
column5: This was a decent amber ale, with a nice bready note, moderate hops to back it up, and overall it’s pretty drinkable.

column1: Angry Hanks Street Fight Imperial Red Ale
column5: Draft - Caramel on the nose and not much else. Dark amber with a decent head. Very sweet caramel and not much else. Much too sweet and no character or hops that I could detect.

column1: Angry Hanks Street Fight Imperial Red Ale
column5: On tap. Clear red/brown pour with an off white head. Scent is roasty and earthy. Taste is toast and sweet caramel.

column1: Angry Hanks Street Fight Imperial Red Ale
column5: Draft at original brewpub. Pale brown with a red tinge. Thinly bubbled head. some juiciness up front, apple/grape juice, but finishes fairly dry with a minor hop. Sticky fruit lingers, odd one, tasty enough but missing a lot.

column1: Angry Hanks Street Fight Imperial Red Ale
column5: Sample at the 2nd annual Montana Brewers festival. slightly hazy amber. Aroma of mostly grain. Taste is not very imperial tasting to me, mostly grain again and caramel.

column1: Angry Hanks Street Fight Imperial Red Ale
column5: Draft sample at brewpub. Poured a clear reddish brown color with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly lasted and had very good lacing. Good roasted malty and small earthy hop aroma. Medium body with slick smooth texture and soft carbonation. Moderate well balanced smooth flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Good complex brew.

column1: Angry Hanks Street Fight Imperial Red Ale
column5: Draft at taphouse; Pours a deep reddish brown with a large creamy head. Nose is earthy and roasy, some bits of rye. Rye remains in the flavor with a more hoppy center and a bit of roasted malts. Kind of sweet, yet dry and piney.

Cask handpull, The Crown, Nuneaton. Almost pitch with faint ruby glints and a ’greige’ lid. Aroma gingernuts dunked in Chianti; mouth red wine, oak, smoky hints, dark cherry. Unusual tasty mild with vinous undertones.
Cask Handpump at the Portland Hotel, Chesterfield (JDW) 19/05/2007 Some floral aroma. Small white head. Golden and smooth on the palate with some dryness and bitterness in a malt finish.

Tasted by a pint at the Swim Inn, a JDW pub on the West Street, Sheffield, where I often found Wentworth’s seasonal/occasional brews on offer. Served on a handpump fixed with a sparkler. Appearance: dark golden with a brown shade, coming with a thick & creamy white froth that refuses to retreat--the work of a sparkler. Aroma: a light note of cream & honey comes with almost feather light lager malts... lack of hops on the nose. Flavour: intense toasted malts upfront, a tad sour, added with a deepening dryish mouthfeel of toastiness as well as a lingering bitter undertone--so there are considerable hops after all~~ The lovely, lingering malt aroma intensifies quietly, hand in hand with a slightly tangy/zesty kick of fruitiness. Palate: thanks to the sparkler, the texture is soft and smooth, yet a slightly spritzy mouthfeel is retained due to the freshness of this cask, I presume. All in all, a solid light mild well worth a try!
caramel aroma. Deep ruby colour. Medium bitterness. Long hoppy finish. Overall, I'd order it again.
Lata @Mas ibus Despacho de cervezas, Torrelavega. 17/06/17. Color ambarino bueno. Aromas a maltas con notas a lúpulos ligeros sabor caramelo y maltosa con cuerpo medio

Appearance: Big thick white head with tanned tinges. Body looks like burnished copper but when held to the light it’ very reddish in color. Smell: Initial weird metallic aroma that gradually dissipates. Roasted smell and as it warms, i get a gentle hop presence. Taste: A nice robust yet discreet taste. Some hops in the fore with a subdued dry bitter finish. There’s also some tea and a type of herbal presence lurking in there. I’m also getting some earthy notes, maybe barley? Mouthfeel: Just a tad too carbonated at first but not uncomfortable by any means and definitely eases as it warms. Nice full body with a smooth flavorful feel.
Canned. Aroma of metal. Brown body, big beige head. Taste of roasted nuts, quite weak and boring.

Slightly hazy dark amber color with a thick cloud of activity. Creamy and frothy beige 2-3 finger island head, lasting around 15-20 minutes, creating a very good amount of lacing. Flavors of caramel and butterscotch, faint ester fruits, citrus, sweet buttery grains, faint floral and herbal spices, faint nutmeg and cinnamon. Highly sweet with the right amount of grassy hops and red ale spices. Creamy smooth medium to full body with carbonation. Medium strength finish with a nice lingering mouthfeel of cinnamon spices, caramel, and grassy noble spices. Overall pretty good craft with a delicious salivating prominent caramel flavor, lots of freshness and well intensified. A pleasure to drink!

OK some days you just need simple tasty beer. Uncomplicated, tasty beer. Kind of a home town brand for me but 1st try. Real beer plain and simple no hoppyness no saison. Just good old basic quality beer. After a bike ride Can from LCBO

473ml can. Clear copper with a foamy off-white head. Flavors are toasted cereals, dirty malts, barley sugar, caramel, berries and earth with woodsy, spicy and metallic notes. Generous bitterness. Light to medium body, moderate to good carbonation, watery texture.
