Appearance: clear medium amber with one finger of creamy ivory head diminishing gradually to a thin cap, patchy lacing. (4/5) Aroma: caramel/toffee malt, pine, toast, citrus zest, earth. (7/10) Taste: moderate-low sweet, moderate bitter. (7/10) Medium body, moderate-soft carbonation, off-dry slightly sticky lingering bitter finish. (4/5) Well, that’s a bit of a surprise: it looks like an amber, but the aromas include a decent hop character in addition to the malt. Moreover, although the taste has some malt elements, it’s not sweet at all, and the bitterness is quite pronounced. I find it hard to believe that it’s only 35 IBU, actually, and can definitely taste the super-alpha hops. The bitterness really sticks around in the slightly sticky finish, lingering and growing. An amber I actually like - who’d’a thunk it? (15/20)

500 ml bottle. Pours a clear weak amber-pale golden with a short lived white head. Aroma is caramel, lots of toast, grains and herbs. Flavor is caramel, lots of roast. Finish is roast, herbal, slightly earthy. Lingering malt, biscuit, slightly herbal. Medium body, average carbonation.

500mL bottle Brewed Jul 6. Pours with zero head or lacing. Not impressive. Colour dark red and a bit orangish. Toasted aroma. Nice. Really nice on the palate. Balanced bitterness. Nice. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It’s unclear golden with a creamy, white head. The wine is very clear i both aroma and the sweet flavour, that also has notes from the weissbier: banana, banana peel and light yeast. The wine is OK, but the overall impression is way too sweet...

Bottled. A hazy light golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma has notes of wheat and wine as well as light notes of banana. The flavor is sweet and acidic with notes of lemon and white wine - a weird combination. The acidity draws a bit of mouthwater.

Bottle 50cl.
Unclear medium to light dark yellow color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, wine acidc, lime, wine. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet with a long to average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20081004]

50 cL bottle, courtesy of Papsoe/Ungstrup. Pours hazy yellow with a diminished white head. Floral and fruity aroma with a mild grape note. Citrusy and sweet flavoured in a light sticky mix. Flat malty finish.
(Bottle 50 cl) Pours a hazy golden with a white head. Sweet aroma of citrus and a little yeast. Medium body with very sweet citrus notes and a whiff of yeast. Has a light underlying tartness. 041008
Bottle. Very buttery aroma. Hazy pale yellow colour. Very small white head. Very sweet flavour, some white wine citric notes. I guess OK drunk very cold in the sun.

Bottle (bought at the Brauerei): Golden, hazy, quickly vanishing white head;, moderate sweet-fruity (oranges, lemons) nose with a touch of wheat and a stronger vinous background; stronger sweetish-sourish flvour, medium to full bodied, almost cloying; sweet vinous finish with a light tartness and acidity in the aftertaste. A taste like a cheap sweet Weinschorle, suitable for lousy german Christmas fairs............

(bottle) Cloudy, yellow colour with a short creamy white layer. Slightly sweet and vinous, better said cheap vinous nose; yeasty with light malt character and a fruity (grapes) touch. Sweet and sour flavour, light to medium bodied with a medium carbonation. Strange taste: the sparkling wine and its fruitiness (grapes, citrus) is dominating the taste, just a weak (wheat-) malty base is still detectable; sweet and quite sour finish. Might be refreshing and even drinkable for someone else but me. My first sample of the “style” and I have to admit that I´m stuffed with this kind of “beer” for the rest of my life. At least it has a proper sweetness-sourness ratio.
Rating from 2005. Insgesamt etwas laff. Malzig und leicht herb. --> 11
Bottled. A golden beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and straw, leading to a lightly bitter finish.

Bottle 50cl.
Clear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, molasses, butter light notess. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20081004]

50 cL bottle, courtesy of Papsoe/Ungstrup. Pours clear and golden orange with a diminished white head. Light malty and mild bitterhops aroma. Light butterish flavour with a mild spice note and slowly increasing bitterness. Ends with a mild caramel note mixed with a medium dry bitterness.
(Bottle 50 cl) Clear deep golden with a white head. Clean and malty nose with a touch of alcohol. Medium body with sweet malts and a whiff of caramel. Almost no bitterness. 041008
Bottle, 5.5%. Slightly sweet aroma, hint of syrup. Clear dark golden colour. Very small white head. The flavour is malty, slightly bready, hint of mold. Hint of spicy hops in the finish.

Bottle (bought at the brewery): Golden coloured, medium-sized, quite stable and slightly lacing white head; moderate bitter-sweet flavour, shy honeyish-malty nose with a distinctive hoppy touch; soft, smooth MF; slightly lingering bitter-grainy-sweet finish. A decent, spicy Märzen, that’s not too aromatic........

(bottle) Light-hazy, almost clear, golden colour with a fluffy white foam, slowly lacing. Sweet bready and slightly caramel-malty aroma with a honey-fruity touch and shy herbal hops in the background. Sweet flavour, medium bodied with a soft and pleasant carbonation. Solid and strong malt-character: bready, very subtle fruity with notes of honey, marzipan and caramel; sweet, light bitter finish with a moderate length. Good stuff.

Bottle best by March 2015. Hazy dark gold with a white head. Strongly flawed aroma is autolyzed yeast, sweat, tomato and cauliflower DMS. Medium body, sour and yeasty and raw and unfinished. Medium sweetness, low bitterness, high silt content. Tastes like it was just pitched. Ugh.
Rating from 2005. Schön hefiges Bier, herb-hopfig im Abgang. --> 11

Bottle looks really good. Beer in the glass zippy, nice head. Starts mild, but not washy. Fine malty notes, modest moldy. Spicy with mild sourish notes. More and more fruity like lemon. Finish malty, modest dry. Spicy aftertaste. Nice!

It’s unclear golden with a creamy, white head, and a mild aroma with notes of light yeast, clover, malt and hints of medicine. The flavour is moderately sweet with notes of malt, flower, clover and light medicine, and the finish is dry.

Bottled. An unclear golden beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and yeast as well as lighter notes of butter and honey. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and straw as well as lighter notes of honey, leading to a dry bitter finish.

Bottle 50cl.
Unclear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, wheat, buttery. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20081004]

50 cL bottle, courtesy of Papsoe/Ungstrup. Mild estery aroma with a mild wheaty note, light butterish note. A bit cardboardish and dry flavoured with a light yeasty to estery note. Mild butterish and light caramelish finish. Smooth yet not clean.
(Bottle 50 cl) Hazy pale golden with a small white head. Aroma of sweet malts and butter. Medium body with sweet - almost sugary - malt and butter notes. Subdued bitterness. 041008

Bottle, 5.0%. Bready aroma. Cloudy yellow colour. OK white head. The flavour has a little green apple, citric and bready. The yeast tastes a little old and does not give the naturtrüby feeling it should.

Bottle (purchased at the brewery): Pale golden, hazy, big, slowly diminishing fluffy white head; sweet-malt and barley in the aroma, with a tinge of fruitiness, distinctive oaky hops also; moderate bitter-sweet flavour, light to medium bodied, soft MF; aromatic hoppy finish. Pleasnt stuff..........

Draft at the brewpub in the City. Pours a clear orange with a small off-white head that settles into a ring. Light-bodied, with modest carbonation. What stands out in this particular pumpkin ale is the ginger. This thing is really, really ginger-forward in the nose and flavor alike, while many pumpkin ales eschew ginger altogether in favor of some nutmeg-cinnamon-allspice-clove combo. There's a bit of sweet malt in here, but not much. It's all about the spice. And as a ginger/pumpkin ale, it's good.

From tap at winery/brewery tasting room. Nice, flavorful seasonal beer with medium body and smooth finish. Aroma of spice, bread. Hint of cinnamon as one spice. Good session beer and let’s say the ladies loved it better than the IPA or wheat beer. Nice establishment in Ste. Genevieve County, MO. We’ll be back!

The Dan Journal #38. The Autumn tasting. Sampled 10/22/2006. Sampled from a growler. Filtered with a bright copper orange hue. Bready aromas with pumpkin and cinnamon notes. Medium bodied and sweet. Roasty bready but a touch thin. Good spices and dry hops. Bitters come out in the finish as it warms. This got the silver for the evening’s Okt’fest samplings. Tasted 9/10/08. Fresh 1L Growler from the brewpub. Filtered with a bright ruby amber hue. Bubbled spiraling bone white head. Lotta spices in the nose with notes of nutmeg, cinnamon and a touch ginger. Touch grassy citrus, almost lemongrass aromas. Medium bodied with a great malt base. Soft effervescence with smooth malts. Spicy middle and a bitter, dry finish. Good rolling spice palate and a great drinkability. Good tingling body and an ample dose of hops. The hop character plays intermixed with the similar spice characteristics of the ginger and cinnamon. The spices dominate most of the palate, especially the finish. The initial malt profile is a mix of pumpkin pie filling and caramel based crust. Everything shines in a nice rolling package!
Great Utah Beer Run – Summer 2007 On Tap – White in color with a thin head. This had a very malty aroma and flavor. I liked this beer but it finished very sweet. No hops at all for this beer.

on tap-pours a white head that laces and gold color. Aroma is some sweet light/medium malt, light hops (saaz)-spice/floral (and peppermint?). Taste is some sweet light/medium malt, light hops (saaz)-spice/floral (and peppermint?)/Hallertau?. Minimum carbonation.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Roasty aroma; coffee-ish. Roasted malt flavor, with some sweet and bread flavors. Nice subtle lager yeast flavor. A little herbal hops.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at the Bayou, SLC. Pours a clear dark brown with a thick tan head. Aroma of simple roasted malt. Flavor is more complex - roasted malt with chocolate (like chocolate covered pretzels) and a mild saltiness. A good swartzbier, strong palate too. 7/4/8/4/15 (3.8/5)

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub Appearance: Clear dark brown with a small beige head and some lacing Aroma: Nutty and roasted coffee Taste: Toasted malts, grainy, ashy and roasted coffee Nice solid beer, enjoyed this one

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: on tap 7/22/10. rootbeer color with an off white head. holy hot dogs aroma and flavor! straight uncooked weiners from out of their package smoked meatiness!... mixed in are notes of barley, chocolate, toasted nuts and florals. the flavor finishes with a light sourness, grain husky bitterness and some sour smoke. . the medium body is crisp and highly drinkable.... if you like hot dogs. 6/4/6/4/14/3.4

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Dark brown, minimal head. Caramelly nose. Sweet with light-medium body and clean, hard mouthfeel. Focus shifts from caramel over treacle and butter to coffee in the finish. The malt feels hard and edgy giving the beer a lifeless impression.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Deep brown with a nice tan head. Smells of dark chocolate, coffee and nuts with a little caramel. Flavor is smooth with lots of chocolate and dark malts and coffee with little hops. FInish is still smooth with a bite of bitterness.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a dark brown/black color with a medium light brown head. The aroma is quite nice; loads of roasted malts and nuts. A really nice toasted flavor; lots of nutty notes, some toasted malts and light chocolate. Very nice.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: on tap-pours a retaining thin light tan head and mahogany color. Aroma is dark malt-nut brown. Taste is dark malt-nut brown/chocolate/oatmeal, secondary/faint hops bitterness. Smooth. OK effervescence.

column4: Coney Island Brewing Company (A&S Brewing - Boston Beer Co.)
column5: Bottle from Backlog, look is darker golden with medium but receding had. Smell and flavor of cereal, cracker, light hops, malt, fruit, and grains. Really bland and boring with a thin mouthfeel.

column4: Coney Island Brewing Company (A&S Brewing - Boston Beer Co.)
column5: Had this one on a hot day at the amusement park at a geocaching Giga event. Pounded a tall one in short order very drinkable and refreshing.

column4: Coney Island Brewing Company (A&S Brewing - Boston Beer Co.)
column5: Vom Fass at Nathan‘s. Am Boardwalk in Coney Island! Braunes Bier, dünner Schaum. Karamell und Malzduft. Würziger Kräuer Antrunk. Malz, Karamell und etwas Lakritz. Dann kommt der Hopfen. Im Abgang wieder derKaramell und Lakritz. Gefällt mir.

column4: Coney Island Brewing Company (A&S Brewing - Boston Beer Co.)
column5: Aroma: caramel, malt, tender notes of hops. Nose is intensive and distinct. Taste: saturated and balanced caramel flavor mixed with grass, roasted malt and bread. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Coney Island Brewing Company (A&S Brewing - Boston Beer Co.)
column5: 12 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy orange with a small tan head. Aroma is toasted malty and slight breadish. Toasted malty, sweet and slight caramelish. Toasted malty and light breadish finish.

column1: Oceanside Ale Works Missionary Mai Bock
column5: Aroma is caramel malt sweetness with some spiciness. Pours reddish brown. Flavor is very malty and sweet. Caramel and toffee malt flavors and that is about all I got. There was some alcohol warmth as well.

column1: Oceanside Ale Works Missionary Mai Bock
column5: On tap @ Stone - Pours a hazy orangish-amber color with a faint off white head. No lacing. Aroma and flavor is primarly biscuit malt. Medium body. This beer reminds me of Fat Tire. A good beer.

Cask handpull at The Crosse Keys London as Weltons Duke’s Toast Belgian Style Saison, 6.6%. Pale golden yellow, clear and still with a foamy beige head. Aroma is candi sugar, caramel wafer, light honey. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is pretty papery and astringent up front, notes of apple pie and honey, clove. Overly astringent and spicy. Interesting and probably not far away from being a success, but it’s pretty harsh as it is. (6-4-4-3-12=2.9)
A Mes rate: Cask at the Wenlock with Rudiger. Amber colour with a slight bubbly head. Caramel and malt is the order of the day. Sadly let down bodly by some tea and apple. Not great.

Cask handpull at Gardener’s Arms, Lewes. Copper colour wtih thin bubbly white head. Rich strong bitter. Hop on finish is OK. Alcohol is a bit obvious. Some citrus, malts are subdued, bit of golden syrup. OK. Not what I would call drinkable.
500ml bottle in 2016. Murky golden with a thin white head. Grainy aroma with some grassy hops and tropical fruit. Banana, tinned fruit and chewy grain flavours.

Bottle at the Brighton Dome. Strange to see such a low rating. I thought this was a fabulous example of a great Sussex best bitter. I love this style. Sweet malts blending with bitter crunch and light hops. Wanted a few more but hey couldnt interrupt the brilliant Nish Kumar with a beer run
Cask somewhere in Brighton. Quite aggressive carbonation, some bitter hops but not a lot else going on. Not great.
Pours with a very slight base. Not much head, quite high carbonation. A subtle hop nose, nothing stands out though. Light with a building bitterness. Easy drinking, pleasant summer ale.

Pours slightly hazy golden colour, topped with a medium sized white head. Slight soury nose initially, fruity and citrusy with mild cellar notes. Sparkly texture, quite, Slightly fruity sweet in the beginning, followed by milder bitterness. Mild and shorter aftertaste, light body.
500ml bottle Light amber with ok head and good carbonation. Grainy/malt aroma. Mild bitterness. Grainy/malt palate. BB was 25/10/18 but still got some oxidation. Meh.

500ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Goldecn colour with a white foam head leaving lacing and aroma of fruity banana, hay. Taste is sweetish, pale malty, fruity, with a mellow citrus note, hay, straw, and earthy bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry clean finish. Quite OK
Cloudy gold. Moderate white head. Pale malts and herbal hops on nose. Light body. Dry taste vague malts and herbal hops of no elegance. Drinkable.
Bottle at some deli in Virginia Water, following train cancellation. 11/11/16. Hazy yeasty aroma. Light gold. Short-lived white head. Light bitter. Pretty watery.

Bottle from Marks and Spencer, Metrocentre, Gateshead. Pale golden coloured with a thin white head. It has a floral fruity and lemon flavour followed by a smooth herbal and slight spicy finish. Pretty good.

Tasting from early 2008. Tried this on draught at the brewery, then a few too many later on that afternoon out the bottle at home. Can’t fault it for presentation; precision, sexy, alluring, artful. Deep set fiery copper with a little chestnut coming through. Shimmers in the light, emits a radiance that dances, and as translucent as polished crystal. A lot of very, very fine carbonation eddies its way up to an inch thick, tight, creamy off-white crown that holds its place to leave a nice web of lace. Gingersnap biscuits, salted peanuts, powdery cocoa, nutmeg and varnished timber, a little rust and ashen wood on the nose, very interesting. Equally complex mix of burnt and charred caramel and demerara up front, smoke, wood, and rough darker malts, tree-bark and mildly astringent, husky grains throughout the rest into the malty and full, mildly bitter, chocolaty and woody swallow. A little cola and peanut cookies linger. I loved this flavour combo and couldn’t understand why. It just works. The body is lighter than the flavour suggests, the mouthfeel soft and comfortable. Goes down a treat just off cool. Very nice stuff. (50cL, Brew-42, Collie)
On tap. Great looking smooth nitro beer. nice malty smooth flavour. finished off nicely
Bottle courtesy of BlueVegie, Aromas of raw malt, and cardboard. Taste is of underattenuated, brew full of crystal or melanoidin malts. Not that nice.
Straight from the tap at Brew 42 in Collie. This was a good session beer for me, nice red body with creamy head and drank very much like a Kilkenny only very fresh.

Draft @ Brewpub. Orange-red pour with a white head. Aroma of grapefruit and other citrus and light sweet malt. Flavors of citrus, light pine and grass hops and subtle sweet malt. Medium body, bitter/bright/sweet with a bitter finish. A damn fine APA.

Draft @ Brewpub: Copper color, light head and lacing. Nose of earthy fresh grassy hops, wet leaf, citronella and vanilla, pale malt. The flavor is nutty and thick with a cottony mouthfeel, super dry and sweet with some hops. Thick and chewy, but not too thick to prevent enjoying. Nice.

Name: Super Centennial Pale Ale Date: 06/23/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear orange, fine white head, solid lace, big sweet grapefruit aroma, lots of citrus hop flavor, sweet caramel balances the hop flavor, bitterness starts halfway through and lasts through a long finish, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **+/4
(Draft) Pours a clear amber body with a small white head. Aroma of mild citrus and caramel. Flavor of citrusy hops and caramel malt.
On tap at the pub for RBSG. Loved the hop nose on this one (much more than I did the 1800 ipa. Brown color with white head. Well balanced hop and malt in the body.

Out of a sampler at the pub at 07 RBSG. Light amber color with a thin off white head that left attractive lacing in the glass. Nice fresh hop nose. Caramel sweetness with grapefruit, peach and apricot flavors. Sharp, crisp hop finish. Nice beer.

RBSG. Pours a hazy deep copper with modest carbonation and a fluffy white head. Aroma is fresh clean centennial, lightly grassy, but mostly citrus, hints of pine and sappy. Good hoppy mouthfell with a good harsh bitterness, clean with mroe pine and citrus notes- ok malt backbone but this one was loaded with hops. Nice IPA/APA.

Draught pint at the brewpub, RBSG Minneapolis pub crawl, June 22 2007. Clear light copper pour, bit of lasting head, touch of lacing....hoppy citric/piny aroma, hits all the right notes but never quite excites; pungent without being nose-altering....really juicy, but solidly bitter body, bracing and fairly harsh, enough pale and lightly caramelized malts show up to keep you going to the moderately dry, very bitter finish....guess I’m not as blown away as most were, but this was certainly a nice pint that I’d be happy to have again.

Super Centennial is the correct rating. On cask. Well hopped aroma with some citrus, it is very full not not complex in the aroma. Flavor has a base of sweet malt, with bitter pine and citrus. Very smooth from tap, and leaves a light hop burn.

RBSG 2007 Pub Crawl - on draft at the brewpub. Clear light amber with a white head. Very nice white lace. Fruity sweet citrus nose. Rather intense bitter flavor, lots of grapefruit rind over light caramel. Some piney notes. Good!

column1: Refsvindinge Den Gyldne Hest Ale No. 100
column5: 33 cl. bottle. Hazy amber colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, bread, caramel, nuts and hops.

A top Irish Red... balance bitterness with lots of dark tasty malts!!! Not much hop aroma to take away from the malts so it was done right IMO. Great during winter and or with desert... CHOCOLATE! Another great loss...
Malty aroma. Clear dark brown colour with good head. Nice coffee flavor with nice creamy finish. Medium to heavy body with low carbonation.

Pours dark amber/copper with a large, lasting head. Nose shows some nutty malt and chocolate, quite sweet smelling but faint. Similar flavours but after the initial burst of malt it falls flat very quickly. Too much carbonation for my liking.

I prefered the Snowy pale ale to this amber style, althoug I usually like a good amber ale. This was a good offering and better than the alternative in the mega-swill breweries. I would quite happily buy and drink this beer again.

Bottle. Clear darkish amber with a small light beige head. Aroma of toffee and nuts. Sweetish with nuts, toasty caramel, grassy bitterness that’s just short of balancing but gives a drying finish. OK, but lacks life.

pours a brilliant amber with a frothy white head, aroma of toffee and toast, flavor of toast, caramel and a sharp citrus bite. overall a nice beer, had it as part of an aus/nz amber ale tasting night and it surprisingly ranked higher then some of the more well known brands.

Out the bottle, chilled, and into a nice flat-wall schooner. Chestnut brown, sparkling and headless, a few off-white bubbles gather on the meniscus. Awkward clingy carbonation sits upon the glass walls. It doesn’t look on the money, but it makes up for it! Pronounced, big, biscuity, woody malt nose. Arguably sweet, a little burnt sugar edge, some cola soda, dried dark fruit, a little rust, very enticing, very alluring. All malt in the mouth, nice rounded woody, smokiness, a little pasty in feel with generous licks of vanilla, cola and praline. Very, very subtle malt astringency late. Dry, malty length has long, long hints of dried, savoury dark fruit. The body is medium, it’s quite bold both in flavour and feel. Nice, relaxed carbonation makes for more pleasantries, this is a nice drinking ale. The fruit starts to dazzle on the palate giving it a rustic savoury edge. I liked this one. An honest, sessionable, malt driven ale. Well done!!! (33cL, no date stamp, Dan Murphy’s)
very dissapointed with this beer. would barely call it a red ale, thought it might save snowy mountains brewery in my mind, but failed to come through
Nice roasty malty body - I would like to see more of the simcoe come through to give this a bit of diversity. Decent but could be much, much better.

330ml bottle. Pours a dark amber-red colour, with a small head. Starts off with strong citrus hops, with notes of lemon and lime in the middle. The finish is smooth, with the coffee and chocolate notes of roast malt. Doubtless an interesting flavour combination, but it seems to work quite well in fact. A beer for winter, and one I would definitely buy again.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: On nitro at the downtown pub: A little roasted malt aroma and flavor, with some light fruity/herbal character from the hops and/or yeast. Roasted flavor is balanced with some bready and caramel/sweet flavors.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Pours a nice hazy golden orange color. Aromas of nice citrus/grapefruit hops. Flavor starts malty and the hops kick in, nice crisp bitter finish.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: On tap at the brewpub Appearance: Dark reddish amber with a nice off-white head leaving some lacing Aroma: Slightly roasted malts, caramel and hops Taste: Toasted malts, caramel, bitter hops in the finish Crisp and clean, leaving no aftertaste.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: On nitro tap at the downtown brewpub in SLC. Pours a deep ruby hue with a nitro infused white thick head. The aroma is nice; light caramel malts and a spicy hop note. The flavor was similar; lots of rich and smooth flavors, caramel malts and light spicy hops. A full nitro mouthfeel. Refreshing and easygoing.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: On tap (nitro); poured a really nice looking reddish amber with a creamy head. Flavor was enjoyable with some nice caramel malt and floral hop elements. Surprisingly good brew.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: on tap-pours a retaining thin off white head that laces and copper/amber color. Aroma is mild, medium malt-caramel, hops. Taste is medium malt-caramel, flat/bitter hops, smoky. OK carbonation which is unusual for a nitro pushed beer.

Bottle. Fairly clear light golden color. White foamy head. Moderately high citrus orange peel aroma with definite coriander. Flavor is coriander, orange peel, wheat, no hops. Finishes lightly bitter. Nice. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12oz bottle. Has that loud hissing carbonation that screams infection. Sour garbage aroma and biting non-to-style sourness. Shabby stuff, shouldn’t be in the marketplace.

On tap at Baileys Range. Hazy gold pour with thin white head. Aroma is wheaty, puke, gastric notes, cheesy, super buttery. Taste is grainy, cheesy, awful. Palate is med bodied with, sweet, light carb. Gross.
Draft at the saint louis brew house. Light pale color cloudy . Interesting flavor. Crisp and light
Gross!! Just hard to stomach. Sweet and sour at the same time. Not a good mix of sweet orange and lack of wheat/yeast notes.
Tap at Heavy Riff. Pale yellow-gold pour with a small head. Wheat and mild floral notes. Very thin. Not very good.

Bottle @ RBSG brunch. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy coriander aroma. Fryuity wheat malty spicy coriander flavor. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy finish.
Bottle during RBSG 2014 at Schlafly Bottleworks brunch. Clear yellow with off-white head. Aromas of wheat, citrus, malt. Tastes of wheat, citrus. Medium-light body with a dry finish.

Bottle @ Brunch. Light golden pour with a white head. Lemon peel, some orange, and white pepper. Some bread and a little bit of cracker. Fairly sweet taste. Lots of orange marmalade, bread, and wheat bread. Light cracker, white pepper, and lemon tartness.
Sampled at Schlafly during RBSG. Pours a golden color with white head. Coriander, lemon, spicy aromas. Tangy coriander, spicy flavors.

BLack pour with a huge tan head. The aroma has some dark fruit notes as well as some tartness, chocolate and roasted malt. The flavor also shows some light signs of infection. I get the chocolate and roasted malt notes but they are accompanied by some tart cherries. Medium mouthfeel and high carbonation.
Bottle - small foamy head, black color with a little bit of amber coming through, roasted malt aroma and flavor, mild coffee and very mild chocolate notes, a little thin mouthfeel for a stout

Location: 22 oz bottle from Colonial Wine and Spirits, 5/30/12 Aroma: The nose has some roasted and burnt malts, some ashy notes, and a little coffee/chocolate Appearance: This one pours a dark brown color with a creamy beige head and some light-medium lace Flavor: Tastes similar to the nose, with roast/burnt malts leading the way, with a slightly ashy and anise finish Palate: The body is on the lighter side for the style, it feels quite smooth, and it has a rather flat carbonation Overall Impression: I found this to be an OK beer, but overall it was kind of unexciting. I wanted it to be better, but the flavors were just not that exciting. The smoothness of the mouthfeel was probably the best part of this one.

This 22 oz bottle was sent to me courtesy of Stykzone. It poured pretty much black with some red around the edges, and raised a medium sized tan head that settled quickly and left moderate lacing. The nose is roasted malts with aromas of chocolate, coffee, oatmeal, ripe fruit, and ashes. Medium in body it was somewhat thin in mouthfeel. The flavor is complex and similar to the nose but vanilla is detected as well. The finish is a tiny bit sour. Overall this a quite decent oatmeal stout.
On draught at the brewpub. It poured a dark color with a small tan head. The aroma was lots of roasted malts with a small amount of chocolate and coffee. The taste was light with some roast and oats.

Bomber to shaker. Pours black with thick tan head that hangs around and laces. Grain, hay, and bready malts, nice. Palate is somewhat creamy and full. Taste is very good for the style--mildly sweet with a very nice finish that ends dry. Good beer from the folks at Ste Gen.

25-Sep-10 (22-oz bottle: Purchased 31-Dec-10 for $4.69 at www.wineandcheeseplace.com) The Charleville beers haven’t really been much to write home about, and though this Oatmeal Stout isn’t exceptional, it is quite pleasant. The beer is dark brown in the glass with solid clarity evident at the edges. The tan head pours to nearly half an inch, but quickly subsides to a razor-thin ring. The nose offers dark chocolate, oatmeal, dark toast, ashtray, decayed wood, licorice, prune and a hint of tart berry. On the palate, moderately sweet, dark chocolate, oatmeal, licorice, earth, wood, and a bit of ashiness are joined once again by a touch of fruity tartness and prunes. The weight is medium-full and the mouthfeel is generally dry despite the light sweetness in the flavor, but the carbonation is a bit rough and prickly for a style that is usually characterized by smooth creaminess. Overall, a pretty nice oatmeal stout, and probably the best beer I’ve tried from this brewery.

Bomber from Wine & Cheese in Clayton, Mo. Pours black with a 3 finger foamy dark tan head. Smells like burnt malt. Med body. Flavor is burnt malt with some chocolate and coffee. Fairly smooth. Drinks well. Going well with an artisanal choc chip cookie.
(bottle) deep black with slightly sweet roasted malt aroma. Flavor is roasted malt, some oats and coffee, dark fruits, a little sweet. Good body, smooth.

22 oz. bottle from Wine and Cheese Place. Pours a dark brown, opaque but not oily, with a small brown head. Notes of roasted malts, coffee, oak, milk sugar, dark chocolate, vanilla, some dark fruits, and a little smoked wood. Medium-bodied, with a roasty mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. I was impressed by this one, just a nice, roasty, surprisingly sweet oatmeal stout.

2014 bottle. Pours a brown color. Barely any head, though has some lacing. Cloudy, I think. Hard to see through. Aroma is lots of dark fruits. Figs, raisins, prunes, cherries, plums, apple skin. Wow. Malty and sweet. Has some light hops to balance. Taste is heavy with dark fruits, berries, and malt. Mouthfeel is full bodied. Heavy and syrupy. Thick and rich. Though no alcohol to be tasted. Overall it’s good. I enjoy it. I would recommend it and I would buy it again.

Got in a BIF from jdell15. 12 ounce bottle into snifter, 2013 vintage bottling. Pours moderately murky dark ruby red, light copper/brown color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense and fluffy light khaki head with awesome retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Thick soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of huge raisin, plum, prune, fig, pear, apricot, red apple, date, caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toffee, and toasted biscuit; with lighter notes of nuttiness, molasses, roast, wood, herbal, grass, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/bready malt, fruity yeast, and light earthy hop notes; with great strength. Slight oxidation coming out as it warms. Taste of huge raisin, plum, prune, fig, pear, apricot, red apple, date, caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toffee, and toasted biscuit; with lighter notes of nuttiness, molasses, roast, wood, herbal, grass, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Light herbal/grassy hop and roast bitterness on the finish. Lingering notes of dark fruit, pear, apricot, red apple, caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toffee, toasted biscuit, nuttiness, molasses, light roast, wood, herbal, grass, and yeast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Great complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt, fruity yeast, and light earthy hop flavors; with a good malt/bitterness balance, and zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Slightly increasing dryness from bitterness. Medium-plus carbonation and very full body; with a very smooth, creamy, silky, and bready mouthfeel that is awesome. Slightly slick, syrupy, sticky, and chalky. Alcohol is very well hidden; very mild warmth of 10.5% lingering after the finish. Overall this is an excellent English barleywine! All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt, fruity yeast, and light earthy hop flavors; very smooth and dangerously easy to sip on for the big ABV. Very rich and complex with perfect balance of yeast fruits and dark/bready malt sweetness. Just enough earthy hop presence to balance. This aged really well, not much oxidation. A really enjoyable offering, and spot on style example.

2015 Bottle; Pour is mahogany, with a dense, fine bubbled beige head into this glass. The appearance is nice initially, and as the head fades on this one - all hope eventually does as well. The nose unveils some typical barleywine features - caramel toffee notes, dark fruit presence. However: The flavor profile is harsh up front - bittering, booze, not -quite- off notes but not quite right either - it melds terribly. There’s some minerality, more dark fruit presence , with candied fruits and I just can’t do it. Not because it’s a barleywine like the previous rater mentioned - but because it’s a poor example of style.
bottle from winter secret santa; not one of my favorite styles - great first sip and then not so much.......that’s why I don’t like the style

Bottle. 2015 vintage. Poured a dark burgundy color. Aroma of dark fruit, figs and bit of caramel. taste of dark fruit, caramel and spice. Mild bitterness and a clean finish. Moderate body, smooth and nicely crafted. Nice drink to kick back and relax with.

12oz bottle. Hazy, reddish-brown tone with a large tan foamstand. Malty nose. Dried leaves, aged figs, raisins, moldy spices, caramel & parchment/cardboard. Full bodied with medium carbonation. Wasn’t bad but could’ve used a touch more sweetness.

bottle courtesy of Strykzone,poured into a tulip glass...burgundy with a thin off white head..aroma of caramel,toffee,booze,dark fruits..tastes of raisins,caramel,figs,toffee..not overly bitter..just ok.

2015 version. Aroma is disappointing. Boozy, malty and not much else with a faint trace of cardboard. Pours a nice reddish color with a tiny ring of white foam. Taste has elements of fig, plum and raisin. Spicy up front with more sweetness than is typical for the style. Alcohol burn in the aftertaste. Not very complex. Palate is thin and weak. I didn’t like this one very much. I should have known this brewery couldn’t produce a decent barleywine. I will be aging a few bottles mostly because I don’t want to drink them. Hopefully some age will open this one up a bit.

The beer pours a cloudy reddish brown color with a medium off-white head that fades somewhat slowly. The aroma blends grain, alcohol, caramel, and raisin. The taste is mildly bitter, mildly sweet, a touch umami, and a touch boozy. The mouthfeel is soft in carbonation, slick in texture, and medium in body.

This has a hazy golden body with a dense ecru head that laces the glass in sheets as you drink. It has an aroma of pale malts sweetened by honey and has the additional smell of wheat. The flavor is lgiht and sweet with pale malt. In the middle a sturdy floral/grassy bitterness appears that lasts long into the finish. Not bad. Lunar Brewing Company, Villa Park, IL

From the tap this pours a cloudy yellow/straw body with a thick head. Nice lacing. The aroma is toffee covered by floral and citric hops. It seems slightly watery and the listed 7% ABV surprizes me, but it does deliver a flavorful drink in which the hoppy bitterness builds as the drinking progresses. Okay. Lunar Brewing Company, Villa Park, IL

Tap at The Farmhouse in Burlington. Commonshawn, rosskyle, and samadouche involved. Snifter pour. Orange and golden with orange wearing the pants in the color relationship. Aroma is definitely citrus with heavy grapefruit influence. Sugars also come through. Taste is bright and also citrus forward. Breakfast juice comes to mind. Mostly bitterness especially at the finish and aftertaste. I think it’s that element that holds it back from really good. Should also be noted the menu calls this the Grapefruit Double IPA.

Enjoyed a bottle of this beer in a restaurant in Woodstock, Vermont, poured into a tulip glass to drink. The beer had a deep amber-copper color with a very large and foamy off white head that had great retention, and very good cling and lacing. It had a pretty strong floral and citrus hops aroma along with a bit of pine and yeast with spice. The taste was mostly bitter with a blend of citrus and floral flavors along with some spices. It was a mostly dry beer with above average carbonation and a thicker, fuller mouthfeel.
On tap. Deep orange with a small head. Very light and grassy. Light body and mouthfeel. Dry.

Deep burnt copper coloured body with a two centimetre tall off-white head and more loose sediment than i’ve ever seen in a beer before - this one is a pure colloid. Aroma of bright grassy and herbal hops with a hint of grapefruit, a decent amount of yeast and some light sugars noticeable. Medium-bodied; Assertive grassy and grapefruity hops with a very mild and perhaps light malt backbone, more of a single IPA than double, for sure. Aftertaste has the grassy and lightly herbal hops with a little malt, some sweetness and not much else - no depth nor complexity. Overall, more of a single IPA (which is fine by me), but still lacking in depth and malt backbone with no complexity at all. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Liqour Outlet in Boonton, New Jersey on 28-May-2012 for US$5.55 sampled at home in Washington on 14-October-2012.
Orange, amber with white lacing. Mighty spicy full-bodied hop flavor; big palette and slightly dry. Really good, will drink again. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a light brown with rocky off white  head. Pulp makes it appear to be apple cider. Aroma of apples and yeast. Tastes of hop notes of pine and fruit. Strong delayed malt presence that is buttery and rich. Bitterness reemerges from the creamy caramel malt and follows into the aftertaste. Butter flavor is what stands out about this IPA.

Amber pour, good sized white head. Pine, Grapefruit in the aroma, some caramel sweetness as well. Lots of Pine up front, Grapefruit, Lemon rind, caramel malt. Medium body, fairly good carbonation. Not a world beater by any stretch but a solid IIPA. Off topic - I wish this brewery would challenge itself a bit more.

22oz bottle in a styrofoam cup. Pours copper with a lacy, cream-colored head. Aroma of citrusy hops, a little light fruits, and some caramel malts. Flavor the same, with some fruitiness. Average texture. A decent beer, but not the best of its style.

Bomber courtesy of some on a BA. Translucent amber capped by small off white head with fair retention. Nose is inviting with caramel over pine and grapefruit. Bitter is the taste, overly bitter with little malt coming through. Pine lingers in the mouth. A bit watery feeling the the mouth.

On tap at Rock art 2 finger crystal clear head. SRM of 4. Light gold and orange appearance. Smell is great hop backbone. Citra and amarillo. Taste is gigantic. Lots of Hops. Dominating the glass entirely. Heavy body. No balance.

Previous incarnations of this stout have been quite good, but this year’s batch is lacking for me - fairly light for the style, with a rather one-dimensional, innocuous sweetness and roasty character - there is an almost tart quality through the middle, with notes of prune and plum that try to make things interesting - this salvages the beer a little, but this brewer makes better stouts than this.

Tap at JH. Aroma of sweet chocolate, mellow roasted coffee. Flavor again largely sweet with a mild roasted component and coffee notes more milky than anything remotely bitter, sweet chocolate remains. Pretty sweet overall and a bit light body-wise for me, but solid in the flavor department.

On tap at JH. Pours a cloudy brown with a thick tan head. Aroma of sweet roasted malt and vanilla. Flavor is more roasted with some bitter chocolate and a sweet finish. A solid, but pretty typical stout. 6/4/7/4/14 (3.5/5)

Tap @ Lake Grove. Poured black with a copper rim and minimal head. The aroma is roasty with mild coffee notes but overall is fairly light. The aroma startss roasty but light. Not much in the middle then coffee shows up quickly before turning to a light thon finish with some semi-dry bitterness.

Deep brown-black with a ruby tint throughout. Thin light brown head. The aroma is great with earthy dark chocolate, light roast coffee and a light rye/wheat spiciness. A fairly aromatic stout, soft chocolate and even a bit floral on the back which is fairly unusual. Flavour is softly sweet, with an earthy/perfumy flavour. Mild roast, dark chocolate. Fairly interesting maltiness with a low to moderate bitterness. Pretty solid stout.

For editors: I doubt this should be combined with the Corporate version b/c: Was known as Seven Grain Stout but the name was changed to Natural Mystic in the honor of an employee of the pub that recently died (his favorite song apparently). Proceeds go to his family. Pours black with a small tan head, just a smidgen of light brown tips. Aroma is roasty-ific. So damn roasty and as the beer warms a light alcohol pruniness emerges (something more common in Imp Stouts but not as strong). Taste is again full of roast and sweet prune. However, the great thing about the beer is the flavor is well balanced in a light and extremely quaffable body. Low on bitterness with coffee and toffee flavors sprinkled throughout. SO damn drinkable and so damn tasty.
Run of the mill brewpub IPA, but done fairly well. Not too hoppy, or boozy. Your usual hallmarks: copper color, caramel flavor and aroma, west coast hops.

Draft at the brewery in a pint glass. Offered as a "summer seasonal" in August. Nice amber colour with a stable white head and good lacing. Aroma was atringent hops but the flavour was nice and light with the hops. No real pungent finish but good bitterness. Good IPA.

The IPA was great. A summer seasonal that I really enjoyed. It had by far the most taste of any other beers at the restaurant. Slightly piney with a definite hop taste. Low malt character. Bitter finish.

Draft @ Brewpub. Deep orange-red pour with a white head. Aroma of apple skin, light spice, oak, yeast, coconut, and light pineapple. Flavors of oak, coconut, pineapple, and sweet caramel malt. Thick body, woody/dry/sweet with a dry finish. Neat stuff, I’m glad I got to try it.

On tap at the brewpub on 6/22/07: Pours a transparent copper ruby with a thin frothy white head. Aroma of sweet rich caramel malt with a healthy dose of bourbon oak. Body starts with a full carbonation and thick, viscous wheaty malty sweetness before giving way to complex oaky bourbon that lasts through the finish with a touch of butterscotch. Nicely balanced and enjoyable brew with a touch of warmth.

Draft @ Brewpub: Murky mahogany, no head or lacing. Nose of bright fruit and melon, some alcohol. Lots of malt and sweet fruit, some citrusy hops, raisin and plenty of resinous fermented fruit and alcohol. Nice.

Im not the biggest fan of barrel beers, certainly not bourban barrell ones. This had a huge bourban nose and flavor to it, to much for me. Fairly stong alcohol burn as well. The 3oz sample was enough for me, glad to try it though.

Date: 06/23/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear dark red, fine beige head, huge sweet bourbon and vanilla aroma with lots of oak, sticky body, rich hot buttered dark caramel malt flavor, lots of sweet bourbon character, very oaky, alcohol fades in and out, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.9/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: ***/4
(Draft) Pours a clear amber body with a medium white head. Aroma of fresh citrus, caramel, oak, and vanilla. Flavor of hops, caramel, and bourbon with a bitter finish.

On tap at Thall RBSG 07. A redish brown pour with a tan head and lace. A strong presence of abv and a bit of malt in the nose. A sweet beer with alot of abv. Some bitter. An almost mediciny taste. Mouthfeel is solid and carbonation is good. A good offering but a high abv that is not masked well. A trait that I think more aging would have done this beer some good.

Dark Amber Color. Wheat, Vinous, Syrupy Sweet Aroma. You Taste the Barrel and Alcohol Initially...Much Warming...Sweet, Syrupy...Lightly Crisped Bittersweet Aftertaste. Overall Quite Nice, Especially After Having Tried the Rubicon..Which Can Hold Its Own with This As Well.

A magenta hued amber pour. Simple, dense whiskey and port aroma, soaked into biscuits and caramel scones. Orange and honey blossoms on the tongue – rather a forceful black licorice sweetness with a cough syrup bite. Cloying and medicinal in general, though certainly not to an offensive degree. Syrupy palate with just a hint of carbonation, lacking movement and clarity. A bit much.
Clear amber brown with a small (if any) head. Taste has that big alcohol burn with maple, vanilla and candi sugar. Mouthfeel and body is full with some dried fruit notes as well.

Nice, dark brown, small, mocha head. Mostly decent, fruity hops and licorice with some darker fruits underneath, light tobacco, a little sweetness of brown sugar and butterscotch. Decent, well balanced hops and sweetness. Pours thinner than a stout which together with the distinct hoppy aroma and taste give this a unique character, quite unusual for a typical belgian ale.

On tap at Brasserie de Bellevaux, Saturday 16th March 2019 en route to our new home in Attenkirchen, Bavaria via a stop off for the night in Heidelberg. Pours dark brown with a ruby glint when the light catches it. This is a decent beer and actually not so different from the Old Peculiar that it's trying to head towards. Malty with a very light roast a bitterness not unlike a UK bitter or porter. A touch of dark fruit, it's good.

From the bottle. Very dark brown with a tall and foamy head. Aroma of blackcurrant, chocolate and overdone toast. Taste is mildly bitter with herbal undertones, including tea and parsley. Body is to the light side of medium, carbonation moderate to prickly, at times a bit empty. Overall though decent stuff.

24th Aug 2018, cask half-pint, gravity pour; 22nd Codsall Station Beer Festival. Clear golden body, white crown. The wheat comes through in both the aroma and taste, decent hop profile too, below the semi-sweet base.
Cask @ Black Horse, Barnet. Dry hopped ale, golden with a very thin head. Slightly malty in its nose, it has an easy-drinking texture with a mild fruitiness.

The Jug and Jester (JDW), Leamington, 17/07/11. Pale, finely-laced gold. Sharp, acetic, white wine vinegar on strawberries aroma leaning into Payottenland. Wild and strange with a presumably unintended lambic sharpness, mildewed cardboard, lemon juice, wisp of smoke, TCP, strawberry hints. Very nearly unblended English lambic. Couldn’t finish. More off-the-scale weirdness from North Cotswold.
Cask Handpump at the GBBF Bar P1 ’Mid East England’ Earls Court, London 08/08/2007 Hop and fruit aromas. Golden coloured hazy and floral with a crisp wheat finish.

Cask @ Volunteer Arms, GBBF 2008. Pours a clear yellow color with a longlasting white head. Has a fruity malty with a slightly hoppy aroma. Sweetish fruity caramel flavor with some hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty caramel finish with some hoppy hints in the aftertaste.
Bottle.Yellow and flat.Slight vinegar flavour s present from the start which diminishes as you drink. Not a pleasant experience trying this one.
cask at JDW cropredy ... pale yellow,lovely lemon fresh hop,light fruity lemon fresh little hop in background

[i] [b] Cask conditioned at the Exchange, Banbury, Oxon, 02-06-08 [/i] [/b] Pours hazy light/mid gold with a white lacing of bubbles. Initially fruity and sweet but backed up with some light bitterness that hangs around a little. Whilst it doesn’t look bad it tastes better than it looks. Some tanginess, served a bit too cool, aroma dulled by being slightly too cool.

Tasting notes from 2003 Harbury beer Festival. Pale golden with very thin head. Some mild citrus & wheat notes in the aroma. Farily sweet (first reaction was sweet corn), with mainly wheat flavours. Fairly watery and lite.

Cask @ GBBF 2007, London. Hazy medium yellow color with virtually none head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, butter. Flavor is light to moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration and a dry finish. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat.
Tried st JDW ritz Lincoln. Amber colour with a thin head. Aroma sweet malty as is the taste. Medium body.

Half-pint, cask ale shared with Finn at Malt Shovel in Northampton. Frothy off-white head to a hazy apricot coloured body. Doughy fruit on the nose. Doughy orange flavours. Bone dry ending. Not in its best condition on the pub, about drinkable though. (12.02.2019).
Fruity bitter with a lightness from the American hop varieties. Decent hoppy finish and bitter dryness. Pours a dark gold, head is stable. Not bad.

Cask at the Turf Tavern, Oxford. It pours a clean Amber color with a minimal beige head. Aroma is medium sweet malty with notes of caramel, biscuit and melon. Taste is also medium sweet malty and lightly crispy crackery with notes of caramel and biscuit. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, average
Pint on cask at Charlton Kings Club. Pours a clear light amber with a minimal head. Malty toffee aromas. Similar flavor, sweet up front, a little balancing bitterness.

[Waterloo Beer Festival, Liverpool, 2014] - Milestone Brewery Missi Sippy, 5.8%, tiefgolden klar. Leichtes Aroma nach Feigen, minimale medizinische Noten. Mittlerer Körper, kaum wässrig, gute Textur. Im Antrunk fruchtig, Orange. In der Mitte deutlich blumig, Orangennote weiterhin vorhanden. Abgang v.a. fruchtig blumig, moderat bitter. Nachhall floral, moderat bitter, aber anhaltend, sogar etwas harzig.
Cask, The Last Plantagenet, Leicester. Golden with a white foam. Aromas are lemon and spices with leafy notes. Flavours are bittersweet lemon with a peppery palate and some gluey aspects. Not great.
Tap at WS - The Last Plantagenet. Honey colour, lovely dense head. No particular aroma, slight hop. Smooth hop bitter taste, deep bitter. Lovely. Very smooth. Very nice.
Malts in its aroma, slightly spiced in texture, but also a fairly ordinary ale.
Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Amber gold. Malt and chocolate aroma and taste. Pretty powerful stuff with a sharp bitter finish. Excellent.
(6%ABV) On tap at Perth Food and Wine Show, Lovely hoppy ose, hazy dark amber body, good hop bite. Very good IPA, hope it end up bottled

column1: Traditional Scottish Ales Sporran Warmer Blonde
column5: Deep mahogany with small cream head. Aroma- hmm, malts- oaky, light coffee. Taste is smooth, sweet start into smooth coffee and toffee malts (light but not *too* watery) at first, then light coffee into watery. Start also barley. Good light malty beer.

column1: Traditional Scottish Ales Sporran Warmer Blonde
column5: Sampled this in the Three Judges, Glasgow in July 2009. Cask, handpump dispense. Opaque pale amber in colour with a creamy white head. Strong and intense aroma of caramel and buttery toffee notes. Silky smooth mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts gives a sweet base with soft vanilla toffee and caramelised banana flavours. Very slight hop presence but really overpowered by the sweet malt right through to the toffee finish. A cracking Scottish blonde ale but some might find this too overly sweet.

column1: Traditional Scottish Ales Sporran Warmer Blonde
column5: Cask @ The Crystal Palace JDW. Slightly hazy golden amber colour, reasonable head. Sour resin malt aroma. Vinegar & malt flavour. Sour aftertaste. Not good.

column1: Traditional Scottish Ales Sporran Warmer Blonde
column5: Cask (gravity dispense) at Pigs Ear Beer Festival, day 4 on 2 December 2010. Definitely listed on the TSA website as a Spring & Summer seasonal so I don’t know what it was doing at a festival in December. And it was certainly the Blonde as is was, well, blonde. But it wasn’t a zesty, hoppy blonde. Creamy malt was more prominent. And some toffee notes. Not a lot of hop presence at all. A bit odd really. Clean enough but not really to my taste.

column1: Traditional Scottish Ales Sporran Warmer Blonde
column5: Cask (gravity) @ 27th Pigs Ear Beer and Cider Festival 2010, at The Round Chapel in Hackney, London, England Clear medium yellow orange color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted - caramel, light to moderate hoppy, hop oil, vomit. Flavor is moderate sweet and light moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat to soft. [20101130]

column1: Traditional Scottish Ales Sporran Warmer Blonde
column5: Cask Handpump at Northwich Victoria FC Marstons Arena, Wincham 12/06/2010 Big fruity aroma. Golden coloured and fruity with an apple flavour. Dry malt finish.

column1: Traditional Scottish Ales Sporran Warmer Blonde
column5: Cask @ Bon Accord. Amber - light brown colour, beige head. Aroma of caramel malts and toffee. Faint skunkyness. Flavour of caramel malts, toffee, metallic. Dry mouthfeeling. Finishes grassy, earthy.

column1: Traditional Scottish Ales Sporran Warmer Blonde
column5: Bottled at RBESG 2007. An amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of phenol and caramel. The flavor has notes of caramel and still phenol, leading to a dry bitter caramel finish. What is it with the phenol?

column1: Traditional Scottish Ales Sporran Warmer Blonde
column5: rbesg07, bottled. golden, aroma of rum’n’raisin, some caramel and vanilla, no bitterness, self raising flour aftertaste which can’t be a good thing

column1: Traditional Scottish Ales Sporran Warmer Blonde
column5: Bottled. RBESG. Amber colour, with off-white head. Pale malty aroma with notes of honey pastilles. Sweet malty with buttery notes as well as caramel. Big on fruits here.

Draught @ Heeren van Liedekercke, Denderleeuw, Belgium. Clear light to medium orange red color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, strawberry, light hoppy grass. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. (090808)
On tap. Red beer, pink head. Aroma of sugar and strawberries, flavour is very sweet, strawberries, syrup.
On tap @ Beerweeknd Hasselt. Dark pinkblond to red color with a small white head. Aroma sweet, strawberry. Medium body. Taste sweet , syrupy, with hints of strawberry, and bit malts. Finish = sweet.
Tap at cafe Janssen, Leiden: A regular Koninck added with strawberry, and not so bad at all, but give me the regular.
Clear red/pink color, short off-white head. Aroma of strawberry, not really sweet, some hop. Bit fruity taste, quite watery, some strawberry, quite bitter for a fruit beer. Uninteresting.
On tap at Gollem. Fruity, dark. Sugary, tangy, strawberries taste. But actually quite good.
red coloured body with a average white head a strawberry aroma a strawberry taste with a wattery strawberry finich

Draught Pours overwhelming head, pink & dense, pretty resistant; fruit-red/orange beer. Artificial raspberry nose, vanilla, ice cream, Delphi wild strawberry liqueur. Bitter, even hoppiness fighting & clashing with the strawberry/raspberry flavouring, even when served ice-cold. It’s like trying to bite (drink) a piece of flavoured soap. Finish is very empty, just a return of the hops, metallic in their context. Watery despite the 6%. Refreshing, maybe - unless you would let it warm up, I suppose - but it does not urge to continue. Whatever brings the perpetrators of the immortal bolleke to brew this kind of rubbish? Utter despair?

Draught at the In de Wildeman. Nice red-amber color. Sweet, very candy-like strawberry essence aroma. Like a dutch pils with very sweet strawberry essence added. Some bitterness and maltiness in the background.
Draft, New at beerpassie Weekend but i had mine at Waagstuk. A strawberry beer that is too sweet.

09.08.2019, 0,35l can (as Suntory Rich Malt) @ hotel room in Tokyo: Nice slightly bubbly-creamy mediumlasting head, clear golden color. Aroma is slightly dry sour-ish grassy, hay, paper, sour grass, minerals, popcorn, bark, grain, hints of smoked weeds. Taste is slightly dry sour-ish mineraly, hay, grain, weeds, minerals, paper, sour grass, popcorn, bark, alcohol. Medium bitterness, watery and harsh mineraly mouthfeel. Meh!

330ml can from a Kyoto convenience store. Poured a crystal clear light golden colour with a big, lasting, frothy white head. The aroma is grainy malt, light floral hop. The flavour is moderate to light bitter, with a light, watery, malt, light hop bitter palate. Light to medium bodied with average carbonation. No body and no flavour at all. Truly very poor indeed.
Beer with gold color, clear aspect, light bitterness, too much carbonized, low volume of foam, (shared a 33cl can beer with PG, bought by PG in Tokyo, JP #857)(#4 JP).

Leuchtend grün, trüb, geringer Schaum. Geruch künstlich süß nach Limette und anderen Früchten. Geschmack sehr künstlich nach Limette, Kiwi. Bier = Fehlanzeige Dennoch für heiße Sommertage ein guter Durstlöscher!

Gelb-grünlich, sieht aus wie ein Cocktail mit Schaum. Grüne Limette im Aroma. Zitronengeschmack, nicht so süß und gegen Ende etwas herb ausklingend, nicht unbedingt nach Hopfen, aber durchaus angenehm. Ein Sommerdrink.
Typisch künstlich angehauchtes Modegetränk mit einer künstlichen Säure und Aromen von Kiwis und vielleicht Zitrone. Gewohnt ekelhaft, wenn man ein Purist sein möchte.

Süßlicher Antrunk mit zuerst zitronigen und später limettenartigen Aromen. Das Ganze wirkt auf Dauer etwas künstlich, ist als Limonade aber erfrischend, zum Ende etwas pappig nach Süßstoff. 6/6/7/5/5/5
Artifical looking in a poison-like green. No real head and thin body. Taste of sour fruits, mild beer and kiwis. Not that sweet like expected.

A strong smell of citrus, a little bit sweet. The head is medium large, white and foamy with a normal duration. The body is pale yellow-green and cloudy. A strong taste of citrus, quite fruity. The body is light, a little bit creamy with a lot of carbonation.
330 ml bottle. This beer isn’t as sweet as most beer mix drinks. It’s okay.
Cloudy, light green colour. Bitter-sour citrus aroma. Pleasant and not too sweet taste. Refreshing alternative to strong beer.
Transferring my data before I used to rate at Ratebeer. I’ll add a more detailed description as I drink it again
The bottle looks good, the beer in the glass also. Starts fruity and sourish, finish only modest fruity and mild.
Bottle. It pours hazy amber with a creamy off white head. The aroma is earthy hoppy and malty. Light hay notes. The flavor is semi sweet with notes of caramel and hay. Grassy and earthy hoppy.

From tap. Pours golden and hazy with a very small white head. Fairly low carbonation. Malt, caramel and orange aroma. Sweet with a nice balancing sourness and a slight bitterness in the finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
nice caramel and coffee aroma,amber, cloudy, off white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, light sweet finish.

Bottle thanks to Vestergaard. Pours almost clear orange with a small white head. Aromas of hops, sourness (what the?), green apples, citrus, light malty, metallic. Taste is sour again - infection goin on? - citrus, pale malts, light grain, dry,

In my older days I have almost only rated beers that are supposed to be "exotic", since it is just too time consuming. Sometimes though, there are just nothing else to do than rate when all your geeky friends sits next to you not able to talk because they are working hard to get yet another tick. So here it is, Smells pretty good, taste like metal (not good) like the kind of spoon that leaves an extra touch to the taste of your corn flakes. If this is the brewer’s launch beer it is a poor brewer. One more tick, check. 25 (or so) and counting.

Bottle thanks to grandpa. Pours a orangy yellow hazy with a small, white head. Aroma has quite a lot of hops. Rather metallic, light acidic. Taste is dry, rather sour, light bitter and a pretty grainy bitter finish. This is weird. If i didn’t know better, i could’ve confused this with a light, dryhopped sour ale.. But i actually think that this is making the beer better, haha! High carbonation and a light body. Most successful infection i’ve tried.

Bottle @ Knuds. Pours golden with an offwhite head. Aroma of malt, yeast, grass, sweet fruit, apples. Flavor is light sweet, light acidic, malt, grass, fruit, light sourness. Medium body, lively carbonation. 090511

Shared 500 ml bottle at local tasting. ABV 5.0%. Golden colour, clear first, cloudy when the yeast is poured in the end. Moderate white head. Aroma of flowers and honey. Slightly sweetish and a bit dull flavour, hints of honey, not very bitter.

Bottle, bought @ Oil and Vinegar, Vejle.
Pours red-brown with a giant, frothy, beige head. Aroma is roasted, light tart liquorice, some dried fruits and chocolate. Highish carbonation, a bit thin mouthfeel. Sweet flavour, a bit sugary, light roasted with chocolate. A fine, long finish with some good, dark chocolate.
Dark brown with medium beige head. Mild roasted malt in the nose. Flavor is fairly sweet with roasted malt and caramel notes.

Bottled (BB 03/2008) Dark ruby color, small coca-cola head. Roasted malts with some cardboard in the nose. A bit fizzy. Dark caramel malts. Some chocolate, raisin-sweetness and light coffee. Quite empty stout.

Bottled (Thanks Timo Alanen!). Dark brown colour, small beigeish head. Aroma is licorice, dark malts, some mild fruityness as well as some mild roasted notes. Flavour is quite much the same with grass and some sweetish sour notes added. More like a dark lager when cold. Once it warms up it gets the sweetish sour notes.

Bottled. A brown beer with a red shine under a thin brown head. The aroma is sweet malty with light notes of roasted malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet malty with primary notes of roasted malt, but also with a light note of vegetables (brewing flaw?), leading to a dry and slightly bitter finish. Thanks Maria for the trade.

Dark brown colored with red hints, little vanishing yellow head. Smoked aroma with licorice and sweetness, some yeasty flowers also here. Medium bodied. Flavor is also slightly smoky with some vegetables and dry tone, I’m not sure what to take from here. Very weird beer, good tones but still nothing. Mild roastiness in aftertaste.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is roasted, coffee, hop. Flavour is sweet, hop, coffee, roasted, fruit, dry. Could be more. OK beer.

Bottle. Acted as a volcano when I uncorked it, and it refused to stop until half of the content was out of the bottle. Dark, dark brown body with floaties, and a beige to tan head, quite small. Coffee dominates the nose, but there’s also a light buttery note and some toffee. Coffee, sweetness, a little touch of hoppy bitterness, and a little hint of metal in the flavor. Toffee-ish, coffee bitter finish with some hops and a little buttery note. The hops last quite long, and gets better at the very end. Medium body. Upon finishing the beer, I also noticed a licorice note in the aroma. Quite nice, but I don’t think I will repeat it. (071203)
Black of color with a small beige head. An aroma of liqurice, grass, coffee and notes of hops. A flavor of hops, hints of liqurice.

Bottle. [ Thanks to Enjoyit ] Unclear light to medium brown color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, beige head. Aroma is moderate hoppy, grass, orange, notes of coffee and licorice. Flavor is light to moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. (271007)
Aus der Flasche 2015-08 getrunken. Ein wunderbares, typisches belgisches Dubbel - schön so was in Dänemak zu finden. Klasse!

Bottle @ Knuds. Pours dark amber with an creamy offwhite head. Aroma of malt, yeast, candy sugar, wood, light flower, sweet fruit. Flavor is rather sweet, malt, yeast, candy sugar, sweet fruit. Medium body, soft carbonation, sweet finish. 090516
Aroma is caramel, hop. Flavour is sweet, hop, apple, alcohol, caramel. Not a typical dubble, but still drinkable.
Unclear brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and yeasty. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 080312

Bottle. Pours dark opaque brown with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, caramel, plum and licorice. Taste is balanced sweet and bitter and body is oily and creamy. Finish is long and has hints of apple, licorice and caramel.

Bottle. Very dark brown with tiny diminishing beige head. Aroma is malt, yeast fruit and caramel. Flavour is malt, yeast, dark fruits, caramel, medium sweet, hops, little liquorice and a little bitter.
Bottle. Hazy brown body with a medium beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, caramel and yeasty notes. Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate and ripe fruits. Ends sweet.
Colur of red/copper with a beige top. Aroma is caramel. Flavour is caramel and sweet fruit. Good CO2.
Bottle. Redbrown with pale brown head, a little cloudy. Aroma sweet malts, some roasted matls and licorice. Taste sweet, malty, licorice and some roasted bitterness in the finish. A good beer.

12-JUN-2010, bottle @home. My first Ugelris, and a nice meeting:) It pours out of the bottle upon opening. Nice brown/orange color with beige head. Nose is fruity and yeasty with a slight bitter alcoholic touch. Very nice dubbel-like taste with a fine creaminess and medium carbonation. Very fine effort from this brewery.

Aus der Flasche (bbe 09.06.2017 / 8.5% Vol. ) im 2018-06 getrunken. Ein typisches English Strong Als mit ausgewogener Hopfennote. Schöne Balance zwischen leichter Süße, Hopfen-, Malz- und Hefearoma. Der Alkohol ist leider nicht ganz perfekt eingebunden wodurch dieses Bier mit bedacht getrunken werden darf.

Derby Ale Churchill Downs May 5, 2007 Two Minutes to Greatness 6/20/2007: Derby Ale has a transparent, amber-orange color and a dark beige head that leaves some lacing. The aroma contains caramel malt, soft citrus hops, and some pineapple. It loosely reminds me of a weak barleywine. The flavor has light caramel malt, toast, and some citrus (orange mostly). This beer has a medium body and is very smooth on the palate. Derby Ale is a very nicely done Maibock. It is quite flavorful and super easy to drink. I really enjoyed it. 1 qt. 2 fl. oz. (1 liter) flip-top bottle shared by supa at the Junedale Beer Klub June "Ales of Summer" beer tasting. Thank you very much for sharing this special bottle of beer with us. I really appreciate it!
2 finger head, it’s a dark orange beer with a lot of cloudiness. smells nice, american hops, herbs, pepper, interesting bitterness with the malt bill. doesn’t come together very well. thin mouthfeel.

Draft @ BCTC, Ommegang Brewery. August, 8, 2015. Aroma is mostly Belgian yeast with traces of honey and hay. Flavor shows the honey grain base with a solid yeast character, maybe some light herbal hints in the backside. Smooth carbonation level. Everything about it is subtle. Pretty standard but rather easy to drink.

Pony Bar, Hell’s Kitchen Mahattan tap ($6): Pours hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma is bubblegum and fruit. Taste is much the same. pretty weak. The flavors don’t come together. Tastes sort of soapy. Palate and profile are pretty bland. This to me is another Kelso failure.
Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Flowery and spicy yeasty aroma. The flavor has spicy yeast and grassy and floral notes. Decent.
A hazed blonde saison with thin lacing white head. In aroma, a grassy soapy spiced malt with light cloves. In mouth, a chalky sweet malt with light spices, so-so. On tap at TAP NY, April 28, 2012.
Pouring at TAPNY. Pours a hazed gold with a thin white head. Soft wheat and musk. Medium bodied, grain and faint musk. Light lemon, musk. Grainy on the finish with a bit more muskiness coming back.
Draught from GRBYF. Yellow pour, fair amount of head. Some yeast floral etc. a decent offering from kelso
tap at RnH - peachy fruit, not enough funk. some bready malts and a touch vegetal. cabbage?
On draft at the Blind Tiger Ale House NYC. Unfiltered with a good palate. A smooth saison with subtle sweetness and mild bitterness.

On tap WFM into my growler. Hazy with a golden color with small white head. Light bitter taste with a lighter body than I prefer for a Saison. Carbonation was average and the finish did not linger. Average beer.

16 ounce pint on tap. I asked for the cask version of this but the bartender fucked up and gave me the draught version instead. Oh well. Piney, hoppy aroma present with plenty of caramel, roasty, malty notes present. A few sweet, chocolate aromas are there, too. Pretty appealing aroma. Transparent amber body with a snakk khaki-colored head and attractive lacing present. Spicy, peppery, crisp hoppy flavors to start, which becomes somewhat chewy. Becomes very burnt and a bit astringent in the middle. A bit chalky, actually. Finishes with plenty of hops...Centennials, I reckon. Pretty tasty stuff.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: 2006 Bottle from Walt at GABF 2011, shared at Woodshop 7 (2012). Pours with a large white head over a hazy golden hued body. Retentive head. Aromas are funky and acidic, vinegar, bready, mild spicy, nutty, peanuts, and berries. Flavors are acetic with low fruit, esters. Very sharp acetic and lactic burn. Lots of sourness. Lively bubbles, dry.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: 9/16/12. 2006 bottle from Walt! Very hazy red pour with a small khaki/pink head. Poured the sediment into a shot glass and it is thick and muddy and very red. May mix it into our glasses a bit after tasting. Huge funky aroma with tartness, berries, hay, leather, tobacco, cream, vinegar, and wood. Bold tart and funky taste with more leather and hay on top of berries and vinegar. Giant over the top soda pop carbonation with huge burning bubbles. Glad to try it!

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Bottle shared at Woodshop 7. Pours tangerine colored with a filmy whitish head. Aroma is fantastic, really vivid with the pomegranate and a little cherry influence as well. Burning acetic sourness, really digging at the corners of the mouth and throat. Vinous, unripe berries and pomegranate.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Thanks to Andrew for the share! Orangish pour, white head. Aroma is lactic sourness, some pomegranate, yeast. Flavor is so damn sour! Lots of fruity notes, vinegar, lactic. Mouth puckering. If you like em sour, you will like this!

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: 37.5 cl bottle. Pours orange with a small off white head. Aroma is tart, citric and pomegranat. Smooth fruity and tart. Dry and crisp tart into a dry finish. Smooth fruity, tart and citric into a dry finish.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Bottle, shared by Walt - Thanks! Copper, big white head. Nose is acid, apples, cherries, rich almost flanders maltiness. Flavor is flanders acidity, cherries, sweet malt which cuts out after the acid kicks in. Tingly finish.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: enjoyed post Friday night GABF with Walt, Rudolf, Dickinson Beer & a Australian Rollie Fingers Impersonator. Golden Orange pour with a pomegranate tinge to it. Berry Pomegranate tart flavor, real TART, palate altering so. Mouth puckering sour tartness, but I liked it

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: sampled from 750ml bottle. thanks to walt for sharing... pours a hazy caramel reddish brown with a thin soapy light tan head... aroma of semi-sharp sour cherries and some acidity...mildly sweet to start, then a bit of acetone, sour cherries, and some faint nuttiness. lively carbonation...think i kind of liked this one.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: (375ml bottle 2006 vintage thanks to Walt) clear amber pour with a ring of bubbles. Nose of cherry skins, wet wood, and brown sugar. Taste of tart apple, cherry, cranberry. Very well balanced sour. Very tart, perfectly carbonated and a long duration.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Bottle in the parking lot at Dark Lord Day. Pours a hazy brown with a thin white head. Pomegranate, wheat, sour tartness on the nose. Nutty acetone in the body, a little sweet. Dry crisp tart finish.

On tap at the 2007 Nebraska Craft Brewer’s festival in Omaha. Pours dark gold with a huge off-white colored head. The aroma seems very promising as it has a pleasant hop floral scent. Unfortunately, the flavor is absolutely awful. It tastes like there is some sort of bacterial contamination. A strong and unpleasant acidic sournes is the dominant flavor.

Smells of dried wheat or hay that got wet. This reminds of Wolavers organic honey wheat but doesn't capture the honey as well as that. You can catch a little honey up front but it fads quickly and you don't have any of the floral citrus or clover of the honey left. Very light and drinkable but not necessarily something I would go out of my way for. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On draft at the brewpub in Kearney. It is a clear pale golden color with a slight white head. The aroma is Wheat and the taste is thin malty with hints of the sweetness of honey
On draft at the brewpub in Kearney. Pours a clear pale gold with an off white head. Wheat aroma. Flavors of biscuits and honey. Sweet finish.
7.5%ABV. Wheat ale. Poured out gold. 6SRM. Nose is raw honey. Mouthfeel is watered honey. Palate pale malt Finish is beery.
Sampled at GABF 2015. In the tasting glass amber with white foam Full body. Nose of wheat and honey . Flavor is lightly roasted malts and honey. Finishes sweet. OK.
12 oz. can. Pours hazy golden with small off white head. Aroma was grains, sweet and yeasty. Taste was sweet and peppery.
Can courtesy of HuskerTan, thanks! Chillhazy golden yellow color, thin white head. Aroma of lemon bubblegum. Taste is slightly sour grapefruit, herbal white pepper.

[ Can ][ 12oz ][ DTF ][ Tasting ][ Tulip ][ 6.20.15 ] >> Clear light golden pour, weaker foam, Nose is old and sticky, burnt caramel, butterscotch. Taste is white sugar, hydrogen peroxide, suddy and bland. Stickier, sickly, cloying sugar.
Can. Golden with one finger head. Bland, light honey sweetness. Just doesn’t go anywhere at all. Alcohol is amazingly well hidden.
Can, thanks DK3THOU, gold pour, white head , nose and taste are citrus, some vanilla, ginger, good

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma of sweaty hops, bready malt, citrus, and pot. Flavor of bready, caramel malt, floral and bitter hops, sweaty hops, and a touch of oily hops. Not super hoppy, but plenty hoppy, it really grew on me as I continued to drink and I loved it by the end of the glass. 8/4/8/4/15 [3.9/5]

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a hazy orange gold color. Thin white head, but good retention and lacing. Aroma is citrus and pineapple. Flavor has some grassy and floral notes, but is dominated by bittering hops, West Coast IPA style. Impressive beer for a small brewery.

On tap @ the brewpub. Minimally hazy orange with a one finger soapy white head, pretty good retention. Oh, and there’s some tiny particulate dark matter in there which looks like hops. Lots of citrus and grapefruit up front with a light caramel malt backbone. The flavor follows suit with a light grassy/herbal dry hop note, also some light florals. Bitterness peaked at a 4. Light carbonation with a light to medium body. Good beer.
(Draught) Pours a lightly cloudy golden body with a moderate white head. Aroma of light citrus, grass, floral, and toasted caramel. Flavor of orange, breadiness, caramel, and pine hoppiness.

On tap at the 2007 Nebraska Craft Brewer’s festival in Omaha. Pours light amber with a medium to thin off white head. A fine wall of lacing remains in the glass. Beer has a very good floral and grapefruit aroma. Very thick and chewy palate. Very big malt bill to this one. Strong orange-chocolate tootsie roll flavor that typically comes from a double IPA. Great residual hoppy pine and citrus finish. This was my beer of the show.
