This was my first schwarzbier/black lager. It was mostly black in color with brown around the edges where the light could peek through. The initial smell was malt vinegar, so much so that I thought they might have accidentally gotten some in my glass. It was a good smell though and I pushed onward to the tasting. The taste was a clean, lager taste with a smooth mouth-feel. I enjoyed this beer and one day I think I will be able to truly appreciate well made lagers. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 07-18-2007 14:57:02

tap at the brewpub. black body that is red/brown on the sides when held to the light. nice gray head. aroma, well, can’t say there is much of one really. slight scent that reminds me of a stale cookie. i can tell something is here, just not what exactly. black patent astringent note at first then i start to think maybe it is something else entirely. this is clean, really clean, not much lingering here. some light doughy notes then some honey flavor. honey flavor without it being sweet. o.k. not sure whats going on here now. interesting and a decent enough food beer.

column1: Empyrean Better World Belgian-Style Wheat Ale
column5: Thanks to Adam in Nebraska. Pours blond with a three fingers white head. Smells of wheat and straw. Weird taste. It’s great drinking, but sour going down. It’s weird, and not entirely pleasant.

column1: Empyrean Better World Belgian-Style Wheat Ale
column5: 12oz bottle-pours a foamy white head with hazy yellow color. Aroma is fruit, light malt/hay, yeast. Taste is fruit hops, light/medium malt/hay, nutmeg.

column1: Empyrean Better World Belgian-Style Wheat Ale
column5: Not an exceptional Belgian White due to the slight sourness and off-flavor, but drinkable enough.

column1: Empyrean Better World Belgian-Style Wheat Ale
column5: Holy cow you can really smell and taste the chamomile in this one. Not what I expected but that’s not a bad thing.

column1: Empyrean Better World Belgian-Style Wheat Ale
column5: 12 oz bottle. Pours a cloudy orange with white fizzy head. Aroma of citrus, wheat, bready and subtle herbel Flavor us much the same with a pleasant tartness. Mouthfeel is light-medium body, soft, with fizzy carbonation. Overall, interesting brew.

column1: Empyrean Better World Belgian-Style Wheat Ale
column5: [Tap] Part of a sampler at Lazlo’s in Omaha. Pours a hazy straw color with a small cap of white head. The nose is of clove, wheat malts and mild vanilla. Taste is mainly of cereal grains, wheat, lemongrass and herbs. Thin body. The aftertaste is a tad sour. Drinkable.

column1: Empyrean Better World Belgian-Style Wheat Ale
column5: Picked up a sixer of this for $2.99. Looking back, I probably still overpaid. It had a taste that resembled a belgian white, but it had a very sickening sour aftertaste. I’ll stick with Hoegaarden or Blue Moon when I want a begian white.

column1: Empyrean Better World Belgian-Style Wheat Ale
column5: Bottle shared by nuplastikk...thanks Greg! - Pours hazy amber with a small white head. Light, fresh and wheaty with a touch of lemon. Taste is wheat with a bit of lemon, but a decent amount of medicinal tinge on the finish. Real aspirin like, though crisp. Light and a bit of carbonation. Refreshing.

column1: Empyrean Better World Belgian-Style Wheat Ale
column5: 12oz bottle. Hazy orange-tan color. Thin white head. Sweet aroma, mellow herbal touch. The chamomile really be considered a Wit in my opinion, this is more along the lines of the new school American Spiced Saisons. Mellow, medium bodied. Not overbearing spice-wise, quite well-balanced. Some orange citrus tones, wheaty, doughy body. Pretty good.

column1: Empyrean Better World Belgian-Style Wheat Ale
column5: Had on draft at the brewery in Lincoln, NE. Did not expect much and frankly, got an average to above avg. wheat. The pour was cloudy with flavors of spice and some fruity citrus with traces of banana. Very clean and refreshing and easy to quaff, but not much in the way of Belgian yeast flavors that I so love in a white. If your in the neighborhood, and the Haymarket in Lincoln is a great place to hang out, then stop in, the place is more of a restaurant with decent beers than a brewpub.

On Tap at the Murrieta Brewery. I was pleasantly surprised by the biscuity aftertaste. It poured a clear light yellow with a nice head. Athought the alcohol % was lower than I would like, if I were to choose a lighter beer for a hot day this would be one I would consider.
On tap at Murrieta. Clear light yellow with no head. Malty bready aroma. Bready taste with a crisp finish.
On tap at Murrieta. Medium brown with fizzy off white head. Roasty caramel, malty, and yeasty aroma. Thick full bodied palate. Licorice and malty taste with a mellow hoppy finish.

On tap at Murrieta. Dark brown with fizzy off white head. Faint aroma. Thick palate. Roasty some what smokey taste with a dry slightly bitter finish. There’s a contest going on to name this beer, so when a name is choosen, some one will have to edit this page.

Tried on Draught at the Burien Brewpub. Simply put, a Blonde Ale with crushed strawberries mixed in. Aroma is totally fruit forward; more like a smoothie than a beer. Extremely cloudy mix of straw color and crushed fruit, white head with decent retention. Flavor is Fruit forward with a decent amount of malt mixed in. Very light hop flavor, with some citrus. Body is medium/full with very low carb texture. Overall, interesting, but probably not for me. Hard to compare to anything else, as this is about as non-commercial as you can find.

Poured a rich copper colour beneath a foamy off-white head, perhaps the thickness of a single finger. Aroma was pleasing, being a nice balance of hops and malt. The taste did have some bitterness to it, almost "sharp". Mouthfeel was smooth, and I had no issues with the finish. A thoroughly enjoyable beer. Nice label, too.

Bottle (500ml). Via trade with mgermani. Clear amber pour, large frothy-fizzy white head. Light caramel malt, good oily, slightly acidic cereal grain character, lightly herbal and bitter. Taste - a decent grainy bitter, nice hint of graham cracker breadiness, has a slightly ferric bite in the den. Solid chewy body, good balance of astringencyacidity and carbonation, and the grainy malt accompanies the herbal bitterness. I quite like it, very nice for a bottle bitter.
Hazy amber, creamy eggshell lacing head. Cookie malt and citric and minerallic hop nose. Light malt and english hops. Medium body, sparkly.
Bottle. Amber brown with a small head. Aromas are toffee and caramel with autumn fruit and citrus. Flavours are malty and dry with herbal notes and some citrus. OK.
aroma of caramel, apple, spiciness. Pours a cloudy orange, thin white head. Sweet caramel, apricot. Not very bitter.
Bottle. Amber, minimal skiff head. Light fruit aroma, apricot and peach. A bit of graininess. Sweet meaty fruit flavour. Moderate bitterness and slightly raw.

Bottle: Poured a medium clear amber color ale with a nice foamy head with some good retention. Aroma of biscuit malt is dominating with very little other attribute noticeable. Taste is also dominated by some biscuit malt with no discernable hops presence and some medium sweetness coming through. A bit too filtered for my liking but interesting nonetheless.

I am a fan of this style and my overall rating will reflect that. A fine balance of malt and hops, representative of English-made bitters. Not much on the nose, unfortunately but my palate was quite happy.
Amber with a small head. Aroma is hoppy with some roots, citrus and a touch of spruce. A tad thin but a nice drying bitterness throughout.
Good hops, mild citric acidity to it. Nothing fancy, or mind blowing, just a solid good sessionable english bitter.

Pours light golden with a fully receding white head. Aroma of insane chai spiciness, and that’s about it, I wish there was more to smell. Taste is 100% chai. In a blind smell/taste comparison to brewed chai tea, I doubt I could have detected the difference. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied, slightly sticky with light carbonation. Chalk this one up as a failed experiment, I don’t think I would have served this one.

im sorry guys but wtf? i saw it on your web site.......on tap now chai mead. Chai Mead? huh.....honey spices tea......doesnt sound bad........could be very bad.......but ill give it a chai.... clear golden with a quickly disappearing white head. cinnamon nutmeg candy aroma. not bad. spicy.....way too spicy flavor with a slightly sweet floral backdrop......but the spicy and sweet are very disconnected unbalanced.....well the flavor is a mess. thin watery and fizzy. spicy........blah........it is watery spicy sprite blah......uhhh just not good at all. really really bad.

650ml bottle pours a darker golden orange color with a 2 finger white head that settles quite quickly and leaves only a thin ring on the surface. Aroma is dominated by raspberries with some hints of yeast and caramel. Taste is light sour raspberries with some malty sweetness and light hop bitterness. Light to medium body with quite a bit of carbonation. A nice tart fruit beer that is quite tasty and not too sweet like some beers of the style.

650 ml bottle from 16th St. Pours an orange/pink with little head. Has a faint raspberry/citrus nose. Has a light raspberry flavor with hints of hops. Fizzy, Crisp. Like a cider. Easy to drink when cold. Alcohol is hidden.

Nose of fresh raspberries on top pf Belgian strong golden. Light spicy yeast pale bread honey ans pepper. Pours red amber no head. Flavors start with fresh nice raspberry notes move throigh honey and yeast notes. Clove dust pepper light banana phenols and fresh light tart raspberry. Little bit of alcohol. Dry finish. Solid fruit beer.

Bottled at Stockholm Beer Festival 2007. A hazy red beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with hints of acidity and strong notes of raspberries. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of raspberries, as well as a light tartness.
1 year old Bottle. Nice raspberry aroma. Amber low head. Very nice, dry, well integrated fruit. Fairly dry mouthfeel. Really well done.

Courtesy of the brewmaster, we drank this limited release back home in their honour. Almost as good as their aged current, this razz was malted down, with sourness just about there. Pours lots of lace down the glass, moderate head on reddish-yellow. It works.SOmewhat drying aftertaste.

0.65 l bottle at Stockholm Beer Festival 2007. Amber color. Sweet juicy and fresh raspberry aroma. Very fresh raspberry flavor which tastes long in the finish. Also some acidity also but more on a sweet and juicy side. The base beer is drowned into fruit.

Bottle at Stockholm Beer Festival 2007 Beautiful shining hazy red-copper color. Light aroma of malt, fruity;light sourness. Good body, solid beer, with the fruits; fresh and dry finish. Not bad, but fruits in beer are not my hit…

Bottled at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Clear red/orange, minimal head. Lightly yeasty nose with plenty of ripe raspberries. Sweet and fruity with rounded mouthfeel. The deeper down the bottle I came the more I disliked the flavour of almondy glue and raspebrry jam. One-dimensional and overly sweet.

Sampled Dec 2007 from 1-yr old bottle at brewpub. Pours a nice bright orange-amber color. Smells peachy, fruity like soda pop. Mellow carbonation, soft mouthfeel, a bit thin. Sour-sweet, more toward the latter end of the spectrum.

The Cidery Blackwood Wheat (on draught at the brewery/restaurant, Bridgetown) The sun had just peaked through the deepest of cloud formation above the tree tops of this lovely brasserie on the upper hill side of a town known more as ‘fridge-town’, on account of it being oh-so-cold for a good portion of each year, than its own namesake, a logging town amongst rivers and streams – beautifully preserved and bursting with charm. The ciders available dominate, but the beers fresh off the wall mounted casks should not be missed upon a visit. This was the first:- Into a stemmed tulip, it produces an ochre tinged, yellow gold, highly translucent with little evident carbonation – are these served straight from the conditioning tanks, I wonder? Crowned off by a nicely formed frothy white head that retains well but laces little. The nose is subdued, a little . wheat malt and pale pils malt. The palate produces a massive burst of strawberries, raspberries and cherries – the ester profile is profound and dominates the softer, mildly earthy malt tones and subtle clove note in back. Very mellow, smooth and endearing presence in the mouth. The swallow is tangy, sweet meets dusty, with more fruit esters and a mild touch of phenols. This was the first wheat beer I have tasted to break right into the berry esters post fermentation. This was a charmingly refreshing wheat beer, one for the people who don’t drink beer that tastes like beer. Original!!!

Tried on tap at the The Cidery. Dull, hazy straw coloured body with non-lasting head. Slight cloves, mushy over ripe banana and soft lemon in the taste but all tastes are a bit flat and a little uninspiring.

50cl bottle thanks to allmyvinyl. Appearance - cloudy amber with a nice head. Nose - toffee and spices. Taste - stewed apples and toffee. A little spice again. Generally toffee apple though. Palate - medium bodied with a big tangy yet crunchy texture. Overall - yeah this is really a Bitter isn’t it?

500ml bottle shared with jeevan. Pours hazy amber with a little head, soft carbonation. Aromas of light caramel malt and floral hops. Taste is light bitter, light biscuity sweetness, and a mineral note at the end. Finishes clean and crisp. A fine beer.
Cask Handpump at the Vernon Arms, Liverpool 12/12/2002 Golden coloured with a little fruit and grain flavours. A hint of bitterness in a dry finish.
Cask-conditioned at the Bag O’Nails, Bristol 13/03/10. Deep gold with a slight white head. Slight, malty aroma with a touch of fruit. Flavour had a mineral edge, some citrus and dry finish. Ok.

Cask, Three Guineas, Reading. Weak, pallid looking gold colour with a thin white head and some lacing. Not much in the aroma, or flavour for that matter. Maybe some watery citrus, but this really wasn’t great at all.
Cask@1st Hinckley Beer Festival, 2008. Golden beer with a light head. The aroma is lightly sour, and the flavour is plainly sour and lightly dry. Overall an average beer.

Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Full title: ’Nemesis the Goddess of Revenge’. Golden with a small white head. Faint aroma, possibly pear. Fruity taste, slightly citric. Mid bitter finish. A bit ordinary.
[Cask from The Three Judges] Pale gold with a moderate head. Bready malt, slightly buttery, light and floral with a citric edge. Light palate, fruity, dry. Very nice.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Wig and Pen Northampton. A golden coloured beer with a white head and nice lacing. The aroma is hoppy with quite sharp citrus notes. The taste is also sharp and hoppy with a really good level of biterness. Very drinkable and popular with the customers in the pub at the time.
never really known the real difference between a lager and vienna, maybe sweeter and fuller taste, malty, quite good, and good looking,

Very nice surprise. Pours honey colour, looking like an average strong lager, but has a nice, rich taste, with slight nut note. Reminds me of splendid Baltic States beers of that kind. Maybe slightly too heavy but very good overall.
Bottle. Clear amber colour with a fully diminishing head. Malty aroma and taste. Nothing special. Boring.
Bottle. Frothy white fair mostly deminishng head. DArk yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Week but ok biter flavor. Oily palate. Standard brew.

Bottled. An amber beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet malty with light notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet with primary notes of caramel, but also light notes of metal, leading to a dry and slightly bitter finish.
Hazy pale golden colour. The aroma is buttery with notes of grass. Flavor is malty and refreshing with some bitterness in the finish. Flat and boring beer.

At the brewpub. Golden with a nice, creamy head. The aroma is fruity and refreshing with notes of caramel, light citrus and very little elder flower. The flavour is smooth and fruity with a light sweetness, notes of caramel, butter, citrus and light elder flower. It’s without any bitterness, uncomplicated and quenching. I have tasted it once since then, the butter was more dominant all over, starting to be too much, but my score is from the first tasting.

Handbottled. A hazy light yellow beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet with primary notes of straw, but also a light touch of citrus. The flavor is sweet again with primary notes of straw, but also light notes of both malt and citrus, leading to a dry strawy finish.
Yellow colour with a white head. Malty, buttery aroma with a light hoppy note. Malty, sweet flavor with notes of butter and hops.

(Handbottled at the brew pub 50 cl) Courtesy of Myrup. Slightly hazy pale golden with a creamy, white head leaving laces. Fruity aroma, sweetish malts and a whiff of butter. Medium body, lightly sweet malt and a dry, lightly hoppy finish. Very ordinary. 150807

Handbottled from tab @ Bryggen. [Courtesy of Myrup, thanks Peter] Average fizzy white head that mostly lasted. Pale yellow color that was clear and flat looking. Aroma of fruit, light butter, citrus, caramel, light grass. Light to medium bodied with a light dry texture and an average carbonation. Balanced bitter and sweet flavor. Light dry and somewhat bitter finish. 15-08-2007
Handbottled from tap. Clear yellow coloured with a white ehad. Light acidic aroma of butter and fruits. Fruity flavour of malts and hops.
Handbottled thanks to Myrup. Pours yellow with a white head. Aroma is buttery and slight cornish. Bitter flavour, mild grainy, cornish to citric flavour. Dry. Dry bitter finish. Mediocre brew.
Hazy light blond color. Aroma of malt, cereals, hop and butter. Medium-light body, with a buttery and dry malt taste; quite good hopping and long final. Not bad, but flawed.
Draught at the brewpub. Hazy pale golden coloured. Light aroma with some elderflowers. Light and refreshing fruity flavour. Some bitterness in the finish. A good thirst quencher, but nothing more.
Draught at the brewpub. Almost black coloured. Unpleasant sourish aroma. The flavour is also quite unclean, but not as bad as the aroma. Mild.
Una lager ambrata con schiuma bianco sporco fine e persistente. Aroma di caramello e luppolo
Rich amber/ruby color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, caramel, & some hops; Flavor of slight roasted sweet malt, caramel, hops, nuts, and some spice; Nicely balanced; Decent.
Pours dark amber with a slightly off white head. Aroma of malts and brown sugar. Some sweetness. Taste is slightly peppery, malty and light. Some hops.
Pours amber color, topped with a decemnt tan colored head. Malty aroma with mild notes of caramel. Taste is sweet, malty and bready with some caramel flavour. Moderate bitterness. Not bad.

Appearance: Amber color with a fine tan head. Some lacing. Aroma: Malty and mild fruity. Palate: Medium body. Tad sweet and a moderate bitterness. Average carbonation. Taste: Very malty, bready, mild hoppy and mild fruity. Overall impression: Not the worst of its kind. Personal stats: Bottle Gro brought with her from Greece.
Bottle. Medium amber color. Medium head. Caramel with a slight toasted aroma. Taste is a slightly sweet caramel flavor.
This isn’t a very good beer, but its better than the regular. Has much of the same character, with a reddish tint to it, a slightly sweeter taste, and the same stale aftertaste.
Bottle. A sweet and drinkable lager. A welcome change to pale lager when in Greece.

Pours reddish-brown with a frothy off-white head that stays a while. Smells a bit sour, like skunky corn or Budweiser. Taste is sour with malty sweetness underneath. Medium body, decent carbonation. Nothing to write home about, but I’d take one on a hot day.
Can’t find it easy in Greece. Very nice taste with awesome aroma and color. A beer to remember !
Clear golden with large white head. Sweet grainy aroma with mild caramel notes. Sweet and mild sourish flavor with caramel and grainy notes. Infected.
From backlog. Cloudy yellow with white head. Aroma and taste of wheat, banana, cloves and yeast. Quite lively carbonation.
Bottled in Hurghada Hazy golden with a medium, white head. Light spiciness in both aroma and flavour. Also som citric notes of sweet oranges in the flavour. By far the most interesting Egyptian beer.

Bottled, 0.5l. Hazy deep golden color with large and long lasting creamy white head. Aroma of grainy malt, yeast and banana with light skunky note, too. Taste starts with rich malt, but it’s quickly followed by refreshing grainy and yeasty sourness which suddenly becomes too plain. Aftertaste is lightly bitter. Light to medium body, slick texture and soft carbonation in palate. Pretty decent hefe...

totally corny label!!! some fine creamy head. cloudy deep yellow. light hefe nose with banana and a little raspberry. medium body and a bit short. taste has some sweet fruit - rasbperry? soft and pleasant - not bad!
0,5l bottle in Luxor, Egypt (April 2008). Good white head. Hazy blond pour. Banana aroma. Very refreshing.
Hazy orange colour with a thin white head. Aroma is a mix of sweet and sour fruity notes. Cranberry fruity flavor with a light glue note.

Tap @ Apollo, Cph. Pours a muddy yellow-orange with a medium kind of foamy white head with only a touch of lacing. Aroma is sour with a clear definition of sour oranges. Mouthfeel is extremely watery - there is simply no texture to this brew. Flavour is equally thin on the ground - only a distinct sourness - and it is not dry enough to come from any cranberries. Finishes weirdly sweet on a caramel note. Really weird brew - you want cranberries? Go to Aarhus Red Ale - at least that tastes of them!

Draft. An unclear orange beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet with cloying notes of fruit combined with notes of cranberries. The flavor has light notes of burnt plastic malt combined with light notes of cranberries, dusty hops, and a light acidity, leading to a dry wheaty end.

Big offwhite lasting head. Hazy orange body. Light flour and cranberry aroma. Watery, bitterish cranberry and flour taste with notes of milky rubber. Dry medicinal aftertaste. Pointless. (0.25l draft.)

On tap at Denver ChopHouse - Denver International Airport. Clear amber/brown appearance with a small beige head. Aroma of toasted malt, cereal, nuts and light husky grains. Similar flavor, malt-forward and moderately sweet with a light body and a smooth finish. OK.

Sampled at the restaurant/brewpub during a layover at the Denver airport. Pours auburn brown with no head and a trace of white residual lacing. Aroma: grease from a McDonald's fryer, brown sugar, nuts. Flavor: brown sugar, nuts, raisins. Mouthfeel: medium-bodied, cloyingly sweet.

Draft at the Denver Airport location, served in a flight. Pours a cloudy amber with a moderate off-white head that settles into a ring and film while lacing the glass. Notes of caramel and toasted and cereal malts, nuts, and leaves. Light-medium bodied, with medium carbonation and a malty, sweet mouthfeel. I'm in line with the consensus rating on this one. My least favorite of the four in my flight.

Pint at the brewpub. This is clear dark brown with a great head on top. There's a well realized Munich malt aroma. It's nutty with hints at chocolate and rich bread. Body is medium full and with a light enough finish. Rich bready flavors abound with not much hop character. Great nutty/chocolatey character throughout. Good attenuation. Just a solid, classic Dunkel.

Draft @ Denver Chophouse, Denver International Airport. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty grainy caramel aroma. Fruity malty grainy caramel flavor with some bitterness. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

Keg @ ChopHouse, DIA. Deep amber pour with a tiny head. A bit of chocolate malt in the nose. Mellow caramel-slathered brown bread. Lift toastiness. Gentle, sweet malty flavor. A bit of toasted brown sugar. Light earthiness. Fine carb.

Pint at the airport location. Dark, ruby brown color, with a small, tan head and some good lacing. The aroma is earth and mulch, bitter chocolate, rye, and black pepper. Sweet and malty, with a mellow bitterness, and a sharp, spicy bite. Medium body, chewy, and sharp. This is a sharp and assertive dunkel. Not bad.
Medium brown. Dark roasted nutty aroma - light bread and fruit on the palate. Oddly bitter finish for the style.
Draft at the source. Brown. Aroma is mild caramel, toast. Taste is sweet, mild burnt toast bitterness at finish. Light body. Not bad.
Sampler at the brewery. Low fluffy white lasting head. Pitch black body. Roasted malt caramel aroma and flavor. Low carbonation, long finish.

Sampled at the restaurant/brewpub during a layover at the Denver airport. Pours clear pale yellow with a spritz of white head and residual lacing. Aroma: faint grass, malt vinegar. Flavor: caramel, biscuit, corn syrup. Mouthfeel: light-bodied.

Draft at the Denver Airport location, served in a flight. Pours a pale clear gold with a barely off-white cap for a head that takes a while to settle, leaving rings of lace on the way down. Pale and crackery and cereal malts, straw, grass, and a light apple note. Light-bodied, with medium-plus carbonation and a malty, slightly sweet mouthfeel. Exceeded expectations.

Keg @ ChopHouse, DIA. Golden pour with a small white head. Gentle nose. Soft grain. Just a bit of honeydew melon and some grass. Drinks a bit sweet. Relatively full bodied. Fine carb, somewhat creamy mouthfeel. Actually, this isn't bad gear at all.
Clear pale gold. Aroma is grainy and gently fruity, as is the flavor. Not great, but slightly better than expected.

On tap at Howl at the Moon (Denver). Clear, pale golden appearance with a white head. Aroma of toasted grains and light hop spice. Similar flavor, adding light to mild bitterness and light sweetness with a crisp finish. OK.
Samler. Low fluffy whote lasting head. Hazy light yellow body. Mild fruity aroma and flavor without much hops bitterness. Low carbonation, short finish.

Draft at the Denver Chop House & Brewery located in the Denver International Airport. Poured a clear yellow color with a small white head. Crisp, sweet light malts, some earthy hops. Light grain. Easy drinking.
Pours a hazy light hold with white head. A grainy and malt based aroma. A malty taste with grains, light caramel, and earthy tones. A dry malt and grain aftertaste.
Beautiful brown red color. Smells of toasted wheat and honey. Flavor leaves a bit to be desired. Nice toasted malt throughout but lacks depth of flavor.
Draft at the source. Clear yellow color, white head. Aroma of white pepper. Taste is a bit funky.

Taster at the brewpub, near-black with a lacing crema and light aromas of coffee, red fruit and ashy malt. Palate is creamy-sweet and ashy-dry, with just a touch of cocoa. Really nice example of the style.
Sampler at the brewery. Low but lasting off-white head. Very dark brown body. Dry roasted malt caramel aroma and flavor. Fair amount of hops bitterness. Low carbonation. Long finish.
Smooth, sweet, malty. Not too flavorful, especially being paired next to the Bourbon Stout.

On tap @ Denver Chophouse. Black in color with a khaki head. Aromas of roasted malt, coffee grounds, and water. Slight fruitiness to the nose as well. Flavor is bitter roasted malt and coffee grounds. Hints of dark chocolate and a light sweetness of dark fruit. Kind of chalky and earthy.
Draft. Pours reddish brown with white head. Nose and taste of dusty cocoa, lightly toasted black malt and touch of cream. Airy light body.
Typical stout... Nothing special about this one. Nice try from the locals here in Denver! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Light in aroma, but coffee would be the primary notes. Brown-black in color. Light mouthfeel, a sweet and creamy stout. Notes: GABF ’09 visit

(Draught) Pours a black (mahogany edges) body with a medium beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, lactose, caramel, and subtle notes of old horse saddle. Flavor of roasted malt, coffee, and lactose with a moderately bitter finish.

Tap @ Chophouse & Brewery, Denver. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, caramel. Taste is roasted malt, coffee, sweet dark fruit, bitter caramel. Thin and watery body, soft carbonation. 240212

On tap at the brewpub. Pours with a clear, near black hued body with a foamy off-white head. Great lace. Aromas are roasty, leathery, mild esters, and a bit floral. Flavors are biscuity, honey, light roast, currants, mild esters. Very inoffensive. Light bubbles, creamy. Decent for what it is.

Very fruity beer, almost no grain notes at all. Foggy red body with a modest head. I was hoping for more balance between currant and beer beer, but overall it’s not bad for a fruit beer. However, could use more complexity.

650ml bottle pours amber in color with a small white head that leaves virtually no lacing on the glass. Aroma is currants with some light grains and hops with hints of yeast. Taste is some sweetness from the currants and malts with some hoppy bitterness and light yeast. Medium bodied with light carbonation and a dry finish. A very easy drinking strong ale that is quite refreshing and enjoyable.
Honey pear light cuurrant. Reddish poyr no head. Reddisg poue ni gwas. Curranta honey poear. Lifht yeast ns pear finish. Meh (jon 2009).

Bottled at Stockholm Beer Festival. A deep red beer with a slight haze under a thin tan head. The aroma is sweet with strong notes of black currant. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of black currant, leading to a dry and slightly woody finish.
Mahogany color,small beige head.Winey brown sugar nose.Acetic tart fruit profile, light brown sugar overtones. Not good, perhaps an old bottle?

650ml bottle from mgermani, thanks. popped the cap, and there was ZERO noise, not a good sign. aroma is wet cardboard, and sour red wine, pretty much a big nose of red wine vinegar. Flavour is sour, syrupy, and vinegary. This bottle has to be off, there is no way they intended it to tatse like this. It actually tastes like a flemish sour ale now. still i couldnt dinrk it, the vinegar flavour was way too much to stand

Grapey brown colour with no real head. Aroma is current and some alcohol. Tastes like currant juice as there is little carbonation or noticeable malts. Very sweet and quite easy to drink despite not tasting very beerlike.

Bomber from Brewery Creek (bloody expensive too!) Poured a reddish brown with no head. Strong currant aroma, young red wine tones, some malt backing it up. Flat tasting, soft dark fruit flavours, some alc presence. Underwhelming. I was hoping for a bigger belgian flavour. Upon opening there was no release of pressure and no head formed when poured, perhaps my bottle was poorly capped...???
Vintage 1 year old Bottle@Spnnakers. Blackcurrant nose. Red amber low head. Light metallic earthy berry notes. Yeast fruitiness in the background. Medium to light body.

Black currants, apples, pears and berries in the nose. Clear purplish-amber coloured body is topped by a low, off white, large bubbled, shy head that recedes to a partial cover. Thick, strong and bready malt profile with fair bitterness. Raisin like fruitiness that lingers is especially notable in the aftertaste. Medium full body is a bit slick in texture with somewhat low carbonation. Tulip glass. Cellar temperatre. Bottle (Brewery Creek, Mar-08).

Gravity, Chester Arms beer festival. Warm amber red, loose soapy white foam. Musky, marmalade hops, a bit of wet dog, blackberries. Warm chewy hop flavor. Rustic. Some apricot dried fruit esters. Surprisingly full bodied for a 4% bitter. Maybe more fitting as a winter sort of beer, but fresh and full of character.

[i] [b] Cask, gravity at Oxford City Football Club Beer Festival 24-05-08 [/i] [/b] Also have had this at the pub before. Pours dark brown with no head. Some chocolate is picked up on the aroma, along with a smattering of hops. Taste is more chocolate, sweet malts, a fine beer.

Gravity, Chester Arms beer festival. Red hued dark brown, small off white head. Soft chocolate aroma, port, earthy hops. Pleasantly sweet, dark brown flavors, bread and chocolate. Soft palate. A nice comforting beer.
*Old rating, best before 10.11.06. Schön frisches, würzig--trockenes Bier. Leicht getreidig, mild, feinherb im Nachgeschmack.
Bready nose. Light golden, layering head. Middle of the road Helles with a slightly sweet note added. Minerally retronasal. Mellow sparkly mouthfeel.

(bottle) Almost clear, pale golden colour with a small foamy white head. Slightly dusty, malty and honey-fruity nose with hay-like hops. Moderately sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a medium carbonation. Strawy malty, slightly chalky taste with soft grainy notes rounded up with herbal hops; moderately dry and light-bitter finish with a pleasant, grainy aftertaste (12.09.07).

Bottle (courtesy by joss !): Pale golden, small and lacing white head, that slowly diminishes, very solid sweet-honeyish-malty nose with a faint hoppy touch; moderate sweet-bitter flavour, medium bodied; distinctive aromatic hops in the sweet-malty finish. A goody, Jonas !
For the malt-heads out there. It sort of reminded of cheap beer, powerful cheap beer. Although, the Steg was a bit lighter, which made it much more palatable.
Where can I obtain this in the Boston, MA area? I am looking to use a ’150’ beer to celebrate the 150th anniversary of an event. Thanks.

It poured a dark amber with a good sized light tan head. I expected a strong heavy malted drink from the color. It was much lighter bodied than I expected, more like a Vienna in the title. It was crisp and refreshing, words I normally write about a good Pilsner. It was well balanced with a light malt aftertaste.

Sometimes I worry when the bottle says "all-malt" because it implies that we would think it WASN’T all-malt. This is not just a normal crappy macro lager though, it’s a good bit darker and has a different flavor. I’m using "different’ because I’m not sure if it’s good yet, but I have 2 more in the fridge so I will find out. It will be a BOLD EXPERIMENT.

January 2009 Beer of the Month Club Overall Impression: Definitely a solid lager style beer, smooth and enjoyable, nothing particularly distinguishable about it, but it drinks nicely. **Photo submitted for this one today.

Bottle, thanks to Mei. Caramel pour. Syrupy sweet malt aroma, maybe some sweet oats. Flavor is the same, mostly sweet, with the grain and oats in the background. Somewhat crisp finish, maybe a little floral hops.
Transfering from notes. Bottle. Copper pour with a medium white head. Aroma is of sweet malt with some hops in the background. Taste is caramel, sweet malt and some mild hops.

Solid. The aroma was overloaded w/ malts and subtle hops. It’s appearance is a dark amber color. It’s flavor is heavy malt and sublte hops, it ends curiosly with a sweetness, possibly fruit or sugars. This rather smooth. A nice session beer.
this was a decent beer. Easy drinking and fairly smooth. Very average .

Bottle from Capone’s. Medium copper with 2-finger off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt, hops, spices, and mild funk. Tastes caramel malty, with noble hops, some toffee, and some honey notes in the finish. Not bad.

On draught at the brewpub in Wausau, WIsconsin. Pours a clear golden pale blonde brew with a fast dissolving white head the dissipates clean with no ring or lacing. Aroma of buttered popcorn, a touch of coconut, some faint grassy hops and some light herbal spice. Taste is smooth, light bodied with flavors of buttered popcorn, some golden grain malt and grass hops. Finish has a light butter aftertaste that slowly disappears to a crisp finish.
A light grainy taste with a dry, faintyly coconut flavor. Light tan color. Slightly sweet aroma. Buttery finish.

Second time I tried this. On tap at the Cranberry H&H. Clear yellow, looks like the ubiquitous pale yellow american lager, filtered and refined. More candy like and sweet than harvest wheat. Slight to medium hop bitterness. Earthy candy attack. Below average carbonation. I think I like their harvest wheat a little more than this even tho it is supposedly a wit bier. This is not a witbier by euro standards. The small amount of hop bitterness in the finish must be to appeal to the hop lovers, but I don’t care for them. This is more like an APA.

From 2007 notes. +++ Sampled on draft a the brewpub this beer poured a medium amber color with a small white head. The aroma was sweet and malty with a hint of vague fruits. The flavor was sweet and malty with hints of molasses and vague fruits. Short finish. Smooth.

Sweet smelling and the aroma of beer. Tan like iced tea. Has a decent size alabaster head. Very nice non offensive initial flavor. Easy and well behaved, has that Scottish gentleman courtesy. This beer seems to have more carbonation than the rest of the H&H beers I’ve tasted, a welcomed addition. Many of the good qualities of a session beer. Barely taste any alcohol, it is well hidden. Of course it is a low alky beer, nice for a change. Friendly easy and fun. Has a slight amount of malt bitterness building on the back of the palate. This is one of the better Scottish ales, nearly ranks right up there with East Ens Old Hickory. IMHO much better than the likes of McEwans and Three Floyyd Robert the Bruce!
Tap - small foamy head, medium copper color, moderate citrus/earthy hop aroma and flavor, fair malt backbone, balanced pretty well - good overall

On draught at the brewpub. Pours a clear pale orange-amber color with a thin white head that diminishes to a film rather quickly. Spotty lacing on the glass. The aroma is mildly hoppy with citrus notes. Light and crisp body with flavors of hops, citrus and mild spices. The finish is citrusy with a short and lightly hoppy aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

Enjoyed at Lewis & Clark Restaurant. A nice looking APA. Caramel colored with a nice thick off white head. Good retention and thin sticky lacing. Aroma begins caramel but soon becomes tart citrus and pine. Flavor behaves pretty much the same. Caramel with grapefruit and pine. A bit of spice. Unfortunately there is a bit of soap as well. Still, a pretty good APA.
(draught at brewpub) amber with very light tan head, some lace. Faint citrus hops aroma. Flavor is citrus hops. Body a bit light.
This beer has a deep amber colour with a small vanilla coloured head. Nice lacing, and aromas of wood and sweet malts. It has a very round mouthfeel, and a slightly bitter finish.

On tap at the brewpub on 6/24/07: Pours a clear bright copper with a thin ring of white head. Has a sweet toasty caramely German malty nose. Body is fairly full with a mild caramely malty sweetness toward a slightly more bitter finish. A pretty standard amber.

Date: 06/24/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear amber, fine beige head, sweet munich malt aroma with a candy sweetness, malty sweetness is quickly balanced by lots of earthy bitterness but the sweetness recovers in time for a sweet finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.8/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

Available on tap only at the Titletown brewpub. Pours a clear brownish amber brew with a light, thin off-white head. Spotty lacing. Aroma is very light. Just a touch of malt and some grassy hops. Taste is lightly carbonated, multi-grain character with a slight bitter finish. The aftertaste is lightly sweet and smooth with a faint hop bitterness.

On tap at Titletown. Appearance is of rich deep copper color with slightly frothy head. Aroma is light straw and mild malt. Not a very assertive aroma. Taste is light grain and light fruit and faint hop, I?m picking up some sweet cherry flavors. Moderate carbonation and smooth finish. Damn tasty.

Can shared at Lucky Bamboo. Pours a clearish gold with a finger of foam that lingers. Big blueberry forward nose with nothing much else. Sweet and artificial blueberry flavors...a bit thin on the palate. Lingering vanilla and blueberry. Not for me.
On tap cloudy dull yellow big blueberry aromas and flavors. A bit soapy and chemically. Full bready malt character right after. Very light bodied
Taster at CopenRoss. Clear golden, light head. Blueberries in the aroma and taste, sweet, not overpowering. Not much weizen body, kind of thin.
This is more of a fruit beer than a Hefeweizen. It’s pleasant, and thirst quenching. Blueberry isn’t shy, but the Hefeweizen isn’t present as much as needed. Still it’s ok.
Aroma is blueberries and slight funk/smelly socks. The flavor is blueberries/berries/muffin, malts, fruit and a mix of tart and mildly sweet in the finish.

twelve ounce CaN .. drank at home .. . blueberry skin and mild sweet wheat .. mouth is quite light .. nice fruitiness, feels real .. quick finish, mild back end sweetness .. low low bitterness .. pretty good, could be fuller but decent fruited wheat .. . what does freedom sound like to you? me swearing at a video game in my boxers
This beer was really quite pleasant. The blueberry isn't overwhelming but it's there. Very sessionable beer.
Can in the discount rack. Blueberry nose when poured. This is honey gold with just a little off white foam. Flavor is wheat and blueberry. Oh well.

Hazy dark gold with decent head and a very clear blueberry aroma. Taste is not as zesty as many hefeweizens but that is good because it lets the blueberry really stand out. I love blueberries and this one is great because it is not overpowering or taste artificial. Overall I had to get it in the CAN and it is a wimpy 4% for the premium price tag so maybe not something I am going to stock up on.
Tastes like a blueberry muffin. Comes in a recyclable can-- great for summer trips! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Amarillo
column5: From a 12 oz bottle called Organic Hop Cuvee Session IPA with Amarillo hops. Pours yellow with head and lace. Aroma of grains, minerals and amber malts. Medium carbonation and mouthfeel. Flavors of light malts, flowery hops, light minerals. Overall a nice session IPA.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Amarillo
column5: 24-Sep-08 (22-oz bottle: Purchased 09-Sep-08 for $3.29 at BevMo in Encinitas, CA) Continuing on with this fun little series, the use of Amarillo hops in this beer really showcasing what you expect from this hops, imparting a fairly strong presence of sweet orange citrus up front while adding moderate earthiness and a touch of citrus rind bitterness in the finish. It’s a very enjoyable and balanced flavor profile, fruity, bright and crisp, but smooth and only moderately bitter, so no trashing of the palate with sharp, resiny bitterness. The base malts are lightly sweet, maybe a touch caramely, but generally a fairly clean pale ale flavor. The nose offers an inviting aroma of sweet oranges, but no pine or aggressive citrus rind. Medium in body with no thinning in the finish, and the moderate carbonation is soft on the palate. Golden-amber in color with a slight haze persisting throughout the session. The off-white head rises to half an inch before slowly settling to a thin, broken layer, leaving a wide, intricate ring of lace at the top of the glass and modest amounts of patchy and stringy lacing below. Overall, this is a really enjoyable IPA. Probably not bitter enough for hopheads, but wonderfully drinkable for the rest of us.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Amarillo
column5: Bison IPA--Single Hop Series--Amarillo Hop--Organic--2007 22 oz. Bottle. 6.80% ABV. 50 IBU’s? (4.0 / 5.0) Thin mild lace head. Clear thin bright light gold color. Mild floral earthy hop front. Crisp clean dry sweet mild caramel body. Mild pine hop spice end. Balanced thinnish malt body highlights. Sampled 7/24/2007.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Amarillo
column5: Pours amber with a white head. Smells of citrus and floral. Tastes of sweet citrus with some wildflower hints and a more restrained bitterness than the others in this series. Nice spicy finish.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Amarillo
column5: Bomber pours clear copper with modest frothy off white head. The aroma is mild with sweet tangelo citrus, malt sweetness, a touch of earthiness and hinting toward organic malt cardboard. The taste is tangelo hops mixing with a pulse of malt sweetness making it taste sweet and citrusy right off. Toward midway I get increasing hop bitterness with pine hops and hop spiciness. The malt sweetness in the background balances this brew out nicely and only shows hints at the organic malt notes I consider off and distracting. But since the organic malt twang is so light it is not a problem. It ends with delicious citrus hop bitterness.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Amarillo
column5: Amber with an off white one finger head. Good amount of lacings. Aroma is orange citrus and floral hop. Taste is quickly earthy bitter hops with enough malt sweetness to take some of the bitter edge off. Some orange and leather. Fairly dry bitter finish. Kudos to Bison for doing these single hop brews. Very interesting. Will look for more in the series.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Amarillo
column5: 22oz bottle. Poured a medium and clear amber color with an averaged sized head. Aromas citrus and some tangerines. Tastes of citrus - oranges and grapefruits, and some pine. Had a lighter maltiness to it as well. Lightly bitter. If I had this blind, I would have guessed this was a Pale Ale.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Amarillo
column5: Not horrible, not great - but this does get high marks for isolating the hop flavor so you know what hops you like. Amarillo by itself is pretty boring. But now I know how to isolate it. Ends on a nice citrus note, and doesn’t have much pine flavor in it.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Amarillo
column5: 22 ounce bottle in the series of single hopped Bison IPAs--Poured darker than the others in the series. A rich, clouded amber body with a fluffy white head. Nose of piny, resinous hops. Bitter and dry in the smell alone. Flavor not as potent as nose might lead one to believe. Grapefruit pine stereotype is true here. Somewhat chalky, bitterness-laden and creamy caramel finish. Pretty good, but not the best single hopped IPA in the series.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Amarillo
column5: Decent, texbook IPA. Nice hop flavor with a caramel , medium bodied malt. I love this single hop series - really gives you a good impression of what each ingredient brings to the drink. This does highlight the alpha acid as it is very astringent and bitter. Heavy pine needle and grapefruit peel. Not a big fan of the Amarillo hop, single or in blends. really decent organic ale.

lattina 50 cl, schiuma bianca fine media persistenza, colore giallo smorto limpido, al naso lievito cereali luppoli, in bocca cerali luppoli (Saaz) e leggero citrica, corpo leggero, carbonazione moderata, leggero dolce, amaro percettibile. Buona, delicata. c. Carrefour Germignaga 17.11.19

Many thanks to Beerhunter111 for sharing! Fresh and slightly grainy beginning. Hints of roast and caramel. Fresh smooth body, sessionable, caramelly malty, moderate bitter. Roasted bread, dark chocolate, refreshing smooth. Very nice and deep, chocolate-caramell in the aftertaste. Nice.
Many thanks for this beer to Beerhunter111. Pours a mahogany color. Aroma is malt, caramel. Flavour is sweet, malt, caramel.

50cl swing top bottle. Pours clear copper brown colour with a huge good lasting beige head. Aroma of strong dark malt, some red fruits, caramel. Taste of strong sweet malt, some dark mild roasted malt, bread, caramel, nice!

Bottled. Caramel and very malty aroma with herbal hops. Dark amber color, beige head, good lace. Sweet, malty, pretty bitter and well hopped, quite full. Nice balance and not overwhelming sweet like many German bocks.

Pours dark clear red with a dark beige head N: well this has almost no hops despite the style. Pretty oxidiced. T: sweet malt juice. Old ale.. You can just taste the age on this. Aftertaste is sweet but with huge depth. Complexity is enormous. Cant really split flavours apart.

Reddish brown of color with a beige head. An aroma of caramel, hops, oxidiexed, sweet tobacco, liqurice and sweets. A flavor of liqurice, caramel, sweet malt and oxidiexed hops. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone

Bottle buried deep in the cellar and re-discovered during move prep. I have no idea what this was originally but it has aged into something fantastic. It starts with a hit of hops in the aroma and flavor. I have no idea how the hops have held on over the years. It quickly mellows into a caramel, sweet, malty English barley wine style ale. This is drinking fantastically right now if you have a bottle tucked somewhere and are wondering if you should open it.
Poured from a 22 ounce bomber, thanks to Jeff. Big notes of caramel, toffee, raisin. This beer has aged well.

Bottle shared at Mikey’s holiday party 2012, thanks to who shared this Appearance: Hazy brown with a small tan head and good lacing Aroma: Toasted malts and dark fruit Taste: Toated malts, dark fruits, caramel, spices and brown suger Very nice, glad I got a chance to try this.

Bottle at a recent bottle share... Poured dark, near brownish with a tan head. A bit of oxidation here with strong malt sweetness and thick, boozy body. Tasted old. Malt sweetness and dark fruits were its saving grace.

Notes from June 2010. Pours a murky mahogany with a thick light tan head, lots of lacing. Aroma of light roasted malt, caramel, dark dried fruits, brown sugar, and slight resin. Flavor matches well and this beer held up surprisingly well. I really wonder what this was like fresh.

750mL bottle, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks a lot Dany!), pours a beautiful dark mahogany with a large foamy beige head. Divine aroma of plums, raisins, brown sugar, heaps of caramel malt / toffee, and even a feint trace of hops still roaming around. Flavour brings out huge grapes, some plum and maybe raisins, toffee, and brown sugar - hops have all but died, but doesn’t matter, this is exceedingly well-balanced and sort of reminiscent of a barley wine. Absolutely no signs of oxidation or anything going off about this. Finishes quite dry and semi-sweet, with everything working in perfect harmony. Sticky, viscous palate and uber-decadent in all aspects.

Bottle at Churchills, San Marcos. It pours very deep ruby, with a thick off-white head. The nose is pine, resin, raisin, currant, plum, caramel and brown sugar. The taste is caramel, varnish, dark fruit - cherry, prune, plum ,raisin, earth and toast, with alcohol warmth in the finish. Full body, moderate carbonation and slightly sticky mouth-feel. Great balance. All-round it’s very good.

750mL split at Churchill’s pub in San Marcos. Pours clear deep mahogany to blood ruby with a larger, thick yellowish head. Awesome tawny Barleywine nose with caramel, wood, butterscotch, thick brown sugar. Fresh lemon. Thick, poofy lace. Taste is sticky, malty, nice older malty character with red fruits. Red fruity, big raisin and date finish. Not too oxidized or papery. Nice aged feel despite the style. Very nice lacework. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at Beer House Hobbit. Listed at 5.5%. Fat caramel nose, biscuits, and condensed dark fruit. Deep amber/orange color. Mild caramel, light tangy hop, gentle raisin, and maybe molasses. Medium body. Very pleasant, for a a style that is generally quite dull.

33cl bottle (5,5%) from Midori, Nagano. Pours muddy amber with a modest off-white head. Fruity and somewhat yeasty aroma with notes of caramel and mild herbal hops. Medium sweet with fairly mild flavours and also rather light bitterness. Quite drinkable, but not very pretty and nothing to write home about in the end.

Bottle from Matsumoto AEON Mall liquor shop. Wheaty nose, with mild roastiness, some smoke, yeast, and dark fruit. Dark brown color, with a thick 3cm rocky tan head. Gentle but rich dark roast, dark fruit, cocoa, touch of wheaty sourness, mild bittering.Medium-heavy body. Unusual one, for the style. But very rich and pleasant. Maybe the best beer from this brewery.

Bottle at Nagano Sake Village into a stem glass. Thanks TimE for the rec! Hazy dark brown with tan head. Aromas of caramel, dark fruit, light chocolate. Tastes of caramel, dark fruit, sweet malt. Medium body with a dry finish. Nicely done.
Bottle - Wheat, smoke and toasted malts. Jet brown with a tiny brown head. Smoke, raisin and dark fruit. Sweet but nice.

33 cl bottle @ home, from IP trade with TimE - thanks! Label says 6% btw. Very dark brown color. Short beige head with good retention. Aroma’s: some roasted malts, drop/licorice, fruit confit, slightly sour, just a hint of banana. Retronasal there’s a bit of the sourness of the wheat. Flavor is light to moderate sweet, roasted malt. Body is rather full. Flavor lingers. Maybe it got too old, but it’s not very true to the style. Pleasant enough though.
Cherry aroma, red fruit, roasted malt. Plum juice, biscuit, sour finish. Nice creamy and fruity Dunkel.
On tap at Ibaraki Bakuon 2013. A cola pour with a beige head. A good mix of weizen & Dunkel with the spiciness & hint of caramel-quite good.
Draught. Aroma of sweet fruits, raisins, dark chocolate. Not fantastic to look at, but the flavours and balance of this were sensational. Rich and creamy. Fantastic depth. Loved it.
Bottle at Shinshu Sake Mura. Dark brown colour, big golden creamy head. Aroma bubblegum, banana, soy sauce. Taste is roasty, wheaty, bit of creaminess. Quite different. Pretty nice.
Not too weizen like - some raisin, a bit of banana, bready and soft grassy/floral hops. Different but a bit non descript.
Bottle at Shinshu Osake Mura. Black colour with a small beige head. Faint aroma of vinegar, banana. Flavour of banana, licorice.
On tap at Dry Dock in Tokyo. Pours a nice oily black. Slight malt on the nose. Medium light bodied. Slightly malty and bitter. Ok.
Tap at Keyaki. All of these Keyaki ratings are a mess. Good stuff, bit oaty, dry and slightly sweet. Hey it’s alright.
Bottle at Hotel Iidaya, Matsumoto - shared with Mette. Black - white head. Roasted malts, light coffee, licorice, ok medium bitterness, light smokey notes, milkey feeling.

Draught at Beer Republic. Jet black, glowing, very smooth, fine head. Roasty chocolate nose, charcoal and coffee. Light fruit. Well roasted, clean flavor, with dark chocolate, coffee, and wood. Bitter and straight-forward. Nice, but a bit simple. Smooth, medium body.

Black colored with little beige head. Caramelly and sweet roasted aroma with thin licorice, somehow tangy still. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is more dry in start with licorice and roastiness too, aftertaste has nice hops with grassy notes.

My Bottom Line: Roasted malts and thin caramel brethren laxly meet and never agree on a common goal. This lightly tart, lean Porter remains a decent dark ale, but it is overshadowed by its Minamishinsyu acolytes. Further Personal Perceptions: -A ring of foam laces atop the burgundy-sleeved black. -A pleasant fruitiness recalls raisins. -The soft effervescence helps drinkability. -Roastiness returns in the finale, but doesn’t have much help. -Earthiness attempts to link the caramel and roastiness, sometimes succeeds. -Not much of a success as a Porter imho, but you can’t say this is not well brewed. On tap at the brewery restaurant.

Dark brown color. Sweet chocolate malty nose with just a faint hint of dark fruit and brownies. Mouth is medium, but flavors are a bit too muted. Dry semi-sweet finish that had me thinking brownies, but I was reaching for something. Decent, but not great. Rerating 12 years on and nothing really new to add. It’s the same beer and I would give it between 3.4 to 3.5 now, but maybe that’s how I felt back then. Detected a bit more soy sauce or vegemite in this. Decent, but not great summaries this perfectly

Bottle from Shinshu Sake Mura. 4.5% a lightly cloudy gold with a foamy white head. Bready sweet and mildly floral aroma. Med-full bodied, the taste is like seltzer water, crackers, and light bitting hoppiness in the finish. Meh.
Bottle at Shinshu Sake Mura. Cloudy blond colour, off white creamy head. Aroma is grainy, malty. Taste similar, very grainy again, flour, slight fruitiness. Bit boring, but ok.

Bottle at the Nagano Sake Village. Dark gold color. Clear medium height, fine head. Very fruity aroma, honey, caramel, sweet. Honey-like flavor. Very malty, but not very interesting. Not enough hops. Thick and cloyingly sweet.

My Bottom Line: This Blond Ale’s shy straw and subtle citrusy, herbal hops definitely point at a watered down version of their regular Golden Ale recipe, and a semi-successful one at that. Further Personal Perceptions: -A sheet of foam disappears into the very pale golden. -This is quite carbonated, but it doesn’t bother that much in the end. -The body is obviously feathery, but the maltiness still retains some crispness. -This is a well-brewed, low gravity Blond Ale, but its flavor profile is surely not for the beer geek. On tap at the brewery restaurant.
Pale golden color. Peaches, pineapples bananas in the nose. Light body, citrus and peachy. Light dry citrusy finish. It reminded me of a watered down version of the golden ale.

Skip the aroma since having it in sampler glass. Dark with minimum head. Sweet with faint bitterness, orange chocolate just like described and some herbal. Long lasting, medium to full bodied. Good but a little bit on the sweet side. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

My Bottom Line: The roasted maltiness and citrusy fruitiness of this wacky Porter ingeniously meld into a perilously drinkable vehicle, ending on a refreshingly bitter note of more roastiness. Believe it or not, this actually works! Further Personal Perceptions: -A ring of foam circles the brown-sleeved black. -Most of Baird’s many fruit beers of the same quality, it seems. -Even though some chocolate cake can be tasted in here, maltiness is not the center of attention. -Carbonation is smooth and thus the mouthfeel is easygoing, like most of Baird’s mouthfeels. On tap at the brewery tap room.

Dark brown color. Chocoate malt and citrusy nose that is not particularly strong. The mouth jumps out with tooties rolls, caramel, citrus, brownies. Slightly tart, but well balanced. Chocolately finish with moderate tartness and bitterness. Kind of like an unsweet tooties roll liquified and put in grapefruit juice.

10 oz tulip draft at the Baird Harajuku Taproom in Los Angeles, California. The pour is a hazed brown with a 1/2 inch tan head that leaves behind a thick coating of lace. The aroma is soft roast, citrus orange fruit, clean and natural. The taste is orange fruit and citrus resin, the fruit soft sweetness is cut by the soft roast malt. The palate is light to medium bodied with soft carbonation and the citrus and roast finish. Simple but incredibly clean and fresh. The balance and cleanliness of this beer are amazing.
Dark brown, big head. Roasty porterish aroma. Quite toasty, light roast, moderate bitterness, like a hoppy, toasty porter.

Bottle. Pours almost black, beige head, decent head and foam that leaves nice lacings. Aroma is relatively soft, with some injected robust roastiness and a bit of fresh hops, green apple. Taste is quite fruity, hop bitterness mixed with some soft raisins and dark plums. Long lingering bitterness at the end, half of it coming from hops and second half from burnt-roasted malts. Overall, the body feels quite round and soft, medium, so the strong hop profile at the end comes a bit of a surprise. Good stuff.

Review from last year. On tap at Nakameguro Taproom. Served in a stemmed tulip. Jet black with purple highlights and a nice big soapy head. Strong chocolatey malt aroma with hints of currant, muscat, citrus, cacao, seaweed and kale. Burned flavors are also present along with some pine needles. Mouthfeel is oily with an astringent finish of charred vegetables. Really interesting and awesome offering from Baird. Easily one of the best seasonals they offer.
Bottle from Yamaoka. Black with beige head. Chocolate malt aroma, no hint of hops. Flavour has a nice hop finish to balance the initial malty chocolate hit.
One of the nicest Baird seasonals in a while, dark chocolate malt balanced with nice fruity hops and hints of berries. Very smooth for a black IPA, okawari kudasai!

On tap at Bungalow. A dark reddish brown pour with a thick foamy light beige head. A good dose of chocolate malts & resinous hops in the nose. Medium bodied with a good chocolatey creamy flavor and a lightly bitting bitter hop finish. Good.

Bottle from The Craic, Takamatsu. Good stinky nose of dark fruits, musty hops, and, yes, kelp. Medium to high fizz, but nicely rounded. Slightly sticky aftertaste. Sweetness of licorice and blackcurrents there too. Juicy and hoppy. I like.

Tap at Good Beer Faucets. Dark brown, very dark red colour with golden head. Aroma is cream, chocolate, roast malt, bit of smokiness, pine and citrus hops. Taste has some dark fruits, lots of malt, ovaltine-like almost. Touch of spice in there too giving it a bit of a prickle. At the same time, some chocolatey sweetness. Maybe something herbal in there too. Finish is toasty with subtle bitterness. Very smooth and medium bodied. Very nice. Rerate Jun 15. Very different, oaty and treacle, smoke and caramel. Interesting. Lots of malt and light hoppiness at the end. Quite different.

Bottle, 12C. Black with a large beige head. Smells very fruity with stone and citrus fruits, some chocolate, pine and slight burnt notes. Oily mouthfeel. Not all that sweet. Astringent roasted and coffee notes straight away, but peaches and a little citrus are there too. A bit of dark toffee and pine are underneath. Bitterness is there but not as pronounced as I’d guess - there’s nearly as much astringency at the end as bitterness. Tasty and well-balanced.
Botella. Deep dark brown colour, medium light brown head. Sweet roasty malty aroma. Flavour is sweet with roasted malt, some chocolate and bit dark fruit. Thin like.

Nose very typical fruity hogs back. Dark chestnut colour, fine off-white head. Not impressive, quite dull, very long bitter finish, little bit of treacle but well overpowered by the very bitterness of it all. ok.

Bottle.Chestnut with a small head,aroma is fruity and musty with old wood and leather,taste has tartness with dark fruits,orange marmalade,leather oak dry and spicy with a long dry bitter finish and some smoke,my senses are fully satisfied,a great experience and i’m still smiling.
BCA. Sweet toffeeish malts with hints of richer roast flavours. A bit of the usual Hogs Back yeast flavour which can be slightly offputting to me. Drinkable enough but not great.
Bottle. Copper with a small head. Aromas are malty with cookies. Some pear and spices. Flavours are sweet toffee and chocolate with pear and some citrus. Dry on the finish. Decent.

Bottle at home, thanks to my mate Bill for this ... Good copper colour... light fruit nose ... Decent enough main beer , little balanced fruit malt but its too drying bitter in linger for me... decent enough session ale.
Bottle. A boring bitter. Balanced beween the hop and the malt. Boring, grainy, lightly sweet mouthfeel. Some chemically type stuff happening in the finish.

Cask handpull at the Wetherspoons in Kingston. Reddish amber colour. Hogs Back yeasty aroma, plenty of deep red berry fruit in mouth and then harsh, but balanced brambly hedgerow hop finish that lasted for a good 5 minutes in the mouth. Malts are hedgerow and berry fruits that are juicy and mix well with this harsh hop finish.

Cask at the Monks Retreat (JDW), Reading. Chstnut with a deep creamy beige head; citrus aromas; fruity and sharp with a predominantly orange flavour, but smooth and creamy and easy to drink; leaves a lingering bitterness.

Draught at Popeye Tokyo (rated Apr 2008). Head is mostly diminishing. Body is dark brown. Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, chocolate, caramel, nuts), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of gum and plum. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, moderately bitter. Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation. Interesting example, quite rich in the malt department, dare I say decadent. Yummy stuff.
Bottle @ RBESG 09 Shefield ... Black color. Raosted malt aroma, with aramel notes. Flavor is raosted malt with an infected sourness. Too bad, it would have been much beter if it wasn’t infected.
[bottle @ RBESG 2009, Grant Tasting] Opaque brown. Tart infection. Wish it was not infected. Flavour is flattened and has a cardboardy plum oneness.
From the Bottle at RBESG Harlequin, Sheffield 19/07/2009 Fruity and rich aroma. Dark coloured and strong in alcohol with a dry and slightly bitter malt finish.

12oz courtesy of KyotoLefty. Pours an oily black with a dark tan ring... more like a stout. The flavors are more stoutish as well, with a sourness that I haven’t tasted in a stout since Harvey’s. Easy enough to drink and nice on the palate.

Bottle @ RBESG 09 Grand Tasting @ [ The Harlequin, Sheffield, England. ] Clear dark red brown color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, raisin, plum, soy sause notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and fruit - berry sour acidic with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090719]
Bottle @ RBESG 09 Shefield ... Black ... nice roast malt .... big toffee .... little sourness ... roast malts ... most likly off.

Bottle from Nightfall, thanks! Deep dark brown color, opague. Roast and milk chocolate in the aroma. Roasty flavor with chocolate and grapes. Upcoming tartness. Creamy mouthfeel. Very pleasant, highly drinkable porter.
Bottle at the RBESG09, Grand tasting, sheffield. Alround rating: Light tartness, vinous raspberry sharpness, good sour red wine vinigar in the finish. If it wasnt infected it would be poor.

[RBESG, Sheffield] Grand Tasting @ The Harlequin, Sheffield. Pours deep brown with a small, creamy, beige head. Aroma is roasted, some chocolate. Light sourish. Thin and watery. Definately infected. Just a bit of chocolate peeping through.

2013 version Aroma: rather mild and hard to name given it was rather cold. Palate: deceptively medium-bodied but quite filling. Flavor: understated roast, malt hint of smoke, and orange. Lingering malty orange flavor. Comment: well integrated flavors gave this an edge over the 2014 version.
Keyaki. Ratings getting messy. Nice sweetness, caramel, good maltiness, good stuff.

At World Craft Tasting 2013, Osaka. An opaque orange-red color with a fruity aroma. The flavor is grainy malty caramel. Some bready toasty qualities but it doesn’t measure up to their normal high standard.

Draught at the brewery. Rather deep amber color with a huge head. Mild, creamy, caramel flavor; slightly fruity and also slightly alcoholic for its strength. OK, but disappointing compared to their other beers.

Draught at the brewpub. Clear brownish amber, rich head. Lightly roasty with a whiff of butter. Medium bodied, well rounded. Lightly caramelly with low bitterness. Pleasant, but not the most outstanding beer at Fujizakura.

Had on draught at the Oktoberfest in Hibiya Park. Clear orange in color with thre fingers of white head. Bread, caramel malts, some fruit hops. Very drinkable and really refreshing. I wish I could have had more.

My Bottom Line: This Märzen’s crunchy biscuity malts and apricot fruitiness thrive unabated in a starkly unfiltered garb. A drying hop finish seals the deal, and one is amazed at how well this has held up. Further Personal Perceptions: -A ring of foam decorates the yeast microcosm living within the orange glow. -A 3-year-old regular gravity lager in tip-top shape. Wow. -The doughy yeast adds a layer of complexity. -The malts also develop some caramel. -Nourishing yet drinkable, flavorful yet at times incohesive (old age, surely). 2004 bottle at Popeye’s.

Found this at the back of the fridge at Popeye’s. Expired in July 2004 and had it in June 2007. Damn, it held up well!!! Would love to try this fresh. Deep amber color, bready, caramel malt with somewhat peachy nose. Somewhat austre malty buscuity mouth with notes of peaches and caramel. Austre buscuity, carmelly finish. Hope they make this again.

Rating for the past, drank lots of these "beer". Pours somewhat green/yellow color, topped with no head to speak od, lot’s of carbonation. Pleasant aroma of red bull (I liked it) - although not for a beer - very sweet and fruity, lots of red bull taste. Ok to drink as a juice, I guess. No way is this a beer.

Bottled, 0.33l. Clear pale greenish yellow color, almost no head and quite fizzy. Artificial red bull aroma with some malt and grassy hops. Tastes of red bull, but not beer, to sweet for sure. Light body, sticky texture and fizzy carbonation in palate. Power of the God succeeded with retirement of this "beer"...
Average aroma, appearance, taste and palate. Not particularly memorable. Rated in the past from the bottle.

Typical slovenian beer. Nothing special, average quality but if there is nothing special around it can make you better evening or more refreshing summer :). Added aroma makes this "beer" not a real beer but more pop-drink. --not available any more
Bottled in Logatec. Looks like lemonade. Smells like Red Bull. Tastes sweet, thin perfumy, soapy and heavily artificial. Un-beery, but not toally horrible. Think Red Bull, but more artificial.

Can. Looks weaker than the cider I just rated before but bit more greenish. Very fast disappearing fizzy head. Strong sweet Red Bull aroma. The flavour is quite sweet with Red Bull...... hmm there is some trace of beer but quite weak..... Sweet bit dry Red Bull bit fruitish finish. Not that bad but nothing to do with beer... as I know it. Well, if I could I would drink this as a substitute to Red Bull but I never drink that either..... Energy Beer...?........ Hvala Ogi.

0.33l can. I told no more bandidos, but a friend brought it from Rijeka, so I had to drink one. Let me see... Some poop color, no head, actually there is somewhat like in orange juice, just some traces of beer in the taste, red bull...yes, more like it but not still... stupid combination anyway and this is not beer however.

Canned(330ml). -From some local store in Rogaška Slatina, Slovenia. Pale green-yellow (like there was a seaweed for a week in a glass and filled it with color), some small fizzy white head and red bull nose. The taste is also red bull with some weak malt and dry (hop) notes. Contains guarana????!!!Stupid...

Can shared with and courtesy of ozujsko (thanks!) A surprising new addition to the Bandidos line that replaced Hot. The two share some of the ingredients (safflower for example), but this one’s pretty much supposed to be beer with red bull. And it shows, especially in the aroma, which is 100% red-bull like energy drink (the 0.01% of guarana seemed to show). The appearance made me question (again) the 85% of beer. It’s extremely, extremely pale green-yellow. The base beer must be damn weak taste and colour-wise... Anyway, the taste is sweet, without the saltiness the energy drinks tend to show.... guarana, a bit malt, caramel even. Crap. Drinkable, passable, but still crap.
Hefetrübes Goldgelb mit reichlich Schaum. Malzig, hefig, fruchtig, Banane, sehr spritzig.
Heller Beginn, moderat hefig, starke Karbonisierung. Herb-hefiger Mittelteil, süffig, wenig würzig. Gut trinkbar, unspektakulär. 11/10/8/9//8

Bottle: Deep golden, hazy, creamy persistent off-white head with a good lacework; sourish-fruity nose (lemons) with both a touch of vegetables and yeast; moderate sourish sweetish flavour with an easily detectable bitterness, medium bodied and pretty soft; soft sourish-wheaty finish. Refreshing Weizen...

(bottle) Cloudy, pale golden colour with a tall foamy white head. Banana-fruity aroma with present wheaty notes, delicately spicy hints of clove and vanilla in the background. Mildly sweet and delicately sour flavour, light to medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Slightly mealy malty and wheaty base with notes of banana, a tinge of citrus and delicately spicy notes; slightly chalky, mildly sweet and sour fruity finish. Balanced Weissbier. 28.II.17
Pours a cloudy golden color. Aroma combines earthy wheat, slightly sweet straw and a bit of banana.
Draught at the brewery. Hazy, deep gold colored. AROMA- wheat, vanilla, honey, yeasty, touch of banana. FLAVOR- slightly sweet, wheat, yeast, spicy. Medium bodied. Average weissbier.

#823 Tap at Brauerei Maisach. Hazy, deep yellow body, high white head. Aroma of yeast, malts, bananas, a bit sour. Taste is neutral to slightly sour. Wheat, yeast, traces of banana. Light body, high carbonation. Not bad.

500ml bottle. Upon a hazy, yellowish golden coloured beer sprouts a mountain of a huge, firm, frothy, long-lasting, white head. Yeasty and wheaty aroma, cautious hints of egg, sulphur, protein, a minimally sourish stitch. Taste is minimally sweet wheaty, hints of banana, cautiously dry, minimally grassy hoppy overtones; soft palate, soft to flat carbonation.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein trübes goldenes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, fruchtig, würzig. Geschmack hefig fruchtig, reife Bananen, leicht würzig.

Bottle 500ml. @ home on the terrace. [ Trade by Boris ]. Hazy medium yellow colour with a large, creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is light malty, wheat, moderate to light light heavy yeasty, banana, dark fruit, pineapple. Flavour is moderate sweet, light light acidic and light bitter with a long duration, yeasty, tropical fruit, pineapple notes. Body is medium, texture is creamy, carbonation is soft. [20121118]

column1: Karl Strauss Raspberry Windansea Wheat Hefeweizen
column5: Firkin at Beach To BreweryAroma is definitlely tart raspberries, some sweet clove and banana are there but not as pronounced as Karl’s regular hefe. Pours hazy yellow. Tart flavor of fresh raspberries. Definitley a natural fruit flavor dominates the original clovey flavor of the standard hefe. Is smooth and mildly carbonated, as it was out of a firkin. Smooth, yet tart, very refreshing. A nice special offering from Karl.

column1: Karl Strauss Oak Aged Balboas Vintage Barley Wine
column5: Firkin keg at Beach To Brewery. Huge oak aroma with some strong pine hops. Pours a reddish orange. Flavor is dominated by the oak up front, followed by intense pine hoppiness. Some malts balance, but this one is hop dominated. Very smooth natural carbonation. Resiny, dry, lots of stuff hangs around on the palate. This is a damn good version of this already good beer. One of the best Karl beers I have had.

Draught at Pivovarna Keros, Rogaška Slatina, Slovenia. Hazy golden/honey yellow coloured, small or almost no head, mild honey and hoppy nose. Slight malty and mild hoppy aroma with strong odd notes of carrots and celery. There’s also Temno, but when I was there it wasn’t available.

Plastic bottle, shared with and courtesy of ozujsko who brought it from the brewpub (thanks!). This poured a hazy golden colour with a small thick & creamy white head that went away slowly. The nose was quite fine... honey, creamy, bit hoppy. The taste was... erm... carrots?, bit malt and a strong background crude chewy hopiness that formed a long aftertaste. Damn odd. Refreshing but strange.
Clear golden color, no head. Malty aroma, some notes that reminded me of Bros beer from Buzetska. Watery, flat carbonated. //2l plastic bottle, thanks to Marko

Bit unclear, golden colored, small white head. Aroma is grainy, some malt and adjunct, eggy sulphur. Taste is medium- sweet malt, grains, some adjuncts, sulphur, eggy, light grassy bitterness. Light bodied, almost flat carbonation, watery. (PET from Marko)

Pours a perfectly clear yellow golden color, topped with a medium sized white frothy head. Very bready aroma with sone gentle honey notes. Easily picked up though not too excessive. Taste is sweet and bready, some mild final bitterness and a hint of soury grains is all there is. Decent, light, drinkable.
Pale golden appearance, medium head. Hay aroma, medium bitterness, overall refreshing.

Bottled, 1.5l. Pours pale golden with medium sized frothy white head and lively carbonation. Honey and hay aroma. Sweet honey taste without any bitterness. Medium bodied with creamy texture and moderate carbonation in palate. Surprisingly good and recommended...

Draught at Restoracija Gastro, Rogatec, Slovenia. Pale golden coloured, white head, extremely lively carbonation, strong hay nose. The aroma is grainy and slight hoppy with strong notes of hay and barnyard.

Rerate (April 2016): Huge thanks to Stela & Silvija for bringing this from Ptuj! Poured a paaaale, shiny golden body with huge carbonation, fizzy, big, somewhat lasting white head. Aroma... sweetish buttery diacetyl, vaaague DMS, bready, spicy. Typical Slo brewpub fare. OK, bready taste, a bit on the sweet side, soft, slightly empty, with a strange note somewhere between herbal and alcohol-like, ends up beet-like and a tad bitterish. Eh, still sub-par for what it is, but likely serves its purpose @Gastro well. up to 2.5, but 2.4 would’ve done as well. June 2007: Plastic bottle shared with and courtesy of ozujsko (thanks!) Imagine that, a few days after I thought I sorted out all the breweries in Slovenia, ozujsko finds a new one. And I’m definitely not complaining. Though, considering the quality, I probably should. This poured a light golden-yellow colour with lively carbonation and a medium sized thick creamy white head that went away slowly. The nose is quite grainy with notes of hay and eggs. The taste is quite grainy with some hay and weak, weak hopiness. Bit creamy but unimpressive and one dimensional. Not bad but distinctly average. Overly so even. 4/2/5/2/11

Pours a clear darker golden color, topped with a small, lasting white head. Mild malty aroma with some bready notes. Taste is gentle, grassy hops with some lemony feel to it and some bready notes again. Moderate bitterness. Crisp and refreshing. Ok.
Slightly cloudy yellow appearance, medium head. Mildly hoppy, light body, not overly balanced. Nothing special, average Premium Lager.

0,50L on tap at Orient Express pub in Divaca, Slovenia. Slightly hazy, yellow colour with average big, thick, white head. Aroma of citrusy hops. Taste is moderate bitter with a lot of lemon and some grapefruit on tongue. Finish is acidic. Watery mouthfeel, soft carbonation, light to medium body.

Draught at Pivovarna Lipnik, Šmarje pri Jelšah, Slovenia. After 6 hours on pools in Rogaška Slatina on +33degrees (celsius), I couldn’t wait to drink beer, especially new one. And that new one disappointed me. Light hazy honey yellow coloured, small airy but lasting white head, lively carbonation. Mild malty and hoppy aroma with slight sweet honey and yeasty notes. Short bitterish finish.

From beer fountain in Zalec. Pitch black color, with a medium beige head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee. Taste is roasted malts, coffee, some little sourness, nice bitterness too, enough. Easy drinkability for a schwarzbier. Nice.

Pours a pitch black color, topped with a small and quickly disappearing beige colored head. Aroma of roasted malts dominating, perhaps a little bit of chocolate.
