Starts sweet, roasty body with some coffee, soury finish with minimal bitterness. Aftertaste is coffee and roasty, but mild. Easily drinkable, surprisingly light and nice.

Pours dark brown with light brown tiny head. Aroma of roasted malts, little presence of chocolate. Similar is taste with sweet notes of chocolate and little too roasted finish. Overall drinkable beer. Medium body, soft carbonation, well balanced bitterness.
Dark red to black appearance, medium to thick head. Roasted malty aroma, mild chocolate and coffee. Decent dark beer.

0,50L on tap at Orient Express pub in Divaca, Slovenia. Clear, dark amber colour with creamy, light brown head. Nice aroma of milk chocolate, roasted malts, cacao and white coffee. Taste starts light acidic, what is kinda weird for this kind of beer, but it turns bitter in the aftertaste. Light to medium body, soft carbonation, astringent finish. Beer with potencial, but this acidity spoils it a bit.
Pours dark with a low head, smell is yeasty and not very strong. The taste is gentle and with low carbonation. A gentle soir aftertaste

Draught at Pivovarna Lipnik, Šmarje pri Jelšah, Slovenia. Black coloured, medium sized pale beige head, buttery and coffee nose. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, mild chocolate and stracciatella. Pleasant chocolate notes in the finish.

Plastic bottle shared with and courtesy of ozujsko (thanks!) Poured a black (really really dark red really) colour body on top of which stood a medium to small white head that went away at a medium pace. The nose was light and pleasant... cocoa and coffee. The taste was similar... strong coffee-cappuccino, maybe a bit thin/watery but very bitter. Too one dimensional for my taste but showed potential.

Canned, 0.50l. Clear golden color with medium frothy white head. Aroma is grainy, grassy and dusty. Taste starts with sweet malt, follows by cooked vegetables flavor with dry mouthfeel and strong typical German bitterness at finish. Light body, thin texture and lively carbonation in palate. Cheap trick...
Average aroma, appearance, taste and palate. Decent, somewhat memorable. Rated in the past from the can.

Canned in Logatec, Slovenia. Clear golden, brief head. Fruity nose with alcohol and vegetables. Sweet and messy. Sticky syrup where rotting fruits are swimming. The sickening sweetness taks the edge of the foul off-flavours caused by cost cutting in the production. Barely tolerable.
Canned(500ml). -Pale golden with small white head and dusty nose. Grainy with sweet notes of malt and faint hop aroma. Strong corn presence and sharp unpleasant bitter finish.

Can courtesy of and shared with ozujsko (thanks!) Poured a lasting white medium sized thick head. The nose is weak... grainy and dusty. The taste is bad... corn primarily, some malt and hopiness. Premium? Don’t make me laugh.

Can 0,5l from Tus supermarket in Koper. Pale golden crystal liquid, almost water like, minimal head. Light smell, a hint of lemon. Light body and carbonation. Light taste of lemon, a hint of metal, medium sweetness, a hint of wine in taste. Weird. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone

Clear yellow color, very small white head with no retention. Aroma of artificial lemon, ice tea. Very sweet, syrupy...light body, light carbonation. More like lemon ice tea... And a bad one. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone

Pours a very pale golden color, topped with a small and quickly disappearing white head. Mild malty aroma, some very faint notes of citruses, but more aroma of grass - skunky and dusty as well (not nice). Taste has a mild sugary sweetness and slight fruity feel, although barely. Not unpleasant taste, but nothing to be excited about.
Slightly hazy pale yellow appearance with low head. Strong lemon and citrus aroma, artificial notes. Refreshing, typical supermarket chain Radler, but below average overall.

Canned, 0.50l. Hazy straw color with medium frothy white head and sparkling appearance. Strong citric aroma, quite artificial. Taste starts with sour refreshing lemon juice, while finished with very light maltiness. Light body, sticky texture and lively carbonation in palate. Pretty decent radler, however still without any beer character...

.5l can from Tus Supermarket in Sarajevo. Pale, light radler, not very sweet as these balkan fruit beers go. Lighter lager body, with artificial lemonade overtones. Sticky, not very quenching, odd and not very good

02/08 0.5 l can from Tuš, Jesenice. Had pale yellow body with small head and typical artificial cheap radler aroma. Sweetish sprite radler flavor, too carbonated... OK, it was drinkable, but boring and it’s radler and, the most important, is very bad, so what else to say...
Canned(500ml). -Pale yellow coloured, airy white head, lively carbonation. Sweet lemony taste with some dusty notes and nothing else.

Can courtesy of and shared with ozujsko (thanks!) Medium to big white head, really pale yellow, bit greenish colour, even for a Radler. Very lively carbonation. The nose... citric acid. The taste is quite sweet and there’s nothing but lemon. Unimpressive, but had worse radlers. This one at least avoids being foul.

Bottle from Manteo location. I couldn’t find any info on the fest this beer was made for. Ok aroma, Toasty, yeasty. Cereal, grass, sourdough. Pale, tad hazed, golden yellow color. Small head that did manage to stay for a while, ok lacing. Bittersweet flavor, like aroma, though in my notes I wrote grainy, doughy, grassy. Lite body, watery mouthfeel, bitter grassy finish. Pleasant enough. easy to drink, classic pale lager.

Tap. Extremely cloudy. I got an unusual sourish aspect out of this one in the citrus (orange, lemon) area, with decent amounts of spices. Maybe I’m crazy, as it was from the same glass as LilBeerDoctor, below. Mustily, earthily yeasty as well. To me unique if nothing else.

On tap. The cloudiest beer I’ve ever seen. Looked like fresh-squeezed grapefruit juice, no head. Aroma of yeast, bread, spices, and rotten eggs. Flavor of the usual clove and other spices, orange peel. Very thick. Decent hefe.

On tap at the Lake Grove location. Arrived at the table a cloudy yellow gold with a very narrow white ring for a head, which promptly disappeared after the first sip. Mild aroma of banana, cloves, and wheat. The wheat is stronger in the flavor than in the aroma, as are the cloves. Some light banana also in the flavor. As the beer warms, a pleasant lemon flavor develops, especially in the aftertaste. An ok beer.

Pint pour. Color is a yellow and misty (as opposed to murky). Aroma is more like a spiced Wit, only lightly estery with a bit of corn. Taste is a bit corn again and again lightly spiced wit mixed with hefe. Not the worst version of a hefe that I have tried at a JH, they really need to rework the angle on this style.

Tap @ Lake Grove John Harvards. Poured a mildly hazed yellow color with no head. Phenolic clovey aroma is mild with some wheaty lemon notes. The flavor has some mild clove to start then a banana middle with the spice coming back again to finish long. Light bodied.

Cloudy yellow beer with no head at all... I’ve never seen such a limp-looking hefeweizen. The aroma is fairly spicy, but more wit than weizen. Lemony citrus, orange peel and a touch of clove. No real banana character speak of. Quite sweet tasting with fairly bready wheaty character. Wheaty spice, full-bodied. It’s okay, but it’s fairly pedestrian.

First of all, best name for a hefeweizen...ever - I like that the bartender asked if I wanted a lemon or not - most just stick it right on there - cloudy yellow pour, with a quickly fading head - moderate wheat malt aroma, with apparent yeastiness, hints of clove, soft earthiness - the expected clove flavor is there, but not too much so, and the banana that so often dominates these beers is hardly there (a welcome change) - medium honey and orange sweetness and mild spicy/peppery notes - a light, slightly unwelcome hop profile develops in the finish - a decent hefe.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a very dark brown with some reddish hues along the edge when held against a light. There is a very thin off-white head that completely disappears within the first two sips. Pleasant aroma of sweet malt and some floral hops. The flavor is again sweet malt with some light roast and just a bit of cocoa. Very mild bitterness at the finish. Very quaffable. Overall, an enjoyable and solid dunkel.
Tap. Aroma of some sweet dark fruits, sweet malt, lightly roasted. Flavor quite sweet with some chocolate. A little thin. Not bad, but a touch sweet, didn’t get me going.

On tap at John Harvards. Pours a dark brown/amber with a tan head. Aroma of sweet malt, flowery hops. Flavor is quite sweet, with roasted malt. Smooth-bodied and easily drinkable. One of the better JH beers I’ve had.

Poured a hazy dark brown color with a medium sized creamy tan head. The aroma was wheaty and roasty with a light spice to it. The flavor is light and again wheaty and roasty. Light bodied with a clean finish and mild hop.

Pint glass, pours black with a tan head, looks like a porter. Aroma is slightly charred and spiced wheat mixing with dark fruits (some light prune). Taste is a light roast. Leaves a slight roasty, fruity-sweet aftertaste. Very quaffable and refreshing despite this "dark" flavors. Recommended for sure.

Gorgeous brown beer with a thick moussey dark brown head. Aroma is fairly soapy initially, although a touch of nuttiness kicks in. It’s really hard to get much of anything out of the nose. The flavour shows a soft toasted wheat character. Full-bodied with soft chocolate and dates. Body lovely and creamy though. There is a chewy chocolatey flavour. The yeast seems awfully clean to me though, lacking all the fruit and spice that I normally go for. Nice enough, but lacks a lot of character.

Dark ruby hue, with a thick ring of off-white foam - aroma of chocolate-covered cherries, caramel, strong wheat malt, faint spices - light-bodied, but a creamy mouthfeel despite this - lightly tart up front, with cherry flavors (pits and skins included), followed by a dry cocoa character, a touch of nutmeg and other spices - complex and refreshing at the same time - the new brewer here has really hit his stride.

Bottle from Yamaoka. Full and rich aromas of banana, chocolate malts and hint of spice. Nicely textured, with smooth rounded finish. Just enough depth, and a nice mellowness that had it go well with food. Good stuff.
Well made and clean as with all their product. Nice chocolate and cherry notes accompany their classic Weizen taste. Good stuff.
Keyaki. Dark brown with golden head. Aroma bit of banana, lots of roast, soy sauce. Taste is similar, banana, vanilla, bit of booze. Slightly savory. Pretty good.

On tap at the Kyoto Craft Beer Fest. A nice dark color with a tan head. A fruity aroma with a slight spiciness to it. The flavor is like a weizen with fruits with clove taste over a rich malt base with perhaps a bit of sour finish. Another solid beer from Fujizakura.

Bottle from Yamaoka. Rather dark brown with a huge, fine, tan head. Fragrant aroma of banana, clove, and a touch of caramel and chocolate. Rich, thick wheat malt flavor with creamy banana and spice. Cloves. Relatively sweet with a touch of sour to balance. Has a slight chocolate touch. Could have more dark malt. Finish is slightly sour and malty with bananas and fruit. Very nice indeed, and certainly very reliably made, although maybe not quite dark enough.
Bottle from trade with TimE. Huge foamy head. Creamy off-white color. Brown-amber color. Not sweet or dry. Not bitter. Easy to drink. Some long-boil caramelization in the aroma.

Bottle. Dark, thick muddy colour with slight amber tones. Nice banana smell from the lavender brown head. Mouthfeel is balanced, but thin, taste is biscuits, cherry coke, slight herbal presence, The taste just sort of creeps out and then fadesd away, so if lacks a real distinguishable finish..but overall a nice beer when the mood strikes. Curious to try this on tap to compare.

Draft at Ushitora. Deep caramel in color with a heavy tan head. Sweet malty aroma with fruit and some wheat. Very flavorful. Fruity, sweet malts, some toasted malts, and a bit of banana. I couldn’t stop drinking this beer, it was too tasty. Could easily drink this all night (and into the morning).

Hazy dark brown color. Cookies, dark chocolate, baked cake and bananas in the nose makes me wish this was sometype of cake. Bananas, chocolate, cookies, mildly sweet mouth. Chocolate banana cake finish. Found this better in the bottle on draft surprisingly.
Cask@Frog and Onion, Dockyards, Bermuda. Golden beer with a light head. The aroma is very weak and the flavour is lightly dry. Overall an average dry lager.
Pours yellow to almost white with a thin white head. Smells of dry malt, some biscuits, earthy. Tastes perfumy with some nice dry grass and hay elements. Refreshing.

Sample at the Frog & Onion in Bermuda: Pale yellow-gold color with a thin and foamy white head. Patchy lacing on the glass. Light hoppy aroma persists throughout, along with notes of grass. Light-bodied and effervescent with a clean hops flavor, as well as a bit of fruit. The finish is mildly bitter hops with a short fruity aftertaste. Overall it is decent.

Happoshu or ’bubbling spirit’ is an easier way to digest that this is a rice fermented beverage more than a beer, but here goes. Smuggled back from Taiwan. Translucent amber with a fine bead and whispy white foam. Aroma of gumboots - oh that is a first! Urinal cakes otherwise. It definitely doesn’t smell like the product it was fermented with. Frothy, foamy, calcium carbonate strong - at least I won’t get heart burn. Nothing in between. Distant malt. Distant grassy hops. Distant hipster that digs a beer like this! Look; nothing offensive as I can see this appealing to the masses, but meh!!! (35cL, can, BBE 06/16, Puro [?], Hai’an road, Tainan, Taiwan)
Vile concoction, weak and ugly. That is, except for the smell and taste, quite full and ugly. Puke aroma, rotten cabbage taste. Avoid.
Can in Macau. 5.5%. The beer starts slightly sweetish. Like all Orion beers, this has nearly the same taste: none. Watery grainy aftertaste. Very watery with hints of sweetish grain.
Even for a Haposhu it is bad. Tastes like soda water with some hops thrown in at the end. It is almost like some guy drank beer once and tried to recreate the taste from his memory.

35 cl can from Wellcome in Hong Kong, i think 4.5% to 5.5% ABV, can’t understand exacly what it says. Clear light yellow color, big bubbly white head. Aroma is uncertain, with some sugary grains, apple, alcohol and cardboard, metallic bitterness. Light body, dusty finish.
Floral toilet paper. Cardboard, dry popcorn, wash-up liquid, watery finish. Pretty naughty, probably wouldn’t finish it without a pack of peanuts...

zapach taniego wina (ale nie jabola), siarki i starych dro¿d¿y. z³oty kolor, piana jak z coli. w karton i powietrze ze œrodka materaca albo dêtki. lekka goryczka. mimo wszystko nie jest odpychaj¹ce i paskudne, zwyczajnie nie jest dobre.

coffee, cereal, orange, clear, white foam, light sweetness, light body, thin feel, sticky, light body, flat. Watered down, flat and has virtually nothing in common with actual ~beer~. Very difficult to ascertain that this is actually an alcoholic beverage; the taste is reminiscent of apple juice left sitting overnight. Almost offensive aftertastes, as it seems to leave a sticky film coating your mouth and teeth. As a fairly regular happoshu drinker, this is bottom-of-barrel stuff.

Can from a souvenir store in central Naha, Okinawa. Clear yellow colour. Small white head. Mild mineral grainy aroma. Thin mouthfeel. Flavour is mild with mineral, grains, bit sweet. Mild short bitterness.

330 ml can bought at Sogo Freshmart in Tsim Sha Tsui. Clear golden yellow colour; Thin head and white foam which last for about 1 minute; Minimal lacing and active carbonation; Aroma of malt, corn syrup, light rice, light bread and faint grass; Minimal light sweet taste of malt, with corn, rice, light rubber, light wet cardboard, and hint of citrus / bitterness; Light body, watery palate; Mouth feel is highly carbo beer-water with notable paint stripper / solvent, pretty uncomfortable, coupled with wet cardboard, this is bad; Hoppiness is faint grassy nose, trace of citrus in taste, and close to zero bitterness. Only fusel finish. Yuck! Slightly Dry after taste, very easy to mouth if you ignore the fusel. Comments: As a happoshu, this one comes at an hefty import price tag but it’s faulted as hell - a fusel-driven beer-water with wet cardboard - makes me wonder why Japanese macros can hit so low and put fabulously-marketed crap such as this. Drain pour, of course.

Pours very crappy and dissapointingly. Pale yellow with a fizzy worthless head that dissapears quickly. Not much aroma here and what little I did get was skunky and boozy. Taste is pretty hoppy and bitter. In fact much more so than I expected, all malts and sweetness are masked by the hops. The hop profile sucks though all bittering hops and nothing for the aroma. This stuff isn’t that great.

Can: Pours a clear gold, no head or lacing, very fizzy and dissapointing appearance like the other japanese beers I’ve had so far. The nose is thin and dry, some light malts and a pleasant lightly hopped tail. The flavor is thin, dry, a hint of malts. Relatively unappetizing and nearly devoid of flavor. Bravo.

i did note dry--overall, a bit buttery in the palate with plain popcorn taste; yeaup...actually, inoffensive and if i had to choose a few among many japanese macros to drink, this would be one of them; clean without a prick; interestingly, the head becomes rocky and leaves some chaotic lacing...
Mich hat es positiv überrascht. Ein feines Bier für den Genuss und für den gesellschaftlichen Abend! 4.75 ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I bought this bottle in the coop city, bahnhof or bling-blingstrasse in Zürich. I drank it the last Sunday at home with my wife at Lausanne. In my point of view, it is a regular lager, fully drinkable. The taste is malty, bready, a bit fruity, hop, decently bitter for the style, a bit watery. The color is yellow/clear and troubled, white foam, regular carbonation. It is a normal lager, better than one cardinal from this beautiful spot of the Zürichsee.
Clear golden color with white head. Aroma is corn grains, slightly sweet aroma. Taste is very sweet, corn. A standard boring Lager. Mouthfeel is smoother than expected.
Sour grass aroma with some yeast Pours golden with thin white head. Tastes bready and mild. Pretty well balanced. Oily mouthfeel and tight carbonation
Courtesy of Philippe (Bov); bb 01.14 Golden color with frothy head. Corn aroma, dry mouthfeel, somehow dry; corn flavor. Very poor.

from bieronlineshop.ch - clear dark golden beer with a modest head retention; vague aromatic hops with notes of flowers and grass; medium-bodied , subtle carbonation and a low bitterness; quite dry corny and buttery finish - modest

pale golden beer with only a little white head. smels of malt and hidden citrus. tasts malty, of some citrus and hops and has a hidden floral hint. aftertaste is a bit cereally and has a hint of cookies. the other beers from this brewery are way better!!

Draught at the Downtown location. Dark brown with light lacing. Roasted malt and cocoa powder aroma. French roast coffee, dark chocolate, and light fruity flavors. Finishes dry with a roasted, but not astringent bitter chocolate. Medium-light bodied. Big props for not being sticky and sweet like I figured it might be after having their triple. A pretty nice, dry, dark chocolate ale with great drinkability. Belgian porter?

Am I supposed to know that style this is? The color is a muddy brown that I imagine I would get if I mashed some wheat bread into a glass of water. The nose is faint cocoa butter and a composition of spices that are pretty indistinguishable... tastes of light bakers chocolate up front then more of a cocoa butter over the middle. Mildly prickling the tongue, finishing empty and almost flavorless. Weird beer, I don’t know if they used chocolate malts in this or some form of actual chocolate.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis 10 Barrel Pale Ale
column5: Well, I’m not a fan of pale ales, and this one didn’t win me over. The flavor is mostly grassy hops backstopped by citrus and wheat. It’s not bad...just not my thing.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis 10 Barrel Pale Ale
column5: Draft @ Minneapolis Brewpub: Copper gold, light head and lacing. Nose of light grassy hops, sweet orange. The flavor is thin, malty, catty. Ok finish with a bit of hops. Decent.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis 10 Barrel Pale Ale
column5: On tap at BP day RBSG 07 grand tasting. A golden pour with just a hint of amber. Some hop on the nose but not alot. Decent hops but not malt. Palate was a bit thin. The whole beer was a bit thin but not unpleasant. Could I drink it again sure. Would I, sure. Was it special nope.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis 10 Barrel Pale Ale
column5: On tap (sampler) at the Minneapolis location, RBSG 2007 pre-tasting dinner. Clear gold with a small white head. Pleasant grass and citrus nose, some grain. Citrusy flavor tempered with some light grain, orange zest. Light herbal bitter finish. OK.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis 10 Barrel Pale Ale
column5: Question: why does the abbreviation for a word with one ’b’ in it, have two ’b’s in it? Just one of those things, and something that has nothing to do with this beer... Very clear, very light, a whispery pear-ish coloration, under a solid lovely white head. Big fruit in the nose...pears, again, some citrus, apple, melon, ...but no, why not stop with pear, ...weird, but that’s it...nice, though... Taste: lightness and bareness reign high ...minimal finish, as well, and small texture, too...not enough smack on the lips, here....and hardly enough body. pity, I’m not happy being unhappy with beers from here...gets dry a bit at the end. But the body is so slim, and the flavor so scant, it’s very dsiappointing. Needs more MORE, dammit! Feels rushed, like a fill-in, ...ah, well...

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis 10 Barrel Pale Ale
column5: On tap (sampler) at the Minneapolis location, June 2007. Pale gold colour. Modicum of spicy, flowery hop in the aroma. The hop character is more herbaceous and "green" in the flavour profile, with a subtle bitterness. The mouthfeel, however, was softer and flatter than the Itasca sampled just before. Not bad, but I much preferred the Itasca, which was considerably more assertive and tasty.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis 10 Barrel Pale Ale
column5: Brewpub draft. Clear gold, modest white cap. Similar to a golden ale or kolsch with a nice addition of floral hops, a bit grainy on the finish. Light fruits in there, also. Medium body, balanced carbonation.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis 10 Barrel Pale Ale
column5: Sampled at brewpub prior to RBSG’07. Pours a clear pale golden blonde brew with a nice white head. Aroma of orange citrus peel, some piney hops and a touch of pineapple. Taste is lightly sweet citrus, light bodied, and lightly carbonated. Very clean finish and aftertaste.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis 10 Barrel Pale Ale
column5: Draft... RBSG 07... Clear, light yellow ale with a small, frothy, white head. To me, it smells almost exactly like their Itasca Extra Pale Ale. Also tastes like a lower gravity version of the Itasca, but more acidity and just a hair less bitterness. Light to medium-bodied and astringent with soft carbonation. Sahara-dry finish.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis 10 Barrel Pale Ale
column5: On tap @ the brew pub: Pours a light copper with a white head. Aroma, citrus. Flavor, pale malts, some bready notes, citrus and floral hops on the end.

This is a backlog rating from 2012 from a bottle picked up at Party Source, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time, work and/or family. Words to describe this beer are grainy, sweet, rice is prominent, some fruit, soft finish.

Bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, mostly lasting. Body is hazy light to medium amber. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted grain/cereal), lightly to moderately yeasty (horseblanket, barnyard), with notes of unripe peach, kumquat, gum, band-aid. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic. Have had this many times both at bars and at home, just getting around to rating it finally. Fun and wild beer with some Orval-ish notes and neat fruit character. The toasty rice aroma is distinct but blends well with the other components.

16.9oz bottle, shared with my cousin Daniel. Was on close-out at The Party Source for $2. Clear orange color. Pours with a big white head, that leaves good lace. Some fruity hop nose (pear, tropical fruit - mango, citrus) and definite rice aroma in the nose. Kind of sweet, like rice pudding or sake cask, with a hint of wood.. Very interesting aroma. Medium body, stronger carbonation, a soft smooth texture. Dry. Taste is light bitter, some sweet. Little savory, not as interesting as the nose. Interesting, though just decent-tasting ale, in the end. After the initial surprise from the unique flavor, I quickly lost interest. No staying power.

16.9oz bottle - pours murky orange with plenty of offwhite head and great lacing. Nose is straight up yeast like a Saison. Flavor adds sake-like qualities and a generic malt backbone. taste is dominated by the yeast flavor and I can’t make out sweetness or bitterness, but if I had to, I would go with light bitterness. light alcoholic bite. in a word: yeast.

Bottle was a gusher. Pours a opaque rusty orange with long lasting foamy off-white head. Barnyard, manure, bread, pepper, lemon, tangerine. Moderately bitter and sweet. Body is carbonated and crisp. More farmhouse ale than pale ale.
Hazy amber color with frothy ivory head. Dry brown rice, nutty, earthy hop, barnyard dung aromas. Medium body. Dry hay, roasted nut, grainy brown rice malty flavors--different

Bottle. Poured clear amber color with an average to large white frothy head that mostly lated with good lacing. Moderate toasted grainy and floral hop aroma. Medium body with a dry smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Soft drinkable brew.
Pours gold with a white head. Smells of spice, floral, some perfumy hints. Tastes floral with some dryness to it. Decent.

Draught in Beer Cafe Hopman, Chigasaki care of Tim Maloney. Colour is a really nice reddish brown with a decent white foam head. Nose has some citrous hop notes but also bit of toastey roasted grain. Taste is very toasty rice and grain. Very light bodied with a bit of ctrous hop at the end but mainly all about the toasted rice and grain character. Very nice.

A very funky brew. Pours burnt golden orange with a big head. Aroma of heavy grassy hops, a tinge of something unpleasant, not sure how to describe it. A bitter, slightly sour taste, reminiscent of brown rice. This particular bottle was not stored under best conditions, but this is still a very, very unique/funky beer. An interesting try, but I would not buy again.
Bottle poured to cup, 2 weeks old. Rich chocolate malt nose thick tan head. Dark nutty brown. Sour with a quick malt nuttyness cut with a bone dry finish.

Hakkaisan Izumi Porter 5% 500ml Bottle from Tricolore in Kibe. This Porter is a deep russet brown with a fluffy beige head. Lightly roasty, chocolate syrup & a mild nuttiness in the aroma. Light bodied with a raspy carbonation. The taste is bitter dark chocolate, minty herbalness & a bit of nuts. All right. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cask at the Tokyo Real Ale Festival. Thin and rather tasteless. Sour, not much happening on the malt. Uninteresting.
A weak chocolate-focused effort. Dark mahogany with a moderate head. Some decent toastiness and it isn’t offensive but it just plain needs more strength.
Light, thin chocolate beer with just a hint of smoke that blends well. Best of there beers.... that doesn’t say much
Pale golden color. Sour weak nose. Light body, errr... no body on second thought. Flavor???? opps they forgot to add it. Certainly not offensive unless you are offended by tap or bottled water.

Can 500ml. Clear light white - cristal color with initial a small, frothy - fizzy, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate spicy, artificial pear, pear notes. Flavor is light moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20110312]
Almost no colour and no head. Artificial perfumed aroma. Heavy sweet flavor, unpleasent. Syrupy texture. Lively carbonation.
Can. Watery colour. Light perry aroma. Ligthr perry flavor. Short light peery finish. watery palate. Rubbish.
Can. Clear as water with no head. Flavour is sweet, appels, watery and little acid.
Can. No head. Color is pale yellow. Aroma and taste are perry, alcohol and sugar.

Pours all audible like a good sparkling pinot noir. It dies down quickly, the body a pee yellow of a man desperate for drink. A single stream of bubbles now rising to atmosphere. Aroma; bubbles, sherbet, bubbles, sherbet, a little pear, bubbles, CO2, I’m blank out of oxygen. Sweet pear and pear drops in the mouth. Body is light when chilled becoming heavy when it warms, the carbonation a little artificial, carbonic and biting. Tangy and rounded fruit juice flavoured with little else, Finish is also sweet, not long to become cloying. Not much to it really. A Passion Pop of the perry world! (50cL, 13/011/12, Thirsty Camel, Butler)

Bottle. (First Perry Sampled). Pours clear, clear body almost like water, no head. Aroma is very light fruit. Flavor is smooth, some bubbly carbonation in the mouth feel. No alcohol at all. Some subtle, but delicious pear flavor in the finish.

[2188-20090521] 500mL can. Lots of soapy pear perfume aroma, an eau de poire. Clear, pale yellow body with no head. More pear fruit perfume continues in the flavour, very mild. Fizzy light body. Weird aroma, it was so confusing we rinsed the glasses and started again with the rest of the can. (from off-license; Cashel, Ireland; w/ jerc)

2009-05-21. Very pale pastel yellow, headless. Aroma is quite sweet, oddly fruit with a touch of dish soap like notes. Perfume like fruit character is not entirely pleasant. Flavour has a range of fruit notes, pears, tropical fruit, other. Starts sweet and gets a touch more dry in the finish. Thin palate is quite carbonated. Bit muddled overall. Not awful, but pretty odd. Can, from Random Off licence in Cashel

(Bottle 33 cl) Courtesy of BelJohansen. Clear - almost crystal clear - with a tiny, white head. Tart and a little perfumy aroma. Light-bodied with a heavy carbonation, rather tart without much carbonation. Vitamin c kinda acidic finish. 080408

Old review from the "lost" notebook. High carbonation, pale golden colour. Taste of sweet apples, not really distinguishable from normal Bulmers. Has a lemonade finish which balances the sweetness a bit. Not worth anyone's time.
*Bottle in Ireland. Smooth and fruity. Sweetish with not too much depth. Easy to drink, sessionable. Not too bad but just sweetish sparkling apple stuff...
Bottle at Dubln hotel. Nice orange body with no head. Taste of apples, malts, caramel. Nice and sweet.

Bottle pour. The cider is a clear copper color with a fizzy white head of foam. It fizzles out quickly. The smell is very sweet apple juice with a bit of zing. The taste is so sweet, it eventually made me gag on each sip. Ive never had that happen before. So over the top sweet, im not aure a person could drink this with any regularity.
Clear orange appearance, medium carbonation. Distinct apple aromas, high sweetness, light body. Meets expectations of a light cider.

Bottle, small fizzy head, clear light orange to pink colour, apple aroma, with light leathery aroma, fruity apple flavour, light sweetness, medium sourness, feels a bit diluted but still quite refreshing.

Can from Centra, Mohill [230514] Orange amber, no head. Nose of slight apple, bit acidic. Taste of slight apple, fairly sweet, artificial sweetener, dull. Palate - soft carb, light body, fairly sweet. Finish quite dry, long soft linger of artificial sweetener left in the mouth Overall - Full of artificial sweetener. Dull. Poor taste and finish
Bottle. Pale orange with no head. Light bitter apple flavour, light sweet dry finish.
bottle at An Poitin Stil .. . pours a very light yellow .. quite fizzy and quite light too .. . mild apple and bubbles .. . a very light beverage, made for teenage girls and justin bieber like people
Dark yellow to orange in colour with a white head. Aroma of sweet and sour apples. Flavour of sweet apples and a little dry finish.

[2085-20090410] 500mL bottle. Floral apple yeast aroma has mild potato, candy and toasted apple notes. Clear, light yellow brown body with a quick foamy white head. Sweet apply floral yeast continues in the flavour with a long sweet aftertaste. Sweet medium body. Good. (c/o garthicus, w/ GregClow, jerc)

Canned (as Stag Premium Cider 5.0%). Thanks TBone! Pale golden colour with no head. Aroma is apples, blue cheese, some sweet nectary notes as well as wood. Flavour is nettle, blue cheese, green apples and some freshly cut birch and juniper wood. For a macro a very good result to reach the real cider feeling.

2009-04-10. Crisp yellow body pours with a white foam that fades. Mild aroma is lightly fruity, cider apples. Sweet-tart dry cider flavour, tart apples, dry commercial finish. Average to thin palate. Decent mainstream cider - better than expected. Can shared by GregClow via Garthicus

Bottled. A light yellow cider with a thin white head. The aroma is very apply combined with light notes of wood and acidity. The flavor is apply combined with notes of wood, leading to a slightly acidic and dry finish.
Light clear golden, vnery fast dissapering head, carbonated. Nice aroma of freah apples and some wood. Mainly sweet dissapointing flavour, but some dryness in finish.

Can (500ml) shared with HogTownHarry, tupalev & garthicus -- courtesy of garthicus. Pours a clear gold with a small diminishing white head. Aroma of apples, slightly sweet. Light flavour of apples, again slightly sweet, not tart. Well carbonated. Simple, but still pretty decent stuff.

Bottle shared with Hogtown Harry, Blankboy, and Garthicus, courtesy of Garthicus. Not a bad aroma - lots of apple, tart, almost sweet and pie like as well. Very light yellow, small head. Good taste - like the aroma, lots of apple although sweet and not tart. Not bad actually, this one surprised me, a very decent cider. And why not, a rare Irish rating for #2200.

Can (500ml). Shared by garthicus with blankboy and tupalev. Clear pale gold, not much head (3-). Aroma - simple sweet apple, slight hint of mid-sweet white wine. Taste - simple apple, a mild alcohol tang, refreshing, goes down easy. Light, properly carbonated body, mildly acidic. Nice drinkin’ cider - thanks, Al!

(Bottle 33 cl) Comes as "Stag Premium Cider". Courtesy of BelJohansen. Clear, pale golden with a rough, white head. Distinct, dry apple aroma. Medium body, sweetish apple notes yet a somewhat astringent, leathery finish. Quite alright. 250308
Bottle. Clear pale yellow coloured with a small white ehad. Fruity aroma of apples with light acidic notes. Fruity flavour of apples with light acidic notes. Tart finish.
Draft: Orange-amber with a creamy white head. Rye and grapefruit-peel aroma. Caramel malt, strong rye and citrus-peel flavour. Nice even bittering. Pretty good.
Very nice floral hop and rye aroma. Pours light amber thin off white head. Taste medium sweet. Light bitter balances finish. Very good.

At Natty Greene's in Greensboro. Dark gold, almost amber color (tough to tell...poor lighting!). Almost no nose. Taste is so-so. Some rye, malt and bitterness - but not particularly interesting. Meh. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Amber in color, clear with a thin head. Nice Rye flavors and a rich thick malt finish. Light spice this was a very tasty session beer.
From tap. Pours red itch white head. Great rye and malt aroma. Taste follows with nice hop balance.

Pint at the Raleigh brewpub. Pours amber with a white head. The rye is very pronounced, which is welcome. Citrusy hops give it a little kick. The flavor is on the metallic side. It seems rough around the edges with blunt yeast and grain flavors, but the boldness of the rye saves it.

Originally reviewed: 11/25/09. This beer came out a deep dark copper color with a thin off-white head on top. No lace stuck behind at all. Smells of sharp rye grains, fresh bread, and a bit of honey. Decent body backed up by a moderate amount of carbonation. Flavor profile of definitive rye, that started out a bit tart, but finished bready and filling. Some mild caramel backing in there as well. Hop presence was moderate with a good pop of bitterness on the finish. Nice beer.

Served on draft at the brewpub, 4/6/11. Pours a hazy copper color with a thin creamy white head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of sweet and spicy rye notes and floral hops. The taste is rye, floral notes, faint caramel malts, nutty notes and a bitter finish. Medium bodied.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a pale amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty rye aroma. Fruity malty rye and caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel finish with some bitterness in the aftertaste.

Growler from brewpub. Pours a hazy orange with a little bit of a tan head. Aroma of toasty grain a little bit of grassy hops. Flavor is much the same with a lot of grassy hops and some hay. A little thin and unassuming but otherwise drinkable.

Bottle. FLowery nose, roange, grapefruit, holunder. Also some cat piss. Bright gold, almost clean, with a low head. Sweet and peppery, lagerish malt, bread, citrus, holunder, pepper. a bit oily and heavy. A bit strange but pretty good.
33 cl bottle. Pours cloudy yelow. Small white head. Aroma is citrusy. Mild estery. Citrusy. Dry and crisp citrusy finish.

330ml bottle [trade with Bartlebier, thank you very much!]. Barely clear, yellow-ish, faint, pale golden colour with small to average, thick, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, white head. Fruity, spicy aroma, notes of elderberry. Taste is monolithic spicy, malty, hints of yellow curry, curcuma; light and minimally watery. As the elderberry is cleary identifiable in the aroma, it is very interesting to find it bonded in an absolutely homogeneous taste of genuine character.
On tap at the brewery. Clean gold body with medium head. Nose is malty, skunky with some hops. Taste hoppy , herbal with floral notes and a bitter finish.
Tap. Slight elderflower indeed, but mostly straw and a little bit of hay. Quite thin and soft, very summery, but not enough carbonation to make it really refreshing. Rather bland.

33cl bb11/2016, merci Jan. - Bref: easily sessionable Helles goes the oragnic/natural way towards Holundersirup. Light, moderately carbonated yellow pour. Malt-sweetness matches the added elderflower to create on-point Holundersirup Radler lemonade in aroma - more enticing than many a coriander broth Wit. - Slightly slick mouthfeel hightens the impression of an elderflower-spiked secco. Taste is mainly pale/pilsner malt natural sweetness again matched with class by the organic sweet and flowery additions. Interesting how this contrasts with e.g. a more complex elderflower-dryherbed saison, - Remains well drinkable and indeed summery, going easier on the added natural aromas in taste than in bouquet.
Bottled. A golden beer with a white head. The aroma has notes lemons, malt, and straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, straw, and lemons.

0.33l bottle in basel. pours a hazy pale yellow with a small white head and no lacing. fresh floral aroma, some elderflowers. flavour is not as hoppy, mostly malty and yeasty, but light and crisp nevertheless. honey, pepper, grains. oily texture. refreshing.
Pours golden color, some malt in the aroma. Nicely balanced with some hop character, and a fruity finish.

Rating from 17.12.2007: "Zutaten: Wasser, Malz (D), Hopfen (CH), Holunderblüten (CH) und Hefe" Die Holunderblüten sind im Geruch schon deutlich spürbar und verleihen ihm etwas Frisches, Besonderes. Der Antrunk ist auch hefig-holunderblütendominiert, in Hauptteil gesellt sich eine leichte, aber nicht zu starke Hopfenherbe hinzu. Insgesamt ist es klasse süffig-vollmundig mit schönem runden Abgang, der sehr lange anhält. Auch werden dort wieder leichte Hefetöne erkennbar. Das Bier ist superweich und schön vollmundig --> klasse erfrischend!! --> 14
On tap at the Ram on Higgins. Light amber color. Decent. Slight sweetness. Serving: Tap
simple malty slightly floral aroma. clear amber color with a bubby white head. smooth simple malt flavor typical of a marzen. No unique components to comment on.

On tap at Ram - Wheeling, IL. Poured a clear medium amber with a nice initial cap of off-white head. Aroma picked up faint soapy off-notes first.. with caramel sweetness and some herbs behind. Flavor was of sweet, toasted caramel at the base with mild herbal and leafy hoppage going outward.. maybe some artificial sweetener.. but I found it tasty. Light-bodied and slick on the palate with some sharper points around.. low-medium bitterness. OK.

Aroma: Smelling of orange soda and some spices. Appearance: A clear straw colored beer. A white head with good lacing and small curtains. Taste: Tasting sweet artificial orange marmalade. Palate: Low carbonation, a soft texture. A medium body with a slightly dry finish. Overall: Orange soda with some bitterness. Note: On-tap at Barossa, Holland Village, Singapore. Reviewed 2013-01-11.

Draught at the pub in Circular Road Hazy yellow color. The wheat gives a light cereal aroma. Also the flavor has some cereals, light wheat (yet not a complete hefeweizen), quite strong bitterness. Not very special.

Sampler at Archipelago. Hazy golden colour, white head. Aroma of lemongrass, ginger, wheat. Flavour is wheat, some asian citrussy spices, light grainy. Light sour finish. Light to medium bodied. Great aroma on this one.

Draught at Archipelago Brewpub, Singapore. Unclear golden with a medium white head. Strong aroma and flavour of orange, ginger, lemon grass and wheat. The balance is just right. Good bitterness and finishes dry and bitter. Refreshing and makes this very quaffable and would pair exceptionally well with the Asian-fusion of Singaporean cuisine.
On tap at brewpub. My least favourite of their lineup. Very fruity gingery nose, with more of the same in the taste. Finish is a too spicey for my liking.

It’s rather spicy and too variant in taste. The aroma is reminiscent of a herb and spice shop with a couple of fruits thrown in; not that of a usual wheat malt beverage This requires a real effort to try acquiring any liking. If you want a very exotic departure from the usual spectrum of wheat beers/ales, this is your ticket. I suspect if a non-professional taster is not informed, he might not realise it’s a wheat ale unless he is aware that wheat tends to be paired with lots of stuff (but not to this extent..). Good for experimentation in my view. But, not as a regular.

Bottled. A hazy golden beer with no head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of wheat and light notes of fruit. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of wheat and fruits - especially oranges and peaches. Thanks fiulijn for sharing.

This one is a bit flat and by the numbers. Aroma is lacking any direction, slight cloves coming though. Murky orange with a thin white head. Flavour is a bit wierd, there is a slight spike of lime sourness that moves in to a more orange citrus. There is some bitterness that leaves a strange finish.

(Bottle 33 cl) Courtesy of fiulijn. Clear amber golden with a dense, off-white head. Spicy gingery nose. Medium body, sweet fruits and ginger, lightly perfumy. The finish is dry. Quite interesting. 160408
Deep golden with medium white head. Sweet fruity aroma with citrus and ginger notes. Sweet flavor with ginger and pepper notes. Ends light bitter.
Bottle. Clear amber coloured with a small white ehad. Sweet and spicy aroa of cardemomme and ginger with fruity notes. Sweet and spicy flavour of fruits, caramel, ginger and liquorice. Spicy finish.

33 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a fully diminished white head. Sweet to citrusy and light spiced aroma. Flavour is medium dry spiced. Light lingering spiced finish. Decent level of spice flavours, not so much of wheat.
Backlog. On tap at the brewpub. Dominated by citrus and a slight caramel, some tropical fruits. Refreshing.

Bottle- Pours a golden color with a fair head that fades to bits of lacing. Aroma of citrus, malt sweetness, bit of fruit and grain. has an initail crisp nip with some malt sweetness,fruit and grain. Light body, crisp and refreshing. Nice beer that goes well with hot humid weather.
Bottle. Clear gold body with a small to sparse white head. Aroma-taste of cooked corn/sorghum, with a bit of tropical fruit (papaya). Light bodied. Awful.
Bottle - slightly hazy gold with small white head. Average carbonation. Caramel malts. Fruity and citrussy. Low to medium bitterness. Dry finish.
bottle. pours a clear yellow with a moderate light head. quite soft and easy to drink, lightly hopped with lemon and some woody flavours.

330ml bottle. Scuzzy, sudsy white head with a quick fade. Golden in colour with a sweet aroma that is pleasant enough. Medium bodied with a nice finsih. Not too bad, would be okay sitting in a steamy humid Singapore bar on a sultry afternoon waiting for a storm to cool things down.
Well I wasn’t expecting a lot so wasn’t disappointed. Clear pale yellow body, short head. Citrus notes in the taste and aroma, low carbonation, moderate bitterness mainly on the finish.
Clear pale yellow, white head. Sweet malt, straw & citrus aromas. Easy at first in the mouth with flavours of sweet malt & light hops. Has some character of lemon & honey. Average beer.

Bottle. Clear golden pour with a quickly diminishing white head and a bit of lacing. Aroma is a little sweet, a little hoppy, and has notes of honey, malt and citrus. Flavour is not so sweet but has hints of malt, lemon, lime, grass and caramel. Light body with lots of carbonation and a mildly bitter finish. Not too bad but not particularly memorable either.

Sampler at Archipelago. Clear light golden colour, white head. Aroma is fruity, citrus, light sulfur and menthol. Flavour is light, bit of citrus, some sweetness, light bitter hoppy finish. Light bodied.
Draught at the pub in Circular Road Amber color. Smells like a Dunkel; smooth like an Ale, some caramel taste and some roasted malt. Boring. Too bitter at the end.

Sampler at Archipelago, ABV 5.4%. Light hazy amber colour, light off white head. Aroma of roasted malts, caramel, some Indian spices. Flavour is spicy, hoppy, light roasted with some caramel notes, grapefruit bitter finish, just a hint of soap. Medium bodied, good and tasty beer with a spicy twist.

Draught at Archipelago Brewpub, Singapore. Copper with a creamy off white head and nicely laced. Toasted malt, licorice, caramel, citrus, pine aroma and flavour. Similar to their other beers is very well balanced. Good carbonation and bitterness. Smooth and bitter finish. A unique beer that tastes great.
On tap at brewpub. My favourite of their lineup. Pours deep red with minimal head. Sweet malts, big ginger spicyness, some nuts. Good, but not something I would want to drink much of.

On tap. Rich lathery head. Deep brown+red colour. A beautiful beer. There is a strong note of hops in the aroma. Ginger - yup. Gula melaka (palm sugar) - better believe it! This beer works really really well. In my opinion, this is because the underlying beer would stand on its own, with the spices added in, it really flies! The solid hop/malt foundation is quite solid and the spices augment, rather than overwhelm the beer itself. Top knotch!

A confusing ale. Beerwise, the yin and yang are all out of balance. The various components do not seem to communicate with each other productively. Uphill task for a palate - like some kind of cultural revolution in your mouth. Queer aroma. Does this brew complement Asian cooking or, is it an Asian dish? If you take out the alcohol and throw in some crushed ice, it can pass off as a street desert in Southeast Asia.

Bottled. A hazy deep red beer with an orangey head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of caramel and light notes of spices. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel as well as lighter notes of nuts and ginger, leading to a dry spicy finish. Thanks fiulijn for sharing.

(330ml bottle, courtesy of Mar) Pours a clear brown body with a spare beige head. Aroma of palm sugar, ginger, caramel, and biscuit. Flavor of ginger, caramel, sugar, tapioca pudding, and nuts with a dry finish.

Definitely a mislabeled style. Bottle shared by Mark at a recent tasting. Thanks! Pours a dark clear brown color with no head. Smell is warm, toasty cinnamon and ginger along with a chocolatey flavor from the malt. Slightly hoppy, and clean with the toasty brown ale flavors mingling with the light ginger-y spiciness
dark brown pour with no real head at all. nothing but molasses and syrup on the nose. nothing but molasses and syrup on the palate besides the ridiculous amount of ginger in this thing.

Bottle courtesy of mar. Pours dark brown with smallish head that dissipates quickly. Aroma of molassas, syrup, raw meat and ginger. Flavor is burnt malts, ginger and molassas. Thinnish mouthfeel. More interesting than good.

column4: Old Capitol Brew Works and Public House
column5: On tap @ Quentin’s 7/19/07. Cloudy pink (think pink grapefruit flesh) with a one finger pinkish white head that fades quickly to a thick film--bah, they served it with a lemon, so that could have something to do with the head. Oh well. Aroma was simply of lemon and tart raspberry. Flavor was lots of tart raspberry and some bitter hairspray, some earthy bitterness as well (peaked at a 3 1/2). There was also some sweat. Moderate carbonation with a light to medium body. Did not care for this one.

column4: Old Capitol Brew Works and Public House
column5: On tap at the brewpub. This poured a cloudy dark red with a white head. The aroma was raspberries with some hints of peahes. There was also a little bit of black pepper spice. The taste was nasty fake raspberry. Yes, I understand they used real raspberries, but it didn’t work. There was also some plastic and grass.

column4: Old Capitol Brew Works and Public House
column5: Draft at Quinton’s in Iowa City. Poured a cloudy, opaque purple-red color. Head was bubbly and white with a pinkish tint. Aroma was of corn bread, citrus, and a touch of raspberry. Slightly sweet on the tongue. Tasted of buttered pancakes and freezer burned berries with citrus tang at the end. So so.

column1: Oakshire The Perfect Storm Double IPA
column5: Bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, mostly diminishing. Body is medium yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain, wort), lightly to moderately hoppy (apricot), with light notes of plastic, onions. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter, slightly unclean/vegetal. Medium body, watery/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Meh, pretty clunky all around...simple hops paired with off notes makes for a non-enticing aroma. Syrupy/flabby mouthfeel and a dirty, vegetal aftertaste makes it a bit unpleasant to drink too. Drain pour for me.

column1: Oakshire The Perfect Storm Double IPA
column5: It pours clear golden with a white head. It has a rich body with soft carbonation. The taste has tropical fruit, rich malt and mild citrus on finish. Really nice.

column1: Oakshire The Perfect Storm Double IPA
column5: Light amber, hazy. Hops are citrusy but a bit oxidized at this point. Bitter, some bright orangey notes, light pale malts. Decent balance.

column1: Oakshire The Perfect Storm Double IPA
column5: On tap at Hunah Day. Pours a clear gold with medium white head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is citrus, pine, earth malt. Medium body, citrus, pine, lingering dry bitterness, good.

column1: Oakshire The Perfect Storm Double IPA
column5: Appearance: Lighter copper, hazy. Finger of off white foam. Nose: Pine and citrus hops restrained. Good amount of honeyed sweetness. Taste: Malty but also resinously sweet with a nice hoppy balance between pine and citrus. Body: Medium to thicker. satiny Parting thoughts: definitely a more subtle hopped brew. Alcohol evident in taste and effect.

column1: Oakshire The Perfect Storm Double IPA
column5: Draft. Light copper. Nose is orange citrus and piney hops, toffee malts. Big malt body but balanced hop bitterness. Solid west coast impy IPA.

column1: Oakshire The Perfect Storm Double IPA
column5: Bottle from The Beer Junction, Seattle; 9% ABV Clean golden color with medium head. The aroma provides a blend af resiny, fruity, dunk hops, and toffee (8.5). Lean body, can’t believe this is 9% beer, with strong toffee malt flavor, light residual sweetness, followed by a strong presence of piney hops and some citrus fruits. Well balanced.. Surgically clean IIPA with excellent malt and hops.

column1: Oakshire The Perfect Storm Double IPA
column5: Kick 081215. Deep golden colour with an off-white head. Aroma is grapefruit, pine, caramel, malt, alcohol. Flavour is grapefruit, pine, caramel, malt, alcohol, herbs. Bitter finish. OK/Nice beer.

column1: Oakshire The Perfect Storm Double IPA
column5: 650 ml bottle @ Kick. Unclear orange body with a rather small but good locking, lacing off-white head. Nice citric fruity aroma with lots of malt as well with caramel. Flavor is sweet pale malt, citric fruit and good bitterness. Well balanced pleasant body and long lasting aftertaste with smooth malt and pleasant bitterness. Alcohol is well hidden, just as a warming feeling in the aftertaste. Not really complex, pretty straight forward, but very smooth and well made. Nice one.

column1: Oakshire The Perfect Storm Double IPA
column5: Bottle@Kick. Pours golden with an off white head. Aroma of herbs, mint, malt and fruitiness. Flavor is sweet and fruity with some herbs, floral notes and bitterness. Medium body, average carbonation.

column1: The Brewhouse Donovan Oat Meal Stout
column5: (growler thanks to jjfoodie) clear gold, wispy white bubbles. Nose and taste is dank, lavender, wit beer like, agave, herbal, liked it when it was colder.

column1: The Brewhouse Donovan Oat Meal Stout
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pitch black with dark tan creamy head. 1/2 finger head lingers forever. Nice. Roasty aroma, with underlying maltiness. No off aromas. The roastiness is less present in the taste. A bit mild, to be expected at 5.3%. Wonderful. Not my favorite style, but done as well as can be.

column1: The Brewhouse Donovan Oat Meal Stout
column5: This had a lasting tight head.Color a nice black.Aroma was of roasted coffee.Palate was a nice sticky one.Perfect palate.The flavor was of roasted coffee and not much else.I was hoping for that elusive chocolate flavor.Creamy taste due to the head which also complements the oatmeal ,Had an underlying sourness to the taste..Creamy like oatmeal.Finished bitter and sour.Decent stout,but needs that chocolate to be one of the best.Will buy again.Had on tap at brewer.

Draft at The Brewhouse. Fairly nice hoppy aroma. Hint of citrus fruits in the aroma. The taste quite mild for a IPA but nice flavor of the citrus fruits and hops. Ovrerall an Ok IPA. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at the brewpub. Maybe just hard to screw up a good hoppy west-coast IPA, but this was better than average for the style and by a long mark the best beer of the night. Pours surprisingly light yellow with a very piney aroma. The flavor is a nice dry bitterness, herbial and medicinal without the caramel and candied grapefruit often found in the style. This one is in the Diamond Knot IPA vein, and quite reasonable though not quite in the league of the Diamon Knot. Still, a nice drink.

This had an average head.Color a medium dark amber.Had a nice aroma of floral and citrus.The palate was sticky.The taste was of oranges and bitter hops.I wanted to taste more subtlties,but none detected.I liked this IPA,but not one of the best.It is a very good one.Much better than average.

I live in central Texas so we were one of the first markets to get this beer. This is my go to morning drink and hot afternoon refresher. Being that I like bloody mary's, this beer is a natural substitute in a pinch and without all the work. While it does have clamato, the taste is very subtle. It helps mellow out the bland taste of budweiser which i don't really drink by itself anymore. it's pretty much a love it or hate it type beer.

25 ounce can into pint glass, canned on 2/24/2018. Pours moderately murky/cloudy reddish orange/amber color with a minimal foamy off white head with poor retention, that reduces to nothing pretty quickly. No lacing on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation and clinging bubbles on the glass. Okay appearance. Aromas of tomato juice, lime, salt, garlic, onion, celery, chili pepper, peppercorn, brown sugar, cracker, and white bread; with light notes of clams, vinegar, and herbal/spice earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance and complexity of lime, clamato, salt, and moderate pale malt notes; with solid strrength. Taste of big tomato juice, lime, salt, garlic, onion, celery, chili pepper, peppercorn, brown sugar, cracker, and white bread; with light notes of clams, vinegar, and herbal/spice earthiness. Mild herbal bitterness and peppery spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of tomato juice, lime, salt, garlic, onion, celery, chili pepper, peppercorn, brown sugar, cracker, white bread, and herbal/spice earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Great complexity, robustness, and balance of lime, clamato, salt, and moderate pale malt flavors; great malt/bitter/spiciness balance, and no cloying flavors after the finish. Lightly increasing dryness from lingering bitter/spiciness. Medium-high carbonation and medium body; with a very smooth, moderately bready/grainy, fairly crisp, and lightly sticky/creamy tomato mouthfeel that is fantastic. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 5%. Lightly increasing pleasant lingering pepper heat through the glass. Overall this is a delicious fruit/spice/vegetable beer. All around nice complexity, robustness, and balance of lime, clamato, salt, and moderate pale malt flavors; very smooth, crisp, and refreshing to drink with the mildly bitter/spicy finish. This is the best one in this style I have had. Was even better than the bud light version, very similar but with more clean malt presence. Most other cheladas I've had were too heavy on tomato juice/body. This is perfect balance of Budweiser and Clamato flavors; with plenty of malt presence for the style. A very enjoyable offering, and outstanding style example.

I like to drink this in lieu of a bloody Mary. It's a nice Latino inspired substitute for the vodka, horseradish, tomato concoction. Easy to grab at most any decent sized liquor store or convenience store, Only about $3.50 a tallboy. Get over the whole "clam" flavor fears. There is barely a hint of it here. Avoid the Modelo version, it's absolutely horrendous.

The appearance was a rough looking burnt orange tomato color with no head or lace. The aroma was toast, burnt tomatoes, salt, cooked lime, burnt hay and skunk. The flavor was salty burnt tomatoes and skunk with some metallic sliding in. Aftertaste was beyond repulsive. The palate was somewhat light bodied with no sessionability about it. Exceptionally distracting all around from off flavors all up in there. Carbonation seemed a bit prickly. ABV did feel fine. Overall, how is this an enjoyable drink, even if I’m supposed to water it down even further with excessive ice?
Aroma is tomatoes, salt and mild malts/grains. The flavor is pretty much the same as the aroma. Could only stand a sip, knew it was going to be a mistake.

Haha I love reading reviews in this one. It is a beer that does crazy well in my hometown because of the Hispanic clientele. Although, that really has nothing to do with my interpretation of it, I enjoy every incantation of it. On this scale where rating should be taken seriously does it score well, but in its own right this tomato, pepper, clam juice brew is a Central Valley staple.

A big dirty 24fl oz can from a random liquor store in Houston. It pours bright pink - read with minimal head. The aroma is very savoury, loads of tomato, salty, dull spice and green veg. The taste is sweet - spicy, wishy washy tomato juice, something meaty, salt water, some spice and savoury vibe with a sweet, tangy tomato finish. Light - medium body and fine, prickly. I wanted to like this infamous beer, but it engaged my gag reflex. Pretty rotten stuff.
Pours a golden reddish yellow. Aromas of grass, malts, and a touch of briney tomato. Flavor is briney, tomato, cheap lager...but I love me some red beer.

Mega-can, part of the Chelada taste-off. Pinkish-red, opaque, short-lived link head, more vibrant than the Modelo, less sero-sanguinous in appearance. Similar briny, spicy, aroma and flavour, but sweeter and less watery (am I seriously saying that about a Budweiser product?). Could be a touch spicier, but I guess that’s why there is a Picante version (which happens to be next on the docket...)
Backlog from Brony Bottle Share at Travlr’s. Terrible, awful, no good garbage juice.
airy white head, fizzy, dead straw body; smooth, fizzy; seltzer, metallic, and buttery aftertaste; something slightly different, though...
It is kind of a summery ale and has a nice foamy head, but the color is a dirty hazy amber. Very little aroma. Flavor is a bit tangy. Not a fan of the corn.

Bottle 49 cl from Bier-Bienne (CH). Pale and haty blonde with short fleeting foam. Grassy aromas, malted sweetness, lemon. The taste is grassy and lemony, smell of corn and its sweetness, present acidity and sourness. A bit disgusting. Herbaceouis bitter, lemon and citrus. Interesting work on a style which is not it.

Hopfiger, schnell abflachender Antrunk. Der Mittelteil ist so etwas schwach, dann kommen aber geringe Fruchtnoten auf, die das Bier zwar nicht sonderlich intensiver, dafür aber deutlich interessanter machen. Ein leichter Resthopfen ist noch da, dazu eine süß-saure Mischung. Interessant! 8/9/9/8/7/9
paler golden beer, small white head. smells of florasl hops, with an interesting hint of tropical fruits and apple. aftertaste is bittersweet wich a lychee hint, floral, herbal
Sampled at the Solothurner Biertage 2009. A very good beer- reminiscent of belgian wit. Fruity with a little arabic gum.

bottled; from Solothurner Biertage 2009 - cloudy dark golden-blond colour with a solid, firm and persistent white foam; beautiful lace on the sides of the glass; solid corny aroma, dusty; shows some spicy notes (I can’t put a name on it) which make a quite fresh impression; moderate malt backbone, quite effervescent and lively palate; some tartness partially coming from the grain used but also from a light acidic touch; the finish is slightly dry and fizzy with more corny notes - original and very interesting; refreshing and very well-made: another great work from Stephen

Trade with Allen, thanks! Appearance: Chestnut brown. Clear, some tan head. Aroma: Slight sweetness, dark malt. Molasses. Some fruit. Taste: Nice malt and hops. Slight smokiness. Info: 500ml bottle, 14/10-2010
0.5 l bottle at Petalax Beer Festival 2010. Hazy brown color. Malty, toffeish, fruity, yeasty and slightly soapy aroma and flavor.
Bottled@PBF2010. Deep golden colour, small head. Aroma is fruits, wood and earthcellar with somemild nuttyness. Flavour is much the same in a nice balance.

Bottle 500ml. w. swing top @ Petalax Beer Festival 2010 - the 4th. edition. Clear medium amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, berry, light roasted. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20100703]
Bottled (PBF) Amber color, small steady beige head, Nutty-caramelly altbier nose. Flavor is also nutty-caramelly, lingering herbal-nutty hoppyness. Clean and balanced, not very interesting though.

swing top bottle (500ml). -Trade with Allen (thanks Julian!). Murky brown coloured, medium sized beige head, hoppy nose with touch of caramel. Toasted malt, caramel and pleasant hoppy with fruity and nutty notes. A bit watery but never mind. Dry moderate bitter finish.

(swing top bottle, courtesy of Allen) Hazy, chestnut-brown colour with a big and beige foamy head. Sweet and moderately yeasty toast-malty aroma with notes of red berries and woody, slightly piney hops. Light-bitter flavour, slim bodied with a moderate carbonation. Toasty malty taste with a tinge of caramel, subtle berry-fruity notes and a good dash of woody and slightly herbal hops; slim and moderately toasted malty finish with a rounded hoppy bitterness. A slim but also well-crafted Alt. 02.XII.09

Bügelverschlußflasche (from Allen!): Amber coloured, unclear, big fluff "dirty" white head; moderate sweetish caramelly nose, toasted malt and some fruits in the nose; moderate bitter-sweetish flavour, light to medium bodied, soft MF; drier hoppy-caramelly finish. Very good Alt......

The bottle looks very simple, but good. The beer in the glass dark brown, modest turbid, creamy head. Starts modest malty, not too dry, a bit roasty. Finish a bit moldy-bitter, drier than the beginning. A bit unbalanced. Big thanks to Allen for the bottle!

Wenig herber, platt getreidiger Antrunk mit dem typisch alkoholfreien bitteren Aroma, das zu Anfang noch angenehm mild ausfällt. Dan wird das Bier etwas penetranter, nach ein paar Schlücken reguliert sich das Ganze bzw. man gewöhnt sich weitestgehend an die Intensität. Erfrischend, trinkbar, nur im Abgang etwas zu pappig. OK. 7/6/5/6/7/5
Bottled 33cl. It pours a golden beer with a bubbly white head. The nose is decent, malty with notes of chestnuts. Apart from that a typical non alcoholic lager. Very sweet.

Bottled. A very light yelloe cider with no head. The aroma is sweet with ntoes of alcohol and apples. The flavor is sweet with notes of apples as well as a light acidity, the flavor is a bit artificial. The body is a bit tart. Thanks Papsoe for sharing.

(Bottle 27,5 cl) Courtesy of yngwie. Pours almost crystal clear with a small white head. Tart apple aroma. Light in body with a heavy carbonation and distinct tart apple notes. Rather authentic and by no means commercial and stickingly sweet. 030608

27.5 cL clear bottle. Pours clear and pale yellow to white with no head. Artificial sweet apple aroma. Flavour on the contrary is not as sweet but still artifical. Goes into a rather dry and acidic to citric flavour and finish. Somewhat bland and quite artificial.

Very pale golden body with a green shine, white head; Not a lot of aroma, what there is is very fresh and flowery; Super fresh body ,great carbonation, sweet and slightly acidy; Long fresh apple flowery finish. Very, very drinkable. Thanks Yngwie.

Medium coarse white head disappears immediately. Nearly colourless body with just a hint of something that might be yellow. Sweet mealy artifical apple aroma with toffeeish notes. Sweetish earthy apple taste with notes of toffee. Quite watery, but clean and smooth mouthfeel. A touch of pear as well. Sharpish on the tongue from the carbonation. No aftertaste. Easy to drink, but too watery, and doesn’t really have much to recommend it. Can imagine teenagers find this easy to get drunk on, though. (0.275l bottle from Ica Gourmet, Aker Brygge, Oslo.)
Bottle. Yellow colour . Aroma is ripe apple. flavour is also ripe apple, yeast. OK cider.

Bottle. Brilliant pale straw yellow. Noisy carbonatian. Medium white coarse head , quickly diminishing. Aroma is part dry apples, part a regular white wine. Scents of yeast. Taste is more like a dry wine-cooler than a cider. Body is light and the palate is not very filling, but still beyond the usual Norwegian alcopops labelled as ’Cider’.

275 ml clear slimline bottle with twist-off cap. Extremely pale straw coloured, fizzy. Moderate apple aroma and flavour (of eating apples, not cider apples), not very exciting but not offensive either. Fizzy and watery mouthfeel. An okay refreshment, no more than that.

Bottle. It pours very pale, just a yellow touch to it, with a nice carbonation. There’s a yeasty sensation to the aroma, which consist mostly of apples, but there’s a pear note as well, even though there’s no pear used in the process. The flavor has apples and yeast, and there’s a note of alcohol as well. Medium to thin mouthfeel. Quite fizzy in the mouth, but not in an unpleasant way. The finish has the same apples and yeast as in the initial flavor, and some alcohol notes. Not a complex cider, but far much better than the other horrible, artificial-tasting, sweet ciders we get in the Norwegian super-markets. Quite easy to down as well. (070713)

250ml bottle. Pale body, close to water in color. Flavor is ripe apple, almost a bit sherry-like, yeast, a hint of alcohol and rather sweet with some sourness. The sweetness feels more natural and balanced than some terrible Norwegian alcopop versions of cider. I’m not to keen on ciders, and believe a cider should be a bit rougher in style, but this is anyway a quite refreshing drink and deserves more success than it probably would get. This is more like a commercial version of a farmer cider.

Cask (handpump) at Peter Kavanaghs, Liverpool, April 2008. Nice bright amber colour. Unfortunately, that’s where the good bits end. The aroma majors on diacetyl and this carries through into a buttery character on the palate, although its not quite as prominent there. Couldn’t really delve below the diacetyl to explore the underlying beer. Drinkable (just) but not a very enjoyable experience. Mark down for a re-rate.
[Cask from The Three Judges] Deep amber colour with a light foamy head. Floral with buttery toffee notes and some ripe berry fruit. Light on the palate, fruity and dry.

Rated from notes on a Flossmoor Station coaster found while cleaning out my beer glass collection. Sampled on tap at the brewpub while out to lunch for work. The day is coming back to me. Poured an impressive blackish hue, almost opaque, with a small but sufficient brownish head. Aromas are largely roasted malts, with coffee and chocolate, mixed with a nice hoppiness. Taste mirrors this: Chocolate and coffee dominant, mixed with some nice roasted malts and rye. Hoppy bite gives it a nice different approach. Hops in these porters and stouts are definitely great. Tad thin in the body. Glad I found this rating. Cheers!

pours black, thin brown head. aroma of malt, chocalt coffee. malt, chocolate, coffee in the flavor with a touch of fruity hoppiness, with a sweetish hint of floral hop. finish is coffee bitter and hoppy. not a great beer, but i enjoyed this. my home brewpub ==> Flossmoor Station Restaurant & Brewery

On tap, with espresso beans. Pours almost black with a smallish beige colored head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, roast, floral hops. Flavor is huge blast of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, a hint of citrus hops. Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, finished bitter. This was decent but the coffee overwhelmed and the body was a bit thin for my liking. Decent but not great.

On tap at the Station for Andrew’s bachelor party. Pours brown black with a brown head. Lots of rye, chocolate, and lightly sweet grain in the nose. Similar flavors of chocolate, rye, biscuit, piney hops, and grain ... complex and finishes dry.

Silky smooth dry hoppy rye stout. Roasty. Bit of Coffee. Yeasty burnt buiscuit. Not too sweet. This is by far the best microbrew-pub reastauant brews I’ve had and food and service was excellent. Highly recommended.

On tap at Flossmoor, 9/22/07. Very deep black color, hints of red around the corners, tan foam with great lacing and retention. Aroma is huge on the dark malts, maybe some tiny bit of hops in there somewhere. Flavor again very big on the malts, the rye comes through very nicely right before the hops hit. Silky smooth texture, only 5.5%? Give me more!
Alright brew! Probably my favorite that was on tap when visited! huge coffe smell Very black red in color. tasted coffee and choclate. balance malts and hops

I split a growler with SurlySober, who picked this up over his weekend travels. SurlySober thought this beer was similar to Founder’s Black Rye, and I respectfully disagree. While I really liked both beers, I thought Black Rye had more of the "burned pizza crust" character I prize in roasty stouts although Black Moon Rye-Sin certainly had plenty. Black Moon Rye-Sin had a lot more hoppiness than Black Rye, and in fact considerably more hop character than any stout I’ve had in recent memory (maybe ever). The end result is a beer that’s extremely malty, with a ton of dry roastiness, but is also fairly heavily hopped. It is really quite good and highly recommended. This beer is an opaque black with plentiful tan head. Aroma is very roasty, a bit sour, and surprisingly hoppy. Flavor is as is I’ve described. Mouthfeel is exceedingly dry, so much so that it hurts drinkability a bit but this is still a very good beer.
Mini-keg courtesy of Rayboy01 at his Cajun Fais Do Do party. Smells like the Black Wolf Schwarzbier. Chocolate notes. Faint malt. Very nice flavor. A little tanniny. Very good.

Draught at the Pub 6/26/07. I came in for dinner, and upon hearing I’d have to wait until eight I stuck around to get one of the first of these served. It was worth the wait. An opaque dark brown with a healthy light brown head. Laced the glass considerably. Roast aroma with obvious rye character. Very tasty. Flavor was potently roast malt, rye was very forward and pleasantly dry.

Cask conditioned at Banbury Beer Fest ’08, sold as Wild Admiral. Red brown with slight head. Sweet toffee caramel to the fore, malty, fruity quite rich but somewhat cloying on the palate. Not much in the way of hops but generally quite reasonable.
[Cask from The Three Judges] red/amber, thin head. Friuty, caramel, almost sugary. Full bodied, sweet upfront, some apricot notes, dry.
Clear pale gold, white head. Aroma is skunky. Taste is skunk, grains, corn. Not very good.

Aroma: lots of skunk and a little grass; Appearance: clear golden pour with creamy white head and lots of carbonation; Taste: lots of apple juice with a little corn and water; Palate: light bodied with short finish; Overall: not pleasant. Would not get again.

from Bieronlineshop.ch - translucide and bright golden beer with a moderate foam left; oily grassy hops; light phenolic; medium-bodied, sweet and oily mouthfeel; a gentle bitterness, light tart corny and grassy finish - decent
Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. yellow colour. Moderate malty and light hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate. Nice.

Sehr wässriger Antrunk mit leichter Süße und einem Hauch von Gerste. Langweilig, es sind kaum Aromen vorhanden. Das Getreide wird immerhin etwas stärker, somit auch die Würzigkeit, die nun zu süß erscheint. Unausgeglichenes Bier! 8/6/6/5/8/6
Bottle from Shrubber85. Blonde. Soft grassy aroma. Grainy grassy flavor with soft oily notes. A soft bitterness in the aftertaste. Drinkable.
Bottle. Sweet-sour corn/barley malt aroma. Clear golden yellow color with moderate head. Sweet strong grainy malt flavor with mild bitter grass hops flavor. Mediocre lager.

Bottled (thanks KR!). Pale golden colour, small white head. Aroma is sweet malts along with some bready and hoppy notes. Flavour is quite much the same with a rather grassy finish. Quite basic, but clean. Smooth carbonation.

Swing top bottle, bought at the supermarket next to the Liechtensteiner Brauhaus in Schaan. Slightly unclear, golden colour with a big and loose foamy white head. Sweet and minimal sugary malty nose with a bready touch. Sweet and slightly flavour, light to medium bodied with a flat carbonation. Malty and bready taste with notes of cardboard, especially towards the shy bitter and slightly hoppy finish 06.IX.09
Bottle. Yellow color, white head. Bready, fruity aroma, Watery hop flavor with some pepper.
A nice pink color with some bubbles. bottle from 1993 at Pressklubben. oxidized aroma and flavor of dirt and earth. blended with a sweetness that doesn’t play for the beers favor in flavor.

Bottle sample at a tasting at the Dancing Camel Pub Florentin. Many thanks Pallieter85. Vintage 1983. Pours red hazy with a small head (flat), aroma of fresh fruits, raspberries, some malt, flavor is sour, fresh with lemon, slightly bitter and burning, medium bodied, really nice with lots of fresh fruits

Bottled (1986 vintage)@Belgobaren, Stockholm (old backlog from about 2010). Red colour with a small pinkish head. Aroma is acidic wooden and fruity notes along with some slight sourness and raspberries. Flavour is acidic berries, some mild tart and sourness as well as mild wooden notes. A bit too acidic for my taste, but that’s always a risk when buying oldies...

Dark dry Earth and asphalt balanced with a touch of acid and an aromatic and juicy sweet flavor of candied raspberries. Darkish Orange Amber colored ale from aged bottle with a sour finish and an aged Ivy character. A mellowness in the alcohol. Smooth mouthfeel it is silky with a frothy and appropriately lively carbonation.

Leicht süßer Geruch. Minimal süßer Antrunk, dann leicht säuerlich (stärker werdend). Auch die Fruchtigkeit wird nach und nach stärker, insgesamt ist es aber ein mildes Bier. Süßer Mittelteil, was die Fruchtigkeit unterstützt. Im Nachgeschmack würziger, etwas saurer werdend, etwas bitter. Test vom 30.5.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,11,11,11,12,11

Re-rate 10/24/13: Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel Florentin. Thanks Pallieter85. 1983 bottle. Murky red with a tiny bit of foam. Pleasant raspberry aroma with some cork and some wood. Sour flavor with light sweetish notes, lots of raspberries, oak, a bit of cork, musty notes and some funk. Light to medium-bodied. Very nice. Still a lot of raspberries after 30 years. 8/3/8/3/16=3.8 [3/3/11] Bottle at Bier Circus in Brussels. 1993 vintage. Surprisingly almost clear red-amber with a slightly pinkish white head. Lovely aroma full of raspberries, lactic notes and some funk. A rather sweet flavor with raspberry, a bit of sugar and some slightly funky sourness. Silky mouthfeel. A lovely sweeter Framboise. 7/3/8/4/15=3.7

Bottle at Bier Circus, 1993-vintage. Clear orange coloured with a medium sized off-white head. Fruity aroma of raspberries and mould with oxidized notes. Fruity flavour of raspberries with oxidized notes. Fruity finish.

Bottled @ Bier Circus. Vintage 1993. Dark amber coloured. Fluffy off white head. Raspberry, sourness and a bit earthstruck aroma. Flavour is still amazingly full of the berries. Has a light sour and earthy touch. Medium bodied. Quite sweet end with a touch of sourness.
