37.5 cL bottle, 1993 Vintage @ BierCircus. Pours almost clear and golden deep amber with a small bubbly white head. Aroma is is dry wooden, slight earthy and citric raspberry fruity. Sweet, raspberry and mild tart acidic underneath. Ends with a mild earthy to wooden note.

In short: A boring semi-lambic with a red fruit hard candy flavor How: Bottle, 1993 vintage, at Bier Circus, Brussels The look: Almost clear golden red body topped by a medium beige head In long: The nose is musty, a little dusty and with a sweet red fruit aroma that I would describe as cherry flavored hard-candy. The bottle seemed to be in good shape with adequate carbonation, although it had an ugly layer of yeast glued at the bottom of the bottle. The taste is pretty much what the nose hinted on. A strong red fruit flavored hard-candy flavor, a bit sweet, light funk. Kind of boring really. This is the type of taste I expect from sweetened commercial fruit lambic like a Mort Subite Framboise or a Boon Framboise. I had never had a beer from Vanderlinden, this old out of business lambic brewery. I saw it (overpriced) at Bier Circus and it was one of those “now or never” moment. I jumped on the occasion but it was not the right move. I got tangled in the screen door of my window of opportunity.

Pours a clear gold colors with a small white head that quickly dissipates into a ring. Aroma of floral hops, cereal malts, sweet pale malts and that’s about it. Taste is sweet pale malts, light floral fruity hops with a touch of bitter clean but too thin to be a premium.

355mL Can from a Fernie Discovery Pack (1 of 4). Pours a clear, golden yellow with a bubbly white head that dissipates like pop fizz. Aroma is grassy, hint of sweet malts - caramel, butter. Taste is a plain jane pilsner-style lager. Mouthfeel is light, moderate to high carbonation. Finishes a little sweet, mild bitter hops in the finish. Would make an ok patio or beach beer in a pinch.
Pours a straw colour with a small white ring around the glass. Aromas consist of sweet pale malts. Taste is sweet pale malts with a light grassy bitter finish.

Clear golden yellow, foamy white head settles quickly. Aroma of sweet corn and grainy malts. Funky malty sweetish taste, not much else. Average carbonation, light bodied, low hopped. Some faint grassy hop in the finish. LF (Lagerboy Friendly)

355ml can pours a pale straw color with a small white head that leaves virtually no lacing on the glass. Aroma is light grains and mild grass. Taste is grainy malt sweetness with a grassy hop bitterness. Light bodied with mild carbonation. Just tastes like a standard macro lager.

Bought a can of this at Zyn in Calgary. The pour is a bright golden yellow with a off-white head atop. The finger of head dies pretty quick. The nose is grainy with light grassy hops and a hint of lemon. The taste is grainy and bready with a hint of hop on the finish. Overall, not a bad beer, but not good at all.
355ml can. Lemon yellow colour with haze. White head fades quickly. Light lemony nose. Bready taste, grains, light lemon hints. Light body lively carbonation. Pretty standard but no bad flavors.

Nose is rich with buttered corn on the cob, sea salt and dandelion. Big corn trend with these Fernie beers! Colour is an interesting Sauvignon Blanc hue. Things fade drastically in the mouth. Not much to report other than a tug of war in all directions. Not really bitter, not really rich, not fruity or flowery. One thing it is however is slightly watery. Often these multi-facet profiles can work in sync but not here. Saving grace: nice butter cream finish.

Sample at Canadian Brewing Awards 2008. Light, clear golden with a small head. Aroma of sweet malt, icing sugar, faint fusel alcohol, slightly sour endnote. Sticky body. Flavour is sweet and cloying with more icing sugar and a faintly hopped finish. Poorly balanced, and just not very good.

A great canned brew to throw into the golf bag. For a canned lager, this is unsurprisingly straightforward with sweet grainy pale malt as it’s sole feature, however it is above macro standards in that it finishes clean and doesn’t become harsh or cloying as it warms above 3 degrees Celsius.

The bottle looks good, the beer in the glass quite dark, not black. Very smoky aroma. Starts also smoky-malty, earthy, a bit like plum. Goes down soft as velvet. Aroma very nice till the end. Unusual, but good!

(bottle, with thanks to Quack-Duck) Clear, dark brown colour with a medium-sized tanned foamy head. Moderately sweet and toasty nose with caramel and a touch of cacao-powder. Medium-sweet flavour, light to medium bodied, soft on carbon. Slightly roasty malty taste with light impressions of burnt caramel; quite dry, light-sweet finish with a balancing burnt and hoppy bitterness. Solid Dunkel.

Bottle (Danke, Quack-Duck !): Chestnut-amber coloured, quite stable off-white head, sticking to the glass; caramelly, roastmalty nose with a faint metallic touch; moderate sweet-bitter flavour; becomes drier towards the roast-malty, caramelly finish. Well done......

bottle, bought at the brewery. Schwirza was a smuggler in the Bohemian-Bavarian border region. Dark brown colour, large creamy head, malty nose. Flavours of malt and roasted malt, quite sweet, but very pleasant. Hoppy background, hints of caramel and hoppy finish and aftertaste.
# 158, 12/2015. Nepøíliš výrazný pivo. Medová pøíchu je jasnì identifikovatelná, dojem sráží kukuøiènost a náznaky plesnivosti.
Prakticky tady pøidávám tento komentáø, jen aby tady nìco bylo, protože zpìtnì dopisuji 900 piv z mého seznamu a asi bych se musel u toho zbláznit.
Zajímavé pivo, se sladkou chutí medu. Nasládlý øíz, jemné medové aroma a pøíjemná, osvìžující chu.

Bottle from Tesco. Heavily lightstruck aroma, which should be hard to do in brown bottles, or so I guessed. Apparently these guys are trying hard. Taste is not so tragic, though it is far from perfect. Light metallic and lightstruck, fizzy, with the blunt bitterness characteristic of extracts. What am I even drinking? And Why?

Pours a clear yellow golden color, topped with small white head. Malty aroma with grassy hops and some spices and herbs present in the back. Taste is similar, malty a bit grassy with medium bitterness in the finish. A decent one.
Bottle at Janoinen Lohi, Helsinki. Originally rated 09122011. Colour is clear golden with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Sweetness, honey, some hops and malts.
Gift from SJ. A mild beer with notes of grass, caramel malt and bread. A bit thin for my tastes, but not bad.
Clear golden colour with medium head. Aroma is malt, hops. Flavour is too watery and only litlle bit of hop taste.

This beer was brewed again for the 2011 Sainsbury’s beer comp (it didn’t win): brown 500ml bottle, best before 30 Dec 2011, drank Oct 2011. Poured into a UK pint sleeve. Lager looking golden body with very little head. The bottle label asked for the beer to be served chilled, unusual for a British ale, I chilled it as requested. Saaz hops dominated the smell, some cereal odours too (barley and wheat used in the brew). The taste had a sharp hop bitterness with no malt content showing throughout the pint in smell or flavour. A true summery beer, not really my sort, but OK if you like light bodied ales that lean more towards hops than malts.
Pale gold, cold and fizzy with hints of diacetyl. Having said that, it was very drinkable and I quite liked it.

0.5 l bottle, thanks hanniku! Golden color. Resiny, citric and peppery hop aroma. Dry fruity taste with citrus, pine resins, pepper, minerals, medium bitterness and some fruity tartness. Light body, minerals in palate. Easy light beer.

500 ml bottle. BBE 30.12.2011. Pours a clear yellow colour with a large white head. Looks like a pils really. Aroma of hay, honey and grainy malts. Flavour of grainy malts, honey, light hops, hay and some cardboard-like notes. Light bodied, slick mouthfeel and a light, sweet, bitter finish. Some unpleasant cardboard notes in the finish too. Rather boring for a Golden Ale. This is more of a pils.
Pours clear golden with a medium head. Aroma is malts and honey. Flavor is mostly malts with hints of hops and honey. Decent.
500ml bottle. Pours light gold with a medium head. Aroma is subtle, floral and grassy hops. Taste is floral and grassy with some gassy hints.

Draft on tap at the brewpub (Lombard, IL). Pours a nice golden yellow hue, decent murky haze but bright, a frothy white head that dies to a thicker film, laces lightly. Aromas are a light cereal wheat, touch of pear and banana, coriander, faint spicing, mellow cereal wheat, flaked white wheat. Initial is light wheaty cereal grains, a touch of orange and banana, bready, touch of sweetness, mellow flaked white wheat, light coriander mellows it out. A fairly light wit that has lost it’s identity. It’s mellow, and it’s fruit base is a bit questionable. Not bad, a bit lost on me though.

Growler at Chris´grill party. Pours a hazy dark yellow with a small white head. Medium sweetness. Light malt aromas. Grassy hopsnotes with hints of dough and Belgian yeast esters. Also hints of banana. Medium bodied. Medium carbonation.

Sampler glass at Yorktown. The color was a hazy straw tone with a foamy, white head and good, sticky lacing. The aroma was light notes of malt, grain, ripe apple, spice, and slight hints of lemon zest and caramel. The flavor mimicked the nose resulting in an altogether very light and sessionable brew.

Draft at RBY. Pours cloudy yellow with a fizzy head. Nose is phenolic, bananas and cloves. A touch spicy, but it’s really missing out with the citric qualities that are usually in these beers. Too fizzy as well, which makes the body seem thin. I guess I was expecting more coriander (which does finally come out near the end) and a creamier body. Not one of my favorite wits...
on tap at RB Yorktown. pours light golden with white head. aroma of sweet biscuit, orange, yeasty. flavor is a bit yeasty, spice, and orange peel. not a bad wit.

On tap at RB – Yorktown. Poured hazy lighter golden with a tall, fluffy cap of white head. The aroma picked up sweet and dusty banana and lighter bubblegum with some vegetal undertones.. sweet overall and OK. The flavor had tangy wheat with grainy bananas and lighter fruity sweetness.. pepper and clovey spices at the back.. OK components, but very drinkable. Lighter-bodied with creamy, thick carbonation on the palate.. a bit too effervescent for my liking.

Poursfaintly hazy golden with a thin creamy lacing white head. Aroma is citrus and clove quite rich with a bubblegum notes. A bit biting in the finish medium bodied, hints of clove and bubblegum in the flavor. Nice.

Pours a hazy yellow with a thin white head. Smell has a little bubblegum and citrus to it. Easily drinkable wit. Has a little bit of spice to it, citrus, and it is refreshing. I didn’t sense any of the plum/berry flavors in the description.
Pour is very hazy dark yellow with a thin white head...smell is spicy with coriander and clove and quite sweet...taste is sweet and toasty with a nice lightly spicy finish...well done!

Even served in an unfrosted mug, this beer was way too cold to begin with. It’s body is a cloudy yellow/gold and it’s topped by a modest, fizzy white head. The aroma (once it warmed) was wheaty with soft malt and a citric twist. Even warmer, a touch of bubblegum joins the fray. The mouthfeel is a touch more harsh than is usual with this style. It tastes of wheat flakes, bubblegum, lemongrass, and a soapy spiciness. Refreshing. An interesting interpretation of the style. Rock Bottom Yorktown, Lombard, IL

Cask at Moran’s. Pours lightly hazy orange with a medium, creamy white head, short retention with good lacing. Aroma is toast and grain malt, earthy hops and apple esters. Flavor is malt forward with light hops and medium bitterness and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Cask Handpump at the Black Horse, Darwen 29/05/2004 Golden coloured fruity and hoppy with a little sourness. A dry malt finish.

Cask conditioned at The Case is Altered, Five Ways, Warks. Yellow gold with white head. Thinnish, malty light bitter, a little tinny and astringent. Sharp dry malt but with little hop character, some toffee, butterscotch. Acceptable.
cask @ Lygon Arms, Chipping Campden, England. Pale yellow, decent lacing, smaller white head, dry floral hops with sweet malt finish

Cask gravity @ Reading Beer Festival 2008. Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a small, virtually none appearance, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, caramel, toffee, moderate buttery. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. (030508)
A Mes rate: Gravicask at Reading Beer Festival. Clean gold with a thin bubbly white head. Nasty, fatty and oily. Full of diacetyl and bacon fat. Not good at all.
Straw with a short head. Not much scent, just slightly citrus. Thin, sweet and flat. Some caramel in the mouth, but it doesn’t last.

Cask conditioned at the Bag O’Nails, Bristol 27/6/07. A pale copper bitter with a slight white head. Aroma was of floral hops with some grainy malt. Flavour started with biscuity malt before a hoppy finish kicked in. Good.
Bottle. Pours amber brown with an off white head. Sweet toffee malts, moderate oxidation, some earthy notes, and a sweet toffee finish. Not horrible for how old it is.

Pours a solid brown with beautiful ruby highlights when held to the light. Large creamy/bubbly off-white head made this difficult to pour. This beer is over carbonated. Smells of citrus hops, some chocolate and some roast. Taste follows the smell. Nice subtle malty roasty taste with some hops mixed in and a lingering chocolate in the aftertaste. Medium body, thin mouthfeel. This isn’t a bad brew, and were it not over carbonated it would have been a tasty almost sessionable brew. I suppose I should have tried this one fresher too.

A: The pour is incredibly light for a porter. Seems like a dark amber color with a big khaki head and a lot of carbonation. S: Very fruity, almost like cherries. I get a strange woody note out of the nose. Still some roasted malt there, which is one of the few indications of this being a porter. Also seems to be a bit of cough syrup. T: The cherries and cough syrup are picked up right away on the palate. That woodiness is there again, which I can’t quite figure out. Maybe some grapes, too, and a mild roasted malt character. M: Medium in body with a moderate to high level of carbonation. D: Eh, sort of what you would expect from a 3-4 year old porter. Hopefully not too many people are really holding on to these anymore.

Bottled. A hazy deep red beer with a lazing tan head. The aroma has notes of malt and citrusy as well as dusty hops. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and both citrusy and dusty hops, as well as light notes of prunes.
Dark brown with a huge beige head. Herbal aroma with roasted malt and caramel notes. Flavour was sweet with roasted malt, caramel, chocolate and bourbon notes.

This is explosively carbonated; a reasonable pour yields me five-fingers of lightly browned, dark tan colored head in my 25cl tulip glass. The beer is a dark brown / concentrated amber color that shows a brilliantly clear, deep red-plum color when held up to the light. The aroma smells a touch musty, with the beginnings of a phenolic, almost Brettanomyces like influence. Touches of acetone, and an light note of artificial fruitiness are also found here in the nose. A touch of fruity, vegetal roast grain notes as well as some nutty toasted malt aromas and a smooth browned malt character. The fruitiness also reminds me of tart berries and perhaps even some pomegranate like notes. Definitely an interesting nose on this beer, I am not quite sure what to think of it. Up front this beer is lightly sweet tasting with a touch of roastiness to balance things out. Browned bread crust flavors and a nice toasted grain character are also found before some fake fruitiness and acetone notes kick in. The finish has a bit of bitter, burnt vegetal notes as well as a hop bitterness. There is also a touch of lightly roasted coffee character in the finish. The “off” flavors are not nearly as noticeable in the flavor as they were in the nose, but still do influence the character of this brew. The body is light, though not quite watery, and has likely been reduced by the infection that has taken hold (the excess carbonation had to come from somewhere), but is still retains a nice quaffable quality. This has definitely turned south and clearly some low grade infection has taken hold here. The beer is not undrinkable yet, but I would definitely recommend drinking all you have on hand at this point. If this had not been infected it would have easily been able to stand up to the two years of bottle age. I am ranking this one at the average, as it is clearly past its best by date, but if rated as is I would put it at a 2.6 (4/3/5/3/11)
Poured watery black with a brown head. Aroma of chocolate and caramel. Light chocolate and caramel flavor. Easy drinker.
Bottle. Pours an brune body with a a tan head. Some toasted malt, and dark fruity esters. Light body with a light roastiness to boot. Mild and bitter with a thin body.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of Miver. Clear orangey brown with a tall, firm and lively shaving foam style beige head leaving some lacework. Spicy, roasted malt aroma. Medium body with hard roasted malts, lightly burned accents and a dry, lightly bitter finish. 010209

From bottle, blindtasting #6. Pours hazy and golden deep amber to brown with huge tan and slowly collapsing head. Dry malty and slight hoppy, vague yeasty note. Sweet malty, slight metallic touch. Light spice note and roasted caramel malt base. Ends with a light bitterness.
On tap at Aiken Brewing Co. Pours a hazy copper color with white head. Light citrus hoppy aroma. Bitter, citrus, grassy, hoppy, light caramel flavors. Alright, but a little stale.
Draft at the pub. Dark murky orange with a thin off white head. Scent is sweet caramel. Taste is the same with a light bitter finish.

8.5% ABV. The aroma was caramel citrus and a strong presence of alcohol. The aroma was fruity and a bit phenolic. Caramel, biscuit and toast were present along with a very strong presence of acetaldehyde (fresh cut green apple). The beer arrived lightly hazy deep golden amber with a tall beige long lasting head which laced the glass. The flavor was fruity with a strong citrusy presence and an extra strong acetaldehyde character. The finish was dry with lasting strong green apple far too long and awfully into the aftertaste. The body was medium-full with a moderate level of carbonation and a creamy texture on the palate. The alcohol warming post consumption was substantial. A beer to surely be skipped! Pint at Aiken.

Draft. Dark brown-copper with a creamy and lasting head. Aroma is earthy fruit - cantaloupe maybe - and some caramel malt. Flavor is big malt with a great cantaloupe-fruity-earthy hop balance, and some alcohol. Medium bodied and alcohol tingly; would make a nice warmer. Unique and tasty.

Draught. Pours stark red with a tan head. The aroma is quite tame for the style with minimal bitterness. Similar to their English IPA, I get mostly malts on this one. Strong hints of fruit and bread are there but also hints of grapefruit and pine. The mouthfeel is slick with heavy suggestions of sweet, dried fruits. It’s a very malty IIPA with hops as a backdrop, considering the style boundaries. However, the nuances in this are many: melons, grass, grapes, berries, rye. I’m glad to see something like this brewed in South Carolina finally. It’s a good start after raising the 6% cap.

Tap. Strong caramel malt and citrus hops aroma. Dark amber color with small head. Sweet caramel malt masterfully blended with a strong sweet orange-pineapple hops flavor. Full bodied with alcohol level not apparent. Given it’s only been legal to brew a strong beer like this in SC for about 2 months, Aiken BC didn’t waste any time and did a great job to boot. A great beer.

Pours a deep reddish brown on tap with thin tan head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of dark fruits, sugar, and sweet malts, almost as if its with ale yeast and not lager. Taste follows, a little thin and sugary, but not bad for what it is. Definitely one of the better beers I had while there.
Draft at source. Red mahogany. Minimal aroma. Thin. Sugary (molasses ). Mediocre. Basically, take Michelob Amber bock and add sugar

Growler at the pub. A clear deep dark red/brown beer with a thin off white head. Scent is malts, caramel and a hint of sugar. Taste is sweet malts, caramel and a hint of nuts. Think I will take another growler home!

Growler. Pours dark reddish brown with light tan head. Aromas of toasted malts, molasses and some smoke. Sweet caramel malt flavor, cherries and a light amount of smoke. Medium to full body with mild carbonation.

Dark brown pour with hints of red. Creamy tan head and lace. Brown sugar and a hint of peat on the nose. Brown sugar, caramel, a hint of metallic cherries and some abv. Medium bodied and light carbonation.

on tap-pours a light tan head that laces and mahogany color. Aroma is sweet medium malt-brown sugar, peat. Taste is sweet medium malt-brown sugar/caramel, peat, fruit, some hops with a hint of metallic.
Dark ruby brown. Tart, rotten fruit and cola nose. Earthy, with some molasses but again it’s a little long in the long maybe.

Deep dark warm brown with tan head. Aroma is chocolate, cocoa, earthy. Soft mouthfeel. A little sourness ruins the palate but otherwise is a nice beer. Maybe it was past its prime. Still, the nice sweet chocolate-cherry malt flavors. A good effort.

Tap. Strong apple/cherry caramel malt aroma with just a hint of astringency. Red-brown color with minimal head. Caramel cherry malt flavor with a very light astringent finish. A great malty aroma and finish. Usually one doppelbock is enough for a night but this one is so drinkable I could drink it all night.. Great stuff.

Name: Liberator Dopple Bock Date: 11/19/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub very dark clear red, short lived fine beige head, too viscous to lace, sweet dark caramel malt aroma, big body, rich sweet dark caramel flavor, light earthy bitterness offers just a touch of balance, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **+/4

Aus der Flasche im 2018-10 getrunken. Oj ja das ist klar ein IPA wo leider über die Jahre der Flaschenlagerung nur ein Hauch von Citrusaromen übrig geblieben ist und nur die sehr domminierde Hopfenbitterkeit bestimmt mir dieses Ale zu sehr.
Draft at Bru Craft. Cloudy orange amber pour with white foam. Lots of lace. Malty grassy DIPA. Mandarins. Dandelions. Peppers. Smoke. Big stuff.

Really intense hoppy brew. But balanced nicely by the caramel malts. Pours an orange\brown. I did smell the hops from a mile away. Big caramel aromas, resin too. Meaty. They don't make a lot of ipas like this anymore. Nice.
I hate that I am forced to write a comment, when all I want to do is rate the beer for my own reference. What happened to not having to integrate with ratebeer.com? ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
caramel, bread, hay, nuts, toast, roasty, rosemary, resin, smoke, amber, cloudy, minimal head, medium bitterness, medium sourness, full body, average carbonation, bitter, long finish,
22oz bottle from tavour. Pours a dark amber color. Really a malt bomb here. The hops and are pretty much equally at play. Aggressive dice and on point.

22 ounce bottle. Pours a deep Amber orange color topped by medium sized frothy beige cap with nice lacing. Caramel malt and pine needle hop nose. First sip follows the nose. Sweet caramel malt is balanced by the big piney hoppiness. Notes of black pepper, biitter citrus peel and alcohol finish this DIPA nicely. Very drinkable.

Sweet grain malts, caramel, molasses, overripe tropical fruits, mango, passion fruit, papaya, some sweet orange. Hazy, dark gold, medium, creamy, off-white head. Medium sweet. More overripe tropical fruits, mango, bitter orange, resin and pine, bitterness intensifies, dry finish, soft carnation, medium bodied. Very nice IIPA, great resinous, tropical fruits in aroma. Bottle from Discount Liquor, Milwaukee.

22oz bottle. Birthday Beer! Pours a clear amber with a nice sticky head of mixed bubbles and cream. Plenty of lacing. Aroma is beautiful malt and sticky hops. Of course the alcohol is high and the hops are plentiful, but Hoppin Frog brings these components together seamlessly and with artistry. The malts are sweet, chewy, delicious, and clean. The hops are sticky and bitter. The alcohol is present but an after-thought that doesn’t impede the enjoyment in any way. Excellent.
22oz bottle pours a pale reddy brown color with a bit of head. Total malt bomb with great balance on the sweetness and hop balance. Some fruity hop flavors.

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle poured into a glass. Clear golden with big white head. Aroma is herbal hops, medium body, medium carbonation, and some lacing. Taste is floral hops, some herbal hops, a little dill, and slightly bitter finish.
Lemongrass and lillies aroma. Clear golden, medium head. New plastic, lemongrass. Medium body, easy carbonation. Refreshing.

Bottle undated though a just out summer seasonal so assumed quite fresh. Stemless wine glass. ABV listed on bottle as 5.8%. A: Poured a small white head atop clear medium gold body. Head fell to film quickly despite large bubbles. S: Sweet caramel malt scent with some light citrus. T: Tart and bitter grapefruit with pith and zest. Baked white bread and a hint of wheat in the background. Nice fresh hop flavors. M: Slick and grainy mouthfeel. Light bodied and dry with subtle carbonation and a clean finish. O: Pretty good mild IPA if you’re into that. Not sure it’s worth buying regularly at $11/6 but it is solid and worth a try at least.

DATE: June 19, 2016... At my second Father’s Day at the Draught House--forty beers on tap and a free dinner! Can’t beat that... drinking from a Miller Lite pint... starts with a frothy, crater-like off-white head that settles to a thin film... clear, golden body--but does NOT look filtered... faint pepper and banana, with some malty biscuit... strong rye suggestions, with aromatic flowery aromas providing some .. the flavor is pepper and biscuit, with lemony hops and Saaz-like pilsener, both of which are softened by the wheat... medium-bodied, with a refreshing, lighthearted passage to the throat, but no staying power here... pairing well with the bourbon pepper steak I ordered, though a bit light for the task... as a kickstarter for my Father’s Day, a winner... a beer that could be sessioned, but not as bright as promised...

Bottled on 04212016. Clear golden with a medium white head. Aroma has hints of Sorachi Ace hops. Flavor has a fair amount of hop flavor left and ends bitter. Well balanced but lacks the fresh hop flavor.

Draft at Bru Craft. Poured a very hazy bright yellow gold with just a touch of white foam that reduced to a tiny ring. No lace. The nondescript hops effortlessly dissappear into the full blonde pale malts. Gently sweet tropical fruit flavors. Pineapple. Papaya. Orange passionfruit. Clementine. Guava. Coconut milk. Plantain. Honeycomb. Stray hints of summer tomato vines and dill. Something nice to sip by the seaside.

The label says- IPA . And it feels more like an IPA than a wheat ale. Hazy , golden color. Medium-sized , white head. Hoppy , citrus notes dominate in aroma . Hops and some acidity in taste . Decent beer.

Six pack from Julio’s. Bottle says "Sun Block IPA". Website says this is a new and improved recipe. Pours out a slightly hazy light golden color. Lacy off white head. Dry earthy hop bitterness. Very little citrus. Somewhat muddled hop profile. Sticky finish.
Draught @ Fools Gold. Dominted by sorachi ace like dill notes and wheat. Soft mouthfeel.

Pours light orange with a half finger white head with pretty nice lacing. Aroma is of citrus, wheat bready, floral hops, some tropical fruits,and some faint coconut. Taste is pretty similar to the aroma. Has a medium body with a slightly watery mouthfeell and a semi bitter, medium finish. Overall, a decently tasty wheat ale that definitely has a summery vibe to it.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: 2008 GABF. Mostly clear amber brown. Grainy with hint of alcohol. Touch of fruitiness. Quite Nice.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draft at brewpub. Amber in color. Spiced yeasty flavors. Good smooth flavors. Nice refreshing weizenbock.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draft at brewery on the way up to GABF. Pretty dark, with a really big head. Aromas of banana. Flavors of banana and maltiness and some wheat. Sopme alcohol on the finish. Pretty tasty.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: 20 oct 07, Draft at Brewpub. Seasonal Beer. Full Pint. Very dark brown/black. Off white head. Super sweet aroma. Nuts, bananas, malts, candi sugar, BUBBLEGUM!!! Flavors of bananas, sweet cane sugar. Very light bitterness. Very chewy with a sticky glass feel. Heavy bodied. Heavy alcohol.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Half-pint sampler tray, current seasonal "strong beer" selection (that is what the sign says). Cloudy dark brown with an almond coloured head generating fine lace. Big aromas of banana and brown sugar, some bubblegum even. Rich brown sugar/caramel and banana flavour, faintly spicey, sweet but not cloying, very smooth with a warming alcoholic finish. I was very happily surprised-- this was excellent!

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Bonus sample. Big head on a very dark brown beer. Strong banana aroma that always seems surprising from a beer this dark. Chocolate scents as well. Great body. Chocolate and banana with some rubbery notes or texture. Some coffee in the finish.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: On tap at Triple 7, poured a brownish color with burgundy edges, off-colored tannish-light brown head. Lacing was excellent. Aroma was nice bananas and yeast, some clovey spices after some warming. The flavor was caramel, bananas, molasses, gentle roast (some ash aspects with higher temperatures), only light spicing (cloves faint even w/ higher temperature). Weak on phenolic / spice character, otherwise a very nice weizenbock, one that surely exceeded my expectations. Mouthfeel was a little sticky, full, appropriate for the style.
On Holiday gold blond-colored body with a white head and with a herby hops aroma a herby hop watery taste with a slight bitter finish
Light fruity aroma. Clear golden colour with good head. Nice fruity flavor with caramel finish. Medium body with very low carbonation.
Bottle. Cloudy, golden, minimal head, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lively, & light body.

Bottle 375 ml from TRC Bottleshop, Launceston, Tas. Sampled on August 6, 2013. Clear golden color, white head. Sweet, malty, sugary scent. Malty, grainy taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Grainy aftertaste.

Pours a light golden color with a decent head that fades to some lacing. Mild aroma of citrus with some malt sweetness and grain. Taste of mild citrus,with bit of malt sweetness and grain. Pretty bland. Just a bit of bitterness and clean finish. Light body, fairly smooth but boring. Another bland Pale Lager in an ocean of lagers.

Poured a clear light amber colour with a one-finger white foamy head that laced OK. Moderate to high carbonation. Aroma of sweet hops. Taste initially slightly sweet followed by very little bitterness. Light body. Dry bland finish.
Bottled at SYD. A golden beer with a white head. The aroma has notes of straw and malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of brewing cereal, and hay, leading to a dry finish. Boring.
Bottle- A very ordinary beer. Better than most mainstream low carb beers, but still nothing special

Pours dark amber with a large, suddy, fading head. Nose shows floral hops, sweet vegetal notes and little else. Faint caramel. Similar overly sweet flavours, more vegetal notes dominating and big corn notes. Very little bitterness. Cloying. Could use more carbonation to help dry things out a bite. Very watery.

Tap at Retreat in Melbourne. Pour is typical macro: wildly fizzy yellow to straw with a detergent, white head. Pretty good suddy lace. Aroma is air freshener, maize, detergent. Taste is less soapy than Pure Blonde with some attempt at malty fullness. Still a wildy suddy, watery, soapy palate that seems the norm with Australian macro lager. Nothing offensive here.

2L plastic bottle pours a pale golden color into glass with 2 fingers of white head that settled almost immediately leaving almost no lacing. Aroma is light cereal grains and some hops. Taste is moderate hoppy bitterness which is not very desirable and hints of grainy malt. Typical macro brewed lager.

341ml bottle. Pours as pale as I’ve seen with a loud soda pop head thats gone in a blink. First beer I’ve had that has a sound to it in addition to everything else. It sounds the same as the sound you hear from inside your mouth after you’ve downed a hand full of pop-rocks. well anywho. Smells awful, tastes like water with puke in it. Stomach acids and everything. Horrible.

Bottle shared with GregClow, Jerc, and Blankboy, Greg’s bottle. Harsh, harsh aroma. Harsh grainy taste. Lighter than piss yellow. Awful. Honestly the worst thing I have had in quite some time and my first 0.5 in a long time. I just couldn’t find one thing here worth a point. Fort Garry, you should be embarrassed.

Bottle (12oz) shared with GregClow, jerc & tupalev -- courtesy of GregClow. Pours a clear incredibly light pale yellow with absolutely no head. Aroma’s sweet, grainy, vegetal and bready -- odd and stale smelling. Flavour’s a sweet, grainy, citrusy, bready mess -- it’s just all wrong -- and incredibly watery too! Light bodied. Just frickin’ awful!

Bottle via trade with piscator34 - shared with jerc, blankboy and tupalev. Very pale yellow with no head. Aroma and flavour of wet grain and stale canned vegetables. Some faint sour white wine notes in the flavour as well. Body is thin and spritzy. Finish is (thankfully) abrupt with no aftertaste. This is some nasty shit right here.

Bottle. Pours a pale yellow body with a small and fast fading white head. Bizarre fruity and grainy aroma has unexpected notes of white grapes. Rough astringent grainy flavour, light wacky fruit notes. Average to thin palate. WTF? Did not finish. 2/3/2-3/2/2-3

Bottle courtesy of Piscator34: Poured a super pale yellow color beer with a very small bubbly white head with no retention and lacing. Aroma of very weak malt with some lemony notes which are just plain weird. Taste is reminiscent of a wine spritzer more then a beer with almost no malt or hops distinguishable. Total drain pour and one of the worst beers I have had the chance of trying recently.

Very pale yellow in colour with spritzy carbonation. Faint lemon aroma, with nuances of pilsner malt, cookie dough, and the slightest bit of spicy hops. Very watery body, with a dry citric finish. Not much to speak of in the way of flavor; it’s vaguely grainy, with a bit more of that lemon element showing up too. Verging into "near-beer" territory with this one. I am not impressed.
Draft. Slightly hazy golden yellow. Aroma of lightly prppery straw. Taste us spiced sweet straw. Not bad.
Draft notes from Collegeville. Hazy gold pour with off-white head. Notes of malt, yeasty funk, hopcitrus, and spices in the nose. Not terribly complex in the flavor, like a yeasty pale ale.

Draft at the brewpub in Gettysburg. Pours extremely clear copper with a thin white head. Tastes sweet, syrupy, like caramel, honey. Dry finish. Medium body and low carbonation. Smells like sweet toffee, caramel, and syrup.

Tap at Gettysburg brewpub. Pours very clear bright gold with fizzy white head. Aroma is bready and toasted malts, candy sugar, floral hops, Belgian yeast, and light spice. Flavor is chewy bready malts, light toffee, candy sugar, light hop bitterness, and faint spice; mostly dry but some balancing sweetness throughout. Medium body and carbonation.

Tap at Appalachian Collegeville, 29/11/13. Listed as Trippel. Lightly hazed golden with a decent off white head. Nose is thin for the style, toffee, sugars, ginger notes. Taste comprises caramel, ginger snap biscuit, lemon rind, light booze, spice. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, dry closure with light boozey notes. Mediocre tripel, lacks depth, pretty boring.

Tap. Pours clear gold with a medium, creamy white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is candi sugar, Pils malt with spicy hops and pear esters. Flavor is malt dominant with light hops and bitterness, heavy sugars and fruity esters with a dry finish. Full body and medium carbonation.

Draught at Harrisburg location. Hazy, rich gold with healthy white head. Smells of moderate banana and spiciness. Flavor is predominantly phenolic, with banana and slight lemon underneath. Bitterness blends with higher alcohols and phenolics to make one distinct flavor. Yummy, but I would agree with the assessment that it is on the harsh end. I’d like to see more fruitiness from the yeast in here and less of that phenolic flavor. It reminds me of modeling glue.

Draught at the Camp Hill location. Pours orange-gold with small tight white head. The aroma is yeasty with some lemon, pepper, banana, and cookie notes. The flavor is bready with some raw grain notes, a slightly harsh spiciness, plenty of yeast, and a very dry finish. Pretty good, but it lacks the subtlety of a truly well made tripel.

Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a tiny white head. Again, very sweet aroma, yeasty, reminiscent of La Fin du Monde. Average tripel body (fyi not a fan of the style, give me a dubbel any day), a light Belgian with an alcoholic kick. Meh.
i thought this was really good. nice thick syrupy body. BIt of a sweet candi aroma, has kinda a honey sweet taste a little bit of candi and maybe an element of spice to it. Very nice brew.

column1: Three Floyds Fantabulous Resplendence (X Anniversary Ale)
column5: From a bomber, vintage 2007. Pours a cloudy apricot with scant off white head. Malty aroma. Flavors are oxidized hops with plenty of bitterness. Clearly this one has not aged well.

column1: Three Floyds Fantabulous Resplendence (X Anniversary Ale)
column5: Bomber. Well I shouldn’t set my expectations too high for an 8 year old hoppy beer. Dark copper pour. The second half of the bottle was a brown sewer water. Lots of alcohol smell, thought that would go down. Some caramel. Reminded me of an old ale, but not really a good one. Dumped most of it. At least the bottle is bad ass.

column1: Three Floyds Fantabulous Resplendence (X Anniversary Ale)
column5: Bootle split with Adnielsen. Pours murky orange with a thin white head. Aroma of citrus and booze with a bit of oxidization. Taste is citrus, big sweet malts, caramel. Thick and creamy mouthfeel. Sticky sweet finish.

column1: Three Floyds Fantabulous Resplendence (X Anniversary Ale)
column5: Bottle offered @ my parent’s basement thanks to RABinCO. Thanks ! Pours a murky orangish brown appearance with a light brown head. Quite a bit of caramel, toasted malts, and caramel with some dull herbal hops. Twangy fruity flavor with some spice, toffee, and cardboard. Surely past it’s prime but kind of fun to try.

column1: Three Floyds Fantabulous Resplendence (X Anniversary Ale)
column5: 22oz. bottle pours a murky orange with golden hues rounding the edges. Surprisingly, there was a small off-white head that managed to settle as a nice cap. Aromas were quite pleasant with pineapple and mango leading the way into a noticeable grain bill. Very faint wafts of alcohol, but pretty aromatic for it’s age. Taste is similar to the nose. Hints of pineapple juice, guava, mango and a thick caramel molasses sweetness and texture. Carbonation was pretty moderate, but far from flat. Some nice cereal notes along with a slight spice/pine come through in the backend and only a slight hint of alcohol. A very warming finish. Very surprised at how well this beer has held up! My expectations were pretty low heading into this, but was pleasantly surprised at what I found.

column1: Three Floyds Fantabulous Resplendence (X Anniversary Ale)
column5: Pours a hazy orange with an eggshell head. Taste is semi sweet. Pretty mellow now. Still pretty good.

column1: Three Floyds Fantabulous Resplendence (X Anniversary Ale)
column5: Pours a cloudy dark copper color with amber edges and a one finger off-white head that quickly settles into a lasting ring. Sporadic streaks and spots of lacing left behind. Slightly herbal and surprisingly hop forward aroma with resinous, grassy pine needle along with leathery malt, sweet booze and dark fruit notes. Slightly earthy with a floral, grassy hop presence followed by leathery malt, caramel, toffee, fig, raisin and alcohol. On the fuller end of medium bodied with a balance of dry, earthy hops, leathery malt and dark fruit. The hop presence is still pretty strong but it’s a bit stale with prominent resinous bitterness that lingers over the sweeter notes into a bone dry finish. This is countered mid-palate by earthy, leathery malt and dark fruit sweetness. Hints of plum, raisin and fig followed by some sweet, boozy heat. Slight warmth in the finish but the high ABV is relatively well masked.

column1: Three Floyds Fantabulous Resplendence (X Anniversary Ale)
column5: 22 oz. bottle from alexsdad06- thanks again, Brad! Pours a mostly clear amber color with a small off-white head. Aroma of caramel malts, pine, honey, brown sugar, and herbs; resinous, almost hints of some hop character after all this time. Flavor of caramel, rye-like spice, pine resin, wood, and mixed tropical fruits. Light-medium bodied, with low carbonation and a sweet, resinous mouthfeel. Not bad.

column1: Three Floyds Fantabulous Resplendence (X Anniversary Ale)
column5: 22 oz bomber. Cloudy with not much head. A little old, some sweet malts but low hop aroma. Slight sourness (oxidation?) Sweet malts, but really not much hop flavors, and finished with a noticeable bitterness. I don’t think I tried this beer in it’s prime. A shame.

column1: Three Floyds Fantabulous Resplendence (X Anniversary Ale)
column5: I felt a bit guilty for letting this one sit around for 3 1/2 years after bottling -- but in retrospect, I’m not sure that was such a terrible mistake. It comes off somewhere between a nicely aged American Strong and a divinely aged IIPA. Pineapple, resin instead of aged-hop cheese. Nice brown sugar caramels, extremely drinkable, just hints of the 10.5% that could easily be more like 8.

I took the twin taste test at 3 Floyds. Remus vs. Romulus A: Light yellow in color kind of cloudy. There was a medium head that died down to a small lily pad. S: Tons of nice sweet floral hops. Fresh cut grass and grapefruit. T: Nice sweetened grapefruit taste. There is some malt in there as well to balance things out. Wonderful tasting brew. I liked it slightly better than its twin brother. Remus Rules Rome. M: Nice and light. Effervescent brew.
On tap at the brewery: More fruity than the brother Romulus. Some yeast to go along with the fruit. Unfortunately a disappointment when compared to the Alpha King, Dreadnaught, etc.

On tap @ 3F for Andrews Bachelor Party. Pours similar to its twin brother, clear gold with an off white head. Carmel grains and cereal in the aroma with a light hop spice, not as pleasant as Romulus. Carmel grapefruit flavors with a lingering light and cloying bitterness. History repeats itself as Romulus kills his brother once again.

On tap @ the Brew pub: Pours a clear copper color with an off white head. Aroma, bready pale malts, some citrusy, grapefruit notes. Flavor, sweet up front, some pale malts, citrus, with some light floral notes as well. I thought it was pretty good.

orangish gold pour. Aroma is herbal somewhat fruity from the hop. Light caramel backs it, maybe a touch of bread. Not bad, but fairly boring. Not up to 3F standards, especially for an APA. You can tell they’re different, but I’m not sure how to put it into words. They are very similar.

On tap at brewpub; poured a copper/gold color. Large white head. Aroma of citrus and spice, slightly more fruity than the other version. Flavor was similar; very good tasting, liked both versions about the same. Good for the style.
on tap, pours clear golden with white head. nose has fruity hops. flavor is biscuit, hop fruity, and spiced. similar to alpha king. very tasty.

On tap at Three Floyds brewpub with Romulus. Orange with small white head, clear. Looks exactly like Romulus, but certainly does not smell. Has nice light citrus hop aroma witj nice sweetness. Pine with major cittus taste, sweet malt and grapefruit. Creamy, med-full body. Very great overall, and less bitter than romulus.

On tap at FFF, and served in a pint glass. This pale ale poured a slightly hazy golden color with a small head that quickly faded. The aroma was very faint compared to the Romulus. It consisted of some light citrus notes. The flavor was about the same as the aroma. Some very smooth, faint grapefruit and caramel, followed by a lightly bitter finish. The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with minimal carbonation. Overall, this was a decent brew, but it was overshadowed by it’s brother, Romulus.

Tap at FFF: Slightly lighter than it’s brother with a smaller head as well, very good lace still. The aroma has notes of grassy and herbal hop, lemongrass, light grapefruit and pear, very bready with a hint of butterscotch. The taste has a strange herbal quality and astringent (not fresh) bitterness with more kaffir lime undertone. Bready pale malt midsection and a dry metallic finish. The mouth feel is twangy and mouth watering but not as bright and clean as it’s twin. I preferred Romulus much more than Remus.

The second of the Roman twin challenge at 3 Floyd’s. A: A little darker than its twin brother. This beer was more golden yellow/orange in color and its also nice and clear. Pours with a nice two finger head that dies down nicely yet remains. S: Nice and floral like its big brother. Tons of citrus with grapefruit peel front and center. Big smelling brew. T: Grapefruit baby. Romulus is a bit more bitter than its sweeter brother Remus. I really like this brew, but the malty sweetness in Remus puts it slightly ahead. I liked Remus a little better making Romulus the heir to the throne. If given the chance Romulus could rule Rome. M: Medium body and Effervescent. Nice brew.
Cask Stillage at the GBBF Bar Sans Frontiers Earl’s Court, London 08/08/2007 Fruity pine aroma. Golden coloured fruity and hoppy with some dryness in a crisp and bitter lasting finish.
On tap at the brewery: Golden in color with a light head and piney hops in the nose. An herbal interpretaion with nice body and dry finish.
Cask at GBBF 2007. A hazy orange beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of grass and pine needles, and so is the flavor, leading to a bitter finish.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body: &nbsp Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 2 &nbsp &nbsp Pale Yellow(1)->Dark brown(5) : 2 &nbsp &nbsp Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 2 Head: &nbsp None(1)->Large(5) : 1 &nbsp White(1)->Tan(5) : 1 &nbsp Lasting: 2 &nbsp Lacing : 1 Aroma: Intensity : 3 &nbsp Yeast : 1 &nbsp Bread : XX &nbsp Apple : XX &nbsp Tropical Fruits : 2 &nbsp Soap : XX &nbsp DMS : XX &nbsp Diacetyl : XX Sulfur : XX &nbsp Malt : 3 &nbsp Biscuity : 2 &nbsp Hay : XX &nbsp Toasty : XX &nbsp Caramel : XX &nbsp Nuts : XX &nbsp Honey : XX &nbsp Cereals : 2 &nbsp Grainy : XX Hops : 4 &nbsp Noble(1)->American(5) : 4 &nbsp Leafy : XX &nbsp Spicy : 2 &nbsp Floral : 4 &nbsp Lemon/Lime : 2 &nbsp Grapefruit : 3 &nbsp Orange : XX &nbsp Herbal : 3 &nbsp Grassy : XX &nbsp Pine/Spruce/Resin : 4 &nbsp Notes : &nbsp Peach/Apricot : XX &nbsp Earth : XX &nbsp Mint : XX &nbsp Butterscotch : XX &nbsp Smoke : XX Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 2 &nbsp Sourness : XX &nbsp Bitterness : 4 &nbsp Complex : XX &nbsp Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 3 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 1 &nbsp Clean : XX &nbsp Sharp : 3 &nbsp Watery : XX &nbsp Oily : XX &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringent : XX &nbsp Alcohol : XX &nbsp Mineral : XX &nbsp Oxidation : XX &nbsp Metallic : XX Comments: Sharply hoppy, resiny, bitter and dry pale ale.

On tap @ 3F for Andrews Bachelor Party. Pours a clear gold yellow with an off white head. Light hop aroma carmel dough pine and a touch of grapefruit. Hoppy carmel flavors sweet pine with a sweet but clean finish. I enjoyed this one.

Cask @ GBBF 2007. Pours a hazy golden color with a small white head. Fruity, hoppy and slightly spicy aroma with lots of grapefruit. Sweet malty spicy hoppy flavor with hints of grapefruit. Malty spicy hoppy bitter finish.

(Cask at GBBF, London, 8 Aug) Pale orange colour with brief white head. Fruity, very hoppy nose with pine needles and grapefruit. Fruity, seriously hoppy taste with notes of pine needles, resin and grapefruit. Very bitter finish with a grapefruity hop character. On the sweet side. Hardly balanced, but lovely hop character.
Cask-GBBF. Hazy golden with a small white head. Grass and fruit in the aroma, lemon, pineapple, peach. Sweet and malty flavour, some fruit, and a bitter finish.

On tap @ the Brew pub: Pours a clear copper color with an off white head. Aroma, floral and grassy notes, some pale malts. Flavor, pale malts, some light sweetness, floral and grassy notes. I don’t think I’ve ever had Apollo hops isolated like this, and I’m not sure it’s one I enjoy that much.

Süffiger, mild süß-hefiger Beginn. Etwas Banane, geringe Herbe, wenig störende Trockenheit, da die milden Aromen dennoch durchkommen. Spritzig, minimal grasig, langer, trocken herb-hefiger Nachgeschmack. 9/9/11/9/8/9

"Vollbier hell" von der Gesellschaftsbrauerei Viechtach, Flasche von Bierlinie, Prenzlauer Berg. - Satt goldgelb, klar. - In der Nase dezente, eigenwillige krautige Hopfenherbe mit zitronigen Spitzen, zart toastiges helles Malz und ein Hauch von Landluft (Kuhstall), der stets etwas Besonderes verspricht. - Antrunk weich und etwas blaß hellmalzig mit zarter Münchner-Malz-Note. Sehr dezente Süße. Blasse aber elegante zitrusfruchtige Hopfenherbe, Anklänge an Pampelmusenschale. Mild rezent, fein mineralisch. Im Abgang wieder die charakterisch blasse aber hintergründige Hopfung, gefolgt von einem langen, komplexen Nachtrunk. - Sehr individuelles Bier, für ein Helles äußerst elegant gehopft, komplex aber nicht exzentrisch, unglaublich rund und süffig. Es liegen Welten zwischen einem solchen Bier und einem Allerwelts-Hellen. (28.9.2019.)

0,5 l bottle from a Hol´ Ab! market. Clear golden with a more than two finger foamy off white head. Smells grassy with some citrus. Starts with a short low bitterness, then very smooth, grain malt mix, caramel background, slick. Little bit metallic bitterness to the end. Refreshing stuff.

Herrliches Helles. Wunderbar weich, sehr süffig, merklich mild (Alliteration bis zur Schmerzgrenze). Sehr dezente Hopfung. Wohlschmeckend. Nur 4,8 % Alk, aber nicht wässrig. Ein ideales Bier für heiße Tage und den großen Durst. Positiv fällt außerdem auf, dass nicht nur Alkoholgehalt, sondern auch Stammwürze (11 %), verwendete Malze (helles & dunkles Münchner Malz, Sauermalz, Gerstenspitzmalz), verwendeter Hopfen (Perle, Tradition, Spalter Select) und der Hinweis, dass in einem offenen Bottich vergoren wird, auf dem Etikett aufgelistet werden. Bravo. So viel Transparenz und Background-Infos findet man sonst nur im Craftbeer-Bereich.

Bottle thanks to Hannes. Gold with a white, foamy head of modest duration. Buttery and grainy aroma. Taste is mildly bitter, grainy, with a touch of white bread sweetness. Medium body, mild carbonation. Another day another Helles.
50cl bottle. A clear golden beer with a small white head. Aroma of moderate sweet grainy malt, fresh hops, some cereals. Taste of moderate sweet fresh malt, grains, cereals. Good!
Bottle. Blonde. Dust, grass and a hint of orange in the aroma. Malty, floral flavor with a hint of orange. Almost medium bodied. Drinkable.

Ein Helles, wie ich es mag. In der Nase noch etwas neutral mit etwas Malz und Vanille, danach jedoch auf der Zunge angenehme Perlung, Butter, Malz und eine gute Prise Vanille. Etwas getreidig zum Schluss, dabei jedoch vanilin. Tolle Sache.
Aus der Flasche in der Brauerei getrunken. Schönes, recht vollmundigees Helles. Leicht würzig, aber mild.
Sampled at the brewpub. Fine off white head. Clear solid yellow color. Small malty aroma. Clean malty taste and a medium biterness.
50cl bottle. A clear reddish brown beer with a small beige head. Aroma of caramelized red malt and nuts. Taste of red malt, burned caramel and nuts, moderate bitterness.

Bottle 500ml. Clear light dark red amber colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, grian, light roasted. Flavour is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20120128]

It’s clear mahogany brown with a creamy, golden head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, loads of caramel, nuts, and the moderately sweet to sweet flavor has notes of roasted malt, caramel, nuts, a little cocoa and hints of licorice, and it finishes dry and slightly burnt.
Bottle. Dark amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, caramel and a little toffee. Flavour is malt, caramel, fruit, little chocolate and medium sweet.
Bottle @ Too many Geuze’s - only one toilet , Ulfborg 2012. Pours dark unclear brown with a small whit head. Bread, caramel and fruit. Medium bodied.
Reddish brown of color with a smal off white head. An aroma of caramel, appels and malt. A flavor of chocolate, sweets and prunes.
Clear reddish brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and caramel. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. 280112
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are caramel, malt, nuts and hops.

(bottle, courtesy of Quack-Duck) Clear, chestnut colour with a medium-sized, non-persistent off-white foamy head. Roasty malty, slightly nutty aroma with a faint herbal hoppy blend. Light-bitter flavour, medium to light body, smooth carbonation, soft mouthfeel. Moderately roasted malty taste with caramel and herbal accents; rather dry, moderately bitter finish with a tinge of caramel. Solid Dunkel.

bottle, bought at the brewery. Amber colour, large and creamy head, which unfortunately quickly diminuishes. Aroma of roasted malt. Malty flavours with clear hints of roasted malt, pleasant hoppy background and hoppy finish. Long-lasting aftertaste with flavours of hops and roasted malt.

Golden pour with a small white head. Sweet grain nose, mild bread, and some fruity esters. A bit of grassy hops, grain husk, and subtle floral notes. The flavor is mostly just sweet grain/malt with a touch of bread character. Some fruit esters, very subtle citrus, floral hops, and grass. A mild bitterness on the finish.
11th October 2008. GABF. Brewed with orange blossom honey but this isn’t discernable in this dry bland beer.
On tap at the brewpub; color was dark gold with not much head. Aroma of sweet malt and bread. Flavor was the same with some fruit, honey and a bit of hopping. Quite enjoyable for the style.

Tap at the brewery. Gold pour with a white head. Slightly sweet aroma. Flavor was slightly sweet as well, could really tell this was brewed with honey, had that lighter honey sweetness to it. Pretty good.
On tap at Mainstreet. Hazy honey yellow with a creamy white head. Malty sweet aroma. Honey bread taste with a crisp finish.
50cl bottle. A hazy golden beer with a mid sized most good lasting off white head. Aroma of phenols, banana, moderate sweet wheat malt. Taste of yeast, moderate sweet banana, dry clove, some phenols.
Frisch vom Hahn in Bodenmais getrunken. Trübes Goldgelb mit viel Schaum im Glas. Schöne Fruchtigkeit.

Mit McTapps geteilt und beim dilo in Bochum geholt. Vom Beginn an sehr getreidig, etwas muffig und leicht staubig. Der Geschmack ist kaum beschreibbar, eher dumpf, leicht grasig und im Abgang etwas kotzig. Nicht gut, nein.

Bottle from Dilo in Bochum. Pours out in a cloudy orange-golden colour with steady head and medium body. Aroma of yeast and wheat. Taste of old yeast, basement, hay and bread. High carbonation. Might be refreshing but the finish was too dusty and awful yeasty-sweet with floral hints that it was hard to enjoy.
Bottle. Pours cloudy yellow with decent white head that disappeared quickly. Aroma is bananas, yeast, malt, wheat. Flavor is wheat, malt, bananas.

bottle, picked up at the pilsen pivoteka. yet another drinkable hefeweizen from just across the border. lightly hazy golden with a lasting head; plenty of gunk in the bottom of the bottle; musk perfume aroma; light apple zest tartness with some bubblegum in the aftertaste
Bottled,thanks motelpogo..Hazy golden with lots of sediment and a lasting creamy head.Aroma of bubblegum banana chewy candy with flavors of coriander,clove, and lime flesh..

It’s unclear golden with a huge, creamy, white head.The aroma is mild with notes of yeast, banana and wheat - fairly "equal" amounts of each. The same is true for the sweet flavor, pleasant, easy to drink, but not challenging in any way.

Bottle 500ml. Unclear medium yellow colour with a small to average, frothy - fizzy and speaking, fair lacing, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light malty, wheat, moderate yeasty, yeast, light banana. Flavour is moderate sweet and light light bitter with a average to long duration, fruity, bubble gum, yeasy. Body is medium, texture is watery - creamy, carbonation is soft. [20111001]

Bottle @ Autumn Tasting, Ulfborg 2011. Pours cloudy golden with a small egg white head and lacings. Phenolic nose and flavor. Banana, wheat, yeast and an herbal note. Medium to thin body. A bit bland. Short end.

deep amber body with very stable, perfect lacing head, off-white, lively visible carbonation, first seems watery, but there comes very fresh bitterness, very tasty hop character, bitter, not very strong taste though, later seems mild,

From notes. Enjoyed in the company of Doug, Travis, Chris, Ryan, and Jake as part of an event we finally planned on November 15. 22 oz bottle. Thanks Ryan for this one man. Whoa. The pour is a nice dark ruby brown with a thin bit of light tan head and a couple spots of lace as it falls away. The aroma is pretty good. There is a light spicy chocolate on the front end that moves through a good maltiness and a bit of Belgian yeast. This is surprisingly complex for its age. The breadiness of the malt comes through a little more on the finish with a light oxidation. It’s not big, but it does balance well. The flavor is much of the same. The bready malts and a light spicy chocolate work well with a light yeast and a bit of oxidation. The small cardboard to this seems to balance this out well. I like this one. This is way better than I thought it would be. The mouth feel is a medium bodied and softly carbonated still with a great chocolate, spicy yeast on the finish. This one is something else, that’s for sure. Hot damn. 8 4 8 4 16

Multiple bottle samples over the years (one at the old Brassworks building where I still have an unopened bottle from, once at Jackie o’s with one of the owners of Founders, at home) from notes. Pours a slightly hazy amber/auburn color with a medium sized beige head. The aroma and flavor had sweet malts, caramel, dark fruit and berries, some earthy notes, herbal character, yeast, complex profile with the different yeast strains both showing up, definitely didn’t want to rate this years ago when I had it fresh because I didn’t feel like I had the vocabulary to describe this properly. I would like to try this once again.

Bottle: Thanks, Matt. Cloudy, ruddy copper and brown color with no real head, small beige collar. Aroma of caramel malt, stale hops, licorice, prune, some earth, a touch of cardboard. Flavor has lots of sweet, nutty hops, caramel, toffee cream, with overtones of earthy hops, light staleness, almonds, some nougat, and an alcohol finish. Medium-heavy mouth feel.

Pours thick unclear dark ruby amber with a sandy head. Aroma is sweet, a bit fruity, and contains big sweet malty barleywine notes. Flavor brings sweet lemony malty notes typical of a barleywine on a bigger body. It is not totally cutting on the palate, but still pretty big.

Bottle (2007) sampled 10/2013. One of the problems with cellaring American beer is that even if it does improve with aging, it would have to improve enormously to keep up with the pace of brewing and distribution improvement that we’ve enjoyed over the past decade. (Full Sail Black Gold, I’m looking at you!) This one is probably suffering from the same problem -- it was doubtless quite a special beer in 2007 but in 2013 we’re spoiled with an overabundance of riches. It took me a while to open this one and I may have let it go past its prime but it seemed like a bit of a special occasion beer and there aren’t that many special occasions when I’m looking for a 13% ABV American ale. Tonight’s not a special occasion either, but I thought this would nicely complement last night’s Pike Old Bawdy Wine. Pours orange-brown with gold highlights and little head into my Samichlaus snifter. Straight-ahead aged (American) barleywine nose: toffee, orange, oxidized hops. Pretty hot even after all these years, warming down the back of my throat. I don’t pick up much in the way of the spices; the flavor more or less follows directly from the aroma: quite sweet, lots of toffee, oxidized hops, never really drying out in the close. It’s an In the end it’s a tasty beer but not a particularly special one -- at 13% it better knock my socks off and this one is just enjoyable.

Bottle @ home, thanks to arminjewell. Thanks Armin! Pours a deep orangish brown appearance with a thin brown head. Somewhat oxidized, a bit boozy, chewy belgian yeast, raisin/plum, somewhat woody, spicy aroma. Big toffee, chocolate, sweet malty, mild to moderate paper/cardboard, a touch fruity flavor. Lots of malt, somewhat oxidized but overall pretty good. I didn’t really get spices in the flavor. Aged pretty well.

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, thanks Markus! Thick dark brown pour with thin white head, aroma brought notes of lots of sherry, dark fruits, lots of caramel, toffee, burnt sugars, hints of oak, slight spice notes. Taste is a nice smooth mix of lots of sherry, brandy notes, some dark fruits, toffee, hints of oak, slight spice, hints of red fruits as well, finishing sweet, dry, and full. Pretty nice at this age.

Bomber. Poured rich, deeper plumy-brown with a short, dense beige head. The aroma picked up rich, fruity malts, caramel, and molasses with accents of black pepper and oxidation.. a hair over the hill, but solid. The flavor found tangy, slightly metallic notes throughout, with dark fruit and molasses at the core.. tangy fruit skins, oxidation, and peppery notes around.. finished tangy and warm. Medium-bodied and a bit too tangy on the palate.. overall it held up well, but it was probably better a few years ago.

Bottle at RBSG. Pours with an orange to brown hued body, with medium-low clarity and a small off-white head. Aromas are sweet, nearly cloying, spicy, medium phenol, earthy. Flavors are sweet, spicy and boozy. Medium strong bitterness, warming, earthy cedar like notes, spruce, brown sugar, cola. Medium carbonation and very warming.

26th February 2011 Cloudy brown beer. Small tan head. Mellow malty nose with some fruit and chocolate. Surprisingly light palate, semi dry. Sweet dried fruits and subtle pineapple cube sweets. Aniseed spice. Subtle and mellow chocolate. Sweet peach and apricot in the finish which is semi dry. Hides the 13.0% very well. Tasty and somewhat exotic beer!

column4: Suishin Yamane Honten Shuzo Co., Ltd.
column5: has a slight yellow coloration; still body. peach and pear esters in the nose with mild perfume / flowers. moderately smooth texture with mild acid. alcohol seems masked better than other sakes of the night. mild cream / milk / rice flavor with a creamy texture. snappy bite of alcohol in the finish. enjoyable.

column4: Suishin Yamane Honten Shuzo Co., Ltd.
column5: Bottle thanks to the Sushi Bar! Pours a mostly clear color. A rich aroma of pear, grains, earthy dust, some floral component. Very dry, almost sucks out the water in your mouth. A huge flavor if old dusty pears and apples, some vanilla perhaps. Akin to a well made apple cider. Enjoyable.

column4: Suishin Yamane Honten Shuzo Co., Ltd.
column5: Bottle at home ... HUGE HUGE HUGE thanks to TimE ... My first actual Sake rating ... clear ... light jasmin nose ... clean ... intence ... light sweet ... light coconut ... and some other nuttyness ... really nice ... but what this has clearly shown is i dont have the any idea of how to describe sake... May i also say i enjoyed this all the more knowing its only had 9 ratings and all of the from RBSG07

column4: Suishin Yamane Honten Shuzo Co., Ltd.
column5: Bottle @ RBSG 07 Minneapolis: Clear, thick legs, nose of sweet plum and grape, ripe melon and very light alcohol. Subtle peach and no koji or rice notes. Super clean, no butteriness, clean, fresh and explosively tasty. A truly beautiful sake. The favor is semi-sweet, light coconut and a touch of alcohol to remind you you’re still drinking an alcoholic beverage.

column4: Suishin Yamane Honten Shuzo Co., Ltd.
column5: The only o’Sake sampled at the RBSG ’07 Grand Tasting. Supplied by BückDich, this sake pours a clear wine body with no bubbles or particles. VIscosity test (alcohol) has deep legs after spinning hte beverage. Aroma of honeydew mellons, pepper, and sweetened rice. Taste is high alcoholic, semi-sweet and a nice watermellon aftertaste.

column4: Suishin Yamane Honten Shuzo Co., Ltd.
column5: RBSG 2007 Grand Tasting - Aquafina clear and still. Nose held notes of melon, florals, and honeysuckle. Sweet honey rice flavor with ripe melon and florals form start to finish. ABV is well hidden. Thin, yet slick and smooth. Not a huge sake fan, but I know a good one when I have it. Thanks for sharing Jordan...

column4: Suishin Yamane Honten Shuzo Co., Ltd.
column5: Bottle... RBSG 07...Crystal clear and colorless. According to previous ratings, it has nice legs, but I have no idea what that means. I couldn’t find it in the RB glossary of terms so someone might want to add that one. As I was saying, it basically looks like water. My nose is pulling tons of fennel from the glass; very pleasant. The flavor is sweet and the body is light with a watery mouthfeel. Despite that sweet, watery nature, this baby totally dries out by the time I’m ready for another sip. That’s a good thing in my book, but in the world of sake? It works for me nonetheless. Overall, I enjoyed it, but not as much as previous raters. It’s fairly highly rated and probably expensive. What else can be said? Kudos to BückDich for supplying the bottle. Although I really don’t know what I just consumed, it surely furthered my experience, knowledge and expectations regarding this ancient style of brew.

column4: Suishin Yamane Honten Shuzo Co., Ltd.
column5: (RBSG07, bottle) Looks like water, but has nice legs. Aroma is medium sweet, alcohol, light plum. Taste is moderately sweet, plum, light perfume, orange. Some alcohol, but not offensive. Medium body.

column4: Suishin Yamane Honten Shuzo Co., Ltd.
column5: RBSG 2007: Bottle thanks to Jordan: Poured clear with some nice legs. Aroma, rice, some fruity notes in the back ground. Flavor, rice, fruits, some sweetness, spice, I never would have guessed it at 15%. I’m not much of a sake drinker but this was pretty solid.

column4: Suishin Yamane Honten Shuzo Co., Ltd.
column5: Sampled at the RBSG 07 Grand Tasting. Almost no color on this sake. Subtle rice scent with a smooth sweet rice taste.

Bottle from Masala. Clear golden colour, off-white head. Nose is grainy, bit of caramel. Flavour is grainy and caramel malts. Taste is fairly bitter and dry. Fairly dry and grainy finish. A bit harsh.
resin, roasty, hay, basement aromas, citrus, golden, cloudy, white foam, medium sweetness, very bitter, medium sourness, medium body, sticky, average carbonation, bitter,

It’s golden with a slightly grey he and a creamy, white head. The aroma ias mild with notes of malt, straw and a touch of celluloses. The flavor has a light sweetness and more pronounced notes of malt, flower, grass and caramel, The finish is slightly dry with caramel sweetness.

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and it’s not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog! Ins Glas hingegen ergießt sich ein wahres Prachtpils. Hohe, feinporige Krone, und eine kräftig goldgelbe Farbe mit viel CO2. Der Geruch ist primär süßhopfig, minimal herb und etwas muffig. Der Antrunk erfolgt auf jeden Fall mal sehr rezent und spritzig, ein guter Aromahopfen kommt durch. Im Abgang zeigt sich wieder der komisch muffige Beigeschmack vom Geruch., ansonsten zeigt dieser sich leicht malzig. Gelungenes Pils!

Bottled. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is grains, grass, some floral and fruity notes along with mild earthy notes. Flavour is wood, grass, some hay and quite bready malts as well. Pleasantly balanced.
Bottle. Frothy off-white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Moderate malty and light hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, butter and hops.

The bottle looks very bio-like, the beer in the glass is okay. Aroma a bit soapy in the first moment, but then intense hoppy. Starts also very hoppy, but not too dry. Flowery, a bit spicy, finish shows also notes of wood. Interesting and good pils!

Bottle 50cl. Clear light to medium yellow color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, toffee, butter. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20090321]
Bottle 50 cl. Clear golden with a white head. Distinct butter aroma. Medium body, completely dominated by buttery accents before a fairly bitter finish. 210309

column1: Main Street Brewery El Diablo Rojo
column5: 5th March 2019. Part of a four beer flight in Lamp Post Pizza and Main Street brewery, Corona (California). Red, ruby hue to the body, beige head. Malty molasses rule the nose and taste with caramel esters and flavours to the fore. Some light hop action tries to calm the beer down and almost manages too.

column1: Main Street Brewery El Diablo Rojo
column5: Amber pour with a khaki head. Sweet caramel malt, tropical fruit, pineapple, and a bit of grapefruit. There’s some pine, a hint of grass, and orange. A bit more bitter than expected on the palate. Sweet caramel, though, a bit of pineapple, and some grapefruit. Piney hop bite on the finish.

column1: Main Street Brewery El Diablo Rojo
column5: Hay red with a foamy off white head. Caramel and a big citrus hops aroma and taste with an oddly enough coco nib flavor to the finish.

column1: Main Street Brewery El Diablo Rojo
column5: Tap at brewpub. Poured a very nice dark ruby red. Nice hop nose, very well put together. Very well balanced flavor, great hop presance with a good malt backbone, very delicious.

column1: Main Street Brewery El Diablo Rojo
column5: Bought a growler of this stuff a while back. Aroma was strong citrus hops. Poured a dark red with a tannish head. Flavor was mostly hop dominated. Strong citrus, some roasty malt that is overpowered by the hop attack. Resiny on the palate. A nice strong ale. Thought I could drink the whole growler in one sitting. Not a good idea.
Light brown. The aroma is mostly sugars, very sweet palate. Dark sugars and not much else. Slight creaminess to the body but no nuance to this beer.

Canned 354ml. -My third beer from Chile. Other two (Cristal Black Lager and Austral Lager) were also cans, but they were 350ml??? Funny. Again, I’m the first European to rate this beer. Black coloured, small to medium pale brown head, strong caramel nose. Disgustingly sweet taste with touch of coffee near the end. Too sweeeeeet!!! Thanks for those 004ml, but no thanks again!!!
Pretty poor. Underattenuated. Nasty sweetness, unpleasant palate. Weird fruitiness. Between a schwarzbier and a stout I would say.

Appearance: dark brown color with reddish tones. Medium head, beige color, few dense but persistent. Aroma: toasty malty, slightly candy and cacao. Berries and figs touches. Slight smoked and hoppy. Flavor: to much sweet, candy and low bitter-toasty for a so-called stout. Artificial flavors. The fruitiness maybe similar to berries, candied fig and black raisin. Aftertaste with slight toasty (like artificial) and smoked. Palate: to much light for the beer style, medium carbonation. Not a stout, extreme sweet and artificial (chemistry), few toasty, totally unbalanced, like a pop-soda. Not advisable

Not really sure if it was a real stout, but it wasn’t that bad. Creamy persistent head. Aroma is malty with notes of coffee beans and bitter chocolate. Flavor was sweet and a little watery... also felt syrupy. I will try with the Porter.

In can, 354 ml. Has a dark brown cor, well opaque. The head is frothy (much), with a quite lasting cord. The aroma is very malty, the best thing of this beer. The flavor is very sweet, is like a burned coffee, with much sugar. This beer is extremely sweet. This is a lager, that is camouflaged with the sugar. It is a good attempt of Ale, but it is not a stout.

Can, 354 ml Pours an opaque reddish brown color. Light brown frothy head with medium retention. Solid lacing. Aroma is malty, roasted with lots of metallic hints (from the can, surely). There are notes of prunes, figs, dates and ther dark fruits. Surprisingly good for a macro. Flavor is VERY sweet, schwarzbier-like. There are notes of dark fruits, blackberries, sweetened coffee, toasted almonds, grains, honey and brown sugar. Well, not too bad but too extremely sweet for a Stout. Medium to big body, thick, syrupy texture. Medium carbonation. The finish is sticky but reveals some adjuncty flavor at last. Very sweet aftertaste. It seems more a Lager than an Ale.

Big creamy head, good lacing. Mahogany colored body with small bubbles. Aroma: mild, malty,smocked, with notes of berries and some saltyness. Flavor: very sweet and watery, some cooked potatos hints at the back of the flavor.

column4: Stonecutters Brewhouse (formerly Granite City Brew Pub)
column5: Draft at the brew pub - Poured a cloudy brown in color with a foamy light tan head. Aroma was faint of caramel malt and spicy hops. Flavor was about the same, but was not a strongly flavored beer. Has a kick to it, for sure, but the alcohol was well hidden in this decent brew. Had a couple of them and enjoyed them both...

Draft at the brewpub - Poured a very dark brown/black in color with a medium dark tan head. Some nice lacing on the glass. Aroma was intense of darkly roasted malts, espresso with hints of chocolate. Palate was quite smooth and medium thick. Flavor was strong of very dark malts and espresso. Smaller amount of dark fruits and chocolate as it warmed up. Alcohol was not present n the flavor, but you could tell that there was plenty by the time you got near the bottom of the pint. One of the better Vermont-brewed imperial stouts that I have had recently. Worth seeking out if you are close by...

on tap at the shed. Deep amber/brown pour which suprised me considering this is an IIPA, I almost thought I was poured the wrong beer. Aroma was initially of grapefruit and mango, with caramel- with a slight off note. As it warmed, rubbery phenols started to show up as well as nail polish remover. Taste was malty with a decent balance of hop character, but also had the rubbery phenols present. Even without that off character, this would be too sweet for me in terms of a IIPA.

6 ounce draught sample at the Vermont Brewer’s Fest (July 2007). Bronze-caramel body, fairly clear, light touch of head....lovely spicy, strongly pungent aroma, with strange tomato-oregano notes that actually seem to work with the resinous pine; a bit like the smell of scraped-off pizza from a wood-heated pizza oven, splashed with fresh wood and a hint of acidic citrus.....sharp and spicy body, medium-full, with a bit of tartness at the finish....unspectacular but quite drinkable and without a hint of alcohol.
Vermont Brewers Fest ’07. Pale amber with a thick white head. Slightly soapy on the hop front with light pine and grapefruit as well. Comes across a bit soapy and unbalanced. Sweet finish.

Draft at the brewpub - Poured a quite dark amber in color that had an orangish hue if you held it up to the light. Medium whitish head... no lacing. Aroma was strong of citrus and pine hopiness. Flavor was also strongly hopped with the same intense citrus/pine/grapefruit hop character. A small amount of malt was detectable and it provided some scant balance to the overwhelming hoppiness. Hops being my "thing", I really liked it, but it really needs better balance before those of the non-hop persuasion will think that it as good as I do. This is one that I would gladly find again on my next visit.

column1: Power House White River Brown Ale
column5: Draft to taster. Looks good for the style; a fairly transparent deep brown with lacing somewhere between off-white and light beige. Smells and tastes malty with notes of coffee and chocolate, and a touch of nuttiness as well. Average on the palate. A nice take on the style.

column1: Power House White River Brown Ale
column5: Draft: Nearly black, rubied, with a small tan head. Chocolate and coffee malt, aroma. Light coffee bitter, chocolate flavours. Creamy. Very nice.

column1: Power House White River Brown Ale
column5: On tap at brewpub I didn’t get much of this as the kegs was almost empty. My half pour provided a good impression however. While the Columbus Bar isn’t worth a huge detour if you are on the way to or from Indianapolis it might be worth swinging by assuming you have an hour or two to kill. Aroma / Appearance - The rich deep brown base is accented by a vanilla hued head. Half melted candy bars, almonds, and syruppy chocolate milk aren’t strong but do hold together well. Flavor / Palate - Black coffee, creamer, almonds, and then a cool soft finish please the palate. Refreshing for the most part, this is a middle of the road brown ale. Even so it might be worth sampling if you enjoy sessionable local taps.

column1: Power House White River Brown Ale
column5: Tap at brewpub. Strong chocolate and coffee malt aroma. Dark brown with large head. Sweet chocolate and coffee malt flavor with a light bitter finish. A great brown ale - excellent malt flavor.

column1: Power House White River Brown Ale
column5: Draft at brewpub. Poured a clear dark brown color with a moderate frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Medium toasted malty aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration.
