column1: Power House White River Brown Ale
column5: Pours clear, brown, with a moderate head. Flavor of chocolate malt. Very basic beer with very little hop hit. A bit of a plasticy/chlorine flavor in the finish.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Way Bad Billy Double Blond Bock
column5: From a 22-oz bottle--Poured a bright golden-amber body with a small whitish head. Lots of lacing in glass. Nose of sour lactic and grainy malts. Crisp and sweet. Couldn’t drink too much of this one. Lots of infection. Quite Belgian, but on purpose?

column1: Raccoon Lodge Way Bad Billy Double Blond Bock
column5: Bottle at Raccoon Lodge & Brewpub, Portland, OR. Small white head that mostly diminished, fair amount of lacing, transparent, fast rising carbonation, and a golden hue. Nose was malty, hoppy, sweet, and a hint of caramel. Flavor was hoppy, citrus, malty, and semi-sweet. Tingly mouthfeel and medium body. Nothing outstanding or special was observed during this rating. Not a brew that was exciting to drink as it was rather a ho-hum beer IMO.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Way Bad Billy Double Blond Bock
column5: This bottled brew from the brew pub poured a medium sized head of foamy fine to large sized white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a typically carbonated light yellow-orange colored body. The aroma was malty sweet and mild hop. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a bubbly aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of malt hops and floral. Was hard for us to finish the bottle.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Way Bad Billy Double Blond Bock
column5: Sampled on tap at the brewery during ABA Beer Tour ’07. Pours a clear golden amber brew with a a creamy white head with excellent retention. Aroma of caramel malt, flowery hops and a strong sense of sweet candy sugar. Taste is lightly carbonated, medium bodied, with a good balance of some sweet citrus hop and malt flavors. Finish has a honey smooth sweetness with a slight bitter aftertaste.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clean, clear brown-tinged orange-gold. Rim in whitish. Served with an orange slice. Pleasant citrus-tinted spice aroma. A little spring rain climbs through as hops. Flavor is a heavily carbonated, explosive orange-flavored (dammit) mild malt sugar. Minimal Belgian profile backed with a bit of mineral-like hop character, leafy. I like the higher, fresh level of hops in this version. Very juicy and resin-like. The wheat and spice character that I should get in this style, however, suffers. But, a fresh version, nonetheless.

On tap at the brewpub, Ishpeming MI. Just presented to me as a seasonal Belgian-style wheat so I couldn’t be certain whether that is the full name. Very pale straw colour, slightly hazy, with a lasting white head. Sweet, estery fruit aroma with a perfumed, cosmetic character. Slight tang of citrus on the palate (it was served with an unnecessary slice of orange) but no spice character to speak of. Clean mouthfeel. Not really to style but pleasant enough.

column1: Great Waters Not Quite Dead Red
column5: Clear amber body with beige head. Aroma is medium sweet, earthy, caramel, some spice. Taste is medium sweet, caramel, spice/earth, light peach. Light-medium body.
Good for the brown style. Hint of sour in the finish tthat works like a beauty spot. Hopcat tap takeover.good malting. Funky yeast.

Black cap......nice brown pour with a generous head. slight malt and warm aroma. A very nice slight nutty, toffee and slight hop flavor. Very drinkable. Thank good I live in a state where we have some of the best brewers and they could come up with a colaberation like this.

Black cap bottle thanks to jgd0608, thanks man! Pours a deep, muddled amber-brown color with a moderate off-white head that slowly faded to a thick layer and left a little lacing. Aroma of chocolate, some light roast, a hint of nuts, and some light hoppiness layered beneath. Smooth, lightly sweet entry with some hints of chocolate and some caramel, toasted malt, and light toffee that finishes with some soft roast and a faint hint of hops on the finish with some light coffee undertones. Moderate carbonation, smooth on the palate with a little bite. Solid brown ale.

9/26/2007 and 1/28/2008: Dark Corner Ale (black cap) pours out in a thick stream of dirty, opaque amber-brown liquid. Wow, this stuff is thick! The bubbles are held back by the heavy liquid and then create a delayed mushroom cloud that allow some bubbles to actually break the surface to create a thin, fleeting tan-colored crown! The earthy aroma contains toasted/roasted malt, coffee tending towards chocolate, and finally some hops buried deep down in there. The flavor is like coffee beans (finely ground) along with a deep fruity caramel maltiness followed up by a roasty, black coffee-like finish. There is also a bit of alcohol that seeps out in the finish. The body is medium-full and is mostly smooth, slightly sticky on the palate. My overall impression is that this is a good, solid beer. 12 fl. oz. bottles shared by Tmoney99. Thanks Tom! Rating #55 for this beer.

Bottle black cap Fall 2007. Poured a clear brown color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate toasted sweet malt and hoppy aroma. Medium body. Solid balanced toasted flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Good complex brew.

Dark brown pour, much darker than expected, light head. Some sweet malt, nut, slight red fruit in the nose. Flavor very similar, good amount of fine carbonation, a bit light bodied. Very smooth and drinkable. Reminded me of a schwarzbier more than a brown ale. This was the black capped version.

12 oz. bottle from the Beer Geek (black cap). Red tinged amber color with almost no head. Interesting aroma that resembles cola, or roasted caramel. Good smell; a bit vinous. Medium body with mild creamy carbonation. Flavor is malt, fruit, treacle, and a hint of coffee? Finish is neither dry nor sweet. The residual is reminiscent of a molasses flavored hard candy, but not all that sugary. Really pretty good drink.

Lightly hazy amber body with a small beige head. Rich, malty nose with toffee, vanilla, vienna malts and grapes. The flavor is lightly sweet, moderately bitter with nuts, raisins, plums, berry and caramel. Medium/full body is soft with light carbonation and a drying finish.

Bottle - black cap. Picked up at Wacky’s party store next to the brewery. Hazy brown color. Small tan head. No lacing. A bit of a coffee aroma. Tastes of molasses, caramel, and brown sugar. Flavors continue to come out as it warms. Dry finish. Good brown beer mouth feel. Overall enjoyed this, but agree it is thinner then most of the Dark Horse beers. Sin City is the first thing I thought of when I saw the label.

Tasted 5/10/08. 12oz bottle. Black Cap. Strong nose from a distance. Hazy brown with a slight bone white head. Aromas of dark fruit and toffee. Figgy and caramel nose. Big nose! Full bodied with big malts. Sticky body with a good dose of alcohol. Nutty and dried fruit flavors. Spicy. Warming with a good palate. Malty with fruity estery undertones. Sticky finish with mild slight hops. Maybe a touch resinous to add to the stickiness. Subtle flavors of pepper caramel and toffee. Mild vanilla note. Touch woody note. Ever so slight citrus hits the palate. A lot of flavor profiles but none of them are overt. But they are all blended wonderfully. Tart with a great complexity. Love the labeling to boot.

going old school 750 ML bottle dark brown, bordering on black color. Light tan head. Great retention for the age of the beer. Good spotty lacing. Amazed how well the head held up. nose is slightly tart, slight oxidation but do get chocolate, roasted malt, and soft banana. Same, Impressed the beer has held up pretty well. taste is chocolate, banana, cream, caramel, and touches of sourness again. One it opened up from being slightly dusty it was pretty tasty. Medium bodied, medium carbonation. Expected a train wreck but got something much better. Grade is more on how well it has held up
Dirty black head. Burnt charcaol and licorice. A bit unbalanced and random. That said was interesting.
Sweet matl hop aroma. Dark red brown colour with good head and lacing. Sweet malt chocolate flavour. Smooth palate.

Another oddball near-miss from Matilda Bay. Good on them for continuing to experiment with this sort of stuff. Can’t say I’ve been blown away by the results so far, but you have the feeling that one of these "limited releases" will be a knockout. This one looked great, dark brown with a bit whipped cream head. The head-scratching began with the aroma, which to my nose combined whipped vanilla cream pudding, natural yoghurt, grout, wheat malts and salt. Especially salt. Great creamy mouthfeel - lovely. The taste evoked lots of sweet flavours, but finished incredibly salty. (As someone smarter than me at the gathering observed, it’s almost savoury.) Sticky caramel and banana cream with a lick of salt for afters. Bizarre. No idea how old the sample is, so the above observations may or not be a feature of bottle age. (Coz’s Ashfield RB get-together 07. Thanks Bridge for this one.)

On tap at automatic, Melbourne. Pours a very deep copper brown with a fluffy, lacy tan head. Aroma of banana, chocolate, a slight wheaty tartness, toffee and apple (in a good way). Perhaps some vanilla too. The mouthful is just amazing, smooth, full, a touch sweet, roasty and herbal... goes down effortlessly. Lots of cocoa line the flavours, as well as a modest amount of dark fruity ester notes, black forest fruits perhaps. Wheaty sharpness comes through in the finish, with more dusty cocoa, cloves and a peppery hoppiness. This stuff is just great!

Deep, dark ruby body with a tight beaded light tan head. Initially the banana notes are noticeable in the aroma followed by a lot of cloves. Cloves at the front in the taste, some cocoa but not too much else. Certainly easy enough to drink just doesn’t do a lot for me

I missed out on the MB21, so here is there next reserve and like Hahn’s Millennium, this could honestly do with some ageing. Served p at just on cool, into a stumpy chalice. Looks solid in the glass. Nice deep, sparkling ruby red body with well-conditioned, minute bubble streaming up a very tight, creamy, beige pad. Laces nicely, the head holds true. Initial waft of mushrooms catches on and lingers. Some dark, gritty malts and Pumpernickel notes join in as some overly ripe bananas and butter (hey, best way to describe - it is no an awful waft by all means, just strange!). Rough, deep cocoa powder in the mouth, a light medicinal note and heaps of cloves. A hint of sherry in back and some buttered bread. This is a very strange brew. Malt driven, that much is evident, but not altogether as yet. Finish is sweet, raw and a good continuation of the palate with an even bigger depth of cloves and a good measure of fresh cracked pepper. Long and lingering, its not alarming at all and actually manages to enter that addictive ’got to drink’ area of strange. The palate is not full and it does reek of green beer, so my guess is my next rating will be much higher. In about a years time!!! (75cL, The Beer Store Morley) A very impressive bottle and label I must say!!!

Cask (handpump) at the Doric Arch, Euston on 17 February 2007. Noted at 4.1%. Amber colour with a thin white head. Not much going on in the aroma. Dry on the palate with plenty of sharp and slightly earthy hop presence. Vaguely nutty malts. Decent balance and good drinkability. Not a huge amount to it but clean, firm and not too weedy. Decent session bitter served in excellent condition.

Cask (handpump) @ The Green Lion Inn, Skeppsbron 9-11, 21120, Malmo, Sweden. Clear medium amber orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted - caramel, fruity, light hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20100313]

Cask Handpump from the Fullers Bar at the Winding Wheel, Chesterfield Beer Festival 02/02/2008 Small white head. Hoppy and slightly sweet aroma. Golden coloured and hoppy with a sweet honey flavour. A little bitterness in a crisp and dry lasting malt finish.

Cask @ Bishops Arms, Malmö. Pours a pale amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty and slightly nutty aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor with some hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.
Handpulled cask at the Wheatsheaf Ealing. Amber with a thin white head. Bland and totally uninteresting. Another pointless use of a defunct brewers name.

From cask at Charlies. Pours clear and golden orange with a small off-white head. Aroma mild fruity and slight toasted malt aroma. Flavour is medium sweet malty wth a light citrusy and vague spiced hoppy note. A bit tea like. Light fruity touch into the finish. Nice and easy.

Cask Conditioned at Bishop’s Arms, Malmö Amber color, thin head. Nice aroma, creamy caramel, lightly grassy, maybe a shadow of apples. Smooth mouthfeel, sweetish caramel with light toffee, a bit buttery, fruity. Correct bitterness, with a herbal touch at the end. Pleasant.

Cask at Bishops Arms, Malmö. Clear amber coloured with a small white head. Fruity aroma of malts, yeast and hops. Fruity flavour of malts, caramel, bread and hops with notes of pine needles. Dry hoppy finish.
Cask gravity at Bree Louise, Euston. Copper, no head. Ok bitter, some fruit salad flavour. OK condition, some biscuity malt. It’s a bitter.

The Oddfellows In The Boat, Somerhill, Staffs. Chestnut with white lace and halo. Sugary strawberry jam aroma. Quite juicy red berry, orange, jellied fruit hops and yeast, hay, grass, strawberry again. Uncomplicated but pretty tasty.

The commotion involved in the current caretakers moving house from the valley to Margeret river managed to uncover this little beast of a beer. Long lost, a single 50 litre keg sitting in the cool room lagering for many years now was on draught last weekend. It was the last beer brewed in the coppers inside the restaurant’s main sitting area. Into a chalice, served up a little too cold for liking. Produced a hazy, seasoned oak brown adorned by a sloppy, tannish head of cream that held and showed good legs. Sweet, gooey toffee and burnt caramel nose with balancing woody and damp earthy soil notes. Sugary, sweet demerara and sticky date pudding in the mouth. Quite savoury like sultanas and prunes with a good dose of those earthy notes picked up in the aroma. It leans towards a Scotch ale as it heads into the nether. Peaty, big malts in back, woody and sweet mix, again savoury and peaty in the finish with good length shown. Body is hard to judge, the residual sugars feel rough on the tongue and it is a little fizzy upfront. Alcohol doesn’t show but it could aid in balancing it out. Nice as an aperitif, but not your average quaffer. Interesting, I wonder if it will ever be brewed again!?!

on cask-pours a thin white head and yellow/gold color. Aroma is medium malt/grain, light/medium fruit-apple cider. Taste is medium malt/grain, light/medium fruit-apple cider, nail polish remover. Minimum carbonation.

Enjoyed this one on draught at the brewpub in Tacoma, WA. Pours to a beautiful, bright, golden color, with a nice, white head that fades, and a moderate amount of carbonation. The nose is very nice, with good pale and sweet malt aroma, paired with some light grassy hops, and peppery alcohol. The palate is firm, with good, crisp, pale malt flavors, on a very clean, round, body. The body is just a touch lean for the style, making this beer dangerously drinkable. This beer finishes with more good pale malt flavors up front, then ends with some good grassy hops, and some peppery alchol that lingers. All and all a nice, domestic example of maibock, from a rock solid Tacoma brewpub. Englne House #9 is well worth a stop if you find yourself in the Tacoma/Seattle, WA area.

Backlog, on draft at Capones 8-9 years ago. Pours a hazy orange color with medium to large foamy head. Notes are rye bread, lemon juice, bubblegum, spices, and malt. Medium carbonation with a dry finish.
East end brought out a 2010 keg and had it on. Pale yellow pour. Slightly cloudy. White head. Aromas of bread and pineapple sourness. Taste is tart sourness. Pretty decent stuff.

Kvass #8: A: Light orangish-yellow body... thick white cap... moderate lacing.. S: Tart sourdough bread dominates... light citrus notes.. mostly lemon and orange... T: Delicious... bready malts... sourdough loaf after sourdough loag after sourdough loaf... nice tart character... light citrus.. some bitterness M: Chewy, but light-medium body... lingering aftertaste O: Top notch kvass... I think i liked the dark kvass from EEBC slightly better... a little more subdued and slightly more complex.. but this is a very good representation of the kvass and I can’t think of anyone that does it better than EEBC

Pours hazy amber with a slight fizzy head. Aroma is spicy and very saison-like. A slight metallic hint, too. Flavor is unexpected. Sorty of salty and grainy. Some nice fruity esters and maybe even some licorice. The body is light and refreshing. I’m glad I tried it, but it wasn’t something I would enjoy all the time.

Poured into my "WE BE JAZZIN’" pint glass from New Orleans. In case you were wondering, I be jazzin’ as well. This is my first encounter with the style. 4.0 A: Murky yellowish brown. One finger of frothy white head that dies down rather quickly and leaves no lacing. 4.5 S: Not surprisingly, this is bready, with plenty of rye earthy spiciness coming through. The bread yeast contribution is interesting for sure and comes off as a doughy funkiness. In a lot of ways, this smells like what it is: a beer made from bread. 4.5 T: Dominant flavor is rye bread, which again isn’t surprising. Good balance of bitterness and breadiness stemming from earthy rye. A touch of sourness on the front end, with a "dirty" doughiness on the back. 4.0 M: Medium body and slightly chewy. Super smooth throughout. This could use a bit more carbonation, but for all I know it could be perfectly to style. Still, if I made it, I’d give it another 0.5 ppm. 5.0 D: I had a hard time figuring out the scores for this brew. I like it quite a bit, but I have absolutely nothing to compare it too. Based on the other kvasses found on this site and the reviews I’ve read, I’d have to venture that this one is tops for the style. In any case, I might go through this whole growler in one sitting, that’s how smooth and drinkable this is. Serving type: growler Reviewed on: 08-07-2010 20:00:02

Thanks to MrChopin for the trade for this one. Wow, this is goddamned wierd. I was expected a dark malty bready Kvass, like so many that are imported from Russia today. This guy was in a clear growler, the color of a giant melted creamsicle. The aroma is also completely unexpected. It’s a lot like a Berliner Weiss, sour, wheat, cereal grains, light fruit, lemon. The flavor is more or less the same, sour, wheat, more lemon. The finish is sour, tart lemon, almost no hop bittering, or actually, very little of any kind of bittering. The body is on the thick side of medium. Wierd, but very interesting. I’m a big fan of traditional beers, and I am very glad I got to try this. Thanks, Kevin. Now, I begin my quest to find the Dark Kvass, or Loaf.

Looks like yellow custard and is one of the most unappealing beers I’ve gazed at, also a thin white ring. Thankfully things improve... nose of pepper and lemon, lightly funky grass, then toast and smoke. Flavor is more lemon and dark bread, metal and a bit of coriander. Sticky, lightly bitter finish, grainy flavor lingers with a touch of lemon. Insanely drinkable and flavorful, but not cohesive start-to-finish.

Draft at Capone’s. Pours an incredibly hazy and cloudy orange body with thick white lacing. Aroma is burnt, roasted bread and slight wheat. Mouthfeel is medium with a thick texture and notes of roasted malts, toasted bread, burnt spices, wheat and yeast.

A- translucent straw yellow body with thin white head. Head fades rather quickly and leaves behind little lacing in the glass. S- Light bready aroma. Herbal hints can be noted too. T- Rye bread taste up front. Bready and a bit tart with herbal flavors added. Slight bitter aftertaste. Some yeast lingers. P- Medium carbonation and light body. Very well done. O- This is quite drinkable. Its a great session beer for any time of the year. Its great to have Kvass available here in Pittsburgh. I hope the style catches on in the US. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 06-12-2007 02:56:49
Poured orange with a white head. Aroma of wheat and fruit. Good fruit flavor with lemon and bread texture in the finish. Slammable.

column1: Speciaalbierbrouwerij Oijen Dn Osche Frater Blond
column5: Bottle. Frothy white good mostly lasting head. Straw-yellow colour. Powerfull heavy hoppy aroma. Light malty. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Hard metallic notes. Oily palate. Strange but I like it.

column1: Speciaalbierbrouwerij Oijen Dn Osche Frater Blond
column5: Bottle from Bier Koning. Nice yellow colour. Healthy head. Spicy and sugary nose. Fruity flavour - pineapples, mango, orange, apple. Some peppers. A bit watery. Flat finish.

column1: Speciaalbierbrouwerij Oijen Dn Osche Frater Blond
column5: Bottle. Blonde, hazy. Yeasty aroma with apple. Thin. Apple flavor with melon, but the yeast dominates. Aftertaste is short, with some hops. Amateuristic beer.

50cl bottle bb11/14 bought at Tettnanger Bierdörfer ’14. Quality almond pale malts muddled by an inconclusive yeast, livened by soapy citrus hops, muddled again by a slightly oily palate and paper-earthy, near-dirty sulphuric finish.
Brewery tap. Pale blonde. Very light malty and citric aroma. Medium bodied. Malty, citric flavor. Just the slightest touch of flowers and soap. Short malty and soapy aftertaste. Good thirst quencher.
Backlog rating from 2007.Pale golden, low white head. Very dusty, papery malt, light glue, light body. Too old?

Old 50cl swing top bottle courtesy of Erzengel! BB 25/05/2004. Almost clear golden head with a virtually white head. Aroma of sweet grainy malt, some honey, straw. Taste of sweet grainy malt, dry hops, straw, caramel.

Vom Faß bei Düll, Gnodstadt. - Goldgelb, klar; üppige Schaumkrone. - Sehr milde Nase: helles Malz, Sahnebonbons, Waldhonig, Kräutertee. - Antrunk ausgeprägt hellmalzig aber nicht zu süß: Anklänge an Honig, Butter, zarte Säure. Erst im Abgang kräuterwürzige Hopfenherbe, die leicht an Ricola-Kräuterbonbons erinnert. Bei einer zweiten Halben aus einem frisch angestochenen Faß kam etwas fruchtige Bittere (Zitronenschale) dazu. Mild rezent, sämig-vollmundig. Unerwartet bitterer Abgang; längerer Nachtrunk. - Sehr malzbetontes, fülliges, nur mild aber aromatisch gehopftes Bier. Kein echtes Pilsner, aber mehr als trinkbar.

*Old rating, best before 25.05.04. Crate bought directly at the brewery (as they didn’t sold single bottles...). Mild-herbes, hopfig-grasiges Bier. Intensive Bittertöne, schön weicher Malzkörper. Lecker!

It’s warm yellow-golden with a creamy, lasting head. The aroma has notes of fresh grain, bread, straw and flower. The flavor has a light sweetness and notes of grain, straw, malt and flower, and the finish is fairly dry and slightly bitter.

Bottle:Pale golden, small foamy layer - stable&lacy, mineralic rural and hayish hoppy nose, some malt detectable; light to moderate sweetish-bitter flavour, light bodied and soft; slightly lingering and drier rural-bitter finish. Mild, but tasty, typical franconian brew…

(draught at the Gasthaus & bottle at home) Clear, pale golden colour with a blond and persistent foamy head. Doughy and strawy pale malty aroma with present herbal and slightly floral hops, some notes of metal in the bottled version. Mildly bitter flavour, light to medium bodied with a well-carbonated mouthfeel. Slightly buttery pale malty taste, again with present herbal and floral hoppy notes, leading into a moderately dry but still malt-accented finish with a mildly hoppy bitterness (bottled: again a bit metallic). A likeable Pilsener, although the bottled version is a bit weak. 10. & 13.XI.12

Draught at the brauhaus Blond color; generous head. Light malt aroma. Dry malt flavor, light crispness; very strong bitterness, maybe lightly biscuity, but without much hop quality. Pleasant, but not exceptional.

Kurzer herber Antrunk, direkt setzten vielschichtige Hopfenaromen ein,d ie das Bier von nun an im Griff halten. Dazu kommt eine starke unterstützende Malznote, die aber erst im Abgang mit typischen Aromen vorprescht. Übermäßig vollmundig, stark hopfig. Dieser umfasst leiche Honignoten, einen deutlichen Gerstenton und dezente, zum Ende offenkundige bittere und blumige Noten. Spitze! 9/13/10/12//12

Very good white head over metallic golden beer; shards of lace left behind. Dry-malty nose, summergrain, chaff, honey or nectar. Actually very nice. Much duller honeyish flavour, malty, but a little hop-sent dryness comes to relief. Still, unspectacular is putting it mildly. Light to medium bodied, quite slick. Durchsnittliches Pilsner , so to say. One to thank Jan for, apparently, great!
bottle, nice work mowbeer. clear amber with a fluffy head; somewhat tinny aroma, hints of red berry and caramel; some alcohol showing, tinny bitterness; simple but okay

The beer starts malty, typical for a Heller Bock. The mainpart is smooth, a bit sharper to the end. Malt, typical sweetness. The aftertaste gets a bit more bitter than expected. Fits nice in and is a great combination to the malty and slightly bitter-sweet character. The aftertaste is long, medium-dry, bitter-malty. --> Round and typical! --> 10/12/10/10

Bottle 33cl from Quack-duck, a cloudy amber beer with medium head and good lacing. Nose is caramelish, with over ripped fruits and grapes touch. Aroma is on dry and burnt caramel, nutty yeast, old apple touch, relative bitterness, finish is dry and bitter.

Bottle from Bierzwerg! Pours clear strong golden yellow, with huge, creamy white head. Smell has lots of sweet caramel, toffee and roasted malts. Starts with lovely caramel malts, paired with some toffee and slight sweet coffee notes. The middle part has also lots of caramel and toffee, again paired with sweetish coffee. Finish has roasted malts and again lots and lots of sweet caramel malts! Tastes like a micro-brewed CZ-style dark lager! I love it!!!

330ml bottle. Minimally cloudy orangey dark golden colour with average to huge, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, white head. Malty aroma with a touch of honey, hoppy overtones with a floral touch. Taste is minimally sweet caramel malty, a touch of honey, floral hoppy overtones.

Thanks to Erzengel for the bottle! Pours a clear deep gold color with a big tan head that falls away quickly. Smell is caramel, sweet fruit, Apple cider. Taste is as it tastes ending dry and a bit crisp. Medium body and a bit oily with nice subtle carbonation. A pretty nice bock..a bit sweet but I know that comes with the territory.

Thanks to quack-duck for that one. Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass brownish-copper coloured, small head. Starts strong-malty with some alcoholic notes. Finish metallically and dry. Could be more balanced. Okay.
Im Geruch zitrushopfig, karamellmalzig. Antrunk süß, zitrushopfig. Mitte karamellmalzig, kräuterig. Abgang bittermalzig, Zitrus, bitter. Super.

On tap @ PRNH Meibock fest. Clear amber color. Rocky, dense white (to off white) head, good lacing. Aroma’s: piney hops, resin, citrus, with some malty sweetness retronasal. Flavor is lightly sweet, with some hoppy acidity. Medium bodied. Finishes caramelly, hardly bitter. Still very nice.

Vom Fass at PINT Meibockfestival ’13. Clear deep golden colour, white head. Aroma of smooth sweet malts, cookie batter, light fruity, floral, nice grassy hops. Flavour is again very slick, bready malts, cookies, floral and fruity, medium-sweet, nice grassy and light herbal bitter finish that lingers a bit. Soft carbonation, oily and smooth mouthfeel. Lovely malt-forward Heller Bock imo.

A Mes rate: cask at the Market (no) Porter. Copper coloured with a thin white collar. Fruity aroma with plenty of apple. Dull caramel aroma with some faint nutty notes. Faintly bitter finish. Straight forward but decent.
Cask at the market porter. Alround rating: Toffee, caramel pale golden malts, grassy, light grapefruit note. Balanced and tasty.
Knickersby ’Spoons. Watery grapefruit and flat lemonade. Gentle straw, meek fruit and zero fizz. Needs more freshness, zest and hop clout..

Cask pint at The Maltings, York. Dark golden with a scummy quarter-inch white head that laces. Aroma is surprisingly malt-centric, slightly dusty but not much hop character to speak of. Taste is the other end of the spectrum: quite piney and resinously bitter, with a nice pale malt backbone. Strong and slightly harsh, rasping bitter aftertaste. Palate is thicker than most blondes, with a fine carbonation and an excellent feel on the tongue. Quite decent with a distinctive hop character.

column1: Fort Street Quatre Seance de Saison
column5: Hazy-dirty yellow, small head, comes back with a quick swirl. Aroma has tons of fruity esters, sour lemon and tart apple dominate. I picked up alot of floral through the middle and faint pepper near the end. Flavor pretty much on par. Although pepper seems to come through more, could be some rye spiciness as well. I prefer a little more carbonation in saison, so mouthfeel takes a little hit, otherwise very solid, highly sessionable.

column1: Fort Street Quatre Seance de Saison
column5: On tap: The aroma consists of apple, banana, yeast, pepper, spice, and light floral notes. It’s hazy yellow with a small white head. The flavor starts with banana and light yeatiness. the finish has light apple, lemon tartness, pepper, and faint floral bitterness. Light bodied with soft carbonation. I wish this had been a bigger batch. I could drink a lot of this.

On tap: A wheat based stout. The aroma consists of chocolate,plum, and roastiness. It’s a dark brown with faint orange hilights around the edges of the glass. The flavor starts with moderate milk chocolate with a hint of plum in the background. Finishes with a nice roasted malt presence with a hint of banana. As it warms the fruitiness increases. Very nice.

column1: Fort Street Much Nothing About Ado
column5: Dark brown almost black, with mahogany edges, minimal head. Aroma up front is very spicy rye and licorice. Plenty of depth. Dark fruit, roasted grain, faint coffee. Flavor even more complex, huge chocolate up front, fades into fruity esters and roast through the middle, rye and zesty citrus bite in the finish. Although it’s hopped up, it’s such a huge malt bomb, hops mainly play a balancing act, preventing any one character from taking over the beer. Very well done. Seems lately Doug has been brewing for the beer lovers instead of the beer masses. Thank you.

column1: Fort Street Much Nothing About Ado
column5: Cask: The aroma consists of black licorice, fruit, light roasted coffee, and faint alcohol. It’s dark brown with red hilights and small beige head that quickly fades to a small ring around the edges of the glass. The flavor starts chocolate, plum, and fruit. Light roasted coffee in the background. The finish has some citrus hoppiness with a touch of alcohol. Medium bodied with a nice slick mouthfeel. The fruitiness and plum increase as it warms. This is outstanding. It reminds me of Old Viscosity.
Tap, pours a nice golden, aroma is grainy, taste is smooth and drinkable, nice offering

(draft @ The Old Towne Restaurant - Niagara on the Lake, ON) Pale gold color with a puffy white head. Aroma is light and full of dry hops and some stale grass. Flavor is rather bitter and dry with hints of hops and some hay. Finish is very watery. Easy to drink and tasted good in the hot weather.
Pours a clear golden with white head. Sweet pineapple and cardboard aroma and taste. Notes: tall boy can from Drinkies, Cairo Feb ‘19

Nechápu, proè je tento pivní styl, tudíž sladový likér hodnì lidmi podhodnocován. Pivo má pøíjemnou sladovou vùni, slušnou chu s jemnými tóny chmele a alkoholu, s vyšším øízem a hustou krémovou pìnou. Na Egypt za mì spokojenost.
Plechovka od kamarata. Farba medova. Pena padla hned. Vona slabsia. Chut sladkasta silna.
Weicher, wenig süßer Beginn von Alkohol, etwas Getreide. Trotzdem nicht plörrig, geringe Süße, monoton. Wenig metallern, kurzer Nachhall. Trinkbar. 10/8/9/7/9/7
Poco cuerpo y sabor muy amargo, carente de olor. No me la he acabado, menudo suplicio de cerveza.
500ml can. Pours dark gold with a large, frothy head. Aroma is corn, straw and warm, eggy alcohol. Taste has corn and straw. Sweet and rubbery.
Clear yellow, no foam remaining. Heavy sweet aroma and likewise alcohol sweet taste. Not too much of a beer taste. (Velp 201701)

Can 500ml. [ As Sakara King ]. Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, pale malt, sweet malt, sweet corn, banana notes. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration, sugary, sweet malt. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20160625]

500 ml can at Ulfborg. Clear pale golden color with white to off white head. Malty aroma, grain, corn, fruity, banana. Sweet and light bitter taste, banana and alcohol. Light thin to oily body with soft carbonation.
Can from Nikos - country #102! Pours clear golden, small off white head, good lacing. Aroma is corn syrup, grain, grape soda. Flavor is medium sweet, light plus bitter, sharp. Medium body, boozy.

Pours a clear darker golden, topped with a very small and quickly dissapearing white head. Malty aroma, smelly and nothing else. No real taste. Watery with sweet malty feel, a bit unpleasant really. Not a nice one.
Clear golden appearance, medium head. Malty flavor, sweet. Not too watery, quite refreshing for a non-alcoholic beer.

33cl bottle in Hurghada, Egypt. Pours clear pale golden with a small, white head. Sweet and lightly malty. Quite watery and not much flavour, but drinkable when in case of emergency. (Backlog - tasted 2009-12-10)
33cl can. decent white head. Clear golden pour. Bland and crap. Not worth buying a second time.

Bottle from C-Town supermarket, inside Amman Mall It has the usual darker shade of blond, with the head disappearing quickly. It has a sweet aroma, wet cereals. Dry and weak mouthfeel, with faint cereals flavor; medium-low bitterness, that in this concotion vanishes quickly in the final. Poor. I feel like I’m becoming the top rater of NA beers from the Middle East...

Bottled 033L. Bought in Hurghada. Clearly orange color, much pale and stagnate (entirely lacking in bubbly) Light and escaping head. Sweetish aroma with notes of the peach tea, dried cereals and waters in the sugar... I’m not be able to describe beyond. Terribly sweet and smooth taste; much arid and with a bitterih back-savor of long persistence on the end. Wretched but thanks however to my dad for this beer.
Bottle from Hopfen & Malz in Berlin - new retro label - clear brown color, white head. a bit watery, a bit weak. toffee, dark malts. medium to high sweetness. okay.

Bernsteinfarben, trüb mit toller beige Krone. Dezent fruchtiger Geruch mit den typischen Weißbieraromen von Nelke und Banane sowie einem Hauch Karamellmalz. Weicher Antrunk dank angenehm zurückhaltender Kohlensäure. Schlank bis wässrig ohne die Charakteristika eines dunklen Weißbieres. Es wirkt sehr zahm und wenig eigen. Wie dem hellen Pendant fehlt leider auch diesem Bier der Wiedererkennungswert.
Pours an amber-brown color. Aromas of bread, malt, and some fruit. Flavor has a touch of malt and clove.

Bottle: Light amber to amber coloured with a medium-sized stable lacy white head; mainly sweetish malty-caramelly nose with a subtle sourish-wheaty Background, a phenolic touch included; moderate sweet-sourish and bitter flavour, light to medium bodied; traces of chocolate in the lingering (...and warming!) sweet and tart finish. A bit slim, but all in all pleasant...

Bottled (thanks Kim!). Deep ambery brown colour, mediumsized beige head. Aroma is chocolate malts (!), some wheat, citrus, mild toffee and some yeasty notes. Flavour is toffee, banana, some chocolate with mild toasted notes. A quite pleasant and somewhat dry weissbier.
50 cL bottle. Pours hazy brown with a small white head. Aroma is dry estery and banana fruity. Banana fruity and roasted malty. Dry and estery finish.

It’s unclear brown with a huge, creamy head. The aroma has notes of yeast, banana, fruit, caramel and wheat. The sweet flavor is very pleasant and well balanced, a remarkably nice dunkle weisse. It has notes of yeast, banana, fruit, caramel, wheat, and the finish is slightly spicy.
500ml bottle. Aroma is fruity, specially banana and some yeast. Appearance is dark amber with a hughe white head. Taste is banana and yeast. Overall a really great dark Weißbier.
Nice white head. Great gold-brown color. It’s like a banana in the glass. Nice creamy palate.

(bottle, courtesy of Quack-Duck) Hazy, dark amber colour with a fuffy, light-beige foamy head. Dusty, moderately sweet wheat-malty nose with a fruity touch of banana, a whiff of cacao and strong notes of phenols (band aid, cloves). Sweet flavour with a light touch of acidity, medium to light bodied, lively carbonated mouthfeel. Wheat-malty, moderately yeasty and fruity taste; a light toasty note arrives late towards the finish, which is furthermore slightly sweet and quite slim with notes of cloves and vanilla. Drinkable Weizen without much Dunkelweizen attributes.

Handpull cask at the Stamford Arms, Groby. Light gold, but not quite straw. Clear with a white head. White grape juice and lychee aroma marred by a drainy sulphurous tinge. Same with the taste except the sulphur is even more noticeable. It's in good condition but it just isn't a very good beer.
Cask conditioned at The Seven Stars, Bristol, Gloucs. Gold with white head. Quite a thinnish, malty beer, some fruitiness with a touch of citrus, reasonably sweet without going too far. It’s fine.

From June 2007 tasting notes, sampled at Thirsty Bear. Clear, attractive bronze with a white head. Caramel, apple/pear and earthy hops in the nose. Tastes more like a Brit Pale Ale. Flavor of full, caramel/toffee-covered apples, pear, earthy English hops and a bit of an alcohol kick too. Ends sweet with a tinge of brown sugar. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Solid.

Nice creamy orange golden color. Smell is of bright fragrant hops, and a strong hop taste. Similar to an IPA in bitterness, and not my favorite Pale Ale, becaust the bitterness was a bit more than I normally care for. Not a bad beer, however. Decent seasonal for hopheads to try at the Thirsty Bear, if in SF.

Draft. nice rich amber beer with a nice light tan head. Low malty, slighly citrus aroma. Good hop complexity. Earthy flavor with lots of pine and grapefruit rind. Some malt backing. It’s the first time I’ve had Bravo hops and they add a nice complexity, but I think they’ll be easy to overdo unless you combine them with another hop varietal. Lingering earthy, pine. Good bitterness - especially for a pale ale. Medium body. Lots of hop flavor.

Cask (handpump), Brunswick, Derby. Brewed by a bunch of Everards licensees.on their ’Cask Ale Champion’ course. How can I describe the colour.... copper. Hedgerow fruits early doors, bready bulk on the tongue and slight sweetness in extra time.

Cask, The Rutland and Derby, Leicester. Copper with a dense cream head. Aromas are malty and sweet with pear and caramel. Flavours are sweet malts with bready yeast and citrus. Light spicy hops and earthy pear.
Cask Handpump at the Brunswick, Derby 27/07/2007 Fruit aroma. Copper golden coloured and fruity with a crisp and slightly dry bitter lasting malt finish.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Brunswick Derby. A mid brown coloured beer. The aroma is malty and fruity with bread and berries. The taste is pretty sweet and those berries come to the fore. A nice body and a decent beer.

Cask, Derby Fest 10. Golden with an off-white foam. Aromas are biscuit and orange marmalade with lemon and grassy hops. Fruity with yeast. Flavours are sweet lemon with grassy hops. Biscuit sweetness with yeast and lager malts. Dry on the finish. OK.

Cask (handpump) at the Brunswick. In a range that’s usually either froth or simplicity, this is a standout strong bitter. Strength to the robust fruity nose and seeping alcohol. Bitter indeed, alongside Rich Tea like bite-i-ness. Shame it’s not a regular beer - I’d take this ahead of Second Brew any day of the week.
Cask Handpump at the Brunswick, Derby 12/07/2007 Strong and fruity aroma. Golden coloured with some alcohol present. A little dryness in a crisp and bitter lasting malt finish.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Brunswick Derby. An orange coloured beer with an off-whote coloured head. The aroma is fruity and hoppy with biscuity malts and alcohol. Some marmalade notes also. All of these attributes come through in the taste, but it’s the orange marmalade and biscuity flavours which stand out. A good chewy body and the alcohol is nice.
Süßlicher, trocken herber Antrunk. Mild würzig, hell getreidig malzig. Süffig, dabei konstant bleibend. Naja... 9/8/9/8/8/8
Pours orange color with a creamy white head and lacings. Grassy, fruit and hay. Medium bodied.

Many thanks to Beerhunter111 for this bottle! 500ml swing-top bottle. The beer starts fresh and smooth. Quite dry and grainy with a moderate dry bitter and grainy aftertaste. Not too deep with lots of bready grains in the body, hints of sweetness to make it highly drinkable without being to sweet. Dusty-dry grain. Interesting aroma.

Das Bier ist fast klar und hat eine orangegelbe Farbe, eine Schaumkrone ist nur zu erahnen. Geruch leicht nussig malzig, fruchtig hopfig. Geschmack sehr malzig, leicht fruchtig süß, getreidig, nussig hopfig, gut!

Fliptop bottled, 0.5 l. Opal orange colour, medium sized fine pored white head, which laces. Citrussy, floral nose. Crisp start followed in the refreshing aroma by lemon, flowers, toast and mild caramel. Dry sweetbitter finish escorted by tart citrusses and bread-crust. A good Zwickl.

It’s hazy dark yellow/golden with a creamy head. The aroma has notes of hay, malt, caramel, flower. The flavor has a light sweetness and notes of grassy hops, malt, caramel, a touch of citrus (when it gets warmer), and the finish is slightly dry with a touch of fruit.

Tap at Lowen brauhaus, Bad Worishofen - 15/07/12. Slightly clouded golden with a decent white head. Malt, yeast and fruit on the nose - touch of spice, taste matches exactly. Medium bodied with a bitter sweet finish.

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly to fully diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, light hoppy. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and light light bitter with a average to long duration, candy - sugar sweet. Body is medium to light, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20101016]

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours a hazy golden with tiny impurities and a tiny white head. Sweet malty nose with a lottle caramel. Medium body, sweet malt and vitamins. Hardly any bitterness. 161010

(Bottle at One Pint Pub Augustfest ’10) Poured golden and hazy. Head was small and white. Aroma was herbal and sweet. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were sweetness, herbalness, malts and medium bitterness. Aftertaste was sweet and bitter.

Bottled@One Pint Pub, Helsinki (shared with FatPhil). Golden colour, not too much head. Aroma is caramel, some mild bready malts, grass. Flavour is rather sweet malts with some mild hops as well. Goes rather well with a cheeseplate available at One Pint Pub.

500ml bottle (One Pint Pub, Helsinki) 5 Quite bland. Simple sweet malts. 2 Pale, small head 5 Simple bocky malts. 2 Thinnish palate, crisp carbonation. Finish a little plasticky. 10 Certainly drinkable, but with no balls.

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, toasted, light to moderate hoppy, grass, silage, green grass. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, green grass, sweet malt. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20101016]

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Clear yellow with a white head. Sweet malty nose with some perfumy aroma hops. Good malty body, very clean with some nice aroma hops. Ends dry but not bitter. 161010
Pale golden body, white head. Grassy floral hops, nice malt profile. Some sugary taste. Some honey. Noticeable bitterness. Ok, but quite dull.
500 ml bottle. Finland. Clear pale golden colour with almost no head. Slightly skunky grassy hoppy aroma with malt. Grassy hops, sweet sugar and malt in flavour. Tasty Helles.
The bottle looks simple, but good. Very zippy in the glass, quite light. Starts fine hoppy, quite dry, a little bit hard-metallically. Soft-sourish finish, still fine hoppy. Not bad!

Bottle (Dank an Jonas !) Golden coloured, mid-sized, lacy white head; fruity-grainy nose with a touch of glue; solid sweet-bitter flavour, medium bodied; grainy-fruity finish. Good, but not great............

(bottle) Clear, greenish golden colour with a short foamy white head. Sweet, strawy malty nose with a light touch of sour dough and faint herbal hoppy notes in the background. Light-bitter flavour with sweet malt giving the right balance, medium to light bodied with a moderate carbonation. Slightly grainy finish with a whiff of hoppy bitterness. Balanced brew (24.06.08).
tap. Maltsweet nose, honey. Pale golden, white lace on the glass. Straw malt base, a bit fruit, ligh candy notes. Hop aromatics retronasal. Mellow wellagered chewy mouthfeel. Nice.
Clear straw colored with a small head. Herbs and spices in the aroma, with a hint of lemon. Dry but mellow flavor. Not bad at all.

On tap at Mikkeller Bar SF. Hazy gold with a creamy head. Taste is honey, caramel and a noble hop sting. Mouthfeel is on the soft and watery side. Nothing much stands out but there’s also nothing offensive about it. OK.

Draft, Beer Revolution. A pleasantly dry and well-made pilsner. It’s hard not to like a good, local pils. This one has a nice light feel. The nose is yeasty with some citrus/grass hops and fresh, light malt. Taste is dry with a lemony finish. Very refreshing and easy to drink. Pours pale yellow with a soapy white head. Good stuff.
On tap at Beer Revolution. Pours clear golden with a modest off-white head and a light floral aroma. There is a thin pale malt flavor with a little banana ester and a bitter finish.

Pours clear golden yellow with a nice dense white head. The aroma is grassy hops with hints of apple, biscuit and grains. The flavor is hugely grassy with some biscuity malts rounding out the middle. Very dry. Pretty flavorful pils if you like them super hoppy.
Clear light yellow with a creamy white head. Faint malty aroma and a faint grain malt and vanilla taste.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a malty grainy and grassy hoppy aroma. Sweetish malty grainy flavor with some grassy hints. Has a sweetish malty grainy and grassy finish.
An amazing Pilsner, it’s flavor ran deep. Very crisp and smooth, just the right hops and light body
Draft. Light golden color with a nice white head. Low grass aroma. Big grassy flavor with backing citrus. Medium body. Lingering grass. Yep - grass, grass, and more grass.

33cl bottle from a trade with Mariusz, thanks. A clear yellow golden beer with a small white lacing. Aroma of grainy malt, straw, pale malt. Taste of straw, grainy bitter malt, spicy bitter hops, easy.

Sampled from 0.33 l bottle, best before January 2020. Clear, golden with a white head. A bit sweetish, slightly grassy aroma of grains, some straw and a touch of lemon peel. Slightly sweet, moderately bitter, gently grassy and a little fruity-floral taste of grains, some straw and traces of lemon peel, followed by a short, gently bitter, quite grassy finish. Thin to medium body, gently effervescent mouthfeel, average carbonation. Pleasant Pils!
Hellmalziger, angenehm weich getreidiger Beginn. Leicht erhöhte Karbonisierung, kein Hopfen, Standard ohne Fehler. 10/9/8/8/9/8

"Gaildorfer Edel-Pils", Fläschchen aus dem Mixpaket Pilsbiere vom Biershop Baden-Württemberg. - Goldgelb, klar. - In der Nase leicht stumpfes helles Malz, milder grasiger Hopfen, Anklänge an Honig. - Antrunk mild grasig hopfenherb bei schöner, zart honigartiger heller Malzigkeit mit deutlicher aber angenehmer Restsüße. Milder rezent, nicht allzu schlank, rund. Im Abgang milde, für ein Pils etwas zu milde, leicht grasige Herbe. - Recht ordentliches süddeutsches Pils, mild aber aromatisch gehopft, mit feinem Malzkörper. Und das schön altmodische Etikett gefällt mir auch.
Klares helles Goldgelb mit relativ wenig Schaum. Malzig, blumig, etwas Honig, süffig, leicht herb.
Dezente Frucht- und Hopfennoten. Hellgelb klare Farbe mit weissem Schaum. antrunk süßlich im Abgang angebehm herb. Ein rundes und gelungenes Pils.
Yellow colour. Moderate malty and light hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Average light bitter finish.

(33cl bottle) Clear, pale golden colour with a mid-sized foamy white head. Sweet grainy, almost a bit bready malty nose with a tinge of honey-fruity sourness and light herbal hoppy notes. Sweet-bitter flavour, light to medium bodied with a slightly fizzy carbonation. Grainy, malt-accented, doughy taste with low to moderate herbal accents; dry-ish, slightly bitter and faint hoppy finish. Drinkable but not overly convincing “Pilsener” (09.05.08).

bottle, brought to me by a friedn who lives in Gaildorf. Golden colour, large head. Malt-accented, though quite hoppy pilsener with hints of grain and honey. Full-bodied, very long finish and extremely long and pleasant aftertaste.
Draft. Dark brown beer with a dark cream colored head. Slight citrus, slight coffee/roast aroma. Slight coffee/roast flavor with chocolate and citrus. Some astringency. Lighter bodied.
Gelbes Bier schöner schaum, im Geruch malzig würzig strohig, im Geschmack recht malzig süß leicht würzig etwas Hopfen
0,5l Bügelflasche. Klares gelbes Bier, schöner Schaum. Getreide und nasses Heu. Der Geschmack ist recht süss. Malz, etwas Gras und Hopfen.
The head is unstable. It smells sweet. The taste is malty a bit sweet and very mild. In the aftertaste hoppy and barley. 8/8/8/7/8/8
Deep amber color, white head. Very malty on the nose. the flavor is sweet, malty, caramel, brown sugar. The finish is not particularly clean, mostly sweet, very slight nobel hops.

Süß-getreidiger Antrunk mit zarter Würzigkeit. Das Bier bleibt mild, dafür ist die hintergründige Wässrigkeit verantwortlich, die im Mittelteil erkennbar wird. Die Getreidenoten bleiben konstant, die Süße vermischt sich mit der wässrig angehauchten Herbe. Zu, Ende herb-würzig auf entäuschend geringem Level, deutlich gerstig. 9/7/8/6/8/6

bottle, brought to me by a friend who lives near the brewery. Dark yellow, nearly amber colour, large and creamy head. Malt accented beer with fruity hints, full-bodied, slightly hoppy and dry, especially towards the finish.

“Falter Export hell“, Flasche vom GVP Getränkemarkt, Neustadt a.d. Waldnaab. - Goldgelb, klar. - In der Nase blaß getreidiges helles Malz, etwas Waldhonig, sehr milder Hopfen. - Antrunk etwas schal hellmalzig mit leichter Weißbrotsüße, Anklängen an Honig, komplementiert durch sehr dezente fruchtige Säure. Dezente hopfenwürzige Hopfung, kaum bitter aber als Grundierung des Malzkörpers doch ausreichend. Milder rezent, eher vollmundig, leicht trocken. Im Abgang knappe, leicht orangenfruchtige Hopfenherbe. - Ganz gewiß kein Knaller aber doch ein altmodisch solides Export mit gekonnter Balance von runder Malzigkeit und milder aber gediegener Hopfung. Gut! (27.8.2019.)

Das Bier hat eine sehr helle Farbe. Beim Geruch fallen blumige Noten auf. Geschmacklich gibt es keine großen Überraschungen. Mild malziger Antrunk, ab dem Mittelteil kommt sehr deutlich der Hopfen, der im Endteil etwas trocken ausläuft und noch lang nachklingt. Trotz reichlich Kohlensäure süffig. Klassisches Export, das auch dem einen oder anderen Pilsliebhaber schmecken dürfte.

From the bottle. Gold with a frothy white head. Aroma of grains and metals with a soft, sweet malty undertone and a touch of turpentine. Taste is mildly bitter, crisp, and goes down dry. Medium body. I’m bored.
* Old rating, best before 22.07.12. The beer starts mild and slightly grainy. Fresh, smooth and round. Not too deep but easy to drink.
Bottle. Cleear yellow color with white head. Aroma - Citrus, grass, grain. Taste - Malts, bread.
Geel bier met schuim. Smaak ik licht zoet en licht bitter, verder vrij vlak. Gemiddeld bier.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit durchschnittlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, getreidig, leicht herb. Geschmack malzig würzig, getreidig, minimale Bitterkeit.
Poured golden color with a white head. Grainy malty aroma. Flavor is sweet malt, grain and some bread.

The beer in the glass is pale yellow and clear, with coarsely porous head. It smells sweet, hoppy, pale malty. Starts very sweet and malty, musty, and unobtrusive hoppy bitter in the background. The middle part is malty-sweet and subtly grainy. Goes into an watery malty finish with some sweet grains and musty hops!
Bottle 50cl from Quack-Duck thanks. A clear yellow beer with low head. Nose is low, aroma is sweet, malty with round hops, metallic note, quite carbonated, light nutty, basic.

Draft at brewpub. Poured clear brown color with a moderate white fizzy head that diminished slowly with good lacing. Good complex toasted nutty aroma. Medium body. Well balanced sweet nutty flavor with a moderate smooth sweet finish of moderate duration. Good drinkable brew.

On tap at the brewery. Clear dark copper or brown body, thin off-white head. Toasty aroma that developed diacetyl notes as it warmed. At its initial serving temperature, the body was dominated by a rough graininess with heavy toast and an earthy, bitter finish with hints of fruitskin/berries. As it warmed, however, diacetyl exerted itself and dominated the flavor profile. Very thin-bodied. A weird beer, and probably not one I’d drink again, with or without the diacetyl.

there isnt much to say about this slightly sickly sweet brown ale that is laced with the typical NHBC patented diacetyl; wait a minute, i guess there was something to say about it...please stop brewing beers that suck in general
Una cerveza de buen cuerpo, color rojizo y un sabor intenso y refrescante al mismo tiempo

Bottle 355ml. Clear medium to dark brown - red amber colour with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting to diminishing, off-white to light beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, fruity, caramel, dried fruit, alcohol, light chocolate, light raisin, light burnt brown sugar. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and light bitter with a long duration, sweet malt, burnt caramel - brown sugar, alcohol. Body is medium, texture is oily and sticky, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20130620]

Smells sweet, almost honey sweet with some alcohol and fruit notes. Taste has more alcohol and a little cane water sense. It almost tastes like a Belgian Strong rather than a barley wine. Some floral hops as well. A bottle my sis-in-law brought from Cervelar in B. Aires.

Bottled at Monks Café, Stockholm. Pours out in a clear reddish amber colour with a small bubbly white head. Dense malty sweet aroma of candied oranges, fudge, dried figs, raisins, alcohol and pepper. Full-bodied with notes of raisins, over-riped oranges, butter, pepper and alcohol. Long warming finish of candied apricots, cookies, alcohol, nuts and white pepper. Felt quite rustic and rough but still quite charming.
On tap. Pours a clear orange with a thin white head. Aroma of perfume, light fruits, citrus. Flavor of pale malts, light fruits, apple. Malty, decent pale. 7/4/6/4/14 (3.5/5)
Tap; pours clear copper with a white head; aroma of citrus, light caramel, and a trace of pine; taste is bittersweet with caramel and citrus; finish is dry with a little pine
on tap cloudy orange pour with white head floral citrus nose with the taste following suit
I did not care for this one...not enough hops....too earthy...bitter and a tad sour...bad bottle?

16 oz can into an Irish pub-style imperial pint glass. No date on the can. Amber color, moderate carbonation, 1 inch light tan head, leaving thick lacing as it receded. Malty aroma, perhaps a bit of pine. medium feel, but little carbonation means it is pretty flat. The malts are the primary component of the taste, initial, middle, and finish, with just a touch of hops flavor. The malts are earthy more than bready. After several sips, a bitterness appears in the finish and lingering aftertaste. The malt taste is good, but I would have preferred more hops presence, both in flavor and bittering. This beer is much different than I was expecting based on the brewer’s description. Overall, disappointing.

I’ve had bombers of these in the past and always liked them but nice to see this in a 16 once can. Pine and citrus on the nose. Starts nice and hoppy with a creamy malt base then ends slightly grapefruit rind bitter. I’ll probably pick up some more.

Tap at New Bohemia in Golden Valley. On happy hour. Coppery almost amber in color. Minimal, feathery head. Aroma draws on citrus, hop characteristics. Taste is hop centric with a little biscuit note. Mouth is dried out from the bitterness. Some malty sweetness at the very back end. Aftertaste is bitter. It’s drinkable and not too harsh.

16iz can shared. Poured a medium orange with white head. The aroma is medium malt base with some citrus hop in the nose. The flavor is where it comes up short. It starts out ok then dies in mid flavor you have the components but it stops about mid tongue. Something just happens here and not good.
Bomber. Clear orange with a tall foamy khaki head. Caramel, light alcohol, dried peaches, and tropical fruit hops. Moderately sweet with a dry bitterness. Body is medium with a sticky feel.

Bomber pours a clear amber/copper color with small off white head and hardly any lacing. Aroma has grapefruit, organge, and a hint of pine. Taste is slightly bitter with some caramel malty sweetness in the middle. Medium body with just enough carbonaton. This one seemed like more than 6% ABV. A good but not great APA.

Growler from artusory, consumed 7-29-07. Wow looks like I am in the minority on this one. Dark amber, tan head, still very carbonated after roughly 10 days. Huge sticky pine sap/resin up front in aroma. All kinds of tropical fruit esters. Mango/apricot dominate with plenty of bitter grapefruit zest. Flavor has a huge candied fruit character from the start. Grapefruit, apricot, carmelized malt, resinous pine. Big sticky mouthfeel. Very over the top, but well done IMO. Maybe tim ein the growler somehow improved this, or beer tastes better with sand between your toes and some salmon fishing on the horizon, I don’t know? Side note: "Bitter and offensive" was the qoute a non-beergeek friend used to describe this, lol....

Amber/orange body with a small beige head. The aroma is sweet caramels and cotton candy with buckets of citrus hops. The flavor is moderately sweet, quite bitter with caramel, toffee, honey, grapefruit and resinous pine. Full body is sticky and slightly astringent with a palate destroyingly bitter finish.

Draft, Franklin’s. Pours a murky, orangish brown color; off-white head with decent lacing. Vegetal aroma, showing citrus and a slightly sour / earthy note. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: very strange mix of flavors in this one; very vegetal, for starters (celery, stalky greenness); decent lingering hops, but seems kind of dissipated at this point, leaving only a sticky and mildly astringent presence in the mouth; there’s also some dry cedar in there as well: woody, earthy, and odd. A messy, messy beer that I couldn’t finish.

Draft. Pours a copper orange, with a slight haze and an off white head. Subtle fruity and piney hop aroma. Flavor reminds me of one of the Choas ales. It has flavors of grapefruit and citrus skin with a bold bitterness. Finishes semi dry with flavors of grape skins and peanut shells. Interesting beer, but I don’t see myself ordering another. Something was very odd about the combination of flavors.

7/7/07 Quite a bit like their Double IPA offering. Deeper red color with a frothy, foamy white head. Smells of pine and grapefruit, wicked hop aroma. Flavor was all of that. Pine, citrus, soap. Finish was far too astringent for me. Needs more balance to be worthy of celebration. 7/20/07 Had this beer a second time when it was being served on cask and dry hopped. Flavor and finish were far more mellow. Dry hopping didn’t increase the bitterness, it actually mellowed all of the astringent hoppiness out. Maybe 2 weeks of setting helped this beer. Either way, I rated this much higher the second time around.

Creamy off-white head atop murky copper body. Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, grapefruit/pine, orange. Taste is moderately sweet, grapefruit/grassy, caramel, some pine, orange. Sharp bitterness. Chewy full body, some acidity, creaminess.
Big frothy kakhi head, mirky brown/amber body, feshly hoppy slightly smoked nose, somewhat dull flavor, poorly balanced pale ale flavor, a little watery

On tap at the brewpub on 6/20/07: Pours a slightly hazy copper orange with an airy clingy-lacing light tan head. Aroma of mild fresh piny hops and some lightly toasted malt. Body starts with a touch of toasty sweetness and decent hoppy balance, but thins a lot toward a fairly bland, bittersweet finish. An average APA.

On tap. Pours a rich opaque copper-caramel and forms rich, dense off-white head with good staying power. Huge chunks of lace cling to the side of the glass as the beer is consumed. Aroma is disappointingly weak but eventually gives off hints of bitter, citrusy hops and little else. Bitter, resiny hops dominate the flavor as well, accompanied by a deeply caramel-sweet malt that clashes with this particular hop profile, leaving an unpleasant cardboardy aftertaste. Solid mouthfeel with a thick, coating palate. A rare miss amongst the parade of hits that otherwise pours forth from Carlyle’s taps.

On tap at brewpub This was towards the end of a sampler flight at Carlyle. If I were to have ordered 10 ounce pours I would have definitely gotten this one after a small sample. It is a classic pale ale with enough flavor to make it worth the effort of ordering. You will certainly get your money’s worth with this one. Aroma / Appearance - The amber red body let through a large amount of light that was only filtered by the thin off white head. Caramel, hops and dusty books are the strongest scents but the background contains stained cherry wood. Overall this is beer that doesn’t pack the whallop of an IPA but does not idly give up either. Flavor / Palate - The hops are the strongest characteristic but the malts do provide a reasonable balance. Tea leaves, caramel and oak wash across the tongue before a finish that reminds me of rust. The mouthfeel is thick for a pale ale and very satisfying. The total impression is mostly woody hops and overall pleasing and balanced.

Had this one on draught as part of a sampler flight at the brewpub in Rockford, Illinois. Medium reddish pour with a wispy head, piney hoppiness, sweet and bitter, balanced and mild. Nice strong finsh. Great!

Nice sessionable ale, having the aroma and flavor of hops but with only a light bitterness. It’s got a slightly hazy amber body with a solid head that sheets the glass with heavy lace. The aroma is a quiet caramel with a blend of citric scents. In the flavor the cirtus is juicy pink grapefruit, complementing the malty sweetness nicely. The finish is fruity and mildly bitter. Nice. Carlyle Brewing Company, Rockford, IL

Date: 06/20/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub cloudy amber, fine white head, drops of lace, big citrus hop aroma with sweet caramel malt, lots of sweet grapefruit flavor, light bitter finish stays out of the way and let’s the hop flavor and caramel sweetness be the star of the show, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **+/4
Pours a clear golden colour with a small white head. Semi sweet malted taste with a pleasent touch of fruit, bread and grass. Aroma is of soft hops and spice.

On tap at the brewpub on 6/24/07: Transparent bright golden color has a clingy airy white head with wispy lacing. Aroma of faint pale malt and noble hops, but subdued. Body has some biting carbonation and mild doughy malty sweetness with more earthy bittering hops toward a dry, bittersweet finish.

Date: 06/24/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear yellow, fine white head, drippy lace, light malt aroma with a touch of grainy sweetness and soft floral hops, slightly sweet malt flavor, light balancing bitterness, Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 9/20 Rating: 2.4/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: **/4

On tap at the Stone Cellar Brewpub. Poured a medium and clear yellow color with a small sized white head. Spicey aroma with a grassiness. Tastes of the same with some sweetness. I probably would have guessed this was a pilsner.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at Grumpy Troll. Hazy, cloudy orange-yellow-tan. Thin white head. Mild toasty aroma. Very citrus forward, but still a quality Wit. Orange coriander all the way. Yeasty and smooth, a pretty decent representation of the style. Nice toasty golden malt balance, almost a touch oily and wheaty. Not perfect, but decent.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Hazy light yellow pour. Orange and clove on the nose. Medium carbonated body. Good orange, wheat, and clove taste.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Not sure what the purpose of the name of this beer is but it is a standard APWA, not a witbier really.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Arrived a hazy yellow with a low white head. Aroma had a light banana, light lemon citrus fruitiness to it with a modest coriander spiciness and a solid wheat presence. Flavor started off with a lemon wheat combination first and a light coriander middle with just a touch of banana in the ending (very light). Body was crisp, kinda bubbly but very finely carbonated and a light body as a whole. Overall a very good wit (usually not my favorite style). Coriander isn’t overpowering as is commonly seen and the lemon is perfect to add that crisp feeling finish at the end.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at the brewpub, pours a murky golden with a thin head, appearance really didn’t blow me away at all, kind of reminded me of very dirty water, the aroma has a decent amount of spice with clove and some sweetness, the flavor has touches of both clove with banana and coriander in the finish, meh.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: No head, cloudy yellow. Slight orange aroma. Orange and coriander flavors, some malt sweetness. Medium-light body, dry finish. no hop aroma, flavors or finish. I liked this, almost a hefe.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at the brewpub 7/31/09: Pours a hazy pale golden with a thin, clingy-lacing white head. Big orange and lemon citrus nose with a hint of coriander and light sweetness. Starts fairly full with a tart citric bite and a touch of coriander and sweet pale malt finishing drier and sweet tart. A pretty good citrusy witbier.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: 11/16/2007: Norwegian Wit is another hazy, gold-colored offering from Grumpty Troll. It has the typical orange and corriander flavors and soft palate. Sample (draught) at the Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria in Mount Horeb, Wisconsin. Rating #11 for this beer.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Murky gold with essentially no head. Bright but fading orange-juice aroma. Flavor is an absolute fruit basket, orange, pineapple, mango. Really a tropical juice cocktail balanced by coriander spice and a touch of hops bitterness. Noticeably still, but the palate is made interesting by a some clove and alcohol fire. Really a nice wit.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at the Grumpy Troll Brew Pub. Poured a medium yellow color with a small sized head. Aromas of wheat with some spiciness. Tastes of fruitiness, bananas, citrus, and lighter spices.
Cask at the GBBF 2011. Golden with a small white head. Malty aroma with grassy and herbal hops. Dry and grainy flavour with a touch of hay.
Cask @ Edgar Wallace, Temple WC2. Pours a clear golden color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty hoppy aroma. Fruity malty hoppy flavor with citrus hints. Has a fruity malty hoppy finish.

Cask at GBBF 2011, Day 2. Pours clear yellow with a faint, foam head. Mild straw, corn and hay in the nose. Light sweet flavor, some honey and a little bitterness. Light bodied with soft carbonation. Mild cereal and grain to finish. Overall pretty bland.

Cask (GBBF2011, Wed) Very simple malty aroma. Tobacco ad black tea too. Bugger all real hopping. Dull and basically infinitely boring. No flaws, plenty of snores. At least after a while the bitterness does build up so you get some tingle in the finish. But that took too long.

Cask @ GBBF 2011, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Clear medium orange yellow colour with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, hay, dusty hay, pale malt, light hoppy, citrus, fruity. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, hay dusty, citrus. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20110802]
Cask @ GBBF, 2011. Pours clear golden with no head. Vague fruit and grain. Medium to thin body. Low carbonation. Short end. Forgettable.

Cask@GBBF2011. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is fruity, floral and mild bready and toasted notes as well. Flavour is fruits, wood, floral and quite flowery notes as well. Mild dry wood and pleasant maltyness in the finish.
Cask @ 3 Judges. Golden colour, white head. Nose is vegetables and slight hops. Flavour is light malted, hops, little citrus and fruits. Not too well.

Cask at Craft Beer Co, London on 7th July 2011. Gold with thinning white head. Citrus hop and quite a bit of malt. Lemon zest and cookies in mouth, and a tangy finish. Mouthfeel is quite velvety. Easy to drink.
14th July 2008. Light creamy pale ale. Very light hops. Mild bitterness. Dry finish. Bland.

column1: Great Waters Bring Out Your Dead Red
column5: On tap at the brewpub on 6/23/07: Transparent bright copper orange pour has a wispy-lacing white head. Aroma of lightly sweet pale malt with a hint of faintly piny hops. Body starts with a touch of caramel sugar and mild earthy bittering hops toward a watery, bland finish. A pretty average red at best.

column1: Great Waters Bring Out Your Dead Red
column5: On tap at the brewpub: Gorgeous bright cinnamon tinted orange color with a smooth, dense topping of firmly thick off-white foam sitting about a finger high. Lacing sticks in many areas of the glass with lots of broken strings and spots. Aroma is fine and light with a clean snappy firmness of malt sweetness rendering honey, honeydew melon, flower oils, and some chamomile spice. Taste is nearly the same as the aroma would lead one to think how it would taste, which makes this drink a bit of a different take on a Red Ale with its light, softer approach of spice and malt. Soothingly clean, soft, and creamy with a mild broad snappy breath of malt. Honey flavors tend to take the overall mixeing with a bit of melon and pale citrusy tea notions. Faint but adequate hintings to floral spice and chamomile trace the middle and back end. Ends short and creamy with no real finishing qualities other then a wiff of sticky honey and very feathery floral notes. Body is lightish medium with a smooth, quite clean, and gently creamyness to it. Mildly snappy when first served then grows a duller malt sense as it warms allowing a bit more of the subtle spices to pull through. However, as good as it was and drinkable as it was, it was unimpressionable, and left me wanting more out of it n some way. What though, I couldn’t say. I think what the beer is after seems to hit pretty good once taken in, but it just doesn’t have much to say or do to the palate to make a full impression other then the addition of spice to a simple Red Ale recipe. A decent enough drinker for the hotter weather I suppose.

column1: Great Waters Bring Out Your Dead Red
column5: Draft @ Brewpub: Copper color, nice head, light lacing. Nose of grass, hay and caramel malt. The flavor is nice, clean and hoppy. Finishes moderate bodied. Eh.

column1: Great Waters Bring Out Your Dead Red
column5: Date: 06/23/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear amber, wispy off white head, sweet caramel malt and light citrus hop aroma, sweet caramel malt flavor, candy caramel sweetness, light hops, little to no bitterness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

column1: Great Waters Bring Out Your Dead Red
column5: Sample from tap at the brewpub. Pours amber red to brown with a lacing light brown head. Aroma is malty, toffee, slight dry. Flavour is spicy (says egyptian chamomille), has caramel but remains dry. Honey provides softness to the dry notes. Ends dry and light spiced.

On Tap @ the Brewpub 6/23- New special brew they had just put on tap: Don’t know why they bothered as it wasn’t much better than anything else I had there. Had a decent hop flavor up front, but nothing excessive considering the Bartender was telling people it was almost like an IIPA. Did have a somewhat floral aroma, had a bit of a grassy taste to it. Drinkable, but not much more & certainly not worth going out of the way for. Short finish, kind of medicinal.

On tap at the brewpub. The body was hazy dark amber gold. There was a strong grapefruit nose. There was also some almonds and toast. The taste was muted grapefruit with some grassy woody notes. There was some ncie citrus to complement the medium mouthfeel. Good stuff.

This is exactly what I expect from an IPA. Nothing over the top, but still good. Very traditional. The hop aroma was very good, a bit light for my taste, but still very good. Great finish. My usuall beer at this location.

Draft sample at Cranberry location. Pours a relatively light golden amber with a small white head. Some big floral and citrus hops in the nose. It has a great dank citrus flavor with a little bit of pine. Finishes with a more earthy hop flavor. Nice, not over the top.

12/27/07 - Winter Road Trip ’07 - Draft sample at brewpub. Gold w/ red hues, white head with decent lacing. Floral hop nose. Floral and piney taste throughout, pretty average, but good. Run of the mill IPA. Tasty to me! Very dry finish with moderate bitterness

On tap. Mild grassy hops, fresh, with a bit of orange rind and spice. Golden amber clear with thin white head. Medoum body with medum carbonation. Starts with mild malty sweetness, dry acidity and flavorful grassy hops. Quickly turns to bitter in the finish, with dry bitter after. Run of the mill IPA.

On tap at the Wausau brewpub on 6/24/07: Transparent copper orange pour has a thin covering of wispy white head. Aroma of lightly sweet caramel malt and big fresh piny hoppy presence. Body starts fairly full with a nice light caramel sweetness and good piny citrusy hop balance toward a drier bittersweet finish. A nice IPA.

On tap at the Trivia Pub. Ubiquitous color, looks like a pale american lager. Barely any carbonation, just a trace. Very little initial aroma but that builds to a slight floral hop towards the end of the session. Perhaps a little less annoying than many IPAs. Taste is all IPA, bitter medicinal and nearly offensive....and that carries over to the finish, which lingers.

Date: 06/24/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear amber, headless, sweet fruity malt aroma with a nice balanced between sweet caramel and fruity hops, almost flat body, lots of sweet malt flavor, touch of fruity character, light lingering bitterness in the finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

Sampled on draft at the Cranberry PA location this beer poured a bright golden color with a medium sized white head. The aroma was sweet, fruity and a bit piney. The flavor was dryish sharp floral hops and light grapefruity hops. The hops linger on the tongue.
Keg at the brewery, 8/20/16. Clear copper, thin head, poor retention. Aroma of bready malt and stone fruit. The taste is bready malt, cinnamon, caramel, stone fruit. Medium bodied.
On tap at the brewery, taste is of wort, alcohol, candy sugar, and malt. I give it an ok, nothing really to write home about, and less than impressive as a strong ale.

On tap at the Old Fashioned - Tasted infected, as I got wave after wave of buttery diacetyl over the biscuity malt backbone and light hopping. I couldn’t even finish a third of it before I had to give up. Obviously something was wrong with this, as it tasted horrible.
Brewpub. Red-berry and caramel nose. Tastes like a mid-strength barley wine - fruity caramel malts over a sweet base. Decent stuff.

On tap at the brewpub on 6/24/07: Pours a transparent golden bronze with a frothy, clingy-lacing white head. Sweet toasty caramel British malty nose with a touch of light fruity esters. Body is smooth and sweet with some toasty caramel malt along with a touch of light fruity complexity and a mildly warming finish. A nice strong ale.

Name: Mortimer’s Strong Ale Date: 06/24/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear dark gold, light sweet caramel malt aroma, creamy yet sticky body, rich sweet caramel malt flavor, nice fruity character is brought out by the sweetness, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **+/4

Dark golden color with just a hint of haze. Smallish white head. Pale malt and light fruit of raisins and honeydew melons. Full feel, and like most of the breweries beers lightly carbonated and easy to drink. Fairly simple flavors of caramel, light melon, pale malt and hint of floral hops. Very drinkable for the higher alcohol content, as the alcohol is not tasted, felt of smelt. Actually sat next to Mortimer himself while trying this one.

During second visit to Calumet brewery this year, this beer pours a clear golden amber brew with a fast dissolving white head. Aroma of sweet caramel malt, some flowery hops and a hint of Hawaiian sweet bread. Taste is smooth, medium bodied, very little carbonation with flavors of sweet caramel malt, passion fruit and a touch of mango. Finish is smooth, creamy, a little alcohol burn, very light bitterness with a old musty cellar aftertaste. One of Calumet’s sweetest brews on tap this summer.
