Pours black with low tan head. Aroma of chocolate and molasses. Taste is thick roasty with tons of molasses in the finish. Rich and creamy body with soft carbonation.

On tap at H&H is Escanaba. Poured dark with hint of red with thin head. Aroma is mixture of leather, alcohol and chocolate. Has very smooth texture and just slides down easy. High ABV is hardly detectable. Really liked this beer, overall a top notch RIS.

On tap at the Wausau brewpub on 6/24/07: Pours a mostly opaque black with a coating of well-lacing frothy dark tan head. Aroma of sweet rich dark caramel with a touch of chocolate and plum complexity. Body starts with good fullness and sweet sticky dark caramel malt before some earthy bittering hoppiness with a touch of dark fruits and a black peppery warming finish. Needs to hide its abv better, but still a pretty nice imperial stout.

Date: 06/24/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub black, fine beige head, drippy lace, light dark chocolate aroma with a touch of roasted, creamy body, rich chocolate flavor, nice vanilla and licorice sweetness, touch of balancing hops blended with a light roasted character, fleeting hint of alcohol just adds to the sweetness Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.9/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: ***/4
The aroma has oatmeal and light coffee. Flavor has a touch of chocolate, and roasted malt. Black and quite thick, but I didn’t enjoy this as much as everyone else.

A Wausau filled growler shared at joebrew’s BBQ by brewfiend pours an opaque dark brown brew with an average tan head that slowly dissolves to a fine film and tan ring. Aroma of dark chocolate, molasses, toasted dark malt, lactose and oatmeal. Taste is full bodied, very light carbonation and a very sweet flavor of dark chocolate lactose sweetness, dark fitted fruits and some oatmeal. Finish is semi-dry with a slight bitterness at fist and then a toasted malty aftertaste. Road Trip to Wausau!!

Shared at Joebrew’s BBQ; courtesy of Brewfiend. Growler. Black color with a medium head. Monster coffee and chocolate aroma. Strong, bitter malt taste with a little oatmeal to sweeten it up. Coffee and chocolate are still there in a very nice harmony. Damn fine!

On tap at the Wausau WI location. Rich roasted malt nose with a nice dry coffee aroma. Pitch black color with nice brown head. Very well done body with similar flavors as in the aroma but with the addition of oatmeal and lactose. Perhaps the faintest hint of fruits in the very finish.
Barrel Draught from the jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 29/09/2005 Black and rich on the palate. Strong in alcohol with a slightly bitter lasting finish.
Deep auroma and a beautiful pour. Wow, really impressed with this beer. Bit of a coffee flavo with no bitter aftertaste. Think this is my fav. Hereford and Hops beer to date.
On tap at Crafted 6/20/17. Black pour with a long-lasting tan head. Roasty, chocolatey, gun metal, wet river rock, lightly sweet, lightly bitter. Good porter.

Draft at Drover’s Run. Dark brown pour with a thick creamy tan head. Aroma of roast, dark chocolate, and espresso. Flavor is heavy roast, espresso, and rich chocolate. Mid-heavy feel, quite rich and satisfying. Solid offering.

On tap. Pours a clear dark red-brown with a small, long lasting, creamy, tan head that laces nicely. Sweet aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate, dark fruit and coffee. Sweet flavour that matches aroma with a mildly bitter finish. Medium body with a smooth, oily texture and soft carbonation. Nice.

On tap @ the brewpub, the second stop on TvM’s Bachelor Party Northwest Ale Trail Expedition. Note: this is not the nitro version. Dark walnut brown, coppery highlights. Nice roasty profile, bitter chocolate with light fruit acids. Balanced, sessionable.

Draught at the brewpub. Very black, small head. Distinct aroma of coffee and tar. Mid sweet with clean mouthfeel and medium body. Dense and compact with lots of espresso and resiny bitterness. A rock solid porter.

Sample at the brewery. Pours dark brown with ruby edges and a creamy brown head. Aroma of rich roasted malts and coffee, cream, toast. Taste is also very thick with burnt malts and creamy sweetness. Finishes with burnt and dark chocolate bitterness. Chewy texture, smooth carbonation.
on tap-pours a light brown head and black color. Aroma is dark malt-molasses/roasty/ashy, some earthy hops. Taste is dark malt-ashy/molasses/roasty/chocolate, secondary earthy hops.

On Nitrogen Poured pitch black with a creamy tan head...aroma is biting and dark...flavour is slightly smokey with rich coffee and charred wood undertones, finishes bitter but smooth...cannot wait to try the stout on nitro...

Tap @ Brewpub: Black, tan head and light lacing. Nose of bright coffee and astringent roast, ample dark husk and chocolate but no tannins. The flavor is creamy and chewy, nice drinkability for the intense dry roast.

Sample tray. Sheet says 5.4%. Looks like a good stout. Black with a heavy brown head. Deep inhalation brings out the roasted malt scents. Flavour is coffee and bitterness. Smooth. OK, straight forward coffee porter.

column1: MickDuffs Tipsy Toe Head Blonde Ale
column5: On tap. Pours a clear gold with a thin, white head that leaves spotty lacing. Sweet aroma of corn and light fruit. Sweet flavour of corn, light fruit, grass and pale malt with a mildly bitter finish. Light body with a watery texture and average carbonation.

column1: MickDuffs Tipsy Toe Head Blonde Ale
column5: On tap @ the brewpub, the second stop on TvM’s Bachelor Party Northwest Ale Trail Expedition. Light gold, lightly hazy. Clean grains, vague fruity undertones. Certainly non-threatening.

column1: MickDuffs Tipsy Toe Head Blonde Ale
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Lightly haz pale golden, no head. Neutral nose. Sweet and fruity with clean mouthfeel and light body. The slightest note of vanilla before a faint finish with minimal bitterness. Too clean and rather tasteless.

column1: MickDuffs Tipsy Toe Head Blonde Ale
column5: Sample at the brewery. Pours clear yellow gold with a thin white head. Aroma of grain and fruit. Taste of jammy bread, lots of fruit, citrusy finish. Medium light body, smooth carbonation.

column1: MickDuffs Tipsy Toe Head Blonde Ale
column5: on tap-pours a white head that laces and hazy yellow color. Aroma is sweet grain/light malt, fruit. Taste is sweet grain/light malt, fruit, secondary spice hops.

column1: MickDuffs Tipsy Toe Head Blonde Ale
column5: Tap @ Brewpub: Pale beige color with light head and no lacing. Nose of metal and husk with a bitter tail and a more husky note in the finish. Light and only bad notes I’m getting.

column1: MickDuffs Tipsy Toe Head Blonde Ale
column5: Sample tray. Mat underneath the beers said 5%. Hazy pale yellow. Faint cookie or bread nose. Fizzy foam body. Light hop bitterness in the end. The mat also said the beer would be good with huckleberries. The bitterness makes me almost think the fruit was already added, but nothing in the aroma.

column1: MickDuffs Tipsy Toe Head Blonde Ale
column5: Bottle: Straw in color, on the darker side, slight haze, moderate spritzy white head, spotty lacing, light carbonation. &nbsp Straw/hay on the nose, somewhat grassy malts. &nbsp Slight musty basement. &nbsp Pale malts on the tongue. &nbsp Fairly clean. &nbsp Tiz even a bit meaty for a Blonde Ale. &nbsp Moderate to full body and mouthfeel. &nbsp This one isn’t thin nor astingent like so many others. &nbsp Better than I anticipated. &nbsp Would definetely have again.

column1: MickDuffs Tipsy Toe Head Blonde Ale
column5: On draught at the brewpub in Sandpoint, Idaho. Pours a semi-clear golden pale brew with a fast dissolving white head that leaves behind a thin white ring. No lacing in glass during dissipation and sampling. Aroma of light roasted malt, with light scents of honey, corn and southern cooked grits. Taste is light bodied, some carbonation with a light bread dough flavor. Taste is light, smooth, crisp with a bready finish. A terrific light beer with flavor from pour to finish. MickDuffs Huckleberry Blonde: This beverage served to me was actually MickDuffs Tipsy Toe Head Blonde Ale with a splash of huckleberry syrup added. Appearance is the syrup clumps together as beads in the brew body like oil and water. Aroma is mostly sweet huckleberrys with light corn malt. Taste is light bodied, subdued carbonation with a light bread with dark berry preserves added. Taste is sweet, smooth, a sweet berry finish. An interesting mixed beer beverage.

Off the tap at the brewery. One and half fingers of tan head on a black body. The aroma is roasted malt with black licorice. The taste is smooth with roasted malt, burnt wood and a dry finish. The texture is soft with low to moderate carbonation. Nothing fancy, but a nicely done dry stout.

Tap at the "brewpub". Pours dark brown with a transient creamy tan head. Aroma is mild dark malt. Near med body. Flavor is not quite smooth burnt malt, a little chocolate. A bit chalky/ashy. Finishes quite dry with chocolate notes over burnt malt, but a little peat (that comes and goes) is sneaking in.
On tap at Sudwerk. Aroma is mild and just roasty flavor is basically the same. Palate is very dry. Overall pretty good, but I like it in the 3 best friends brew better.

On tap at the brewery. Black with a tan head. Aroma is very mild with just some roastiness. Flavor is roasted malt. Palate is medium bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and dry finish. Overall a decent dry stout.

On tap at the brewery. Black with a lasting tan head. Tart cocoa aroma. The flavor is bitter roast, with a little cocoa. Smooth and clean overall. Medium-light bodied with medium carbonation and a smooth texture. A nicely done dry stout.
Pours black with brown in the thin areas. Notes of sesame, nuts and unsweetened chocolate. One of the better Dry Stouts I’ve had.
A very dark, dry stout. It didn’t have the most flavor of other stouts I’ve had, but Sudwerk always has a great brew on tap.
Dark brown with curiously light tan head. Papery, earthy anise aroma, some coffee. Mild, lightly earthily malty flavor with plenty of roastiness, but not overwhelming. Well-melded dry stout.
On tap at the Sudwerks brewery. A dark bear, almost black. Small lightly tanned head. Moderate beer with a slightly nutty taste. Overall an little better than average beer.

On tap at the brewpub in late June 2007. 0.3 L sample. Roasted, toasted, mildly metallic and hoppy aroma present. Lightly peppery and a bit of smokiness is in there, too. An interesting enough aroma. Moderately opaque dark brown-mahogany colored body with a frothy light tan head and nice lacing present. Starts a bit grainy and cereal-like. Lightly roasted, choco, and burnt flavors are present in the middle. Becomes quite hoppy with plenty of "C" hops in the finish. Kind of thin-bodied and overly hoppy. Just seems kind of lacking. I think this is too hoppy to fit the "Dry Stout" classification.

Hand-pulled pint in ’The White hart’ Shifnal on 21 Aug 2013. Golden body with a copper hue, the head snow white and full. Mixed blend of aromas and tastes: some biscuity malts and an undertone of floral hop notes. No great strength to any one flavour, just an easy drinking beer that doesn’t upset or excite your taste buds either way. Was it sweet? No: was it bitter? No, it wasn’t anything really, just a session brew. Not enough oomph for me, but pleasant all the same.

Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury. Brown, copper with white head. Boys bitter with lots of flavour, treacle, smokey notes with a malty bitterness, richly roasted, maybe a little powdery on the tongue. Some hoppy notes late on. A decent enough beer.

Cask at The Maltings, York. Pours a clear deep orange with an average size diminishing white head. Mild, easy-drinking flavour of light fruit, malt and faint hops with short bitter finish. A decent Bitter.
Cask conditioned @ Sirloin of Beef, Portsmouth. Toffee and nuttiness with some cottage earthiness. One of their malty efforts which arent some of my favourites.

Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury. Dark brown with white head. There is a weird taste to this one, akin to fermented vegetable mass, somewhat stewed. There is a malty, oaty flavour initially, but then this pungent type flavour takes over. Not good.
Old notes. Nothing else to say that this tastes like homebrewish wort that has been fermented for about a week. Poor.
330 ml bottle. Golden color, wisp of a white head. Weak, malty aroma. Watery flavor with lemon and some sour notes, malty finish. Light body, light carbonation. Eww.
feels raw, very flat and uninteresting. I finnished it but did not enjoy much. Feels very same as the other tuorlan beers.

330 ml bottle. Finland. Hazy amber colour with almost no head. Very weak aroma of yeast. Flavour of malts and yeast. Not much hops to get the Pilsenerness. Almost no carbonation. Feels like it’s not quite ready yet. Very much home brewed image.
(bottled and shared with frie nds) nice golden colour with nice aroma of butter. No carbon and lots of butter on tongue.

Bottle from Tbone, thanks! Orange blonde, hazy. Soft aroma with hints of tangerine and caramel. Thin. Sharp citric flavor with hints of caramel. Notes of pineapple. Hints of flowery hops in the aftertaste. The first signs of an upcoming sourness. The beer is infected, but in an early stage, so quite drinkable.

330ml bottle (Eat&Joy, Helsinki) Decent golden colour, brief head. Lovely rich caramelly malty aroma, touch of ginger too. Simple palate, a touch flat. Gingery and slightly creamy or buttery vapours while in the mouth. Slightly husky and grainy malty body, some slight sourness and slightly drying hops. Vague hoppy finish, I think. Quite tasty, and full bodied for a lager. Alas flatness spoils the experience a bit.
A 0.33L bottle. Mild malty nose. Pale head. Pale golden yellow colour. Mild malty waterly taste. Low carbonation. At the end slight hoppiness.
0,33l bottle. Light amber color, little head. Nose is malty with a little butter and sweetness. Flavor continues along the same theme, added with a hint of hops. Pretty basic stuff.

33cl bottle from the brewery shop. Hazy golden, tiny disappearing pale head. Midly grainy nose with gooseberry sourness. Moderate hayish hoppy flavor, apparent berry sourness, hint of apple and butter, smooth maltiness. A tad chewy palate, very low carbonation. A sympathetic microbrewery, too bad my palate isn’t quite ready for this kind of authentic sour pilsners..

Rating #25.000 at RB! 50cl bottle. A clear pale golden beer with a huge most good lasting white head. Aroma of straw, pale grainy malt. Taste of mid sweet grainy malt, straw, cereals, cardboard, spicy bitterness. Meh....

500ml bottle from Beers of Europe; BBD 1st May 18. Poured (twice) into an old Paderborner Gold Pilsner badged flute (0.3 litre) at home on a cold and windy 15th Feb 18. Pale golden body, bright, clean and clear, on top a snowy white blanket of bubbles. Grainy aroma and taste, slight grassy, floral and herbal hints within the flavour, semi-sweet, yet with a good hop bitterness which gives a dry aftertaste.
Wonderful spices in here. Pine and dry hops mix well with the sweet malts. One of the best pils ive had in a while.
(500ml . In a Bitburger jug)Easy to drink , dry and sweet , woody bitter ,floral . An ok Kraut pils.
50 cl bottle. Normal pils colour.Hay and grass taste. Thin body. Cool retro label .

Bottle. Pours apale straw color with a head that fades very quickly. Aroma of grass, bit of malt sweetness and hint of citrus. Taste of light malt sweetness and grain. Mild bitterness and a fairly clean finish. Light body, just a bit of crispness and not much else. A non-offensive, non-descript pilsener.
Low fluffy quickly disappearing white head. Clear yellow body. Malty hoppy hay aroma.
It’s golden with a white head. The aroma has notes of dusty straw, vegetables, malt and a little bread. The flavour has a light sweetness and notes of straw, grass, malt and the finish is dry.

Bottle 50cl. @ home. Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, corn, light hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to modrate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20090628]
Bottle. Clear golden colour with a little head. Malty aroma with notes of hops. Very fruity flavour with a bitter and dry finish very tasty endeed.

500ml bottle. Pours an unclear dark brown almost black with amber hue and a medium, frothy, short lived, light brown head that leaves spotty lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, espresso, ash and dark chocolate. Sweet flavour of roasted malt, espresso, dark chocolate, licorice, ash and a metallic twang with a dry, bitter coffee finish. Medium body with a thin texture and soft carbonation. Not bad.

Pours a thick frothy beige cap that sticks around for a while. Has a very dark brown appearance. Thick lacing. Dark roasted malts and coffee aromas are quite substantial. Definitely strong dark roast coffee flavours, dark roasted malts, breads, some earthy type hops and mild spices. Slick oily and somewhat creamy mouthfeel. A little bit watery though. It’s like having a cold coffee with a big creamy mocha head. Really good, smooth and just like its namesake.
Gout juste correcte de café super belle mousse mais attention verser lentement si vous ne voulez pas de mousse! 5% c est parfait! 8/10 pour moi!
